original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Khuddakanikāye🔽Mahāniddesa-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: khuddaka nikāye  mahāniddesa aṭṭhakathā
translated: In the Khuddaka Nikāya

original: Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā
translated: The Commentary on the Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness🔽The Introduction

original: Avijjālaṅgiṃ ghātento, nandirāgañca mūlato;
analyzed: nandi rāgam ca mūlataḥ
translated: Striking away the darkness of ignorance, and uprooting delight and passion,

original: Bhāventaṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ, phusi yo amataṃ padaṃ.
analyzed: bhāventa ṭṭhaṅgikam maggam yaḥ amatam padam
translated: Cultivating the eightfold path, he touched the deathless state.

original: Pāpuṇitvā jino bodhiṃ, migadāyaṃ vigāhiya;
analyzed: pāpuṇitvā jinaḥ bodhim migadāyam vigāhiya
translated: Having attained awakening, the Victor, in the Deer Park, having triumphed,

original: Dhammacakkaṃ pavattetvā, theraṃ koṇḍaññamādito.
analyzed: dhammacakkam pavattetvā theram koṇḍaññam āditas
translated: Turning the wheel of the Dhamma, first inspiring the elder Koṇḍañña.

original: Aṭṭhārasannaṃ koṭīnaṃ, bodhesi tāpaso tahiṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhārasannam koṭīnam bodhesi tāpaso tahim
translated: He awakened eighteen koṭis there, the ascetic,

original: Vandehaṃ sirasā tañca, sabbasattānamuttamaṃ.
analyzed: vandeham sirasā tam ca sabba sattānam uttamam
translated: I pay homage with my head to him, the highest of all beings.

original: Tathā dhammuttamañceva, saṅghañcāpi anuttaraṃ;
analyzed: tathā dhamma uttamam ca iva saṅgham ca api anuttaram
translated: Likewise the supreme Dhamma, and also the unsurpassed Saṅgha,

original: Saṃkhittena hi yo vuttaṃ, dhammacakkaṃ vibhāgaso.
analyzed: saṃkhittena hi yaḥ vuttam dhammacakkam
translated: In brief, he who spoke the turning of the Dhamma wheel, by way of analysis.

original: Sāriputto mahāpañño, satthukappo jinatrajo;
translated: Sāriputta of great wisdom, the teacher's heir, the Victor's son,

original: Dhammacakkaṃ vibhājetvā, mahāniddesamabravi;
analyzed: dhammacakkam vibhājetvā mahā niddesam abravi
translated: Having analyzed the turning of the Dhamma wheel, spoke the Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness;

original: Pāṭho visiṭṭho niddeso, taṃnāmavisesito ca.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ visiṭṭhaḥ niddeso tad nāma visesito ca
translated: The reading, the analysis, the explanation, distinguished by its name.

original: Taṃ sāriputtaṃ jinarājaputtaṃ, theraṃ thirānekaguṇādhivāsaṃ;
analyzed: tam sāriputtam jina rāja puttam theram thira aneka guṇa adhivāsam
translated: That Sāriputta, the Victor's royal son, the elder, dwelling in many virtues,

original: Paññāpabhāvuggatacārukittiṃ, sunīcavuttiñca atho namitvā.
analyzed: atho namitvā
translated: Whose fame is lovely, risen to the height of wisdom, and who was of lowly conduct, and then bowing to him,

original: Khamādayādiyuttena, yuttamuttādivādinā;
analyzed: yutta mutta ādi vādinā
translated: Who was endowed with patience and so on, who spoke well the U and so on,

original: Bahussutena therena, devena abhiyācito.
analyzed: bahussutena therena devena abhiyācitaḥ
translated: Who was learned, an elder, who was requested by the god,

original: Mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ, sajjhāyamhi patiṭṭhito;
analyzed: mahāvihāra vāsīnam patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Who was established in the recitation of those who lived in the Great Monastery,

original: Gahetabbaṃ gahetvāna, porāṇesu vinicchayaṃ.
analyzed: gahetabbam gahetvāna porāṇesu vinicchayam
translated: Who, having grasped what was to be grasped, the ancient decisions,

original: Avokkamento samayaṃ sakañca, anāmasanto samayaṃ parañca;
analyzed: avokkamentaḥ samayam sakam ca an āmasantaḥ samayam param ca
translated: Who did not contradict the time, his own or that of others, who did not boast about the time, his own or that of others,

original: Pubbopadesaṭṭhakathānayañca, yathānurūpaṃ upasaṃharanto.
analyzed: pubbopadesa ṭṭhakathā nayam ca yathānurūpam upasaṃharantaḥ
translated: Who, following the method of the eight commentaries of the ancients, brought together what was suitable,

original: Ñāṇappabhedāvahanassa tassa, yogīhi nekehi nisevitassa;
analyzed: ñāṇa ppabheda āvahanassa tassa yogīhi nekehi nisevitassa
translated: Of him who brought about the division of knowledge, who was frequented by many yogis,

original: Atthaṃ apubbaṃ anuvaṇṇayanto, suttañca yuttiñca anukkamento.
analyzed: attham apubbam anuvaṇṇayantaḥ suttam ca yuttiñca anukkamentaḥ
translated: I will relate the previously unknown meaning, following the discourses and the logical method.

original: Ārabhissaṃ samāsena, mahāniddesavaṇṇanaṃ;
analyzed: ārabhissam samāsena mahāniddesa vaṇṇanam
translated: I will begin, in brief, the commentary on the Great Analysis,

original: Saddhammabahumānena, nāttukkaṃsanakamyatā.
analyzed: saddhamma bahu mānena na attukkaṃsana kamya tā
translated: Out of respect for the true Dhamma, not out of a desire for self-praise.

original: Vakkhāmahaṃ aṭṭhakathaṃ janassa, hitāya saddhammaciraṭṭhitatthaṃ;
analyzed: vakkhāmaham aṭṭha katham janassa hitāya saddhamma cira ṭṭhita ttham
translated: I will speak this commentary for the welfare of people, for the sake of the long-lasting establishment of the true Dhamma,

original: Sakkacca saddhammapajotikaṃ taṃ, suṇātha dhāretha ca sādhu santoti.
analyzed: sakkacca saddhamma pajotikam tam suṇātha dhāretha ca sādhu santaḥ iti
translated: That which illuminates the true Dhamma well, listen to it and remember it well, good people.

original: Tattha “pāṭho visiṭṭho niddeso, taṃnāmavisesito cā”ti vuttattā duvidho pāṭho – byañjanapāṭho,🔽atthapāṭho ca. Tesu byañjanapāṭho akkharapadabyañjanaākāraniruttiniddesavasena chabbidho.
analyzed: tattha pāṭhaḥ visiṭṭhaḥ niddeso taṃnāma visesito ca ati vutta ttā duvidhaḥ pāṭhaḥ byañjana pāṭho  attha pāṭho ca tesu byañjana pāṭho akkhara pada byañjana ākāra nirutti niddesa vasena chabbidhaḥ
translated: Herein, the recitation of the phrasing is of six kinds as the recitation of syllables, words, phrasing, litotes, synonyms, and etymologies.

original: Atthapāṭho saṅkāsanapakāsanavivaraṇavibhajanauttānīkaraṇapaññattivasena chabbidho.🔽Tattha tīsu dvāresu parisuddhapayogabhāvena visuddhakaruṇānaṃ cittena pavattitadesanā
analyzed: attha pāṭhaḥ saṅkāsana pakāsana vivaraṇa vibhajana auttānīkaraṇa paññatti vasena chabbidhaḥ  tattha tīsu dvāresu parisuddha payoga bhāvena visuddha karuṇānam cittena pavattita desanā
translated: The recitation of the meaning is of six kinds as the recitation of the meaning of the text, the meaning of the connected speech, the meaning of the uncon- nected speech, the meaning of the connected and unconnected speech, the meaning of the connected and unconnected speech with the phrasing, and the meaning of the connected and unconnected speech without the phrasing.🔽Herein, the syllables are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present in the mind of one whose mind is purified by the practice of purification and who has entered upon the way to the cessation of suffering.

original: vācāhi akathitattā adesitattā akkharamiti saññitā, taṃ pārāyanikabrāhmaṇānaṃ manasā🔽pucchitapañhānaṃ vasena bhagavatā ratanaghare nisīditvā sammasitapaṭṭhānamahāpakaraṇavasena🔽ca akkharaṃ nāmāti gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vācāhi a kathita ttā a desita ttā akkharam iti saññitā tam pārāyanika brāhmaṇānam manasā  pucchita pañhānam vasena bhagavatā ratana ghare nisīditvā sammasita paṭṭhāna mahā apakaraṇa vasena  ca akkharam nāma ati gahetabbam
translated: They are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present in the mind of one whose mind is purified by the practice of purification and who has entered upon the way to the cessation of suffering.🔽They are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present in the mind of one whose mind is purified by the practice of purification and who has entered upon the way to the cessation of suffering.🔽They are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present in the mind of one whose mind is purified by the practice of purification and who has entered upon the way to the cessation of suffering.🔽They are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present in the mind of one whose mind is purified by the practice of purification and who has entered upon the way to the cessation of suffering.

original: Atha vā aparipuṇṇaṃ padaṃ akkharamiti gahetabbaṃ “saṭṭhivassasahassānī”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: atha vā a paripuṇṇam padam akkharam iti gahetabbam saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni iti evamādīsu
translated: They are called “syllables” because they are not taught by speech, that is to say, because they are not taught by speech in the three doors, though they are present

original: viya. Ettha hi sakāra nakāra sokārādīni akkharamiti, ekakkharaṃ vā padaṃ akkharamiti
analyzed: viya ettha hi sakāra nakāra sokāra ādīni akkharam iti eka akkharam vā padam akkharam iti
translated: For here a letter is a syllable, or a word consisting of a single syllable.

original: eke. “Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobhavikā”ti evamādīsu vibhatyantaṃ atthajotakaṃ akkharapiṇḍaṃ🔽padaṃ. “Nāmañca rūpañcā”ti evamādīsu bahuakkharehi yuttaṃ padaṃ nāma. Saṃkhittena
analyzed: eke yā ayam taṇhā ponobhavikā iti evamādīsu vi bh ati antam attha jotakam akkhara piṇḍam  padam nāma ca rūpam ca ati evamādīsu bahu akkharehi yuttam padam nāma saṃkhittena
translated: Some say that a word is a collection of syllables that illuminates a meaning, as in the passage beginning, “This craving which produces further becoming.”

original: vuttaṃ padaṃ vibhāveti. Padena abhihitaṃ byañjayati byattaṃ pākaṭaṃ karotīti byañjanaṃ,🔽vākyameva. “Cattāro iddhipādā”ti saṅkhepena kathitamatthaṃ. “Katame cattāro? Idha,🔽bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti. Vīriyacittavīmaṃsasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: vuttam padam vibhāvā iti padena abhihitam byañjayati byattam pākaṭam karoti iti byañjanam  vākyam eva cattāraḥ iddhipādāḥ ti saṅkhepena kathitam attham katame cattāraḥ idha  bhikkhave bhikkhu chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam iddhipādam bhāveti vīriya citta vīmaṃsa samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam
translated: A name is a word consisting of many syllables, as in the passage beginning, “Name-and-form.” It illuminates, i.e., it makes clear, it makes evident, what is expressed by the word.🔽A sentence is a collection of words that illuminates a meaning, as in the passage beginning, “Four are the bases for spiritual power.” It makes clear the meaning stated in brief.

original: iddhipādaṃ bhāvetī”tiādīsu pākaṭakaraṇabhāvena byañjanaṃ nāma. Byañjanavibhāgapakāso
analyzed: iddhipādam pākaṭa karaṇa bhāvena byañjanam nāma byañjana vibhāga pakāsaḥ
translated: In the passages beginning, “What are the four? Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops the basis for spiritual power that possesses concentration due to desire and volitional formations of striving,” etc., it is a sentence because it has the function of making clear.

original: ākāro. “Tattha katamo chando? Yo chando chandikatā kattukamyatā”ti evamādīsu kathitabyañjanaṃ
analyzed: ākāro tattha katamo chando yaḥ chando chandika tā kattu kamya tā ati evamādīsu kathita byañjanam
translated: Mode is the mode of expression of the word in the various ways in which it is analysed.🔽The mode of expression of the word is called “mode.”🔽The explanation of the mode of expression is called “etymology.”🔽The explanation of the mode of expression is called “etymology.”

analyzed: anekavidhena vibhāga karaṇam ākāraḥ nāma ākāra abhihitassa nibbacanam nirutti phassaḥ  vedanā iti evamādīsu ākārena kathitam phusati iti phassaḥ nīharitvā

analyzed: vacanam nirutti nāma nibbacana vitthāraḥ nissesataḥ deso ti niddesaḥ vediyati iti vedanā ati

analyzed: nibbacana laddha padam sukhā dukkhā adukkham asukhā sukhayati iti sukhā dukkhayati iti  dukkhā na iva dukkhayati na sukhayati iti adukkham asukhā ati attha vitthāraḥ niravasesena

original: kathitattā niddeso nāma.🔽Evaṃ chabbidhāni byañjanapadāni jānitvā ca chasu atthapadesu saṅkhepato kāsanā dīpanā
analyzed: 🔽evam chabbidhāni byañjana padāni jānitvā ca chasu attha padesu saṅkhepato kāsanā dīpanā
translated: The explanation of the mode of expression is called “etymology.”🔽The explanation of

original: saṅkāsanā, “maññamāno kho, bhikkhu, bandho mārassa amaññamāno mutto pāpimato”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: saṅkāsanā maññamānaḥ kho bhikkhu bandho mārassa a maññamānaḥ muttaḥ pāpimato ti evamādīsu
translated: In such passages as “If he conceives, he is bound by Mara; if he does not conceive, he is freed from the Evil One,”

original: saṅkhepena atthadīpanā saṅkāsanā nāma. Eso pana thero “buddhena bhagavatā evaṃ saṅkhepaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhepena attha dīpanā saṅkāsanā nāma esaḥ pana theraḥ buddhena bhagavatā evam saṅkhepam
translated: the revealing of the meaning in brief is called “the revealing.” But this Elder was able to penetrate the meaning stated in brief by the Blessed One

original: katvā vuttamatthaṃ ‘aññātaṃ bhagavā, aññātaṃ sugatā”’ti kathetuṃ samattho paṭivijjhi.🔽Upari vattabbamatthaṃ ādito kāsanā dīpanā pakāsanā, “sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, āditta”nti
analyzed: katvā vutta mattham aññātam bhagavā aññātam sugata iti kathetum samatthaḥ paṭivijjhi  upari vattabbam attham āditas kāsanā dīpanā pakāsanā sabbam bhikkhave ādittam ti
translated: and to explain it thus: “The Blessed One knows, the Well-Farer knows: ‘The meaning is this, venerable sir.’“

original: evamādīsu pacchā kathitabbamatthaṃ paṭhamavacanena dīpanā pakāsanā nāma. Evaṃ paṭhamaṃ🔽dīpitaṃ atthaṃ puna pākaṭaṃ katvā dīpanena “kiñca, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ ādittaṃ? Cakkhuṃ,
analyzed: evamādīsu pacchā kathitabbam attham paṭhama vacanena dīpanā pakāsanā nāma evam paṭhamam  dīpitam attham puna pākaṭam katvā dīpanena kiñca bhikkhave sabbam ādittam cakkhum
translated: The revealing of the meaning to be stated later by the first statement is called “the revealing” and “the illuminating” in such passages as “Bhikkhus, all is burning”🔽and in such passages as “What, bhikkhus, is all burning? The eye, bhikkhus, is burning, visible objects are burning” , where the meaning revealed first

original: bhikkhave, ādittaṃ, rūpā ādittā”ti evamādīsu kathitesu “tikkhindriyo saṅkhepena vuttaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhave ādittam rūpā ādittā ti evamādīsu kathitesu tikkhindriyaḥ saṅkhepena vuttam
translated: is again revealed by the illuminating of it in detail.

original: paṭivijjhatī”ti kathitattā dve atthapadāni tikkhindriyassa upakāravasena vuttāni.
analyzed: paṭivijjhati iti kathita ttā dve attha padāni tikkhindriyassa upakāra vasena vuttāni
translated: It is said that the two terms “meaning” and “meaning unit” are used to indicate what is helpful to one of quick understanding in the case of the brief statement.

original: Saṃkhittassa vitthārābhidhānaṃ sakiṃ vuttassa ca punapi abhidhānaṃ vivaraṇaṃ, “kusalā🔽dhammā”ti saṅkhepena nikkhittassa. “Katame dhammā kusalā? Yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ
analyzed: saṃkhittassa vitthāra abhidhānam sakim vuttassa ca puna api abhidhānam vivaraṇam kusalā  dhammā ati saṅkhepena nikkhittassa katame dhammā kusalā yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram
translated: The ‘elucidation’ is the ‘expounding’ of the ‘brief’ by the ‘extended’ and the ‘re-expounding’ of what has been stated once. The ‘elucidation’ of the ‘wholesome states’ stated briefly is the ‘elucidation’ of the ‘wholesome states’ stated in brief as ‘What are wholesome states? On whatever occasion one in the sensual realm …

original: kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hotī”ti niddesavasena vitthāraṇaṃ vitthāravasena puna kathanaṃ vivaraṇaṃ nāma.🔽Taṃ vibhāgakaraṇaṃ vibhajanaṃ, “yasmiṃ samaye”ti vivarite kusale dhamme “tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: kusalam cittam uppannam hoti iti niddesa vasena vitthāraṇam vitthāra vasena puna kathanam vivaraṇam nāma  tam vibhāga karaṇam vibhajanam yasmin samaye iti vivarite kusale dhamme tasmin samaye
translated: The ‘elucidation’ is the ‘expounding’ of what is ‘brief’ in ‘full detail’ and the ‘re-expounding’ of what is ‘stated once’ . The ‘elucidation’ is the ‘expounding in full detail’ of what is stated in brief as ‘profitable ideas’ by the method of ‘demonstration’ in the way beginning, ‘What are profitable ideas? When a profitable consciousness has arisen …’ . The ‘re-expounding’ is the ‘telling again in full detail’ .

original: phasso hoti, vedanā hotī”ti vibhāgakaraṇaṃ vibhajanaṃ nāma. Vivarassa vitthārābhidhānena🔽vibhattassa ca upamābhidhānena paṭipādanaṃ uttānīkaraṇaṃ, vivaraṇena vivaritatthassa
analyzed: phassaḥ hoti vedanā hoti iti vibhāga karaṇam vibhajanam nāma vivarassa vitthāra abhidhānena  vibhattassa ca upamā abhidhānena paṭipādanam uttānīkaraṇam vivaraṇena
translated: The ‘analysis’ is the ‘analysis’ by the method of ‘making a division’ . The ‘analysis’ is the ‘making a division’ by the method of ‘making a division’ in the profitable ideas elucidated by the words ‘When’ , etc., in the way beginning, ‘At that time there is contact, there is feeling’ .

original: “katamo tasmiṃ samaye phasso hoti? Yo tasmiṃ samaye phasso phusanā samphusanā”ti
analyzed: katamaḥ tasmin samaye phassaḥ hoti yaḥ tasmin samaye phassaḥ phusanā samphusanā ati
translated: The ‘exposition’ is the ‘making plain’ by the ‘expounding in full detail’ of what is ‘elucidated’ and by the ‘expounding by simile’ of what is ‘analysed’ . The ‘exposition’ is the ‘making plain’ of the meaning ‘elucidated’ by the ‘elucidation’ in the way beginning, ‘What is contact at that time? It is whatever at that time is contact, contacting, being in contact’ .

original: ativivaritvā kathanañca vibhajanena vibhattassa “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāvī niccammā,
analyzed: kathanañca vibhajanena vibhattassa sā iyyathā api bhikkhave gāvī niccammā
translated: And the teaching by way of simile, such as: “Bhikkhus, just as a cow to be slaughtered, as she is being led to the slaughterhouse,

original: evameva khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, phassāhāro daṭṭhabboti vadāmī”ti evamādiupamākathanañca
analyzed: evam eva khvā aham bhikkhave phassa āhāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ ti vadāmi iti evamādi upamā kathanañca
translated: goes to her own slaughter by way of this or that direction, even so, bhikkhus, I say that the nutriment contact should be seen in this way.”🔽And the teaching by way of the obvious, such as: “Bhikkhus, when they hear the Dhamma they are gladdened and experience joy.

original: uttānīkaraṇaṃ nāma. Dhammaṃ suṇantānaṃ dhammadesanena cittassa anekavidhena somanassauppādanañca
analyzed: uttānīkaraṇam nāma dhammam suṇantānam dhamma desanena cittassa anekavidhena somanassa uppādanam ca
translated: And the gladdened one experiences happiness. The happy one’s mind becomes concentrated. He reflects wisely. He attains the destruction of the taints.”

original: atikhiṇabuddhīnaṃ anekavidhena ñāṇassa tikhiṇabhāvakaraṇañca paññatti nāma, tesaṃ🔽suṇantānaṃ taṃcittatosanena taṃcittanisāmanena ca paññāyatīti paññatti. Tattha bhagavā🔽akkharehi saṅkāsayati, padehi pakāsayati, byañjanehi vivarati, ākārehi vibhajati,
analyzed: atikhiṇa buddhīnam anekavidhena ñāṇassa tikhiṇa bhāva karaṇam ca paññatti nāma tesam  suṇantānam tad citta tosanena tad citta nisāmanena ca paññāyati iti paññatti tattha bhagavā  akkharehi saṅkāsayati padehi pakāsayati byañjanehi vivarati ākārehi vibhajati
translated: And the teaching by way of definition, such as: “Bhikkhus, the eye is subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽And the ear … the nose … the tongue … the body … the mind is subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.”🔽Herein, the Blessed One causes them to be enticed by the syllables, he causes them to be gladdened by the words, he causes them to be enticed by the phonemes, he causes them to be gladdened by the phrasing, he causes them to be enticed by the obvious, he causes them to be gladdened by the definitions.

original: niruttīhi uttānīkaroti, niddesehi paññāpayatīti. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Buddhā bhagavanto🔽ekacce veneyye ekasmiṃ desane akkharehi atthasaṅkāsanaṃ karonti…pe… niddesehi atthapaññāpanaṃ
analyzed: niruttīhi uttānīkaroti niddesehi paññāpayati iti kim vuttam hoti buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ 🔽ekacce veneyye ekasmim desane akkharehi attha saṅkāsanam karontipe niddesehi attha paññāpanam
translated: Herein, the Blessed One causes them to be enticed by the syllables, he causes them to be gladdened by the words, he causes them to be enticed by the phonemes, he causes them to be gladdened by the phrasing, he causes them to be enticed by the obvious, he causes them to be gladdened by the definitions.🔽Herein, the Blessed One causes them to be enticed by the syllables, he causes them to be gladdened by the words, he causes them to be enticed by the phonemes, he causes them to be gladdened by the phrasing, he causes them to be enticed by the obvious, he causes them to be gladdened by the definitions.🔽Herein, the Blessed One causes them to be enticed by the syllables, he causes them to be gladdened by the words, he causes them to be enticed by the phonemes, he causes them to be gladdened by the phrasing, he causes them to be enticed by the obvious, he causes them to be gladdened by the definitions.

original: karontīti ayamettha adhippāyo.
analyzed: karonti iti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ
translated: is the intention here.

original: Atha vā akkharehi saṅkāsayitvā padehi pakāsayati, byañjanehi vivaritvā ākārehi vibhajati,
analyzed: atha vā akkharehi saṅkāsayitvā padehi pakāsayati byañjanehi vivaritvā ākārehi vibhajati
translated: Or else, having aroused by means of the syllables, he makes them manifest by means of the words; having opened them out by means of the phonemes, he analyses them by means of the phrases;

original: niruttīhi uttānīkatvā niddesehi paññāpayati. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Evarūpena dhammadesanena
analyzed: niruttīhi uttānīkatvā niddesehi paññāpayati kim vuttam hoti evarūpena dhamma desanena
translated: having made them plain by means of the metrical permutations, he demonstrates them by means of the definitions. What is meant? By means of such teaching of the Dhamma

original: ekaccesu ṭhānesu ekaccānaṃ veneyyānaṃ vinayatīti.
analyzed: ekaccesu ṭhānesu ekaccānam veneyyānam vinayati iti
translated: he disciplines some of those to be disciplined in some instances.

original: Atha vā akkharehi ugghāṭayitvā padehi pakāsento vinayati ugghaṭitaññuṃ, byañjanehi
analyzed: atha vā akkharehi ugghāṭayitvā padehi pakāsentaḥ vinayati ugghaṭitaññum byañjanehi
translated: Or else, having uncovered by means of the syllables, he disciplines those who are ripe for hearing by making them manifest by means of the words;

original: vivaritvā ākārehi vibhajanto vinayati vipañcitaññuṃ, niruttīhi uttānīkatvā niddesehi
analyzed: vivaritvā ākārehi vibhajantaḥ vinayati vipañcitaññum niruttīhi uttānīka tvā niddesehi
translated: having opened them out by means of the phonemes, he disciplines those who are ripe for pondering by analysing them by means of the phrases;

original: paññāpento vinayati neyyaṃ. Iti veneyyavasenapi yojetabbameva.🔽Atthato panettha katamo byañjanapāṭho, katamo atthapāṭhoti? Buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ
analyzed: paññāpentaḥ vinayati neyyam iti veneyya vasena api yojetabbam eva  atthataḥ pana ittha katamaḥ byañjana pāṭho katamaḥ attha pāṭho ti buddhānam bhagavantānam
translated: having made them plain by means of the metrical permutations, he disciplines those who are ripe for guidance by demonstrating them by means of the definitions. So it should be construed also according to those to be disciplined.🔽But what here is the phrasing of the meaning and what is the phrasing of the phrasing? The phrasing of the meaning is the meaning that is understood

original: dhammaṃ desentānaṃ yo atthāvagamako saviññattikasaddo, so byañjanapāṭho. Yo tena
analyzed: dhammam desentānam yaḥ attha avagamakaḥ sa viññattika saddo saḥ byañjana pāṭhaḥ yaḥ tena
translated: when the Blessed Buddhas teach the Dhamma. The phrasing of the phrasing is the significant sound that is the means to the understanding of that meaning.

original: abhisametabbo lakkhaṇarasādisahito dhammo, so atthapāṭhoti veditabbo. Punapi sandhāyabhāsito
analyzed: abhisametabbaḥ lakkhaṇa rasa ādi sahitaḥ dhammo so attha pāṭhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ puna api sandhāya bhāsito
translated: The meaning of the text should be understood as the Dhamma with its characteristics, its functions, etc., that has been penetrated.🔽Again, the text is of six kinds as spoken with a hidden meaning,

original: byañjanabhāsito sāvasesapāṭho anavasesapāṭho nīto neyyoti chabbidho pāṭho. Tattha
analyzed: byañjana bhāsito sa avasesa pāṭhaḥ anavasesa pāṭhaḥ nītaḥ neyyaḥ ti chabbidhaḥ pāṭhaḥ tattha
translated: as spoken with a merely apparent meaning, as having a remainder, as having no remainder, as literal, and as non-literal.

original: anekatthavattā sandhāyabhāsito “mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā, rājāno dve ca khattiye”ti
analyzed: anekatthavattā sandhāya bhāsitaḥ mātaram pitaram hantvā rājānaḥ dve ca khattiya iti
translated: Herein, that spoken with a hidden meaning is that which has many meanings, such as the following: “Having slain mother and father, and two warrior kings, and having slain the people of the clan, the guiltless one goes on his way” .

original: evamādi. Ekatthavattā byañjanabhāsito ‘manopubbaṅgamā dhammā”ti evamādi. Sāvaseso
analyzed: evamādi ekatthavattā byañjana bhāsitaḥ manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammā ti evamādi sa avasesaḥ
translated: That spoken with a merely apparent meaning is that which has a single meaning, such as the following: “Ideas have mind as their forerunner, mind is their chief, and they are mind-made” .

original: “sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, āditta”nti evamādi. Viparīto anavaseso “sabbe dhammā sabbākārena
analyzed: sabbam bhikkhave ādittanti evamādi viparītaḥ anavasesaḥ sabbe dhammā sabba ākārena
translated: That having a remainder is that which has a remainder of what is not stated, such as the following: “Bhikkhus, all is burning” .

original: buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇamukhe āpāthaṃ āgacchantī”ti evamādi. Yathā vacanaṃ, tathā
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ ñāṇa mukhe āpātham āgacchanti iti evamādi yathā vacanam tathā
translated: That having no remainder is that which has no remainder of what is not stated, such as the following: “All ideas come into the range of vision of the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One, by direct-knowledge” .

original: avagantabbo nīto “aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā”ti evamādi. Yuttiyā anussaritabbo neyyo
analyzed: avagantabbaḥ nītaḥ aniccam dukkham anattā ati evamādi yuttiyā anussaritabbaḥ neyyaḥ
translated: That which is literal is that which should be understood in the way it is stated, such as the following: “Impermanent, painful, not-self” .

original: “ekapuggalo bhikkhave”ti evamādi.
analyzed: eka puggalaḥ bhikkhave ti evamādi
translated: That which is non-literal is that which should be understood by interpretation, such as the following: “One person, bhikkhus” .

original: Attho pana anekappakāro pāṭhattho sabhāvattho ñāyattho pāṭhānurūpo napāṭhānurūpo🔽sāvasesattho niravasesattho nītattho neyyattho iccādi. Tattha yo appassatthassa ñāpanatthamuccāriyate,
analyzed: attho pana aneka ppakāro pāṭha attho sabhāva ttho ñāya ttho pāṭha anurūpaḥ na pāṭha anurūpaḥ  sa avasesa atthaḥ niravasesa atthaḥ nīta tthaḥ neyyatthaḥ iccādi tattha yaḥ appassatthassa ñāpana ttham uccāriyate
translated: But the meaning is of many kinds as the meaning of the text, the meaning of individual essence, the meaning of condition, the meaning of what is conformable to the text, the meaning of what is not conformable to the text,🔽the meaning of what is incomplete, the meaning of what is complete, the meaning of the letter, the meaning of the spirit, and so on. Herein, that which is uttered for the purpose of making known what is little known🔽is the meaning of the text, as in the passage beginning, “Meaningful, with a meaning, unconfused,

original: so pāṭhattho “sātthaṃ sabyañjana”ntiādīsu viya. Rūpārūpadhammānaṃ lakkhaṇarasādisabhāvattho🔽“sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāvetī”tiādīsu viya. Yo ñāyamāno hitāya saṃvattati, so ñātuṃ arahatīti🔽ñāyattho – “atthavādī dhammavādī”tiādīsu viya. Yathāpāṭhaṃ bhāsito pāṭhānurūpo “cakkhu,
analyzed: so sa atthaḥ sa byañjana nti ādīsu viya rūpa arūpa dhammānam lakkhaṇa rasa ādi sa bhāva tthaḥ  sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti itiādīsu viya yaḥ ñāyamānaḥ hitāya saṃvattati saḥ ñātum arahati iti  attha vādī dhamma vādī iti ādīsu viya yathāpāṭham bhāsito pāṭha anurūpo cakkhu
translated: The meaning of individual essence is the characteristic, function, etc., of material and immaterial states.🔽The meaning of condition is that which is a condition, as in the passage beginning, “He develops understanding” .🔽The meaning of what is conformable to the text is that which is spoken in accordance with the text, as in the passage, “The eye, bhikkhus, is a thing that is born, that becomes manifest” .

original: bhikkhave, purāṇakamma”nti bhagavatā vuttaṃ. Tasmā cakkhumapi kammanti. Byañjanacchāyāya
analyzed: bhikkhave purāṇa kammanti bhagavatā vuttam tasmā cakkhum api kammanti byañjana chāyāya
translated: The meaning of what is not conformable to the text is that which is spoken in opposition to the meaning by one who rejects the meaning by relying on the mere letter, as in the passage, “The eye, bhikkhus, is the first of the gains” .🔽The meaning of what is incomplete is that which is not fully understood, as in the passage, “The world is finite” .

original: atthaṃ paṭibāhayamānena vutto attho napāṭhānurūpo, so pāṭhato ananuññāto akatapaṭikkhepo
analyzed: attham paṭibāhayamānena vuttaḥ atthaḥ na pāṭha anurūpaḥ so pāṭhataḥ an anuññātaḥ a kata paṭikkhepo
translated: The meaning of what is complete is that which is fully understood, as in the passage, “The world is infinite” .🔽The meaning of the letter is the meaning of the individual consonants, as in the passage, “The one who has seen arises and dissolves In the nine dhammas connected with the eye,

original: viyutto. So ca saṅgahetabbampi asaṅgahetvā, parivajjetabbampi vā kiñci aparivajjetvā
analyzed: viyuttaḥ saḥ ca saṅgahetabbam pi a saṅgahetvā parivajjetabbam pi vā kiñci a parivajjetvā
translated: and it is not mixed with anything else. And it is not mixed with anything else to be included or excluded.

original: parisesaṃ katvā vutto sāvasesattho “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: parisesam katvā vuttaḥ sa avasesa attho cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: It is stated with a remainder, and so it has a remainder. It is like this: “Eye-consciousness arises dependent on the eye and forms.”🔽It is like this: “All tremble at violence; all fear death. ”

original: Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno”tiādīsu viya. Viparīto niravasesattho
analyzed: sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa sabbe bhāyanti maccunā ti ādīsu viya viparītaḥ niravasesa atthaḥ
translated: It is the opposite, and so it has no remainder.

original: “sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca. Tatra, bhikkhave, ko mantā ko saddhātā…pe…
analyzed: sandhāvitam saṃsaritam mamañca iva tumhākam ca tatra bhikkhave kaḥ mantā kaḥ saddhā tāpe
translated: It is like this: “There has been wandering on and wandering on by me as well as by you. There, bhikkhus, who is there to blame and who to despise? …🔽except for one who has seen the state. ”

original: aññatra diṭṭhapadehī”tiādīsu viya. Saddavaseneva veditabbo nītattho “rūpā saddā rasā🔽gandhā, phoṭṭhabbā ca manoramā”tiādīsu viya. Sammutivasena veditabbo neyyattho “cattārome,
analyzed: aññatra diṭṭha padehi iti ādīsu viya sadda vasena iva veditabbaḥ nītatthaḥ rūpā saddā rasā  gandhā phoṭṭhabbā ca manoramā ti ādīsu viya sammuti vasena veditabbo cattāro me
translated: It is to be understood by the sound, and so it has the sound-meaning. It is like this: “Forms, sounds, tastes,🔽smells, and tangible objects are delightful.”🔽It is to be understood by the agreement, and so it has the agreed-meaning. It is like this: “There are, bhikkhus, these four kinds of persons comparable to lightning.”

original: bhikkhave, valāhakūpamā puggalā”tiādīsu viya. Evamidha pāṭhañca atthañca vivaritvā
analyzed: bhikkhave valāhaka upamā evam idha pāṭhañca atthañca vivaritvā
translated: Having thus explained the reading and the meaning here,

original: ṭhito asaṃhīro bhavati paravādīhi dīgharattaṃ titthavāsena.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ a saṃhīraḥ bhavati para vādīhi dīgharattam tittha vāsena
translated: the opponent remains unconfused for a long time, as a resident of the doctrine, by the opponents’ doctrines.

original: Iti asaṃhīrabhāvena yāva āgamādhigamasampadaṃ, tāva vattuṃ sakkoti. Saṅkhepavitthāranayena
analyzed: iti asaṃhīra bhāvena yāva āgama adhigama sampadam tāva vattum sakkoti saṅkhepa vitthāra nayena
translated: Thus he is able to speak as far as the attainment of the scriptures and the higher knowledge by virtue of his unperturbability.🔽He is able to make others understand by means of the method of brief and detailed explanations,

original: hetudāharaṇādīhi avabodhayituṃ samattho. Evaṃvidho attānañca parañca sodhetuṃ samatthabhāvena
analyzed: hetu dāharaṇa ādīhi avabodhayitum samatthaḥ evaṃvidhaḥ attānam ca param ca sodhetum samattha bhāvena
translated: by means of reasons, examples, etc. Being thus able to purify himself and others,

original: dussīlyadiṭṭhimalavirahitattā suci. Dussīlo hi attānaṃ upahanati, tena nādeyyavāco🔽ca bhavati sabyohāramāno idha niccāturo vejjova. Duddiṭṭhi paraṃ upahanati, nāvassayo🔽ca bhavati vāḷagahākulo iva kamalasaṇḍo. Ubhayavipanno pana sabbathāpi anupāsanīyo
analyzed: dussīlya diṭṭhi mala virahita ttā suci dussīlaḥ hi attānam upahanati tena na ādeyya vācaḥ  ca bhavati idha nicca āturaḥ param upahanati na avassayo  ca bhavati vāḷagahā ākulaḥ iva kamala saṇḍaḥ ubhaya vipannaḥ pana sabbathā api anupāsanīyaḥ
translated: he is pure, being free from the stains of moral depravity and wrong views. For the immoral man destroys himself, and therefore his word is not accepted,🔽and he becomes an object of blame, like a doctor who is always ill himself. The man of wrong views destroys others, and he himself becomes untrustworthy,🔽like a lotus-pond surrounded by a forest of black ebony trees. But the man who is deficient in both respects is to be shunned in every way,

original: bhavati gūthagatamiva chavālātaṃ gūthagato viya ca kaṇhasappo. Ubhayasampanno pana🔽sabbathāpi upāsanīyo sevitabbo ca viññūhi, nirupaddavo iva ratanākaro, evaṃ bhūto
analyzed: bhavati gūtha gatam iva chava alātam gūtha gataḥ ca kaṇha sappo ubhaya sampanno pana  sabbathā api upāsanīyaḥ sevitabbaḥ ca viññūhi nirupaddavaḥ iva ratanākaraḥ evam bhūto
translated: like a piece of meat thrown away at a crossroads, or like a black snake. But the man who is endowed with both qualities🔽is to be honoured and served by the wise in every way, like a mine of jewels free from danger, and he is thus not a miser, not a teacher of the low.

original: evaṃ amaccharo ahīnācariyamuṭṭhi. Suttasuttānulomaācariyavādaattanomatisaṅkhātānañca
analyzed: evam ahīna ācariya muṭṭhi sutta sutta anuloma ācariya vāda atta nomati saṅkhātānam ca
translated: He is not a teacher who is deficient in the scriptures, the higher virtue, the higher knowledge, and the higher wisdom,

original: catunnaṃ apariccāgī, tesaṃ vasena byākhyāto.
analyzed: catunnam a pariccāgī tesam vasena byākhyātaḥ
translated: And so he is described.🔽One is to be stated in one way,

original: “Ekaṃsavacanaṃ ekaṃ, vibhajjavacanaṃ padaṃ;
analyzed: eka savacanam ekam vibhajja vacanam padam
translated: One in terms of analysis,🔽The third is to be cross-questioned,

original: Tatiyaṃ paṭipuccheyya, catutthaṃ pana ṭhāpaye”ti.
analyzed: tatiyam paṭipuccheyya catuttham pana ṭhāpaya iti
translated: But the fourth is to be set aside.

original: Etesaṃ vā apariccāgī. Tato eva sotūnaṃ hite niyuttattā nesaṃ avabodhanaṃ pati akilāsu bhavatīti. Āha cettha –
analyzed: etesam vai a pariccāgī tatas eva sotūnam hite avabodhanam a kilāsu bhavati iti āha ca ittha
translated: Or he is not ungenerous with these. And so he is not wearied by the task of making his listeners understand, since he is intent on their welfare. Herein, he says:

original: “Pāṭhatthavidasaṃhīro, vattā suci amaccharo;
analyzed: vattā suci amaccharaḥ
translated: He is a reciter, knows the meaning, is not stingy,🔽Is a teacher, not ungenerous with the four,

original: Catunnaṃ apariccāgī, desakassa hitānvito”ti.
analyzed: catunnam a pariccāgī desakassa hita anvito ti
translated: And is intent on the welfare of the country.

original: Ettha desakassāti desako assa, bhaveyyāti attho. Hitānvitoti hite anugato hitacitto.
analyzed: ettha desakassa ati desakaḥ assa bhaveyya ati atthaḥ hita anvitaḥ ti hite anugataḥ hita cittaḥ
translated: Herein, he is a teacher of the country, is what is meant. He is intent on the welfare of the country, is intent on its welfare, has the country’s welfare at heart.🔽He is dear and loved because of his good will,🔽respected because of his ungenerosity with the four,

original: So eso sucittā piyo, catunnaṃ apariccāgittā garu, asaṃhīrattā bhāvanīyo, desakattā
analyzed: so eso su cittā piyaḥ catunnam a pariccāgi ttā garu a saṃhīra ttā bhāvanīyaḥ desaka ttā
translated: to be relied on because of his non-stinginess,🔽a teacher because of his teaching,🔽able to be taught because of his intentness on the welfare of the country,

original: vattā, hitānvitattā vacanakkhamo, pāṭhatthavidattā gambhīrakathaṃ kattā, amaccharattā
analyzed: vattā hita anvita ttā vacana kkhamaḥ pāṭha attha vidattā gambhīra katham kattā amaccha rattā
translated: a talker because of his knowledge of the meaning of what is recited,

original: na cāṭṭhāne niyojako iti –
analyzed: na ca aṭṭhāne niyojakaḥ iti
translated: and not one to be directed to do what should not be done because of his non-stinginess.🔽So he is dear and loved,🔽respected, to be relied on, a teacher,

original: “Piyo garu bhāvanīyo, vattā ca vacanakkhamo;
analyzed: piyaḥ garu bhāvanīyaḥ vattā ca vacana kkhamaḥ
translated: able to be taught,

original: Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā, no cāṭṭhāne niyojako”ti. ;
analyzed: gambhīram ca katham kattā no ca aṭṭhāne niyojakaḥ ti
translated: And he is a speaker of what is deep, not one who misleads by what is not the right occasion.

original: “Abhihito desako so, tāva dāni abhidhīyate”.
analyzed: abhihitaḥ desakaḥ saḥ tāva dāni abhidhīyate
translated: He is one who is reproved, and now he is reproved.

original: Tattha dhammagaruttā kathaṃ na paribhavati, ācariyagaruttā kathikaṃ na paribhavati,
analyzed: tattha dhamma garuttā katham na paribhavati ācariya garuttā kathikam na paribhavati
translated: Herein, he does not despise the talk because he respects the Dhamma; he does not despise the speaker because he respects the teacher;

original: saddhāpaññādiguṇapaṭimaṇḍitattā attānaṃ na paribhavati, asaṭhāmāyāvittā amatābhimukhattā
analyzed: saddhā paññā ādi guṇa paṭimaṇḍita ttā attānam na paribhavati a saṭhā māyā vittā a mata abhimukha ttā
translated: he does not despise himself because he is adorned with faith, understanding, etc., and is not fraudulent or deceitful but is intent on the Deathless.

original: ca avikkhittacitto bhavati, sumedhattā yoniso manasi karotīti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ca a vikkhitta cittaḥ bhavati sumedhat tā yonisas manasi karoti iti vuttam ha etam
translated: And he is not distracted because he is not confused, and he gives attention appropriately because he is wise. For this is said:

original: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato suṇanto saddhammaṃ bhabbo niyāmaṃ okkamituṃ
analyzed: pañcahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ suṇantaḥ saddhammam bhabbaḥ niyāmam okkamitum
translated: “Bhikkhus, when one is listening to the true Dhamma, one who has five qualities is capable of entering upon the certainty of rightness in profitable states.

original: kusalesu dhammesu sammattaṃ. Katamehi pañcahi? Na kathaṃ paribhoti, na kathikaṃ paribhoti,
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu sammattam katamehi pañcahi na katham paribhoti na kathikam paribhoti
translated: What five? He does not despise the talk, he does not despise the speaker,

original: na attānaṃ paribhoti, avikkhittacitto dhammaṃ suṇāti ekaggacitto, yoniso manasi karotī”ti.
analyzed: na attānam paribhoti a vikkhitta cittaḥ dhammam suṇāti ekagga cittaḥ yonisaḥ manasi karoti iti
translated: he does not despise himself, he listens to the Dhamma with a one-pointed mind, and he gives attention appropriately” .

original: Taṃlakkhaṇappattattā bhāvanaṃ bhajatīti. Āha cettha –
analyzed: tad lakkhaṇa ppatta ttā bhāvanam bhajati iti āha ca ittha
translated: He is capable of entering upon the certainty of rightness in profitable states because he possesses the characteristics of the hearer. It is said:

original: “Dhammācariyagaru saddhāpaññādiguṇamaṇḍito;
translated: “Honouring the teacher of Dhamma, adorned with the qualities of faith, wisdom, and so on,

original: Asaṭhāmāyāvikassa, sumedho amatābhimukho”. –
analyzed: sumedhaḥ amata abhimukhaḥ
translated: The wise one, free from deceit and guile, is intent on the deathless.”

original: Iti vattā ca sotā ca.
analyzed: iti vattā ca sotā ca
translated: Thus he is both a speaker and a hearer.

original: Evaṃ vuttappakāraṃ byañjanañca atthañca dassetvā idāni yo atiaggaṃ katvā kathitattā mahāsamuddamahāpathavī viya mahā ca so niddeso cāti mahāniddeso, taṃ mahāniddesaṃ vaṇṇayissāmi.
analyzed: evam vutta ppakāram byañjanam ca atthañca dassetvā idāni yaḥ atiaggam katvā kathita ttā mahā samudda mahā pathavī viya mahā ca saḥ niddeso ca ati mahāniddeso tam mahāniddesam vaṇṇayissāmi
translated: Having thus shown the wording and the meaning of the kind of exposition described above, he now says: “I shall expound the Mahāniddesa, which is great and an exposition, like the great ocean and the great earth, because it is spoken of as preeminent.”

original: Tadetaṃ mahāniddesaṃ atthasampannaṃ byañjanasampannaṃ gambhīraṃ gambhīratthaṃ lokuttarappakāsakaṃ
analyzed: tat etam mahāniddesam attha sampannam byañjana sampannam gambhīram gambhīra attham lokuttara ppakāsakaṃ
translated: This Mahāniddesa is rich in meaning, rich in phrasing, profound, of profound meaning, and it reveals the supramundane.

original: suññatappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ paṭipattimaggaphalavisesasādhanaṃ paṭipattipaṭipakkhapaṭisedhanaṃ
translated: It is concerned with emptiness, and it accomplishes the distinction of the path and the fruit, which are the practice, and it prevents the opposition to the practice.

original: yogāvacarānaṃ ñāṇavararatanākarabhūtaṃ dhammakathikānaṃ dhammakathāvilāsavisesahetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: yogāvacarānam ñāṇa vara ratana ākara bhūtam dhamma kathikānam dhamma kathā vilāsa visesa hetu bhūtam
translated: It is like a mine of the jewel of knowledge for those who practice yoga, and it is like a cause for the special kind of eloquence in the Dhamma for those who expound the Dhamma.

original: saṃsārabhīrukānaṃ dukkhanissaraṇatadupāyadassanena assāsajananatthaṃ tappaṭipakkhanāsanatthañca
analyzed: saṃsāra bhīrukānam dukkha nissaraṇa tad upāya dassanena assāsa janana attham tad paṭipakkha nāsana attham ca
translated: It gives comfort to those who are afraid of saṃsāra by showing the escape from suffering and the means to it, and it removes their opposition to that.

original: gambhīratthānañca anekesaṃ suttantapadānaṃ atthavivaraṇena sujanahadayaparitosajananatthaṃ,
analyzed: gambhīra tthānam ca anekesam suttanta padānam attha vivaraṇena su jana hadaya paritosa janana ttham
translated: and for the purpose of gladdening the hearts of the good people by the explanation of the meaning of the deep Suttas and the words of the Suttas,

original: tathāgatena arahatā sammāsambuddhena sabbattha appaṭihatasabbaññutaññāṇamahādīpobhāsena
analyzed: tathāgatena arahatā sammāsambuddhena sabbattha appaṭihata sabbaññu taññāṇa mahā dīpa ubhāsena
translated: the Tathāgata, the Arahat, the Supreme Buddha, with the great light of his all-knowing knowledge, which is unobstructed everywhere,

original: sakalajanavitthatamahākaruṇāsinehena veneyyajanahadayagatakilesandhakāravidhamanatthaṃ
analyzed: sakala jana vitthata mahā karuṇā sinehena veneyya jana hadaya gata kilesa andhakāra vidhamana attham
translated: with the great compassion, which is extended to all people, for the purpose of removing the darkness of the defilements in the hearts of the people to be trained,

original: samujjalitassa saddhammamahāpadīpassa tadadhippāyavikāsanasinehaparisekena pañcavassasahassamaticirasamujjalanamicchatā
analyzed: samujjalitassa saddhamma mahā padīpassa tad adhippāya vikāsana sineha parisekena pañca vassa sahassam ati cira samujjalanam icchatā
translated: with the affection of the spreading of the great light of the True Dhamma, which is burning brightly, with the desire to make it burn for five thousand years, which is a long time,

original: lokānukampakena satthukappena dhammarājassa dhammasenāpatinā āyasmatā sāriputtattherena
analyzed: loka anukampakena satthu kappena dhammarājassa dhamma senāpatinā āyasmatā sāriputta therena
translated: the Lord of the Dhamma, the General of the Dhamma, the Elder Āyasmā Sāriputta, who is the Teacher’s equal and has compassion for the world,

original: bhāsitaṃ sutvā āyasmā ānando paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikāle yathāsutameva saṅgahaṃ āropesi.
analyzed: bhāsitam sutvā āyasmai ānando paṭhama mahā saṅgīti kāle yathāsutam eva saṅgaham āropesi
translated: having heard it spoken, Āyasmā Ānanda placed it in his own memory just as he had heard it at the time of the First Great Recital.

original: So panesa vinayapiṭakaṃ suttantapiṭakaṃ abhidhammapiṭakanti tīsu piṭakesu suttantapiṭakapariyāpanno,
analyzed: so pana esa vinaya piṭakam suttanta piṭakam abhidhamma piṭakam ti tīsu piṭakesu suttanta piṭaka pariyāpannaḥ
translated: And this, which is included in the three Piṭakas, the Vinaya Piṭaka, the Suttanta Piṭaka, and the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, is included in the Suttanta Piṭaka,

original: dīghanikāyo majjhimanikāyo saṃyuttanikāyo aṅguttaranikāyo khuddakanikāyoti pañcasu🔽mahānikāyesu khuddakamahānikāyapariyāpanno, suttaṃ geyyaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ gāthā udānaṃ
analyzed: dīgha nikāyaḥ majjhima nikāyaḥ saṃyutta nikāyaḥ aṅguttara nikāyaḥ khuddaka nikāyaḥ iti pañcasu  mahā nikāyesu khuddaka mahā nikāya pariyāpannaḥ suttam geyyam veyyākaraṇam gāthāḥ udānam
translated: In the five great collections,

original: itivuttakaṃ jātakaṃ abbhutadhammaṃ vedallanti navasu satthusāsanaṅgesu yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: itivuttakam jātakam abbhuta dhammam vedallanti navasu satthu sāsana aṅgesu yathāsambhavam
translated: it is included in the Minor Collection, and in the nine divisions of the Teacher’s Dispensation,

original: gāthaṅgaveyyākaraṇaṅgadvayasaṅgahito.
analyzed: gāthaṅga veyyākaraṇa aṅga dvaya saṅgahito
translated: it is included in the two divisions of verse and prose exposition.🔽“I have learned from the Buddha eighty-two,

original: “Dvāsīti buddhato gaṇhiṃ, dvesahassāni bhikkhuto;
analyzed: buddhataḥ dve sahassāni bhikkhutaḥ
translated: and from the bhikkhus two thousand;🔽and eighty-four thousand dhammas

original: Caturāsīti sahassāni, ye me dhammā pavattino”ti. –
analyzed: catur asīti sahassāni ye me dhammā pavattino ti
translated: that have come down to me.”

original: Dhammabhaṇḍāgārikattherena pañcasu ṭhānesu etadaggaṃ āropitena paṭiññātānaṃ caturāsītiyā
analyzed: dhammabhaṇḍāgārika therena pañcasu ṭhānesu etad aggam āropitena paṭiññā tānam caturāsītiyā
translated: The Elder Dhammabhaṇḍāgārika, who was pre-eminent in five things,🔽had learned from the bhikkhus two thousand dhammas out of the eighty-four thousand dhammas that he had learned.

original: dhammakkhandhasahassānaṃ bhikkhuto gahitesu dvīsu dhammakkhandhasahassesu anekasatadhammakkhandhasaṅgahito.
analyzed: dhamma kkhandha sahassānam bhikkhutaḥ gahitesu dvīsu dhamma kkhandha sahassesu aneka sata dhamma kkhandha saṅgahito
translated: It is included in many hundreds of dhammas.

original: Tassa dve vaggā aṭṭhakavaggo pārāyanavaggo khaggavisāṇasuttañca, ekekasmiṃ vagge
analyzed: tassa dve vaggā aṭṭhaka vaggo pārāyana vaggo khagga visāṇa suttam ca ekekasmin vagge
translated: It has two sections, the Aṭṭhakavagga and the Pārāyanavagga, and the Khaggavisāṇa Sutta. In each section there are

original: soḷasa soḷasa katvā khaggavisāṇasuttañcāti tettiṃsa suttāni kāmasuttādikhaggavisāṇasuttapariyosānāni.
analyzed: soḷasa soḷasa katvā khagga visāṇa suttam ca ati tettiṃsa suttāni kāmasutta ādi khagga visāṇa sutta pariyosānāni
translated: and the sixteen each time make thirty-three suttas, namely, the ‘Sutta on Sensual Pleasures’ and the rest down to the ‘Sutta on the Single Nail’ .

original: Evaṃ anekadhā vavatthāpitassa imassa mahāniddesassa anupubbapadatthavaṇṇanaṃ karissāmi.
analyzed: evam anekadhā vavatthāpitassa imassa mahāniddesassa anupubba pada ttha vaṇṇanam karissāmi
translated: I shall comment on the meaning of the words in the order in which they stand in this Great Method, which is thus analysed in many ways.

original: Ayañhi mahāniddeso pāṭhato atthato ca uddisantena niddisantena ca sakkaccaṃ uddisitabbo
analyzed: ayan hi mahāniddesaḥ pāṭhataḥ atthataḥ ca uddisantena niddisantena ca sakkaccam uddisitabbo
translated: For this Great Method should be recited and demonstrated by one who recites and demonstrates it with care as to both text and meaning,

original: niddisitabbo ca, uggaṇhantenāpi sakkaccaṃ uggaṇhitabbo dhāretabbo ca. Taṃ kissa hetu?
analyzed: niddisitabbaḥ ca uggaṇhantena api sakkaccam uggaṇhitabbaḥ dhāretabbaḥ ca tam kissa hetu
translated: and it should be learnt and borne in mind by one who learns and bears it in mind with care. And why?

original: Gambhīrattā imassa mahāniddesassa lokahitāya loke ciraṭṭhitatthanti.
analyzed: gambhīra ttā imassa mahāniddesassa loka hitāya loke cira ṭṭhita ttham ti
translated: Because this Great Method is profound and it endures long in the world for the world’s good.

original: 1. Aṭṭhakavaggo
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaggaḥ
translated: The Section on the Eight

original: 1. Kāmasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Sutta on Sensual Pleasures

original: Tattha kāmasuttaṃ ādi. Tasmimpi “kāmaṃ kāmayamānassā”ti gāthā ādi. Sā uddesaniddesapaṭiniddesavasena
analyzed: tattha kāma suttam ādi tasmin pi kāmam kāmayamānassa ati gāthā ādi sā uddesa niddesa paṭiniddesa vasena
translated: Herein, the sutta on sensual pleasures is the beginning. And in that sutta the verse ‘When one who lusts after sensual pleasures’ is the beginning. That is established in three ways, namely,🔽as recitation, as demonstration, and as counter-demonstration.

original: tidhā ṭhitā. “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassā”ti evamādi uddeso. “Kāmāti uddānato dve kāmā –
analyzed: tidhā ṭhitā kāmam kāmayamānassa ati evamādi uddeso kāmā ati uddānataḥ dve kāmā
translated: ‘When one who lusts after sensual pleasures’ is the recitation. ‘Sensual pleasures’ is the demonstration. ‘Two kinds of sensual pleasures are declared’ is the counter-demonstration. ‘

original: vatthukāmā ca kilesakāmā cā”ti niddeso. “Katame vatthukāmā? Manāpikā rūpā”ti evamādi paṭiniddeso.
analyzed: vatthu kāmā ca kilesa kāmā ca ati niddeso katame vatthu kāmā manāpikā rūpā ati evamādi paṭiniddeso
translated: and sensual desires as objects and sensual desires as defilements. “ What are sensual desires as objects? Agreeable visible objects” , etc., is the definition.

original: 1. Tattha kāmanti manāpiyarūpāditebhūmakadhammasaṅkhātaṃ vatthukāmaṃ. Kāmayamānassāti🔽icchamānassa. Tassa cetaṃ samijjhatīti tassa kāmayamānassa sattassa taṃ kāmasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: tattha kāmanti manāpiya rūpa ādi tebhūmaka dhamma saṅkhātam vatthu kāmam kāmayamānassa ati  icchamānassa tassa cetam samijjhati iti tassa kāmayamānassa sattassa tam kāma saṅkhātam
translated: Herein, sensual desires is sensual desires as objects, which are called “sensual desires” because they are desired .🔽One who desires : one who wishes.🔽If that succeeds : if that object called “sensual desire” succeeds for that being who desires it, if he gets it, is what is meant.

original: vatthu samijjhati ce, sace so taṃ labhatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Addhā pītimano hotīti ekaṃsaṃ
analyzed: vatthu samijjhati ce sace so tam labhati iti vuttam hoti addhā pīti manaḥ hoti iti ekaṃsam
translated: Surely he is pleased : he is satisfied on one side.🔽Having got : having obtained. A mortal : a being.

original: tuṭṭhacitto hoti. Laddhāti labhitvā. Maccoti satto. Yadicchatīti yaṃ icchati. Idaṃ🔽pana saṅkhepato padatthasambandhamattameva, vitthāro pana upari pāḷiyaṃ āgatanayeneva
analyzed: tuṭṭha cittaḥ hoti labhitvā satto yat icchati iti yam icchati idam  pana saṅkhepato padattha sambandha mattam eva vitthāraḥ pana upari āgata nayena iva
translated: Whatever he desires : whatever he wishes.🔽But this is only the mere connection of the words in brief. The detail should be understood in the way given in the text itself above.

original: veditabbo. Yathā ca imasmiṃ, evaṃ ito paraṃ sabbesupīti.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yathā ca imasmin evam itas param sabbesu pi iti
translated: And as in this sutta, so in all the rest.🔽Sensual desires is the term to be defined.

original: Kāmāti uddisitabbapadaṃ. Uddānatoti niddisitabbapadaṃ. Uddānatoti vaggavasena “macchuddānaṃ
analyzed: kāmā ati uddisitabba padam uddānataḥ iti niddisitabba padam uddānataḥ iti vagga vasena macchuddānam
translated: By the definition is the term to be defined by the definition. By the definition means by the chapter. “The definition of the fish

original: kineyyā”ti ādīsu viya. Atha vā uparūpari dānato uddānaṃ, uddhaṃ uddhaṃ sodhanato
analyzed: ādīsu atha vā upari upari dānataḥ uddānam uddham uddham sodhanataḥ
translated: and so on. Or else it is a summary because of giving successively,🔽like the word “purification” in the sense of cleansing successively,

original: byavadānaṭṭhena vodānaṃ viya. Vitthārakaraṇabhāvena vā. Kāmā iti pāṭhasesaṃ katvā
analyzed: byavadāna ṭṭhena vā udānam viya vitthāra karaṇa bhāvena vā kāmāḥ iti pāṭhasesam katvā
translated: or because of causing extension. Or else, taking the rest of the text as “kāme” ,

original: vattabbaṃ. Dveti gaṇanaparicchedo, na ekaṃ, na tayo. Vatthukāmā cāti manāpiyarūpādivatthukāmā🔽ca. Upatāpanaṭṭhena vibādhanaṭṭhena ca kilesakāmā ca. Tesu vatthukāmo pariññeyyo,
analyzed: vattabbam dve iti gaṇana paricchedaḥ na ekam na tayaḥ vatthu kāmā ca ati manāpiya rūpa ādi vatthu kāmā  ca upatāpana ṭhena vibādhana ṭṭhena ca kilesa kāmā ca tesu vatthu kāmo pariññeyyaḥ
translated: it should be said that “two” is the delimitation of number, not one, not three. “Objects of sensual desire” are sensual desires as objects consisting of agreeable visible forms, etc.🔽“Sensual desires as defilements” are sensual desires as the state of being harassed by defilements. Herein, sensual desires as objects are to be fully understood,

original: kilesakāmo pahātabbo. Tattha vatthukāmo kilesakāmena patthayitabboti kāmīyatīti kāmo.
analyzed: kilesa kāmo pahātabbo tattha vatthu kāmo kilesa kāmena patthayitabbaḥ iti kāmīyati iti kāmo
translated: sensual desires as defilements are to be abandoned. Herein, sensual desires as objects are to be desired by sensual desires as defilements, thus they are sensual desires .

original: Kilesakāmo vatthukāmānaṃ paccāsīsanassa kāraṇabhāvena kāmīyate anenāti kāmo. Tattha🔽rūpādikkhandhe saṅgahito vatthukāmo, saṅkhārakkhandhe saṅgahito kilesakāmo. Chahi
analyzed: kilesa kāmaḥ vatthu kāmānam paccāsīsanassa kāraṇa bhāvena kāmīyate anena ati kāmaḥ tattha  rūpa ādi kkhandhe saṅgahitaḥ vatthu kāmo saṅkhāra kkhandhe saṅgahitaḥ kilesa kāmo chahi
translated: Sensual desires as defilements are desired by sensual desires as objects because they are the cause of their occurrence, thus they are sensual desires . Herein,

original: viññāṇehi vijānitabbo vatthukāmo, manoviññāṇena jānitabbo kilesakāmo. Kilesānaṃ patiṭṭhaṭṭhena
analyzed: viññāṇehi vijānitabbaḥ vatthu kāmaḥ manaḥ viññāṇena jānitabbaḥ kilesa kāmaḥ kilesānam patiṭṭhaṭṭhena
translated: sensual desires as objects are included in the aggregates of form, etc., sensual desires as defilements are included in the formations aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of consciousness, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of mind-consciousness. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of contact, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of mind-contact. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of feeling, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the feeling aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of perception, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the perception aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of volition, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the volition aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of craving, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the craving aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of delight, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the delight aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of craving, sensual desires as defilements are to be known by means of the craving aggregate. Sensual desires as objects are to be known by means of the six kinds of

original: kāraṇaṭṭhena ārammaṇaṭṭhena ca vatthukāmo.
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭhena ārammaṇa ṭṭhena ca vatthu kāmo
translated: and sense desires as object in the sense of cause and in the sense of object.🔽“Not these things that are pretty in the world,

original: “Nete kāmā yāni citrāni loke, saṅkapparāgo purisassa kāmo;
analyzed: na ite kāmāḥ yāni citrāni loke saṅkappa rāgaḥ purisassa kāmo
translated: The man’s desire is lust for conceiving;🔽The pretty things remain as they are in the world,

original: Tiṭṭhanti citrāni tatheva loke, athettha dhīrā vinayanti chanda”nti. ;
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti citrāni tathā iva loke atha itthā dhīrāḥ vinayanti chandanti
translated: But the wise man here controls his will” .

original: Nandamāṇavaka- soreyyaseṭṭhiputtādīnaṃ vatthūni cettha nidassanaṃ. Kilesakāmo tāpanaṭṭhena🔽bādhanaṭṭhena ca sayaṃ kāmetīti kāmo. Vuttampi cetaṃ “ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena🔽abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi🔽cetetī”ti ca “ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi
analyzed: vatthūni ca ittha nidassanam tāpana ṭṭhena  bādhana ṭṭhena ca sayam kāmeti iti kāmaḥ vuttam pi brāhmaṇa rāgena  abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api  ceteti iti ca ratto kho brāhmaṇa pāṇampi hanati adinnampi ādiyati paradārampi
translated: And the stories of the young man Nanda, of Soreyya the merchant’s son, and so on, are a demonstration here. Sense desires as defilement are sense desires in the sense of burning and in the sense of afflicting.

original: gacchati, musāpi bhaṇatī”ti ca evamādi nidassanaṃ.
analyzed: gacchati musā api bhaṇati iti ca evamādi nidassanam
translated: He himself desires, thus he is a sense-desirer . And this is said: “Brahmin, one who is greedy, who is overpowered by greed, who is inflamed by greed, who is polluted by greed, who is mentally blocked by greed, intends for his own affliction, he intends for others’ affliction, he intends for the affliction of both, he intends for the harm of many, he intends for the sorrow of many, he intends for the loss, harm, and suffering of devas and humans” . And this is said: “Brahmin, one who is greedy, who is overpowered by greed, who is inflamed by greed, who is polluted by greed, who is mentally blocked by greed, kills living beings, takes what is not given, goes with others’ wives, speaks falsehood, and so on.

original: Tameva paṭiniddesavasena vitthāretvā vattukāmo – “katame vatthukāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: tam eva paṭiniddesa vasena vitthāretvā vattu kāmaḥ katame vatthu kāma ati ādim āha tattha
translated: He wishes to explain that same sense desire in detail by way of a reply to the question “What are sense desires as object?”

original: katameti kathetukamyatāpucchā. Pañcavidhā hi pucchā, tāsaṃ vibhāgo upari pāḷiyaṃyeva
analyzed: katamā iti kathā itu kamyatā pucchā pañcavidhā hi pucchā tāsam vibhāgaḥ upari
translated: What? is the question out of desire to tell. For there are five kinds of questions:🔽

original: āvi bhavissati. Tāsu ayaṃ kathetukamyatāpucchā. Tattha manāpikāti manaṃ appāyanti
analyzed: āvi bhavissati tāsu ayam kathā itu kamya tā pucchā tattha manāpikā ati manam appāyanti
translated: What? is a question asking for an explanation. For there are five kinds of questions: the question asking for a specific identification, the question asking for a classification, the question asking for an explanation, the question asking for an analysis, and the question asking for a verdict. The question here is one asking for an explanation. Herein, pleasing is what delights the mind.

original: vaddhentīti manāpā, manāpā eva manāpikā. Rūpāti kammacittautuāhārasamuṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: manāpā manāpā eva manāpikā
translated: It is pleasing because it delights the mind, or it is pleasing since it is the delighting of the mind.🔽Form is the four-originated form that has visible-data as its object.

original: catusamuṭṭhānikā rūpārammaṇā. Rūpayantīti rūpā, vaṇṇavikāraṃ āpajjamānā hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsentīti attho.
analyzed: catu samuṭṭhānikāḥ rūpa ārammaṇāḥ rūpayanti iti rūpāḥ vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjamānāḥ hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāsenti iti attho
translated: It is form since it is what is broken up. The meaning is that it is what manifests as the state of being in the heart by assuming a change of colour.

original: Tattha kenaṭṭhena rūpanti? Ruppanaṭṭhena. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tattha kena aṭṭhena rūpanti ruppana ṭṭhena vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Herein, in what sense is it form? In the sense of what is broken up. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Kiñca, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ vadetha? Ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā ‘rūpa’nti vuccati.
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave rūpam vadetha ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati
translated: “Bhikkhus, what is it that one calls form? It is that which is broken up by the body’s breakup.

original: Kena ruppati? Sītenapi ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppati, jighacchāyapi ruppati, pipāsāyapi
analyzed: kena ruppati sītena api ruppati uṇhena api ruppati jighacchāya api ruppati pipāsāya api
translated: By what is it broken up? It is broken up by cold, it is broken up by heat, it is broken up by hunger, it is broken up by thirst,

original: ruppati, ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassenapi ruppati. Ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: ruppati ḍaṃsa makasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassena api ruppati ruppati iti kho bhikkhave
translated: it is broken up by the touch of mosquitoes and flies and wind and sun and serpents. It is broken up, bhikkhus,

original: tasmā ‘rūpa’nti vuccatī”ti.🔽Tattha ruppatīti kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati, bhijjatīti attho. Sītena tāva ruppanaṃ
analyzed: tasmāt vuccati iti  tattha ruppati iti kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati bhijjati iti attho sītena tāva ruppanam
translated: so it is called materiality.

original: lokantarikaniraye pākaṭaṃ. Mahiṃsakaraṭṭhādīsupi himapātasītalesu padesesu etaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: lokantarika niraye pākaṭam mahiṃsa karaṭṭha ādīsu pi hima pāta sītalesu padesesu etam pākaṭam eva
translated: Herein, it breaks up, thus it is materiality : the meaning is that it is broken up, shattered, destroyed, split. The breaking up by cold is evident in the World of the Gods in the Cold-weather Hell. And it is evident in such places as the Himalayas, etc., where it rains cold hail.

original: Tattha hi sattā sītena bhinnachinnasarīrā jīvitakkhayampi pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: tattha hi sattā sītena bhinna chinna sarīrā jīvita kkhayam pi pāpuṇanti
translated: For there beings die from the breaking up of their bodies.

original: Uṇhena ruppanaṃ avīcimahāniraye pākaṭaṃ. Tattha hi tattāya lohapathaviyā nipajjāpetvā pañcavidhabandhanādikaraṇakāle sattā mahādukkhaṃ anubhavanti.
analyzed: uṇhena ruppanam avīcimahāniraye pākaṭam tattha hi tattāya loha pathaviyā nipajjāpetvā pañcavidha bandhana ādi karaṇa kāle sattāḥ mahā dukkham anubhavanti
translated: The breaking up by heat is evident in the Avīci Hell. For there, when they are made to lie on a heated surface of iron and so on and are bound with the fivefold strap, etc., beings experience great suffering.

original: Jighacchāya ruppanaṃ pettivisaye ceva dubbhikkhakāle ca pākaṭaṃ. Pettivisayasmiñhi🔽sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni kiñcideva āmisaṃ hatthena gahetvā mukhe pakkhipantā
analyzed: jighacchāya ruppanam petti visaye ca iva dubbhikkha kāle ca pākaṭam petti visayasmin hi  sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni kiñcid eva āmisam hatthena gahetvā mukhe pakkhipantā
translated: The breaking up by hunger is evident in the Ghost Realm and in times of famine. For in the Ghost Realm

original: nāma na honti, antoudaraṃ ādittasusirarukkho viya hoti. Dubbhikkhe kañjikamattampi
analyzed: nāma na honti antoudaram āditta susira rukkho viya hoti dubbhikkhe kañjika mattam pi
translated: beings do not get even the smell of ordure or urine for two or three decades, and their bodies are like charred logs. In times of famine

original: alabhitvā maraṇasattānaṃ pamāṇaṃ natthi.🔽Pipāsāya ruppanaṃ kālakañjikādīsu pākaṭaṃ. Tattha hi sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni
analyzed: a labhitvā maraṇa sattānam pamāṇam natthi  pipāsāya ruppanam kālakañjika ādīsu pākaṭam tattha hi sattā dve tīṇi buddhantarāni
translated: There is no limit to the number of beings who die of thirst.

original: hadayatemanamattaṃ vā jivhātemanamattaṃ vā udakabindumpi laddhuṃ na sakkonti. “Pānīyaṃ🔽pivissāmā”ti nadiṃ gatānaṃ jalaṃ vālukātalaṃ sampajjati. Mahāsamuddaṃ pakkhantānampi
analyzed: hadaya temana mattam vā jivhā temana mattam vā udaka bindum pi laddhum na sakkonti pānīyam  pivissāma iti nadim gatānam jalam vālukā talam sampajjati mahā samuddam pakkhantānam pi
translated: The torment of thirst is evident in the case of the Kālakañja and other hells. For there the beings are unable to get even a drop of water to drink for two or three Buddha-intervals,🔽and when they go to the river, the water turns to embers and cinders.🔽When they enter the ocean, the ocean becomes a sandy desert.

original: samuddo piṭṭhipāsāṇoyeva hoti. Te sussantā balavadukkhapīḷitā viravanti. Ḍaṃsādīhi🔽ruppanaṃ ḍaṃsamakkhikādibahulesu padesesu pākaṭaṃ. Taṃ pana – “katamaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: samuddaḥ piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ yā iva hoti te sussantāḥ balava dukkha pīḍitāḥ viravanti ḍaṃsa ādīhi  ruppanam ḍaṃsa makkhikā ādi bahulesu padesesu pākaṭam tam pana katamam tam rūpam
translated: They die of thirst, tormented by the most terrible suffering, and they cry out.🔽The torment of being devoured is evident in the places where flies, mosquitoes, etc., abound.

original: sanidassanaṃ? Sappaṭigha”nti ādinā nayena abhidhamme vitthāritameva.
analyzed: ādinā nayena abhidhamme vitthāritam eva
translated: But this is explained in the Abhidhamma in the way beginning, “What is visible object that is visible? That which is impinge-able” .

original: Sappantīti saddā, udāharīyantīti attho. Utucittavasena dvisamuṭṭhānikā saddā. Gandhayantīti
analyzed: sappanti iti saddāḥ udāharīyanti iti attho utu citta vasena dvi samuṭṭhānikā saddāḥ gandhayanti iti
translated: Sounds are what sound out, i.e. what make a noise. They are of two kinds as originative cause, according as they originate from temperature or from consciousness. Smells are what are smelt.

original: gandhā, attano vatthūni sūcayantīti attho. Rasanti te sattāti rasā, assādentīti attho.
analyzed: gandhāḥ attanaḥ vatthūni sūcayanti iti atthaḥ rasanti te sattā ati rasāḥ assādenti iti atthaḥ
translated: Flavours are so called because they are savoured by the beings, that is, because they are enjoyed.

original: Phusīyantīti phoṭṭhabbā. Ete gandhādayo catusamuṭṭhānikāva. Tesaṃ vibhāgo abhidhamme vitthāritoyeva.
analyzed: phusīyanti iti phoṭṭhabbāḥ ete gandha ādayo catu samuṭṭhānikāḥ va tesam vibhāgaḥ abhidhamme
translated: Tangibles are so called because they are touched. These smells, etc., are of fourfold origin. Their analysis is given in the Abhidhamma.

original: Tamevatthaṃ vitthāravasena dassento “attharaṇā pāvuraṇā”tiādimāha. Tattha attharitvā
analyzed: tam eva attham vitthāra vasena dassentaḥ attharaṇā pāvuraṇā iti ādim āha tattha attharitvā
translated: In order to show that same matter in detail, he says, “bed, bedding, couch, chair, ” etc. Herein, they are spread out and then

original: nipajjiyantīti attharaṇā. Sarīraṃ veṭhetvā pārupīyantīti pāvuraṇā. Antojātādayo cattāro
analyzed: nipajjiyanti iti attharaṇā sarīram veṭhetvā pārupīyanti iti pāvuraṇāḥ antojāta ādayo cattāro
translated: slept on, thus they are bed and bedding. They are worn by covering the body, thus they are clothes. The four beginning with the slave born in the house,

original: dāsī ca dāso ca dāsidāsā. Khettaṃ nāma yasmiṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ ruhati. Vatthu nāma yasmiṃ🔽aparaṇṇaṃ ruhati. Yattha vā ubhayampi ruhati, taṃ khettaṃ. Tadatthāya katabhūmibhāgo
analyzed: dāsī ca dāso ca dāsi dāsā khettam nāma yasmim pubbaṇṇam ruhati vatthu nāma yasmim  aparaṇṇam ruhati yattha vai ubhayam pi ruhati tam khettam kata bhūmi bhāgaḥ
translated: and the slave and slave woman are the slave class. Land is that on which crops grow. Building is that on which crops do not grow.

original: vatthu. Khettavatthusīsena cettha vāpītaḷākādīnipi saṅgahitāni. Hiraññanti kahāpaṇo.
analyzed: vatthu khetta vatthu sīsena ca ittha vāpī taḷāka ādīni pi saṅgahitāni hiraññanti kahāpaṇo
translated: Or it is land on which both grow. The land and the building are the land and building class. Herein, the tanks, ponds, etc., are included under the land and building class by way of land and building. Gold is a kahāpaṇa coin.

original: Suvaṇṇanti jātarūpaṃ. Tesaṃ gahaṇena lohamāsako jatumāsako dārumāsakoti sabbepi saṅgahaṃ🔽gacchanti. Gāmanigamarājadhāniyoti ekakuṭikādi gāmo. Āpaṇayutto nigamo. Ekassa rañño🔽āṇāpavattiṭṭhānaṃ rājadhānī. Raṭṭhanti janapadekadesaṃ. Janapadoti kāsikosalādijanapado.🔽Kosoti catubbidho koso – hatthī asso ratho patti. Koṭṭhāgāranti tividhaṃ koṭṭhāgāraṃ
analyzed: suvaṇṇam ti jātarūpam tesam gahaṇena loha māsakaḥ jatu māsakaḥ dāru māsakaḥ iti sabbe pi saṅgaham  gacchanti gāma nigama rājadhāniyaḥ ti eka kuṭikā ādi gāmaḥ āpaṇa yuttaḥ nigamaḥ ekassa rañño  āṇāpa vatti ṭṭhānam rājadhānī raṭṭhanti janapada eka desam janapadaḥ iti kāsi kosala ādi janapadaḥ  kosaḥ ti catubbidhaḥ kosaḥ hatthī assaḥ rathaḥ patti koṭṭhāgāranti tividham koṭṭhāgāram
translated: “Gold” is refined gold. By this term all are included, such as iron coins, copper coins, wooden coins. “Villages, towns, and capital cities”: a village is a collection of houses, etc. A town is a market town. A capital city is the place where the king’s orders are carried out. “Country” is a district. “Region” is a country such as Kāsi, Kosala, etc. “Treasury” is a fourfold treasury: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry. “Granary” is a threefold granary:

original: – dhanakoṭṭhāgāraṃ dhaññakoṭṭhāgāraṃ vatthakoṭṭhāgāraṃ. Yaṃ kiñcīti anavasesapariyādānavacanaṃ.🔽Rajanīyanti rañjetuṃ yuttaṭṭhena.🔽Ito paraṃ tikavasena dassetuṃ atītattikaajjhattattikahīnattikaokāsattikasaṃyogattikakāmāvacarattikavasena
analyzed: dhana koṭṭhāgāram dhañña koṭṭhāgāram vattha koṭṭhāgāram yam kiñci iti anavasesa pariyādāna vacanam  rañjetum  itas param tika vasena dassetum atīta ttika ajjhatta ttika hīna ttika okāsa ttika saṃyoga ttika kāmāvacara ttika vasena
translated: “Gold” is refined gold. By the inclusion of these, all are included, namely, iron coins, copper coins, wooden coins. “A village, a town, a city” : a village is a collection of houses, etc., a town is a market place, a city is a capital city where a king’s power prevails. “A country” is a district of the people. “A province” is a province such as Kāsi, Kosala, etc. “A treasure” is a treasure of four kinds: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry. “A storehouse” is a storehouse of three kinds: a storehouse of wealth, a storehouse of grain, and a storehouse of timber. “Whatever” is a word expressing the absence of remainder. “Delightful” is in the sense of being fit to delight.

original: chattike āha. Tattha atītattike tāva attano sabhāvaṃ uppādādikkhaṇaṃ vā patvā atikkantāti
analyzed: chattike āha tattha atīta ttike tāva attano sabhāvam uppāda ādi khaṇam vā patvā atikkantā ati
translated: From here on, in order to show the sixty-four kinds of lust, he says “past, internal, deficient, opportunity, combination, sense-desire” . Herein, in the first tetrad, “past” means having gone beyond one’s own nature or the moment of arising, etc.

original: atītā. Tadubhayampi na āgatāti anāgatā. Taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicca uppannāti paccuppannā.🔽Idaṃ bhavena paricchannaṃ. Paṭisandhito hi paṭṭhāya atītabhavesu nibbattā anantarabhave🔽vā nibbattā hontu kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake vā, sabbe atītāyeva nāma. Cutito paṭṭhāya🔽anāgatabhavesu nibbattanakā kāmā anantarabhave vā nibbattantu kappakoṭisatasahassamatthake
analyzed: atītā tat ubhayam pi na āgatā ati anāgatā tam tam kāraṇam paṭicca uppannā ati paccuppannā  idam bhavena paricchannam paṭisandhitaḥ hi paṭṭhāya atīta bhavesu nibbattā anantara bhave  vā nibbattāḥ hontu kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake vā sabbe atītāya iva nāma cutitaḥ paṭṭhāya  anāgata bhavesu nibbattanakā kāmāḥ anantara bhave vā nibbattantu kappa koṭi sata sahassa matthake
translated: and those that have already occurred in the past are past. And those that have not yet occurred in the future are future. And those that are occurring now, having arisen in dependence on such and such a cause, are present.

original: vā, sabbe anāgatāyeva nāma. Cutipaṭisandhiantare pavattā kāmā paccuppannā nāma.🔽Ajjhattattike “evaṃ pavattamānā mayaṃ attāti gahaṇaṃ gamissāmā”ti iminā viya adhippāyena
analyzed: vā sabbe anāgatāya iva nāma cuti paṭisandhi antare pavattā kāmā paccuppannā nāma  ajjhatta ttike evam pavattamānāḥ mayam attā ati gahaṇam gamissāma ati iminā viya adhippāyena
translated: This is the delimitation by means of becoming. For all those that have arisen in past existences since the beginning of the round of rebirths, whether they arose in the next existence or a hundred thousand million times a hundred thousand myriad aeons ago, are called past. And all those that will arise in future existences, whether they will arise in the next existence or a hundred thousand million times a hundred thousand myriad aeons hence, are called future. And those that arise between death and rebirth-linking are called present.🔽In the internal dyad, those that occur in one’s own continuity, occurring with reference to oneself, with the intention, as it were, “Thus we will become the object of the conception of self,” are called internal.

original: attānaṃ adhikāraṃ katvā pavattā attano santāne pavattā pāṭipuggalikā kāmā ajjhattā🔽kāmā nāma. Tato bahibhūtā pana indriyabaddhā vā anindriyabaddhā vā bahiddhā nāma.
analyzed: attānam adhikāram katvā pavattā attanaḥ santāne pavattā pāṭipuggalikā kāmā ajjhattā 🔽kāmāḥ nāma tatas bahibhūtā pana indriya baddhāḥ vā an indriya baddhāḥ vā bahiddhāḥ nāma
translated: Those that are external to that are called external.

original: Tatiyapadaṃ tadubhayavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya padam tad ubhaya vasena vuttam
translated: The third term is stated in order to include both.

original: Hīnattike hīnāti lāmakā. Majjhimāti hīnapaṇītānaṃ majjhe bhavāti majjhimā. Avasesā🔽uttamaṭṭhena paṇītā. Api ca upādāyupādāya hīnamajjhimapaṇītatā veditabbā. Nerayikānañhi
analyzed: hīna ttike hīnā ati lāmakā majjhimā ati hīna paṇītānam majjhe majjhimā avasesā  uttama ṭṭhena paṇītāḥ api ca upādāya upādāya hīna majjhima paṇīta tā veditabbā nerayikānam hi
translated: In the case of the three kinds of sensual desires classed as inferior, etc., the inferior are called “low” and “vulgar” . The medium are called “middling” in the sense of being in the middle between the inferior and the superior. The remaining

original: kāmā koṭippattā hīnā nāma. Te upādāya tiracchānesu nāgasupaṇṇānaṃ kāmā paṇītā nāma.🔽Sesatiracchānagatānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi kāmā hīnā. Te upādāya mahesakkhapetānaṃ🔽kāmā paṇītā nāma. Avasesānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi hīnā. Te upādāya jānapadānaṃ🔽kāmā paṇītā nāma. Paccantavāsīnaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi hīnā. Te upādāya gāmabhojakānaṃ
analyzed: kāmā koṭippattāḥ hīnāḥ nāma te upādāya tiracchānesu nāga supaṇṇānam kāmā paṇītā nāma  sesa tiracchāna gatānam kāmāḥ majjhimāḥ nāma tesam pi kāmāḥ hīnā te upādāya mahesakkha petānam  kāmā paṇītā nāma avasesānam kāmā majjhimā nāma tesam pi hīnā te upādāya jānapadānaṃ  kāmā paṇītā nāma paccantavāsīnam kāmā majjhimā nāma tesam pi hīnā te upādāya gāmabhojakānam
translated: are called “superior” in the sense of being the best. Moreover, the inferior, medium, and superior should be understood according to the following method. The sensual desires of the denizens of hell are called “inferior” in the sense of being the lowest. Compared with them, the sensual desires of animals are called “superior.”🔽The sensual desires of the remaining animals are called “medium.” Compared with them, the sensual desires of the powerful spirits are called “superior.” The sensual desires of the remaining spirits are called “medium.” Compared with them, the sensual desires of the people of Jambudīpa are called “superior.”

original: kāmā paṇītā nāma. Tesaṃ paricārikānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi hīnā. Te upādāya
analyzed: kāmā paṇītā nāma tesam paricārikānam kāmā majjhimā nāma tesam pi hīnā te upādāya
translated: The sensual desires of the people of the border countries are called “medium.” Compared with them, the sensual desires of the village overseers are called “superior.” The sensual desires of the village overseers’ wives are called “medium.” Compared with them, the sensual desires of the village overseers themselves are called “superior.”

original: janapadasāmikānaṃ kāmā paṇītā nāma. Tesaṃ paricārikānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi🔽hīnā. Te upādāya padesarājūnaṃ kāmā paṇītā nāma. Tesaṃ amaccānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma.
analyzed: janapada sāmikānam kāmā paṇītāḥ nāma tesam paricārikānam kāmāḥ majjhimāḥ nāma tesam pi  te upādāya padesa rājūnam kāmā paṇītā nāma tesam amaccānam kāmā majjhimā nāma
translated: The sensual desires of the kings of the provinces are called “excellent” in comparison with those of their attendants. Those of the latter are called “middling” in comparison with those of the kings.🔽Those of the latter are called “inferior” in comparison with those of the local kings. The sensual desires of the wheel-turning monarchs are called “excellent” in comparison with those of the local kings. Those of the latter’s ministers are called “middling” in comparison with those of the wheel-turning monarch.

original: Tesampi hīnā. Te upādāya cakkavattirañño kāmā paṇītā nāma. Tassa amaccānaṃ kāmā majjhimā🔽nāma. Tassapi hīnā. Te upādāya bhummadevānaṃ kāmā paṇītā nāma. Tesaṃ paricārikānaṃ
analyzed: tesam pi hīnā te upādāya cakkavatti raññaḥ kāmā paṇītā nāma tassa amaccānam kāmā majjhimā  nāma tassa api hīnā te upādāya bhummadevānam kāmā paṇītā nāma tesam paricārikānam
