translated: Those of the latter are called “inferior” in comparison with those of the earth gods. The sensual desires of the earth gods are called “excellent” in comparison with those of the gods’ attendants.🔽Those of the latter are called “middling” in comparison with those of the gods of the Four Kings’ Heaven.

original: devānaṃ kāmā majjhimā nāma. Tesampi hīnā. Te upādāya cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ kāmā🔽paṇītātiādinā nayena yāva akaniṭṭhadevānaṃ kāmā matthakappattā paṇītā nāma. Evaṃ
analyzed: devānam kāmāḥ majjhimāḥ nāma tesam pi hīnā te upādāya cātumahārājikānam devānam kāmāḥ  paṇītā iti ādinā nayena yāva akaniṭṭha devānam kāmā matthaka ppattā paṇītā nāma evam
translated: Those of the latter are called “inferior” in comparison with those of the gods of the Thirty-three. The sensual desires of the gods of the Thirty-three are called “excellent” in comparison with those of the gods of the Four Kings’ Heaven.

original: upādāyupādāya hīnamajjhimapaṇītatā veditabbā.
analyzed: upādāya upādāya hīna majjhima paṇīta tā veditabbā
translated: In this way, by successive comparison, the sensual desires of the gods of the Akaniṭṭha realm are called “excellent” and reach the peak. This is how the inferior, middling, and excellent should be understood.

original: Okāsattike āpāyikā kāmāti avaḍḍhisaṅkhātesu apagataayesu catūsu apāyesu nibbattakāmā āpāyikā. Manussesu nibbattakāmā mānusikā. Devesu nibbattakāmā dibbā.
analyzed: okāsattike āpāyikā kāmā ati avaḍḍhi saṅkhātesu apagata ayesu catūsu apāyesu nibbatta kāmā āpāyikā manussesu nibbatta kāmā mānusikā devesu nibbatta kāmā dibbā
translated: In the case of the kinds of sensual desires classed according to the place, those called “of the states of loss” are sensual desires to be born among the four states of loss called “without expectation of release.” Those called “of the human world” are sensual desires to be born among human beings. Those called “of the divine world” are sensual desires to be born among deities.

original: Saṃyogattike paccupaṭṭhitānaṃ kāmānaṃ paribhuñjanato ṭhapetvā nerayike sesaapāyasattānaṃ
analyzed: saṃyoga ttike paccupaṭṭhitānam kāmānam paribhuñjanataḥ ṭhapetvā nerayike sesa a pāyasa ttānam
translated: In the case of the kinds of sensual desires classed according to the mode of experience, those called “experienced in common” are the sensual desires experienced by the beings in the states of loss other than those in hell,

original: manussānaṃ cātumahārājike deve upādāya yāva tusitakāyikānañca devānaṃ kāmā paccupaṭṭhitā🔽kāmā nāma. Pakatipaṭiyattārammaṇato atirekena ramitukāmatākāle yathārucitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ🔽nimminitvā nimminitvā ramantīti nimmānaratīnaṃ devānaṃ kāmā nimmitā kāmā nāma. Attano🔽ajjhāsayaṃ ñatvā parehi nimmite ārammaṇe sevantīti paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ kāmā paranimmitā
analyzed: manussānam cātumahārājike deve upādāya yāva tusitakāyikānam ca devānam kāmā paccupaṭṭhitā  kāmāḥ nāma pakati paṭiyatta ārammaṇataḥ atirekena ramitu kāma tā kāle yathārucitam ārammaṇam  nimminitvā nimminitvā ramanti iti nimmāna ratīnam devānam kāmāḥ nimmitā kāmāḥ nāma attanaḥ  ajjhāsayam ñatvā parehi nimmite ārammaṇe sevanti iti para nimmita vasa vattīnam kāmā para nimmitā
translated: and by human beings, and by the deities of the four divine worldly realms up to the Tusita realm.🔽Those called “experienced in creation” are the sensual desires of the deities of the creation realm who, when the time comes for them to enjoy themselves with a special object of sensual desire, create an object of sensual desire as they wish and enjoy themselves with that.

original: kāmā nāma. Pariggahitāti “mayhaṃ eta”nti gahitā kāmā. Apariggahitāti tathā apariggahitā
analyzed: kāmā nāma pariggahitā ati mayham etat ti gahitā kāmā a pariggahitā ati tathā a pariggahitā
translated: Those called “experienced in the creation of others” are the sensual desires of the deities who control the creation of others, who enjoy themselves with objects of sensual desire created by others after they have discerned their own intentions.

original: uttarakurukānaṃ kāmā. Mamāyitāti taṇhāvasena “mama eta”nti gahitā. Amamāyitāti vuttapaṭipakkhā.
analyzed: uttarakurukānam kāmā mamāyitā ati taṇhā vasena mama etat ti gahitā amamāyitā ati vutta paṭipakkhā
translated: Sensual desires of the Uttarakurus. “Mine” : taken as “mine” by way of craving. “Not mine” : the opposite of what was stated.

original: Sabbepi kāmāvacarā dhammāti “heṭṭhato avīcinirayaṃ pariyantaṃ karitvā”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: sabbe api kāmāvacarā dhammā ati heṭṭhatas avīcinirayam pariyantam karitvā iti ādinā nayena
translated: All states belonging to the sensual-desire realm : the states belonging to the sensual-desire realm stated in the way beginning, “Below, down to Avici Hell” .

original: vuttesu kāmāvacaradhammesu pariyāpannā. Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – uddānato dve kāmā,🔽vatthukāmo ca kilesakāmo cāti. Tattha kilesakāmo atthato chandarāgo. Vatthukāmo tebhūmakaṃ
analyzed: vuttesu kāmāvacara dhammesu pariyāpannā tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ uddānataḥ dve kāmā  vatthu kāmo ca kilesa kāmo ca ati tattha kilesa kāmaḥ atthatas chanda rāgaḥ vatthu kāmo tebhūmakam
translated: Here is the word-meaning: in the summary there are two kinds of sensual desires,🔽the sensual desire as object and the sensual desire as defilement. Herein, the sensual desire as defilement is, in fact, will and lust. The sensual desire as object is the round of existence in the three planes.

original: vaṭṭaṃ. Kilesakāmo cettha kāmetīti kāmo. Itaro kāmīyatīti. Yasmiṃ pana padese duvidhopeso
analyzed: vaṭṭam kilesa kāmo ca ittha kāmeti iti kāmo itaro kāmīyati iti yasmin pana padese duvidha upeso
translated: Herein, the sensual desire as defilement is called “sensual desire” because it desires . The other is called “sensual desire” because it is desirable .

original: kāmo pavattivasena avacarati, so catunnaṃ apāyānaṃ manussānaṃ channañca devalokānaṃ🔽vasena ekādasavidho padeso kāmo ettha avacaratīti kāmāvacaro. Tattha pariyāpannadhamme
analyzed: kāmo pavatti vasena avacarati so catunnam apāyānam manussānam channam ca deva lokānam  vasena ekādasavidhaḥ padesaḥ kāmaḥ ettha avacarati iti kāmāvacaro tattha pariyāpanna dhamme
translated: But the place where the twofold sensual desire occurs is the elevenfold place consisting of the four lower worlds, the human world, and the six divine worlds of the sensual sphere.

original: sandhāya “sabbepi kāmāvacarā dhammā”ti vuttaṃ. Attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhammā.
analyzed: sandhāya sabbe pi kāmāvacarā dhammā ti vuttam attanaḥ sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhammā
translated: Sensual desire occurs here, thus it is the sensual desire realm . The states included there are referred to by the words “all states belonging to the sensual-desire realm.” They bear their own individual essences , thus they are states .

original: Rūpāvacarā dhammāti “heṭṭhato brahmalokaṃ pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito akaniṭṭhe deve🔽antokaritvā”tiādinā nayena vuttānaṃ rūpāvacaradhammānaṃ vasena sabbepi dhammā rūpāvacarā.🔽Arūpāvacarā dhammāti “heṭṭhato ākāsānañcāyatanupage deve pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito
analyzed: rūpāvacarāḥ dhammā ati heṭṭhatas brahma lokam pariyantam karitvā uparitas akaniṭṭhe deve  antokaritvā ati ādinā nayena vuttānam rūpāvacara dhammānam vasena sabbe pi dhammāḥ rūpāvacarā  arūpāvacarāḥ dhammā ati heṭṭhatas ākāsa anañca āyatana upage deve pariyantam karitvā uparitas
translated: “Fine-material-sphere dhammas” are all dhammas in the sense of the fine-material-sphere dhammas stated in the way beginning, “Having made the Brahmā-world the limit, above the earth gods” .

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanupage deve antokaritvā”tiādinā nayena vuttā sabbepi arūpāvacarā
analyzed: deve antokaritvā ati ādinā nayena vuttā sabbe pi arūpāvacarā
translated: “Non-fine-material-sphere dhammas” are all dhammas in the sense of the non-fine-material-sphere dhammas stated in the way beginning, “Having made the base consisting of boundless space the limit, above the gods of the base consisting of boundless space” .

original: dhammā. Tattha rūpe avacarantīti rūpāvacarā. Arūpe avacarantīti arūpāvacarā. Taṇhāvatthukāti🔽patiṭṭhaṭṭhena kāraṇaṭṭhena ca taṇhāya vatthubhūtā. Taṇhārammaṇāti taṇhāpavattivasena
analyzed: dhammā tattha rūpe avacaranti iti rūpa avacarāḥ arūpe avacaranti iti arūpa avacarā taṇhā vatthukā ati  patiṭṭha ṭṭhena kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca taṇhāya vatthu bhūtā taṇhā ārammaṇā ti taṇhā apavatti vasena
translated: Herein, they are fine-material-sphere dhammas because they occur in the fine-material sphere. They are non-fine-material-sphere dhammas because they do not occur in the fine-material sphere.🔽They are “objects of craving” in the sense of a footing and in the sense of a cause for craving.🔽They are “objects of craving” in the sense of being objects of craving’s occurrence.🔽They are “desirable” in the sense of being worth choosing.

original: taṇhāya ārammaṇabhūtā. Kāmanīyaṭṭhenāti paccāsīsitabbaṭṭhena. Rajanīyaṭṭhenāti rañjetuṃ
analyzed: taṇhāyaḥ ārammaṇa bhūtā kāmanīya ṭṭhena ati paccāsīsitabba ṭṭhena rajanīya ṭṭhena ati rañjetum
translated: They are “lovely” in the sense of being worth enjoying.

original: yuttaṭṭhena. Madanīyaṭṭhenāti kulamadādimadaṃ uppādanīyaṭṭhena.
analyzed: yutta ṭṭhena madanīya ṭṭhena ati kula mada ādi madam uppādanīya ṭṭhena
translated: They are “intoxicating” in the sense of being worth intoxicating with the intoxication of clans and so on.

original: Tattha “katame vatthukāmā? Manāpikā rūpā”tiādiṃ katvā “yaṃ kiñci rajanīyaṃ vatthū”ti pariyosānaṃ saviññāṇakaaviññāṇakavasena vuttaṃ. Avasesaṃ ekacatukkādikachattikanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha katame vatthu kāmāḥ manāpikāḥ rūpa ati ādim katvā yam kiñci rajanīyam vatthu uti pariyosānam saviññāṇaka aviññāṇaka vasena vuttam avasesam eka catukka ādika chattikam ti veditabbam
translated: Herein, the first section beginning thus: “What are the kinds of sensual desires as objects? Agreeable visible objects” and ending thus: “Any kind of object that is desirable” refers to the kinds of sensual desires as objects that are associated with consciousness and dissociated from consciousness respectively. The rest should be understood as the three dyads beginning with the dyad of sensual desires as defilements.

original: Evaṃ vatthukāmaṃ dassetvā kilesakāmaṃ dassetuṃ “katame kilesakāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: evam vatthu kāmam dassetvā kilesa kāmam dassetum katame kilesa kāmā ti ādim āha tattha
translated: Having thus shown the kinds of sensual desires as objects, the Exalted One said, “What are the kinds of sensual desires as defilements?” in order to show the kinds of sensual desires as defilements. Herein,

original: chandoti dubbalarāgo. Rāgoti tato balavataro. Upari tayopi rāgā imehi balavatarā.
analyzed: chanda uti dubbala rāgaḥ upari tayo api rāgāḥ imehi balavatarā
translated: longing is weak passion. Passion is stronger than that. The three above are stronger than these.

original: Kāmesūti pañcasu kāmaguṇesu. Kāmacchandoti kāmasaṅkhāto chando, na kattukamyatāchando,
analyzed: kāmesu iti pañcasu kāma guṇesu kāma chandaḥ iti kāma saṅkhātaḥ chandaḥ na kattu kamyatā chandaḥ
translated: In the sense pleasures: in the five strands of sense pleasure. Sensual longing is longing called sensual, not longing to do,

original: na dhammacchando. Kāmanavasena rajjanavasena ca kāmoyeva rāgo kāmarāgo. Kāmanavasena
analyzed: na dhammacchando kāmana vasena rajjana vasena ca rāgo kāma rāgo kāmana vasena
translated: not longing for the Dhamma. Sensual desire is just desire by way of sensual desire and by way of passion. Sensual delight is just delight by way of sensual desire

original: nandanavasena ca kāmoyeva nandī kāmanandī. Evaṃ sabbattha kāmatthaṃ viditvā taṇhāyanaṭṭhena
analyzed: nandana vasena ca nandī kāma nandī evam sabbattha kāmattham viditvā taṇhāyana ṭṭhena
translated: and by way of delight. Having thus known the meaning of sensual desire in all these cases, sensual craving is in the sense of being a path of craving.

original: kāmataṇhā. Sinehanaṭṭhena kāmasneho. Pariḍayhanaṭṭhena kāmapariḷāho. Mucchanaṭṭhena
analyzed: kāma taṇhā sinehana ṭṭhena kāma snehaḥ pariḍayhana ṭṭhena kāma pariḷāhaḥ mucchana ṭṭhena
translated: Sensual affection is in the sense of being a bond. Sensual fever is in the sense of burning. Sensual agitation is in the sense of distraction.

original: kāmamucchā. Gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpanaṭṭhena kāmajjhosānaṃ. Vaṭṭasmiṃ oghehi osīdāpetīti
analyzed: kāma mucchā gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpana ṭṭhena kāma ajjhosānam vaṭṭasmim oghehi osīdāpeti iti
translated: and the ‘desire’ is the desire for sensual-desire indulgence.🔽The ‘flood of sensual desire’ is that which causes one to sink in the round of rebirths by the floods.

original: kāmogho. Vaṭṭasmiṃ yojetīti kāmayogo. Daḷhavasena taṇhādiṭṭhiggahaṇaṃ upādānaṃ. Cittaṃ
analyzed: kāma oghaḥ vaṭṭasmim yojeti iti kāma yogaḥ daḷha vasena taṇhā diṭṭhi ggahaṇam upādānam cittam
translated: The ‘bond of sensual desire’ is that which binds one to the round of rebirths. The ‘clinging’ is the grasping of craving and views by the firm mode. The ‘hindrance’ is that which hinders the mind

original: nīvarati pariyonandhatīti nīvaraṇaṃ.🔽Addasanti addakkhiṃ. Kāmāti ālapanaṃ. Teti tava. Mūlanti patiṭṭhaṃ. Saṅkappāti parikappena. Na taṃ saṅkappayissāmīti taṃ parikappanaṃ na karissāmi. Na hohisīti na bhavissasi.
analyzed: nīvarati pariyonandhati iti nīvaraṇam  addasanti kāma ati ālapanam te iti tava mūlam ti patiṭṭham saṅkappa ati parikappena na tam saṅkappayissāmi iti tam parikappanam na karissāmi na hohisi iti na bhavissasi
translated: and obscures it.🔽‘I saw’: I saw. ‘Sensual desire’: an address. ‘Your’: yours. ‘Root’: support. ‘Thought’: by way of conjecture. ‘I shall not think that’: I shall not make that conjecture. ‘You will not be’: you will not exist.

original: Icchamānassāti paccāsīsantassa. Sādiyamānassāti assādiyamānassa. Patthayamānassāti
analyzed: icchamānassa ati paccāsīsantassa sādiyamānassa ati assādiyamānassa patthayamānassa ati
translated: ‘If you should wish’: if you should long for. ‘If you should enjoy’: if you should delight in. ‘If you should hope’:

original: patthanaṃ uppādentassa. Pihayamānassāti pāpuṇituṃ icchaṃ uppādentassa. Abhijappamānassāti
analyzed: patthanam uppādentassa pihayamānassa ati pāpuṇitum iccham uppādentassa abhijappamānassa ati
translated: if you should arouse hope. ‘If you should yearn’: if you should arouse a wish to attain. ‘If you should long’:🔽if you should arouse a wish to attain. ‘If you should expect’:

original: taṇhāvasena tittiṃ uppādentassa. Atha vā abhivadantassa.
analyzed: taṇhā vasena tittim uppādentassa atha vā abhivadantassa
translated: if you should arouse satisfaction by way of craving. Or else, if you should greet.

original: Khattiyassa vātiādi catujjātivasena vuttaṃ. Gahaṭṭhassa vā pabbajitassa vāti liṅgavasena
analyzed: khattiyassa vā iti ādi catur jāti vasena vuttam gahaṭṭhassa vā pabbajitassa vā iti liṅga vasena
translated: Khattiya, etc., is said according to the four castes. Householder or one gone forth is said according to the sex.

original: vuttaṃ. Devassa vā manussassa vāti upapattivasena vuttaṃ. Ijjhatīti nipphajjati.🔽Samijjhatīti sammā nipphajjati. Ijjhati visesarūpapaṭilābhavasena. Labhati dassanīyarūpapaṭilābhavasena.
analyzed: vuttam devassa vā manussassa vā ati upapatti vasena vuttam ijjhati iti nipphajjati  samijjhati iti sammā nipphajjati ijjhati visesa rūpa paṭilābha vasena labhati dassanīya rūpa paṭilābha vasena
translated: God or human is said according to the rebirth. Succeeds is produced.🔽Is successful is produced rightly. Succeeds by the acquisition of the form of distinction. Is gained by the acquisition of the form of beauty.

original: Paṭilabhati pasādanīyarūpapaṭilābhavasena. Adhigacchati saṇṭhānarūpapaṭilābhavasena.
analyzed: paṭilabhati pasādanīya rūpa paṭilābha vasena adhigacchati saṇṭhāna rūpa paṭilābha vasena
translated: Is obtained by the acquisition of the form of confidence. Is reached by the acquisition of the form of shape.

original: Vindati chavippasādarūpapaṭilābhavasena. Atha vā puññamahattena ijjhati. Jātimahattena
analyzed: vindati chavi ppasāda rūpa paṭilābha vasena atha vā puñña mahattena ijjhati jāti mahattena
translated: Is found by the acquisition of the form of skin-clarity. Or alternatively, it succeeds by the greatness of merit.

original: labhati. Issariyamahattena paṭilabhati. Sukhamahattena adhigacchati. Sampattimahattena vindatīti.
analyzed: labhati issariya mahat tena paṭilabhati sukha mahat tena adhigacchati sampatti mahat tena vindati iti
translated: Is gained by the greatness of birth. Is obtained by the greatness of dominion. Is reached by the greatness of happiness. Is found by the greatness of prosperity.

original: Ekaṃsavacananti ekakoṭṭhāsavacanaṃ. “Ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā, ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyo pañho”tiādīsu
analyzed: ekaṃsa vacanam ti eka koṭṭhāsa vacanam eka aṃsam cīvaram katvā ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyaḥ pañhaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: One-sided statement: a statement with one part. “Having made the robe one-sided, a question to be answered one-sidedly” , etc.

original: viya anekaṃsagahaṇapaṭikkhepo. Nissaṃsayavacananti saṃsayavirahitavacanaṃ, sandehapaṭikkhepavacananti
analyzed: viya aneka aṃsa gahaṇa paṭikkhepaḥ nissaṃsaya vacanan ti saṃsaya virahita vacanam sandeha paṭikkhepa vacanan ti
translated: as the rejection of the taking of many factors. The words “without doubt” are the words free from doubt, the words rejecting doubt.

original: attho. Nikkaṅkhāvacananti “kathamidaṃ kathamida”nti kaṅkhāpaṭikkhepavacanaṃ. Advejjhavacananti🔽dvidhābhāvaṃ dvejjhaṃ, taṃabhāvena advejjhavacanaṃ. Dvidhābhāvavirahitaṃ “advejjhavacanā
analyzed: atthaḥ nikkaṅkhā vacanan ti katham idam katham idam ti kaṅkhā paṭikkhepa vacanaṃ a dvejjha vacanan ti  dvidhābhāvam dvejjham taṃ abhāvena advejjha vacanam dvidhābhāva virahitam advejjha vacanā
translated: as the rejection of the taking of many parts. The words “without doubt” are words free from doubt; the meaning is, words rejecting uncertainty. The words “without hesitation” are words rejecting the hesitation “How is this? How is this?” The words “without vacillation” are words without vacillation, which is twofoldness;

original: buddhā”tiādīsu viya vimatipaṭikkhepo. Adveḷhakavacananti dvihadayābhāvena adveḷhakaṃ.
analyzed: buddha ati ādīsu viya vimati paṭikkhepaḥ adveḷhaka vacanam ti dvi hadaya abhāvena adveḷhakam
translated: the meaning is, words without the state of being twofold. As in the case of the words “The Buddhas are without vacillation,” etc., this is a rejection of uncertainty. The words “without duplicity” are without duplicity because of the absence of two minds.

original: “Itihāsa, itihāsā”ti dveḷhakapaṭikkhepavacanaṃ. Niyogavacananti ekasmiṃ atthe dve🔽na yujjantīti niyogavacanaṃ dvidhāpathapaṭikkhepo. Aññattha pana “niyogā anāgatārammaṇā
analyzed: itihāsaḥ itihāsa ati dveḷhaka paṭikkhepa vacanam niyoga vacananti ekasmin atthe dve  na yujjanti iti niyoga vacanam dvidhā patha paṭikkhepaḥ aññattha pana niyogāḥ anāgata ārammaṇā
translated: The meaning is, words rejecting duplicity such as “itihasa, itihāsa.” The words “without equivocation” are words that are not equivocal;

original: natthī”ti āgataṃ. Apaṇṇakavacananti palāsarahitaṃ sāravacanaṃ aviraddhakāraṇaṃ “apaṇṇakaṃ
analyzed: na atthi iti āgatam apaṇṇaka vacanam ti palāsa rahitam sāra vacanam aviraddha kāraṇam apaṇṇakam
translated: the meaning is, words that are not twofold. As in the case of the words “The Buddhas are without equivocation,” etc., this is a rejection of the state of being twofold. Elsewhere, however, it is said: “There is no equivocation, no future object” . The words “without fail” are words that are not futile, words that are not deceptive, words that are not false.

original: ṭhānameke”tiādīsu viya, apaṇṇakamaṇi viya sappatiṭṭhavacanaṃ. Avatthāpanavacanametanti
analyzed: ṭhānam eka iti ādīsu viya apaṇṇa kamaṇi viya sa patiṭṭha vacanam avatthāpana vacanam etat ti
translated: and in such passages as ‘Some are of no account’ , it is a word of settled meaning like the ‘jewel of no account’ .🔽It is a word of settled meaning in the sense of a word of establishment.

original: etaṃ vacanaṃ otaritvā patiṭṭhitaṃ santiṭṭhāpanaṃ ṭhapanaṃ.
analyzed: etam vacanam otaritvā patiṭṭhitam santiṭṭhāpanam ṭhapanam
translated: It is a word of establishment, a word of setting up, a word of placing,

original: Yāni imasmiṃ mahāniddese vibhattiṃ āropitāni padāni, tāni vibhattiṃ gacchantāni tīhi
analyzed: yāni imasmin mahāniddese vibhattim āropitāni padāni tāni vibhattim gacchantāni tīhi
translated: The words that are analysed in this Great Exposition go to analysis in three ways

original: kāraṇehi vibhattiṃ gacchanti, nānā hontāni catūhi kāraṇehi nānā bhavanti. Aparadīpanā🔽panettha dve ṭhānāni gacchanti. Kathaṃ? Tāni hi byañjanavasena upasaggavasena atthavasena
analyzed: kāraṇehi vibhattim gacchanti nānā hontāni catūhi kāraṇehi nānā bhavanti apara dīpanā  pana ittha dve ṭhānāni gacchanti katham tāni hi byañjana vasena upasagga vasena attha vasena
translated: and they are different in four ways. But in this explanation two other ways of going are implied.🔽How? For they go to analysis in three ways, that is to say, by way of letter, by way of prefix, and by way of meaning.

original: vāti imehi tīhi kāraṇehi vibhattiṃ gacchanti. Tattha “kodho kujjhanā kujjhitattaṃ,
analyzed: vāti imehi tīhi kāraṇehi vibhattim gacchanti tattha kodhaḥ kujjhanā
translated: Herein, the going to analysis by way of letter should be understood as follows: ‘Anger, the state of being angry, the state of having been angry,🔽hatred, the state of hating, the state of having hated’ .

original: doso dussanā dussitatta”nti evaṃ byañjanavasena vibhattigamanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tattha🔽hi ekova kodho byañjanavasena evaṃ vibhattiṃ labhati. “Ijjhati samijjhati labhati
analyzed: dosaḥ dussanā evam byañjana vasena vibhatti gamanam veditabbam tattha 🔽hi ekaḥ iva kodhaḥ byañjana vasena evam vibhattim labhati ijjhati samijjhati labhati
translated: Herein, anger is analysed in this way by way of letter, and it is only anger that gets this analysis by way of letter. ‘To succeed, to be successful, to obtain,🔽to get, to reach, to arrive at, to attain, to realize, to come upon, to come to, to come across, to meet with, to find, to be found, to be met with, to be encountered, to be reached, to be arrived at, to be attained, to be realized, to be come upon, to be come to, to be come across, to be met with, to be found, to be found in, to be found out, to be discovered, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met with, to be met up with, to be met by, to be met, to be met

original: paṭilabhati gacchati adhigacchatī”ti evaṃ pana upasaggavasena vibhattigamanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭilabhati gacchati adhigacchati iti evam pana upasagga vasena vibhatti gamanam veditabbam
translated: he obtains, he goes, he reaches” .

original: “Paṇḍiccaṃ kosallaṃ nepuññaṃ vebhabyā cintā upaparikkhā”ti evaṃ atthavasena vibhattigamanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṇḍiccam kosallam nepuññam vebhabyā cintā upaparikkhāti evam attha vasena vibhatti gamanam veditabbam
translated: “Skill, cleverness, subtlety, ingenuity, reflection, investigation” .

original: Tesu pītipadaniddese tāva imā tisso vibhattiyo labbhanti. Pīti pāmojjanti hi byañjanavasena
analyzed: tesu pīti pada niddese tāva imāḥ tissaḥ vibhattiyaḥ labbhanti pīti hi byañjana vasena
translated: Herein, in the case of the description of the first factor, namely, “Rapture” , these three kinds of verbal expression are found. For rapture is “joy” in the sense of the deathless state,🔽and it is “gladness” in the sense of gladness,

original: vibhattigamanaṃ hoti. Āmodanā pamodanā pahāsoti upasaggavasena. Vitti tuṭṭhi odagyaṃ
analyzed: vibhatti gamanam hoti āmodanā pamodanā pahāso ti upasagga vasena vitti tuṭṭhi odagyam
translated: and it is “elation” in the sense of rising up.

original: attamanatāti atthavasena. Iminā nayena sabbapadaniddesesu vibhattigamanaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Nānā hontānipi nāmanānattena lakkhaṇanānattena kiccanānattena paṭikkhepanānattenāti
analyzed: atta mana tā ti attha vasena iminā nayena sabba pada niddesesu vibhatti gamanam veditabbam  nānā hontāni pi nāma nānattena lakkhaṇa nānattena kicca nānattena paṭikkhepa nānattena ati
translated: This is how the verbal expression should be understood in each instance.🔽Although they are different, they are nevertheless called “one” because of the difference of name, the difference of characteristic, the difference of function, and the difference of proximate cause.

original: imehi catūhi kāraṇehi nānā honti. Tattha “katamo tasmiṃ samaye byāpādo hoti? Yo tasmiṃ
analyzed: imehi catūhi kāraṇehi nānā honti tattha katamo tasmin samaye byāpādaḥ hoti yaḥ tasmin
translated: Herein, “What is ill will on that occasion? It is this:

original: samaye doso dussanā”ti ettha byāpādoti vā dosoti vā dvepi ete kodho eva, nāmena pana
analyzed: samaye dosaḥ dussanā ti ettha byāpādo ati vā doso ati vā dve pi ete kodho eva nāmena pana
translated: “At the time of hate, hate is the defilement” , here both “ill will” and “hate” are just anger, but they have come to have different names.

original: nānattaṃ gatāti evaṃ nāmanānattena nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nānattam gatā ati evam nāma nānattena nānattam veditabbam
translated: So this is how they are different in name.

original: Rāsaṭṭhena ca pañcapi khandhā ekova khandho hoti. Ettha pana rūpaṃ ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: ca pañca api khandhāḥ ekaḥ iva khandho hoti ettha pana rūpam ruppana lakkhaṇam
translated: And as to the mass, all the five aggregates are just one aggregate. But here, material form has the characteristic of being molested .🔽Feeling has the characteristic of being felt.🔽Perception has the characteristic of perceiving.

original: vedanā vedayitalakkhaṇā, saññā sañjānanalakkhaṇā, cetanā cetayitalakkhaṇā, viññāṇaṃ🔽vijānanalakkhaṇanti iminā lakkhaṇanānattena pañcakkhandhā honti. Evaṃ lakkhaṇanānattena
analyzed: vedanā vedayita lakkhaṇā saññā sañjānana lakkhaṇā cetanā cetayita lakkhaṇā viññāṇam  vijānana lakkhaṇam ti iminā lakkhaṇa nānattena pañca kkhandhāḥ honti evam lakkhaṇa nānattena
translated: Mentality has the characteristic of moulding .🔽Consciousness has the characteristic of cognizing .

original: nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽“Cattāro sammappadhānā – idha bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: nānattam veditabbam  cattāro sammappadhānāḥ idha bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānaṃ
translated: So this is how they are different in characteristic.

original: anuppādāya…pe… cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahatī”ti ekameva vīriyaṃ kiccanānattena catūsu
analyzed: cittam paggaṇhāti padahati iti ekam eva vīriyam kicca nānattena catūsu
translated: “There are four right endeavours: here a bhikkhu awakens zeal for the non-arising of unarisen evil unwholesome states … and he makes effort, stirs up his energy, exerts his mind and strives” .

original: ṭhānesu āgataṃ. Evaṃ kiccanānattena nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhānesu āgatam evam kicca nānattena nānattam veditabbam
translated: Herein, one energy is given in four places with a difference of function. So this is how they are different in function.

original: “Cattāro asaddhammā kodhagarutā, na saddhammagarutā, makkhagarutā, na saddhammagarutā,
analyzed: cattāro asaddhammā kodha garutā na saddhamma garutā makkha garutā na saddhamma garutā
translated: But in such passages as “The four wrong guises are: being given to anger, not being given to the True Idea; being given to hypocrisy, not being given to the True Idea;

original: lābhagarutā, na saddhammagarutā, sakkāragarutā, na saddhammagarutā”ti evamādīsu pana
analyzed: lābha garutā na saddhamma garutā sakkāra garutā na saddhamma garutā ati evamādīsu pana
translated: being given to greed for gain, not being given to the True Idea; being given to honour, not being given to the True Idea” ,

original: paṭikkhepanānattena nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭikkhepa nānattena nānattam veditabbam
translated: the difference should be understood as due to the difference of prohibition.

original: Imāni pana cattāri nānattāni na pītiyāyeva labbhanti, sabbesupi yathālābhavasena
analyzed: imāni pana cattāri nānattāni na pītiyāya iva labbhanti sabbesu pi yathā lābha vasena
translated: But these four differences are not only found in joy but in all of them according to circumstances.

original: labbhanti. Pītiyā hi pītīti nāmaṃ, cittassa cittanti nāmaṃ. Pīti ca pharaṇalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: labbhanti pītiyā hi pīti iti nāmam cittassa cittam ti nāmam pīti ca pharaṇa lakkhaṇā
translated: For joy has the name “joy” and cognizance has the name “cognizance.” Joy has the characteristic of diffusing;

original: vedanā vedayitalakkhaṇā, saññā sañjānanalakkhaṇā, cetanā cetayitalakkhaṇā, viññāṇaṃ vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: vedanā vedayita lakkhaṇā saññā sañjānana lakkhaṇā cetanā cetayita lakkhaṇā viññāṇam vijānana lakkhaṇam
translated: feeling has the characteristic of being felt; perception has the characteristic of perceiving; volition has the characteristic of willing; consciousness has the characteristic of cognizing.

original: Tathā pīti pharaṇakiccā, vedanā anubhavanakiccā, saññā sañjānanakiccā, cetanā cetayitakiccā,
analyzed: tathā pīti pharaṇa kiccā vedanā anubhavana kiccā saññā sañjānana kiccā cetanā cetayita kiccā
translated: So too, joy has the function of diffusing; feeling has the function of being felt; perception has the function of perceiving; volition has the function of willing;

original: viññāṇaṃ vijānanakiccanti evaṃ kiccanānattena nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ. Paṭikkhepanānattaṃ pītipade natthi.
analyzed: viññāṇam vijānana kiccanti evam kicca nānattena nānattam veditabbam paṭikkhepa nānattam pīti pade natthi
translated: consciousness has the function of cognizing. The difference should be understood as due to the difference of function. The difference of prohibition is not found in the case of joy.

original: Alobhādiniddese pana “alobho alubbhanā alubbhitatta”ntiādinā nayena labbhatīti evaṃ🔽paṭikkhepanānattena nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ sabbapadaniddesesu labbhamānavasena
analyzed: alobha ādi niddese pana alobhaḥ alubbhanā alubbhita ttanti ādinā nayena labbhati iti evam  paṭikkhepa nānattena nānattam veditabbam evam sabba pada niddesesu labbhamāna vasena
translated: But in the description of non-greed, etc., it is found in the way beginning, “Non-greed is non-covetousness, the state of being non-covetous” , and so on. So the difference should be understood as being due to the difference of the denial in each case. This is how the difference should be understood as occurring in the description of all the terms.

original: catubbidhampi nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Aparadīpanā pana padatthuti vā hoti daḷhīkammaṃ vāti evaṃ dve ṭhānāni gacchati. Yaṭṭhikoṭiyā
analyzed: catubbidham pi nānattam veditabbam  apara dīpanā pana vā hoti daḷhīkammam vā ati evam dve ṭhānāni gacchati yaṭṭhi koṭiyā
translated: In the description of non-greed, etc., it is found in the way beginning, “Non-greed is non-covetousness, the state of being non-covetous” , and so on. So the difference should be understood as a difference in the way of denying. This is how the difference should be understood as fourfold according to what is found in the description of all the terms.

original: uppīḷentena viya hi sakimeva “pītī”ti vutte etaṃ padaṃ phullitamaṇḍitavibhūsitaṃ🔽nāma na hoti, punappunaṃ byañjanavasena upasaggavasena atthavasena “pīti pāmojjaṃ
analyzed: uppīḍentena viya hi sa kim eva pīti iti vutte etam padam phullita maṇḍita vibhūsitam  nāma na hoti punappunam byañjana vasena upasagga vasena attha vasena pīti pāmojjam
translated: But the further description either gives the meaning of the term or else it is a strengthening. So it goes to two places. For when the word “happiness” is said once, that word is not yet fully blossomed, adorned, and ornamented, as it were, by the syllables, as if it were being pressed down at the tip of the tongue.

original: āmodanā pamodanā hāso pahāso vittī”ti vutte phullitamaṇḍitavibhūsitaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: āmodanā pamodanā hāsaḥ pahāsaḥ vitti iti vutte phullita maṇḍita vibhūsitam nāma hoti
translated: But when it is said again and again, by syllables, by prefixes, and by meanings, as “happiness, gladdening, gladness, joy, exultation, elation, rapture,” then it is fully blossomed, adorned, and ornamented.

original: Yathā hi daharakumāraṃ nahāpetvā manoramaṃ vatthaṃ paridahāpetvā pupphāni piḷandhāpetvā
analyzed: yathā hi dahara kumāram nahāpetvā manoramam vattham paridahāpetvā pupphāni piḷandhāpetvā
translated: For just as when a young boy has been bathed and scented and is being dressed in a beautiful cloth,

original: akkhīni añjetvā athassa nalāṭe ekameva manosilābinduṃ kareyya, na tassa ettāvatā
analyzed: akkhīni añjetvā athassa nalāṭe ekam eva manosilā bindum kareyya na tassa ettāvatā
translated: and after anointing his eyes he would put a single streak of sandalwood ointment on his forehead,🔽it would not be a forehead streak to that extent.

original: cittatilako nāma hoti, nānāvaṇṇehi pana parivāretvā bindūsu katesu cittatilako nāma
analyzed: cittatilakaḥ nāma hoti nānā vaṇṇehi pana parivāretvā bindūsu katesu cittatilakaḥ nāma
translated: But when the streaks are made in various colours and the forehead streak is completed,

original: hoti. Evaṃ sampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ayaṃ padatthuti nāma.🔽Byañjanavasena pana upasaggavasena atthavasena ca punappunaṃ bhaṇanameva daḷhīkammaṃ
analyzed: hoti evam sampadam idam veditabbam ayam padatthu ti nāma  byañjana vasena pana upasagga vasena attha vasena ca punappunam bhaṇanam eva daḷhīkammam
translated: it is a forehead streak. This is how it should be understood in detail. This is the word-meaning.🔽But the repetition of the word by way of the letters, by way of the prefix, and by way of the meaning is what is called the emphasis.

original: nāma. Yathā hi “āvuso”ti vā “bhante”ti vā “yakkho”ti vā “sappo”ti vā vutte daḷhīkammaṃ
analyzed: nāma yathā hi āvuso ti vā bhante ti vā yakkho iti vā sappo iti vā vutte daḷhīkammam
translated: For just as when “friend” or “sir” or “ghost” or “snake” is said once, there is no emphasis,

original: nāma na hoti, “āvuso āvuso, bhante bhante, yakkho yakkho, sappo sappo”ti vutte pana
analyzed: nāma na hoti āvuso āvuso bhante bhante yakkhaḥ yakkho sappo sappo ti vutte pana
translated: but when it is said again and again, “friend friend, sir sir, ghost ghost, snake snake,”

original: daḷhīkammaṃ nāma hoti, evameva sakiṃdeva yaṭṭhikoṭiyā uppīḷentena viya “pītī”ti vuttamatte
analyzed: daḷhīkammam nāma hoti evam eva sakiṃdeva yaṭṭhi koṭiyā uppīḷentena viya pīti iti vutta matte
translated: there is emphasis, so too, when “happiness” is said once, as if by pressing the tip of a stick,

original: daḷhīkammaṃ nāma na hoti, punappunaṃ byañjanavasena upasaggavasena atthavasena “pīti
analyzed: daḷhīkammam nāma na hoti punappunam byañjana vasena upasagga vasena attha vasena pi iti
translated: there is no emphasis, but when it is said again and again by way of the letters, by way of the prefix, and by way of the meaning, “happiness

original: pāmojjaṃ āmodanā pamodanā hāso pahāso vittī”ti vutteyeva daḷhīkammaṃ nāma hotīti
analyzed: pāmojjam āmodanā pamodanā hāsaḥ pahāsaḥ vitti iti vuttā iya iva daḷhīkammam nāma hoti iti
translated: and “ gladness is the gladdening, the gladdenedness, the gladness, the gladdening state, the gladdened state” is a strengthening of the term.

original: evaṃ aparadīpanā dve ṭhānāni gacchati. Etissāpi vasena labbhamānakapadaniddesesu
analyzed: evam apara dīpanā dve ṭhānāni gacchati etissā api vasena labbhamānaka pada niddesesu
translated: So this is the way in which the two terms are not repeated.

original: sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in all instances in the way already stated.

original: Tattha pīnayatīti pīti. Sā sampiyāyanalakkhaṇā, kāyacittapīṇanarasā pharaṇarasā vā,
analyzed: tattha pīnayati iti sā sampiyāyana lakkhaṇā kāya citta pīṇana rasā pharaṇa rasā vā
translated: Herein, it refreshes , thus it is happiness . Its characteristic is that of gladdening. Its function is to refresh the body and the mind or to cause the experience of refreshment. It is manifested as elation.

original: odagyapaccupaṭṭhānā. Yā pañcakāmaguṇapaṭisaññuttāti yā rūpādipañcakāmakoṭṭhāsapaṭisaṃyuttā
analyzed: odagya paccupaṭṭhānā yā pañca kāmaguṇa paṭisaññuttā ati yā rūpa ādi pañca kāma koṭṭhāsa paṭisaṃyuttā
translated: That which is associated with the perception of the five strands of sensual desire: that which is associated with the five object fields of sensual desire consisting of visible forms and so on.🔽It refreshes , thus it is happiness . This is the literal meaning. The state of being gladdened is gladness .

original: pīti, sā pīnayatīti pīti, idaṃ sabhāvapadaṃ. Pamuditassa bhāvo pāmojjaṃ. Āmodanākāro🔽āmodanā. Pamodanākāro pamodanā. Yathā vā bhesajjānaṃ vā telānaṃ vā uṇhodakasītodakānaṃ🔽vā ekato karaṇaṃ “modanā”ti vuccati, evamayampi pītidhammānaṃ ekato karaṇena modanā.
analyzed: pīti sā pīnayati iti pīti idam sabhāva padam pamuditassa bhāvaḥ pāmojjam āmodana ākāraḥ  āmodanā pamodanā ākāraḥ pamodanā yathā vā bhesajjānam vā telānam vā uṇha udaka sītā udakānam  vā ekatas karaṇam modanā ati vuccati evam ayam pi pīti dhammānam ekatas karaṇena modanā
translated: The mode of the gladdening is the gladdening.🔽The mode of the gladdenedness is the gladdenedness. Or just as the bringing together of medicines or of oils or of hot and cold water is called “mixing,” so too, this is the mixing of the states of happiness.

original: Upasaggavasena pana maṇḍetvā “āmodanā pamodanā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: upasagga vasena pana maṇḍetvā āmodanā pamodanā iti vuttā
translated: But it is said to be “the gladdening, the gladdenedness” in order to show the mode of the gladdening and the gladdenedness by way of prefixing a preposition.

original: Hāsetīti hāso. Pahāsetīti pahāso, haṭṭhapahaṭṭhākārānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vittīti🔽vittaṃ, dhanassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ayaṃ pana somanassapaccayattā vittisarikkhatāya vitti.🔽Yathā hi dhanino dhanaṃ paṭicca somanassaṃ uppajjati, evaṃ pītimatopi pītiṃ paṭicca🔽somanassaṃ uppajjati. Tasmā “vittī”ti vuttā. Tuṭṭhīti sabhāvasaṇṭhitāya pītiyā etaṃ
analyzed: hāseti iti hāsaḥ pahāseti iti pahāsaḥ adhivacanam vitti iti  vittam dhanassa etam nāmam ayam pana somanassa paccaya ttā vitti sarikkha tāya vitti  yathā hi dhaninaḥ dhanam paṭicca somanassam uppajjati evam pītimataḥ api pītim paṭicca  somanassam uppajjati tasmai vittī iti vuttā tuṭṭhi iti sa bhāva saṇṭhitāya pītiyā etam
translated: It makes one laugh, thus it is laughter . It makes one laugh again, thus it is merriment . This is a term for the state of being greatly delighted. It is wealth

original: nāmaṃ. Pītimā pana puggalo kāyacittānaṃ uggatattā abbhuggatattā “udaggo”ti vuccati,
analyzed: nāmam pītimā pana puggalo kāya cittānaṃ uggata ttā abbhuggata ttā udaggaḥ ti vuccati
translated: because it is like wealth in being a condition for joy. For just as a rich man’s joy arises with his wealth as its support, so too the joy-possessed man’s joy arises with his joy as its support. That is why it is called “wealth.” Contentment is the name for the kind of joy that is satisfied with what one has. But a person who has joy is said to be “uplifted” because his body and mind are uplifted,

original: udaggassa bhāvo odagyaṃ.🔽Attano manatā attamanatā. Anabhiraddhassa hi mano dukkhapadaṭṭhānattā na attano mano🔽nāma hoti, abhiraddhassa sukhapadaṭṭhānattā attano mano nāma hoti, iti attano manatā
analyzed: udaggassa bhāvaḥ odagyam  attanaḥ manatā attamanatā an abhiraddhassa hi manaḥ dukkha padaṭṭhāna tā na attanaḥ manaḥ  nāma hoti abhiraddhassa sukha padaṭṭhāna ttā attanaḥ manaḥ nāma hoti iti attanaḥ mana tā
translated: and the state of being uplifted is elation.

original: attamanatā, sakamanatā, sakamanassa bhāvoti attho. Sā pana yasmā na aññassa kassaci
analyzed: attamana tā sa kamana tā sa kamanassa bhāvaḥ ti attho sā pana yasmā na aññassa kassaci
translated: Being pleased with oneself is satisfaction. For the mind of one who is dissatisfied is not one’s own because it is the basis for pain, but the mind of one who is satisfied is one’s own because it is the basis for pleasure. So being pleased with oneself is satisfaction. The meaning is: the state of being pleased with one’s own mind. And that is not the state of being pleased with anyone else’s mind.

original: attano manatā, cittasseva panesā bhāvo cetasiko dhammo, tasmā “attamanatā cittassā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: attanaḥ manatā cittassa iva pana esā bhāvo cetasiko dhammo tasmā atta manatā cittassa ati vuttā
translated: But this is a state of the mind, and so it is said to be “the gladdening of the mind” .

original: Cittavicittatāya cittaṃ. Ārammaṇaṃ minamānaṃ jānātīti mano. Mānasanti mano eva, “antalikkhacaro pāso, yvāyaṃ carati mānaso”ti hi ettha pana sampayuttakadhammo “mānaso”ti vutto.
analyzed: citta vicitta tāya cittam ārammaṇam minamānam jānāti iti manaḥ mānasanti manaḥ eva antalikkha caraḥ pāsaḥ yvā ayam carati mānasaḥ ti hi ettha pana sampayuttaka dhammo mānasaḥ ti vutto
translated: The mind is so called because of its variety of states . The mental factor is so called because it knows by bending towards the object . The mental is so called because it is associated with the mind .

original: “Kathañhi bhagavā tuyhaṃ, sāvako sāsane rato;
analyzed: katham hi bhagavā tuyham sāvakaḥ sāsane rataḥ
translated: “How can it be, Lord, that a disciple of yours, delighting in the Master’s Dispensation,

original: Appattamānaso sekkho, kālaṃkayirā jane sutā”ti. –
analyzed: a patta mānasaḥ sekkhaḥ kālaṃkayirā jane sutā ti
translated: Should die with his mind still untaught, while there are other people to instruct him?”

original: Ettha arahattaṃ “mānasa”nti vuttaṃ. Idha pana mano eva mānasaṃ, byañjanavasena hetaṃ padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: ettha arahattam mānasanti vuttam idha pana manaḥ eva mānasam byañjana vasena ha itam padam vaḍḍhitam
translated: Here arahatship is called “the mental.” But here the mental is the mind itself, the word being extended by association.🔽The heart is the mind . Here “heart” is the chest ,

original: Hadayanti cittaṃ. “Cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmī”ti ettha uro
analyzed: hadayanti cittam cittam vā te khipissāmi hadayam vā te phālessāmi iti ettha uro
translated: “I will either crush your heart or split your heart open” .

original: “hadaya”nti vuttaṃ. “Hadayā hadayaṃ maññe aññāya tacchatī”ti ettha cittaṃ. “Vakkaṃ
analyzed: hadayanti vuttam hadayā hadayam maññe aññāya tacchati iti ettha cittam vakkam
translated: “The heart seems to be pierced by the heart” . Here the heart is the mind .

original: hadaya”nti ettha hadayavatthu. Idha pana cittameva abbhantaraṭṭhena “hadaya”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Tameva parisuddhaṭṭhena paṇḍaraṃ, bhavaṅgaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Yathāha – “pabhassaramidaṃ,
analyzed: hadayanti ettha hadaya vatthu idha pana cittam eva abbhantara ṭṭhena hadayanti vuttam  tam eva parisuddha ṭṭhena paṇḍaram bhavaṅgam sandhāya itam vuttam yathā āha pabhassaram idam
translated: Here, however, the word “heart” is used to denote the mind itself in the sense of its being the inner core .🔽It is called “pure” in the sense of being purified, and this refers to the life-continuum , as it is said: “Monks, this mind is luminous, but it is defiled by taints that come from without” .

original: bhikkhave, cittaṃ, tañca kho āgantukehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭha”nti. Tato nikkhantattā🔽pana akusalampi gaṅgāya nikkhantā nadī gaṅgā viya godhāvarito nikkhantā godhāvarī
analyzed: bhikkhave cittam tat ca kho āgantukehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhanti tatas nikkhanta ttā  pana akusalam pi gaṅgāya nikkhantā nadī gaṅgā viya godhāvaritaḥ nikkhantā godhāvarī
translated: But because it has emerged from that ,

original: viya ca “paṇḍara”ntveva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viya ca vuttam
translated: it is called “pure” like a river that has emerged from the Ganges is called “Gaṅga” and a river that has emerged from the Godhāvarī is called “Godhāvarī” .

original: Mano manāyatananti idha pana manoggahaṇaṃ manasseva āyatanabhāvadīpanatthaṃ. Tenetaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ mana āyatanam ti idha pana manaḥ gahaṇam manassa iva āyatana bhāva dīpana attham tena itam
translated: The mind base is the mind. Here, however, the word “mind” is used in order to show that the mind itself is the mind base. Thus this is what is being said:

original: dīpeti “nayidaṃ devāyatanaṃ viya manassa āyatanattā manāyatanaṃ, atha kho mano eva
analyzed: dīpeti na idam devāyatanam viya manassa āyatanattā manāyatanam atha kho manaḥ eva
translated: “This is not a mind base in the sense of being a place for the mind, like a deva-world is a place for devas. Rather, it is the mind itself that is the mind base” .

original: āyatanaṃ manāyatana”nti. Tattha nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: āyatanam manāyatananti tattha nivāsa ṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the mind is a “base” in the sense of a dwelling place , in the sense of a source , and in the sense of a meeting place .

original: sañjātidesaṭṭhena kāraṇaṭṭhena ca āyatanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi loke “issarāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca āyatanam veditabbam tathā hi loke issara āyatanam
translated: It should be understood as the sense base in the sense of a place of rebirth and in the sense of a cause. For in the world, in such passages as “The sense base of the lord,”

original: vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ “āyatana”nti vuccati. “Suvaṇṇāyatanaṃ, rajatāyatana”ntiādīsu
analyzed: vāsudevāyatana ntiādīsu nivāsa ṭṭhānam āyatananti vuccati suvaṇṇāyatanam rajatāyatana ntiādīsu
translated: “The sense base of Vāsudeva,” a place of dwelling is called “sense base.” In such passages as “The sense base of gold,” “The sense base of silver,”

original: ākaro. Sāsane pana “manorame āyatane, sevanti naṃ vibhaṅgamā”tiādīsu samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pana manorame āyatane sevanti naṃ vibhaṅga māti ādīsu samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam
translated: a shape is . In the scriptures, in such passages as “In a delightful sense base they frequent it, the breakers up of states,” a place of meeting is .

original: “Dakkhiṇāpatho gunnaṃ āyatana”ntiādīsu sañjātideso. “Tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ🔽pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ. Idha pana sañjātidesaṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: dakkhiṇāpathaḥ gunnam āyatana nti ādīsu sañjā atidesaḥ tatra tatra iva  pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatana iti ādīsu kāraṇam idha pana sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: In such passages as “The southern region is the sense base of horses,”

original: kāraṇaṭṭhenāti tidhāpi vaṭṭati.🔽Phassādayo hi dhammā ettha sañjāyantīti sañjātidesaṭṭhenapi etaṃ āyatanaṃ. Bahiddhā
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭṭhena ati tidhā api vaṭṭati  phassa ādayaḥ hi dhammā ettha sañjāyanti iti etam āyatanam bahiddhā
translated: a place of origin is . In such passages as “He attains the ability to be a witness, through realization by direct-knowledge, of any state realizable by direct-knowledge that he wishes, whenever there is a sense base for it,” a cause is . Here it is appropriate in all three senses, that is, as a place of origin, a place of meeting, and a cause.

original: rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbā ārammaṇabhāvenettha osarantīti samosaraṇaṭhānaṭṭhenapi
analyzed: rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbāḥ ārammaṇa bhāvena ittha osaranti iti samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena api
translated: For the states beginning with contact are generated here, thus it is a sense base in the sense of a place of origin. External visible data, sounds, odours, flavours, and tangible data meet here as objects, thus it is a sense base in the sense of a place of meeting.

original: āyatanaṃ. Phassādīnaṃ pana sahajātādipaccayaṭṭhena kāraṇattā kāraṇaṭṭhenapi āyatananti
analyzed: āyatanam phassa ādīnam pana sahajāta ādi paccaya ṭṭhena kāraṇa ttā kāraṇa ṭṭhena pi āyatanam ti
translated: The base is the eye, etc., as the physical bases for the eye-consciousness, etc. But it should be understood that they are also a base in the sense of a reason for the occurrence of eye-consciousness, etc., in the sense of a cause in the sense of a reason for the occurrence of contact, etc., in the way already stated.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tadeva mananalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti indriyaṃ, mano eva indriyaṃ manindriyaṃ.🔽Vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ. Viññāṇameva khandho viññāṇakkhandho. Tassa rāsiādivasena attho
analyzed: veditabbam tat eva manana lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti indriyam manaḥ eva indriyam manindriyam  vijānāti iti viññāṇam viññāṇam eva khandhaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho tassa rāsi ādi vasena attho
translated: It is the faculty in the sense of predominance of the mind itself, which has the characteristic of directing, in the act of directing. The mind itself is a faculty, thus it is the mind faculty.

original: veditabbo. “Mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti ettha hi rāsaṭṭhena khandho🔽vutto. “Sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandho”tiādīsu guṇaṭṭhena. “Addasā kho bhagavā mahantaṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ mahā udaka khandhaḥ tu eva saṅkham gacchati iti ettha hi rāsaṭṭhena khandho  vuttaḥ sīla kkhandhaḥ samādhi kkhandho ti ādīsu guṇa ṭṭhena addasā kho bhagavā mahantam
translated: It cognizes, thus it is consciousness . Consciousness itself is an aggregate, thus it is the consciousness aggregate. Its meaning should be understood according to the sense of a heap, etc. For in the passage, “It is called a great mass of water” , a heap is spoken of in the sense of a collection.

original: dārukkhandha”nti ettha paṇṇattimattaṭṭhena. Idha pana ruḷhito khandho vutto. Rāsaṭṭhena🔽hi viññāṇakkhandhassa ekadeso ekaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Tasmā yathā rukkhassa ekadesaṃ chindanto
analyzed: dāru khandhanti ettha paṇṇattimatta ṭṭhena idha pana ruḷhitaḥ khandhaḥ vuttaḥ rāsa ṭṭhena  hi viññāṇa kkhandhassa eka deso ekam viññāṇam tasmā yathā rukkhassa eka desam chindanto
translated: In the passage, “The aggregate of virtue, the aggregate of concentration” , it is spoken of in the sense of a quality. In the passage, “The Blessed One saw a great tree trunk” , it is spoken of in the sense of a mere concept. But here it is spoken of in the sense of a part of a whole.

original: “rukkhaṃ chindatī”ti vuccati, evameva viññāṇakkhandhassa ekadesabhūtaṃ ekampi viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: rukkham chindati iti vuccati evam eva viññāṇa kkhandhassa eka desa bhūtam ekam pi viññāṇam
translated: For a part of the consciousness aggregate in the sense of a collection is a single consciousness. Therefore, just as one is said to “cut down a tree” when he cuts off a single branch of a tree, so too, when a single consciousness is spoken of, it is a part of the consciousness aggregate.

original: rūḷhito “viññāṇakkhandho”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: rūḷhitaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho ti vuttam
translated: and because it is grown, it is called the consciousness aggregate.

original: Tajjā manoviññāṇadhātūti tesaṃ phassādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ anucchavikā manoviññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: tajjā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu ti tesam phassa ādīnam dhammānam anucchavikā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: The mind-consciousness element that is associated with them: the mind-consciousness element that is appropriate to those states beginning with contact.

original: Imasmiñhi pade ekameva cittaṃ minanaṭṭhena mano, vijānanaṭṭhena viññāṇaṃ, sabhāvaṭṭhena
analyzed: imasmin hi pade ekam eva cittam minana ṭṭhena manaḥ vijānana ṭṭhena viññāṇam sabhāva ṭṭhena
translated: For in this passage the same consciousness is called “mind” in the sense of “that which is bent” , “consciousness” in the sense of “that which knows” , and “element” in the sense of “own-nature” ,

original: nissattaṭṭhena vā dhātūti tīhi nāmehi vuttaṃ. Sahagatoti avijahito. Sahajātoti saddhiṃ
analyzed: nissatta ṭṭhena vā dhātu uti tīhi nāmehi vuttam sahagataḥ ti a vijahitaḥ sahajātaḥ ti saddhim
translated: or in the sense of “non-self” . Associated is unseparated. Born together is born together with.

original: niggato. Saṃsaṭṭhoti saṃsaggo hutvā ṭhito. Sampayuttoti samaṃ pakārehi yutto. Katamehi
analyzed: niggataḥ saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti saṃsaggaḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ sampayuttaḥ ti samam pakārehi yuttaḥ katamehi
translated: Combined is existing in combination. Conjoined is conjoined by the same conascence conditions. What are the conascence conditions?

original: pakārehīti? Ekuppādādīhi. Natthi keci dhammā kehici dhammehi sampayuttāti? Āmantā.🔽Iti hi imassa pañhassa paṭikkhepe “nanu atthi keci dhammā kehici dhammehi sahagatā
analyzed: pakārehi iti ekuppāda ādīhi natthi keci dhammā kehici dhammehi sampayuttā ati āmantā  iti hi imassa pañhassa paṭikkhepe nanu atthi keci dhammā kehici dhammehi sahagatā
translated: Arising together, etc. Are there any states that are conjoined with any states? No.

original: sahajātā saṃsaṭṭhā ekuppādā ekanirodhā ekavatthukā ekārammaṇā”ti evaṃ ekuppādatādīnaṃ
analyzed: sahajātā saṃsaṭṭhā eka uppādā eka nirodhā eka vatthukā eka ārammaṇā ati evam eka uppāda tā ādīnam
translated: For when this question is answered in the negative, the following question arises: “Are there any states that are associated with any states, that are born together, that are born together and are combined, that are born together, are combined, and are conjoined, that have a single arising and a single passing away and a single location, that have states as their object and not non-states?”

original: vasena sampayogattho vutto. Iti imehi ekuppādatādīhi samaṃ pakārehi yutto sampayutto.
analyzed: vasena sampayoga atthaḥ vuttaḥ iti imehi ekuppāda tā ādīhi samam pakārehi yuttaḥ sampayuttaḥ
translated: The meaning of “conjoined” is stated by the word “together.” So it is “conjoined” by these terms beginning with “arising together.”

original: Ekuppādoti ekato uppanno, na vināti attho. Ekanirodhoti ekato nirodho. Ekavatthukoti
analyzed: eka uppādaḥ ti ekatas uppannaḥ na vinā ti attho eka nirodho ti ekatas nirodhaḥ eka vatthukaḥ ti
translated: “Arising together”: arising together, not dispersing, is the meaning. “Cessation together”: cessation together. “Having the same physical basis”:

original: hadayavatthuvasena ekavatthuko. Ekārammaṇoti rūpādivasena ekārammaṇo.
analyzed: hadaya vatthu vasena eka vatthuko eka ārammaṇaḥ ti rūpa ādi vasena eka ārammaṇaḥ
translated: having the same physical basis, the heart-basis. “Having the same object”: having the same object, visible form, etc.🔽The word “together” is found in the scriptures of the Victor in five senses:

original: Ettha sahagatasaddo tabbhāve, vokiṇṇe, ārammaṇe, nissaye, saṃsaṭṭheti pañcasu atthesu🔽dissati jinavacane. “Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobhavikā nandirāgasahagatā”ti ettha tabbhāve
analyzed: ettha sahagata saddo tad bhāve vokiṇṇe ārammaṇe nissaye saṃsaṭṭha iti pañcasu atthesu  dissati jina vacane yā ayam taṇhā ponobhavikā nandi rāga sahagatā ati ettha tad bhāve
translated: in the sense of “having the same nature,” in the sense of “intermittent,” in the sense of “object,” in the sense of “support,” and in the sense of “combined.”

original: veditabbo, nandirāgabhūtāti attho. “Yā, bhikkhave, vīmaṃsā kosajjasahagatā kosajjasampayuttā”ti🔽ettha vokiṇṇe, antarantarā uppajjamānena kosajjena vokiṇṇāti ayamettha attho. “Lābhī
analyzed: veditabbaḥ nandi rāga bhūtā ati atthaḥ yā bhikkhave vīmaṃsā kosajja sahagatā kosajja sampayuttā ati  ettha vokiṇṇe antar antarā uppajjamānena kosajjena vokiṇṇā ati ayam ettha atthaḥ lābhī
translated: In the passage, “This craving accompanied by enjoyment and passion” , it should be understood in the sense of “having the same nature.” The meaning is: having enjoyment and passion as its nature. In the passage, “Bhikkhus, that investigation which is accompanied by indolence, associated with indolence” ,

original: hoti rūpasahagatānaṃ vā samāpattīnaṃ arūpasahagatānaṃ vā samāpattīna”nti ettha ārammaṇe,
analyzed: hoti rūpa sahagatānam vā samāpattīnam arūpa sahagatānam vā samāpattīnam ti ettha ārammaṇe
translated: it is in the sense of “intermittent.” The meaning here is: interrupted by the intermittent indolence that arises from time to time. In the passage, “He is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhānas that constitute the higher mind and are pleasant dwellings in this very life” , it is in the sense of “object.”

original: rūpārammaṇānaṃ arūpārammaṇānanti attho. “Aṭṭhikasaññāsahagataṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇānam arūpa ārammaṇānam ti atthaḥ aṭṭhika saññā sahagatam sati sambojjhaṅgam
translated: the meaning is “with material-object and immaterial-object” .🔽In the passage “He develops the mindfulness factor of complete awakening accompanied by the perception of a skeleton” ,

original: bhāvetī”ti ettha nissaye, aṭṭhikasaññaṃ nissāya aṭṭhikasaññaṃ bhāvetvā paṭiladdhanti
analyzed: bhāveti iti ettha nissaye aṭṭhika saññam nissāya aṭṭhika saññam bhāvetvā paṭiladdhanti
translated: the meaning is “having developed the perception of a skeleton, having obtained it, in dependence on the perception of a skeleton” .

original: attho. “Idaṃ sukhaṃ imāya pītiyā sahagataṃ hoti sahajātaṃ sampayutta”nti ettha saṃsaṭṭhe,
analyzed: attho idam sukham imāya pītiyā sahagatam hoti sahajātam sampayuttam ti ettha saṃsaṭṭhe
translated: In the passage “This bliss is associated with this rapture, is born together with this rapture, is conjoined with this rapture” , the meaning is “mixed up with” .

original: saṃmissanti attho. Imasmimpi ṭhāne saṃsaṭṭhe āgato.
analyzed: saṃmissanti attho imasmim pi ṭhāne saṃsaṭṭhe āgataḥ
translated: Here too it is come to in the sense of “mixed up with” .

original: Sahajātasaddo “sahajātaṃ purejātaṃ pacchājāta”nti ettha viya sahajāte. Saṃsaṭṭhasaddo🔽“gihīhi saṃsaṭṭho”ti ca, “evaṃ saṃsaṭṭho, bhante”ti cāti evamādīsu saṃsagge. “Kise
analyzed: sahajāta saddo sahajātam purejātam pacchājātam ti ettha viya sahajāte saṃsaṭṭha saddo  gihīhi saṃsaṭṭhaḥ iti ca evam saṃsaṭṭhaḥ bhante iti ca ati evamādīsu saṃsagge kise
translated: The word “born together with” is in the sense of “born together with” , as in the passage “What is born together with? What is born before? What is born after?” . The word “mixed up with”🔽is in the sense of “associated with” , as in the passages “He is mixed up with householders” and “Mixed up in this way, venerable sir” .

original: thūle vivajjetvā saṃsaṭṭhā yojitā hayā”ti ettha sadise.
analyzed: thūle vivajjetvā saṃsaṭṭhā yojitā hayāti ettha sadise
translated: It is in the sense of “similar” as in the passage “Horses similar to those that have been rejected, that have been weeded out, are yoked” .

original: “Pucimandaparivāro, ambo te dadhivāhana;
analyzed: pucimanda parivāraḥ ambo te dadhivāhana
translated: “The mango with its surrounding grove of tamarind trees,

original: Mūlaṃ mūlena saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, sākhā sākhā nisevare”ti. –
analyzed: mūlam mūlena saṃsaṭṭham sākhā sākhā nisevara iti
translated: Its roots mixed up with the roots, its branches with its branches” .

original: Ettha upacite. “Cittasaṃsaṭṭhā dhammā”ti ettha cittasampayuttadhamme. Idha pana yo
analyzed: ettha upacite citta saṃsaṭṭhāḥ dhammā ati ettha citta sampayutta dhamme idha pana yaḥ
translated: “Associated with consciousness” here is the states associated with consciousness. But here

original: phalappadāne aviyogadhammo vinibbhogaṃ akatvā ekuppādādidhammo hutvā “sampayutto”ti🔽vuccati. Taṃvisayo. Atha vā “sahagato”ti vatvā pacchato pacchato āgatasuttena viya🔽so na hotīti dassetuṃ “sahajāto”ti vuttaṃ. Ekato uppannarūpārūpaṃ viya sopi na hotīti
analyzed: phala ppadāne aviyoga dhammo vinibbhogam a katvā ekuppāda ādi dhammaḥ hutvā sampayuttaḥ ti  vuccati tad visayaḥ atha vā sahagato ti vatvā pacchatas pacchatas āgata suttena viya  so na hoti iti dassetum sahajātaḥ iti vuttam ekatas uppanna rūpa arūpam viya saḥ api na hoti iti
translated: what is meant is that which is not dissociated from the function of producing a result, which is of the nature of having a single arising, etc., and is called “associated.”

original: dassetuṃ “saṃsaṭṭho”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Khīrodakaṃ viya ca sopi na hotīti dassetuṃ “sampayutto”ti vuttaṃ. Vinibbhogaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: dassetum saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti vuttam  khīra udakam viya ca saḥ api na hoti iti dassetum sampayuttaḥ iti vuttam vinibbhogam kātum
translated: Or alternatively, in order to show that it is not like the latter terms that come later, which are stated by the word “accompanied,” it is said to be “conascent.” In order to show that it is not like the material and immaterial states that arise together, it is said to be “combined.”

original: asakkuṇeyyaṭṭhena hi sahuppannā dhammā sampayuttāpi atthi khīratelaṃ viya. Tathā🔽vippayuttāpi khīrato apanītaṃ navanītaṃ viya. Evaṃ lakkhaṇasampayutto ekuppādādilakkhaṇoyeva
analyzed: asakkuṇeyya ṭṭhena hi sahuppannā dhammā sampayuttā api atthi khīra telam viya tathā 🔽vippayuttā api khīrataḥ apanītam navanītam viya evam lakkhaṇa sampayuttaḥ eka uppāda ādi lakkhaṇaḥ yā iva
translated: And in order to show that it is not like milk and water, it is said to be “associated.” For states that arise together are associated in the sense that they cannot be separated by disentanglement.

original: hotīti dassetuṃ “ekuppādo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ettha ekuppādasahajātānaṃ kiṃ nānattaṃ? Uppāde🔽antaravirahito ekuppādo. Khīrakālamuttassāpi dadhino mathane mathane pākaṭaṃ navanītaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti dassetum ekuppādo tiādi vuttam ettha ekuppāda sahajātānam kim nānattam uppāde  antara virahitaḥ eka uppādaḥ dadhinaḥ mathane mathane pākaṭam navanītam
translated: The words “arisen together” are stated to show that they are arisen together. Herein, what is the difference between those arisen together and those arisen with the same arising?

original: viya purebhattapacchābhattavasena ekadivasameva jāto viya so na hotīti dassetuṃ ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: viya purebhatta pacchābhatta vasena eka divasam eva jātaḥ viya saḥ na hoti iti dassetum eka kkhaṇe
translated: Those arisen with the same arising are without interval of time between their arising. Like fresh butter that becomes evident when the churning of curd is not interrupted,🔽they are not like that. To show this, the words “arisen in a single conscious moment” are stated.

original: nibbattoti sahajāto. Ekavatthukoti patiṭṭhaṭṭhena ekaparicchedena ekavatthuko, dvinnaṃ🔽bhikkhūnaṃ ekavatthukatā viya ṭhānantaravirahito. Ekārammaṇoti aniyatekārammaṇo na
analyzed: nibbattaḥ ti sahajātaḥ eka vatthuko ti patiṭṭha ṭṭhena eka paricchedena eka vatthukaḥ dvinnam  bhikkhūnam eka vatthukatā viya ṭhāna antara virahito eka ārammaṇaḥ ti aniyata eka ārammaṇaḥ na
translated: Those arisen together are of one physical basis in the sense of being established on one physical basis with one delimitation, like the physical basis of two bhikkhus who are of one physical basis.🔽They are not like that. To show this, the words “of one physical basis” are stated.🔽Those arisen together are of one object in the sense of having no object in common, like eye-consciousness.

original: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ viyāti evameke vaṇṇayanti.🔽Maccoti mūlapadaṃ. Rūpādīsu satto laggo laggitoti satto. Vuttañhetaṃ “satto sattoti,
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam viyāti evam eke vaṇṇayanti  macco iti mūla padam rūpa ādīsu sattaḥ laggaḥ laggito ti sattaḥ vuttam ha etam satto satto iti
translated: They are not like that. To show this, the words “of one object” are stated.

original: bhante, vuccati, kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, ‘satto’ti vuccatīti? Rūpe kho, rādha,
analyzed: bhante vuccati kittāvatā nu kho bhante sattā iti vuccati iti rūpe kho rādha
translated: The word “creature” is the basic expression. The being who is attached to visible data, etc., is a “creature” . This is said: “‘Creature, creature,’ it is said, Bhante. In what way, Bhante, is one a creature? “ ‘Rādha, it is owing to eye and visible objects that a creature is said’ …

original: yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, tatra satto tatra visatto, tasmā ‘satto’ti vuccatī”ti.🔽Sattayogena vā satto. Sugatiduggatiṃ naratīti naro. Manuno puttoti mānavo. Upakaraṇena
analyzed: yā chandaḥ yā rāgaḥ yā nandī yā taṇhā tatra satto tatra visatto tasmā satto ti vuccati iti  satta yogena vā sattaḥ sugati duggatim narati iti naraḥ manuno putto ti mānavaḥ upakaraṇena
translated: “Whatever desire, whatever lust, whatever delight, whatever craving there is for that, he is bound to it, he is bound by that, thus he is called ‘a being’ .🔽Or alternatively, ‘being’ is in the sense of ‘being yoked to a destiny’ . ‘Man’ is one who is born in a happy destiny or a miserable one. ‘Manava’ is a son of Manu. ‘Puso’ is one who nourishes himself with requisites.

original: sayaṃ posayatīti poso. Puṃ vuccati nirayo, taṃ galatīti puggalo. Jīvitindriyaṃ dhāretīti
analyzed: sayam posayati iti poso pum vuccati nirayaḥ tam galati iti puggalaḥ jīvitindriyam dhāreti iti
translated: ‘Puggala’ is one who goes to hell, it seems. ‘Jīva’ is one who bears up the life faculty.

original: jīvo. Cutito jātiṃ gacchatīti jāgu. Jiyatīti jantu. Indriyena gacchatīti indagu.
analyzed: cutitaḥ jātim gacchati iti jāgu jiyati iti jantu indriyena gacchati iti indagu
translated: ‘Jantu’ is one who goes from death to birth. ‘Indagu’ is one who goes by means of the faculties.

original: Atha vā indabhūtena kammunā gacchatīti indagu. “Hindagū”tipi pāḷi. Hindanti maraṇaṃ,
analyzed: atha vai inda bhūtena kammunā gacchati iti hindanti maraṇam
translated: Or alternatively, ‘indagu’ is one who goes by means of kamma that has become the cause of the faculties. The reading is ‘hindagu.’

original: taṃ gacchatīti hindagu. Manuto jātoti manujo. Yaṃ sādiyatīti yaṃ rūpādiṃ assādiyati.
analyzed: tam gacchati iti manutaḥ jātaḥ iti manujaḥ yam sādiyati iti yam rūpa ādim
translated: ‘Hindagu’ is one who goes to death. ‘Manujo’ is one who is born of mind. ‘Yaṃsādī’ is one who delights in visible forms, etc.,

original: Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Ito paraṃ vuttamatthaṃ nigamento tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: sesam vutta nayam eva itas param vutta mattham tena āha bhagavā
translated: The rest is as already stated. And in order to conclude the meaning already stated he said:🔽‘When one who desires desires what is desirable, …

original: “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa…pe… laddhā macco yadicchatī”ti;
analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānaḥ sape laddhā maccaḥ yat icchati iti
translated: Having obtained what he wants, a man can do as he wishes’ .

original: Ito paraṃ ettakampi avatvā visesamattameva vakkhāma.
analyzed: itas param ettakam pi a vatvā visesa mattam eva vakkhāma
translated: From here on we shall explain only the difference, without repeating what is the same.

original: 2. Tassa ce kāmayānassāti tassa puggalassa kāme icchamānassa, kāmena vā yāyamānassa.🔽Chandajātassāti jātataṇhassa. Jantunoti sattassa. Te kāmā parihāyantīti te kāmā parihāyanti
analyzed: tassa ce kāmayānassa ati tassa puggalassa kāme icchamānassa kāmena vā yāyamānassa  chanda jātassa ati jāta taṇhassa jantunā iti sattassa te kāmā parihāyanti iti te kāmā parihāyanti
translated: ‘If he should wish for sensual desires’: if that person should wish for sensual desires, or if he should be desirous of sensual desires.🔽‘If he should be lust-inspired’: if he should be inspired with craving. ‘Of a being’: of a living being. ‘Those sensual desires of his would diminish’: those sensual desires of his would diminish.

original: ce. Sallaviddhova ruppatīti atha so ayomayādinā sallena viddho viya pīḷīyati. Ito
analyzed: ce salla viddhaḥ uva ruppati iti atha saḥ ayaḥ maya ādinā sallena viddhaḥ pīḍīyati itas
translated: ‘He would suffer as if pierced by a dart’: then he would suffer as if he were pierced by an iron dart, etc.

original: paraṃ vuttaṃ vajjetvā avuttesu yaṃ yaṃ anuttānaṃ, taṃ tadeva kathayissāmi.🔽Cakkhupīṇanaṃ ārammaṇaṃ pāpuṇanavasena yāyati gacchati. Dassanīyavasena piyattaṃ
analyzed: param vuttam vajjetvā a vuttesu yam yam anuttānam tam tat eva kathayissāmi  cakkhu pīṇanam ārammaṇam pāpuṇana vasena yāyati gacchati dassanīya vasena piyattam
translated: From here on I shall explain only those things that are not explained in the text, leaving out what is already explained.🔽‘He would go by means of the eye’: it goes by reaching the object by means of the eye’s distension. ‘It would be dear by means of the visible-form’: it is dear by means of the object.

original: ārammaṇavasena appāpetīti niyyati. Savanīyaṃ hutvā kaṇṇasotapīṇanaṃ ārammaṇavasena
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena appāpeti iti niyyati savanīyam hutvā kaṇṇa sota pīṇanam ārammaṇa vasena
translated: ‘It would lead by means of the object’: it leads by means of the object. ‘It would be borne along by means of the ear’: it is borne along by means of the ear’s distension by sound as object.

original: parikaḍḍhatīti vuyhati. Saritabbaṃ hutvā cittapīṇanaṃ ārammaṇavasena gahetvā upasaṃharīyatīti
analyzed: parikaḍḍhati iti vuyhati saritabbam hutvā citta pīṇanam ārammaṇa vasena gahetvā upasaṃharīyati iti
translated: ‘It would be drawn by means of the object’: it is drawn by means of the object. ‘It would be gathered by means of the mind’: it is gathered by means of the mind’s distension by the object.

original: saṃharīyati. Yathāti opammatthe nipāto. Hatthinā yāyati gacchatīti hatthiyānena vā,
analyzed: saṃharīyati yathā iti opamma atthe nipātaḥ hatthinā yāyati gacchati iti hatthi yānena vā
translated: ‘Just as’: the indeclinable yathā has the sense of simile. ‘He would go by means of the elephant’: he would go by means of the elephant as vehicle,

original: vāiti vikappatthe. Assena yāyati gacchatīti assayānena vā. Goyuttaṃ vayhādiyānaṃ
analyzed: vā iti vikappa atthe assena yāyati gacchati iti assa yānena vā go yuttam vayha ādi yānam
translated: Vāiti is a word of conjecture. Assena yāyati gacchatīti assayānena vā. Goyuttaṃ vayhādiyānaṃ

original: goyānaṃ, tena goyānena. Ajayānādīsupi eseva nayo. Iṭṭhavasena jāto sañjāto.
analyzed: goyānam tena goyānena ajayāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ iṭṭha vasena jāto sañjāto
translated: goyānaṃ, tena goyānena. Ajayānādīsupi eseva nayo. Iṭṭhavasena jāto sañjāto.

original: Ārammaṇapiyattavasena nibbatto abhinibbatto. Ārammaṇamanāpabhāvena pātubhūto. Atha
analyzed: ārammaṇa piyatta vasena nibbattaḥ abhinibbattaḥ ārammaṇa manāpa bhāvena pātubhūtaḥ atha
translated: Ārammaṇapiyattavasena nibbatto abhinibbatto. Ārammaṇamanāpabhāvena pātubhūto. Atha

original: vā kāmarāgavasena jāto sañjāto. Kāmanandivasena nibbatto abhinibbatto. Kāmataṇhāvasena
analyzed: vā kāma rāga vasena jātaḥ sañjātaḥ kāma nandi vasena nibbattaḥ abhinibbattaḥ kāma taṇhā vasena
translated: vā kāmarāgavasena jāto sañjāto. Kāmanandivasena nibbatto abhinibbatto. Kāmataṇhāvasena

original: kāmasinehavasena kāmacchandavasena kāmapariḷāhavasena ca pātubhūtoti veditabbo.
analyzed: kāma sineha vasena kāma chanda vasena kāma pariḷāha vasena ca pātubhūtaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: kāmasinehavasena kāmacchandavasena kāmapariḷāhavasena ca pātubhūtoti veditabbo.

original: Te vā kāmā parihāyantīti te vatthukāmādayo parihāyanti vigacchanti. So vā kāmehi
analyzed: te vā kāmā parihāyanti iti te vatthu kāma ādayo parihāyanti vigacchanti saḥ vā kāmehi
translated: Te vā kāmā parihāyantīti te vatthukāmādayo parihāyanti vigacchanti. So vā kāmehi

original: parihāyatīti eso khattiyādipuggalo vatthukāmādikāmehi parihāyati vigacchati “pubbeva
analyzed: parihāyati iti esaḥ khattiya ādi puggalaḥ vatthu kāma ādi kāmehi parihāyati vigacchati pubbe eva
translated: parihāyatīti eso khattiyādipuggalo vatthukāmādikāmehi parihāyati vigacchati “pubbeva

original: maccaṃ vijahanti bhogā, macco dhane pubbataraṃ jahātī”ti evamādīsu viya. Kathanti
analyzed: maccam vijahanti bhogāḥ maccaḥ dhane pubbataram jahāti iti evamādīsu viya kathanti
translated: maccaṃ vijahanti bhogā, macco dhane pubbataraṃ jahātī”ti evamādīsu viya. Kathanti

original: kena pakārena. Tiṭṭhantassevāti dharantasseva. Te bhogeti te vatthukāmādayo bhoge.
analyzed: kena pakārena tiṭṭhantassa eva ati dharantassa eva te bhoge ti te vatthu kāma ādayaḥ bhoge
translated: In what way? “While they stand still”: while they remain as they are. “Those goods”: those goods consisting of material things, etc.

original: Rājāno vāti pathabyādirājāno. Harantīti gahetvā gacchanti, apaharanti vā. Corā vāti
analyzed: rājānaḥ vāti pathabya ādi rājānaḥ haranti iti gahetvā gacchanti apaharanti vā corāḥ vāti
translated: “Kings”: kings of the earth, etc. “Carry off”: seize and take away, or they carry off by force. “Thieves”:

original: sandhicchedādikā. Aggi vāti dāvaggiādi. Dahatīti jhāpeti bhasmaṃ karoti. Udakaṃ vāti
analyzed: sandhi cheda ādikāḥ aggi vāti dāva aggi ādi dahati iti bhasmam karoti udakam vāti
translated: those who break into houses, etc. “Fire”: forest fire, etc. “Burns”: it consumes, reduces to ashes. “Water”:

original: oghādiudakaṃ. Vahatīti gahetvā mahāsamuddaṃ pāpeti. Appiyā vāti akantā amanāpā. Dāyādā
analyzed: ogha ādi udakam vahati iti gahetvā mahā samuddam pāpā iti appiyā vāti akantā amanāpā dāyādā
translated: flood water, etc. “Carries off”: it seizes and carries away to the great ocean. “Enemies”: those who are unloved, disagreeable. “Heirs”:

original: harantīti dāyajjavirahitā assāmikā haranti. Nihitaṃ vāti nidhānaṃ katvā ṭhapitaṃ.
analyzed: haranti iti dāyajja virahitāḥ a ssāmikāḥ haranti nihitam vā ati nidhānam katvā ṭhapitam
translated: those who take away without being owners, without being entitled to the inheritance. “What is stored away”: what is kept as a treasure.

original: Nādhigacchatīti na vindati na paṭilabhati, na passatīti attho. Duppayuttāti visamapayogena
analyzed: na adhigacchati iti na vindati na paṭilabhati na passati iti atthaḥ duppayuttā ati visama payogena
translated: “He does not get”: he does not find, does not obtain; the meaning is, he does not see. “Unprofitable ventures”: ventures that are undertaken in an improper way,

original: yojitā kasivāṇijjādikammantā. Bhijjantīti bhedaṃ pāpuṇanti, na pavattantīti attho.
analyzed: yojitā kasi vāṇijja ādi kammantāḥ bhijjanti iti bhedam pāpuṇanti na pavattanti iti attho
translated: such as agriculture, trade, etc. “Fail”: they come to ruin; the meaning is, they do not succeed.

original: “Bhañjanti rathaṃ ayānakā”tiādīsu sambhavo veditabbo.
analyzed: bhañjanti ratham ayānakāti ādīsu sambhavaḥ veditabbo
translated: “The chariot breaks down, the horses are lost” , etc. The meaning of “to be” should be understood here in the sense of “to be possible.”

original: Kule vā kulaṅgāro uppajjatīti khattiyādikule kulajhāpako kule antimapuriso nibbattati.
analyzed: kule vā kulaṅgāraḥ uppajjati iti khattiya ādi kule kula jhāpakaḥ kule antima purisaḥ nibbattati
translated: He is born in a clan as a clan-polluter: he is born as the last man in a clan of nobles, etc., as a destroyer of the clan.🔽The reading is also kulaṅkaro.

original: “Kulaṅkaro”tipi pāḷi. Yo te bhoge vikiratīti yo eso kule pacchimako te hiraññādike🔽bhoge khepeti. Vidhamatīti viyogaṃ karoti, dūre khipati. Viddhaṃsetīti nāseti adassanaṃ🔽gameti. Atha vā itthidhutto hutvā vikirati. Surādhutto hutvā vidhamati. Akkhadhutto
analyzed: yaḥ te bhoge vikirati iti yaḥ eso kule te hirañña ādike  bhoge khepeti vidhamati iti viyogam karoti dūre khipati adassanam  gama iti atha vā itthi dhuttaḥ hutvā vikirati surā dhuttaḥ hutvā vidhamati akkha dhuttaḥ
translated: He squanders your wealth: this last man in the clan squanders your wealth consisting of gold, etc.🔽He scatters it: he makes it disappear, he sends it far away. He dissipates it: he destroys it, he causes it to vanish.

original: hutvā viddhaṃseti. Vikirati vā uppannaṃ āyaṃ ajānanena. Vidhamati vissajjanamukhaṃ
analyzed: hutvā viddhaṃseti vikirati vā uppannam āyam a jānanena vidhamati vissajjana mukham
translated: Or else, he squanders it by being a drunkard, a gambler, a womanizer. He scatters it by being a drunkard. He dissipates it by being a gambler. He dissipates it by being a womanizer.

original: ajānanena. Viddhaṃseti ṭhapitaṭṭhāne ārakkhaṃ asaṃvidhānenāti evamādinā yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: a jānanena viddha ṃse ti ṭhapita ṭṭhāne ārakkham a saṃvidhānena ati evamādinā yojetabbam
translated: Or else, he squanders it by not knowing the income. He scatters it by not knowing the outlets. He dissipates it by not making provision for storage.🔽The eighth is impermanence: the eighth is the state of dissolution.

original: Aniccatāyeva aṭṭhamīti vināsabhāvo eva aṭṭhamo. Hāyantīti adassanaṃ yanti. Parihāyantīti
analyzed: anicca tāya iva aṭṭhamā iti vināsa bhāvaḥ eva aṭṭhamaḥ hāyanti iti adassanam yanti parihāyanti iti
translated: They disappear: they vanish. They are lost:

original: na puna paññāyanti. Paridhaṃsentīti ṭhānato apagacchanti. Paripatantīti paggharanti.
analyzed: na puna paññāyanti paridhaṃsenti iti ṭhānataḥ apagacchanti paripatanti iti paggharanti
translated: they are not seen again. They are scattered: they are removed from their place. They are dispersed: they are scattered about.

original: Antaradhāyantīti antaradhānaṃ adassanaṃ gacchanti. Vippalujjantīti cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā apagacchanti.
analyzed: antaradhāyanti iti antaradhānam a dassanam gacchanti vippalujjanti iti cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā apagacchanti
translated: They disappear: they vanish, become invisible. They break up: they go away in bits and pieces.

original: Tiṭṭhanteva te bhogeti tesaṃ dhanānaṃ ṭhitakāle “tiṭṭhante nibbute cāpī”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: tiṭṭhante iva te bhoge iti tesam dhanānam ṭhita kāle tiṭṭhante nibbute ca api iti evamādīsu
translated: They remain as they were: they remain as they were when they were acquired.

original: viya. Soti so bhogasāmiko puggalo. Cavati devalokato. Marati manussalokato. Vippalujjati
analyzed: viya so ti so bhoga sāmiko puggalo cavati deva lokataḥ marati manussa lokataḥ vippalujjati
translated: He: the owner of the wealth. He sinks: he sinks from the world of the gods. He dies: he dies from the human world. He breaks up:

original: nāgasupaṇṇādilokato. Atha vā hāyati dhaññakoṭṭhāgāravasena. Parihāyati dhanakoṭṭhāgāravasena.
analyzed: nāga supaṇṇa ādi lokataḥ atha vā hāyati dhañña koṭṭhāgāra vasena parihāyati dhana koṭṭhāgāra vasena
translated: he breaks up from the worlds of the nāgas, supaṇṇas, and so on. Or else: he diminishes in terms of his store of grain; he is diminished in terms of his store of wealth;

original: Paridhaṃsati balibaddahatthiassādivasena. Paripatati dāsidāsavasena. Antaradhāyati
analyzed: paridhaṃsati bali badda hatthi assa ādi vasena paripatati dāsi dāsa vasena antaradhāyati
translated: he is destroyed in terms of his store of cattle, slaves, elephants, horses, and so on; he is dispersed in terms of his store of female and male slaves; he disappears

original: dārābharaṇavasena. Nassati udakādivasenāti eke vaṇṇayanti.🔽Ayomayenāti kāḷalohādinibbattena. Sallenāti kaṇḍena. Aṭṭhimayenāti manussaṭṭhiṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: dāra ābharaṇa vasena nassati udaka ādi vasena ati eke vaṇṇayanti  ayaḥ mayena ati kāḷa loha ādi nibbattena sallena ati kaṇḍena aṭṭhi mayena ati manussa ṭṭhim ṭhapetvā
translated: in terms of his store of wives and ornaments; he is lost in terms of his store of water, and so on.🔽Made of iron: made of black iron and so on. With a spike: with a spike on top. Made of bone: made of any bone

original: avasesena. Dantamayenāti hatthidantādinā. Visāṇamayenāti govisāṇādinā. Kaṭṭhamayenāti
analyzed: avasesena danta mayena ati hatthi danta ādinā visāṇa mayena ati go visāṇa ādinā kaṭṭha mayena ati
translated: except human bone. Made of ivory: made of elephant tusk and so on. Made of wood:

original: veḷukaṭṭhādinā. Viddhoti vuttappakārasallānaṃ aññataraññatarena pahaṭo. Ruppatīti
analyzed: veḷu kaṭṭha ādinā viddhaḥ ti vutta ppakāra sallānam aññatara aññatarena pahaṭaḥ ruppati iti
