analyzed: tatiya magga vasena patareyya catuttha magga vasena samatikkameyya phala vasena vītivatteyya ati
translated: he crosses through by means of the third path, he gets completely across by means of the fourth path, and he goes beyond by means of the fruition.

original: Atha vā “kāmoghavasena tareyya, bhavoghavasena uttareyya, diṭṭhoghavasena patareyya,
analyzed: atha vā kāma ogha vasena tareyya bhava ogha vasena uttareyya diṭṭha ogha vasena patareyya
translated: Or alternatively, he crosses by means of the flood of sensual desire, he crosses over by means of the flood of becoming, he crosses through by means of the flood of views,

original: avijjoghavasena samatikkameyya, sabboghavasena vītivatteyyā”ti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: avijja ogha vasena samatikkameyya sabba ogha vasena vītivatteyya ati evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: Some commentators explain the passage thus: “He would cross over the flood of ignorance by means of the noble path, and he would emerge from all the floods by means of the fruition of the path.”

original: Garukanti na sallahukaṃ. Bhārikanti bhārabhaṇḍaṃ ettha ṭhapayantīti bhārikaṃ. Udakaṃ🔽sitvāti udakaṃ siñcitvā. Osiñcitvāti atirekaṃ siñcitvā. Chaḍḍetvāti pātetvā. Lahukāyāti
analyzed: garukanti na sat lahukam bhārikanti bhārabhaṇḍam ettha ṭhapayanti iti bhārikam udakam  sitvā ati udakam siñcitvā osiñcitvā ati atirekam siñcitvā chaḍḍetvā ati pātetvā lahukāya ati
translated: Heavy: not light. Laden: a laden vehicle is called bhārika because it is placed on the back .🔽Having watered the feet: having sprinkled water over the feet. Having washed the feet: having washed the feet well. Having put away: having laid aside. With a light heart: with a light, i.e., unconcerned, mind.

original: sallahukāya. Khippanti sīghaṃ. Lahunti taṃkhaṇaṃ. Appakasirenevāti nidukkheneva.
analyzed: sallahukāya khippanti sīgham lahunti taṃkhaṇam appa kasirena iva ati nidukkhena iva
translated: Swiftly: quickly. Lightly: at that moment. With little difficulty: with little trouble.🔽The other shore is called the deathless Nibbāna: the other shore is Nibbāna, which is the opposite of the near shore of the round of rebirths.

original: Pāraṃ vuccati amataṃ nibbānanti sakkāyaorato pārabhūtaṃ pāraṃ. Taṇhāvānato nikkhantaṃ🔽nibbānaṃ kathīyati. Yosoti yo eso. Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādi sabbaṃ nibbānameva.
analyzed: pāram vuccati amatam nibbānan ti sakkāya orataḥ pāra bhūtam pāram taṇhā vānataḥ nikkhantam  nibbānam kathīyati yosaḥ ti yaḥ esaḥ sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ tiādi sabbam nibbānam eva
translated: The one who has crossed over: the one who has crossed over from the near shore of craving to the other shore of Nibbāna.🔽All formations have come to rest: all formations have come to rest, i.e., have been stilled, in Nibbāna.🔽All clinging is abandoned: all clinging is abandoned in Nibbāna.

original: Yasmā hi taṃ āgamma sabbasaṅkhāravipphanditāni samanti vūpasamanti, tasmā “sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti🔽vuccati. Yasmā cetaṃ āgamma sabbe upadhayo paṭinissaṭṭhā honti, sabbā taṇhā khīyanti,
analyzed: yasmā hi tam āgamma sabba saṅkhāra vipphanditāni samanti vūpasamanti tasmā sabba saṅkhāra samatha uti 🔽vuccati yasmai cetaṃ āgamma sabbe upadhayaḥ paṭinissaṭṭhāḥ honti sabbā taṇhā khīyanti
translated: All craving is destroyed: all craving is destroyed in Nibbāna.

original: sabbe kilesarajjā virajjanti, sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, tasmā “sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo,🔽taṇhakkhayo, virāgo, nirodho”ti vuccati. Yā panesā taṇhā bhavena bhavaṃ, phalena
analyzed: sabbe kilesa rajjāḥ virajjanti sabbam dukkham nirujjhati tasmā sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo  taṇhā khayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodho ti vuccati yā pana esā taṇhā bhavena bhavam phalena
translated: all the kings of defilement fade away, all suffering ceases. That is why it is called “the relinquishing of all conceivings,🔽the destruction of craving, fading away, cessation.” But this craving, which is called “the fetter of becoming,” is said to “lead to” becoming, either together with kamma as its fruit,

original: vā saddhiṃ kammaṃ vinati saṃsibbatīti katvā vānanti vuccati, tato nikkhantaṃ vānatoti🔽nibbānaṃ. Pāraṃ gaccheyya nimittavasena ekato vuṭṭhānagotrabhuñāṇena nibbānapāraṃ
analyzed: vā saddhim kammam vinati saṃsibbati iti katvā vānanti vuccati tatas nikkhantam vānato ti  nibbānam pāram gaccheyya nimitta vasena ekatas vuṭṭhāna gotra bhuñāṇena nibbāna pāram
translated: or else as the outcome of kamma. So Nibbāna is said to be “beyond the leadings” .🔽He would reach the further shore by means of the path knowledge of the first emergence from the jhāna that has the sign as its object.

original: pāpuṇeyya. Adhigaccheyya nimittapavattehi ubhatovuṭṭhānamaggañāṇena nibbānapāraṃ🔽visesena pāpuṇeyya. Phuseyya nibbānārammaṇaphalacittavasena nibbānapāraṃ phuseyya.
analyzed: pāpuṇeyya adhigaccheyya nimitta pavattehi ubhatas vuṭṭhāna magga ñāṇena nibbāna pāram  visesena pāpuṇeyya phuseyya nibbāna ārammaṇa phala citta vasena nibbāna pāram phuseyya
translated: He would reach the further shore by means of the path knowledge of the second emergence from the jhāna that has the process as its object.🔽He would touch the further shore by means of the fruition consciousness that has Nibbāna as its object.

original: Sacchikareyya guṇavasena phusitvā paccavekkhaṇañāṇena nibbānapāraṃ paccakkhaṃ kareyya.
analyzed: sacchikareyya guṇa vasena phusitvā paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena nibbāna pāram paccakkham kareyya
translated: He would realize the further shore by means of the knowledge of reviewing that has the special qualities of Nibbāna as its object.

original: Atha vā “paṭhamamaggena pāraṃ gaccheyya, dutiyena adhigaccheyya, tatiyena phuseyya,
analyzed: atha vā paṭhama maggena pāram gaccheyya dutiyena adhigaccheyya tatiyena phuseyya
translated: Or alternatively, he would reach the further shore by means of the first path,

original: catutthena sacchi kareyyā”ti evameke vaṇṇayanti. Yopi pāraṃ gantukāmoti yo koci vipassanāñāṇe
analyzed: catutthena sacchi kareyya iti evam eke vaṇṇayanti yaḥ api pāram gantu kāmo ti yaḥ koci vipassanā ñāṇe
translated: Some commentators explain the fourth as one who has made truth his raft.

original: ṭhito puggalo nibbānapāraṃ gantukāmo, sopi avassaṃ tattha gamissatīti pāragū. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ puggalaḥ nibbāna pāram gantu kāmo saḥ api avassam tattha gamissati iti pāragū vuttam ha etam
translated: “One who would cross over” is a person who is established in insight knowledge and who would cross over to the further shore of Nibbāna. He too is one who has crossed over. For this is said:

original: – “otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehī”tiādi.
analyzed: otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi itiādi
translated: “I have crossed over birth, ageing, and death; sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair; I have here and now attained to that supreme goal of the holy life for the sake of which clansmen rightly go forth from the home life into homelessness” .

original: Pubbabhāge ajjhāsayavasena vipassanāyogena ca, sopi pāragū nāma. Yopi pāraṃ gacchatīti🔽yopi maggasamaṅgī nibbānapāraṃ gacchati, sopi pāragū nāma. Yopi pāraṃ gatoti yopi
analyzed: pubba bhāge ajjhāsaya vasena vipassanā yogena ca saḥ api pāragū nāma yaḥ api pāram gacchati iti  yaḥ api magga samaṅgī nibbāna pāram gacchati saḥ api pāragū nāma yaḥ api pāram gataḥ iti yaḥ api
translated: And in the earlier stage, too, he is called one who has crossed over in the sense of the aspiration and in the sense of the development of insight.🔽“One who is crossing over” is one who is crossing over to the further shore of Nibbāna by means of the path. He too is one who has crossed over.

original: maggena kiccaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā phale ṭhito nibbānapāraṅgato, sopi pāragū nāma.
analyzed: maggena kiccam niṭṭhāpetvā phale ṭhitaḥ nibbāna pāraṅgato saḥ api pāragū nāma
translated: “One who has crossed over” is one who has reached the further shore of Nibbāna by completing his task with the path and who is established in fruition. He too is one who has crossed over.

original: Taṃ jinavacanena dassetuṃ “vuttampi hetaṃ bhagavatā – tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati
analyzed: tam jina vacanena dassetum vuttam api ha itam bhagavatā pāraṅgataḥ thale tiṭṭhati
translated: In order to show this by means of the word of the Conqueror, he said, “This has been said by the Blessed One: ‘The brahmin who has crossed over doubt, who has risen above all fetters, who has laid aside the rod against all beings, who has gone to the further shore—he is a brahmin indeed’ .

original: brāhmaṇo”tiādimāha. Abhiññāpāragūti adhigatena ñāṇena ñātapariññāya nibbānapāraṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇa uti ādim āha abhiññā pāragū ti adhigatena ñāṇena ñāta pariññāya nibbāna pāram
translated: “One who has crossed over by knowledge” is one who has crossed over to the further shore of Nibbāna by means of the knowledge that has been attained, by the full understanding through knowledge.

original: gantukāmo gacchati, gatoti pāragū. Pariññāpāragūti sabbadhammānaṃ tīraṇapariññāya
analyzed: gantu kāmaḥ gacchati gataḥ iti pāragū pariññā pāragū ti sabba dhammānam tīraṇa pariññāya
translated: He who wants to go goes, and when he has gone he is called “gone across.” He who has gone across to full understanding is one who has gone across by the full understanding of the crossing of all things,

original: samatikkamitvā vuttanayena pāragū. Pahānapāragūti samudayapakkhikānaṃ kilesānaṃ pahānapariññāya
analyzed: samatikkamitvā vutta nayena pāragū pahāna pāragū ti samudaya pakkhikānam kilesānam pahāna pariññāya
translated: and he is called “gone across” in the way already stated by surmounting. He who has gone across to abandoning is one who has gone across by the full understanding of the abandoning of the defilements on the side of the origin

original: samatikkamitvā vuttanayena pāragū. Yo hi sabbadhammaṃ parijānāti, so tīhi pariññāhi
analyzed: samatikkamitvā vutta nayena pāragū yaḥ hi sabba dhammam parijānāti saḥ tīhi pariññāhi
translated: and he is called “gone across” in the way already stated by surmounting. For he who fully understands all things fully understands them by means of the three full understandings,

original: parijānāti ñātapariññāya tīraṇapariññāya pahānapariññāyāti. Tattha katamā ñātapariññā?
analyzed: parijānāti ñāta pariññāya tīraṇa pariññāya pahāna pariññāya ati tattha katamā ñāta pariññā
translated: that is to say, by the full understanding of what is to be directly known, by the full understanding of the crossing, and by the full understanding of abandoning. Herein, what is the full understanding of what is to be directly known?

original: Sabbadhammaṃ jānāti “ime ajjhattikā, ime bāhirā, idamassa lakkhaṇaṃ, imāni rasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānānī”ti,🔽ayaṃ ñātapariññā. Katamā tīraṇapariññā? Evaṃ ñātaṃ katvā labbhamānavasena sabbadhammaṃ
analyzed: sabba dhammam jānāti ime ajjhattikāḥ ime bāhirāḥ idam assa lakkhaṇam imāni rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānāni iti  ayam ñāta pariññā katamā tīraṇa pariññā evam ñātam katvā labbhamāna vasena sabba dhammam
translated: He knows all things thus: “These are the internal, these are the external; this is their characteristic, this their manifestation, this their function, this their incidence, this their delimitation, this their proximate cause, this their consequence, this their fruit, this their outcome” .

original: tīreti “aniccato dukkhato rogato”tiādinā, ayaṃ tīraṇapariññā. Katamā pahānapariññā?
analyzed: tīre ti aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogato ti ādinā ayam tīraṇa pariññā katamā pahāna pariññā
translated: This is the full understanding of what is to be directly known. What is the full understanding of the crossing? Having known all things thus, he crosses them by means of the crossing called the three contemplations, that is, by the contemplation of impermanence, the contemplation of pain, and the contemplation of not-self. This is the full understanding of the crossing. What is the full understanding of abandoning?

original: Evaṃ tīrayitvā aggamaggena dhammesu chandarāgaṃ pajahati, ayaṃ pahānapariññāti. Imā
analyzed: evam tīrayitvā agga maggena dhammesu chanda rāgam pajahati ayam pahāna pariññā ati imā
translated: Having thus crossed over, he abandons desire and lust for the Dhamma by means of the path of arahatship. This is the full understanding of abandoning.

original: pariññāyo sandhāya “so abhiññāpāragū pariññāpāragū pahānapāragū”ti āha.🔽Bhāvanāpāragūti bhāvanāya koṭiṃ patvā maggavasena nibbānapāraṃ gato. Sacchikiriyāpāragūti
analyzed: sandhāya saḥ abhiññā pāragū pariññā pāragū pahāna pāragū ti āha  bhāvanā pāragū ti bhāvanāya koṭim patvā magga vasena nibbāna pāram gataḥ sacchikiriyā pāragū ti
translated: With reference to these kinds of full understanding, the Exalted One said: “He has reached the peak of full understanding, the peak of the state of peace” .🔽He has reached the peak of development : having reached the peak of development by means of the path, he has gone to the other shore of nibbana. He has reached the peak of realization : having reached the other shore of the fruit of realization and nibbana,

original: phalanibbānavasena sacchi kiriyāphalanibbānapāraṃ gato. Samāpattipāragūti aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: phala nibbāna vasena sacchi kiriyā phala nibbāna pāram gataḥ samāpatti pāragū ti aṭṭhannam
translated: he has reached the peak of attainment : having reached the other shore of the eight attainments,

original: samāpattīnaṃ pāraṃ patto. Sabbadhammānanti pañcakkhandhādisabbadhammānaṃ. Sabbadukkhānanti
analyzed: samāpattīnam pāram pattaḥ sabba dhammānam ti pañca kkhandha ādi sabba dhammānam sabba dukkhānam ti
translated: he has reached the peak of all dhammas : having reached the other shore of all dhammas, such as the five aggregates, etc.,🔽he has reached the peak of all suffering : having reached the other shore of all suffering, such as the suffering of birth, etc.,

original: jātidukkhādisabbadukkhānaṃ. Sabbakilesānanti kāyaduccaritādisabbakilesānaṃ. Ariyamaggānanti
analyzed: jāti dukkha ādi sabba dukkhānam sabba kilesānam ti kāya duccarita ādi sabba kilesānam ariya maggānam ti
translated: he has reached the peak of all defilements : having reached the other shore of all defilements, such as bodily misconduct, etc.,🔽he has reached the peak of the noble paths : having reached the other shore of the four noble paths, such as the path of stream-entry, etc.,

original: sotāpattimaggādicatunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ. Nirodhassāti nibbānassa. Sabbasamāpattīnanti
analyzed: sotāpatti magga ādi catunnam ariya maggānam nirodhassa ati nibbānassa sabba samāpattīnam
translated: he has reached the peak of cessation : having reached the other shore of nibbana,🔽he has reached the peak of all attainments : having reached the other shore of all eight attainments, both material and immaterial,

original: sabbāsampi aṭṭhannaṃ rūpārūpasamāpattīnaṃ. Soti so ariyo. Vasippattoti vasībhāvappatto.
analyzed: sabbāsam pi aṭṭhannam rūpa arūpa samāpattīnam saḥ ti so ariyaḥ vasi patto ti vasībhāva ppatto
translated: he, the noble one, has reached mastery : having reached the state of mastery.

original: Atha vā kantabhāvaṃ issariyabhāvaṃ nipphannabhāvaṃ patto. Pāramippattoti pāramīti
analyzed: atha vā kanta bhāvam issariya bhāvam nipphanna bhāvam patto pārami patto ti pāramī iti
translated: Or else he has reached the state of being lovable, the state of being a lord, the state of being fulfilled. He has reached perfection :

original: avasānaṃ niṭṭhānaṃ, uttamabhāvaṃ vā taṃ patto. Kattha pattoti āha “ariyasmiṃ sīlasmi”ntiādi.
analyzed: avasānam niṭṭhānam uttama bhāvam vā tam patto kattha patto ti āha ariyasmin sīlasmin tiādi
translated: Perfection is the end, the conclusion, the state of being supreme. He has reached that. Where has he reached it? He has reached it in noble virtue, etc.

original: Tattha ariyasmiṃ sīlasminti niddose sīlasmiṃ. Ariyasmiṃ samādhisminti niddose samādhismiṃ.
analyzed: tattha ariyasmin sīlasmin ti niddose sīlasmin ariyasmin samādhismin ti niddose samādhismin
translated: Herein, in noble virtue is in virtue free from blemish. In noble concentration is in concentration free from blemish.

original: Ariyāya paññāyāti niddosāya paññāya. Ariyāya vimuttiyāti niddosāya phalavimuttiyā.
analyzed: ariyāya paññāya ati niddosāya paññāya ariyāya vimuttiyā ati niddosāya phala vimuttiyā
translated: In noble wisdom is in wisdom free from blemish. In noble deliverance is in fruition deliverance free from blemish.

original: Purimena vācākammantājīvā gahitā, dutiyena vāyāmasatisamādhayo gahitā, tatiyena vitakkasammādiṭṭhiyo
analyzed: purimena vācā kammanta ājīvāḥ gahitāḥ dutiyena vāyāma sati samādhayaḥ gahitā tatiyena vitakka sammādiṭṭhiyo
translated: Or alternatively, the first line includes speech, action, and livelihood, the second includes energy, mindfulness, and concentration, the third includes thinking, investigation, and view,

original: gahitā, catutthena taṃsampayuttā sesadhammā gahitāti veditabbā.🔽Antagatoti maggena saṅkhāralokantaṃ gato. Antappattoti tameva lokantaṃ phalena patto.
analyzed: gahitā catutthena tad sampayuttā sesa dhammā gahitā ati veditabbā  anta gataḥ ti maggena saṅkhāra loka antam gataḥ anta patto ti tam eva loka antam phalena patto
translated: and the fourth includes the remaining states associated with them.🔽He has gone to the end of suffering : he has gone to the end of the world of formations by means of the path. He has reached the end of the world : he has reached that end of the world by means of fruition.

original: Koṭigatoti maggena saṅkhārakoṭiṃ gato. Koṭippattoti tameva koṭiṃ phalena patto. Pariyantagatoti
analyzed: koṭi gataḥ ti maggena saṅkhāra koṭim gataḥ koṭippatto ti tam eva koṭim phalena patto pariyanta gataḥ ti
translated: He has gone to the end of the round :

original: maggena khandhāyatanādilokapariyantaṃ paricchedaṃ parivaṭumaṃ katvā gato. Pariyantappattoti
analyzed: maggena khandha āyatana ādi loka pariyantam paricchedam parivaṭumam katvā gataḥ pariyanta ppatto ti
translated: He has gone by the path to the end of the aggregates, bases, etc., to the end of the world. He has reached the end of the world:

original: tameva lokaṃ phalena pariyantaṃ katvā patto. Vosānagatoti maggena avasānaṃ gato.🔽Vosānappattoti phalena avasānaṃ patto. Tāṇagatoti maggena tāyanaṃ gato. Tāṇappattoti🔽phalena tāyanaṃ patto. Leṇagatoti maggena nilīyanaṃ gato. Leṇappattoti taṃ phalena
analyzed: tam eva lokam phalena pariyantam katvā pattaḥ vosāna gataḥ ti maggena avasānam gataḥ  vosāna patto ti phalena avasānam patto tāṇa gataḥ ti maggena tāyanam gataḥ tāṇa patto ti  phalena tāyanam patto leṇa gato ti maggena nilīyanam gataḥ leṇa ppatto ti tam phalena
translated: he has reached the end of the world with its three planes as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the end of craving: he has gone to the end of craving with the end of suffering. He has reached the end of craving:🔽he has reached the end of craving with the end of suffering as the fruit of the path. He has gone to safety: he has gone to safety with the path. He has reached safety:🔽he has reached safety with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the shelter: he has gone to the shelter with the path. He has reached the shelter:

original: nilīyanaṃ patto. Saraṇagatoti maggena patiṭṭhaṃ gato. Saraṇappattoti phalena saraṇaṃ🔽patto. Abhayagatoti maggena nibbhayaṃ gato. Abhayappattoti phalena nibbhayaṃ nibbānaṃ🔽patto. Accutagatoti cutivirahitaṃ nibbānaṃ maggena gato. Accutappattoti taṃ phalena
analyzed: nilīyanam patto saraṇa gato ti maggena patiṭṭham gato saraṇa ppatto ti phalena saraṇam  pattaḥ abhaya gataḥ iti maggena nibbhayam gataḥ abhaya ppattaḥ iti phalena nibbhayam nibbānam  pattaḥ accuta gataḥ ti cuti virahitam nibbānam maggena gataḥ accuta ppatto ti tam phalena
translated: he has reached the shelter with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the refuge: he has gone to the refuge with the path. He has reached the refuge:🔽he has reached the refuge with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the fearlessness: he has gone to the fearlessness with the path. He has reached the fearlessness:🔽he has reached the fearlessness with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the immovable: he has gone to the immovable with the path. He has reached the immovable:

original: patto. Amatagatoti maraṇarahitaṃ nibbānaṃ maggena gato. Amatappattoti taṃ phalena
analyzed: pattaḥ amatagataḥ ti maraṇa rahitam nibbānam maggena gataḥ amata ppatto ti tam phalena
translated: he has reached the immovable with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path. He has gone to the undying: he has gone to the undying with the path. He has reached the undying:🔽he has reached the undying with Nibbāna as the fruit of the path.

original: patto. Nibbānagatoti taṇhāvānato nikkhantaṃ nibbānaṃ maggena gato. Nibbānappattoti
analyzed: pattaḥ nibbāna gataḥ ti taṇhā vānataḥ nikkhantam nibbānam maggena gataḥ nibbāna ppatto ti
translated: Gone to Nibbāna: gone by the path to Nibbāna, which is the escape from craving. Reached Nibbāna: reached it by the fruition.🔽He is one who has lived the life: he is one who has lived, who has dwelt, in the ten dwellings of the ariyans.

original: tameva phalena patto. So vuṭṭhavāsoti so arahā dasasu ariyavāsesu vasi parivasi vuṭṭho
analyzed: tam eva phalena patto saḥ vuṭṭhavāsaḥ ti so arahā dasasu ariya vāsesu vasi parivasi vuṭṭhaḥ
translated: He is one who has lived the life. He has done what had to be done: he is one who has done what had to be done in the eight attainments together with virtue.🔽He has done what had to be done. He has laid down the burden: he is one who has laid down the burden of defilements.🔽He has reached his own goal: he is one who has reached the goal of the eight attainments together with virtue.

original: vuṭṭhāti ca vuṭṭhavāso. Ciṇṇacaraṇoti sīlena saha aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu ciṇṇavasīti🔽ciṇṇacaraṇo. Gataddhoti saṃsāraddhānaṃ atikkanto. Gatadisoti supinantenapi agatapubbaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhā ati ca vuṭṭha vāso ciṇṇa caraṇo ti sīlena saha aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu  ciṇṇa caraṇaḥ gataddhaḥ ti saṃsāraddhānam atikkantaḥ gata disaḥ iti supin antena api a gata pubbam
translated: He has reached his own goal. He has destroyed the fetters of being: he is one who has destroyed the fetters of being in the eight attainments together with virtue.🔽He has destroyed the fetters of being. He has passed beyond suffering: he is one who has passed beyond suffering, which is the destruction of cankers.

original: nibbānadisaṃ gato. Gatakoṭikoti anupādisesanibbānakoṭiṃ gato hutvā ṭhito. Pālitabrahmacariyoti
analyzed: nibbāna disam gataḥ gata koṭiko ti anupādisesa nibbāna koṭim gataḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ pālita brahmacariyaḥ ti
translated: He has passed beyond suffering. He has reached the highest goal: he is one who has reached the highest goal, which is the destruction of cankers.

original: rakkhitabrahmacariyo. Uttamadiṭṭhippattoti uttamaṃ sammādiṭṭhiṃ patto. Paṭividdhākuppoti
analyzed: rakkhita brahmacariyaḥ uttama diṭṭhi patto ti uttamam sammādiṭṭhim patto paṭividdha akuppaḥ ti
translated: He has reached the highest goal. He has attained the highest benefit: he is one who has attained the highest benefit, which is the destruction of cankers.🔽He has attained the highest benefit. He has laid down the rod: he is one who has laid down the rod of violence towards all beings.🔽He has laid down the rod. He has thrown off the burden: he is one who has thrown off the burden of defilements.🔽He has thrown off the burden. He has unyoked: he is one who has unyoked from the yoke of kamma- formations.

original: akuppaṃ acalanaṃ arahattaphalaṃ paṭivijjhitvā ṭhito. Sacchikatanirodhoti nirodhaṃ
analyzed: akuppam acalanam arahatta phalam paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaḥ sacchikata nirodho ti nirodham
translated: He has unyoked. He has attained to the destruction of the cankers: he is one who has attained to the destruction of the cankers, which is the destruction of suffering.

original: nibbānaṃ sacchikatvā ṭhito.
analyzed: nibbānam sacchikatvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: He has attained to the destruction of the cankers.

original: Dukkhaṃ tassa pariññātanti tividhaṃ dukkhaṃ tena samatikkamitvā paricchinnaṃ. Abhiññeyyanti🔽sabhāvalakkhaṇāvabodhavasena sobhanena ākārena jānitabbaṃ. Abhiññātanti adhikena
analyzed: dukkham tassa pariññātanti tividham dukkham tena samatikkamitvā paricchinnam abhiññeyyanti  sabhāva lakkhaṇa avabodha vasena sobhanena ākārena jānitabbam abhiññātanti adhikena
translated: “Suffering is fully understood by him”: the three kinds of suffering are delimited by him after being transcended.🔽“Should be directly known”: should be known by means of the mode of beauty through the penetration of the specific characteristics.🔽“Is directly known”: is known by means of the mode of excellence.

original: ñāṇena ñātaṃ. Pariññeyyanti sāmaññalakkhaṇāvabodhavasena kiccasamāpannavasena ca
analyzed: ñāṇena ñātam pariññeyyanti sāmañña lakkhaṇa avabodha vasena kicca samāpanna vasena ca
translated: “Should be fully understood”: should be fully comprehended by means of the penetration of the general characteristics and by means of the fulfilment of the task.🔽“Is fully understood”: is known all round.

original: byāpitvā parijānitabbaṃ. Pariññātanti samantato ñātaṃ. Bhāvetabbanti vaḍḍhetabbaṃ.🔽Sacchikātabbanti paccakkhaṃ kātabbaṃ. Duvidhā hi sacchikiriyā paṭilābhasacchikiriyā
analyzed: byāpitvā parijānitabbam pariññātanti samantataḥ ñātam bhāvetabbam nti vaḍḍhetabbam  sacchikātabbanti paccakkham kātabbam duvidhā hi sacchikiriyā paṭilābha sacchikiriyā
translated: “Should be developed”: should be increased.

original: ārammaṇasacchikiriyā cāti.
analyzed: ārammaṇa sacchikiriyā ca ati
translated: “Should be realized”: should be made evident. For there are two kinds of realization: realization by obtainment and realization by direct knowledge.

original: Ukkhittapalighoti ettha palighoti vaṭṭamūlikā avijjā. Ayañhi dukkhipanaṭṭhena “paligho”ti
analyzed: ukkhitta paligho ti ettha palighaḥ ti vaṭṭamūlikā avijjā ayam hi dukkhipana ṭṭhena palighaḥ ti
translated: “The burden is laid down”: here, the burden is the ignorance that is the root of the round. For this is called “burden” in the sense of oppressing.🔽Since he has removed it, he is called “one who has laid down the burden.”

original: vuccati. Tenesa tassā ukkhittattā “ukkhittapaligho”ti vutto. Saṃkiṇṇaparikhoti parikhā
analyzed: vuccati tena isa tassā ukkhitta ttā ukkhitta palighaḥ ti vutto saṃkiṇṇa parikho ti parikhā
translated: “The fetters are destroyed”:

original: vuccati punabbhavadāyako bhavesu jāyanavasena ceva saṃsaraṇavasena ca “jātisaṃsāro”ti
analyzed: vuccati punabbhava dāyakaḥ bhavesu jāyana vasena ca iva saṃsaraṇa vasena ca jāti saṃsāraḥ ti
translated: and it is called “the round of birth-and-death” because of the occurrence of birth in the kinds of becoming and because of the occurrence of the round of rebirths.

original: laddhanāmānaṃ punabbhavakkhandhānaṃ paccayo kammābhisaṅkhāro. So hi punappunaṃ uppattikaraṇavasena
analyzed: laddha nāmānam punabbhava kkhandhānam paccayaḥ kamma abhisaṅkhāro so hi punappunam uppatti karaṇa vasena
translated: The kamma-formations are a condition for the aggregates of renewed becoming that have acquired a name. For they are called “the round of kamma-formations” because they cause rebirth again and again.🔽It is called “the round with a trench” because it is surrounded by a trench.

original: parikkhipitvā ṭhitattā “parikhā”ti vuccati. Tenesa tassā saṃkiṇṇattā vikiṇṇattā “saṃkiṇṇaparikho”ti
analyzed: parikkhipitvā ṭhita ttā parikhā ati vuccati tena isa tassā saṃkiṇṇa ttā vikiṇṇa ttā saṃkiṇṇa parikhā ti
translated: It is called “the round with the trench uprooted” because the trench has been dug up and removed.

original: vutto. Abbūḷhesikoti esikāti vaṭṭamūlikā taṇhā. Ayañhi gambhīrānugataṭṭhena “esikā”ti
analyzed: vuttaḥ abbūḷhesiko ti esikā ati vaṭṭamūlikā taṇhā ayam hi gambhīra anugata ṭṭhena esikā ti
translated: The round with the bolt drawn out: the bolt is craving, which is called “the bolt” because it is deeply embedded.

original: vuccati. Tenesa tassā abbūḷhattā luñcitvā chaḍḍitattā “abbūḷhesiko”ti vuccati. Niraggaḷoti
analyzed: vuccati tena isa tassāḥ abbūḷha ttā luñcitvā chaḍḍita ttā abbūḷhesikaḥ ti vuccati niraggaḷaḥ ti
translated: It is called “the round with the bolt drawn out” because the bolt has been pulled out and thrown away.

original: aggaḷaṃ vuccanti orambhāgajanakāni kāmabhave uppattipaccayāni orambhāgiyāni. Etāni
analyzed: aggaḷam vuccanti orambhāga janakāni kāma bhave uppatti paccayāni orambhāgiyāni etāni
translated: The round without a door-post: the door-posts are the conditions for rebirth in the lower world, the sense-desire world, which are the lower fetters.

original: hi mahākavāṭaṃ viya nagaradvāraṃ cittaṃ pidahitvā ṭhitattā “aggaḷa”nti vuccanti.
analyzed: hi mahā kavāṭam viya nagara dvāram cittam pidahitvā ṭhita ttā aggaḷanti vuccanti
translated: They are called “door-posts” because they stand blocking the door of the mind as a city gate does a city.

original: Tenesa tesaṃ niraggaḷattā bhinnattā “niraggaḷo”ti vutto. Ariyoti nikkileso parisuddho.
analyzed: tena isa tesam niraggaḷa ttā bhinna ttā niraggaḷaḥ iti vuttaḥ ariyaḥ ti nikkilesaḥ parisuddho
translated: “With the door unbarred” : because they are unbarred, because they are broken. “Noble” : free from defilements, purified.

original: Pannaddhajoti pātitamānaddhajo. Pannabhāroti khandhabhārakilesabhāraabhisaṅkhārabhārapañcakāmaguṇabhārā
analyzed: pannaddhajā iti pātita mānaddhajā pannabhārā iti khandha bhāra kilesa bhāra abhisaṅkhāra bhāra pañca kāmaguṇa bhārā
translated: “With the banner lowered” : with the banner of conceit lowered. “With the burden dropped” : the burden of the five aggregates, the burden of defilements, the burden of formations, the burden of the five strands of sense pleasure,

original: pannā oropitā assāti pannabhāro. Api ca idha mānabhārasseva oropitattā “pannabhāro”ti
analyzed: pannā oropitā assa ati panna bhāraḥ api ca idha māna bhārassa iva oropita ttā panna bhāraḥ iti
translated: has been dropped, has been laid down. Furthermore, here the burden of conceit is meant by the word “burden.”

original: adhippeto. Visaṃyuttoti catūhi yogehi sabbakilesehi ca visaṃyutto. Idha pana mānayogeneva
analyzed: adhippetaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ ti catūhi yogehi sabba kilesehi ca visaṃyuttaḥ idha pana māna yogena iva
translated: “Dispassionate” : dispassionate through the four yokes and through all defilements. But here dispassionateness through the yoke of conceit

original: visaṃyuttattā “visaṃyutto”ti adhippeto.🔽Ettāvatā therena maggena kilese khepetvā nirodhasayanavaragatassa khīṇāsavassa nibbānārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: visaṃyutta ttā visaṃyuttaḥ ti adhippeto  ettāvatā therena maggena kilese khepetvā nirodha sayana vara gatassa khīṇāsavassa nibbāna ārammaṇam
translated: is meant by the word “dispassionate.”🔽Up to this point the Elder has shown the time of his dwelling in the fruition attainment with Nibbāna as object after exhausting the defilements by the path and reaching the foremost bed of Nibbāna.

original: phalasamāpattiṃ appetvā viharaṇakālo dassito. Yathā hi dve nagarāni ekaṃ coranagaraṃ,
analyzed: phala samāpattim appetvā viharaṇa kālaḥ dassitaḥ yathā hi dve nagarāni ekam cora nagaram
translated: For it is just as if there were two cities, one a city of thieves,

original: ekaṃ khemanagaraṃ. Atha ekassa mahāyodhassa evaṃ icchā uppajjeyya “yāvimaṃ coranagaraṃ
analyzed: ekam khema nagaram atha ekassa mahā yodhassa evam icchā uppajjeyya yāva imam cora nagaram
translated: the other a city of safety. Then a great warrior might think thus: “I will go from this city of thieves

original: tiṭṭhati, tāva khemanagaraṃ bhayato na muccati. Coranagaraṃ anagaraṃ karissāmī”ti🔽sannāhaṃ katvā khaggaṃ gahetvā coranagaraṃ upasaṅkamitvā nagaradvāre ussāpite esikatthambhe🔽khaggena chinditvā saddhiṃ dvārabāhāhi kavāṭaṃ bhinditvā palighaṃ ukkhipitvā pākāraṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhati tāva khema nagaram bhayataḥ na muccati cora nagaram a nagaram karissāmi iti  sannāham katvā khaggam gahetvā cora nagaram upasaṅkamitvā nagara dvāre ussāpite esikatthambhe  khaggena chinditvā saddhim dvāra bāhāhi kavāṭam bhinditvā paligham ukkhipitvā pākāram
translated: and as long as it does, the city of safety is not freed from danger. I will make the city of thieves a non-city.”🔽and having girded up his loins and taken his sword, he approaches the city of thieves and cuts down the post at the city gate with his sword, and having broken down the door together with the door-posts, and having pulled up the cross-bar,

original: bhindanto parikhaṃ saṃkiritvā nagarasobhanatthāya ussāpite dhaje pātetvā nagaraṃ
analyzed: bhindantaḥ parikham saṃkiritvā nagara sobhana tthāya ussāpite dhaje pātetvā nagaram
translated: and having broken through the rampart, and having felled the flagstaff that was raised for the beauty of the city, and having

original: agginā jhāpetvā khemanagaraṃ pavisitvā uparipāsādamāruyha ñātigaṇaparivuto surasabhojanaṃ
analyzed: agginā jhāpetvā khema nagaram pavisitvā upari pāsādam āruyha ñāti gaṇa parivutaḥ su rasa bhojanam
translated: burnt the city with fire, he enters the city of safety and having ascended to the upper palace, surrounded by the assembly of his relatives,

original: bhuñjeyya. Evaṃ coranagaraṃ viya sakkāyo, khemanagaraṃ viya nibbānaṃ, mahāyodho viya
analyzed: bhuñjeyya evam cora nagaram viya sakkāyaḥ khema nagaram viya nibbānam mahā yodhaḥ viya
translated: he would eat the food of the gods. Just as the city of thieves is like personality, the city of safety is like Nibbāna, the great warrior is like

original: yogāvacaro. Tassevaṃ hoti “yāva sakkāyavaṭṭaṃ vaṭṭati, tāva dvattiṃsakammakāraṇehi
analyzed: yogāvacaro tassa ivam hoti yāva sakkāyavaṭṭam vaṭṭati tāva dvattiṃsa kamma kāraṇehi
translated: the meditator. He thinks thus: “As long as the round of personality revolves, so long there is no freedom from the thirty-two trades,

original: aṭṭhanavutirogehi pañcavīsatimahabbhayehi ca parimuccanaṃ natthī”ti. So mahāyodho
analyzed: aṭṭhanavuti rogehi pañcavīsati mahā bhayehi ca parimuccanam natthi iti saḥ mahā yodhaḥ
translated: the eighty-nine diseases, and the twenty-five great fears.” The great warrior

original: viya sannāhaṃ sīlasannāhaṃ katvā paññātiṇhakhaggaṃ gahetvā khaggena esikatthambhe🔽viya arahattamaggena taṇhesikaṃ chinditvā, so yodho sadvārabāhakaṃ nagarakavāṭaṃ
analyzed: viya sannāham sīla sannāham katvā paññā tiṇha khaggam gahetvā khaggena esikatthambhe  arahatta maggena taṇhesikam chinditvā saḥ yodhaḥ sa dvāra bāhakam nagara kavāṭam
translated: and having put on the armor, the armor of virtue, and having taken the sword of wisdom, he cuts down the tree of craving with the sword of the path of arahantship.🔽Then the warrior opens the city gate, the gate of the five lower fetters, with the crowbar of the path of arahantship.

original: viya pañcorambhāgiyasaṃyojanaggaḷaṃ ugghoṭetvā, so yodho palighaṃ viya avijjāpalighaṃ🔽ukkhipitvā, so yodho pākāraṃ bhindanto parikhaṃ viya kammābhisaṅkhārapākāraṃ bhindanto🔽jātisaṃsāraparikhaṃ saṃkiritvā, so yodho nagarasobhanatthāya ussāpite dhaje viya
analyzed: viya pañcorambhāgiya saṃyojana ggaḷam ugghoṭetvā saḥ yodhaḥ paligham viya avijjā paligham  ukkhipitvā saḥ yodhaḥ pākāram bhindantaḥ parikham viya kamma abhisaṅkhāra pākāram bhindantaḥ  jāti saṃsāra parikham saṃkiritvā saḥ yodhaḥ nagara sobhana thāya ussāpite dhaje viya
translated: Then the warrior uproots the pillar, ignorance, with the crowbar of the path of arahantship.🔽Then the warrior breaks through the wall, the wall of the kamma-formations, and fills in the moat, the moat of rebirth-linking, with the crowbar of the path of arahantship.

original: mānaddhaje pātetvā sakkāyanagaraṃ jhāpetvā, so yodho khemanagaraṃ pavisitvā uparipāsāde
analyzed: mānaddhaje pātetvā sakkāya nagaram jhāpetvā saḥ yodhaḥ khema nagaram pavisitvā upari pāsāde
translated: Then the warrior pulls down the banner of conceit, the banner of conceit that is raised for the sake of the beauty of the city of conceit.

original: surasabhojanaṃ bhuñjanto viya nibbānanagaraṃ pavisitvā amatanirodhārammaṇaṃ phalasamāpattisukhaṃ
analyzed: surasa bhojanam bhuñjantaḥ viya nibbāna nagaram pavisitvā amata nirodha ārammaṇam phala samāpatti sukham
translated: Then the warrior enters the city of security, the city of Nibbāna, and enjoys the bliss of the fruition attainment, the bliss of the deathless.

original: anubhavamāno kālaṃ vītināmeti. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: anubhavamānaḥ kālam vītināma iti vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: This is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho hoti? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu ukkhitta palighaḥ hoti idha bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ avijjā
translated: “And how is a monk one who has lifted up the cross-bar? There is the case where a monk’s ignorance is abandoned and wisdom arises.

original: pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā. Evaṃ🔽kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ukkhittapaligho hoti.🔽“Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṃkiṇṇaparikho hoti? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ponobhaviko jātisaṃsāro pahīno hoti…pe… evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṃkiṇṇaparikho hoti.🔽“Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abbūḷhesiko hoti? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti…pe… evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abbūḷhesiko hoti.
analyzed: pahīnā hoti ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatim an uppāda dhammā evam  kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ukkhitta palighaḥ hoti  katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu saṃkiṇṇa parikhaḥ hoti idha bhikkhave bhikkhuno ponobhavikaḥ jāti saṃsāraḥ pahīnaḥ hoti pe evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu saṃkiṇṇa parikhaḥ hoti  kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu abbūḷhesikaḥ hoti idha bhikkhave bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti pe evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu abbūḷhesikaḥ hoti
translated: “How is a monk one who has pulled out the dart of doubt? There is the case where a monk has abandoned the conceit ‘I am,’ has cut it off at the root… So a monk is one who has pulled out the dart of doubt.🔽“How is a monk one who has cut the fetter? There is the case where a monk has abandoned the fetter of renewed existence… So a monk is one who has cut the fetter.🔽“How is a monk one who has untied the bundle? There is the case where a monk has abandoned craving… So a monk is one who has untied the bundle.

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu niraggaḷo hoti? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni honti…pe… evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu niraggaḷo hoti.
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu niraggaḷaḥ hoti idha bhikkhave bhikkhuno pañca orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni honti pe evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu niraggaḷaḥ hoti
translated: “How is a monk one who has removed the bar? There is the case where a monk has abandoned the five lower fetters… So a monk is one who has removed the bar.

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hoti? Idha,🔽bhikkhave, bhikkhuno asmimāno pahīno hoti ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṃkato
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyaḥ pannaddha jaḥ panna bhāraḥ visaṃyuttaḥ hoti idha  bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ asmimānaḥ pahīnaḥ hoti ucchinna mūlaḥ tālāvatthukataḥ anabhāvaṃkataḥ
translated: “And how is a monk a noble one with spiritual power, a noble one with penetrative wisdom, a noble one detached from the world?🔽Here, a monk has abandoned the conceit ‘I am,’ has cut it off at the root…

original: āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo. Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo pannaddhajo pannabhāro visaṃyutto hoti.
analyzed: āyatim an uppāda dhammaḥ evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyaḥ pannaddha jaḥ panna bhāraḥ visaṃyuttaḥ hoti
translated: so that it is no longer subject to future arising. That is how a monk is a noble one with spiritual power, a noble one with penetrative wisdom, a noble one detached from the world.

original: “Evaṃ vimuttacittaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ saindā devā sabrahmakā sapajāpatikā anvesaṃ nādhigacchanti ‘idaṃnissitaṃ tathāgatassa viññāṇa”’nti.
analyzed: evam vimutta cittam kho bhikkhave bhikkhum saindāḥ devāḥ sa brahmakāḥ sa pajāpatikāḥ anu esam na adhigacchanti idam nissitam tathāgatassa viññāṇam ti
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu’s mind is thus released, the devas together with Indra, Brahma, and Pajapati search for the gross substance, thinking: ‘With what gross substance is the consciousness of the Tathāgata bound up? ‘“

original: Pañcaṅgavippahīnoti kāmacchandādipañcaṅgāni vividhehi upāyehi pajahitvā ṭhito. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: pañcaṅga vippahīno ti kāmacchanda ādi pañcaṅgāni vividhehi upāyehi pajahitvā ṭhitaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: He has abandoned the five factors: he has abandoned the five factors beginning with sensual desire by various means. This is said:

original: “Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti? Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno
analyzed: kathañca āvuso bhikkhu pañcaṅga vippahīnaḥ hoti idha āvuso bhikkhuno kāmacchandaḥ pahīno
translated: “And how, friends, has a bhikkhu abandoned the five factors? Here, a bhikkhu has abandoned sensual desire,

original: hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti,
analyzed: hoti byāpādaḥ pahīnaḥ hoti thinam iddham pahīnam hoti uddhacca kukkuccam pahīnam hoti
translated: ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse,

original: vicikicchā pahīnā hoti. Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hotī”ti.🔽Chaḷaṅgasamannāgatoti channaṃ aṅgānaṃ pūretvā chasu dvāresu rūpādiārammaṇe paṭighānunayaṃ
analyzed: vicikicchā pahīnā hoti evam kho āvuso bhikkhu pañcaṅga vippahīnaḥ hoti iti  chaṭṭha aṅga samannāgataḥ ti channam aṅgānam pūretvā chasu dvāresu rūpa ādi ārammaṇe paṭigha anunayam
translated: and his uncertainty is abandoned. That is how a bhikkhu is possessed of five factors.”

original: vajjetvā upekkhāvasena sato sampajāno hutvā viharaṇavasena chaḷaṅgāni pūretvā paripuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vajjetvā upekkhā vasena sataḥ sampajānaḥ hutvā viharaṇa vasena chaḷaṅgāni pūretvā paripuṇṇam
translated: Possessed of six factors: having fulfilled the six factors, he abides in the six doors by means of equanimity, having avoided aversion and greed for the objective fields of visible data, etc.,

original: katvā ṭhitattā “chaḷaṅgasamannāgato”ti vutto. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: katvā ṭhita ttā chaḍaṅga samannāgataḥ iti vuttaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: and having fulfilled the six factors by making them complete and perfect, he is said to be “possessed of six factors.” For this is said:

original: “Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti? Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ🔽disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno. Sotena saddaṃ
analyzed: katham ca āvuso bhikkhu chaḷaṅga samannāgataḥ hoti idha āvuso bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam  disvā na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajāno sotena saddam
translated: “And how, friends, is a bhikkhu possessed of six factors? Here, friends, a bhikkhu, seeing a visible object with the eye,

original: sutvā…pe… ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā, jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā, kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā,
analyzed: sutvā āpe ghānena gandham ghāyitvā jivhāya rasam sāyitvā kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: is neither glad nor sad, but dwells equanimous, mindful and clearly comprehending. Hearing a sound with the ear … Smelling an odour with the nose … Tasting a flavour with the tongue … Touching a tangible with the body …

original: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na iva su manaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajāno
translated: Cognizing a mental object with the mind, he is neither glad nor sad, but dwells equanimous, mindful and clearly comprehending.

original: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho āvuso bhikkhu chaḷaṅga samannāgataḥ hoti iti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu possesses six factors.”

original: Ekārakkhoti satiārakkhena eko uttamo ārakkho assāti ekārakkho. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: eka ārakkhaḥ ti sati ārakkhena ekaḥ uttamaḥ ārakkhaḥ assa ati eka ārakkhaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: Possessing one guard: he has one supreme guard in the form of mindfulness as guard. This is said:🔽“And how, friends, does a bhikkhu possess one guard? Here, a bhikkhu dwells with his heart guarded by mindfulness. That is how a bhikkhu possesses one guard.”🔽Possessing four supports: by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, determination, energy, and inquiry, which are the opposites of the four defilements of desire, etc.,

original: “Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti? Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satārakkhena cetasā samannāgato viharati. Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hotī”ti.🔽Caturāpassenoti paññāya paṭisevanaparivajjanavinodanapajahanānaṃ vasena catunnaṃ🔽apassayānaṃ ito cito ca aparivattamānānaṃ vasena caturāpasseno, tesaṃ pāpuṇitvā ṭhito. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti? Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati,
analyzed: katham ca āvuso bhikkhu eka ārakkhaḥ hoti idha āvuso bhikkhu satā ārakkhena cetasā samannāgataḥ viharati evam kho āvuso bhikkhu eka ārakkhaḥ hoti iti  catur āpassena uti paññāya paṭisevana parivajjana vinodana pajahanānam vasena catunnam  apassayānam itas citas ca a parivattamānānam vasena catur āpassenaḥ tesam pāpuṇitvā ṭhitaḥ vuttam ha etam  katham ca āvuso bhikkhu catur āpassenaḥ hoti idha āvuso bhikkhu saṅkhāya ekam paṭisevati
translated: and by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., themselves, which are the opposites of the four defilements of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by one who is possessed of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc.,

original: saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti. Saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ pajahatī”tiādinā nayena vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhāya ekam parivajjeti saṅkhāya ekam vinodeti saṅkhāya ekam pajahati iti ādinā nayena vitthāretabbam
translated: and by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., themselves, which are the opposites of the four defilements of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by one who is possessed of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned by means of the four supports for spiritual power consisting of desire, etc., that are to be abandoned

original: Paṇunnapaccekasaccoti “idameva dassanaṃ saccaṃ, idameva sacca”nti evaṃ pāṭiekkaṃ gahitattā paccekasaṅkhātāni diṭṭhisaccāni paṇunnāni nihaṭāni pahīnāni assāti paṇunnapaccekasacco.
analyzed: paṇunna pacceka sacco ti idam eva dassanam saccam idam eva saccanti evam pāṭiekkam gahita ttā pacceka saṅkhātāni diṭṭhi saccāni paṇunnāni nihaṭāni pahīnāni assa ati paṇunna pacceka saccaḥ
translated: He has abandoned the several kinds of rightness of view, thus he is one who has abandoned the several kinds of rightness of view.🔽He is one who has sought out the sixfold base thoroughly, thus he is one who has sought out the sixfold base thoroughly.

original: Samavayasaṭṭhesanoti ettha avayāti anūnā. Saṭṭhāti vissaṭṭhā. Sammā avayā saṭṭhā
analyzed: ettha avayā ati anūnā saṭṭhā ati vissaṭṭhā sammā avayā saṭṭhā
translated: He is one who has sought out the sixfold base thoroughly: here, avay means not less, saṭṭha means scattered,🔽sammā avayā saṭṭhā

original: esanā assāti samavayasaṭṭhesano. Sammā vissaṭṭhasabbaesanoti attho. Kevalīti paripuṇṇo.
analyzed: esanā assa ati sama vaya saṭṭha esano sammā vissaṭṭha sabba esano ti attho kevalī iti paripuṇṇo
translated: esanā assāti samavayasaṭṭhesano. The meaning is: one who has sought out all thoroughly.

original: Vusitavāti vusitabrahmacariyo, garusaṃvāse ariyamaggepi dasasu ariyavāsesupi vusitavanto.🔽Uttamapurisoti khīṇakilesattā visesapuriso ājaññapuriso. Paramapurisoti uttamapuriso,
analyzed: vusitavāti vusita brahmacariyaḥ garu saṃvāse ariya magge pi dasasu ariya vāsesu pi vusitavanto  uttama puriso ti khīṇa kilesa ttā visesa purisaḥ ājañña purisaḥ parama purisaḥ ti uttama purisaḥ
translated: He is one who has lived the life, thus he is one who has lived the life. He has lived the life of purity, he has lived the life of respect, he has lived the life of the noble path, he has lived the life of the ten noble abodes.🔽He is a supreme person, thus he is a supreme person.

original: paramaṃ vā paṭilābhaṃ pattattā uttamaṃ pattabbaṃ arahattapaṭilābhaṃ patto anuttarapuññakkhettabhūto
analyzed: paramam vā paṭilābham pattattā uttamam pattabbam arahatta paṭilābham patto anuttara puññakkhetta bhūto
translated: He is a supreme person: he is a distinguished person because of the destruction of defilements, he is a person who has known, he is a person who has attained the supreme attainment that is to be attained, he is a person who is a supreme field of merit.

original: uttamapuriso, tenevatthena paramapuriso. Anuttaraṃ samāpattiṃ samāpajjituṃ amataṃ🔽paṭilābhaṃ pattattā paramapattippatto. Atha vā “gharāvāse ādīnavaṃ sañjānitvā sāsanapavisanavasena
analyzed: uttama purisaḥ tena ivatthena parama purisaḥ anuttaram samāpattim samāpajjitum amatam  paṭilābham pattattā parama patti ppattaḥ atha vā ghara āvāse ādīnavam sañjānitvā sāsana pavisana vasena
translated: He is the Supreme Person, the Best Person, because of the meaning of that word. He has attained the supreme attainment, the attainment of the deathless,🔽because of the attainment of the acquisition of the deathless. Or else, having seen the danger in living at home, he has entered the Dispensation🔽

original: uttamapuriso. Attabhāve ādīnavaṃ sañjānitvā vipassanāpavisanavasena paramapuriso.
analyzed: uttama purisaḥ atta bhāve ādīnavam sañjānitvā vipassanā pavisana vasena parama purisaḥ
translated: He is a supreme person in the sense of being the highest person. He has reached the highest attainment in the sense of having attained the attainment of the deathless, which is unsurpassed. Or else, he is a supreme person in the sense of having entered the Dispensation by seeing the danger in the household life. He is a highest person in the sense of having entered insight by seeing the danger in the individual existence.

original: Kilese ādīnavaṃ sañjānitvā ariyabhūmantaraṃ paviṭṭho paramapattippattoti evameke vaṇṇayanti.🔽Nevācinatīti kusalākusalānaṃ pahīnattā tesaṃ vipākaṃ na vaḍḍheti. Nāpacinatīti phale🔽ṭhitattā na viddhaṃseti. Apacinitvā ṭhitoti paṭippassaddhipahāne ṭhitattā kilese
analyzed: kilese ādīnavam sañjānitvā ariya bhūmantaram paviṭṭhaḥ parama patti patto ti evam eke vaṇṇayanti  na iva ācinati iti kusala akusalānam pahīna ttā tesam vipākam na vaḍḍheti na apacinati iti phale  ṭhita ttā na apacinitvā ṭhitaḥ ti paṭippassaddhi pahāne ṭhita ttā kilese
translated: He has reached the highest attainment in the sense of having entered the noble plane by seeing the danger in the defilements. So some explain.🔽He does not accumulate: he does not increase the result of the profitable and unprofitable because he has abandoned them. He does not store up: he does not destroy it because he is established in the fruit.

original: viddhaṃsetvā ṭhito. Ito paraṃ tīhipi padehi maggaphalavaseneva yojetabbaṃ. Neva pajahatīti
analyzed: viddhaṃsetvā ṭhitaḥ itas param tīhi pi padehi magga phala vasena iva yojetabbam na iva pajahati iti
translated: He is established by destroying: he is established by the subsiding of the abandoning. From here on the text should be construed in each case as the path and fruition. He does not abandon: he does not abandon defilements because there is nothing to be abandoned.

original: pahātabbābhāvena kilese na pajahati. Na upādiyatīti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīhi gahetabbābhāvato
analyzed: pahātabba abhāvena kilese na pajahati na upādiyati iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhīhi gahetabba abhāvato
translated: He does not grasp: because there is nothing to be grasped by craving, conceit, and views.

original: tehi na gaṇhāti. Pajahitvā ṭhitoti cajitvā ṭhito. Neva saṃsibbatīti taṇhāvasena neva🔽saṃsibbati. Na ussinetīti mānavasena na ukkaṃsati. Visinitvā ṭhitoti taṇhāsaṃsīvanaṃ🔽akatvā ṭhitoti evameke vaṇṇayanti. Neva vidhūpetīti kilesaggiṃ na nibbāpeti. Na sandhūpetīti
analyzed: tehi na gaṇhāti pajahitvā ṭhitaḥ uti cajitvā ṭhitaḥ na iva saṃsibbati iti taṇhā vasena na iva  saṃsibbati na ussineti iti māna vasena na ukkaṃsati visinitvā ṭhitaḥ iti taṇhā saṃsīvanam  a katvā ṭhitaḥ iti evam eke vaṇṇayanti na iva vidhūpeti iti kilesa aggim na nibbāpeti na sandhūpeti iti
translated: He does not take hold of them. He stands having given them up: he stands having rejected them. He does not get entangled: he does not get entangled through craving. He does not get excited: he does not over-excite himself through conceit. He stands having surveyed: he stands having surveyed without getting entangled through craving.

original: kilesaggiṃ na jālāpeti. Vidhūpetvā ṭhitoti taṃ nibbāpetvā ṭhito.🔽Asekkhena sīlakkhandhenāti sikkhitabbābhāvena asekkhena vācākammantājīvasīlakkhandhena🔽sīlarāsinā samannāgatattā ṭhito, aparihīnabhāvena ṭhito. Samādhikkhandhenāti vāyāmasatīhi
analyzed: kilesaggim na jālāpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhitaḥ ti tam nibbāpetvā ṭhitaḥ  asekkhena sīla kkhandhena ati sikkhitabba abhāvena asekkhena vācā kammanta ājīva sīla kkhandhena  sīla rāsinā samannāgata ttā ṭhitaḥ a parihīna bhāvena ṭhitaḥ samādhi kkhandhena ati vāyāma satīhi
translated: Some explain it thus. He does not blow out: he does not extinguish the fire of defilements. He does not fan: he does not fan the fire of defilements. He stands having blown out: he stands having extinguished it.

original: sampayuttena samādhinā. Vimuttikkhandhenāti phalavimuttisampayuttakkhandhena. Vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhenāti
analyzed: sampayuttena samādhinā vimutti kkhandhena ati phala vimutti sampayutta kkhandhena vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandhena ati
translated: With the aggregate of virtue of one beyond training: he stands because he possesses the aggregate of virtue, the mass of virtue, of one beyond training, of one who has no more to train in, because he stands without falling away. With the aggregate of concentration: with concentration associated with energy and mindfulness. With the aggregate of deliverance: with the aggregate associated with the deliverance of fruition. With the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of deliverance:

original: paccavekkhaṇañāṇena. Saccaṃ sampaṭipādiyitvāti catuariyasaccaṃ sabhāvavasena sakasantāne
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena saccam sampaṭipādiyitvā ati caturiya saccam sabhāva vasena saka santāne
translated: By knowledge of reviewing. Having realized the Truths: having realized the four noble Truths by making them his own in his own mental continuity by penetrating them in accordance with their individual characteristics.

original: sampādiyitvā paṭivijjhitvā ṭhito. Ejaṃ samatikkamitvāti kampanataṇhaṃ atikkamitvā.
analyzed: sampādiyitvā paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaḥ ejam samatikkamitvā ati kampana taṇham atikkamitvā
translated: Having gone beyond this: having gone beyond the craving for shaking.🔽The fire of defilements: the fire of the defilements of lust, etc.

original: Kilesagginti rāgādikilesaggiṃ. Pariyādiyitvāti khepetvā nibbāpetvā. Aparigamanatāyāti
analyzed: kilesa ggin ti rāga ādi kilesa ggim pariyādiyitvā ati khepetvā nibbāpetvā a parigamana tāya ati
translated: Having extinguished: having exhausted, having extinguished.🔽Not going again: the meaning is, not going again to the round of rebirths.

original: saṃsāre agamanabhāvena punāgamanābhāvenāti attho. Kaṭaṃ samādāyāti jayaggāhaṃ gahetvā.
analyzed: saṃsāre a gamana bhāvena punar āgamana abhāvena ati kaṭam samādāya ati jayaggāham gahetvā
translated: Having taken up the spade: having taken up the victory-in-battle.

original: Muttipaṭisevanatāyāti sabbakilesehi muccitvā rūpādiārammaṇasevanavasena. Atha vā
analyzed: mutti paṭisevana tāya ati sabba kilesehi muccitvā rūpa ādi ārammaṇa sevana vasena atha vā
translated: By resorting to the freedom: by resorting to the object of form, etc., after being freed from all defilements. Or else,🔽by resorting to the fruition attainment that is freed from all defilements.

original: sabbakilesehi muttaphalasamāpattisevanavasena. Mettāya pārisuddhiyāti upakkilesamuttāya
analyzed: sabba kilesehi mutta phala samāpatti sevana vasena mettāya pārisuddhiyā ati upakkilesa muttāya
translated: By the purification of loving-kindness: by the loving-kindness that has reached purification by going beyond the state of being mixed with defilements.

original: parisuddhabhāve ṭhitāya mettāya ṭhito. Karuṇādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: parisuddha bhāve ṭhitāya mettāya ṭhitaḥ karuṇā ādīsu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ
translated: He stands by the loving-kindness that has reached the state of purification. The same method applies to compassion, and so on.

original: Accantapārisuddhiyāti atikkantaparisuddhabhāvena parisuddhiyā antaṃ pāpuṇitvā ṭhito.
analyzed: accanta pārisuddhiyā ti atikkanta parisuddha bhāvena parisuddhiyāḥ antam pāpuṇitvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: By the extreme purification: having reached the end of purification by means of purification that has gone beyond the state of being mixed with defilements.

original: Atammayatāyāti taṇhādiṭṭhimānā “tammayā”ti vuccanti. Tesaṃ abhāvo atammayatā, tāya
analyzed: a tammaya tāya ati taṇhā diṭṭhi mānā tammayā ati vuccanti tesam abhāvaḥ a tammaya tā tāya
translated: ‘In the unclung-to’: craving, views, and conceit are called ‘clung-to’. The absence of these is the unclung-to.

original: taṇhādiṭṭhimānavirahitatāya ṭhito. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi māna virahita tāya ṭhitaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: He stands in that, since he is devoid of craving, views, and conceit. For this is said:🔽‘Such is he, the knower of the world, the well-gone, the seer, The sage who is unclung-to in regard to all ideas’ .

original: “So tādiso lokavidū sumedho, sabbesu dhammesu atammayo munī”ti. Etthāpi taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivirahitoti🔽attho. Vimuttattāti sabbakilesehi muttabhāvena. Santussitattāti yathālābhayathābalayathāsāruppasantosavasena
analyzed: so tādisaḥ loka vidū sumedhaḥ sabbesu dhammesu atammayaḥ muni iti ettha api taṇhā māna diṭṭhi virahitaḥ ti  attho vimutta ttā ati sabba kilesehi mutta bhāvena santussita ttā ati yathā lābha yathā bala yathā sāruppa santosa vasena
translated: Here too the meaning is ‘ devoid of craving, conceit, and views’.🔽‘In the liberated’: in the state of being liberated from all defilements.

original: santuṭṭhabhāvena ṭhito.
analyzed: santuṭṭha bhāvena ṭhitaḥ
translated: ‘In the content’: he stands in the state of being contented by being satisfied with what he gets, with what strength he has, and with what is suitable.

original: Khandhapariyanteti ekacatupañcakkhandhānaṃ tīhi pariññaggīhi jhāpetvā ante avasāne🔽ṭhito, natthi etassa antoti vā pariyantaṃ, tasmiṃ pariyante. Dhātupariyantādīsupi
analyzed: khandha pariyantā iti eka catu pañca khandhānam tīhi jhāpetvā ante avasāne  ṭhitaḥ na atthi etassa antaḥ iti vā pariyantam tasmin pariyante dhātu pariyanta ādīsu pi
translated: ‘In the end of the aggregates’: he stands in the end, the last, of the one-, four-, and five-aggregate kinds of becoming after burning them up with the three kinds of full-understanding.

original: eseva nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – dhātupariyanteti aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ pariyante.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ dhātu pariyantā iti aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam pariyante
translated: Or alternatively, there is no end to him, thus he is ‘endless’; he stands in that end. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the end of the elements, and so on. But the difference in meaning here is this. ‘In the end of the elements’: in the end of the eighteen elements.

original: Āyatanapariyanteti dvādasannaṃ āyatanānaṃ. Gatipariyanteti nirayādipañcannaṃ gatīnaṃ.
analyzed: āyatana pariyantā iti gati pariyantā iti niraya ādi pañcannam
translated: ‘In the end of the bases’: in the end of the twelve bases. ‘In the end of the destinies’: in the end of the five destinies beginning with the hells.

original: Upapattipariyanteti sugatiduggatīsu nibbattiyā. Paṭisandhipariyanteti kāmarūpārūpabhavesu
analyzed: upapatti pariyantā iti sugati duggatīsu nibbattiyā paṭisandhi pariyantā iti kāmarūpa arūpa bhavesu
translated: At the end of rebirth: in good and bad destinations. At the end of rebirth-linking: in the sense-desire, fine-material, and immaterial realms.

original: paṭisandhiyā. Bhavapariyanteti ekavokāracatupañcasaññāasaññānevasaññānāsaññākāmarūpaarūpabhavānaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhiyā bhava pariyantā iti eka vokāra catu pañca saññā asaññā nevasaññā na asaññā kāmarūpa arūpa bhavānam
translated: In the end of rebirth : in the rebirth in happy and unhappy destinations. In the end of rebirth-linking : in the rebirth-linking in the sensual-sphere, fine-material-sphere, and immaterial-sphere existences. In the end of becoming : in the single-constituent, four-constituent, five-constituent, percipient, non-percipient, neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient, sensual-sphere, fine-material-sphere, and immaterial-sphere kinds of becoming.

original: Saṃsārapariyanteti khandhadhātuāyatanānaṃ abbocchinnapavattiyā. Vaṭṭapariyanteti
analyzed: saṃsāra pariyantā iti khandha dhātu āyatanānam abbocchinna pavattiyā vaṭṭa pariyantā iti
translated: In the end of the round : in the uninterrupted occurrence of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases. In the end of the round of existence :

original: kammavipākakilesavaṭṭānaṃ pariyante. Antime bhaveti avasāne upapattibhave. Antime🔽samussaye ṭhitoti avasāne samussaye sarīre ṭhito. Antimadehadharoti antimaṃ avasānadehaṃ
analyzed: kamma vipāka kilesa vaṭṭānam pariyante antime bhava iti avasāne upapatti bhave antime  samussaye ṭhito ti avasāne samussaye sarīre ṭhitaḥ antima deha dharo ti antimam avasāna deham
translated: in the end of the round of kamma, its result, and defilement. In his last bodily existence : in his last rebirth existence. Standing : standing in his last body.

original: sarīraṃ dhāretīti antimadehadharo. Arahāti ārakattā arīnaṃ, arānañca hatattā, paccayādīnaṃ🔽arahattā, pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvā arahā.
analyzed: sarīram dhāreti iti antima deha dharaḥ āraka ttā arīnam hata ttā paccaya ādīnam  a rahat tā pāpa karaṇe a rahā
translated: Bearing his last body : bearing his last, final body. Arahant : he is an arahant because he is far removed from the pollutants , because he has destroyed the enemies , because he is worthy of the requisites , and because he is worthy of offerings .🔽This is his last : this is the last body, the last existence, of that one whose cankers are exhausted. His final :

original: Tassāyaṃ pacchimakoti tassa khīṇāsavassa ayaṃ samussayo attabhāvo avasāno. Carimoti
analyzed: tassa ayam pacchimakaḥ ti tassa khīṇa āsavassa ayam samussayaḥ atta bhāvaḥ avasāno carimā iti
translated: his last.

original: appo mando carimo ālopo, carimaṃ kabaḷaṃ viya. Puna paṭisandhiyā natthibhāvaṃ sandhāya🔽“jātimaraṇasaṃsāro, natthi tassa punabbhavo”ti āha. Jananaṃ jāti, maranti tenāti
analyzed: appaḥ mandaḥ carimaḥ ālopaḥ carimam kabaḷam viya puna paṭisandhiyā natthi bhāvam sandhāya  jāti maraṇa saṃsāro na atthi tassa punabbhavaḥ ti āha jananam jāti maranti tena ati
translated: it is the last, the lowest, the vilest, like the last morsel of food. And again, in the sense of the non-existence of rebirth:🔽“No more is there birth and death for him, no more wandering in saṃsāra.”

original: maraṇaṃ, khandhādīnaṃ abbocchinnā saṃsārapavatti ca tassa khīṇāsavassa puna natthīti
analyzed: maraṇam khandha ādīnam abbocchinnā saṃsāra pavatti ca tassa khīṇāsavassa puna natthi iti
translated: Birth is jāti, and death is maraṇa, and the saṃsāra-process of the aggregates, etc., is no more for him who is without cankers.

original: vuttaṃ gāthaṃ nigamento āha tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: vuttam gātham nigamentaḥ āha tena āha bhagavā
translated: Concluding the sutta with what was said, he said: Tenāha bhagavā:

original: “Tasmā jantu…pe… nāvaṃ sitvāva pāragū”ti.
analyzed: tasmai jantupe nāvam sitvā ava pāragūti
translated: “Tasmā jantu…pe… nāvaṃ sitvāva pāragū”ti.

original: Imasmiṃ sutte yaṃ antarantarā na vuttaṃ, taṃ pāṭhānusārena gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: imasmin sutte yam antar antarā na vuttam tam pāṭha anusārena gahetabbam
translated: In this sutta what is not stated in the middle can be taken by the method of the recitation.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Great Commentary on the “Lamp on the True Dhamma”

original: Kāmasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāma sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Kāma Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Guhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: guhaṭṭhaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Guhatthaka Sutta Explanation

original: 7. Dutiye – sattoti laggo. Guhāyanti kāye. Kāyo hi rāgādīnaṃ vāḷānaṃ vasanokāsato
analyzed: dutiye sattoti laggaḥ guhāyanti kāye kāyaḥ hi rāga ādīnam vasana ukāsataḥ
translated: In the second sutta: satto means attached. Guhāyanti kāye. The body is called “guha” because it is the dwelling place for the wild beasts of lust, etc.

original: “guhā”ti vuccati. Bahunābhichannoti bahunā rāgādikilesajātena abhicchanno. Etena
analyzed: guhā iti vuccati bahunā abhichannaḥ ti bahunā rāga ādi kilesa jātena abhicchannaḥ etena
translated: Bahunābhichanno means covered with much lust, etc., defilement. By this

original: ajjhattabandhanaṃ vuttaṃ. Tiṭṭhanti rāgādivasena tiṭṭhanto. Mohanasmiṃ pagāḷhoti
analyzed: ajjhatta bandhanam vuttam tiṭṭhanti rāga ādi vasena tiṭṭhantaḥ mohanasmin pagāḷhaḥ ti
translated: “Bound within” is said. “He who stands” stands by way of lust, etc. “In the pit of delusion”

original: mohanaṃ vuccati kāmaguṇo. Ettha hi devamanussā muyhanti tesu ajjhogāḷhā hutvā; etena🔽bāhirabandhanaṃ vuttaṃ. Dūre vivekā hi tathāvidho soti so tathārūpo naro tividhāpi
analyzed: mohanam vuccati kāma guṇaḥ ettha hi deva manussāḥ muyhanti tesu ajjhogāḷhāḥ hutvā etena  bāhira bandhanam vuttam dūre vivekāḥ hi tathāvidhaḥ saḥ ti saḥ tathārūpaḥ naraḥ tividhā api
translated: The sense-pleasures are called “delusion.” Herein, gods and humans are deluded, having fallen into them. By this🔽“bound without” is said. “He who stands” is far from the kinds of seclusion, i.e. seclusion of the body, etc.

original: kāyavivekādivivekā dūre, anāsanne. Kiṃkāraṇā? Kāmā hi loke na hi suppahāyāti yasmā🔽loke kāmā suppahāyā na honti, tasmāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kāya viveka ādi vivekāḥ dūre anāsanne kiṃkāraṇāḥ kāmāḥ hi loke na hi yasmai  loke kāmā su pahāyāḥ na honti tasmā iti vuttam hoti
translated: Why? “For sense-pleasures in the world are hard to abandon.” Because sense-pleasures in the world are not easily abandoned,🔽thus is it said.

original: Sattoti hi kho vuttanti “satto, naro, mānavo”ti evamādinā nayena kathitoyeva. Guhā🔽tāva vattabbāti guhā tāva kathetabbā. Kāyoti vātiādīsu ayaṃ tāva padayojanā – kāyo
analyzed: satto ti hi kho vuttanti sattaḥ naraḥ mānavo ti evamādinā nayena kathitaḥ iva guhā  tāva vattabbā ati guhā tāva kathetabbā kāyaḥ iti vā ati ādīsu ayam tāva pada yojanā kāyaḥ
translated: “A being” is said. “A being,” “man,” “person,” etc., are said in this way. “Cave”🔽should be spoken of. “Body” is said. In “body” and “cave,” etc., this is the connection of the words: “body”

original: iti vā guhā iti vā…pe… kumbho iti vāti. Tattha kāyoti “kucchitānaṃ āyoti kāyo”tiādinā
analyzed: iti vā guhā iti vāpe kumbho iti vā ati tattha
translated: is said. “Cave” is said. “Belly” is said. “Pot” is said. “House” is said. “Home” is said. “Womb” is said. “Prison” is said. “Pit” is said. “Delusion” is said. “Sense-pleasures” are said. “World” is said. “Hard to abandon” is said.🔽Herein, “body” is said in the sense of a collection of the four great elementals and the form derived from the four great elementals. “Cave” is said in the sense of a place of concealment. “Belly” is said in the sense of a place of accumulation. “Pot” is said in the sense of a container. “House” is said in the sense of a place of dwelling. “Home” is said in the sense of a place of living. “Womb” is said in the sense of a place of concealment. “Prison” is said in the sense of a place of confinement. “Pit” is said in the sense of a place of falling. “Delusion” is said in the sense of a place of delusion. “Sense-pleasures” are said in the sense of a place of enjoyment. “World” is said in the sense of a place of wandering.

original: heṭṭhā satipaṭṭhānakathāyaṃ vuttoyeva. Rāgādivāḷānaṃ vasanokāsaṭṭhena guhā, “paṭicchādanaṭṭhenā”tipi
analyzed: heṭṭhā sati paṭṭhāna kathā ayam vuttā yā iva rāga ādi vāḷānam vasana ukāsa ṭṭhena guhā paṭicchādana ṭṭhena ati pi
translated: and this has been explained in the section on the foundations of mindfulness . “Cave” is a place for the dwelling of the defilements of lust, etc., “as a place for concealment,” say some.

original: eke. “Dūraṅgamaṃ ekacaraṃ, asarīraṃ guhāsaya”ntiādīsu viya. Rāgādīhi jhāpanaṭṭhena
analyzed: eke dūraṅgamam ekacaram asarīram rāga ādīhi jhāpana ṭṭhena
translated: As in such passages as “Roaming far, solitary, with a body that is a cave” .🔽“Body” is a place for the burning up of lust, etc.,

original: deho “te hitvā mānusaṃ deha”ntiādīsu viya. Pamattakaraṇaṭṭhena sandeho “bhijjati
analyzed: te hitvā mānusam pamatta karaṇa ṭṭhena sandehaḥ bhijjati
translated: as in such passages as “Having abandoned the human body” .🔽“Corpse” is a place for negligence,🔽as in such passages as “The corpse of negligence, for death is life’s end” .

original: pūtisandeho, maraṇantañhi jīvita”ntiādīsu viya. Saṃsāre sañcaraṇaṭṭhena nāvā “siñca
analyzed: pūti sandehaḥ saṃsāre sañcaraṇa ṭṭhena nāvā siñca
translated: “Ship” is a place for travelling in the round of rebirths,

original: bhikkhu imaṃ nāvaṃ, sittā te lahumessatī”tiādīsu viya. Iriyāpathassa atthibhāvaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhikkhu imam nāvam sittā te lahumessati itiādīsu viya iriyāpathassa atthi bhāva ṭṭhena
translated: as in such passages as “Water the ship, bhikkhu, and the ship will go lightly for you” .🔽“Chariot” is a place for the existence of the postures,

original: ratho “ratho sīlaparikkhāro, jhānakkho cakkavīriyo”tiādīsu viya. Accuggataṭṭhena
analyzed: rathaḥ rathaḥ sīla parikkhāraḥ jhāna kkho cakka vīriya uti ādīsu viya accuggata ṭṭhena
translated: as in such passages as “The chariot is the equipment of virtue, the axle-pin is jhāna, the wheel is energy” .🔽“Banner” is a place for what is outstanding,

original: dhajo “dhajo rathassa paññāṇa”ntiādīsu viya.
analyzed: dhajaḥ dhajaḥ rathassa paññāṇa nti ādīsu viya
translated: as in such passages as “The banner is the proclamation of the chariot” .

original: Kimikulānaṃ āvāsabhāvena vammiko “vammikoti kho, bhikkhu, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa
analyzed: kimi kulānam āvāsa bhāvena vammikaḥ vammikaḥ iti kho bhikkhu imassa etam cātumahābhūtikassa
translated: “Ant-hill” is a place for the dwelling of the families of ants,

original: kāyassa adhivacana”ntiādīsu viya. Yatheva hi bāhirako vammiko, vamati vantako vantussayo
analyzed: kāyassa adhivacana nti ādīsu viya yathā iva hi bāhirakaḥ vammikaḥ vamati vantakaḥ
translated: as in the passage beginning, “The body is a designation for the four great elements” .🔽For just as the external anthill is called “an anthill” for four reasons, so too is the body.🔽It vomits forth various kinds of living beings such as snakes, mongooses, vipers, rats, and so on,

original: vantasinehasambaddhoti catūhi kāraṇehi “vammiko”ti vuccati. So hi ahinakulaundūragharagoḷikādayo🔽nānappakāre pāṇake vamatīti vammiko. Upacikāhi vantakoti vammiko. Upacikāhi vamitvā
analyzed: vanta sineha sambaddho ti catūhi kāraṇehi vammikaḥ ti vuccati saḥ hi ahi nakula aundūra ghara goḷikā ādayo  nānappakāre pāṇake vamati iti vammikaḥ upacikāhi vantako iti vammikaḥ upacikāhi vamitvā
translated: so it is called “an anthill” . It is an anthill because it is built up by the ants’ vomit.

original: mukhatuṇḍakehi ukkhittapaṃsucuṇṇena kaṭippamāṇenapi porisappamāṇenapi ussitoti vammiko.
analyzed: mukha tuṇḍakehi ukkhitta paṃsu cuṇṇena kaṭi ppamāṇena api porisa ppamāṇena api ussitaḥ ti vammikaḥ
translated: The ants’ vomit is the dust and particles of soil thrown up by the ants’ mouths and beaks, which is built up to the size of a termite-mound or the size of a man.

original: Upacikāhi vantakheḷasinehena ābaddhatāya sattasattāhaṃ deve vassantepi na vippakirīyati,
analyzed: vanta kheḷa sinehena ābaddha tāya satta sattāham deve vassante pi na vippakirīyati
translated: It is an anthill because it is bound together by the ants’ saliva. Even when it rains for seven days on end, the anthill does not crumble away,

original: nidāghepi tato paṃsumuṭṭhiṃ gahetvā tasmiṃ muṭṭhinā pīḷiyamāne sineho nikkhamati,🔽evaṃ vantasinehena sambaddhoti vammiko. Evamayaṃ kāyopi “akkhimhā aggigūthako”tiādinā
analyzed: nidāghe pi paṃsu muṭṭhim gahetvā tasmin muṭṭhinā pīḷiyamāne sinehaḥ nikkhamati  evam vanta sinehena sambaddhaḥ ti vammikaḥ evam ayam kāyaḥ api akkhimhā aggi gūthakaḥ iti ādinā
translated: and when a handful of soil is taken from it and pressed in the hand, the saliva exudes.🔽So it is called “an anthill” because it is bound together by the ants’ saliva. So too, the body vomits forth various kinds of impurities and filth, beginning with “eye-dirt, ear-dirt, snot, and phlegm,”🔽so it is called “an anthill” .

original: nayena nānappakāraṃ asucikalimalaṃ vamatīti vammiko. Buddhapaccekabuddhakhīṇāsavā
analyzed: nayena nānappakāram asuci kali malam vamati iti vammikaḥ buddha paccekabuddha khīṇa āsavā
translated: The Buddha, Paccekabuddhas, and those who have attained arahatship

original: imasmiṃ attabhāve nikantipariyādānena attabhāvaṃ chaḍḍetvā gatāti ariyehi vantakotipi
analyzed: imasmin atta bhāve nikanti pariyādānena atta bhāvam chaḍḍetvā gatā ati ariyehi
translated: He has gone by the exhaustion of his attachment to this selfhood, thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ .

original: vammiko. Yehi cāyaṃ tīhi aṭṭhisatehi ussito nahārusambaddho maṃsāvalepano allacammapariyonaddho
analyzed: vammikaḥ yehi ca ayam tīhi aṭṭhi satehi ussitaḥ nahāru sambaddhaḥ maṃsa avalepanaḥ alla camma pariyonaddhaḥ
translated: And the bones that are piled up in this selfhood, bound together with sinews, plastered over with flesh, covered with moist inner skin,

original: chavirañjito satte vañceti, taṃ sabbaṃ ariyehi vantamevāti vantussayotipi vammiko.
analyzed: chavi rañjitaḥ satte vañceti tam sabbam ariyehi vantam eva ati vammikaḥ
translated: wrapped in dry outer skin, and deceive beings, all that is despised by the Noble Ones, thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ .

original: “Taṇhā janeti purisaṃ, cittamassa vidhāvatī”ti evaṃ taṇhāya janitattā ariyehi vanteneva
analyzed: taṇhā janeti purisam cittam assa vidhāvati iti evam taṇhāya janita ttā ariyehi vantena iva
translated: And because he is generated by craving in the way beginning, ‘Craving generates the person, his cognizance runs wild’ , he is despised by the Noble Ones as if generated by craving,

original: taṇhāsinehena sambaddho ayanti vantasinehena sambaddhotipi vammiko. Yathā ca vammikassa
analyzed: taṇhā sinehena sambaddhaḥ vanta sinehena sambaddhaḥ utipi vammikaḥ yathā ca vammikassa
translated: thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ . And because he is bound up with the craving for what is despised, he is despised by the Noble Ones as if bound up with the affection for what is despised, thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ .

original: anto nānappakārā pāṇakā tattheva jāyanti, uccārapassāvaṃ karonti, gilānā sayanti,🔽matā nipatanti. Iti so tesaṃ sūtigharaṃ vaccakuṭi gilānasālā susānañca hoti. Evaṃ
analyzed: antar nānappakārā pāṇakā tattha iva jāyanti uccāra passāvam karonti gilānā sayanti  matāḥ nipatanti iti saḥ tesam sūtigharam vaccakuṭi gilāna sālā susānam ca hoti evam
translated: And just as in an ant-hill there are various kinds of creatures that are born there, defecate there, lie down and get up there,🔽die there, and fall down there, so too this selfhood is a lying-in home, a privy, a sick-room, and a charnel-ground for various kinds of creatures,

original: khattiyamahāsālādīnampi kāyo “ayaṃ gopitarakkhito maṇḍitapasādito mahānubhāvānaṃ
analyzed: khattiya mahāsāla ādīnam pi kāyaḥ ayam gopita rakkhitaḥ maṇḍita pasāditaḥ mahā anubhāvānam
translated: thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ . And just as an ant-hill is the resort of ants and not the resort of such creatures as tortoises, so too this selfhood is the resort of craving and not the resort of such creatures as the Noble Ones,🔽thus he is ‘despised by the Noble Ones’ .

original: kāyo”ti acintetvā chavinissitā pāṇā cammanissitā pāṇā maṃsanissitā pāṇā nahārunissitā
analyzed: kāyaḥ iti a cintetvā chavi nissitā pāṇā camma nissitā pāṇā maṃsa nissitā pāṇā nahāru nissitā
translated: without thinking, “There are living beings dependent on the outer skin, the inner skin, the flesh, the sinews, the bones, the bone marrow.”

original: pāṇā aṭṭhinissitā pāṇā aṭṭhimiñjanissitā pāṇāti evaṃ kulagaṇanāya asītimattāni kimikulasahassāni
analyzed: pāṇā aṭṭhi nissitā pāṇā aṭṭhimiñja nissitā pāṇā ati evam kula gaṇanāya asīti mattāni kimi kula sahassāni
translated: In this way, by counting the families, there are eighty thousand kinds of worms

original: antokāyasmiṃyeva jāyanti, uccārapassāvaṃ karonti, gelaññena āturitāni sayanti, matāmatā
analyzed: antokāyasmiṃyeva jāyanti uccāra passāvam karonti gelaññena āturitāni sayanti mata amatā
translated: that are born, defecate and urinate, lie down and die in the body itself.

original: nipatanti. Iti ayampi tesaṃ pāṇānaṃ sūtigharaṃ vaccakuṭi gilānasālā susānañca hotīti
analyzed: nipatanti iti ayam pi tesam pāṇānam sūtigharam vaccakuṭi gilāna sālā susānam ca hoti iti
translated: So this is a lying-in hospital, a privy, a hospital ward, and a charnel ground for those living beings.

original: “vammiko”ti saṅkhaṃ gato.🔽Manāpāmanāpapatanaṭṭhena nagaraṃ “sakkāyanagara”ntiādīsu viya. Rogādīnaṃ nīḷabhāvena
analyzed: vammikā iti saṅkham gataḥ  manāpa amanāpa patana ṭṭhena nagaram roga ādīnam nīḍa bhāvena
translated: It is called a “womb”🔽in the sense of a place for the pleasant and unpleasant, like the city in the passage beginning, “The city of the heart, the stronghold of death” .🔽In the sense of a lair for diseases, etc.,🔽like the passage beginning, “The lair of the kamma-born, the lair of the kamma-born” .

original: kulāvakabhāvena nīḷaṃ “roganīḷaṃ pabhaṅgura”ntiādīsu viya. Paṭisandhiyā nivāsagehaṭṭhena
analyzed: kulāvaka bhāvena nīḷam roga nīḷam pabhaṅgu ranti ādīsu paṭisandhiyā nivāsa geha ṭṭhena
