stations of consciousness, in the round of the nine abodes of beings, in the round of the three realms, in the

original: paramavodānappattāna”nti evameke vaṇṇayanti. Nirūpadhīnanti vigatūpadhīnaṃ. Visaṅkhāragatānanti
analyzed: parama vodāna pattānam ti evam eke vaṇṇayanti vigata upadhīnam visaṅkhāra gatānam
translated: some describe them as “having reached the highest purity.” “Without underlying tendency”: without underlying tendency to lust, etc. “Gone to the destruction of the cankers”:

original: saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ cajitvā vigatasaṅkhāraṃ nibbānaṃ ārammaṇavasena upagatānaṃ. Visaṅkhāragataṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra ārammaṇam cajitvā vigata saṅkhāram nibbānam ārammaṇa vasena upagatānam visaṅkhāra gatam
translated: Some describe it as “having reached the highest purity.” “Without clinging”: without clinging to anything. “Gone to the destruction of the substratum”: gone to Nibbāna, the destruction of the substratum, by way of object, having abandoned the substratum of formations. “Gone to the destruction of the substratum”

original: cittanti etthapi hi nibbānameva “visaṅkhāra”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cittanti ettha api hi nibbānam eva visaṅkhāranti vuttam
translated: Here too, Nibbāna is called “the destruction of the substratum.”

original: Vidūreti vividhe dūre. Suvidūreti suṭṭhu vidūre. Na santiketi na samīpe. Na sāmantāti
analyzed: vidūrā iti vividhe dūre su vidūrā iti suṭṭhu vidūre na santikā iti na samīpe na sāmantā ati
translated: “Far away”: far away from the various things. “Very far away”: very far away. “Not near”: not near. “Not in the vicinity”:

original: na ekapasse. Anāsanneti anaccantasamīpe. Vivekaṭṭheti atidūre, vigateti attho. Tādisoti
analyzed: na eka passe anāsannā iti anaccanta samīpe viveka ṭṭhā iti atidūre vigatā iti attho tādisaḥ ti
translated: not in one place. “Not in the immediate vicinity”: not in the immediate vicinity. “Far removed”: very far away; the meaning is, “gone.” “Such”:

original: taṃsadiso. Tassaṇṭhitoti tena ākārena ṭhito. Tappakāroti tena pakārena ṭhito. Tappaṭibhāgoti
analyzed: taṃsadisaḥ tassaṇṭhitaḥ iti tena ākārena ṭhitaḥ tad pakāraḥ iti tena pakārena ṭhitaḥ tad paṭibhāgaḥ iti
translated: like that. “Standing in that”: standing in that mode. “In that way”: standing in that manner. “In that aspect”:

original: taṃkoṭṭhāsiko. Atha vā “attabhāvaguhāya laggabhāvena tādiso. Kilesehi channabhāvena
analyzed: taṃkoṭṭhāsikaḥ atha vā atta bhāva guhāya lagga bhāvena tādisaḥ kilesehi channa bhāvena
translated: in that part. Or alternatively, “such” means “clinging to the cave of the body”; “far away” means “far away from the defilements”;🔽“very far away” means “very far away from the defilements”; “not near” means “not near the defilements”; “not in the vicinity” means “not in the vicinity of the defilements”; “not in the immediate vicinity” means “not in the immediate vicinity of the defilements”; “far removed” means “very far removed from the defilements”; “gone to the destruction of the substratum” means “gone to the destruction of the substratum of the defilements.”

original: tassaṇṭhito. Mohanasmiṃ pagāḷhabhāvena tappakāro. Tīhi vivekehi dūrabhāvena tappaṭibhāgoti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: tassa ṭhitaḥ mohanasmin pagāḷha bhāvena tad pakāro tīhi vivekehi dūra bhāvena tad paṭibhāgaḥ ti evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: and it is hard to get out of it. It is hard to get out of it because of the depth of the delusion in it, they say. And it is hard to get out of it because of the distance from it by means of the three kinds of seclusion.

original: Duppahāyāti sukhena pahātabbā na honti. Duccajjāti sukhena jahituṃ na sakkā. Duppariccajjāti
analyzed: duppahāyā ati sukhena pahātabbāḥ na honti duccajjā ati sukhena jahitum na sakkā duppariccajjā ati
translated: Hard to abandon: they are not easy to abandon. Hard to give up: they cannot be given up easily. Hard to relinquish:

original: sabbākārena jahituṃ na sakkā. Dunnimmadayāti nimmadaṃ amadaṃ kātuṃ na sakkā. Dubbiniveṭhayāti🔽viniveṭhanaṃ mocanaṃ kātuṃ na sakkā. Duttarāti uttaritvā atikkantuṃ na sakkā. Duppatarāti
analyzed: sabba ākārena jahitum na sakkā dunnimmadayāti nimmadam a madam kātum na sakkā dubbiniveṭhayāti  viniveṭhanam mocanam kātum na sakkā duttarāti uttaritvā atikkantum na sakkā duppatarāti
translated: they cannot be relinquished in every way. Hard to cool: they cannot be cooled by non-delusion. Hard to remove:🔽they cannot be removed by non-concealment. Hard to cross over: they cannot be crossed over by being gone beyond. Hard to get across:

original: visesetvā tarituṃ na sakkā. Dussamatikkamāti dukkhena atikkamitabbā. Dubbinivattāti🔽nivattetuṃ dukkhā. Atha vā “pakativasena duppariccajjā. Goṇapatāsaṃ viya dunnimmadayā.
analyzed: visesetvā taritum na sakkā dussamatikkamā ati dukkhena atikkamitabbā dubbinivattā ati  nivattetum dukkhā atha vā pakati vasena duppariccajjā goṇa patāsam viya dunnimmadayā
translated: they cannot be got across by being gone specially across. Hard to get out of: they are hard to get out of by being gone out of. Hard to turn back:🔽they are hard to turn back by being turned back. Or alternatively, they are hard to give up in the sense of giving up the road. They are hard to cool in the sense that they cannot be cooled by non-delusion, like a blanket of goat’s hair.

original: Nāgapāsaṃ viya dubbiniveṭhayā. Gimhasamaye marukantāraṃ viya duttarā duppatarā. Byagghapariggahitā
analyzed: nāga pāsam viya gimha samaye maru kantāram viya duttarā duppatarā byaggha pariggahitā
translated: They are hard to remove in the sense that they cannot be removed by non-concealment, like a snake’s slough. They are hard to cross over and hard to get across in the sense that they are hard to cross over and hard to get across like a desert in summer. They are hard to turn back in the sense that they are hard to turn back by being turned back, like a chariot with a refractory yoke-ox going down a steep place.

original: aṭavī viya dussamatikkamā. Samuddavīci viya dubbinivattāti evameke vaṇṇayanti.🔽8. Evaṃ paṭhamagāthāya “dūre vivekā hi tathāvidho”ti sādhetvā puna tathāvidhānaṃ🔽sattānaṃ dhammataṃ āvi karonto “icchānidānā”tiādigāthamāha. Tattha icchānidānāti🔽taṇhāhetukā. Bhavasātabaddhāti sukhavedanādimhi bhavasātena baddhā. Te duppamuñcāti
analyzed: aṭavī viya dussamatikkamā samudda vīci viya dubbinivattā ti evam eke vaṇṇayanti  evam dūre hi tathāvidhā iti sādhetvā  sattānam dhammataṃ āvi karontaḥ icchā nidānā iti ādi gātham āha tattha icchā nidānā iti  taṇhā hetukā bhava sāta baddhā ati sukha vedanā ādimhi bhava sātena baddhā te duppamuñcā ati
translated: and the second, like a forest for the crossing of the difficult. And like the ocean’s rim for the difficult to cross, some explain.

original: te bhavasātavatthubhūtā dhammā. Te vā tattha baddhā icchānidānā sattā duppamocayā.
analyzed: te bhava sāta vatthu bhūtā dhammā te vā tattha baddhā icchā nidānā sattā duppamocayā
translated: So after establishing the first stanza with the words “For such a one, seclusion is far away,” he spoke the second stanza beginning with “With craving as their source” in order to reveal the nature of such beings. Herein, with craving as their source means with craving as their cause. Bound by the fetter of delight in being means bound by the fetter of delight in the feeling of pleasure, etc., in being. They are hard to free means these things that are the basis for the delight in being, or the beings bound there by craving as their source, are hard to free.

original: Na hi aññamokkhāti aññe ca mocetuṃ na sakkonti. Kāraṇavacanaṃ vā etaṃ. Te sattā duppamuñcā.
analyzed: na hi añña mokkhāti aññe ca mocetum na sakkonti kāraṇa vacanam vā etam te sattāḥ duppamuñcā
translated: For they cannot free themselves, or this is a reason clause: they are hard to free.

original: Kasmā? Yasmā aññena mocetabbā na honti. Yadi sattā muñceyyuṃ, sakena thāmena muñceyyunti
analyzed: kasmai yasmai aññena mocetabbāḥ na honti yadi sattāḥ muñceyyum sakena thāmena muñceyyunti
translated: Why? Because they are not to be freed by another. If beings could free themselves, they would free themselves by their own strength.

original: ayamassa attho. Pacchā pure vāpi apekkhamānāti anāgate atīte vā kāme apekkhamānā.
analyzed: ayam assa atthaḥ pacchā pure vā api apekkhamānā ati anāgate atīte vā kāme apekkhamānā
translated: This is the meaning. Expectant of what is past and what is yet to come means expectant of sensual desires in the past and in the future.

original: Ime va kāme purime va jappanti ime vā paccuppanne kāme purime vā duvidhepi atītānāgate
analyzed: ime va kāme purime va jappanti ime vā paccuppanne kāme purime vā duvidhe pi atīta anāgate
translated: which are the two kinds of sensual desires.

original: balavataṇhāya patthayamānā. Imesañca dvinnaṃ padānaṃ “te duppamuñcā na hi aññamokkhā”ti🔽imināva saha sambandho veditabbo. Itarathā apekkhamānā jappaṃ kiṃ karonti, kiṃ vā
analyzed: balava taṇhāya patthayamānāḥ imesam ca dvinnam padānam te duppamuñcāḥ na hi  iminā ava saha sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ itarathā apekkhamānāḥ jappam kim karonti kim vā
translated: And the connection of these two terms with the words “hard to abandon, not easily abandoned”

original: katāti na paññāyeyyuṃ.
analyzed: katā ati na paññāyeyyum
translated: should be understood in the way already stated. Otherwise, if they were to be connected with the words “they are the same as the past and future,” it would not be known what they are that are “hard to abandon, not easily abandoned.”

original: Bhavasātabaddhāti bhave sātaṃ bhavasātaṃ, tena bhavasātena sukhassādena baddhā hutvā
analyzed: bhava sāta baddhā ati bhave sātam bhava sātam tena bhava sātena sukhassādena baddhā hutvā
translated: “Bound by the fetter of sensual desires”: sensual desires are pleasure in existence, pleasure of existence; they are bound by that pleasure of existence, bound by the pleasure of existence, bound by the pleasure of the existence of sensual desires.

original: ṭhitā. Taṃ bhājetvā dassetuṃ “ekaṃ bhavasātaṃ – sukhā vedanā”tiādimāha. Yobbanabhāvo
analyzed: ṭhitā tam bhājetvā dassetum ekam bhava sātam sukhā vedanā iti ādim āha yobbana bhāvaḥ
translated: Having thus divided the compound, he shows it with the words “One kind of pleasure of existence is pleasant feeling” and so on.🔽Youthfulness is the state of being young.

original: yobbaññaṃ. Arogabhāvo ārogyaṃ. Jīvitindriyassa pavattabhāvo jīvitaṃ. Lābhoti catunnaṃ
analyzed: aroga bhāvaḥ ārogyam jīvitindriyassa pavatta bhāvaḥ jīvitam lābho ti catunnam
translated: Health is the state of being healthy. Life is the state of the presence of the life faculty. Gain is the acquisition of the four requisites.

original: paccayānaṃ lābho. Yasoti parivāro. Pasaṃsāti kitti. Sukhanti kāyikacetasikaṃ sukhaṃ.
analyzed: paccayānam lābhaḥ yasoti parivāro sukhanti kāyika cetasikam sukham
translated: Fame is the retinue. Praise is reputation. Pleasure is bodily and mental pleasure.

original: Manāpikā rūpāti manavaḍḍhanakā rūpā. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: manāpikā rūpā ati sesesu pi esā iva nayo
translated: Delightful forms are forms that increase delight. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Cakkhusampadāti cakkhussa sampadā. “Mayhaṃ cakkhu sampannaṃ maṇivimāne ugghāṭitasīhapañjaraṃ🔽viya khāyatī”ti uppannaṃ sukhassādaṃ sandhāya “cakkhusampadā”ti vuttaṃ. Sotasampadādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Sukhāya vedanāya sātabaddhā…pe… vibaddhāti vividhākārena baddhā. Ābaddhāti
analyzed: cakkhu sampadā ati cakkhussa sampadā mayham cakkhu sampannam maṇi vimāne ugghāṭita sīha pañjaram  viya khāyati iti uppannam sukha ssādam sandhāya cakkhu sampadā iti vuttam sota sampad ādīsu pi  sukhāya vedanāya vibaddhā ati vividha ākārena baddhā ābaddhā ati
translated: ‘Eye-purity’: the purity of the eye. ‘Eye-purity’ is said with reference to the relish for pleasure that arises thus: ‘My eye appears to me as though it were a crystal casket with the lid off.’ The same method applies in the case of ear-purity, etc.

original: visesena ādito baddhā. Laggāti ārammaṇena saddhiṃ appitā. Laggitāti nāgadante phāṇitavārako🔽viya laggitā. Yamettha ca avuttaṃ, taṃ satto visattotiādimhi vuttanayena gahetabbaṃ.🔽Na hi aññamokkhāti na parehi mokkhā. Te vā bhavasātavatthū duppamuñcāti bhave sukhassādavatthubhūtā🔽dhammā te muñcituṃ dukkhā. Sattā vā etto dummocayāti sattā eva vā etasmā bhavasātavatthuto mocetuṃ dukkhā.
analyzed: visesena āditas baddhā laggā ati ārammaṇena saddhim appitā laggitā ati nāgadante phāṇitavārako 🔽viya laggitā yam ettha ca avuttam tam sattaḥ visattaḥ iti ādimhi vutta nayena gahetabbam 🔽na hi añña mokkhā ati na parehi mokkhā te vā bhava sāta vatthū bhave 🔽dhammā te muñcitum dukkhā sattāḥ vai ettas sattāḥ eva vai etasmā bhava sāta vatthutaḥ mocetum dukkhā
translated: ‘Bound up with pleasant feeling’: bound up with the pleasant feeling that arises in the eye door, etc. ‘Bound up with painful feeling’: bound up with the painful feeling that arises in the eye door, etc. ‘Bound up with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling’: bound up with the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling that arises in the eye door, etc. ‘Bound up in various ways’: bound up in various ways with the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Bound up from the beginning’: bound up from the very beginning with the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Clinging’: adhering to the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Sticking’: sticking to the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Glued’: glued to the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Adhering’: adhering to the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Entangled’: entangled in the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Entwined’: entwined in the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Entangled and entwined’: entangled and entwined in the pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings that arise in the eye door, etc. ‘Not released’: not released by others. ‘Hard to release’: hard to release oneself. ‘Hard to extricate’: hard to extricate oneself. ‘Hard to disentangle’: hard to disentangle oneself. ‘Hard to unentwine’: hard to unentwine oneself. ‘Hard to extricate and disentangle and unentwine’: hard to

original: Duruddharāti uddharituṃ dukkhā. Dussamuddharāti samantato chinnataṭe narakāvāṭe patito🔽viya uddhaṃ katvā uddharituṃ dukkhā. Dubbuṭṭhāpayāti uṭṭhāpetuṃ dukkhā. Dussamuṭṭhāpayāti
analyzed: duruddharāti uddharitum dukkhā dussamuddharāti samantataḥ chinna taṭe naraka āvāṭe patitaḥ  viya uddham katvā uddharitum dukkhā uṭṭhāpetum dukkhā dussamuṭṭhāpayāti
translated: Hard to pull out : hard to pull out. Hard to drag out : hard to drag out by pulling up as one who has fallen into a hell-pit with its banks cut away all round.

original: sukhumaattabhāvaṃ pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāpanaṃ viya ussāpetuṃ ativiya dukkhā.
analyzed: sukhuma atta bhāvam pathaviyam patiṭṭhāpanam viya ussāpetum ati viya dukkhā
translated: Hard to raise up : hard to raise up. Hard to lift up : hard to lift up by raising up as one who has fallen on the ground with a delicate body.

original: Te attanā palipapalipannāti gambhīrakaddame yāva sīsato nimuggā na sakkonti. Paraṃ🔽palipapalipannaṃ uddharitunti aparaṃ tatheva nimuggaṃ hatthe vā sīse vā gahetvā uddharitvā
analyzed: te attanā gambhīra kaddame yāva sīsataḥ nimuggāḥ na sakkonti param  uddharitunti aparam tathā iva nimuggam hatthe vā sīse vā gahetvā uddharitvā
translated: They are themselves submerged : they are submerged up to their heads in a deep morass and are unable to get out.

original: thale patiṭṭhāpetuṃ na sakkonti. So vata cundāti soti vattabbākārapuggalaniddeso.🔽Tassa “yo”ti imaṃ uddesavacanaṃ āharitvā yo attanā palipapalipanno, so vata, cunda,
analyzed: thale patiṭṭhāpetum na sakkonti saḥ vata cunda ati saḥ ti vattabba ākāra puggala niddeso  tassa yaḥ ti imam uddesa vacanam āharitvā yaḥ attanā saḥ vata cunda
translated: They are unable to pull out another who is submerged : they are unable to pull out another who is submerged in the same way by the head or by the hand and to set him on dry land.🔽So, Cunda : this is a demonstrative pronoun indicating a person who should be spoken of as “he.”

original: paraṃ palipapalipannaṃ uddharissatīti. Evaṃ sesapadesu sambandho veditabbo. Palipapalipannoti
analyzed: param palipa palipannam uddharissati iti evam sesa padesu sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ palipa palipannaḥ ti
translated: After that, the words “he who” are a summary statement. So, Cunda, he who is himself submerged will pull out another who is submerged—thus the connection should be understood in the other passages too. Submerged :

original: gambhīrakaddame nimuggo vuccati. Yathā, cunda, koci puriso yāva sīsato gambhīrakaddame
analyzed: gambhīra kaddame nimuggaḥ vuccati yathā cunda koci purisaḥ yāva sīsataḥ gambhīra kaddame
translated: is said to be submerged in a deep morass. Just as, Cunda, some person, from the head down, is submerged in a deep morass,

original: nimuggo, parampi tatheva nimuggaṃ hatthe vā sīse vā gahetvā uddharissatīti netaṃ
analyzed: nimuggaḥ param pi tathā iva nimuggam hatthe vā sīse vā gahetvā uddharissati iti na etam
translated: is said to be submerged in a deep pit. Just as if a man were submerged in a deep pit up to his head, and another man, submerged in the same way, were to seize him by the head or seize him by the body, and pull him out, it is not possible.

original: ṭhānaṃ vijjati. Na hi taṃ kāraṇamatthi, yena so taṃ uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpeyyāti.
analyzed: ṭhānam vijjati na hi tam kāraṇam atthi yena saḥ tam uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpeyya ati
translated: There is no reason why he should pull him out and set him on dry land.

original: Adanto avinīto aparinibbutoti ettha pana anibbisevanatāya adanto. Asikkhitavinayatāya
analyzed: a dantaḥ a vinītaḥ a parinibbutaḥ ti ettha pana a nibbisevana tāya a dantaḥ a sikkhita vinaya tāya
translated: As to “untamed, untrained, unpurified”: he is untamed because he has not practiced the training;

original: avinīto. Anibbutakilesatāya aparinibbutoti veditabbo. So tādiso paraṃ damessati nibbisevanaṃ
analyzed: avinītaḥ anibbuta kilesa tāya aparinibbutaḥ iti veditabbaḥ saḥ tādisaḥ param damessati nibbisevanam
translated: untrained because he has not learned the training; unpurified because his defilements are not extinguished.

original: karissati, vinessati tisso sikkhā sikkhāpessati. Parinibbāpessati tassa kilese nibbāpessati.
analyzed: karissati vinessati tissaḥ sikkhāḥ sikkhāpessati parinibbāpessati tassa kilese nibbāpessati
translated: Such a one will tame another, will practice the training, will train in the three trainings, will purify another, will extinguish another’s defilements.

original: Natthañño kocīti añño koci puggalo mocetuṃ samattho natthi. Sakena thāmenāti attano
analyzed: nattha aññaḥ koci iti aññaḥ koci puggalaḥ mocetum samatthaḥ natthi sakena thāmena ati attanaḥ
translated: There is no other person who is able to liberate him. By his own strength: by his own strength of energy.

original: ñāṇathāmena. Balenāti ñāṇabalena. Vīriyenāti ñāṇasampayuttacetasikavīriyena. Purisaparakkamenāti
analyzed: ñāṇa thāmena balena ati ñāṇa balena vīriyena ati ñāṇa sampayutta cetasika vīriyena purisa parakkamena ati
translated: By the front of knowledge. By strength: by the strength of knowledge. By energy: by the energy of mind associated with knowledge. By the utmost of manly exertion:

original: paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanena mahantavīriyena.
analyzed: param param ṭhānam akkamanena mahanta vīriyena
translated: by the great energy of going to the utmost, to the furthermost, place.

original: Nāhaṃ sahissāmīti ahaṃ na sahissāmi na sakkomi, na vāyamissāmīti vuttaṃ hoti. Pamocanāyāti pamocetuṃ. Kathaṃkathinti sakaṅkhaṃ. Dhotakāti ālapanaṃ. Taresīti tareyyāsi.
analyzed: na aham sahissāmi iti aham na sahissāmi na sakkomi na vā āyamissāmi iti vuttam hoti pamocanāya ati pamocetum kathaṃkathinti sakaṅkham dhotaka ati ālapanam taresi iti tareyyāsi
translated: I will not endure: I will not endure it, I am not able, I will not strive, is what is said. For the sake of deliverance: for the sake of deliverance. How? How? is a question. Dhotakas: an address. You will cross: you will cross over.

original: “Attanā hi kataṃ pāpaṃ, attanā saṃkilissati;
analyzed: attanā hi katam pāpam attanā saṃkilissati
translated: Evil is done by oneself, by oneself defiled,

original: Attanā akataṃ pāpaṃ, attanāva visujjhati;
analyzed: attanā a katam pāpam attanā ava visujjhati
translated: Evil is done by oneself, by oneself purified;🔽Purity and impurity belong to oneself,

original: Suddhī asuddhi paccattaṃ, nāñño aññaṃ visodhaye”ti. –🔽Etthāyamattho – yena attanā akusalaṃ kammaṃ kataṃ hoti, so catūsu apāyesu dukkhaṃ
analyzed: suddhī paccattam na aññaḥ aññam visodhaya iti  ettha ayam atthaḥ yena attanā akusalam kammam katam hoti so catūsu apāyesu dukkham
translated: No one can purify another.🔽Herein, this is the meaning: By oneself who has done evil, unwholesome, kamma,

original: anubhavanto attanāva saṃkilissati. Yena pana attanā akataṃ pāpaṃ, so sugatiñceva
analyzed: anubhavantaḥ attanā ava saṃkilissati yena pana attanā a katam pāpam saḥ sugatim ca iva
translated: while experiencing suffering in the four lower worlds, is defiled. But by oneself who has not done evil,

original: agatiñca gacchanto attanāva visujjhati. Kusalakammasaṅkhātā suddhi akusalakammasaṅkhātā
analyzed: agatim ca gacchantaḥ attanā ava visujjhati kusala kamma saṅkhātā suddhi akusala kamma saṅkhātā
translated: and he who goes to the wrong place is purified by himself. Purification is called good kamma and impurity is called bad kamma.

original: ca asuddhi paccattaṃ kārakasattānaṃ attaniyeva vipaccati. Añño puggalo aññaṃ puggalaṃ
analyzed: ca paccattam kāraka sattānam attaniyā iva vipaccati aññaḥ puggalaḥ aññam puggalam
translated: Purification and impurity ripen in the individual doer himself.🔽No one can purify another person,

original: na visodhaye neva visodheti, na kilesetīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na visodhaye na iva visodheti na kileseti iti vuttam hoti
translated: nor can he defile another.🔽Nibbana remains: the great deathless Nibbana remains.

original: Tiṭṭhateva nibbānanti amatamahānibbānaṃ tiṭṭhatiyeva. Nibbānagāmimaggoti pubbabhāgavipassanāto
analyzed: tiṭṭhatā iva nibbānanti amata mahānibbānam tiṭṭhatiyā iva nibbāna gāmi maggo ti pubba bhāga vipassanāto
translated: The path leading to Nibbana: from the time of insight in the preliminary stage🔽onwards, the Noble Path.

original: paṭṭhāya ariyamaggo. Tiṭṭhāmahaṃ samādapetāti ahaṃ gaṇhāpetā patiṭṭhāpetā tiṭṭhāmi.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya ariya maggo tiṭṭhāma aham samādapetā ati aham gaṇhāpetā patiṭṭhāpetā tiṭṭhāmi
translated: I remain exhorting and instructing: I remain exhorting and instructing.🔽Thus exhorted and instructed: thus exhorted and instructed by me.

original: Evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānāti mayā evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā. Ettha🔽uppanne vatthusmiṃ vadanto ovadati nāma, anuppanne vatthusmiṃ anusāsanto “ayasopi
analyzed: evam ovadiyamānā evam anusāsiyamānā ati mayā evam ovadiyamānā evam anusāsiyamānā ettha  uppanne vatthusmim vadantaḥ ovadati nāma an uppanne vatthusmim anusāsantaḥ ayasaḥ pi
translated: Here: in this case.

original: te bhavissatī”tiādivasena anāgataṃ dassento anusāsati nāma. Sammukhā vadantopi ovadati
analyzed: te bhavissati iti ādi vasena anāgatam dassentaḥ anusāsati nāma sammukhāḥ vadantaḥ api ovadati
translated: Exhorting is speaking about a matter that has arisen; instructing is showing the future by saying, “This will happen to you too,” etc., about a matter that has not yet arisen.🔽Exhorting and instructing face to face is called “exhorting and instructing.”

original: nāma, parammukhā dūtasāsanaṃ vā pesento anusāsati nāma. Sakiṃ vadantopi ovadati nāma,
analyzed: nāma parammukhāḥ dūta sāsanam vā pesentaḥ anusāsati nāma sakim vadantaḥ api ovadati nāma
translated: He instructs by sending a message to someone else, saying, “Tell so-and-so this.” He admonishes by speaking himself.

original: punappunaṃ vadanto anusāsati nāma. Ovadanto eva vā anusāsati nāma. Appekacceti api
analyzed: punappunam vadantaḥ anusāsati nāma ovadantaḥ eva vā anusāsati nāma appekacca iti api
translated: He instructs by speaking again and again. Or he admonishes by speaking.🔽Some: some, a few.🔽The meaning is: some.

original: ekacce, eketi attho. Accantaniṭṭhaṃ nibbānaṃ ārādhentīti khayavayasaṅkhātaṃ antaṃ
analyzed: ekacce eke iti atthaḥ accanta niṭṭham nibbānam ārādhenti iti khaya vaya saṅkhātam antam
translated: They reach the ultimate end, Nibbāna: the end called destruction and fall is the ultimate.

original: atītanti accantaṃ, accantañca taṃ sabbasaṅkhārānaṃ appavattiṭṭhānattā niṭṭhañcāti
analyzed: atītam ti accantam accantam ca tam sabba saṅkhārānam appavatti ṭṭhāna ttā niṭṭham ca ati
translated: It is the ultimate because it is the end of all formations. And it is the end because it is the state of non-occurrence of all formations.

original: accantaniṭṭhaṃ, ekantaniṭṭhaṃ, satataniṭṭhanti attho. Taṃ accantanibbānaṃ ārādhenti
analyzed: accanta niṭṭham ekanta niṭṭham satata niṭṭham ti attho tam accanta nibbānam ārādhenti
translated: Thus it is the ultimate end. The meaning is: the sole end, the constant end. They reach that ultimate Nibbāna.🔽They accomplish it.

original: sampādenti. Nārādhentīti na sampādenti, na paṭilabhantīti attho. Ettha kyāhanti etesu
analyzed: sampādenti na ārādhenti iti na sampādenti na paṭilabhanti iti attho ettha etesu
translated: They do not reach: they do not accomplish it. The meaning is: they do not obtain it.🔽What can I do here? What can I do here for them?

original: kiṃ ahaṃ, kiṃ karomīti attho. Maggakkhāyīti paṭipadāmaggakkhāyī. Ācikkhati katheti.
analyzed: kim aham kim karomi iti atthaḥ magga khāyī iti paṭipadā magga khāyī ācikkhati kathā iti
translated: The one who shows the path: the one who shows the path of practice.🔽He explains, he teaches.

original: Attanā paṭipajjamānā muñceyyunti paṭipajjantā mayaṃ muñceyyuṃ.
analyzed: attanā paṭipajjamānāḥ muñceyyunti paṭipajjantāḥ mayam muñceyyuṃ
translated: If we were to practice, we would be released: if we were to practice, we would be released.

original: Atītaṃ upādāyāti atītaṃ paṭicca. Kathaṃ pure apekkhaṃ karotīti kena pakārena ikkhaṃ
analyzed: atītam upādāya ati atītam paṭicca katham pure apekkham karoti iti kena pakārena ikkham
translated: Taking the past as a basis: depending on the past. How does he make the past the object of his looking?

original: olokanaṃ karoti. Evaṃrūpo ahosinti dīgharassaaṇukathūlādivasena evaṃjātiko evarūpo
analyzed: olokanam karoti evaṃrūpaḥ dīgha rassa aṇuka thūla ādi vasena evaṃjātikaḥ evarūpaḥ
translated: In what way does he look? “I was in the past” : he looks in the way beginning “I was handsome or ugly” , “I was of such a name, family, clan, virtue, and wisdom, I ate such food, experienced such pleasure and pain, had such a life span, lived for so long, and so I died and was reborn.”

original: abhaviṃ. Tattha nandiṃ samannānetīti tasmiṃ rūpārammaṇe taṇhaṃ sammā ānayati upaneti.
analyzed: tattha nandim samannāneti iti tasmin rūpa ārammaṇe taṇham sammā ānayati upaneti
translated: “Therein he takes delight” : he brings craving to that form as object, he brings it along.

original: Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vedanā ādī supi esā iva nayoḥ
translated: The same method applies to feeling, etc.

original: “Iti me cakkhū”tiādayo vatthuārammaṇavasena taṇhuppattiṃ dassento āha. Iti rūpātīti
analyzed: iti me cakkhu uti ādayaḥ vatthu ārammaṇa vasena taṇhuppattim dassentaḥ āha iti
translated: “Thus was I in the past” : he says this in order to show the arising of craving through the object of the basis. Thus was I in the past: in this way I was in the past.

original: evaṃ rūpā iti. Tattha chandarāgapaṭibaddhanti tesu cakkhurūpesu dubbalasaṅkhāto chando🔽ca balavasaṅkhāto rāgo ca, tena chandarāgena paṭibaddhaṃ allīnaṃ. Viññāṇanti javanacittaṃ.
analyzed: evam rūpāḥ iti tattha chanda rāga paṭibaddhanti tesu cakkhu rūpesu dubbala saṅkhāto chando  ca balava saṅkhātaḥ rāgaḥ ca tena chanda rāgena paṭibaddham viññāṇanti javana cittam
translated: Therein he is bound by craving and lust : in those eye and form, weak craving and strong lust.🔽Consciousness : the impulsion consciousness.

original: Chandarāgapaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassāti tassa javanaviññāṇassa chandarāgena baddhabhāvā.
analyzed: chanda rāga paṭibaddha ttā viññāṇassa ati tassa javana viññāṇassa chanda rāgena baddha bhāvā
translated: Because of his being bound by craving and lust : because of the bound state of that impulsion consciousness by craving and lust.

original: Tadabhinandatīti taṃ ārammaṇaṃ taṇhāvasena abhinandati.
analyzed: tat abhinandati iti tam ārammaṇam taṇhā vasena abhinandati
translated: He delights in that : he delights in that object through craving.

original: Yānissa tānīti yāni assa tāni. Pubbeti atīte. Saddhinti ekato. Hasitalapitakīḷitānīti
analyzed: yāni assa tāni iti yāni assa tāni pubbe ti atīte saddhinti ekatas hasita lapita kīḷitāni iti
translated: ‘Whatever his’: whatever his. ‘In the past’: in the past time. ‘Together with’: together with. ‘Laugh-talk-play’:

original: dantavidaṃsādihasitāni ca, vacībhedaṃ katvā lapitāni ca, kāyakhiḍḍādikīḷitāni ca.
analyzed: danta vidaṃsa ādi hasitāni ca vacī bhedam katvā lapitāni ca kāya khiḍḍa ādi kīḷitāni ca
translated: teeth-showing-laughing and so on, and talk with a variety of words, and body-play and so on.

original: Tadassādetīti taṃ assādayati assādaṃ vindati sādiyati. Taṃ nikāmetīti taṃ nikāmayati🔽paccāsīsati. Vittiṃ āpajjatīti tuṭṭhiṃ pāpuṇāti.🔽Siyanti bhaveyyaṃ. Appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāyāti appattassa pāpuṇanatthāya. Cittaṃ paṇidahatīti cittaṃ ṭhapeti. Cetaso paṇidhānapaccayāti cittassa ṭhapanakāraṇā.🔽Sīlena vāti pañcasīlādisīlena vā. Vatena vāti dhutaṅgasamādānena vā. Tapena vāti
analyzed: tat assādeti iti tam assādayati assādam vindati sādiyati tam nikāmeti iti tam nikāmayati  paccāsīsati vittim āpajjati iti tuṭṭhim pāpuṇāti  siyanti bhaveyyam appaṭiladdhassa paṭilābhāya ati appattassa pāpuṇana thāya cittam paṇidahati iti cittam ṭhapeti cetasaḥ paṇidhāna paccayā ati cittassa ṭhapana kāraṇā  sīlena vāti pañcasīla ādi sīlena vā vatena vāti dhutaṅga samādānena vā tapena vāti
translated: ‘He delights in that’: he delights in that, he finds delight in that, he enjoys that. ‘He longs for that’: he longs for that,

original: vīriyasamādānena vā. Brahmacariyena vāti methunaviratiyā vā. Devo vāti mahānubhāvo🔽devarājā vā. Devaññataro vāti tesaṃ aññataro vā.
analyzed: vīriya samādānena vā brahmacariyena vā ati methuna viratiyā vā devaḥ vā ati mahā anubhāvaḥ 🔽devarājā vā devaññataraḥ vā ati tesam aññataraḥ vā
translated: he hankers after that. ‘He is devoted to that’: he is devoted to that, he is intent on that. ‘He is intent on that’: he is intent on that, he is fixed on that. ‘He is absorbed in that’: he is absorbed in that, he is engrossed in that. ‘He is attached to that’: he is attached to that, he is bound to that. ‘He is bound to that’: he is bound to that, he is fettered to that. ‘He is fettered to that’: he is fettered to that, he is tied to that. ‘He is tied to that’: he is tied to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that, he is joined to that. ‘He is joined to that’: he is joined to that,

original: Jappantāti guṇavasena kathentā. Pajappantāti pakārena kathentā. Abhijappantāti visesena kathentā, upasaggavasena vā vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: jappantā ati guṇa vasena kathentā pajappantā ati pakārena kathentā abhijappantā ati visesena kathentā upasagga vasena vā vaḍḍhitam
translated: Jappantīti kathentā guṇavasena. Pajappantīti pakārena kathentā. Abhijappantīti visesena kathentā, upasaggavasena vā vaḍḍhitaṃ.

original: 9. Evaṃ paṭhamagāthāya “dūre vivekā hi tathāvidho”ti sādhetvā dutiyagāthāya ca tathāvidhānaṃ dhammataṃ āvi katvā idāni tesaṃ pāpakaraṇaṃ āvi karonto “kāmesu giddhā”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: evam paṭhama gāthāya dūre vivekā hi tathāvidhā ti sādhetvā dutiya gāthāya ca tathāvidhānam dhammataṃ āvi katvā idāni tesam pāpa karaṇam āvi karontaḥ kāmesu giddhā iti gātham āha
translated: . Evaṃ paṭhamagāthāya “dūre vivekā hi tathāvidho”ti sādhetvā dutiyagāthāya ca tathāvidhānaṃ dhammataṃ āvi katvā idāni tesaṃ pāpakaraṇaṃ āvi karonto “kāmesu giddhā”ti gāthamāha.

original: Tassattho – te sattā kāmesu paribhogataṇhāya giddhā, pariyesanādimanuyuttattā pasutā,
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ te sattā kāmesu paribhoga taṇhāya giddhā pariyesana ādi manu yutta ttā pasutā
translated: Tassattho – te sattā kāmesu paribhogataṇhāya giddhā, pariyesanādimanuyuttattā pasutā,

original: sammohamāpannattā pamūḷhā, avagamanatāya macchariyatāya buddhādīnaṃ vacanaṃ anādiyatāya
analyzed: sammoham āpannattā pamūḍhāḥ avagamanatāya mad śariyatāya buddha ādīnam vacanam an ādiyatāya
translated: sammohamāpannattā pamūḷhā, avagamanatāya macchariyatāya buddhādīnaṃ vacanaṃ anādiyatāya

original: ca avadāniyā, kāyavisamādimhi visame niviṭṭhā, antakāle maraṇadukkhūpanītā, “kiṃsu
analyzed: ca avadāniyā kāya visama ādimhi visame niviṭṭhā anta kāle maraṇa dukkha upanītā
translated: ca avadāniyā, kāyavisamādimhi visame niviṭṭhā, antakāle maraṇadukkhūpanītā, “kiṃsu

original: bhavissāma ito cutāse”ti paridevayantīti.
analyzed: bhavissāmaḥ itas cutāsā iti paridevayanti iti
translated: bhavissāma ito cutāse”ti paridevayantīti.

original: Giddhāti kāmarāgena giddhā. Gadhitāti saṅkapparāgena paccāsīsamānā hutvā gadhitā.
analyzed: giddhā ati kāma rāgena giddhā gadhitā ati saṅkappa rāgena paccā āsīsamānā hutvā gadhitā
translated: Giddhāti kāmarāgena giddhā. Gadhitāti saṅkapparāgena paccāsīsamānā hutvā gadhitā.

original: Mucchitāti kāmataṇhāya mucchāparetā. Ajjhosannāti kāmanandiyā adhiosannā ajjhotthaṭā.
analyzed: mucchitā ati kāma taṇhāya mucchā paretā ajjhosannā ati kāma nandiyā adhiosannā ajjhotthaṭā
translated: “Bewitched” means infatuated with sensual desire. “Clinging” means clinging to sensual lust.

original: Laggāti kāmasinehena allīnā. Laggitāti kāmapariḷāhena ekībhūtā. Palibuddhāti kāmasaññāya🔽āvaṭṭitā. Atha vā “diṭṭhidassane giddhā. Abhiṇhadassane gadhitā. Saṃsaggakiriyasmiṃ
analyzed: laggā ati kāma sinehena allīnā laggitā ati kāma pariḷāhena ekībhūtā palibuddhā ati kāma saññāya  āvaṭṭitā atha vā diṭṭhi dassane giddhā abhiṇha dassane gadhitā saṃsagga kiriyasmiṃ
translated: “Sticking” means sticking with sensual craving. “Clinging to” means being united with sensual passion. “Obstructed” means obstructed by sensual perception.

original: mucchitā. Vissāsakiriyasmiṃ ajjhosannā. Sinehavaḷañjasmiṃ laggā. Dvayaṃdvayasamāpattimhi🔽laggitā. Aparāparaṃ amuñcamānā hutvā palibuddhā”ti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: mucchitā vissāsa kiriyasmiṃ ajjhosannā sineha vaḷañjasmim laggā dvayaṃdvaya samāpattimhi  laggitā apara aparam a muñcamānā hutvā palibuddhā iti evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: Or else, “greedy for seeing” means greedy for seeing visible forms. “Clinging to” means clinging to the visible forms. “Bewitched” means being bewitched by the visible forms. “Clinging to” means clinging to the visible forms. “Sticking” means sticking to the visible forms. “Obstructed” means being obstructed by the visible forms.

original: Esantīti paccāsīsanti. Gavesantīti maggayanti. Pariyesantīti sabbākārena icchanti
analyzed: esanti iti gavesanti iti maggayanti pariyesanti iti sabba ākārena icchanti
translated: “Seeking” means seeking for visible forms. “Searching” means searching for visible forms. “Investigating” means investigating visible forms.

original: patthenti. Atha vā diṭṭhārammaṇe subhāsubhaṃ atthi, natthīti esanti. Subhāsubhārammaṇe🔽paccakkhaṃ katvā vaḷañjanatthāya piyaṃ karontā gavesanti. Cittavasena esanti. Payogavasena
analyzed: patthenti atha vā diṭṭha ārammaṇe subha asubham atthi natthi iti esanti subha asubha ārammaṇe 🔽paccakkham katvā vaḷañjana atthāya piyam karontā gavesanti citta vasena esanti payoga vasena
translated: Or else, “seeking” means seeking visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.” “Searching” means searching for visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.” “Investigating” means investigating visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.”🔽“Seeking” means seeking visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.” “Searching” means searching for visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.” “Investigating” means investigating visible forms as “beautiful” or “ugly.”

original: gavesanti. Karaṇavasena pariyesanti. Te duvidhe kāme paṭicca otaritvā carantīti taccaritā.
analyzed: karaṇa vasena pariyesanti te duvidhe kāme paṭicca otaritvā caranti iti tad caritā
translated: They seek them by way of the act of seeking. They are called “those who engage in sensual desires” because they descend and go about in sensual desires of two kinds.

original: Te ca kāme bahulaṃ yebhuyyena vaḍḍhenti pavattayantīti tabbahulā. Te ca kāme garuṃ
analyzed: te ca kāme bahulam yebhuyyena vaḍḍhenti pavattayanti iti tad bahulā te ca kāme garum
translated: They are called “those who indulge in sensual desires” because they increase and indulge in sensual desires to a high degree.🔽They are called “those who are devoted to sensual desires” because they live devoted to sensual desires.

original: katvā rahantīti taggarukā. Tesu kāmesu ninnā namitā hutvā vasantīti tanninnā. Tesu🔽kāmesu sanninnā hutvā vasantīti tappoṇā. Tesu kāmesu avalambitā hutvā tesuyeva namitā
analyzed: katvā rahanti iti tad garukā tesu kāmesu ninnā namitā hutvā vasanti iti tad ninnā tesu  kāmesu sanninnā hutvā vasanti iti tad poṇā tesu kāmesu avalambitā hutvā namitā
translated: They are called “those who are intent upon sensual desires” because they live intent upon sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are absorbed in sensual desires” because they live absorbed in sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are devoted to sensual desires” because they live devoted to sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are intent upon sensual desires” because they live intent upon sensual desires.

original: vasantīti tappabbhārā. Tesu kāmesu avattharitvā mucchāparetappasaṅgā hutvā vadantīti
analyzed: vasanti iti tad pabbhārā tesu kāmesu avattharitvā mucchā pareta pasaṅgā hutvā vadanti iti
translated: They are called “those who are absorbed in sensual desires” because they live absorbed in sensual desires.

original: tadadhimuttā. Te ca kāme adhipatiṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā vasantīti tadadhipateyyā. Atha
analyzed: tad adhimuttā te ca kāme adhipatim jeṭṭhakam katvā vasanti iti tad ādhipateyyāḥ atha
translated: They are called “those who are devoted to sensual desires” because they live devoted to sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are intent upon sensual desires” because they live intent upon sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are absorbed in sensual desires” because they live absorbed in sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are devoted to sensual desires” because they live devoted to sensual desires.

original: vā “ārammaṇassa iṭṭhabhāvena taccaritā. Ārammaṇassa kantabhāvena tabbahulā. Ārammaṇassa
analyzed: vā ārammaṇassa iṭṭha bhāvena tad caritā ārammaṇassa kanta bhāvena tad bahulā ārammaṇassa
translated: They are called “those who are intent upon sensual desires” because they live intent upon sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are absorbed in sensual desires” because they live absorbed in sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are devoted to sensual desires” because they live devoted to sensual desires.🔽They are called “those who are intent upon sensual desires” because they live intent upon sensual desires.

original: manāpabhāvena taggarukā. Ārammaṇassa piyabhāvena tanninnā. Ārammaṇassa kāmupasaṃhitabhāvena
analyzed: manāpa bhāvena taggarukāḥ ārammaṇassa piya bhāvena tanninnāḥ ārammaṇassa kāma upasaṃhita bhāvena
translated: They are called “those who are absorbed in sensual desires” because they live absorbed in sensual desires.

original: tappoṇā. Ārammaṇassa rajanīyabhāvena tappabbhārā. Ārammaṇassa mucchanīyabhāvena tadadhimuttā.
analyzed: tad poṇā ārammaṇassa rajanīya bhāvena tad pabbhārā ārammaṇassa mucchanīya bhāvena tad adhimuttā
translated: and the rest are respectively governed by the object’s being desirable, by its being relishable, and by its being binding.

original: Ārammaṇassa bandhanīyabhāvena tadadhipateyyā”ti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: ārammaṇassa bandhanīya bhāvena tad adhipateyyā ati evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: So they explain it.

original: Rūpe pariyesantītiādīsu pariyesantīti aladdhassa lābhāya esanavasena. Paṭilabhantīti
analyzed: rūpe pariyesanti iti ādīsu pariyesanti iti a laddhassa lābhāya esana vasena paṭilabhanti iti
translated: In the passage beginning, “Seeking forms with the eye” , seeking is as the seeking for the obtaining of what has not been obtained;🔽obtaining is as the holding in the hand;

original: hatthagatavasena. Paribhuñjantīti vaḷañjanavasena vuttanti ñātabbaṃ. Kalahaṃ vivādaṃ
analyzed: hattha gata vasena paribhuñjanti iti vaḷañjana vasena vuttan ti ñātabbam kalaham vivādam
translated: and using is as the rubbing in. The rest can be understood in the same way.

original: karotīti kalahakārako. Tasmiṃ niyuttoti kalahapasuto. Kammakārakādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: karoti iti kalaha kārako tasmin niyutto ti kalaha pasuto kamma kāraka ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: He is a maker of quarrels, etc., because he is occupied with quarrels, etc.

original: Gocare carantoti vesiyādigocare, satipaṭṭhānādigocare vā caramāno. Tesu niyutto gocarapasuto.
analyzed: gocare caranto ti vesiyā ādi gocare sati paṭṭhāna ādi gocare vā caramāno tesu niyuttaḥ gocara pasutaḥ
translated: He is occupied with the range, etc., because he is occupied with the range of a prostitute, etc., or because he is occupied with the range of the foundations of mindfulness, etc.🔽He is occupied with jhāna because he has jhāna by means of the absorption of the object.

original: Ārammaṇūpanijjhānavasena jhānaṃ assa atthīti jhāyī. Tasmiṃ niyutto jhānapasuto.
analyzed: ārammaṇa upanijjhāna vasena jhānam assa atthi iti jhāyī tasmin niyuttaḥ jhāna pasutaḥ
translated: He is occupied with understanding because he has understanding by means of the absorption of the object.

original: Avagacchantīti apāyaṃ gacchanti. Maccharinoti sakasampattiṃ niguhantā. Vacananti
analyzed: avagacchanti iti apāyam gacchanti saka sampattim niguhantāḥ vacananti
translated: He goes to destruction; he is stingy, concealing his own excellence.

original: kathanaṃ. Byapathanti vākyapathaṃ. Desananti vissajjanaovādaṃ. Anusiṭṭhinti anusāsaniṃ.
analyzed: kathanam vākyapatham anusiṭṭhinti anusāsanim
translated: and speaking. “Byapath” is byapathana. “Desanā” is answering questions and giving advice. “Anusiṭṭhi” is instruction.

original: Nādiyantīti na gaṇhanti na garuṃ karonti. “Na paṭissantī”ti vā pāṭho, soyeva attho.
analyzed: na ādiyanti iti na gaṇhanti na garum karonti na paṭissanti iti vā pāṭhaḥ saḥ yā iva atthaḥ
translated: “Do not accept” means they do not take it up or respect it. The reading “do not consent” is the same in meaning.

original: Vatthuto macchariyadassanatthaṃ “pañca macchariyāni āvāsamacchariya”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vatthutaḥ macchariya dassana attham pañca macchariyāni āvāsamacchariya ntiādi vuttam
translated: The five kinds of stinginess are stated in the way beginning, “Stinginess regarding dwellings” in order to show stinginess by way of the object.

original: Tattha āvāse macchariyaṃ āvāsamacchariyaṃ. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tattha āvāse macchariyam āvāsa macchariyam sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: Herein, stinginess regarding dwellings is stinginess about dwellings. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: Āvāso nāma sakalārāmopi pariveṇampi ekovarakopi rattiṭṭhānādīnipi. Tesu vasantā sukhaṃ🔽vasanti, paccaye labhanti. Eko bhikkhu vattasampannasseva pesalassa bhikkhuno tattha
analyzed: āvāsaḥ nāma sakala ārāmaḥ api pariveṇam pi ekovarakaḥ api ratti ṭṭhāna ādīni pi tesu vasantā sukham  vasanti paccaye labhanti ekaḥ bhikkhu vatta sampannassa iva pesalassa bhikkhuno tattha
translated: A dwelling is a whole monastery, a room, a hut, a night-quarters, etc. Those who live there live happily

original: āgamanaṃ na icchati, āgatopi “khippaṃ gacchatū”ti cintesi, idaṃ āvāsamacchariyaṃ
analyzed: āgamanam naḥ icchati āgataḥ api khippam gacchatu uti cintesi idam āvāsa macchariyam
translated: and obtain requisites. A certain monk does not want a well-behaved monk who is a good companion to come there, and when he has come, he thinks, “Let him go away quickly.” This is called stinginess regarding dwellings.

original: nāma. Bhaṇḍanakārakādīnaṃ pana tattha vāsaṃ anicchato āvāsamacchariyaṃ nāma na hoti.
analyzed: nāma bhaṇḍana kāraka ādīnam pana tattha vāsam an icchataḥ āvāsamacchariyam nāma na hoti
translated: But if one does not want quarrelsome monks, etc., to live there, this is not called stinginess regarding dwellings.

original: Kulanti upaṭṭhākakulampi ñātikulampi. Tattha aññassa upasaṅkamanaṃ anicchato kulamacchariyaṃ
analyzed: kulanti upaṭṭhāka kulam pi ñāti kulam pi tattha aññassa upasaṅkamanam an icchataḥ kulamacchariyam
translated: “Family” is either a family that supports the Sangha or a family of relatives. Here, if one does not want another to visit either of these, he commits the offense of miserliness.

original: hoti. Pāpapuggalassa pana upasaṅkamanaṃ anicchatopi macchariyaṃ nāma na hoti. So
analyzed: hoti pāpa puggalassa pana upasaṅkamanam an icchataḥ pi macchariyam nāma na hoti so
translated: But if one does not want to visit a bad person, it is not called miserliness.

original: hi tesaṃ pasādabhedāya paṭipajjati. Pasādaṃ rakkhituṃ samatthasseva pana bhikkhuno
analyzed: hi tesam pasāda bhedāya paṭipajjati pasādam rakkhitum samatthassa iva pana bhikkhuno
translated: For he is acting to break their confidence. But if a bhikkhu is capable of protecting his confidence,

original: tattha upasaṅkamanaṃ anicchato macchariyaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: tattha upasaṅkamanam an icchataḥ macchariyam nāma hoti
translated: if he does not want to visit there, it is called miserliness.

original: Lābhoti catupaccayalābhova. Taṃ aññasmiṃ sīlavanteyeva labhante “mā labhatū”ti cintentassa
analyzed: lābhaḥ ti catu paccaya lābhaḥ uva tam aññasmin sīlavante iya iva labhante mā labhatu iti cintentassa
translated: “Gain” is the gain of the four requisites. If one thinks, “May he not get it,” when one who is virtuous gets it,

original: lābhamacchariyaṃ hoti. Yo pana saddhādeyyaṃ vinipāteti, aparibhogadupparibhogādivasena
analyzed: lābha macchariyam hoti yaḥ pana saddhā deyyam vinipātā iti a paribhoga dupparibhoga ādi vasena
translated: one commits the offense of miserliness regarding gain. But if one destroys a gift by misappropriating it, by wasting it, etc.,

original: vināseti, pūtibhāvaṃ gacchantampi aññassa na deti, taṃ disvā “sace imaṃ esa na labheyya,
analyzed: vināseti pūti bhāvam gacchantam pi aññassa na deti tam disvā sace imam esa na labheyya
translated: and if one does not give it to another, even though it has become rotten, and if one does not think, “If he does not get it,

original: añño sīlavā labheyya, paribhogaṃ gaccheyyā”ti cintentassa macchariyaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: aññaḥ sīlavā labheyya paribhogam gaccheyya ati cintentassa macchariyam nāma natthi
translated: another who is virtuous will get it and use it,” it is not called miserliness.

original: Vaṇṇo nāma sarīravaṇṇopi guṇavaṇṇopi. Tattha sarīravaṇṇe maccharī “paro pāsādiko🔽rūpavā”ti vutte taṃ na kathetukāmo hoti. Guṇavaṇṇamaccharī parassa sīlena dhutaṅgena
analyzed: vaṇṇo nāma sarīra vaṇṇaḥ api guṇa vaṇṇaḥ api tattha sarīra vaṇṇe maccharī paraḥ pāsādiko  rūpavā ati vutte tam na kathetu kāmaḥ hoti guṇa vaṇṇa maccharī parassa sīlena dhutaṅgena
translated: “Beauty” is either bodily beauty or the beauty of good qualities. Herein, one who is envious about bodily beauty is unwilling to speak about another’s beauty when it is being praised, thinking “He is good-looking, handsome, pleasing,🔽of beautiful complexion, of beautiful eyes, of beautiful arms, of beautiful legs, of beautiful hands and feet, of beautiful speech, of beautiful teeth, of beautiful lips, of beautiful eyebrows, of beautiful forehead, of beautiful head, of beautiful face, of beautiful shoulders, of beautiful neck, of beautiful ears, of beautiful nose, of beautiful buttocks, of beautiful hips, of beautiful private parts, of beautiful thighs, of beautiful knees, of beautiful shanks, of beautiful ankles, of beautiful fingers, of beautiful toes, of beautiful nails, of beautiful hands and feet, of beautiful fingers and toes, of beautiful palms, of beautiful skin, of beautiful bodily hairs, of beautiful bodily complexion, of beautiful gait, of beautiful posture, of beautiful limbs, of beautiful hands and feet, of beautiful fingers and toes, of beautiful nails, of beautiful eyes, of beautiful ears, of beautiful nose, of beautiful mouth, of beautiful teeth, of beautiful lips, of beautiful eyebrows, of beautiful forehead, of beautiful head, of beautiful face, of beautiful shoulders, of beautiful neck, of beautiful jaw, of beautiful cheeks, of beautiful voice, of beautiful speech, of beautiful laughter, of beautiful smile, of beautiful gestures, of beautiful movements, of beautiful deportment, of beautiful rising up, of beautiful sitting down, of beautiful lying down, of beautiful reclining, of beautiful rising up from his seat, of beautiful sitting down on his seat, of beautiful walking, of beautiful standing, of beautiful lying, of beautiful sitting, of beautiful reclining, of beautiful rising up from his bed, of beautiful dressing, of beautiful undressing, of beautiful wearing his robes, of beautiful carrying his bowl, of beautiful bending, of beautiful stretching, of beautiful contracting, of
