intermediate points, of beautiful looking at the directions, of beautiful looking at the quarters, of beautiful looking at the sky, of beautiful looking at the ground, of beautiful looking at the quarters, of beautiful

original: paṭipadāya ācārena vaṇṇaṃ na kathetukāmo hoti.
analyzed: paṭipadāya ācārena vaṇṇam na kathetu kāmo hoti
translated: “Color” is the color of the body and the color of good qualities. Herein, one who is stingy about the color of the body does not want to speak about it when someone else is praised as “good-looking” or “handsome.” One who is stingy about the color of good qualities does not want to speak about the other’s virtue, ascetic practices,🔽conduct, or way of life.

original: Dhammoti pariyattidhammo ca paṭivedhadhammo ca. Tattha ariyasāvakā paṭivedhadhammaṃ🔽na maccharāyanti, attanā paṭividdhadhamme sadevakassa lokassa paṭivedhaṃ icchanti.
analyzed: dhammo ti pariyatti dhammo ca paṭivedha dhammo ca tattha ariya sāvakā paṭivedha dhammaṃ  na mat śarāyanti attanā paṭividdha dhamme sa devakassa lokassa paṭivedham icchanti
translated: “Dhamma” is the Dhamma of the scriptures and the Dhamma of the path. Herein, noble disciples are not stingy about the Dhamma of the path,🔽for they want others to understand the Dhamma that they themselves have understood.

original: Taṃ pana paṭivedhaṃ “pare jānantū”ti icchanti, tantidhammeyeva pana dhammamacchariyaṃ
analyzed: tam pana paṭivedham pare jānantu uti icchanti pana
translated: But they want others to understand that Dhamma, thinking: “May others know it.” However, there is stinginess about the Dhamma of the scriptures,

original: nāma hoti. Tena samannāgato puggalo yaṃ guḷhaṃ ganthaṃ vā kathāmaggaṃ vā jānāti,
analyzed: nāma hoti tena samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ yam guḷham gantham vā kathāmaggam vā jānāti
translated: which is found in one who, knowing a certain secret text or line of argument,

original: taṃ aññe na jānāpetukāmo hoti. Yo pana puggalaṃ upaparikkhitvā dhammānuggahena dhammaṃ
analyzed: tam aññe na jānāpetu kāmo hoti yaḥ pana puggalam upaparikkhitvā dhamma anuggahena dhammaṃ
translated: does not want others to know it. But one who, after examining a person, teaches him the Dhamma out of compassion,

original: vā upaparikkhitvā puggalānuggahena na deti, ayaṃ dhammamaccharī nāma na hoti. Tattha
analyzed: vā upaparikkhitvā puggala anuggahena na deti ayam dhammamaccharī nāma na hoti tattha
translated: and he does not give it after testing the person, he is not one who is miserly about the Dhamma.

original: ekacco puggalo lolo hoti, kālena samaṇo hoti, kālena brāhmaṇo, kālena nigaṇṭho. Yo🔽hi bhikkhu “ayaṃ puggalo paveṇiāgataṃ tantiṃ saṇhaṃ sukhumaṃ dhammantaraṃ bhinditvā
analyzed: ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ lolaḥ hoti kālena samaṇaḥ hoti kālena brāhmaṇaḥ kālena nigaṇṭhaḥ yo  hi bhikkhu ayam puggalaḥ paveṇi āgatam tantim saṇham su khumam dhammantaram bhinditvā
translated: Herein, a certain person is fickle: sometimes he is a monk, sometimes a brahmin, sometimes a naked ascetic.

original: āluḷessatī”ti na deti, ayaṃ puggalaṃ upaparikkhitvā dhammānuggahena na deti nāma.🔽Yo pana “ayaṃ dhammo saṇho sukhumo, sacāyaṃ puggalo gaṇhissati, aññaṃ byākaritvā
analyzed: āluḷessati iti na deti ayam puggalam upaparikkhitvā dhamma anuggahena na deti nāma  yaḥ pana ayam dhammo saṇhaḥ sukhumaḥ sacā ayam puggalaḥ gaṇhissati aññam byākaritvā
translated: If a bhikkhu does not give it, thinking “This person will break the fine, delicate, subtle thread of the tradition that has come down from the elders,” he is one who does not give after testing the Dhamma.

original: attānaṃ āvi katvā nassissatī”ti na deti, ayaṃ dhammaṃ upaparikkhitvā puggalānuggahena🔽na deti nāma. Yo pana “sacāyaṃ imaṃ dhammaṃ gaṇhissati, amhākaṃ samayaṃ bhindituṃ
analyzed: attānam āvi katvā nassissati iti na deti ayam dhammam upaparikkhitvā puggala anuggahena  na deti nāma yaḥ pana sacā ayam imam dhammam gaṇhissati amhākam samayam bhinditum
translated: But if he does not give it, thinking “This Dhamma is fine and delicate. If this person learns it, he will explain it to others, and then he will be lost,” he is one who does not give after testing the person.

original: samattho bhavissatī”ti na deti, ayaṃ dhammamaccharī nāma hoti.
analyzed: samatthaḥ bhavissati iti na deti ayam dhammamaccharī nāma hoti
translated: But if he does not give it, thinking “If this person learns this Dhamma, he will be able to break our agreement,” he is one who is miserly about the Dhamma.

original: Imesu pañcasu macchariyesu āvāsamacchariyena tāva yakkho vā peto vā hutvā tasseva🔽āvāsassa saṅkāraṃ sīsena ukkhipitvā vicarati. Kulamacchariyena tasmiṃ kule aññesaṃ
analyzed: imesu pañcasu macchariyesu āvāsamacchariyena tāva yakkho vā petaḥ vā hutvā tassa iva  āvāsassa saṅkāram sīsena ukkhipitvā vicarati kulamacchariyena tasmim kule aññesam
translated: As to the five kinds of stinginess, firstly, as a ghost or animal he carries the rubbish of that very dwelling on his head and wanders about because of dwelling-place stinginess. Because of family stinginess, he is not allowed to enter the houses of others in that family.

original: dānamānanādīni karonte disvā “bhinnaṃ vatidaṃ kulaṃ mamā”ti cintayato lohitampi mukhato🔽uggacchati, kucchivirecanampi hoti, antānipi khaṇḍākhaṇḍāni hutvā nikkhamanti. Lābhamacchariyena🔽saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā santake lābhe maccharāyitvā puggalikaparibhogaṃ viya paribhuñjitvā🔽yakkho vā peto vā mahāajagaro vā hutvā nibbattati. Sarīravaṇṇaguṇavaṇṇamaccharena
analyzed: dāna mānana ādīni karonte disvā bhinnam vati dam kulam mama ati cintayataḥ mukhataḥ  uggacchati kucchi virecanam pi hoti antāni api khaṇḍa akhaṇḍāni hutvā nikkhamanti lābha macchariyena  saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā santake lābhe puggalika paribhogam viya paribhuñjitvā  yakkhaḥ vā petaḥ vā mahā ajagaraḥ vā hutvā nibbattati sarīra vaṇṇa guṇa vaṇṇa maccharena
translated: As to the five kinds of stinginess, firstly, as a ghost or a spirit, one who is stingy about the dwelling has to wander carrying the refuse of that dwelling on one’s head. As to stinginess about family, when one who is stingy about family sees others being given food and honour in that family, thinking, “The family is divided against me,” blood comes out of his mouth,

original: pana pariyattidhammamacchariyena ca attanova vaṇṇaṃ vaṇṇeti, paresaṃ vaṇṇe “kiṃ vaṇṇo
analyzed: pana pariyatti dhamma macchariyena ca attanā uva vaṇṇam vaṇṇeti paresam vaṇṇe kim vaṇṇo
translated: he has a purging of the bowels, and his entrails come out in pieces. As to stinginess about gains, one who is stingy about gains, after using for himself the gains that have been given in common to the Community or to a group, is reborn as a ghost, or as a spirit, or as a great python. As to stinginess about the excellence of one’s own complexion and beauty, and as to stinginess about the True Idea, one who is stingy about the True Idea praises only himself and deprecates others, thinking, “What is the use of praising others?

original: eso”ti taṃ taṃ dosaṃ vadanto pariyattidhammañca kassaci kiñci adento dubbaṇṇo ceva eḷamūgo ca hoti.
analyzed: eso ti tam tam dosam vadantaḥ pariyatti dhammam ca kassaci kiñci a dentaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ ca iva eḷamūgaḥ ca hoti
translated: and so on, and he does not give anyone anything of the kind of the Dhamma, he is ugly and dumb.

original: Api ca āvāsamacchariyena lohagehe paccati, kulamacchariyena appalābho hoti, lābhamacchariyena
analyzed: api ca āvāsa macchariyena loha gehe paccati kula macchariyena appa lābhaḥ hoti lābha macchariyena
translated: Moreover, by stinginess about dwelling he is roasted in the Hell of Houses of Iron, by stinginess about family he has little gain, by stinginess about gain

original: gūthaniraye nibbattati, vaṇṇamacchariyena bhave bhave nibbattassa vaṇṇo nāma na hoti,
analyzed: gūthaniraye nibbattati vaṇṇa macchariyena bhave bhave nibbattassa vaṇṇo nāma na hoti
translated: he is reborn in the Hell of Excrement, by stinginess about reputation he has no reputation in any existence in which he is reborn,

original: dhammamacchariyena kukkuḷaniraye nibbattatīti.
analyzed: dhammamacchariyena kukkuḷaniraye nibbattati iti
translated: and by stinginess about the Dhamma he is reborn in the Hell of Hot Embers.🔽Stinginess is due to the state of being a miser. The state of being a miser is the aspect of miserliness.

original: Maccharāyanavasena macchariyaṃ. Maccharāyanākāro maccharāyanā. Maccharena ayitassa
analyzed: maccharāyana vasena macchariyam maccharāyana ākāraḥ maccharāyanā maccharena ayitassa
translated: That which is made miserly by miserliness

original: maccherasamaṅgino bhāvo maccharāyitattaṃ. “Mayhameva hontu, mā aññassā”ti sabbāpi🔽attano sampattiyo byāpetuṃ na icchatīti viviccho, vivicchassa bhāvo vevicchaṃ, mudumacchariyassetaṃ
analyzed: mad chera samaṅginaḥ bhāvaḥ mad śarāyi tattam mayham eva hontu mā aññassa ati sabbā api  attanaḥ sampattiyaḥ byāpetum naḥ icchati iti vivicchaḥ vivicchassa bhāvaḥ veviccham mudumat śariyassa etam
translated: is the state of being miserly. “Let them be mine and not another’s” is all the prosperity of one who does not want to share. He is called “exclusive” . The state of being exclusive is exclusiveness. This is a name for mild miserliness.

original: nāmaṃ. Kadariyo vuccati anādaro, tassa bhāvo kadariyaṃ, thaddhamacchariyassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: nāmam kadariyaḥ vuccati anādaraḥ tassa bhāvaḥ kadariyam thaddhamat śariyassa etam nāmam
translated: One who is called “mean” is disrespectful. The state of that is meanness. This is a name for stiff miserliness.

original: Tena hi samannāgato puggalo parampi paresaṃ dadamānaṃ nivāreti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: tena hi samannāgataḥ puggalo param pi paresam dadamānam nivāreti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: A person who possesses this is one who “restrains others from giving to others.” And this is said:🔽“The miser is of evil thought,

original: “Kadariyo pāpasaṅkappo, micchādiṭṭhianādaro;
analyzed: kadariyaḥ pāpa saṅkappaḥ micchā diṭṭhi anādaro
translated: He is disrespectful, of wrong view,🔽He restrains the giver from giving

original: Dadamānaṃ nivāreti, yācamānāna bhojana”nti. ;
analyzed: dadamānam nivāra iti
translated: To those who ask for food.”

original: Yācake disvā kaṭukabhāvena cittaṃ añcati saṅkocetīti kaṭukañcuko, tassa bhāvo kaṭukañcukatā.
analyzed: yācake disvā kaṭuka bhāvena cittam añcati saṅkoceti iti kaṭu kañcukaḥ tassa bhāvo kaṭu kañcuka tā
translated: He is called a “miser” because his mind shrinks back and contracts itself with a feeling of pain when he sees beggars. The state of being a miser is miserliness.

original: Aparo nayo – kaṭukañcukatā vuccati kaṭacchuggāho. Samatittikapuṇṇāya hi ukkhaliyā
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ kaṭu kañcuka tā vuccati kaṭacchu ggāhaḥ sama tittika puṇṇāya hi ukkhaliyā
translated: Another method: miserliness is said to be a tight fist. For when he takes rice from a pot that is full to the brim,

original: bhattaṃ gaṇhanto sabbatobhāgena saṅkuṭitena aggakaṭacchunā gaṇhāti pūretvā gahetuṃ
analyzed: bhattam gaṇhantaḥ sabbatobhāgena saṅkuṭitena agga kaṭacchunā gaṇhāti pūretvā gahetum
translated: he takes it with the tip of his nose of the spoon drawn in all around, and he cannot take it by filling the spoon,

original: na sakkoti, evaṃ maccharipuggalassa cittaṃ saṅkucati, tasmiṃ saṅkucite kāyopi tatheva
analyzed: na sakkoti evam macchari puggalassa cittam saṅkucati tasmin saṅkucite kāyaḥ api tathā iva
translated: so too the miser’s mind contracts. When it contracts, his body

original: saṅkucati paṭikuṭati paṭinivaṭṭati na sampasārīyatīti maccheraṃ “kaṭukañcukatā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkucati paṭikuṭati paṭinivaṭṭati na sampasārīyati iti maccheram kaṭu kañcuka tā iti vuttam
translated: contracts likewise, shrinks, turns back, and does not expand. That is why miserliness is said to be “a tight fist.”

original: Aggahitattaṃ cittassāti paresaṃ upakārakaraṇe dānādinā ākārena yathā na sampasārīyati,
analyzed: cittassa ati paresam upakāra karaṇe dāna ādinā ākārena yathā na sampasārīyati
translated: His mind does not expand: his mind does not expand in the way beginning with giving, that is, in the doing of favours to others.

original: evaṃ āvaritvā gahitabhāvo cittassa. Yasmā pana maccharipuggalo attano santakaṃ paresaṃ🔽adātukāmo hoti, parasantakaṃ gaṇhitukāmo. Tasmā “idaṃ acchariyaṃ mayhameva hotu,
analyzed: evam āvaritvā gahita bhāvaḥ cittassa yasmā pana mad śari puggalaḥ attano santakam paresam  a dātu kāmaḥ hoti parasantakam gaṇhitu kāmaḥ tasmai idam acchariyam mayham eva hotu
translated: This is the characteristic of stinginess as a state of the mind’s being covered and closed.🔽But because the stingy man does not want to give his own property to others and wants to take the property of others for himself, it should be understood that his stinginess has the characteristic of concealing his own possessions and the characteristic of taking the possessions of others, thinking: “Let this treasure be mine alone;

original: mā aññassā”ti pavattivasenassa attasampattinigūhanalakkhaṇatā parasampattiggahaṇalakkhaṇatā ca veditabbā.
analyzed: mā aññassa ati pavatti vasena assa atta sampatti nigūhana lakkhaṇa tā para sampatti ggahaṇa lakkhaṇa tā ca veditabbā
translated: let it not be anyone else’s.”

original: Khandhamacchariyampi macchariyanti attano pañcakkhandhasaṅkhātaṃ upapattibhavaṃ aññehi🔽asādhāraṇaṃ “acchariyaṃ mayhameva hotu, mā aññassā”ti pavattaṃ macchariyaṃ khandhamacchariyaṃ
analyzed: khandha macchariyam pi macchariyanti attanaḥ pañca kkhandha saṅkhātam upapatti bhavam aññehi  asādhāraṇam acchariyam mayham eva hotu mā aññassa ati pavattam macchariyam khandha macchariyam
translated: Stinginess about the aggregates is the stinginess that occurs thus: “Let this treasure, which is called the rebirth-process consisting of the five aggregates, be mine alone;🔽let it not be anyone else’s.” The same method applies to stinginess about elements and bases.

original: nāma. Dhātuāyatanamacchariyesupi eseva nayo. Gāhoti gāhanicchayavasena gahaṇaṃ. Avadaññutāyāti
analyzed: nāma esā iva nayaḥ gāho ti gāhan nicchaya vasena gahaṇam
translated: Grasping is the act of grasping by the wish to grasp.🔽Because of his ignorance of what is said by those who ask,

original: sabbaññubuddhānampi kathitaṃ ajānanabhāvena. Yācakānaṃ adadamāno hi tehi kathitaṃ
analyzed: sabbaññu buddhānam pi kathitam a jānana bhāvena yācakānam a dadamānaḥ hi tehi kathitam
translated: for the ignorant man does not know what is said by the omniscient Buddhas. For the stingy man, who does not give to those who ask,

original: na jānāti nāma. Janā pamattāti sativippavāsā janā. Vacananti saṅkhepavacanaṃ. Byappathanti
analyzed: na jānāti nāma janā pamattā ati sati vippavāsāḥ janāḥ saṅkhepa vacanam byappathanti
translated: “Does not know”: he does not know. “People are heedless”: people who are devoid of mindfulness. “Statement”: a brief statement. “Explanation”:

original: vitthāravacanaṃ. Desananti upamaṃ dassetvā atthasandassanavacanaṃ. Anusiṭṭhinti punappunaṃ🔽saṃlakkhāpanavacanaṃ. Atha vā dassetvā kathanaṃ vacanaṃ nāma. Gaṇhāpetvā kathanaṃ
analyzed: vitthāra vacanam desanan ti upamam dassetvā attha sandassana vacanam anusiṭṭhin ti punappunam  saṃlakkhāpana vacanam atha vā dassetvā kathanam vacanam nāma gaṇhāpetvā kathanam
translated: an extensive statement. “Teaching”: a statement that shows the meaning after showing a simile. “Instruction”: a statement that is

original: byappathaṃ nāma. Tosetvā kathanaṃ desanaṃ nāma. Padassetvā kathanaṃ anusiṭṭhi nāma.🔽Atha vā paritāpadukkhaṃ nāsetvā kathanaṃ vacanaṃ nāma. Pariḷāhadukkhaṃ nāsetvā kathanaṃ🔽byappathaṃ nāma. Apāyadukkhaṃ nāsetvā kathanaṃ desanaṃ nāma. Bhavadukkhaṃ nāsetvā
analyzed: byappatham nāma tosetvā kathanam desanam nāma padassetvā kathanam anusiṭṭhi nāma  atha vā paritāpa dukkham na āsetvā kathanam vacanam nāma pariḷāha dukkham na āsetvā kathanam  byappatham nāma apāya dukkham na āsetvā kathanam desanam nāma bhava dukkham na āsetvā
translated: repeatedly given. Or alternatively, a statement is a statement that is made after showing. An explanation is a statement that is made after making one understand. A teaching is a statement that is made after arousing . An instruction is a statement that is made after showing the words.

original: kathanaṃ anusiṭṭhi nāma. Atha vā dukkhasaccapariññāpaṭivedhayuttaṃ vacanaṃ. Samudayasaccapahānapaṭivedhayuttaṃ
analyzed: kathanam anusiṭṭhi nāma atha vā dukkha sacca pariññā paṭivedha yuttam vacanam samudaya sacca apahāna paṭivedha yuttam
translated: Or alternatively, a statement is a statement that is made after removing the suffering of remorse. An explanation is a statement that is made after removing the suffering of fever. A teaching is a statement that is made after removing the suffering of the lower realms. An instruction is a statement that is made after removing the suffering of existence. Or alternatively, a statement is a statement that is connected with the penetration of the knowledge of the noble truths. An explanation is a statement that is connected with the penetration of the knowledge of the abandoning of the truth of the origin.

original: byappathaṃ. Nirodhasaccasacchikiriyapaṭivedhayuttaṃ desanaṃ. Maggasaccabhāvanāpaṭivedhayuttaṃ
analyzed: byappatham nirodha sacca sacchikiriya paṭivedha yuttam desanam magga sacca bhāvanā paṭivedha yuttam
translated: The exposition is the teaching connected with the penetration of the truth of cessation, and the teaching connected with the penetration of the truth of the path through development.

original: anusiṭṭhīti evamādinā nayena eke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: anusiṭṭhī iti evamādinā nayena eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: Some explain the word anussati in the verse as meaning “instruction” in the sense of “recollection” .

original: Na sussusantīti na suṇanti. Na sotaṃ odahantīti savanatthaṃ kaṇṇasotaṃ na ṭhapenti.
analyzed: na sussusanti iti na suṇanti na sotam odahanti iti savana attham kaṇṇa sotam na ṭhapenti
translated: They do not listen: they do not hear. They do not give ear: they do not direct their ear-consciousness to the sound.

original: Na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapentīti jānanatthaṃ cittaṃ na patiṭṭhapenti. Anassavāti ovādaṃ
analyzed: na aññā cittam upaṭṭhapenti iti jānana attham cittam na patiṭṭhapenti ovādam
translated: They do not raise up their minds: they do not establish their minds for the purpose of knowing. They do not listen to the advice: they do not hear the advice.

original: asuṇamānā. Avacanakarāti suṇamānāpi vacanaṃ na karontīti avacanakarā. Paṭilomavuttinoti
analyzed: a suṇamānā a vacana karā ati suṇamānā api vacanam na karonti iti a vacana karā paṭiloma vuttino ti
translated: They do not do what he says: they do not do what he says even though they hear it. They act contrary: they act in opposition.

original: paṭāṇī hutvā pavattanakā. Aññeneva mukhaṃ karontīti karontāpi mukhaṃ na dentīti attho.🔽Visameti kāyasucaritādisammatassa samassa paṭipakkhattā visamaṃ, tasmiṃ visame. Niviṭṭhāti
analyzed: paṭāṇī hutvā pavattanakāḥ aññena iva mukham karonti iti karontā api mukham na denti iti atthaḥ  visamā iti kāya su carita ādi sammatassa samassa paṭipakkha ttā visamam tasmim visame niviṭṭhāti
translated: They turn their faces away: the meaning is that they do not give their faces, i.e. do not consent.🔽In the uneven: uneven because it is the opposite of the even, i.e. good conduct of body, etc. In the uneven, in that uneven way. They are stuck fast: they are stuck fast, difficult to pull out.

original: paviṭṭhā dunnīharā. Kāyakammeti kāyato pavatte, kāyena vā pavatte kāyakamme. Vacīkammādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: paviṭṭhā dunnīharā kāya kamme iti kāyataḥ pavatte kāyena vā pavatte kāya kamme vacī kamma ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: In bodily action: in what occurs by way of the body, or in what occurs through the body, i.e. in bodily action. The same method applies to verbal action, etc.

original: Tattha kāyakammavacīkammamanokammāni duccaritavasena vibhattāni, pāṇātipātādayo dasaakusalakammapathavasena🔽vibhattāti ñātabbaṃ. Ayaṃ tāvettha sādhāraṇapadavaṇṇanā, asādhāraṇesu pana pāṇassa
analyzed: tattha kāya kamma vacī kamma manaḥ kammāni duccarita vasena vibhattāni pāṇātipāta ādayaḥ dasa akusala kammapatha vasena  vibhattā iti ñātabbam ayam tāva ettha sādhāraṇa pada vaṇṇanā asādhāraṇesu pana pāṇassa
translated: Herein, bodily action, verbal action, and mental action should be understood as divided according to bad conduct, and killing breathing things, etc., as divided according to the ten courses of unprofitable action. This, firstly, is the comment on the words that are common to both . As regards the uncommon words, however, in the case of a breathing thing ,🔽🔽

original: atipāto pāṇātipāto, pāṇavadho pāṇaghātoti vuttaṃ hoti. Pāṇoti cettha vohārato satto,🔽paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ. Tasmiṃ pana pāṇe pāṇasaññino jīvitindriyupacchedakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpitā🔽kāyavacīdvārānaṃ aññataradvārapavattā vadhakacetanā pāṇātipāto. So guṇavirahitesu
analyzed: atipāto pāṇa atipāto pāṇa vadho pāṇa ghāto ti vuttam hoti pāṇaḥ iti ca ittha vohārato satto  paramatthataḥ jīvitindriyam tasmin pana pāṇe pāṇa saññinaḥ jīvitindriya upacchedaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpitā  kāya vacī dvārānaṃ aññatara dvāra pavattā vadhaka cetanā pāṇātipātaḥ saḥ guṇa virahitesu
translated: Herein, bodily action, verbal action, and mental action are classed according to bad conduct, and the ten courses of unprofitable action beginning with killing breathing things are classed according to the unprofitable. This, firstly, is the commentary on the words in the stanza classed under the headings. As regards the words classed under the headings not shared in common, killing breathing things is killing breathing things; it is the killing of breathing things, is what is said. Herein, breathing thing is a being in the sense of usage;

original: tiracchānagatādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāsarīre mahāsāvajjo. Kasmā?
analyzed: tiracchāna gata ādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appa sāvajjaḥ mahā sarīre mahā sāvajjaḥ kasmā
translated: it is the life faculty in the ultimate sense. But in the case of a breathing thing, killing breathing things is the volition to kill that occurs in one of the three doors, the bodily or the verbal door, and is aroused by a perception of a breathing thing as such in one who has the wish to kill a breathing thing. That is classed according to the breathing things, which are destitute of special qualities, such as animals, etc., as less blameworthy when the breathing thing is small, and more blameworthy when the breathing thing is big. Why?

original: Payogamahantatāya, payogasamattepi vatthumahantatāya. Guṇavantesu manussādīsu appaguṇe
analyzed: payoga mahanta tāya payoga samatte api vatthu mahanta tāya guṇavantesu manussa ādīsu appaguṇe
translated: Because of the magnitude of the effort. And even when the effort is the same, it is because of the magnitude of the object. In the case of those possessing special qualities, such as human beings, etc., it is less blameworthy when the special quality is small, and more blameworthy when the special quality is great.

original: pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāguṇe mahāsāvajjo. Sarīraguṇānaṃ pana samabhāve sati kilesānaṃ
analyzed: pāṇe appasāvajjaḥ mahā guṇe mahā sāvajjaḥ sarīra guṇānam pana sama bhāve sati kilesānam
translated: The more valuable the life, the more serious the offence. But if the qualities of the body are equal, then the more wicked the defilements,

original: upakkamānañca mudutāya appasāvajjo, tibbatāya mahāsāvajjoti veditabbo.
analyzed: upakkamānam ca mudu tāya appa sāvajjo tibba tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: the more serious the offence. The more tender the life, the less serious the offence; the more mature, the more serious.

original: Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – pāṇo pāṇasaññitā vadhakacittaṃ upakkamo tena maraṇanti.
analyzed: tassa pañca sambhārāḥ honti pāṇaḥ pāṇa saññitā vadhaka cittam upakkamaḥ tena maraṇanti
translated: It has five constituents: a living being, the perception of a living being, the thought of killing, the effort, and death through that means.

original: Chappayogā – sāhatthiko āṇattiko nissaggiyo thāvaro vijjāmayo iddhimayoti. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: cha ppayogā sāhatthikaḥ āṇattikaḥ nissaggiyaḥ thāvaraḥ vijjā mayaḥ iddhi mayaḥ ti imasmin
translated: There are six means: by one’s own hand, by command, by hurling, by contrivance, by magic, by supernormal power.

original: panatthe vitthāriyamāne atipapañco hoti, tasmā naṃ na vitthārayissāma. Aññañca evarūpaṃ,
analyzed: panatthe vitthāriyamāne atipapañcaḥ hoti tasmai nam na vitthārayissāma aññam ca evarūpam
translated: But when this matter is being elaborated, it is too much. Therefore we shall not elaborate it. And other such matters

original: atthikehi pana samantapāsādikaṃ vinayaṭṭhakathaṃ oloketvā gahetabbaṃ.🔽Adinnassa ādānaṃ adinnādānaṃ, parassa haraṇaṃ theyyaṃ corikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha
analyzed: atthikehi pana samantapāsādikam vinaya ṭṭhakatham oloketvā gahetabbam  a dinnassa ādānam a dinna ādānam parassa haraṇam theyyam corikā ati vuttam hoti tattha
translated: should be taken from the commentary on the Vinaya, the Sāratthappakāsinī, which is entirely trustworthy, by those who want to know.🔽Taking what is not given: taking what is not given is theft, taking what belongs to another, robbery. Herein

original: adinnanti parapariggahitaṃ, yattha paro yathākāmakāritaṃ āpajjanto adaṇḍāraho anupavajjo
analyzed: a dinna nti para pariggahitam yattha paraḥ yathā kāma kāritam āpajjantaḥ a daṇḍa ārahaḥ an upavajjaḥ
translated: what is not given is what is possessed by another, where the other, by his possession, is not open to punishment for assaulting, or to a lawsuit for theft,

original: ca hoti, tasmiṃ pana parapariggahite parapariggahitasaññino tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: ca hoti tasmin pana para pariggahite para pariggahita saññinaḥ tad ādāyaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: and it is another’s, and he perceives it as such, then the act of taking it away with the aim of stealing it,

original: theyyacetanā adinnādānaṃ. Taṃ hīne parasantake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ, paṇīte mahāsāvajjaṃ.🔽Kasmā? Vatthupaṇītatāya, vatthusamatte sati guṇādhikānaṃ santake vatthusmiṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ.
analyzed: theyya cetanā adinnādānam tam hīne para santake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjam paṇīte mahāsāvajjam  kasmā vatthu paṇīta tāya vatthu samatte sati guṇa adhikānam santake vatthusmim mahā sāvajjam
translated: is the taking of what is not given. It is less blameworthy when the object is of little value and more blameworthy when it is of great value.🔽Why? Because of the value of the object. When the value of the object is the same, it is more blameworthy when the object belongs to one of good qualities and less blameworthy when it belongs to one of bad qualities.

original: Taṃ taṃ guṇādhikaṃ upādāya tato tato hīnaguṇassa santake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ.
analyzed: tam tam guṇa adhikam upādāya tatas tatas hīna guṇassa santake vatthusmim appa sāvajjam
translated: And it is more blameworthy when the object belongs to one of still better qualities, and less blameworthy when it belongs to one of still worse qualities.

original: Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – parapariggahitaṃ parapariggahitasaññitā theyyacittaṃ🔽upakkamo tena haraṇanti. Chappayogā sāhatthikādayova. Te ca kho yathānurūpaṃ theyyāvahāro
analyzed: tassa pañca sambhārāḥ honti para pariggahitam para pariggahita saññitā theyya cittam  upakkamaḥ tena haraṇanti cha ppayogā sāhatthika ādayaḥ va te ca kho yathānurūpam theyya avahāro
translated: It has five constituents: it is another’s, he perceives it as such, he has the intention to steal it,🔽he makes an effort to take it away, and he moves it from its base. The five means are the means of theft, the means of force, the means of concealment, the means of stratagem, and the means of magic.

original: pasayhāvahāro paṭicchannāvahāro parikappāvahāro kusāvahāroti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ avahārānaṃ
analyzed: pasayhāvahāro paṭicchannāvahāro parikappāvahāro kusāvahāro ti imesam pañcannam avahārānam
translated: These occur in the five ways of taking what is not given, namely,

original: vasena pavattanti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto.
analyzed: vasena pavattanti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana samantapāsādikāyam vutto
translated: by theft, by force, by concealment, by stratagem, and by magic. This is the brief account of this training rule. The detailed account is given in the Book of the Discipline .

original: Kāmesumicchācāroti ettha pana kāmesūti methunasamācāresu. Micchācāroti ekantanindito
analyzed: ettha pana kāmesu uti methuna samācāresu micchācāro ti ekanta ninditaḥ
translated: Herein, in the clause “in the case of sexual intercourse that is not in accordance with the Dhamma,” sexual intercourse is intercourse for the purpose of enjoyment. “Not in accordance with the Dhamma” is intercourse that is censured,

original: lāmakācāro. Lakkhaṇato pana asaddhammasevanādhippāyena kāyadvārappavattā agamanīyaṭṭhānavītikkamacetanā kāmesumicchācāro.
analyzed: lāmaka ācāraḥ lakkhaṇato pana asat dhamma sevana adhippāyena kāya dvāra ppavattā agamanīya ṭṭhāna vītikkama cetanā kāmesu micchā ācāro
translated: low, and vulgar. But by characteristic, sexual intercourse that is not in accordance with the Dhamma is the volition that transgresses a non-offence-range object, occurring in the body door with the aim of enjoying an unallowable object.

original: Tattha agamanīyaṭṭhānaṃ nāma purisānaṃ tāva māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā🔽bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sārakkhā
analyzed: tattha agamanīya ṭṭhānam nāma purisānam tāva mātu rakkhitā pitu rakkhitā mātā pitu rakkhitā  bhātu rakkhitā bhagini rakkhitā ñāti rakkhitā gotta rakkhitā dhamma rakkhitā sārakkhā
translated: Herein, a non-offence-range object for men is a woman guarded by mother, father, brother, sister, relatives, or by the threat of punishment, a married woman, and one betrothed.

original: saparidaṇḍāti māturakkhitādayo dasa, dhanakkītā chandavāsinī bhogavāsinī paṭavāsinī🔽odapattakinī obhatacumbaṭakā dāsī ca bhariyā kammakārī ca bhariyā dhajāhaṭā muhuttikāti
analyzed: sa paridaṇḍā ti māturakkhitā ādayaḥ dasa dhanakkītā chanda vāsinī bhoga vāsinī paṭa vāsinī  dāsī ca bhariyā kammakārī ca bhariyā dhajāhaṭā muhuttikā ati
translated: A woman bought with money, a slave woman, a woman who lives by her body, a woman servant, a woman obtained by inheritance, a woman obtained along with a village, a woman obtained together with the dowry, and a woman who is pregnant—these are the twenty kinds of women who are bought with money.

original: etā dhanakkītādayo dasāti vīsati itthiyo. Itthīsu pana dvīnnaṃ sārakkhasaparidaṇḍānaṃ
analyzed: etāḥ dhanakkīta ādayaḥ dasāti vīsati itthiyaḥ itthīsu pana
translated: But among these twenty, two kinds are guarded and two are not guarded.

original: dasannañca dhanakkītādīnanti dvādasannaṃ itthīnaṃ aññe purisā, idaṃ agamanīyaṭṭhānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: dasannam ca dhanakkīta ādīnam ti dvādasannam itthīnam aññe purisāḥ idam agamanīyaṭṭhānam nāma
translated: And twelve women, namely, the ten kinds of women beginning with the one bought with money, are called “places where one should not go.”

original: So panesa micchācāro sīlādiguṇarahite agamanīyaṭṭhāne appasāvajjo, sīlādiguṇasampanne
analyzed: so pana esa micchā ācāraḥ sīla ādi guṇa rahite agamanīya ṭhāne appasāvajjo sīla ādi guṇa sampanne
translated: This sexual misconduct is less blameworthy when the place where one should not go is devoid of such special qualities as virtue, etc.,🔽and more blameworthy when it possesses such qualities.

original: mahāsāvajjo. Tassa cattāro sambhārā – agamanīyavatthu tasmiṃ sevanacittaṃ sevanapayogo
analyzed: mahāsāvajjo tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ agamanīya vatthu tasmim sevana cittam sevana payogaḥ
translated: Its four constituents are: the place where one should not go, the intention to have intercourse there, the act of intercourse,

original: maggena maggapaṭipattiadhivāsananti. Eko payogo sāhatthiko eva.🔽Musāti visaṃvādanapurekkhārassa atthabhañjanako vacīpayogo kāyapayogo vā. Visaṃvādanādhippāyena🔽panassa paravisaṃvādakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo. Aparo nayo – musāti🔽abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu. Vādoti tassa bhūtato tacchato viññāpanaṃ. Lakkhaṇato pana🔽atathaṃ vatthuṃ tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo.
analyzed: maggena magga paṭipatti adhivāsananti ekaḥ payogo sāhatthikaḥ eva 🔽musā ati visaṃvādana purekkhārassa attha bhañjanakaḥ vacī payogaḥ kāya payogaḥ vā visaṃvādana adhippāyena 🔽panassa para visaṃvādaka kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ musā ti 🔽abhūtam ataccham vatthu vādo ti tassa bhūtato tacchataḥ viññāpanam lakkhaṇato pana 🔽atatham vatthum tathatas param viññāpetu kāmassa tathā viññatti samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ
translated: and the approval of it by the way of acquiescence. There is only one way of committing it, and that is personally.

original: So yamatthaṃ bhañjati, tassa appatāya appasāvajjo, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Api ca
analyzed: saḥ yam attham bhañjati tassa appa tāya appa sāvajjaḥ mahanta tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ api ca
translated: and it is less blameworthy when the object is less, more blameworthy when the object is greater.

original: gahaṭṭhānaṃ attano santakaṃ adātukāmatāya “natthī”tiādinayappavatto appasāvajjo,🔽sakkhinā hutvā atthabhañjanatthaṃ vutto mahāsāvajjo. Pabbajitānaṃ appakampi telaṃ
analyzed: gaha ṭṭhānam attanaḥ santakam a dātu kāma tāya natthi iti ādi naya ppavatto appa sāvajjaḥ  sakkhinā hutvā attha bhañjana attham vuttaḥ mahā sāvajjaḥ pabbajitānam appakampi telam
translated: Moreover, it is less blameworthy in householders when it occurs in the form of saying “I have none” out of unwillingness to give what they possess to others,🔽and it is more blameworthy when it occurs for the purpose of deceiving others by saying “I have none” when one has.

original: vā sappiṃ vā labhitvā hasādhippāyena “ajja gāme telaṃ nadī maññe sandatī”ti pūraṇakathānayena
analyzed: vā sappim vā labhitvā hasa adhippāyena ajja gāme telam nadī maññe sandati iti pūraṇa kathā nayena
translated: And it is less blameworthy in the bhikkhu when it occurs in the form of saying “Today oil or ghee is being distributed in the village, it seems” in the manner of a joke after getting a little oil or ghee,

original: pavatto appasāvajjo, adiṭṭhaṃyeva pana diṭṭhantiādinā nayena vadantānaṃ mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: pavattaḥ appasāvajjaḥ adiṭṭham yeva pana diṭṭham ti ādinā nayena vadantānam mahāsāvajjaḥ
translated: and it is more blameworthy when it occurs in the manner of saying “I have seen it” when one has not seen it.

original: Tassa cattāro sambhārā honti – atathaṃ vatthu visaṃvādanacittaṃ tajjo vāyāmo parassa🔽tadatthavijānananti. Eko payogo sāhatthikova. So ca kāyena vā kāyapaṭibaddhena vā
analyzed: tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ honti atatham vatthu visaṃvādana cittam tad jaḥ vā āyāmaḥ parassa  tad attha vijānanam ti ekaḥ payogo sāhatthikaḥ uva saḥ ca kāyena vā kāya paṭibaddhena vā
translated: It has four constituents: the object that is not as it is, the intention to deceive, the effort that is appropriate to that, and the other’s understanding of that meaning.🔽There is one mode of procedure, and that is by one’s own hand. And that should be understood as the performance of the action of deceiving another by body or by what is connected with body or by speech.

original: vācāya vā paravisaṃvādakakiriyākaraṇe daṭṭhabbo. Tāya ce kiriyāya paro tamatthaṃ
analyzed: vācāya vā para visaṃvādaka kiriyā karaṇe daṭṭhabbo tāya ce kiriyāya paraḥ tam attham
translated: And if, by that action,

original: jānāti, ayaṃ kiriyasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanākkhaṇeyeva musāvādakammunā bajjhati.🔽Pisuṇavācātiādīsu yāya vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tassa hadaye attano piyabhāvaṃ🔽parassa ca suññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇavācā. Yāya pana attānampi parampi pharusaṃ
analyzed: jānāti ayam kiriya samuṭṭhāpikā musāvāda kammunā bajjhati  pisuṇa vācā ati ādīsu vācāya yassa tam vācam bhāsati tassa hadaye piya bhāvam  parassa ca suñña bhāvam karoti sā pisuṇa vācā yāya pana attānam pi param pi pharusam
translated: He is bound by the action of lying at the moment of the volition that instigates the action.🔽In the case of malicious speech and so on, the speech by which one makes another’s mind ill-disposed towards a third person,

original: karoti, yā vācā sayampi pharusā neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayaṅgamā, ayaṃ pharusavācā.
analyzed: karoti yā vācā sayam pi pharusā na iva kaṇṇa sukhā na hadayaṅgamā ayam pharusa vācā
translated: or the speech by which one makes both ill-disposed towards each other, is malicious speech. The speech by which one makes another ill-disposed towards oneself, or the speech by which one makes both oneself and another ill-disposed, is harsh speech.

original: Yena samphaṃ palapati niratthakaṃ, so samphappalāpo. Tesaṃ mūlabhūtāpi cetanā pisuṇavācādināmameva
analyzed: yena sampham palapati niratthakam so sampha ppalāpaḥ tesam mūla bhūtā api cetanā pisuṇa vācā ādi nāmam eva
translated: The speech by which one prattles meaninglessly is gossip. The volition that is the root cause of these is called malicious speech, etc.,

original: labhati, sā eva idha adhippetāti.
analyzed: labhati sā eva idha adhippetā ati
translated: and that is what is intended here.

original: Tattha saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa paresaṃ vā bhedāya attano piyakamyatāya vā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: tattha saṃkiliṭṭha cittassa paresam vā bhedāya attanaḥ piya kamyatāya vā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: Herein, the volition that instigates bodily and verbal effort in one whose mind is defiled, either for the purpose of dividing others or for the purpose of winning friends for oneself,

original: cetanā pisuṇavācā. Sā yassa bhedaṃ karoti, tassa appaguṇāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā.
analyzed: cetanā pisuṇa vācā sā yassa bhedam karoti tassa appaguṇāya appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā
translated: is malicious speech. It is less blameworthy when the person divided has few good qualities and is of little account, and it is more blameworthy when the person divided has great qualities and is of great account.

original: Tassā cattāro sambhārā honti – bhinditabbo paro “iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissantī”ti
analyzed: tassā cattāro sambhārāḥ honti bhinditabbaḥ paraḥ iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissanti iti
translated: Its four constituents are: the other person who is to be split up, the thought “Thus they will be different, they will be split up”,

original: bhedapurekkhāratā vā, “iti ahaṃ piyo bhavissāmi vissāsiko”ti viyakamyatā vā, tajjo
analyzed: bheda purekkhāra tā vā iti aham piyaḥ bhavissāmi vissāsikaḥ iti viyakamyatā vā tajjo
translated: or the thought of pre-occupation with splitting them up, or the thought of the wish to split them up thus “Thus I shall be dear and trusted”, or the appropriate

original: vāyāmo, tassa tadatthavijānananti.
analyzed: vāyāmaḥ
translated: effort, or the knowledge of the meaning of that.

original: Parassa mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā ekantapharusacetanā pharusavācā.
analyzed: parassa ekanta pharusa cetanā pharusa vācā
translated: Harsh speech is a harsh intention that originates in a bodily or verbal effort to cut another person’s affection.

original: Mammacchedakopi payogo cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti. Mātāpitaro hi kadāci puttake🔽evampi vadanti “corā vo khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ karontū”ti, uppalapattampi ca nesaṃ upari
analyzed: payogo citta saṇhatāya pharusa vācā na hoti mātā pitaraḥ hi kadāci  evam pi vadanti corāḥ vaḥ khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam karontu uti uppala pattam pi upari
translated: And the effort to cut another’s affection is not harsh speech if it is done with a mind that is not harsh. For parents sometimes say to their children:🔽“Let thieves cut you limb from limb,” and they do not want even a lotus leaf to fall on them. And teachers and preceptors sometimes say to their pupils:

original: patantaṃ na icchanti. Ācariyupajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evaṃ vadanti “kiṃ ime ahirikā🔽anottappino caranti, niddhamatha ne”ti. Atha ca nesaṃ āgamādhigamasampattiṃ icchanti.
analyzed: patantam na icchanti ācariya upajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evam vadanti kim ime ahirikā 🔽caranti caranti atha ca āgama adhigama sampattim icchanti
translated: “Why do you behave like shameless, brazen people? Get out!” and they want them to acquire the ability to understand the scriptures and the commentaries.

original: Yathā ca cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti, evaṃ vacanasaṇhatāya apharusavācāpi
analyzed: yathā ca citta saṇhatāya pharusa vācā na evam vacana saṇhatāya a pharusa vācā api
translated: And just as harsh speech is not so when the mind is softened, so also it is not so when the speech is softened.

original: na hoti. Na hi mārāpetukāmassa “imaṃ sukhaṃ sayāpethā”ti vacanaṃ apharusavācā hoti,🔽cittapharusatāya panesā pharusavācāva, sā yaṃ sandhāya pavattitā. Tassa appaguṇatāya
analyzed: na hoti na hi māra apetu kāmassa imam sukham vacanam a pharusa vācā hoti  citta pharusa tāya pana isā pharusa vācā ava sā yam sandhāya tassa appaguṇa tāya
translated: And just as harsh speech is not so when the mind is tender, so it is not so when the speech is tender. For when one who wants to have another killed says, “Let him have a comfortable bed to lie on,” his words are not harsh speech;

original: appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā tayo sambhārā – akkositabbo paro kupitacittaṃ akkosananti.🔽Anatthaviññāpikā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā samphappalāpo. So āsevanamandatāya
analyzed: appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā tassā tayo sambhārā akkositabbo parassa kupita cittam  anattha viññāpikā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā akusala cetanā samphappalāpaḥ saḥ āsevana manda tāya
translated: but because of the harshness of the mind they are harsh speech, and they are so described because of the state of mind in which they occur. They are less blameworthy when the person concerned has few good qualities and more blameworthy when he has great qualities. Its three constituents are another who should not be abused, a mind that is affected by hate, and the act of abusing.

original: appasāvajjo, āsevanamahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Tassa dve sambhārā honti – bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādiniratthakakathāpurekkhāratā🔽tathārūpīkathākathanañcāti.
analyzed: appasāvajjaḥ āsevana mahanta tāya mahāsāvajjaḥ tassa dve sambhārāḥ honti bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi niratthaka kathā purekkhāra tā  tathārūpī kathā kathanam ca ati
translated: Meaningless speech is unprofitable volition initiating a bodily or vocal effort that conveys no meaning. It is less blameworthy when the effort is slight and more blameworthy when the effort is great. Its two constituents are the desire to talk nonsense and the talking.

original: Abhijjhāyatīti abhijjhā, parabhaṇḍābhimukhī hutvā tanninnatāya pavattatīti attho.
analyzed: abhijjhāyati iti abhijjhā parabhaṇḍa abhimukhī hutvā tad ninna tāya pavattati iti attho
translated: Covetousness is the state of the mind of one who covets, the meaning is that it occurs tending, leaning towards another’s property.

original: Sā “aho vata idaṃ mamāssā”ti evaṃ parabhaṇḍābhijjhāyanalakkhaṇā. Adinnādānaṃ viya
analyzed: sā aho vata idam mama assa ati evam parabhaṇḍa abhijjhāyana lakkhaṇā adinnādānam viya
translated: Its characteristic is the desire to make another’s property one’s own thus, “Oh, that this should be mine!”🔽Like taking what is not given, it is sometimes less blameworthy and sometimes more blameworthy.

original: appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca. Tassā dve sambhārā honti – parabhaṇḍaṃ attano pariṇāmanañcāti.🔽Parabhaṇḍavatthuke hi lobhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti, yāva “aho vatidaṃ
analyzed: appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca tassā dve sambhārā honti parabhaṇḍam attano pariṇāmanam ca ati  parabhaṇḍa vatthuke hi lobhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti yāva aho
translated: Its two concomitants are another’s property and the resolve to make it one’s own.

original: mamāssā”ti attano na pariṇāmeti.
analyzed: na
translated: For even when greed has arisen in respect of another’s property, there is no breach of the path of action until there is the resolve to make it one’s own thus, “Oh, that this should be mine!”

original: Hitasukhaṃ byāpādayatīti byāpādo, so paravināsāya manopadosalakkhaṇo. Pharusavācā
analyzed: hita sukham byāpādayati iti byāpādo saḥ para vināsāya manaḥ padosa lakkhaṇo pharusa vācā
translated: It is ill will because it does harm and ill to one who is dear and pleasant . Its characteristic is the wish to harm another.🔽Like harsh speech, it is sometimes less blameworthy and sometimes more blameworthy.

original: viya appasāvajjo mahāsāvajjo ca. Tassa dve sambhārā honti – parasatto ca tassa ca🔽vināsacintāti. Parasattavatthuke hi kodhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti,
analyzed: viya appasāvajjaḥ mahāsāvajjo ca tassa dve sambhārā honti parasatto ca tassa ca  vināsa cintā ati para satta vatthuke hi kodhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti
translated: Its two concomitants are a living being and the wish to harm it.

original: yāva “aho vatāyaṃ ucchijjeyya vinasseyyā”ti tassa vināsaṃ na cintesi.
analyzed: yāva aho vata ayam ucchijjeyya vinasseyya ati tassa vināsam na cintesi
translated: For even when anger has arisen in respect of a living being, there is no breach of the path of action until there is the wish to harm it thus, “Oh, that this one might be cut up, destroyed, or annihilated!”

original: Yathābhuccagahaṇābhāvena micchā passatīti micchādiṭṭhi. Sā “natthi dinna”ntiādinā nayena viparītadassanalakkhaṇā. Samphappalāpo viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca.🔽Saññī, asaññī, nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissāmāti rūpādivasena kaṅkhanti. Bhavissāma nu
analyzed: yathā abhucca gahaṇa abhāvena micchā passati iti micchādiṭṭhi sā natthi dinna nti ādinā nayena viparīta dassana lakkhaṇā samphappalāpaḥ viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca  saññī asaññī nevasaññī na asaññī bhavissāma ati rūpa ādi vasena kaṅkhanti bhavissāma nu
translated: He sees wrongly because he does not take up what is as it is. Thus he is one of wrong view. It has the characteristic of seeing contrary to the facts, as in the case of the view “There is nothing given” , etc. It is less blameworthy or more blameworthy like frivolous talk.🔽He is doubtful about form, etc., thus: “Will I be? Will I not be? What will I be? How will I be? Where will I be? Will I be having form? Will I be formless? Will I be percipient? Will I be non-percipient? Will I be neither percipient nor non-percipient?”

original: kho mayantiādinā attānaṃ kaṅkhanti. Tattha bhavissāma nu kho. Na nu kho bhavissāmāti
analyzed: kho mayanti ādinā attānam kaṅkhanti tattha bhavissāma nu kho na nu kho bhavissāma ati
translated: He is doubtful about himself thus: “Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future? What will I be in the future? How will I be in the future?”🔽Herein, he is doubtful about himself in the future thus, “Will I exist or not exist?”

original: tassa sassatākārañca ucchedākārañca nissāya anāgate attānaṃ vijjamānatañca avijjamānatañca
analyzed: tassa sassata ākāram ca uccheda ākāram ca nissāya anāgate attānam vijjamāna tañca a vijjamāna tañca
translated: through the mode of conceiving the self as eternal and through the mode of conceiving the self as perishable.

original: kaṅkhanti. Kiṃ nu kho bhavissāmāti jātiliṅgupapattiyo nissāya “khattiyā nu kho bhavissāma,
analyzed: kaṅkhanti kim nu kho bhavissāma ati jāti liṅga upapattiyaḥ nissāya khattiyāḥ nu kho bhavissāma
translated: He is doubtful about what he will be in the future thus: “What will I be in the future? ”

original: brāhmaṇavessasuddagahaṭṭhapabbajitadevamanussānaṃ aññatarā”ti kaṅkhanti. Kathaṃ nu
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vessa sudda gahaṭṭha pabbajita deva manussānam aññatarā ati kaṅkhanti katham nu
translated: through the mode of conceiving the self as having a particular birth, sex, etc., he is doubtful thus: “Will I be a warrior, a brahman, a merchant, a worker, a deity, a human being, or one of the various kinds of ghosts? Will I be male, female, or of the sexless kind? Will I be of such a name, lineage, appearance, and so on?”🔽He is doubtful about how he will be in the future thus: “How will I be in the future? ”

original: kho bhavissāmāti saṇṭhānākāraṃ nissāya “dīghā nu kho bhavissāma, rassaodātakaṇhapamāṇikaappamāṇikādīnaṃ
analyzed: kho bhavissāma iti saṇṭhāna ākāram nissāya dīghāḥ nu kho bhavissāma rassa odāta kaṇha pamāṇika appamāṇika ādīnam
translated: through the mode of conceiving the self as having a particular shape, he is doubtful thus: “Will I be tall, short, or of medium height? Will I be dark, fair, or of what complexion? Will I be long-lived or short-lived? Will I stay thus for a long time or for a short time?”

original: aññatarā”ti kaṅkhanti. Keci pana “issaranimmānādīni nissāya ‘kena nu kho kāraṇena
analyzed: aññatarā ti kaṅkhanti keci pana issara nimmāna ādīni nissāya kena nu kho kāraṇena
translated: They are doubtful about the other.

original: bhavissāmā’ti hetuto kaṅkhantī”ti vadanti. Kiṃ hutvā kiṃ bhavissāma nu kho mayanti
analyzed: bhavissāma ati hetutaḥ kaṅkhanti iti vadanti kim hutvā kim bhavissāma nu kho
translated: But some say that they are doubtful about the cause, wondering by what means they will come to be in the future.

original: jātiādīni nissāya “khattiyā hutvā nu kho brāhmaṇā bhavissāma…pe… devā hutvā manussā”ti
analyzed: jāti ādīni nissāya khattiyāḥ hutvā nu kho brāhmaṇāḥ bhavissāma pe devāḥ hutvā manussā ati
translated: They are doubtful about their own future continuity, wondering whether they will be reborn as a deity after being a human being, or as a human being after being a deity, and so on.

original: attano paramparaṃ kaṅkhanti. Sabbattheva pana addhānanti kālādhivacanametaṃ.🔽10. Yasmā etadeva tasmā hi sikkhetha…pe… āhu dhīrāti. Tattha sikkhethāti tisso sikkhā
analyzed: attano paramparam kaṅkhanti sabbattha iva pana addhānan ti kāla adhivacanam etam  yasmai etat eva tasmai hi sikkhetha pe āhu dhīrā ati tattha sikkhetha ati tisso sikkhā
translated: But in all cases the word “future” is a term for time.🔽Since this is so, therefore: “One should train thus: ‘I shall be heedful, mindful, possessed of full awareness,

original: āvajjeyya. Idhevāti imasmiṃyeva sāsane. Tattha sikkhitabbāti sikkhā. Tissoti gaṇanaparicchedo.🔽Adhisīlasikkhāti adhikaṃ uttamaṃ sīlanti adhisīlaṃ, adhisīlañca taṃ sikkhitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: āvajjeyya idha iva ati imasmiṃ yeva sāsane tattha sikkhitabbā ati sikkhā tissā ti gaṇana paricchedaḥ  adhi sīla sikkhā adhikam uttamam sīlanti adhi sīlam adhi sīlam ca tam sikkhitabba ṭṭhena
translated: and will thoroughly comprehend the mind’s tendency’—so it was said. And with reference to what was this said? There are three kinds of training:🔽the training in the higher virtue, the training in the higher mind, and the training in the higher wisdom.

original: sikkhā cāti adhisīlasikkhā. Esa nayo adhicittaadhipaññāsikkhāsu.
analyzed: sikkhā ca ati adhi sīla sikkhā esa nayaḥ adhi citta adhi paññā sikkhāsu
translated: The training in the higher virtue is the training in the higher virtue and it is a training; thus it is the training in the higher virtue. So too with the training in the higher mind and the training in the higher wisdom.

original: Katamaṃ panettha sīlaṃ, katamaṃ adhisīlaṃ, katamaṃ cittaṃ, katamaṃ adhicittaṃ, katamā🔽paññā, katamā adhipaññāti? Vuccate – pañcaṅgadasaṅgasīlaṃ tāva sīlameva. Tañhi buddhe🔽uppannepi anuppannepi loke pavattati. Uppanne buddhe tasmiṃ sīle buddhāpi sāvakāpi🔽mahājanaṃ samādapenti, anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhā ca kammavādino ca dhammikā🔽samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca cakkavattī ca mahārājāno mahābodhisattā ca samādapenti, sāmampi🔽paṇḍitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā samādiyanti. Te taṃ kusalaṃ dhammaṃ paripūretvā devesu ca
analyzed: katamam pana itthā sīlam katamam adhisīlam katamam cittam katamam adhicittam katamā  paññā katamā adhipaññā iti vuccate sīlam tāva sīlam eva tat hi buddhe  uppanne api anuppanne pi loke pavattati uppanne buddhe tasmin sīle buddhāḥ api sāvakāḥ api  mahājanam samādapenti anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhāḥ ca kamma vādinaḥ ca dhammikā  samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca cakkavattī ca mahā rājānaḥ mahā bodhisattā ca samādapenti sāmam pi  paṇḍitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā te tam kusalam dhammam paripūretvā devesu ca
translated: What, then, is virtue? What is higher virtue? What is consciousness? What is higher consciousness? What is understanding? What is higher understanding?

original: manussesu ca sampattiṃ anubhonti.
analyzed: manussesu ca sampattim anubhonti
translated: It may be stated as follows: The virtue of the five and eight precepts is simply virtue. For that is practiced in the world whether Buddhas arise or not. When Buddhas arise, Buddhas and their disciples encourage people to practice that virtue. When Buddhas do not arise, Paccekabuddhas, religious wanderers and brahmans who are righteous and proclaimers of the Dhamma, universal monarchs, and great bodhisattvas encourage people to practice it. Even animals observe that virtue. Wise religious wanderers and brahmans undertake it. Having fulfilled that wholesome practice, they enjoy the benefits both in the heavenly worlds and among mankind.

original: Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ pana “adhisīla”nti vuccati. Tañhi sūriyo viya pajjotānaṃ sineru
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam pana adhisīlam ti vuccati tat hi sūriyaḥ viya pajjotānam sineru
translated: But virtue consisting in the restraint of the Patimokkha is called “higher virtue.” For that is like the sun among the stars, like Mount Sineru among the mountains,

original: viya pabbatānaṃ sabbalokiyasīlānaṃ adhikañceva uttamañca, buddhuppādeyeva ca pavattati,
analyzed: viya pabbatānam sabba lokiya sīlānam adhikam ca iva uttamam ca ca pavattati
translated: and it is the best and highest of all mundane kinds of virtue. It comes into being only when a Buddha arises,

original: na vinā buddhuppādā. Na hi taṃ paññattiṃ uddharitvā añño satto ṭhapetuṃ sakkoti.
analyzed: na vinā buddhuppādāḥ na hi tam paññattim uddharitvā aññaḥ satto ṭhapetum sakkoti
translated: not when a Buddha has not arisen. For no being can establish it by extracting the description of it from somewhere else.

original: Buddhāyeva pana sabbaso kāyavacīdvāraajjhācārasotaṃ chinditvā tassa tassa vītikkamassa
analyzed: buddhāya iva pana sabbaso kāyavacī dvāra ajjhācāra sotam chinditvā tassa tassa vītikkamassa
translated: But when a Buddha has arisen, he cuts off the stream of misconduct in the three doors of bodily action, speech and mind, and he describes the virtue of restraint in the various rules of training in accordance with the different kinds of transgression.

original: anucchavikaṃ taṃ sīlasaṃvaraṃ paññapenti. Pātimokkhasaṃvaratopi ca maggaphalasampayuttameva sīlaṃ adhisīlaṃ.
analyzed: anucchavikam tam sīla saṃvaram paññapenti pātimokkha saṃvarataḥ pi ca magga phala sampayuttam eva sīlam adhisīlam
translated: And of the virtue of restraint in the Pāṭimokkha, too, it is that accompanied by the path and fruition that is the highest virtue.

original: Kāmāvacarāni pana aṭṭha kusalacittāni lokiyaaṭṭhasamāpatticittāni ca ekajjhaṃ katvā🔽cittamevāti veditabbāni. Buddhuppādānuppāde cassa pavatti, samādapanaṃ samādānañca
analyzed: kāmāvacarāni pana aṭṭha kusala cittāni lokiya aṭṭha samāpatti cittāni ca ekajjham katvā  cittam eva ati veditabbāni buddhuppāda anuppāde ca ssa pavatti samādapanam samādānañca
translated: But the eight kinds of profitable consciousness of the sense sphere and the eight kinds of consciousness of the fine-material sphere together with the four path consciousnesses and the four fruition consciousnesses, making sixteen, are all called “mind” .

original: sīle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sīle vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: It comes into being both when a Buddha has arisen and when he has not arisen. The undertaking of it and the undertaking of it are to be understood in the way already described under virtue.🔽But the eight kinds of consciousness of the fine-material sphere that lead to insight are called “the highest mind” .

original: Vipassanāpādakaṃ aṭṭhasamāpatticittaṃ pana “adhicitta”nti vuccati. Tañhi adhisīlaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā pādakam aṭṭha samāpatti cittam pana adhicittam ti vuccati tat hi adhisīlam
translated: For that is higher than virtue,

original: viya sīlānaṃ, sabbalokiyacittānaṃ adhikañceva uttamañca, buddhuppādeyeva ca hoti,
analyzed: sīlānam sabbalokiya cittānam adhikam ca iva uttamam ca ca hoti
translated: and it is the highest and best of all mundane consciousnesses. It comes about only when a Buddha has arisen,

original: na vinā buddhuppādā. Tatopi ca maggaphalacittameva adhicittaṃ.
analyzed: na vinā buddhuppādā tatas api ca magga phala cittam eva adhicittam
translated: not when a Buddha has not arisen. And for that reason too consciousness of the path and of fruition is the highest state of consciousness.

original: “Atthi dinnaṃ atthi yiṭṭha”ntiādinayappavattaṃ pana kammassakatāñāṇaṃ paññā. Sā hi
analyzed: atthi dinnam atthi yiṭṭhanti ādi naya ppavattam pana kammassaka tā ñāṇam paññā sā hi
translated: But the knowledge of the efficacy of kamma, which occurs with the words, “There is what is given,” and so on, is understanding.🔽For that occurs in the world whether a Buddha has arisen or not.

original: buddhe uppannepi anuppannepi loke pavattati. Uppanne buddhe tassā paññāya buddhāpi🔽sāvakāpi mahājanaṃ samādapenti, anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhā ca kammavādino ca
analyzed: buddhe uppanne api anuppanne pi loke pavattati uppanne buddhe tassā paññāya buddhā api  sāvakāḥ api mahājanam samādapenti anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhā ca kamma vādinaḥ ca
translated: When a Buddha has arisen, he and his disciples convert the great multitude to that understanding.

original: dhammikā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca cakkavattī ca mahārājāno mahābodhisattā ca samādapenti,
analyzed: dhammikā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca cakkavattī ca mahā rājānaḥ mahā bodhisattā ca samādapenti
translated: When a Buddha has not arisen, the paccekabuddhas and the religious teachers who teach kamma, and the righteous recluses and brahmans, and the great universal monarchs, and the great future Buddhas convert the great multitude to it.

original: sāmampi paṇḍitā sattā samādiyanti. Tathā hi aṅkuro dasavassasahassāni mahādānaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: sāmam pi samādiyanti tathā hi aṅkuraḥ dasa vassa sahassāni mahādānam adāsi
translated: And wise men undertake it even by themselves. Thus Aṅkura gave great gifts for ten thousand years.

original: Velāmo vessantaro aññe ca bahū paṇḍitamanussā mahādānāni adaṃsu. Te taṃ kusalaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: velāmaḥ vessantaraḥ aññe ca bahū paṇḍita manussāḥ mahā dānāni adaṃsu te tam kusalam dhammaṃ
translated: And Velāma, Vessantara, and many other wise men gave great gifts. They did so because they had understood that good and bad deeds

original: paripūretvā devesu ca manussesu ca sampattiṃ anubhaviṃsu.
analyzed: paripūretvā devesu ca manussesu ca sampattim anubhaviṃsu
translated: and after fulfilling it they have experienced the fulfilment of their own welfare.

original: Tilakkhaṇākāraparicchedakaṃ pana vipassanāñāṇaṃ “adhipaññā”ti vuccati. Sā hi adhisīlaadhicittāni
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇa ākāra paricchedakam pana vipassanā ñāṇam adhipaññā iti vuccati sā hi adhi sīla adhicittāni
translated: But the knowledge of insight that defines the three characteristics is called “higher understanding.” For that is higher and best than virtue and consciousness and than all mundane understanding,

original: viya sīlacittānaṃ, sabbalokiyapaññānaṃ adhikā ceva uttamā ca, na ca vinā buddhuppādā
analyzed: sīla cittānam sabbalokiya paññānam adhikā ca iva uttamā ca na ca vinā buddhuppādā
translated: like the higher virtue and the higher consciousness. And it does not occur in the world without the arising of Buddhas.

original: loke pavattati. Tatopi ca maggaphalapaññāva adhipaññā.
analyzed: loke pavattati tatas pi ca magga phala paññā va adhipaññā
translated: And it is also higher understanding because it is understanding that is the path and its fruit.

original: Idāni ekekaṃ dassento “katamā adhisīlasikkhā – idha bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto
analyzed: idāni ekekam dassento katamā adhi sīla sikkhā idha bhikkhu sīlavā hoti pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ
translated: Now, in order to show each of them, he said: “What is the training in the higher virtue? Here a bhikkhu is virtuous, he dwells restrained with the restraint of the Patimokkha,

original: viharatī”tiādimāha. Idhāti vacanaṃ pubbabhāgakaraṇīyasampadāya sampannassa sabbapakārasīlaparipūrakassa
analyzed: viharati itiādim āha idha iti vacanam pubbabhāga karaṇīya sampadāya sampannassa sabba pakāra sīla paripūrakassa
translated: resolute, ardent, and resolute in right behaviour and in good conduct. ” Here is a word of comment: the word “here” indicates the Dispensation as the resort for one who has achieved the requisite conditions for the higher virtue and is fulfilling all the aspects of virtue.

original: puggalassa sannissayabhūtasāsanaparidīpanaṃ, aññasāsanassa ca tathābhāvapaṭisedhanaṃ.
analyzed: puggalassa sannissaya bhūta sāsana paridīpanaṃ añña sāsanassa ca tathābhāva paṭisedhanaṃ
translated: It also denies that any other Dispensation has that virtue.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ – “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo…pe… suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam ha etam idha iva bhikkhave samaṇa upe suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehi iti
translated: For this is said: “Here, bhikkhus, is the recluse, here is the divine life; the other dispensations are empty of recluses, empty of divine life” .

original: Bhikkhūti tassa sīlassa paripūrakassa puggalassa paridīpanaṃ. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti
analyzed: bhikkhu iti tassa sīlassa paripūrakassa puggalassa paridīpanam pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvuto ti
translated: Bhikkhu: this shows the person who fulfills that virtue. Restrained with the restraint of the Patimokkha:🔽this shows his being established in the Patimokkha restraint.

original: idamassa pātimokkhasaṃvare patiṭṭhitabhāvaparidīpanaṃ. Viharatīti idamassa tadanurūpavihārasamaṅgībhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: idam assa pātimokkha saṃvare patiṭṭhita bhāva paridīpanam viharati iti idam assa tad anurūpa vihāra samaṅgībhāva paridīpanam
translated: He dwells: this shows his being endowed with a way of life in conformity with that.

original: Ācāragocarasampannoti idamassa pātimokkhasaṃvarassa upakārakadhammaparidīpanaṃ. Aṇumattesu
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampannaḥ ti idam assa pātimokkha saṃvarassa upakāraka dhamma paridīpanam aṇumattesu
translated: Possessed of good conduct and resort: this shows the things that help his Patimokkha restraint. Seeing fear in the slightest fault:

original: vajjesu bhayadassāvīti idamassa pātimokkhato acavanadhammatāparidīpanaṃ. Samādāyāti🔽idamassa sikkhāpadānaṃ anavasesato ādānaparidīpanaṃ. Sikkhatīti idamassa sikkhāya
analyzed: vajjesu idam assa pātimokkhataḥ a cavana dhamma tā paridīpanam samādāya ati  idam assa sikkhā apadānam anavasesataḥ ādāna paridīpanam sikkhati iti idam assa sikkhāya
translated: this shows his not transgressing the Patimokkha. Having undertaken:🔽this shows his taking up the training rules without exception. He trains: this shows his being endowed with the training.

original: samaṅgībhāvaparidīpanaṃ. Sikkhāpadesūti idamassa sikkhitabbadhammaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: samaṅgībhāva paridīpanam sikkhāpadesu iti idam assa sikkhitabba dhamma paridīpanam
translated: In the training rules: this shows the things that should be trained in.

original: Tattha bhikkhūti saṃsāre bhayaṃ ikkhatīti bhikkhu. Sīlamassa atthīti sīlavāti ettha
analyzed: tattha bhikkhu iti saṃsāre bhayam ikkhati iti bhikkhu sīlam assa atthi iti sīlavā ati ettha
translated: Herein, he sees fear in the world, thus he is a bhikkhu . He has virtue, thus he is virtuous .

original: sīlanti sīlanaṭṭhena sīlaṃ. Kimidaṃ sīlanaṃ nāma? Samādhānaṃ vā, kāyakammādīnaṃ susīlyavasena
analyzed: sīlanti sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam kim idam sīlanam nāma samādhānam vā kāya kamma ādīnam susīlya vasena
translated: “Morality” is so called because of its nature of moral habit . What is this moral habit? It is the state of being unscattered , in the sense of the good habit of bodily action, etc., by means of concentration.

original: avippakiṇṇatāti attho. Upadhāraṇaṃ vā, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ patiṭṭhāvasena ādhārabhāvoti🔽attho. Etadeva hi ettha atthadvayaṃ saddalakkhaṇavidū anujānanti. Aññe pana “adhisevanaṭṭhena
analyzed: a vippakiṇṇa tā ti attho upadhāraṇam vā kusalānam dhammānam patiṭṭhā vasena ādhāra bhāvaḥ ti  attho etat eva hi ettha attha dvayam sadda lakkhaṇa vidū anujānanti aññe pana adhisevana ṭṭhena
translated: Or it is the state of being a foundation , in the sense of being the foundation for profitable things.🔽For this is the twofold meaning here that those who know the characteristics of words admit.

original: ācāraṭṭhena sīlanaṭṭhena siraṭṭhena sītalaṭṭhena sivaṭṭhena sīla”nti vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: ācāra aṭṭhena sīlana ṭṭhena sira ṭṭhena sītala ṭṭhena siva ṭṭhena sīlanti vaṇṇayanti
translated: But others describe it as “moral habit” in the sense of frequenting , in the sense of conduct , in the sense of moral habit , in the sense of head , in the sense of coolness , in the sense of auspiciousness .🔽The characteristic of that is moral habit,

original: Sīlanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ tassa, bhinnassāpi anekadhā;
analyzed: sīlanam lakkhaṇam tassa bhinnassa api anekadhā
translated: Though it is divided up in many ways,

original: Sanidassanattaṃ rūpassa, yathā bhinnassanekadhā.🔽Yathā hi nīlapītādibhedenanekadhā bhinnassāpi rūpāyatanassa sanidassanattaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: rūpassa yathā bhinnassa anekadhā  yathā hi nīla pīta ādi bhedena anekadhā bhinnassa api rūpa āyatanassa lakkhaṇam
translated: Just as the characteristic of visible form is visibility,🔽Though it is divided up in many ways.🔽For just as the visible-form base has visibility as its characteristic, though it is divided up in many ways by the divisions of blue, yellow, and so on,

original: nīlādibhedena bhinnassāpi sanidassanabhāvānatikkamanato. Tathā sīlassa cetanādibhedena
analyzed: nīla ādi bhedena bhinnassa api sa nidassana bhāva anatikkamanataḥ tathā sīlassa cetanā ādi bhedena
translated: and does not transcend visibility, so morality has the characteristic of moral habit, though it is divided up by the divisions of volition, etc.,

original: anekadhā bhinnassāpi yadetaṃ kāyakammādīnaṃ samādhānavasena, kusalānañca dhammānaṃ
analyzed: anekadhā bhinnassa api yat etam kāya kamma ādīnam samādhāna vasena kusalānam ca dhammānam
translated: And even though it is classified in many ways as bodily action, etc., and as virtue of restraint, virtue of undertaking, and so on, still its characteristic is simply this, that it is the consolidating of bodily, etc., action, and the foundation for the profitable states.

original: patiṭṭhāvasena vuttaṃ sīlanaṃ, tadeva lakkhaṇaṃ cetanādibhedena bhinnassāpi samādhānapatiṭṭhābhāvānatikkamanato.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā vasena vuttam sīlanam tat eva lakkhaṇam cetanā ādi bhedena bhinnassa api samādhāna patiṭṭhā bhāva anatikkamanato
translated: And this characteristic is not exceeded even when it is classified according to the various kinds of consciousness beginning with volition.

original: Evaṃ lakkhaṇassa panassa –
analyzed: evam lakkhaṇassa panassa
translated: The meaning of the word “virtue” is this:

original: Dussīlyaviddhaṃsanatā, anavajjaguṇo tathā;
analyzed: dussīlya viddhaṃsana tā anavajja guṇaḥ tathā
translated: It is the cleanser, and likewise The blameless quality as well;

original: Kiccasampattiatthena, raso nāma pavuccati.
analyzed: kicca sampatti atthena raso nāma pavuccati
translated: And also the success is called The meaning of the word “virtue” .

original: Tasmā idaṃ sīlaṃ nāma kiccaṭṭhena rasena dussīlyaviddhaṃsanarasaṃ, sampattiatthena rasena anavajjarasanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai idam sīlam nāma kicca ṭṭhena rasena dussīlya viddhaṃsana rasam sampatti atthena rasena anavajja rasanti veditabbam
translated: So this virtue should be understood as having the meaning of cleansing in the sense of success, and as having the meaning of the blameless in the sense of meaning.

original: Soceyyapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, tayidaṃ tassa viññubhi;
analyzed: soceyya paccupaṭṭhānam tayidam tassa viññubhi
translated: The wise declare its footing To be conscience and shame;

original: Ottappañca hirī ceva, padaṭṭhānanti vaṇṇitaṃ.
analyzed: hirī ca iva padaṭṭhāna nti vaṇṇitam
translated: And it is said to have as its support The two, conscience and shame.

original: Tañhidaṃ sīlaṃ “kāyasoceyyaṃ vacīsoceyyaṃ manosoceyya”nti evaṃ vuttasoceyyapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: tat hi idam sīlam kāya soceyyam vacī soceyyam manaḥ soceyyam ti evam vutta soceyya paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: This virtue has the support of the cleansing called bodily cleansing, verbal cleansing, and mental cleansing, which is stated thus: “One should be cleansed by bodily cleansing, cleansed by verbal cleansing, cleansed by mental cleansing” .

original: soceyyabhāvena paccupaṭṭhāti gahaṇabhāvaṃ gacchati. Hirottappañca pana tassa viññūhi
analyzed: soceyya bhāvena paccupaṭṭhāti gahaṇa bhāvam gacchati hirottappam ca pana tassa viññūhi
translated: It is supported by cleansing, it is taken up by cleansing. And the wise declare that its support is conscience and shame.

original: padaṭṭhānanti vaṇṇitaṃ, āsannakāraṇanti attho. Hirottappe hi sati sīlaṃ uppajjati
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam ti vaṇṇitam āsanna kāraṇam ti attho hirottappe hi sati sīlam uppajjati
translated: The meaning is that it is the proximate cause of virtue. For virtue arises and persists when there is shame and moral dread,

original: ceva tiṭṭhati ca, asati neva uppajjati ceva na tiṭṭhati cāti evaṃvidhena sīlena sīlavā🔽hoti. Etaṃ sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi vā viramantassa, vattapaṭipattiṃ vā pūrentassa
analyzed: ca iva tiṭṭhati ca asati na iva uppajjati ca iva na tiṭṭhati ca ati evaṃvidhena sīlena sīlavā  hoti etam sīlam nāma pāṇātipāta ādīhi vā viramantassa vatta paṭipattim vā pūrentassa
translated: and it does not arise and does not persist when there is not. So it is of this kind that the virtuous man is virtuous.🔽This virtue should be understood as the states beginning with volition in one who abstains from killing living things, etc., or in one who fulfils the practice of the duties.

original: cetanādayo dhammā veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ “kiṃ sīlanti? Cetanā sīlaṃ,
analyzed: cetanā ādayaḥ dhammā veditabbāḥ vuttam ha etam paṭisambhidā ayam kim sīlam ti cetanā sīlam
translated: For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “What is virtue? The volition of abstinence is virtue;

original: cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ, saṃvaro sīlaṃ, avītikkamo sīla”nti.
analyzed: cetasikam sīlam saṃvaraḥ sīlam a vītikkamaḥ sīlanti
translated: the mental factor of abstinence is virtue; the restraint is virtue; the non- transgression is virtue” .

original: Tattha cetanā sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi vā viramantassa vattapaṭipattiṃ vā pūrentassa🔽cetanā. Cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ nāma pāṇātipātādīhi viramantassa virati. Api ca cetanā sīlaṃ
analyzed: tattha cetanā sīlam nāma pāṇātipāta ādīhi vā viramantassa vatta paṭipattim vā pūrentassa  cetanā cetasikam sīlam nāma pāṇātipāta ādīhi viramantassa virati api ca cetanā sīlam
translated: Herein, the volition of abstinence is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc., or in one who fulfils the practice of the duties.🔽The mental factor of abstinence is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc. Moreover, the volition of abstinence is virtue in one who abandons killing living things, etc.;

original: nāma pāṇātipātādīni pajahantassa sattakammapathacetanā. Cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ nāma “abhijjhaṃ
analyzed: nāma pāṇa atipāta ādīni pajahantassa satta kamma patha cetanā cetasikam sīlam nāma abhijjham
translated: the mental factor of abstinence is virtue in one who abstains from killing living things, etc. Furthermore, the volition of abstinence is virtue in one who abandons the ten courses of unwholesome kamma;🔽the mental factor of abstinence is virtue in one who abstains from the ten courses of unwholesome kamma.

original: pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharatī”tiādinā nayena saṃyuttamahāvagge vuttā anabhijjhābyāpādasammādiṭṭhidhammā.
analyzed: pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati iti ādinā nayena saṃyutta mahāvagge vuttāḥ anabhijjhā byāpāda sammādiṭṭhi dhammā
translated: and he abides with a mind that is without ill will. ” These are the ideas of non-greed, non-ill-will, and right view stated in the way beginning, “He abides with a mind free from covetousness” in the “Great Series of Questions” in the Saṃyutta Nikāya .

original: Saṃvaro sīlanti ettha pañcavidhena saṃvaro veditabbo – pātimokkhasaṃvaro satisaṃvaro
analyzed: saṃvaro sīlanti ettha pañcavidhena saṃvaraḥ veditabbo pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ sati saṃvaro
translated: Restraint is virtue: here restraint should be understood as of five kinds, that is to say, restraint by the rules of training , restraint by mindfulness ,

original: ñāṇasaṃvaro khantisaṃvaro vīriyasaṃvaro. Tassa nānākaraṇaṃ upari āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: ñāṇa saṃvaro khanti saṃvaro vīriya saṃvaro tassa nānākaraṇam upari bhavissati
translated: restraint by knowledge , restraint by patience , and restraint by energy . The difference between these will be explained later .

original: Avītikkamo sīlanti samādinnasīlassa kāyikavācasiko avītikkamo. Ettha ca saṃvarasīlaṃ,
analyzed: avītikkamaḥ sīlanti samādinna sīlassa kāyika vācasikaḥ avītikkamaḥ ettha ca saṃvara sīlam
translated: Non-transgression is virtue: non-transgression of the kind stated in the following passage, “Bhikkhus, one should not intentionally destroy life, nor take what is not given, nor misbehave in sensual pleasures, nor tell a deliberate lie” , is non-transgression by one who has undertaken the training rules. And here restraint virtue and

original: avītikkamasīlanti idameva nippariyāyato sīlaṃ. Cetanāsīlaṃ, cetasikaṃ sīlanti pariyāyato sīlanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: avītikkama sīlanti idam eva nippariyāyataḥ sīlam cetanā sīlam cetasikam sīlanti pariyāyataḥ sīlanti veditabbaṃ
translated: non-transgression virtue are the actual virtue. But volition virtue and mental virtue should be understood as virtue by designation.

original: Pātimokkhanti sikkhāpadasīlaṃ. Tañhi yo naṃ pāti rakkhati, taṃ mokkheti moceti āpāyikādīhi
analyzed: pātimokkham ti sikkhāpada sīlam tat hi yaḥ nam pāti rakkhati tam mokkheti moca iti āpāyika ādīhi
translated: Pāṭimokkha is virtue consisting in the training precepts. For one who keeps it, guards it, protects it, is released from the suffering of the states of loss, etc.,

original: dukkhehi, tasmā “pātimokkha”nti vuttaṃ. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlena
analyzed: dukkhehi tasmā pātimokkhanti vuttam pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ ti pātimokkha saṃvara sīlena
translated: and so it is called “Pāṭimokkha” . “Restrained by the Pāṭimokkha training rule” :

original: samannāgato. Ācāragocarasampannoti ācārena ceva gocarena ca sampanno. Aṇumattesūti🔽appamattakesu. Vajjesūti akusaladhammesu. Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassī. Samādāyāti sammā🔽ādiyitvā. Sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati. Api ca

translated: is endowed. Endowed with virtue and resort: endowed with virtue and resort. In the slightest faults:🔽in the smallest. Seeing fear: seeing danger. Having undertaken: having undertaken properly. Trains: having undertaken this and that training rule, he trains. Moreover,🔽🔽

Mahantoti pārājikādiniravaseso.🔽Yasmā pana pātimokkhasīlena bhikkhu sāsane patiṭṭhāti nāma, tasmā taṃ “patiṭṭhā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Patiṭṭhahati vā ettha bhikkhu, kusalā dhammā eva vā ettha patiṭṭhahantīti

He is possessed of unconfused knowledge. He is possessed of unconfused deliverance. He is possessed of the character of a good person. He is possessed of the character of a good friend. This is the meaning of the passage: “The wise man, established well in virtue” , and: “The characteristic of virtue, sire, is support, it is the foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is established well, he is unshaken by the vicissitudes of life” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a refuge for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a foundation for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a basis for all profitable things” , and: “The man of virtue, sire, is a support for all profitable things” , and: “The

original: kusalā dhammā na parihāyantī”ti ca ādisuttavasena veditabbo.🔽Tadetaṃ pubbuppattiatthena ādi. Vuttampi cetaṃ “tasmātiha tvaṃ uttiya ādimeva visodhehi
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammāḥ na parihāyanti iti ca ādi sutta vasena veditabbo  tat etam pubbuppatti atthena ādi vuttam pi tasmā ati ha tvam uttiye ādim eva visodhehi
translated: It is the foundation. This is the meaning. And it is said: “The man of understanding, established well in virtue” , and “The characteristic of virtue, sire, is that it is a foundation for all profitable things” , and “When a man is established in virtue, sire, … all profitable things do not decline” , and so on.

original: kusalesu dhammesu. Ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ, sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā”ti.🔽Yathā hi nagaravaḍḍhakī nagaraṃ māpetukāmo paṭhamaṃ nagaraṭṭhānaṃ sodheti, tato aparabhāge
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu kaḥ ca ādi kusalānam dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā ati  yathā hi nagara vaḍḍhakī nagaram mā apetu kāmaḥ paṭhamam nagara ṭṭhānam sodheti tatas apara bhāge
translated: This is the beginning in the sense of prior condition. And this is said: “Therefore, Uttiya, you should purify the beginning of profitable things. What is the beginning of profitable things? Virtue that is quite purified and right view” .

original: vīthicatukkasiṅghāṭakādiparicchedena vibhajitvāva nagaraṃ māpeti. Evameva yogāvacaro
analyzed: vīthi catukka siṅghāṭaka ādi paricchedena vibhajitvā ava nagaram mā āpa iti evam eva yogāvacaraḥ
translated: Just as a town-planner, who wants to build a town, first of all clears a site for the town, and then, after dividing it up into streets and quarters, etc., he builds the town, so too the meditator

original: ādito sīlaṃ visodheti, tato aparabhāge samādhivipassanāmaggaphalanibbānāni sacchikaroti.
analyzed: āditas sīlam visodheti tatas apara bhāge samādhi vipassanā magga phala nibbānāni sacchikaroti
translated: first of all purifies his virtue, and then he realizes concentration, insight, the path, fruition, and Nibbāna.

original: Yathā vā pana rajako paṭhamaṃ tīhi khārehi vatthaṃ dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakaṃ
