analyzed: yathā vā pana rajakaḥ paṭhamam tīhi khārehi vattham dhovitvā parisuddhe vatthe yadicchakam
translated: Or just as a laundryman first washes a soiled cloth with a strong lye, and then, when the cloth is clean, he dyes it with whatever dye he likes,

original: raṅgajātaṃ upaneti, yathā vā pana cheko cittakāro rūpaṃ likhitukāmo āditova bhittiparikammaṃ🔽karoti, tato aparabhāge rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Evameva yogāvacaro āditova sīlaṃ visodhetvā
analyzed: raṅga jātam upaneti yathā vā pana chekaḥ cittakāraḥ rūpam likhitu kāmaḥ āditas va bhitti parikammam  karoti tatas apara bhāge rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti evam eva yogāvacaraḥ āditas va sīlam visodhetvā
translated: or just as a skilled painter, when he wants to paint pictures, first prepares the ground and then later on paints the pictures,🔽so too the meditator first purifies his virtue and then later realizes the states beginning with concentration. That is why virtue is called the “beginning.”🔽And this is called “the beginning” because it is the footing for the other two kinds of beginning. For just as a man with sound feet walks without stumbling, and just as a man with sound hands handles things without difficulty,

original: aparabhāge samathavipassanādayo dhamme sacchikaroti. Tasmā sīlaṃ “ādī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apara bhāge samatha vipassanā ādayaḥ dhamme sacchikaroti tasmā sīlam ādi iti vuttam
translated: so too the meditator who has purified his virtue enters into and abides in the jhānas without difficulty, and he investigates and explores the states of the dependent origination without difficulty. That is why virtue is called the “footing.”

original: Tadetaṃ caraṇasarikkhatāya caraṇaṃ. Caraṇāti hi pādā vuccanti. Yathā hi chinnacaraṇassa🔽purisassa disaṃ gamanābhisaṅkhāro na jāyati, paripuṇṇapādasseva jāyati, evameva yassa
analyzed: tat etam caraṇa sarikkhatāya caraṇam caraṇa ati hi pādāḥ vuccanti yathā hi chinna caraṇassa  purisassa disam gamana abhisaṅkhāraḥ na jāyati paripuṇṇa pādassa iva jāyati evam eva yassa
translated: And this is called “the beginning” because it is the footing for the other two kinds of beginning. For just as a man with sound feet walks without stumbling, and just as a man with sound hands handles things without difficulty,

original: sīlaṃ bhinnaṃ hoti khaṇḍaṃ aparipuṇṇaṃ, tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ na sampajjati.🔽Yassa pana taṃ abhinnaṃ hoti akhaṇḍaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ, tassa nibbānagamanāya ñāṇagamanaṃ
analyzed: sīlam bhinnam hoti khaṇḍam a paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam na sampajjati 🔽yassa pana tat abhinnam hoti akhaṇḍam paripuṇṇam tassa nibbāna gamanāya ñāṇa gamanam
translated: so too the meditator who has purified his virtue enters into and abides in the jhānas without difficulty, and he investigates and explores the states of the dependent origination without difficulty. That is why virtue is called the “footing.”

original: sampajjati. Tasmā sīlaṃ “caraṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sampajjati tasmā sīlam caraṇan ti vuttam
translated: So virtue is called “conduct.”

original: Tadetaṃ saṃyamanavasena saṃyamo. Saṃvaraṇavasena saṃvaroti ubhayenāpi sīlasaṃyamo🔽ceva sīlasaṃvaro ca kathito. Vacanattho panettha saṃyameti vītikkamavipphandanaṃ,
analyzed: tat etam saṃyamana vasena saṃyamaḥ saṃvaraṇa vasena saṃvaroti ubhayena api sīla saṃyamaḥ  ca iva sīla saṃvaro ca kathitaḥ vacana atthaḥ pana ittha saṃyama iti vītikkama vipphandanam
translated: It is restraint in the sense of restraining , and it is a restraint in the sense of restraining . So it is called both “restraint of virtue” and “restraint by virtue.”

original: puggalaṃ vā saṃyameti vītikkamavasena tassa vipphandituṃ na detīti saṃyamo. Vītikkamassa
analyzed: puggalam vā saṃyameti vītikkama vasena tassa vipphanditum na deti iti saṃyamaḥ vītikkamassa
translated: The meaning of the words in the first case is this: it restrains , i.e. it prevents the occurrence of transgression by restraining the occurrence of transgression in a person, or it restrains , i.e. it prevents the occurrence of the perturbation of transgression.

original: pavesanadvāraṃ saṃvarati pidahatīti saṃvaro.🔽Mokkhanti uttamaṃ mukhabhūtaṃ vā. Yathā hi sattānaṃ catubbidho āhāro mukhena pavisitvā
analyzed: pavesana dvāram saṃvarati pidahati iti  uttamam mukha bhūtam vā yathā hi sattānam catubbidhaḥ āhāraḥ mukhena pavisitvā
translated: The meaning of the words in the second case is this: it restrains , i.e. it prevents, it closes, the door of entry for transgression.

original: aṅgamaṅgāni pharati, evaṃ yoginopi catubhūmakakusalaṃ sīlamukhena pavisitvā atthasiddhiṃ
analyzed: aṅgam aṅgāni pharati evam yoginaḥ api catu bhūmaka kusalam sīla mukhena pavisitvā attha siddhim
translated: It is the foremost , or it is the face , of deliverance. Just as the four kinds of nutriment enter in by the mouth and spread through the various limbs, so too this virtue of the four kinds classed according to the four paths enters in by the mouth, i.e. by the door of the face, and it brings success in the aim.🔽So it is called “deliverance.”

original: sampādeti. Tena “mokkha”nti. Pamukhe sādhūti pāmokkhaṃ, pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ padhānanti
analyzed: sampādeti tena mokkhanti pamukhe sādhu uti pāmokkham pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham padhānanti
translated: It is the foremost , the first, the best, the chief, is the meaning.

original: attho. Kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyāti catubhūmakakusalānaṃ paṭilābhatthāya pāmokkhaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ kusalānam dhammānam samāpattiyā ati catu bhūmaka kusalānam paṭilābha atthāya pāmokkham
translated: It is the foremost for the obtaining of profitable states, for the obtaining of the four kinds of profitable states classed according to the four paths.

original: pubbaṅgamaṃ seṭṭhaṃ padhānanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pubbaṅgamam seṭṭham padhānan ti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood as the best, the chief, the foremost.

original: Vivicceva kāmehīti kāmehi vivicca vinā hutvā apakkamitvā. Yo panāyamettha evakāro,🔽so niyamatthoti veditabbo. Yasmā ca niyamattho, tasmā tasmiṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi iti kāmehi vivicca vinā hutvā a pakkamitvā yaḥ pana ayam ettha eva kāraḥ  saḥ niyama atthaḥ ti veditabbaḥ yasmā ca niyama atthaḥ tasmā tasmim paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja
translated: Quite secluded from sense desires: secluded means separated, detached, from sense desires. But the word eva in the text

original: viharaṇasamaye avijjamānānampi kāmānaṃ tassa paṭhamajjhānassa paṭipakkhabhāvaṃ kāmapariccāgeneva
analyzed: viharaṇa samaye a vijjamānānam pi kāmānam tassa paṭhamajjhānassa paṭipakkha bhāvam kāma pariccāgena iva
translated: should be understood to have the meaning of “only.” And because it has the meaning of “only,” it shows that at the time of entering upon and dwelling in the first jhāna, sense desires are abandoned only,

original: cassa adhigamaṃ dīpeti. Kathaṃ? “Vivicceva kāmehī”ti evañhi niyame kariyamāne idaṃ🔽paññāyati, nūnimassa jhānassa kāmā paṭipakkhabhūtā, yesu sati idaṃ na pavattati andhakāre
analyzed: cassa adhigamam dīpeti katham vivicca iva kāmehi iti evam hi niyame kariyamāne idam  paññāyati nūna imassa jhānassa kāmā paṭipakkha bhūtā yesu sati idam na pavattati andhakāre
translated: and that the first jhāna is reached only with the abandoning of sense desires. How? For when the seclusion is stated thus “Quite secluded from sense desires,”

original: sati padīpobhāso viya, tesaṃ pariccāgeneva cassa adhigamo hoti orimatīrapariccāgena
analyzed: sati padīpa ubhāsaḥ viya tesam pariccāgena iva ca ssa adhigamaḥ hoti orima tīra pariccāgena
translated: it is evident that sense desires are an obstruction to the jhāna, in the way opposed to it, and that the jhāna is reached only with the abandoning of the sense desires, like the light of a lamp, which is opposed to darkness and is reached only with the abandoning of the darkness.

original: pārimatīrasseva. Tasmā niyamaṃ karotīti.
analyzed: tasmai niyamam karoti iti
translated: Therefore it is said that the word eva is used to show the abandoning of the sense desires.

original: Tattha siyā “kasmā panesa pubbapadeyeva vutto na uttarapade, kiṃ akusalehi dhammehi
analyzed: tattha siyā kasmā pana esa pubba padeya iva vuttaḥ na uttara pade kim akusalehi dhammehi
translated: Here it may be asked: But why is this word eva used only in the first jhāna and not in the others? What is wrong with that?

original: aviviccāpi jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyā”ti? Na kho panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Taṃnissaraṇato🔽hi pubbapade eva esa vutto. Kāmadhātusamatikkamanato hi kāmarāgapaṭipakkhato ca idaṃ
analyzed: a vivicca api jhānam upasampajja vihareyya iti na kho pana etam evam daṭṭhabbam tad nissaraṇato  hi pubba pade eva esa vutto kāmadhātu samatikkamanataḥ hi kāma rāga paṭipakkhato ca idam
translated: “And how could one enter upon and abide in jhāna without having abandoned sensual desire, etc., by surmounting them?” It should not be regarded in that way.🔽For this is said in the Vibhaṅga in order to show the surmounting of the defilements belonging to the lower plane.

original: jhānaṃ kāmānameva nissaraṇaṃ. Yathāha – “kāmānametaṃ nissaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ nekkhamma”nti.
analyzed: jhānam kāmānam eva nissaraṇam yathā āha kāmānam etam nissaraṇam yat idam nekkhammanti
translated: For this jhāna is the escape from the defilements of the lower plane, both because it surmounts the sense-sphere element and because it is the counterstate for greed for sense desires. As it is said: “The escape from sense desires is renunciation” .

original: Uttarapadepi pana yathā “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo”ti ettha evakāro🔽ānetvā vuccati, evaṃ vattabbo. Na hi sakkā ito aññehipi nīvaraṇasaṅkhātehi akusalehi
analyzed: uttara pade pi pana yathā idha iva bhikkhave samaṇaḥ idha dutiyaḥ samaṇaḥ ti ettha evakāraḥ  ānetvā vuccati evam vattabbaḥ na hi sakkā itas aññehi pi nīvaraṇa saṅkhātehi akusalehi
translated: And just as the word “here” in the passage, “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu … abides” is to be taken as having a place value,

original: dhammehi avivicca jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ. Tasmā vivicceva kāmehi vivicceva
analyzed: dhammehi a vivicca jhānam upasampajja viharitum tasmai vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca iva
translated: so too this word “here” should be taken as having a time value. For it is not possible to enter upon and abide in jhāna without having abandoned the unprofitable things called hindrances that occur in one’s own continuity at the time.

original: akusalehi dhammehīti evaṃ padadvayepi esa daṭṭhabbo. Padadvayepi ca kiñcāpi viviccāti
analyzed: akusalehi dhammehi iti evam pada dvaye pi esa daṭṭhabbo pada dvaye pi ca kiñcā api vivicca ati
translated: So the phrase “quite secluded from sensual desires, secluded from unprofitable things” should be regarded as stated with reference to both phrases.

original: iminā sādhāraṇavacanena tadaṅgavivekādayo kāyavivekādayo ca sabbepi vivekā saṅgahaṃ
analyzed: iminā sādhāraṇa vacanena tad aṅga viveka ādayo kāya viveka ādayo ca sabbe api vivekā saṅgaham
translated: And although the word “secluded” is a general term for all kinds of seclusion, still the meaning intended here should be understood as stated in the Vibhaṅga, where the following is said: “‘Secluded from sensual desires, secluded from unprofitable things’: the seclusion consisting in the removal of desire is seclusion from sensual desires; the seclusion consisting in the removal of ill will … the seclusion consisting in the removal of confusion is seclusion from unprofitable things” .

original: gacchanti, tathāpi pubbabhāge kāyavivekacittavivekavikkhambhanavivekā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: gacchanti tathā api pubba bhāge kāya viveka citta viveka vikkhambhana vivekāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: and so on, still the three kinds of seclusion of the body, of consciousness, and by suppression should be understood in the earlier stage.

original: Lokuttaramaggakkhaṇe kāyavivekacittavivekasamucchedavivekanissaraṇavivekā.
analyzed: lokuttara magga kkhaṇe kāya viveka citta viveka samuccheda viveka nissaraṇa vivekā
translated: At the moment of the supramundane path the three kinds of seclusion of the body, of consciousness, and by cutting off, and the three kinds of seclusion of the body, of consciousness, and by surmounting should be understood.🔽But by the words “having abandoned sensual pleasures” all sensual pleasures are included, namely,

original: Kāmehīti iminā pana padena ye ca idha “katame vatthukāmā manāpikā rūpā”tiādinā nayena🔽vatthukāmā vuttā, ye ca idheva vibhaṅge “chando kāmo rāgo kāmo chandarāgo kāmo saṅkappo🔽kāmo rāgo kāmo saṅkapparāgo kāmo”ti evaṃ kilesakāmā vuttā, te sabbepi saṅgahitā icceva
analyzed: kāmehi iti iminā pana padena ye ca idha katame vatthu kāmāḥ manāpikāḥ rūpāti ādinā nayena  vatthu kāmāḥ vuttāḥ ye ca idha iva vibhaṅge chandaḥ kāmaḥ rāgaḥ kāmaḥ chanda rāgaḥ kāmaḥ saṅkappo  kāmaḥ rāgaḥ kāmaḥ saṅkappa rāgaḥ kāmo ti evam kilesa kāmā vuttā te sabbe pi saṅgahitāḥ icca eva
translated: those called “sensual desires as objects” stated in the way beginning, “What are sensual desires as objects? They are: pleasing forms” ,🔽and those called “sensual desires as defilements” stated in the Vibhaṅga thus: “Longing is sensual desire as longing, lust is sensual desire as lust, love is sensual desire as love, affection is sensual desire as affection, attachment is sensual desire as attachment, holding is sensual desire as holding, obsession is sensual desire as obsession” .

original: daṭṭhabbā. Evañhi sati vivicceva kāmehīti vatthukāmehipi viviccevāti attho yujjati.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā evam hi sati vivicca iva kāmehi iti vatthu kāmehi pi vivicca iva ati atthaḥ yujjati
translated: They should be regarded as included in this way, for only then does the meaning of the words “quite secluded from sensual pleasures” fit in with the words “sensual desires as objects.”

original: Tena kāyaviveko vutto hoti.
analyzed: tena kāya viveko vutto hoti
translated: So the seclusion of the body is stated.

original: Vivicca akusalehi dhammehīti kilesakāmehi sabbākusalehi vā viviccāti attho yujjati.
analyzed: vivicca akusalehi dhammehi iti kilesa kāmehi sabba akusalehi vā vivicca ati atthaḥ yujjati
translated: And the meaning of the words “quite secluded from unprofitable things” fits in with the words “sensual desires as defilements” if it is interpreted as seclusion from sensual desires as defilements or from all unprofitable things.

original: Tena cittaviveko vutto hoti. Purimena cettha vatthukāmehi vivekavacanato eva kāmasukhapariccāgo,
analyzed: tena citta vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti purimena ca ittha vatthu kāmehi viveka vacanataḥ eva kāma sukha pariccāgo
translated: And here the first is distinguished by the expression of the relinquishing of sensual pleasure since it is the expression of seclusion from sensual desires as objects,

original: dutiyena kilesakāmehi vivekavacanato nekkhammasukhapariggaho vibhāvito hoti. Evaṃ
analyzed: dutiyena kilesa kāmehi viveka vacanataḥ nekkhamma sukha pariggahaḥ vibhāvitaḥ hoti evam
translated: and the second is distinguished by the expression of the adoption of the pleasure of renunciation since it is the expression of seclusion from sensual desires as defilements.

original: vatthukāmakilesakāmavivekavacanatoyeva ca etesaṃ paṭhamena saṃkilesavatthuppahānaṃ,
analyzed: vatthu kāma kilesa kāma viveka vacanato yā iva ca etesam paṭhamena saṃkilesa vatthu pahānam
translated: And so too, by the expression of seclusion from sensual desires as objects and as defilements,🔽the first is distinguished by the abandoning of the basis for defilement, and the second by the abandoning of defilement.

original: dutiyena saṃkilesappahānaṃ. Paṭhamena lolabhāvassa hetupariccāgo, dutiyena bālabhāvassa.
analyzed: dutiyena saṃkilesa ppahānam paṭhamena lola bhāvassa hetu pariccāgaḥ dutiyena bāla bhāvassa
translated: And by the first the relinquishing of the cause of greed is shown, and by the second the relinquishing of the cause of folly.

original: Paṭhamena ca payogasuddhi, dutiyena āsayaposanaṃ vibhāvitaṃ hotīti ñātabbaṃ. Esa
analyzed: paṭhamena ca payoga suddhi dutiyena āsaya posanam vibhāvitam hoti iti ñātabbam esa
translated: And by the first the purification of the undertaking is shown, and by the second the nourishing of the inclination. This should be understood.

original: tāva nayo “kāmehī”ti ettha vuttakāmesu vatthukāmapakkhe.
analyzed: tāva nayo kāmehi iti ettha vutta kāmesu vatthu kāma pakkhe
translated: This is the method in the case of the sensual desires stated in the words “sensual desires” .

original: Kilesakāmapakkhe pana chandoti ca rāgoti ca evamādīhi anekabhedo kāmacchandova “kāmo”ti
analyzed: kilesa kāma pakkhe pana chando ti ca rāgo ti ca evamādīhi aneka bhedo kāma chando va kāmo ti
translated: But in the case of the defilements, sensual desire itself, which is of many kinds as “will” , “lust” , etc., is intended by “sensual desires” .

original: adhippeto. So ca akusalapariyāpannopi samāno “tattha katamo kāmacchando, kāmo”tiādinā
analyzed: adhippeto so ca akusala pariyāpannaḥ api samāno tattha katamaḥ kāmacchandaḥ kāmaḥ iti ādinā
translated: And although that is included in the unprofitable, still it is shown by the words “Herein, what is sensual desire? Sensual desires are of two kinds, I say:

original: nayena vibhaṅge jhānapaṭipakkhato visuṃ vutto. Kilesakāmattā vā purimapade vutto,
analyzed: nayena vibhaṅge jhāna paṭipakkhataḥ visum vutto kilesa kāmattā vā purima pade vutto
translated: Or it is stated in the first place because of the grossness of the defilements,🔽and in the second place because of its inclusion in the unprofitable.

original: akusalapariyāpannattā dutiyapade. Anekabhedato cassa kāmatoti avatvā kāmehīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: akusala pariyāpanna ttā dutiya pade aneka bhedato ca ssa kāmato ti avatvā kāmehi iti vuttam
translated: And instead of saying “because of its having many divisions” it is said “because of its being various” .

original: Aññesampi ca dhammānaṃ akusalabhāve vijjamāne “tattha katame akusalā dhammā, kāmacchando”tiādinā
analyzed: aññesam pi ca dhammānam akusala bhāve vijjamāne tattha katame akusalāḥ dhammā kāmacchanda ti ādinā
translated: And although other states as well are unprofitable, still only the hindrances are mentioned in the Vibhaṅga in the way beginning, “What are unprofitable states? They are greed, ”

original: nayena vibhaṅge uparijhānaṅgānaṃ paccanīkapaṭipakkhabhāvadassanato nīvaraṇāneva vuttāni.
analyzed: nayena vibhaṅge upari jhā anaṅgānam paccanīka paṭipakkha bhāva dassanataḥ vuttāni
translated: showing them as the opposites and enemies of the factors of the higher jhāna.🔽For the hindrances are the opposites of the jhāna factors, they are their enemies,

original: Nīvaraṇāni hi jhānaṅgapaccanīkāni tesaṃ jhānaṅgāneva paṭipakkhāni, viddhaṃsakāni🔽vighātakānīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathā hi “samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkho, pīti byāpādassa,
analyzed: nīvaraṇāni hi jhāna aṅga paccanīkāni tesam jhāna aṅgāni eva paṭipakkhāni viddhaṃsakāni  vighātakāni iti vuttam hoti tathā hi samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkho pīti byāpādassa
translated: their destroyers, their despats.

original: vitakko thinamiddhassa, sukhaṃ uddhaccakukkuccassa, vicāro vicikicchāyā”ti peṭake vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vitakkaḥ thinam iddhassa sukham uddhacca kukkuccassa vicāraḥ vicikicchāya ati peṭake vuttam
translated: That is why it is said in the Peṭaka: “Concentration is the opposite of greed for sensual desires, happiness is the opposite of ill will, applied thought is the opposite of stiffness and torpor, bliss is the opposite of agitation and worry, sustained thought is the opposite of uncertainty” .

original: Evamettha vivicceva kāmehīti iminā kāmacchandassa vikkhambhanaviveko vutto hoti,
analyzed: evam ettha vivicca iva kāmehi iti iminā kāmacchandassa vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti
translated: So here, by the words “quite secluded from sensual desires” the seclusion from sensual desire by suppression is stated,

original: vivicca akusalehi dhammehīti iminā pañcannampi nīvaraṇānaṃ. Aggahitaggahaṇena pana🔽paṭhamena kāmacchandassa, dutiyena sesanīvaraṇānaṃ. Tathā paṭhamena tīsu akusalamūlesu
analyzed: vivicca akusalehi dhammehi iti iminā pañcannam pi nīvaraṇānam aggahita ggahaṇena pana  paṭhamena kāmacchandassa dutiyena sesa nīvaraṇānam tathā paṭhamena tīsu akusala mūlesu
translated: By ‘apart from unprofitable ideas’ he shows the abandoning of the five hindrances.🔽But by the first he shows the abandoning of lust, and by the second that of the remaining hindrances.

original: pañcakāmaguṇabhedavisayassa lobhassa, dutiyena āghātavatthubhedādivisayānaṃ dosamohānaṃ.
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa bheda visayassa lobhassa dutiyena āghāta vatthu bheda ādi visayānam dosa mohānam
translated: And likewise by the first he shows the abandoning of greed for the five strands of sensual desire among the three unprofitable roots, and by the second that of hate and delusion with the object of the grounds for annoyance, etc.,

original: Oghādīsu vā dhammesu paṭhamena kāmoghakāmayogakāmāsavakāmupādānaabhijjhākāyaganthakāmarāgasaṃyojanānaṃ,
analyzed: ogha ādīsu vā dhammesu paṭhamena kāma ogha kāma yoga kāma āsava kāma upādāna abhijjhā kāya gantha kāma rāga saṃyojanānam
translated: or else by the first he shows the abandoning of the sensual-desire flood, the sensual-desire yoke, the sensual-desire inherent tendency, the sensual-desire clinging, the greed as bodily tie, and the sensual-desire as bondage,🔽and by the second that of the remaining floods, yokes, inherent tendencies, clingings, ties, and bondages.

original: dutiyena avasesaoghayogāsavaupādānaganthasaṃyojanānaṃ. Paṭhamena ca taṇhāya taṃsampayuttakānañca,
analyzed: dutiyena avasesa ogha yoga āsava aupādāna gantha saṃyojanānam paṭhamena ca taṇhāya tad sampayuttakānam ca
translated: And by the first he shows the abandoning of craving and what is associated with it,🔽and by the second that of ignorance and what is associated with it.

original: dutiyena avijjāya taṃsampayuttakānañca. Api ca paṭhamena lobhasampayuttaaṭṭhacittuppādānaṃ,
analyzed: dutiyena avijjāya tad sampayuttakānam ca api ca paṭhamena lobha sampayutta aṭṭha cittuppādānam
translated: And again, by the first he shows the abandoning of the eight kinds of consciousness accompanied by greed,

original: dutiyena sesānaṃ catunnaṃ akusalacittuppādānaṃ vikkhambhanaviveko vutto hotīti veditabbo.
analyzed: dutiyena sesānam catunnam akusala cittuppādānam vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ
translated: and by the second that of the remaining four kinds of unprofitable consciousness. This is how the abandoning of the hindrances should be understood.

original: Ettāvatā ca paṭhamassa jhānassa pahānaṅgaṃ dassetvā idāni sampayogaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca paṭhamassa jhānassa pahāna aṅgam dassetvā idāni sampayoga aṅgam dassetuṃ
translated: So far the abandoning factors of the first jhāna have been shown. Now, in order to show its associated factors,

original: “savitakkaṃ savicāra”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ārammaṇe cittassa abhiniropanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: sa vitakkam sa vicāra ntiādi vuttam tattha ārammaṇe cittassa abhiniropana lakkhaṇo
translated: “With applied thought and sustained thought” is said. Herein, applied thought has the characteristic of directing the mind onto the object.🔽Sustained thought has the characteristic of keeping the mind anchored on the object.

original: vitakko, ārammaṇānumajjanalakkhaṇo vicāro. Santepi ca nesaṃ katthaci aviyoge oḷārikaṭṭhena
analyzed: vitakko ārammaṇa anumajjana lakkhaṇaḥ vicāro sante pi ca nesam katthaci aviyoge oḷārika ṭṭhena
translated: Although they are inseparable in their actual being, still applied thought is gross compared with sustained thought,

original: pubbaṅgamaṭṭhena ca ghaṇḍābhighāto viya cetaso paṭhamābhinipāto vitakko, sukhumaṭṭhena
analyzed: pubbaṅgama ṭṭhena ca ghaṇḍa abhighātaḥ viya cetasaḥ paṭhama abhinipātaḥ vitakkaḥ sukhuma ṭṭhena
translated: which is why it is called preliminary work, like the striking of the bell; sustained thought is subtle,

original: anumajjanasabhāvena ca ghaṇḍānuravo viya anupabandho vicāro. Vipphāravā cettha vitakko
analyzed: anumajjana sabhāvena ca an upabandhaḥ vicāraḥ ca ittha vitakko
translated: like the ringing of its sound, which is why it is called continuity.

original: paṭhamuppattikāle paripphandanabhūto cittassa, ākāse uppatitukāmassa pakkhino pakkhavikkhepo
analyzed: paṭhama uppatti kāle paripphandana bhūtaḥ cittassa ākāse uppatitu kāmassa pakkhino pakkha vikkhepaḥ
translated: Applied thought is expansive,

original: viya, padumābhimukhapāto viya ca gandhānubandhacetaso bhamarassa. Santavutti vicāro
analyzed: viya paduma abhimukha pātaḥ viya ca gandha anubandha cetasaḥ bhamarassa vicāro
translated: like the bird’s spreading out its wings when it is about to fly into the air; and like the bee’s diving when it is about to alight on a flower.🔽Sustained thought is less expansive,

original: nātiparipphandanabhāvo cittassa, ākāse uppatitassa pakkhino pakkhappasāraṇaṃ viya,
analyzed: na ati paripphandana bhāvaḥ cittassa ākāse uppatitassa pakkhino pakkha ppasāraṇam viya
translated: like the bird’s wings when it is in the air;

original: paribbhamanaṃ viya ca padumābhimukhapatitassa bhamarassa padumassa uparibhāge.
analyzed: paribbhamanam viya ca paduma abhimukha patitassa bhamarassa padumassa upari bhāge
translated: and like a bee’s alighting on a lotus with its face turned towards the lotus.

original: Dukanipātaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “ākāse gacchato mahāsakuṇassa ubhohi pakkhehi vātaṃ gahetvā🔽pakkhe sannisīdāpetvā gamanaṃ viya ārammaṇe cetaso abhiniropanabhāvena pavatto vitakko,
analyzed: duka nipāta ṭṭhakathā ayam pana ākāse gacchataḥ mahā sakuṇassa ubhohi pakkhehi vātam gahetvā  pakkhe sannisīdāpetvā gamanam viya ārammaṇe cetasaḥ abhiniropana bhāvena pavattaḥ vitakko
translated: But in the Commentary to the Dukanipāta it is said, “It is like a great bird flying in the air that, after catching the wind with both wings,🔽goes on its way with its wings stiffened. So too, applied thought occurs with the stiffening of the mind on to the object.

original: vātaggahaṇatthaṃ pakkhe phandāpayamānassa gamanaṃ viya anumajjanabhāvena pavatto
analyzed: vāta ggahaṇa attham pakkhe phandāpayamānassa gamanam viya anumajjana bhāvena pavattaḥ
translated: Sustained thought occurs with the mind’s keeping to that object.

original: vicāro”ti vuttaṃ. Taṃ anuppabandhena pavattiyaṃ yujjati. So pana nesaṃ viseso paṭhamadutiyajjhānesu🔽pākaṭo hoti. Api ca malaggahitaṃ kaṃsabhājanaṃ ekena hatthena daḷhaṃ gahetvā itarena
analyzed: vicāraḥ ti vuttam tam anuppabandhena pavattiyam yujjati saḥ pana nesam visesaḥ paṭhama dutiya jhānesu  pākaṭaḥ hoti api ca malagga hitam kaṃsa bhājanam ekena hatthena daḷham gahetvā itarena
translated: This is the difference between them. But that difference is evident only in the first and second jhānas.🔽Moreover, applied thought is like the hand that firmly grasps a brass dish smeared with treacle, while sustained thought is like the hand that wipes it.

original: hatthena cuṇṇatelavālaṇḍupakena parimajjantassa daḷhaggahaṇahattho viya vitakko.
analyzed: hatthena cuṇṇa tela vāla ṇḍupakena parimajjantassa daḷha ggahaṇa hatthaḥ viya vitakkaḥ
translated: And applied thought is like the hand that firmly grasps a brass dish smeared with treacle, while sustained thought is like the hand that wipes it.

original: Parimajjanahattho viya vicāro. Tathā kumbhakārassa daṇḍappahārena cakkaṃ bhamayitvā
analyzed: parimajjana hatthaḥ viya vicāraḥ tathā kumbhakārassa daṇḍa pahārena cakkam bhamayitvā
translated: And just as a potter’s wheel, though started by a little impetus with the hand, yet goes on being turned by the force of the momentum, so too, when the mind has been made to go on to the object by the impetus given to it by the two jhānas, it goes on being turned by the force of the momentum of the jhāna factors, and it is called “unprompted” because it does not need prompting by applied thought again.

original: bhājanaṃ karontassa uppīḷanahattho viya vitakko. Ito cito ca sañcaraṇahattho viya🔽vicāro. Tathā maṇḍalaṃ karontassa majjhe sannirumbhitvā ṭhitakaṇṭako viya abhiniropano
analyzed: bhājanam karontassa uppīḷana hatthaḥ viya vitakkaḥ itas citas ca sañcaraṇa hatthaḥ viya  vicāraḥ tathā maṇḍalam karontassa majjhe sannirumbhitvā ṭhita kaṇṭakaḥ viya abhiniropanaḥ
translated: Applied thought is like the hand that turns the wheel, and sustained thought is like the hand that guides it.

original: vitakko. Bahi paribbhamanakaṇṭako viya anumajjamāno vicāro. Iti iminā ca vitakkena
analyzed: vitakkaḥ bahi paribbhamana kaṇṭakaḥ viya anumajjamānaḥ vicāraḥ iti iminā ca vitakkena
translated: Applied thought is like the central pin that holds the wheel together, and sustained thought is like the spokes that reach out from it.

original: iminā ca vicārena saha vattati rukkho viya pupphena ca phalena cāti idaṃ jhānaṃ “savitakkaṃ
analyzed: iminā ca vicārena saha vattati rukkhaḥ viya pupphena ca phalena ca ati idam jhānam sa vitakkam
translated: So this jhāna occurs together with this applied thought and this sustained thought, as the tree occurs together with the flowers and fruits;

original: savicāra”nti vuccati.
analyzed: sa vicāran ti vuccati
translated: hence it is said to be with applied thought and sustained thought.🔽“Born of seclusion”: here seclusion is absence of hindrances; the meaning is, disappearance of hindrances.

original: Vivekajanti ettha vivitti viveko, nīvaraṇavigamoti attho. Vivittoti vā viveko, nīvaraṇavivitto
analyzed: viveka janti ettha vivitti vivekaḥ nīvaraṇa vigamo ti attho vivitto ti vā vivekaḥ nīvaraṇa vivitto
translated: Or alternatively, seclusion is the jhāna itself, which is secluded from hindrances;🔽the meaning is, the collection of associated states is secluded from hindrances.

original: jhānasampayuttadhammarāsīti attho. Tasmā vivekā, tasmiṃ vā viveke jātanti vivekajaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna sampayutta dhamma rāsi iti tasmai tasmin vā viveke viveka jam
translated: So it is born of seclusion, either as seclusion itself or in a place of seclusion.

original: Pītisukhanti ettha piṇayatīti pīti, sā sampiyāyanalakkhaṇā. Sā panesā khuddikāpīti,
analyzed: pīti sukhanti ettha piṇayati iti pīti sā sampiyāyana lakkhaṇā sā pana isā khuddikā api iti
translated: “Rapture and pleasure”: it refreshes and exhilarates , thus it is rapture . Its characteristic is elation. It is classified as minor, etc.,

original: khaṇikāpīti, okkantikāpīti, ubbegāpīti, pharaṇāpītīti pañcavidhā hoti.🔽Tattha khuddikāpīti sarīre lomahaṃsamattameva kātuṃ sakkoti. Khaṇikāpīti khaṇe khaṇe🔽vijjuppādasadisā hoti. Okkantikāpīti samuddatīraṃ vīci viya, kāyaṃ okkamitvā okkamitvā🔽bhijjati. Ubbegāpīti balavatī hoti, kāyaṃ uddhaggaṃ katvā ākāse laṅghāpanappamāṇapattā.🔽Pharaṇāpīti atibalavatī hoti. Tāya hi uppannāya sakalasarīraṃ dhamitvā pūritavatthi
analyzed: khaṇikā api iti okkantikā api iti ubbegā api iti pharaṇā api iti iti pañcavidhā  tattha khuddikā api iti sarīre loma haṃsa mattam eva kātum sakkoti khaṇikā api iti khaṇe khaṇe  vijjuppāda sadisā hoti okkantikā api iti samudda tīram kāyam okkamitvā okkamitvā  bhijjati ubbegā apīti balavatī hoti kāyam uddhaggam katvā ākāse laṅghāpana pamāṇa pattā  ati balavatī hoti tāya hi uppannāya sakala sarīram dhamitvā
translated: It is fivefold as thrilling, thrilling-happiness, ecstatic-happiness, uplifting-happiness, and suffusing-happiness.

original: viya mahatā udakoghena pakkhandapabbatakucchi viya ca anuparipphuṭaṃ hoti. Sā panesā🔽pañcavidhā pīti gabbhaṃ gaṇhantī paripākaṃ gacchantī duvidhaṃ passaddhiṃ paripūreti🔽kāyapassaddhiñca cittapassaddhiñca, passaddhi gabbhaṃ gaṇhantī paripākaṃ gacchantī
analyzed: viya mahatā udaka oghena pakkhanda pabbata kucchi viya ca anuparipphuṭam hoti sā pana isā 🔽pañcavidhā pīti gabbham gaṇhantī paripākam gacchantī duvidham passaddhim paripūreti 🔽kāya passaddhim ca citta passaddhim ca passaddhi gabbham gaṇhantī paripākam gacchantī
translated: Herein, thrilling-happiness can only make the hairs of the body bristle. Thrilling-happiness is like the flash of lightning. Ecstatic-happiness breaks out all over the body like waves on the sea shore. Uplifting-happiness is strong enough to make the body buoyant and able to leap into the air. Suffusing-happiness is very strong. For when it arises the whole body is as if suffused with a stream of oil, as if plastered with a medicated plaster, as if bathed in a stream of cool water, as if overlaid with a mantle of soft cloud.

original: duvidhampi sukhaṃ paripūreti kāyikaṃ cetasikañca, sukhaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhantaṃ paripākaṃ
analyzed: duvidham pi sukham paripūreti kāyikam cetasikam ca sukham gabbham gaṇhantam paripākam
translated: and it fulfills the twofold pleasure, bodily and mental, in the case of the pleasure that conceives and the pleasure that perfects.

original: gacchantaṃ tividhaṃ samādhiṃ paripūreti khaṇikasamādhiṃ upacārasamādhiṃ appanāsamādhiñcāti.
analyzed: gacchantam tividham samādhim paripūreti khaṇika samādhim upacāra samādhim appanā samādhim ca ati
translated: And it fulfills the three kinds of concentration, namely, momentary concentration, access concentration, and absorption concentration.

original: Tāsu yā appanāsamādhissa mūlaṃ hutvā vaḍḍhamānā samādhisampayogaṅgatā pharaṇāpīti,
analyzed: tāsu yā appanā samādhissa mūlam hutvā vaḍḍhamānā samādhi sampayoga aṅga tā pharaṇā api iti
translated: Of these, the happiness that is intended here is that which, becoming the root of absorption concentration, increases and is associated with concentration.

original: ayaṃ imasmiṃ atthe adhippetā pītīti.
analyzed: ayam imasmin atthe adhippetā pīti iti
translated: The other kind is called pleasure.

original: Itaraṃ pana sukhayatīti sukhaṃ, yassa uppajjati, taṃ sukhitaṃ karotīti attho. Sukhanaṃ
analyzed: itaram pana sukhayati iti sukham yassa uppajjati tam sukhitam karoti iti attho sukhanam
translated: But pleasure is what pleases, the meaning is that it makes the person in whom it arises pleased.

original: vā sukhaṃ, suṭṭhu vā khādati khaṇati ca kāyacittābādhanti sukhaṃ, somanassavedanāyetaṃ
analyzed: vā sukham suṭṭhu vā khādati khaṇati ca kāya citta ābādhanti sukham somanassa vedanāya itaṃ
translated: Or alternatively, pleasure is what is pleasant; it is what eats, consumes, the affliction of body and mind, well, thoroughly. This is a name for the feeling of joy.🔽Its characteristic is coolness.

original: nāmaṃ. Taṃ sātalakkhaṇaṃ. Santepi ca nesaṃ katthaci avippayoge iṭṭhārammaṇapaṭilābhatuṭṭhi
analyzed: nāmam tam sāta lakkhaṇam sante pi ca nesam katthaci avippayoge iṭṭha ārammaṇa paṭilābha tuṭṭhi
translated: And although they are not dissociated in any way, the satisfaction in obtaining a desirable object is happiness,

original: pīti, paṭiladdharasānubhavanaṃ sukhaṃ. Yattha pīti, tattha sukhaṃ, yattha sukhaṃ,
analyzed: pīti paṭiladdha rasa anubhavanam sukham yattha pīti tattha sukham yattha sukham
translated: and the experiencing of what has been obtained is pleasure. Where there is happiness there is pleasure,

original: tattha na niyamato pīti. Saṅkhārakkhandhasaṅgahitā pīti, vedanākkhandhasaṅgahitaṃ🔽sukhaṃ. Kantārakhinnassa vanantodakadassanasavanesu viya pīti, vanacchāyappavesanaudakaparibhogesu
analyzed: tattha na niyamataḥ pi iti saṅkhāra kkhandha saṅgahitā pi iti vedanā kkhandha saṅgahitam  sukham kantāra khinnassa vananta udaka dassana savanesu viya pīti vana chāya ppavesana odaka paribhogesu
translated: Herein, happiness is not invariably present. Happiness is included in the formations aggregate,🔽and pleasure is included in the feeling aggregate. Happiness is like the seeing and hearing of a man exhausted by weariness in a desert when he sees and hears a pond in a wood,

original: viya sukhaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ samaye pākaṭabhāvato cetaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Iti ayañca🔽pīti idañca sukhaṃ assa jhānassa, asmiṃ vā jhāne atthīti idaṃ jhānaṃ “pītisukha”nti vuccati.
analyzed: viya sukham tasmin tasmin samaye pākaṭa bhāvato ca itam vuttan ti veditabbam iti ayam ca  pīti idam ca sukham assa jhānassa asmim vā jhāne atthi iti idam jhānam pīti sukhanti vuccati
translated: and pleasure is like his entering the wood’s shade and bathing in the water. But this is said according to what is outstanding in each case. So this happiness and this pleasure are of this jhāna, or in this jhāna, thus it is “happiness and pleasure born of seclusion.”

original: Atha vā pīti ca sukhañca pītisukhaṃ dhammavinayādayo viya. Vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ assa
analyzed: atha vā pīti ca sukham ca pīti sukham dhamma vinaya ādayaḥ viya viveka jam pīti sukham assa
translated: Or alternatively, happiness and pleasure are “happiness and pleasure” ; they are born of seclusion thus they are “born of seclusion” . This happiness and pleasure born of seclusion are of this jhāna, or in this jhāna, thus it is “born of seclusion, happiness and pleasure.”

original: jhānassa, asmiṃ vā jhāne atthīti evampi vivekajaṃpītisukhaṃ. Yatheva hi jhānaṃ, evaṃ🔽pītisukhampettha vivekajameva hoti, tañcassa atthi, tasmā alopasamāsaṃ katvā ekapadeneva
analyzed: jhānassa asmim vā jhāne atthi iti evam pi viveka jam pīti sukham yathā iva hi jhānam evam  pīti sukham pa ittha viveka jam eva hoti tat ca assa atthi tasmai a lopa samāsam katvā eka padena iva
translated: And just as the jhāna is born of seclusion, so too the happiness and pleasure are born of seclusion. And that is present in this jhāna, thus it is “born of seclusion, happiness and pleasure.”

original: “vivekajaṃpītisukha”ntipi vattuṃ yujjati.
analyzed: vattum yujjati
translated: And just as it is permissible to call the jhāna itself “born of seclusion” by ellipsis of the middle term, since it is “born of seclusion, happiness and pleasure,” so too it is permissible to call the happiness and pleasure “born of seclusion” by ellipsis of the middle term, since they are “happiness and pleasure born of seclusion.”

original: Paṭhamanti gaṇanānupubbatā paṭhamaṃ, idaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppannantipi paṭhamaṃ. Jhānanti🔽duvidhaṃ jhānaṃ ārammaṇūpanijjhānaṃ lakkhaṇūpanijjhānañcāti. Tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo
analyzed: paṭhamam ti gaṇanā anupubba tā paṭhamam idam paṭhamam uppannam ti pi paṭhamam jhānan ti  duvidham jhānam ārammaṇa upanijjhānam lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam ca ati tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ
translated: First: it is first in the numerical series; and it is first in that it arises first.🔽Jhāna: there are two kinds of jhāna, that is to say, absorption and insight.🔽Herein, the eight attainments are called absorption because they absorb the mind upon a single object ,

original: pathavīkasiṇādiārammaṇaṃ upanijjhāyantīti ārammaṇūpanijjhānanti saṅkhyaṃ gatā. Vipassanāmaggaphalāni
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇa ādi ārammaṇam upanijjhāyanti iti ārammaṇa upanijjhānanti saṅkhyam gatāḥ vipassanā magga phalāni
translated: and insight is called absorption because it absorbs the object’s characteristics.

original: pana lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ nāma. Tattha vipassanā aniccādilakkhaṇassa upanijjhānato
analyzed: pana lakkhaṇūpanijjhānam nāma tattha vipassanā anicca ādi lakkhaṇassa upanijjhānato
translated: Herein, insight is absorption because it absorbs the characteristics of impermanence, and so on.

original: lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ. Vipassanāya katakiccassa maggena ijjhanato maggo lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam vipassanāya kata kiccassa maggena ijjhanataḥ maggaḥ lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam
translated: The path is absorption because it is the means to the realization of the characteristics,

original: phalaṃ pana nirodhasaccaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ upanijjhāyatīti lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ. Tesu
analyzed: phalam pana nirodha saccam tathalakkhaṇam upanijjhāyati iti lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam tesu
translated: and fruition is absorption because it absorbs the object of the characteristics, which is the state of cessation.

original: idha pubbabhāge ārammaṇūpanijjhānaṃ, lokuttaramaggakkhaṇe lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: idha pubba bhāge ārammaṇa upanijjhānam lokuttara magga kkhaṇe lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam adhippetaṃ
translated: Herein, it is absorption as absorption of the object in the preliminary stage that is intended, and absorption as absorption of the characteristics in the path moment of the supramundane jhāna.

original: Tasmā ārammaṇūpanijjhānato ca lakkhaṇūpanijjhānato ca paccanīkajhāpanato ca jhānanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Upasampajjāti upagantvā, pāpuṇitvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Upasampādayitvā vā, nipphādetvāti
analyzed: tasmai ārammaṇa upanijjhānato ca lakkhaṇa upanijjhānato ca paccanīka jhāpanato ca jhānanti veditabbam  upasampajja āti upagantvā pāpuṇitvā iti vuttam hoti upasampādayitvā vā nipphādetvā ati
translated: So it should be understood that it is a “meditation” because of the investigating of the object, because of the investigating of the characteristics of the object, and because of the abandoning of opposition.🔽He enters upon and dwells in: he arrives at and he lives by the kind of life appropriate to it. Or alternatively, he produces and he lives by the kind of life appropriate to it.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Viharatīti tadanurūpena iriyāpathavihārena iriyati, vuttappakārajhānasamaṅgī🔽hutvā attabhāvassa iriyanaṃ vuttiṃ abhinipphādeti.
analyzed: vuttam hoti viharati iti tad anurūpena iriyāpatha vihārena iriyati vutta pakāra jhāna samaṅgī  hutvā atta bhāvassa iriyanam vuttim abhinipphādeti
translated: He lives: he makes his living by the kind of life appropriate to one possessing the jhāna of the kind stated.

original: Taṃ panetaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ tividhakalyāṇaṃ,
analyzed: tam pana itam paṭhama jhānam pañcaṅga vippahīnam pañcaṅga samannāgatam tividha kalyāṇam
translated: This first jhāna is five- factored, according to the method of analysis into factors, and it is good in three ways, according to the method of analysis into classes.

original: dasalakkhaṇasampannaṃ. Tattha kāmacchando byāpādo thinamiddhaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ
analyzed: dasa lakkhaṇa sampannam tattha kāmacchandaḥ byāpādaḥ thinam iddham uddhacca kukkuccam
translated: It possesses ten characteristics, according to the method of analysis into characteristics.

original: vicikicchāti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ pahānavasena pañcaṅgavippahīnatā veditabbā.
analyzed: vicikicchāti imesam pañcannam nīvaraṇānam pahāna vasena pañcaṅga vippahīna tā veditabbā
translated: Herein, the abandoning of the five hindrances should be understood as the five factors that have been abandoned.

original: Na hi etesu appahīnesu jhānaṃ uppajjati. Tenassetāni pahānaṅgānīti vuccanti. Kiñcāpi
analyzed: na hi etesu appahīnesu jhānam uppajjati tenassa etāni pahānaṅgāni iti vuccanti kiñca api
translated: For the jhāna does not arise if the hindrances are unabandoned. That is why they are called factors of abandoning.🔽And although applied thought, etc., are not hindrances, still they are impediments to the second jhāna in the way already stated, and so they too are abandoned there.

original: hi jhānakkhaṇe aññepi akusalā dhammā pahīyanti, tathāpi etāneva visesena jhānantarāyakarāni.
analyzed: hi jhāna kkhaṇe aññe pi akusalāḥ dhammāḥ pahīyanti tathā api etān eva visesena jhā anantarāya karāni
translated: Although other unprofitable states are also abandoned at the moment of absorption, still these are mentioned by way of their pre-eminence.

original: Kāmacchandena hi nānāvisayappalobhitaṃ cittaṃ na ekattārammaṇe samādhiyati, kāmacchandābhibhūtaṃ
analyzed: kāma chandena hi nānā visaya ppalobhitam cittam na ekatta ārammaṇe samādhiyati kāma chanda abhibhūtam
translated: For the mind is not concentrated on a single object when it is enticed by sensual desires in various objects,

original: vā, taṃ na kāmadhātuppahānāya paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjati. Byāpādena vā ārammaṇe paṭihaññamānaṃ🔽na nirantaraṃ pavattati. Thinamiddhābhibhūtaṃ akammaññaṃ hoti. Uddhaccakukkuccaparetaṃ
analyzed: vā tam na kāmadhātu pahānāya paṭipadam paṭipajjati byāpādena vā ārammaṇe paṭihaññamānam  na nirantaram pavattati thinam iddha abhibhūtam akammaññam hoti uddhacca kukkucca paretam
translated: or when it is overcome by ill will and does not enter upon the way to abandon the sensual desires of the sense sphere,🔽or when it is obstructed by stiffness and torpor and does not occur uninterruptedly,🔽or when it is overwhelmed by agitation and worry and goes straying about unquiet,

original: avūpasantameva hutvā paribbhamati. Vicikicchāya upahataṃ jhānādhigamasādhikaṃ paṭipadaṃ
analyzed: a vūpasantam eva hutvā paribbhamati vicikicchāyaḥ upahatam jhāna adhigama sādhikam paṭipadam
translated: or when it is afflicted by uncertainty and does not ascend to the way to attain the jhāna.

original: nārohati. Iti visesena jhānantarāyakarattā etāneva pahānaṅgānīti vuttāni.
analyzed: na ārohati iti visesena etān eva pahānaṅgāni iti vuttāni
translated: So they are called the factors of abandoning because they are the specific conditions for the jhāna.

original: Yasmā pana vitakko ārammaṇe cittaṃ abhiniropeti, vicāro anupabandhati, tehi avikkhepāya
analyzed: yasmā pana vitakkaḥ ārammaṇe cittam abhiniropeti vicāraḥ an upabandhati tehi avikkhepāya
translated: But applied thought directs the mind onto the object; sustained thought presses it on to the object;

original: sampāditapayogassa cetaso payogasampattisambhavā pīti pīṇanaṃ sukhañca upabrūhanaṃ
analyzed: sampādita payogassa cetasaḥ payoga sampatti sambhavā pīti pīṇanam sukham ca upabrūhanam
translated: and when the mind’s means of progress has been perfected by these two, happiness refreshes it and bliss uplifts it.

original: karoti. Athassa sesasampayuttadhammā etehi abhiniropanānubandhanapīṇanupabrūhanehi
analyzed: karoti athassa sesa sampayutta dhammāḥ etehi abhiniropana anubandhana pīṇana upabrūhanehi
translated: He does so. Then the remaining associated states are assisted by these, which are respectively the means whereby they are brought to, kept at, and lifted to the pitch of their occurrence.

original: anuggahitā ekaggatā ekattārammaṇe samaṃ sammā ca ādhiyati. Tasmā vitakko vicāro pīti🔽sukhaṃ cittekaggatāti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ uppattivasena pañcaṅgasamannāgatatā veditabbā.
analyzed: anuggahitā ekagga tā ekatta ārammaṇe samam sammā ca tasmā vitakkaḥ vicāraḥ pi iti  sukham citta ekagga tā ti imesam pañcannam uppatti vasena pañcaṅga samannāgata tā veditabbā
translated: They are unified, and so they are rightly and evenly placed on the single object. That is why it should be understood that the jhāna possesses the five factors with the arising of applied thought, etc.,

original: Uppannesu hi etesu pañcasu jhānaṃ uppannaṃ nāma hoti. Tenassa etāni pañcaṅgasamannāgatānīti
analyzed: uppannesu hi etesu pañcasu jhānam uppannam nāma hoti tenassa etāni pañcaṅga samannāgatāni iti
translated: for when these five are arisen, jhāna is said to be arisen. That is why it is said to possess these five factors.

original: vuccanti. Tasmā na etehi samannāgataṃ aññadeva jhānaṃ nāma atthīti gahetabbaṃ. Yathā🔽pana aṅgamattavaseneva caturaṅginī senā, pañcaṅgikaṃ tūriyaṃ, aṭṭhaṅgiko ca maggoti
analyzed: vuccanti tasmā na etehi samannāgatam aññat eva jhānam nāma atthi iti gahetabbam yathā  pana aṅga matta vasena iva caturaṅginī senā pañcaṅgikam tūriyam aṭṭhaṅgiko ca maggo ti
translated: So it should not be taken that there is a jhāna called “possessing the five factors” apart from the five factors beginning with applied thought.

original: vuccati, evamidampi aṅgamattavaseneva pañcaṅgikanti vā pañcaṅgasamannāgatanti vā🔽vuccatīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati evam idam pi aṅga matta vasena iva pañcaṅgikanti vā pañcaṅga samannāgatanti vā  vuccati iti veditabbam
translated: But just as a four-divisioned army is called “possessing five factors” and a five-part musical instrument is called “possessing eight factors” because of the presence of the factors, that is, the divisions and parts, so too this jhāna should be understood to be called “possessing the five factors” or “possessing the five jhāna factors” because of the presence of the factors, that is, the jhāna factors.

original: Etāni ca pañcaṅgāni kiñcāpi upacārakkhaṇepi atthi, atha kho upacāre pakaticittato
analyzed: etāni ca pañcaṅgāni kiñcā api upacāra kkhaṇe pi atthi atha kho upacāre pakati cittato
translated: And although these five factors are present too in access, still they are called “factors of jhāna” since they are similar to the factors of jhāna and are a condition for the jhāna factors.🔽But they are called “factors of access” in the Paṭisambhidā since they are only a condition for jhāna and are not similar to the factors of jhāna.🔽And in the Vibhaṅga they are called “factors of absorption” since they are a condition for jhāna and are similar to the factors of jhāna: “The jhāna factors are five. Translation: tato sesasampayuttadhammā etehi abhiniropanānubandhanapīṇanupabrūhanehi anuggahitā ekaggatā ekattārammaṇe samaṃ sammā ca ādhiyati, tasmā vitakko vicāro pīti sukhaṃ cittekaggatāti imesaṃ pañcannaṃ uppattivasena pañcaṅgasamannāgatatā veditabbā |🔽uppannesu hi etesu pañcasu jhānaṃ uppannaṃ nāma hoti, tasmā etāni pañcaṅgasamannāgatanti vuccanti |🔽tasmā na et

original: balavatarāni. Idha pana upacāratopi balavatarāni rūpāvacaralakkhaṇappattāni nipphannāni.
analyzed: balavatarāni idha pana upacārataḥ pi balavatarāni rūpāvacara lakkhaṇa ppattāni nipphannāni
translated: and they are stronger than those of the access. But here they have reached the characteristic of the fine-material sphere and are produced.

original: Ettha hi vitakko suvisadena ākārena ārammaṇe cittaṃ abhiniropayamāno uppajjati. Vicāro🔽ativiya ārammaṇaṃ anumajjamāno. Pītisukhaṃ sabbāvantampi kāyaṃ pharamānaṃ. Tenevāha
analyzed: ettha hi vitakkaḥ su visadena ākārena ārammaṇe cittam abhiniropayamāno uppajjati vicāraḥ  ativiya ārammaṇam anumajjamāno pīti sukham sabbāvantam pi kāyam pharamānam tena iva āha
translated: For here applied thought arises making the mind descend upon the object with very clear expression,

original: – “nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hotī”ti. Cittekaggatāpi
analyzed: na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa viveka jena pīti sukhena apphuṭam hoti iti citta ekagga tā api
translated: and sustained thought is the very insistent occurrence of that. Rapture and happiness pervade the whole body. Hence it is said: “There is nothing of his entire body that is not pervaded by the rapture and happiness born of seclusion” . And unification of mind

original: heṭṭhimamhi samuggapaṭale uparimaṃ samuggapaṭalaṃ viya ārammaṇesu phusitā hutvā uppajjati,🔽ayametesaṃ itarehi viseso. Tattha cittekaggatā kiñcāpi “savitakkaṃ savicāra”nti imasmiṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhimamhi samugga paṭale uparimam samugga paṭalam viya ārammaṇesu phusitā hutvā uppajjati  ayam etesam itarehi visesaḥ tattha citta ekagga tā kiñca api sa vitakkam sa vicāranti imasmin
translated: arises touching the object with the whole-body sense.

original: pāṭhe na niddiṭṭhā, tathāpi vibhaṅge “jhānanti vitakko vicāro pīti sukhaṃ cittekaggatā”ti
analyzed: pāṭhe na niddiṭṭhā tathā api vibhaṅge jhānanti vitakkaḥ vicāraḥ pi iti sukham citta ekagga tā ti
translated: This is the difference between these and the others. Herein, although unification of mind is not mentioned in the text of the jhāna in the way in which it is in the case of the first jhāna, nevertheless it exists there too, and so it should be mentioned in the definition of this jhāna too, as it is in the Vibhaṅga, where it is said: “‘Jhāna’ is applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and unification of mind” .

original: evaṃ vuttattā aṅgameva. Yena hi adhippāyena bhagavatā uddeso kato, soyeva tena vibhaṅge pakāsitoti.
analyzed: evam vutta ttā aṅgam eva yena hi adhippāyena bhagavatā uddeso kato saḥ yā iva tena vibhaṅge pakāsito ti
translated: and because it is stated thus, it is a factor. The exposition in the Vibhaṅga is given in terms of the purpose for which the recitation was made.

original: Tividhakalyāṇaṃ🔽Tividhakalyāṇaṃ dasalakkhaṇasampannanti ettha pana ādimajjhapariyosānavasenatividhakalyāṇatā.
analyzed: tividha kalyāṇam  tividha kalyāṇam dasa lakkhaṇa sampannanti ettha pana ādi majjha pariyosāna vasena tividha kalyāṇa tā
translated: Good in the beginning,🔽Good in the beginning, middle, and end: here the goodness in the beginning, middle, and end is in virtue of the beginning, middle, and end.

original: Tesaṃyeva ca ādimajjhapariyosānānaṃ lakkhaṇavasena dasalakkhaṇasampannatā veditabbā. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –
analyzed: tesam yeva ca ādi majjha pariyosānānam lakkhaṇa vasena dasa lakkhaṇa sampanna tā veditabbā tatra ayam
translated: And the possession of the ten characteristics should be understood in virtue of the characteristics of the beginning, middle, and end. Here is the text:

original: “Paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadāvisuddhi ādi, upekkhānubrūhanā majjhe, sampahaṃsanā
analyzed: paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadā visuddhi ādi upekkhā anubrūhanā majjhe sampahaṃsanā
translated: “The purification by overcoming doubt is the beginning of the first jhāna. The intensification of equanimity is in the middle. The gladdening is

original: pariyosānaṃ, paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadāvisuddhi ādi. Ādissa kati lakkhaṇāni? Ādissa
analyzed: pariyosānam paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadā visuddhi ādi ādissa kati lakkhaṇāni ādissa
translated: the end. The purification by overcoming doubt is the beginning of the first jhāna. How many characteristics has the beginning?

original: tīṇi lakkhaṇāni – yo tassa paripantho, tato cittaṃ visujjhati, visuddhattā cittaṃ
analyzed: tīṇi lakkhaṇāni yaḥ tassa paripantho tatas cittam visujjhati visuddha tā cittam
translated: The beginning has three characteristics: the mind becomes steadied, the mind becomes unified, and the mind goes to its goal.🔽The purification by overcoming doubt is the beginning of the first jhāna. How many characteristics has the middle?

original: majjhimaṃ samathanimittaṃ paṭipajjati, paṭipannattā tattha cittaṃ pakkhandati. Yañca
analyzed: majjhimam samatha nimittam paṭipajjati paṭipanna ttā tattha cittam pakkhandati yat ca
translated: The middle has three characteristics: the mind acquires confidence, the mind acquires serenity, and the mind acquires unification.🔽The purification by overcoming doubt is the beginning of the first jhāna. How many characteristics has the end?

original: paripanthato cittaṃ visujjhati, yañca visuddhattā cittaṃ majjhimaṃ samathanimittaṃ
analyzed: paripanthataḥ cittam visujjhati yat ca cittam majjhimam samatha nimittam
translated: the mind is purified of hindrances, and because of that purification the mind becomes unified and settles down in samādhi.🔽

original: paṭipajjati, yañca paṭipannattā tattha cittaṃ pakkhandati. Paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadāvisuddhi
analyzed: paṭipajjati yat ca paṭipanna ttā tattha cittam pakkhandati paṭhamassa jhānassa paṭipadā visuddhi
translated: and the mind becomes pure, clean, and bright, owing to which he enters upon and abides in the second jhāna … the third jhāna … the fourth jhāna, which has as its special factor the equanimity that is neither pleasant nor painful, then the purification of the way is the beginning of the fourth jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the equanimity as a special factor is its end.

original: ādi, ādissa imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni. Tena vuccati – ‘paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ ādikalyāṇañceva🔽hoti tilakkhaṇasampannañcā’ti.🔽“Paṭhamassa jhānassa upekkhānubrūhanā majjhe. Majjhassa kati lakkhaṇāni? Majjhassa
analyzed: ādi ādissa imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni tena vuccati paṭhamam jhānam ādikalyāṇam ca eva  hoti ti lakkhaṇa sampannam ca ati  paṭhamassa jhānassa upekkhā anubrūhanā majjhe majjhassa kati lakkhaṇāni majjhassa
translated: So it is of four kinds as ‘beautiful here and blissful in heaven’ and so on.🔽‘The first jhāna is good in the beginning with the special quality of seclusion’: the purification of the way is the beginning of the first jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the special quality of seclusion is its end.

original: tīṇi lakkhaṇāni – visuddhaṃ cittaṃ ajjhupekkhati, samathapaṭipannaṃ ajjhupekkhati,🔽ekattupaṭṭhānaṃ ajjhupekkhati. Yañca visuddhaṃ cittaṃ ajjhupekkhati, yañca samathapaṭipannaṃ
analyzed: tīṇi lakkhaṇāni visuddham cittam ajjhupekkhati samatha paṭipannam ajjhupekkhati  ekattupaṭṭhānam ajjhupekkhati yat ca visuddham cittam ajjhupekkhati yat ca samatha paṭipannam
translated: ‘The first jhāna is good in the beginning with the special quality of seclusion’: the purification of the way is the beginning of the first jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the special quality of seclusion is its end.🔽‘The first jhāna is good in the middle with the special quality of the intensification of happiness’: the purification of the way is the beginning of the first jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the intensification of happiness is its end.🔽‘The first jhāna is good in the end with the special quality of the steadying of consciousness’: the purification of the way is the beginning of the first jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the steadying of consciousness is its end.

original: ajjhupekkhati, yañca ekattupaṭṭhānaṃ ajjhupekkhati. Paṭhamassa jhānassa upekkhānubrūhanā
analyzed: ajjhupekkhati yat ca ekattupaṭṭhānam ajjhupekkhati paṭhamassa jhānassa upekkhā anubrūhanā
translated: ‘The first jhāna is good in the beginning with the special quality of seclusion’: the purification of the way is the beginning of the first jhāna, and the mind’s steadiness on its object is its middle, and the steadying of consciousness is its end.

original: majjhe, majjhassa imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni. Tena vuccati – ‘paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ majjhekalyāṇañceva🔽hoti tilakkhaṇasampannañcā’ti.🔽“Paṭhamassa jhānassa sampahaṃsanā pariyosānaṃ. Pariyosānassa kati lakkhaṇāni? Pariyosānassa🔽cattāri lakkhaṇāni – tattha jātānaṃ dhammānaṃ anativattanaṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā, indriyānaṃ
analyzed: majjhe majjhassa imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni tena vuccati paṭhamam jhānam majjhe kalyāṇam ca iva  hoti ti lakkhaṇa sampannam ca ati  paṭhamassa jhānassa sampahaṃsanā pariyosānam pariyosānassa kati lakkhaṇāni pariyosānassa  cattāri lakkhaṇāni tattha jātānam dhammānam an ativattana ṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā indriyānaṃ
translated: ‘The first jhāna is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end.🔽‘“The first jhāna is good in the beginning”: the development of the first jhāna is good in the beginning.🔽‘“The first jhāna is good in the middle”: the first jhāna is good in the middle.🔽‘“The first jhāna is good in the end”: the first jhāna is good in the end.🔽‘“The first jhāna is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end”: the development of the first jhāna is good in the beginning, the first jhāna is good in the middle, and the first jhāna is good in the end. Hence it was said: ‘The first jhāna is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end’

original: ekarāsaṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā, tadupagavīriyavāhanaṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā, āsevanaṭṭhena🔽sampahaṃsanā. Paṭhamassa jhānassa sampahaṃsanā pariyosānaṃ, pariyosānassa imāni cattāri🔽lakkhaṇāni. Tena vuccati ‘paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇañceva hoti catulakkhaṇasampannañcā”’ti.
analyzed: eka rāsa ṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā tad upaga vīriya vāhana ṭṭhena sampahaṃsanā āsevana ṭṭhena  sampahaṃsanā paṭhamassa jhānassa sampahaṃsanā pariyosānam pariyosānassa imāni cattāri  lakkhaṇāni tena vuccati paṭhamam jhānam pariyosāna kalyāṇam ca iva hoti catu lakkhaṇa sampannam ca ati
translated: ‘“The first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end”: the development of the first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, the first jhāna is of good nature in the middle, and the first jhāna is of good nature in the end. Hence it was said: ‘The first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end’🔽‘“The first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end”: the development of the first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, the first jhāna is of good nature in the middle, and the first jhāna is of good nature in the end. Hence it was said: ‘The first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end’

original: “Tatra paṭipadāvisuddhi nāma sasambhāriko upacāro. Upekkhānubrūhanā nāma appanā.
analyzed: tatra paṭipadā visuddhi nāma sa sambhārikaḥ upacāraḥ upekkhā anubrūhanā nāma appanā
translated: ‘“The first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end”: the development of the first jhāna is of good nature in the beginning, the first jhāna is of good nature in the middle, and the first jhāna is of good nature in the end. Hence it was said: ‘The first

original: Sampahaṃsanā nāma paccavekkhaṇā”ti evameke vaṇṇayanti. Yasmā pana “ekattagataṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: sampahaṃsanā nāma paccavekkhaṇā ti evam eke vaṇṇayanti yasmai pana ekatta gatam cittam
translated: But since it is said in the text, “The mind that has entered into the first jhāna is purified from the defilements of the hindrances” ,

original: paṭipadāvisuddhipakkhandañceva hoti upekkhānubrūhitañca ñāṇena ca sampahaṃsita”nti
analyzed: paṭipadā visuddhi pakkhandañca iva hoti upekkhā anubrūhitañca ñāṇena ca sampahaṃsitanti
translated: and “it is tranquilized, tranquilized, and has become unified and unified, and it is well liberated, well liberated, and has become well unified and well unified” ,

original: pāḷiyaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā antoappanāyameva āgamanavasena paṭipadāvisuddhi, tatramajjhattupekkhāya
analyzed: pāḷiyam vuttam tasmai āgamana vasena tatram ajjhatta upekkhāya
translated: therefore it should be understood that purification is the state of having entered upon the first jhāna, tranquillization is the surmounting of the defilements of the hindrances, and enrapturing is the surmounting of the grossness of the five aggregates.

original: kiccavasena upekkhānubrūhanā, dhammānaṃ anativattanādibhāvasādhanena pariyodāpakassa🔽ñāṇassa kiccanipphattivasena sampahaṃsanā ca veditabbā.🔽Kathaṃ? Yasmiñhi vāre appanā uppajjati, tasmiṃ yo nīvaraṇasaṅkhāto kilesagaṇo tassa🔽jhānassa paripantho, tato cittaṃ visujjhati. Visuddhattā āvaraṇavirahitaṃ hutvā majjhimaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇassa kicca nipphatti vasena sampahaṃsanā ca veditabbā  katham yasmin hi vāre appanā uppajjati tasmin yaḥ nīvaraṇa saṅkhātaḥ kilesa gaṇaḥ tassa  jhānassa paripantho tatas cittam visujjhati visuddha ttā āvaraṇa virahitam hutvā majjhimam
translated: How? In the first place, in the stage of access the mind is purified by suppression of the hindrances. Then, with the arising of jhāna, it is purified by substitution of the jhāna factors for the hindrances.🔽And in the second place, in the first stage of jhāna the mind is tranquilized by suppression of applied thought. Then, with the arising of the second jhāna, it is tranquilized by substitution of the second jhāna factors for the first jhāna factors.🔽And in the third place, in the first stage of jhāna the mind is unified by suppression of the hindrances. Then, with the arising of the second jhāna, it is unified by substitution of the second jhāna factors for the first jhāna factors.

original: samathanimittaṃ paṭipajjati. Majjhimasamathanimittaṃ nāma samappavatto appanāsamādhiyeva.
analyzed: samatha nimittam paṭipajjati majjhima samatha nimittam nāma sama ppavattaḥ appanā samādhiyā iva
translated: And in the fourth place, in the first stage of jhāna the mind is well liberated by suppression of the hindrances. Then, with the arising of the second jhāna, it is well liberated by substitution of the second jhāna factors for the first jhāna factors.

original: Tadanantaraṃ pana purimacittaṃ ekasantatipariṇāmanayena tathattaṃ upagacchamānaṃ
analyzed: tad anantaram pana purima cittam eka santati pariṇāma nayena tathattam upagacchamānam
translated: But the next consciousness, which is the first of the series, is the same as that, in the sense of its having become that by a transformation of the continuity.

original: majjhimaṃ samathanimittaṃ paṭipajjati nāma, evaṃ paṭipannattā tathattupagamanena🔽tattha pakkhandati nāma. Evaṃ tāva purimacitte vijjamānākāranipphādikā paṭhamassa
analyzed: majjhimam samatha nimittam paṭipajjati nāma evam paṭipanna ttā tathattu upagamanena  tattha pakkhandati nāma evam tāva purima citte vijjamāna ākāra nipphādikā paṭhamassa
translated: But the next consciousness, which is the first of the three in the cognitive series, is called “the path of serenity” because it is approaching that state by the process of the transformation of the continuum.🔽And because it has entered upon that state by approaching it, it is called “the state of serenity.”

original: jhānassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva āgamanavasena paṭipadāvisuddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: jhānassa uppāda kkhaṇe yeva āgamana vasena paṭipadā visuddhi veditabbā
translated: So firstly, the purification of the way should be understood here as the arising of the first jhāna at the instant of the arising of the first consciousness in the cognitive series, which is the cause for the arising of the second consciousness, and so on.

original: Evaṃ visuddhassa pana tassa puna visodhetabbābhāvato visodhane byāpāraṃ akaronto🔽visuddhaṃ cittaṃ ajjhupekkhati nāma. Samathabhāvūpagamanena samathapaṭipannassa puna🔽samādhāne byāpāraṃ akaronto samathapaṭipannaṃ ajjhupekkhati nāma. Samathapaṭipannabhāvato
analyzed: evam visuddhassa pana tassa puna visodhetabba abhāvataḥ visodhane byāpāram a karontaḥ  visuddham cittam ajjhupekkhati nāma samatha bhāva upagamanena samatha paṭipannassa puna  samādhāne byāpāram a karontaḥ samatha paṭipannam ajjhupekkhati nāma samatha paṭipanna bhāvato
translated: But when it has been purified in this way, it has no further need of purification, so it is called “equanimity about purification” since it is equanimity consisting in the absence of any more purification being needed.🔽And when it has entered upon the state of serenity by approaching it, it has no further need of concentration, so it is called “equanimity about concentration” since it is equanimity consisting in the absence of any more concentration being needed.🔽And since it has entered upon the state of serenity, it has abandoned association with defilements, so it is called “equanimity about association” since it is equanimity consisting in the absence of any more association with defilements.

original: eva cassa kilesasaṃsaggaṃ pahāya ekattena upaṭṭhitassa puna ekattupaṭṭhāne byāpāraṃ
analyzed: eva cassa kilesa saṃsaggam pahāya ekattena upaṭṭhitassa puna ekatta upaṭṭhāne byāpāram
translated: And since it has become unified by the abandoning of association with defilements, it has no further need of unification, so it is called “equanimity about unification” since it is equanimity consisting in the absence of any more unification being needed.

original: akaronto ekattupaṭṭhānaṃ ajjhupekkhati nāma. Evaṃ tatramajjhattupekkhāya kiccavasena
analyzed: a karontaḥ ekattupaṭṭhānam ajjhupekkhati nāma evam tatram ajjhattupekkhāya kicca vasena
translated: and not doing so is called equanimity about the signless.🔽This is how equanimity about the signless should be understood as the function of equanimity about what is one’s own concern.

original: upekkhānubrūhanā veditabbā.🔽Ye panete evaṃ upekkhānubrūhite tattha jātā samādhipaññāsaṅkhātā yuganaddhadhammā🔽aññamaññaṃ anativattamānā hutvā pavattā, yāni ca saddhādīni indriyāni nānākilesehi
analyzed: upekkhā anubrūhanā veditabbā  ye pana ete evam tattha jātā samādhi paññā saṅkhātā yuga naddha dhammā  aññam aññam an ativattamānāḥ hutvā pavattā yāni ca saddhā ādīni indriyāni nānā kilesehi
translated: He is called “equally and continuously in touch with the mental state of equanimity” when he does not do so. This is how the intensification of equanimity should be understood as a function of equanimity as specific neutrality.🔽And when equanimity has been intensified in this way, the states of concentration and understanding that arise are called “twin things” because they occur without varying from the twin states of nonexcess and balance.

original: vimuttattā vimuttirasena ekarasāni hutvā pavattāni, yañcesa tadupagaṃ tesaṃ anativattanaekarasabhāvānaṃ
analyzed: vimutta ttā vimutti rasena ekarasāni hutvā pavattāni yat ca īsa tad upagam tesam an ativattana ekarasa bhāvānam
translated: And the faith, etc., that occur with the same taste as the twin states of nonexcess and balance because they are liberated from the various defilements,

original: anucchavikaṃ vīriyaṃ vāhayati, yā cassa tasmiṃ khaṇe pavattā āsevanā, sabbepi te🔽ākārā yasmā ñāṇena saṃkilesavodānesu taṃ taṃ ādīnavañca ānisaṃsañca disvā tathā tathā
analyzed: anucchavikam vīriyam vāhayati yā ca assa tasmin khaṇe pavattā āsevanā sabbe api te  ākārāḥ yasmai ñāṇena saṃkilesa vodānesu tam tam ādīnavam ca ānisaṃsam ca disvā tathā tathā
translated: and the energy that is appropriate to them and does not overstep those twin states of nonexcess and balance, and the repetition that occurs at that time—

original: sampahaṃsitattā visodhitattā pariyodāpitattā nipphannāva, tasmā “dhammānaṃ anativattanādibhāvasādhanena
analyzed: sampahaṃsita ttā visodhita ttā pariyodāpita ttā nipphannā ava tasmā dhammānam an ativattana ādi bhāva sādhanena
translated: all these aspects are called “the path of purification” because they are produced by seeing the danger in the defilements and in what is unprofitable, and by seeing the benefit in the purification and in what is profitable, and by repeatedly verifying them with knowledge, and by repeatedly verifying them with knowledge, and by purifying and cleansing them thus.

original: pariyodāpakassa ñāṇassa kiccanipphattivasena sampahaṃsanā veditabbā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pariyodāpakassa ñāṇassa kicca nipphatti vasena sampahaṃsanā veditabbā iti vuttam
translated: The second jhāna should be understood as gladdened by the fulfilment of the function of the knowledge that refreshes.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamāti vitakkassa ca vicārassa cāti imesaṃ dvinnaṃ vūpasamā
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ati vitakkassa ca vicārassa ca ati imesam dvinnam vūpasamā
translated: With the stilling of applied and sustained thought: with the stilling, with the surmounting, of these two kinds of thought,

original: samatikkamā, dutiyajjhānakkhaṇe apātubhāvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha kiñcāpi dutiyajjhāne🔽sabbepi paṭhamajjhānadhammā na santi, aññeyeva hi paṭhamajjhāne phassādayo, aññe🔽idha. Oḷārikassa pana oḷārikassa aṅgassa samatikkamā paṭhamajjhānato paresaṃ dutiyajjhānādīnaṃ
analyzed: samatikkamā dutiya jhāna kkhaṇe apātubhāvā ti vuttam hoti tattha kiñcā api dutiya jhāne  sabbe pi paṭhamajjhāna dhammāḥ na santi aññe iya iva hi paṭhamajjhāne phassa ādayaḥ aññe  idha oḷārikassa pana oḷārikassa aṅgassa samatikkamā paṭhama jhānataḥ paresam dutiya jhāna ādīnam
translated: which is described in the way beginning, “He … has entered upon the second jhāna, which … has internal confidence and singleness of mind without applied thought, with sustained thought only” .

original: adhigamo hotīti dassanatthaṃ “vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti evaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Ajjhattanti idha niyakajjhattaṃ adhippetaṃ, vibhaṅge pana “ajjhattaṃ paccatta”nti
analyzed: adhigamaḥ hoti iti dassana attham vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ati evam vuttam ti veditabbam  ajjhattam ti idha niyaka ajjhattam adhippetam vibhaṅge pana ajjhattam paccattanti
translated: Herein, although all states in the first jhāna are absent in the second jhāna, still the words “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” should be understood to be said in order to point out the specific characteristic of the second jhāna, just as it is said in the texts, “The first jhāna has five factors,” specifically pointing out the specific characteristic of the first jhāna.🔽Internally: here what is intended by “internally” is what is one’s own , but in the Vibhaṅga only this much is said: “‘Internally’ means either in oneself or in what is one’s own” .

original: ettakameva vuttaṃ. Yasmā niyakajjhattaṃ adhippetaṃ, tasmā attani jātaṃ, attano santāne
analyzed: ettakam eva vuttam yasmā niyaka jjhattam adhippetam tasmā attani jātam attano santāne
translated: And since what is one’s own is also one’s own only because it is included in one’s continuity, therefore it should be understood that what is intended here by “internally” is what is included in one’s own continuity.

original: nibbattanti ayamettha attho.🔽Sampasādananti sampasādanaṃ vuccati saddhā. Sampasādanayogato jhānampi sampasādanaṃ,
analyzed: nibbattanti ayam ettha atthaḥ  sampasādanam ti sampasādanam vuccati saddhā sampasādana yogataḥ jhānam pi sampasādanam
translated: is the meaning here.

original: nīlavaṇṇayogato nīlavatthaṃ viya. Yasmā vā taṃ jhānaṃ sampasādanasamannāgatattā vitakkavicārakkhobhavūpasamanena🔽ca ceto sampasādayati, tasmāpi “sampasādana”nti vuttaṃ. Imasmiñca atthavikappe sampasādanaṃ
analyzed: nīla vaṇṇa yogataḥ nīlavattham viya yasmai vā tam jhānam sampasādana samannāgata ttā vitakka vicāra khobha vūpasamanena  ca cetaḥ sampasādayati tasmā api sampasādanam ti vuttam imasmin ca attha vikappe sampasādanam
translated: Confidence: confidence is what is meant. The jhāna is called confidence-inspiring because it inspires confidence, just as a true man is called a “confidence- inspirer” . Or alternatively, it inspires confidence in the mind, which is why it is called confidence-inspiring, since it is associated with confidence and since it allays the disturbance of applied and sustained thought and so brings about mental confidence,🔽just as the colour blue, etc., is called “blue-inspiring,” etc., because it inspires confidence in the mind as to the colour blue, and so on.🔽And in this construction the word confidence-inspiring should be understood as a noun formed from the adjective “confidence-inspiring” .

original: cetasoti evaṃ padasambandho veditabbo. Purimasmiṃ pana atthavikappe cetasoti etaṃ
analyzed: cetasaḥ ti evam pada sambandhaḥ veditabbo purimasmin pana attha vikappe cetasaḥ ti etam
translated: But in the construction beginning “The mind that is confident,” the word confidence-inspiring should be understood as a noun formed from the verb “to inspire confidence” .

original: ekodibhāvena saddhiṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: eka udi bhāvena saddhim yojetabbam
translated: Here is the construction of the meaning.

original: Tatrāyaṃ atthayojanā – eko udetīti ekodi, vitakkavicārehi anajjhārūḷhattā aggo seṭṭho
analyzed: tatra ayam attha yojanā ekaḥ udeti iti ekodi vitakka vicārehi an ajjhārūḍha ttā aggaḥ seṭṭho
translated: It rises alone : it is alone because it is not shared by applied and sustained thought. It is the best, the highest,

original: hutvā udetīti attho. Seṭṭhopi hi loke ekoti vuccati. Vitakkavicāravirahito vā eko
analyzed: hutvā udeti iti attho seṭṭhaḥ api hi loke ekaḥ ti vuccati vitakka vicāra virahitaḥ vā ekaḥ
translated: the meaning being that it rises having become the best. For the best is called “alone” in the world. Or alternatively, it is alone because it is without companion,🔽since it is devoid of applied and sustained thought. Or it is alone since it is without a second,

original: asahāyo hutvātipi vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Atha vā sampayuttadhamme udāyatīti udi, uṭṭhāpetīti
analyzed: asahāyaḥ hutvā atipi vattum vaṭṭati atha vā sampayutta dhamme udāyati iti udi uṭṭhāpeti iti
translated: It rises: it causes to rise, it causes the associated states to rise.

original: attho. Seṭṭhaṭṭhena eko ca so udi cāti ekodi, samādhissetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Iti imaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ seṭṭha ṭṭhena ekaḥ ca saḥ udi ca ati eka udi samādhiḥ etam adhivacanam iti imam
translated: and the meaning is this. It is unified because it is one in being the best, thus it is unification ; this is a term for concentration. So it is said:🔽“He develops that unification of mind which is concentration ;

original: ekodiṃ bhāveti vaḍḍhetīti idaṃ dutiyajjhānaṃ ekodibhāvaṃ. So panāyaṃ ekodi yasmā
analyzed: ekodim bhāveti vaḍḍheti iti idam dutiya jhānam ekodi bhāvam saḥ pana ayam ekodi yasmā
translated: he increases it, expands it, and expands it again. This is the unification of mind that is concentration.”

original: cetaso, na sattassa, na jīvassa. Tasmā etaṃ “cetaso ekodibhāva”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cetasaḥ na sattassa na jīvassa tasmai etam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvanti vuttam
translated: But this unification is of the mind, not of the being or the living being. That is why it is said that it is “unification of mind.”

original: Nanu cāyaṃ saddhā paṭhamajjhānepi atthi, ayañca ekodināmako samādhi, atha kasmā idameva🔽“sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāva”nti vuttanti? Vuccate – aduñhi paṭhamajjhānaṃ vitakkavicārakkhobhena🔽vīcitaraṅgasamākulamiva jalaṃ na suppasannaṃ hoti, tasmā satiyāpi saddhāya sampasādananti🔽na vuttaṃ. Na suppasannattāyeva cettha samādhipi na suṭṭhu pākaṭo, tasmā ekodibhāvantipi
analyzed: nanu ca ayam paṭhama jhāne pi atthi ayam ca ekodi nāmakaḥ atha kasmai idam eva  sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvan ti vuttan ti vuccate  vīci taraṅga samākulam iva jalam na su pasannam hoti tasmā satiyā api saddhāya sampasādanan ti  na vuttam na su pasanna ttāya iva ca ittha samādhi na suṭṭhu pākaṭaḥ tasmai
translated: But has not faith already been mentioned in the first jhāna too, and also this concentration called “unification”? If it has,

original: na vuttaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana jhāne vitakkavicārapalibodhābhāvena laddhokāsā balavatī saddhā,
analyzed: na vuttam imasmim pana jhāne vitakka vicāra palibodha abhāvena laddha ukāsā balavatī saddhā
translated: why say “confidence and trust” and “unification of mind” again here? —It may be replied as follows: The first jhāna is not well defined since it is disturbed by applied thought and sustained thought, like water ruffled by ripples and wavelets. That is why “confidence and trust” is not mentioned of it. And concentration is not very evident there since it is not well defined. That is why “unification of mind” is not mentioned. But in this second jhāna, which is attained when the disturbance due to applied thought and sustained thought has been stilled, faith is strong because it has obtained the opportunity to do so,🔽and it is therefore called “confidence and trust.”

original: balavasaddhāsahāyapaṭilābheneva ca samādhipi pākaṭo. Tasmā idameva evaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: balava saddhā sahāya paṭilābhena iva ca tasmai idam eva evam vuttam ti veditabbam
translated: And concentration is evident to him too with the acquisition of the support of strong faith. So it should be understood that this is what is referred to here.

original: Avitakkaṃ avicāranti bhāvanāya pahīnattā etasmiṃ, etassa vā vitakko natthīti avitakkaṃ.🔽Imināva nayena avicāraṃ. Etthāha “nanu ca ‘vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā’ti imināpi ayamattho
analyzed: a vitakkam a vicāranti bhāvanāya pahīna ttā etasmin etassa vā vitakko na atthi iti a vitakkam  iminā ava nayena avicāram ettha āha nanu ca vitakka vicārāṇam iminā api ayam attho
translated: It is without thought and without investigation: there is no thinking in this or of this, thus it is without thought .🔽In the same way it is without investigation .🔽Here it may be objected: “But isn’t this meaning already established by the words ‘with the stilling of thought and investigation’?

original: siddho. Atha kasmā puna vuttaṃ ‘avitakkaṃ avicāra”’nti? Vuccate – evametaṃ, siddhovāyamattho.🔽Na panetaṃ tadatthadīpakaṃ, nanu avocumha “oḷārikassa pana oḷārikassa aṅgassa samatikkamā🔽paṭhamajjhānato paresaṃ dutiyajjhānādīnaṃ samadhigamo hotīti dassanatthaṃ ‘vitakkavicārānaṃ
analyzed: siddhaḥ atha kasmā puna vuttam a vitakkam a vicāram ti vuccate evam etam siddhaḥ uva ayam atthaḥ  na pana itam tad attha dīpakam nanu avocumha oḷārikassa pana oḷārikassa aṅgassa samatikkamā  paṭhama jhānataḥ paresam dutiya jhāna ādīnam samadhigamaḥ hoti iti dassana ttham
translated: So why is it said again that it is without thought and without investigation? ”🔽—It is so established, no doubt.

original: vūpasamā’ti evaṃ vutta”nti.
analyzed: vūpasamā iti evam vuttan ti
