translated: But that does not illuminate the meaning. We said that the words “with the stilling of thought and investigation” are stated in order to show that the other jhānas beginning with the second are reached by surmounting the gross factor in each case.

original: Api ca vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā idaṃ sampasādanaṃ, na kilesakālussiyassa. Vitakkavicārānañca
analyzed: api ca vitakka vicāra ānam vūpasamāḥ idam sampasādanam na kilesa kālussiyassa vitakka vicāra ānam ca
translated: And besides, this confidence is due to the stilling of thought and investigation, not to the removal of the defilements’ coarseness.

original: vūpasamā ekodibhāvaṃ, na upacārajjhānamiva nīvaraṇappahānā, na paṭhamajjhānamiva
analyzed: vūpasamāḥ eka udi bhāvam na upacāra jhānam iva nīvaraṇa ppahānāḥ na paṭhama jhānam iva
translated: and the unification is not like the abandoning of hindrances in access concentration, nor like the manifestation of the factors in the first jhāna,

original: ca aṅgapātubhāvāti evaṃ sampasādanaekodibhāvānaṃ hetuparidīpakamidaṃ vacanaṃ. Tathā🔽vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā idaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ, na tatiyacatutthajjhānāni viya
analyzed: ca evam hetu paridīpakam idam vacanam tathā  vitakka vicārāṇam vūpasamāḥ idam a vitakkam a vicāram na tatiya catuttha jhānāni
translated: so this phrase “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” shows the cause for confidence and unification.🔽And it shows the cause for the absence of applied thought and sustained thought,🔽which is not the same as the absence of applied thought and sustained thought in the third and fourth jhānas and in eye consciousness, etc.,

original: cakkhuviññāṇādīni viya ca abhāvāti, evaṃ avitakkaavicārabhāvassa hetuparidīpakañca,🔽na vitakkavicārābhāvamattaparidīpakaṃ. Vitakkavicārābhāvamattaparidīpakameva pana
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni viya ca abhāvā ti evam avitakka avicāra bhāvassa hetu paridīpakam ca  na vitakka vicāra abhāva matta paridīpakam vitakka vicāra abhāva matta paridīpakam eva pana
translated: so it shows the cause for the absence of applied thought and sustained thought.🔽But the phrase “without applied thought, without sustained thought” shows only the absence of applied thought and sustained thought.

original: “avitakkaṃ avicāra”nti idaṃ vacanaṃ. Tasmā purimaṃ vatvāpi puna vattabbamevāti.🔽Samādhijanti paṭhamajjhānasamādhito sampayuttasamādhito vā jātanti attho. Tattha
analyzed: a vitakkam a vicāranti idam vacanam tasmai purimam vatvā api puna vattabbam eva ati  samādhi janti paṭhamajjhāna samādhito sampayutta samādhito vā attho tattha
translated: That is why it should be repeated even though it has already been stated in the phrase “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought.”🔽“Born of concentration”: born of the first jhāna, or born of the concentration associated with the first jhāna. Herein,

original: kiñcāpi paṭhamampi sampayuttasamādhito jātaṃ, atha kho ayameva samādhi “samādhī”ti
analyzed: kiñca api paṭhamam pi sampayutta samādhitaḥ jātam atha kho ayam eva samādhi samādhi iti
translated: although the first jhāna is also born of the concentration associated with it, nevertheless it is this jhāna that is called “concentration” in this context,

original: vattabbataṃ arahati, vitakkavicārakkhobhavirahena ativiya acalattā suppasannattā
analyzed: vattabba tam arahati vitakka vicāra khobha virahena ati viya acala tā suppasanna ttā
translated: It is worthy of being spoken of as born of concentration because it is extremely unshakable and serene owing to the absence of the disturbance of applied and sustained thought.

original: ca. Tasmā imassa vaṇṇabhaṇanatthaṃ idameva “samādhija”nti vuttaṃ. Pītisukhanti idaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: ca tasmai imassa vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham idam eva samādhi janti vuttam pīti sukhanti idam vutta nayam eva
translated: So it is said of this that “it is born of concentration” in order to extol it. The words rapture and happiness are as already explained.

original: Dutiyanti gaṇanānupubbatā dutiyaṃ. Idaṃ dutiyaṃ uppannantipi dutiyaṃ.🔽Pītiyā ca virāgāti virāgo nāma vuttappakārāya pītiyā jigucchanaṃ vā samatikkamo vā.
analyzed: dutiyam ti gaṇanā anupubba tā dutiyam idam dutiyam uppannam ti pi dutiyam  pītiyā ca virāgā ti virāgaḥ nāma vutta ppakārāya pītiyā jigucchanam vā samatikkamaḥ vā
translated: Second: it is second in numerical order, and it is second in the order of development.🔽And with the fading away of rapture: fading away is the act of disliking or the surmounting of the rapture of the kind already described.

original: Ubhinnaṃ pana antarā ca-saddo sampiṇḍanattho, so vūpasamaṃ vā sampiṇḍeti vitakkavicāravūpasamaṃ🔽vā. Tattha yadā vūpasamameva sampiṇḍeti, tadā pītiyā virāgā ca, kiñca bhiyyo vūpasamā🔽cāti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā. Imissā ca yojanāya virāgo jigucchanattho hoti, tasmā
analyzed: ubhinnam pana antarā ca saddo sampiṇḍana attho saḥ vūpasamam vā sampiṇḍeti vitakka vicāra vūpasamam  vā tattha yadā tadā ca kiñca bhiyyas  ca ati evam yojanā veditabbā imissā ca yojanāya virāgaḥ jigucchana atthaḥ hoti tasmā
translated: But the word and in the phrase “with the fading away of rapture and with the abandoning of delight” has the meaning of a conjunction, and it conjoins either the fading away of rapture or the abandoning of delight with the equanimity that is dependent on the third jhāna.🔽Herein, when it conjoins the fading away of rapture, the construction should be understood to be “with the fading away of rapture and with the equanimity that is dependent on the third jhāna and that has abandoned delight” .

original: pītiyā jigucchanā ca samatikkamā cāti ayamattho daṭṭhabbo. Yadā pana vitakkavicāravūpasamaṃ
analyzed: pītiyāḥ jigucchanā ca samatikkamā ca ati ayam attho daṭṭhabbo yadā pana vitakka vicāra vūpasamam
translated: And in this construction the word fading away has the meaning of dislike, so the meaning should be regarded as “with the fading away, that is, the dislike, of rapture, and with the equanimity that is dependent on the third jhāna and that has abandoned delight.”🔽But when it conjoins the abandoning of delight, the construction should be understood to be “with the fading away of rapture and with the equanimity that is dependent on the third jhāna and with the abandoning of delight” .

original: sampiṇḍeti, tadā pītiyā ca virāgā, kiñca bhiyyo vitakkavicārānañca vūpasamāti evaṃ
analyzed: tadā ca virāgā kiñca bhiyyas vitakka vicārā anañca evam
translated: and he identifies with it, then with the fading away of happiness he enters upon and dwells in the third jhāna, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.🔽The construction here should be understood thus: “With the fading away of happiness he enters upon and dwells in the third jhāna, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and unification of mind due to equanimity.”

original: yojanā veditabbā. Imissā ca yojanāya virāgo samatikkamanattho hoti, tasmā pītiyā🔽ca samatikkamā vitakkavicārānañca vūpasamāti ayamattho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Kāmañcete vitakkavicārā dutiyajjhāneyeva vūpasantā, imassa pana jhānassa maggaparidīpanatthaṃ🔽vaṇṇabhaṇanatthañcetaṃ vuttaṃ. “Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti hi vutte idaṃ paññāyati
analyzed: yojanā veditabbā imissā ca yojanāya virāgaḥ samatikkamana atthaḥ hoti tasmā pītiyā  ca samatikkamāḥ vitakka vicārā nañca vūpasamā ti ayam atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  kāmañca ete vitakka vicārāḥ vūpasantāḥ imassa pana jhānassa magga paridīpana attham  vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham ca itam vuttam vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā iti hi vutte idam paññāyati
translated: And in this construction the meaning of “fading away” is the meaning of “surmounting,” so the meaning of “With the surmounting of happiness” should be regarded as the meaning of “With the fading away of happiness.”🔽But though applied thought and sustained thought have already subsided in the second jhāna, still he is called “with mental release by choice” since he has attained by overcoming the choice consisting in applied thought and sustained thought.🔽And the words “With the fading away of happiness” are said in order to point out the third jhāna as the one that has actually been attained by him, and in order to make it clear that the words “With the fading away of joy” in the description of the second jhāna are stated with reference to the fading away of the kind of joy that has no counterpart in the first jhāna.

original: “nūna vitakkavicāravūpasamo maggo imassa jhānassā”ti. Yathā ca tatiye ariyamagge
analyzed: nūna vitakka vicāra vūpasamaḥ maggaḥ imassa jhānassa ati yathā ca tatiye ariya magge
translated: For when it is said that “With the fading away of happiness he enters upon and dwells in the third jhāna,” it is clear that “The fading away of happiness is the path” to the third jhāna.

original: appahīnānampi sakkāyadiṭṭhādīnaṃ “pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ pahānā”ti
analyzed: appahīnānam pi sakkāyadiṭṭha ādīnam pañcannam orambhāgiyānam saṃyojanānam pahānāti
translated: And just as in the case of the third noble path, though the false view of individuality, etc., have not been abandoned in their entire aspect, yet their abandonment is expressed in the words, “With the abandoning of the five lower fetters” ,

original: evaṃ pahānaṃ vuccamānaṃ vaṇṇabhaṇanaṃ hoti, tadadhigamāya ussukkānaṃ ussāhajanakaṃ,
analyzed: evam pahānam vuccamānam vaṇṇa bhaṇanam hoti tad adhigamāya ussukkānam ussāha janakam
translated: so too here the fading away of happiness should be understood as stated in order to make it clear that the words “With the fading away of happiness” are stated with reference to the fading away of the kind of happiness that has no counterpart in the first jhāna, and in order to make it clear that the words “With the fading away of joy” in the description of the second jhāna are stated with reference to the fading away of the kind of joy that has no counterpart in the first jhāna.

original: evameva idha avūpasantānampi vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamo vuccamāno vaṇṇabhaṇanaṃ hoti,🔽tenāyamattho vutto “pītiyā ca samatikkamā vitakkavicārānañca vūpasamā”ti.
analyzed: evam eva idha a vūpasantānam pi vitakka vicārānam vūpasamaḥ vuccamānaḥ vaṇṇa bhaṇanam hoti  tena ayam atthaḥ vuttaḥ pītiyā ca samatikkamā vitakka vicārānam ca vūpasamā ti
translated: So too, here, the quieting of applied and sustained thought, though not yet quietened, is spoken of as quietened when it is spoken of as “the quieting of applied and sustained thought.”🔽That is why the meaning of the words “with the surmounting of happiness” is given as “with the abandoning of happiness” and the meaning of the words “with the disappearance of applied and sustained thought” is given as “with the stilling of initial and sustained thought.”

original: Upekkhako ca viharatīti ettha upapattito ikkhatīti upekkhā, samaṃ passati, apakkhapatitā
analyzed: upekkhakaḥ ca viharati iti ettha upapattitaḥ ikkhati iti upekkhā samam passati a pakkha pati tā
translated: He dwells in equanimity: here equanimity is the seeing of things as equal, the seeing of them impartially,

original: hutvā passatīti attho. Tāya visadāya vipulāya thāmagatāya samannāgatattā tatiyajjhānasamaṅgī
analyzed: hutvā passati iti attho tāya visadāya vipulāya thāma gatāya samannāgata ttā tatiya jhāna samaṅgī
translated: the seeing of them as they really are. The person who possesses this equanimity, which is clear, bright, purified, and cleansed,

original: “upekkhako”ti vuccati.🔽Upekkhā pana dasavidhā hoti – chaḷaṅgupekkhā brahmavihārupekkhā bojjhaṅgupekkhā vīriyupekkhā
analyzed: upekkhakaḥ iti vuccati  upekkhā pana dasavidhā hoti chaḷaṅgu pekkhā brahmavihāru pekkhā bojjhaṅgu pekkhā vīriyupekkhā
translated: is called “one who dwells in equanimity.”

original: saṅkhārupekkhā vedanupekkhā vipassanupekkhā tatramajjhattupekkhā jhānupekkhā pārisuddhupekkhāti.
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā vedanā upekkhā vipassanā upekkhā tatra majjhatta upekkhā jhānu pekkhā pārisuddha upekkhā ati
translated: Equanimity is of ten kinds: equanimity as a divine abiding, equanimity as a factor of complete purification, equanimity as a factor of final knowledge, equanimity as a factor of complete emancipation, equanimity as a factor of final Nibbāna, equanimity as a factor of purification of mindfulness, equanimity as a factor of right concentration, equanimity as a factor of the establishment of mindfulness, equanimity as a factor of the development of concentration, and equanimity as a factor of the path.

original: Tattha yā “idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano,
analyzed: tattha yā idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ
translated: Herein, equanimity as a divine abiding is that described thus: “He dwells in equanimity mindful and fully aware” .🔽Equanimity as a factor of complete purification is that described thus: “He dwells in equanimity, mindful and fully aware” .

original: upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno”ti evamāgatā khīṇāsavassa chasu dvāresu iṭṭhāniṭṭhachaḷārammaṇāpāthe
analyzed: upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ sampajānoti evam āgatā khīṇāsavassa chasu dvāresu iṭṭha aniṭṭha chaṭ ārammaṇa āpāthe
translated: and he dwells independent, not clinging to anything in the world.🔽🔽This is called the Noble Truth of the Cessation of Suffering.

original: parisuddhapakatibhāvāvijahanākārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ chaḷaṅgupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: parisuddha pakati bhāva avijahana ākāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam chaḷaṅgupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that is found in the passage beginning, “He dwells in equanimity, mindful and clearly comprehending” , is equanimity in the sense of the absence of alteration in the face of desirable and undesirable objects that reach the six bases in one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Yā pana “upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatī”ti evamāgatā sattesu majjhattākārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ brahmavihārupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana upekkhā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati iti evam āgatā sattesu majjhatta ākāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam brahmavihārupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that is found in the passage beginning, “He dwells pervading one direction with a mind imbued with loving-kindness” , is equanimity in the sense of neutrality towards beings.

original: Yā pana “upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissita”nti evamāgatā sahajātānaṃ dhammānaṃ majjhattākārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ bojjhaṅgupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana upekkhā sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti viveka nissitam ti evam āgatā sahajātānam dhammānam majjhatta ākāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam bojjhaṅgupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that is found in the passage beginning, “He develops the equanimity factor of complete awakening depending on seclusion” , is equanimity in the sense of neutrality towards the states associated with it.

original: Yā pana “kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasi karotī”ti evamāgatā anaccāraddhanātisithilavīriyasaṅkhātā upekkhā, ayaṃ vīriyupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana kālena kālam upekkhā nimittam manasi karoti iti evam āgatā anacca āraddha na ati sithila vīriya saṅkhātā upekkhā ayam vīriyupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that is found in the passage beginning, “From time to time he brings to mind the sign of equanimity” , is equanimity in the sense of the avoidance of over-exertion and slackness.

original: Yā pana “kati saṅkhārupekkhā samathavasena uppajjanti, kati saṅkhārupekkhā vipassanāvasena
analyzed: yā pana kati saṅkhāra upekkhā samatha vasena uppajjanti kati saṅkhāra upekkhā vipassanā vasena
translated: The equanimity that is found in the passage beginning, “How many kinds of equanimity arise through serenity? How many kinds of equanimity arise through insight?

original: uppajjanti? Aṭṭha saṅkhārupekkhā samathavasena uppajjanti, dasa saṅkhārupekkhā vipassanāvasena
analyzed: uppajjanti aṭṭha saṅkhāra upekkhāḥ samatha vasena uppajjanti dasa saṅkhāra upekkhāḥ vipassanā vasena
translated: How do they arise? The eight kinds of equanimity about formations arise by way of serenity, and the ten kinds of equanimity about formations arise by way of insight.

original: uppajjantī”ti evamāgatā nīvaraṇādipaṭisaṅkhāsantiṭṭhanāgahaṇe majjhattabhūtā upekkhā,
analyzed: uppajjanti iti evam āgatā nīvaraṇa ādi paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā gahaṇe majjhatta bhūtā upekkhā
translated: ” So equanimity is included in the “standing-point of reflection” in the passage beginning, “He dwells in equanimity, mindful and clearly comprehending, having removed covetousness and grief regarding the world” .

original: ayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: ayam saṅkhārupekkhā nāma
translated: This is called equanimity about formations.🔽But the equanimity called equanimity of feeling, which is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant, is included in the passage beginning, “When a profitable mind-element has arisen accompanied by equanimity” .

original: Yā pana “yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hoti upekkhāsahagata”nti evamāgatā adukkhamasukhasaṅkhātā upekkhā, ayaṃ vedanupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam cittam uppannam hoti upekkhā sahagatam ti evam āgatā adukkham asukha saṅkhātā upekkhā ayam vedanupekkhā nāma
translated: This is called equanimity of feeling.🔽The equanimity called equanimity of insight is included in the passage beginning, “What exists, what has become, that he abandons, and obtains equanimity” .

original: Yā pana “yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ, taṃ pajahati, upekkhaṃ paṭilabhatī”ti evamāgatā vicinane majjhattabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ vipassanupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana yat atthi yam bhūtam tam pajahati upekkham paṭilabhati iti evam āgatā vicinane majjhatta bhūtā upekkhā ayam vipassanupekkhā nāma
translated: This is called equanimity of insight.🔽But the equanimity called equanimity about what is seen, etc., is included in the passage beginning, “He dwells in equanimity towards pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling as they arise” .🔽This is called equanimity about what is seen, etc.

original: Yā pana chandādīsu yevāpanakesu āgatā sahajātānaṃ samavāhitabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ tatramajjhattupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana chanda ādīsu yevāpanakesu āgatā sahajātānam samavāhita bhūtā upekkhā ayam tatra majjhattupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity called simple equanimity is included in the passage beginning, “He dwells in equanimity, mindful and clearly comprehending, having removed covetousness and grief regarding the world” .🔽This is called simple equanimity.

original: Yā pana “upekkhako ca viharatī”ti evamāgatā aggasukhepi tasmiṃ apakkhapātajananī upekkhā, ayaṃ jhānupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana upekkhakaḥ ca viharati iti evam āgatā agga sukhe pi tasmim a pakkhapāta jananī upekkhā ayam jhānupekkhā nāma
translated: But equanimity as “he dwells in equanimity” is equanimity as non-partisan, and that is called equanimity as a divine abiding.

original: Yā pana “upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhāna”nti evamāgatā sabbapaccanīkaparisuddhā paccanīkavūpasamanepi abyāpārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ pārisuddhupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānanti evam āgatā sabba paccanīka parisuddhā paccanīka vūpasamane pi a byāpāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam pārisuddhupekkhā nāma
translated: But equanimity as “purification by equanimity, the fourth jhāna” is equanimity as purification, and that is called equanimity as purification.

original: Tattha chaḷaṅgupekkhā ca brahmavihārupekkhā ca bojjhaṅgupekkhā ca tatramajjhattupekkhā
analyzed: tattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhā ca brahmavihāru pekkhā ca bojjhaṅgu pekkhā ca tatra ajjhattu pekkhā
translated: Herein, equanimity as six-factoredness, equanimity as a divine abiding, equanimity as a factor of complete awakening, equanimity as specific neutrality,🔽equanimity as a jhāna factor, and equanimity as purification are all one in meaning, that is, specific neutrality.

original: ca jhānupekkhā ca pārisuddhupekkhā ca atthato ekā, tatramajjhattupekkhāva hoti. Tena
analyzed: ca jhānupekkhā ca pārisuddhupekkhā ca atthataḥ ekā hoti tena
translated: But they are classed according to the different functions of specific neutrality.

original: tena avatthābhedena panassā ayaṃ bhedo. Ekassāpi sato sattassa kumārayuvatherasenāpatirājādivasena🔽bhedo viya, tasmā tāsu yattha chaḷaṅgupekkhā, na tattha bojjhaṅgupekkhādayo. Yattha
analyzed: tena avatthā bhedena panassāḥ ayam bhedaḥ ekassa api sato sattassa kumāra yuvathera senāpati rāja ādi vasena 🔽bhedaḥ tāsu yattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhāḥ na tattha bojjhaṅgu pekkhā ādayaḥ yattha
translated: Just as there is a single being, a single human being, a single man, a single person, a single individual, a single soul, a single breathing thing, a single creature, a single king, a single lord, a single great man, a single noble-clan man, a single brahmin, a single khattiya, a single merchant, a single worker, a single chief, a single householder, a single monk, a single bhikkhu, a single bhikkhunī, a single male novice, a single female novice, a single male lay follower, a single female lay follower, a single brahmin, a single recluse, a single one gone forth, a single one who has renounced, a single ascetic, a single one who bears his own share, a single one who is all-conquered, a single one who has entered upon the way, a single one who has entered upon the way to the complete destruction of suffering, a single one who has entered upon the way to omniscience, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of all bonds, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the five lower fetters, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the five higher fetters, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of all defilements, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the cankers, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the round, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the underlying tendencies, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the round’s root, a single one who has entered upon the way to the destruction of the cankers’ root, a single one

original: vā pana bojjhaṅgupekkhā, na tattha chaḷaṅgupekkhādayo hontīti veditabbā.
analyzed: vā pana bojjhaṅgu pekkhā na tattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhā ādayaḥ honti iti veditabbā
translated: Or the equanimity of the enlightenment factor is the equanimity of the path, and the equanimity of the path is the equanimity of fruition.

original: Yathā cetāsaṃ atthato ekībhāvo, evaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāvipassanupekkhānampi. Paññā eva🔽hi esā, kiccavasena dvidhā bhinnā, yathā hi purisassa sāyaṃ gehaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ sappaṃ🔽ajapadadaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pariyesamānassa taṃ thusakoṭṭhake nipannaṃ disvā “sappo nu
analyzed: yathā cetāsam atthataḥ ekībhāvaḥ evam saṅkhāra upekkhā vipassanā upekkhānam pi paññā eva  hi esā kicca vasena dvidhā bhinnā yathā hi purisassa sāyam geham paviṭṭham sappam  aja pada daṇḍam gahetvā pariyesamānassa tam thusa koṭṭhake nipannam disvā sappaḥ nu
translated: And just as these three are the same in meaning, so too are equanimity about formations and equanimity of insight and equanimity of purification.🔽For this is simply understanding divided into three according to function.

original: kho no”ti avalokentassa sovatthikattayaṃ disvā nibbematikassa “sappo na sappo”ti🔽vicinane majjhattatā uppajjati, evameva yā āraddhavipassakassa vipassanāñāṇena lakkhaṇattaye
analyzed: kho no ti avalokentassa sovatthika ttayam disvā nibbematikassa sappaḥ na sappo ti  vicinane majjhatta tā uppajjati evam eva yā āraddha vipassakassa vipassanā ñāṇena lakkhaṇa ttaye
translated: Just as when a man has seen a snake go into his house in the evening and has hunted for it with a forked stick, and then when he has seen it lying in the grain store and has looked to discover whether it is actually a snake or not, and then when he has seen the three marks of a snake and has become certain, there arises in him neutrality about the investigation “snake or no snake?”;

original: diṭṭhe saṅkhārānaṃ aniccabhāvādivicinane majjhattatā uppajjati, ayaṃ vipassanupekkhā.
analyzed: diṭṭhe saṅkhārānam anicca bhāva ādi vicinane majjhatta tā uppajjati ayam vipassanā upekkhā
translated: so too, when a man has begun insight, there arises in him neutrality about the investigation of formations’ impermanence, etc., when the three characteristics have been seen with insight knowledge. This is equanimity of insight.

original: Yathā pana tassa purisassa ajapadadaṇḍakena gāḷhaṃ sappaṃ gahetvā “kintāhaṃ imaṃ
analyzed: yathā pana tassa purisassa aja pada daṇḍakena gāḷham sappam gahetvā kintā aham imaṃ
translated: But just as when the man has caught hold of the snake firmly with the forked stick and has looked to see which kind of snake it is, there arises in him neutrality about the investigation “poisonous or not poisonous?”;

original: sappaṃ aviheṭhento attānañca iminā aḍaṃsāpento muñceyya”nti muñcanākārameva pariyesato🔽gahaṇe majjhattatā hoti, evameva yā lakkhaṇattayassa diṭṭhattā āditte viya tayo bhave
analyzed: sappam a viheṭhentaḥ attānam ca iminā muñceyyanti muñcana ākāram eva pariyesato  gahaṇe majjhatta tā hoti evam eva yā lakkhaṇa ttayassa diṭṭha ttā āditte viya tayaḥ bhave
translated: When he is seeking the mode of letting go,🔽he is neutral about apprehending formations. So when he sees the three kinds of becoming as burning with the three kinds of suffering because he has seen the three characteristics,

original: passato saṅkhāraggahaṇe majjhattatā, ayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā. Iti vipassanupekkhāya siddhāya🔽saṅkhārupekkhāpi siddhāva hoti. Iminā panesā vicinanaggahaṇesu majjhattatāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: passataḥ saṅkhāra ggahaṇe majjhatta tā ayam saṅkhāra upekkhā iti vipassanā upekkhāya siddhāya  saṅkhāra upekkhā api hoti iminā pana isā vicinana ggahaṇesu majjhatta tā saṅkhātena
translated: he is neutral about apprehending formations. This is equanimity about formations. Thus when equanimity about insight is accomplished,🔽equanimity about formations is also accomplished. But this is twofold in function as neutrality about investigating and apprehending.

original: kiccena dvidhā bhinnāti. Vīriyupekkhā pana vedanupekkhā ca aññamaññañca avasesāhi
analyzed: kiccena dvidhā bhinnā ati vīriyupekkhā pana vedanupekkhā ca aññamaññam ca avasesāhi
translated: Equanimity of energy and equanimity about feelings are different in meaning from each other and from the rest.

original: ca atthato bhinnāyevāti. Āha cettha –
analyzed: ca atthataḥ bhinnāya iva ati āha ca ittha
translated: Herein, it may be stated as follows:

original: “Majjhattabrahmabojjhaṅgachaḷaṅgajhānasuddhiyo;🔽Vipassanā ca saṅkhāravedanāvīriyaṃ iti.🔽“Vitthārato dasopekkhā-chamajjhattādito tato;
analyzed: vipassanā ca saṅkhāra vedanā vīriyam iti  vitthārataḥ dasa upekkhā cham ajjhatta āditaḥ tatas
translated: Neutrality, the divine abidings, enlightenment factor of equanimity,🔽The six factors, jhāna purification, insight,🔽And formations, feelings, energy, thus these ten kinds of equanimity,

original: Duve paññā tato dvīhi, catassova bhavantimā”ti.
analyzed: duve paññā tatas dvīhi catassā uva
translated: Are classed as neutrality, etc., and then as insight, and so on.

original: Iti imāsu upekkhāsu jhānupekkhā idha adhippetā. Sā majjhattalakkhaṇā, anābhogarasā,
analyzed: iti imāsu upekkhāsu jhānupekkhā idha adhippetā sā majjhatta lakkhaṇā anābhoga rasā
translated: So among these kinds of equanimity, equanimity as a jhāna factor is intended here. It has the characteristic of neutrality. Its function is to be unconcerned, or its function is to abandon the concerns consisting in greed and hate. It is manifested as the removal of greed and hate.

original: abyāpārapaccupaṭṭhānā, pītivirāgapadaṭṭhānāti. Etthāha – “nanu cāyaṃ atthato tatramajjhattupekkhāva
analyzed: abyāpāra paccupaṭṭhānā pīti virāga padaṭṭhānā ti ettha āha nanu ca ayam atthato
translated: So it is among these kinds of equanimity that the equanimity of jhāna is intended here. It has the characteristic of neutrality. Its function is to abandon interference. It is manifested as non-aversion. Its proximate cause is the fading away of happiness. Here it may be asked: But is not this equanimity in fact equanimity as specific neutrality?

original: hoti, sā ca paṭhamadutiyajjhānesupi atthi. Tasmā tatrāpi ‘upekkhako ca viharatī’ti🔽evamayaṃ vattabbā siyā, sā kasmā na vuttā”ti? Aparibyattakiccato. Aparibyattañhi
analyzed: hoti sā ca paṭhama dutiya jhānesu pi atthi tasmā tatra api upekkhakaḥ ca viharati iti  evam ayam vattabbā siyā sā kasmā na vuttā iti a paribyatta kiccataḥ a paribyattam hi
translated: And that exists in the first and second jhānas too. So it should be said that he dwells in equanimity in those jhānas too. Why is it not said?

original: tassā tattha kiccaṃ, vitakkādīhi abhibhūtattā. Idha panāyaṃ vitakkavicārapītīhi anabhibhūtattā
analyzed: tassā tattha kiccam vitakka ādīhi idha pana ayam vitakka vicāra pītīhi an abhibhūta ttā
translated: Because its function is not paramount there. For its function there is not paramount, since it is surpassed by applied thought and the rest. But here it is paramount, since it is not surpassed by applied thought, etc.,

original: ukkhittasirā viya hutvā paribyattakiccā jātā, tasmā vuttāti.🔽Sato ca sampajānoti ettha saratīti sato. Sampajānātīti sampajāno. Iti puggalena sati
analyzed: ukkhitta sirā viya hutvā paribyatta kiccā jātā tasmā vuttā ati  sataḥ ca sampajānoti ettha sarati iti sataḥ sampajānāti iti sampajāno iti puggalena sati
translated: and so it is said.

original: ca sampajaññañca vuttaṃ. Tattha saraṇalakkhaṇā sati, asammussanarasā ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: ca sampajaññam ca vuttam tattha saraṇa lakkhaṇā sati a sammussana rasā ārakkha paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Mindful and fully aware: here he is mindful, thus he is mindful ; he is fully aware, thus he is fully aware . So it is a person that is called “mindful” and “fully aware” . Herein, mindfulness has the characteristic of remembering. Its function is to attend. It is manifested as guarding .

original: Asammohalakkhaṇaṃ sampajaññaṃ, tīraṇarasaṃ, pavicayapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: asammoha lakkhaṇam sampajaññam tīraṇa rasam pavicaya paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: Translation: Sampajaññaṃ asammohalakkhaṇaṃ, tīraṇarasmi, pavicayapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ |

original: Tattha kiñcāpi idaṃ satisampajaññaṃ purimajjhānesupi atthi, muṭṭhassatissa hi asampajānassa
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api idam sati sampajaññam purima jhānesu pi atthi muṭṭha satissa hi a sampajānassa
translated: Tattha kiñcāpi idaṃ satisampajaññaṃ purimajjhānesupi atthi, muṭṭhassatissa hi asampajānassa,

original: upacāramattampi na sampajjati, pageva appanā. Oḷārikattā pana tesaṃ jhānānaṃ bhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: upacāra mattam pi na sampajjati pagā iva appanā oḷārika ttā pana tesam jhānānam bhūmiyam
translated: upacāramattaṃpi na sampajjati, pageva appanā | Oḷārikattā pana tesaṃ jhānānaṃ bhūmiyaṃ,

original: viya purisassa cittassa gati sukhā hoti, abyattaṃ tattha satisampajaññakiccaṃ. Oḷārikaṅgappahānena
analyzed: viya purisassa cittassa gati sukhā hoti abyattam tattha sati sampajañña kiccam oḷārika aṅga ppahānena
translated: purisassa cittassa gati sukhā hoti, abyattaṃ tattha satisampajaññakiccaṃ | Oḷārikaṅgappahānena,

original: pana sukhumattā imassa jhānassa purisassa khuradhārāyaṃ viya satisampajaññakiccapariggahitā
analyzed: pana sukhuma ttā imassa jhānassa purisassa khura dhārā ayam viya sati sampajañña kicca pariggahitā
translated: sukhumattā imassa jhānassa purisassa khuradhārāyaṃ viya satisampajaññakiccapariggahitā,🔽eva cittassa gati icchitabbāti idheva vuttaṃ | Kiñca bhiyyo – yathā dhenupago vaccho,

original: eva cittassa gati icchitabbāti idheva vuttaṃ. Kiñca bhiyyo – yathā dhenupago vaccho🔽dhenuto apanīto arakkhiyamāno punadeva dhenuṃ upagacchati, evamidaṃ tatiyajjhānasukhaṃ🔽pītito apanītampi satisampajaññārakkhena arakkhiyamānaṃ punadeva pītiṃ upagaccheyya,
analyzed: eva cittassa gati icchitabbā ti idha iva vuttam kiñca bhiyyas yathā dhenu upagaḥ vacchaḥ 🔽dhenutaḥ apanītaḥ a rakkhiyamānaḥ punar eva dhenum upagacchati evam idam tatiya jhāna sukham 🔽pītitaḥ apanītam pi sati sampajaññā rakkhena a rakkhiyamānam punar eva pītim upagaccheyya
translated: dhenuto apanīto arakkhiyamāno

original: pītisampayuttameva siyā, sukhe vāpi sattā sārajjanti. Idañca atimadhurasukhaṃ, tato
analyzed: pīti sampayuttam eva siyā sukhe vā api sattā idam ca ati madhura sukham
translated: Or it may be associated with happiness. Or beings delight in the pleasure. But this is very sweet pleasure,

original: paraṃ sukhābhāvā. Satisampajaññānubhāvena panettha sukhe asārajjanā hoti, no aññathāti
analyzed: param sukha abhāvā sati sampajaññā anubhāvena pana ittha sukhe a sārajjanā hoti no aññathā ati
translated: and there is no pleasure higher than this. But it is because of the influence of mindfulness and full awareness that he does not delight in the pleasure here, and that is not otherwise.

original: imampi atthavisesaṃ dassetuṃ idamidheva vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Idāni sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedetīti ettha kiñcāpi tatiyajjhānasamaṅgino sukhapaṭisaṃvedanābhogo
analyzed: imam pi attha visesam dassetum idam idha iva vuttan ti veditabbam  idāni sukham ca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti iti ettha kiñca api tatiya jhāna samaṅgino sukha paṭisaṃvedanā bhogo
translated: So this special meaning should be understood as the reason why this is said.🔽Now, as to the words he feels pleasure with his body: although one possessing the third jhāna has no experiencing of pleasure, nevertheless there is pleasure associated with his mental body,

original: natthi, evaṃ santepi yasmā tassa nāmakāyena sampayuttaṃ sukhaṃ. Yaṃ vā taṃ nāmakāyasampayuttaṃ
analyzed: natthi evam sante pi yasmā tassa nāmakāyena sampayuttam sukham yam vā tam nāmakāya sampayuttam
translated: or the pleasure associated with his mental body is itself the experiencing.

original: sukhaṃ, taṃsamuṭṭhānenassa yasmā atipaṇītena rūpena rūpakāyo phuṭo, yassa phuṭattā🔽jhānā vuṭṭhitopi sukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeyya, tasmā etamatthaṃ dassento “sukhañca kāyena
analyzed: sukham yasmai ati paṇītena rūpena rūpa kāyaḥ phuṭaḥ yassa phuṭa ttā  jhānā vuṭṭhitaḥ api sukham paṭisaṃvedeyya tasmai etam attham dassento sukham ca kāyena
translated: And because his material body is touched by the very refined materiality originated by that,🔽he would feel pleasure even when he has emerged from the jhāna, since it is touched.

original: paṭisaṃvedetī”ti āha.
analyzed: āha
translated: So showing this meaning, he said: “He feels pleasure with his body” .

original: Idāni yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti ettha yaṃjhānahetu
analyzed: idāni yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti ettha yaṃ jhāna hetu
translated: Now, as to the words: The Noble Ones announce this kind of pleasure, saying: “It is equanimous and mindful, and has pleasure in it” ,

original: yaṃjhānakāraṇā taṃ tatiyajjhānasamaṅgīpuggalaṃ buddhādayo ariyā ācikkhanti desenti🔽paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti pakāsenti, pasaṃsantīti
analyzed: yaṃ jhāna kāraṇā tam tatiya jhāna samaṅgī puggalam buddha ādayaḥ ariyāḥ ācikkhanti desenti  paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti pakāsenti pasaṃsanti iti
translated: They praise him by commending him, by commending the third jhāna.🔽What do they praise? They praise him with the words “equanimous, mindful, one who experiences happiness,” and so on.

original: adhippāyo. Kinti? Upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti. Taṃ tatiyajjhānaṃ upasampajja viharatīti
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ kinti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti tam tatiya jhānam upasampajja viharati iti
translated: The meaning is this: “He enters upon and dwells in the third jhāna.”

original: evamettha yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: evam ettha yojanā veditabbā
translated: This is how the construction of the words should be understood here.

original: Kasmā pana taṃ te evaṃ pasaṃsantīti? Pasaṃsārahato. Ayañhi yasmā atimadhurasukhe
analyzed: kasmai pana tam te evam pasaṃsanti iti pasaṃsāra hataḥ ayan hi yasmai ati madhura sukhe
translated: But why do they praise him? Because he is worthy of praise. For this person is worthy of praise because,

original: sukhapāramippattepi tatiyajjhāne upekkhako, na tattha sukhābhisaṅgena ākaḍḍhīyati.🔽Yathā ca pīti na uppajjati, evaṃ upaṭṭhitasatitāya satimā. Yasmā ca ariyakantaṃ ariyajanasevitameva
analyzed: sukha pārami ppatte pi tatiya jhāne upekkhakaḥ na tattha sukha abhisaṅgena ākaḍḍhīyati  yathā ca pīti na uppajjati evam upaṭṭhita sati tāya satimā ca ariya kantam ariya jana sevitam eva
translated: in the third jhāna, which is supremely sweet and blissful, he is “equanimous,” that is, he is not drawn by the extreme bliss to abandon the second jhāna and take his stand in the first jhāna.🔽And because he is “mindful,” he is not drawn by the extreme bliss to abandon the third jhāna and take his stand in the first jhāna, as happens in the case of ordinary people who enjoy worldly pleasures, or in the second jhāna, as happens in the case of the first jhāna.

original: ca asaṃkiliṭṭhaṃ sukhaṃ nāmakāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, tasmā pasaṃsāraho. Iti pasaṃsārahato
analyzed: ca a saṃkiliṭṭham sukham nāmakāyena paṭisaṃvedeti tasmai iti
translated: And because he “experiences happiness with the body,” he is worthy of praise because he experiences the kind of happiness that is dear to noble ones, that is, happiness that is untainted and approved by the wise.

original: naṃ ariyā te evaṃ pasaṃsāhetubhūte guṇe pakāsento “upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī”ti
analyzed: naṃ ariyā te evam pasaṃsā hetu bhūte guṇe pakāsento upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti
translated: He is equanimous, mindful, experiencing happiness with the body.🔽He is to be understood as praising the qualities that are the grounds for praise in this way.

original: evaṃ pasaṃsantīti veditabbaṃ. Tatiyanti gaṇanānupubbatā tatiyaṃ, idaṃ tatiyaṃ uppannantipi tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: evam pasaṃsanti iti veditabbam tatiyanti gaṇanā anupubba tā tatiyam idam tatiyam uppannam tipi tatiyam
translated: The third: it is the third in the numerical series; it is the third to arise;

original: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānāti kāyikasukhassa ca kāyikadukkhassa ca pahānā.
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā ati kāyika sukhassa ca kāyika dukkhassa ca pahānā
translated: Abandoning pleasure, abandoning pain: abandoning bodily pleasure, abandoning bodily pain.

original: Pubbevāti tañca kho pubbeva, na catutthajjhānakkhaṇe. Somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāti
analyzed: pubbā iva ati tat ca kho pubbā iva na catuttha jhāna kkhaṇe somanassa domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā ati
translated: And previously: and that previously, not at the moment of the fourth jhāna. With the disappearance of former happiness and former unhappiness:🔽with the disappearance of former mental pleasure and former mental pain.

original: cetasikasukhassa ca cetasikadukkhassa cāti imesampi dvinnaṃ pubbeva atthaṅgamā, pahānā icceva vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Kadā pana nesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti? Catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ upacārakkhaṇe. Somanassañhi catutthajjhānassa
analyzed: cetasika sukhassa ca cetasika dukkhassa ca ati imesam pi dvinnam pubbā iva atthaṅgamā pahānā iccā iva vuttam hoti  kadā pana nesam pahānam hoti catunnam jhānānam upacāra kkhaṇe somanassam hi catuttha jhānassa
translated: With the disappearance of both former happiness and former unhappiness: with the disappearance of both these two, namely, mental pleasure and mental pain.🔽Abandoning: thus it is the abandoning of these two that is referred to.

original: upacārakkhaṇeyeva pahīyati, dukkhadomanassasukhāni paṭhamadutiyatatiyajjhānānaṃ upacārakkhaṇesu.
analyzed: upacāra kkhaṇe iya iva pahīyati dukkha domanassa sukhāni paṭhama dutiya tatiya jhānānam upacāra kkhaṇesu
translated: But when is there the abandoning of these? At the moment of the access of the four jhānas. For the mental pleasure of the fourth jhāna is abandoned at the moment of its access. The pain, displeasure, and pleasure of the first, second, and third jhānas are abandoned at the moments of their respective accesses.

original: Evametesaṃ pahānakkamena avuttānaṃ, indriyavibhaṅge pana indriyānaṃ uddesakkameneva
analyzed: evam etesam pahāna kkamena avuttānam indriya vibhaṅge pana indriyānam uddesa kkamena iva
translated: So too, though these have not been mentioned in the order of abandoning, their abandoning should be understood as stated in the Description of the Faculties in the order of the faculties.

original: idhāpi vuttānaṃ sukhadukkhasomanassadomanassānaṃ pahānaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Yadi panetāni tassa tassa jhānassa upacārakkhaṇeyeva pahīyanti, atha kasmā “kattha🔽cuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhati? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva
analyzed: idha api vuttānam sukha dukkha somanassa domanassānam pahānam veditabbam  yadi pana etāni tassa tassa jhānassa upacāra kkhaṇeya iva pahīyanti atha kasmā kattha  cuppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam nirujjhati idha bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva
translated: And the abandoning of the pleasure faculty, pain faculty, joy faculty, and grief faculty should be understood in the same way as stated here in the order of the faculties.

original: kāmehi…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettha cuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ
analyzed: kāmehipe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati ettha cuppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam
translated: But if these are abandoned only at the moment of access concentration to the respective jhānas, then why is it said in the way beginning, “Where does the arisen pain faculty cease without remainder? Here a bhikkhu … enters upon and dwells in the first jhāna … It is here that the arisen pain faculty ceases without remainder” ,

original: nirujjhati. Kattha cuppannaṃ domanassindriyaṃ… sukhindriyaṃ… somanassindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ🔽nirujjhati? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, sukhassa ca pahānā…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja🔽viharati. Ettha cuppannaṃ somanassindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhatī”ti evaṃ jhānesveva
analyzed: nirujjhati kattha cuppannam domanassa indriyam sukha indriyam somanassa indriyam aparisesam 🔽nirujjhati idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānāpe catuttham jhānam upasampajja 🔽viharati ettha cuppannam somanassindriyam aparisesam nirujjhati iti evam jhānesu eva
translated: and similarly in the case of the grief faculty, the pleasure faculty, and the joy faculty?

original: nirodho vuttoti. Atisayanirodhattā. Atisayanirodho hi nesaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīsu, na
analyzed: nirodho vutto ti atisaya nirodhattā atisaya nirodho hi nesam paṭhamajjhāna ādīsu na
translated: Cessation is mentioned. Because of the cessation of excess. For their cessation is an excess in the first jhāna, etc.,

original: nirodhoyeva. Nirodhoyeva pana upacārakkhaṇe nātisayanirodho.
analyzed: nirodho yā iva nirodho yā iva pana upacāra kkhaṇe na ati saya nirodho
translated: but it is not cessation as such. But in the first-jhāna access it is cessation as such, not an excess.

original: Tathā hi nānāvajjane paṭhamajjhānūpacāre niruddhassāpi dukkhindriyassa ḍaṃsamakasādisamphassena
analyzed: tathā hi nānā vajjane paṭhama jhānu upacāre niruddhassa api dukkha indriyassa ḍaṃsama kasā ādi samphassena
translated: For although the pain faculty has ceased in the first-jhāna access, which is a single-area , it can arise again through contact with gadflies, flies, etc., or with unevenness of the postures,

original: vā visamāsanupatāpena vā siyā uppatti, na tveva antoappanāyaṃ. Upacāre vā niruddhampetaṃ
analyzed: vā vā upacāre vā
translated: but not in the first jhāna. Or again, although it has ceased in the access, it has not ceased well,

original: na suṭṭhu niruddhaṃ hoti, paṭipakkhena avihatattā. Antoappanāyaṃ pana pītipharaṇena
analyzed: na suṭṭhu niruddham hoti paṭipakkhena a vihata ttā antoappanāyam pana pīti pharaṇena
translated: because it has not been suppressed by its opposite. But in the first jhāna it has ceased in both ways.

original: sabbo kāyo sukhokkanto hoti, sukhokkantakāyassa ca suṭṭhu niruddhaṃ hoti dukkhindriyaṃ,
analyzed: sabbo kāyaḥ sukha ukkantaḥ hoti sukha ukkanta kāyassa ca suṭṭhu niruddham hoti dukkha indriyam
translated: And when the happiness pervades the whole body, the pain faculty has ceased there too because of being suppressed by its opposite.

original: paṭipakkhena vihatattā. Nānāvajjaneyeva ca dutiyajjhānūpacāre pahīnassāpi domanassindriyassa
analyzed: paṭipakkhena vihata ttā ca dutiya jhāna upacāre pahīnassa api domanassindriyassa
translated: And although the grief faculty has been abandoned in the second-jhāna access, which is a single-area ,

original: yasmā etaṃ vitakkavicārapaccayepi kāyakilamathe cittupaghāte ca sati uppajjati, vitakkavicārābhāve
analyzed: yasmai etam vitakka vicāra paccaye pi kāya kilamathe citta upaghāte ca sati uppajjati vitakka vicāra abhāve
translated: it can arise again if there is bodily weariness and mental vexation due to the conditions for it, but not in the second jhāna.

original: neva uppajjati. Yattha pana uppajjati, tattha vitakkavicārabhāve. Appahīnāyeva ca
analyzed: na iva uppajjati yattha pana uppajjati tattha vitakka vicāra bhāve ca
translated: but it does not arise where they do.🔽But it may arise in the second-jhāna access, though not in the second jhāna itself,

original: dutiyajjhānūpacāre vitakkavicārāti tatthassa siyā uppatti, na tveva dutiyajjhāne,🔽pahīnappaccayattā. Tathā tatiyajjhānūpacāre pahīnassāpi sukhindriyassa pītisamuṭṭhānapaṇītarūpaphuṭakāyassa
analyzed: dutiya jhāna upacāre vitakka vicārā ti tattha siyā uppatti na tu eva dutiya jhāne  pahīna ppaccaya ttā tathā tatiya jhāna upacāre pahīnassa api sukha indriyassa pīti samuṭṭhāna paṇīta rūpa phuṭa kāyassa
translated: because the condition for it has not been completely abandoned there.🔽So too, it may arise in the third-jhāna access, though not in the third jhāna itself, because the faculty of pleasure, though abandoned there, arises in one whose body is affected by the superior materiality originated by the happiness.

original: siyā uppatti, na tveva tatiyajjhāne. Tatiyajjhāne hi sukhassa paccayabhūtā pīti sabbaso🔽niruddhāti. Tathā catutthajjhānūpacāre pahīnassāpi somanassindriyassa āsannattā,
analyzed: siyā uppatti na tu eva tatiya jhāne tatiya jhāne hi sukhassa paccaya bhūtā pi iti sabbaso  niruddhā iti tathā catuttha jjhāna upacāre pahīnassa api somanassindriyassa āsanna ttā
translated: For in the third jhāna happiness, which is the condition for the faculty of pleasure, is quite suppressed.🔽So too, it may arise in the fourth-jhāna access, though not in the fourth jhāna itself, because the faculty of joy, though abandoned there, is near,

original: appanāpattāya upekkhāya abhāvena sammā anatikkantattā ca siyā uppatti, na tveva catutthajjhāne.
analyzed: appanā āpattāya upekkhāya abhāvena sammā an atikkanta ttā ca siyā uppatti na tu eva catuttha jjhāne
translated: and because the equanimity that has reached absorption has not quite overcome the faculty of grief.

original: Tasmā eva ca “etthuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhatī”ti tattha tattha aparisesaggahaṇaṃ katanti.
analyzed: tasmai eva ca ettha uppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam nirujjhati iti tattha tattha aparisesa ggahaṇam katanti
translated: That is why the words “Any pain faculty that has arisen here ceases completely” are said in each case with the words “without remainder.”

original: Etthāha – “athevaṃ tassa tassa jhānassupacāre pahīnāpi etā vedanā idha kasmā samāhaṭā”ti?
analyzed: ettha āha atha ivam tassa tassa jhānassa upacāre pahīnā api etāḥ vedanā idha kasmā
translated: Here it may be asked: “But if these feelings are abandoned in the preparatory stage of each jhāna, why are they mentioned here?”🔽For the purpose of easy comprehension. For the feeling called neither-painful-nor-pleasant,

original: Sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ. Yā hi ayaṃ adukkhamasukhanti ettha adukkhamasukhā vedanā vuttā,
analyzed: sukha ggahaṇa attham yā hi ayam adukkham asukhanti ettha adukkham asukhā vedanā vuttā
translated: which is mentioned here in the phrase “neither-painful-nor-pleasant” ,

original: sā sukhumā dubbiññeyyā, na sakkā sukhena gahetuṃ, tasmā yathā nāma duṭṭhassa yathā
analyzed: sā sukhumā dubbiññeyyā na sakkā sukhena gahetum tasmā yathā nāma duṭṭhassa yathā
translated: is subtle and hard to recognize. It cannot be easily grasped. Therefore, just as a cowherd uses a stick

original: vā tathā vā upasaṅkamitvā gahetuṃ asakkuṇeyyassa goṇassa sukhagahaṇatthaṃ gopo ekasmiṃ🔽vaje sabbā gāvo samāharati, athekekaṃ nīharanto paṭipāṭiyā āgataṃ “ayaṃ so gaṇhatha
analyzed: vā tathā vā upasaṅkamitvā gahetum a sakkuṇeyyassa goṇassa sukha gahaṇa attham gopaḥ ekasmin  vaje sabbāḥ gāvaḥ samāharati atha ekekam nīharantaḥ paṭipāṭiyā āgatam ayam saḥ gaṇhatha
translated: to gather all the cows together into one place in order to easily milk them,

original: na”nti tampi gāhāpeti, evameva bhagavā sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ sabbā etā samāharīti. Evañhi🔽samāhaṭā etā dassetvā “yaṃ neva sukhaṃ, na dukkhaṃ, na somanassaṃ, na domanassaṃ,
analyzed: tam pi gāhāpeti evam eva bhagavā sukha ggahaṇa attham sabbā etā samāhari iti evam hi  samāhaṭāḥ etāḥ dassetvā yam na iva sukham na dukkham na somanassam na domanassam
translated: so too the Blessed One gathered all these feelings together in order to easily grasp them.

original: ayaṃ adukkhamasukhā vedanā”ti sakkā hoti esā gāhayituṃ.
analyzed: ayam adukkham asukhā vedanā ati sakkā hoti esā gāhayituṃ
translated: For when they are shown gathered together in this way, it is possible to grasp them thus: “That which is neither painful nor pleasant is the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.”

original: Api ca adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā paccayadassanatthañcāpi etā vuttāti veditabbā.🔽Dukkhappahānādayo hi tassā paccayā. Yathāha – “cattāro kho, āvuso, paccayā adukkhamasukhāya🔽cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā. Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: api ca adukkha masukhāya cetaḥ vimuttiyāḥ paccaya dassana ttham ca api etā vuttā iti veditabbā  dukkha ppahāna ādayaḥ hi tassā paccayāḥ yathā āha cattāro kho āvuso paccayāḥ adukkhamasukhāya  cetaḥ vimuttiyā samāpattiyā idha āvuso bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānaṃ
translated: But they should be understood as stated here in order to show the conditions for the third jhāna.

original: upasampajja viharati. Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā🔽samāpattiyā”ti. Yathā vā aññattha pahīnāpi sakkāyadiṭṭhiādayo tatiyamaggassa vaṇṇabhaṇanatthaṃ
analyzed: upasampajja viharati ime kho āvuso cattāro paccayāḥ adukkhamasukhāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā  samāpattiyā iti yathā vā aññattha pahīnā api sakkāya diṭṭhi ādayaḥ tatiya maggassa vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham
translated: For the abandoning of pain, etc., are its conditions. As it is said: “There are four conditions, friend, for the attainment of the third jhāna. Here, friend, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief a bhikkhu enters upon and dwells in the fourth jhāna … equanimity. These are the four conditions for the attainment of the third jhāna” .

original: “tattha pahīnā”ti vuttā, evaṃ vaṇṇabhaṇanatthampetassa jhānassetā idha vuttātipi
analyzed: tattha pahīnā ati vuttā evam vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham petassa jhānassa etāḥ idha vuttā ati pi
translated: Or just as elsewhere the view of existence, etc., are stated as “abandoned” in the description of the third path though they are in fact only weakened there, so too these states are stated here in the description of the third jhāna though they are in fact only weakened there.

original: veditabbā. Paccayaghātena vā ettha rāgadosānaṃ atidūrabhāvaṃ dassetumpetā vuttāti
analyzed: veditabbā paccaya ghātena vā ettha rāga dosānam ati dūra bhāvam dassetum petā vuttā iti
translated: Or alternatively, they are stated here in order to show that the third jhāna is far from greed and hate by the fact that their conditions are suppressed.

original: veditabbā. Etāsu hi sukhaṃ somanassassa paccayo, somanassaṃ rāgassa, dukkhaṃ domanassassa,
analyzed: veditabbāḥ etāsu hi sukham somanassassa paccayaḥ somanassam rāgassa dukkham domanassassa
translated: For pleasure is a condition for joy, and joy for greed; pain is a condition for grief, and grief for hate;

original: domanassaṃ dosassa. Sukhādighātena ca te sappaccayā rāgadosā hatāti atidūre hontīti.🔽Adukkhamasukhanti dukkhābhāvena adukkhaṃ, sukhābhāvena asukhaṃ. Etenettha sukhadukkhapaṭipakkhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: domanassam dosassa sukha ādi ghātena ca te sappaccayāḥ rāga dosāḥ hatā ati atidūre honti iti  adukkham asukhanti dukkha abhāvena adukkham sukha abhāvena asukham etena ittha sukha dukkha paṭipakkha bhūtam
translated: and grief is due to hate. And by the impact of pleasure, etc., these, namely, greed, hate, and delusion, are very far away indeed.🔽Neither-painful-nor-pleasant: it is not painful because of the absence of pain, and it is not pleasant because of the absence of pleasure. By this he shows that the third kind of feeling is the opposite of pleasure and pain,

original: tatiyavedanaṃ dīpeti, na dukkhasukhābhāvamattaṃ. Tatiyavedanā nāma adukkhamasukhā,
analyzed: tatiya vedanam dīpeti na dukkha sukha abhāva mattam tatiya vedanā nāma adukkham asukhā
translated: not just the absence of pleasure and pain. The third kind of feeling is called neither-painful-nor-pleasant,

original: upekkhātipi vuccati. Sā iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītānubhavanalakkhaṇā, majjhattarasā, avibhūtapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: upekkhā ati pi vuccati sā iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparīta anubhavana lakkhaṇā majjhatta rasā avibhūta paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: and it is also called equanimity. Its characteristic is the experiencing of what is contrary to pleasure and pain. Its function is to taste the neutral. It is manifested as non-excess.

original: sukhanirodhapadaṭṭhānāti veditabbā.
analyzed: sukha nirodha padaṭṭhānā ti veditabbā
translated: Its proximate cause should be understood as the cessation of pleasure.

original: Upekkhāsatipārisuddhinti upekkhāya janitasatipārisuddhiṃ. Imasmiñhi jhāne suparisuddhā
analyzed: upekkhā sati pārisuddhim ti upekkhāya janita sati pārisuddhim imasmin hi jhāne su parisuddhā
translated: Purity of mindfulness due to equanimity: the purity of mindfulness due to equanimity. For in this jhāna mindfulness is very pure,

original: sati, yā ca tassā satiyā pārisuddhi, sā upekkhāya katā, na aññena. Tasmā etaṃ “upekkhāsatipārisuddhi”nti
analyzed: sati yā ca tassā satiyā pārisuddhi sā upekkhāya katā na aññena tasmai etam upekkhā sati pārisuddhinti
translated: and that purity of mindfulness is due to equanimity, not to anything else. That is why it is said to be “purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.”

original: vuccati. Yāya ca upekkhāya ettha sati pārisuddhi hoti, sā atthato tatramajjhattatāti
analyzed: vuccati yāya ca upekkhāya ettha sati pārisuddhi hoti sā atthato tatram ajjhatta tā ati
translated: And the equanimity due to which there is purity of mindfulness here is, in fact, the equanimity of the fourth jhāna.

original: veditabbā. Na kevalañcettha tāya satiyeva parisuddhā, api ca kho sabbepi sampayuttadhammā,
analyzed: veditabbāḥ na kevalam ca ittha tāya satiyā iva parisuddhāḥ api ca kho sabbe pi sampayutta dhammāḥ
translated: And not only is it purified by that mindfulness, but also all the associated states.

original: satisīsena pana desanā vuttā.
analyzed: pana desanā vuttā
translated: But it is called “mindfulness” in the sense of the head, as it were.🔽Herein, although this equanimity exists in the three lower jhānas, nevertheless, just as,

original: Tattha kiñcāpi ayaṃ upekkhā heṭṭhāpi tīsu jhānesu vijjati, yathā pana divā sūriyappabhābhibhavā🔽sommabhāvena ca attano upakārakattena vā sabhāgāya rattiyā alābhā divā vijjamānāpi
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api ayam upekkhā heṭṭhā api tīsu jhānesu vijjati yathā pana divā sūriya ppabhā abhibhavā  somma bhāvena ca attanaḥ upakāraka ttena vā sabhāgāya rattiyāḥ alābhā divā vijjamānā api
translated: because of being overcome by the radiance of the sun🔽or because of the absence of the moon’s helpfulness, the line of the moon’s path,

original: candalekhā aparisuddhā hoti apariyodātā, evamayampi tatramajjhattupekkhācandalekhā
analyzed: canda lekhā a parisuddhā hoti a pariyodātā evam ayam pi tatra majjhattu pekkhā canda lekhā
translated: though existing by day, is impure and not purified,🔽so too, this line of equanimity in the third jhāna,

original: vitakkādipaccanīkadhammatejābhibhavā sabhāgāya ca upekkhāvedanārattiyā apaṭilābhā
analyzed: vitakka ādi paccanīka dhamma teja abhibhavā sabhāgāya ca upekkhā vedanā rattiyā a paṭilābhā
translated: being overcome by the glare of the opposing states consisting of applied thought, etc., and because of the absence of the helpfulness of the equanimity feeling associated with pleasant feeling,

original: vijjamānāpi paṭhamajjhānādibhedesu aparisuddhā hoti. Tassā ca aparisuddhāya divā
analyzed: vijjamānā api paṭhamajjhāna ādi bhedesu aparisuddhā hoti tassā ca aparisuddhāya divā
translated: though existing in the first jhāna, etc., is impure.

original: aparisuddhacandalekhāya pabhā viya sahajātāpi satiādayo aparisuddhāva honti. Tasmā
analyzed: pabhā sahajātāḥ api honti tasmā
translated: And because it is impure, the associated mindfulness, etc., are also impure, like the radiance of the impure line of the moon’s path by day.

original: tesu ekampi “upekkhāsatipārisuddhi”nti na vuttaṃ. Idha pana vitakkādipaccanīkadhammatejābhibhavābhāvā🔽sabhāgāya ca upekkhāvedanārattiyā paṭilābhā ayaṃ tatramajjhattupekkhācandalekhā ativiya🔽parisuddhā, tassā parisuddhattā parisuddhacandalekhāya pabhā viya sahajātāpi satiādayo
analyzed: tesu ekam pi upekkhā sati pārisuddhin ti na vuttam idha pana vitakka ādi paccanīka dhamma teja abhibhava abhāvā  sa bhāgāya ca upekkhā vedanā rattiyā paṭilābhā ayam tatra majjhatta upekkhā candalekhā  parisuddhā tassā parisuddha ttā parisuddha canda lekhāya pabhā sahajātā api
translated: But none of them is called “purity of equanimity and mindfulness. ” But here, because there is no suppression of the defilements opposed to applied thought, etc.,🔽and because of the acquisition of the day-to-day equanimity of feeling that is in conformity with it, the streak of equanimity consisting in specific neutrality is very pure,

original: parisuddhā honti pariyodātā. Tasmā idameva “upekkhāsatipārisuddhi”nti vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: parisuddhāḥ honti pariyodātā tasmai idam eva upekkhā sati pārisuddhin ti vuttam ti veditabbam
translated: and because of its purity, the associated mindfulness, etc., are also pure and clear, like the light of the streak of a gem. That is why it should be understood that this jhāna is called “purity of equanimity and mindfulness. ”

original: Catutthanti gaṇanānupubbatā catutthaṃ. Idaṃ catutthaṃ uppannantipi catutthaṃ.🔽Paññavā hotīti paññā assa atthīti paññavā. Udayatthagāminiyāti udayagāminiyā ceva
analyzed: catuttham ti gaṇanā anupubba tā catuttham idam catuttham uppannam tipi catuttham  paññavā hoti iti paññā assa atthi iti paññavā udaya ttha gāminiyā ati udaya gāminiyā ca iva
translated: Fourth: it is the fourth in numerical order, and fourth in the order of development. It is the fourth to arise, thus it is the fourth.

original: atthagāminiyā ca. Samannāgatoti paripuṇṇo. Ariyāyāti niddosāya. Nibbedhikāyāti nibbedhapakkhikāya.
analyzed: attha gāminiyā ca samannāgato ti paripuṇṇaḥ ariyāya ati niddosāya nibbedhikāya ati nibbedha pakkhikāya
translated: He is wise: he has wisdom, thus he is wise. Possessed of … that penetrates to the … origin and passing away: he is possessed of the wisdom that penetrates to the origin and passing away of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: Dukkhakkhayagāminiyāti nibbānagāminiyā. So idaṃ dukkhanti evamādīsu “ettakaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: dukkha kkhaya gāminiyā ti nibbāna gāminiyā saḥ idam dukkhan ti evamādīsu ettakam dukkham
translated: Leading to the destruction of suffering means leading to Nibbāna. He understands as it really is, penetrates, by the penetration of the individual essences of the taste of the entire truth of suffering in the passages beginning “This is suffering” and so on, thinking “Suffering is just this much,🔽no more than this.”

original: na ito bhiyyo”ti sabbampi dukkhasaccaṃ sarasalakkhaṇapaṭivedhena yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti🔽paṭivijjhati. Tassa ca dukkhassa nibbattikaṃ taṇhaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo”ti. Tadubhayampi🔽yaṃ ṭhānaṃ patvā nirujjhati, taṃ tesaṃ appavattiṃ nibbānaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhanirodho”ti.🔽Tassa ca sampāpakaṃ ariyamaggaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā”ti sarasalakkhaṇapaṭivedhena
analyzed: na itas bhiyyas ti sabbam pi dukkha saccam sa rasa lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena yathābhūtam pajānāti  paṭivijjhati tassa ca dukkhassa nibbattikam taṇham ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti tat ubhayam pi  yam ṭhānam patvā nirujjhati tam tesam appavattim nibbānam ayam dukkha nirodho ti  tassa ca sampāpakam ariya maggam ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati sa rasa lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena
translated: He understands as it really is, penetrates, by the penetration of the individual essences of the taste of the entire truth of the origin of suffering in the passage “This is the origin of suffering” as craving which is the cause of that suffering.🔽He understands as it really is, penetrates, by the penetration of the individual essences of the taste of the entire truth of the cessation of suffering in the passage “This is the cessation of suffering” as the cessation of both of them, that is, of suffering and its origin, which occurs when they reach a state beyond their occurrence.

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti paṭivijjhatīti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti paṭivijjhati iti evamatthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: He understands as it really is, penetrates, by the penetration of the individual essences of the taste of the entire truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering in the passage “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering” as the noble path which causes the attainment of that cessation. This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: Evaṃ sarūpato saccāni dassetvā idāni kilesavasena pariyāyato dassento “ime āsavā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: evam sarūpataḥ saccāni dassetvā idāni kilesa vasena pariyāyataḥ dassentaḥ ime āsavā ti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the truths in their individual essences, he now shows them by way of the defilements, saying “These are the taints” and so on.

original: Te vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Evaṃ tisso sikkhāyo dassetvā idāni tāsaṃ pāripūrikkamaṃ
analyzed: te vutta nayena iva veditabbāḥ evam tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ dassetvā idāni tāsam pāripūrikkamam
translated: These should be understood in the way already stated. Having thus shown the three trainings, he now shows the order in which they are perfected.

original: dassetuṃ “imā tisso sikkhāyo āvajjanto sikkheyyā”tiādimāha. Tassattho – paccekaṃ
analyzed: dassetum imāḥ tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ āvajjanto sikkheyya iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ paccekam
translated: He says this in order to show the three trainings. The meaning is: he should train by adverting to them in order to fulfil them each in its own way.

original: paripūretuṃ āvajjantopi sikkheyya, āvajjitvāpi “ayaṃ nāma sikkhā”ti jānantopi sikkheyya,
analyzed: paripūretum āvajjantaḥ api sikkheyya āvajjitvā api ayam nāma sikkhāti jānantaḥ api sikkheyya
translated: He should train by adverting and by knowing “This is the training.”🔽He should train by seeing again and again what he has known.

original: jānitvā punappunaṃ passantopi sikkheyya, passitvā yathādiṭṭhaṃ paccavekkhantopi sikkheyya,
analyzed: jānitvā punappunam passantaḥ api sikkheyya passitvā yathādiṭṭham paccavekkhantaḥ api sikkheyya
translated: He should train by reviewing what he has seen as he has seen it.🔽He should train by establishing his mind in that same object without wavering.

original: paccavekkhitvā tattheva cittaṃ acalaṃ katvā patiṭṭhapentopi sikkheyya, taṃtaṃsikkhāsampayuttasaddhāvīriyasatisamādhipaññāhi
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā tattha iva cittam acalam katvā patiṭṭhapentaḥ api sikkheyya tad tad sikkhā sampayutta saddhā vīriya sati samādhi paññāhi
translated: He should train by performing the several functions of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding associated with the several trainings.

original: sakasakakiccaṃ karontopi sikkheyya, abhiññeyyābhijānanakālepi taṃ taṃ kiccaṃ karontopi
analyzed: sakasaka kiccam karontaḥ api sikkheyya abhiññeyya abhijānana kāle pi tam tam kiccam karontaḥ api
translated: He should train by performing the several functions at the time of the direct knowledges.

original: tisso sikkhāyo sikkheyya, adhisīlaṃ ācareyya, adhicittaṃ sammā careyya, adhipaññaṃ samādāya vatteyya.
analyzed: tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ sikkheyya adhi sīlam ācareyya adhi cittam sammā careyya adhi paññam samādāya vatteyya
translated: He should train in the three trainings. He should observe the higher virtue, he should pursue the higher consciousness, he should undertake the higher understanding.

original: Idhāti mūlapadaṃ. Imissā diṭṭhiyātiādīhi dasahi padehi sikkhattayasaṅkhātaṃ sabbaññubuddhasāsanameva
analyzed: idha āti mūla padam imissā diṭṭhiyā ati ādīhi dasahi padehi sikkhattaya saṅkhātam sabbaññu buddha sāsanam eva
translated: Here: this is the basic expression. The Blessed One’s Dispensation, which is called “the three trainings,” is referred to by the ten terms beginning with “this view.”

original: kathitaṃ. Tañhi buddhena bhagavatā diṭṭhattā diṭṭhīti vuccati. Tasseva khamanavasena
analyzed: kathitam tat hi buddhena bhagavatā diṭṭhattā diṭṭhī iti vuccati tassa iva khamana vasena
translated: It is called “view” because it is seen by the Blessed One. It is called “acceptance” because it is accepted by him.

original: khanti, ruccanavasena ruci, gahaṇavasena ādāyo, sabhāvaṭṭhena dhammo, sikkhitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: khanti ruccana vasena ruci gahaṇa vasena ādāyo sabhāva ṭhena dhammo sikkhitabba ṭṭhena
translated: It is called “interest” because he is interested in it. It is called “adoption” because he adopts it. It is called “Dhamma” because it has its own individual essence.

original: vinayo, tadubhayenapi dhammavinayo, pavuttavasena pāvacanaṃ, seṭṭhacariyaṭṭhena brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: vinayo tad ubhayena api dhamma vinayo pavutta vasena seṭṭha cariya ṭṭhena brahmacariyam
translated: It is called “discipline” because it should be practised. It is called “Dhamma and discipline” because it is both. It is called “the good way” because it is the way to the good.

original: anusiṭṭhidānavasena satthusāsananti vuccati. Tasmā “imissā diṭṭhiyā”tiādīsu imissā🔽buddhadiṭṭhiyā imissā buddhakhantiyā imissā buddharuciyā imasmiṃ buddhaādāye imasmiṃ
analyzed: anusiṭṭhi dāna vasena satthu sāsananti vuccati tasmai imissā diṭṭhiyā tiādīsu imissā  buddha diṭṭhiyāḥ imissā buddha khantiyāḥ imissāḥ buddha ruciyāḥ imasmin buddha ādāye imasmin
translated: It is called “the holy life” because it is the best way. It is called “the Teacher’s Dispensation” because it is given by the Teacher.

original: buddhadhamme imasmiṃ buddhavinaye.
analyzed: buddha dhamme imasmim buddha vinaye
translated: Therefore, in the passage beginning “in this view” , “in this view of the Buddha” should be understood as “in this acceptance of the Buddha,” “in this interest in the Buddha,” “in this adoption of the Buddha,” “in this Dhamma of the Buddha,” “in this discipline of the Buddha.”

original: “Ye kho tvaṃ, gotami, dhamme jāneyyāsi ‘ime dhammā sarāgāya saṃvattanti, no virāgāya,
analyzed: ye kho tvam gotami dhamme jāneyyāsi ime dhammā sa rāgāya saṃvattanti no virāgāya
translated: “Whatever things, Gotami, you know to be conducive to passion, not to non-passion,

original: saññogāya saṃvattanti, no visaññogāya, ācayāya saṃvattanti, no apacayāya, mahicchatāya
analyzed: saññogāya saṃvattanti no visaññogāya ācayāya saṃvattanti no apacayāya mahicchatāya
translated: conducive to bondage, not to the absence of bondage, conducive to accumulation, not to the absence of accumulation, conducive to great desires, not to the absence of great desires,

original: saṃvattanti, no appicchatāya, asantuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti, no santuṭṭhiyā, saṅgaṇikāya🔽saṃvattanti, no pavivekāya, kosajjāya saṃvattanti, no vīriyārambhāya, dubbharatāya🔽saṃvattanti, no subharatāyā’ti. Ekaṃsena, gotami, dhāreyyāsi ‘neso dhammo, neso vinayo,
analyzed: saṃvattanti naḥ appicchatāya a santuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti no santuṭṭhiyā saṅgaṇikāya  saṃvattanti no pavivekāya kosajjāya saṃvattanti no vīriya ārambhāya dubbharatāya  saṃvattanti naḥ subharatāya ati ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyāsi na isaḥ dhammo na isaḥ vinayo
translated: They lead to discontent, not to contentment; to socializing, not to seclusion;🔽to laziness, not to being energetic; to being difficult to support, not to being easy to support.’

original: netaṃ satthusāsana’nti.
analyzed: na itam satthu sāsanam ti
translated: You should definitely remember this as: ‘This is not Dhamma, this is not the Teaching, this is not the Teacher’s instruction.’

original: “Ye ca kho tvaṃ, gotami, dhamme jāneyyāsi ‘ime dhammā virāgāya saṃvattanti, no sarāgāya…pe…🔽subharatāya saṃvattanti, no dubbharatāyā’ti. Ekaṃsena, gotami, dhāreyyāsi ‘eso dhammo,
analyzed: ye ca kho tvam gotami dhamme jāneyyāsi ime dhammāḥ virāgāya saṃvattanti no sa rāgāya pe  subharatāya saṃvattanti no dubbharatāya ati ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyāsi esaḥ dhammo
translated: “But, Gotami, you should definitely remember this as: ‘Those things that you know lead to passion, not to dispassion …🔽to being easy to support, not to being difficult to support.’

original: eso vinayo, etaṃ satthusāsana”’nti –
analyzed: esaḥ vinayaḥ etam satthu sāsanam ti
translated: You should definitely remember this as: ‘This is Dhamma, this is the Teaching, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

original: Evaṃ vutte imasmiṃ buddhadhammavinaye imasmiṃ buddhapāvacane imasmiṃ buddhabrahmacariye imasmiṃ buddhasāsaneti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: evam vutte imasmim buddha dhamma vinaye imasmim buddha pāvacane imasmim buddha brahmacariye imasmim buddha sāsane iti evamatthaḥ veditabbo
translated: When this was said, the meaning of this should be understood in this way: in this Dhamma and Discipline, in this instruction, in this spiritual life, in this Teaching.

original: Api cetaṃ sikkhattayasaṅkhātaṃ sakalaṃ sāsanaṃ bhagavatā diṭṭhattā sammādiṭṭhipaccayattā
analyzed: api ca itam sikkhattaya saṅkhātam sakalam sāsanam bhagavatā diṭṭha ttā sammādiṭṭhi paccaya ttā
translated: And this Dispensation, which is called the “three trainings,” is the view because it is the condition for right view since it is seen by the Blessed One,

original: sammādiṭṭhipubbaṅgamattā ca diṭṭhi. Bhagavato khamanavasena khanti. Ruccanavasena
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi pubbaṅgamattā ca diṭṭhi bhagavataḥ khamana vasena khanti ruccana vasena
translated: and because it is the forerunner of right view since it is preceded by right view. It is the forbearance because of the Blessed One’s forbearance. It is the preference because of his preference.

original: ruci. Gahaṇavasena ādāyo. Attano kārakaṃ apāyesu apatamānaṃ katvā dhāretīti dhammo.🔽Sova saṃkilesapakkhaṃ vinetīti vinayo. Dhammo ca so vinayo cāti dhammavinayo. Kusaladhammehi
analyzed: ruci kārakam apāyesu a patamānam katvā dhāreti iti dhammo  so uva saṃkilesa pakkham vineti iti vinayaḥ dhammo ca so vinayo ca ati dhamma vinayo kusala dhammehi
translated: It is the acceptance because of his acceptance. It is the Dhamma because it is what he bears in mind by making it the cause of his own welfare without falling into states of loss.

original: vā akusaladhammānaṃ esa vinayoti dhammavinayo. Teneva vuttaṃ –
analyzed: vā akusala dhammānam esa vinayo ti dhamma vinayo tena iva vuttam
translated: And it is the discipline because it disciplines the side of corruption. It is both Dhamma and discipline, thus it is the Dhamma and the discipline. Or alternatively, it is the discipline of the unprofitable states by means of the profitable states, thus it is the Dhamma and the discipline.

original: “Ye ca kho tvaṃ, gotami, dhamme jāneyyāsi ‘ime dhammā virāgāya saṃvattanti, no sarāgāya…pe… ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyāsi ‘eso dhammo, eso vinayo, etaṃ satthusāsana”’nti.
analyzed: ye ca kho tvam gotami dhamme jāneyyāsi ime dhammāḥ virāgāya saṃvattanti no ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyāsi esaḥ dhammaḥ esaḥ vinayaḥ etam satthu sāsanam ti
translated: Hence it is said: “Whatever states you know to be conducive to dispassion, not to passion, to being unbinding, not to bondage, to fewness of wishes, not to being insatiable, to contentment, not to discontent, to seclusion, not to entanglement, to being easy to support, not to being difficult to support, to being a field of good habits, not to being a field of bad habits, to being a distinguished field of merit, to being an undistinguished field of merit, to the arising of the as-yet-unarisen noble path and to the increase, expansion and fulfilment by development of the already-arisen noble path, you should bear in mind as a unity, thus: ‘This is Dhamma, this is Discipline, this is the Teacher’s Dispensation’” .

original: Dhammena vā vinayo, na daṇḍādīhīti dhammavinayo. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: dhammena vā vinayaḥ na daṇḍa ādīhi iti dhamma vinayaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is the discipline by means of the Dhamma, not by means of the stick, thus it is the Dhamma and the discipline. And this is said:🔽“Some people are disciplined by the stick,

original: “Daṇḍeneke damayanti, aṅkusehi kasāhi ca;
analyzed: daṇḍena ike damayanti aṅkusehi kasāhi ca
translated: Some by punishment with the scourge,

original: Adaṇḍena asatthena, nāgo danto mahesinā”ti. ;
analyzed: a daṇḍena a satthena nāgaḥ dantaḥ mahesinā ati
translated: The elephant was tamed by the Great Seer Without rod or weapon.

original: Tathā –
analyzed: tathā
translated: And so:

original: “Dhammena nīyamānānaṃ, kā usūyā vijānata”nti. ;
analyzed: dhammena nīyamānānam kāḥ usūyāḥ
translated: When they are led by Dhamma, what envy Can those who know have?

original: Dhammāya vā vinayo dhammavinayo. Anavajjadhammatthañhesa vinayo, na bhavabhogāmisatthaṃ.
analyzed: dhammāya vā vinayaḥ dhamma vinayaḥ anavajja dhamma attham ha esa vinayaḥ na bhava bhoga āmisa ttham
translated: Or alternatively, the training is Dhamma, thus it is Dhamma-training. This training has the harmless state as its aim, not the enjoyment of becoming.

original: Tenāha bhagavā “nayidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati janakuhanattha”nti vitthāro.
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā na idam bhikkhave brahmacariyam vussati jana kuhana attham ti vitthāraḥ
translated: Hence the Blessed One said: “Bhikkhus, this spiritual life is lived with the destruction of lust, not for the enjoyment of lust” , and so on.

original: Puṇṇattheropi āha “anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti.🔽Visiṭṭhaṃ vā nayatīti vinayo. Dhammato vinayo dhammavinayo. Saṃsāradhammato hi sokādidhammato
analyzed: puṇṇa theraḥ api āha anupādā parinibbāna attham kho āvuso bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati iti  visiṭṭham vā nayati iti vinayaḥ dhammataḥ vinayaḥ dhamma vinayo saṃsāra dhammataḥ hi soka ādi dhammataḥ
translated: And the Elder Puṇṇa said: “Friend, it is for the purpose of final Nibbāna without clinging that the Blessed One lives the spiritual life” .🔽Or it is training that leads to what is distinguished, thus it is training. The training is Dhamma, thus it is Dhamma-training. For this training leads to what is distinguished, that is to say, Nibbāna.

original: vā esa visiṭṭhaṃ nibbānaṃ nayati. Dhammassa vā vinayo, na titthakarānanti dhammavinayo.
analyzed: vā esa visiṭṭham nibbānam nayati dhammassa vā vinayaḥ na titthakara ānanti dhamma vinayo
translated: Or it is the training of the Dhamma, not of sectarians, thus it is Dhamma-training.

original: Dhammabhūto hi bhagavā, tasseva vinayo.
analyzed: dhamma bhūtaḥ hi bhagavā tassa iva vinayaḥ
translated: For the Blessed One is the Dhamma in the sense of being the one who possesses the Dhamma.

original: Yasmā vā dhammā eva abhiññeyyā pariññeyyā pahātabbā bhāvetabbā sacchikātabbā ca,
analyzed: yasmai vā dhammā eva abhiññeyyā pariññeyyā pahātabbā bhāvetabbā sacchikātabbā ca
translated: Or else, the Dhamma is what should be directly known, fully understood, abandoned, developed, and realized,

original: tasmā esa dhammesu vinayo, na sattesu na jīvesu cāti dhammavinayo. Sātthasabyañjanatādīhi
analyzed: tasmai esa dhammesu vinayaḥ na sattesu na jīvesu ca ati dhamma vinayaḥ sa attha sa byañjana tā ādīhi
translated: So it is Discipline in ideas, not in creatures or in souls.

original: aññesaṃ vacanato padhānaṃ vacananti pavacanaṃ, pavacanameva pāvacanaṃ. Sabbacariyāhi
analyzed: aññesam vacanataḥ padhānam vacananti pavacanam pavacanam eva pāvacanam sabba cariyāhi
translated: It is the utterance of the best, since it is the utterance of what is best in the sense of being foremost in meaning and in phrasing, and so on, as compared with other utterances.🔽It is the life of purity since it is the life of purity that is outstanding by comparison with all other kinds of life.

original: visiṭṭhacariyabhāvena brahmacariyaṃ. Devamanussānaṃ satthubhūtassa bhagavato sāsananti
analyzed: visiṭṭha cariya bhāvena brahmacariyam deva manussānam satthu bhūtassa bhagavataḥ sāsanam ti
translated: It is the Master’s Dispensation since it is the Master’s Dispensation in the Blessed One who is the Master of gods and men.

original: satthusāsanaṃ. Satthubhūtaṃ vā sāsanantipi satthusāsanaṃ. “So vo mamaccayena satthāti
analyzed: satthu sāsanam satthu bhūtam vā satthu sāsanam saḥ vaḥ mamaccayena satthā ti
translated: Or alternatively, it is the Master’s Dispensation since it is the Dispensation of the Master. For it is said: ‘After my death this will be your Master’ ,

original: hi dhammavinayova satthā”ti vuttoti evametesaṃ padānaṃ attho veditabbo.
analyzed: hi dhamma vinayaḥ iva satthā iti vuttaḥ ti evam etesam padānam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: and the Dhamma and Discipline is called the Master because it is the Master of bhikkhus, and so on. This is how the meaning of these terms should be understood.

original: Yasmā pana imasmiṃyeva sāsane sabbappakārajjhānanibbattako bhikkhu dissati, na aññatra, tasmā tattha tattha “imissā”ti ca “imasmi”nti ca ayaṃ niyamo katoti veditabbo.
analyzed: yasmā pana imasmin yeva sāsane sabba ppakāra jjhāna nibbattakaḥ bhikkhu dissati na aññatra tasmā tattha tattha imissa ati ca imasmin ti ca ayam niyamo kato ti veditabbo
translated: But since a bhikkhu who produces all kinds of memory is found only in this Dispensation and not elsewhere, the specification ‘in this Dispensation’ should be understood as stated here and there.

original: Jīvanti tena taṃsampayuttakā dhammāti jīvitaṃ. Anupālanalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti
analyzed: jīvanti tena tad sampayuttakāḥ dhammā ati jīvitam anupālana lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti
translated: It is life since it is what lives, that is, what causes the associated states to live. It is the faculty of life since it is the controlling agency for the characteristic of maintaining associated states.

original: indriyaṃ. Jīvitameva indriyaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ. Taṃ pavattasantatādhipateyyaṃ hoti.
analyzed: indriyam jīvitam eva indriyam jīvitindriyam tam pavatta santata ādhipateyyam hoti
translated: The life faculty is the faculty of life. It is the predominance in the continuity of the occurrence of the aggregates.

original: Lakkhaṇādīhi pana attanā avinibhuttānaṃ dhammānaṃ anupālanalakkhaṇaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādīhi pana attanā a vinibhuttānam dhammānam anupālana lakkhaṇam jīvitindriyam
translated: But the life faculty has the characteristic of maintaining those states that are not dissociated from life.

original: tesaṃ pavattanarasaṃ, tesaṃyeva ṭhapanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, yāpayitabbadhammapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: tesam pavattana rasam tesam yeva ṭhapana paccupaṭṭhānam yāpayitabba dhamma padaṭṭhānam
translated: Its function is to cause their occurrence. It is manifested as the support of those same states. Its proximate cause is the life-continuum.

original: Santepi ca anupālanalakkhaṇādimhi vidhāne atthikkhaṇeyeva taṃ te dhamme anupāleti,
