analyzed: sante api ca anupālana lakkhaṇa ādimhi vidhāne atthi kkhaṇe iva tam te dhamme anupāleti
translated: And although the function of maintaining is present, it maintains those states only while they are present.

original: udakaṃ viya uppalādīni. Yathāsakaṃ paccayehi uppannepi ca dhamme pāleti, dhāti viya🔽kumāraṃ, sayaṃpavattitadhammasambandheneva ca pavattati, niyāmako viya nāvaṃ. Na
analyzed: udakam viya uppala ādīni yathāsakam paccayehi uppanne pi ca dhamme pāleti dhāti viya  kumāram sayaṃpavattita dhamma sambandhena iva ca pavattati niyāmakaḥ viya nāvam na
translated: It maintains them like water a lotus, and it maintains those states that have arisen through their respective conditions like a nurse🔽a child. And it occurs only through its connection with the states that it maintains, like a helmsman a ship.

original: bhaṅgato uddhaṃ pavattayati, attano ca pavattayitabbānañca abhāvā. Na bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: bhaṅgataḥ uddham pavattayati attanaḥ ca pavattayitabbānam ca abhāvāḥ na bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: It does not occur after the break-up, because there are no states to maintain and because it itself has ceased. Nor does it occur at the moment of break-up,

original: ṭhapeti, sayaṃ bhijjamānattā, khīyamāno viya vaṭṭisineho padīpasikhaṃ, na ca anupālanapavattanaṭṭhapanānubhāvavirahitaṃ,
analyzed: ṭhapeti sayam khīyamāna viya vaṭṭi sinehaḥ padīpa sikham na ca anupālana pavattana ṭṭhapana anubhāva virahitam
translated: and it is not devoid of the power of maintaining, developing, and establishing.🔽It should be regarded as accomplishing this or that in the stated moment.

original: yathāvuttakkhaṇe tassa tassa sādhanatoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ṭhitiparittatāya vāti ṭhitikkhaṇassa🔽mandatāya thokatāya. Appakanti mandaṃ lāmakaṃ. Sarasaparittatāya vāti attano paccayabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutta kkhaṇe tassa tassa sādhanato ti daṭṭhabbam ṭhiti paritta tāya vā āti ṭhiti kkhaṇassa  manda tāya thoka tāya appakanti mandam lāmakam sarasa paritta tāya vāti attanaḥ paccaya bhūtānam
translated: By the brevity of the duration: by the shortness, the smallness, of the moment of presence.🔽Small means short, brief.

original: kiccānaṃ sampattīnaṃ vā appatāya dubbalatāya.
analyzed: kiccānam sampattīnam vā appa tāya dubbala tāya
translated: By the weakness of the conditions: by the weakness, the feebleness, of the functions or attainments of the conditions that are its own.

original: Tesaṃ dvinnaṃ kāraṇaṃ vibhāgato dassetuṃ “kathaṃ ṭhitiparittatāyā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: tesam dvinnam kāraṇam vibhāgataḥ dassetum katham ṭhiti paritta tāya ati ādim āha tattha
translated: In order to show the two reasons separately, he says, “How by the brevity of the duration?” and so on. Herein,

original: “atīte cittakkhaṇe jīvitthāti evamādi pañcavokārabhave pavattiyaṃ cittassa nirujjhanakāle
analyzed: atīte citta kkhaṇe jīvittha ati evamādi pañcavokāra bhave pavattiyam cittassa nirujjhana kāle
translated: “In the past moment of consciousness, the life faculty has ceased” and so on: at the time of the cessation of consciousness in the occurrence of the five-constituent becoming,

original: sabbasmiṃ rūpārūpadhamme anirujjhantepi rūpato arūpassa paṭṭhānabhāvena arūpajīvitaṃ
analyzed: sabbasmin rūpa arūpa dhamme a nirujjhante api rūpataḥ arūpassa paṭṭhāna bhāvena arūpa jīvitam
translated: although all material and immaterial states do not cease, the immaterial life faculty is intended by way of the conditionality of the immaterial from the material.

original: sandhāya, cuticittena vā saddhiṃ sabbesaṃ rūpārūpānaṃ nirujjhanabhāvena pañcavokārabhave
analyzed: sandhāya cuti cittena vā saddhim sabbesam rūpa arūpānam nirujjhana bhāvena pañcavokāra bhave
translated: Or by the cessation of all material and immaterial states together with the death consciousness in the five-constituent becoming,

original: cuticittaṃ sandhāya, catuvokārabhave rūpassa abhāvena catuvokārabhavaṃ sandhāya kathita”nti
analyzed: cuti cittam sandhāya catuvokāra bhave rūpassa abhāvena catuvokāra bhavam sandhāya kathitan ti
translated: and the death-consciousness, and the four-constituent becoming, because there is no materiality in it.”

original: veditabbaṃ. Atīte cittakkhaṇeti atītacittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇasamaṅgīkāle taṃsamaṅgīpuggalo
analyzed: veditabbam atīte citta kkhaṇe iti atīta cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇa samaṅgī kāle tad samaṅgī puggalaḥ
translated: “In the past, in a moment of consciousness”: when a person is associated with the moment of the dissolution of a past consciousness,

original: “jīvittha” iti vattuṃ labbhati. Na jīvatīti “jīvatī”tipi vattuṃ na labbhati. Na jīvissatīti
analyzed: jīvittha iti vattum labbhati na jīvati iti jīvati iti pi vattum na labbhati na jīvissati iti
translated: it is proper to say that he “lived,” but it is not proper to say that he “lives” or that he “will live.”

original: “jīvissatī”tipi vattuṃ na labbhati. Anāgate cittakkhaṇe jīvissatīti anāgatacittassa🔽anuppajjanakkhaṇasamaṅgīkāle “jīvissatī”ti vattuṃ labbhati. Na jīvatīti “jīvatī”ti
analyzed: jīvissati iti pi vattum na labbhati anāgate citta kkhaṇe jīvissati iti anāgata cittassa  an uppajjana khaṇa samaṅgīkāle jīvissati iti vattum labbhati na jīvati iti jīvati iti
translated: It is not proper to say that he “will live,”🔽but it is proper to say that he “lived” when he is associated with the moment of the non-arising of a future consciousness.

original: vattuṃ na labbhati. Na jīvitthāti “jīvittha”itipi vattuṃ na labbhati. Paccuppanne
analyzed: vattum na labbhati na jīvittha ati jīvittha eti pi vattum na labbhati paccuppanne
translated: It is not proper to say that he “lives” or that he “will live.”🔽“In the present, in a moment of consciousness”: when a person is associated with the present moment of consciousness,

original: cittakkhaṇeti paccuppannacittakkhaṇasamaṅgīkāle. Jīvatīti “idāni jīvatī”ti vattuṃ
analyzed: citta kkhaṇa iti paccuppanna citta kkhaṇa samaṅgīkāle jīvati iti idāni jīvati iti vattum
translated: it is proper to say that he “lives” now,

original: labbhati. Na jīvitthāti “jīvittha”iti vattuṃ na labbhati. Na jīvissatīti “jīvissatī”tipi vattuṃ na labbhati.
analyzed: labbhati na jīvittha ati jīvittha eti vattum na labbhati na jīvissati iti jīvissati iti pi vattum na labbhati
translated: “It is not allowable to say ‘he will live,’ ” means it is not allowable to say “he will live.” “It is not allowable to say ‘he will not live,’ ” means it is not allowable to say “he will not live.”

original: Jīvitaṃ attabhāvo ca sukhadukkhā cāti ayaṃ gāthā pañcavokārabhavaṃ amuñcitvā labbhamānāya
analyzed: jīvitam atta bhāvaḥ ca sukha dukkhā ca ati ayam gāthā pañcavokāra bhavam a muñcitvā labbhamānāya
translated: “Life, body, and pleasure and pain,” this verse is allowable when it is said without abandoning the five-holding-aggregates.

original: dukkhāya vedanāya gahitattā pañcavokārabhavameva sandhāya vuttāti veditabbā. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: dukkhāya vedanāya gahita ttā pañcavokāra bhavam eva sandhāya vuttā ati veditabbā katham
translated: It should be understood that it is said only in reference to the five-holding-aggregates because it includes painful feeling. How?

original: Jīvitanti jīvitasīsena saṅkhārakkhandho. Attabhāvoti rūpakkhandho. “Upekkhā pana
analyzed: jīvitanti jīvita sīsena saṅkhāra kkhandho atta bhāvaḥ ti rūpa kkhandhaḥ upekkhā pana
translated: “Life” is the formation aggregate in the sense of the life faculty. “Body” is the form aggregate. “Pleasure and pain”🔽is the feeling aggregate, including the equanimity feeling,

original: santattā, sukhamicceva bhāsitā”ti vuttattā upekkhāvedanā antokaritvā sukhadukkhā
analyzed: santattā sukham icca iva bhāsitā ati vutta ttā upekkhā vedanā antokaritvā sukha dukkhā
translated: because it is said: “Equanimity is spoken of as pleasure🔽because of its peacefulness.” “Mind” is the consciousness aggregate.

original: cāti vedanākkhandho, cittaṃ iti viññāṇakkhandho vutto. Imesaṃ catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ
analyzed: ca ati vedanā khandho cittam iti viññāṇa kkhandho vuttaḥ imesam catunnam khandhānam
translated: Because these four aggregates are mentioned, the perception aggregate is also mentioned

original: kathitattāyeva khandhalakkhaṇena ekalakkhaṇabhāvena lakkhaṇākāravasena saññākkhandhopi
analyzed: kathita ttāya iva khandha lakkhaṇena eka lakkhaṇa bhāvena lakkhaṇa ākāra vasena saññā kkhandhaḥ api
translated: by the characteristic of the aggregates, by the characteristic of the single characteristic.

original: kathitoti veditabbo. Evaṃ vuttesu pañcasu khandhesu arūpadhammaṃ muñcitvā kammasamuṭṭhānādirūpassa
analyzed: kathito ti veditabbaḥ evam vuttesu pañcasu khandhesu arūpa dhammam muñcitvā kamma samuṭṭhāna ādi rūpassa
translated: “The state of being associated with a single consciousness” should be understood as stated.

original: appavattanabhāvena ekacittasamāyuttāti arūpapadhānabhāvo kathito hoti. Kathaṃ? Asaññasatte
analyzed: appavattana bhāvena eka citta samāyuttā ati arūpa padhāna bhāvo kathitaḥ hoti katham asañña satte
translated: When the five aggregates are mentioned in this way, the state of being associated with a single consciousness is stated in the case of materiality that is originated by kamma, etc., by excluding the immaterial dhammas, since it does not occur.🔽In the case of the non-percipient beings, materiality occurs without relinquishing the power of accumulated kamma.

original: rūpampi idhupacitakammabalaṃ amuñcitvāva pavattati, nirodhasamāpannānaṃ rūpampi paṭhamasamāpannasamāpattibalaṃ🔽amuñcitvāva pavattati. Evaṃ attano appavattiṭṭhānepi rūpapavattiṃ attano santakameva
analyzed: rūpam pi idha upacita kamma balam a muñcitvā ava pavattati nirodha samāpannānam rūpam pi paṭhama samāpanna samāpatti balam  a muñcitvā ava pavattati evam attanaḥ appavatti ṭhāne pi rūpa pavattim attanaḥ santakam eva
translated: In the case of those attained to cessation, materiality occurs without relinquishing the power of the first attainment.🔽Thus, even in the case of the occurrence of materiality in a place where it does not occur, it occurs by making the materiality that occurs in its own place its own,

original: katvā pavattanasabhāvassa arūpadhammassa attano pavattiṭṭhāne rūpapavattiyā padhānakāraṇabhāvena
analyzed: katvā pavattana sabhāvassa arūpa dhammassa attano pavatti ṭṭhāne rūpa pavattiyā padhāna kāraṇa bhāvena
translated: and the state of being associated with a single consciousness is stated in the case of the immaterial dhamma that has the nature of occurring by making the occurrence of materiality in its own place its own as the predominant cause.

original: ekacittasamāyuttāti cittapadhānabhāvo kathitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: eka citta samāyuttā ati citta padhāna bhāvaḥ kathitaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: “The state of being associated with a single consciousness” should be understood as stated in the sense of the predominance of consciousness.

original: Evaṃ pañcavokārabhave pavattiyaṃ rūpapavattiyā padhānabhūtacittanirodhena rūpe dharamāneyeva
analyzed: evam pañcavokāra bhave rūpa pavattiyā padhāna bhūta citta nirodhena rūpe
translated: Thus, in the occurrence of the five-constituent becoming, the state of being associated with a single consciousness is stated in the sense of the predominance of consciousness by the cessation of the consciousness that is the predominant cause of the occurrence of materiality.

original: pavattānaṃ nirodho nāma hotīti arūpadhammavasena eva “lahuso vattate khaṇo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pavattānam nirodhaḥ nāma hoti iti arūpa dhamma vasena eva lahusaḥ vattate khaṇo ti vuttam
translated: and the cessation of the processes is called “the signless.” So it is said: “The moment is fleeting, hard to understand.”🔽Or alternatively, it should be understood that it is said with reference to the death consciousness in the five-constituent becoming.

original: Atha vā pañcavokārabhave cuticittaṃ sandhāya kathitāti veditabbā. Evaṃ kathiyamāne
analyzed: atha vā pañcavokāra bhave cuti cittam sandhāya kathitā ati veditabbā evam kathiyamāne
translated: When it is said thus,

original: sukhadukkhā cāti kāyikacetasikasukhavedanā ca kāyikacetasikadukkhavedanā ca cuticittakkhaṇe🔽ahontīpi ekasantativasena cuticittena saddhiṃ nirujjhatīti kathitā. Catuvokārabhavaṃ
analyzed: sukha dukkhā ca ati kāyika cetasika sukha vedanā ca kāyika cetasika dukkha vedanā ca cuti citta kkhaṇe  eka santati vasena cuti cittena saddhim nirujjhati iti kathitā catuvokāra bhavam
translated: the pleasant and painful are the bodily and mental pleasant and painful feelings. Although they do not exist at the moment of death consciousness,🔽they are said to cease together with the death consciousness in the sense of a single continuity.🔽Or it should be understood that it is said with reference to the four-constituent becoming. How?

original: vā sandhāya kathitātipi veditabbā. Kathaṃ? Aññasmiṃ ṭhāne attabhāvoti saññākkhandhassa
analyzed: vā sandhāya kathitā ati pi veditabbā katham aññasmin ṭhāne atta bhāvaḥ ti saññā kkhandhassa
translated: The “self’s existence in another place” is the perception aggregate.🔽The “self’s existence” is taken as the perception aggregate itself by the method stated in the case of the perception aggregate.

original: vuttabhāvena attabhāvoti saññākkhandhova gahito. Brahmaloke kāyikasukhadukkhadomanassaṃ
analyzed: vutta bhāvena atta bhāvo ti saññā kkhandhaḥ uva gahitaḥ brahma loke kāyika sukha dukkha domanassam
translated: In the Brahma-world, although there is no bodily pain, grief,

original: ahontampi sukhadukkhā cāti vedanāsāmaññato labbhamāno vedanākkhandho gahitoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sukha dukkhā ca ati vedanā sāmaññataḥ labbhamānaḥ vedanā kkhandhaḥ gahito ti veditabbam
translated: and the pleasant and painful are the feeling aggregate that is found in common as the pleasant and painful. It should be understood that the feeling aggregate is taken.🔽The rest is as already stated.

original: Sesaṃ vuttasadisameva. Imesu ca tīsu vikappesu kevalāti dhuvasukhasubhaattā natthi,
analyzed: sesam vutta sadisam eva imesu ca tīsu vikappesu kevalā ati dhuva sukha subha attā natthi
translated: In these three speculations there is no “only,” because of permanence, pleasure, and beauty.

original: kevalaṃ tehi avomissā. Lahuso vattati khaṇoti vuttanayena ekacittakkhaṇikatāya lahuko
analyzed: kevalam tehi lahusaḥ vattati khaṇo ti vutta nayena eka citta khaṇika tāya lahukaḥ
translated: and they are only to be expected. The moment of life, etc., is fleeting,

original: atiparitto jīvitādīnaṃ khaṇo vattati.
analyzed: atiparittaḥ jīvita ādīnam khaṇaḥ vattati
translated: as stated in the verse, “The moment is fleeting, the life span is short” .

original: Ekato dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ appavattiṃ dassento “cullāsītisahassānī”ti gāthamāha. Cullāsītisahassāni,
analyzed: ekatas dvinnam cittānam appavattim dassentaḥ culla asīti sahassāni iti gātham āha culla asīti sahassāni
translated: Showing that two consciousnesses do not occur together, he says, “Eighty-four thousand” .🔽The gods who live for eighty-four thousand eons,

original: kappā tiṭṭhanti ye marūti ye devagaṇā caturāsīti kappasahassāni āyuṃ gahetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatane
analyzed: kappā tiṭṭhanti ye ye deva gaṇā caturāsīti kappa sahassāni āyum gahetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatane
translated: the gods who take up a life span of eighty-four thousand eons in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,🔽“the men” .

original: tiṭṭhanti. “Ye narā”tipi pāḷi. Na tveva tepi jīvanti, dvīhi cittasamohitāti tepi🔽devā dvīhi cittehi samohitā ekato hutvā yuganaddhena cittena na tu eva jīvanti, ekenekena
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti ye narā atipi na tu eva te pi jīvanti dvīhi te pi  devāḥ dvīhi cittehi samohitāḥ ekatas hutvā yuga naddhena cittena na tu eva jīvanti ekena ekena
translated: But they do not live with two consciousnesses combined,

original: cittena jīvantīti attho.🔽Idāni maraṇakālaṃ dassento “ye niruddhā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha ye niruddhāti ye khandhā
analyzed: cittena jīvanti iti attho  idāni maraṇa kālam dassentaḥ ye niruddhā iti gātham āha tattha ye niruddhā ati ye khandhā
translated: those gods with two consciousnesses combined, having become one, with a double consciousness, do not live; the meaning is, they live with one consciousness.🔽Now, showing the time of death, he says, “Those who have ceased” . Herein, those who have ceased are the aggregates that have ceased, that have disappeared. Dying is of one who is dead. Living is of one who is living. All

original: niruddhā atthaṅgatā. Marantassāti matassa. Tiṭṭhamānassa vāti dharamānassa vā. Sabbepi
analyzed: niruddhāḥ atthaṅgatāḥ marantassa ati matassa tiṭṭhamānassa vā ati dharamānassa vā sabbe pi
translated: are

original: sadisā khandhāti cutito uddhaṃ niruddhakkhandhā vā pavatte niruddhakkhandhā vā puna🔽ghaṭetuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṭṭhena sabbepi khandhā sadisā. Gatā appaṭisandhikāti niruddhakkhandhānaṃ
analyzed: sadisāḥ khandhā ati cutitaḥ uddham niruddha khandhāḥ vā pavatte niruddha kkhandhāḥ vā puna  ghaṭetum a sakkuṇeyya ṭṭhena sabbe pi khandhā sadisāḥ gatāḥ appaṭisandhikā ati niruddha kkhandhānam
translated: “Similar aggregates” : after death, either the aggregates that have ceased or the aggregates that are ceasing are “similar” in the sense that they cannot be brought together again.

original: puna āgantvā paṭisandhānābhāvena gatā appaṭisandhikāti vuccanti.
analyzed: punar āgantvā paṭisandhāna abhāvena gatā appaṭisandhikā iti vuccanti
translated: “Gone without grasping” : because the ceased aggregates do not return to grasp a new existence, they are said to be “gone without grasping.”

original: Idāni tīsu kālesu niruddhakkhandhānaṃ nānattaṃ natthīti dassetuṃ “anantarā”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tattha anantarā ca ye bhaggā, ye ca bhaggā anāgatāti ye khandhā anantarātītā hutvā
analyzed: idāni tīsu kālesu niruddha kkhandhānam nānattam natthi iti dassetum anantarā ti gātham āha  tattha anantarā ca ye bhaggāḥ ye ca bhaggāḥ anāgatā ati ye khandhāḥ anantara atītāḥ hutvā
translated: Now, in order to show that there is no difference between the aggregates that have ceased in the three periods of time, he says the verse beginning with “Anantara.”🔽Herein, those that have been broken up and those that will be broken up in the future are “anantara” .

original: bhinnā niruddhā, ye ca anāgatā khandhā bhijjissanti. Tadantareti tesaṃ antare niruddhānaṃ🔽paccuppannakhandhānaṃ. Vesamaṃ natthi lakkhaṇeti visamassa bhāvo vesamaṃ, taṃ vesamaṃ
analyzed: bhinnāḥ niruddhāḥ ye ca anāgatāḥ khandhāḥ bhijjissanti tad antarā iti tesam antare niruddhānam  paccuppanna khandhānam vesamam natthi lakkhaṇā iti visamassa bhāvaḥ vesamam tam vesamam
translated: Those aggregates that have ceased having been immediately past are “broken up” . Those aggregates that will be broken up are those that will cease in the future.🔽“Tadantare” : among those that have ceased in the interval,

original: natthi, tehi nānattaṃ natthīti attho. Lakkhīyatīti lakkhaṇaṃ, tasmiṃ lakkhaṇe.
analyzed: natthi tehi nānattam natthi iti atthaḥ lakkhīyati iti lakkhaṇam tasmim lakkhaṇe
translated: among the present aggregates. “There is no difference in their characteristics” : “visamam” is the state of being uneven; there is no such unevenness, is the meaning. “Lakkhaṇe” : in the characteristic.

original: Idāni anāgatakkhandhānaṃ vattamānakkhandhehi asammissabhāvaṃ kathento “anibbattena🔽na jāto”ti gāthamāha. Anibbattena na jātoti ajātena apātubhūtena anāgatakkhandhena
analyzed: idāni anāgata khandhānam vattamāna khandhehi asammissa bhāvam kathentaḥ anibbattena  na jātaḥ iti gātham āha a nibbattena na jātaḥ iti a jātena a pātubhūtena anāgata kkhandhena
translated: Now, in order to show that the future aggregates are not mixed up with the present aggregates, he says the stanza, “Not born with the unborn,”🔽etc. Not born with the unborn: not born, not arisen, with the future aggregates which are not born, not become manifest.

original: na jāto na nibbatto. Etena anāgatakkhandhassa vattamānakkhandhena asammissabhāvaṃ🔽kathesi. Paccuppannena jīvatīti khaṇapaccuppannena vattamānakkhandhena jīvati. Etena🔽ekakkhaṇe dvīhi cittehi na jīvatīti kathitaṃ. Cittabhaggā matoti dvīhi cittehi ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: na jātaḥ na nibbattaḥ etena anāgata kkhandhassa vattamāna kkhandhena a sammissa bhāvam  kathesi paccuppannena jīvati iti khaṇa paccuppannena vattamāna khandhena jīvati etena  eka kkhaṇe dvīhi cittehi na jīvati iti kathitam citta bhaggā mato ti dvīhi cittehi eka kkhaṇe
translated: By this he shows that the future aggregates are not mixed up with the present aggregates.🔽Lives with the present: lives with the present aggregates which arise moment by moment. By this he shows that one does not live with two consciousnesses in a single moment.

original: ajīvanabhāvena cittabhaṅgena mato. “Uparito cittabhaṅgā”tipi pāḷi, taṃ ujukameva.🔽Paññatti paramatthiyāti “rūpaṃ jīrati maccānaṃ, nāmagottaṃ na jīratī”ti vacanakkamena
analyzed: a jīvana bhāvena citta bhaṅgena uparitas tam ujukam eva  rūpam jīrati maccānam nāma gottam na jīrati iti vacana kkamena
translated: Dead with the break-up of consciousness: dead with the break-up of consciousness, because one does not live with two consciousnesses in a single moment. The text reads “with the break-up above,” but this is incorrect.🔽The designation is the ultimate: the designation is not subject to decay by way of the nature of decay, as is shown by the statement, “The form of mortals decays, but name-and-surname does not decay.”

original: paṇṇattimattaṃ na jīraṇasabhāvena paramā ṭhiti etissāti paramatthiyā, sabhāvaṭṭhitikāti
analyzed: paṇṇattimattam na jīraṇa sabhāvena paramā ṭhiti etissa ati paramatthiyā sabhāva ṭṭhitikā ti
translated: The ultimate is the ultimate state, the state of individual essence.

original: attho. “Datto mato, mitto mato”ti paṇṇattimattameva hi tiṭṭhati. Atha vā paramatthiyāti
analyzed: atthaḥ dattaḥ mataḥ mittaḥ mataḥ iti paṇṇatti mattam eva hi tiṭṭhati atha vā param atthiyā ati
translated: Or else, “in the ultimate sense” :

original: paramatthikā. Paramo attho etissāti paramatthikā. Ajaṭākāsoti paññattiyā natthidhammaṃ
analyzed: paramatthikā paramaḥ atthaḥ etissa ati paramatthikā a jaṭā kāsā ti paññattiyā natthi dhammam
translated: they are “ultimate” because they are the ultimate meaning.

original: paṭicca kathanaṃ viya matoti paññatti natthidhammaṃ paṭicca na kathiyati, jīvitindriyabhaṅgasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: paṭicca kathanam viya mato ti paññatti natthi dhammam paṭicca na kathiyati jīvita indriya bhaṅga saṅkhātam
translated: “Not a mere void” : just as the statement “He has died” is not made with reference to the mere non-existence of the designation “he has died,” but is made with reference to the state of death, the cessation of the life faculty,

original: dhammaṃ paṭicca kathiyati.🔽Anidhānagatā bhaggāti ye khandhā bhinnā, te nidhānaṃ nihitaṃ nicayaṃ na gacchantīti
analyzed: dhammam paṭicca kathiyati  a nidhāna gatā bhaggā ati ye khandhāḥ bhinnā te nidhānam nihitam nicayam na gacchanti iti
translated: so too the statement “the aggregates” is not made with reference to a mere void, but with reference to the five aggregates of clinging.🔽“Not a heap” : the aggregates that have been broken up do not go to a heap, a collection, a pile,

original: anidhānagatā. Puñjo natthi anāgateti anāgatepi nesaṃ puñjabhāvo rāsibhāvo natthi.
analyzed: a nidhāna gatā puñjaḥ natthi anāgatā iti anāgate pi na īsam puñja bhāvaḥ rāsi bhāvaḥ natthi
translated: therefore they are said to “not go to a heap.” “No heap in the future” : even in the future they will not have the nature of a heap, the nature of a collection.

original: Nibbattāyeva tiṭṭhantīti paccuppannavasena uppannā ṭhitikkhaṇe vayadhammāva hutvā
analyzed: nibbattāya iva tiṭṭhanti iti paccuppanna vasena uppannāḥ ṭhiti kkhaṇe vaya dhammā ava hutvā
translated: “They stand arisen” : arisen in the present, they stand as subject to destruction at the moment of their duration.

original: tiṭṭhanti. Kimiva? Āragge sāsapūpamāti sūcimukhe sāsapo viya.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti kim iva āragge sūci mukhe sāsapaḥ viya
translated: What is it like? “Like a mustard seed on the point of an awl” : like a mustard seed on the point of a needle.

original: Idāni khandhānaṃ dassanabhāvaṃ dassento “nibbattāna”nti gāthamāha. Tattha nibbattānaṃ
analyzed: idāni khandhānam dassana bhāvam dassentaḥ nibbattānam ti gātham āha tattha nibbattānam
translated: Now, showing the state of seeing the aggregates, he said, “Arisen” . Therein, “arisen” :

original: dhammānanti paccuppannānaṃ khandhānaṃ. Bhaṅgo nesaṃ purakkhatoti etesaṃ bhedo purato🔽katvā ṭhapito. Palokadhammāti nassanasabhāvā. Purāṇehi adhissitāti pure uppannehi
analyzed: dhammānan ti paccuppannānam khandhānam bhaṅgaḥ nesam purakkhataḥ ti etesam bhedaḥ puratas  katvā ṭhapitaḥ palokadhammā ati nassana sabhāvā purāṇehi adhissitā ati pure uppannehi
translated: ‘Of ideas’: of the presently arisen aggregates. ‘With their dissolution placed foremost’: with their dissolution placed in front, set forth. ‘Subject to destruction’: having the nature of vanishing. ‘Overpowered by the old’: overpowered by those arisen in the past.

original: khandhehi na missitā na saṃsaggā.
analyzed: khandhehi na missitā na saṃsaggā
translated: ‘Of ideas’: of the presently arisen aggregates. ‘With their dissolution placed foremost’: with their dissolution placed in front, set up in the foremost position. ‘Subject to destruction’: of the nature of perishing. ‘Not mixed with past’: not mixed up, not in contact, with the aggregates that arose in the past.

original: Idāni khandhānaṃ adassanabhāvaṃ dassento “adassanato āyantī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha🔽adassanato āyantīti adissamānāyeva āgacchanti uppajjanti. Bhaṅgā gacchantidassananti🔽bhedā bhaṅgato uddhaṃ adassanabhāvaṃ gacchanti. Vijjuppādova ākāseti vivaṭākāse vijjulatāniccharaṇaṃ
analyzed: idāni khandhānam adassana bhāvam dassentaḥ adassanataḥ āyanti iti gātham āha tattha  a dassanataḥ āyanti iti a dissamānāya iva āgacchanti uppajjanti bhaṅgāḥ  bhedāḥ bhaṅgataḥ uddham a dassana bhāvam gacchanti ākāseti vivaṭa ākāse
translated: Now, showing the non-appearance of the aggregates, he stated the verse ‘They come from non-appearance ‘. Herein

original: viya. Uppajjanti vayanti cāti pubbantato uddhaṃ uppajjanti ca bhijjanti ca, nassantīti🔽attho. “Udeti āpūrati veti cando”ti evamādīsu viya.
analyzed: viyaḥ uppajjanti vayanti ca ati pubbantataḥ uddham uppajjanti ca bhijjanti ca nassanti iti 🔽attho udeti āpūrati veti cando ti evamādīsu viya
translated: ‘They come from non-appearance ‘: they come, they arise, only from non-appearance. ‘ They go to dissolution ‘: they go to non-appearance after dissolution, after breaking up. ‘ Like lightning in the sky ‘: like a flash of lightning in the open sky, which has no support. ‘ They arise and cease ‘: they arise and they break up, they perish, is the meaning, from the past. ‘ Like the moon filling and then waning ‘ , and so on.

original: Evaṃ ṭhitiparittataṃ dassetvā idāni sarasaparittataṃ dassento “kathaṃ sarasaparittatāyā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: evam ṭhiti paritta tam dassetvā idāni sarasa paritta tam dassentaḥ katham sarasa paritta tāya ati ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the weakness of duration, he now said “How is there weakness of the life faculty?” in order to show the weakness of the life faculty.

original: Tattha assāsūpanibandhaṃ jīvitanti abbhantarapavisananāsikavātapaṭibaddhaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ.🔽Passāsoti bahinikkhamananāsikavāto. Assāsapassāsoti tadubhayaṃ. Mahābhūtūpanibandhanti
analyzed: tattha assāsu upanibandham jīvitanti abbhantara pavisana nāsika vāta paṭibaddham jīvita indriyam  passāso ti bahi nikkhamana nāsika vātaḥ assāsa passāso ti tat ubhayam mahābhūtu upanibandhanti
translated: Herein, the life faculty bound up with in-breath is the life faculty bound up with the in-breath that enters inside and is bound up with the nostril wind.🔽Out-breath is the nostril wind that goes out. In-breath and out-breath are both of them. Bound up with the primary elements is the life faculty bound up with the four primary elements of the fourfold origin.

original: catusamuṭṭhānikānaṃ pathavīāpatejavāyānaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ paṭibaddhaṃ jīvitaṃ. Kabaḷīkārāhārūpanibandhanti
analyzed: catu samuṭṭhānikānam mahābhūtānam paṭibaddham jīvitam kabaḷīkāra āhāra upanibandhanti
translated: Bound up with physical nutriment is the life faculty bound up with the physical nutriment consisting of what is eaten, drunk, consumed and tasted.

original: asitapītādikabaḷīkāraāhārena upanibandhaṃ. Usmūpanibandhanti kammajatejodhātūpanibandhaṃ.
analyzed: asita pīta ādika baḷīkāra āhārena upanibandham usmu upanibandhanti kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu upanibandham
translated: Bound up with heat is the life faculty bound up with the heat element born of kamma.

original: Viññāṇūpanibandhanti bhavaṅgaviññāṇūpanibandhaṃ. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “āyu usmā ca
analyzed: viññāṇa upanibandhanti bhavaṅga viññāṇa upanibandham yam sandhāya vuttam ca
translated: Bound up with consciousness is the life faculty bound up with the life-continuum consciousness. It is with reference to this that it is said: “When the life faculty, heat,

original: viññāṇaṃ, yadā kāyaṃ jahantima”nti.
analyzed: viññāṇam yadā kāyam jahantimanti
translated: And consciousness leave the body” .

original: Idāni nesaṃ dubbalakāraṇaṃ dassento “mūlampi imesaṃ dubbala”ntiādimāha. Tattha mūlampīti
analyzed: idāni na isam dubbala kāraṇam dassentaḥ mūlam pi imesam dubbala nti ādim āha tattha mūlam pi iti
translated: Now, in order to show the reason for their weakness, he said “The root too of these is weak” . Herein, the root too is the root of the life faculty, etc.,

original: patiṭṭhaṭṭhena mūlabhūtampi. Assāsapassāsānañhi karajakāyo mūlaṃ. Mahābhūtādīnaṃ
analyzed: patiṭṭha ṭṭhena mūla bhūtam pi assāsa passāsānam hi karaja kāyaḥ mūlam mahābhūta ādīnam
translated: and it is the root in the sense of being the foundation. For the in-breath and out-breath have the body as their root, and the great primaries, etc.,🔽have ignorance, kamma-formations, craving, and clinging as their roots.

original: avijjākammataṇhāhārā. Imesanti vuttappakārānaṃ assāsādīnaṃ jīvitindriyapavattikāraṇavasena
analyzed: avijjā kamma taṇhā āhārāḥ imesan ti vutta ppakārānam assāsa ādīnam jīvitindriya pavatti kāraṇa vasena
translated: Of these: of the in-breath, etc., described above, which are stated as the conditions for the occurrence of the life faculty,

original: vuttānaṃ. Etesu hi ekekasmiṃ asati jīvitindriyaṃ na tiṭṭhati. Dubbalanti appathāmaṃ.
analyzed: vuttānam etesu hi ekekasmin asati jīvitindriyam na tiṭṭhati appathāmam
translated: for the life faculty does not continue to exist when any one of them is absent. Weak: slight.

original: Pubbahetūpīti atītajātiyaṃ imassa vipākavaṭṭassa hetubhūtā kāraṇasaṅkhātā avijjāsaṅkhārataṇhupādānabhavāpi.
analyzed: pubba hetu ūpī ti atīta jātiyam imassa vipāka vaṭṭassa hetu bhūtā kāraṇa saṅkhātā avijjā saṅkhāra taṇhu pādāna bhavā api
translated: Previous causes: ignorance, kamma-formations, craving, and clinging, which are called the conditions for the occurrence of the life faculty in the present birth, and which were the causes for the occurrence of the present life-continuum.🔽These are weak conditions.

original: Imesaṃ dubbalā ye paccayā tepi dubbalāti ye ārammaṇādisādhāraṇapaccayā. Pabhāvikāti
analyzed: imesam dubbalāḥ ye paccayā te api dubbalā ati ye ārammaṇa ādi sādhāraṇa paccayā pabhāvikā ati
translated: The conditions that are weak are the object condition, etc.,🔽that are shared in common.🔽The future: craving for becoming, which is the cause for the arising of the future life-continuum.

original: padhānaṃ hutvā uppādikā bhavataṇhā. Sahabhūmīti sahabhavikāpi rūpārūpadhammā. Sampayogāpīti
analyzed: padhānam hutvā uppādikā bhava taṇhā sahabhūmī iti sahabhavikā api rūpa arūpa dhammā sampayogā api iti
translated: The co-existent: the material and immaterial states that are co-existent.🔽The associated: the immaterial states that are associated.

original: ekato yuttāpi arūpadhammā. Sahajāpīti saddhiṃ ekacitte uppannāpi. Yāpi payojikāti
analyzed: ekatas yuttā api arūpa dhammā sahajā api iti saddhim eka citte uppannā api yā api payojikā ati
translated: The conascent: the states that arise together with consciousness in a single cognitive process.🔽The states that are helpful: the states that are helpful to the arising of the life-continuum.

original: cutipaṭisandhivasena yojetuṃ niyuttāti payojikā, vaṭṭamūlakā taṇhā. Vuttañhetaṃ “taṇhādutiyo
analyzed: cuti paṭisandhi vasena yojetum niyuttā ati payojikā vaṭṭamūlakā taṇhā vuttam ha etam taṇhādutiyaḥ
translated: They are ‘to be yoked’ by means of death and rebirth-linking, and so they are ‘useful’ . Craving is ‘rooted in the round’ . For this is said: ‘A man with craving as his second’ .

original: puriso”ti. Niccadubbalāti nirantarena dubbalā. Anavaṭṭhitāti na avaṭṭhitā, otaritvā🔽na ṭhitā. Paripātayanti imeti ime aññamaññaṃ pātayanti khepayanti. Aññamaññassāti
analyzed: puriso ti nicca dubbalā ati nirantarena dubbalā anavaṭṭhitā ati na avaṭṭhitā otaritvā  na ṭhitā paripātayanti ime iti ime aññam aññam pātayanti khepayanti aññam aññassa ati
translated: ‘Always weak’: continuously weak. ‘Not fixed’: not fixed, not standing after descending.

original: añño aññassa, eko ekassāti attho. Hi-iti kāraṇatthe nipāto. Natthi tāyitāti tāyano🔽rakkhako natthi. Na cāpi ṭhapenti aññamaññanti aññe aññaṃ ṭhapetuṃ na sakkonti. Yopi
analyzed: aññaḥ aññassa ekaḥ ekassa ati atthaḥ hi iti kāraṇa tthe nipātaḥ na atthi tāyitā ati tāyanaḥ  rakkhakaḥ natthi na ca api ṭhapenti aññam aññanti aññe aññam ṭhapetum na sakkonti yaḥ pi
translated: ‘They make each other fall’: they make each other fall, they make each other suffer. ‘Each other’s’: one another’s. ‘One’s own’: one’s own. ‘Hi’ is a particle indicating reason.🔽‘There is no saviour’: there is no protector.

original: nibbattako so na vijjatīti yopi imesaṃ uppādako dhammo, so idāni natthi.
analyzed: nibbattakaḥ saḥ na vijjati iti yaḥ api imesam uppādakaḥ dhammo so idāni natthi
translated: ‘Nor do they stand by each other’: they cannot stand by each other. ‘Nor is there any one who is born’: there is no state that is the producer of these.

original: Na ca kenaci koci hāyatīti koci ekopi kassaci vasena na parihāyati. Gandhabbā ca
analyzed: na ca kenaci koci hāyati iti koci ekaḥ api kassaci vasena na parihāyati gandhabbā ca
translated: ‘Nor does anyone ever fail’: not even one fails in anyone’s case. ‘Gandhabbas’:

original: ime hi sabbasoti sabbe hi ime khandhā sabbākārena bhaṅgaṃ pāpuṇituṃ yuttā. Purimehi
analyzed: ime hi sabbaso ti sabbe hi ime khandhāḥ sabba ākārena bhaṅgam pāpuṇitum yuttā purimehi
translated: ‘All these’: all these aggregates are fit to reach dissolution in every way.

original: pabhāvitā imeti pubbahetupaccayehi ime vattamānakā uppādikā. Yepi pabhāvikāti yepi
analyzed: pabhāvitāḥ ime ti pubba hetu paccayehi ime vattamānakāḥ uppādikāḥ ye pi pabhāvikā ati ye pi
translated: “These are developed”: these present ones are the arising ones by means of the former-conditions condition. “And those that are to be developed”:

original: ime vattamānakā uppādakā pubbahetupaccayā. Te pure matāti te vuttappakārapaccayā
analyzed: ime vattamānakā uppādakā pubba hetu paccayā te pure matā ati te vutta ppakāra paccayā
translated: these present ones are the arising ones by means of the former-conditions condition. “They died first”: those conditions of the aforementioned kind

original: vattamānaṃ apāpuṇitvā paṭhamameva maraṇaṃ pattā. Purimāpi ca pacchimāpi cāti purimā🔽pubbahetupaccayāpi ca pacchimā vattamāne paccayasamuppannā ca. Aññamaññaṃ na kadāci
analyzed: vattamānam apāpuṇitvā paṭhamam eva maraṇam pattā purimā api ca pacchimā api ca ati purimā  pubba hetu paccayā api ca pacchimā vattamāne paccaya samuppannā ca aññam aññam na kadāci
translated: died first before reaching the present. “The former and the latter”: the former

original: maddasaṃsūti aññamaññaṃ kismiñci kāle na diṭṭhapubbā. Ma-kāro padasandhivasena vutto.🔽Cātumahārājikānaṃ devānanti dhataraṭṭhavirūḷhakavirūpakkhakuverasaṅkhātā catumahārājā🔽issarā etesanti cātumahārājikā. Rūpādīhi dibbanti kīḷantīti devā. Te sinerupabbatassa
analyzed: aññam aññam kismiñci kāle na diṭṭha pubbā makāro pada sandhi vasena vutto  cātumahārājikānam devānam ti dhata raṭṭha virūḍhaka virūpakkha kuvera saṅkhātā catu mahārājā  issarāḥ cātumahārājikāḥ rūpa ādīhi dibbanti kīḷanti iti devā te sineru pabbatassa
translated: former-conditions condition and the latter present-conditions-originated . “Never saw each other”: never saw each other at any time. The syllable ma is stated for the sake of word division.

original: vemajjhe honti. Tesu atthi pabbataṭṭhakāpi, atthi ākāsaṭṭhakāpi. Tesaṃ paramparā
analyzed: vemajjhe honti tesu atthi pabbata ṭṭhakā api atthi ākāsa ṭṭhakā api tesam paramparā
translated: “The gods of the Four Great Kings”: the Four Great Kings called Dhataraṭṭha, Virūḷhaka, Virūpakkha, and Kuvera are the lords of these, thus they are the gods of the Four Great Kings . They are gods because they shine and play with the divine forms, etc. They are in the middle of the Sineru mountain. Among them, some are situated on the mountain, some are situated in space. Their succession

original: cakkavāḷapabbataṃ pattā. Khiḍḍāpadosikā manopadosikā sītavalāhakā uṇhavalāhakā candimā
analyzed: cakkavāḷa pabbatam pattā khiḍḍā padosikā manopadosikā sītavalāhakā uṇhavalāhakā candimā
translated: and they reach the Cakkavāḷa mountain. The gods called the ‘Playful’ and the ‘Thoughtless’ and the ‘Cool-rayed’ and the ‘Warm-rayed’ and the god called the ‘Moon’ and the god called the ‘Sun’—all these are just in the realm of the gods of the Four Kings.

original: devaputto sūriyo devaputtoti ete sabbepi cātumahārājikadevalokaṭṭhā eva tesaṃ cātumahārājikānaṃ🔽jīvitaṃ. Upādāyāti paṭicca. Parittakanti vuddhipaṭisedho. Thokanti mandakālaṃ, dīghadivasapaṭisedho.
analyzed: deva putto sūriyaḥ deva putto ti ete sabbe pi cātumahārājika deva loka ṭṭhāḥ eva tesam cātumahārājikānam  jīvitam upādāya ati paṭicca parittakam ti vuddhi paṭisedho thokam ti manda kālam dīgha divasa paṭisedho
translated: The life of these gods of the Four Kings is …🔽‘In dependence on’ means ‘in relation to’. ‘Short’ is a restriction of increase. ‘Little’ is a restriction of the long period, a restriction of the long day.

original: Khaṇikanti mandakālaṃ, kālantarapaṭisedho. Lahukanti sallahukaṃ, alasapaṭisedho.🔽Itaranti sīghabalavapaṭisedho. Anaddhanīyanti kālavasena na addhānakkhamaṃ. Naciraṭṭhitikanti
analyzed: khaṇikam ti manda kālam kāla antara paṭisedhaḥ lahukam ti sat lahukam alasa paṭisedho  itaranti sīgha balava paṭisedhaḥ anaddhanīyanti kāla vasena na addhānakkhamam naciraṭṭhitikam ti
translated: ‘Momentary’ is a restriction of the long period, a restriction of the time. ‘Light’ is a restriction of laziness.🔽‘Otherwise’ is a restriction of the quick and strong. ‘Not to be extended’ means not to be extended in time. ‘Not long-lasting’

original: divasena ciraṃ na tiṭṭhatīti naciraṭṭhitikaṃ, divasapaṭisedho.🔽Tāvatiṃsānanti tettiṃsajanā tattha upapannāti tāvatiṃsā. Api ca tāvatiṃsāti tesaṃ
analyzed: divasena ciram na tiṭṭhati iti naciraṭṭhitikam divasa paṭisedho  tettiṃsa janā tattha upapannā ati tāvatiṃsā api ca tāvatiṃsā ati tesam
translated: means ‘not long-lasting’, a restriction of the day.🔽‘The Thirty-Three’ means the Thirty-Three people who have arisen there. Moreover, it is said that ‘Thirty-Three’ is just the name of those gods. They are some who live on the mountain, some who live in space. Their succession

original: devānaṃ nāmamevātipi vuttaṃ. Tepi atthi pabbataṭṭhakā, atthi ākāsaṭṭhakā, tesaṃ paramparā
analyzed: devānam nāmam eva atipi vuttam te pi atthi pabbata ṭṭhakā atthi ākāsa ṭṭhakā tesam paramparā
translated: is as follows:

original: cakkavāḷapabbataṃ pattā. Tathā yāmādīnaṃ. Ekadevalokepi hi devānaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ
analyzed: cakkavāḷa pabbatam pattā tathā yāma ādīnam eka deva loke pi hi devānam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam
translated: and they reach the Cakkavāḷa mountain. So too with the Yāma gods, and so on. For in a single divine world there are no gods who have not reached the Cakkavāḷa mountain.

original: appattā nāma natthi. Dibbasukhaṃ yātā payātā sampattāti yāmā. Tuṭṭhā pahaṭṭhāti tusitā.🔽Pakatipaṭiyattārammaṇato atirekena nimmitukāmakāle yathārucite bhoge nimminitvā ramantīti
analyzed: appattā nāma natthi dibba sukham yātā payātā sampattā ati yāmā tuṭṭhā pahaṭṭhā ati tusitā  pakati paṭiyatta ārammaṇataḥ atirekena nimmitu kāma kāle yathā rucite bhoge nimminitvā ramanti iti
translated: They have gone, have departed, have reached, divine bliss, thus they are Yāma gods . They are satisfied, well satisfied, thus they are Tusita gods .

original: nimmānaratī. Cittācāraṃ ñatvā parehi nimmitesu bhogesu vasaṃ vattentīti paranimmitavasavattī.
analyzed: nimmāna ratī citta ācāram ñatvā parehi nimmitesu bhogesu vasam vattenti iti para nimmita vasa vattī
translated: When they want to create more than the ordinary created objects, they create objects of sensual desire as they choose and they delight in them, thus they are Nimmāṇarati gods . They exercise control over the objects of sensual desire created by others, thus they are Paranimmitavasavatti gods .

original: Brahmakāye brahmaghaṭāya niyuttāti brahmakāyikā. Sabbepi pañcavokārabrahmāno gahitā.
analyzed: brahmakāye brahma ghaṭāya brahmakāyikā sabbe api pañcavokāra brahmānaḥ gahitā
translated: They are appointed to the divine drum in the Brahmā group, thus they are Brahmakāyika gods . All the five-constituent Brahmās are included.

original: Gamaniyoti gandhabbo. Samparāyoti paraloko. Yo bhikkhave ciraṃ jīvati, so vassasatanti
analyzed: gamaniyaḥ ti gandhabbo samparāyaḥ ti para lokaḥ yaḥ bhikkhave ciram jīvati saḥ vassa satan ti
translated: A gandhabba is one who goes by smell . The next world is the world beyond. One who lives long, monks, lives a hundred years,

original: yo ciraṃ tiṭṭhamāno, so vassasatamattaṃ tiṭṭhati. Appaṃ vā bhiyyoti vassasatato upari
analyzed: yaḥ ciram tiṭṭhamāno saḥ vassa sata mattam tiṭṭhati appam vā bhiyyo ti vassa satataḥ upari
translated: one who lives a long time stands a hundred years. Or less, monks,

original: tiṭṭhamāno dve vassasatāni tiṭṭhamāno nāma natthi. Hīḷeyya nanti naṃ jīvitaṃ avaññātaṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhamānaḥ dve vassa satāni tiṭṭhamānaḥ nāma natthi hīḷeyya nanti nam jīvitam avaññātam
translated: There is no one who can live for two hundred years while remaining the same.🔽He would despise his life: he would despise it, make light of it, think it worthless.

original: kareyya, lāmakato cinteyya. “Hīḷeyyāna”nti ca paṭhanti. Accayantīti atikkamanti.
analyzed: ca paṭhanti accayanti iti atikkamanti
translated: They also read “he would despise it” .🔽They would pass beyond: they would go beyond.🔽Day and night: the day and night are the means of measuring time.

original: Ahorattāti rattindivaparicchedā. Uparujjhatīti jīvitindriyaṃ nirujjhati, abhāvaṃ
analyzed: ahar rattā ati ratti indiva paricchedāḥ uparujjhati iti jīvitindriyam nirujjhati abhāvam
translated: It would cease: the life faculty would cease, go to destruction.

original: upagacchati. Āyu khiyyati maccānanti sattānaṃ āyusaṅkhāro khayaṃ yāti. Kunnadīnaṃva
analyzed: upagacchati āyu khiyyati sattānam āyu saṅkhāraḥ khayam yāti
translated: The life of mortals fades away: the life-formation of beings fades away, goes to destruction.

original: odakanti yathā udakacchinnāya kunnadiyā udakaṃ, evaṃ maccānaṃ āyu khiyyati. Paramatthato
analyzed: yathā udaka chinnāya kunnadiyāḥ udakam evam āyu khiyyati paramatthato
translated: Like the water in a hoofprint: just as the water in a hoofprint left by a horse or a cow fades away, so the life of mortals fades away.

original: hi atiparitto sattānaṃ jīvitakkhaṇo ekacittakkhaṇikamattoyeva. Yathā nāma rathacakkaṃ
analyzed: hi ati parittaḥ sattānam jīvita khaṇaḥ yathā nāma ratha cakkam
translated: For in the ultimate sense the life-span of beings is extremely short, being only as much as a single conscious moment.

original: pavattamānampi ekeneva nemipadesena pavattati, tiṭṭhamānampi ekeneva tiṭṭhati, evameva
analyzed: pavattamānam api ekena iva nemi padesena pavattati tiṭṭhamānam api ekena iva tiṭṭhati evam eva
translated: Just as a chariot wheel, when it is rolling, is supported by one point of its circumference,

original: ekacittakkhaṇikaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitaṃ tasmiṃ citte niruddhamatte satto niruddhoti vuccati.
analyzed: eka citta khaṇikam sattānam jīvitam tasmim citte niruddha matte sattaḥ niruddhaḥ iti vuccati
translated: and when it is at rest, is supported by another point, so too the life of beings is momentary. When a consciousness has ceased, the being is said to have ceased.

original: Dhīrāti dhīrā iti. Puna dhīrāti paṇḍitā. Dhitimāti dhiti assa atthīti dhitimā. Dhitisampannāti🔽paṇḍiccena samannāgatā. Dhīkatapāpāti garahitapāpā. Taṃyeva pariyāyaṃ dassetuṃ “dhī🔽vuccati paññā”tiādimāha. Tattha pajānātīti paññā. Kiṃ pajānāti? “Idaṃ dukkha”ntiādinā🔽nayena ariyasaccāni. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “paññāpanavasena paññā”ti vuttā. Kinti paññāpeti?
analyzed: dhīrā ati dhīrā iti puna dhīrā ati paṇḍitā dhitimā ati dhiti assa atthi iti dhitimā dhiti sampannā ati  paṇḍiccena samannāgatā dhīkata pāpā ati garahita pāpā taṃyeva pariyāyam dassetum dhī  vuccati paññā iti ādim āha tattha pajānāti iti paññā kim pajānāti idam dukkham ti ādinā  nayena ariya saccāni aṭṭhakathā ayam pana paññāpana vasena paññā ati vuttā kinti paññāpeti
translated: “Wise” : wise ones are called “wise” . Again, “wise” : clever. “Endowed with wisdom” : he has wisdom , thus he is “endowed with wisdom” . “Possessed of wisdom” : he is endowed with cleverness . “Having abandoned evil” : having abandoned evil . In order to show that very method, he said “wisdom is called understanding” , etc. Herein, “understanding” : she understands , thus she is “understanding” . What does she understand? She understands the noble truths in the way beginning “This is suffering” . But in the commentary it is said: “Understanding is so called in the sense of making known . What does she make known?

original: “Aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā”ti paññāpeti. Sāva avijjāya abhibhavanato adhipatiyaṭṭhena🔽indriyaṃ, dassanalakkhaṇe vā indaṭṭhaṃ kāretītipi indriyaṃ, paññāva indriyaṃ paññindriyaṃ.🔽Sā panesā obhāsanalakkhaṇā, pajānanalakkhaṇā ca; yathā hi catubhittike gehe rattibhāge
analyzed: aniccam dukkham anattā ti paññāpeti sāva avijjāya abhibhavanataḥ adhipatiya ṭṭhena 🔽indriyam dassana lakkhaṇe vā indaṭṭham kāreti itipi indriyam paññāvaḥ indriyam paññindriyam 🔽sā pana isā obhāsana lakkhaṇā pajānana lakkhaṇā ca yathā hi catu bhittike gehe ratti bhāge
translated: “Wise” : wise ones are called “wise” . Again, “wise” : clever. “Endowed with wisdom” : he has wisdom , thus he is “endowed with wisdom” . “Endowed with wisdom” : endowed with cleverness. “Having abandoned evil” : having abandoned evil . In order to show that very method, he said “wisdom is called … ” . Herein, “one understands” : wisdom . What does one understand? The noble truths in the way beginning “This is suffering” . But in the Commentary it is said: “Wisdom is so called in the sense of making known . What does it make known? It makes known “impermanent, suffering, not-self” . And that is a faculty in the sense of predominance, since it is not overcome by ignorance . Or it is a faculty since it causes the doing of the function of seeing in the characteristic of wisdom . Wisdom itself is a faculty is the faculty of wisdom . And that has the characteristic of illuminating, the characteristic of understanding ; for just as in a house with four walls, at night-time

original: dīpe jalite andhakāraṃ nirujjhati, āloko pātubhavati, evameva obhāsanalakkhaṇā paññā.
analyzed: dīpe jalite andhakāram nirujjhati āloko pātubhavati evam eva obhāsana lakkhaṇā paññā
translated: When the lamp is lit, the darkness ceases, light appears. So understanding has the characteristic of illuminating.🔽There is no light equal to understanding. For when a man of understanding sits cross-legged,

original: Paññobhāsasamo obhāso nāma natthi. Paññavato hi ekapallaṅkena nisinnassa dasasahassilokadhātu
analyzed: paññobhāsasamo obhāsaḥ nāma natthi paññavataḥ hi eka pallaṅkena nisinnassa dasa sahassi lokadhātu
translated: the ten-thousand world-element

original: ekālokā hoti. Tenāha thero –
analyzed: tena āha theraḥ
translated: becomes one light. Therefore the Elder said:

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, puriso andhakāre gehe telappadīpaṃ paveseyya, paviṭṭho padīpo andhakāraṃ🔽viddhaṃseti, obhāsaṃ janeti, ālokaṃ vidaṃseti, pākaṭāni ca rūpāni karoti; evameva🔽kho, mahārāja, paññā uppajjamānā avijjandhakāraṃ viddhaṃseti, vijjobhāsaṃ janeti,
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja purisaḥ andhakāre gehe tela ppadīpam paveseyya paviṭṭhaḥ padīpaḥ andhakāram  obhāsam jana iti ālokam vidaṃsa iti pākaṭāni ca rūpāni karoti evam eva  kho mahā rāja paññā uppajjamānā a vijja andhakāram viddhaṃseti vijjobhāsam janeti
translated: “As, sire, a man might bring a lamp into a dark house, and when it had come in the darkness would be dispelled,🔽light would appear, the darkness being destroyed, and the forms would become manifest; even so, sire, understanding, when it arises, dispels the darkness of ignorance,

original: ñāṇālokaṃ vidaṃseti, pākaṭāni ariyasaccāni karoti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, obhāsanalakkhaṇā paññā”ti.
analyzed: ñāṇa ālokam vidaṃseti pākaṭāni ariya saccāni karoti evam kho mahā rāja obhāsana lakkhaṇā paññā ati
translated: produces the light of knowledge, makes the light of understanding appear, and makes the Noble Truths manifest. Thus, sire, understanding has the characteristic of illuminating.”

original: Yathā pana cheko bhisakko āturānaṃ sappāyāsappāyāni bhojanādīni jānāti, evaṃ paññā
analyzed: yathā pana chekaḥ bhisakkaḥ āturānam sappāya asappāyāni bhojana ādīni jānāti evam paññā
translated: And just as a skilled physician knows what is beneficial and harmful in food, etc., for the sick, so does understanding.

original: uppajjamānā kusalākusale sevitabbāsevitabbe hīnappaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgaappaṭibhāge
analyzed: uppajjamānā kusala akusale sevitabba asevitabbe hīna ppaṇīta kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāga appaṭibhāge
translated: He understands profitable and unprofitable, blamable and blameless, rough and refined, what is within the sphere of the homely and what is beyond it, and the way and the way out,

original: dhamme pajānāti. Vuttampi cetaṃ dhammasenāpatinā “pajānāti pajānātīti kho, āvuso,
analyzed: dhamme pajānāti vuttam pi ca itam dhamma senāpatinā pajānāti pajānāti iti kho āvuso
translated: as well as the profitable and unprofitable, etc., that have appeared. And this is said by the General of the Dhamma: “He understands, he understands, thus ‘understanding’ is said.

original: tasmā paññavāti vuccati. Kiñca pajānāti? Idaṃ dukkhanti pajānātī”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā paññavā ti vuccati kiñca pajānāti idam dukkhanti pajānāti iti vitthāretabbam
translated: What does he understand? He understands ‘This is suffering’ … “ and so on. The detail should be taken as in the Description of the Aggregates .

original: Evamassā pajānanalakkhaṇatā veditabbā.
analyzed: evam assā pajānana lakkhaṇa tā veditabbā
translated: This is how the characteristic of understanding should be understood.

original: Aparo nayo – yathāsabhāvapaṭivedhalakkhaṇā paññā, akkhalitapaṭivedhalakkhaṇā vā,
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ yathā sabhāva paṭivedha lakkhaṇā paññā akkhalita paṭivedha lakkhaṇā vā
translated: Another method: understanding has the characteristic of penetrating the specific nature of an object. Or it has the characteristic of unerring penetration,

original: kusalissāsakhittausupaṭivedho viya. Visayobhāsarasā, padīpo viya. Asammohapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: viya visaya ubhāsa rasā padīpaḥ viya asammoha paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: like the penetration of a skilled fletcher. Its function is to illuminate an object, like a lamp. It is manifested as non-confusion,

original: araññagatasudesako viya.🔽Khandhadhīrāti pañcasu khandhesuñāṇaṃ pavattentīti khandhadhīrā. Aṭṭhārasasu dhātūsu
analyzed: arañña gata sudesakaḥ viya  khandha dhīrā ati pañcasu khandhesu ñāṇam pavattenti iti khandha dhīrāḥ aṭṭhārasasu dhātūsu
translated: like a guide in a forest.🔽The wise in the aggregates: the wise in the five aggregates. The wise in the six internal sense bases: the wise in the eye, etc.,🔽the wise in the six external sense bases: the wise in visible data, etc.,🔽The wise in the six classes of consciousness: the wise in eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: ñāṇaṃ pavattentīti dhātudhīrā. Sesesupi iminā nayena attho netabbo. Te dhīrā evamāhaṃsūti
analyzed: ñāṇam pavattenti iti dhātu dhīrāḥ sesesu pi iminā nayena atthaḥ netabbo te dhīrāḥ evam āhaṃsu iti
translated: The wise in the six classes of contact: the wise in eye-contact, etc.,🔽The wise in the six classes of feeling: the wise in eye-contact-born feeling, etc.,🔽The wise in the six classes of craving: the wise in craving for visible data, etc.,🔽The wise in the four noble truths: the wise in the noble truth of suffering, etc.,

original: ete paṇḍitā evaṃ kathayiṃsu. Kathentīti “appakaṃ parittaka”nti kathayanti. Bhaṇantīti
analyzed: ete paṇḍitāḥ evam kathayiṃsu kathenti iti appakam parittakam ti kathayanti bhaṇanti iti
translated: These are the wise ones who say thus. They say: “A little, a small amount” . They speak:🔽“A little, a short time” . They illuminate:

original: “thokaṃ khaṇika”nti bhāsanti. Dīpayantīti “lahukaṃ ittara”nti patiṭṭhapenti. Voharantīti
analyzed: thokam bhāsanti dīpayanti iti lahukam ittaranti patiṭṭhapenti voharanti iti
translated: “Light, trifling” . They use:

original: “anaddhanikaṃ naciraṭṭhitika”nti nānāvidhena byavaharanti.🔽11. Idāni ye tathā na karonti, tesaṃ byasanuppattiṃ dassento “passāmī”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: anaddhanikam naciraṭṭhitikam ti nānāvidhena byavaharanti  idāni ye tathā na karonti tesam byasana uppattim dassentaḥ passāmi iti gātham āha
translated: “Not lasting, not long-lasting” .🔽Now, showing the misfortune of those who do not do so, he said the verse “Passāmi” .

original: Tattha passāmīti maṃsacakkhuādīhi pekkhāmi. Loketi apāyādimhi. Pariphandamānanti
analyzed: tattha passāmi iti maṃsa cakkhu ādīhi pekkhāmi loke ti apāya ādimhi pariphandamānanti
translated: There, passāmīti I see with the fleshly eye, etc. Loketi in the bad destinations, etc. Pariphandamānanti

original: ito cito ca phandamānaṃ. Pajaṃ imanti imaṃ sattakāyaṃ. Taṇhāgatanti taṇhāya gataṃ🔽abhibhūtaṃ nipātitanti adhippāyo. Bhavesūti kāmabhavādīsu. Hīnā narāti hīnakammantā
analyzed: itas citas ca phandamānam pajam imanti imam satta kāyam taṇhā gatam taṇhāya gatam  abhibhūtam nipātitam ti adhippāyaḥ bhavesu iti kāma bhava ādīsu hīnāḥ narā ati hīna kammantā
translated: wandering here and there. Pajaṃ imanti this group of beings. Taṇhāgatanti gone to craving,🔽overcome, fallen into, is the meaning. Bhavesūti in the sensual realm, etc. Hīnā narāti

original: narā. Maccumukhe lapantīti antakāle sampatte maraṇamukhe paridevanti. Avītataṇhāseti
analyzed: narāḥ mad cu mukhe lapanti iti anta kāle sampatte maraṇa mukhe paridevanti a vīta taṇhāsā iti
translated: low in action, low in conduct, low in morality, low in wisdom, low in birth, low in livelihood, low in means of living, low in the good, low in the good life, low in the good practice, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of life, low in the good way of livelihood, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in the good way of living, low in

original: avigatataṇhā. Bhavāti kāmabhavādikā. Bhavesūti kāmabhavādikesu. Atha vā bhavābhavesūti
analyzed: avigata taṇhāḥ kāma bhava ādikāḥ bhavesu uti kāma bhava ādikesu atha vā bhava abhavesu uti
translated: in sense-desire becoming, etc., and in the cessation of sense-desire becoming, etc.

original: bhavabhavesu, punappunabhavesūti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: bhava bhavesu punappunabhavesu iti vuttam hoti
translated: ‘Again and again’ means repeatedly.

original: Passāmīti maṃsacakkhunāpi passāmīti duvidhaṃ maṃsacakkhu – sasambhāracakkhu pasādacakkhūti.
analyzed: passāmi iti maṃsa cakkhunā api passāmi iti duvidham maṃsa cakkhu sa sambhāra cakkhu pasāda cakkhu iti
translated: ‘I see’ means I see with the fleshly eye. The fleshly eye is of two kinds: the eye with physical nutriment as its support and the eye with faith as its support.

original: Tattha yoyaṃ akkhikūpake patiṭṭhito heṭṭhā akkhikūpakaṭṭhikena upari bhamukaṭṭhikena🔽ubhato akkhikūṭehi bahiddhā akkhilomehi paricchinno akkhikūpakamajjhā nikkhantena
analyzed: tattha yaḥ ayam akkhi kūpake patiṭṭhitaḥ heṭṭhā akkhi kūpaka ṭṭhikena upari bhamuka ṭṭhikena  ubhatas akkhi kūṭehi bahiddhā akkhi lomehi paricchinnaḥ akkhi kūpaka majjhā nikkhantena
translated: Herein, the lump of flesh that is situated in the eye socket, below the eye socket bone, above the eye muscle,🔽enclosed on both sides by the eye socket rims, and bound to the brain by a sinew that emerges from the middle of the eye socket,

original: nhārusuttakena matthaluṅge ābaddho setakaṇhamaṇḍalavicitto maṃsapiṇḍo, idaṃ sasambhāracakkhu🔽nāma. Yo pana ettha sito ettha paṭibaddho catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya pasādo, idaṃ
analyzed: nhāru suttakena mattha luṅge ābaddhaḥ seta kaṇha maṇḍala vicittaḥ maṃsa piṇḍaḥ idam sa sambhāra cakkhu  nāma yaḥ pana ettha sitaḥ ettha paṭibaddho catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya pasādaḥ idam
translated: and which is variegated with white, black, and red patches, is called the eye with physical nutriment as its support.🔽But the clarity that is clear in that , that is bound up with that , and that is derived from the four great primaries, is called the eye with faith as its support.

original: pasādacakkhu nāma. Idamadhippetaṃ. Tadetaṃ tassa sasambhāracakkhuno setamaṇḍalaparikkhittassa
analyzed: pasāda cakkhu nāma idam adhippetam tat etam tassa sa sambhāra cakkhuno seta maṇḍala parikkhittassa
translated: That is what is intended here. That is surrounded by the white circle of the eye with physical nutriment as its support.

original: kaṇhamaṇḍalassa majjhe abhimukhe ṭhitānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānuppattipadese diṭṭhamaṇḍale
analyzed: kaṇha maṇḍalassa majjhe abhimukhe ṭhitānam sarīra saṇṭhāna uppatti padese diṭṭha maṇḍale
translated: In the middle of the black circle, in the place where the shape of the body appears to those who stand facing it, there is a circle seen as follows:

original: sattasu picupaṭalesu āsittatelaṃ picupaṭalāni viya sattakkhipaṭalāni byāpetvā pamāṇato
analyzed: sattasu picu paṭalesu āsitta telam picu paṭalāni viya satta kkhipaṭalāni byāpetvā pamāṇato
translated: Just as oil pervades sesame seed, so the seven layers of the eye pervade the seven layers of the eye with the oil of bile. As to measurement,

original: ūkāsiramattaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati.🔽Taṃ cakkhatīti cakkhu, tena maṃsacakkhunā passāmi. Dibbacakkhunāti “addasaṃ kho ahaṃ,
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati  tam cakkhati iti cakkhu tena maṃsa cakkhunā passāmi dibba cakkhunā ati addasam kho aham
translated: it is the size of a jujube kernel. It is present accomplishing the state of physical basis and door for the eye-consciousness, etc., as appropriate.

original: bhikkhave, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhenā”ti evaṃvidhena dibbacakkhunā. Paññācakkhunāti
analyzed: bhikkhave dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena ati evaṃvidhena dibba cakkhunā paññā cakkhunā ati
translated: It is called eye because it is rolled (cakka) in a circle (cakka). I see with that fleshly eye. With the divine eye: with the divine eye described thus, “Bhikkhus, with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, I see beings” . With the wisdom eye:

original: “virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādī”ti evaṃ āgatena paññācakkhunā. Buddhacakkhunāti
analyzed: virajam vīta malam dhammacakkhum udapādi iti evam āgatena paññācakkhunā buddha cakkhunā ati
translated: with the wisdom eye described thus, “The dust-free, stainless eye of Dhamma arose in me” . With the Buddha eye:

original: “addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento”ti evamāgatena buddhacakkhunā.
analyzed: addasam kho aham bhikkhave buddha cakkhunā lokam volokento ti evam āgatena buddha cakkhunā
translated: with the Buddha eye described thus, “Bhikkhus, looking around the world with my Buddha eye” .

original: Samantacakkhunāti “samantacakkhu vuccati sabbaññutaññāṇa”nti evamāgatena samantacakkhunā.
analyzed: samanta cakkhunā ati samanta cakkhu vuccati sabbaññuta ññāṇam ti evam āgatena samanta cakkhunā
translated: With the all-seeing eye: with the all-seeing eye described thus, “The all-seeing eye is called the knowledge of omniscience” .

original: Passāmīti maṃsacakkhunā hatthatale ṭhapitāmalakaṃ viya rūpagataṃ maṃsacakkhunā. Dakkhāmīti
analyzed: passāmi iti maṃsa cakkhunā hattha tale ṭhapita āmalakam viya rūpa gatam maṃsa cakkhunā dakkhāmi iti
translated: “I see” means that he sees the visible form with the fleshly eye, as if he were seeing a myrobalan fruit in the palm of his hand.

original: sañjānāmi dibbena cakkhunā cutūpapātaṃ. Olokemīti avalokemi paññācakkhunā catusaccaṃ.🔽Nijjhāyāmīti cintemi buddhacakkhunā saddhāpañcamakāni indriyāni. Upaparikkhāmīti
analyzed: sañjānāmi dibbena cakkhunā cutūpapātam olokemi iti avalokemi paññā cakkhunā catu saccam  nijjhāyāmi iti cintemi buddha cakkhunā saddhā pañcamakāni indriyāni upaparikkhāmi iti
translated: I see: I see with the fleshly eye, as though a myrobalan fruit were lying in the palm of my hand, a visible object. I behold: I behold with the divine eye the passing away and arising of beings. I look: I look with the eye of wisdom at the Four Noble Truths.

original: samantato ikkhāmi pariyesāmi samantacakkhunā pañca neyyapathe.🔽Taṇhāphandanāya phandamānanti taṇhācalanāya calamānaṃ. Ito paraṃ diṭṭhiphandanādidiṭṭhibyasanena
analyzed: samantataḥ ikkhāmi pariyesāmi samanta cakkhunā pañca neyya pathe  taṇhā phandanāya taṇhā calanāya calamānam ito param diṭṭhi phandana ādi diṭṭhi byasanena
translated: I contemplate: I contemplate with the Buddha-eye the five faculties beginning with faith. I investigate: I investigate with the all-seeing eye the five kinds of persons.

original: dukkhena phandamānapariyosānaṃ vuttanayattā uttānameva. Samphandamānanti punappunaṃ🔽phandamānaṃ. Vipphandamānanti nānāvidhena calamānaṃ. Vedhamānanti kampamānaṃ. Pavedhamānanti
analyzed: dukkhena phandamāna pariyosānam vutta naya ttā uttānam eva samphandamānanti punappunam  phandamānam vipphandamānanti nānāvidhena calamānam vedhamānanti kampamānam pavedhamānanti
translated: Shaking with the shaking of craving: shaking with the trembling of craving. From here on the text is self-evident up to the end of the sutta, where the shaking is due to the suffering of the defilements.

original: padhānena kampamānaṃ. Sampavedhamānanti punappunaṃ kampamānaṃ. Upasaggena vā padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: padhānena kampamānam sampavedhamānanti punappunam kampamānam upasaggena vā padam vaḍḍhitam
translated: Shaking again and again: shaking repeatedly. Trembling: trembling in various ways. Quaking: trembling. Trembling violently: trembling violently. The word is strengthened by the prefix sam-.

original: Taṇhānugatanti taṇhāya anupaviṭṭhaṃ. Taṇhāyānusaṭanti taṇhāya anupatthaṭaṃ. Taṇhāyāsannanti
analyzed: taṇhā anugatanti taṇhāya anupaviṭṭham taṇhāya anusaṭanti taṇhāya anupatthaṭam taṇhāya āsannanti
translated: “Gone by craving” : gone by craving. “Clung to by craving” : clung to by craving. “Immersed in craving” :

original: taṇhāya nimuggaṃ. Taṇhāya pātitanti taṇhāya khittaṃ. “Paripātita”nti vā pāṭho. Abhibhūtanti
analyzed: taṇhāya nimuggam taṇhāya pātitanti taṇhāya khittam paripātitanti vā pāṭhaḥ abhibhūtanti
translated: immersed in craving. “Cast by craving” : cast by craving. Or the reading is “paripātita” . “Overwhelmed by craving” :

original: taṇhāya madditaṃ ajjhotthaṭaṃ. Pariyādinnacittanti khepetvā gahitacittaṃ. Atha vā
analyzed: taṇhāya madditam ajjhotthaṭam pariyādinna cittam ti khepetvā gahita cittam atha vā
translated: crushed by craving, overwhelmed by craving. “With mind obsessed” : with mind obsessed. Or

original: oghena gataṃ viya taṇhāgataṃ. Upādiṇṇakarūpapaccayehi patitvā gataṃ viya taṇhānugataṃ.🔽Udakapiṭṭhiṃ chādetvā patthaṭanīlikā udakapiṭṭhi viya taṇhānusaṭaṃ. Vaccakūpe nimuggaṃ
analyzed: oghena gatam viya taṇhā gatam upādiṇṇaka rūpa paccayehi patitvā gatam viya taṇhā anugatam  udaka piṭṭhim chādetvā patthaṭa nīlikā udaka piṭṭhi viya taṇhā anusaṭam vaccakūpe nimuggaṃ
translated: “gone by craving” is like one gone by a stream. “Gone by craving” is like one gone by falling on the supporting conditions of the materiality clung to.🔽“Clung to by craving” is like a dark snake lying hidden on the back of the water. “Immersed in craving” is like one immersed in a cesspool.

original: viya taṇhāyāsannaṃ. Rukkhaggato patitvā narake patitaṃ viya taṇhāpātitaṃ. Upādiṇṇakarūpaṃ
analyzed: viya taṇhāya āsannam rukkha aggataḥ patitvā narake patitam viya taṇhā pātitam upādiṇṇaka rūpam
translated: “Cast by craving” is like one fallen from the top of a tree and fallen into hell. “Overwhelmed by craving” is like the materiality clung to in union with craving.

original: saṃyogaṃ viya taṇhāya abhibhūtaṃ. Upādiṇṇakarūpapariggāhakassa uppannavipassanaṃ
analyzed: saṃyogam viya taṇhāya abhibhūtam upādiṇṇaka rūpa pariggāhakassa uppanna vipassanam
translated: “With mind obsessed” is like insight arisen in one who has taken up the materiality clung to and its supporting conditions.

original: viya taṇhāya pariyādinnacittaṃ. Atha vā kāmacchandena taṇhāgataṃ. Kāmapipāsāya taṇhānugataṃ.
analyzed: taṇhāya pariyādinna cittam atha vā kāma chandena taṇhā gatam kāma pipāsāya taṇhā anugatam
translated: as if his mind were possessed by craving. Or else: “Craving-rooted” means rooted in craving. “Craving-accompanied” means accompanied by craving.

original: Kāmāsavena taṇhānusaṭaṃ. Kāmapariḷāhena taṇhāyāsannaṃ. Kāmajjhosānena taṇhāya pātitaṃ.🔽Kāmoghena taṇhāya abhibhūtaṃ. Kāmupādānena taṇhāya pariyādinnacittanti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: kāma āsavena taṇhā anusaṭam kāma pariḷāhena taṇhāya āsannam kāma ajjhosānena taṇhāya pātitam  kāma oghena taṇhāya abhibhūtam kāma upādānena taṇhāya evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: “Craving-connected” means connected with craving. “Craving-proximate” means near to craving. “Craving-fallen” means fallen into craving.🔽“Craving-overwhelmed” means overwhelmed by craving. “Craving-possessed” means his mind is possessed by craving.

original: Kāmabhaveti kāmāvacare. Rūpabhaveti rūpāvacare. Arūpabhaveti arūpāvacare. Tesaṃ nānattaṃ
analyzed: kāma bhava iti kāmāvacare rūpa bhava iti rūpāvacare arūpa bhava iti arūpāvacare tesam nānattam
translated: So some explain. “In the sense-desire becoming” means in the sense-desire realm. “In the form becoming” means in the form realm. “In the formless becoming” means in the formless realm. The difference between these three is

original: heṭṭhā pakāsitaṃyeva.🔽Bhavābhavesūti bhavābhaveti bhavoti kāmadhātu. Abhavoti rūpārūpadhātu. Atha vā bhavoti🔽kāmadhātu rūpadhātu. Abhavoti arūpadhātu. Tesu bhavābhavesu. Kammabhaveti kammavaṭṭe.
analyzed: heṭṭhā pakāsitaṃ yeva  bhava abhavesu uti bhava abhava iti bhavoti kāmadhātu abhavoti rūpa arūpadhātu atha vā  kāmadhātu rūpadhātu abhavoti arūpadhātu tesu bhava abhavesu kamma bhaveti kamma vaṭṭe
translated: explained below.🔽“In becoming and in the absence of becoming” means: “becoming” is the sense-desire realm, “absence of becoming” is the form and formless realms. Or else: “becoming” is the sense-desire realm and the form realm, “absence of becoming” is the formless realm. In these “becoming and absence of becoming.” “In the becoming of kamma” means in the round of kamma.

original: Punabbhaveti ponobhavike vipākavaṭṭe. Kāmabhaveti kāmadhātuyā. Kammabhaveti kammavaṭṭe.
analyzed: punabbhava iti ponobhavike vipāka vaṭṭe kāma bhaveti kāmadhātuyā kamma bhaveti kamma vaṭṭe
translated: “In the rebirth-process” means in the round of results. “In the sense-desire becoming” means in the sense-desire realm. “In the becoming of kamma” means in the round of kamma.

original: Tattha kammabhavo bhāvayatīti bhavo. Kāmabhave punabbhaveti kāmadhātuyā upapattibhave🔽vipākavaṭṭe. Vipākabhavo bhavatīti bhavo. Rūpabhavādīsupi eseva nayo. Ettha ca “kāmabhave
analyzed: tattha kamma bhavaḥ bhāvayati iti bhavaḥ kāma bhave punabbhave iti kāmadhātuyāḥ upapatti bhave  vipāka vaṭṭe vipāka bhavaḥ bhavati iti bhavaḥ rūpa bhava ādīsupi eṣa iva nayaḥ ettha ca kāma bhave
translated: Herein, kamma-process becoming is becoming because it makes become ; in sense-desire becoming, in rebirth-process becoming in the sense-desire element,

original: rūpabhave arūpabhave”ti okāsabhavaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tīsupi “kammabhave”ti kammabhavaṃ,
analyzed: rūpa bhave arūpa bhave iti okāsa bhavam sandhāya vuttam tīsu pi kamma bhave iti kamma bhavam
translated: in the result round, the result-process becoming is becoming because it becomes . The same method applies in the case of the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming. And here “in sense-desire becoming” and “in fine-material becoming” and “in immaterial becoming” are said with reference to the location kind of becoming. And in all three “in kamma-process becoming” is said with reference to the kamma-process kind of becoming,

original: tathā “punabbhave”ti upapattibhavaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Punappunabbhaveti aparāparaṃ
analyzed: tathā punabbhava iti upapatti bhavam sandhāya vuttam punar punabbhava iti apara aparam
translated: and “in rebirth-process becoming” is said with reference to the rebirth-process kind of becoming. “In becoming again and again” is in the sense of arising again and again.

original: uppattiyaṃ. Gatiyāti pañcagatiyā aññatarāya. Attabhāvābhinibbattiyāti attabhāvānaṃ
analyzed: uppattiyam gatiyā ati pañca gatiyāḥ aññatarāya atta bhāva abhinibbattiyā ati atta bhāvānam
translated: “In destinies” is in the sense of one of the five kinds of destiny. “In the generation of individual existence” is in the sense of the generation of individual existence.

original: abhinibbattiyā. Avītataṇhāti mūlapadaṃ. Avigatataṇhāti khaṇikasamādhi viya khaṇikappahānābhāvena🔽na vigatā taṇhā etesanti avigatataṇhā. Acattataṇhāti tadaṅgappahānābhāvena apariccattataṇhā.
analyzed: abhinibbattiyā avīta taṇhā ati mūla padam avigata taṇhā ati khaṇika samādhi viya khaṇika ppahāna abhāvena 🔽na vigatā taṇhā etesanti avigata taṇhā acatta taṇhā ati tad aṅga ppahāna abhāvena apariccatta taṇhā
translated: “With craving unweakened” is the basic phrase. “With craving undiminished” is in the sense of the undiminishedness of craving by way of momentary abandoning, as in the case of momentary concentration.🔽“With craving unrenounced” is in the sense of the unrenouncedness of craving by way of abandoning its associatedness.

original: Avantataṇhāti vikkhambhanappahānābhāvena na vantataṇhāti avantataṇhā. Amuttataṇhāti🔽accantasamucchedappahānābhāvena na muttataṇhā. Appahīnataṇhāti paṭippassaddhippahānābhāvena🔽na pahīnataṇhā. Appaṭinissaṭṭhataṇhāti nissaraṇappahānābhāvena bhave patiṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: avanta taṇhā ati vikkhambhana ppahāna abhāvena na vanta taṇhā ati avanta taṇhā amutta taṇhā  accanta samuccheda pahāna abhāvena na mutta taṇhā a ppahīna taṇhā ati paṭippassaddhi ppahāna abhāvena  na pahīna taṇhā appaṭinissaṭṭha taṇhā ti nissaraṇa ppahāna abhāvena bhave patiṭṭhitam
translated: He has not got rid of craving for what is in front of him: he has not got rid of it by suppression,🔽he has not got rid of it by substitution of opposites,🔽he has not got rid of it by substitution of opposites and by suppression,🔽he has not got rid of it by escape,🔽

original: anusayakilesaṃ appaṭinissajjitvā ṭhitattā appaṭinissaṭṭhataṇhā.
analyzed: anusaya kilesam a paṭinissajjitvā ṭhita ttā a paṭinissaṭṭha taṇhā
translated: Avantataṇhā is avantataṇhā since it is not vantataṇhā through the absence of the abandoning of the suppression of craving. Amuttataṇhā is amuttataṇhā since it is not muttataṇhā through the absence of the abandoning of the annihilation of craving. Appahīnataṇhā is appahīnataṇhā since it is not pahīnataṇhā through the absence of the abandoning of the appeasement of craving. Appaṭinissaṭṭataṇhā is appaṭinissaṭṭataṇhā since it is not paṭinissaṭṭataṇhā through the absence of the abandoning of the escape from craving, through being established in existence, through not relinquishing the underlying tendency of defilement.

original: 12. Idāni yasmā avigatataṇhā evaṃ phandanti ca lapanti ca, tasmā taṇhāvinaye samādapento
analyzed: idāni yasmai avigata taṇhāḥ evam phandanti ca lapanti ca tasmai taṇhā vinaye samādapentaḥ
translated: Now, since those who are not free from craving thus flutter and prattle, the Master, exhorting them to train in the destruction of craving,

original: “mamāyite”ti gāthamāha. Tattha mamāyiteti taṇhādiṭṭhimamattehi “mama”nti pariggahite
analyzed: mamāyitā iti gātham āha tattha mamāyitā iti taṇhā diṭṭhi mamattehi mamanti pariggahite
translated: said the verse, “What is ‘mine’?” Herein, what is “mine” is a basis appropriated as “mine” by mere craving and views.

original: vatthusmiṃ. Passathāti sotāre ālapanto āha. Etampīti etampi ādīnavaṃ. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: vatthusmim passatha ati sotāre ālapantaḥ āha etam pi iti etam pi ādīnavam sesam pākaṭam eva
translated: “See” he said, addressing the listeners. “This danger too” : this danger too. The rest is clear.

original: Dve mamattāti dve ālayā. Yāvatāti paricchedaniyamatthe nipāto. Taṇhāsaṅkhātenāti
analyzed: dve mamatta ati dve ālayāḥ yāvatā ati pariccheda niyama atthe nipātaḥ taṇhā saṅkhātena ati
translated: Two kinds of “mine” : two kinds of attachment. Yāvat : the indeclinable yāvat has the meaning of a limit. Taṇhāsaṅkhātena : by the reckoning of craving.

original: taṇhākoṭṭhāsena, saṅkhā saṅkhātanti atthato ekaṃ “saññānidānā hi papañcasaṅkhā”tiādīsu
analyzed: taṇhā koṭṭhāsena saṅkhā saṅkhātanti atthataḥ ekam saññā nidānāḥ hi papañca saṅkhā ati ādīsu
translated: “Craving is the source of determinations” is the same in meaning as “Determina- tions are determined by craving” in such passages as “For determinations are proliferations with perception as their source” .

original: viya. Sīmakatanti aparicchedadosavirahitaṃ mariyādakataṃ “tiyojanaparamaṃ sīmaṃ sammannitu”nti🔽ādīsu viya. Odhikatanti vacanaparicchedadosavirahitaṃ paricchedakataṃ sīmantarikarukkho
analyzed: apariccheda dosa virahitam mariyāda katam ti yojana paramam sīmam  ādīsu viya odhikatanti vacana pariccheda dosa virahitam paricchedakatam
translated: “Bounded” : not lacking in delimitation, delimited, as in such passages as “They should agree on a territory for the territory of the monastery, at most three leagues” .🔽“Defined” : not lacking in definition, defined, as in the case of a boundary tree.

original: viya. Pariyantakatanti paricchedakataṃ. Sīmantarikarukkho pana dvinnaṃ sādhāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: viya pariyantaka tanti paricchedaka tam pana dvinnam sādhāraṇam
translated: “Limited” : defined. But a boundary tree is common to two .

original: ayaṃ pana ekābaddhatālapanti viya katanti pariyantakataṃ. Pariggahitanti kālantarepi
analyzed: ayam pana viya katanti kāla antare pi
translated: This is made as if it were a single unbroken palm-leaf fan.🔽“Possessed” : taken in every way, after relinquishing dependence on it even for a future period.

original: parāyattaṃ muñcitvā sabbākārena gahitaṃ. Mamāyitanti ālayakataṃ vassūpagataṃ senāsanaṃ
analyzed: parāyattam muñcitvā sabba ākārena gahitam ālaya katam vassu upagatam senāsanam
translated: “Considered as ‘mine’” : made a resort to, as a dwelling during the rains.

original: viya. Idaṃ mamanti samīpe ṭhitaṃ. Etaṃ mamanti dūre ṭhitaṃ. Ettakanti parikkhāraniyamanaṃ
analyzed: viya idam mamanti samīpe ṭhitam etam mamanti dūre ṭhitam ettakanti parikkhāra niyamanaṃ
translated: “This is mine” : near at hand. “That is mine” : far away. “So much is mine” : the delimitation of the requisites.

original: “ettakampi nappaṭibhāseyyā”ti viya. Ettāvatāti paricchedatthepi nipātaniyamanaṃ “ettāvatā
analyzed: ettakam pi na paṭibhāseyya iti viya ettāvatā ati pariccheda tthe pi nipāta niyamanam ettāvatā
translated: “He would not be able to reply even to that.” The particle evaṃ is also used in the sense of limitation: “To this extent …

original: kho mahānāmā”ti viya. Kevalampi mahāpathavinti sakalampi mahāpathaviṃ.
analyzed: kho kevalampi mahā pathavinti sakalampi mahā pathaviṃ
translated: “He would not be able to answer even that much” . As far as … is a particle in the sense of limitation, like “Mahānāma, as far as … ” . The whole great earth: the whole of the great earth.

original: Aṭṭhasataṃ taṇhāvicaritanti aṭṭhuttarasataṃ taṇhāgamanavitthāraṃ. Aṭṭhuttarasataṃ🔽kathaṃ hotīti ce? Rūpataṇhā…pe… dhammataṇhāti evaṃ cakkhudvārādīsu javanavīthiyā🔽pavattā taṇhā “seṭṭhiputto, brāhmaṇaputto”ti evamādīsu pitito laddhanāmā viya pitusadisārammaṇe
analyzed: aṭṭhasatam taṇhā vicaritanti aṭṭhuttara satam taṇhā gamana vitthāram aṭṭhuttara satam  katham hoti iti ce dhamma taṇhā ti evam cakkhu dvāra ādīsu javana vīthiyā  pavattā taṇhā seṭṭhi putto brāhmaṇa putto ti evamādīsu pititaḥ laddha nāmā viya pitu sadisa ārammaṇe
translated: The eighty-four hundredfold proliferation of craving: the eighty-four hundredfold spread of the coming of craving.

original: bhūtā. Ettha ca rūpārammaṇā rūpe taṇhāti rūpataṇhā. Sā kāmarāgabhāvena rūpaṃ assādentī🔽pavattamānā kāmataṇhā. Sassatadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena “rūpaṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassata”nti
analyzed: bhūtāḥ ettha ca rūpa ārammaṇāḥ rūpe taṇhā ati rūpa taṇhā sā kāma rāga bhāvena rūpam assādentī  pavattamānā kāma taṇhā sassata diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena rūpam niccam dhuvam sassatanti
translated: How is there eighty-four hundred? Craving for visible forms … craving for mental objects. Thus craving that occurs in the cognitive series in the eye door, etc., is like a son’s name that is given after his father, such as “son of the merchant” or “son of the brahmin.” It is so called because it is similar to its object. And here craving for visible forms in visible forms is called craving for visible forms. That, as sensual desire, occurs enjoying visible forms.🔽As craving associated with the eternalist view, it occurs enjoying visible forms thus: “Visible forms are permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change” .

original: evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā bhavataṇhā. Ucchedadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena “rūpaṃ ucchijjati
analyzed: evam assādentī pavattamānā bhava taṇhā uccheda diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena rūpam ucchijjati
translated: As craving associated with the annihilationist view, it occurs enjoying visible forms thus: “Visible forms are annihilated, destroyed, and broken up” .

original: vinassati pacchedaṃ bhavissatī”ti evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā vibhavataṇhāti evaṃ
analyzed: vinassati pacchā idam bhavissati iti evam assādentī pavattamānā vibhava taṇhā ati evam
translated: and so on. When it occurs relishing thus, it is called craving for non-existence.
