original: tividhā hoti. Yathā ca rūpataṇhā, tathā saddataṇhādayopīti etāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni
analyzed: tividhā hoti yathā ca rūpa taṇhā tathā sadda taṇhā ādayaḥ api iti etāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: So it is of three kinds. And as with craving for visible forms, so too with craving for sounds, and so on. These are the eighteen kinds of craving.

original: honti. Tāni ajjhattarūpādīsu aṭṭhārasa, bahiddhārūpādīsu aṭṭhārasāti chattiṃsa, iti
analyzed: honti tāni ajjhatta rūpa ādīsu aṭṭhārasa bahiddhā rūpa ādīsu aṭṭhārasa ati chattiṃsa iti
translated: There are eighteen kinds in the case of internal visible data, etc., and eighteen in the case of external visible data, etc., making thirty-six.

original: atītāni chattiṃsa, anāgatāni chattiṃsa, paccuppannāni chattiṃsāti aṭṭhasataṃ. Ajjhattikassa🔽upādāya “asmī”ti hoti, “itthasmī”ti hotīti vā evamādīni ajjhattikarūpādinissitāni
analyzed: atītāni chattiṃsa anāgatāni chattiṃsa paccuppannāni chattiṃsa ati aṭṭhasatam ajjhattikassa  upādāya asmi iti hoti itthasmi iti hoti iti vā evamādīni ajjhattika rūpa ādi nissitāni
translated: So there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present, which make one hundred and eight.🔽“Because of what is internal, ‘I am’ occurs, ‘I am this’ occurs” , and so on. These are the eighteen kinds of craving based on internal visible data, etc.

original: aṭṭhārasa, bāhirassupādāya iminā “asmī”ti hoti, iminā “itthasmī”ti hotīti bāhirarūpādinissitāni🔽aṭṭhārasāti chattiṃsa. Iti atītāni chattiṃsa, anāgatāni chattiṃsa, paccuppannāni
analyzed: bāhirassa upādāya iminā asmi iti hoti iminā itthasmi iti hoti iti bāhira rūpa ādi nissitāni  aṭṭhārasā ati chattiṃsa iti atītāni chattiṃsa anāgatāni chattiṃsa paccuppannāni
translated: “Because of what is external, ‘I am’ occurs, ‘I am this’ occurs” , and so on. These are the eighteen kinds of craving based on external visible data, etc.

original: chattiṃsāti evampi aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni honti.
analyzed: chattiṃsa ati evam pi aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni honti
translated: So there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present, which make one hundred and eight kinds of craving.

original: Vīsativatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhīti rūpādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ ekekampi “rūpaṃ attato🔽samanupassatī”tiādinā nayena catudhā gāhavasena pavattāni vatthūni katvā uppannā
analyzed: vīsati vatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhī iti rūpa ādīnam pañcannam khandhānam ekekam pi rūpam  samanupassati iti ādinā nayena catudhā gāha vasena pavattāni vatthūni katvā uppannā
translated: The view of the aggregates of existence is twentyfold, since it occurs in twenty ways, namely, by taking each of the five aggregates, such as material form, in four ways, thus: “Material form is the self of the self is material form …🔽… the self possesses material form …🔽… material form is in the self …🔽… the self is in material form” .

original: vijjamānaṭṭhena sati khandhapañcakasaṅkhāte kāye diṭṭhīti sakkāyadiṭṭhi. Dasavatthukā🔽micchādiṭṭhīti “natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭha”ntiādinayappavattā micchādiṭṭhi, ayāthāvadiṭṭhi
analyzed: vijjamāna ṭṭhena sati khandha pañcaka saṅkhāte kāye diṭṭhī iti sakkāyadiṭṭhi dasa vatthukā  micchādiṭṭhi iti natthi dinnam natthi micchādiṭṭhi ayāthāvadiṭṭhi
translated: The view of the aggregates of existence is so called because it is a view that occurs in regard to the five aggregates of existence called the body, which exist in the sense of being present.

original: virajjhitvā gahaṇato vā vitathā diṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi, anatthāvahattā paṇḍitehi kucchitā
analyzed: virajjhitvā gahaṇataḥ vā vitathā diṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi anattha avahattā paṇḍitehi kucchitā
translated: The wrong view is tenfold, since it occurs in ten ways, thus: “There is nothing given … no offering … no sacrifice … no good or bad action … no result of good or bad action … no this world … no other world … no mother … no father … no beings who are reborn spontaneously … no ascetics and brahmans faring and practising rightly in this world who proclaim this world and the other world after having directly known and realized them for themselves” .

original: diṭṭhītipi micchādiṭṭhi. Sā ayoniso abhinivesalakkhaṇā, parāmāsarasā, micchābhinivesapaccupaṭṭhānā,🔽ariyānamadassanakāmatādipadaṭṭhānā, paramavajjāti daṭṭhabbā. Dasavatthukā antaggāhikā
analyzed: diṭṭhi iti pi micchādiṭṭhi sā ayonisas abhinivesa lakkhaṇā parāmāsa rasā micchā abhinivesa paccupaṭṭhānā 🔽ariya anama dassana kāma tā ādi padaṭṭhānā parama vat jāti daṭṭhabbā dasa vatthukā antaggāhikā
translated: This wrong view is so called because it is a view that is not in accordance with the way things are , or because it is a view that is wrongly taken up . It should be regarded as the most reprehensible of all views because it is the cause for the most woeful states of existence.🔽The view of holding to a particular extreme is tenfold, since it occurs in ten ways, thus: “The world is eternal … not eternal … eternal and not eternal … neither eternal nor not eternal … the world is finite … infinite … finite and infinite … neither finite nor infinite … the soul and the body are the same … the soul is one thing and the body another” .

original: diṭṭhīti sassato loko, asassato loko, antavā loko”ti ādinayappavattā ekekaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ🔽patiṭṭhaṃ katvā gahaṇavasena evaṃ pavattā diṭṭhi dasavatthukā antaggāhikā diṭṭhi.
analyzed: diṭṭhī iti sassataḥ lokaḥ a sassataḥ lokaḥ antavā loko ti ādi naya ppavattā ekekam koṭṭhāsam  patiṭṭham katvā gahaṇa vasena evam pavattā diṭṭhi dasa vatthukā antaggāhikā diṭṭhi
translated: The view that the world is eternal, that it is not eternal, that it is finite, that it is infinite, and so on, is the view that occurs by apprehending each of the sixteen parts as a basis.🔽This is the view that is called “the view of holding to a doctrine of self” in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: Yā evarūpā diṭṭhīti yā evaṃjātikā diṭṭhi. Diṭṭhigatanti diṭṭhīsu gataṃ. Idaṃ dassanaṃ🔽dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiantogadhattāti diṭṭhigataṃ, diṭṭhiyeva duratikkamanaṭṭhena gahanaṃ🔽diṭṭhigahanaṃ tiṇagahanavanagahanapabbatagahanāni viya. Sāsaṅkasappaṭibhayaṭṭhena🔽diṭṭhikantāraṃ corakantāravāḷakantāranirudakakantāradubbhikkhakantārā viya. Sammādiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: yā evarūpā diṭṭhī iti yā evaṃjātikā diṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatam ti diṭṭhīsu gatam idam dassanam  diṭṭhi gatam diṭṭhiyā iva duratikkamana aṭṭhena gahanam  diṭṭhi gahanam tiṇa gahana vana gahana pabbata gahanāni viya sa āsaṅka sa paṭibhaya ṭṭhena  diṭṭhi kantāram cora kantāra vāḷa kantāra nirudaka kantāra dubbhikkha kantārāḥ viya sammādiṭṭhiyā
translated: “Such a view”: such a view as this. “A false view”: gone to views. This seeing

original: vinivijjhanaṭṭhena vilomanaṭṭhena ca diṭṭhivisūkāyikaṃ. Micchādassanañhi uppajjamānaṃ🔽sammādassanaṃ vinivijjhati ceva vilometi ca. Kadāci sassatassa, kadāci ucchedassa
analyzed: vinivijjhana ṭhena vilomana ṭṭhena ca diṭṭhi visūkāyikam micchā dassanam hi uppajjamānam 🔽sammādassanam vinivijjhati ca iva vilomā iti ca kadāci sassatassa kadāci ucchedassa
translated: is called “gone to views” because it is gone to the sixty-two views. It is a thicket of views, a wilderness of views, a thorny spike of views, an entanglement of views, a fetter of views, a tendency of views, a bias of views, a leaning of views, a falling of views, a clinging of views, a grasping of views, a holding of views, a wrong path, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong support, a wrong basis, a wrong foundation, a wrong mainstay, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong resort, a wrong practice, a wrong

original: gahaṇato diṭṭhiyā virūpaṃ phanditanti diṭṭhivipphanditaṃ. Diṭṭhigatiko hi ekasmiṃ🔽patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti. Kadāci sassataṃ anussarati, kadāci ucchedaṃ. Diṭṭhiyeva bandhanaṭṭhena🔽saṃyojananti diṭṭhisaṃyojanaṃ. Susumārādayo viya purisaṃ ārammaṇaṃ daḷhaṃ gaṇhātīti🔽gāho. Patiṭṭhahanato patiṭṭhāho. Ayañhi balavapavattibhāvena patiṭṭhahitvā gaṇhāti.
analyzed: gahaṇataḥ diṭṭhiyā virūpam phanditan ti diṭṭhi vipphanditam diṭṭhi gatikaḥ hi ekasmin  patiṭṭhātum na sakkoti kadāci sassatam anussarati kadāci ucchedam diṭṭhiyā iva bandhana ṭṭhena  saṃyojananti diṭṭhi saṃyojanam susumāra ādayaḥ viya purisam ārammaṇam daḷham gaṇhāti iti  gāhaḥ patiṭṭhahanataḥ patiṭṭhāhaḥ ayan hi balava pavatti bhāvena patiṭṭhahitvā gaṇhāti
translated: and because of its grasping it is called “the shaking of views” . For the view-fixated person cannot stand still; sometimes he remembers eternalism, sometimes annihilationism. And because of its binding, the view itself is called “the fetter of views” . It is a “grasping” because it grasps its object tenaciously, like a strong man. And because of its standing firm, it is a “standing-point” . For it grasps its object by standing firm with a strong current.

original: Niccādivasena abhinivisatīti abhiniveso. Dhammasabhāvaṃ atikkamitvā niccādivasena🔽parato āmasatīti parāmāso. Anatthāvahattā kucchito maggo, kucchitānaṃ vā apāyānaṃ🔽maggoti kummaggo. Ayāthāvapathato micchāpatho. Yathā hi disāmūḷhena “ayaṃ asukagāmassa🔽nāma patho”ti gahitopi taṃ gāmaṃ na sampāpeti, evaṃ diṭṭhigatikena “sugatipatho”ti
analyzed: nicca ādi vasena abhinivisati iti abhinivesaḥ dhamma sabhāvam atikkamitvā nicca ādi vasena 🔽paratas āmasati iti parāmāsaḥ anattha avahattā kucchitaḥ maggaḥ kucchitānam vā apāyānam 🔽maggo ti kummaggaḥ a yāthāva pathataḥ micchā pathaḥ yathā hi disā mūḍhena ayam asuka gāmassa 🔽nāma pathā uti gahitaḥ api tam gāmam na sampāpeti evam diṭṭhigatikena sugati pathā uti
translated: and because of its grasping it is a distortion of view, a distorting of view. For one of fixed view cannot stand still; sometimes he remembers eternalism, sometimes annihilationism. View itself, in the sense of a fetter, is the fetter of views. It is a grasping because it grasps its object tenaciously, like a creeper, etc., grasping a tree. It is a stand because it stands firmly. For it grasps after standing firm by the occurrence of a strong current. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by apprehending as permanent, etc. It is a misinterpreting because it misinterprets by misapprehending as permanent, etc., in the mode of permanence, etc., in the sense of misrepresenting the individual essences of states. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc. It is a misapprehending because it misapprehends by misrepresenting the individual essences of states in the mode of permanence, etc

original: gahitāpi diṭṭhi sugatiṃ na pāpetīti ayāthāvapathato micchāpatho. Micchāsabhāvato
analyzed: gahitā api sugatim na pāpeti iti a yāthāva pathataḥ micchā pathaḥ micchā sabhāvataḥ
translated: It is a wrong view because it is wrongly seen.

original: micchattaṃ. Tattheva paribbhamanato taranti ettha bālāti titthaṃ, titthañca taṃ anatthānañca🔽āyatananti titthāyatanaṃ, titthiyānaṃ vā sañjātidesaṭṭhena nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ca
analyzed: micchattam tattha iva paribbhamanataḥ taranti ettha tittham tittham ca tam  āyatanam ti titthāyatanam titthiyānam vā sañjā atidesa ṭhena nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭhena ca
translated: It is a source of dispute because fools dispute about it, thinking “This is the only truth, other ideas are wrong views” .🔽Or alternatively, it is a source of dispute because it is a source of the disputes called “the disputes of the Brahmins” .🔽It is a wrong grasp because it is a perverted grasp, or because it is a grasping of what is not there.

original: āyatanantipi titthāyatanaṃ. Vipariyesabhūto gāho, vipariyesato vā gāhoti vipariyesaggāho.
analyzed: tittha āyatanam vipariyesa bhūtaḥ gāhaḥ vipariyesataḥ vā gāhaḥ ti vipariyesa ggāhaḥ
translated: It is a perverted grasping because it is a grasping of what is not the real nature of things.

original: Asabhāvagāhoti viparītaggāho. “Anicce nicca”nti ādinayappavattavasena parivattetvā🔽gāho vipallāsaggāho. Anupāyagāho micchāgāho. Ayāthāvakasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ na sabhāvasmiṃ
analyzed: asabhāvagāho ti viparīta ggāho anicce niccan ti ādi naya ppavatta vasena parivattetvā  gāhaḥ vipallāsa ggāhaḥ an upāya gāhaḥ micchā gāhaḥ a yāthāvakasmin vatthusmin na sabhāvasmin
translated: It is a perverted grasping because it is a grasping that occurs by turning away from the real nature of things, which is stated in the way beginning, “In what is impermanent he makes permanence” .🔽It is a wrong grasping because it is a grasping that is not the way, not the real nature of things, in a case where there is no real nature of things.

original: vatthusmiṃ tathaṃ yāthāvakaṃ sabhāvanti gāho “ayāthāvakasmiṃ yāthāvaka”nti gāho.
analyzed: vatthusmim tatham yāthāvakam sabhāvanti gāho a yāthāvakasmin yāthāvakanti gāho
translated: It is a wrong grasping because it is a grasping that is not the way, not the real nature of things, in a case where there is a real nature of things, and it is a grasping that is the way, the real nature of things, in a case where there is no real nature of things.

original: Yāvatāti yattakā. Dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatānīti brahmajāle āgatāni dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatāni.
analyzed: yāvatā ati yattakā dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni iti brahmajāle āgatāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni
translated: As many as: as much as. The sixty-two views: the sixty-two views stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta .

original: Acchedasaṃkinopi phandantīti acchinditvā pasayha balakkārena gaṇhissantīti uppannasaṃkinopi🔽calanti. Acchindantepīti vuttanayena acchijjantepi. Acchinnepīti vuttanayena acchinditvā
analyzed: accheda saṃkinaḥ phandanti iti a chinditvā pasayha balakkārena gaṇhissanti iti uppanna saṃkinaḥ pi  calanti a chindante pi iti vutta nayena a chijjante pi a chinne pi iti vutta nayena a chinditvā
translated: Even when he is doubtful about their being cut off, they tremble, i.e. they move, thinking, “They will cut them off and take them away by force after overpowering us.”🔽Even when they are being cut off, i.e. even when they are being cut off in the way already described.🔽Even when they are cut off, i.e. even when they are taken away after being cut off in the way already described.

original: gahitepi. Vipariṇāmasaṃkinopīti parivattetvā aññathābhāvena āsaṃkinopi. Vipariṇāmantepīti🔽viparivattanakālepi. Vipariṇatepīti viparivattitepi. Phandantīti calanti. Samphandantīti
analyzed: gahite api vipariṇāma saṃkino api iti parivattetvā aññathā bhāvena āsaṃkino api vipariṇāma ante pi iti  viparivattana kāle api vipariṇate api iti viparivattite pi phandanti iti calanti samphandanti iti
translated: Even when he is doubtful about their changing, i.e. even when he is doubtful about their changing by becoming otherwise.🔽Even when they are changing, i.e. even when they are in the process of changing.

original: sabbākārena calanti. Vipphandantīti vividhākārena phandanti. Vedhantīti bhayaṃ disvā🔽kampanti. Pavedhantīti chambhitattā bhayena visesena kampanti. Sampavedhantīti lomahaṃsanabhayena
analyzed: sabba ākārena calanti vipphandanti iti vividha ākārena phandanti vedhanti iti bhayam disvā  kampanti pavedhanti iti chambhita ttāḥ bhayena visesena kampanti sampavedhanti iti loma haṃsana bhayena
translated: Even when they have changed, i.e. even when they have changed. They tremble, i.e. they move. They tremble violently, i.e. they move in every way. They tremble intensely, i.e. they tremble in various ways. They quake, i.e. they tremble on seeing danger.🔽They quake violently, i.e. they tremble especially violently through fear. They quake intensely, i.e. they tremble in every way through fear, with their hair standing on end.

original: sabbākārena kampanti. Phandamāneti upayogabahuvacanaṃ. Appodaketi mandodake. Parittodaketi
analyzed: sabba ākārena kampanti phandamānā iti upayoga bahuvacanam appa udakā iti manda udake paritta udakā iti
translated: They tremble, i.e. they move. This is a plural of apposition. In little water, i.e. in shallow water.

original: luḷitodake. Udakapariyādāneti khīṇodake. Balākāhi vāti vuttāvasesāhi pakkhijātīhi.
analyzed: luḷita udake udaka pariyādāne iti khīṇa udake balākāhi vā ati vutta avasesāhi pakkhi jātīhi
translated: In water that has become turbid: in water that has become muddy. In water that has gone down: in water that has become low. By the herons: by the remaining kinds of birds mentioned in the verse.

original: Paripātiyamānāti vihiṃsiyamānā ghaṭṭiyamānā. Ukkhipiyamānāti kaddamantarato nīhariyamānā
analyzed: paripātiyamānā ati vihiṃsiyamānā ghaṭṭiyamānā ukkhipiyamānā ati kaddama antarataḥ nīhariyamānā
translated: They are being devoured: they are being harmed, they are being struck. They are being pulled out: they are being taken out from the mud.

original: giliyamānā vā. Khajjamānāti khādiyamānā. Phandanti kākehi. Samphandanti kulalehi.
analyzed: vā khajjamānā ati khādiyamānā phandanti kākehi samphandanti kulalehi
translated: They are being swallowed: they are being eaten. The crows are pecking at them. The otters are attacking them.

original: Vipphandanti balākāhi. Vedhanti tuṇḍena gahitakāle maraṇavasena. Pavedhanti vijjhanakāle.
analyzed: vipphandanti balākāhi vedhanti tuṇḍena gahita kāle maraṇa vasena pavedhanti vijjhana kāle
translated: The herons are striking at them. They are being pierced: they are dying when seized with the beak. They are being deeply pierced: they are dying when struck.

original: Sampavedhanti maraṇasamīpe.
analyzed: sampavedhanti maraṇa samīpe
translated: They are being deeply pierced: they are dying when they are near death.

original: Passitvāti aguṇaṃ passitvā. Tulayitvāti guṇāguṇaṃ tulayitvā. Tīrayitvāti guṇāguṇaṃ
analyzed: passitvā ati aguṇam passitvā tulayitvā ati guṇa aguṇam tulayitvā tīrayitvā ati guṇa aguṇam
translated: Having seen: having seen the disqualification. Having weighed: having weighed the qualification and the disqualification. Having measured: having measured the qualification and the disqualification

original: vitthāretvā. Vibhāvayitvāti vatthuhānabhāgiṃ muñcitvā vajjetvā. Vibhūtaṃ katvāti
analyzed: vitthāretvā vibhāvayitvā ati vatthu hāna bhāgim muñcitvā vajjetvā vibhūtam katvā iti
translated: having extended them. Having discerned: having released the part that is subject to the loss of the subject-matter, having rejected it. Having made clear:

original: nipphattiṃ pāpetvā āveṇikaṃ katvā. Atha vā saṃkiṇṇadosaṃ mocetvā vatthuvibhāgakaraṇena
analyzed: nipphattim pāpetvā āveṇikam katvā atha vā saṃkiṇṇa dosam mocetvā vatthu vibhāga karaṇena
translated: having brought about the result, having made it unique. Or else, having released the mixed faults, having made the subject-matter clear🔽by means of the discernment of the subject-matter,

original: passitvā. Aparicchedadosaṃ mocetvā pamāṇakaraṇavasena tulayitvā. Vatthudosaṃ mocetvā🔽vibhāgakaraṇavasena tīrayitvā. Sammohadosaṃ mocayitvā aggavibhāgakaraṇavasena vibhāvayitvā.🔽Ghanadosaṃ mocetvā pakativibhāgakaraṇena vibhūtaṃ katvā. Pahāyāti pajahitvā. Paṭinissajjitvāti
analyzed: passitvā apariccheda dosam mocetvā pamāṇa karaṇa vasena tulayitvā vatthu dosam mocetvā  vibhāga karaṇa vasena tīrayitvā sammoha dosam mocayitvā agga vibhāga karaṇa vasena vibhāvayitvā  ghana dosam mocetvā pakati vibhāga karaṇena vibhūtam katvā pahāya ati pajahitvā paṭinissajjitvā ati
translated: Having seen, having weighed by way of making a measure, having freed the fault of non-definition.🔽Having crossed over, having freed the fault of confusion, having defined by way of making the foremost definition.

original: nissajjitvā. Amamāyantoti taṇhādiṭṭhīhi ālayaṃ akaronto. Agaṇhantoti diṭṭhiyā pubbabhāge
analyzed: nissajjitvā a mamāyantaḥ ti taṇhā diṭṭhīhi ālayam a karontaḥ a gaṇhantaḥ ti diṭṭhiyā pubba bhāge
translated: Having freed the fault of compactness, having made it clear by way of making the individual definition. Having abandoned, having given up, having relinquished.

original: paññāya taṃ na gaṇhanto. Aparāmasantoti vitakkena ūhanaṃ akaronto. Anabhinivesantoti
analyzed: paññāya tam na gaṇhantaḥ a parāmasantaḥ ti vitakkena ūhanam a karontaḥ an abhinivesantaḥ ti
translated: Not making a store, not making a basis through craving and views. Not grasping, not taking it with wisdom in the preliminary stage of views.🔽Not cleaving, not making a search with applied thought. Not adhering,

original: niyāmokkantidiṭṭhivasena nappavisanto.🔽Akubbamānoti pariggāhataṇhāvasena akaronto. Ajanayamānoti ponobhavikataṇhāvasena
analyzed: niyāma ukkanti diṭṭhi vasena na pavisanto  a kubbamānaḥ ti pariggāha taṇhā vasena a karontaḥ a janayamānaḥ iti ponobhavika taṇhā vasena
translated: not entering into it by way of the view of deliverance.🔽Not making, not making it by way of the craving of grasping. Not producing,

original: ajanayamāno. Asañjanayamānoti visesena asañjanayamāno. Anibbattayamānoti patthanātaṇhāvasena
analyzed: a janayamānaḥ a sañjanayamānaḥ ti visesena a sañjanayamānaḥ a nibbattayamānaḥ ti patthanā taṇhā vasena
translated: not producing it by way of the craving for renewed existence. Not accumulating, not accumulating it by way of distinction. Not making manifest, not making it manifest by way of the craving of aspiration.

original: na nibbattayamāno. Anabhinibbattayamānoti sabbākārena na abhinibbattayamāno. Upasaggavasena
analyzed: na nibbattayamānaḥ an abhinibbattayamānaḥ ti sabba ākārena na abhinibbattayamānaḥ upasagga vasena
translated: not being reborn. Not being reborn in any way: not being reborn in any way at all.

original: vā etāni padāni vaḍḍhitāni. Evamettha paṭhamagāthāya assādaṃ.
analyzed: vā etāni padāni vaḍḍhitāni evam ettha paṭhama gāthāya assādam
translated: not being reborn. Not being reborn in any way: not being reborn in any way at all. Or else these terms are extended to cover the case of the present existence. So he shows the gratification in the first stanza.

original: 13. Tato parāhi catūhi gāthāhi ādīnavañca dassetvā idāni saupāyaṃ nissaraṇaṃ nissaraṇānisaṃsañca
analyzed: tatas parāhi catūhi gāthāhi ādīnavañca dassetvā idāni sa upāyam nissaraṇam nissaraṇa anisaṃsam ca
translated: . Then, after showing the danger in the next four stanzas, he now shows the escape with the means for it and the benefit of the escape.

original: dassetuṃ, sabbāhi vā etāhi kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesañca dassetvā idāni nekkhamme
analyzed: dassetum sabbāhi vā etāhi kāmānam ādīnavam okāram saṃkilesam ca dassetvā idāni nekkhamme
translated: Or else, after showing the danger, the disadvantage, and the defilement in all these stanzas, he now shows the benefit in renunciation. He said the two stanzas beginning with “At both ends” .

original: ānisaṃsaṃ dassetuṃ “ubhosu antesū”ti gāthādvayamāha. Tattha ubhosu antesūti phassaphassasamudayādīsu🔽dvīsu, dvīsu paricchedesu. Vineyya chandanti chandarāgaṃ vinetvā. Phassaṃ pariññāyāti🔽cakkhusamphassādiphassaṃ, phassānusārena vā taṃsampayutte sabbepi arūpadhamme, tesaṃ
analyzed: ānisaṃsam dassetum ubhosu antesu iti gāthā dvayam āha tattha ubhosu antesu iti phassa phassa samudaya ādīsu  dvīsu dvīsu paricchedesu vineyya chandanti chanda rāgam vinetvā phassam pariññāya ati  cakkhu samphassa ādi phassam phassa anusārena vā tad sampayutte sabbe pi arūpa dhamme tesam
translated: Herein, at both ends: in the two, in the two sections, namely, the end of contact and the end of the origin of contact.

original: vatthudvārārammaṇavasena rūpadhamme cāti sakalampi nāmarūpaṃ tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā.
analyzed: vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena rūpa dhamme ca ati sakalam pi nāma rūpam tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā
translated: Having stilled desire: having stilled will and lust. Having fully understood contact: having fully understood eye-contact, etc., or else all the immaterial states associated with contact, or else material states as the basis, door, and object of that contact, he has fully understood all mentality-materiality by means of the three full understandings.🔽.

original: Anānugiddhoti rūpādīsu sabbadhammesu agiddho. Yadattagarahī tadakubbamānoti yaṃ attanā🔽garahati, taṃ akurumāno. Na limpatī diṭṭhasutesu dhīroti so evarūpo dhitisampanno
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu sabba dhammesu a giddhaḥ yad atta garahī tad akubbamānaḥ iti yam attanā  garahati tam a kurumānaḥ na limpati diṭṭha sutesu dhīra uti saḥ evarūpaḥ dhiti sampannaḥ
translated: Ananugiddho = not greedy. He is not greedy for any of the things of the world, such as form, etc.🔽Yadattagarahī tadakubbamāno = he does not do what he has censured.🔽Na limpati diṭṭhasutesu dhīro = such a wise man is not attached to what he has seen or heard.

original: dhīro diṭṭhesu ca sutesu ca dhammesu dvinnaṃ lepānaṃ ekenāpi lepena na limpati, ākāsamiva
analyzed: dhīraḥ diṭṭhesu ca sutesu ca dhammesu dvinnam lepānam ekena api lepena na limpati ākāsam iva
translated: “Not greedy” : not greedy for any of the things beginning with visible forms. “Not blaming what is not done” : not blaming oneself for not doing what should be done. “The wise man is not stained by what is seen or heard” : the wise man endowed with steadfastness is not stained by any of the two stains in regard to what is seen or heard. He is like space,

original: nirupalitto accantavodānappatto hoti.
analyzed: nirupalittaḥ accanta vodāna pattaḥ hoti
translated: unstained, utterly pure.

original: Phasso eko antoti phasso ekaparicchedo. Phusatīti phasso. Svāyaṃ phusanalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: phasso ekaḥ anto ti phasso eka paricchedo phusati iti phassaḥ svāyam phusana lakkhaṇo
translated: Contact is one extreme : contact is the extreme of limitation. It contacts , thus it is contact . It has the characteristic of contacting.

original: saṅghaṭṭanaraso, sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno, āpāthagatavisayapadaṭṭhāno. Ayañhi arūpadhammopi
analyzed: saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ sannipāta paccupaṭṭhānaḥ āpātha gata visaya padaṭṭhānaḥ ayam hi arūpa dhammaḥ api
translated: Its function is to impinge; its manifestation is to meet. Its proximate cause is an object that has come into focus. Although this is an immaterial state,

original: samāno ārammaṇe phusanākāreneva pavattatīti phusanalakkhaṇo. Ekadeseneva anallīyamānopi
analyzed: samānaḥ ārammaṇe phusana ākārena iva pavattati iti phusana lakkhaṇaḥ eka desena iva
translated: it occurs in the mode of contacting an object, thus it has the characteristic of contacting. Although it does not adhere to the object in the manner that a magnet does to iron,

original: rūpaṃ viya cakkhuṃ, saddo viya ca sotaṃ cittaṃ ārammaṇañca saṅghaṭṭetīti saṅghaṭṭanaraso,
analyzed: rūpam viya cakkhum saddaḥ viya ca sotam cittam ārammaṇam ca saṅghaṭṭeti iti saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ
translated: it impinges on the eye like a form, and on the ear like a sound, and it impinges on the mind and the object,

original: vatthārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭanato vā uppannattā sampattiatthenapi rasena “saṅghaṭṭanaraso”ti🔽veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ –🔽“Catubhūmakaphasso no phusanalakkhaṇo nāma natthi, saṅghaṭṭanaraso pana pañcadvārikova🔽hoti. Pañcadvārikassa hi phusanalakkhaṇotipi saṅghaṭṭanarasotipi nāmaṃ. Manodvārikassa
analyzed: vattha ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭanataḥ vā uppanna ttā sampatti atthena api rasena saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ ti  veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam aṭṭhakathāyam  catu bhūmaka phasso no phusana lakkhaṇaḥ nāma natthi saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ pana pañca dvārikaḥ uva  hoti pañca dvārikassa hi phusana lakkhaṇaḥ itipi saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ itipi nāmam manaḥ dvārikassa
translated: Or alternatively, it is to be understood that it is called “the faculty of touch” in the sense of “touching” because it arises through the impingement of the physical support and the object. For this is said in the commentary:🔽“There is no contact in the four bases that is called ‘the characteristic of touching’; but the faculty of touch has the function of touching in the five doors.🔽For the five doors have the characteristic of touching and the function of touching.🔽But in the mind door

original: phusanalakkhaṇotveva nāmaṃ, na saṅghaṭṭanaraso”ti.
analyzed: nāmam na saṅghaṭṭana rasā iti
translated: Or alternatively, it is to be understood that it has the function of impingement because it arises from the impingement of the object on the physical basis. For this is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The fourfold contact is not called ‘having the characteristic of impingement’; but it has the function of impingement, and it is only the five-door contact that has the function of impingement. For the five-door contact has the characteristic of impingement and the function of impingement. But the mind-door contact has only the characteristic of impingement, not the function of impingement.”

original: Idañca vatvā idaṃ suttaṃ ābhataṃ –
analyzed: idam ca vatvā idam suttam ābhatam
translated: And after saying this, he quotes the following sutta:

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, dve meṇḍā yujjheyyuṃ, yathā eko meṇḍo, evaṃ cakkhu daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja dve meṇḍāḥ yujjheyyum yathā ekaḥ meṇḍaḥ evam cakkhu daṭṭhabbam
translated: “As, sire, if two rams were to fight, the eye should be regarded as one ram and visible data as the other.

original: Yathā dutiyo meṇḍo, evaṃ rūpaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā tesaṃ sannipāto, evaṃ phasso daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: yathā dutiyaḥ meṇḍaḥ evam rūpam daṭṭhabbam yathā tesam sannipātaḥ evam phassaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: As the second ram, so should visible data be regarded. As their clashing together, so should contact be regarded.

original: Evaṃ phusanalakkhaṇo ca phasso saṅghaṭṭanaraso ca. Yathā, mahārāja, dve sammā vajjeyyuṃ,
analyzed: evam phusana lakkhaṇaḥ ca phassaḥ saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ ca yathā mahā rāja dve sammā vajjeyyum
translated: Thus contact has the characteristic of impingement and the function of impingement. As, sire, if two well-matched wrestlers were to fight,

original: dve pāṇī vajjeyyuṃ. Yathā eko pāṇi, evaṃ cakkhu daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā dutiyo pāṇi, evaṃ🔽rūpaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā tesaṃ sannipāto, evaṃ phasso daṭṭhabbo. Evaṃ phusanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: dve pāṇī vajjeyyum yathā ekaḥ pāṇi evam cakkhu daṭṭhabbam yathā dutiyaḥ pāṇi evam  rūpam daṭṭhabbam yathā tesam sannipātaḥ evam phassaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ evam phusana lakkhaṇo
translated: and the visible datum as the second hand. The contact should be

original: ca phasso saṅghaṭṭanaraso cā”ti vitthāro.
analyzed: ca phasso saṅghaṭṭana raso ca ati vitthāro
translated: regarded as the meeting of the two hands. So contact has the characteristic of touching; its function is to impinge; its manifestation is impinging; its proximate cause is the three .

original: Yathā vā “cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā”tiādīsu cakkhuviññāṇādīni cakkhuādināmena vuttāni,🔽evamidhāpi tāni cakkhuādināmeneva vuttānīti veditabbāni. Tasmā “evaṃ cakkhu daṭṭhabba”ntiādīsu
analyzed: yathā vā cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati ādīsu cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni cakkhu ādi nāmena vuttāni  evam idha api tāni cakkhu ādi nāmena iva vuttāni iti veditabbāni tasmai evam cakkhu daṭṭhabba nti ādīsu
translated: Or just as in such passages as “Having seen a visible object with the eye” the eye-consciousness is called “eye,”🔽so too here the eye-consciousness should be understood as called “eye” and so on. So the meaning of the words “The eye should be seen” should be understood in this way:

original: evaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbanti iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Evaṃ sante cittārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭanato🔽imasmimpi sutte kiccaṭṭheneva rasena “saṅghaṭṭanaraso”ti siddho hoti. Tiṇṇaṃ sannipātasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: evam cakkhu viññāṇam daṭṭhabban ti iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam sante citta ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭanato  imasmim pi sutte kicca ṭṭhena iva rasena saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ ti siddhaḥ hoti sannipāta saṅkhātassa
translated: “Eye-consciousness should be seen as the eye.” When that is so, then since it is the meeting of consciousness with its object,🔽the meaning of “impingement” as function is established here too in this sutta. But it is described by way of its own cause, which is called the “meeting of the three,”

original: pana attano kāraṇassa vasena paveditattā sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno. Ayañhi tattha tattha
analyzed: pana attanaḥ kāraṇassa vasena pavedita ttā sannipāta paccupaṭṭhānaḥ ayam hi tattha tattha
translated: and so it is manifested as the meeting of the three. For this is described in the way beginning, “When there is eye and forms and eye-consciousness” .

original: “tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso”ti evaṃ kāraṇasseva vasena paveditoti. Imassa ca suttapadassa
analyzed: tiṇṇam phasso ti evam kāraṇassa iva vasena pavedito ti imassa ca sutta padassa
translated: “Contact is the meeting of the three” .

original: tiṇṇaṃ saṅgatiyā phassoti ayamattho, na saṅgatimattameva phasso.
analyzed: tiṇṇam saṅgatiyā phasso ti ayam attho na saṅgatimattam eva phasso
translated: The meaning of this sutta passage is that contact is the meeting of the three, not mere meeting.

original: Evaṃ paveditattā pana tenevākārena paccupaṭṭhātīti “sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno”ti vutto.
analyzed: evam pavedita ttā pana tena iva ākārena paccupaṭṭhāti iti sannipāta paccupaṭṭhānaḥ ti vutto
translated: But because it is stated in this way, it is “manifest as the meeting” in that same way.

original: Phalaṭṭhena pana paccupaṭṭhānenesa vedanāpaccupaṭṭhāno nāma hoti. Vedanaṃ hesa paccupaṭṭhāpeti,
analyzed: phala aṭṭhena pana paccupaṭṭhānena isa vedanā paccupaṭṭhānaḥ nāma hoti vedanam ha esa paccupaṭṭhāpeti
translated: But as presence in the sense of fruit, it is called “manifest as feeling” . For it manifests feeling,

original: uppādetīti attho. Uppādayamāno ca yathā bahiddhā uṇhapaccayāpi samānā lākhāsaṅkhātadhātunissitā
analyzed: uppādeti iti atthaḥ uppādayamānaḥ ca yathā bahiddhā uṇha paccayā api samānā lākhā saṅkhāta dhātu nissitā
translated: it produces it, is the meaning. And while it is producing it, it is like the heat that is dependent on lac dye, etc., as its external condition,

original: usmā attano nissaye mudubhāvakārī hoti, na attano paccayabhūtepi bahiddhā vītaccitaṅgārasaṅkhāte🔽uṇhabhāve. Evaṃ vatthārammaṇasaṅkhātaaññapaccayopi samāno cittanissitattā attano
analyzed: attano nissaye mudu bhāva kārī hoti na attano paccaya bhūte pi bahiddhā  uṇha bhāve evam vattha ārammaṇa saṅkhāta añña paccayaḥ api samānaḥ citta nissita ttā attano
translated: which softens its own support, not the heat called “the burning of charcoal,” which is its external condition.🔽So too, while it is dependent on other conditions called “the physical basis and the object,” it is the producer of feeling in its own support,

original: nissayabhūte citte eva esa vedanuppādako hoti, na attano paccayabhūtepi vatthumhi
analyzed: nissaya bhūte citte eva esa vedan uppādako hoti na attanaḥ paccaya bhūte pi vatthumhi
translated: which is the cognizance, not in the physical basis, which is the condition for it.

original: ārammaṇevāti veditabbo. Tajjena samannāhārena pana indriyena ca parikkhate visaye
analyzed: ārammaṇā iva ati veditabbo tajjena samannāhārena pana indriyena ca parikkhate visaye
translated: But when the object is delimited by the sense faculty and the appropriate kamma-resultant nutriment,

original: anantarāyena uppajjanato esa “āpāthagatavisayapadaṭṭhāno”ti vuccati.
analyzed: anantarāyena uppajjanato esa āpātha gata visaya padaṭṭhāno ti vuccati
translated: it is called “the object that has come into focus,” because it arises without obstruction.

original: Phasso yato samudeti uppajjati, so “phassasamudayo”ti vuccati. Vuttañhetaṃ – “saḷāyatanapaccayā🔽phasso”ti. Atītaduko kālavasena vutto. Vedanāduko “upekkhā pana santattā, sukhamicceva
analyzed: phassaḥ yatas samudeti uppajjati saḥ phassa samudayaḥ iti vuccati vuttam ha etam saḷāyatana paccayā  phasso ti atīta duko kāla vasena vutto vedanā duko upekkhā pana santattā sukham icca eva
translated: The contact from which it arises is called “the arising of contact.” For this is said: “With the sixfold base as condition, contact” .🔽The past triad is stated according to time. The feeling triad is stated as pleasure and pain, taking the feeling of equanimity as pleasure,

original: bhāsitā”ti vuttattā upekkhāvedanaṃ sukhameva katvā sukhadukkhavasena, nāmarūpaduko
analyzed: bhāsitā ati vutta ttā upekkhā vedanam sukham eva katvā sukha dukkha vasena
translated: because it is said, “Equanimity is spoken of as pleasure because of peace” . The name-and-form triad is stated

original: rūpārūpavasena, āyatanaduko saṃsārapavattivasena, sakkāyaduko pañcakkhandhavasena
analyzed: rūpa arūpa vasena āyatana duko saṃsāra pavatti vasena sakkāya duko pañca kkhandha vasena
translated: as the fine-material and immaterial, and the sense-base triad is stated as the process of wandering on in saṃsāra. The individuality triad is stated

original: vuttoti veditabbo. Tattha sukhayatīti sukhā. Vedayatīti vedanā. Dukkhayatīti dukkhā.
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ tattha sukhayati iti sukhā vedayati iti vedanā dukkhayati iti dukkhā
translated: as the five aggregates. Herein, it refreshes , thus it is pleasure . It feels , thus it is feeling . It distresses , thus it is pain .

original: Namanalakkhaṇaṃ nāmaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ. Cakkhāyatanādīni cha ajjhattikāni.
analyzed: namana lakkhaṇam nāmam ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam cakkhāyatana ādīni cha ajjhattikāni
translated: The characteristic of bending is name . The characteristic of being molested is form . The six internal sense bases beginning with the eye.

original: Rūpāyatanādīni cha bāhirāni. Rūpakkhandhādayo pañcakkhandhā vijjamānaṭṭhena sakkāyo.
analyzed: rūpa āyatana ādīni cha bāhirāni rūpa kkhandha ādayaḥ pañca kkhandhāḥ vijjamāna ṭṭhena sa kkāyaḥ
translated: The six external bases beginning with visible forms are the six external bases. The five aggregates of form, etc., are personality in the sense of existing.

original: Avijjākammataṇhāāhāraphassanāmarūpā sakkāyasamudayo.
analyzed: avijjā kamma taṇhā āhāra phassa nāma rūpā sa kāya samudayaḥ
translated: Ignorance, kamma-formations, craving, craving for existence, clinging, and becoming are the origin of personality.

original: Cakkhusamphassoti cakkhatīti cakkhu, rūpaṃ assādeti vibhāveti cāti attho. Cakkhuto🔽pavatto samphasso cakkhusamphasso. So pana attanā sampayuttāya vedanāya sahajātaaññamaññanissayavipākaāhārasampayuttaatthiavigatavasena
analyzed: cakkhu samphasso ti cakkhati iti cakkhu rūpam assādeti vibhāveti ca ati atthaḥ cakkhuto  pavatto samphasso cakkhu samphasso so pana attanā sampayuttāya vedanāya sahajāta aññamañña nissaya vipāka āhāra sampayutta atthi avigata vasena
translated: Eye-contact: the eye is so called because it sees . The meaning is that it enjoys visible forms and discerns them. Eye-contact is the contact occurring through the eye.🔽It is a condition in eight ways, as conascence, mutuality, support, kamma-result, nutriment, faculty, dissociation, and presence, for the feeling associated with it.

original: aṭṭhadhā paccayo hoti. Suṇātīti sotaṃ. Taṃ sasambhārasotabilassa anto tanutambalomācite🔽aṅguliveṭhakasaṇṭhāne padese sotaviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhadhā paccayaḥ hoti suṇāti iti sotam tam sa sambhāra sota bilassa antaḥ tanu tamba loma ācite  aṅguliveṭhaka saṇṭhāne padese sota viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam
translated: The ear is so called because it hears . It is the ear-sensitivity that occurs in the place in the ear-drum, etc., which has the shape of a shrivelled ear of corn and is lined with fine hairs, together with conascent ear-consciousness, etc.🔽It is a condition in eight ways, as conascence, mutuality, support, kamma-result, nutriment, faculty, dissociation, and presence, for the feeling associated with it.

original: tiṭṭhati. Sotato pavatto samphasso sotasamphasso. Ghānasamphassādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati sotataḥ pavattaḥ samphassaḥ sota samphassaḥ ghāna samphassa ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The nose is so called because it smells . It is the nose-sensitivity that occurs in the place in the nostril, etc., which has the shape of a split pea and is lined with fine hairs, together with conascent nose-consciousness, etc.

original: Ghāyatīti ghānaṃ. Taṃ sasambhārabilassa anto ajapadasaṇṭhāne padese ghānaviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: ghāyati iti ghānam tam sa sambhāra bilassa antar aja pada saṇṭhāne padese ghāna viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: It smells, thus it is the nose . It is to be found in the place inside the nose-bone, which is the size of a finger joint,

original: yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati. Jīvitamavhāyatīti jivhā, sāyanaṭṭhena🔽vā jivhā. Sā sasambhārajivhāya atiaggamūlapassāni vajjetvā uparimatalamajjhe bhinnauppaladalaggasaṇṭhāne
analyzed: yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati jīvitam avhāyati iti jivhā sa ayanaṭṭhena  vā jivhā sā sa sambhāra jivhāya ati agga mūla passāni vajjetvā uparima tala majjhe bhinna oppala da lagga saṇṭhāne
translated: and it serves as the physical basis and door for nose-consciousness, etc., as appropriate. It is the life faculty, thus it is the tongue . Or alternatively, it is the tongue because it is what one leans on in speaking .

original: padese jivhāviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānā tiṭṭhati. Kucchitānaṃ🔽sāsavadhammānaṃ āyoti kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso. Yāvatā imasmiṃ kāye upādiṇṇapavatti🔽nāma atthi, tattha yebhuyyena kāyappasādo kāyaviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ
analyzed: padese jivhā viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānā tiṭṭhati  sāsava dhammānam āyo ti kāyaḥ āyo ti uppatti desaḥ yāvatā imasmin kāye upādiṇṇa pavatti  nāma atthi tattha yebhuyyena kāya ppasādo kāya viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam
translated: It is to be found in the place inside the throat, which is the size of a joint of a radish, and it serves as the physical basis and door for tongue-consciousness, etc., as appropriate. It is the destination for the foul things, thus it is the body .

original: sādhayamāno tiṭṭhati. Munātīti mano, vijānātīti attho. Manoti sahāvajjanabhavaṅgaṃ;
analyzed: sādhayamānaḥ tiṭṭhati munāti iti manaḥ vijānāti iti atthaḥ sahāvat jana bhavaṅgam
translated: The destination is the place of origin. It is to be found in the place inside the body where there is what is called “sensed experience” in the process of clinging to a particular rebirth-linking, and it serves as the physical basis and door for body-consciousness, etc., as appropriate. It is the mind because it is what is measured by the occurrence of the associated states, thus it is the mind . The meaning is that it is what cognizes . It is the mind because it is what is measured by the occurrence of the associated states, thus it is the mind . The meaning is that it is what cognizes .

original: manato pavatto samphasso manosamphasso.
analyzed: manataḥ pavattaḥ samphassaḥ manaḥ samphassaḥ
translated: The contact that occurs from the mind is mind-contact.

original: Chabbidhampi phassaṃ duvidhameva hotīti dassetuṃ “adhivacanasamphasso paṭighasamphasso”ti
analyzed: chabbidham pi phassam duvidham eva hoti iti dassetum adhivacana samphassaḥ paṭigha samphasso ti
translated: In order to show that the sixfold contact is of two kinds only, he said “contact by designation, contact by reaction.”

original: āha. Manodvāriko adhivacanasamphasso. Pañcadvāriko vatthārammaṇādipaṭighena uppajjanato paṭighasamphasso.🔽Sukhavedanāya ārammaṇe sukhavedanīyo. Dukkhavedanāya ārammaṇe dukkhavedanīyo. Adukkhamasukhavedanāya🔽ārammaṇe adukkhamasukhavedanīyo. Tattha sukhayatīti sukhaṃ, yassuppajjati, taṃ sukhitaṃ🔽karotīti attho. Suṭṭhu vā khanati, khādati ca kāyacittābādhanti sukhaṃ. Dukkhayatīti
analyzed: āha manaḥ dvārikaḥ adhivacana samphassaḥ pañca dvārikaḥ vattha ārammaṇa ādi paṭighena uppajjanato paṭigha samphasso  sukha vedanāya ārammaṇe sukha vedanīyaḥ dukkha vedanāya ārammaṇe dukkha vedanīyaḥ adukkhamasukha vedanāya  ārammaṇe adukkham asukha vedanīyo tattha sukhayati iti sukham yassa uppajjati tam sukhitam  karoti iti attho suṭṭhu vā khanati khādati ca kāya citta ābādhanti sukham dukkhayati iti
translated: Contact by designation is that occurring in the mind door. Contact by reaction is that occurring in the five doors, because it arises by way of the resistance of the physical basis, the object, etc.🔽When the object is associated with pleasant feeling, it is productive of pleasant feeling. When the object is associated with painful feeling, it is productive of painful feeling. When the object is associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling,

original: dukkhaṃ, yassuppajjati, taṃ dukkhitaṃ karotīti attho. Na dukkhaṃ na sukhanti adukkhamasukhaṃ,
analyzed: dukkham yassa uppajjati tam dukkhitam karoti iti atthaḥ na dukkham na sukhanti adukkham asukham
translated: it is productive of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. Herein, it delights , thus it is pleasant . It makes that which arises become delighted, is the meaning. Or it is pleasant because it pierces well , it eats well , and it eats away the affliction of body and mind. It afflicts , thus it is painful . It makes that which arises become afflicted, is the meaning. It is neither painful nor pleasant , thus it is neither-painful-nor-pleasant .

original: ma-kāro padasandhivasena vutto.
analyzed: makāraḥ pada sandhi vasena vutto
translated: The letter m is stated for the purpose of euphony.

original: Kusalotiādayo jātivasena vuttā. Tattha kusaloti ekavīsatikusalacittasampayutto. Akusaloti dvādasākusalacittasampayutto. Abyākatoti avasesavipākakiriyābyākatacittasampayutto.
analyzed: kusala uti ādayaḥ jāti vasena vuttā tattha kusalo ti ekavīsati kusala citta sampayutto akusalo ti dvādasa akusala citta sampayutto abyākato ti avasesa vipāka kiriyā abyākata citta sampayutto
translated: “Skilled” and the rest are stated according to the kinds of rebirth. Herein, “skilled” is associated with one of the twenty-one kinds of profitable consciousness. “Un-skilled” is associated with one of the twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness. “Undetermined” is associated with one of the remaining kinds of resultant and functional indeterminate consciousness.

original: Puna bhavappabhedavasena niddisanto “kāmāvacaro”tiādimāha. Catupaññāsakāmāvacaracittasampayutto
analyzed: puna bhava ppabheda vasena niddisantaḥ kāmāvacara iti ādim āha catu paññāsa kāmāvacara citta sampayuttaḥ
translated: Again, when he is demonstrating by way of the division of becoming, he says “pertaining to the sense sphere” and so on. Pertaining to the sense sphere is associated with one of the fifty-four kinds of sense-sphere consciousness.

original: kāmāvacaro. Kāmaṃ pahāya rūpe avacaratīti rūpāvacaro, kusalābyākatavasena pañcadasarūpāvacaracittasampayutto.
analyzed: kāmāvacaraḥ kāmam pahāya rūpe avacarati iti rūpāvacaraḥ kusala abyākata vasena pañcadasa rūpāvacara citta sampayutto
translated: Pertaining to the fine-material sphere is associated with one of the fifteen kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness, profitable and indeterminate, since it “pertains to the fine-material sphere” by having abandoned sense desire.

original: Kāmañca rūpañca pahāya arūpe avacaratīti arūpāvacaro, kusalābyākatavasena dvādasārūpāvacaracittasampayutto.🔽Idāni abhinivesavasena dassento “suññato”tiādimāha. Tattha suññatoti rāgadosamohehi🔽suññattā suññato. Rāgadosamohanimittehi animittattā animitto. Rāgadosamohapaṇidhīnaṃ🔽abhāvato appaṇihitoti vuccati.
analyzed: kāmam ca rūpam ca pahāya arūpe avacarati iti arūpa avacaraḥ kusala abyākata vasena dvādasa arūpāvacara citta sampayutto 🔽idāni abhinivesa vasena dassento suññatā tiādim āha tattha suññatā ti rāga dosa mohehi 🔽suññattā suññataḥ rāga dosa moha nimittehi animitta ttā animittaḥ rāga dosa moha paṇidhīnam 🔽abhāvataḥ appaṇihito ti vuccati
translated: Pertaining to the immaterial sphere is associated with one of the twelve kinds of immaterial-sphere consciousness, profitable and indeterminate, since it “pertains to the immaterial sphere” by having abandoned sense desire and the fine-material.

original: Idāni vaṭṭapariyāpannaapariyāpannavasena dassento “lokiyo”tiādimāha. Loko vuccati🔽lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena vaṭṭaṃ, tasmiṃ pariyāpannabhāvena loke niyuttoti lokiyo. Uttiṇṇoti
analyzed: idāni vaṭṭa pariyāpanna apariyāpanna vasena dassentaḥ lokiyaḥ iti ādim āha lokaḥ vuccati  lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena vaṭṭam tasmim pariyāpanna bhāvena loke niyuttaḥ ti lokiyaḥ uttiṇṇaḥ ti
translated: Now, in order to show the mundane and supramundane, he says “mundane” and so on. The world is called🔽the round of rebirths in the sense of being broken and being broken up again. He is bound to the world because he is included in the world. He has gone beyond.🔽🔽

original: uttaro, loke apariyāpannabhāvena lokato uttaroti lokuttaro. Phusanāti phusanākāro.🔽Samphusanā samphusitattanti upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.🔽Evaṃ ñātaṃ katvāti evaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā jānanto tīreti tīrayati, upari vattabbākārena
analyzed: uttaraḥ loke a pariyāpanna bhāvena lokataḥ uttaraḥ iti lokuttaraḥ phusana ati phusana ākāro  samphusanā upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam  evam ñātam katvā iti evam pākaṭam katvā jānantaḥ tīreti tīrayati upari vattabba ākārena
translated: Now, in order to show it as included and not included in the round, he says “mundane” , etc. The round is called the world in the sense of pressing and being pressed ; he is bound to the world because he is included in the round, thus he is mundane . He is beyond , thus he is supramundane . He is the aspect of touching , thus he is a toucher . He is touched because he is touched by the three kinds of feeling, thus he is the touched .

original: cinteti. Aniccantikatāya ādiantavantatāya ca aniccato tīreti. Uppādavayapaṭipīḷanatāya🔽dukkhavatthutāya ca dukkhato. Paccayayāpanīyatāya rogamūlatāya ca rogato. Dukkhatāsūlayogitāya
analyzed: cintā iti anicca antika tāya ādi antavanta tāya ca aniccataḥ tīra iti uppāda vaya paṭipīḍana tāya  dukkha vatthu tāya ca dukkhataḥ paccaya yāpanīya tāya roga mūla tāya ca rogataḥ dukkha tā sūla yogi tāya
translated: Having known thus, having made it clear thus, he leads across, he causes to cross over, he thinks about in the sense of what should be said above . He leads across as impermanent because of the state of having a beginning and an end.🔽He leads across as painful because of the state of being oppressed by arising and subsidence and because of being the footing for pain. He leads across as a disease because of the state of being maintained by conditions and because of being the root of disease.

original: kilesāsucipaggharatāya uppādajarābhaṅgehi uddhumātaparipakkapabhinnatāya ca gaṇḍato.
analyzed: uppāda jarā bhaṅgehi ca gaṇḍataḥ
translated: He leads across as a boil because of the state of being associated with the dart of pain, because of the state of oozing with the impurity of defilement, and because of the state of being swollen, ripe, and burst by arising, ageing, and dissolution.

original: Pīḷājanakatāya antotudanatāya dunnīharaṇīyatāya ca sallato. Vigarahaṇīyatāya avaḍḍhiāvahanatāya
analyzed: pīḍā janaka tāya antotudana tāya dunnīharaṇīya tāya ca sallataḥ vigarahaṇīya tāya a vaḍḍhi āvahana tāya
translated: As a dart, because it causes pain, because it is pierced inside, and because it is hard to draw out.🔽As a plague, because it is to be loathed, because it brings misfortune,

original: aghavatthutāya ca aghato. Aseribhāvajanakatāya ābādhapadaṭṭhānatāya ca ābādhato.
analyzed: agha vatthu tāya ca aghataḥ aseri bhāva janaka tāya ābādha padaṭṭhāna tāya ca ābādhataḥ
translated: and because it is the basis for the plague of defilements.🔽As alien, because it is not one’s own, because it is not to be commanded,

original: Avasatāya avidheyyatāya ca parato. Byādhijarāmaraṇehi lujjanapalujjanatāya palokato.
analyzed: ca paratas byādhi jarā maraṇehi
translated: and because it is subject to destruction by sickness, ageing, and death.🔽As a disaster, because it brings many misfortunes, because it is the basis for all calamities,

original: Anekabyasanāvahanatāya ītito. Aviditānaṃyeva vipulānaṃ anatthānaṃ āvahanato sabbūpaddavavatthutāya
analyzed: aneka byasana āvahana tāya ītitaḥ aviditānam yeva vipulānam anatthānam āvahanataḥ sabbū paddava vatthu tāya
translated: and because it brings about the unknown and extensive evils.

original: ca upaddavato. Sabbabhayānaṃ ākaratāya ca dukkhavūpasamasaṅkhātassa paramassāsassa🔽paṭipakkhabhūtatāya ca bhayato. Anekehi anatthehi anubaddhatāya dosūpasaṭṭhatāya,
analyzed: ca upaddavataḥ sabba bhayānam ākaratāya ca dukkha vūpasama saṅkhātassa parama ssāsassa  paṭipakkha bhūta tāya ca bhayataḥ anekehi anatthehi anubaddha tāya dosa upasaṭṭha tāya
translated: As fear, because it is the source of all fears, because it is the opposite of the supreme comfort called the stilling of suffering,🔽and because it is the opposite of the supreme bliss called Nibbāna.🔽As a calamity, because it is connected with many misfortunes, because it is mixed with hate,

original: upasaggo viya anadhivāsanārahatāya ca upasaggato. Byādhijarāmaraṇehi ceva lābhādīhi🔽ca lokadhammehi pacalitatāya calato. Upakkamena ceva sarasena ca pabhaṅgupagamanasīlatāya
analyzed: upasaggaḥ ca upasaggāt byādhi jarā maraṇehi ca iva lābha ādīhi 🔽ca loka dhammehi pacalita tāya calataḥ upakkamena ca iva sarasena ca pabhaṅgu pagamana sīla tāya
translated: and because it is not to be endured like a calamity. As fickle, because it is shaken by sickness, ageing, death, and the mundane states of gain, etc.,🔽and because it is unsteady like a water bubble.

original: pabhaṅguto. Sabbāvatthāvinipātitāya, thirabhāvassa ca abhāvatāya adhuvato. Atāyanatāya🔽ceva alabbhaneyyakhematāya ca atāṇato. Allīyituṃ anarahatāya, allīnānampi ca leṇakiccākāritāya🔽aleṇato. Nissitānaṃ bhayasārakattābhāvena asaraṇato. Yathāparikappitehi dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvehi
analyzed: pabhaṅgutaḥ sabba avatthā vinipāti tāya thira bhāvassa ca abhāva tāya a dhuvataḥ a tāyana tāya  ca iva a labbha neyya khema tāya ca a tāṇataḥ allīyitum an arahatāya ca leṇa kiccā kāritāya  a leṇataḥ nissitānam bhaya sāraka ttā abhāvena a saraṇataḥ yathā parikappitehi dhuva subha sukhatta bhāvehi
translated: It is impermanent because it is subject to destruction and because it has no stable nature. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for fear,🔽and because it is not a shelter for those who have taken refuge in it. It is not a shelter because it is not a shelter for those who have come to it for protection. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge because it is not a refuge for those who are dependent on it. It is not a refuge

original: rittatāya rittato. Rittatāyeva tucchato, appakattā vā. Appakampi hi loke “tuccha”nti🔽vuccati. Sāminivāsivedaka kārakādhiṭṭhāyakavirahitatāya suññato.🔽Sayañca asāmikabhāvāditāya anattato. Pavattidukkhatāya, dukkhassa ca ādīnavatāya🔽ādīnavato. Atha vā ādīnaṃ vāti gacchati pavattatīti ādīnavo, kapaṇamanussassetaṃ
analyzed: rittatāya rittataḥ rittatāya iva tucchataḥ appakattā vai appakam hi loke tucchanti  vuccati sāmi nivāsi vedaka kāraka adhiṭṭhāyaka virahita tāya  sayam ca a sāmika bhāva ādi tāya anattataḥ pavatti dukkhatāya dukkhassa ca ādīnava tāya  ādīnavataḥ atha vā ādīnam vāti gacchati pavattati iti ādīnavaḥ kapaṇa manussassa etam
translated: and because it is not a state of stability, it is inconstant. Because it is not a resting-place for what is called “I” and “mine,”

original: adhivacanaṃ. Khandhāpi ca kapaṇāyevāti ādīnavasadisatāya ādīnavato. Jarāya ceva maraṇena
analyzed: adhivacanam ca kapaṇāya iva ati ādīnava sadisatāya ādīnavataḥ jarāya ca iva maraṇena
translated: and because it is not a refuge, it is not a self. Because it is not a shelter, it is not a self. Because it is not a support, it is not a self. Because it is not a mainstay, it is not a self. Because it is not a saviour, it is not a self. Because it is not a protector, it is not a self. Because it is not a master, it is not a self. Because it is not a witness, it is not a self. Because it is not a revealer, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower, it is not a self. Because it is not a seer, it is not a self. Because it is not a hearer, it is not a self. Because it is not a smeller, it is not a self. Because it is not a taster, it is not a self. Because it is not a toucher, it is not a self. Because it is not a cognizer, it is not a self. Because it is not a doer, it is not a self. Because it is not a commissioner, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of what is to be done and what is not to be done, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the right and wrong way, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the suitable and unsuitable, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the visible, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the visible, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of the past, future and present, it is not a self. Because it is not a knower of

original: cāti dvedhā pariṇāmapakatitāya vipariṇāmadhammato. Dubbalatāya, pheggu viya sukhabhañjanīyatāya
analyzed: ca ati dvedhā pariṇāma pakati tāya vipariṇāma dhammataḥ dubbala tāya pheggu sukha bhañjanīya tāya
translated: As subject to change: as subject to change in the two ways of change in ripening and change in alteration.🔽As without essence: as weak, like a lump of foam, and as unable to bear being probed with wisdom.🔽As a dart: as a dart because it is the cause of pain, like a poisoned arrow.

original: ca asārakato. Aghahetutāya aghamūlato. Mittamukhasapatto viya vissāsaghātitāya vadhakato.
analyzed: ca asārakataḥ agha hetutāya agha mūlataḥ mitta mukha sapatto viya vissāsa ghāti tāya vadhakataḥ
translated: As a disease: as a disease because it is the cause of the disease of the round, like a chronic disease.🔽As a boil: as a boil because it is the cause of the boil of the round, like a carbuncle.🔽As a dart: as a dart because it is the cause of the dart of the round, like a poisoned dart.

original: Vigatabhavatāya vibhavasambhūtatāya ca vibhavato. Āsavapadaṭṭhānatāya sāsavato. Hetupaccayehi
analyzed: vigata bhava tāya vibhava sambhūta tāya ca vibhavataḥ āsava padaṭṭhāna tāya sa āsavataḥ hetu paccayehi
translated: As a calamity: as a calamity because it is the cause of the calamity of the round, like a blow.🔽As a misfortune: as a misfortune because it is the cause of the misfortune of the round, like a misfortune.🔽As a corruption: as a corruption because it is the cause of the corruption of the round, like a corruption.

original: abhisaṅkhatatāya saṅkhatato. Maccumārakilesamārānaṃ āmisabhūtatāya mārāmisato. Jātijarābyādhimaraṇapakatitāya
analyzed: abhisaṅkhata tāya saṅkhatataḥ āmisa bhūta tāya māra āmisataḥ jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa pakati tāya
translated: As a bondage: as a bondage because it is the cause of the bondage of the round, like a bondage.🔽As a thorn: as a thorn because it is the cause of the thorn of the round, like a thorn.

original: jātijarābyādhimaraṇadhammato. Sokaparidevaupāyāsahetutāya sokaparidevaupāyāsadhammato.
analyzed: jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa dhammato soka parideva aupāyāsa hetutāya soka parideva aupāyāsa dhammato
translated: As a plague: as a plague because it is the cause of the plague of the round, like a plague.🔽As a calamity: as a calamity because it is the cause of the calamity of the round, like a calamity.🔽As a misfortune: as a misfortune because it is the cause of the misfortune of the round, like a misfortune.

original: Taṇhādiṭṭhiduccaritasaṃkilesānaṃ visayadhammatāya saṃkilesadhammato. Avijjākammataṇhāsaḷāyatanavasena
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi duccarita saṃkilesānam visaya dhamma tāya saṃkilesa dhammataḥ avijjā kamma taṇhā saḷāyatana vasena
translated: As a disease: as a disease because it is the cause of the disease of the round, like a disease.🔽As a boil: as a boil because it is the cause of the boil of the round, like a boil.

original: uppattito samudayato. Tesaṃ abhāvena atthaṅgamato. Phasse chandarāgavasena madhurassādena
analyzed: uppattitaḥ samudayataḥ tesaṃ abhāvena atthaṅgamato phasse chanda rāga vasena madhura ssādena
translated: As a dart: as a dart because it is the cause of the dart of the round, like a dart.🔽As a calamity: as a calamity because it is the cause of the calamity of the round, like a calamity.🔽As a misfortune: as a misfortune because it is the cause of the misfortune of the round, like a misfortune.🔽As a plague: as a plague because it is the cause of the plague of the round, like a plague.

original: assādato. Phassassa vipariṇāmena ādīnavato. Ubhinnaṃ nissaraṇena nissaraṇato tīretīti
analyzed: assādataḥ phassassa vipariṇāmena ādīnavataḥ ubhinnam nissaraṇena nissaraṇataḥ tīreti iti
translated: As to gratification. As to danger through change-of-lineage. As to escape by way of the escape from both.

original: sabbesu ca imesu “tīretī”ti pāṭhaseso daṭṭhabbo.🔽Pajahatīti sakasantānato nīharati. Vinodetīti tudati. Byantiṃ karotīti vigatantaṃ
analyzed: sabbesu ca imesu tīre ti iti pāṭha sesaḥ daṭṭhabbo  pajahati iti saka santānataḥ nīharati vinodeti iti tudati byantim karoti iti vigata antam
translated: And in all these passages the reading is “he crosses over” .🔽He removes from his own continuity: he takes out. He dispels: he scatters. He makes it go to non-existence: he makes it go to non-existence in the various ways.

original: karoti. Anabhāvaṃ gametīti anu anu abhāvaṃ gameti. Ariyamaggasatthena ucchinnaṃ taṇhāavijjāmayaṃ
analyzed: karoti anabhāvam gama iti iti anu anu abhāvam gama iti ariya magga satthena ucchinnam taṇhā avijjā mayam
translated: The root of these is cut off by the noble path’s sword: they are “cut off at the root.”

original: mūlametesanti ucchinnamūlā. Tālavatthu viya nesaṃ vatthu katanti tālāvatthukatā.🔽Yathā hi tālarukkhaṃ samūlaṃ uddharitvā tassa vatthumatte tasmiṃ padese kate na puna
analyzed: ucchinna mūlā tāla vatthu viya nesam vatthu tālāvatthuka tā  yathā hi tāla rukkham sa mūlam uddharitvā tassa vatthumatte tasmin padese kate na punar
translated: They are “made like a palm stump” since their occurrence is made like a palm stump.

original: tassa tālassa uppatti paññāyati, evaṃ ariyamaggasatthena samūle rūpādirase uddharitvā
analyzed: tassa tālassa uppatti paññāyati evam ariya magga satthena sa mūle rūpa ādi rase uddharitvā
translated: For just as when a palm is uprooted and its occurrence is made like a palm stump in that place, the reappearance of that palm is not evident, so too, when the noble path’s sword has uprooted the “palm” of defilements together with its root, and has made the occurrence of those defilements in the past merely a pastness,

original: tesaṃ pubbe uppannapubbabhāvena vatthumatte cittasantāne kate sabbepi te “tālāvatthukatā”ti
analyzed: tesam pubbe uppanna pubba bhāvena vatthumatte citta santāne kate sabbe pi te tālā vatthuka tā ati
translated: all those defilements are called “made like a palm stump” .

original: vuccanti. Yassesoti yassa puggalassa eso gedho. Samucchinnoti ucchinno. Vūpasantoti
analyzed: vuccanti yassa isoti yassa puggalassa eso gedho samucchinno ti ucchinnaḥ vūpasanto ti
translated: “It is said”: it is said. “Whose”: of which person. “Cut off”: cut off. “Allayed”:

original: phalena vūpasanto. Paṭipassaddhoti paṭipassaddhippahānena paṭipassambhito. Upasaggena
analyzed: phalena vūpasantaḥ paṭipassaddho ti paṭipassaddhi ppahānena paṭipassambhitaḥ upasaggena
translated: allayed by the fruit. “Quenched”: quenched by the abandonment of quenching. The word pada is extended by the prefix upa.

original: vā padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ. Abhabbuppattikoti puna uppajjituṃ abhabbo. Ñāṇagginā daḍḍhoti
analyzed: vā padam vaḍḍhitam abhabbuppattikaḥ ti punar uppajjitum abhabbaḥ ñāṇa agginā daḍḍho ti
translated: “No longer subject to cankers”: no longer able to arise again. “Burned up by the fire of knowledge”:

original: maggañāṇagginā jhāpito. Atha vā visanikkhittaṃ bhājanena saha chaḍḍitaṃ viya vatthunā🔽saha pahīno. Mūlacchinnavisavalli viya samūlacchinnoti samucchinno. Uddhane udakaṃ🔽siñcitvā nibbāpitaaṅgāraṃ viya vūpasanto. Nibbāpitaaṅgāre patitaudakaphusitaṃ viya
analyzed: magga ñāṇa agginā jhāpitaḥ atha vā visa nikkhittam bhājanena saha chaḍḍitam viya vatthunā  saha samucchinnaḥ udakam  siñcitvā nibbāpita aṅgāram viya vūpasantaḥ nibbāpita aṅgāre patita udaka phusitam viya
translated: burned up by the fire of path-knowledge. Or else: “cut off” means abandoned together with the object, like a pot with its contents thrown into a crevasse.🔽“Allayed” means like a fire extinguished by pouring water into the flue. “Quenched” means

original: paṭipassaddho. Aṅkuruppattiyā hetucchinnabījaṃ viya abhabbuppattiko. Asanipātavisarukkho
analyzed: paṭipassaddhaḥ aṅkura uppattiyā hetu chinna bījam viya abhabba uppattikaḥ a sanipāta visarukkhaḥ
translated: like a drop of water fallen on a fire that has been extinguished. “No longer subject to cankers” means like a seed whose cause for sprouting has been cut off. “Burned up by the fire of knowledge” means like a tree struck down by lightning.

original: viya ñāṇagginā daḍḍhoti evameke vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: viya ñāṇagginā evam eke vaṇṇayanti
translated: This is how some explain.

original: Vītagedhoti idaṃ sakabhāvapariccajanavasena vuttaṃ. Vigatagedhoti idaṃ ārammaṇe sālayabhāvapariccajanavasena.
analyzed: vīta gedhaḥ ti idam saka bhāva pariccajana vasena vuttam vigata gedhaḥ ti idam ārammaṇe sa ālaya bhāva pariccajana vasena
translated: “Free from grief” is said in the sense of relinquishing one’s own state. “Grief-free” is said in the sense of relinquishing the state of attachment to the object.

original: Cattagedhoti idaṃ puna anādiyanabhāvadassanavasena. Muttagedhoti idaṃ santatito vinimocanavasena.
analyzed: catta gedhā ti idam puna anādiyana bhāva dassana vasena mutta gedhā ti idam santatitaḥ vinimocana vasena
translated: “Grief-abandoned” is said in the sense of showing that one does not take it up again. “Grief-released” is said in the sense of being released from continuity.

original: Pahīnagedhoti idaṃ muttassāpi kvaci anavaṭṭhānadassanavasena. Paṭinissaṭṭhagedhoti🔽idaṃ ādinnapubbassa nissaggadassanavasena vuttaṃ. Vītarāgo vigatarāgo cattarāgoti
analyzed: pahīna gedhaḥ ti idam muttassa api kvaci anavaṭṭhāna dassana vasena paṭinissaṭṭha gedhaḥ ti  idam ādinna pubbassa nissagga dassana vasena vuttam vīta rāgaḥ vigata rāgo catta rāgo ti
translated: “Grief-given up” is said in the sense of showing that even though it is released, it does not remain anywhere. “Grief-discarded” is said🔽in the sense of showing the discarding of what was previously taken up. “Free from passion, detached from passion, with passion abandoned” should be construed in the way already stated.

original: vuttanayena yojetabbaṃ. Tattha gijjhanavasena gedho. Rañjanavasena rāgo. Nicchātoti
analyzed: vutta nayena yojetabbam tattha gijjhana vasena gedhaḥ rañjana vasena rāgaḥ nicchāto ti
translated: Herein, “grief” is in the sense of the cry of distress. “Passion” is in the sense of delight. “Content” is

original: nittaṇho. “Nicchado”tipi pāṭho, taṇhāchadanavirahitoti attho. Nibbutoti nibbutasabhāvo.
analyzed: nittaṇhaḥ nicchado tipi pāṭho taṇhā chadana virahito ti attho nibbutaḥ ti nibbuta sabhāvaḥ
translated: without craving. The reading “nicchado” is also allowable; the meaning is: devoid of the covering of craving. “Quenched” is of the nature of being quenched.

original: Sītibhūtoti sītasabhāvo. Sukhapaṭisaṃvedīti kāyikacetasikasukhaṃ anubhavanasabhāvo.
analyzed: sīti bhūtaḥ iti sīta sabhāvaḥ sukha paṭisaṃvedī iti kāyika cetasika sukham anubhavana sabhāvaḥ
translated: “Cooled” is of the nature of being cool. “Experiencing bliss” is of the nature of experiencing bodily and mental bliss.

original: Brahmabhūtenāti uttamasabhāvena. Attanāti cittena.
analyzed: brahma bhūtena ati uttama sabhāvena cittena
translated: “With the supreme state” is with the nature of the highest. “In himself” is in his mind.

original: Katattā cāti pāpakammānaṃ katabhāvena ca. Akatattā cāti kusalānaṃ akatabhāvena ca.
analyzed: kata ttā ca ati pāpa kammānam kata bhāvena ca a kata ttā ca ati kusalānam a kata bhāvena ca
translated: And by what has been done and what has not been done: by what has been done, that is, by evil actions, and by what has not been done, that is, by good actions.

original: Kataṃ me kāyaduccaritaṃ, akataṃ me kāyasucaritantiādayo dvāravasena avirativirativasena
analyzed: me dvāra vasena avirati virati vasena
translated: “Evil bodily conduct has been done by me, good bodily conduct has not been done” , etc., are stated by way of door, by way of non-restraint and restraint,

original: kammapathavasena ca vuttā. Sīlesumhi na paripūrakārītiādayo catupārisuddhisīlavasena.
analyzed: kammapatha vasena ca vuttā sīlesumhi na paripūra kārī iti ādayo catu pārisuddhi sīla vasena
translated: and by way of the courses of action. “I have not fulfilled the virtue consisting in the fourfold purity” , etc., are stated by way of the virtue of the fourfold purity.

original: Jāgariyamananuyuttoti pañcajāgaraṇavasena. Satisampajaññenāti sātthakādisampajaññavasena.🔽Cattāro satipaṭṭhānātiādayo bodhipakkhiyadhammā lokiyalokuttaravasena. Dukkhaṃ me
analyzed: jāgariyam an anuyuttaḥ ti pañca jāgaraṇa vasena sati sampajaññena ati sātthaka ādi sampajañña vasena  cattāro sati paṭṭhāna ati ādayaḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammāḥ lokiya lokuttara vasena dukkham me
translated: “I am devoted to watchfulness” , etc., are stated by way of the five kinds of watchfulness. “I am endowed with mindfulness and full awareness” , etc., are stated by way of the full awareness of meaning, etc.

original: apariññātantiādayo cattāro ariyasaccavasena vuttāti veditabbaṃ. Te atthato tattha
analyzed: apariññāta nti ādayo cattāro ariya sacca vasena vuttā iti veditabbam te atthataḥ tattha
translated: “The four foundations of mindfulness” , etc., are stated by way of the mundane and supramundane factors of enlightenment. “I have not fully understood suffering” , etc., are stated by way of the four noble truths.

original: tattha vuttanayattā pākaṭāyeva.
analyzed: tattha vutta naya ttā pākaṭāya iva
translated: This should be understood. Their meaning is evident in each instance, since the method of explanation is given there in each case.

original: Dhīro paṇḍitoti satta padā vuttatthāyeva. Api ca dukkhe akampiyaṭṭhena dhīro. Sukhe
analyzed: dhīro paṇḍito ti satta padā vutta tthāya iva api ca dukkhe akampiya ṭṭhena dhīro sukhe
translated: “The wise one” , etc., are seven terms whose meaning is self-evident. Moreover, “wise” in the sense of unshaken by suffering,🔽“brave” in the sense of not being frightened by the three lower realms,

original: anuppilavaṭṭhena paṇḍito. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthe kataparicayaṭṭhena paññavā.
analyzed: anuppilava ṭṭhena paṇḍitaḥ diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika tthe kata paricaya ṭṭhena paññavā
translated: and by the meaning of not being filled up, he is wise. And by the meaning of being skilled in the matter of this present life and the life to come, he is wise.

original: Attatthaparatthe niccalaṭṭhena buddhimā. Gambhīrauttānatthe apaccosakkanaṭṭhena ñāṇī.
analyzed: a t ttha para tthe nicca laṭṭhena buddhimā gambhīra auttāna tthe a paccosakkana aṭṭhena ñāṇī
translated: By the meaning of being unmoved in his own and others’ welfare, he is intelligent. And by the meaning of not being confused about the deep and the obvious, he is knowledgeable.

original: Guḷhapaṭicchannatthe obhāsanaṭṭhena vibhāvī. Nikkilesabyavadānaṭṭhena tulāsadisoti🔽medhāvī. Na limpatīti sajātiyā na limpati ākāse lekhā viya. Na palimpatīti visesena
analyzed: guḷha paṭicchanna tthe obhāsana ṭṭhena vibhāvī nikkilesa byavadāna ṭṭhena tulā sadisaḥ ti  medhāvī na limpati iti sajātiyā na limpati ākāse lekhā viya na palimpati iti visesena
translated: By the meaning of illuminating the hidden and the concealed, he is discerning. And by the meaning of being like a balance in being free from corruption, he is

original: na limpati. Na upalimpatīti saññogo hutvāpi na limpati hatthatale lekhā viya. Alittoti🔽saññogo hutvāpi na kilissati kāsikavatthe ṭhapitamaṇiratanaṃ viya. Apalittoti visesena🔽na kilissati maṇiratane paliveṭhitakāsikavatthaṃ viya. Anupalittoti upagantvāpi na
analyzed: na limpati na upalimpati iti saññogaḥ hutvā api na limpati hattha tale lekhā viya a littā ti  saññogaḥ hutvā api na kilissati kāsikavatthe ṭhapita maṇi ratanam viya apalittaḥ ti visesena  na kilissati maṇi ratane paliveṭhita kāsika vattham viya upagantvā api na
translated: clever. He does not stick: he does not stick to his own kind, like a line in the sky. He does not cling: he does not stick to it in a special way. He does not adhere: though he has stuck to it, he does not stick to it, like a line on the palm of the hand. He is not soiled:🔽though he has stuck to it, he is not defiled, like a gem placed on Kāsi cloth. He is not stained: he is not defiled in a special way,

original: allīyati pokkharapatte udakabindu viya. Nikkhantoti bahi nikkhanto bandhanāgārato
analyzed: allīyati pokkhara patte udaka bindu viya nikkhanto ti bahi nikkhantaḥ bandhanāgārato
translated: like the Kāsi cloth wrapped around the gem. He is not smeared: though he has gone near to it, he does not smear it, like a drop of water on a lotus leaf. He has come out: he has come out from the prison-house of views.

original: palāto viya. Nissaṭoti pāpapahīno amittassa paṭicchāpitakiliṭṭhavatthu viya. Vippamuttoti
analyzed: palātaḥ viya nissaṭaḥ ti pāpa pahīnaḥ amittassa paṭicchāpita kiliṭṭha vatthu viya vippamutto ti
translated: like a snake that has cast off its skin. Disengaged : having abandoned evil, like a piece of cloth that has been hidden by an enemy and then soiled. Liberated :

original: suṭṭhu mutto gayhūpage vatthumhi ratiṃ nāsetvā puna nāgamanaṃ viya. Visaññuttoti
analyzed: suṭṭhu muttaḥ gayhu upage vatthumhi ratim na āsetvā puna na āgamanam viya visaññuttaḥ ti
translated: well liberated, like one who has removed delight in the object of sensual pleasure and does not return to it. Unfettered :

original: kilesehi ekato na yutto byādhinā muttagilāno viya. Vimariyādikatena cetasāti vigatamariyādakatena
analyzed: kilesehi ekataḥ na yuttaḥ byādhinā mutta gilānaḥ viya vimariyādikatena cetasā ati vigata mariyāda katena
translated: not fettered together with the defilements, like one who is cured of an illness. With a mind that is free from the stain of doubt :

original: cittena, sabbabhavena sabbārammaṇena sabbakilesehi muttacittenāti attho.
analyzed: cittena sabba bhavena sabba ārammaṇena sabba kilesehi mutta cittena ati attho
translated: with a mind that is free from the stain of doubt, with a mind that is free from all becoming, from all objects, from all defilements, is the meaning.

original: 14. Saññaṃ pariññāti gāthāya pana ayaṃ saṅkhepattho – na kevalañca phassameva, api
analyzed: saññam pariññā ti gāthāya pana ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ na kevalam ca phassam eva api
translated: The meaning of the verse beginning with the words “Perception” is this: Not only the contact,

original: ca kho pana kāmasaññādibhedaṃ saññaṃ, saññānusārena vā pubbe vuttanayeneva nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: ca kho pana kāma saññā ādi bhedam saññam saññā anusārena vā pubbe vutta nayena iva nāma rūpam
translated: but also the perception, which is of the kind called perception of sense desires, etc., or the mentality and materiality mentioned earlier in the verse by the word “perception” through the influence of perception,

original: tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā imāya paṭipadāya catubbidhampi vitareyya oghaṃ, tato so
analyzed: tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā imāya paṭipadāya catubbidham pi vitareyya ogham tatas so
translated: having fully understood with the three kinds of full understanding, he should spread out the fourfold flood by this way. Then he,

original: tiṇṇogho taṇhādiṭṭhipariggahesu taṇhādiṭṭhikilesappahānena anupalitto khīṇāsavamuni
