original: Arahantoti kilesehi ārakattā, arīnaṃ arānañca hatattā, paccayādīnaṃ arahattā, pāpakaraṇe🔽rahābhāvā tathāgato arahaṃ. Ārakā hi so sabbakilesehi suvidūravidūre ṭhito maggena
analyzed: arahanto ti kilesehi ārakattā arīnam arānam ca hatattā paccaya ādīnam arahattā pāpa karaṇe  tathāgataḥ arahan ārakā hi so sabba kilesehi su vidūra vidūre ṭhitaḥ maggena
translated: “Worthy”: he is worthy because he is far from defilements, because he has destroyed the enemies and their enmity, because he is worthy of offerings, and because he is devoid of secrecy about evil deeds.🔽For he is far, very far, from all defilements, standing as he does with the path that has destroyed the defilements together with their residual tendencies.

original: savāsanānaṃ kilesānaṃ viddhaṃsitattāti ārakattā arahaṃ.
analyzed: kilesānam ārakattā araham
translated: He is worthy because he is far .

original: “So tato ārakā nāma, yassa yenāsamaṅgitā;
analyzed: saḥ tatas ārakā nāma yassa
translated: “He is called far because he is not associated With that by which he is not associated;

original: Asamaṅgī ca dosehi, nātho tenārahaṃ mato”.
analyzed: asamaṅgī ca dosehi tena araham mataḥ
translated: And because he is not associated with faults, The Lord is considered worthy.”

original: Te cānena kilesārayo maggena hatāti arīnaṃ hatattāpi arahaṃ.
analyzed: te ca anena kilesa arayaḥ maggena arīnam hatattāpi
translated: And he is worthy because he has destroyed the enemies, the defilements, with the path.

original: “Yasmā rāgādisaṅkhātā, sabbepi arayo hatā;
analyzed: yasmā rāga ādi saṅkhātā sabbe pi arayaḥ hatā
translated: Since all the enemies called greed, etc.,🔽Have been slain by the Lord with the sword of wisdom,

original: Paññāsatthena nāthena, tasmāpi arahaṃ mato”.
analyzed: paññāsatthena nāthena tasmā api araham mato
translated: He is therefore called the Worthy One.🔽The wheel of existence, which has ignorance and craving for its nave,

original: Yañcetaṃ avijjābhavataṇhāmayanābhiṃ puññādiabhisaṅkhārānaṃ jarāmaraṇanemiṃ āsavasamudayamayena
analyzed: avijjā bhava taṇhā maya nābhim jarā maraṇa nemim āsava samudaya mayena
translated: the formations of merit, etc., for its spokes, and aging and death for its felly,🔽which is fixed with the axle of the origin of cankers,

original: akkhena vijjhitvā tibhavarathe samāyojitaṃ anādikālappavattaṃ saṃsāracakkaṃ, tassānena🔽bodhimaṇḍe vīriyapādehi sīlapathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya saddhāhatthena kammakkhayakaraṃ
analyzed: akkhena vijjhitvā tibhava rathe samāyojitam anādi kāla ppavattam saṃsāra cakkam tassa anena  bodhimaṇḍe vīriya pādehi sīla pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya saddhā hatthena kamma khaya karam
translated: and which has revolved from beginningless time, was struck by the Lord🔽with the arrow of knowledge, which he took in his hand of faith, having established himself on the ground of virtue with the feet of energy,

original: ñāṇapharasuṃ gahetvā sabbe arā hatāti arahaṃ.
analyzed: gahetvā sabbe arāḥ hatā ati araham
translated: at the foot of the Bodhi tree, and all its spokes were broken. Therefore he is the Worthy One.🔽Since the Lord of the World has slain

original: “Arā saṃsāracakkassa, hatā ñāṇāsinā yato;
analyzed: arā saṃsāra cakkassa hatā ñāṇa asinā yataḥ
translated: The spokes of the wheel of existence with the sword of knowledge,

original: Lokanāthena tenesa, ‘araha’nti pavuccati”.
analyzed: lokanāthena tena isa arahanti pavuccati
translated: He is therefore called the Worthy One.🔽And because he is worthy of requisites such as robes, etc., and of the special worship offered to a Buddha,

original: Aggadakkhiṇeyyattā ca cīvarādipaccaye arahati pūjāvisesañca, teneva ca uppanne tathāgate
analyzed: ca cīvara ādi paccaye arahati pūjā visesam ca tena iva ca uppanne tathāgate
translated: and because when a Tathāgata has arisen🔽all the great gods and men do not render worship elsewhere but only to him,

original: ye keci mahesakkhā devamanussā, na te aññattha pūjaṃ karonti. Tathā hi brahmā sahampati
analyzed: ye keci mahesakkhāḥ deva manussāḥ na te aññattha pūjam karonti tathā hi brahmā sahampati
translated: as did Brahmā Sahampati,

original: sinerumattena ratanadāmena tathāgataṃ pūjesi, yathābalañca aññe devā ca manussā ca🔽bimbisārakosalarājādayo. Parinibbutampi ca bhagavantaṃ uddissa channavutikoṭidhanaṃ
analyzed: sineru mattena ratana dāmena tathāgatam pūjesi yathābalam ca aññe devā ca manussā ca  bimbisāra kosala rāja ādayaḥ parinibbutam pi ca bhagavantam uddissa channavuti koṭi dhanam
translated: He worshipped the Enlightened One with a garland of jewels worth the whole of India, and other gods and men worshipped him according to their means,

original: vissajjetvā asokamahārājā sakalajambudīpe caturāsītivihārasahassāni patiṭṭhāpesi.🔽Ko pana vādo aññesaṃ pūjāvisesānanti paccayādīnaṃ arahattāpi arahaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjetvā asoka mahā rājā sakala jambudīpe caturāsīti vihāra sahassāni patiṭṭhāpesi  kaḥ pana vādaḥ aññesam pūjā visesānam ti paccaya ādīnam arahattā api araham
translated: as did Bimbisāra, King of Magadha, and Pasenadi, King of Kosala, and so on. And after the Blessed One’s final attainment of Nibbāna, King Asoka, having spent ninety-six koṭis of treasure on the funeral ceremonies, established eighty-four thousand monasteries throughout the whole of India.

original: “Pūjāvisesaṃ saha paccayehi, yasmā ayaṃ arahati lokanātho;
analyzed: pūjā visesam saha paccayehi yasmai ayam arahati loka nātho
translated: So what need is there to speak of other kinds of worship? He is worthy of requisites, etc., because he is worthy of offerings of requisites, such as the four requisite-conditions beginning with robes, and of worship, etc., and because he is worthy of the highest offerings of all.🔽Since he is worthy of requisites, worship, and offerings,🔽And since he is worthy of the world’s highest homage,

original: Atthānurūpaṃ arahanti loke, tasmā jino arahati nāmametaṃ”.
analyzed: attha anurūpam arahanti loke tasmai jinaḥ arahati nāmam etam
translated: He is called the Worthy One in accordance with the meaning.

original: Yathā ca loke ye keci paṇḍitamānino bālā asilokabhayena raho pāpaṃ karonti, evamesa na kadāci pāpaṃ karotīti pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvatopi arahaṃ.
analyzed: yathā ca loke ye paṇḍita māninaḥ bālāḥ asi loka bhayena raho pāpam karonti evam esa na kadācid pāpam karoti iti pāpa karaṇe
translated: And just as fools who are conceited about their wisdom commit evil secretly for fear of losing their reputation, so he never commits evil, and for this reason too he is worthy.🔽Since there is no secret for him,

original: “Yasmā natthi raho nāma, pāpakammesu tādino;
analyzed: yasmai natthi rahaḥ nāma pāpa kammesu tādinaḥ
translated: Who is so scrupulous in matters of evil,🔽He is renowned as the Worthy One

original: Rahābhāvena tenesa, arahaṃ iti vissuto”.
analyzed: raha abhāvena tena īsa araham iti vissutaḥ
translated: Because he has no secrets.

original: Evaṃ sabbathāpi –
analyzed: evam sabbathā api
translated: So in every way he is worthy.

original: “Ārakattā hatattā ca, kilesārīna so muni;
analyzed: ārakattā hatattā ca saḥ muni
translated: “He is a muni because he has destroyed and cut off the defilements,

original: Hatasaṃsāracakkāro, paccayādīna cāraho;
analyzed: hata saṃsāra cakkāro
translated: He is worthy to receive gifts because he has stopped the wheel of the round of rebirths and because he has penetrated conditions, etc.,

original: Na raho karoti pāpāni, arahaṃ tena vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: na rahaḥ karoti pāpāni araham tena vuccati iti
translated: He is worthy because he does not commit evil in secret” .

original: Yasmā pana sabbe buddhā arahattaguṇenāpi samasamā, tasmā sabbesampi vasena “arahanto”ti🔽āha. Sammāsambuddhāti sammā sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddho. Tathā
analyzed: yasmā pana sabbe buddhāḥ arahatta guṇena api samasamā tasmā sabbesam pi vasena arahantoti  āha sammāsambuddha iti sammā sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ tathā
translated: But since all Buddhas are equal in the perfection of their worthiness, he said “worthy ones” in order to include all.🔽Fully awakened : he is fully awakened because he has awakened to all things rightly and by himself.🔽Thus he is fully awakened to all things because he has awakened rightly to all things that are to be awakened to by direct knowledge,

original: hesa sabbadhamme sammāsambuddho, abhiññeyye dhamme abhiññeyyato, pariññeyye dhamme
analyzed: ha esa sabba dhamme sammāsambuddhaḥ abhiññeyye dhamme abhiññeyyataḥ pariññeyye dhamme
translated: to all things that are to be fully understood by full understanding,

original: pariññeyyato, pahātabbe dhamme pahātabbato, sacchikātabbe dhamme sacchikātabbato,
analyzed: pariññeyyataḥ pahātabbe dhamme pahātabbataḥ sacchikātabbe dhamme sacchikātabbataḥ
translated: to all things that are to be abandoned by abandoning, to all things that are to be realized by realizing,

original: bhāvetabbe dhamme bhāvetabbato. Tenevāha –
analyzed: bhāvetabbe dhamme bhāvetabbato tena iva āha
translated: and to all things that are to be developed by developing. Hence it is said:🔽“What is to be directly known has been directly known,

original: “Abhiññeyyaṃ abhiññātaṃ, bhāvetabbañca bhāvitaṃ;
analyzed: abhiññeyyam abhiññātam bhāvetabbañca bhāvitam
translated: What is to be developed has been developed,🔽What is to be abandoned has been abandoned by me,

original: Pahātabbaṃ pahīnaṃ me, tasmā buddhosmi brāhmaṇā”ti. ;
analyzed: pahātabbam pahīnam me tasmai buddhaḥ asmi brāhmaṇa ati
translated: Therefore, brahmin, I am awakened” .

original: Atha vā cakkhu dukkhasaccaṃ, tassa mūlakāraṇabhāvena samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: atha vā cakkhu dukkha saccam tassa mūla kāraṇa bhāvena samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā samudaya saccam
translated: Or else, the eye is the truth of suffering, the craving which is its root-cause and which arises in the form of desire for the experience of the eye’s object is the truth of origin,

original: ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, nirodhapajānanā paṭipadā maggasaccanti evaṃ ekekapaduddhārenāpi
analyzed: ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam nirodha pajānanā paṭipadā magga saccanti evam ekeka paduddhārena api
translated: the non-occurrence of both is the truth of cessation, and the way leading to the cessation of both is the truth of the path. Thus he understands all dhammas rightly and by himself.🔽This method should be applied to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

original: sabbadhamme sammā sāmañca buddho. Esa nayo sotaghānajivhākāyamanesu. Eteneva ca nayena
analyzed: sabba dhamme sammā sāmañca buddhaḥ esa nayo sota ghāna jivhā kāya manesu etena iva ca nayena
translated: By this same method,

original: rūpādīni cha āyatanāni, cakkhuviññāṇādayo cha viññāṇakāyā, cakkhusamphassādayo cha
analyzed: rūpa ādīni cha āyatanāni cakkhu viññāṇa ādayo cha viññāṇa kāyā cakkhu samphassa ādayo cha
translated: the six bases beginning with the eye, the six groups of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness, the six kinds of contact beginning with eye-contact,

original: phassā, cakkhusamphassajā vedanādayo cha vedanā, rūpasaññādayo cha saññā, rūpasañcetanādayo🔽cha cetanā, rūpataṇhādayo cha taṇhākāyā, rūpavitakkādayo cha vitakkā, rūpavicārādayo
analyzed: phassā cakkhu samphassa jāḥ vedanā ādayo cha vedanā rūpa saññā ādayo cha saññā rūpa sañcetanā ādayo  cha cetanāḥ rūpa taṇhā ādayo cha taṇhā kāyāḥ rūpa vitakka ādayo cha vitakkāḥ rūpa vicāra ādayo
translated: the six kinds of feeling beginning with eye-contact-born feeling, the six kinds of perception beginning with perception of visible objects, the six kinds of volition beginning with volition regarding visible objects,

original: cha vicārā, rūpakkhandhādayo pañcakkhandhā, dasa kasiṇāni, dasa anussatiyo, uddhumātakasaññādivasena
analyzed: cha vicārāḥ rūpa kkhandha ādayo pañca kkhandhāḥ dasa kasiṇāni dasa anussatiyaḥ uddhumātaka saññā ādi vasena
translated: the six kinds of craving beginning with craving for visible objects, the six kinds of applied thought beginning with applied thought about visible objects, the six kinds of sustained thought beginning with sustained thought about visible objects, the five aggregates beginning with the aggregate of material form, the ten kasiṇas, the ten recollections,🔽the perception of a bloated corpse, etc.

original: dasa saññā, kesādayo dvattiṃsākārā, dvādasāyatanāni, aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo, kāmabhavādayo
analyzed: dasa saññā kesa ādayaḥ dvattiṃsa ākārāḥ dvādasa āyatanāni aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo kāma bhava ādayo
translated: Ten perceptions, the thirty-two aspects beginning with head hairs, the twelve bases, the eighteen elements, the nine kinds of becoming beginning with sensual becoming,

original: nava bhavā, paṭhamādīni cattāri jhānāni, mettābhāvanādayo catasso appamaññāyo, catasso
analyzed: nava bhavā paṭhama ādīni cattāri jhānāni mettā bhāvanā ādayo catasso appamaññāyo catasso
translated: the four jhānas beginning with the first, the four measureless states beginning with the development of loving-kindness, the four

original: arūpasamāpattiyo, paṭilomato jarāmaraṇādīni, anulomato avijjādīni paṭiccasamuppādaṅgāni ca yojetabbāni.🔽Tatrāyaṃ ekapadayojanā – jarāmaraṇaṃ dukkhasaccaṃ, jāti samudayasaccaṃ, ubhinnaṃ🔽nissaraṇaṃ nirodhasaccaṃ, nirodhapajānanā paṭipadā maggasaccanti evaṃ ekekapaduddhārena
analyzed: arūpa samāpattiyaḥ paṭilomataḥ jarā maraṇa ādīni anulomataḥ avijjā ādīni paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgāni ca yojetabbāni  tatra ayam eka pada yojanā jarā maraṇam dukkha saccam jāti samudaya saccam ubhinnam  nissaraṇam nirodha saccam nirodha pajānanā paṭipadā magga saccanti evam ekeka paduddhārena
translated: formless attainments, the factors of the dependent origination in reverse order beginning with ageing-and-death, and in forward order beginning with ignorance, should be construed.

original: sabbadhamme sammā sāmañca buddho anubuddho paṭividdho. Yaṃ vā pana kiñci atthi neyyaṃ
analyzed: sabba dhamme sammā sāmañca buddhaḥ anubuddhaḥ paṭividdhaḥ yam vā pana kiñci atthi na iyyam
translated: Here is the construction in terms of single terms: Ageing-and-death is the truth of suffering; birth is the truth of origin; the escape from both is the truth of cessation; the understanding of cessation is the path. Thus he has fully awakened to all dhammas by right understanding and by penetrating them one by one. Or else, since he is fully enlightened about whatever is knowable,

original: nāma, sabbassa sammā sambuddhattā vimokkhantikañāṇavasena sammāsambuddho. Tesaṃ pana
analyzed: nāma sabbassa sammā sambuddha ttā vimokkha antika ñāṇa vasena sammāsambuddhaḥ tesam pana
translated: he is the Enlightened One, the Fully Enlightened One, by virtue of the knowledge that is emancipating. But as to the words “He is the One who understands, the One who sees,”

original: vibhāgo upari āvi bhavissati. Yasmā pana sabbabuddhā sammāsambuddhaguṇenāpi samasamā,
analyzed: vibhāgaḥ upari bhavissati yasmā pana sabba buddhā sammāsambuddha guṇena api samasamā
translated: But since all Buddhas are equal in the qualities of a Perfect One,

original: tasmā sabbesampi vasena “sammāsambuddhā”ti āha.
analyzed: tasmā sabbesam pi vasena sammāsambuddhā iti āha
translated: he says “perfect ones” in the sense of all of them.

original: Monenāti kāmañhi moneyyapaṭipadāsaṅkhātena maggañāṇamonena muni nāma hoti, idha pana
analyzed: monena ati kāmañhi moneyya paṭipadā saṅkhātena magga ñāṇa monena nāma hoti idha pana
translated: “Not by his silence”: for one is called a sage by the knowledge of the path called the practice of silence. But here

original: tuṇhībhāvaṃ sandhāya “na monenā”ti vuttaṃ. Mūḷharūpoti tuccharūpo. Aviddasūti aviññū.🔽Evarūpo hi tuṇhībhūtopi muni nāma na hoti. Atha vā moneyyamuni nāma na hoti, tucchabhāvo
analyzed: tuṇhībhāvam sandhāya na monena ati vuttam mūḷha rūpo ti tuccha rūpaḥ aviddasū ti aviññū  evarūpaḥ hi tuṇhībhūtaḥ api muni nāma na hoti atha vā nāma na hoti tuccha bhāvaḥ
translated: “not by his silence” is said with reference to the state of silence. “A mere void” means a void of mere emptiness. “A mere non-knower” means a mere non-knower.

original: ca pana aññāṇī ca hotīti attho. Yo ca tulaṃva paggayhāti yathā hi tulaṃ gahetvā ṭhito
analyzed: ca pana aññāṇī ca hoti iti attho yaḥ ca tulam iva paggayha ati yathā hi tulam gahetvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: For one who is in the state of silence is not a sage. Or the meaning is: he is not a sage by the practice of silence, but he is a mere void and a mere non-knower.

original: atirekaṃ ce hoti, harati, ūnaṃ ce hoti, pakkhipati; evameva so atirekaṃ haranto viya
analyzed: atirekam ce hoti harati ūnam ce hoti pakkhipati evam eva so atirekam harantaḥ viya
translated: “Who, like a scale-pan, sways to and fro”: just as one standing holding a scale-pan sways to and fro if it is not balanced,

original: pāpaṃ harati parivajjeti, ūnake pakkhipanto viya kusalaṃ paripūreti. Evañca pana
analyzed: pāpam harati parivajjeti ūnake pakkhipantaḥ viya kusalam paripūreti evam ca pana
translated: so too, he sways to and fro as it were, by removing evil and by fulfilling the good.

original: karonto sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttivimuttiñāṇadassanasaṅkhātaṃ varaṃ uttamameva ādāya
analyzed: karontaḥ sīla samādhi paññā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassana saṅkhātam varam uttamam eva ādāya
translated: He who does so, taking the best, the supreme, namely virtue, concentration, wisdom, deliverance, and the knowledge and vision of deliverance,

original: pāpāni akusalakammāni parivajjeti sa muni nāmāti attho. Tena so munīti kasmā pana
analyzed: pāpāni akusala kammāni parivajjeti sa muni nāma ati attho tena saḥ muni iti kasmā pana
translated: shuns evil, unwholesome states. This is the meaning. Why is he called a sage?

original: so munīti ce? Yaṃ heṭṭhā vuttakāraṇaṃ, tena so munīti attho. Yo munāti ubho loketi
analyzed: saḥ munī iti ce yam heṭṭhā vutta kāraṇam tena saḥ munī iti atthaḥ yaḥ munāti ubho loke iti
translated: If it be asked, why is he called a sage? the meaning is: because of the reason stated above.

original: yo puggalo imasmiṃ khandhādiloke tulaṃ āropetvā minanto viya “ime ajjhattikā khandhā,
analyzed: yaḥ puggalaḥ imasmin khandha ādi loke tulam āropetvā minantaḥ viya ime ajjhattikāḥ khandhāḥ
translated: He who measures out both worlds: this person, as if weighing, measuring in this world of aggregates, etc.,🔽“These are the internal aggregates, these are the external,” etc., measures out both these things.

original: ime bāhirā”tiādinā nayena ime ubho atthe munāti. Muni tena pavuccatīti tena pana
analyzed: ime bāhirā ti ādinā nayena ime ubho atthe munāti tena pavuccati iti tena pana
translated: Therefore he is called a sage: therefore,

original: kāraṇena “munī”ti vuccatiyevāti attho.
analyzed: kāraṇena muni iti attho
translated: the meaning is, he is called a sage.🔽The verse’s meaning in brief is this: The unwholesome and the wholesome states,

original: Asatañcāti gāthāya ayaṃ saṅkhepattho – yvāyaṃ akusalakusalappabhedo, asatañca satañca
analyzed: asatam ca ati gāthāya ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yvā ayam akusala kusala ppabhedaḥ asatam ca satam ca
translated: the unwholesome and the wholesome things,

original: dhammo, taṃ “ajjhattaṃ bahiddhā”ti imasmiṃ sabbaloke pavicayañāṇena asatañca satañca
analyzed: dhammo tam ajjhattam bahiddhā ti imasmin sabba loke pavicaya ñāṇena asatam ca satam ca
translated: he measures out by the knowledge of search in this whole world, “internally and externally.”

original: ñatvā dhammaṃ. Tassa ñātattā eva, rāgādibhedato sattavidhaṃ saṅgaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhibhedato
analyzed: ñatvā dhammam tassa ñāta ttā eva rāga ādi bhedato sattavidham saṅgam taṇhā diṭṭhi bhedato
translated: He is a sage because he has gone beyond the sevenfold and twofold net of craving and views.

original: duvidhaṃ jālañca aticca atikkamitvā ṭhito, so tena monasaṅkhātena pavicayañāṇena
analyzed: duvidham jālam ca aticca atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ saḥ tena mona saṅkhātena pavicaya ñāṇena
translated: He is a sage because he is endowed with the knowledge of investigation, which is called “mindfulness.”

original: samannāgatattā muni. Devamanussehi pūjitoti idaṃ panassa thutivacanaṃ. So hi khīṇāsavamunittā
analyzed: samannāgata ttā deva manussehi pūjitaḥ ti idam panassa thuti vacanam saḥ hi khīṇāsava muni ttā
translated: He is worshipped by gods and men: this is a statement of praise. For he, a sage with cankers destroyed,

original: devamanussānaṃ pūjāraho hoti, tasmā evaṃ vuttoti.🔽Sallanti mūlapadaṃ. Satta sallānīti gaṇanaparicchedo. Rāgasallanti rañjanaṭṭhena🔽rāgo ca pīḷājanakatāya antotudanatāya dunnīharaṇatāya sallañcāti rāgasallaṃ. Dosasallādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Abbūḷhasalloti mūlapadaṃ. Abbahitasalloti nīhaṭasallo. Uddhatasalloti
analyzed: deva manussānam pūjā rahaḥ hoti tasmai evam vuttaḥ ti  mūla padam satta sallāni iti gaṇana paricchedaḥ rāgasallanti rañjana ṭṭhena  ca pīḷā janaka tāya antotudanatāya dunnīharaṇatāya sallam ca ati rāga sallam dosa salla ādīsupi  esa iva nayaḥ abbūḍha sallo ti mūla padam abbahita sallo uddhata sallo ti
translated: is worthy of worship by gods and men. That is why he is said thus.🔽The word “arrow” is the basic expression. “Seven arrows”: this is the delimitation by number. The arrow of lust: because it delights, it is lust; and because it causes pain, because it is hard to pull out, because it is hard to extract, it is an arrow. The same method applies in the case of the arrow of hate, and so on.

original: uddhaṃ haṭasallo uddharitasallo. Samuddhatasalloti upasaggavasena vutto. Uppāṭitasalloti
analyzed: uddham haṭa sallaḥ uddharita sallo samuddhata sallaḥ ti upasagga vasena vuttaḥ uppāṭita sallaḥ ti
translated: The word “extracted” is the basic expression. “Shot out” is “extracted.” “Drawn out” is “extracted.” “Utterly drawn out” is expressed by the prefix upa. “Cut out” is “extracted.”

original: luñcitasallo. Samuppāṭitasalloti upasaggavaseneva.
analyzed: luñcita sallo samuppāṭita sallo ti upasagga vasena iva
translated: He is one who has cut the fetter. He is one who has torn the fetter, by the method of attack.

original: Sakkaccakārīti dānādīnaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyyadhammassa vā
analyzed: sakkacca kārī iti dāna ādīnam kusala dhammānam bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyya dhammassa vā
translated: He is one who acts respectfully: he is one who acts respectfully in the development of profitable things such as giving, etc., or in the case of a person or an object to be given.

original: sakkaccakaraṇavasena sakkaccakārī. Satatabhāvakaraṇena sātaccakārī. Aṭṭhitakaraṇena
analyzed: sakkacca karaṇa vasena sakkacca kārī satata bhāva karaṇena sātacca kārī aṭṭhita karaṇena
translated: He is one who acts continuously by making it last. He is one who acts persistently by standing firm.

original: aṭṭhitakārī. Yathā nāma kakaṇṭako thokaṃ gantvā thokaṃ tiṭṭhati, na nirantaraṃ gacchati;
analyzed: aṭṭhita kārī yathā nāma kakaṇṭakaḥ thokam gantvā thokam tiṭṭhati na nirantaram gacchati
translated: Just as a hedgehog goes a little way and then stops, and does not go on continuously,

original: evameva yo puggalo ekadivasaṃ dānaṃ datvā pūjaṃ vā katvā dhammaṃ vā sutvā samaṇadhammaṃ🔽vā katvā puna cirassaṃ karoti, taṃ na nirantaraṃ pavatteti. So “asātaccakārī, anaṭṭhitakārī”ti
analyzed: evam eva yaḥ puggalaḥ eka divasam dānam da tvā pūjam vā katvā dhammam vā sutvā samaṇa dhammaṃ  vā katvā puna cirassam karoti tam na nirantaram pavatteti saḥ a sātacca kārī an aṭṭhita kārī iti
translated: so too, when a person gives a gift, or does honour, or listens to the True Idea, or does the ascetic’s duties, and then does it again only after a long interval, he does not keep it up continuously.

original: vuccati. Ayaṃ evaṃ na karotīti aṭṭhitakārī. Anolīnavuttikoti nirantarakaraṇasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: vuccati ayam evam na karoti iti aṭṭhita kārī anolīnavuttikaḥ ti nirantara karaṇa saṅkhātassa
translated: He is called one who does not act continuously, one who does not act persistently. This one does not do so: he is one who acts persistently. He is one whose habit is not to be slack: he is not one whose habit is to be slack by the habit of the spread of the state of not acting continuously.🔽He is one whose habit is not to be slack. He is one whose desire is not abandoned:

original: vipphārassa bhāvena na līnavuttikoti anolīnavuttiko. Anikkhittacchandoti kusalakaraṇe
analyzed: vipphārassa bhāvena na līna vuttikaḥ ti anolīna vuttikaḥ a nikkhitta chandaḥ ti kusala karaṇe
translated: he is not one whose desire is abandoned by the abandonment of the state of not acting continuously.

original: vīriyacchandassa anikkhittabhāvena anikkhittacchando. Anikkhittadhuroti vīriyadhurassa🔽anoropanena anikkhittadhuro, anosakkitamānasoti attho. Yo tattha chando ca vāyāmo
analyzed: vīriya chandassa a nikkhitta bhāvena a nikkhitta chandaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ ti vīriya dhurassa  anoropanena a nikkhitta dhuraḥ anosakkita mānasaḥ ti atthaḥ yaḥ tattha chandaḥ ca vāyāmaḥ
translated: He is one who does not lay aside his zeal in the sense of not laying aside his zeal for energy. He is one who does not lay aside his energy in the sense of not laying aside his energy for the foundations of mindfulness. He is one who does not lay aside his persistence in the sense of not laying aside his persistence for the right endeavours. He is one who does not lay aside his steadfastness in the sense of not laying aside his steadfastness for the bases of spiritual success. He is one who does not lay aside his calm in the sense of not laying aside his calm for the faculties. He is one who does not lay aside his insight in the sense of not laying aside his insight for the powers. He is one who does not lay aside his mindfulness in the sense of not laying aside his mindfulness for the factors of enlightenment. He is one who does not lay aside his concentration in the sense of not laying aside his concentration for the path. He is one who does not lay aside his wisdom in the sense of not laying aside his wisdom for the fruits. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the jhānas. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the immaterial states. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the liberations. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the states of distinction. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the attainment of cessation. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling. He is one who does not lay aside his desire for non-distraction in the sense of not laying aside his desire for the attainment of

original: cāti yo tesu kusaladhammesu kattukamyatādhammacchando ca payattasaṅkhāto vāyāmo ca.🔽Ussahanavasena ussāho ca. Adhimattussahanavasena ussoḷhī ca. Vāyāmo ceso pāraṃ gamanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: ca ati yaḥ tesu kusala dhammesu kattu kamya tā dhamma chando ca payatta saṅkhāto vā āyāmaḥ ca  ussahana vasena ussāhaḥ ca adhimatta ussahana vasena ussoḷhī ca vāyāmaḥ ca iso pāram gamana ṭṭhena
translated: He is “unrelenting in will” because he has not put down his will to energy. “Unrelenting in steadfastness” means that he has not put down his steadfastness in energy. The meaning is that he has not put down his resolution. “The will and the effort” here are the will to undertake and the effort called exertion, in regard to those profitable things.🔽Exertion is the state of going to the further shore.

original: Ussāho ceso pubbaṅgamanaṭṭhena. Ussoḷhī ceso adhimattaṭṭhena. Appaṭivāni cāti anivattanā🔽ca. Sati ca sampajaññanti saratīti sati. Sampajānātīti sampajaññaṃ, samantato pakārehi
analyzed: ussāhaḥ ca iso pubbaṅgamana ṭhena ussoḷhī ca iso adhimatta ṭṭhena ca ati a nivattanā  ca sati ca sampajaññanti sarati iti sati sampajānāti iti sampajaññam samantataḥ pakārehi
translated: Resolution is the state of going in front. Exertion is the state of going to the further shore. Resolution is the state of going in front. Exuberance is the state of excessive going. “Unflagging” means not turning back.

original: jānātīti attho. Sātthakasampajaññaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ gocarasampajaññaṃ asammohasampajaññanti
analyzed: jānāti iti sa atthaka sampajaññam sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam a sammoha sampajaññanti
translated: “Mindfulness and full awareness” : he remembers, thus it is mindfulness . He fully understands, thus it is full awareness . The meaning is that he knows all round. There is mindfulness with a beneficial object, mindfulness with a suitable object, mindfulness with a proper object, and mindfulness with a blameless object.

original: imassa sampajānassa vasena bhedo veditabbo. Ātappanti kilesatāpanavīriyaṃ. Padhānanti
analyzed: imassa sampajānassa vasena bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ ātappanti kilesa tāpana vīriyam padhānan ti
translated: The distinction should be understood according to the right understanding of each of these terms. Exertion is energy in the form of the burning up of defilements.🔽Striving is

original: uttamavīriyaṃ. Adhiṭṭhānanti kusalakaraṇe patiṭṭhābhāvo. Anuyogoti anuyuñjanaṃ. Appamādoti
analyzed: uttama vīriyam adhiṭṭhānam ti kusala karaṇe patiṭṭhā bhāvo anuyogo ti anuyuñjanam appamādaḥ ti
translated: supreme energy. Resolution is the state of being established in doing what is wholesome. Application is the act of applying. Non-complacency is

original: nappamajjanaṃ, satiyā avippavāso.🔽Imaṃ lokaṃ nāsīsatīti mūlapadaṃ. Sakattabhāvanti attano attabhāvaṃ. Parattabhāvanti
analyzed: na appamajjanam satiyāḥ a vippavāsaḥ  imam lokam mūlapadam
translated: non-negligence, the non-abandoning of mindfulness.🔽The root-meaning of “he does not look to this world” is as follows. One’s own being is one’s own five aggregates in this world. Another’s being is

original: paraloke attabhāvaṃ. Sakarūpavedanādayo attano pañcakkhandhe, pararūpavedanādayo
analyzed: para loke atta bhāvam saka rūpa vedanā ādayaḥ pañca kkhandhe para rūpa vedanā ādayaḥ
translated: another’s five aggregates in the other world. One’s own form, feeling, etc., are one’s own five aggregates in this world. Another’s form, feeling, etc., are

original: ca paraloke pañcakkhandhe. Kāmadhātunti kāmabhavaṃ. Rūpadhātunti rūpabhavaṃ. Arūpadhātunti
analyzed: ca para loke pañca kkhandhe kāmadhātum ti kāma bhavam rūpadhātum ti rūpa bhavam a rūpa dhātum ti
translated: another’s five aggregates in the other world. The sense-desire element is sense-desire becoming. The form element is form becoming. The formless element is

original: arūpabhavaṃ. Puna rūpārūpavasena dukaṃ dassetuṃ kāmadhātuṃ rūpadhātuṃ ekaṃ katvā,
analyzed: arūpa bhavam punar rūpa arūpa vasena dukam dassetum kāmadhātum rūpadhātum ekam katvā
translated: formless becoming. The two terms “form” and “formless” are used again to show the dyad. The sense-desire element and the form element are taken together

original: arūpadhātuṃ ekaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Gatiṃ vāti patiṭṭhānavasena pañcagati vuttā. Upapattiṃ
analyzed: arūpa dhātum ekam katvā vuttam gatim vā ti patiṭṭhāna vasena pañca gati vuttā upapattim
translated: as one, and the formless element is taken as the other. The destiny is the five destinies stated in terms of the basis. The rebirth-state is

original: vāti nibbattivasena catuyoni vuttā. Paṭisandhiṃ vāti tiṇṇaṃ bhavānaṃ ghaṭanavasena
analyzed: vā ti nibbatti vasena catu yoni vuttā paṭisandhim vā ti tiṇṇam bhavānam ghaṭana vasena
translated: “In the four kinds of generation” means in the four kinds of generation. “In the four kinds of birth” means in the four kinds of birth. “In the four kinds of wombs” means in the four kinds of wombs. “In the four kinds of destinies” means in the four kinds of destinies.

original: paṭisandhi vuttā. Bhavaṃ vāti kammabhavavasena. Saṃsāraṃ vāti khandhādīnaṃ abbocchinnavasena.
analyzed: paṭisandhi vuttā bhavam vāti kamma bhava vasena saṃsāram vāti khandha ādīnam abbocchinna vasena
translated: “The round of rebirths” is stated as rebirth-linking. “The round of becoming” is stated as kamma-process becoming. “The round of existence” is stated as the uninterrupted continuity of aggregates, etc.

original: Vaṭṭaṃ vāti tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ nāsīsatīti.
analyzed: vaṭṭam vāti tebhūmaka vaṭṭam na āsīsati iti
translated: “The round of births” is stated as the round of the three planes.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Great Commentary on the Niddesa called Saddhammappajjotikā,

original: Guhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: guhaṭṭhaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Guhatthaka Sutta is finished.

original: 3. Duṭṭhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽15. Duṭṭhaṭṭhake paṭhamagāthāyaṃ tāva tattha vadantīti bhagavantaṃ bhikkhusaṅghañca
analyzed: duṭṭhaṭṭhaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā  duṭṭhaṭṭhake paṭhama gāthāyam tāva tattha vadanti iti bhagavantam bhikkhu saṅgham ca
translated: . The commentary on the explanation of the Duṭṭhaṭṭhaka Sutta

original: upavadanti. Duṭṭhamanāpi eke, athopi ve saccamanāti ekacce duṭṭhacittā, ekacce tathasaññinopi
analyzed: upavadanti eke ekacce duṭṭha cittāḥ ekacce tatha saññinaḥ pi
translated: . In the first stanza of the Duṭṭhaṭṭhaka, “they say” means that they revile the Blessed One and the community of bhikkhus. Some are ill-disposed, and some, though they have the same view,

original: hutvā titthiyā tuṭṭhacittā, ye tesaṃ sutvā saddahiṃsu, te saccamanāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: hutvā titthiyā tuṭṭha cittāḥ ye tesam sutvā saddahiṃsu te saccamanā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: are not satisfied. The heretics, having made offerings, are satisfied. Those who, having heard them, believe, they say, is the meaning.

original: Vādañca jātanti etaṃ akkosavādaṃ uppannaṃ. Muni no upetīti akārakatāya ca akuppanatāya
analyzed: vādam ca jātanti etam akkosa vādam uppannam muni no upeti iti akāraka tāya ca a kuppana tāya
translated: “And the talk that has arisen” is the talk of abuse that has arisen. “The sage does not come to us” means that he does not act and he does not become angry.

original: ca buddhamuni na upeti. Tasmā munī natthi khilo kuhiñcīti tena kāraṇena ayaṃ muni,
analyzed: ca buddha muni na upeti tasmā munī na atthi khilo kuhiñci iti tena kāraṇena ayam muni
translated: and the Buddha-Sage does not approach it. Therefore, the Sage has no crookedness anywhere.

original: rāgādikhilehi natthi khilo kuhiñcīti veditabbo.
analyzed: rāga ādi khilehi na atthi khilo kuhiñci iti veditabbo
translated: Thus it should be understood that he has no crookedness anywhere by way of the crookedness of lust, etc.

original: Duṭṭhamanāti uppannehi dosehi dūsitacittā. Viruddhamanāti tehi kilesehi kusalassa
analyzed: duṭṭha manāti uppannehi dosehi dūsita cittā viruddha manāti tehi kilesehi kusalassa
translated: “Corrupted in mind” means corrupted in mind by the arisen defilements. “Contradicted in mind” means obstructed in mind by those defilements,

original: dvāraṃ adatvā āvaritacittā. Paṭiviruddhamanāti upasaggavasena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ. Āhatamanāti🔽paṭighena āhataṃ cittaṃ etesanti āhatamanā. Paccāhatamanāti upasaggavaseneva. Āghātitamanāti
analyzed: dvāram a datvā āvarita cittā paṭiviruddha manāti upasagga vasena padam vaḍḍhitam āhata manāti  paṭighena āhatam cittam etesan ti āhata manā paccāhata manā ati upasagga vasena iva āghātita manā ati
translated: not giving a chance to the wholesome. “Contradicted” is the word extended by prefix. “Afflicted in mind” means🔽those whose minds are afflicted by resistance. “Counter-afflicted” is the word extended by prefix.

original: vihiṃsāvasena āghātitaṃ manaṃ etesanti āghātitamanā. Paccāghātitamanāti upasaggavaseneva.
analyzed: vihiṃsā vasena āghātitam manam etesanti āghātita manā paccāghātita manā ti upasagga vasena iva
translated: “Oppressed in mind” means those whose minds are oppressed by violence. “Counter-oppressed” is the word extended by prefix.

original: Atha vā “kodhavasena duṭṭhamanā, upanāhavasena paduṭṭhamanā, makkhavasena viruddhamanā,
analyzed: atha vā kodha vasena duṭṭha manāḥ upanāha vasena paduṭṭha manāḥ makkha vasena viruddha manāḥ
translated: Or else, “corrupted in mind” is by way of anger, “contradicted in mind” is by way of enmity, “contradicted in mind” is by way of contempt,

original: paḷāsavasena paṭiviruddhamanā, dosavasena āhatapaccāhatamanā, byāpādavasena āghātitapaccāghātitamanā.
analyzed: paḷāsa vasena paṭiviruddha manāḥ dosa vasena āhata paccāhata manāḥ byāpāda vasena āghātita paccāghātita manāḥ
translated: “counter-contradicted in mind” is by way of domineering, “afflicted in mind and counter-afflicted in mind” is by way of hate, “oppressed in mind and counter-oppressed in mind” is by way of ill will.

original: Paccayānaṃ alābhena duṭṭhamanā paduṭṭhamanā, ayasena viruddhamanā paṭiviruddhamanā,🔽garahena āhatapaccāhatamanā, dukkhavedanāsamaṅgībhāvena āghātitapaccāghātitamanā”ti🔽evamādinā nayena eke vaṇṇayanti. Upavadantīti garahaṃ uppādenti. Abhūtenāti asaṃvijjamānena.🔽Saddahantāti pasādavasena saddhaṃ uppādentā. Okappentāti guṇavasena otaritvā avakappayantā.
analyzed: paccayānam alābhena duṭṭha manā paduṭṭha manā ayasena viruddha manā paṭiviruddha manā  garahena āhata paccāhata manāḥ dukkha vedanā samaṅgībhāvena āghātita paccāghātita manā ati  evamādinā nayena eke vaṇṇayanti upavadanti iti garaham uppādenti abhūtena ati asaṃvijjamānena  saddahantā ati pasāda vasena saddham uppādentā okappentā ati guṇa vasena otaritvā avakappayantā
translated: Some explain the words thus: “With the non-acquisition of conditions, with a mind that is ill-disposed, with a mind that is very ill-disposed, with a mind that is opposed, with a mind that is very opposed,🔽with a mind that is struck and counter-struck by blame, with a mind that is struck and counter-struck by painful feeling.”🔽In this way they explain the words. They revile: they give rise to blame. With what is untrue: with what is non-existent.🔽They believe: they give rise to faith by way of confidence. They accept: they accept after descending and entering into the qualities.

original: Adhimuccantāti sampasādanavasena sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā tesaṃ kathaṃ adhivāsentā. Saccamanāti🔽tacchamanā. Saccasaññinoti tacchasaññino. Tathamanāti aviparītamanā. Bhūtamanāti🔽bhūtatthamanā. Yāthāvamanāti niccalamanā. Aviparītamanāti nicchayamanā. Tattha “saccamanā
analyzed: adhimuccantā iti sampasādana vasena sanniṭṭhānam katvā tesam katham adhivāsentā saccamanā ti 🔽tacchamanā sacca saññino ti aviparīta manāḥ bhūta manā ati 🔽bhūtatthamanāḥ yāthāvamanāḥ ati niccalamanāḥ aviparītamanāḥ ati nicchaya manāḥ tattha sacca manāḥ

original: saccasaññino”ti saccavādiguṇaṃ, “tathamanā tathasaññino”ti saccasaddhāguṇaṃ, “bhūtamanā🔽bhūtasaññino”ti ṭhitaguṇaṃ, “yāthāvamanā yāthāvasaññino”ti paccayikaguṇaṃ, “aviparītamanā
analyzed: sacca saññino ti sacca vādi guṇam tatha manāḥ sacca saddhā guṇam bhūta manāḥ  bhūta saññino ti ṭhita guṇam yāthāva manāḥ yāthāva saññino ti paccayika guṇam aviparīta manāḥ
translated: the quality of being truthful, “With a mind that is so and a perception that is so” is the quality of faith in truth, “With a mind that is real and a perception that is real” is the quality of stability, “With a mind that is as it really is and a perception that is as it really is” is the quality of being dependent, “With a mind that is not upside-down and a perception that is not upside-down” is the quality of being unperverted,

original: aviparītasaññino”ti avisaṃvādaguṇaṃ kathitanti ñātabbaṃ.
analyzed: aviparīta saññino ti avisaṃvāda guṇam kathitan ti ñātabbam
translated: “They have right view” is the quality of being one who speaks what is so; “They have right thought and right view” is the quality of faith in the true idea; “They have right thought and right view” is the quality of being established; “They have right thought and right view” is the quality of being one who has the conditions ; “They have right thought and right view” is the quality of being one who is not deceived.

original: Paratoghosoti aññesaṃ santikā uppannasaddo. Akkosoti jātiādīsu dasasu akkosesu aññataro.🔽Yo vādaṃ upetīti yo puggalo upavādaṃ upagacchati. Kārako vāti katadoso vā. Kārakatāyāti
analyzed: paratoghoso ti aññesam santike uppanna saddaḥ akkoso ti jāti ādīsu dasasu akkosesu aññataro  yaḥ vādam upeti iti yaḥ puggalaḥ upavādam upagacchati kārakaḥ vā ati kata dosaḥ vā kāraka tāya ati
translated: “Another’s voice” is the sound that arises from others. “Blame” is one of the ten kinds of blame beginning with “birth.”

original: dosassa katabhāvena vuccamānoti kathiyamāno. Upavadiyamānoti dosaṃ upavajjamāno.
analyzed: dosassa kata bhāvena vuccamānaḥ iti kathiyamānaḥ upavadiyamānaḥ iti dosam upavajjamānaḥ
translated: “One who takes up a case” is a person who takes up a charge. “One who is to blame” is one who has done wrong. “Because of his being to blame” is because of the fact that he is blamed. “When he is being blamed” is when he is being told. “When he is being charged” is when he is being charged with a fault.

original: Kuppatīti kopaṃ karoti.🔽Khīlajātatāpi natthīti cittabandhabhāvacittakacavarabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ paṭighakhilaṃ
analyzed: kuppati iti kopam karoti  khīla jāta tā api na atthi iti citta bandha bhāva citta kaca vara bhāva saṅkhātam paṭigha khilam
translated: “He is angry” is he makes anger.🔽“There is no trace of resentment” : there is no trace of resentment called “bondage of the mind” or “hardness of the mind.”

original: jātaṃ assāti khilajāto, tassa bhāvo khilajātatā, tāpi natthi na santi. Pañcapi cetokhilāti
analyzed: jātam assa ati khila jātaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ khila jāta tā tā api natthi na santi pañca api cetas khilā ati
translated: “Resentment” is what has arisen as a trace. “There is no trace of resentment” : there is no resentment, there is no trace of resentment. “The five mental obstructions” :

original: kāme avītarāgo, kāye avītarāgo, rūpe avītarāgo, yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: kāme a vīta rāgaḥ kāye a vīta rāgaḥ rūpe a vīta rāgaḥ yāvadattham udara avadehakam bhuñjitvā
translated: Not being free from lust for sensual desires, not being free from lust for the body, not being free from lust for forms, eating as much as he likes until his belly is full,

original: seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati, aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya
analyzed: seyya sukham passa sukham middha sukham anuyuttaḥ viharati aññataram devanikāyam paṇidhāya
translated: he lives devoted to the pleasure of lying down, the pleasure of sloth, the pleasure of sleep, and he lives devoted to this or that order of gods,

original: brahmacariyaṃ carati “imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo
analyzed: brahmacariyam carati iminā aham sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā
translated: practicing the holy life for the sake of being born there, thinking, “By this virtue or observance or asceticism or holy life I will become

original: vā bhavissāmi, devaññataro vā”ti evarūpā pañcapi cittassa bandhabhāvakacavarabhāvasaṅkhātā cetokhilā natthi.🔽16. Imañca gāthaṃ vatvā bhagavā ānandattheraṃ pucchi – “evaṃ khuṃsetvā vambhetvā🔽vuccamānā bhikkhū, ānanda, kiṃ vadantī”ti, “na kiñci bhagavā”ti. “Na, ānanda, ‘ahaṃ
analyzed: vā bhavissāmi devaññataraḥ vā ati evarūpā pañca api cittassa bandha bhāva kacavara bhāva saṅkhātā cetas khilā natthi  iman ca gātham vatvā bhagavā ānandattheram pucchi evam khuṃsetvā vambhetvā  vuccamānāḥ bhikkhū ānanda kim vadanti iti na kiñci bhagavā ati na ānanda aham
translated: a great god or some lesser god.” Such are the five kinds of mental obstructions, called “thorns,” that do not exist for him.

original: sīlavā’ti sabbattha tuṇhī bhavitabbaṃ. Loke hi nābhāsamānaṃ jānanti, missaṃ bālehi
analyzed: sīlavāti sabbattha tuṇhī bhavitabbam loke hi na ābhāsamānam jānanti missam bālehi
translated: After saying this, the Blessed One asked the Venerable Ananda, “When the bhikkhus are thus reproved and rebuked by me, Ananda, what do they say?” “They say nothing, Blessed One.” “Ananda, when one is virtuous, one should not remain silent everywhere. For in the world they do not recognize one who does not make himself known; the fool is mixed up with the wise

original: paṇḍita”nti vatvā “bhikkhū, ānanda, te manusse evaṃ paṭicodentū”ti dhammadesanatthāya
analyzed: paṇḍita nti vatvā bhikkhū ānanda te manusse evam paṭicodentu uti dhamma desana tthāya
translated: one.” After saying this, he said, “Ananda, the bhikkhus should reprove those people thus.”

original: “abhūtavādī nirayaṃ upetī”ti imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi. Thero taṃ uggahetvā bhikkhū āha
analyzed: abhūta vādī nirayam upeti iti imam gātham abhāsi thero tam uggahetvā bhikkhū āha
translated: “He who speaks falsely goes to hell” . The Elder learned it and said to the monks,

original: – “manussā tumhehi imāya gāthāya paṭicodetabbā”ti. Bhikkhū tathā akaṃsu. Paṇḍitamanussā
analyzed: manussā tumhehi imāya gāthāya paṭicodetabbā ati bhikkhū tathā akaṃsu paṇḍita manussā
translated: “You should accuse them with this verse.” The monks did so. The wise people

original: tuṇhī ahesuṃ. Rājāpi rājapurise sabbattha pesetvā yesaṃ dhuttānaṃ lañjaṃ datvā titthiyā
analyzed: tuṇhī ahesum rājā api rāja purise sabbattha pesetvā yesam dhuttānam lañjam da tvā titthiyā
translated: kept silent. The king also sent royal messengers everywhere. Those rogues who had been bribed by the sectarians

original: taṃ mārāpesuṃ, te gahetvā niggayha taṃ pavattiṃ ñatvā titthiye paribhāsi. Manussāpi
analyzed: tam mārāpesum te gahetvā niggayha tam pavattim ñatvā titthiye paribhāsi manussā api
translated: to kill the monk were arrested, and after they had been interrogated and the facts were known, the sectarians were rebuked. When people saw the sectarians,

original: titthiye disvā leḍḍunā hananti, paṃsunā okiranti “bhagavato ayasaṃ uppādesu”nti.
analyzed: titthiye disvā leḍḍunā hananti paṃsunā okiranti bhagavataḥ ayasam uppādesunti
translated: they beat them with sticks and threw dust on them, saying, “You have caused the Blessed One’s disrepute.”

original: Ānandatthero taṃ disvā bhagavato ārocesi, bhagavā therassa imaṃ gāthamabhāsi “sakañhi
analyzed: ānanda ttheraḥ tam disvā bhagavataḥ ārocesi bhagavā therassa imam gātham abhāsi sakan hi
translated: When the Elder Ānanda saw this, he reported it to the Blessed One, and the Blessed One spoke this verse to the Elder:🔽“One should speak only what is true and beneficial,

original: diṭṭhiṃ…pe… vadeyyā”ti.
analyzed: diṭṭhiṃpe vadeyyā ti
translated: and not what is false and harmful, even if it is beneficial.”

original: Tassa attho – yāyaṃ diṭṭhi titthiyajanassa “sundariṃ māretvā samaṇānaṃ sakyaputtiyānaṃ
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yā ayam diṭṭhi titthiya janassa sundarim māretvā samaṇānam sakya puttiyānam
translated: The meaning is this: “One should not speak what is false and harmful, even if it is beneficial, like the view of the sectarians that ‘Sundarī was killed by the ascetics, the sons of the Sakyans,🔽and that the ascetics, the sons of the Sakyans, are of black complexion, ugly, and repulsive.’

original: avaṇṇaṃ pakāsetvā etenupāyena laddhaṃ sakkāraṃ sādiyissāmā”ti so taṃ diṭṭhiṃ kathaṃ🔽atikkameyya? Atha kho so ayaso tameva titthiyajanaṃ paccāgato taṃ diṭṭhiṃ accetuṃ
analyzed: avaṇṇam pakāsetvā etena upāyena laddham sakkāram sādiyissāma ati saḥ tam diṭṭhim katham  atikkameyya atha kho saḥ ayasaḥ tam eva titthiya janam paccāgataḥ tam diṭṭhim accetum
translated: How could he get out of that view?🔽But that one who is without gain has come back to that very sect of sectarians,🔽and is unable to give up that view.

original: asakkontaṃ. Yo vā sassatādivādī, sopi sakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ kathamaccayeyya, tena diṭṭhichandena
analyzed: a sakkontam yaḥ vā sassata ādi vādī saḥ api sakam diṭṭhim katham accayeyya tena diṭṭhi chandena
translated: Or else, one who holds the view of eternalism, etc., how could he get out of his view?

original: anunīto tāya ca diṭṭhiruciyā niviṭṭho, api ca kho pana sayaṃ samattāni pakubbamāno
analyzed: anunītaḥ tāya ca diṭṭhi ruciyā niviṭṭhaḥ api ca kho pana sayam samattāni pakubbamānaḥ
translated: He is led on by the will to views, and he is fixed in the liking for views.🔽But he might himself be performing the rites of asceticism,

original: attanāva paripuṇṇāni tāni diṭṭhigatāni karonto yathā jāneyya, tatheva vadeyyāti.
analyzed: paripuṇṇāni tāni diṭṭhi gatāni karontaḥ yathā jāneyya tathā iva vadeyya ati
translated: and he might be making those views complete by himself, and he would know it, and he would say it.🔽Having so done: having made the bad qualities manifest.

original: Avaṇṇaṃ pakāsayitvāti aguṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā. Sakkāranti catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ sakkaccakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: avaṇṇam pakāsayitvā ati aguṇam pākaṭam katvā catunnam paccayānam sakkacca karaṇam
translated: Gains: the proper performance of the four requisites.🔽Respect: the high esteem of the mind.🔽We will get it back: we will bring about this gain, etc.

original: Sammānanti cittena bahumānanaṃ. Paccāharissāmāti etaṃ lābhādiṃ nibbattessāma. Evaṃdiṭṭhikāti
analyzed: sammānanti cittena bahu mānanam paccāharissāma ati etam lābha ādim nibbattessāma evaṃdiṭṭhikā ti
translated: One who has such a view:🔽one who has such a gain.

original: evaṃladdhikā. Yathā taṃ “lābhādiṃ nibbattessāmā”ti evaṃ ayaṃ laddhi tesaṃ atthi,
analyzed: evaṃladdhikāḥ yathā tam lābha ādim nibbattessāma ati evam ayam laddhi tesam atthi
translated: As to how he would bring about the gain, etc., he has that gain,

original: tathā “atthi me vuttappakāro dhammo”ti etesaṃ khamati ceva ruccati ca, evaṃsabhāvameva
analyzed: tathā atthi me vutta ppakāraḥ dhammaḥ ti etesam khamati ca iva ruccati ca evam sabhāvam eva
translated: “I have such a doctrine” is the same.🔽Or their consciousness is of such a nature that they think, “I have consciousness.”

original: vā tesaṃ cittaṃ “atthi me citta”nti. Tadā tesaṃ diṭṭhi vā, diṭṭhiyā saha khanti vā,🔽diṭṭhikhantīhi saddhiṃ ruci vā, diṭṭhikhantirucīhi saddhiṃ laddhi vā, diṭṭhikhantiruciladdhīhi
analyzed: vā tesam cittam atthi me cittanti tadā tesam diṭṭhi vā diṭṭhiyā saha khanti vā  diṭṭhi khantīhi saddhim ruci vā diṭṭhi khanti rucīhi saddhim laddhi vā diṭṭhi khanti ruci laddhīhi
translated: Then their view, or their acquiescence together with the view,🔽or their approval together with the acquiescence and the view,🔽or their opinion together with the approval, the acquiescence, and the view,

original: saddhiṃ ajjhāsayo vā, diṭṭhikhantiruciladdhiajjhāsayehi saddhiṃ adhippāyo vā hotīti
analyzed: saddhim ajjhāsayaḥ vā diṭṭhi khanti ruci laddhi ajjhāsayehi saddhim adhippāyaḥ vā hoti iti
translated: or their inclination together with the opinion, the acquiescence, the approval, and the view, or their underlying tendency together with the inclination, the acquiescence, the approval, the opinion, and the view, or their proclivity together with the underlying tendency, the acquiescence, the approval, the opinion, and the inclination, is a view.🔽Showing this, he said, “They have such a view … such a proclivity.”

original: dassento “evaṃdiṭṭhikā…pe… evaṃadhippāyā”ti āha. Sakaṃ diṭṭhinti attano dassanaṃ.🔽Sakaṃ khantinti attano sahanaṃ. Sakaṃ rucinti attano ruciṃ. Sakaṃ laddhinti attano
analyzed: dassentaḥ evaṃdiṭṭhika āpe evam adhippāyā ti āha sakam diṭṭhim ti attanaḥ dassanam  sakam khantinti attanaḥ sahanam sakam rucinti attanaḥ rucim sakam laddhinti attanaḥ
translated: “Their own view”: their own seeing.🔽“Their own acquiescence”: their own acquiescing. “Their own approval”: their own approving. “Their own opinion”: their own opinion.

original: laddhiṃ. Sakaṃ ajjhāsayanti attano ajjhāsayaṃ. Sakaṃ adhippāyanti attano bhāvaṃ.🔽Atikkamitunti samatikkamituṃ. Atha kho sveva ayasoti so eva ayaso ekaṃsena. Te paccāgatoti
analyzed: laddhim sakam ajjhāsayanti attanaḥ ajjhāsayam sakam adhippāyanti attanaḥ bhāvam 🔽atikkamitum ti samatikkamitum atha kho su eva ayasaḥ iti saḥ eva ayasaḥ ekaṃsena te paccāgataḥ iti
translated: “Their own inclination”: their own inclination. “Their own proclivity”: their own proclivity.🔽“To surpass”: to surpass. “Then that very dishonor”: that very dishonor, certainly. “They have come back”:

original: tesaṃ patiāgato. Teti sāmiatthe upayogavacanaṃ.🔽Atha vāti atthantaradassanaṃ. Sassatoti nicco dhuvo. Lokoti attabhāvo. Idameva saccaṃ,
analyzed: tesam sāmi atthe upayoga vacanam  atha vā ati atthantara dassanam niccaḥ dhuvaḥ loko ti atta bhāvaḥ idam eva saccam
translated: ‘Their opponent’ : the word ‘their’ is used in the sense of ‘his’.🔽‘Or else’ : the showing of another meaning. ‘Eternal’ : permanent, lasting. ‘World’ : individual essence. ‘This alone is the truth’ : this alone is true, real,

original: moghamaññanti idaṃ eva tacchaṃ tathaṃ, aññaṃ tucchaṃ. Samattāti sampuṇṇā. Samādinnāti
analyzed: mogham aññanti idam eva taccham tatham aññam tuccham samattā ati sampuṇṇā samādinnā ati
translated: but the other is void. ‘Complete’ : fulfilled. ‘Grasped at’ :

original: sammā ādinnā. Gahitāti upagantvā gahitā.
analyzed: sammā ādinnā gahitā ati upagantvā gahitā
translated: taken up. ‘Clung to’ : taken up after approaching.

original: Parāmaṭṭhāti sabbākārena parāmasitvā gahitā. Abhiniviṭṭhāti visesena laddhappatiṭṭhā. Asassatoti vuttavipariyāyena veditabbo.
analyzed: parāmaṭṭhā ati sabba ākārena parāmasitvā gahitā abhiniviṭṭhā ati visesena laddha patiṭṭhā asassataḥ ti vutta vipariyāyena veditabbaḥ
translated: ‘Substantially maintained’ : taken up after substantiating in every way. ‘Invested in’ : established in a special way. ‘Not eternal’ : to be understood in the opposite sense to the above.

original: Antavāti saanto. Anantavāti vuddhianantavā. Taṃ jīvanti so jīvo, liṅgavipallāso kato.
analyzed: antavā ati sa antaḥ anantavā ati vuddhi anantavā tam jīvanti saḥ jīvaḥ liṅga vipallāso kataḥ
translated: ‘Finite’ : limited. ‘Infinite’ : having growth without end. ‘That living being’ : that living being. The change of gender is intentional.

original: Jīvoti ca attāyeva. Tathāgatoti satto, “araha”nti eke. Paraṃ maraṇāti maraṇato uddhaṃ,
analyzed: jīvaḥ iti ca attāya iva tathāgato ti satto arahanti eke param maraṇā ati maraṇataḥ uddham
translated: ‘Living being’ : the self itself. ‘Tathāgata’ : a being. ‘The Worthy One’ : some say. ‘After death’ : after death,

original: paraloketi attho. Na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti maraṇato uddhaṃ na hoti. Hoti
analyzed: para loka iti atthaḥ na hoti tathāgato param maraṇā ati maraṇataḥ uddham na hoti hoti
translated: the meaning is ‘in the next world’. ‘The Tathāgata does not exist after death’ : after death he does not exist.

original: ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti maraṇato uddhaṃ hoti ca na hoti ca. Neva hoti
analyzed: ca na ca hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇāti maraṇataḥ uddham hoti ca na hoti ca na iva hoti
translated: “After death, a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist” means that after death, a Tathāgata both exists and does not exist.

original: na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti ucchedavasena neva hoti, takkikavasena na na hoti.
analyzed: na na hoti tathāgataḥ param uccheda vasena na iva hoti takkika vasena na na hoti
translated: and after death a Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist’ is the annihilationist view. ‘A Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death’ is the view of the materialists, not the view of the annihilationists.

original: Sakāya diṭṭhiyātiādayo karaṇavacanaṃ. Allīnoti ekībhūto.
analyzed: karaṇa vacanam ekībhūtaḥ
translated: ‘By his own insight’ and so on is the instrumental case. ‘Enters’ is the same as ‘becomes one’.

original: Sayaṃ samattaṃ karotīti attanā ūnabhāvaṃ mocetvā sammā attaṃ samattaṃ karoti. Paripuṇṇanti🔽atirekadosaṃ mocetvā sampuṇṇaṃ. Anomanti hīnadosaṃ mocetvā alāmakaṃ. Agganti ādiṃ.🔽Seṭṭhanti padhānaṃ niddosaṃ. Visesanti jeṭṭhakaṃ. Pāmokkhanti adhikaṃ. Uttamanti🔽visesaṃ na heṭṭhimaṃ. Pavaraṃ karotīti atirekena uttamaṃ karoti. Atha vā “āsayadosamocanena
analyzed: sayam samattam karoti iti attanā ūna bhāvam mocetvā sammā attam samattam karoti paripuṇṇanti  atireka dosam mocetvā sampuṇṇam anomanti hīna dosam mocetvā alāmakam agganti ādim  seṭṭhanti padhānam niddosam visesanti jeṭṭhakam pāmokkhanti adhikam uttamanti  visesam na heṭṭhimam pavaram karoti iti atirekena uttamam karoti atha vā āsaya dosa mocanena
translated: ‘Makes himself complete’ is the same as ‘makes himself perfect by freeing himself from deficiency’. ‘Perfect’ is the same as ‘complete’ by freeing himself from excess. ‘Faultless’ is the same as ‘flawless’ by freeing himself from deficiency. ‘Beginning’ is the same as ‘first’.

original: aggaṃ, saṃkilesadosamocanena seṭṭhaṃ, upakkilesadosamocanena visesaṃ, pamattadosamocanena
analyzed: aggam saṃkilesa dosa mocanena seṭṭham upakkilesa dosa mocanena visesam pamatta dosa mocanena
translated: ‘Foremost’ is the same as ‘best’ by freeing himself from faults. ‘Excellent’ is the same as ‘superior’. ‘Supreme’ is the same as ‘best’ by freeing himself from what is inferior. ‘Matchless’ is the same as ‘supreme’ by freeing himself from what is superior. ‘Peerless’ is the same as ‘matchless’ by freeing himself from what is equal. ‘Solitary’ is the same as ‘peerless’ by freeing himself from what is similar. ‘Unique’ is the same as ‘solitary’ by freeing himself from what is dissimilar. ‘He makes himself the highest’ is the same as ‘he makes himself the best’ by freeing himself from what is not the highest. Or alternatively, by freeing himself from the fault of the basis he makes himself the highest; by freeing himself from the fault of defilement he makes himself the best; by freeing himself from the fault of the subsidiary defilements he makes himself excellent; by freeing himself from the fault of negligence he makes himself superior; by freeing himself from the fault of what is inferior he makes himself unsurpassed; by freeing himself from the fault of what is equal he makes himself matchless; by freeing himself from the fault of what is dissimilar he makes himself peerless; by freeing himself from the fault of what is similar he makes himself solitary; by freeing himself from the fault of what is superior he makes himself unique.

original: pāmokkhaṃ, majjhimadosamocanena uttamaṃ, uttamamajjhimadosamocanena pavaraṃ karotī”ti
analyzed: pāmokkham majjhima dosa mocanena uttamam uttama majjhima dosa mocanena pavaram karoti iti
translated: the best by the medium-grade deliverance from the worst, and the most excellent by the best-grade deliverance from the medium-grade.🔽Thus some explain it.

original: evameke vaṇṇayanti. Ayaṃ satthā sabbaññūti ayaṃ amhākaṃ satthā sabbajānanavasena
analyzed: evam eke vaṇṇayanti ayam satthā sabbaññū ti ayam amhākam satthā sabba jānana vasena
translated: This Teacher is omniscient: this Teacher of ours is omniscient in the sense of knowing all things.🔽This Dhamma is well proclaimed: this Dhamma of ours is well proclaimed in the sense of being well penetrated.

original: sabbaññū. Ayaṃ dhammo svākkhātoti ayaṃ amhākaṃ dhammo suṭṭhu akkhāto. Ayaṃ gaṇo suppaṭipannoti
analyzed: sabbaññū ayam dhammo su ākkhāto ti ayam amhākam dhammo suṭṭhu akkhāto ayam gaṇo suppaṭipanno ti
translated: This Community is practising well: this Community of ours is practising well in the sense of practising in the way it is taught.🔽This view is good: this view of ours is good in the sense of being beautiful.🔽This way is well laid out: this way of ours is well laid out in the sense of being well laid out for the beginning.

original: ayaṃ amhākaṃ gaṇo suṭṭhu paṭipanno. Ayaṃ diṭṭhi bhaddikāti ayaṃ amhākaṃ laddhi sundarā.🔽Ayaṃ paṭipadā supaññattāti ayaṃ amhākaṃ pubbabhāgā attanta pādipaṭipadā suṭṭhu paññattā.🔽Ayaṃ maggo niyyānikoti ayaṃ amhākaṃ niyyāmokkantiko maggo niyyānikoti sayaṃ samattaṃ karoti.
analyzed: ayam amhākam gaṇaḥ suṭṭhu paṭipannaḥ ayam bhaddikā ati ayam amhākam laddhi sundarā  ayam paṭipadā su paññattā ati ayam amhākam pubbabhāgā attanta pādi paṭipadā suṭṭhu paññattā  ayam maggaḥ niyyāniko ti ayam amhākam niyyāma ukkantikaḥ maggaḥ niyyānikaḥ ti sayam samattam karoti
translated: This path is leading out: this path of ours is leading out in the sense of leading out to the escape.

original: Katheyya “sassato loko”ti. Bhaṇeyya “idameva saccaṃ moghamañña”nti. Dīpeyya “antavā loko”ti. Vohareyya nānāvidhena gaṇhāpeyya “hoti ca na ca hotī”ti.
analyzed: katheyya sassataḥ loko ti bhaṇeyya idam eva saccam mogham aññanti dīpeyya antavā loko ti vohareyya nānāvidhena gaṇhāpeyya hoti ca na ca hoti iti
translated: He would say, ‘The world is eternal’: he would say, ‘This alone is the truth, other ideas are silly.’ He would say, ‘The world is finite’: he would say, ‘The world is infinite’: he would say, ‘The soul and the body are the same’: he would say, ‘The soul is one thing and the body another’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata exists after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The world is eternal’: he would say, ‘The world is not eternal’: he would say, ‘The world is finite’: he would say, ‘The world is infinite’: he would say, ‘The soul and the body are the same’: he would say, ‘The soul is one thing and the body another’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata exists after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death’: he would say, ‘The world is eternal’: he would say, ‘The world is not eternal’: he would say, ‘The world is finite’: he would say, ‘The world is infinite’: he would say, ‘The soul and the body are the same’: he would say, ‘The

original: 17. Atha rājā sattāhaccayena taṃ kuṇapaṃ chaḍḍāpetvā sāyanhasamayaṃ vihāraṃ gantvā
analyzed: atha rājā sattāhaccayena tam kuṇapam chaḍḍāpetvā sāyanha samayam vihāram gantvā
translated: Then, after seven days, the king had the corpse thrown out and went to the monastery in the evening.

original: bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā āha – “nanu, bhante, īdise ayase uppanne mayhampi ārocetabbaṃ
analyzed: bhagavantam abhivādetvā āha  nanu bhante īdise ayase uppanne mayham pi ārocetabbam
translated: He paid homage to the Blessed One and said, “Venerable sir, when such a thing happens, should I not be informed?

original: siyā”ti? Evaṃ vutte bhagavā “na, mahārāja, ‘ahaṃ sīlavā guṇasampanno’ti paresaṃ ārocetuṃ
analyzed: siyā iti evam vutte bhagavā na mahā rāja aham sīlavā guṇa sampannaḥ iti paresam ārocetum
translated: ” When this was said, the Blessed One replied, “Great king, it is not proper for Noble Ones to inform others that ‘I am virtuous, I am accomplished in good qualities.’ ”

original: ariyānaṃ paṭirūpa”nti vatvā tassā aṭṭhuppattiyā “yo attano sīlavatānīti avasesagāthāyo abhāsi.
analyzed: ariyānam paṭirūpam ti vatvā tassā aṭṭhuppattiyā yaḥ attano sīlava tāni iti avasesa gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: So saying, he expounded the origin of the story in the verses beginning with “He who praises himself as virtuous” .

original: Tattha sīlavatānīti pātimokkhādīni sīlāni, āraññikādīni dhutaṅgavatāni ca. Anānupuṭṭhoti🔽apucchito. Pāvāti vadati. Anariyadhammaṃ kusalā tamāhu, yo ātumānaṃ sayameva pāvāti
analyzed: tattha sīlavatāni iti pātimokkha ādīni sīlāni āraññika ādīni dhutaṅgavatāni ca  a pucchitaḥ pāvā ti vadati anariya dhammam kusalā tam āhu yaḥ ātumānam sayam eva pāvā ati
translated: Herein, as virtuous means as possessing the virtue of the Pātimokkha and the virtue of the undertaking of the ascetic practices such as living in the forest, and so on. Unasked means🔽unrequested. He speaks thus: “He who praises himself as virtuous, unasked, is a braggart.”🔽The wise declare that this is not the Dhamma of Noble Ones.

original: yo evaṃ attānaṃ sayameva vadati, tassa taṃ vādaṃ “anariyadhammo eso”ti kusalā evaṃ kathenti.
analyzed: yaḥ evam attānam sayam eva vadati tassa tam vādam anariya dhammo esa oti kusalāḥ evam kathenti
translated: He who speaks thus of himself, the wise declare that “This is not the Dhamma of Noble Ones.”

original: Atthi sīlañceva vatañcāti sīlanaṭṭhena sīlañceva atthi, samādānaṭṭhena vatañca atthi,
analyzed: atthi sīlam ca iva vatañca ati sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam ca iva atthi samādāna ṭṭhena vatañca atthi
translated: There is virtue and also austerity: there is virtue in the sense of the virtuousness of virtue, and there is austerity in the sense of the undertaking of it.

original: vataṃ na sīlanti vuttatthena vataṃ atthi, taṃ na sīlaṃ. Katamanti kathetukamyatāpucchā.
analyzed: vatam na sīlanti vuttatthena vatam atthi tam na sīlam katamanti kathetu kamya tā pucchā
translated: Austerity is not virtue: there is austerity in the sense stated, but it is not virtue. What? is a question asking for an explanation of what is already known.

original: Idha bhikkhu sīlavātiādayo vuttanayā eva. Saṃvaraṭṭhenāti saṃvaraṇaṭṭhena, vītikkamadvāraṃ🔽pidahanaṭṭhena. Samādānaṭṭhenāti taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ sammā ādānaṭṭhena. Āraññikaṅganti
analyzed: idha bhikkhu sīlavāti ādayo vutta nayāḥ eva saṃvara ṭṭhena ati saṃvaraṇa ṭṭhena vītikkama dvāram  pidahana ṭhena samādāna ṭṭhena ati tam tam sikkhāpadam sammā ādāna ṭṭhena āraññikaṅgam ti
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu is virtuous is as already stated. In the sense of restraint: in the sense of restraining, in the sense of closing the door of the openings for the transgression of training precepts.

original: araññe nivāso sīlaṃ assāti āraññiko, tassa aṅgaṃ āraññikaṅgaṃ. Piṇḍapātikaṅganti
analyzed: araññe nivāsaḥ sīlam assa ati āraññiko tassa aṅgam āraññika aṅgam piṇḍapātika aṅgam ti
translated: In the sense of undertaking: in the sense of properly taking up this or that training precept. The forest-dweller’s practice: one who dwells in the forest is a forest-dweller . Its practice is the forest-dweller’s practice. The alms-food-eater’s practice:

original: bhikkhāsaṅkhātānaṃ paraāmisapiṇḍānaṃ pāto piṇḍapāto, parehi dinnānaṃ piṇḍānaṃ patte🔽nipatananti vuttaṃ hoti. Taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ uñchati taṃ taṃ kulaṃ upasaṅkamanto gavesatīti
analyzed: bhikkhā saṅkhātānam para āmisa piṇḍānam pāto piṇḍapāto parehi dinnānam piṇḍānam patte  nipatananti vuttam hoti tam piṇḍapātam uñchati tam tam kulam upasaṅkamantaḥ gavesati iti
translated: the alms-food is the collection of requisites consisting of the requisites of robes, alms food, resting place, and medicine, which are the requisites of a bhikkhu. The alms-food is the morning meal. What is given by others is what is meant. The alms-food falls into the bowl,🔽is what is meant. He seeks, he searches, by going to this or that family, for that alms-food.

original: piṇḍapātiko, piṇḍāya vā patituṃ vatametassāti piṇḍapātī. Patitunti carituṃ. Piṇḍapātī
analyzed: piṇḍapātikaḥ piṇḍāya vā patitum vatam etassa ati piṇḍapātī patitum ti caritum piṇḍapātī
translated: Therefore he is an alms-food-eater . Or alternatively, it falls to be his portion, thus it is alms-food . Patituṃ is to wander for. An alms-food-eater is one who wanders for alms-food.

original: eva piṇḍapātiko, tassa aṅgaṃ piṇḍapātikaṅgaṃ. Aṅganti kāraṇaṃ vuccati. Tasmā yena
analyzed: eva piṇḍapātikaḥ tassa aṅgam piṇḍapātika aṅgam aṅgam ti kāraṇam vuccati tasmai yena
translated: He is a “one-bowl-user.” The “one-bowl” is his bowl. The “using” is his using of the bowl. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of him. The “one-bowl-user” is he who has the one-bowl-using. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using” is the one-bowl-using of the one-bowl-user. The “one-bowl-using

original: samādānena so piṇḍapātiko hoti, tassetaṃ adhivacananti veditabbaṃ. Eteneva nayena
analyzed: samādānena saḥ piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti tassa itam adhivacanan ti veditabbam etena iva nayena
translated: The ascetic practice of the alms-food-eater is the practice of one who is an alms-food-eater. The word “practice” is a term for a cause. Therefore it should be understood that this is a designation for the undertaking by which one is an alms-food-eater. In the same way,

original: rathikāsusānasaṅkārakūṭādīnaṃ yattha katthaci paṃsūnaṃ upari ṭhitattā abbhuggataṭṭhena
analyzed: rathikā susāna saṅkāra kūṭa ādīnam yattha katthaci paṃsūnam upari ṭhita ttā abbhuggata ṭṭhena
translated: because it is arisen in the sense of being placed on refuse, on a charnel-ground, on a rubbish heap, etc.,

original: tesu paṃsukūlamivāti paṃsukūlaṃ. Atha vā paṃsu viya kucchitabhāvaṃ ulatīti paṃsukūlaṃ,
analyzed: tesu paṃsu kūlam iva ati paṃsu kūlam atha vā paṃsu kucchita bhāvam paṃsu kūlam
translated: it is refuse-rag. Or alternatively, it is a rag that goes to the state of being refuse, that is, it is discarded,

original: kucchitabhāvaṃ gacchatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ laddhanibbacanassa paṃsukūlassa dhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: kucchita bhāvam gacchati iti vuttam hoti evam laddha nibbacanassa paṃsukūlassa dhāraṇam
translated: as if it were refuse. The wearing of a refuse-rag, which has been given a name in this way,

original: paṃsukūlaṃ, paṃsukūlaṃ sīlamassāti paṃsukūliko, paṃsukūlikassa aṅgaṃ paṃsukūlikaṅgaṃ.🔽Saṅghāṭiuttarāsaṅgaantaravāsakasaṅkhātaṃ ticīvaraṃ sīlamassāti tecīvariko, tecīvarikassa
analyzed: paṃsu kūlam paṃsu kūlam sīlam assa ati paṃsukūlikaḥ paṃsukūlikassa aṅgam paṃsukūlika aṅgam  saṅghāṭi uttarāsaṅga antaravāsaka saṅkhātam ti cīvaram sīlam assa ati tecīvariko tecīvarikassa
translated: is the practice of the refuse-rag-wearer. The practice of the refuse-rag-wearer is the practice of one who is a refuse-rag-wearer.🔽The practice of the triple-robe-wearer is the practice of one who is a triple-robe-wearer. The triple-robe-wearer is one for whom the triple robe is the practice.

original: aṅgaṃ tecīvarikaṅgaṃ. Sapadānacārikaṅganti dānaṃ vuccati avakhaṇḍanaṃ, apetaṃ dānato
analyzed: aṅgam tecīvarikaṅgam sa padānacārikaṅganti dānam vuccati avakhaṇḍanam apetam dānato
translated: The word “robe” is a term for the three robes consisting of the outer cloak, the upper robe, and the inner clothing. The practice of the triple-robe-wearer is the practice of the triple-robe-wearer.🔽The practice of the house-to-house seeker is the practice of one who goes from house to house. The word “house” is a term for a family. The word “house” is also a term for a dwelling. The word “house” is also a term for a shop. The word “house” is also a term for a storehouse. The word “house” is also a term for a place. The word “house” is also a term for a village. The word “house” is also a term for a town. The word “house” is also a term for a city. The word “house” is also a term for a country. The word “house” is also a term for a region. The word “house” is also a term for a continent. The word “house” is also a term for the world. The word “house” is also a term for a world-sphere. The word “house” is also a term for a world-sphere with its four continents. The word “house” is also a term for a great triple-world. The word “

original: apadānaṃ, anavakhaṇḍananti attho. Saha apadānena sapadānaṃ, avakhaṇḍanavirahitaṃ,
analyzed: apadānam an avakhaṇḍanam ti saha apadānena sa padānam avakhaṇḍana virahitam
translated: The meaning is: without breaking the practice of going on the alms round.🔽He goes on the alms round together with the practice of going on the alms round, without breaking it,

original: anugharanti vuttaṃ hoti. Sapadānaṃ carituṃ idamassa sīlanti sapadānacārī, sapadānacārīyeva
analyzed: anugharanti vuttam hoti sa padānam caritum idam assa sīlanti sa padāna cārī sa padāna cārīyā iva
translated: without omitting it, is what is meant. The practice of going on the alms round is his virtue. He is one who goes on the alms round.🔽He is a goer on the alms round. The practice of going on the alms round is a limb of his.

original: sapadānacāriko, tassa aṅgaṃ sapadānacārikaṅgaṃ. Khalupacchābhattikaṅganti khalūti🔽paṭisedhanatthe nipāto. Pavāritena satā pacchā laddhaṃ bhattaṃ pacchābhattaṃ nāma,
analyzed: sa padāna cārikaḥ tassa aṅgam sa padāna cārika aṅgam khalu pacchābhattika anti khalu uti  paṭisedhana atthe nipātaḥ pavāritena satā pacchā laddham bhattam pacchābhattam nāma
translated: The practice of eating in one part: khalu is a particle in the sense of denial.🔽Food obtained after inviting is called “after-invitation food.”

original: tassa pacchābhattassa bhojanaṃ pacchābhattabhojanaṃ, tasmiṃ pacchābhattabhojane pacchābhattasaññaṃ
analyzed: tassa pacchābhattassa bhojanam pacchābhatta bhojanam tasmim pacchābhatta bhojane pacchābhatta saññam
translated: The eating of that after-invitation food is “eating after-invitation food.”🔽Having made the perception of after-invitation food arise in regard to that eating of after-invitation food, he is one who has the virtue of eating after invitation.

original: katvā pacchābhattaṃ sīlamassāti pacchābhattiko, na pacchābhattiko khalupacchābhattiko,
analyzed: katvā pacchābhattam sīlam assa ati pacchābhattikaḥ na pacchābhattikaḥ khalu pacchābhattikaḥ
translated: He is a non-eater of after-invitation food. He is a non-eater of after-invitation food in the sense of denial.

original: samādānavasena paṭikkhittātirittabhojanassetaṃ nāmaṃ, tassa aṅgaṃ khalupacchābhattikaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: samādāna vasena paṭikkhitta atiritta bhojanassa itam nāmam tassa aṅgam khalu pacchābhattika ṅgam
translated: This is a name for the abstaining from excessive eating that is undertaken. The practice of eating in one part is a limb of that.

original: Nesajjikaṅganti sayanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā nisajjāya viharituṃ sīlamassāti nesajjiko,
analyzed: nesajjikaṅganti sayanam paṭikkhipitvā nisajjāya viharitum sīlam assa ati nesajjikaḥ
translated: The practice of the sitter: he is a sitter because he has the virtue of sitting down after getting up from sleeping.

original: tassa aṅgaṃ nesajjikaṅgaṃ. Yathāsanthatikaṅganti yadeva santhataṃ yathāsanthataṃ,
analyzed: tassa aṅgam nesajjikaṅgam yathā santhatikaṅganti yat eva santhatam yathā santhatam
translated: The ascetic practice is the “lying-down-anywhere practice.” The “as-blankets-found practice” is the use of any kind of blanket that is found.

original: “idaṃ tuyhaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti evaṃ paṭhamaṃ uddiṭṭhasenāsanassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: idam tuyham pāpuṇāti iti evam paṭhamam adhivacanam tasmin
translated: It is a term for the kind of resting place that is first mentioned thus, “If he should get one, it is to be used” .

original: yathāsanthate viharituṃ sīlamassāti yathāsanthatiko, tassa aṅgaṃ yathāsanthatikaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: yathā santhate viharitum sīlam assa ati yathāsanthatikaḥ tassa aṅgam yathāsanthatika ṅgam
translated: He has the habit of living with that kind of resting place that is found, thus he is an “as-blankets-found user” . The ascetic practice is the “as-blankets-found practice.”

original: Sabbāneva panetāni tena tena samādānena dhutakilesattā dhutassa bhikkhuno aṅgāni,🔽kilesadhunanato vā dhutanti laddhavohāraṃ ñāṇaṃ aṅgaṃ etesanti dhutaṅgāni. Atha vā
analyzed: sabbāni eva pana itāni tena tena samādānena dhuta kilesa ttā dhutassa bhikkhuno aṅgāni  kilesa dhunanataḥ vā laddha vohāram ñāṇam aṅgam dhutaṅgāni atha vā
translated: But all these are the limbs of the bhikkhu who is a “shaker of the can” , since they shake off defilements by the undertaking of each one.🔽Or alternatively, the shaking off of defilements is what is called “shaking,” and knowledge is the limb by means of which that is done, thus these are “shaking-off-of-defilements limbs.”

original: dhutāni ca tāni paṭipakkhānaṃ dhunanato aṅgāni ca paṭipattiyātipi dhutaṅgāni. Evaṃ
analyzed: dhutāni ca tāni paṭipakkhānam dhunanataḥ aṅgāni ca paṭipattiyā atipi dhuta aṅgāni evam
translated: Or alternatively, they are “shaking-off limbs” since they are limbs that shake off their opposites, and they are “practices” since they are what should be practised by one who is a “shaker of the can” .🔽This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known here as to meaning.

original: tāvettha atthato viññātabbo vinicchayo. Sabbāneva cetāni samādānacetanālakkhaṇāni. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: tāva ettha atthataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayo sabbān eva cetāni samādāna cetanā lakkhaṇāni vuttam pi
translated: But as to characteristic, etc., all these ascetic practices have the characteristic of volition consisting in undertaking. For this is said:

original: “Yo samādiyati, so puggalo. Yena samādiyati, cittacetasikā ete dhammā. Yā samādānacetanā, taṃ dhutaṅgaṃ. Yaṃ paṭikkhipati, taṃ vatthu”nti.
analyzed: yaḥ samādiyati saḥ puggalaḥ yena samādiyati citta cetasikāḥ ete dhammāḥ yā samādāna cetanā tam dhutaṅgam yam paṭikkhipati tam vatthum ti
translated: “The person who undertakes it. The states of consciousness and its concomitants by which he undertakes it. The volition of the undertaking. The subject matter that is renounced.

original: Sabbāneva ca loluppaviddhaṃsanarasāni, nilloluppabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānāni, appicchatādiariyadhammapadaṭṭhānāni. Evamettha lakkhaṇādīhi vinicchayo veditabbo.🔽Vīriyasamādānampīti vīriyaggahaṇampi. Kāmanti ekaṃsatthe nipāto. Taco ca nhāru cāti🔽chavi ca nhāruvalliyo ca. Aṭṭhi cāti sabbā aṭṭhiyo ca. Avasissatūti tiṭṭhatu. Upasussatu🔽maṃsalohitanti sabbaṃ maṃsañca lohitañca sukkhatu. “Taco”ti ekaṃ aṅgaṃ, “nhārū”ti
analyzed: sabbān eva ca loluppa viddhaṃsana rasāni nilloluppa bhāva paccupaṭṭhānāni appiccha tā ādi ariya dhamma padaṭṭhānāni evam ettha lakkhaṇa ādīhi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo  vīriya samādānam pi iti vīriya ggahaṇam pi kāmanti ekaṃsa tthe nipāto taco ca nhāru ca ati  chavi ca nhāruvalliyaḥ ca aṭṭhi ca ati sabbāḥ aṭṭhiyaḥ ca avasissatu uti tiṭṭhatu upasussatu  maṃsa lohitanti sabbam maṃsam ca lohitam ca sukkhatu taco ti ekam aṅgam
translated: “All have the function of eliminating greed. They are manifested as the state of nongreed. They are based on such noble states as fewness of wishes. This is how the exposition should be known here as to characteristic, etc.”

original: ekaṃ, “aṭṭhī”ti ekaṃ, “upasussatu maṃsalohita”nti ekaṃ aṅgaṃ. Yaṃ tanti upari vattabbapadena
analyzed: ekam aṭṭhi iti ekam upasussatu maṃsa lohitanti ekam aṅgam yam tam ti upari vattabba padena
