original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasantassa āraddhavipassakassa uppajjati, uppanne🔽ca suddhasamathalābhī suddhavipassanālābhī vā antarā ṭhapeti. So hi dasapi vassāni🔽vīsampi vassāni tiṃsampi vassāni asītipi vassāni kilesasamudācāraṃ apassanto “ahaṃ
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasantassa āraddha vipassakassa uppajjati uppanne  ca suddha samatha lābhī suddha vipassanā lābhī vā antarā ṭhapeti saḥ hi dasa api vassāni  vīsam pi vassāni tiṃsam pi vassāni asīti pi vassāni kilesa samudācāram a passantaḥ aham
translated: who has dispelled perplexity by investigating conditions in discerning mentality-materiality,🔽and who is engaged in insight, having discerned formations with the three characteristics.🔽And when it has arisen, one who has attained only serenity or only insight postpones it.

original: sotāpanno”ti vā “sakadāgāmī”ti vā “anāgāmī”ti vā maññati, samathavipassanālābhī pana🔽arahatteyeva ṭhapeti. Tassa hi samādhibalena kilesā vikkhambhitā, vipassanābalena
analyzed: sotāpannaḥ iti vā sakadāgāmī iti vā anāgāmī iti vā maññati samatha vipassanā lābhī pana  arahattā iya iva ṭhapeti tassa hi samādhi balena kilesāḥ vikkhambhitāḥ vipassanā balena
translated: For he does not see the occurrence of defilements for ten years, or twenty, or thirty, or eighty years, and he thinks, “I am a stream-enterer, a once-returner, a non-returner,”🔽but one who has attained both serenity and insight postpones it only until he reaches Arahantship.

original: saṅkhārā supariggahitā, tasmā saṭṭhipi vassāni asītipi vassāni vassasatampi kilesā
analyzed: saṅkhārā su pariggahitā tasmā saṭṭhi pi vassāni asīti pi vassāni vassa satam pi kilesā
translated: For the defilements are suppressed in him by the power of concentration, and formations are well discerned by the power of insight, so that for sixty, eighty, or a hundred years he does not see the occurrence of defilements,

original: na samudācaranti, khīṇāsavasseva cittācāro hoti. So evaṃ dīgharattaṃ kilesasamudācāraṃ
analyzed: na samudācaranti khīṇāsavassa iva citta ācāro hoti saḥ evam dīgharattam kilesa samudācāram
translated: He does not see the manifestation of defilements in himself, and he thinks, “I have the same mental behaviour as those whose cankers are destroyed.”

original: apassanto antarā aṭṭhatvāva “arahā aha”nti maññati.
analyzed: a passantaḥ antarā aṭṭhatvā ava arahā aham ti maññati
translated: Not seeing the manifestation of defilements in himself for a long time, he does not pause to reflect, and he thinks, “I am an Arahant.”

original: Asmimānoti rūpe asmītiādinā nayena pañcasu khandhesu “ahaṃ rūpādayo”ti uppanno māno.
analyzed: rūpe asmi itiādinā nayena pañcasu khandhesu aham uppannaḥ mānaḥ
translated: “Conceit based on self” is the conceit that arises in the five aggregates through the idea “I am” in the way beginning, “I am visible forms … I am consciousness.”

original: Micchāmānoti pāpakehi kammāyatanasippāyatanavijjāṭṭhānasutapaṭibhānasīlabbatehi,🔽pāpikāya ca diṭṭhiyā uppanno māno. Tattha pāpakaṃ kammāyatanaṃ nāma kevaṭṭamacchabandhanesādānaṃ
analyzed: micchāmāno ti pāpakehi kamma āyatana sippāyatana vijjāṭṭhāna suta paṭibhāna sīlabbatehi  pāpikāya ca diṭṭhiyā uppannaḥ māno tattha pāpakam kammāyatanam nāma kevaṭṭa macchabandha nesādānam
translated: “Wrong conceit” is the conceit that arises through evil kamma-bases, evil arts, evil sciences, evil learning, and evil views.🔽Herein, evil kamma-bases are the kamma of fishermen, hunters, pig killers, bird catchers, thieves, executioners, and those who follow these trades.🔽Evil arts are the arts of making nets, snares, traps, etc., and of poisoning, and the arts of the fortune-teller, the physiognomist, the augur, the palmist, and so on.

original: kammaṃ. Pāpakaṃ sippāyatanaṃ nāma macchajālakhipakumīnakaraṇesu ceva pāsaoḍḍanasūlāropanādīsu🔽ca chekatā. Pāpakaṃ vijjāṭṭhānaṃ nāma yā kāci parūpaghātavijjā. Pāpakaṃ sutaṃ nāma
analyzed: kammam pāpakam sippāyatanam nāma maccha jāla khipa kumīna karaṇesu ca iva pāsa oḍḍana sūla āropana ādīsu  ca cheka tā pāpakam vijjāṭṭhānam nāma yā kāci para upaghāta vijjā pāpakam sutam nāma
translated: Evil sciences are the science of making love potions, the science of making people invisible, and the science of causing death to others.🔽Evil learning is learning in the epics, the Purāṇas, etc., that is not conducive to disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, peace, higher knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna.

original: bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ. Pāpakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ nāma dubbhāsitayuttaṃ
analyzed: bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi paṭisaṃyuttam pāpakam paṭibhānam nāma dubbhāsita yuttam
translated: Evil views are the views of those who hold that the world and beings are created by an Overlord, etc., and the views of those who hold that there is no cause or condition for the defilement of beings, etc.

original: kappanāṭakavilappanādipaṭibhānaṃ. Pāpakaṃ sīlaṃ nāma ajasīlaṃ gosīlaṃ. Vatampi ajavatagovatameva.
analyzed: kappa nāṭaka vilappana ādi paṭibhānam pāpakam sīlam nāma aja sīlam go sīlam ajavata govatam eva
translated: and the like. Bad morality is the morality of goats and pigs. The cow and the goat are also bad.

original: Pāpikā diṭṭhi pana dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhigatesu yākāci diṭṭhi. Aṭṭhavidhamāno uttānatthoyeva.
analyzed: pāpikā diṭṭhi pana dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi gatesu yā kāci diṭṭhi aṭṭhavidha māno uttāna atthaḥ yeva
translated: Bad view is any view among the sixty-two views. The eight kinds of conceit are self-evident.

original: Navavidhena mānaniddese seyyassa “seyyohamasmī”tiādayo nava mānā puggalaṃ nissāya
analyzed: navavidhena māna niddese seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti ādayaḥ nava mānā puggalam nissāya
translated: In the description of the nine kinds of conceit, the nine conceits beginning with “I am better” are stated with reference to a person.

original: vuttā. Ettha pana seyyassa “seyyohamasmī”ti māno rājānañceva pabbajitānañca uppajjati.
analyzed: vuttā ettha pana seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti mānaḥ rājānam ca iva pabbajitānam ca uppajjati
translated: Herein, the conceit “I am better” arises in a king and in one gone forth.

original: Rājā hi “raṭṭhena vā dhanavāhanehi vā ko mayā sadiso atthī”ti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: rājā hi raṭṭhena vā dhana vāhanehi vā kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti etam mānam karoti
translated: For a king thinks “Who is my equal in the realm or in wealth?” and he conceives conceit.

original: Pabbajitopi “sīladhutaṅgādīhi ko mayā sadiso atthī”ti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ api sīla dhutaṅga ādīhi kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti etam mānam karoti
translated: And one gone forth thinks “Who is my equal in virtue, in the ascetic practices, and so on?” and he conceives conceit.

original: Seyyassa “sadisohamasmī”ti mānopi etesaṃyeva uppajjati. Rājā hi “raṭṭhena vā dhanavāhanehi
analyzed: seyyassa sadisaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ api etesam yeva uppajjati rājā hi raṭṭhena vā dhana vāhanehi
translated: The conceit “I am the equal of” also arises in these same two. For the king thinks “What difference is there between me and other kings in the realm or in wealth?”

original: vā aññarājūhi saddhiṃ mayhaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa”nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti. Pabbajitopi “sīladhutaṅgādīhi
analyzed: vā añña rājūhi saddhim mayham kim nānākaraṇam ti etam mānam karoti pabbajitaḥ api sīla dhutaṅga ādīhi
translated: and he conceives conceit. And one gone forth thinks “What difference is there between me and others in virtue, in the ascetic practices, and so on?”🔽and he conceives conceit.

original: aññena bhikkhunā mayhaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa”nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.🔽Seyyassa “hīnohamasmī”ti mānopi etesaṃyeva uppajjati. Yassa hi rañño raṭṭhaṃ vā dhanavāhanādīni
analyzed: aññena bhikkhunā mayham kim nānākaraṇanti etam mānam karoti  seyyassa hīnaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ api etesam yeva uppajjati yassa hi raññaḥ raṭṭham vā dhana vāhana ādīni
translated: “What difference is there between me and another bhikkhu?”

original: vā nātisampannāni honti, so “mayhaṃ rājāti vohārasukhamattakameva, kiṃ rājā nāma🔽aha”nti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti. Pabbajitopi appalābhasakkāro “ahaṃ dhammakathiko, bahussuto,
analyzed: vā na atisampannāni honti saḥ mayham rājā ati vohāra sukha mattakam eva kim rājā nāma  aham ti etam mānam karoti pabbajitaḥ api appa lābha sakkāraḥ aham dhamma kathikaḥ bahu sutaḥ
translated: The inferior man has the conceit “I am inferior.” For when a king’s realm or his wealth and corn, etc., are not abundant, he thinks, “I have only the mere pleasant sound ‘king.’ What is a king?

original: mahātheroti kathāmattameva, kiṃ dhammakathiko nāmāhaṃ, kiṃ bahussuto nāmāhaṃ, kiṃ
analyzed: mahā thero ti kathā mattam eva kim dhammakathikaḥ nāma aham kim bahussutaḥ nāma aham kim
translated: I am not a king,” and he has the conceit “I am inferior.” When a bhikkhu has little gain and honour, he thinks, “I have only the mere sound ‘dhammakathika,’ ‘one who is learned,’ ‘a great elder.’ What is a dhammakathika? What is one who is learned? What is a great elder?

original: mahāthero nāmāhaṃ, yassa me lābhasakkāro natthī”ti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: mahātheraḥ nāma aham yassa me lābha sakkāraḥ natthi iti etam mānam karoti
translated: I am not a great elder, since I have no gain and honour,” and he has the conceit “I am inferior.”

original: Sadisassa “seyyohamasmī”ti mānādayo amaccādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Amacco vā hi raṭṭhiyo
analyzed: sadisassa seyya uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ amacca ādīnam uppajjanti amaccaḥ vā hi raṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: The conceit “I am equal” and the rest arise in one who is equal, etc.,

original: vā “bhogayānavāhanādīhi ko mayā sadiso añño rājapuriso atthī”ti vā, “mayhaṃ aññehi
analyzed: vā bhoga yāna vāhana ādīhi kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ rāja purisaḥ atthi iti vā mayham aññehi
translated: For a minister or a clansman thinks, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in wealth, vehicles, clothes, etc.? Or what other royal officer is better than I am?”

original: saddhiṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇa”nti vā, “amaccoti nāmameva mayhaṃ, ghāsacchādanamattampi me
analyzed: vai me
translated: “What difference is there between me and him?” Or he is conceited thus: “I am a slave, I have nothing of my own, not even grass or a leaf to chew,

original: natthi, kiṃ amacco nāmāha”nti vā ete māne karoti.🔽Hīnassa “seyyohamasmī”ti mānādayo dāsādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Dāso hi “mātito vā pitito
analyzed: natthi kim amaccaḥ nāma ahanti vai ete māne karoti  hīnassa seyyā uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ dāsa ādīnam uppajjanti dāsaḥ hi mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ
translated: so what is a slave?”

original: vā ko mayā sadiso añño dāso nāma atthi, aññe jīvituṃ asakkontā kucchihetu dāsā nāma🔽jātā, ahaṃ pana paveṇīāgatattā seyyo”ti vā, “paveṇīāgatabhāvena ubhatosuddhikadāsattena
analyzed: vā kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ dāsaḥ nāma atthi aññe jīvitum a sakkontā kucchi hetu dāsāḥ nāma  jātā aham pana paveṇī āgata ttā vā paveṇī āgata bhāvena ubhatosuddhika dāsattena
translated: Conceit of the kind “I am better” arises in the low-born, etc., thus: a slave thinks “There is no other slave equal to me. Others have become slaves because they were unable to live, because they sold themselves for food when starving,

original: asukadāsena nāma saddhiṃ ki mayhaṃ nānākaraṇa”nti vā, “kucchivasenāhaṃ dāsabyaṃ upagato,
analyzed: asuka dāsena nāma vā kucchi vasena aham dāsabyam upagataḥ
translated: but I am better because I come of a good family.” Or he is conceited thus: “What difference is there between me and such and such a slave, who comes of a good family and is pure in respect of his bowl and robe and is well behaved and virtuous?” Or he is conceited thus: “I have become a slave because of my kamma-formation;

original: mātāpitukoṭiyā pana me dāsaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, kiṃ dāso nāma aha”nti vā ete māne karoti.
analyzed: mātā pitu koṭiyā pana me dāsa ṭṭhānam natthi kim dāsaḥ nāma ahanti vā ete māne karoti
translated: I am not a slave by birth, so what is a slave?”

original: Yathā ca dāso, evaṃ pukkusacaṇḍālādayopi ete māne karontiyeva.
analyzed: yathā ca dāsaḥ evam pukkusa caṇḍāla ādayaḥ api ete māne
translated: And as a slave, so too a pauper, a cripple, and an outcast.

original: Ettha ca seyyassa “seyyohamasmī”ti uppannamānova yāthāvamāno, itare dve ayāthāvamānā.
analyzed: ettha ca seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti uppanna mānā iva itare dve a yāthāvamānā
translated: And here the conceit “I am superior” in one who is superior is a right conceit, the other two are wrong conceits.

original: Tathā sadisassa “sadisohamasmī”ti, hīnassa “hīnohamasmī”ti uppannamānova yāthāvamāno,
analyzed: tathā sadisassa sadisaḥ uham asmi iti hīnassa hīnaḥ uham asmi iti uppanna mānaḥ uva yāthāvamānaḥ
translated: And likewise the conceit “I am equal” in one who is equal, and the conceit “I am inferior” in one who is inferior are right conceits,

original: itare dve ayāthāvamānā. Tattha yāthāvamānā arahattamaggavajjhā, ayāthāvamānā sotāpattimaggavajjhā.
analyzed: itare dve ayāthāvamānā tattha yāthāvamānā arahatta magga vajjhā ayāthāvamānā sotāpatti magga vajjhā
translated: while the other two are wrong conceits. Herein, the right conceits are excluded by the Arahant path, and the wrong conceits are excluded by the Stream-Entry path.

original: Ettha ca seyyassa “seyyohamasmī”ti māno uttamassa uttamaṭṭhena “ahaṃ seyyo”ti evaṃ🔽uppannamāno, seyyassa “sadisohamasmī”ti māno uttamassa samaṭṭhena “ahaṃ sadiso”ti
analyzed: ettha ca seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti māno uttamassa uttama aṭṭhena aham seyyā iti evam  uppanna mānaḥ seyyassa sadisaḥ ham asmi iti mānaḥ uttamassa samaṭṭhena aham sadisaḥ ti
translated: And here the conceit “I am superior” in one who is superior is a conceit that has arisen thus “I am superior” in the sense of being the best.🔽The conceit “I am equal” in one who is superior is a conceit that has arisen thus “I am equal” in the sense of being the same.

original: evaṃ uppannamāno. Seyyassa “hīnohamasmī”ti māno uttamassa lāmakaṭṭhena “ahaṃ hīno”ti🔽evaṃ uppannamāno. Evaṃ seyyamāno sadisamāno hīnamānoti ime tayo mānā seyyassa uppajjanti.
analyzed: evam uppanna mānaḥ seyyassa hīnaḥ aham asmi iti mānaḥ uttamassa lāmakaṭṭhena aham hīnaḥ ti  evam uppanna mānaḥ evam seyyamānaḥ sadisa mānaḥ hīna mānaḥ ti ime tayaḥ mānā seyyassa uppajjanti
translated: The conceit “I am inferior” in one who is superior is a conceit that has arisen thus “I am inferior” in the sense of being the least.🔽So these three conceits, namely, the conceit “I am superior,” the conceit “I am equal,” and the conceit “I am inferior,” arise in one who is superior.

original: Sadisassāpi ahaṃ seyyo, sadiso, hīnoti tayo mānā uppajjanti. Hīnassāpi ahaṃ hīno,
analyzed: sadisassa api aham seyyaḥ sadisaḥ hīnaḥ ti tayaḥ mānāḥ uppajjanti hīnassa api aham hīnaḥ
translated: And three conceits arise in one who is equal: the conceit “I am superior,” the conceit “I am equal,” and the conceit “I am inferior.”🔽And three conceits arise in one who is inferior:

original: sadiso, seyyoti tayo mānā uppajjanti.🔽Dasavidhamānaniddese idhekacco mānaṃ janetīti ekacco puggalo mānaṃ janayati. Jātiyā🔽vāti khattiyabhāvādijātisampattiyā vā. Gottena vāti gotamagottādinā ukkaṭṭhagottena🔽vā. Kolaputtiyena vāti mahākulabhāvena vā. Vaṇṇapokkharatāya vāti vaṇṇasampannasarīratāya🔽vā. Sarīrañhi “pokkhara”nti vuccati, tassa vaṇṇasampattiyā abhirūpabhāvenāti attho.
analyzed: sadisaḥ seyyaḥ iti tayaḥ mānāḥ uppajjanti  dasavidha māna niddese idha ekaccaḥ mānam janeti iti ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ mānam janayati jātiyā  vāti khattiya bhāva ādi jāti sampattiyā vā gottena vāti gotama gotta ādinā ukkaṭṭha gottena  vā kola puttiyena vā ati mahā kula bhāvena vā vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya vā ati vaṇṇa sampanna sarīra tāya  vā sarīram hi pokkharanti vuccati tassa vaṇṇa sampattiyā abhirūpa bhāvena ati attho
translated: Three kinds of conceit arise: “I am equal” and “I am superior.”

original: Dhanena vāti dhanasampannabhāvena vā, mayhaṃ nidhānagatassa dhanassa pamāṇaṃ natthīti🔽attho. Ajjhenena vāti ajjhāyanavasena vā. Kammāyatanena vāti “avasesā sattā chinnapakkhakākasadisā,🔽ahaṃ pana mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo”ti vā, “ahaṃ yaṃ yaṃ kammaṃ karomi, taṃ taṃ samijjhatī”ti
analyzed: dhanena vā ati dhana sampanna bhāvena vā mayham nidhāna gatassa dhanassa pamāṇam natthi iti 🔽atthaḥ ajjhenena vā ati ajjhāyana vasena vā kamma āyatanena vā ati avasesā sattā chinna pakkha kāka sadisā 🔽aham pana mahiddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ iti vai aham yam yam kammam karomi tam tam samijjhati iti
translated: In the description of the ten kinds of conceit, “someone conceives conceit” means that a certain person conceives conceit. “On account of birth” means on account of the excellence of his birth as a noble, etc. “On account of family” means on account of an excellent family such as the Gotama family, etc. “On account of wealth” means on account of the excellence of his wealth. “On account of his profession” means on account of his profession as a brahmin. “On account of his craft” means on account of his craft as a physician, etc. “On account of his cattle” means on account of the excellence of his cattle. “On account of his slaves” means on account of the excellence of his slaves. “On account of his merit” means on account of the excellence of his merit. “On account of his wisdom” means on account of the excellence of his wisdom. “On account of his learning” means on account of the excellence of his learning. “On account of his eloquence” means on account of the excellence of his eloquence. “On account of his beauty” means on account of the excellence of his body. For the body is called “a pool” . The meaning is: on account of the excellence of his beauty, on account of his being handsome. “On account of his wealth” means on account of the excellence of his wealth. The meaning is: there is no limit to the wealth that is stored up by me. “On account of his eloquence” means on account of his eloquence in the Vedas. “On account of his craft” means on account of his craft as a physician, etc. “On account of his profession” means on account of his profession as a brahmin. “On account of his cattle” means on account of the excellence of his cattle. “On account of his slaves” means on account of the excellence of his slaves. “On account of his merit” means on account of the excellence of his merit. “On account of his wisdom” means on account of the excellence of his wisdom. “On account of his learning” means on account of the excellence of his learning. “On account of his eloquence” means on account of the excellence of his eloquence. “On account of his beauty” means on account of the excellence of his body. For the body is called “a pool” . The meaning is: on account

original: vā evamādinayappavattena kammāyatanena vā. Sippāyatanena vāti “avasesā sattā nisippā,🔽ahaṃ sippavā”ti evamādinayappavattena sippāyatanena vā. Vijjāṭṭhānena vāti idaṃ heṭṭhā
analyzed: vā evamādi naya ppavattena kamma āyatanena vā sippa āyatanena vā ati avasesā sattā nisippā  aham sippavā ti evamādi naya ppavattena sippāyatanena vā vijjāṭṭhānena vā ti idam heṭṭhā
translated: By the sphere of craft, thus: “Other beings are unskilful in a craft, but I am skilful in a craft,” and so on.

original: vuttanayameva. Sutena vāti “avasesā sattā appassutā, ahaṃ pana bahussuto”ti evamādisutena🔽vā. Paṭibhānena vāti “avasesā sattā appaṭibhānā, mayhaṃ pana paṭibhānappamāṇaṃ natthī”ti
analyzed: vutta nayam eva sutena vā ati avasesā sattā appassutā aham pana bahu ssutaḥ ti evamādi sutena  vā paṭibhānena vā ati avasesā sattā appaṭibhānā mayham pana paṭibhāna ppamāṇam natthi iti
translated: By the sphere of learning, thus: “Other beings are unlearned, but I am learned,” and so on.🔽By the sphere of ready speech, thus: “Other beings are unready in speech, but I am ready in speech,” and so on.

original: evamādipaṭibhānena vā. Aññataraññatarena vā vatthunāti avuttena aññena vatthunā vā.
analyzed: evamādi paṭibhānena vā aññatara aññatarena vā vatthunā ati avuttena aññena vatthunā vā
translated: By some other ground, thus: “Other beings are not of such and such a kind, but I am of such and such a kind,” and so on.

original: Yo evarūpo mānoti mānakaraṇavasena māno. Maññanā maññitattanti ākārabhāvaniddeso.
analyzed: yaḥ evarūpaḥ māno ti māna karaṇa vasena mānaḥ maññanā ākāra bhāva niddeso
translated: This is the kind of conceit that is “conceit” in the sense of the act of conceiving. “Conceiving” is the act of conceiving. “Conceit” is the state of being conceited.

original: Ussitaṭṭhena unnati. Yassuppajjati, taṃ puggalaṃ unnāmeti ukkhipitvā ṭhapetīti unnāmo.
analyzed: ussita ṭṭhena unnati yassa uppajjati tam puggalam unnāmeti ukkhipitvā ṭhapeti iti unnāmaḥ
translated: It is “arrogance” in the sense of haughtiness. It “makes one high” : it makes the person in whom it arises high, it makes him stand high.

original: Samussitaṭṭhena dhajo. Ukkhipanaṭṭhena cittaṃ sampaggaṇhātīti sampaggāho. Ketu vuccati
analyzed: samussita ṭṭhena dhajaḥ ukkhipana ṭṭhena cittam sampaggaṇhāti iti sampaggāhaḥ ketu vuccati
translated: It is a “banner” in the sense of being hoisted up. It is a “grasp” in the sense of grasping the mind and hoisting it up. “Banner” is said

original: bahūsu dhajesu accuggatadhajo. Mānopi punappunaṃ uppajjamāno aparāpare upādāya accuggataṭṭhena🔽ketu viyāti ketu, taṃ ketuṃ icchatīti ketukamyaṃ, tassa bhāvo ketukamyatā. Sā pana
analyzed: bahūsu dhajesu accuggata dhajaḥ mānaḥ api punappunam uppajjamānaḥ apara apare upādāya accuggata ṭṭhena  ketu viyāti ketu tam ketum icchati iti ketu kamyam tassa bhāvaḥ ketu kamya tā sā pana
translated: Conceit, occurring again and again, is the highest in the sense of being the highest in relation to others.🔽It is a banner, thus it is a flag . He desires the flag, thus he is one who desires the flag . The state of that is flag-desire . But that is of the mind, not of itself. Hence it is said: “Flag-desire is of the mind.”

original: cittassa, na attano. Tena vuttaṃ “ketukamyatā cittassā”ti. Mānasampayuttañhi cittaṃ🔽ketuṃ icchati, tassa bhāvo, ketusaṅkhāto mānoti. Dhono māyañca mānañca pahāya pajahitvā🔽yo so dhono arahā heṭṭhā vuttanayena vinodanabyantikaraṇādivasena kilese pajahitvā🔽ṭhito, so tena rāgādinā kilesena gaccheyya.🔽Nerayikoti vāti niraye nibbattakasattoti vā. Tiracchānayonikādīsupi eseva nayo. So
analyzed: cittassa na tena vuttam ketu kamya tā cittassa ati māna sampayuttam hi cittam  ketum icchati tassa bhāvaḥ ketu saṅkhātaḥ dhonaḥ māyañca mānañca pahāya pajahitvā  yaḥ saḥ dhonaḥ arahā heṭṭhā vutta nayena vinodana byanti karaṇa ādi vasena kilese pajahitvā  ṭhitaḥ saḥ tena rāga ādinā kilesena gaccheyya  nerayikaḥ ti vā ti niraye nibbattaka satto ti vā tiracchānayonika ādīsu pi esa iva nayo so
translated: For the mind associated with conceit desires the flag. The state of that is the conceit called the flag .🔽Having abandoned conceit and pride, having abandoned the conceit and pride

original: hetu natthīti yena janakahetunā gatiyādīsu nibbatteyya, so hetu natthi. Paccayoti
analyzed: hetu natthi iti yena janaka hetunā gatiyā ādīsu so hetu natthi paccayaḥ ti
translated: that are called the flag, the one who is a destroyer of conceit, who is a destroyer of pride, who is a destroyer of the flag, who is a destroyer of the banner, who is a destroyer of the symbol, who is a destroyer of the emblem, who is a destroyer of the sign, who is a destroyer of the mark, who is a destroyer of the banner of conceit, who is a destroyer of the banner of pride, who is a destroyer of the flag of conceit, who is a destroyer of the flag of pride, who is a destroyer of the flag of the flag, who is a destroyer of the banner of the banner, who is a destroyer of the symbol of the symbol, who is a destroyer of the emblem of the emblem, who is a destroyer of the sign of the sign, who is a destroyer of the mark of the mark, who is a destroyer of the banner of the banner, who is a destroyer of the flag of the flag, who is a destroyer of the symbol of the symbol, who is a destroyer of the emblem of the emblem, who is a destroyer of the sign of the sign, who is a destroyer of the mark of the mark, who is a destroyer of the banner of the banner, who is a destroyer of the flag of the flag, who is a destroyer of the symbol of the symbol, who is a destroyer of the emblem of the emblem, who is a destroyer of the sign of the sign, who is a destroyer of the mark of the mark, who is a destroyer of the banner of the banner, who is a destroyer of the flag of the flag, who is a destroyer of the symbol of the symbol, who is a destroyer of the emblem of the emblem, who is a destroyer of the sign of the sign, who is a destroyer of the mark of the mark, who is a destroyer of the banner

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Kāraṇanti ṭhānaṃ. Kāraṇañhi tadāyattavuttitāya attano phalassa
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam kāraṇan ti ṭhānam kāraṇam hi tad āyatta vutti tāya attanaḥ phalassa
translated: and that is a synonym for it. “Cause” is a reason. For that is called a reason because its fruit occurs dependent on it.

original: ṭhānanti vuccati. Tasmā yena hetunā yena paccayena gatiyādīsu nibbatteyya, taṃ kāraṇaṃ natthi.
analyzed: ṭhānam ti vuccati tasmai yena hetunā yena paccayena gatiyā ādīsu tam kāraṇam natthi
translated: So there is no cause, no reason, for his being reborn in the destinies, etc.,

original: 22. Yo pana nesaṃ dvinnaṃ upayānaṃ bhāvena upayo hoti, so upayo hi…pe… diṭṭhimidheva
analyzed: yaḥ pana nesam dvinnam upayānam bhāvena upayaḥ hoti saḥ upayaḥ hipe diṭṭhi midhā iva
translated: But the “approach” is the approach by way of craving and views.🔽“All”:

original: sabbanti. Tattha upayoti taṇhādiṭṭhinissito. Dhammesu upeti vādanti “ratto”ti vā
analyzed: sabbanti tattha upayaḥ ti taṇhā diṭṭhi nissitaḥ dhammesu upeti vā adanti ratto ti vā
translated: Herein, the “approach” is that based on craving and views. “He approaches views about things” means that he approaches views about such and such things, saying “he is lustful” or

original: “duṭṭho”ti vā evaṃ tesu tesu dhammesu upeti vādaṃ. Anūpayaṃ kena kathaṃ vadeyyāti🔽taṇhādiṭṭhippahānena pana anūpayaṃ khīṇāsavaṃ kena rāgena vā dosena vā kathaṃ “ratto”ti
analyzed: duṭṭhaḥ iti vai evam tesu tesu dhammesu upeti vādam anūpayam kena katham vadeyya ati  taṇhā diṭṭhi ppahānena pana kena rāgena vā dosena vā katham
translated: “he is hating.” “How could one without an approach be spoken of?”

original: vā “duṭṭho”ti vā vadeyya. Evaṃ anupavajjo ca so kiṃ titthiyā viya katapaṭicchādako
analyzed: vā duṭṭhaḥ ti vā vadeyya evam anupavajjaḥ ca saḥ kim titthiyāḥ viya kata paṭicchādako
translated: But one without an approach, one who has abandoned craving and views, is an Arahant whose cankers are destroyed. How could he be spoken of as “lustful” or as “hating” because of lust or hatred? The intention is this: “How could he be spoken of in such a way?” “He is without reproach. How could he be like the sectarians, who cover up their faults?”

original: bhavissatīti adhippāyo. Attā nirattā na hi tassa atthīti tassa hi attadiṭṭhi vā ucchedadiṭṭhi
analyzed: bhavissati iti adhippāyaḥ attā nirattā na hi tassa atthi iti tassa hi atta diṭṭhi vā uccheda diṭṭhi
translated: “He has no self, no ‘mine’” means that he has no self-view or annihilation view.

original: vā natthi, gahaṇamuñcanaṃ vāpi attanirattasaññitaṃ natthi. Kiṃ kāraṇā natthīti ce?
analyzed: vā natthi gahaṇa muñcanam vā api atta niratta saññitam natthi kim kāraṇā natthi iti ce
translated: Or there is no grasping and relinquishing, or the perception of self-possession, why is there not?

original: Adhosi so diṭṭhimidheva sabbanti. Yasmā so idheva attabhāve ñāṇambunā sabbadiṭṭhigataṃ
analyzed: adhosi saḥ diṭṭhim idhā iva sabbanti yasmā saḥ idhā iva atta bhāve ñāṇa ambunā sabba diṭṭhi gatam
translated: He destroyed all views right here. Because he destroyed, abandoned, removed, all views right here in this very selfhood by means of the water of knowledge,

original: adhosi pajahi vinodesīti arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi. Taṃ sutvā rājā attamano
analyzed: adhosi pajahi vinodesi iti arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi tam sutvā rājā atta manaḥ
translated: he reached the peak of arahatship. Thus he concluded the teaching. Having heard it, the king was pleased.

original: bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā pakkāmīti.🔽Rattoti vāti rāgena rattoti vā. Duṭṭhoti vātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Te abhisaṅkhārā
analyzed: bhagavantam abhivādetvā pakkāmi iti  ratto ti vā ati rāgena ratto ti vā duṭṭho ti vā ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayo te
translated: He paid homage to the Blessed One and departed.

original: appahīnāti ye puññāpuññaāneñjābhisaṅkhārā, te appahīnā. Abhisaṅkhārānaṃ appahīnattāti🔽tesaṃ vuttappakārānaṃ kammābhisaṅkhārānaṃ na pahīnabhāvena. Gatiyā vādaṃ upetīti
analyzed: appahīnā ati ye puññāpuñña āneñja abhisaṅkhārā te appahīnāḥ abhisaṅkhārānam appahīna ttā ti  tesam vutta pakārānam kamma abhisaṅkhārānam na pahīna bhāvena gatiyā vādam upeti iti
translated: “One who is lustful” means one who is lustful because of lust. “One who is hateful” and so on should be understood in the same way. “Those determinations are not abandoned” means those determinations of merit, demerit, and imperturbability are not abandoned. “Because the determinations are not abandoned” means

original: pañcannaṃ gatīnaṃ aññatarāya kathanaṃ upagacchati. Tenevāha – “nerayikoti vā…pe…
analyzed: pañcannam gatīnam aññatarāya kathanam upagacchati tena iva āha na īrayikā iti vāpe
translated: because those determinations of action are not abandoned in the aforementioned way. “He takes up a view about destiny” means he takes up the assertion of one of the five destinies. Therefore it is said: “He takes up a view about destiny, saying: ‘I will be after death, I will be not after death, I will be and will not be after death, I will neither be nor not be after death.’

original: vādaṃ upeti upagacchatī”ti. Vadeyyāti katheyya. Gahitaṃ natthīti gahetabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: vādam upeti upagacchati iti vadeyya ati katheyya gahitam na atthi iti gahetabbam na atthi
translated: He would say: he would tell. There is no holding: there is nothing to be held.

original: Muñcitabbaṃ natthīti muñcitvā ṭhitattā mocetabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: muñcitabbam na atthi iti muñcitvā ṭhita ttā mocetabbam na atthi
translated: There is no letting go: because he stands having let go, there is no letting go.

original: Yassatthi gahitanti yassa puggalassa “ahaṃ mamā”ti gahitaṃ atthi. Tassatthi muñcitabbanti
analyzed: yassa atthi gahitanti yassa puggalassa aham mama ati gahitam atthi tassa atthi muñcitabbanti
translated: There is letting go for one who holds:

original: tassa puggalassa mocetabbaṃ atthi. Upari padāni parivattetvā yojetabbāni. Gahaṇaṃ🔽muñcanā samatikkantoti gahaṇamocanā arahā atikkanto. Buddhiparihānivītivattoti vaḍḍhiñca🔽parihāniñca atikkamitvā pavatto. So vuṭṭhavāsotiādiṃ katvā ñāṇagginā daḍḍhānīti pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: tassa puggalassa mocetabbam atthi upari padāni parivattetvā yojetabbāni gahaṇam  muñcanā samatikkantoti gahaṇa mocanā arahā atikkanto buddhi parihāni vīti vatto ti vaḍḍhim ca  parihāniñca atikkamitvā pavattaḥ so vuṭṭhavāsaḥ ti ādim katvā ñāṇa agginā daḍḍhāni iti pariyosānam
translated: there is letting go for that person. The above lines should be construed by reversing the order.🔽He has gone beyond holding and letting go: the Arahant has gone beyond holding and letting go. He has gone beyond increase and decrease: he has gone beyond increase and decrease.🔽He has burnt up the fuel of being, etc.: the meaning of this should be understood in the way already stated.

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Adhosīti kantesi. Dhuni sandhuni niddhunīti upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.🔽Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva adhosi iti kantesi dhuni sandhuni niddhuni iti upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam  saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: He has shaken off the dust: the word “dust” is a term for defilements.

original: Duṭṭhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: duṭṭhaṭṭhaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Sutta on the Wicked Death is finished.

original: 4. Suddhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 4. The Fourfold Purity

original: 23. Catutthe suddhaṭṭhake paṭhamagāthāya tāvattho – na, bhikkhave, evarūpena dassanena
analyzed: catutthe suddhaṭṭhake paṭhama gāthāya tāvatthaḥ na bhikkhave evarūpena dassanena
translated: In the fourth group, the first stanza means: “Monks, purity is not to be found in such a view.

original: suddhi hoti, api ca kho kilesamalīnattā asuddhaṃ, kilesarogānaṃ adhigamā sarogameva
analyzed: suddhi hoti api ca kho asuddham kilesa rogāṇam adhigamā sa rogam eva
translated: On the contrary, it is impure because of being defiled by defilements, and it is sick because of the sickness of defilements.

original: candābhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ, aññaṃ vā evarūpaṃ disvā diṭṭhigatiko bālo abhijānāti “passāmi
analyzed: canda ābham brāhmaṇam aññam vā evarūpam disvā diṭṭhi gatikaḥ bālaḥ abhijānāti passāmi
translated: Having seen a brahmin who is radiant, or anyone else of such a kind, the fool who is a victim of views thinks: ‘I see

original: suddhaṃ paramaṃ arogaṃ, tena ca diṭṭhisaṅkhātena dassanena saṃsuddhi narassa hotī”ti,
analyzed: suddham paramam arogam tena ca diṭṭhi saṅkhātena dassanena saṃsuddhi narassa hoti iti
translated: a pure, supreme, and healthy person. And by that view which is called a view, a man’s purity is accomplished.’

original: so evaṃ abhijānanto taṃ dassanaṃ “parama”nti ñatvā tasmiṃ dassane suddhānupassī samāno
analyzed: saḥ evam abhijānantaḥ tam dassanam paramanti ñatvā tasmin dassane suddha anupassī samānaḥ
translated: Thinking thus, he knows that view to be ‘supreme.’ Contemplating that view as pure,

original: taṃ dassanaṃ “maggañāṇa”nti pacceti. Taṃ pana maggañāṇaṃ na hoti.
analyzed: tam dassanam magga ñāṇanti pacceti tam pana magga ñāṇam na hoti
translated: he accepts that view as ‘knowledge of the path.’ But that is not knowledge of the path.

original: Paramaṃ ārogyappattanti uttamaṃ nibyādhiṃ pāpuṇitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tāṇappattanti tathā pālanappattaṃ.
analyzed: paramam uttamam nibyādhim pāpuṇitvā ṭhitam tāṇa ppattanti tathā pālana ppattam
translated: Having attained supreme health, he stands having reached the highest state of being free from disease. Having attained protection, he has reached such protection.

original: Leṇappattanti nilīyanappattaṃ.Saraṇappattanti patiṭṭhāpattaṃ, dukkhanāsanaṃ vā pattaṃ.
analyzed: leṇa pattanti nilīyana pattaṃsaraṇa pattanti patiṭṭhā pattam dukkha nāsanam vā pattam
translated: “He has reached the cave” : he has reached the cave of seclusion. “He has reached the refuge” : he has reached the refuge of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha, or he has reached the state of being a refuge for others, or he has reached the state of being a refuge for himself.

original: Abhayappattanti nibbhayabhāvappattaṃ. Accutappattanti niccalabhāvaṃ pattaṃ. Amatappattanti
analyzed: abhaya ppattanti nibbhaya bhāva ppattam accuta ppattanti niccala bhāvam pattam amata ppattanti
translated: “He has reached the state of fearlessness” : he has reached the state of being fearless. “He has reached the state of being unshakable” : he has reached the state of being unshakable. “He has reached the deathless” : he has reached the deathless state of Nibbāna.

original: amataṃ mahānibbānaṃ pattaṃ. Nibbānappattanti vānavirahitaṃ pattaṃ.
analyzed: amatam mahānibbānam pattam nibbāna ppattanti vāna virahitam pattam
translated: “He has reached Nibbāna” : he has reached the state of being free from bondage.

original: Abhijānantoti visesena jānanto. Ājānantoti ājānamāno. Vijānantoti anekavidhena jānamāno. Paṭivijānantoti taṃ taṃ paṭicca vijānamāno. Paṭivijjhantoti hadaye kurumāno.
analyzed: abhijānantaḥ iti visesena jānantaḥ ājānantaḥ iti ājānamānaḥ vijānantaḥ iti anekavidhena jānamānaḥ paṭivijānantaḥ iti tam tam paṭicca vijānamānaḥ paṭivijjhantaḥ iti hadaye kurumānaḥ
translated: “He remembers” : he remembers by means of the knowledge of recollection. “He understands” : he understands by means of the knowledge of comprehension. “He is fully aware” : he is fully aware by means of the knowledge of full awareness. “He penetrates” : he penetrates by means of the knowledge of penetration.

original: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ rūpadassanenāti cakkhuviññāṇena rūpadassanaṃ. Ñāṇanti paccetīti paññā
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam rūpa dassanena ati cakkhu viññāṇena rūpa dassanam ñāṇam ti pacceti iti paññā
translated: “Eye-consciousness and visible form” : eye-consciousness and visible form. “He knows” : he knows by means of the knowledge of understanding.

original: iti saddahati. Maggoti paccetīti “upāyo”ti saddahati. Pathoti sañcāro. Nīyānanti🔽gahetvā yātīti nīyānaṃ. “Niyyāna”nti vā pāṭho.
analyzed: iti saddahati maggo ti pacceti iti upāyaḥ iti saddahati patho ti sañcāraḥ 🔽yāti iti vā
translated: “He has confidence” : he has confidence by means of the knowledge of confidence. “He has a keen sense of conscience” : he has a keen sense of conscience by means of the knowledge of conscience. “He has a keen sense of shame” : he has a keen sense of shame by means of the knowledge of shame.🔽“He has attained” : he has attained by means of the knowledge of attainment. “He has realized” : he has realized by means of the knowledge of realization. “He has comprehended” : he has comprehended by means of the knowledge of comprehension. “He has fully understood” : he has fully understood by means of the knowledge of full understanding.🔽“He has crossed over and gone beyond” : he has crossed over and gone beyond by means of the knowledge of crossing over and going beyond. “He has directly known” : he has directly known by means of the knowledge of direct knowledge. “He has fully understood” : he has fully understood by means of the knowledge of full understanding. “He has abandoned” : he has abandoned by means of the knowledge of abandoning. “He has realized” : he has realized by means of the knowledge of realization. “He has developed” : he has developed by means of the knowledge of development.

original: 24. “Diṭṭhena ce suddhī”ti dutiyagāthā. Tassattho – tena rūpadassanasaṅkhātena diṭṭhena
analyzed: diṭṭhena ce suddhi iti dutiya gāthā tassa atthaḥ tena rūpa dassana saṅkhātena diṭṭhena
translated: If by the seen, by that which is called the seeing of materiality,

original: yadi kilesasuddhi narassa hoti, tena vā ñāṇena so yadi jātiādidukkhaṃ pajahāti, evaṃ🔽sante ariyamaggato aññena asuddhimaggeneva so sujjhati, rāgādīhi upadhīhi saupadhiko🔽eva samāno sujjhatīti vattabbataṃ āpanno hoti, na ca evaṃvidho sujjhati. Tasmā diṭṭhī
analyzed: yadi kilesa suddhi narassa hoti tena vā ñāṇena saḥ yadi jāti ādi dukkham pajahāti evam  sante ariya maggataḥ aññena asuddhi maggena iva so sujjhati rāga ādīhi upadhīhi sa aupadhikaḥ  eva samānaḥ sujjhati iti vattabbatam āpannaḥ hoti na ca evaṃvidhaḥ sujjhati tasmā diṭṭhī
translated: a man’s defilements are purified, or if by that knowledge he abandons the suffering of birth, etc.,🔽then he is purified by a path that is not the noble path, and he comes to be one who should be called “purified while still possessed of attachments by lust, etc.,🔽but he is not purified in this way. Therefore,

original: hi naṃ pāva tathā vadānaṃ, sā naṃ diṭṭhiyeva “micchādiṭṭhiko aya”nti katheti, diṭṭhianurūpaṃ
analyzed: hi nam pāva tathā vadānam sā nam diṭṭhiyā iva micchādiṭṭhikaḥ ayanti kathā iti diṭṭhi anurūpam
translated: the view that he is purified by the seen,

original: “sassato loko”tiādinā nayena tathā tathā vadatīti.
analyzed: lokaḥ uti ādinā nayena tathā tathā vadati iti
translated: the view itself declares him to be “one of right view” .

original: Rāgena saha vattatīti sarāgo, rāgavāti attho. Sadosotiādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽25. Na brāhmaṇoti tatiyagāthā. Tassattho – yo pana bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇo hoti, so
analyzed: rāgena saha vattati iti sa rāgaḥ rāgavā ati attho sa dosaḥ ti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ 🔽na brāhmaṇaḥ ti tatiya gāthā tassa atthaḥ yaḥ pana bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇaḥ hoti so
translated: He is accompanied by lust because he goes about with lust. The same method applies in the case of hate, etc.

original: maggena adhigatāsavakkhayo khīṇāsavabrāhmaṇo ariyamaggañāṇato aññena abhimaṅgalasammatarūpasaṅkhāte🔽diṭṭhe, tathāvidhasaddasaṅkhāte sute, avītikkamasaṅkhāte sīle, hatthivatādibhede
analyzed: maggena adhigata āsava kkhayaḥ khīṇāsava brāhmaṇaḥ ariya magga ñāṇataḥ aññena abhimaṅgala sammata rūpa saṅkhāte  diṭṭhe tathāvidha sadda saṅkhāte sute avītikkama saṅkhāte sīle hatthivata ādi bhede
translated: The destruction of cankers by the path is the brahmin who has destroyed cankers. He does not claim purity by means of the visible form called “auspicious signs” that are accepted as such by the noble path knowledge,🔽and likewise by means of the sound called “the sound of a drum” , by means of virtue called “non-transgression” , by means of the wind called “elephant-tusk” ,

original: vate, pathaviādibhede mute ca uppannena micchāñāṇena suddhiṃ na āhāti. Sesamassa
analyzed: vate pathavi ādi bhede mute ca uppannena micchā ñāṇena suddhim na āha ati sesamassa
translated: and by means of the earth called “elephant’s footprint” .

original: brāhmaṇassa vaṇṇabhaṇanāya vuttaṃ. So hi tedhātukapuññe sabbasmiñca pāpe anūpalitto,
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa vaṇṇa bhaṇanāya vuttam saḥ hi tedhātuka puññe sabbasmin ca pāpe an upalittaḥ
translated: The rest is said for the praise of that brahmin. He is untainted by any merit in the three worlds and by any evil.🔽Why? Because of the abandoning of that, of the view of self, or of the grasping of anything as “mine.”

original: kasmā? Tassa pahīnattā tassa attadiṭṭhiyā, yassa kassaci vā gahaṇassa pahīnattā attañjaho,
analyzed: kasmā tassa pahīna ttā tassa attadiṭṭhiyā yassa kassaci vā gahaṇassa pahīna ttā
translated: He is called “one who has renounced self” because he has abandoned the view of self and the grasping of anything as “mine.”

original: puññābhisaṅkhārādīnaṃ akaraṇato “nayidha pakubbamāno”ti vuccati. Tasmā naṃ evaṃ pasaṃsanto
analyzed: puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīnam a karaṇataḥ na yidha pakubbamānaḥ iti vuccati tasmā nam evam pasaṃsantaḥ
translated: He is called “one who does not make here” because he does not make merit, etc. Therefore, praising him thus,🔽the Blessed One said: “Untainted by merit or evil,

original: āha. Sabbasseva cassa purimapādena sambandho veditabbo – puññe ca pāpe ca anūpalitto
analyzed: āha sabbassa iva ca ssa purima pādena sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ puññe ca pāpe ca an upalittaḥ
translated: he is untainted by anything in the three worlds.”

original: attañjaho nayidha pakubbamāno na brāhmaṇo aññato suddhimāhāti. Nāti paṭikkhepoti na iti paṭisedho.
analyzed: attañjahaḥ nayidha pakubbamānaḥ na brāhmaṇaḥ aññatas suddhim āha ati na ati paṭikkhepaḥ ti na iti paṭisedho
translated: Na iti paṭikkhepo = “I do not say so.”

original: Bāhitvā sabbapāpakānīti gāthāyattho – yo catutthamaggena bāhitvā sabbapāpakāni ṭhitatto
analyzed: bāhitvā sabba pāpakāni iti yaḥ catuttha maggena bāhitvā sabba pāpakāni ṭhita ttaḥ
translated: Bāhitvā sabbapāpakānīti gāthāyattho = Yo catutthamaggena bāhitvā sabbapāpakāni ṭhitatto

original: ṭhitoicceva vuttaṃ hoti. Bāhitapāpattā eva ca vimalo vimalabhāvaṃ brahmabhāvaṃ seṭṭhabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti eva ca vimalaḥ vimala bhāvam brahma bhāvam seṭṭha bhāvam
translated: ṭhitoicceva vuttaṃ hoti. Bāhitapāpattā eva ca vimalo vimalabhāvaṃ brahmabhāvaṃ seṭṭhabhāvaṃ

original: patto, paṭinissaṭṭhasamādhivikkhepakarakilesamalena aggamaggaphalasamādhinā sādhusamāhito,
analyzed: patto paṭinissaṭṭha samādhi vikkhepa kara kilesa malena agga magga phala samādhinā sādhu samāhitaḥ
translated: patto, paṭinissaṭṭhasamādhivikkhepakarakilesamalena aggamaggaphalasamādhinā sādhusamāhito,

original: saṃsārahetusamatikkamena saṃsāramaticca pariniṭṭhitakiccatāya kevalīti ca, taṇhādiṭṭhīhi
analyzed: saṃsāra hetu samatikkamena pariniṭṭhita kicca tāya kevalī iti ca taṇhā diṭṭhīhi
translated: saṃsārahetusamatikkamena saṃsāramaticca pariniṭṭhitakiccatāya kevalīti ca, taṇhādiṭṭhīhi

original: anissitattā anissitoti ca, lokadhammehi nibbikārattā tādīti ca pavuccati. Evaṃ thutiraho
analyzed: anissita ttā anissitaḥ ti ca loka dhammehi nibbikāra ttā tādī iti ca pavuccati evam thuti raho
translated: anissitattā anissitoti ca, lokadhammehi nibbikārattā tādīti ca pavuccati. Evaṃ thutiraho

original: sa brahmā so brāhmaṇoti.
analyzed: sa brahmā saḥ brāhmaṇa uti
translated: sa brahmā so brāhmaṇoti.

original: Aññatra satipaṭṭhānehīti cattāro satipaṭṭhāne muñcitvā. Sammappadhānādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: aññatra sati paṭṭhānehi iti cattāraḥ sati paṭṭhāne muñcitvā sammappadhāna ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: Aññatra satipaṭṭhānehīti cattāro satipaṭṭhāne muñcitvā. Sammappadhānādīsupi eseva nayo.

original: Santeke samaṇabrāhmaṇāti ekacce lokasaṅketena “samaṇabrāhmaṇā”ti laddhavohārā saṃvijjanti.
analyzed: santi ike samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati ekacce loka saṅketena samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati laddha vohārā saṃvijjanti
translated: ‘Some ascetics and Brahmins’: some who are called ‘ascetics and Brahmins’ by common consent.

original: Diṭṭhasuddhikāti diṭṭhena suddhiṃ icchamānā. Te ekaccānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassananti ete
analyzed: diṭṭhasuddhikā ati diṭṭhena suddhim icchamānā te ekaccānam rūpānam ete
translated: ‘Purity through seeing’: they desire purity through seeing. ‘Of some visible objects’:

original: diṭṭhasuddhikā etesaṃ rūpārammaṇānaṃ olokanaṃ. Maṅgalaṃ paccentīti iddhikāraṇaṃ buddhikāraṇaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhasuddhikāḥ etesam rūpa ārammaṇānaṃ olokanam maṅgalam paccenti iti iddhi kāraṇam buddhi kāraṇam
translated: of these objects with visible data as their object. ‘They make merit’: they establish a cause for success, a cause for wisdom,

original: sabbasampattikāraṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpenti. Amaṅgalaṃ paccentīti aniddhikāraṇaṃ na buddhikāraṇaṃ
analyzed: sabba sampatti kāraṇam patiṭṭhāpenti amaṅgalam paccenti iti aniddhi kāraṇam na buddhi kāraṇam
translated: a cause for all kinds of prosperity. ‘They make demerit’: they establish a cause for failure, a cause for lack of wisdom,

original: na sampattikāraṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpenti. Te kālato vuṭṭhahitvāti ete diṭṭhādimaṅgalikā puretarameva🔽uṭṭhahitvā. Abhimaṅgalagatānīti visesena vuḍḍhikāraṇagatāni. Rūpāni passantīti nānāvidhāni
analyzed: na sampatti kāraṇam patiṭṭhāpenti te kālataḥ vuṭṭhahitvā ati ete diṭṭha ādi maṅgalikā puretaram eva  uṭṭhahitvā abhimaṅgala gatāni iti visesena vuḍḍhi kāraṇa gatāni rūpāni passanti iti nānāvidhāni
translated: a cause for lack of prosperity. ‘When they have got up at the proper time’: these people who make merit and demerit through seeing, etc., get up early in the morning.

original: rūpārammaṇāni dakkhanti. Cāṭakasakuṇanti evaṃnāmakaṃ. Phussaveḷuvalaṭṭhinti phussanakkhattena
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇāni dakkhanti cāṭaka sakuṇanti evaṃnāmakam phussa veḷu valaṭṭhinti phussa nakkhattena
translated: ‘To go to the auspicious’: to go to what is a cause for distinction. ‘They see visible objects’: they will see various objects with visible data as their object. ‘The bird called the cāṭaka’: one called by that name. ‘The bamboo of the Phussā constellation’:

original: uppannaṃ taruṇabeḷuvalaṭṭhiṃ. Gabbhinitthinti sagabbhaṃ itthiṃ. Kumārakaṃ khandhe
analyzed: uppannam taruṇa beḷu valaṭṭhim sa gabbham itthim kumārakam khandhe
translated: a young bamboo-shoot. A woman with child: a woman who is pregnant. A boy or a girl:🔽

original: āropetvā gacchantanti taruṇadārakaṃ aṃse ussāpetvā gacchamānaṃ. Puṇṇaghaṭanti udakapuṇṇaghaṭaṃ.
analyzed: āropetvā taruṇa dārakam aṃse ussāpetvā gacchamānam puṇṇa ghaṭanti udaka puṇṇa ghaṭam
translated: A young woman with child: a pregnant woman. Carrying a boy on her hip: carrying a young boy on her shoulder. A water-pot: a pot full of water.

original: Rohitamacchanti rattarohitamacchaṃ. Ājaññarathanti sindhavayuttarathaṃ. Usabhanti🔽maṅgalausabhaṃ. Gokapilanti kapilagāviṃ.
analyzed: rohitam acchanti rattarohitam accham ājaññarathanti sindhavayuttaratham usabhanti  maṅgalausabham kapilagāvim
translated: Red mullet: red mullet of the night. A chariot with a pair of Ajanas: a chariot yoked with a pair of Ajanas. A bull:🔽a lucky bull. A tawny cow: a tawny cow.

original: Palālapuñjanti thusarāsiṃ. Takkaghaṭanti gotakkādipūritacāṭiṃ. Rittaghaṭanti tucchaghaṭaṃ.
analyzed: palāla puñjanti thusarāsim takka ghaṭanti go takka ādi pūrita cāṭim ritta ghaṭanti tuccha ghaṭam
translated: A bundle of straw: a heap of straw. A magic pot: a pot filled with magic spells. An empty pot: a pot without water.

original: Naṭanti naṭakādiṃ. “Dhuttakiriya”nti eke. Naggasamaṇakanti niccoḷasamaṇaṃ. Kharanti🔽gadrabhaṃ. Kharayānanti gadrabhayuttaṃ vayhādikaṃ. Ekayuttayānanti ekena vāhanena
analyzed: naṭanti naṭaka ādim eke nagga samaṇakanti niccoḷa samaṇam kharanti  gadrabham khara yānanti gadrabha yuttam vayha ādikam eka yutta yānanti ekena vāhanena
translated: An actor: a dancer, etc. “A dhuttakiriya” is according to some. A naked ascetic: a permanent-rag-wearer ascetic. A donkey:

original: saṃyuttaṃ yānaṃ. Kāṇanti ekakkhiubhayakkhikāṇaṃ. Kuṇinti hatthakuṇiṃ. Khañjanti khañjapādaṃ
analyzed: saṃyuttam yānam kāṇanti kuṇinti hattha kuṇim khañjanti khañja pādam
translated: a mule. A donkey-cart: a cart drawn by a mule, etc. A two-wheeled cart: a cart yoked with one animal. A one-eyed man: a man with one eye or both eyes blind. A cripple: a man with a crippled hand.

original: tiriyagatapādaṃ. Pakkhahatanti pīṭhasappiṃ. Jiṇṇakanti jarājiṇṇaṃ. Byādhikanti byādhipīḷitaṃ. Matanti kālaṅkataṃ.
analyzed: tiriya gata pādam pakkhahatanti pīṭhasappim jiṇṇakanti jarā jiṇṇam byādhikanti byādhi pīḷitam matanti kālaṅkatam
translated: ‘One who has gone to the other side’ is one who has gone to the other side of the ocean. ‘One who has crossed over’ is one who has crossed over the ocean. ‘One who has gone beyond’ is one who has gone beyond the ocean. ‘One who has gone far’ is one who has gone far into the ocean. ‘One who has gone to the further shore’ is one who has gone to the further shore of the ocean. ‘One who has gone to the other side of the foot’ is one who has gone to the other side of the foot of the ocean. ‘One who has flown away’ is a snake. ‘One who is old’ is one who is old with age. ‘One who is sick’ is one who is afflicted with illness. ‘One who is dead’ is one who has died.

original: Sutasuddhikāti sotaviññāṇena sutena suddhiṃ icchamānā. Saddānaṃ savananti saddārammaṇānaṃ
analyzed: suta suddhikā ati sota viññāṇena sutena suddhim icchamānā saddānam savanan ti sadda ārammaṇānam
translated: ‘One who desires purification by hearing’ is one who desires purification by hearing with ear-consciousness. ‘Hearing sounds’ is hearing the objects of sound.

original: savanaṃ. Vaḍḍhāti vātiādayo loke pavattasaddamattāni gahetvā vuttā. Amaṅgalaṃ pana
analyzed: savanam vaḍḍhāti vāti ādayaḥ loke gahetvā vuttāḥ amaṅgalam pana
translated: ‘Increase’ is said by taking the mere sounds that occur in the world such as ‘wind’ and so on. But inauspicious

original: “kāṇo”tiādinā tena tena nāmena vuttasaddāyeva. “Chinda”nti vāti hatthapādādicchinnanti
analyzed: kāṇa uti ādinā tena tena nāmena vutta saddāya iva chindanti vā
translated: sounds are those that are spoken by name such as ‘one-eyed’ and so on. ‘Cut’ is said by cutting off hands, feet, and so on.

original: vā. “Bhinda”nti vāti sīsādibhinnanti vā. “Daḍḍha”nti vāti agginā jhāpitanti vā. “Naṭṭha”nti
analyzed: vā bhindanti vā ati sīsa ādi bhinnanti vā daḍḍhanti vā ati agginā jhāpitanti vā naṭṭhanti
translated: ‘Split’ is said by splitting the head and so on. ‘Burnt’ is said by burning with fire. ‘Destroyed’

original: vāti corādīhi vināsitanti vā. “Natthī”ti vāti na vijjatīti vā.
analyzed: vāti cora ādīhi vā natthi iti vāti na vijjati iti vā
translated: is said by being destroyed by thieves and so on. ‘Non-existent’ is said by not existing.

original: Sīlasuddhikāti sīlena visuddhiṃ icchanakā. Sīlamattenāti saṃvaraṇamattena. Saṃyamamattenāti
analyzed: sīla suddhikā ati sīlena visuddhim icchanakā sīla mattena ati saṃvaraṇa mattena saṃyama mattena ati
translated: ‘One who desires purification by virtue’ is one who desires purification by virtue. ‘By virtue alone’ is by restraint alone. ‘By restraint alone’ is by restraint alone.

original: uparamamattena. Saṃvaramattenāti dvārathakanamattena. Avītikkamamattenāti na atikkamitamattena.
analyzed: uparama mattena saṃvara mattena ati dvārathakana mattena avītikkama mattena ati na atikkamita mattena
translated: By the mere restraint, by the mere gate-keeping. By the mere non-transgression, by the mere non-doing.

original: Samaṇo muṇḍikāputtoti mātito laddhanāmaṃ. Sampannakusalanti paripuṇṇakusalaṃ. Paramakusalanti
analyzed: samaṇaḥ muṇḍikā putto ti mātitaḥ laddha nāmam sampanna kusalanti paripuṇṇa kusalam parama kusalanti
translated: The ascetic Muṇḍiya: the name he received from his mother. Accomplished in good: complete in good. Supremely good:

original: uttamakusalaṃ. Uttamapattippattanti uttamaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇitabbataṃ patvā ṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: uttama kusalam uttama patti pattanti uttamam arahattam pāpuṇitabba tam patvā ṭhitam
translated: supremely good. Attained the supreme attainment: having attained the state of being able to attain the supreme state of Arahantship, he remained there.

original: Ayojjanti parājetuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ samaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ayojjanti parājetum a sakkuṇeyyam samaṇam
translated: The unconquered: the ascetic who is unable to be defeated.

original: Vatasuddhikāti samādānena vatena suddhiṃ icchanakā. Hatthivatikā vāti samādinnaṃ
analyzed: vata suddhikā ati samādānena vatena suddhim icchanakā hatthi vatikā vāti samādinnam
translated: The pure in virtue: those who desire purification by virtue through undertaking. The elephant-drivers: those who have undertaken

original: hatthivataṃ etesaṃ atthīti hatthivatikā, sabbahatthikiriyaṃ karontīti attho. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: hatthi vatam etesam atthi iti hatthivatikā sabba hatthi kiriyam karonti iti attho katham
translated: the elephant-duty. The meaning is: they do all the duties of an elephant. How?

original: “Ajja paṭṭhāya hatthīhi kātabbaṃ karissāmī”ti evaṃ uppannacittā hatthīnaṃ gamanākāraṃ
analyzed: ajja paṭṭhāya hatthīhi kātabbam karissāmi iti evam uppanna cittā hatthīnam gamana ākāram
translated: “From today onwards I will do what is to be done by elephants,” having given rise to this thought, they imitate the elephant’s way of going,

original: tiṭṭhanākāraṃ nisīdanākāraṃ sayanākāraṃ uccārapassāvakaraṇākāraṃ, aññe hatthī disvā
analyzed: tiṭṭhana ākāram nisīdana ākāram sayana ākāram uccāra passāva karaṇa ākāram aññe hatthī disvā
translated: its way of standing, its way of sitting, its way of lying down, its way of defecating and urinating, and having seen other elephants

original: soṇḍaṃ ussāpetvā gamanākārañca sabbaṃ karontīti hatthivatikā. Assavatikādīsupi labbhamānavasena🔽yathāyogaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Tesu avasāne disāvatikā vāti puratthimādidisānaṃ namassanavasena🔽samādinnadisāvatikā, etesaṃ vuttappakārānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ vatasamādānaṃ sampajjamānaṃ
analyzed: soṇḍam ussāpetvā gamana ākāram ca sabbam karonti iti hatthivatikā assavatikā ādīsu pi labbhamāna vasena  yathāyogam yojetabbam tesu avasāne disāvatikā vāti puratthima ādi disānam namassana vasena  samādinna disāvatikā etesam vutta ppakārānam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam vata samādānam sampajjamānam
translated: and they go about with their trunks held up.🔽The rest should be construed in the appropriate way according to the meaning.🔽Among them, the last are called “those who live looking to the directions” because they undertake the directions of east, etc., by paying homage to them.🔽The undertaking of the various kinds of virtue by these recluses and brahmins is called “the undertaking of virtue that is limited” because it is limited by time, etc.,🔽

original: hatthiādīnaṃ sahabyataṃ upaneti. Sace kho panassa micchādiṭṭhi hoti “imināhaṃ sīlavatasamādānabrahmacariyena
analyzed: hatthi ādīnam sahabyatam upaneti sace kho panassa micchādiṭṭhi hoti iminā aham sīlavata samādāna brahmacariyena
translated: and they go about with their trunks held high. The elephant-like are those who do so. The horse-like, etc., should be construed in the same way as the elephant-like, taking the word “horse” , etc., in each case. Among these, the last are the direction-followers. They are those who have undertaken the direction-observance by paying homage to the eastern direction, etc. The undertaking of the observance of the various kinds of virtue by these recluses and brahmins leads to rebirth in the company of the elephants, etc.

original: devo vā devaññataro vā homī”ti cintayantassa nirayatiracchānayonīnaṃ aññataro hotīti
analyzed: devaḥ vā devaññataraḥ vā homi iti cintayantassa niraya tiracchāna yonīnam aññataraḥ hoti iti
translated: But if they have a wrong view, thinking “By this virtue I shall become a god or some other being,” then they should be understood to be reborn in hell or as an animal.

original: ñātabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: ñātabbam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Idha, puṇṇa, ekacco kukkuravataṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurasīlaṃ bhāveti
analyzed: idha puṇṇaḥ ekaccaḥ kukkuravatam bhāveti paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura sīlam bhāveti
translated: “Here, Punna, someone cultivates the elephant-like virtue, he cultivates the horse-like virtue, he cultivates the ram-like virtue, he cultivates the dog-like virtue, he cultivates the jackal-like virtue.

original: paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkuracittaṃ bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurākappaṃ
analyzed: paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura cittam bhāveti paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura ākappam
translated: He cultivates a contracted mind, he cultivates an distracted mind, he cultivates an unpurified mind, he cultivates an undeveloped mind.

original: bhāveti paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ. So kukkuravataṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurasīlaṃ🔽bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkuracittaṃ bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ, kukkurākappaṃ
analyzed: bhāveti paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam saḥ kukkuravatam bhāvetvā paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura sīlam  bhāvetvā paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura cittam bhāvetvā paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kukkura ākappam
translated: He develops it, makes it his own, makes it familiar, keeps it up, and consolidates it. When he has done this, then as a result of his deeds he is reborn among dogs.🔽He develops the dog-like virtue, the dog-like mind, and the dog-like view.

original: bhāvetvā paripuṇṇaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kukkurānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.🔽Sace kho panassa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena
analyzed: bhāvetvā paripuṇṇam abbokiṇṇam kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā kukkurānam sahabyatam upapajjati  sace kho panassa evaṃdiṭṭhi hoti iminā aham sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena
translated: When he has done this, then as a result of his deeds he is reborn among dogs.

original: vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhissa
analyzed: vā devaḥ vā bhavissāmi devaññataraḥ vā ati sā assa hoti micchādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhissa
translated: But if he has the view that by this virtue or duty or austerity or holy life I will become a god or some other being, this is his wrong view.

original: kho ahaṃ, puṇṇa, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ
analyzed: kho aham puṇṇa dvinnam gatīnam aññataram gatim vadāmi nirayam vā tiracchānayonim
translated: I say that this wrong view of his leads to one of two destinies: to hell or to rebirth as an animal.

original: vā. Iti kho, puṇṇa, sampajjamānaṃ kukkuravataṃ kukkurānaṃ sahabyataṃ upaneti, vipajjamānaṃ niraya”nti.
analyzed: vā iti khalu puṇṇa sampajjamānam kukkuravatam kukkurānam sahabyatam upaneti vipajjamānam nirayanti
translated: Thus, Punna, when the dog-like life is successful, it leads to rebirth as an animal, and when it fails, to hell.”

original: Gandhabbavatikādayo gandhabbādīnaṃ sahabyataṃ upagacchantīti attho na gahetabbo, micchādiṭṭhiyā gahitattā nirayatiracchānayonimeva upagacchantīti gahetabbo.🔽Mutasuddhikāti phusitena suddhikā. Pathaviṃ āmasantīti sasambhārikaṃ mahāpathaviṃ🔽kāyena phusanti. Haritanti allanīlasaddalaṃ. Gomayanti gavādigomayaṃ. Kacchapanti🔽aṭṭhikacchapādianekavidhaṃ. Phālaṃ akkamantīti ayaphālaṃ maddanti. Tilavāhanti tilasakaṭaṃ🔽tilarāsiṃ vā. Phussatilaṃ khādantīti maṅgalapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ tilaṃ khādanti. Phussatelaṃ
analyzed: gandhabbavatikā ādayaḥ gandhabba ādīnam sahabyatam upagacchanti iti atthaḥ na gahetabbaḥ micchādiṭṭhiyāḥ gahita ttā niraya tiracchāna yonim eva upagacchanti iti gahetabbaḥ  muta suddhikā ati phusitena suddhikā pathavim āmasanti iti sa sambhārikam mahā pathavim  kāyena phusanti alla nīla sat dalam gomayanti go ādi gomayam  aṭṭhi kacchapa ādi anekavidham phālam akkamanti iti aya phālam maddanti tila vāhanti tila sakaṭam  tila rāsim vā phussa tilam khādanti iti maṅgala paṭisaṃyuttam tilam khādanti phussa telam
translated: The meaning that the Gandhabbavatika, etc., go to the company of gandhabbas, etc., should not be taken; the meaning that they go to hell and to the animal world should be taken, since they are held by wrong view.

original: makkhentīti tathārūpaṃ tilatelaṃ sarīrabbhañjanaṃ karonti. Dantakaṭṭhanti dantapoṇaṃ.
analyzed: makkhenti iti tathārūpam tila telam sarīra bbhañjanam karonti danta kaṭṭhanti danta poṇam
translated: ‘Purity by touching’: purity by touching the earth. ‘They touch the earth’: they touch the earth with its furniture. ‘Green grass’: soft green grass. ‘Cow-dung’: cow-dung from cows, etc. ‘Tortoise’: a tortoise, etc., of various kinds. ‘They tread on the plough’: they tread on the iron plough. ‘Sesame’: a cartload of sesame, or a heap of sesame. ‘They eat sesame’: they eat sesame connected with auspiciousness. ‘They anoint themselves with sesame oil’: they anoint their bodies with such sesame oil as is used for rubbing the body. ‘Tooth wood’: tooth cleansing wood.

original: Mattikāya nhāyantīti kuṅkuṭṭhādikāya saṇhamattikāya sarīraṃ ubbaṭṭetvā nhāyanti.
analyzed: mattikāya nhāyanti iti kuṅkuṭṭha ādikāya saṇha mattikāya sarīram ubbaṭṭetvā nhāyanti
translated: ‘They bathe with clay’: they bathe after smearing their bodies with soft clay such as is found in a pond, etc.

original: Sāṭakaṃ nivāsentīti maṅgalapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ vatthaṃ paridahanti. Veṭhanaṃ veṭhentīti
analyzed: sāṭakam nivāsenti iti maṅgala paṭisaṃyuttam vattham paridahanti veṭhanam veṭhenti iti
translated: She puts on a sarong: she puts on a piece of cloth connected with a festival. She puts on a head-dress:

original: sīsaveṭhanaṃ pattuṇṇādipaṭaṃ sīse ṭhapenti paṭimuccanti.
analyzed: sīsa veṭhanam pattuṇṇa ādi paṭam sīse ṭhapenti paṭimuccanti
translated: she puts on a head-cloth, a turban, etc., on her head.

original: Tedhātukaṃ kusalābhisaṅkhāranti kāmadhāturūpadhātuarūpadhātūsu paṭisandhidāyakaṃ🔽kosallasambhūtaṃ paccayābhisaṅkhāraṃ. Sabbaṃ akusalanti dvādasavidhaṃ akosallasambhūtaṃ
analyzed: tedhātukam kāmadhātu rūpadhātu arūpadhātūsu paṭisandhi dāyakam  kosalla sambhūtam paccaya abhisaṅkhāram sabbam akusalanti dvādasavidham akosalla sambhūtam
translated: The three elements are the profitable formations: the profitable formations that give rebirth-linking in the sense-desire element, the material-form element, and the immaterial element,🔽which are produced by skill. All unprofitable : the twelve kinds of unprofitable formations,

original: akusalaṃ. Yatoti yadā. Te dasavidho puññābhisaṅkhāro ca, dvādasavidho apuññābhisaṅkhāro
analyzed: akusalam yato ti yadā te dasavidho puñña abhisaṅkhāro ca dvādasavidho apuñña abhisaṅkhāro
translated: which are produced by unskill. When: at the time when. These ten kinds of profitable formations, twelve kinds of unprofitable formations,

original: ca, catubbidho āneñjābhisaṅkhāro ca yathānurūpaṃ samucchedappahānena pahīnā honti.🔽Attadiṭṭhijahoti “eso me attā”ti gahitadiṭṭhiṃ jaho. Gāhaṃ jahoti “esohamasmī”ti
analyzed: ca catubbidhaḥ āneñja abhisaṅkhāro ca yathānurūpam samuccheda pahānena pahīnāḥ honti  atta diṭṭhi jahoti esaḥ me attā ati gahita diṭṭhim jaho gāham jahoti esaḥ aham asmi iti
translated: and four kinds of indeterminate formations are abandoned by the abandonment of the severance of the life-continuum.🔽He abandons the view of self: he abandons the view that has grasped “This is my self.” He abandons grasping: he abandons the grasping associated with the mind that has grasped “I am this.”

original: mānasampayuttagahaṇaṃ jaho. Puna attañjahoti “etaṃ mamā”ti taṇhāgahaṇavasena ca diṭṭhigahaṇavasena
analyzed: māna sampayutta gahaṇam puna etam mama ati taṇhā gahaṇa vasena ca diṭṭhi gahaṇa vasena
translated: He abandons self: he abandons the grasping due to craving and the grasping due to views that have grasped “This is mine.”

original: ca parāmasitvā gahitaṃ, parato āmaṭṭhañca, tasmiṃ abhiniviṭṭhañca, balavataṇhāvasena
analyzed: ca parāmasitvā gahitam paratas tasmin abhiniviṭṭham ca balava taṇhā vasena
translated: and what is clung to, what is grasped, what is seized upon, what is laid hold of, what is adhered to, what is obsessed by, what is clung to by the underlying tendency to conceit,

original: gilitvā ajjhositañca, balavamucchitañca. Sabbaṃ taṃ cattaṃ hotītiādayo vuttanayāyeva.🔽26. Evaṃ “na brāhmaṇo aññato suddhimāhā”ti vatvā idāni ye diṭṭhigatikā aññato suddhiṃ
analyzed: gilitvā ajjhositam ca balavam ucchitam ca sabbam tam cattam hoti iti ādayaḥ vutta nayāya iva  evam na brāhmaṇaḥ aññatas suddhim āha ati vatvā idāni ye diṭṭhigatikāḥ aññatas suddhim
translated: and what is clung to after being grasped at, what is chewed over from another, and what is obsessed with, and what is swallowed and adhered to through strong craving, and what is strongly desired. All that is rejected, and so on in the way already stated.🔽Having said, “The brahmans do not declare purity through another,” the Master now uttered the stanza, “Having abandoned the former,” in order to show that those who declare purity through another, and who are of speculative views,

original: bruvanti, tesaṃ tassā diṭṭhiyā anibbāhakabhāvaṃ dassento “purimaṃ pahāyā”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tassattho – tehi aññato suddhivādā samānāpi yassā diṭṭhiyā appahīnattā gahaṇamuñcanaṃ
analyzed: bruvanti tesam tassā diṭṭhiyāḥ anibbāhaka bhāvam dassento purimam pahāya iti gātham āha  tassa atthaḥ tehi aññatas suddhi vādā samānā api yassā diṭṭhiyāḥ a pahīna ttā gahaṇa muñcanam
translated: are not liberated through that view.

original: hoti, tāya purimaṃ satthārādiṃ pahāya aparaṃ nissitā, ejāsaṅkhātāya taṇhāya anugatā
analyzed: hoti tāya purimam satthārā ādim pahāya aparam nissitā ejā saṅkhātāya taṇhāya anugatā
translated: The meaning is this. Although they declare purity through another, they still have grasping and rejecting because they have not abandoned the view through which they do so. Having abandoned the former teacher, etc., they adhere to another, and they are followed by craving called “greed.”

original: abhibhūtā rāgādibhedaṃ na taranti saṅgaṃ, tañca atarantā taṃ taṃ dhammaṃ uggaṇhanti
analyzed: abhibhūtāḥ rāga ādi bhedam na taranti saṅgam tam ca a tarantā tam tam dhammaṃ uggaṇhanti
translated: They are overcome by it and do not cross the bog called lust, etc. Not crossing it, they learn the various doctrines

original: ca nirassajanti ca makkaṭova sākhanti.
analyzed: ca nirassajanti ca makkaṭā uva sākhanti
translated: and reject them, like a monkey who lets go of one branch to grasp another.

original: Purimaṃ satthāraṃ pahāyāti purimagahitaṃ satthupaṭiññaṃ vajjetvā. Paraṃ satthāraṃ nissitāti aññaṃ satthupaṭiññaṃ nissitā allīnā. Purimaṃ dhammakkhānaṃ pahāyātiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: purimam satthāram pahāya ati purima gahitam satthu paṭiññam vajjetvā param satthāram nissitā ati aññam satthu paṭiññam nissitā allīnā purimam dhamma kkhānam pahāya iti ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: Having abandoned the former teacher: having rejected the former teacher who was accepted. Relying on another teacher: relying on, depending on, another teacher who is accepted. Having abandoned the former doctrine: the same method applies here.

original: Ejānugāti taṇhāya anugā. Ejānugatāti taṇhāya anugatā. Ejānusaṭāti taṇhāya anusaṭā pakkhandā vā. Ejāya pannā patitāti taṇhāya nimuggā ca nikkhipitā ca.
analyzed: ejā anugā ati taṇhāya anugā ejā anugatā ati taṇhāya anugatā ejā anusaṭā ati taṇhāya anusaṭā pakkhandā vā ejāya pannā patitā ati taṇhāya nimuggā ca nikkhipitā ca
translated: Followed by craving: followed by craving. Craving-ridden: ridden with craving. Craving-ridden, craving-bound: craving-ridden, having plunged into craving. Craving-ridden, craving-ensnared: having sunk into craving and having been caught in it.

original: Makkaṭoti vānaro. Araññeti vipine. Pavaneti mahāvane. Caramānoti gacchamāno. Evamevāti
analyzed: makkaṭaḥ iti vānaraḥ araññe iti vipine pavane iti mahā vane caramānaḥ iti gacchamānaḥ evam eva ati
translated: Monkey: a monkey. Forest: a jungle. Wilderness: a great forest. Roaming: going. Thus:

original: opammasaṃsandanaṃ. Puthūti nānā. Puthudiṭṭhigatānīti nānāvidhāni diṭṭhigatāni. Gaṇhanti🔽ca muñcanti cāti gahaṇavasena gaṇhanti ca cajanavasena muñcanti ca. Ādiyanti ca nirassajanti
analyzed: opamma saṃsandanam puthu uti nānā puthu diṭṭhi gatāni iti nānāvidhāni diṭṭhi gatāni gaṇhanti  ca muñcanti ca ati gahaṇa vasena gaṇhanti ca cajana vasena muñcanti ca ādiyanti ca nirassajanti
translated: the application of the simile. Various: different. Various views: different kinds of views. They grasp🔽and they let go: they grasp by way of grasping and they let go by way of abandoning. They take up

original: cāti palibodhaṃ karonti ca vissajjenti ca khipanti ca.
analyzed: ca ati palibodham karonti ca vissajjenti ca khipanti ca
translated: and they give up: they make an obstacle and they give it up, they throw it away.

original: 27. Pañcamagāthāya ca sambandho – yo ca so “diṭṭhī hi naṃ pāva tathā vadāna”nti vutto,
analyzed: pañcama gāthāya ca sambandhaḥ yaḥ ca saḥ diṭṭhī hi nam pāva tathā vadānan ti vutto
translated: And the connection of the fifth stanza is this. He who was spoken of as “He who has views, he who speaks thus”🔽is the same as the one who is said to “take up” .

original: so sayaṃ samādāyāti. Tattha sayanti sāmaṃ. Samādāyāti gahetvā. Vatānīti hatthivatādīni.
analyzed: saḥ sayam samādāya ati tattha sayanti sāmam samādāya ati gahetvā vatāni iti hatthi vata ādīni
translated: Herein, sayam = sāmaṃ . Samādāya = gahetvā . Vatānī = having taken up vehicles, etc.

original: Uccāvacanti aparāparaṃ, hīnapaṇītaṃ vā satthārato satthārādiṃ. Saññasattoti kāmasaññādīsu🔽laggo. Vidvā ca vedehi samecca dhammanti paramatthavidvā ca arahā catūhi maggañāṇavedehi
analyzed: uccāvacanti apara aparam hīna paṇītam vā satthārataḥ satthāra ādim kāma saññā ādīsu  laggaḥ vidvā ca vedehi paramattha vidvā ca arahā catūhi magga ñāṇa vedehi
translated: Uccāvacanti aparāparaṃ , or inferior and superior, from teacher to teacher. Saññasatto = attached to perceptions of sensual desire, etc.🔽Vidvā ca vedehi samecca dhammanti and the Arahant who is a knower of the ultimate , having penetrated the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths with the four kinds of knowledge of the paths,

original: catusaccadhammaṃ abhisameccāti. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: catu sacca dhammam sesam pākaṭam eva
translated: Sesaṃ pākaṭameva .

original: Sāmaṃ samādāyāti sayameva gahetvā. Ādāyāti ādiyitvā gaṇhitvā. Samādāyāti sammā ādāya.
analyzed: sāmam samādāya ati sayam eva gahetvā ādāya ati ādiyitvā gaṇhitvā samādāya ati ādāya
translated: Sāmaṃ samādāya = having taken up by oneself. Ādāyāti = having taken up, having grasped. Samādāya = having taken up rightly.

original: Ādiyitvāti palibodhaṃ katvā. Samādiyitvāti sammā palibodhaṃ katvā. Gaṇhitvāti avissajjetvā.
analyzed: ādiyitvā ati palibodham katvā samādiyitvā ati sammā palibodham katvā gaṇhitvā ati a vissajjetvā
translated: Ādiyitvā = having made an obstacle. Samādiyitvā = having made a right obstacle. Gaṇhitvā = without letting go.

original: Parāmasitvāti dassitvā. Abhinivisitvāti patiṭṭhahitvā. Kāmasaññādayo vuttanayā eva.
analyzed: parāmasitvā ti dassitvā abhinivisitvā ati patiṭṭhahitvā kāma saññā ādayaḥ vutta nayāḥ eva
translated: Parāmasitvā = having shown. Abhinivisitvā = having established. The perceptions of sensual desire, etc., are as already stated .

original: Vidvāti medhāvī. Vijjāgatoti vijānanabhāvaṃ gato. Ñāṇīti paññāsampanno. Vibhāvīti
analyzed: vidvā iti medhāvī vijjāgato ti vijānana bhāvam gataḥ ñāṇī iti paññā sampannaḥ vibhāvī iti
translated: “Wise” means possessing wisdom. “Possessing knowledge” means having attained the state of knowing. “Wise” means possessing understanding. “Intelligent” means

original: ñāṇena vīmaṃsako. Medhāvīti aniccādīhi tulitañāṇo. Paññātiādayo heṭṭhā vuttanayāyeva.🔽Catusaccadhammaṃ vicinātīti dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo. Bojjhaṅgattho heṭṭhā vuttova.🔽Vīmaṃsāti catusaccadhammavicinanā paññāva. “Vīmaṃsā dhammacintanā”ti hi vuttā. Vipassanāti🔽maggasampayuttā vividhākārena passanā paññāva. Sammādiṭṭhīti sobhanā pasaṭṭhā sundarā
analyzed: ñāṇena vīmaṃsakaḥ medhāvī iti anicca ādīhi tulita ñāṇo paññāti ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayāya iva  catu sacca dhammam vicināti iti dhamma vicaya sambojjhaṅgaḥ bojjhaṅga atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ vat  vīmaṃsā ati catu sacca dhamma vicinanā paññā ava vīmaṃsā dhamma cintanā ati hi vuttā vipassanā ati  magga sampayuttā vividha ākārena passanā paññā ava sammādiṭṭhi iti sobhanā pasaṭṭhā sundarā
translated: “Wise” means possessing wisdom. “Possessed of knowledge” means having gone to the state of knowing. “Wise” means possessing understanding. “Intelligent” means possessing the wisdom that weighs impermanence, etc. “Possessed of wisdom” and the rest are as already stated.🔽“He investigates the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths”: the factor of enlightenment of investigation of Dhamma. The meaning of the factors of enlightenment has already been explained.

original: maggasampayuttā sammādiṭṭhi. Tehi vedehīti eteheva catūhi maggañāṇehi. Antagatoti🔽jātijarāmaraṇassa pariyosānaṃ gato. Koṭigatotiādayo heṭṭhā vuttanayāva. Vedānaṃ vā
analyzed: magga sampayuttā sammādiṭṭhi tehi vedehi iti etehi iva catūhi magga ñāṇehi antagataḥ ti  jāti jarā maraṇassa pariyosānam gataḥ koṭi gataḥ ti ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayā ava vedānam vā
translated: “Investigation” is the wisdom that investigates the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths. For it is said: “Investigation is the pondering of the Dhamma” . “Insight” is the wisdom that sees in various ways the truths associated with the path. “Right view” is the right view associated with the path, which is beautiful, excellent, good,

original: antagatoti jānitabbānaṃ avasānappatto. Vedehi vā antagatoti catūhi maggañāṇavedehi
analyzed: antagataḥ ti jānitabbānam avasāna ppattaḥ vedehi vā antagataḥ ti catūhi magga ñāṇa vedehi
translated: and sublime. “He has known the end”: he has gone to the end of birth, aging, and death. “He has reached the end” and the rest are as already stated. “He has known the end of the known”: he has reached the end of what is to be known. Or “he has known the end” means that he has reached the end by means of the four knowledges of the path.

original: vaṭṭadukkhassa pariyantabhāvena antasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānaṃ gato. Viditattāti viditabhāvena jānitabhāvena.🔽Vedāni viceyya kevalānīti gāthāya ayamattho – yo catūhi maggañāṇavedehi kilesakkhayaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhassa pariyanta bhāvena anta saṅkhātam nibbānam gataḥ vidita ttā ati vidita bhāvena jānita bhāvena  vedāni viceyya kevalāni iti gāthāya ayam attho yaḥ catūhi magga ñāṇa vedehi kilesa kkhayam
translated: He has gone to the extinction that is called the end of the round of rebirths. By knowing: by knowing, by understanding.🔽In the verse “He who has gone by knowing the destruction of all suffering,🔽Having discerned all the Vedas, he is the true knower of the Vedas” the meaning is this: He who has gone by knowing the destruction of defilements

original: karonto gato, so paramatthato vedagū nāma hoti. Sova sabbasamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ satthasaññitāni
analyzed: karontaḥ gataḥ saḥ paramatthataḥ vedagū nāma hoti saḥ uva sabba samaṇa brāhmaṇānam sattha saññitāni
translated: through the four kinds of knowledge of the paths is called the true knower of the Vedas in the ultimate sense. He has discerned the Vedas, which are called the weapons of all recluses and brahmins,

original: vedāni tāyeva maggabhāvanāya kiccato aniccādivasena viceyya. Tattha chandarāgappahānena
analyzed: vedāni tāya iva magga bhāvanāya kiccataḥ anicca ādi vasena viceyya tattha chanda rāga ppahānena
translated: through the development of those very paths, by way of impermanence, etc. Having abandoned desire and lust for them,

original: tameva sabbaṃ vedamaticca yāpi vedapaccayā, aññathā vā uppajjanti vedanā, tāsu sabbavedanāsu
analyzed: tam eva sabbam vedam aticca yā api veda paccayāḥ aññathā vā uppajjanti vedanā tāsu sabba vedanāsu
translated: he has gone beyond all the Vedas and all the feelings that arise in dependence on the Vedas or in any other way. He is free from lust for all feelings.

original: vītarāgo hoti. Tasmā tamatthaṃ dassento “kiṃ pattinamāhu vedagu”nti puṭṭho “idaṃ
analyzed: vīta rāgaḥ hoti tasmā tam attham dassento kim pattinam āhu vedagum ti puṭṭhaḥ idam
translated: Therefore, showing this meaning, when asked “What is the true knower of the Vedas?” he did not say “This is the true knower of the Vedas,”

original: pattina”nti avatvā “vedāni viceyya…pe… vedagū so”ti āha. Yasmā vā yo pavicayapaññāya
analyzed: avatvā vedāni vedagū saḥ ti āha yasmai vā yaḥ pavicaya paññāya
translated: but said: “He who has discerned all the Vedas … he is the true knower of the Vedas.” Or else, he who has discerned the Vedas

original: vedāni viceyya, tattha chandarāgappahānena sabbaṃ vedamaticca vattati. So satthasaññitāni
analyzed: vedāni viceyya tattha chanda rāga ppahānena sabbam vedam aticca vattati saḥ sattha saññitāni
translated: Having investigated the kinds of feeling, he goes beyond all kinds of feeling by abandoning desire and lust. He is called “one who has gone beyond the kinds of feeling” .

original: vedāni gato ñāto atikkantova hoti. Yo vedanāsu vītarāgo, sopi vedanāsaññitāni vedāni🔽gato atikkanto, ativedanaṃ gatotipi vedagū. Tasmā tampi atthaṃ dassento “idaṃ pattina”nti
analyzed: vedāni gataḥ ñātaḥ atikkantaḥ iva hoti yaḥ vedanāsu vīta rāgaḥ saḥ api vedanā saññitāni vedāni  gataḥ atikkantaḥ ativedanam gataḥ iti pi vedagū tasmā tam pi attham dassentaḥ idam
translated: One who is free from lust for feeling has gone beyond the kinds of feeling, has gone beyond feeling. He is called “one who has gone beyond” .

original: avatvā “vedāni viceyya…pe… vedagū so”ti āha.🔽Sameccāti ñāṇena samāgantvā. Abhisameccāti ñāṇena paṭivijjhitvā. Dhammanti catusaccadhammaṃ.
analyzed: avatvā vedāni viceyya pe vedagū sā uti āha  samecca ati ñāṇena samāgantvā abhisamecca ati ñāṇena paṭivijjhitvā dhammanti catu sacca dhammaṃ
translated: Therefore, in order to show this meaning, the Exalted One said: “Having investigated the kinds of feeling … he is called ‘one who has gone beyond’ ” .

original: Sabbe saṅkhārāti sabbe sappaccayā dhammā. Te hi saṅkhatasaṅkhārā nāma. Paccayehi🔽saṅgamma karīyantīti saṅkhārā, te evaṃ paccayehi saṅgamma katattā “saṅkhatā”ti visesetvā
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā ati sabbe sappaccayāḥ dhammāḥ te hi saṅkhata saṅkhārāḥ nāma paccayehi  saṅgamma karīyanti iti saṅkhārā te evam paccayehi saṅgamma kata ttā saṅkhatā ati visesetvā
translated: He has gone to the end of suffering : he has gone to the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has penetrated the end of suffering : he has penetrated the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has gone to the end of the world : he has gone to the end of the world by means of knowledge. He has gone beyond the kinds of suffering : having investigated the kinds of suffering, he has gone beyond all kinds of suffering by abandoning desire and lust. He is called “one who has gone beyond the kinds of suffering” .🔽He has gone to the end of the world : he has gone to the end of the world by means of knowledge.
