He has penetrated the end of the world : he has penetrated the end of the world by means of knowledge. He has gone to the end of suffering : he has gone to the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has gone beyond the kinds of suffering : having investigated the kinds of suffering, he has gone beyond all kinds of suffering by abandoning desire and lust. He is called “one who has gone beyond the kinds of suffering” .

original: vuttā. “Kammanibbattā tebhūmakarūpārūpadhammā abhisaṅkhatasaṅkhārā”ti aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: vuttā kamma nibbattā tebhūmaka rūpa arūpa dhammā abhisaṅkhata saṅkhārā ti aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: He has gone to the end of suffering : he has gone to the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has penetrated the end of suffering : he has penetrated the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has gone to the end of the world : he has gone to the end of the world by means of knowledge. He has gone beyond the kinds of feeling : having investigated the kinds of feeling, he has gone beyond all kinds of feeling by abandoning desire and lust. He is called “one who has gone beyond the kinds of feeling” .🔽He has gone to the end of suffering : he has gone to the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has penetrated the end of suffering : he has penetrated the end of suffering by means of knowledge. He has gone to the end of the world : he has gone to the end of the world by means of knowledge. He has gone

original: vuttā. Tepi “aniccā vata saṅkhārā”tiādīsu saṅkhatasaṅkhāresu saṅgahaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: vuttā te api aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārāḥ ati ādīsu saṅkhata saṅkhāresu saṅgaham gacchanti
translated: and they are included among formed formations in the passage beginning, “Impermanent, indeed, are formations” .

original: “Avijjāgatoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo puññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharotī”tiādīsu
analyzed: avijjā gataḥ ayam bhikkhave purisa puggalaḥ saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti itiādīsu
translated: In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, this person is overcome with ignorance and does not know as it really is the arising and falling away, the gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of the six bases for contact” ,

original: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāva āgatā. Tebhūmikakusalākusalacetanā abhisaṅkharaṇakasaṅkhārā
analyzed: avijjā paccayā āgatā tebhūmika kusala akusala cetanā abhisaṅkharaṇaka saṅkhārā
translated: only formations with ignorance as condition are stated. The volitions of the three planes of existence that form kamma are called “forming formations” .

original: nāma. “Yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati, tāvatikaṃ gantvā akkhāhataṃ maññe aṭṭhāsī”tiādīsu🔽āgataṃ kāyikacetasikavīriyaṃ payogābhisaṅkhāro nāma. “Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa🔽kho, āvuso visākha, bhikkhuno paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati vacīsaṅkhāro, tato kāyasaṅkhāro,
analyzed: nāma yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati tāvatikam gantvā akkhāhatam maññe aṭṭhāsi iti ādīsu  āgatam kāyika cetasika vīriyam payoga abhisaṅkhāraḥ nāma saññā vedayita nirodham samāpannassa  kho āvuso visākha bhikkhuno paṭhamam nirujjhati vacī saṅkhāro tato kāya saṅkhāro
translated: In the passage beginning, “He abides resolved upon and pervading … with the thought ‘He is happy’ … ‘He is blissful’ … ‘He has equanimity’ to the extent that, without thinking, ‘I am experiencing happiness,’ only the happiness is experienced” ,🔽the bodily and mental energy stated there is called “forming by exertion” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when perception and attention accompanied by sensuality have been abandoned in a bhikkhu, when he dwells having entered upon a pleasant deliverance of mind that is void, and so on, and he looks on with equanimity at the mind that is rightly released, then his faculties are activated, and so on” ,🔽the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed … his faculties are activated, and so on” ,

original: tato cittasaṅkhāro”tiādīsu āgatā vitakkavicārā vācaṃ saṅkharontīti vacīsaṅkhārā,🔽assāsapassāsā kāyena saṅkharīyantīti kāyasaṅkhārā, saññā ca vedanā ca cittena saṅkharīyantīti
analyzed: āgatāḥ vitakka vicārāḥ vācam saṅkharonti iti vacī saṅkhārā 🔽assāsa passāsā kāyena saṅkharīyanti iti kāya saṅkhārā saññā ca vedanā ca cittena saṅkharīyanti iti
translated: the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed … his faculties are activated, and so on” ,🔽the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed … his faculties are activated, and so on” ,🔽the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed … his faculties are activated, and so on” ,🔽the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant with taints destroyed … his faculties are activated, and so on” ,🔽the equanimity stated there is called “forming by resolution” . In the

original: cittasaṅkhārā. Idha pana saṅkhatasaṅkhārā adhippetā. Aniccā hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena. Dukkhā
analyzed: citta saṅkhārāḥ idha pana saṅkhata saṅkhārāḥ adhippetāḥ aniccāḥ hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena dukkhā
translated: Here, however, the term “formations” is intended to mean “formed formations.” They are impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been. They are suffering in the sense of oppression.

original: paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena. Sabbe dhammāti nibbānampi antokatvā vuttā. Anattā avasavattanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena sabbe dhammā ti nibbānam pi antokatvā vuttāḥ anattā avasavattana ṭṭhena
translated: All dhammas are mentioned including Nibbāna. They are non-self in the sense of having no core.

original: Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti ettha yaṃ paṭicca phalameti, so paccayo. Paṭiccāti na vinā,
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti ettha yam paṭicca phalam eti saḥ paccayaḥ paṭicca ati na vinā
translated: With the words “With ignorance as condition, formations,” etc., a condition is that by which an effect is caused to come into being. The meaning of “with” is “not without.”

original: apaccakkhitvāti attho. Etīti uppajjati ceva pavattati cāti attho. Apica upakārakaṭṭho
analyzed: a paccakkhitvā iti atthaḥ eti iti uppajjati ca iva pavattati ca ati atthaḥ apica upakāraka ṭṭhaḥ
translated: The meaning is “not without having been seen.” “Comes into being” means arises and occurs. Moreover, the meaning of “condition” is that of being a helper.

original: paccayaṭṭho. Avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo, tasmā avijjāpaccayā. Saṅkhārā
analyzed: paccaya ṭṭhaḥ avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayo tasmai avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā
translated: Ignorance is that, and it is a condition, thus it is “ignorance as condition.” Therefore, “with ignorance as condition.”

original: sambhavantīti nibbattanti, evaṃ sambhavantisaddassa sesapadehipi yojanā kātabbā.🔽Tattha katamā avijjā? Dukkhe aññāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye aññāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe aññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: sambhavanti iti nibbattanti evam sambhavanti saddassa sesa padehi pi yojanā kātabbā  tattha katamā avijjā dukkhe aññāṇam dukkha samudaye aññāṇam dukkha nirodhe aññāṇam
translated: The formations come into being, are born, originate, are produced, arise, occur, manifest, and are actualized. The word “come into being” should be construed with each of the remaining terms.🔽Herein, what is ignorance? It is unknowing about suffering, unknowing about the origin of suffering, unknowing about the cessation of suffering,

original: dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṃ, pubbante aññāṇaṃ, aparante aññāṇaṃ, pubbantāparante
analyzed: dukkha nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇam pubbante aññāṇam aparante aññāṇam pubbanta aparante
translated: unknowing about the way leading to the cessation of suffering, unknowing about the past, unknowing about the future, unknowing about the past and the future,

original: aññāṇaṃ, idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇaṃ. Katame saṅkhārā? Puññābhisaṅkhāro
analyzed: aññāṇam idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇam katame saṅkhārā puñña abhisaṅkhāro
translated: Non-cognizance is non-cognizance of states that are conditionally arisen by cause. What are determinations? The determination of merit,

original: apuññābhisaṅkhāro āneñjābhisaṅkhāro, kāyasaṅkhāro vacīsaṅkhāro cittasaṅkhāro, aṭṭha
analyzed: apuñña abhisaṅkhāro āneñja abhisaṅkhāro kāya saṅkhāro vacī saṅkhāro citta saṅkhāro aṭṭha
translated: the determination of demerit, the determination of imperturbability, the determination of body, the determination of speech, the determination of thought.

original: kāmāvacarakusalacetanā, pañca rūpāvacarakusalacetanā puññābhisaṅkhāro, dvādasa akusalacetanā🔽apuññābhisaṅkhāro, catasso arūpāvacarakusalacetanā āneñjābhisaṅkhāro, kāyasañcetanā
analyzed: kāmāvacara kusala cetanā pañca rūpāvacara kusala cetanā puñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ dvādasa akusala cetanā  apuñña abhisaṅkhāro catasso arūpāvacara kusala cetanāḥ āneñja abhisaṅkhāro kāya sañcetanā
translated: Eight kinds of profitable consciousness in the sense-world sphere are the determination of merit. Five kinds of profitable consciousness in the fine-material world sphere are the determination of merit. Twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness are the determination of demerit.

original: kāyasaṅkhāro, vacīsañcetanā vacīsaṅkhāro, manosañcetanā cittasaṅkhāro.
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāraḥ vacī sañcetanā vacī saṅkhāraḥ manaḥ sañcetanā citta saṅkhāraḥ
translated: Four kinds of profitable consciousness in the immaterial world sphere are the determination of imperturbability. Determination of body is the determination of body. Determination of speech is the determination of speech. Determination of thought is the determination of thought.

original: Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “ime saṅkhārā avijjāpaccayā hontī”ti? Avijjābhāve
analyzed: tattha siyā katham pana etam jānitabbam ime saṅkhārāḥ avijjā paccayāḥ honti iti avijjā bhāve
translated: Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that these determinations have ignorance as their condition?

original: bhāvato. Yassa hi dukkhādīsu avijjāsaṅkhātaṃ aññāṇaṃ appahīnaṃ hoti, so dukkhe tāva
analyzed: bhāvato yassa hi dukkha ādīsu avijjā saṅkhātam aññāṇam appahīnam hoti saḥ dukkhe tāva
translated: Because of presence when ignorance is. For when ignorance, called “non-cognizance” in regard to suffering, etc., is unabandoned, then,

original: pubbantādīsu ca aññāṇena saṃsāradukkhaṃ sukhasaññāya gahetvā tasseva hetubhūte tividhepi
analyzed: pubbanta ādīsu ca aññāṇena saṃsāra dukkham sukha saññāya gahetvā tassa iva hetu bhūte tividhe pi
translated: through non-cognizance of the past, etc., the suffering of the round of rebirths is apprehended as pleasure, and the three kinds of determinations that are the cause of that are made.

original: saṅkhāre ārabhati. Samudaye aññāṇena dukkhahetubhūtepi taṇhāparikkhāre saṅkhāre sukhahetuto🔽maññamāno ārabhati. Nirodhe pana magge ca aññāṇena dukkhassa anirodhabhūtepi gativisese
analyzed: saṅkhāre ārabhati samudaye aññāṇena dukkha hetu bhūte api taṇhā parikkhāre saṅkhāre sukha hetuto  maññamānaḥ ārabhati nirodhe pana magge ca aññāṇena dukkhassa anirodha bhūte pi gati visese
translated: He misapprehends formations as a cause of pleasure, not knowing the origin of suffering, which is formations that are a condition for craving.🔽He misapprehends cessation, not knowing the cessation of suffering, which is a particular kind of non-occurrence of the round of rebirths.

original: dukkhanirodhasaññī hutvā nirodhassa ca amaggabhūtesupi yaññāmaratapādīsu nirodhamaggasaññī
analyzed: dukkha nirodha saññī hutvā nirodhassa ca amagga bhūtesu pi yaññā amaratapādīsu nirodha magga saññī
translated: He misapprehends the path, not knowing the path to the cessation of suffering, which is the noble path, but taking as the path to cessation such things as sacrifices, mortification rites, and the worship of the sun and moon.

original: hutvā dukkhanirodhaṃ patthayamāno yaññāmaratapādimukhena tividhepi saṅkhāre ārabhati.
analyzed: hutvā dukkha nirodham patthayamānaḥ tividhe api saṅkhāre ārabhati
translated: He misapprehends the three kinds of formations as a means to the attainment of cessation, seeking the cessation of suffering through such things as sacrifices, mortification rites, and the worship of the sun and moon.

original: Api ca so tāya catūsu saccesu appahīnāvijjatāya visesato jātijarārogamaraṇādianekādīnavavokiṇṇampi🔽puññaphalasaṅkhātaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhato ajānanto tassa adhigamāya kāyavacīcittasaṅkhārabhedaṃ
analyzed: api ca saḥ tāya catūsu saccesu visesataḥ jāti jarā roga maraṇa ādi aneka ādīnava vokiṇṇam pi  puñña phala saṅkhātam dukkham dukkhataḥ a jānantaḥ tassa adhigamāya kāya vacī citta saṅkhāra bhedam
translated: Moreover, he misapprehends formations as a means to the attainment of the fruit of merit, not knowing that the fruit of merit, which is mixed with the manifold dangers of birth, aging, sickness, death, etc.,🔽is suffering. He misapprehends the meritorious formations consisting in bodily, verbal, and mental action as a means to the attainment of the fruit of merit,

original: puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ ārabhati devaccharakāmako viya maruppapātaṃ. Sukhasammatassāpi
analyzed: puñña abhisaṅkhāram ārabhati deva chara kāmakaḥ viya maru ppapātam sukha sammatassa api
translated: like one who desires heaven misapprehends the ascent to heaven as a means to the attainment of heaven. He misapprehends formations as a means to the attainment of the fruit of demerit, not knowing that the fruit of demerit, which is mixed with the manifold dangers of the states of deprivation,

original: ca tassa puññaphalassa ante mahāpariḷāhajanikaṃ vipariṇāmadukkhataṃ appassādatañca
analyzed: ca tassa puñña phalassa ante mahā pariḷāha janikam vipariṇāma dukkha taṃ appassāda tañca
translated: and not seeing the great suffering of change that is born of the result of that merit, and the little satisfaction in it,

original: apassantopi tappaccayaṃ vuttappakārameva puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ ārabhati salabho viya
analyzed: a passantaḥ api tad paccayam vutta ppakāram eva puñña abhisaṅkhāram ārabhati salabhaḥ viya
translated: he generates the formation of merit of the kind already stated, as a moth does the formation consisting in flying into the flame,

original: dīpasikhābhinipātaṃ, madhubindugiddho viya ca madhulittasatthadhārālehanaṃ.🔽Kāmupasevanādīsu ca savipākesu ādīnavaṃ apassanto sukhasaññāya ceva kilesābhibhūtatāya
analyzed: dīpa sikhā abhinipātam madhu bindu giddhaḥ ca madhu litta sattha dhārā lehanam  kāma upasevana ādīsu ca sa vipākesu ādīnavam a passanto sukha saññāya ca iva kilesa abhibhūta tāya
translated: and as one greedy for a drop of honey does the formation consisting in licking up the honey smeared on a knife-blade.

original: ca dvārattayappavattampi apuññābhisaṅkhāraṃ ārabhati bālo viya gūthakīḷanaṃ, maritukāmo
analyzed: ca dvāra ttaya pavattam pi apuñña abhisaṅkhāram ārabhati bālaḥ viya gūtha kīḷanam maritu kāmo
translated: And when he does not see the danger in the enjoyment of sensual desires, etc., that have resultant birth, he generates the formation of demerit consisting in the occurrence of the three doors of action, through the perception of pleasure and through being overwhelmed by defilements,🔽as a fool does the formation consisting in playing with excrement, and as one who wants to die does the formation consisting in eating poison.

original: viya ca visakhādanaṃ. Āruppavipākesu cāpi saṅkhāravipariṇāmadukkhataṃ anavabujjhamāno🔽sassatādivipallāsena cittasaṅkhārabhūtaṃ āneñjābhisaṅkhāraṃ ārabhati disāmūḷho viya
analyzed: viya ca visa khādanam āruppa vipākesu ca api saṅkhāra vipariṇāma dukkha tam an avabujjhamānaḥ  sassatā ādi vipallāsena citta saṅkhāra bhūtam āneñja abhisaṅkhāram ārabhati disāmūḷhaḥ viya
translated: And when he does not understand the suffering of formations and the suffering of change in the resultant states of the immaterial sphere,🔽he generates the formation of the imperturbable, which is a formation of consciousness, through the perversion of permanence, etc.,🔽as one bewildered about the directions does the formation consisting in setting out on a path leading to a city of ghosts.

original: pisācanagarābhimukhamaggagamanaṃ. Evaṃ yasmā avijjābhāvatova saṅkhārabhāvo, na abhāvato.
analyzed: pisāca nagara abhimukha magga gamanam evam yasmai avijjā bhāvataḥ va saṅkhāra bhāvaḥ na abhāvataḥ
translated: So the state of formations is due to the presence of ignorance, not to its absence.

original: Tasmā jānitabbametaṃ “ime saṅkhārā avijjāpaccayā hontī”ti.🔽Etthāha – gaṇhāma tāva etaṃ “avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ paccayo”ti, kiṃ panāyamekāva avijjā
analyzed: tasmā jānitabbam etam ime saṅkhārāḥ avijjā paccayāḥ honti iti  ettha āha gaṇhāma tāva etam avijjā saṅkhārānam paccayo ti kim pana ayam ekā ava avijjā
translated: So it should be understood that “formations have ignorance as their condition.”

original: saṅkhārānaṃ paccayo, udāhu aññepi paccayā santīti? Kiṃ panettha yadi tāva ekāva,
analyzed: saṅkhārānam paccayaḥ udāhu aññe pi paccayā santi iti kim pana ittha yadi tāva ekāva
translated: Here it may be asked: “Let us assume that ignorance is a condition for formations. But is ignorance the only condition for formations, or are there other conditions too? And what is the point of this? If ignorance is the only condition,

original: ekakāraṇavādo āpajjati. Atha aññepi santi, “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti ekakāraṇaniddeso
analyzed: eka kāraṇa vādaḥ āpajjati atha aññe pi santi avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti eka kāraṇa niddesaḥ
translated: then the doctrine of a single cause is affirmed. But if there are other conditions too, then the statement of a single condition, ‘With ignorance as condition there are formations,’🔽is contradicted. So how can it be maintained?”🔽It can be maintained. Why?

original: nupapajjatīti? Na nupapajjati. Kasmā? Yasmā –
analyzed: nu upapajjati iti na nu upapajjati kasmai yasmai
translated: Because:

original: “Ekaṃ na ekato idha, nānekamanekatopi no ekaṃ;
analyzed: ekam naḥ ekatas idha na anekam anekatas api na u ekam
translated: “Here one is not one, nor many; nor is one many

original: Phalamatthi atthi pana eka-hetuphaladīpane attho”. ;🔽Bhagavā hi katthaci padhānattā, katthaci pākaṭattā, katthaci asādhāraṇattā desanāvilāsassa
analyzed: phalam atthi atthi pana eka hetu phala dīpane  bhagavā hi katthaci padhāna ttā katthaci pākaṭa ttā katthaci asādhāraṇa ttā desanā vilāsassa
translated: In the teaching of the single cause and fruit; there is a purpose.”

original: ca veneyyānañca anurūpato ekameva hetuṃ vā phalaṃ vā dīpeti. Tasmā ayamidha avijjā
analyzed: ca veneyyānam ca anurūpatas ekam eva hetum vā phalam vā dīpeti tasmai ayam idha avijjā
translated: For the Exalted One sometimes teaches a single cause or a single fruit because of preeminence, sometimes because of clarity, sometimes because of non-differentiation, and sometimes out of skill in the means of teaching and in adapting himself to the inclinations of those to be trained. Therefore, in the present context,

original: vijjamānesupi aññesu vatthārammaṇasahajātadhammādīsu saṅkhārakāraṇesu “assādānupassino🔽taṇhā pavaḍḍhatī”ti ca, “avijjāsamudayā āsavasamudayo”ti ca vacanato aññesampi taṇhādīnaṃ🔽saṅkhārahetūnaṃ hetūti padhānattā, “avidvā, bhikkhave, avijjāgato puññābhisaṅkhārampi
analyzed: vijjamānesu pi aññesu vattha ārammaṇa sahajāta dhamma ādīsu saṅkhāra kāraṇesu assāda anupassinaḥ  taṇhā pavaḍḍhati iti ca avijjā samudayā āsava samudayo ti ca vacanataḥ aññesam pi taṇhā ādīnam  saṅkhāra hetūnam hetū ti padhāna ttā avidvā bhikkhave avijjā gataḥ puñña abhisaṅkhāram pi
translated: Although other conditions such as the other bases, objects, and conascent states are also conditions for formations, still craving is called the condition for formations because it is the principal cause.🔽For it is said: “With regard to what is liked, craving increases” , and “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of cankers” .🔽And it is called the condition for formations because it is the principal cause of craving, etc.,

original: abhisaṅkharotī”ti pākaṭattā, asādhāraṇattā ca saṅkhārānaṃ hetubhāvena dīpitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: abhisaṅkharoti iti pākaṭa ttā asādhāraṇa ttā ca hetu bhāvena dīpitā iti veditabbā
translated: which are the causes of formations, because it is evident as the cause of formations in the passage, “Bhikkhus, the uninstructed worldling, who is not a seer of what is good, regards form as self, or self as possessed of form, or form as in self, or self as in form” , and because it is not shared by others.

original: Eteneva ca ekekahetuphaladīpanaparihāravacanena sabbattha ekekahetuphaladīpane payojanaṃ veditabbanti.
analyzed: etena iva ca ekeka hetu phala dīpana parihāra vacanena sabbattha ekeka hetu phala dīpane payojanam veditabbanti
translated: And by this statement of the avoidance of the indication of a single cause and a single effect it should be understood that there is a purpose in the indication of a single cause and a single effect in each instance.

original: Etthāha – evaṃ santepi ekantāniṭṭhaphalāya sāvajjāya avijjāya kathaṃ puññāneñjābhisaṅkhārapaccayattaṃ
analyzed: ettha āha evam sante pi ekanta aniṭṭha phalāya sāvajjāya avijjāya katham puñña aneñja abhisaṅkhāra paccaya ttam
translated: Here it may be asked: “But if this is so, then how can blameworthy ignorance, which has only an undesirable result, be a condition for formations that are meritorious and undetermined?🔽For a coconut does not grow from a nim tree seed.”

original: yujjati? Na hi nimbabījato ucchu uppajjatīti. Kathaṃ na yujjissati? Lokasmiñhi –
analyzed: yujjati na hi nimba bījataḥ ucchu uppajjati iti katham na yujjissati lokasmin hi
translated: How does it not fit? For in the world:

original: “Viruddho cā viruddho ca, sadisāsadiso tathā;
analyzed: viruddhaḥ ca viruddhaḥ ca sadisa asadisaḥ tathā
translated: “Opposed and not opposed, and likewise similar and dissimilar,

original: Dhammānaṃ paccayo siddho, vipākā eva te ca na”.
analyzed: dhammānam paccayaḥ siddhaḥ vipākāḥ eva te ca na
translated: And they are established as conditions for states, But they are not themselves results.

original: Iti ayaṃ avijjā vipākavasena ekantāniṭṭhaphalā, sabhāvavasena ca sāvajjāpi samānā🔽sabbesampi etesaṃ puññābhisaṅkhārādīnaṃ yathānurūpaṃ ṭhānakiccasabhāvaviruddhāviruddhapaccayavasena,
analyzed: iti ayam avijjā vipāka vasena ekanta aniṭṭha phalā sabhāva vasena ca sā avajjā api samānā  sabbesam pi etesam puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīnam yathānurūpam ṭhāna kicca sabhāva viruddha aviruddha paccaya vasena
translated: So this ignorance, though its fruit is wholly undesirable since it is a result, is blameworthy in itself.🔽But it should be understood as a condition for all these formations of merit, etc., in various ways, that is, as a condition by prenascence, postnascence, and so on, and as a condition by object, and as a condition that is the support, etc., and as a condition that is a state’s own individual essence, and as a condition that is a cause, and as a condition that is neither homogeneous nor a decisive support, and as a condition that is a homogeneous state and a decisive support, and as a condition that is a cause and a homogeneous state, and as a condition that is a cause and a decisive support, and as a condition that is a cause, a homogeneous state, and a decisive support.

original: sadisāsadisapaccayavasena ca paccayo hotīti veditabbā. Api ca ayaṃ aññopi pariyāyo –
analyzed: sadisa asadisa paccaya vasena ca paccayaḥ hoti iti veditabbā api ca ayam aññaḥ api pariyāyo
translated: And there is another method:

original: “Cutūpapāte saṃsāre, saṅkhārānañca lakkhaṇe;
analyzed: cutūpapāte saṃsāre lakkhaṇe
translated: “In death and rebirth, in saṃsara, And in the characteristics of formations,

original: Yo paṭiccasamuppanna-dhammesu ca vimuyhati.🔽“Abhisaṅkharoti so ete, saṅkhāre tividhe yato;
analyzed: yaḥ paṭicca samuppanna dhammesu ca vimuyhati  abhisaṅkharoti saḥ ete saṅkhāre tividhe yatas
translated: He who is confused about the states That are conditionally arisen,

original: Avijjā paccayo tesaṃ, tividhānampayaṃ tato.
analyzed: avijjā paccayaḥ tesam tividha anampayam tatas
translated: “He forms these three kinds of formations, And so this ignorance is a condition For these three kinds of formations, And so it is threefold.

original: “Yathāpi nāma jaccandho, naro apariṇāyako;
analyzed: yathā api nāma naraḥ apariṇāyakaḥ
translated: “Just as a man who is blind from birth, Who has no guide,

original: Ekadā yāti maggena, ummaggenāpi ekadā.
analyzed: ekadā yāti maggena ummaggena api ekadā
translated: Sometimes goes by a path And sometimes by a wrong path,

original: “Saṃsāre saṃsaraṃ bālo, tathā apariṇāyako;
analyzed: saṃsāre saṃsaram bālaḥ tathā apariṇāyakaḥ
translated: “So too the fool who has no guide Saṃsaras in saṃsara,

original: Karoti ekadā puññaṃ, apuññamapi ekadā.
analyzed: karoti ekadā puññam apuññam api ekadā
translated: Sometimes doing merit, And sometimes demerit.

original: “Yadā ca ñatvā so dhammaṃ, saccāni abhisamessati;
analyzed: yadā ca ñatvā saḥ dhammam saccāni abhisamessati
translated: And when he knows the Dhamma, And penetrates the Truths,

original: Tadā avijjūpasamā, upasanto carissatī”ti.🔽Saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇanti chaviññāṇakāyā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ sotaviññāṇaṃ ghānaviññāṇaṃ🔽jivhāviññāṇaṃ kāyaviññāṇaṃ manoviññāṇaṃ. Tattha cakkhuviññāṇaṃ kusalavipākaṃ akusalavipākanti
analyzed: tadā avijjūpasamā upasanto carissati iti  saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇanti cha viññāṇa kāyā cakkhu viññāṇam sota viññāṇam ghāna viññāṇam  jivhā viññāṇam kāya viññāṇam manaḥ viññāṇam tattha cakkhu viññāṇam kusala vipākam akusala vipākam ti
translated: Then, with the cessation of ignorance, He will go about quite quenched.🔽With formations as condition, consciousness: the six groups of consciousness, namely, eye-consciousness, ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, and mind-consciousness. Herein, eye-consciousness is twofold, being either profitable or unprofitable result.

original: duvidhaṃ. Tathā sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇāni. Manoviññāṇaṃ pana dve vipākamanodhātuyo,
analyzed: duvidham tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇāni manaḥ viññāṇam pana dve vipāka manaḥ dhātuyo
translated: So too are ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness. But mind-consciousness is of twenty-two kinds, being the two kinds of resultant mind element ,

original: tisso ahetukavipākamanoviññāṇadhātuyo, aṭṭha sahetukavipākacittāni, pañca rūpāvacaravipākacittāni,
analyzed: tissaḥ ahetuka vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ aṭṭha sa hetuka vipāka cittāni pañca rūpāvacara vipāka cittāni
translated: the three kinds of unprofitable result, the eight kinds of profitable result, the five kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness,

original: cattāri arūpāvacaravipākacittānīti bāvīsatividhaṃ. Iti sabbāni bāttiṃsalokiyavipākaviññāṇāni.
analyzed: cattāri arūpa avacara vipāka cittāni iti bāvīsatividham iti sabbāni bāttiṃsa lokiya vipāka viññāṇāni
translated: and the four immaterial-sphere kinds. So all the twenty-two kinds of resultant consciousness are mundane.

original: Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “idaṃ vuttappakāraṃ viññāṇaṃ saṅkhārapaccayā
analyzed: tattha siyā katham pana itam jānitabbam idam vutta ppakāram viññāṇam saṅkhāra paccayā
translated: Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that this or that kind of consciousness is with formations as its condition?

original: hotī”ti? Upacitakammābhāve vipākābhāvato. Vipākañhetaṃ, vipākañca na upacitakammābhāve🔽uppajjati, yadi uppajjeyya, sabbesaṃ sabbavipākāni uppajjeyyuṃ, na ca uppajjantīti
analyzed: hoti iti upacita kamma abhāve vipāka abhāvataḥ vipākam ha etam vipākam ca na upacita kamma abhāve  uppajjati yadi uppajjeyya sabbesam sabba vipākāni uppajjeyyum na ca uppajjanti iti
translated: because there is no kamma-result if there is no stored-up kamma. For this is kamma-result, and kamma-result does not arise if there is no stored-up kamma.🔽If it did, then the results of all kamma would arise at once, and yet they do not all arise at once.🔽

original: jānitabbametaṃ “saṅkhārapaccayā idaṃ viññāṇaṃ hotī”ti. Sabbameva hi idaṃ pavattipaṭisandhivasena🔽dvedhā pavattati. Tattha dve pañcaviññāṇāni, dve manodhātuyo, somanassasahagatā ahetukamanoviññāṇadhātūti
analyzed: jānitabbam etam saṅkhāra paccayā idam viññāṇam hoti iti sabbam eva hi idam pavatti paṭisandhi vasena  dvedhā pavattati tattha dve pañca viññāṇāni dve manaḥ dhātuyo somanassa sahagatāḥ ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti
translated: because without stored-up kamma there is no result. For this is a result, and a result does not arise without stored-up kamma. If it did, then the result of all kamma stored up by everyone would arise in everyone, and that is not so. So it should be understood that “This consciousness has formations as its condition.”🔽All this occurs in two ways, that is to say, as occurrence in the course of an individual existence and as rebirth-linking.

original: imāni terasa pañcavokārabhave pavattiyaṃyeva pavattanti. Sesāni ekūnavīsati tīsu
analyzed: imāni terasa pañcavokāra bhave pavattiyaṃyeva pavattanti sesāni ekūnavīsati tīsu
translated: Herein, the two sets of five consciousnesses, the two mind elements, and the two kinds of mind-consciousness element accompanied by joy but not associated with any root are the thirteen that occur only in the course of an existence in the five-constituent kind of becoming.

original: bhavesu yathānurūpaṃ pavattiyampi paṭisandhiyampi pavattanti.
analyzed: bhavesu yathānurūpam pavattiyam pi paṭisandhiyam pi pavattanti
translated: The remaining nineteen occur in the three kinds of becoming, in the course of an existence and as rebirth-linking, according to the kind of becoming.

original: “Laddhappaccayamiti dhamma-mattametaṃ bhavantaramupeti;
analyzed: laddhappaccayam iti dhammam attam etam bhavantaram upeti
translated: “The state that has conditions is only a mere state that goes to a new becoming;

original: Nāssa tato saṅkanti, na tato hetuṃ vinā hoti”.
analyzed: na assa tatas na tatas hetum vinā hoti
translated: It does not pass on from there, nor is there without a cause” .

original: Iti hetaṃ laddhappaccayaṃ rūpārūpadhammamattaṃ uppajjamānaṃ “bhavantaramupetī”ti
analyzed: iti ha etam laddha ppaccayam rūpa arūpa dhamma mattam uppajjamānam bhavantaram upeti iti
translated: So this mere state consisting of materiality and immateriality that arises having obtained conditions “goes to a new becoming” .

original: vuccati, na satto na jīvo. Tassa ca nāpi atītabhavato idha saṅkanti atthi, nāpi tato🔽hetuṃ vinā idha pātubhāvo. Ettha ca purimaṃ cavanato cuti, pacchimaṃ bhavantarādipaṭisandhānato
analyzed: vuccati na satto na jīvaḥ tassa ca nā api atīta bhavataḥ idha atthi nā api tatas  hetum vinā idha pātubhāvaḥ ettha ca purimam cavanato pacchimam bhavantara ādi paṭisandhānato
translated: and it is said that there is no being or soul. And there is no transference of it from a past becoming to this becoming, nor is there manifestation here without cause. And here the first is death as the passing away, and the second is death as the taking up of a new existence in another becoming, etc.

original: paṭisandhīti vuccati.🔽Etthāha – nanu evaṃ asaṅkantipātubhāve sati ye imasmiṃ manussattabhāve khandhā, tesaṃ🔽niruddhattā, phalapaccayassa ca kammassa tattha agamanato, aññassa aññato ca taṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi iti vuccati  ettha āha nanu evam asaṅkanti pātubhāve sati ye imasmin manussatta bhāve khandhāḥ tesam  niruddha ttā phala paccayassa ca kammassa tattha agamanataḥ aññassa aññatas ca taṃ
translated: It is called neither a being nor a soul. And there is no transference of it from a past becoming to this becoming, nor is there manifestation here without a cause. And here the first is called death because of the dying of the aggregates, and the second is called rebirth-linking because of the linking of rebirth-linking in the next becoming.

original: phalaṃ siyā, upabhuñjake ca asati kassa taṃ phalaṃ siyā, tasmā na sundaramidaṃ vidhānanti? Tatridaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: phalam siyā upabhuñjake ca asati kassa tam phalam siyā tasmā na sundaram idam vidhānam ti tatra idam vuccati
translated: Here it may be objected: “But if there is no transference and no manifestation, then the aggregates in this human existence must be the same as those in the past becoming, and in that case, since the aggregates have ceased there, and since the kamma that is the condition for the fruit has not gone there, the fruit would be without a cause. And if there is no one to enjoy the fruit, whose fruit would it be? So this theory is not a good one.” As to that, this is said:

original: “Santāne yaṃ phalaṃ etaṃ, nāññassa na ca aññato;
analyzed: santāne yam phalam etam na aññassa na ca aññatas
translated: The fruit is in the continuity, Not of another nor without cause.

original: Bījānaṃ abhisaṅkhāro, etassatthassa sādhako.🔽“Phalassuppattiyā eva, siddhā bhuñjakasammuti;
analyzed: bījānam abhisaṅkhāraḥ etassa atthassa sādhakaḥ  phalassa uppattiyāḥ eva siddhā bhuñjaka sammuti
translated: The volition of the seeds Is the proof of this statement.🔽The agreement to enjoy Is established by the fruit’s appearance;

original: Phaluppādena rukkhassa, yathā phalati sammutī”ti.
analyzed: phala uppādena rukkhassa yathā phalati sammuti iti
translated: The tree’s fruitfulness is agreed upon By the appearance of the fruit.

original: Yopi vadeyya “evaṃ santepi ete saṅkhārā vijjamānā vā phalassa paccayā siyuṃ, avijjamānā🔽vā. Yadi ca vijjamānā, pavattikkhaṇeyeva nesaṃ vipākena bhavitabbaṃ. Atha avijjamānā,
analyzed: yaḥ api vadeyya evam sante pi ete saṅkhārāḥ vijjamānāḥ vā phalassa paccayāḥ siyum a vijjamānā  vā yadi ca vijjamānā pavatti kkhaṇeya iva na esam vipākena bhavitabbam atha a vijjamānā
translated: And if anyone should say this, “Even so, are these formations conditions for their fruit when they are present or when they are absent?🔽If they are present, then they must give their fruit at the very moment of their occurrence. If they are absent, then they must give their fruit after they have ceased and are absent.

original: pavattito pubbe pacchā ca niccaṃ phalāvahā siyu”nti. So evaṃ vattabbo –
analyzed: pavattitaḥ pubbe pacchā ca niccam phala āvahāḥ siyunti saḥ evam vattabbaḥ
translated: In that case they must give their fruit both before and after their occurrence, and so they would be permanent,” he should be told:

original: “Katattā paccayā ete, na ca niccaṃ phalāvahā;
analyzed: kata ttā paccayāḥ ete na ca niccam phala āvahā
translated: “They are conditions when done, not always giving fruit;

original: Pāṭibhogādikaṃ tattha, veditabbaṃ nidassana”nti.🔽Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpanti idha vedanāsaññāsaṅkhārakkhandhā nāmaṃ, cattāri mahābhūtāni
analyzed: pāṭibhoga ādikam tattha veditabbam nidassanam ti  viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti idha vedanā saññā saṅkhāra kkhandhāḥ nāmam cattāri mahābhūtāni
translated: The illustration there is the ‘reaping of what is sown’ ” .🔽“With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality”: the three aggregates beginning with feeling and materiality derived by clinging are mentality ; the four great entities and the materiality derived from the great entities that cling to them are materiality .

original: catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpaṃ rūpaṃ. Abhāvakagabbhaseyyakānaṃ aṇḍajānañca
analyzed: catunnam ca mahābhūtānam upādāya rūpam rūpam abhāvaka gabbhaseyyakānam aṇḍa jānam ca
translated: In the case of those who are born spontaneously and of those who are born from the womb and from eggs,

original: paṭisandhikkhaṇe vatthudasakaṃ kāyadasakanti vīsati rūparūpāni, tayo ca arūpino khandhāti
analyzed: paṭisandhi kkhaṇe vatthu dasakam kāya dasakanti vīsati rūpa rūpāni tayo ca arūpino
translated: at the moment of descent into the womb the tenfold physical basis and the tenfold materiality of the physical basis, that is, the twenty kinds of materiality, and the three immaterial aggregates,

original: ete tevīsati dhammā “viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti veditabbā. Sabhāvakānaṃ bhāvadasakaṃ
analyzed: ete tevīsati dhammā viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpan ti veditabbā sabhāvakānam bhāva dasakam
translated: these thirty-three states should be understood as “with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality.” In the case of those who are born spontaneously, the tenfold materiality of the physical basis is present at the moment of descent into the womb.

original: pakkhipitvā tettiṃsa, opapātikasattesu brahmakāyikādīnaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe cakkhusotavatthudasakāni
analyzed: pakkhipitvā tettiṃsa opapātika sattesu brahmakāyika ādīnam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe cakkhu sota vatthu dasakāni
translated: and inserting the thirty-three, there are the ten consisting of the eye, ear, and physical-basis faculties in the case of the kinds of rebirth-linking of the Brahmā-world gods, and so on.

original: jīvitindriyanavakañcāti ekūnacattālīsa rūparūpāni, tayo ca arūpino khandhāti ete
analyzed: rūpa rūpāni tayo ca arūpino khandhāti ete
translated: and adding the thirty-three, there are forty-nine material instances in the case of the beings who are spontaneously born, namely, the ten consisting of the eye-, ear-, and nose-sensitivity bases, the ten consisting of the life faculty, and the three immaterial aggregates.🔽These forty-nine states should be understood as “mentality-materiality with consciousness as condition.”

original: bācattālīsa dhammā “viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti veditabbā. Kāmabhave pana sesaopapātikānaṃ,
analyzed: dhammāḥ viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpan ti veditabbā kāma bhave pana sesa opapātikānam
translated: But in the sense-desire becoming, in the case of the remaining spontaneously born beings,

original: saṃsedajānaṃ vā sabhāvakaparipuṇṇāyatanānaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe cakkhusotaghānajivhākāyavatthubhāvadasakānīti
analyzed: saṃseda jānam vā sabhāvaka paripuṇṇa āyatanānam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā kāya vatthu bhāva dasakāni iti
translated: or in the case of the egg-born and womb-born who are complete with the faculties, there are seventy material instances at the moment of rebirth-linking, namely, the ten consisting of the eye-, ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-sensitivity bases, the ten consisting of the femininity and masculinity faculties, and the ten consisting of the life faculty, and the three immaterial aggregates.

original: sattati rūparūpāni, tayo ca arūpino khandhāti ete tesattati dhammā “viññāṇapaccayā🔽nāmarūpa”nti veditabbā. Esa ukkaṃso, avakaṃsena pana taṃtaṃdasakavikalānaṃ tassa
analyzed: sattati rūparūpāni tayo ca arūpino khandhā ti ete tesattati dhammā viññāṇa paccayā  nāma rūpam ti veditabbā esaḥ ukkaṃsaḥ avakaṃsena pana taṃ taṃ dasa kavikalānam tassa
translated: These seventy states should be understood as “mentality-materiality with consciousness as condition.”

original: tassa vasena hāpetvā hāpetvā paṭisandhiyaṃ viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpasaṅkhā veditabbā.
analyzed: tassa vasena hāpetvā hāpetvā paṭisandhiyam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpa saṅkhā veditabbā
translated: This is the maximum. But by omitting the ten consisting of the femininity and masculinity faculties, and by omitting the ten consisting of the eye-, ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-sensitivity bases, the mentality-materiality should be understood as “with consciousness as condition” in the case of the rebirth-linking consciousnesses in the various planes.

original: Arūpīnaṃ pana tayova arūpino khandhā. Asaññīnaṃ rūpato jīvitindriyanavakamevāti.
analyzed: arūpīnam pana tayo va arūpino khandhāḥ asaññīnam rūpataḥ jīvitindriya navakam eva ati
translated: But in the case of immaterial beings there are only the three immaterial aggregates. In the case of non-percipient beings there is the life faculty, which is the ninth of the materiality categories.

original: Esa tāva paṭisandhiyaṃ nayo.
analyzed: esa tāva paṭisandhiyam nayo
translated: This is the method in the case of rebirth-linking.

original: Pavatte pana sabbattha rūpapavattidese paṭisandhicittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe paṭisandhicittena
analyzed: pavatte pana sabbattha rūpa pavatti dese paṭisandhi cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe paṭisandhi cittena
translated: But in the case of the course of existence, in the case of every occurrence of materiality, at the moment of the life-continuum’s presence after the rebirth-linking consciousness,

original: saha pavattaututo utusamuṭṭhānaṃ suddhaṭṭhakaṃ pātubhavati. Paṭhamabhavaṅgato pabhuti
analyzed: saha utu samuṭṭhānam suddhaṭṭhakam pātubhavati paṭhama bhavaṅgataḥ
translated: the materiality originated by temperature, that is, the pure octad, becomes manifest together with the temperature that occurred together with the rebirth-linking consciousness.🔽From the first life-continuum onwards,

original: cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ suddhaṭṭhakaṃ, saddapātubhāvakāle ututo ceva cittato ca saddanavakaṃ,
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhānam suddhaṭṭhakam sadda pātubhāva kāle ututaḥ ca iva cittataḥ ca sadda navakam
translated: the materiality originated by consciousness, that is, the pure octad, becomes manifest. At the moment of the manifestation of sound, the sound ennead originated by temperature and by consciousness becomes manifest.

original: kabaḷīkārāhārūpajīvīnaṃ āhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ suddhaṭṭhakanti evaṃ āhārasamuṭṭhānassa,🔽suddhaṭṭhakassa, utucittasamuṭṭhānānañca dvinnaṃ navakānaṃ vasena chabbīsatividhaṃ,
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra āhāra upajīvīnam āhāra samuṭṭhānam suddhaṭṭhakanti evam āhāra samuṭṭhānassa  suddhaṭṭhakassa utu citta samuṭṭhānānam ca dvinnam navakānam vasena chabbīsatividham
translated: In the case of those who subsist on material food, the materiality originated by nutriment, that is, the pure octad, becomes manifest. So there are twenty-six kinds of materiality originated by temperature,

original: ekekacitte tikkhattuṃ uppajjamānaṃ vuttakammasamuṭṭhānañca sattatividhanti channavutividhaṃ
analyzed: ekeka citte ti khattum uppajjamānam vutta kamma samuṭṭhānam ca sattatividhanti channavutividham
translated: by nutriment, and by consciousness, and there are seventy kinds of materiality originated by kamma, which occurs three times with each consciousness. Thus there are ninety-six kinds of materiality.

original: rūpaṃ, tayo ca arūpino khandhāti navanavutidhammā yathāsambhavaṃ “viññāṇapaccayā
analyzed: rūpam tayo ca arūpino khandhā ti nava navuti dhammāḥ yathāsambhavam viññāṇa paccayā
translated: The nine-and-ninety dhammas are the five aggregates, the twelve sense bases, and the eighteen elements, which are the three kinds of aggregates, bases, and elements.🔽

original: nāmarūpa”nti veditabbā.
analyzed: nāma rūpam iti veditabbā
translated: The nine-and-ninety states, namely, the three immaterial aggregates and the three kinds of materiality, should be understood as “mentality-materiality with consciousness as condition” in the way already stated.

original: Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ viññāṇapaccayā hotī”ti?
analyzed: tattha siyā katham pana etam jānitabbam paṭisandhi nāma rūpam viññāṇa paccayā hoti iti
translated: Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that mentality-materiality at rebirth-linking has consciousness as its condition?

original: Suttato yuttito ca. Sutte hi “cittānuparivattino dhammā”tiādinā nayena bahudhā vedanādīnaṃ
analyzed: suttataḥ yuttitaḥ ca sutte hi citta anuparivattinaḥ dhammā ati ādinā nayena bahudhā vedanā ādīnam
translated: From the Suttas and from sound reasoning. For in the Suttas it is established in many places that feeling,

original: viññāṇapaccayatā siddhā. Yuttito pana –
analyzed: viññāṇa paccaya tā siddhā yuttitaḥ pana
translated: perception, and formations have consciousness as their condition. And from sound reasoning:🔽“By the type of consciousness that is seen here,

original: “Cittajena hi rūpena, idha diṭṭhena sijjhati;
analyzed: citta jena hi rūpena idha diṭṭhena sijjhati
translated: The unseen type of materiality is proved;🔽And consciousness is the condition too

original: Adiṭṭhassāpi rūpassa, viññāṇaṃ paccayo itī”ti.
analyzed: a diṭṭhassa api rūpassa viññāṇam paccayaḥ iti iti
translated: For the unseen type of mentality.”

original: Nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatananti nāmaṃ vuttameva. Idha pana rūpaṃ niyamato cattāri mahābhūtāni,
analyzed: nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanam ti nāmam vuttam eva idha pana rūpam niyamato cattāri mahābhūtāni
translated: Mentality-materiality with mentality as condition. The mentality stated there is the same as the mentality stated here. But the materiality is of eleven kinds, namely, the four primary elements and the seven kinds of matter derived from the primary elements, which are the physical basis of eye-consciousness, etc., and the physical basis of body-consciousness.

original: cha vatthūni, jīvitindriyanti ekādasavidhaṃ. Saḷāyatanaṃ pana cakkhāyatanaṃ sotaghānajivhākāyamanāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: cha vatthūni ekādasavidham saḷāyatanam pana cakkhāyatanam sota ghāna jivhā kāya mana āyatanam
translated: The sixfold base is the eye-base, ear-base, nose-base, tongue-base, body-base, and mind-base.

original: Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “nāmarūpaṃ saḷāyatanassa paccayo”ti? Nāmarūpabhāve bhāvato. Tassa tassa hi nāmassa rūpassa ca bhāve taṃ taṃ āyatanaṃ hoti, na aññathāti.
analyzed: tattha siyā  katham pana etam jānitabbam nāma rūpam saḷāyatanassa paccayo ti nāma rūpa bhāve bhāvato tassa tassa hi nāmassa rūpassa ca bhāve tam tam āyatanam hoti na aññathā ati
translated: Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that mentality-materiality is a condition for the sixfold base? It is to be known as follows: because of presence and absence. For the respective base is only when there is the respective kind of mentality and materiality, not otherwise.

original: Saḷāyatanapaccayā phassoti –
analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti
translated: With the sixfold base as condition, contact:🔽Six contacts in brief,

original: “Chaḷeva phassā saṅkhepā, cakkhusamphassaādayo;
analyzed: chaḷ eva phassā saṅkhepā cakkhu samphassa ādayo
translated: Eye-contact, etc.,🔽Are thirty-two in detail,

original: Viññāṇamiva bāttiṃsa, vitthārena bhavanti te”.
analyzed: viññāṇam iva vāttiṃsa vitthārena bhavanti te
translated: Like consciousness.

original: Phassapaccayā vedanāti –🔽“Dvārato vedanā vuttā, cakkhusamphassajādikā;
analyzed: phassa paccayā vedanā ti  dvārataḥ vedanā vuttā cakkhu samphassa jā ādikā
translated: With contact as condition, feeling:🔽Feelings are said to be six,🔽Eye-contact-born, etc.,🔽Six only in brief,

original: Chaḷeva tā pabhedena, idha bāttiṃsa vedanā”.
analyzed: chaḷā iva tā pabhedena idha bāttiṃsa vedanā
translated: But thirty-two in detail here.

original: Vedanāpaccayā taṇhāti –
analyzed: vedanā paccayā taṇhā ati
translated: With feeling as condition, craving:🔽Craving is shown here

original: “Rūpataṇhādibhedena, cha taṇhā idha dīpitā;
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedena cha taṇhā dīpitā
translated: As sixfold, classed as craving for forms, etc.;🔽Each is threefold there,

original: Ekekā tividhā tattha, pavattākārato matā.
analyzed: ekekā tividhā tattha pavatta ākārataḥ matā
translated: According to the mode of activity.🔽The miserable longs for pleasure,

original: “Dukkhī sukhaṃ patthayati, sukhī bhiyyopi icchati;
analyzed: dukkhī sukham patthayati sukhī bhiyyas api icchati
translated: The pleasure-drenched longs for more,🔽But equanimity is said

original: Upekkhā pana santattā, sukhamicceva bhāsitā.
analyzed: upekkhā pana santattā sukham iccā iva bhāsitā
translated: To be just pleasure, being peaceful.🔽So from craving there arise

original: “Taṇhāya paccayā tasmā, honti tissopi vedanā;
analyzed: taṇhāya paccayā tasmā honti tissaḥ api vedanā
translated: The three feelings, it is said,

original: Vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, iti vuttā mahesinā”ti.
analyzed: vedanā paccayā taṇhā iti vuttā mahesinā ati
translated: And feeling is a requisite for craving, So the Great Sage has declared.

original: Taṇhāpaccayā upādānanti cattāri upādānāni kāmupādānaṃ diṭṭhupādānaṃ sīlabbatupādānaṃ🔽attavādupādānaṃ. Upādānapaccayā bhavoti idha kammabhavo adhippeto, upapattibhavo
analyzed: taṇhā paccayā upādānanti cattāri upādānāni kāma upādānam diṭṭh upādānam sīla bbata upādānam  upādānam upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ ti idha kamma bhavaḥ adhippetaḥ upapatti bhavo
translated: With craving as condition, clinging: there are four kinds of clinging: clinging to sensual pleasures, clinging to views, clinging to virtue and practice, and clinging to a doctrine of self.🔽With clinging as condition, existence: here, the kind of existence that is kamma is intended; but the kind of existence that is rebirth-linking is stated by way of the outcome of the kamma.

original: pana paduddhāravasena vutto. Bhavapaccayā jātīti kammabhavapaccayā jāti paṭisandhikhandhānaṃ pātubhavo.
analyzed: pana paduddhāra vasena vutto bhava paccayā jāti iti kamma bhava paccayā jāti paṭisandhi khandhānam pātubhavaḥ
translated: With existence as condition, birth: with the kind of existence that is kamma as condition, birth, the manifestation of the aggregates, comes about.🔽Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that existence is a condition for birth?

original: Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “bhavo jātiyā paccayo”ti ce? Bāhirapaccayasamattepi
analyzed: tattha siyā katham pana itam jānitabbam bhavaḥ jātiyā paccayaḥ ti ce bāhira paccaya samatte pi
translated: Even when external conditions are present,🔽the difference of inferior and superior, etc., is seen.

original: hīnapaṇītatādivisesadassanato. Bāhirānañhi janakajananisukkasoṇitāhārādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ🔽samattepi sattānaṃ yamakānampi sataṃ hīnapaṇītatādiviseso dissati. So ca na ahetuko
analyzed: hīna paṇīta tā ādi visesa dassanataḥ bāhirānam hi janaka janani sukka soṇita āhāra ādīnam paccayānam  samatte pi sattānam yamakānam pi satam hīna paṇīta tā ādi visesaḥ dissati saḥ ca na ahetukaḥ
translated: Even when the external conditions such as the parents, the act of conception, the nutriment, the blood, the semen, etc., are present,🔽the difference of inferior and superior, etc., among beings is seen. And that is not without a cause,

original: sabbadā ca sabbesañca abhāvato, na kammabhavato aññahetuko tadabhinibbattakasattānaṃ
analyzed: sabbadā ca sabbesam ca abhāvataḥ na kamma bhavataḥ añña hetukaḥ tad abhinibbattaka sattānam
translated: because it would then follow that all beings would be born alike, and because it would then follow that there would be no point in doing wholesome and unwholesome kamma. Nor is it caused by anything else than kamma-existence that produces rebirth-linking,🔽because it is not reasonable to suppose that there is a separate kamma-result for each of the aggregates.

original: ajjhattasantāne aññassa kāraṇassa abhāvatoti kammabhavahetukova. Kammañhi sattānaṃ
analyzed: ajjhatta santāne aññassa kāraṇassa abhāvato ti kamma bhava hetukaḥ uva kammaṃ hi sattānam
translated: because there is no other cause in the individual’s own continuity.

original: hīnapaṇītatādivisesassa hetu. Tenāha bhagavā – “kammaṃ satte vibhajati yadidaṃ hīnapaṇītatāyā”ti.
analyzed: hīna paṇīta tā ādi visesassa hetu tena āha bhagavā kammam satte vibhajati yat idam hīna paṇīta tāya ati
translated: For kamma is the cause of the distinction of beings as inferior and superior, and so on. Hence the Blessed One said: “It is kamma that distinguishes beings as inferior and superior” .

original: Tasmā jānitabbametaṃ “bhavo jātiyā paccayo”ti.🔽Jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇantiādīsu yasmā asati jātiyā jarāmaraṇañceva sokādayo ca dhammā
analyzed: tasmā jānitabbam etam bhavaḥ jātiyā paccayaḥ ti  jāti paccayā jarā maraṇan ti ādīsu yasmai asati jātiyā jarā maraṇan ca iva soka ādayo ca dhammā
translated: So it should be understood that “becoming is a condition for birth.”🔽In the case of the remaining terms beginning with “ageing-and-death,” since there would be no ageing-and-death and sorrow, etc.,🔽if there were no birth, but since there are ageing-and-death and sorrow, etc.,

original: na honti, jātiyā pana sati jarāmaraṇañceva jarāmaraṇasaṅkhātadukkhadhammaphuṭṭhassa
analyzed: na honti jātiyā pana sati jarā maraṇam ca iva jarā maraṇa saṅkhāta dukkha dhamma phuṭṭhassa
translated: when there is birth, whether or not the fool who is touched by ageing-and-death, etc., is in contact with the various kinds of suffering called ageing, etc.,

original: bālassa jarāmaraṇādisambandhā vā tena tena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa anabhisambandhā
analyzed: bālassa jarā maraṇa ādi sambandhāḥ vā tena tena dukkha dhammena phuṭṭhassa an abhisambandhā
translated: and whether or not he is in contact with the various kinds of suffering called sorrow, etc.,

original: vā sokādayo ca dhammā honti. Tasmā jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti. Samecca abhisamecca
analyzed: vā soka ādayo ca dhammā honti tasmā jāti paccayā jarā maraṇanti samet ca abhisamet ca
translated: then it is because of this that “birth is a condition for ageing-and-death,” and so on.

original: dhammanti ñāṇena samāgantvā catusaccadhammaṃ paṭivijjhitvā.
analyzed: dhammanti ñāṇena samāgantvā catu sacca dhammam paṭivijjhitvā
translated: Having fully understood, fully penetrated, the Dhamma, that is, the Four Noble Truths, by means of the knowledge of suffering, etc.

original: Evaṃ dvādasapadikaṃ paccayākārappavattiṃ dassetvā idāni vivaṭṭavasena avijjādīnaṃ🔽nirodhadassanatthaṃ “avijjānirodhā saṅkhāranirodhoti samecca abhisamecca dhamma”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: evam dvādasa padikam paccaya ākāra ppavattim dassetvā idāni vivaṭṭa vasena avijjā ādīnam  nirodha dassana ttham avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho ti samet ca abhisamet ca dhamma nti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the occurrence of the twelvefold formula of conditions, he now said, “When he has fully understood and penetrated the Dhamma as ‘When this is, that is’ … “ in order to show the cessation of ignorance, etc., in the reverse order.🔽Herein, with the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of volitional formations: with the cessation of ignorance, which is non- arising, non-occurrence, non-manifestation, there is the cessation of volitional formations.

original: Tattha avijjānirodhāti avijjāya anuppādanirodhā puna appavattinirodhena. Saṅkhāranirodhoti
analyzed: tattha avijjā nirodhā ati avijjāya anuppāda nirodhā puna appavatti nirodhena saṅkhāra nirodho ti
translated: With the cessation of volitional formations there is the cessation of consciousness: with the cessation of volitional formations there is the cessation of consciousness.🔽With the cessation of consciousness there is the cessation of mentality-materiality: with the cessation of consciousness there is the cessation of mentality-materiality.🔽With the cessation of mentality-materiality there is the cessation of the sixfold base: with the cessation of mentality-materiality there is the cessation of the sixfold base.🔽With the cessation of the sixfold base there is the cessation of contact: with the cessation of the sixfold base there is the cessation of contact.🔽With the cessation of contact there is the cessation of feeling: with the cessation of contact there is the cessation of feeling.🔽With the cessation of feeling there is the cessation of craving: with the cessation of feeling there is the cessation of craving.🔽With the cessation of craving there is the cessation of clinging: with the cessation of craving there is the cessation of clinging.🔽With the cessation of clinging there is the cessation of existence: with the cessation of clinging there is the cessation of existence.🔽With the cessation of existence there is the cessation of birth: with the cessation of existence there is the cessation of birth.🔽With the cessation of birth there is the cessation of ageing and death: with the cessation of birth there is the cessation of ageing and death.

original: saṅkhārānaṃ anuppādanirodho hoti. Evaṃ sesapadesupi. Idaṃ dukkhantiādayo pubbe vuttanayā
analyzed: saṅkhārānam anuppāda nirodhaḥ hoti evam sesa padesu pi idam dukkham ti ādayo pubbe vutta nayā
translated: Thus there is a cessation of this whole mass of suffering.

original: eva. Ime dhammā abhiññeyyāti ime tebhūmakā dhammā sabhāvalakkhaṇāvabodhavasena sobhanākārena,🔽adhikena ñāṇena vā sabhāvato jānitabbā. Pariññeyyāti sāmaññalakkhaṇāvabodhavasena,
analyzed: eva ime dhammā abhiññeyyā ati ime tebhūmakāḥ dhammā sabhāva lakkhaṇa avabodha vasena sobhana ākārena  adhikena ñāṇena vā sabhāvataḥ jānitabbā pariññeyyā ati sāmañña lakkhaṇa avabodha vasena
translated: Translation: Evaṃ dvādasapadikāya paccayākārappavattiṃ dassetvā idāni vivaṭṭavasena avijjādīnaṃ🔽nirodhadassanatthaṃ avijjānirodhā saṅkhāranirodhoti samecca abhisamecca dhammotiādimāha |

original: kiccasamāpanavasena ca byāpitvā jānitabbā. Ime dhammā pahātabbāti ime samudayapakkhikā
analyzed: kicca samāpana vasena ca byāpitvā jānitabbāḥ ime dhammā pahātabbā ati ime samudaya pakkhikā
translated: Tattha avijjānirodhāti avijjāya anuppādanirodhā punappunaṃ appavatti nirodhena | Saṅkhāranirodho

original: dhammā tena tena guṇaṅgena pahātabbā. Bhāvetabbāti vaḍḍhetabbā. Sacchikātabbāti paccakkhaṃ
analyzed: dhammā tena tena guṇaṅgena pahātabbā bhāvetabbā ati vaḍḍhetabbā sacchikātabbā ati paccakkham
translated: and the ideas should be abandoned by him in this way and that way. “Should be developed”: should be increased. “Should be realized”: should be made evident.

original: kātabbā. Duvidhā sacchikiriyā paṭilābhasacchikiriyā ca ārammaṇasacchikiriyā ca. Channaṃ
analyzed: kātabbā duvidhā sacchikiriyā paṭilābha sacchikiriyā ca ārammaṇa sacchikiriyā ca channam
translated: There are two kinds of realization: realization by obtaining and realization by fathoming.

original: phassāyatanānanti cakkhādīnaṃ channaṃ āyatanānaṃ. Samudayañca atthaṅgamañcāti uppādañca nirodhañca.
analyzed: phassa āyatanānanti cakkha ādīnam channam āyatanānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca ati uppādañca nirodhañca
translated: “The six bases of contact”: of the eye, etc., the six bases. “Arising and passing away”: arising and cessation.

original: Bhūripaññoti bhūri viyāti bhūri, tāya bhūripaññāya samannāgato bhūripañño. Mahāpaññotiādīsu mahāpaññādīhi samannāgatoti attho.
analyzed: bhūri pañño ti bhūri viyā ati bhūri tāya bhūri paññāya samannāgataḥ bhūri pañño mahā pañño ti ādīsu mahā paññā ādīhi samannāgataḥ ti attho
translated: “Greatly wise”: “great” is “greatly”; he is greatly wise, is greatly wise, because he possesses that great wisdom. “Greatly intelligent” and so on: the meaning is that he possesses great intelligence, etc.

original: Tatridaṃ mahāpaññādīnaṃ nānattaṃ – katamā mahāpaññā? Mahante atthe pariggaṇhātīti🔽mahāpaññā. Mahante dhamme…pe… mahantā niruttiyo… mahantāni paṭibhānāni pariggaṇhātīti
analyzed: tatra idam mahāpaññā ādīnam nānattam katamā mahāpaññā mahante atthe pariggaṇhāti iti  mahā paññā mahante dhammepe mahantāḥ niruttiyaḥ mahantāni paṭibhānāni pariggaṇhāti iti
translated: Herein, the difference between great wisdom, etc., is this. What is great wisdom?🔽He apprehends great meanings,

original: mahāpaññā. Mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā. Mahante samādhikkhandhe…pe…
analyzed: mahā paññā mahante sīla kkhandhe pariggaṇhāti iti mahā paññā mahante
translated: great ideas, great letters, great expressions, great eloquence, great virtue, great concentration, great understanding, great liberation, great wisdom of liberation.

original: paññākkhandhe… vimuttikkhandhe… vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhe pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā.🔽Mahantāni ṭhānāṭhānāni…pe… mahāvihārasamāpattiyo… mahantāni ariyasaccāni… mahante🔽satipaṭṭhāne… sammappadhāne… iddhipāde… mahantāni indriyāni … balāni… bojjhaṅgāni…🔽mahante ariyamagge… mahantāni sāmaññaphalāni… mahāabhiññāyo… mahantaṃ paramatthaṃ
analyzed: paññā kkhandhe vimutti kkhandhe vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandhe pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññā  mahantāni ṭhānāṭhānānipe mahāvihāra samāpattiyaḥ mahantāni ariya saccāni mahante  satipaṭṭhāne sammappadhāne iddhipāde mahantāni indriyāni balāni bojjhaṅgāni  mahante ariya magge mahantāni sāmañña phalāni mahā abhiññāyaḥ mahantam paramattham
translated: He has great understanding because he has penetrated the aggregate of understanding, the aggregate of emancipation, the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of emancipation.

original: nibbānaṃ pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā.🔽Katamā puthupaññā? Puthunānākhandhesu ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti puthupaññā. Puthunānādhātūsu…pe…🔽puthunānāāyatanesu… puthunānāpaṭiccasamuppādesu… puthunānāsuññatamanupalabbhesu…
analyzed: nibbānam pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññā  katamā puthu paññā puthu nānā khandhesu ñāṇam pavattati iti puthu paññā puthu nānā dhātu supe  puthu nānā āyatanesu puthu nānā paṭiccasamuppādesu puthu nānā suññatama nupalabbhesu
translated: He has great understanding because he has penetrated the great bases, the great abodes of beings, the great monasteries, the great attainments, the great noble truths, the great foundations of mindfulness, the great right endeavours, the great bases of spiritual success, the great powers, the great factors of enlightenment, the great path, the great fruits of asceticism, the great kinds of direct-knowledge, the great ultimate goal, Nibbāna.

original: puthunānāatthesu… dhammesu… niruttīsu… paṭibhānesu… puthunānāsīlakkhandhesu… puthunānāsamādhipaññāvimuttivimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhesu…
analyzed: puthu nānā atthesu dhammesu niruttīsu paṭibhānesu puthu nānā sīla kkhandhesu puthu nānā samādhi paññā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandhesu
translated: What is versatile understanding? Understanding that occurs in regard to the various and diverse aggregates, elements, sense bases, dependent origination, void states, meanings, dhammas, expressions, and insights, and in regard to the various and diverse aggregates of virtue, concentration, understanding, emancipation, and the knowledge and vision of emancipation—this is called versatile understanding.

original: puthunānāṭhānāṭhānesu… puthunānāvihārasamāpattīsu… puthunānāariyasaccesu… puthunānāsatipaṭṭhānesu…🔽sammappadhānesu… iddhipādesu… indriyesu… balesu… bojjhaṅgesu… puthunānāariyamaggesu…🔽sāmaññaphalesu… abhiññāsu… puthunānājanasādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkamma paramatthe
analyzed: puthu nānā ṭhāna aṭhānesu puthu nānā vihāra samāpattīsu puthu nānā ariya saccesu puthu nānā sati paṭṭhānesu  sammappadhānesu iddhipādesu indriyesu balesu bojjhaṅgesu puthu nānā ariya maggesu  sāmañña phalesu abhiññāsu puthuna anājana sādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkamma paramatthe
translated: in the various kinds of diverse abodes of animals, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of ghosts, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of gods, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of human beings, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of Brahmās, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the base of infinite space, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the base of infinite consciousness, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the base of nothingness, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of diverse abodes of the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, in the various kinds of original: Hāsabahulo vihārasamāpattiyo paripūretīti hāsapaññā. Hāsabahulo ariyasaccāni paṭivijjhatīti
analyzed: hāsa bahulaḥ vihāra samāpattiyaḥ paripūreti iti hāsa paññā hāsa bahulaḥ ariya saccāni paṭivijjhati iti
translated: He penetrates the Noble Truths with much laughter.

original: hāsapaññā. Satipaṭṭhāne bhāveti sammappadhāne… iddhipāde… indriyāni… balāni… bojjhaṅge…
analyzed: hāsa paññā sati paṭṭhāne bhāveti sammappadhāne iddhipāde indriyāni balāni bojjhaṅge
translated: He develops the foundations of mindfulness, the right efforts, the bases of psychic power, the faculties, the powers, the factors of enlightenment,

original: ariyamaggaṃ bhāvetīti hāsapaññā, hāsabahulo sāmaññaphalāni sacchikarotīti hāsapaññā,
analyzed: ariya maggam bhāveti iti hāsa paññā hāsa bahulaḥ sāmañña phalāni sacchikaroti iti hāsa paññā
translated: the Noble Eightfold Path with much laughter. He realizes the fruits of asceticism with much laughter.

original: abhiññāyo paṭivijjhatīti hāsapaññā, hāsabahulo paramatthaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikarotīti hāsapaññā.🔽Katamā javanapaññā? Yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā
analyzed: abhiññāyo paṭivijjhati iti hāsa paññā hāsa bahulaḥ paramattham nibbānam sacchikaroti iti hāsa paññā  katamā javana paññā yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā
translated: He penetrates the kinds of direct knowledge with much laughter. He realizes the ultimate good, Nibbana, with much laughter.🔽What is quick-darting understanding? Whatever materiality there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—🔽all materiality is impermanent, suffering, and nonself. He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the Teacher’s instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the Dhamma’s instruction.

original: vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: vā oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam rūpam
translated: He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the Sangha’s instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the training’s instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the virtues’ instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the generosity’s instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the devas’ instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the aggregates’ instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the sense-spheres’ instruction.🔽He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the elements’ instruction.

original: aniccato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā. Dukkhato, anattato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.
analyzed: aniccataḥ khippam javati iti javana paññā dukkhataḥ anattataḥ khippam javati iti javana paññā
translated: He darts quickly, swiftly, fast, without delay, without tarrying, with the darting of the mind that has faith in the truths’ instruction.🔽He

original: Yā kāci vedanā…pe… yā kāci saññā… ye keci saṅkhārā… yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ…pe…
analyzed: yā kāci vedanā pe yā kāci saññā ye keci saṅkhārāḥ yam kiñci viññāṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam pe
translated: Whatever feelings there are … Whatever perceptions there are … Whatever volitions there are … Whatever consciousness there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near:

original: yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccato… dukkhato… anattato khippaṃ javatīti
analyzed: yam dūre santike vā sabbam viññāṇam aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ khippam javati iti
translated: Whatever feelings there are… Whatever perceptions there are… Whatever (volitional) processes there are… Whatever consciousness there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—having seen all consciousness as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’ one is freed by nonclinging.🔽This is called wisdom that is swift.

original: javanapaññā. Cakkhuṃ…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccato… dukkhato…
analyzed: javana paññā cakkhuṃpe jarā maraṇaṃ atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccataḥ dukkhato
translated: The eye, forms, eye-consciousness, eye-contact, and whatever feeling that arises with eye-contact as condition—whether pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—having seen all this as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’ one is freed by nonclinging.

original: anattato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.
analyzed: an attataḥ khippam javati iti javana paññā
translated: This is called wisdom that is swift.

original: Rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena, dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena, anattā asārakaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena anattā asāraka ṭṭhena ati
translated: Form is impermanent because of destruction, painful because of oppression, and not self because of being without substance.

original: tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā vibhūtaṃ katvā rūpanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti🔽javanapaññā. Vedanā… saññā… saṅkhārā… viññāṇaṃ… cakkhuṃ…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā vibhūtam katvā rūpa nirodhe nibbāne khippam javati iti  javana paññā vedanā saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam cakkhuṃpe jarā maraṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam
translated: Having weighed, having considered, having discerned, having analyzed, one is swift in nibbāna, which is the cessation of form.

original: aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena, dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena, anattā asārakaṭṭhenāti tulayitvā…pe… vibhūtaṃ
analyzed: aniccam khaya ṭṭhena dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena anattā asāraka ṭṭhena ati tulayitvā āpe vibhūtam
translated: This is called wisdom that is swift. Feelings… Perceptions… (volitional) Processes… Consciousness… The eye… Forms… Eye-consciousness… Eye-contact… Whatever feeling that arises with eye-contact as condition—whether pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—having seen all this as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’ one is freed by nonclinging.🔽This is called wisdom that is swift.

original: katvā jarāmaraṇanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.🔽Rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ🔽virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti tulayitvā…pe… vibhūtaṃ katvā rūpanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ🔽javatīti javanapaññā. Vedanā…pe… saññā… saṅkhārā… viññāṇaṃ… cakkhuṃ…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ🔽atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ…pe… nirodhadhammanti tulayitvā…pe… vibhūtaṃ katvā🔽jarāmaraṇanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.
analyzed: katvā jarā maraṇa nirodhe nibbāne khippam javati iti javana paññā  rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam  virāga dhammam nirodha dhammanti tulayitvā āpe vibhūtam katvā rūpa nirodhe nibbāne khippam  javati iti javana paññā saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam cakkhuṃpe jarā maraṇam  atīta anāgata paccuppannam anicca āpe nirodha dhammanti tulayitvā āpe vibhūtam katvā  jarā maraṇa nirodhe nibbāne khippam javati iti javana paññā
translated: and quickly penetrates to the extinction of ageing-and-death, which is Nibbāna, it is penetration understanding.

original: Katamā tikkhapaññā? Khippaṃ kilese chindatīti tikkhapaññā. Uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ🔽nādhivāseti. Uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ… uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ… uppannuppanne pāpake
analyzed: katamā tikkha paññā khippam kilese chindati iti tikkha paññā uppannam kāma vitakkam 🔽na adhivāseti uppannam byāpāda vitakkam uppannam vihiṃsā vitakkam uppanna uppanne pāpake
translated: He comprehends form … Feeling … Perception … Formations … Consciousness … Eye … Ear … Nose … Tongue … Body … Mind … Visible objects … Mental phenomena … Eye-consciousness … Ear-consciousness … Nose-consciousness … Tongue-consciousness … Body-consciousness … Mind-consciousness … Eye-contact … Ear-contact … Nose-contact … Tongue-contact … Body-contact … Mind-contact … Feeling that arises from eye-contact … Feeling that arises from ear-contact … Feeling that arises from nose-contact … Feeling that arises from tongue-contact … Feeling that arises from body-contact … Feeling that arises from mind-contact … Perception of visible objects … Perception of mental phenomena … Volition about visible objects … Volition about mental phenomena … Craving for visible objects … Craving for mental phenomena … Applied thought about visible objects … Applied thought about mental phenomena … Sustained thought about visible objects … Sustained thought about mental phenomena … Doubt about the visible objects … Doubt about mental phenomena … Longing for visible objects … Longing for mental phenomena … Disenchantment with visible objects … Disenchantment with mental phenomena … Desire for visible objects … Desire for mental phenomena … Aversion towards visible objects … Aversion towards mental phenomena … Translation: jarāmaraṇanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā | rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti tulayitvā …pe… vibhūtaṃ katvā rūpanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā | vedanaṃ … saññaṃ … saṅkhāre … viññāṇaṃ … cakkhuṃ … jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ …pe… nirodhadhammanti tulayitvā …pe… vibhūtaṃ katvā jarāmaraṇanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā | katamā tikkhapaññā? khippaṃ kilese chindatīti tikkhapaññā | uppannaṃ kāmavit

original: akusale dhamme… uppannaṃ rāgaṃ… uppannaṃ dosaṃ… mohaṃ… kodhaṃ… upanāhaṃ… makkhaṃ…
analyzed: akusale dhamme uppannam rāgam uppannam dosam moham kodham upanāham makkham
translated: in unwholesome thoughts… in lust that has arisen… in hate that has arisen… in delusion that has arisen… in anger…🔽in enmity… in disparaging… in insolence…

original: paḷāsaṃ… issaṃ… macchariyaṃ… māyaṃ… sāṭheyyaṃ… thambhaṃ… sārambhaṃ… mānaṃ… atimānaṃ…🔽madaṃ… pamādaṃ… sabbe kilese… sabbe duccarite… sabbe abhisaṅkhāre… sabbe bhavagāmikamme
analyzed: paḷāsam issam macchariyam māyam sāṭheyyam thambham sa ārambham mānam atimānam  madam pamādam sabbe kilese sabbe duccarite sabbe abhisaṅkhāre sabbe bhava gāmi kamme
translated: in envy… in avarice… in deceit… in fraud… in obstinacy… in domineering… in conceit… in vanity…🔽in arrogance… in negligence… in all defilements… in all evil actions… in all volitional formations…

original: nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gametīti tikkhapaññā. Ekamhi
analyzed: na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti iti tikkha paññā ekamhi
translated: in all deeds that lead to renewed existence, he does not acquiesce in them, he abandons them, he dispels them, he destroys them, he abolishes them, he does not tolerate them, he relinquishes them, he gives them up, he rejects them.

original: āsane cattāro ariyamaggā, cattāri ca sāmaññaphalāni, catasso ca paṭisambhidāyo, cha
analyzed: āsane cattāro ariya maggā cattāri ca sāmañña phalāni catasso ca paṭisambhidāyo cha
translated: In a single seat he has attained the four noble paths, the four fruits of asceticism, the four discriminations,

original: abhiññāyo adhigatā honti sacchikatā phassitā paññāyāti tikkhapaññā.
analyzed: abhiññāyaḥ adhigatāḥ honti sacchikatā phassitā paññāyāti tikkha paññā
translated: and the six kinds of direct knowledge. He has realized them with wisdom.

original: Katamā nibbedhikapaññā? Idhekacco sabbasaṅkhāresu ubbegabahulo hoti uttāsabahulo
analyzed: katamā nibbedhika paññā idha ekaccaḥ sabba saṅkhāresu ubbega bahulaḥ hoti uttāsa bahulaḥ
translated: What is deep wisdom? Here someone is full of anxiety, full of dread,

original: ukkaṇṭhanabahulo aratibahulo anabhiratibahulo bahimukho na ramati sabbasaṅkhāresu,
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhana bahulaḥ arati bahulaḥ anabhirati bahulaḥ bahimukhaḥ na ramati sabba saṅkhāresu
translated: full of distress, full of discontent, turned outward, not delighting in all formations,

original: anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ lobhakkhandhaṃ nibbijjhati padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā.🔽Anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ dosakkhandhaṃ…pe… mohakkhandhaṃ… kodhaṃ… upanāhaṃ…pe…🔽sabbe bhavagāmikamme nibbijjhati padāletīti nibbedhikapaññā.🔽28. Sa sabbadhammesu visenibhūto, yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vāti so bhūripañño
analyzed: a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam lobha kkhandham nibbijjhati padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā  a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam dosa kkhandham pe moha kkhandham kodham upanāham pe  sabbe bhava gāmi kamme nibbijjhati padāleti iti nibbedhika paññā  sa sabba dhammesu viseni bhūtaḥ yam kiñci diṭṭham va sutam mutam vā ati saḥ bhūri paññaḥ
translated: He penetrates and bursts asunder the mass of greed, the mass of hate, the mass of delusion, the mass of anger, the mass of malice, the mass of anger-and-malice, the mass of denigration, the mass of domineering, the mass of envy, the mass of avarice, the mass of deceit, the mass of fraud, the mass of craftiness, the mass of presumption, the mass of arrogance, the mass of craving, the mass of false views, the mass of conceit, the mass of obstinacy, the mass of stubbornness, the mass of obstinacy-and-stubbornness, the mass of agitation, the mass of negligence, the mass of all evil, unwholesome things.🔽He penetrates and bursts asunder all the kamma-formations that lead to renewed existence.🔽He is penetrating understanding.🔽He is the one of great understanding who, in regard to all things, is free from bondage,🔽who has seen, heard, or sensed anything.

original: khīṇāsavo yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā mutaṃ vā tesu sabbadhammesu mārasenaṃ vināsetvā🔽ṭhitabhāvena visenibhūto. Tameva dassinti taṃ eva visuddhadassiṃ. Vivaṭaṃ carantanti🔽taṇhāchadanādivigamena vivaṭaṃ hutvā carantaṃ. Kenīdha lokasmi vikappayeyyāti kena🔽idha loke taṇhākappena vā diṭṭhikappena vā koci vikappeyya, tesaṃ vā pahīnattā rāgādinā pubbe vuttenāti.
