original: Kāmā te paṭhamā senātiādīsu catūsu gāthāsu ayamattho – yasmā āditova agāriyabhūte
analyzed: kāmā te paṭhamā senā ati ādīsu catūsu gāthāsu ayam attho yasmai āditas va agāriya bhūte
translated: In the four stanzas beginning, “The first army of the Lord of Death,” the meaning is this. Since from the very beginning sensual desires delude beings who are householders,

original: satte vatthukāmesu kilesakāmā mohayanti, te abhibhuyya anagāriyabhāvaṃ upagatānaṃ
analyzed: satte vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmāḥ mohayanti te abhibhuyya anagāriya bhāvam upagatānam
translated: and since, after overcoming them, they have gone forth from the home life,

original: pantesu vā senāsanesu, aññataraññataresu vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati uppajjati.
analyzed: pantesu vā senāsanesu aññatara aññataresu vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati uppajjati
translated: then, in regard to the dwelling places in the forest or to the various kinds of unwholesome states, discontent arises.

original: Vuttañcetaṃ – “pabbajitena kho, āvuso, abhirati dukkarā”ti. Tato te parapaṭibaddhajīvikattā
analyzed: vuttam ca itam pabbajitena kho āvuso abhirati dukkarā ti tatas te para paṭibaddha jīvika ttā
translated: For this is said: “It is difficult, friend, for one who has gone forth to find satisfaction” . Then, because their livelihood is dependent on others,

original: khuppipāsā bādheti, tāya bādhitānaṃ pariyesanataṇhā cittaṃ kilamayati, atha nesaṃ🔽kilantacittānaṃ thinamiddhaṃ okkamati tato visesamanadhigacchantānaṃ durabhisambhavesu
analyzed: khuppipāsā bādheti tāya bādhitānam pariyesana taṇhā cittam kilamayati atha nesam  kilanta cittānam thinam iddham okkamati tatas visesam anadhigacchantānam durabhisambhavesu
translated: hunger and thirst afflict them. Afflicted by these, the craving for search for requisites torments their minds. Then,🔽when their minds are tormented, they fall into sloth and torpor. Then, not attaining distinction, they dwell in dwelling places in the forest and in the jungle that are difficult to enter and leave.

original: araññavanapatthesu senāsanesu viharataṃ utrāsasaññitā bhīru jāyati, tesaṃ ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitānaṃ
analyzed: arañña vana patthesu senāsanesu viharatam utrāsa saññitā bhīru jāyati tesam ussaṅkita parisaṅkitānam
translated: Then fear arises in them, which is called “perception of terror.” For those who are frightened and anxious,

original: dīgharattaṃ vivekarasamanassādayamānānaṃ viharataṃ “na siyā nu kho esa maggo”ti paṭipattiyaṃ
analyzed: dīgharattam viveka rasa manaḥ sādayamānānam viharatam na siyā nu kho esa maggo ti paṭipattiyam
translated: who dwell for a long time tasting the flavour of seclusion, the perception arises, “Perhaps this is not the path to enlightenment.”

original: vicikicchā uppajjati, taṃ vinodetvā viharataṃ appamattakena visesādhigamena mānamakkhathambhā🔽jāyanti, tepi vinodetvā viharataṃ tato adhikataraṃ visesādhigamaṃ nissāya lābhasakkārasilokā
analyzed: vicikicchā uppajjati tam vinodetvā viharatam appamattakena visesa adhigamena  jāyanti te pi vinodetvā viharatam tatas adhikataram visesa adhigamam nissāya lābha sakkāra silokā
translated: Doubt arises, and when they live on removing that, conceit and contempt arise in them through the attainment of distinction by means of slight heedlessness.🔽And when they live on removing those, gain, honour and fame arise in them on account of the further distinction they have attained.

original: uppajjanti, lābhādimucchitā dhammapaṭirūpakāni pakāsentā micchāyasaṃ adhigantvā tattha
analyzed: uppajjanti lābha ādi mucchitāḥ dhamma paṭirūpakāni pakāsentāḥ micchāyasam adhigantvā tattha
translated: And when they live on removing those, they, deluded by gain, etc., and expounding mere dhamma-like doctrines, come to false practice, and when they are established in that, they exalt themselves and disparage others on account of birth, etc.

original: ṭhitā jātiādīhi attānaṃ ukkaṃsenti, paraṃ vambhenti. Tasmā kāmādīnaṃ paṭhamasenādibhāvo veditabbo.🔽Evametaṃ dasavidhaṃ senaṃ uddisitvā yasmā sā kaṇhadhammasamannāgatattā kaṇhassa namucino
analyzed: ṭhitāḥ jāti ādīhi attānam ukkaṃsenti param vambhenti tasmā kāma ādīnam paṭhama senā ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ  evam etam dasavidham senam uddisitvā yasmā sā kaṇha dhamma samannāgata ttā kaṇhassa namucino
translated: That is why the order of greed, etc., should be understood as beginning with the first.

original: upakārāya saṃvattati, tasmā naṃ “tava senā”ti niddisanto āha – “esā namuci te senā,
analyzed: upakārāya saṃvattati tasmai nam tava senā iti niddisantaḥ āha esā namuci te senā
translated: So after defining this tenfold order thus, since it is helpful to Namuci the Dark because it is possessed of dark states, he said: “This, Namuci, is your order,” defining it as “yours,”

original: kaṇhassābhippahārinī”ti. Tattha abhippahārinīti samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ghātinī nippothinī,
analyzed: kaṇhassa abhippahārinī ti tattha abhippahārinī iti samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ghātinī nippothinī
translated: and adding: “Which will lead you on to darkness.” Herein, which will lead you on to darkness means which will kill and destroy ascetics and brahmans,

original: antarāyakarīti attho. Na naṃ asūro jināti, jetvāva labhate sukhanti evaṃ tava senaṃ🔽asūro kāye ca jīvite ca sāpekkho puriso na jināti, sūro pana jināti, jetvāva maggasukhaṃ
analyzed: antarāya karī ti atthaḥ na nam asūraḥ jināti jetvā ava labhate sukhanti evam tava senam  asūraḥ kāye ca jīvite ca sa apekkhaḥ puriso na jināti sūraḥ pana jināti jetvā ava magga sukham
translated: The meaning is: it is an obstacle.🔽The fearless one does not conquer it, but only by conquering it does he gain happiness.

original: phalasukhañca adhigacchati.
analyzed: phala sukhañca adhigacchati
translated: Thus, the fearless one, the person who is concerned about the body and life, does not conquer your army, but the fearless one conquers it, and only by conquering it does he attain the happiness of the path and the happiness of the fruit.

original: Yato catūhi ariyamaggehīti yadā catūhi niddosanibbānamagganasaṅkhātehi maggehi. Mārasenāti
analyzed: yatas catūhi ariya maggehi iti yadā catūhi niddosa nibbāna maggana saṅkhātehi maggehi māra senā ati
translated: Since by the four noble paths: when by the four paths called the path to the deathless and Nibbāna.🔽The army of Māra: the defilements that are obedient to Māra.🔽The counter-army: the ones who make opposition.

original: mārassa senā vacanakarā kilesā. Paṭisenikarāti paṭipakkhakarā. Jitā cāti parājayamānā
analyzed: mārassa senā vacana karā kilesā paṭiseni karā ati paṭipakkha karā jitā ca ati parājayamānā
translated: The conquered: the ones who are being defeated.🔽The slain: the ones who are being killed. The defeated: the ones who are being suppressed.

original: hanitā ca. Parājitā cāti niggahitā ca. Bhaggāti bhinnā. Vippaluggāti cuṇṇavicuṇṇā.
analyzed: hanitā ca parājitā ca ati niggahitā ca bhaggā ati bhinnā vippaluggā ati cuṇṇa vicuṇṇā
translated: The shattered: the ones who are broken. The routed: the ones who are scattered in pieces.

original: Parammukhāti vimukhabhāvaṃ pāpitā. Visenibhūtoti nikkileso hutvā ṭhito.
analyzed: parammukhā ati vimukha bhāvam pāpitā visenibhūtā iti nikkilesaḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: The turned away: the ones who are made to have a turned away state. The army that is scattered: the one that is established after becoming free from defilements.🔽The one who sees the clear: the one who sees the clear. Those six coverings: these are the coverings of defilements such as craving.

original: Vodātadassinti byavadātadassiṃ. Tāni chadanānīti etāni taṇhādikilesachadanāni. Vivaṭānīti
analyzed: vodāta dassinti byavadāta dassim tāni chadanāni iti etāni taṇhā ādi kilesa chadanāni vivaṭāni iti
translated: The opened: the ones that are opened.

original: pākaṭīkatāni. Viddhaṃsitānīti ṭhitaṭṭhānato apahatāni. Ugghāṭitānīti uppāṭitāni.
analyzed: pākaṭīkatāni viddhaṃsitāni iti ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ apahatāni ugghāṭitāni iti uppāṭitāni
translated: They are “laid bare” when they are made manifest. They are “broken” when they are removed from their place of stability. They are “torn away” when they are uprooted.

original: Samugghāṭitānīti visesena uppāṭitāni.
analyzed: samugghāṭitāni iti visesena uppāṭitāni
translated: They are “completely torn away” when they are uprooted in a special way.

original: 29. Na kappayantīti gāthāya sambandho attho ca – kiñca bhiyyo? Te hi tādisā santo
analyzed: na kappayanti iti gāthāya sambandhaḥ attho ca kiñca bhiyyas te hi tādisāḥ santaḥ
translated: The meaning of the connection with the verse is this: “And what is more?”

original: dvinnaṃ kappānaṃ purekkhārānañca kenaci na kappayanti, na purekkharonti. Paramatthaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam kappānam purekkhārānam ca kenacid na kappayanti na purekkharonti paramattham
translated: They, being such, do not “make” or “take” any of the two kinds of “pre- eminence” for the sake of the two kinds of “perfection” .

original: accantasuddhiṃ adhigatattā anaccantasuddhiṃyeva akiriyasassatadiṭṭhiṃ “accantasuddhī”ti
analyzed: accanta suddhim adhigata ttā an accanta suddhim yeva a kiriya sassata diṭṭhim accanta suddhi iti
translated: Because they have attained the ultimate perfection, they do not say that “the perfection of the supramundane state” is “the ultimate perfection” ,🔽which is the view of eternalism of the kind called “the non-doing of what is to be done” .

original: na te vadanti. Ādānaganthaṃ gatitaṃ visajjāti catubbidhampi rūpādīnaṃ ādāyakattā
analyzed: na te vadanti ādāna gantham catubbidham pi rūpa ādīnam ādāyaka ttā
translated: They “let go of the fetter that has gone to the destination” , which is the fourfold “fetter of grasping” because it grasps materiality, etc.,

original: ādānaganthaṃ attano cittasantāne gathitaṃ baddhaṃ ariyamaggasatthena vissajja chinditvā. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: ādāna gantham citta santāne gathitam baddham ariya magga satthena vissajja chinditvā sesam pākaṭam eva
translated: and which is “gone to the destination” because it is bound to and fettered in their own mental continuity. They “let go” of it by cutting it with the sword of the noble path. The rest is clear.

original: Accantasuddhinti accantaṃ paramatthaṃ suddhiṃ. Saṃsārasuddhinti saṃsārato suddhiṃ.
analyzed: accanta suddhim ti accantam paramattham suddhim saṃsāra suddhim ti saṃsārataḥ suddhim
translated: “The ultimate perfection”: the ultimate, the highest, perfection. “The perfection of the round of rebirths”: the perfection of the round of rebirths.

original: Akiriyadiṭṭhinti karoto na karīyati pāpanti akiriyadiṭṭhiṃ. Sassatavādanti “nicco
analyzed: akiriya diṭṭhim ti karotaḥ na karīyati pāpam ti akiriya diṭṭhim sassata vādanti nicco
translated: The view of non-action: “No evil is done by one who kills one who is permanent, eternal, and everlasting.” The view of eternalism: “The world is permanent, eternal, and everlasting.”

original: dhuvo sassato”ti vacanaṃ. Na vadanti na kathenti.🔽Ganthāti nāmakāyaṃ ganthenti, cutipaṭisandhivasena vaṭṭasmiṃ ghaṭentīti ganthā. Abhijjhā🔽ca sā nāmakāyaghaṭanavasena gantho cāti abhijjhākāyagantho. Hitasukhaṃ byāpādayatīti🔽byāpādo. Byāpādo ca so vuttanayena gantho cāti byāpādo kāyagantho. Sīlabbataparāmāsoti🔽“ito bahiddhā samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sīlena suddhi vatena suddhī”ti parato āmāso. Idaṃsaccābhinivesoti
analyzed: dhuvaḥ sassatoti vacanam na vadanti na kathenti  ganthā ati nāmakāyam cuti paṭisandhi vasena vaṭṭasmim ghaṭenti iti ganthā abhijjhā  ca sā nāmakāya ghaṭana vasena gantho ca ati abhijjhā kāya gantho hita sukham byāpādayati iti  byāpādaḥ byāpādo ca so vutta nayena gantho ca ati byāpādo kāya gantho sīlabbata parāmāso ti  itas bahiddhā samaṇa brāhmaṇānam sīlena suddhi vatena suddhi iti paratas idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ ti
translated: The view that there is no action: the view that “one who acts does not undergo the result of action” . The eternalist view: the view that “the world is eternal” . They do not say, they do not speak.

original: sabbaññubhāsitampi paṭikkhipitvā “sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti iminā🔽ākārena abhiniveso idaṃsaccābhiniveso. Attano diṭṭhiyā rāgoti attanā abhinivisitvā
analyzed: sabbaññu bhāsitam pi paṭikkhipitvā sassataḥ lokaḥ idam eva saccam mogham aññanti iminā 🔽ākārena abhiniveso idaṃsacca abhiniveso attanaḥ diṭṭhiyā rāgo ti attanā abhinivisitvā
translated: The fetters: they fetter the aggregates of existence, they bind them to the round of rebirths by means of the process of passing away and rebirth, thus they are fetters. Covetousness is a fetter and it fetters the aggregates of existence by causing them to be bound together, thus it is the fetter of covetousness. Malice is the wish for the harm and unhappiness of others. It is a fetter and it fetters the aggregates of existence by causing them to be bound together, thus it is the fetter of malice. The adherence to rules and observances: the adherence to the view that “purification comes through rules and observances” . The adherence to a view: the adherence to the view that “the world is eternal” , etc., after rejecting the words of the Omniscient One. The adherence to a view is the adherence to the view that “the world is eternal” , etc., in the way stated. The adherence to one’s own views: the adherence to the view that “my self is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body” , after rejecting the words of the Omniscient One.

original: gahitāya diṭṭhiyā chandarāgo. Paravādesu āghātoti parassa vacanesu kopo. Appaccayoti
analyzed: gahitāya diṭṭhiyā chanda rāgaḥ paravādesu āghāto ti parassa vacanesu kopaḥ appaccayo ti
translated: ‘In the views he has grasped, desire and lust’: in the views he has grasped, there is desire and lust. ‘Anger towards other doctrines’: anger towards the words of others. ‘Discontent’:

original: atuṭṭhākāro. Attano sīlaṃ vāti attanā samādinnaṃ gosīlādisīlaṃ vā. Attano diṭṭhīti
analyzed: atuṭṭhākāraḥ attanaḥ sīlam vā ati attanā samādinnam go sīla ādi sīlam vā attanaḥ diṭṭhi iti
translated: the state of being dissatisfied. ‘His own virtue’: the virtue he has undertaken, such as the virtue of the cow, etc. ‘His own views’:

original: attanā gahitā parāmaṭṭhā diṭṭhi. Tehi ganthehīti etehi vuttehi nāmakāyaghaṭanehi.
analyzed: attanā gahitā parāmaṭṭhā diṭṭhi tehi ganthehi iti etehi vuttehi nāma kāya ghaṭanehi
translated: the views he has grasped and adhered to. ‘By these means’: by these means stated, by these means of constructing the name-group.

original: Rūpaṃ ādiyantīti catusamuṭṭhānikaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ ādiyanti gaṇhanti. Upādiyantīti upagantvā
analyzed: rūpam ādiyanti iti catu samuṭṭhānikam rūpa ārammaṇam ādiyanti gaṇhanti upādiyanti iti upagantvā
translated: ‘Seizing upon form’: seizing upon, taking, the form that is the four primary elements as object. ‘Clinging to’: going up to,

original: gaṇhanti taṇhāgahaṇena. Parāmasanti diṭṭhigahaṇena. Abhinivisanti mānagahaṇena. Vaṭṭanti
analyzed: gaṇhanti taṇhā gahaṇena parāmasanti diṭṭhi gahaṇena abhinivisanti māna gahaṇena vaṭṭanti
translated: taking by the taking of craving. ‘Adhering to’: adhering by the taking of views. ‘Insistence’: insistence by the taking of conceit. ‘Wandering on’:

original: tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ. Gantheti bandhane.🔽Vosajjitvā vāti sammā vissajjitvā vā. Gathiteti bandhane. Ganthiteti ganthanena ganthite.
analyzed: tebhūmaka vaṭṭam gantha iti bandhane  vosajjitvā vā ati sammā vissajjitvā vā gathitā iti bandhane ganthitā iti ganthanena ganthite
translated: wandering on in the three planes. ‘Bond’: bondage.🔽‘Having well untied’: having well untied, having well released. ‘Bondage’: bondage. ‘Bound’: bound by bondage.🔽‘Bondage-bond’: bondage by the bond. ‘Bondage-bondage’: bondage by bondage. ‘Obstruction’: non-release.

original: Vibandheti visesena bandhe. Ābandheti anekavidhena bandhe. Palibuddheti amuñcite.
analyzed: vibandha iti visesena bandhe ābandha iti anekavidhena bandhe palibuddha iti amuñcite
translated: ‘Obstruction-obstruction’: obstruction by obstruction. ‘Obstruction-bondage’: bondage by obstruction. ‘Obstruction-bond’: bond by obstruction. ‘Obstruction-bondage-bond’: bondage by the bond of obstruction. ‘Obstruction-bondage-bondage’: bondage by the bondage of obstruction. ‘Obstruction-bondage-bond-bondage’: bondage by the bond of the bond of obstruction.

original: Bandhane poṭayitvāti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhibandhanāni pappoṭayitvā. Visajjāti cajitvā.
analyzed: bandhane poṭayitvā iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi bandhanāni pappoṭayitvā visajja ati cajitvā
translated: “He has unraveled the bonds” means he has unraveled the bonds of craving, conceit, and views. “He has let go” means he has abandoned.

original: Ime pana cattāro ganthe kilesapaṭipāṭiyāpi āharituṃ vaṭṭati, maggapaṭipāṭiyāpi –🔽kilesapaṭipāṭiyā abhijjhākāyagantho arahattamaggena pahīyati, byāpādo kāyagantho
analyzed: ime pana cattāro ganthe kilesa paṭipāṭiyā api āharitum vaṭṭati magga paṭipāṭiyā api  kilesa paṭipāṭiyā abhijjhā kāya gantho arahatta maggena pahīyati byāpādaḥ kāya gantho
translated: But these four knots can also be brought in according to the order of the defilements and according to the order of the paths.

original: anāgāmimaggena, sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyagantho sotāpattimaggena.🔽Maggapaṭipāṭiyā sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyagantho sotāpattimaggena,
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena sīlabbata parāmāso kāya gantho idaṃsacca abhiniveso kāya gantho sotāpatti maggena  magga paṭipāṭiyā sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ kāya gantho idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ kāya gantho sotāpatti maggena
translated: According to the order of the defilements: the knot of covetousness is abandoned by the path of arahatship; the knot of ill will is abandoned by the path of non-return; the knot of adherence to rules and observances is abandoned by the path of stream-entry.🔽According to the order of the paths: the knot of adherence to rules and observances is abandoned by the path of stream-entry; the knot of ill will is abandoned by the path of non-return; the knot of covetousness is abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: byāpādo kāyagantho anāgāmimaggena, abhijjhākāyagantho arahattamaggenāti. Ete cattāro
analyzed: byāpādaḥ kāya ganthaḥ anāgāmi maggena abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ arahatta maggena ati ete cattāro
translated: These four knots

original: ganthā yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ cutipaṭisandhivasena vaṭṭasmiṃ ganthenti ghaṭentīti
analyzed: ganthāḥ yassa saṃvijjanti tam cuti paṭisandhi vasena vaṭṭasmim ganthenti ghaṭenti iti
translated: are called “knots” because they tie and bind one to the round of rebirths through the process of death and rebirth.

original: ganthā. Te catuppabhedā abhijjhāyanti etāya, sayaṃ vā abhijjhāyati, abhijjhāyanamattameva
analyzed: ganthā te catur pabhedāḥ abhijjhāyanti etāya sayam vā abhijjhāyati abhijjhāyana mattam eva
translated: They are fourfold, being classified according to covetousness, etc. One covets through them, or one covets oneself, or one merely covets.

original: vā esāti abhijjhā. Lobhoyeva nāmakāyaṃ gantheti cutipaṭisandhivasena vaṭṭasmiṃ ghaṭetīti
analyzed: vā esā ati abhijjhā lobhoyā iva nāmakāyam ganthā iti cuti paṭisandhi vasena vaṭṭasmim ghaṭeti iti
translated: and it is greed. Greed itself is the “body of terms” : it is “woven” in the round of rebirths by way of death and rebirth.

original: kāyagantho. Byāpajjati tena cittaṃ pūtibhāvaṃ gacchati, byāpādayati vā vinayācārarūpasampattihitasukhādīnīti
analyzed: kāya ganthaḥ byāpajjati tena cittam pūti bhāvam gacchati byāpādayati vā vinaya ācāra rūpa sampatti hita sukha ādīni iti
translated: It is “body-tie” . The mind is “afflicted” by it; it becomes putrid. Or it “afflicts” the excellence of virtue, conduct, and the true state of things, and the attainment of welfare and pleasure.

original: byāpādo. “Ito bahiddhā samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sīlena suddhi vatena suddhī”ti parāmasanaṃ
analyzed: itas bahiddhā samaṇa brāhmaṇānam sīlena suddhi vatena suddhi iti parāmasanam
translated: It is “ill will” . The clinging to the view “Purification comes about through virtue and practice” is

original: sīlabbataparāmāso, sabbaññubhāsitampi paṭikkhipitvā “sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ,
analyzed: sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ sabbaññu bhāsitam pi paṭikkhipitvā sassataḥ lokaḥ idam eva saccaṃ
translated: “clinging to rules and observances” . After rejecting even the Buddha’s word, one “adheres” to the view “The world is eternal” or “The world is not eternal,” etc.,

original: moghamañña”ntiādinā ākārena abhinivisatīti idaṃsaccābhiniveso. Yathā vayhaṃ vātiādiṃ
analyzed: mogham aññanti ādinā ākārena abhinivisati iti idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ yathā vayham vāti ādim
translated: in the way described. This is “adherence to a view of self” . The simile of the “wind-blown dust-heap” is given

original: vayhādivisaṅkharaṇaṃ ganthānaṃ viyogakaraṇe upamaṃ dassento āha.🔽Na janentīti na uppādenti. Na sañjanentīti na nibbattenti. Nābhinibbattentīti upasaggavasena
analyzed: vayha ādi visaṅkharaṇam ganthānam viyoga karaṇe upamam dassentaḥ āha  na janenti iti na uppādenti na sañjanenti iti na nibbattenti na abhinibbattenti iti upasagga vasena
translated: to illustrate the dispersal of the fetters.

original: padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ. Na sañjanentīti uppādakkhaṇaṃ. Na nibbattenti nābhinibbattentīti
analyzed: padam vaḍḍhitam na sañjanenti iti uppāda khaṇam na nibbattenti na abhinibbattenti iti
translated: “Do not generate” : do not produce. “Do not give rise to” : do not bring forth. “Do not cause to come forth” : the word is extended by way of prefix. “Do not give rise to” refers to the moment of arising.

original: pavattikkhaṇaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pavatti khaṇam sandhāya vuttam
translated: and the moment of occurrence is intended.

original: 30. Sīmātigoti gāthā ekapuggalādhiṭṭhānāya desanāya vuttā. Pubbasadiso eva panassā
analyzed: sīmātigaḥ ti gāthā eka puggala adhiṭṭhānāya desanāya vuttā pubba sadisaḥ eva pana assā
translated: The verse “The one who has gone beyond the four” is stated in a teaching based on a single person. But the connection is the same as before.

original: sambandho, so evaṃ atthavaṇṇanāya saddhiṃ veditabbo – kiñca bhiyyo? So īdiso bhūripañño
analyzed: sambandhaḥ saḥ evam attha vaṇṇanāya saddhim veditabbaḥ kiñca bhiyyas saḥ īdisaḥ bhūri pañño
translated: It should be understood together with the commentary on the meaning as follows: “And what is more? He is such, of great understanding,

original: catunnaṃ kilesasīmānaṃ atītattā sīmātigo, bāhitapāpattā ca brāhmaṇo, itthambhūtassa
analyzed: catunnam kilesa sīmānam atīta ttā sīmātigaḥ ca brāhmaṇaḥ itthambhūtassa
translated: and he has gone beyond the four boundaries of defilement, thus he is ‘one who has gone beyond the boundaries’ and ‘a brahmin’ because he has expelled evil.

original: ca tassa natthi, paracittapubbenivāsañāṇehi ñatvā vā maṃsadibbacakkhūhi disvā vā
analyzed: ca tassa natthi para citta pubbenivāsa ñāṇehi ñatvā vā maṃsa dibba cakkhūhi disvā vā
translated: And for such a one there is nothing that he has grasped at, either by knowing it with the knowledge of others’ minds or by seeing it with the divine eye,

original: kiñci samuggahītaṃ, abhiniviṭṭhanti vuttaṃ hoti. So ca kāmarāgābhāvato na rāgarāgī🔽rūpārūparāgābhāvato na virāgaratto, yato evaṃvidhassa tassa “idaṃ parama”nti kiñci
analyzed: kiñci samuggahītam abhiniviṭṭhanti vuttam hoti so ca kāma rāga abhāvataḥ na rāga rāgī  rūpa arūpa rāga abhāvataḥ na virāga rattaḥ yatas evaṃvidhassa tassa idam kiñci
translated: that is to say, he is ‘one who has nothing grasped at.’ He is not ‘one who is passionate about passion’ because he is without lust for sensual desires,

original: idha uggahītaṃ natthīti arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: idha uggahītam natthi iti arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: nor is he ‘one who is passionate about dispassion’ because he is without lust for the form and formless worlds. Since for such a one there is nothing here that he has grasped at, thinking ‘This is the highest,’🔽the Exalted One concluded the teaching with the peak of arahantship.”

original: Catasso sīmāyoti cattāro paricchedā. Diṭṭhānusayoti diṭṭhi ca sā appahīnaṭṭhena anusayo
analyzed: catasso cattāro paricchedāḥ diṭṭhānusayo ti diṭṭhi ca sā a pahīna ṭṭhena anusayo
translated: The four boundaries are the four limitations. The underlying tendency to views is a view that is an underlying tendency in the sense of not being abandoned.

original: cāti diṭṭhānusayo. Vicikicchānusayādīsupi eseva nayo. Kenaṭṭhena anusayā? Anusayanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: ca ati diṭṭha anusayaḥ vicikicchā anusaya ādīsu pi esā iva nayo kena ṭṭhena anusayāḥ anusayana ṭṭhena
translated: In what sense are they underlying tendencies? In the sense of underlying tendencies.🔽What is this “underlying tendency” ?

original: Ko esa anusayaṭṭho nāmāti? Appahīnaṭṭho. Ete hi appahīnaṭṭhena tassa tassa santāne
analyzed: kaḥ esa anusaya ṭṭho nāma ati appahīna ṭṭho ete hi appahīna ṭṭhena tassa tassa santāne
translated: It is the sense of “not yet abandoned.” For these are called “underlying tendencies” because they underlie in the sense of not yet abandoned.

original: anusenti nāma, tasmā “anusayā”ti vuccanti. Anusentīti anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantīti🔽attho. Athāpi siyā – anusayaṭṭho nāma appahīnākāro, appahīnākāro ca “uppajjatī”ti
analyzed: anusenti nāma tasmai anusayā ati vuccanti anusenti iti anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti  attho atha api siyā anusayaṭṭhaḥ nāma appahīna ākāraḥ appahīna ākāro ca uppajjati iti
translated: The meaning is that they occur when they obtain a suitable condition.🔽But it might be argued that the sense of “underlying tendency” is the mode of not yet being abandoned, and that it is not proper to say that what is not yet abandoned “occurs.”

original: vattuṃ na yujjati, tasmā na anusayā uppajjantīti. Tatridaṃ paṭivacanaṃ – appahīnākāro🔽anusayo, anusayoti pana appahīnaṭṭhena thāmagatā kilesā vuccanti. So cittasampayutto
analyzed: vattum na yujjati tasmai na anusayāḥ uppajjanti iti tatra idam paṭivacanam appahīna ākāraḥ  anusayo anusayo ti pana appahīna ṭṭhena thāma gatāḥ kilesāḥ vuccanti so citta sampayutto
translated: The answer to that is this: the underlying tendency is the mode of not yet being abandoned. But “underlying tendency” is said of defilements that have become chronic.

original: sārammaṇo sappaccayaṭṭhena sahetuko ekantākusalo atītopi hoti anāgatopi paccuppannopi,
analyzed: sa ārammaṇaḥ sa paccaya ṭṭhena sa hetukaḥ ekanta akusalaḥ atītaḥ api hoti anāgataḥ api paccuppannaḥ pi
translated: And that underlying tendency is associated with consciousness, has an object, and is a condition in the sense of decisive support. It is rooted in ignorance, is accompanied by craving, and is of the nature of dark action. It is unwholesome throughout the three periods of time,

original: tasmā “uppajjatī”ti vattuṃ yujjati.
analyzed: tasmai uppajjati iti vattum yujjati
translated: and therefore it is proper to say that it occurs.

original: Tatridaṃ pamāṇaṃ – paṭisambhidāyaṃ tāva abhisamayakathāyaṃ “paccuppanne kilese pajahatī”ti
analyzed: tatra idam pamāṇam paṭisambhidā ayam tāva abhisamaya kathā ayam paccuppanne kilese pajahati iti
translated: Here is the measure: In the Abhisamaya section of the Paṭisambhidā, the question is asked, “Does one abandon defilements that have arisen?”

original: pucchitvā anusayānaṃ paccuppannabhāvassa atthitāya “thāmagato anusayaṃ pajahatī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Dhammasaṅgaṇiyaṃ mohassa padabhājane “avijjānusayo avijjāpariyuṭṭhānaṃ, avijjālaṅgī
analyzed: pucchitvā anusayānam paccuppanna bhāvassa atthitāya thāma gataḥ anusayam pajahati iti  vuttam dhammasaṅgaṇiyam mohassa pada bhājane avijjā anusayaḥ avijjā pariyuṭṭhānam avijjā laṅgī
translated: and the answer is given, “One who has reached the path abandons the underlying tendency.”

original: moho akusalamūlaṃ, ayaṃ tasmiṃ samaye moho hotī”ti akusalacittena saddhiṃ avijjānusayassa
analyzed: mohaḥ akusala mūlam ayam tasmin samaye mohaḥ hoti iti akusala cittena saddhim avijjā anusayassa
translated: In the Padabhājaniya of the Dhamma-saṅgaṇi, in the analysis of delusion, it is said: “The underlying tendency to ignorance, the perversion of ignorance, the delusion that is the root of unprofit—this is the delusion on that occasion.”🔽So the arising of the underlying tendency to ignorance is stated together with unprofitable consciousness.

original: uppannabhāvo vutto. Kathāvatthusmiṃ “anusayā abyākatā anusayā ahetukā anusayā cittavippayuttā”ti
analyzed: uppanna bhāvaḥ vutto kathā vatthusmiṃ anusayāḥ abyākatāḥ anusayāḥ ahetukāḥ anusayā citta vippayuttā ti
translated: In the Kathāvatthu it is said: “The underlying tendencies are indeterminate, the underlying tendencies are without root-cause, the underlying tendencies are dissociated from cognizance” .

original: sabbe vādā paṭisedhitā. Anusayayamake sattannaṃ mahāvārānaṃ aññatarasmiṃ uppajjanavāre
analyzed: sabbe vādā paṭisedhitā anusaya yamake sattannam mahāvārānam aññatarasmin uppajjana vāre
translated: All these statements are refuted.🔽In the section on the arising of the seven great divisions, it is said: “In one in whom the underlying tendency to lust is present, the underlying tendency to hate arises” .

original: “yassa kāmarāgānusayo uppajjati tassa paṭighānusayo uppajjatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: yassa kāma rāga anusayaḥ uppajjati tassa paṭigha anusayaḥ uppajjati itiādi vuttam tasmā
translated: Therefore

original: “anusentīti anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantī”ti yaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ iminā tantippamāṇena
analyzed: anusenti iti anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti yam vuttam tam iminā tanti ppamāṇena
translated: “Anusaya is a term for what arises when it gets a suitable object” is well said, it should be understood, by this standard.

original: suvuttanti veditabbaṃ. Yampi “cittasampayutto sārammaṇo”tiādi vuttaṃ, tampi suvuttameva.
analyzed: su vuttanti veditabbam yat api citta sampayuttaḥ sārammaṇaḥ ti ādi vuttam tat api su vuttam eva
translated: And what is said beginning with “associated with consciousness, having an object” is also well said.

original: Anusayo hi nāmesa parinipphanno cittasampayutto akusaladhammoti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: anusayaḥ hi nāma esa parinipphannaḥ citta sampayutto akusala dhammo ti niṭṭham ettha gantabbam
translated: For anusaya should be understood as a non-manifest unprofitable state associated with consciousness.

original: Tattha diṭṭhānusayo catūsu diṭṭhisampayuttesu, vicikicchānusayo vicikicchāsahagate,
analyzed: tattha diṭṭhā anusayo catūsu diṭṭhi sampayuttesu vicikicchā anusayo vicikicchā sahagate
translated: Herein, the embodiment-view anusaya is in the four consciousnesses associated with embodiment-view. The view-consisting-of-false-doctrine anusaya is in the four consciousnesses associated with that. The uncertainty anusaya is in the consciousness associated with uncertainty.

original: avijjānusayo dvādasasu akusalacittesu sahajātavasena ārammaṇavasena ca; tayopi avasesatebhūmakadhammesu
analyzed: avijjā anusayaḥ dvādasasu akusala cittesu sahajāta vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca tayaḥ api avasesa tebhūmaka dhammesu
translated: The ignorance anusaya is in the twelve unprofitable consciousnesses by conascence and by object. These three are in the remaining states of the three planes by object only.🔽The lust for sensual desire anusaya is in the consciousness associated with greed by conascence and by object.

original: ārammaṇavasena diṭṭhivicikicchāmohā. Kāmarāgānusayo cettha lobhasahagatacittesu sahajātavasena🔽ārammaṇavasena ca, manāpesu avasesakāmāvacaradhammesu ārammaṇavasena uppajjamāno
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena diṭṭhi vicikicchā mohā kāma rāga anusayo ca ittha lobha sahagata cittesu sahajāta vasena 🔽ārammaṇa vasena ca manāpesu avasesa kāmāvacara dhammesu ārammaṇa vasena uppajjamāno
translated: It arises in the remaining sensual-desire states by object only.

original: lobho. Paṭighānusayo domanassasahagatacittesu sahajātavasena ārammaṇavasena ca, amanāpesu🔽avasesakāmāvacaradhammesu ārammaṇavaseneva uppajjamāno doso. Mānānusayo diṭṭhivippayuttalobhasahagatacittesu
analyzed: lobho paṭigha anusayaḥ domanassa sahagata cittesu sahajāta vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca amanāpesu  avasesa kāmāvacara dhammesu ārammaṇa vasena iva uppajjamānaḥ dosaḥ māna anusayaḥ diṭṭhi vippayutta lobha sahagata cittesu
translated: Greed is the underlying tendency to greed. It occurs in the two unprofitable consciousnesses accompanied by grief, as conascence and as object, and in the remaining sensual-sphere formations, as object only.🔽Aversion is hate occurring in disagreeable visible data, etc., as object and as conascence.

original: sahajātavasena ārammaṇavasena ca, dukkhavedanāvajjesu avasesakāmāvacaradhammesu rūpārūpāvacaradhammesu🔽ca ārammaṇavaseneva uppajjamāno māno. Bhavarāgānusayo catūsu diṭṭhivippayuttesu uppajjamānopi
analyzed: sahajāta vasena ārammaṇa vasena ca dukkha vedanā vajjesu avasesa kāmāvacara dhammesu rūpa arūpāvacara dhammesu  ca ārammaṇa vasena iva uppajjamānaḥ mānaḥ bhava rāga anusayo catūsu diṭṭhi vippayuttesu uppajjamānaḥ api
translated: Conceit is the underlying tendency to conceit. It occurs in the two consciousnesses accompanied by greed unaccompanied by false view, as conascence and as object, and in the remaining sensual-sphere formations except the kinds of pain, and in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming, as object only.

original: sahajātavasena vutto. Ārammaṇavaseneva pana rūpārūpāvacaradhammesu uppajjamāno lobho vutto.
analyzed: sahajāta vasena vuttaḥ ārammaṇa vasena iva pana rūpa arūpa avacara dhammesu uppajjamānaḥ lobho vuttaḥ
translated: Lust for becoming is the underlying tendency to lust for becoming. It occurs in the four consciousnesses unaccompanied by false view, as conascence, and in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming, as object only.

original: Tattha diṭṭhānusayoti dvāsaṭṭhividhā diṭṭhi. Vicikicchānusayoti aṭṭhavatthukā vicikicchā.
analyzed: tattha diṭṭhā anusayo ti dvāsaṭṭhividhā diṭṭhi vicikicchā anusayo ti aṭṭha vatthukā vicikicchā
translated: Herein, the underlying tendency to false view is the sixty-two kinds of view . The underlying tendency to uncertainty is the eight kinds of uncertainty .

original: Tadekaṭṭhā ca kilesāti sahajekaṭṭhavasena diṭṭhiyā vicikicchāya, sahajekaṭṭhavasena
analyzed: tad ekaṭṭhā ca kilesā ati sahaja ekaṭṭha vasena diṭṭhiyāḥ vicikicchāya sahaja ekaṭṭha vasena
translated: And the defilements that have the same proximate cause as these are stated together with them as having the same proximate cause.

original: ekato ṭhitā. Mānānusayoti navavidhamāno. Paramatthañāṇena vā ñatvāti paresaṃ cittācārajānanapaññāya🔽jānitvā, cetopariyañāṇena jānitvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇena vāti atīte
analyzed: ekatas ṭhitā māna anusayo ti navavidha māno paramattha ñāṇena vā ñatvā ati paresam citta ācāra jānana paññāya  jānitvā cetas upariya ñāṇena jānitvā iti vuttam hoti pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇena vā ti atīte
translated: and standing on one side. The underlying tendency to conceit: the nine kinds of conceit. Or by knowing the ultimate truth: by knowing through the knowledge of reading the minds of others;🔽what is meant is: by knowing through the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others. Or by recollecting his past lives: by knowing through the knowledge of recollecting past lives;

original: nivuṭṭhakkhandhānussaraṇañāṇena jānitvā. Maṃsacakkhunā vāti pakaticakkhunā. Dibbacakkhunā🔽vāti dibbasadisena dibbavihārasannissitena vā dibbacakkhunā passitvā. Rāgarattāti🔽rāgena rañjitā. Ye pañcasu kāmaguṇesūti ye pañcasu rūpādivatthukāmakoṭṭhāsesu. Virāgarattāti
analyzed: nivuṭṭha kkhandha anussaraṇa ñāṇena jānitvā maṃsa cakkhunā vāti pakati cakkhunā dibba cakkhunā  vā ti dibba sadisena dibba vihāra sannissitena vā dibba cakkhunā passitvā rāga rattā ati  rāgena rañjitāḥ ye pañcasu kāma guṇesu iti ye pañcasu rūpa ādi vatthu kāma koṭṭhāsesu virāga rattā ati
translated: what is meant is: by knowing through the knowledge of recollecting past aggregates that have occurred in the past. Or with the fleshly eye: with the ordinary eye. Or with the divine eye: with the divine eye that is similar to the divine and that is dependent on the divine life.

original: virāgasaṅkhātāsu rūpārūpasamāpattīsu atirattā allīnā. Yato kāmarāgo cāti yadā kāmabhave
analyzed: virāga saṅkhātāsu rūpa arūpa samāpattīsu ati rattāḥ yatas kāma rāgaḥ ca ati yadā kāma bhave
translated: Having seen: having seen with the divine eye. Lustful for sensual pleasure: excited by lust. Those who delight in the five strands of sense pleasure: those who delight in the five kinds of sense objects consisting of visible forms, etc. Lustful for non-form: excited by lust for the attainments called “non-form” . Those who delight in the formless: those who delight in, are attached to, the formless attainments. When there is lust for the sensual: when there is lust for the sensual plane of existence.

original: rāgo ca. Rūpārūparāgesupi eseva nayo.🔽Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: rāgaḥ ca rūpa a rūpa rāgesupi eṣa iva nayo  saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The same method applies to lust for the fine-material and immaterial.

original: Suddhaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suddhaṭṭhaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Suddhaka Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Paramaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Parama Sutta is next.

original: 31. Pañcame paramaṭṭhakasutte paramanti diṭṭhīsu paribbasānoti idaṃ paramanti gahetvā🔽sakāya sakāya diṭṭhiyā vasamāno. Yaduttariṃ kuruteti yaṃ attano satthārādiṃ seṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pañcame paramaṭṭhaka sutte paramanti diṭṭhīsu paribbasāno ti idam paramanti gahetvā  sakāya sakāya diṭṭhiyā vasamānaḥ yat uttarim kuruta iti yam satthārā ādim seṭṭham
translated: In the fifth, the Discourse on the Ultimate, the words “he is bound by the bondage of views” mean that he is bound by his own views.

original: karoti. Hīnāti aññe tato sabbamāhāti taṃ attano satthārādiṃ ṭhapetvā tato aññe sabbe
analyzed: karoti hīnā ati aññe tatas sabbam āha ati tam attano satthāra ādim ṭhapetvā tatas aññe sabbe
translated: “He makes the rest inferior” means that he makes his own teacher, etc., superior and the rest inferior.

original: “hīnā ime”ti āha. Tasmā vivādāni avītivattoti tena kāraṇena so diṭṭhikalahe avītivattova hoti.🔽Vasantīti paṭhamuppannadiṭṭhivasena vasanti. Pavasantīti pavisitvā vasanti. Āvasantīti
analyzed: hīnāḥ ime iti āha tasmai vivādāni avītivatto iti tena kāraṇena so diṭṭhi kalahe avītivatto va hoti  vasanti iti paṭhama uppanna diṭṭhi vasena vasanti pavasanti iti pavisitvā vasanti āvasanti iti
translated: “He does not transcend disputes” means that he does not transcend disputes about views.🔽“They dwell” means that they dwell by the views that have arisen first. “They dwell together” means that they dwell together after entering. “They dwell in a state of union” means that they dwell in a special state of union. “They dwell in a state of mutual association” means that they dwell in a state of complete union.

original: visesena vasanti. Parivasantīti sabbabhāgena vasanti. Taṃ upamāya sādhento “yathā🔽āgārikā vā”tiādimāha. Āgārikā vāti gharasāmikā. Gharesu vasantīti attano gharesu
analyzed: visesena vasanti parivasanti iti sabba bhāgena vasanti tam upamāya sādhentaḥ yathā  āgārikāḥ vā iti ādim āha āgārikāḥ vā ati ghara sāmikāḥ gharesu vasanti iti gharesu
translated: In order to illustrate this, he says, “Just as householders,” etc.🔽“Householders” means the masters of the house. “They dwell in the house” means that they live in their own houses without being attached.

original: āsaṅkavirahitā hutvā nivasanti. Sāpattikā vāti āpattibahulā. Sakilesā vāti rāgādikilesabahulā.
analyzed: āsaṅka virahitāḥ hutvā nivasanti sa āpattikā vāti āpatti bahulā sa kilesā vāti rāga ādi kilesa bahulā
translated: “They are offenders” means that they are full of offenses. “They are defiled” means that they are full of defilements such as lust.

original: Uttariṃ karotīti atirekaṃ karoti. Ayaṃ satthā sabbaññūti ‘ayaṃ amhākaṃ satthā sabbaṃ jānāti’.
analyzed: uttarim karoti iti atirekam karoti ayam satthā sabbaññu iti ayam amhākam satthā sabbam jānāti
translated: He makes more of it : he makes it excessive. This teacher is omniscient : this teacher of ours knows everything.

original: Sabbe parappavāde khipatīti sabbā paraladdhiyo chaḍḍeti. Ukkhipatīti nīharati. Parikkhipatīti parammukhe karoti. Diṭṭhimedhagānīti diṭṭhivihesakāni.🔽32. Dutiyagāthāyattho – evaṃ avītivatto ca yaṃ diṭṭhe sute sīlavate muteti etesu
analyzed: sabbe para pavāde khipati iti sabbā para laddhiyaḥ chaḍḍeti ukkhipati iti nīharati parikkhipati iti parammukhe karoti diṭṭhi medhagāni iti diṭṭhi vihesakāni  evam ca yam diṭṭhe sute sīlavate muta iti etesu
translated: He flings away all other doctrines : he discards all other people’s theories. He throws them out : he banishes them. He casts them aside : he puts them out of sight. He is a theorist : he is a theorist in the sense of one who is hostile to views.🔽The meaning of the second stanza is this. He who has not transcended the four standpoints and sees in himself, in what is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, in what is affirmed and in what is speculated about,

original: catūsu vatthūsu uppannadiṭṭhisaṅkhāte attani pubbe vuttappakāraṃ ānisaṃsaṃ passati,
analyzed: catūsu vatthūsu uppanna diṭṭhi saṅkhāte attani pubbe vutta ppakāram ānisaṃsam passati
translated: the aforesaid advantages,

original: tadeva so tattha sakāya diṭṭhiyā ānisaṃsaṃ “idaṃ seṭṭha”nti abhinivisitvā aññaṃ sabbaṃ🔽parasatthārādikaṃ nihīnato passati.
analyzed: tat eva saḥ tattha sakāya diṭṭhiyā ānisaṃsam idam seṭṭhanti abhinivisitvā aññam sabbaṃ  para satthāra ādikam nihīnataḥ passati
translated: he, having settled down on the advantages of his own view thus “This is the best,” sees all the rest as inferior.

original: Dve ānisaṃse passatīti dve guṇe oloketi. Diṭṭhadhammikañcāti diṭṭhe paccakkhe attabhāve
analyzed: dve ānisaṃse passati iti dve guṇe oloketi diṭṭhadhammikañca ati diṭṭhe paccakkhe attabhāve
translated: He sees two advantages : he looks at two qualities. The advantage here and now : in the visible here and now, in his own person.

original: vipaccanakaraṇaṃ. Samparāyikañcāti paraloke paṭilabhitabbaguṇañca. Yaṃdiṭṭhiko satthāti
analyzed: vipaccana karaṇam samparāyikam ca ati para loke paṭilabhitabba guṇam ca yaṃdiṭṭhikaḥ satthā ati
translated: and the making of a counter-part. And the future: and the special qualities that will be obtained in the next world. The teacher of what is seen:

original: yaṃladdhiko titthāyatanasāmiko. Alaṃ nāgattāya vāti nāgarājabhāvāya vā pariyattaṃ.🔽Supaṇṇattādīsupi eseva nayo. Devattāya vāti sammutidevādibhāvāya. Āyatiṃ phalapāṭikaṅkhī
analyzed: titthāyatana sāmikaḥ alam nāga ttāya vāti nāga rāja bhāvāya vā pariyattam  supaṇṇatta ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ devattāya vāti sammuti deva ādi bhāvāya āyatim phala pāṭikaṅkhī
translated: the one who has obtained what is seen, the head of a sect. It is not enough for the king: it is not sufficient for the state of a king of the nāgas.

original: hotīti anāgate vipākaphalaṃ patthayāno hoti. Diṭṭhasuddhiyāpi dve ānisaṃse passatīti🔽cakkhuviññāṇena diṭṭharūpāyatanassa vasena suddhiyā hetuttāpi attano gahitagahaṇena
analyzed: hoti iti anāgate vipāka phalam patthayānaḥ hoti diṭṭha suddhiyā api dve ānisaṃse passati iti  cakkhu viññāṇena diṭṭha rūpa āyatanassa vasena suddhiyāḥ attanaḥ gahita gahaṇena
translated: The same method applies to the states of a supaṇṇa, and so on. For the state of a god: for the state of a god by general consent, and so on. He is looking for fruit in the future: he is hoping for a ripening in the future. He sees two advantages in purification by what is seen:

original: dve guṇe oloketi. Sutasuddhiyādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽33. Tatiyagāthāyattho – evaṃ passato ca yaṃ attano satthārādiṃ nissito aññaṃ parasatthārādiṃ
analyzed: dve guṇe oloka iti esa iva nayaḥ  evam passataḥ ca yam attano satthārā ādim nissitaḥ aññam para satthārā ādim
translated: because of the cause for purification by means of the visible-data base seen by eye-consciousness, he looks at two special qualities by his own acceptance of what is accepted. The same method applies to purification by what is heard, and so on.

original: hīnaṃ passati, taṃ pana dassanaṃ ganthameva kusalā vadanti, bandhananti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: hīnam passati tam pana dassanam gantham eva kusalāḥ vadanti bandhananti vuttam hoti
translated: The meaning of the third stanza is this. And when he sees in this way, he sees another teacher, etc., who is inferior to his own teacher, etc., and he takes sides with his own teacher, etc. But the wise say that this view is just a fetter, a bondage.

original: Yasmā etadeva, tasmā hi diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā, sīlabbataṃ bhikkhu na nissayeyya,
analyzed: yasmai etat eva tasmai hi diṭṭham va sutam mutam vā sīlabbatam bhikkhu na
translated: Or on virtue and practice.

original: nābhiniveseyyāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na abhiniveseyya ati vuttam hoti
translated: He should not be attached to them.

original: Kusalāti khandhādijānane chekā. Khandhakusalāti rūpādīsu pañcasu khandhesu kusalā.🔽Dhātuāyatanapaṭiccasamuppādasatipaṭṭhānasammappadhānaiddhipādaindriyabalabojjhaṅgamaggaphalanibbānesupi
analyzed: kusalā ati khandha ādi jānane chekā khandha kusalā ati rūpa ādīsu pañcasu khandhesu kusalā  dhātu āyatana paṭiccasamuppāda sati paṭṭhāna sammappadhāna eddhipāda aindriya bala bojjhaṅga magga phala nibbānesu pi
translated: Skilled in aggregates, etc.: skilled in the five aggregates of form, etc.🔽In the elements, bases, dependent origination, foundations of mindfulness, right efforts, bases of psychic power, faculties, powers, factors of enlightenment, path, fruits, and Nibbāna.

original: eseva nayo. Tattha maggakusalāti catūsu maggesu. Phalakusalāti catūsu phalesu. Nibbānakusalāti🔽duvidhe nibbāne chekā. Te kusalāti te etesu vuttappakāresu chekā. Evaṃ vadantīti🔽evaṃ kathenti. Gantho esoti passato ca attano satthārādinissitañca aññaṃ parasatthārādiṃ
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tattha magga kusalā ati catūsu maggesu phala kusalā ati catūsu phalesu nibbāna kusalā ati  duvidhe nibbāne chekā te kusalā ati te etesu vutta ppakāresu chekā evam vadanti iti  evam kathenti gantho eso ti passataḥ ca attano satthāra ādi nissitam ca aññam para satthāra ādim
translated: The same method applies here. Skilled in the four paths. Skilled in the four fruits. Skilled in the two kinds of Nibbāna.🔽They are skilled in these.🔽They say this:🔽They say that the seeing of one’s own teacher, etc., and the seeing of another’s teacher, etc., as inferior is a fetter, a bondage.

original: hīnato dassanañca gantho bandhano esoti vadanti. Lagganaṃ etanti etaṃ vuttappakāraṃ
analyzed: hīnataḥ dassanam ca ganthaḥ bandhano eso ti vadanti lagganam etat ti etam vutta ppakāram
translated: They say that this kind of seeing is a shackle.

original: nāgadante laggitaṃ viya adholambanaṃ. Bandhanaṃ etanti nicchindituṃ dukkhaṭṭhena
analyzed: nāga dante laggitam viya adhas lambanam bandhanam etat ti nicchinditum dukkhaṭṭhena
translated: Like a post stuck in the ground, it is hard to pull out.🔽It is a fetter in the sense of being hard to cut through.

original: saṅkhalikādibandhanaṃ viya etaṃ bandhanaṃ. Palibodho esoti saṃsārato nikkhamituṃ🔽appadānaṭṭhena eso palibodho.
analyzed: saṅkhalikā ādi bandhanam viya etam bandhanam palibodho eso ti saṃsārataḥ nikkhamitum  appadāna ṭṭhena eso palibodho
translated: It is an impediment in the sense of being hard to cross over.

original: 34. Catutthagāthāyattho – na kevalaṃ diṭṭhasutādīsu na nissayeyya, apica kho pana
analyzed: na kevalam diṭṭha suta ādīsu na apica kho pana
translated: The meaning of the fourth stanza is this. Not only should one not rely on what is seen, heard, etc., but also

original: asañjātaṃ uparūpari diṭṭhimpi lokasmiṃ na kappayeyya, na janeyyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kīdisaṃ?
analyzed: a sañjātam upari upari diṭṭhim pi lokasmim na kappayeyya na janeyya ati vuttam hoti kīdisam
translated: one should not form a view about the world, which is not yet arisen, i.e., one should not generate a view. What kind of view?

original: Ñāṇena vā sīlavatena vāpi, samāpattiñāṇādiñāṇena vā sīlavatena vā yā kappiyati, etaṃ🔽diṭṭhiṃ na kappeyya. Na kevalañca diṭṭhiṃ na kappayeyya, apica kho pana mānenapi
analyzed: ñāṇena vā sīlavatena vā api samāpatti ñāṇa ādi ñāṇena vā sīlavatena vā yā etam  diṭṭhim na kappeyya na kevalañca diṭṭhim na kappayeyya apica kho pana mānena api
translated: One should not form a view that is approved by one who is wise or virtuous, i.e., by one who possesses the knowledge of the eight attainments, etc., or by one who is virtuous.🔽And not only should one not form a view, but also one should not be conceited.

original: jātiādīhi vatthūhi samoti attānamanūpaneyya, hīno na maññetha visesi vāpīti.
analyzed: jāti ādīhi vatthūhi samaḥ ti attānam anūpaneyya hīnaḥ na maññetha visesi vā api iti
translated: One should not exalt oneself because of one’s family, etc., nor should one despise others because of one’s own superiority in these respects.

original: Aṭṭhasamāpattiñāṇena vāti paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ sampayuttapaññāya
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti ñāṇena vāti paṭhama jhāna ādīnam aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam sampayutta paññāya
translated: By the knowledge of the eight attainments: by the wisdom associated with the eight attainments, i.e., the first jhāna, etc.

original: vā. Pañcābhiññāñāṇena vāti lokiyānaṃ pañcannaṃ abhiññānaṃ sampayuttapaññāya vā. Micchāñāṇena
analyzed: vā pañca abhiññā ñāṇena vā ati lokiyānam pañcannam abhiññānam sampayutta paññāya vā micchā ñāṇena
translated: Or by the five kinds of direct-knowledge: by the five kinds of mundane direct-knowledge associated with understanding.

original: vāti viparītasabhāvena pavattāya paññāya amutte muttaṃ passāti evaṃ uppannena micchāñāṇena vā.
analyzed: vāti viparīta sabhāvena pavattāya paññāya amutte muttam passāti evam uppannena micchāñāṇena vā
translated: Or by wrong knowledge: by the understanding that occurs with the nature of perversion, that is, by wrong knowledge arisen thus.

original: 35. Pañcamagāthāyattho – evañhi diṭṭhiṃ akappento amaññamāno ca attaṃ pahāya anupādiyāno
analyzed: evam hi diṭṭhim a kappentaḥ a maññamānaḥ ca attam pahāya an upādiyānaḥ
translated: The meaning of the fifth stanza: Thus, not assuming a view, not conceiving an individual essence,🔽Abandoning what was previously grasped, not grasping anything else,

original: yaṃ pubbe gahitaṃ, taṃ pahāya paraṃ aggaṇhanto tasmimpi vuttappakāre ñāṇe duvidhaṃ
analyzed: yam pubbe gahitam tam pahāya param aggaṇhanto tasmim pi vutta ppakāre ñāṇe duvidham
translated: he does not rely on the two kinds of support in that same kind of knowledge described above.

original: nissayaṃ no karoti, akaronto ca sa ve viyattesu nānādiṭṭhivasena bhinnesu sattesu
analyzed: nissayam no karoti a karontaḥ ca sa ve viyattesu nānā diṭṭhi vasena bhinnesu sattesu
translated: Not relying, he does not go in a group,

original: na vaggasārī chandādivasena agacchanadhammo hutvā dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu kiñci diṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: na vaggasārī chanda ādi vasena a gacchana dhammaḥ hutvā dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu kiñci diṭṭhim
translated: not being a doctrine-follower by way of desire, etc., he does not return to any of the sixty-two views.

original: na pacceti, na paccāgacchatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti vuttam hoti
translated: He does not return, does not come back, is what is meant.

original: Catūhi upādānehīti kāmupādānādīhi catūhi bhusaṃ gahaṇehi sa ve viyattesūti so puggalo nicchitesu. Bhinnesūti dvidhā bhinnesu.
analyzed: catūhi upādānehi iti kāma upādāna ādīhi catūhi gahaṇehi sa ve viyattesu iti saḥ puggalaḥ nicchitesu bhinnesu iti dvidhā bhinnesu
translated: By the four kinds of clinging: by the four kinds of clinging beginning with sense-desire clinging. He does not go in a group: that person does not go in a group of beings who are divided, who are split in two ways.

original: 36. Idāni yo so imāya gāthāya vutto khīṇāsavo, tassa vaṇṇabhaṇanatthaṃ “yassūbhayante”tiādikā
analyzed: idāni yaḥ saḥ imāya gāthāya vuttaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ tassa vaṇṇa bhaṇana attham
translated: Now, in order to extol the one who is called “the canker-free” in this stanza, he spoke three stanzas beginning with “Whose two ends are known” .

original: tisso gāthāyo āha. Tattha paṭhamagāthāya yassūbhayanteti pubbe vutte phassādibhede.🔽Paṇidhīti taṇhā. Bhavābhavāyāti punappunabhavāya. Idha vā huraṃ vāti sakattabhāvādibhede
analyzed: tissaḥ gāthāyaḥ āha tattha paṭhama gāthāya pubbe vutte phassa ādi bhede  taṇhā bhava abhavāya ati punappunabhavāya vā vāti
translated: Herein, in the first stanza “Whose two ends are known” is the kind of contact, etc., already mentioned above.

original: idha vā parattabhāvādibhede parattha vā.
analyzed: idha vā paratta bhāva ādi bhede vā
translated: “Resolve” is craving. “For being and non-being” is for renewed being again and again. “Here or beyond” is in the kind of selfhood here or in the kind of selfhood there.

original: Phasso eko antoti cakkhusamphassādiko eko koṭṭhāso. Phassasamudayoti vatthārammaṇo.
analyzed: phassaḥ ekaḥ anto ti cakkhu samphassa ādikaḥ ekaḥ koṭṭhāso phassa samudayo ti vattha ārammaṇo
translated: “Contact is one end” is one section, namely, eye-contact, etc. “The arising of contact” is the physical basis and the object.

original: Yato samudeti uppajjati, so samudayo. Dutiyo antoti dutiyo koṭṭhāso. Atītanti ati
analyzed: yatas samudeti uppajjati saḥ samudayaḥ dutiyaḥ anto ti dutiyaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ atīta nti ati
translated: From which it arises, that is its arising. “The other end” is the second section. “The past” is what is past,

original: itaṃ atītaṃ, atikkantanti vuttaṃ hoti. Anāgatanti na āgataṃ, anuppannanti vuttaṃ
analyzed: itam atītam atikkantanti vuttam hoti anāgatanti na āgatam anuppannanti vuttam
translated: what has gone beyond, is what is meant. “The future” is what has not come, what has not arisen, is what is meant.

original: hoti. Sukhā vedanādayo visabhāgavasena. Nāmarūpadukaṃ namanaruppanavasena. Ajjhattikādayo
analyzed: hoti sukhāḥ vedanā ādayaḥ visa bhāga vasena nāma rūpa dukam namana ruppana vasena ajjhattika ādayaḥ
translated: Pleasant feeling, etc., are different kinds. The description of mentality-materiality is in the sense of bending and occurring. The internal, etc., are different kinds.

original: ajjhattabāhiravasena. Sakkāyādayo khandhapañcakānaṃ pavattisamudayavasena vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ajjhatta bāhira vasena sakkāya ādayaḥ khandha pañcakānam pavatti samudaya vasena vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: and internally and externally. The aggregates should be understood as stated in the sense of the arising of the five aggregates, beginning with personality-view.

original: Sakattabhāvoti attano attabhāvo. Parattabhāvoti parassa attabhāvo.
analyzed: sakattabhāvo ti attanaḥ atta bhāvo parattabhāvo ti parassa atta bhāvo
translated: “One’s own state” is one’s own individuality. “Another’s state” is another’s individuality.

original: 37. Dutiyagāthāya diṭṭhe vāti diṭṭhasuddhiyā vā. Esa nayo sutādīsu. Saññāti saññāsamuṭṭhāpikā diṭṭhi.
analyzed: dutiya gāthāya diṭṭhe vā ati diṭṭha suddhiyā vā esa nayo suta ādīsu saññā ati saññā samuṭṭhāpikā diṭṭhi
translated: In the second stanza, “in the seen” means in the purification of view. The same method applies to the heard, etc. “Perception” is the view that arises from perception.

original: Aparāmasantanti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīhi na parāmasantaṃ. Anabhinivesantanti teheva anabhinivisantaṃ.🔽“Vinibaddho”ti vāti mānena vinibaddhoti vā. “Parāmaṭṭho”ti vāti parato niccasukhasubhādīhi
analyzed: a parāmasantam ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhīhi na parāmasantam an abhinivesantam ti tehi iva an abhinivisantam  vinibaddhaḥ iti vā ati mānena vinibaddhaḥ iti vā parāmaṭṭhaḥ iti vā ati paratas nicca sukha subha ādīhi
translated: “Not clinging” means not clinging through craving, conceit, and views. “Not adhering” means not adhering through those same .🔽“Bound” means bound by conceit. “Clinging” means clinging to the other as permanent, blissful, beautiful, etc.

original: parāmaṭṭhoti vā. Vikkhepagatoti uddhaccavasena. Aniṭṭhaṅgatoti vicikicchāvasena.
analyzed: parāmaṭṭho ti vā vikkhepa gato ti uddhacca vasena aniṭṭhaṅgato ti vicikicchā vasena
translated: “Gone astray” means gone astray through agitation. “Not gone to destruction” means not gone to destruction through perplexity.

original: Thāmagatoti anusayavasena. Gatiyāti gantabbavasena.
analyzed: anusaya vasena gatiyā iti gantabba vasena
translated: “Gone to a stand” means gone to a stand through latent tendencies. “Gone to destinations” means gone to destinations through going.

original: 38. Tatiyagāthāya dhammāpi tesaṃ na paṭicchitāseti dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatadhammāpi tesaṃ
analyzed: tatiya gāthāya dhammā api tesam na dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata dhammā api tesam
translated: In the third stanza, “they do not accept even ideas” means they do not accept the sixty-two views.

original: “idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti evaṃ na paṭicchitā. Pāraṅgato na pacceti tādīti nibbānapāraṃ
analyzed: idam eva saccam mogham aññanti evam na paṭicchitā pāraṅgataḥ na pacceti tādi iti nibbāna pāram
translated: He has gone beyond, he does not return: he has gone beyond to extinction,

original: gato tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna nāgacchati pañcahi ca ākārehi tādī hotīti. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva.🔽Vīsativatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhīti “rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”tiādinā nayena ekekasmiṃ
analyzed: gataḥ tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna na āgacchati pañcahi ca ākārehi tādī hoti iti sesam pākaṭam eva  vīsati vatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhī iti rūpam attataḥ samanupassati itiādinā nayena ekekasmin
translated: he does not return to the defilements abandoned by the respective path. And he is of such kind in five ways. The rest is clear.🔽Twenty kinds of personality view: the view that occurs by taking the five aggregates as a self in each of the four ways beginning with “Material form is the self” is called “personality view.”

original: khandhe catūhi catūhi ākārehi pañcakkhandhe patiṭṭhaṃ katvā pavattā vijjamāne kāye
analyzed: khandhe catūhi catūhi ākārehi pañca kkhandhe patiṭṭham katvā pavattā vijjamāne kāye
translated: It is a view about a real self in a real world.

original: diṭṭhi. Dasavatthukā micchādiṭṭhīti “natthi dinna”ntiādinayappavattā diṭṭhi. Antaggāhikādiṭṭhīti
analyzed: diṭṭhi dasa vatthukā micchādiṭṭhī iti natthi dinna nti ādi naya ppavattā diṭṭhi antaggāhikādiṭṭhīti
translated: Ten kinds of wrong view: the view that occurs in the way beginning “There is nothing given” is called “wrong view.”

original: “sassato loko idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”ntiādinayappavattā ekekaṃ antaṃ atthīti
analyzed: sassataḥ lokaḥ idam eva saccam mogham aññanti ādi naya ppavattā ekekam antam atthi iti
translated: Extreme view: the view that occurs by taking one of the extremes as an existent in the way beginning “The world is eternal: this alone is the truth, other ideas are foolish” is called “extreme view.”

original: gahetvā pavattā diṭṭhi. Yā evarūpā diṭṭhīti idāni vuccamānānaṃ ekūnavīsapadānaṃ sādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā pavattā diṭṭhi yā evarūpā diṭṭhī iti idāni vuccamānānam ekūnavīsa padānam sādhāraṇam
translated: Any such view: this is a general term for the nineteen kinds of view that are now going to be described.

original: mūlapadaṃ. Yā diṭṭhi, tadeva diṭṭhigataṃ; yā diṭṭhi, tadeva diṭṭhigahananti sabbesaṃ🔽sambandho kātabbo. Yā ayāthāvadassanaṭṭhena diṭṭhi, tadeva diṭṭhīsu gataṃ dassanaṃ
analyzed: mūla padam yā diṭṭhi tat eva diṭṭhi gatam yā diṭṭhi tat eva diṭṭhi gahanan ti sabbesam  sambandhaḥ kātabbaḥ yā a yāthāvadassana ṭṭhena diṭṭhi tat eva diṭṭhīsu gatam dassanam
translated: The root-clause. The view is the same as the view-class, the view is the same as the view-group. The connection should be made in all cases.

original: dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyā antogatattāti diṭṭhigataṃ. Heṭṭhāpissa attho vuttoyeva.
analyzed: dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyāḥ antogata ttā ti diṭṭhi gatam heṭṭhā api issa atthaḥ vuttaḥ yeva
translated: The view which is in the sense of seeing not as it actually is is the same as the class of views, the seeing which is included in the sixty-two views. The meaning below has already been stated.

original: Dvinnaṃ antānaṃ ekantagatattātipi diṭṭhigataṃ. Tattha sassatoti nicco. Lokoti attā.🔽“Idha sarīraṃyeva nassati, attā pana idha parattha ca soyevā”ti maññanti. So hi sāmaññeva
analyzed: dvinnam antānam diṭṭhi gatam tattha sassatoti niccaḥ loko ti attā  idha sarīraṃya iva nassati attā pana idha parattha ca soyā iva ati maññanti so hi sāmaññā iva
translated: The view-class is also the going to one of the two extremes. Herein, eternal means permanent. World means self.🔽They think: “Here the body is destroyed, but the self is just this here and there.” He is called a world because he looks at the same .

original: āloketīti katvā lokoti maññati. Asassatoti anicco. Attā sarīreneva saha nassatīti
analyzed: āloka iti iti katvā maññati a sassatoti aniccaḥ attā sarīrena iva saha nassati iti
translated: Not eternal means impermanent. They think: “The self is destroyed together with the body.”

original: maññanti. Antavāti paritte kasiṇe jhānaṃ uppādetvā taṃ parittakasiṇārammaṇaṃ cetanaṃ
analyzed: maññanti antavāti paritte kasiṇe jhānam uppādetvā tam paritta kasiṇa ārammaṇam cetanam
translated: Having aroused jhāna in a limited kasiṇa, they think: “The self has an end,” having made the volition with the limited kasiṇa as object.

original: “sapariyanto attā”ti maññanti. Ananta vāti na antavā appamāṇe kasiṇe jhānaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: sapariyantaḥ attā iti maññanti ananta vāti na antavā appamāṇe kasiṇe jhānam uppādetvā
translated: Having aroused jhāna in an unlimited kasiṇa, they think: “The self is not endless,” having made the volition with the unlimited kasiṇa as object.

original: taṃ appamāṇakasiṇārammaṇaṃ cetanaṃ “apariyanto attā”ti maññanti. Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti🔽jīvo ca sarīrañca taṃyeva. Jīvoti attā, liṅgavipallāsena napuṃsakavacanaṃ kataṃ.🔽Sarīranti rāsaṭṭhena khandhapañcakaṃ. Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti añño jīvo aññaṃ🔽khandhapañcakaṃ. Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti khandhā idheva vinassanti, satto maraṇato
analyzed: tam appamāṇa kasiṇa ārammaṇam cetanam a pariyantaḥ attā iti maññanti tam jīvam tam sarīram ti  ca sarīram ca attā liṅga vipallāsena napuṃsaka vacanam katam  sarīranti rāsaṭṭhena khandha pañcakam aññam jīvam aññam sarīranti aññaḥ jīvaḥ aññam  khandha pañcakam hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇā ati khandhāḥ idha iva vinassanti satto maraṇato
translated: They assume that the self is infinite, thinking that the intention which has the measureless kasiṇa as its object is the self. The self and the body are the same.

original: paraṃ hoti vijjati na nassati, tathāgatoti cetaṃ sattādhivacananti. Keci pana “tathāgatoti🔽arahā”ti vadanti. Ime na hotīti pakkhe dosaṃ disvā evaṃ gaṇhanti. Na hoti tathāgato🔽paraṃ maraṇāti khandhāpi idheva nassanti, tathāgato ca maraṇato paraṃ na hoti ucchijjati.🔽Ime hotīti pakkhe dosaṃ disvā evaṃ gaṇhanti. Hoti ca na ca hotīti ime ekekapakkhapariggahe

original: dosaṃ disvā ubhayapakkhaṃ gaṇhanti. Neva hoti na na hotīti ime ubhayapakkhapariggahe
analyzed: dosam disvā ubhaya pakkham gaṇhanti na iva hoti na na hoti iti ime ubhaya pakkha pariggahe
translated: and when they see the danger in both they take the side of neither assertion.

original: ubhayadosāpattiṃ disvā “hoti ca na hotī”ti ca “neva hoti na na hotī”ti ca amarāvikkhepapakkhaṃ gaṇhanti.🔽Ayaṃ panettha aṭṭhakathānayo – “sassato loko”ti vātiādīhi dasahākārehi diṭṭhipabhedova
analyzed: ubhaya dosa āpattim disvā hoti ca na hoti iti ca na iva hoti na na hoti iti ca amarā vikkhepa pakkham gaṇhanti  ayam pana ittha aṭṭhakathā nayo sassataḥ loko ti vā ati ādīhi dasa hākārehi diṭṭhi pabhedaḥ va
translated: When they see the danger in both these sides, they take the side of the assertion that it both is and is not and that it neither is nor is not.🔽But here is the method of the commentary: the tenfold view is stated by the words “The world is eternal,” etc.,

original: vutto. Tattha sassato lokoti ca khandhapañcakaṃ lokoti gahetvā “ayaṃ loko nicco dhuvo🔽sabbakāliko”ti gaṇhantassa sassatanti gahaṇākārappavattā diṭṭhi. Asassatoti tameva
analyzed: vuttaḥ tattha sassataḥ loko ti ca khandha pañcakam loko ti gahetvā ayam lokaḥ niccaḥ dhuvaḥ  sabbakāliko ti gaṇhantassa gahaṇa ākāra ppavattā diṭṭhi tam eva
translated: and here the view that occurs as the mode of conceiving “The world is eternal” is stated by the words “The world is eternal” when one who has taken the five aggregates as the world conceives it thus, “This world is permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change” .🔽The view that occurs as the mode of conceiving annihilation is stated by the words “The world is not eternal” when one who has taken that same world conceives it thus, “It is annihilated, destroyed, and does not exist after death” .

original: lokaṃ “ucchijjati vinassatī”ti gaṇhantassa ucchedaggahaṇākārappavattā diṭṭhi. Antavāti🔽parittakasiṇalābhino suppamatte vā sarāvamatte vā kasiṇe samāpannassa antosamāpattiyaṃ
analyzed: lokam ucchijjati vinassati iti gaṇhantassa uccheda ggahaṇa ākāra ppavattā diṭṭhi antavāti 🔽paritta kasiṇa lābhino suppamatte vā sarāva matte vā kasiṇe samāpannassa antosamāpattiyam
translated: The view that occurs as the mode of conceiving finitude is stated by the words “The world is finite” when one who has obtained the limited kasiṇas conceives the world thus, “The world is finite, limited, by so and so much” .🔽The view that occurs as the mode of conceiving infinitude is stated by the words “The world is infinite” when one who has obtained the measureless kasiṇas conceives the world thus, “The world is infinite, immeasurable, endless, unbounded” .

original: pavattitarūpārūpadhamme “loko”ti ca kasiṇaparicchedantena “antavā”ti ca gaṇhantassa
analyzed: ca kasiṇa pariccheda antena ca gaṇhantassa
translated: and he apprehends the material and immaterial states occurring in the kasiṇa as “the world” and as “finite” by delimiting them by the kasiṇa’s extent,

original: “antavā loko”ti gahaṇākārappavattā diṭṭhi. Sā sassatadiṭṭhipi hoti ucchedadiṭṭhipi.🔽Vipulakasiṇalābhino pana tasmiṃ kasiṇe samāpannassa antosamāpattiyaṃ pavattitarūpārūpadhamme
analyzed: antavā loko ti gahaṇa ākāra ppavattā diṭṭhi sā sassata diṭṭhi pi hoti uccheda diṭṭhi pi  vipula kasiṇa lābhinaḥ pana tasmin kasiṇe samāpannassa antosamāpattiyam pavattita rūpa arūpa dhamme
translated: then the view that occurs in the mode of apprehending them as “The world is finite” is a form of eternalism.🔽But when one who has attained the measureless kasiṇa apprehends the material and immaterial states occurring in the attainment as “the world” and as “infinite” by delimiting them by the extent of the kasiṇa,

original: “loko”ti ca kasiṇaparicchedantena ca “ananto”ti gaṇhantassa “anantavā loko”ti gahaṇākārappavattā🔽diṭṭhi. Sā sassatadiṭṭhi hoti, ucchedadiṭṭhipi. Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti bhedanadhammassa
analyzed: loko ti ca kasiṇa pariccheda antena ca anantaḥ ti gaṇhantassa ananta vā loko ti gahaṇa ākāra ppavattā  diṭṭhi sā sassata diṭṭhi hoti uccheda diṭṭhi pi tam jīvam tam sarīran ti bhedana dhammassa
translated: then the view that occurs in the mode of apprehending them as “The world is infinite” is a form of eternalism. It is also a form of annihilationism.🔽Because he apprehends the body itself as “the living being” since it is subject to destruction,🔽the view that occurs in the mode of apprehending it as “When the body is destroyed the living being is destroyed” is annihilationism.

original: sarīrasseva “jīva”nti gahitattā “sarīre ucchijjamāne jīvampi ucchijjatī”ti ucchedaggahaṇākārappavattā🔽diṭṭhi. Dutiyapadena sarīrato aññassa jīvassa gahitattā “sarīre ca ucchijjamānepi
analyzed: sarīrassa iva jīvanti gahita ttā sarīre ucchijjamāne jīvam pi ucchijjati iti uccheda ggahaṇa ākāra ppavattā 🔽diṭṭhi dutiya padena sarīrato aññassa jīvassa gahita ttā sarīre ca ucchijjamāne pi
translated: Because he apprehends the living being as something different from the body,

original: jīvaṃ na ucchijjatī”ti sassatagahaṇākārappavattā diṭṭhi. Hoti tathāgatotiādīsu “satto
analyzed: jīvam na ucchijjati iti sassata gahaṇa ākāra ppavattā diṭṭhi hoti tathāgato tiādīsu satto
translated: The first eternalist view is that of one who holds the view “The soul is the same as the self-existent ;

original: tathāgato nāma, so paraṃ maraṇā hotī”ti gaṇhato paṭhamā sassatadiṭṭhi. “Na hotī”ti
analyzed: tathāgataḥ nāma saḥ param maraṇā hoti iti gaṇhataḥ paṭhamā sassata diṭṭhi na hoti iti
translated: after death it becomes a self-existent” . The second annihilationist view is that of one who holds the view “It does not become a self-existent” .

original: gaṇhato dutiyā ucchedadiṭṭhi. “Hoti ca na ca hotī”ti gaṇhato tatiyā ekaccasassatadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: gaṇhataḥ dutiyā uccheda diṭṭhi hoti ca na ca hoti iti gaṇhataḥ tatiyā ekacca sassata diṭṭhi
translated: The third eternalist view is that of one who holds the view “It both becomes and does not become a self-existent” .🔽The fourth view is that of one who holds the view “It neither becomes nor does not become a self-existent” .

original: “Neva hoti na na hotī”ti gaṇhato catutthā amarāvikkhepadiṭṭhīti vuttappakārā dasavidhā
analyzed: na iva hoti na na hoti iti gaṇhataḥ catutthā amarā vikkhepa diṭṭhī iti vutta ppakārā dasavidhā
translated: These are the ten views of the self-existent stated in the way already given.

original: diṭṭhi. Yathāyogaṃ bhavadiṭṭhi ca vibhavadiṭṭhi cāti dvidhā hoti. Tāsu ekāpi tesaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi yathāyogam bhava diṭṭhi ca vibhava diṭṭhi ca ati dvidhā hoti tāsu ekā api tesam
translated: They are twofold as the view of becoming and the view of non-becoming according to the way in which they are held.

original: khīṇāsavānaṃ na paṭicchitāti attho.
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam na paṭicchitā ati atthaḥ
translated: Not one of them is admitted by them whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Ye kilesāti ye kilesā sotāpattimaggena pahīnā, te kilese. Na punetīti na puna eti.
analyzed: ye kilesā ati ye kilesā sotāpatti maggena pahīnā te kilese na puneti iti na punar eti
translated: The defilements that are abandoned by the path of stream-entry are the defilements. He does not return: he does not return again.

original: Na paccetīti puna nibbattetvā na paṭieti, na paccāgacchatīti paccabhave nāgacchati.
analyzed: na pacceti iti puna nibbattetvā na paṭieti na paccāgacchati iti paccabhave na āgacchati
translated: He does not come back: having been reborn again, he does not come back, he does not return. He does not come to this world again: he does not come to a next existence.

original: Pañcahākārehi tādīti pañcahi kāraṇehi koṭṭhāsehi vā sadiso. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhe tādīti iṭṭhārammaṇe🔽ca aniṭṭhārammaṇe ca anunayapaṭighaṃ muñcitvā ṭhitattā dvīsu sadiso. Cattāvīti kilese🔽cajitavā. Tiṇṇāvīti saṃsāraṃ atikkamitavā. Muttāvīti rāgādito muttavā. Taṃniddesā
analyzed: pañcahā ākārehi tādi iti pañcahi kāraṇehi koṭṭhāsehi vā sadisaḥ iṭṭha aniṭṭhe tādi iti iṭṭha ārammaṇe  ca aniṭṭha ārammaṇe ca anunaya paṭigham muñcitvā ṭhita ttā dvīsu kilese  cajitavā tiṇṇāvī iti saṃsāram atikkamitavā muttāvī iti rāga āditaḥ muttavā tad niddesā
translated: “The same in five ways”: he is the same in five instances or aspects. “The same in the agreeable and disagreeable” : he is the same in regard to agreeable objects and disagreeable objects, because he stands without emitting affection or aversion. “The same in the four” : he has abandoned the defilements. “The same in the three” : he has gone beyond the round of existence. “The same in the seven” : he is the same in regard to the seven kinds of rebirth. “The same in the eight” : he is the same in regard to the eight worldly conditions. “The same in the nine” : he is the same in regard to the nine abodes of beings. “The same in the ten” : he is the same in regard to the ten bases.

original: tādīti tena tena sīlasaddhādinā niddisitvā niddisitvā kathetabbato sadiso.
analyzed: tādi iti tena tena sīla saddhā ādinā niddisitvā niddisitvā kathetabbataḥ sadisaḥ
translated: He is the same in five ways: he is the same in five instances or aspects. He is the same in regard to the desirable and the undesirable: he is the same in regard to desirable objects and undesirable objects because he stands without emitting affection or aversion. He has abandoned the four: he has abandoned the four taints . He has crossed over the four : he has crossed over the four floods . He has escaped from the four : he has escaped from lust, etc. He is the same in the sense of being shown: he is the same in the sense of being shown by this or that virtue, faith, etc.

original: Taṃ pañcavidhaṃ vitthāretvā kathetukāmo “kathaṃ arahā iṭṭhāniṭṭhe tādī”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha lābhepīti catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ lābhepi. Alābhepīti tesaṃ alābhepi. Yasepīti🔽parivārepi. Ayasepīti parivāravipattiyāpi. Pasaṃsāyapīti vaṇṇabhaṇanāyapi. Nindāyapīti
analyzed: tam pañcavidham vitthāretvā kathetu kāmaḥ katham arahā iṭṭha aniṭṭhe tādi iti ādim āha  tattha lābhe pi iti catunnam paccayānam lābhe pi alābhe pi iti tesam alābhe pi yase pi iti  parivāre pi ayase pi iti parivāra vipattiyā api pasaṃsāya api iti vaṇṇa bhaṇanāya api nindāya api iti
translated: Desiring to explain the fivefold equality in detail, he asks, “How is the arahant the same in regard to the desirable and the undesirable?”

original: garahāyapi. Sukhepīti kāyikasukhepi. Dukkhepīti kāyikadukkhepi. Ekañce bāhaṃ gandhena
analyzed: sukhe pi iti kāyika sukhe pi dukkhe pi iti kāyika dukkhe pi ekam ce bāham gandhena
translated: Therein, in regard to gain: in regard to the acquisition of the four requisites. In regard to loss: in regard to the non-acquisition of the four requisites. In regard to fame: in regard to the acquisition of a retinue. In regard to ill-fame: in regard to the misfortune of a retinue. In regard to blame: in regard to censure. In regard to praise: in regard to commendation. In regard to happiness: in regard to bodily pleasure. In regard to suffering: in regard to bodily pain. If one arm is smeared with fragrant oil

original: limpeyyunti sace ekaṃ bāhaṃ catujātiyagandhena lepaṃ uparūpari dadeyyuṃ. Vāsiyā taccheyyunti
analyzed: limpeyyunti sace ekam bāham catu jātiya gandhena lepam upari upari dadeyyum vāsiyā taccheyyunti
translated: ‘If they were to smear it with oil’: if they were to smear it with oil of the four medicinal plants. ‘I would have it cut with a sharp knife’:

original: yadi ekaṃ bāhaṃ vaḍḍhakī vāsiyā tacchetvā tacchetvā tanuṃ kareyyuṃ. Amusmiṃ natthi🔽rāgoti amusmiṃ gandhalepane sineho natthi na saṃvijjati. Amusmiṃ natthi paṭighanti
analyzed: yadi ekam bāham vaḍḍhakī vā asiyā tat śetvā tat śetvā tanum kareyyuṃ amusmin na atthi  rāgaḥ ti amusmin gandha lepane sinehaḥ natthi na saṃvijjati amusmin natthi paṭighanti
translated: if they were to cut it with a sharp carpenter’s knife. ‘I would have no concern for it’:🔽I would have no affection for the oil-smearing. ‘I would have no aversion to it’:

original: amusmiṃ vāsiyā tacchane paṭihananasaṅkhātaṃ paṭighaṃ kopaṃ natthi na saṃvijjati.🔽Anunayapaṭighavippahīnoti sinehañca kopañca pajahitvā ṭhito. Ugghātinighātivītivattoti
analyzed: amusmin vā asiyā tad śane paṭihanana saṅkhātam paṭigham kopam natthi na saṃvijjati  anunaya paṭigha vippahīnaḥ ti sinehañca kopañca pajahitvā ṭhitaḥ ugghāti nighāti vīti vatto ti
translated: I would have no aversion to the cutting with the sharp knife. ‘I would be free from affection and aversion’:🔽I would be standing free from affection and aversion. ‘I would have overcome and directly known it’:

original: anunayavasena anuggahañca paṭighavasena niggahañca atikkamitvā ṭhito. Anurodhavirodhasamatikkantoti
analyzed: anunaya vasena anuggaham ca paṭigha vasena niggaham ca atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ anurodha virodha samatikkantaḥ ti
translated: I would be standing having overcome and directly known both the favouring of affection and the opposing of aversion. ‘I have gone beyond con-cord and conflict’:

original: anunayañca paṭighañca sammā atikkanto.
analyzed: anunayam ca paṭigham ca sammā atikkanto
translated: I have rightly gone beyond both affection and aversion.

original: Sīle satīti sīle saṃvijjamāne. Sīlavāti sīlasampanno. Tena niddesaṃ kathanaṃ labhatīti tādī. Saddhāya sati saddhoti evamādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sīle sati iti sīle saṃvijjamāne sīlavāti sīla sampannaḥ tena niddesam kathanam labhati iti tādī saddhāya sati saddhā iti evamādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: ‘When virtue is present’: when virtue is found. ‘Virtuous’: endowed with virtue. ‘He is called’: he is spoken of. ‘When faith is present’: when faith is found. ‘Faithful’: endowed with faith. The same method of explanation applies to the rest of the text.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Great Commentary on the Major Readings,

original: Paramaṭṭhakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Jarāsuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on the Paramatthaka Sutta is finished.🔽The commentary on the section on the Aging Sutta🔽In the sixth sutta, on aging, the words “Life is short, indeed,

original: 39. Chaṭṭhe jarāsutte appaṃ vata jīvitaṃ idanti idaṃ vata manussānaṃ jīvitaṃ appakaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe jarā sutte appam vata jīvitam idam ti idam vata manussānam jīvitam appakam
translated: and there is much to be done” mean that the human life span is short,

original: parittaṃ ṭhitiparittatāya sarasaparittatāyāti guhaṭṭhakasuttepi vuttanayametaṃ. Oraṃ🔽vassasatāpi miyyatīti vassasatā oraṃ kalalādikālepi miyyati. Aticcāti vassasataṃ🔽atikkamitvā. Jarasāpi miyyatīti jarāya miyyati. Ito paraṃ guhaṭṭhakasuttavaṇṇanāya
analyzed: parittam ṭhiti paritta tāya sarasa paritta tāya ati guhaṭṭhaka sutte pi vutta nayam etam  vassa satā api miyyati iti vassa satā oram kalala ādi kāle api miyyati aticca ati vassa satam  atikkamitvā jarasā api miyyati iti jarāya miyyati itas param guhaṭṭhaka sutta vaṇṇanāya
translated: limited in duration and limited in vitality, as explained in the Guhatthaka Sutta.🔽“One dies before one’s time” means that one dies before one’s time, even in the state of an embryo, etc. “One dies after one’s time” means that one dies after one’s hundredth year.

original: vuttanayeneva gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva gahetabbam
translated: “One dies through old age” means that one dies through the aging process. The rest should be understood in the way stated in the commentary on the Guhatthaka Sutta.

original: Appanti mandaṃ. Gamanīyo samparāyoti paraloko gantabbo. Kalalakālepīti ettha kalalakālaṃ
analyzed: mandam gamanīyo samparāyo ti para lokaḥ gantabbo kalala kāle iti ettha kalala kālam
translated: “One is slow” means that one is slow in one’s movements. “One must go to the next world” means that one must go to the other world. “Even in the state of an embryo” means that one dies even in the state of an embryo.

original: nāma paṭisandhikkhaṇe tīhi jātiuṇṇaṃsūhi katasuttagge ṭhitatelabinduppamāṇaṃ acchaṃ
analyzed: nāma paṭisandhi kkhaṇe tīhi jāti uṇṇa ṃsūhi kata sutta agge ṭhita tela bindu ppamāṇam accham
translated: limpid, unturbid, like a polished mirror-surface, the size of a drop of oil on water, according to the amount of kamma performed.

original: vippasannakalalaṃ hoti. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: vippasanna kalalam hoti yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: And it is said of it:🔽“Like a drop of oil on water

original: “Tilatelassa yathā bindu, sappimaṇḍo anāvilo;
analyzed: tila telassa yathā bindu sappi maṇḍaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: That spreads itself without a break,🔽So does the embryo’s appearance

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇappaṭibhāgaṃ, kalalaṃ sampavuccatī”ti. ;
analyzed: evam vaṇṇa paṭibhāgam kalalam sampavuccati iti
translated: Spread itself in like manner.”
