original: sīlasutādiguṇayuttehi ariyehi janotipi puthujjano.
analyzed: sīla suta ādi guṇa yuttehi ariyehi puthujjano
translated: Or they are ordinary people because they are a separate group, a separate class, separate from the noble ones who are endowed with virtue, learning, etc.

original: Evaṃ ye te –
analyzed: evam ye te
translated: Thus it is said:

original: “Duve puthujjanā vuttā, buddhenādiccabandhunā;
analyzed: duve puthujjanāḥ vuttāḥ buddhena adicca bandhunā
translated: “Two kinds of ordinary men Are mentioned by the Kinsman of the Sun:

original: Andho puthujjano eko, kalyāṇeko puthujjano”ti. –
analyzed: andhaḥ puthujjanaḥ ekaḥ kalyāṇa ekaḥ puthujjanaḥ ti
translated: One kind of ordinary man is blind, The other kind is sighted.”

original: Dveva puthujjanā vuttā, tesu andhaputhujjano vutto hotīti veditabbo.
analyzed: dve iva puthujjanāḥ vuttā tesu andha puthujjanaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ
translated: Of these two kinds of ordinary men, the blind ordinary man should be understood as referred to here.

original: 52. Yaso kitti cāti lābhasakkāro pasaṃsā ca. Pubbeti pabbajitabhāve. Hāyate vāpi
analyzed: yaso kitti ca ati lābha sakkāro pasaṃsā ca pubbe iti pabbajita bhāve hāyate vā api
translated: “Fame and glory”: gain and honor, and praise. “In the past”: in the time of his going forth. “Would decline”

original: tassa sāti tassa vibbhantakassa sato so ca yaso sā ca kitti hāyati. Etampi disvāti
analyzed: tassa sāti tassa vibbhantakassa sataḥ saḥ ca yaso sā ca kitti hāyati etam pi disvā ati
translated: “For him”: for him who is distracted. “That fame and glory”: that fame and glory. “Seeing this”:

original: etampi pubbe yasakittīnaṃ lābhaṃ pacchā ca hāniṃ disvā. Sikkhetha methunaṃ vippahātaveti
analyzed: etam pi pubbe yasa kittīnam lābham pacchā ca hānim disvā sikkhetha methunam vippahātave ti
translated: seeing that in the past there was gain of fame and glory, and later there was decline. “One should train”

original: tisso sikkhāyo sikkhetha. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Methunaṃ vippahātave, methunappahānatthāyāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ sikkhetha kim kāraṇā methunam vippahātave methuna ppahāna atthāya ati vuttam hoti
translated: “in the three trainings.” Why? “To abandon sexual intercourse”: to abandon sexual intercourse is what is meant.

original: Kittivaṇṇagatoti bhagavā kittivaṇṇo, kittisaddañceva guṇañca ukkhipitvā vadanto hotīti attho. Cittaṃ nānānayena kathanaṃ assa atthīti cittakathī. Kalyāṇapaṭibhānoti sundarapañño.
analyzed: kitti vaṇṇa gataḥ ti bhagavā kittivaṇṇo kitti saddam ca iva guṇam ca ukkhipitvā vadantaḥ hoti iti attho cittam nānā nayena kathanam assa atthi iti citta kathī kalyāṇa paṭibhāno ti sundara pañño
translated: “One who speaks of fame and glory”: the Blessed One is one who speaks of fame and glory, who speaks having raised up fame and glory, and also the sound of good qualities, is what is meant. “One who speaks with a clever tongue”: he has a clever way of speaking in various ways. “One of beautiful expression”: one of beautiful wisdom.

original: Hāyatīti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Parihāyatīti samantato hāyati. Paridhaṃsatīti adhopathaviṃ
analyzed: hāyati iti niddesassa uddesa padam parihāyati iti samantataḥ hāyati paridhaṃsati iti adhopathavim
translated: “Would decline”: this is a word of indication for the description. “Would be lost”: would decline all round. “Would be destroyed”: would be destroyed down to the earth.

original: patati. Paripatatīti samantato apagacchati. Antaradhāyatīti adassanaṃ yāti. Vippalujjatīti ucchijjati.
analyzed: patati paripatati iti samantataḥ apagacchati antaradhāyati iti a dassanam yāti vippalujjati iti ucchijjati
translated: It falls away: it goes away all round. It disappears: it goes out of sight. It is destroyed: it is annihilated.

original: Khuddako sīlakkhandhoti thullaccayādi. Mahanto sīlakkhandhoti pārājikasaṃṅghādiseso.🔽Methunadhammassa pahānāyāti tadaṅgādipahānena pajahanatthāya. Vūpasamāyāti malānaṃ🔽vūpasamanatthāya. Paṭinissaggāyāti pakkhandanapariccāgapaṭinissaggatthāya. Paṭipassaddhiyāti
analyzed: khuddako sīla kkhandho ti thullaccaya ādi mahantaḥ sīla kkhandho ti pārājika saṃṅgha ādiseso  methuna dhammassa pahānāya ati tad aṅga ādi pahānena pajahana tthāya vūpasamāyāti  vūpasamana atthāya paṭinissaggāya ati pakkhandana pariccāga paṭinissagga tthāya paṭipassaddhiyā ati
translated: The small category of virtue: the thullaccaya and so on. The great category of virtue: the pārājika and saṅghādisesa.🔽For the abandoning of sexual intercourse: for the abandoning by the abandoning of its components, and so on. For the allaying of lust: for the allaying of the defilements. For the casting out of lust: for the casting out by the casting out of the object, the casting out of the basis, and the casting out of both. For the pacification of lust: for the pacification called the fruit.🔽For the overcoming of lust: for the overcoming by the overcoming of the object, the overcoming of the defilements, and the overcoming of both.

original: paṭipassaddhisaṅkhātassa phalassa atthāya.
analyzed: paṭipassaddhi saṅkhātassa phalassa atthāya
translated: For the complete destruction of lust: for the complete destruction by the complete destruction of the object, the complete destruction of the defilements, and the complete destruction of both.🔽For the utter destruction of lust: for the utter destruction by the utter destruction of the object, the utter destruction of the defilements, and the utter destruction of both.🔽For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of both: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of both the object and the defilements.🔽For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of both: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of both the object and the defilements.

original: 53. Yo hi methunaṃ na vippajahati saṅkappehi…pe… tathāvidho. Tattha paretoti samannāgato. Paresaṃ nigghosanti upajjhāyādīnaṃ nindāvacanaṃ. Maṅku hotīti dummano hoti.
analyzed: yaḥ hi methunam na vippajahati tathāvidhaḥ tattha paretaḥ ti samannāgataḥ paresam upajjhāya ādīnam nindā vacanam maṅku hoti iti dummanaḥ hoti
translated: For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the defilements. For the destruction of lust by the destruction of both: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of both the object and the defilements.

original: Kāmasaṅkappenāti kāmapaṭisaṃyuttena vitakkena. Upariṭṭhepi eseva nayo. Phuṭṭhoti
analyzed: kāma saṅkappena ati kāma paṭisaṃyuttena vitakkena upariṭṭhe pi esa eva nayaḥ phuṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: For the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object: for the destruction of lust by the destruction of the object. For the destruction

original: vitakkehi phusito. Paretoti aparihīno. Samohitoti sammā ohito anto paviṭṭho. Kapaṇo🔽viyāti duggatamanusso viya. Mando viyāti aññāṇī viya. Momūho viyāti sammohabhūto
analyzed: vitakkehi phusito paretaḥ iti a parihīnaḥ samohito ti sammā ohito antar paviṭṭho kapaṇo  viyāti duggata manussaḥ viya mandaḥ viyāti aññāṇī viya momūhaḥ viyāti sammoha bhūto
translated: He is touched by thoughts. He is not without loss. He is well-covered, well-concealed, well-hidden. He is like a beggar.🔽He is like a fool. He is like one who is confused.

original: viya. Jhāyatīti cinteti. Pajjhāyatīti bhusaṃ cinteti. Nijjhāyatīti anekavidhena cinteti.🔽Apajjhāyatīti tato apagantvā cinteti. Ulūkoti ulūkasakuṇo. Rukkhasākhāyanti rukkhe🔽uṭṭhitasākhāya, viṭape vā. Mūsikaṃ magayamānoti mūsikaṃ gavesamāno, “maggayamāno”tipi
analyzed: viya jhāyati iti cintā iti pajjhāyati iti bhusam cintā iti nijjhāyati iti anekavidhena cintā iti  apajjhāyati iti tatas apagantvā cinteti ulūkaḥ iti ulūka sakuṇaḥ rukkhasākhāyanti rukkhe  uṭṭhita sākhāya viṭape vā mūsikam magayamānaḥ iti mūsikam gavesamānaḥ maggayamānaḥ iti pi
translated: He is struck by thoughts. He is not free from thoughts. He is overwhelmed by thoughts: he is properly overwhelmed, properly penetrated by thoughts. He is like a poor man: like a man of low status. He is like a fool: like one who is ignorant. He is like one bewildered: like one who is in a state of bewilderment. He thinks: he reflects. He thinks thoroughly: he reflects thoroughly. He thinks again and again: he reflects in many ways.

original: paṭhanti. Kotthūti siṅgālo. Biḷāroti babbu. Sandhisamalasaṅkaṭireti dvinnaṃ gharānaṃ
analyzed: paṭhanti siṅgālaḥ biḷāraḥ iti babbu
translated: He thinks away: he reflects after going away from there. An owl: a bird called an owl. In a tree-top: in a branch that grows from a tree, or in a bough. Seeking a mouse: looking for a mouse. “Seeking a path” is also read. A jackal: a dog. A cat: a mongoose. In a crevice, a hole, a difficult place, a junction: between two houses,

original: antare ca udakaniddhamanacikkhallakacavaranikkhipanaṭṭhāne ca thaṇḍile ca. Vahacchinnoti
analyzed: antare ca udaka niddhamana cikkhallaka cavara nikkhipana ṭṭhāne ca thaṇḍile ca vaha chinnā ti
translated: and in a place for removing water, a place for removing rubbish, and in a mound. He is like one whose neck is broken:

original: piṭṭhigīvamaṃsacchinno. Ito parā gāthā pākaṭasambandhā eva.
analyzed: piṭṭhigīva maṃsacchinnaḥ itas parā gāthā pākaṭa sambandhā eva
translated: whose neck and back flesh is broken. The verses from here on are of obvious meaning.

original: 54. Tāsu satthānīti kāyaduccaritādīni. Tāni hi attano paresañca chedanaṭṭhena “satthānī”ti
analyzed: tāsu satthāni iti kāya duccarita ādīni tāni hi attanaḥ paresam ca chedana ṭṭhena satthāni iti
translated: Among these, the weapons are bodily misconduct, etc.,🔽for these are “weapons” in the sense of cutting oneself and others.

original: vuccanti. Tesu vāyaṃ visesena tāva ādito musāvacanasatthāneva karoti, “iminā kāraṇenāhaṃ🔽vibbhanto”ti bhaṇanto. Tenevāha – “esa khvassa mahāgedho, mosavajjaṃ pagāhatī”ti.
analyzed: vuccanti tesu vā ayam visesena tāva āditas musā vacana satthān eva karoti iminā kāraṇena aham  vibbhantaḥ iti bhaṇantaḥ tena iva āha esa khvassa mahā gedhaḥ mosa vajjam pagāhati iti
translated: “Among these weapons” : bodily misconduct, etc. For these are called “weapons” in the sense of cutting oneself and others. Or, in the first place, he is especially armed with the weapon of false speech, saying, “For this reason I am disappointed.” Therefore it is said: “This is his great weapon, the false speech he utters.”

original: Tattha esa khvassāti esa kho assa. Mahāgedhoti mahābandhanaṃ. Katamoti ce? Yadidaṃ
analyzed: tattha esa khvassa ati esa kho assa mahāgedhoti mahābandhanam katamaḥ iti ce yat idam
translated: Herein, this is his: this is his. Great weapon: great bondage. If it be asked: what? —

original: mosavajjaṃ pagāhati, svāyaṃ musāvādajjhogāho “mahāgedho”ti veditabbo.🔽Tīṇi satthānīti tayo chedakā. Kāyaduccaritaṃ kāyasatthaṃ. Vacīsatthādīsupi eseva
analyzed: mosavajjam pagāhati svāyam musāvāda ajjhogāhaḥ mahā gedhaḥ iti veditabbo  tīṇi satthāni iti kāya duccaritam kāya sattham vacī sattha ādīsu pi esā eva
translated: it is the false speech he utters, which should be understood as his “great weapon” .

original: nayo. Taṃ vibhāgato dassetuṃ “tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ kāyasattha”nti āha. Sampajānamusā
analyzed: nayo tam vibhāgataḥ dassetum tividham kāya duccaritam kāya satthan ti āha sampajāna musā
translated: Three weapons: three cutters. Bodily misconduct is the weapon of the body. The same method applies to the weapon of speech, etc. In order to show this in detail, he says: “Three kinds of bodily misconduct are the weapon of the body.”

original: bhāsatīti jānanto tucchaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati. Abhirato ahaṃ bhante ahosiṃ pabbajjāyāti
analyzed: bhāsati iti jānantaḥ tuccham vācam bhāsati abhirataḥ aham bhante ahosim pabbajjāya ati
translated: He speaks deliberately: he speaks deliberately, uttering empty words. “I was delighted, venerable sir, with the going forth” .

original: sāsane pabbajjāya anabhirativirahito ahaṃ āsiṃ. Mātā me posetabbāti mātā mayā posetabbā.🔽Tenamhi vibbhantoti bhaṇatīti tena kāraṇena paṭikkanto asmītipi katheti. Pitā me
analyzed: sāsane pabbajjāya anabhirati virahitaḥ aham āsim mātā me posetabbā ati mātā mayā posetabbā  tenamhi vibbhantaḥ iti bhaṇati iti tena kāraṇena paṭikkantaḥ asmi iti pi kathā iti pitā me
translated: I was not interested in going forth in the Dispensation. ‘I must support my mother’ means ‘my mother must be supported by me.’

original: posetabbotiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: posetabba iti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: ‘Therefore I am disappointed’ means ‘therefore I have turned back.’ ‘I must support my father’ and so on is to be understood in the same way.

original: Eso tassa mahāgedhoti tassa puggalassa eso mahābandho. Mahāvananti mahantaṃ duṭṭhavanaṃ.
analyzed: eso tassa mahā gedhaḥ ti tassa puggalassa esaḥ mahā bandho mahā vanam ti mahantam duṭṭha vanam
translated: ‘This is his great bog’ means ‘this is his great bondage.’ ‘Great forest’ means ‘a great evil forest.’

original: Gahananti duratikkamaṃ. Kantāroti corakantārādisadiso. Visamoti kaṇṭakavisamo. Kuṭiloti
analyzed: gahanam ti duratikkamam kantāro ti cora kantāra ādi sadisaḥ visamaḥ ti kaṇṭaka visamaḥ kuṭilaḥ ti
translated: ‘Impassable’ means ‘difficult to cross.’ ‘Desert’ means ‘like a desert of thieves’ and so on. ‘Rough’ means ‘rough with thorns.’ ‘Winding’ means ‘like a crooked path.’

original: vaṅkakaṭakasadiso. Paṅkoti pallalasadiso. Palipoti kaddamasadiso. Palibodhoti mahādukkho.
analyzed: vaṅka kaṭaka sadiso paṅkoti pallala sadiso palipoti kaddama sadiso palibodhoti mahā dukkho
translated: ‘Mud’ means ‘like a swamp.’ ‘Sand’ means ‘like sand.’ ‘Obstacle’ means ‘great suffering.’

original: Mahābandhananti mahantaṃ dumocayabandhanaṃ. Yadidaṃ sampajānamusāvādoti yo ayaṃ sampajānamusāvādo.
analyzed: mahā bandhanam ti mahantam dumocaya bandhanam yat idam yaḥ ayam sampajāna musāvādaḥ
translated: ‘Great bondage’ means ‘great bondage that is difficult to escape.’ ‘This is his deliberate lie’ means ‘this is his deliberate lie.’

original: Sabhaggato vāti sabhāyaṃ ṭhito vā. Parisaggato vāti gāmaparisāyaṃ ṭhito vā. Ñātimajjhagato
analyzed: sabhaggataḥ vā ati sabhāyam ṭhitaḥ vā parisaggataḥ vā ati gāma parisāyam ṭhitaḥ vā ñāti majjha gataḥ
translated: ‘In an assembly’ means ‘standing in an assembly.’ ‘In a group’ means ‘standing in a village group.’ ‘Among relatives’ means ‘among relatives.’

original: vāti dāyādānaṃ majjhe ṭhito vā. Pūgamajjhagato vāti senīnaṃ majjhe ṭhito vā. Rājakulamajjhagato
analyzed: vāti dāyādānam majjhe ṭhitaḥ vā pūga majjha gataḥ vāti senīnam majjhe ṭhitaḥ vā rāja kula majjha gataḥ
translated: or in the middle of his heirs,🔽or in the middle of the village,🔽or in the middle of the army,

original: vāti rājakulassa majjhe mahāvinicchaye ṭhito vā. Abhinītoti pucchanatthāya nīto.
analyzed: vāti rāja kulassa majjhe mahā vinicchaye ṭhitaḥ vā abhinītaḥ ti pucchana atthāya nītaḥ
translated: Or in the middle of the assembly: in the middle of a group of people. Or in the middle of the army: in the middle of an army. Or in the middle of the royal family: in the middle of the royal family, in the midst of a great legal case.🔽Is summoned: is brought for the purpose of questioning.

original: Sakkhipuṭṭhoti sakkhiṃ katvā pucchito. Ehambho purisāti ālapanametaṃ. Attahetu vā
analyzed: sakkhi puṭṭhaḥ ti sakkhim katvā pucchitaḥ eham bho purisa iti ālapanam etam atta hetu vā
translated: Is asked as a witness: is questioned after being made a witness. Come, good man: this is an address.

original: parahetu vāti attano vā parassa vā hatthapādādihetu vā dhanahetu vā. Āmisakiñcikkhahetu🔽vāti ettha āmisanti lābho adhippeto. Kiñcikkhanti yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ, antamaso
analyzed: para hetu vā ati attanaḥ vā parassa vā hattha pāda ādi hetu vā dhana hetu vā āmisa kiñcikkha hetu  vā ti ettha lābhaḥ adhippeto yam vā tam vā appamattakam antamasaḥ
translated: For one’s own sake or for the sake of others: for the sake of oneself or for the sake of another’s hand, foot, etc., or for the sake of wealth.

original: tittiravaṭṭakasappipiṇḍanavanītapiṇḍādimattakassapi lābhassa hetūti attho. Sampajānamusā
analyzed: tittira vaṭṭaka sappi piṇḍa navanīta piṇḍa ādi mattakassa api lābhassa hetu iti attho sampajāna musā
translated: Or for the sake of a trifling thing: here “wealth” is intended to mean gain. “A trifling thing” is something or other, even as little as a handful of bean soup, a handful of lentil soup, etc. The meaning is: for the sake of gain as little as that.

original: bhāsatīti jānantoyeva musāvādaṃ karoti.🔽Puna aññaṃ pariyāyaṃ dassento “api ca tīhākārehi musāvādo hoti, pubbevassa hotī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhāsati iti musāvādam karoti 🔽puna aññam pariyāyam dassentaḥ api ca tīhākārehi musāvādaḥ hoti pubbevassa hoti itiādim āha
translated: Speaks a deliberate lie: knowing that it is a lie, he speaks it.

original: Tattha tīhākārehīti sampajānamusāvādassa aṅgabhūtehi tīhi kāraṇehi. Pubbevassa hotīti
analyzed: tattha tīhākārehi iti sampajāna musāvādassa aṅga bhūtehi tīhi kāraṇehi pubbeva assa hoti iti
translated: He has it in mind beforehand:

original: pubbabhāgeyeva assa puggalassa evaṃ hoti “musā bhaṇissa”nti. Bhaṇantassa hotīti bhaṇamānassa🔽hoti. Bhaṇitassa hotīti bhaṇite assa hoti. Yaṃ vattabbaṃ tasmiṃ vutte hotīti attho.
analyzed: assa puggalassa evam hoti musā bhaṇissanti bhaṇantassa hoti iti bhaṇamānassa  hoti bhaṇitassa hoti iti bhaṇite assa hoti yat vattabbam tasmin vutte hoti iti atthaḥ
translated: beforehand, that is, at the beginning, it occurs to that person thus, “I shall tell a deliberate lie.”🔽He has it in mind while telling it:🔽it occurs to him while he is telling it.🔽He has it in mind when he has told it: the meaning is that it occurs to him when he has finished saying what he had intended to say.

original: Atha vā bhaṇitassāti vuttavato niṭṭhitavacanassa hotīti. Yo evaṃ pubbabhāgepi jānāti,
analyzed: atha vā bhaṇitassa ati vuttavataḥ niṭṭhita vacanassa hoti iti yaḥ evam pubba bhāge pi jānāti
translated: Or alternatively, he has it in mind when he has told it can also be understood as he has it in mind when he has spoken, when he has finished speaking.🔽So it is one who knows thus at the beginning,

original: bhaṇantopi jānāti, pacchāpi jānāti “musā mayā bhaṇita”nti, so evaṃ vadanto musāvādakammunā
analyzed: bhaṇantaḥ api jānāti pacchā api jānāti musā mayā bhaṇita nti saḥ evam vadantaḥ musāvāda kammunā
translated: who knows thus while telling it, and who knows thus when he has told it, that is called “one who lies in full awareness.”🔽The meaning shown here is this: “He is one who is defiled by the action of lying.”

original: bajjhatīti ayamettha attho dassito. Kiñcāpi dassito, atha kho ayamettha viseso –🔽pucchā tāva hoti, “musā bhaṇissa”nti pubbabhāgo atthi, “musā mayā bhaṇita”nti pacchābhāgo🔽natthi. Vuttamattameva hi koci pamussati kiṃ tassa musāvādo hoti, na hotīti? Sā evaṃ
analyzed: bajjhati iti ayam ettha atthaḥ dassito kiñcā api dassitaḥ atha kho ayam ettha viseso 🔽pucchā tāva hoti musā bhaṇissanti pubba bhāgaḥ atthi musā mayā bhaṇitanti pacchābhāgaḥ 🔽natthi vutta mattam eva hi koci pamussati kim tassa musāvādaḥ hoti na hoti iti sā evam
translated: But although this is the meaning shown, still the distinction here is this:

original: aṭṭhakathāsu vissajjitā – pubbabhāge “musā bhaṇissa”nti ca, bhaṇantassa “musā bhaṇāmī”ti
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāsu vissajjitā pubba bhāge musā bhaṇissanti ca bhaṇantassa musā bhaṇāmi iti
translated: In the commentaries it is said: “In the preliminary stage, ‘I shall tell a lie’ and ‘I am telling a lie’

original: ca jānato pacchābhāge “musā mayā bhaṇita”nti na sakkā na bhavituṃ, sacepi na hoti,
analyzed: ca jānato pacchābhāge musā mayā bhaṇitanti na sakkā na bhavitum sace pi na
translated: must be known. Afterwards, ‘I have told a lie’ must not be unknown. Even if it is not known,

original: musāvādoyeva. Purimameva hi aṅgadvayaṃ pamāṇaṃ. Yassāpi pubbabhāge “musā bhaṇissa”nti
analyzed: musāvādaḥ yā iva purimam eva hi aṅga dvayam pamāṇam yassa api pubba bhāge musā bhaṇissanti
translated: it is still a telling of lies. For the first two factors are the criterion.

original: ābhogo natthi, bhaṇanto pana “musā bhaṇāmī”ti jānāti. Bhaṇitepi “musā mayā bhaṇita”nti
analyzed: ābhogaḥ natthi bhaṇantaḥ pana musā bhaṇāmi iti jānāti bhaṇite pi musā mayā bhaṇitanti
translated: Even if there is no resolve in the preliminary stage, ‘I shall tell a lie,’ but he knows, ‘I am telling a lie’ while he is telling it, and he knows, ‘I have told a lie’ when it is finished,

original: jānāti. So musāvādena na kāretabbo. Pubbabhāgo hi pamāṇataro. Tasmiṃ asati davā bhaṇitaṃ
analyzed: jānāti saḥ musāvādena na kāretabbaḥ pubba bhāgaḥ hi pamāṇataraḥ tasmin asati davā bhaṇitam
translated: he is not to be charged with a telling of lies. For the preliminary stage is the more important. When that is absent, it is a mere chance remark

original: vā, ravā bhaṇitaṃ vā hotīti.🔽Ettha ca taṃñāṇatā ca ñāṇasamodhānañca pariccajitabbaṃ. Taṃñāṇatā pariccajitabbāti
analyzed: vā bhaṇitam vā  ettha ca taṃñāṇa tā ca ñāṇa samodhānañca pariccajitabbam taṃñāṇa tā pariccajitabbā ati
translated: or a mere exclamation.”🔽And here the knowledge and the linking of the knowledge must be omitted.

original: yena cittena “musā bhaṇissa”nti jānāti, teneva “musā bhaṇāmī”ti ca, “musā mayā bhaṇita”nti
analyzed: yena cittena musā bhaṇissanti jānāti tena iva musā bhaṇāmi iti ca musā mayā bhaṇitanti
translated: “The knowledge must be omitted” means that he does not know with the same consciousness by which he knows, “I shall tell a lie,” that “I am telling a lie” and that “I have told a lie.”

original: ca jānātīti evaṃ ekacitteneva tīsu khaṇesu jānātīti ayaṃ taṃñāṇatā pariccajitabbā.
analyzed: ca jānāti iti evam eka cittena iva tīsu khaṇesu jānāti iti ayam taṃñāṇa tā pariccajitabbā
translated: and he knows that he knows, then it must be admitted that he knows in three moments with a single consciousness.

original: Na hi sakkā teneva cittena taṃ cittaṃ jānituṃ, yathā na sakkā teneva asinā so asi🔽chinditunti. Purimaṃ purimaṃ pana cittaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa cittassa tathā uppattiyā
analyzed: na hi sakkā tena iva cittena tam cittam jānitum yathā na sakkā tena iva asinā saḥ asi  chinditum ti purimam purimam pana cittam pacchimassa pacchimassa cittassa tathā uppattiyā
translated: For it is not possible to know that consciousness with that same consciousness, just as it is not possible to cut that sword with that same sword.

original: paccayo hutvā nirujjhati. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: paccayaḥ hutvā nirujjhati tena itam vuccati
translated: But the preceding consciousness ceases having become a condition for the arising of the next one in that way. That is why it is said:

original: “Pamāṇaṃ pubbabhāgova, tasmiṃ sati na hessati;
analyzed: pamāṇam pubba bhāgaḥ uva tasmin sati na
translated: “The measure is the prior part, and that is not in the latter;

original: Sesadvayanti nattheta, miti vācā tivaṅgikā”ti. ;
analyzed: nattha itas miti vācā tivaṅgikā ati
translated: The remainder is not two, so the statement is three-factored.”

original: Ñāṇasamodhānaṃ pariccajitabbanti etāni tīṇi cittāni ekakkhaṇe uppajjantīti na gahetabbāni. Idañhi cittaṃ nāma –
analyzed: ñāṇa samodhānam pariccajitabbanti etāni tīṇi cittāni eka khaṇe uppajjanti iti na gahetabbāni idam hi cittam nāma
translated: “The combination of knowledge must be rejected”: it must not be held that these three consciousnesses arise in one moment. For this consciousness is described thus:

original: “Aniruddhamhi paṭhame, na uppajjati pacchimaṃ;
analyzed: aniruddhamhi paṭhame na uppajjati pacchimam
translated: “The first is not stopped, the latter does not arise;

original: Nirantaruppajjanato, ekaṃ viya pakāsatī”ti. ;
analyzed: nirantar uppajjanataḥ ekam viya pakāsati iti
translated: It appears as one because of arising without a break.”

original: Ito paraṃ pana yvāyaṃ ajānaṃyeva “jānāmī”tiādinā nayena sampajānamusā bhaṇati, yasmā
analyzed: itas param pana jānāmi iti ādinā nayena bhaṇati yasmai
translated: But from here on, the one who lies in full awareness, saying “I know” when he does not know, and so on,

original: so “idaṃ abhūta”nti evaṃdiṭṭhiko hoti, tassa hi attheva ayaṃ laddhi. Tathā “idaṃ🔽abhūta”nti evamassa khamati ceva ruccati ca. Evamassa saññā, evaṃsabhāvameva cassa
analyzed: saḥ idam abhūtanti evaṃdiṭṭhikaḥ hoti tassa hi attha iva ayam laddhi tathā idam  evam assa khamati ca iva ruccati ca evam assa saññā evaṃsabhāvam eva cassa
translated: “This is not so” is his view, and he has the right to hold that view. Likewise, “This is not so” is what he approves and likes. Thus is his perception, thus is his cognizance, thus is his thought,

original: cittaṃ “idaṃ abhūta”nti. Yadā pana musā vattukāmo hoti, tadā taṃ diṭṭhiṃ vā diṭṭhiyā🔽saha khantiṃ vā diṭṭhikhantīhi saddhiṃ ruciṃ vā diṭṭhikhantirucīhi saddhiṃ saññaṃ
analyzed: cittam idam abhūtanti yadā pana musā vattu kāmo hoti tadā tam diṭṭhim vā diṭṭhiyā  saha khantim vā diṭṭhi khantīhi saddhim rucim vā diṭṭhi khanti rucīhi saddhim saññam
translated: He has the view that it is not so. For he has the right to hold that view. Likewise he approves of it thus “It is not so” and he has the perception that it is not so. His mind is of that nature.

original: vā diṭṭhikhantirucisaññāhi saddhiṃ bhāvaṃ vā vinidhāya nikkhipitvā paṭicchādetvā
analyzed: vā diṭṭhi khanti ruci saññāhi saddhim bhāvam vā vinidhāya nikkhipitvā paṭicchādetvā
translated: But when he wants to tell a lie, then he speaks after laying hold of that view or that approval or that perception or that state of mind, after placing it, after concealing it, after making it not so.

original: abhūtaṃ katvā bhaṇati. Tasmā tesampivasena aṅgabhedaṃ dassetuṃ “api ca catūhākārehī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: abhūtam katvā bhaṇati api ca catūhākārehi itiādi vuttam
translated: Therefore, in order to show the analysis of the terms by way of those, it is said: “Or alternatively, in four ways.”

original: Ettha ca vinidhāya diṭṭhinti balavadhammavinidhānavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Vinidhāya khantintiādīni
analyzed: ettha ca vinidhāya diṭṭhi nti balava dhamma vinidhāna vasena itam vuttam vinidhāya khanti ntiādīni
translated: And here “after laying hold of a view” is said figuratively for the laying hold of a strong state. “After laying hold of an approval” and so on are said figuratively for the laying hold of a weak state.

original: tato dubbaladubbalānaṃ vinidhānavasena. Vinidhāya saññanti idaṃ panettha sabbadubbaladhammavinidhānavasena.
analyzed: tatas dubbala dubbalānam vinidhāna vasena vinidhāya idam pana ittha sabba dubbala dhamma vinidhāna vasena
translated: The laying hold on perception is the laying hold on the weakest of all states.

original: Saññāmattampi nāma avinidhāya sampajānamusā bhāsissatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
analyzed: saññā mattam pi nāma a vinidhāya sampajāna musā bhāsissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It is impossible to tell a conscious lie without laying hold on perception.

original: 55. Mandova parikissatīti pāṇavadhādīni karonto tatonidānañca dukkhamanubhonto bhogapariyesanārakkhaṇāni ca karonto momūho viya parikilissati.
analyzed: mandaḥ iva parikissati iti pāṇa vadha ādīni karontaḥ tatonidānam ca dukkham anubhontaḥ bhoga pariyesanā rakkhaṇāni ca karontaḥ momūhaḥ viya parikilissati
translated: He is slow to understand: he is confused as if stupid, doing such things as killing breathing things and experiencing suffering as a consequence of that, and doing such things as seeking for and guarding his wealth.

original: Tamenaṃ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārentīti na rājāno karonti, rājādhīnapurisā🔽nānāvidhāni kammakāraṇāni karonti. Kasāhipi tāḷentīti kasādaṇḍakehipi vitajjenti.🔽Vettehīti vettalatāhi. Addhadaṇḍakehīti muggarehi, pahārasādhanatthaṃ vā catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: tam enam rājānaḥ gahetvā vividhā kamma kāraṇā kārenti iti na rājāno karonti rāja adhīna purisā  nānāvidhāni kamma kāraṇāni karonti tāḷenti iti vitajjenti  vettehi iti vetta latāhi addhadaṇḍakehi iti muggarehi pahāra sādhana tham vā catuhattha daṇḍam
translated: They seize him and make him undergo various punishments: not the kings themselves do this, but the king’s men.🔽They make him undergo various punishments: they do such things as flog him with whips.🔽With whips: with whips having thongs of leather.

original: dvedhā chetvā gahitadaṇḍakehi. Bilaṅgathālikanti kañjiyaukkhalikakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ
analyzed: dvedhā chetvā gahita daṇḍakehi kañji yaukkhalika kamma kāraṇam tam
translated: With canes: with canes. With scourges: with scourges. With mallets: with mallets. With iron-tipped whips: with whips having thongs of leather tipped with iron. With pick handles: with pick handles. With half-whips: with half-whips. With fists: with fists. With clods: with clods of earth. With sticks: with sticks. With rods: with rods. With swords: with swords.🔽They cut off his hands: they cut off his hands at the shoulders. They cut off his feet: they cut off his feet at the ankles. They cut off his hands and feet: they cut off his hands at the shoulders and his feet at the ankles. They cut off his ears: they cut off his ears at the roots. They cut off his nose: they cut off his nose at the roots. They cut off his ears and nose: they cut off his ears at the roots and his nose at the roots. They cut off his head: they cut off his head at the neck.

original: karontā sīsakapālaṃ uppāṭetvā tattaṃ ayoguḷaṃ saṇḍāsena gahetvā tattha pakkhipanti,
analyzed: karontā sīsa kapālam uppāṭetvā tat tam ayaḥ guḷam saṇḍāsena gahetvā tattha pakkhipanti
translated: As they do so, they take a red-hot iron ball with pincers, break open the skull, and drop it in.

original: tena matthaluṅgaṃ pakkuṭṭhitvā upari uttarati. Saṅkhamuṇḍikanti saṅkhamuṇḍakammakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tena mattha luṅgam pakkuṭṭhitvā upari uttarati saṅkhamuṇḍikam ti saṅkha muṇḍa kamma kāraṇam
translated: The brain boils, rises to the top, and overflows. The “conch-shell-head” is the name for the “conch-shell-head” punishment.

original: Taṃ karontā uttaroṭṭhaubhatokaṇṇacūḷikagalavāṭakaparicchedena cammaṃ chinditvā sabbakese🔽ekato gaṇṭhiṃ katvā daṇḍakena veṭhetvā uppāṭenti, saha kesehi cammaṃ uṭṭhahati. Tato🔽sīsakaṭāhaṃ thūlasakkharāhi ghaṃsitvā dhovantā saṅkhavaṇṇaṃ karonti. Rāhumukhanti
analyzed: tam karontāḥ uttara uṭṭhaubha tokaṇṇa cūḷika galavāṭaka paricchedena cammam chinditvā sabba kese  ekatas gaṇṭhim katvā daṇḍakena veṭhetvā uppāṭenti saha kesehi cammam uṭṭhahati tatas  sīsa kaṭāham ghaṃsitvā dhovantā saṅkha vaṇṇam karonti rāhu mukham
translated: As they do it, they cut the skin in the region of the upper lip, the two ears, and the hair-tuft,🔽gather all the hair together, tie it in a knot, wrap it in a bandage, and pull it out. The skin comes out together with the hair.🔽Then they break open the skull with a heavy hammer and wash it out, making it as white as a conch shell. The “Rahu-mouth” is the name for the “Rahu-mouth” punishment.

original: rāhumukhakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā saṅkunā mukhaṃ vivaritvā antomukhe dīpaṃ jālenti,🔽kaṇṇacūḷikāhi vā paṭṭhāya mukhaṃ nikhādanena khananti, lohitaṃ paggharitvā mukhaṃ pūreti.
analyzed: rāhumukha kamma kāraṇam tam karontā saṅkunā mukham antar mukhe dīpam jālenti  kaṇṇacūḷikāhi vā paṭṭhāya mukham nikhādanena khananti lohitam paggharitvā mukham pūreti
translated: As they do it, they open the mouth with a crowbar, light a torch inside the mouth,🔽and dig out the mouth from the hair-tuft onwards. Blood gushes out and fills the mouth.

original: Jotimālikanti sakalasarīraṃ telapilotikāya veṭhetvā ālimpenti. Hatthapajjotikanti
analyzed: joti mālikanti sakala sarīram tela pilotikāya veṭhetvā ālimpenti hattha pajjotikanti
translated: The “Jotimālika” is the name for the “Jotimālika” punishment. As they do it, they wrap the whole body in a cotton wick soaked in oil, set it alight, and burn it.

original: hatthe telapilotikāya veṭhetvā dīpaṃ viya pajjālenti. Erakavattikanti erakavattakammakāraṇaṃ.🔽Taṃ karontā heṭṭhāgīvato paṭṭhāya cammavaṭṭe kantitvā gopphake pātenti. Atha naṃ🔽yottehi bandhitvā kaḍḍhanti. So attano cammavaṭṭe akkamitvā akkamitvā patati. Cirakavāsikanti
analyzed: hatthe tela pilotikāya veṭhetvā dīpam viya pajjālenti erakavattikam ti eraka vatta kamma kāraṇam  tam karontā heṭṭhāgīvataḥ paṭṭhāya camma vaṭṭe kantitvā gopphake pātenti atha naṃ  yottehi bandhitvā kaḍḍhanti saḥ attano camma vaṭṭe akkamitvā akkamitvā patati cirakavāsikanti
translated: and they light it as though it were a lamp. The “erakavattika” is the erakavattika torture.🔽In inflicting this torture, they flog the victim’s skin from head to foot and then throw him into a pit.🔽They bind him with ropes and drag him out. He falls down, dragging his flayed skin behind him. The “cirakavāsika” is the cirakavāsika torture.

original: cirakavāsikakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā tatheva cammavaṭṭe kantitvā kaṭiyaṃ ṭhapenti,
analyzed: cirakavāsika kamma kāraṇam tam karontā tathā iva camma vaṭṭe kantitvā kaṭiyam ṭhapenti
translated: In inflicting this torture, they flog the victim’s skin in the same way and then throw him into a pit.

original: kaṭito paṭṭhāya kantitvā gopphakesu ṭhapenti, uparimehi heṭṭhimasarīraṃ cirakanivāsananivatthaṃ
analyzed: kaṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya kantitvā gopphakesu ṭhapenti uparimehi heṭṭhima sarīram ciraka nivāsana nivattham
translated: They flog him from the waist down and throw him into the pit. His upper body is like a long-standing resident’s robe,

original: viya hoti. Eṇeyyakanti eṇeyyakakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā ubhosu kapparesu ca ubhosu
analyzed: viya hoti eṇeyyakanti eṇeyyaka kamma kāraṇam tam karontāḥ ubhosu kapparesu ca ubhosu
translated: which is worn out and in shreds. The “eṇeyyaka” is the eṇeyyaka torture. In inflicting this torture, they give him iron rings for both wrists and both ankles,

original: jaṇṇukesu ca ayavalayāni datvā ayasūlāni koṭṭenti, so catūhi ayasūlehi bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhahati.
analyzed: jaṇṇukesu ca aya valayāni datvā aya sūlāni koṭṭenti saḥ catūhi aya sūlehi bhūmiyam patiṭṭhahati
translated: and they drive iron spikes through them. He falls to the ground on four iron spikes.

original: Atha naṃ parivāretvā aggiṃ karonti. “Eṇeyyako jotipariggaho yathā”ti āgataṭṭhānepi
analyzed: atha nam parivāretvā aggim karonti eṇeyyakaḥ joti pariggahaḥ yathā ati āgata ṭṭhāne pi
translated: They surround it and make a fire.🔽The same thing is said in the passage beginning, “The fire-brand is like the search for a needle.”

original: idameva vuttaṃ. Taṃ sandhito sandhito sūlāni apanetvā catūhi aṭṭhikoṭīhiyeva ṭhapenti.
analyzed: idam eva vuttam tam sandhitaḥ sandhitaḥ sūlāni apanetvā catūhi ṭhapenti
translated: They remove the bones from the joints and set them up with four or eight tufts of bone.

original: Evarūpā kammakāraṇā nāma natthi.🔽Baḷisamaṃsikanti ubhatomukhehi baḷisehi paharitvā cammamaṃsanhārūni uppāṭenti. Kahāpaṇikanti🔽sakalasarīraṃ tiṇhāhi vāsīhi koṭito paṭṭhāya kahāpaṇamattaṃ kahāpaṇamattaṃ pātentā
analyzed: evarūpā kamma kāraṇā nāma natthi  baḷisa maṃsikanti ubhatomukhehi baḷisehi paharitvā camma maṃsa nhārūni uppāṭenti kahāpaṇikanti  sakala sarīram tiṇhāhi vāsīhi koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya kahāpaṇa mattam kahāpaṇa mattam pātentā
translated: There is no such kind of punishment.🔽The “stake-impaler” is one who is struck with stakes through both sides, tearing away flesh and skin. The “coin-counter” is one who is struck with sharp knives,🔽beginning from the skin, and is made to bleed coin-measures.

original: koṭṭenti. Khārāpatacchikanti sarīraṃ tattha tattha āvudhehi paharitvā kocchehi khāraṃ🔽ghaṃsenti, cammamaṃsanhārūni paggharitvā pasavanti, aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikāva tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sarīram tattha tattha āvudhehi paharitvā kocchehi khāram  ghaṃsenti camma maṃsa nhārūni paggharitvā pasavanti aṭṭhika saṅkhalikā iva tiṭṭhati
translated: The “lye-cauldron” is one in which they strike the body here and there with weapons and pour lye into the wounds,🔽so that the flesh and skin melt away and only the skeleton remains.

original: Palighaparivattikanti ekena passena nipajjāpetvā kaṇṇacchiddena ayasūlaṃ koṭṭetvā
analyzed: paligha parivattikanti ekena passena nipajjāpetvā kaṇṇa chiddena aya sūlam koṭṭetvā
translated: The “turning-them-over-on-the-mangle” is one in which they make him lie on his side and then roll him back and forth with a log,

original: pathaviyā ekābaddhaṃ karonti. Atha naṃ pāde gahetvā āviñchanti. Palālapīṭhakanti🔽chekā kāraṇikā chavicammaṃ acchinditvā nisadapotakāhi aṭṭhīni chinditvā kesesu gahetvā🔽ukkhipanti, maṃsarāsiyeva hoti. Atha naṃ keseheva pariyonandhitvā gaṇhanti, palālapīṭhaṃ🔽viya katvā paliveṭhenti. Sunakhehipīti katipayāni divasāni āhāraṃ adatvā chātasunakhehi
analyzed: pathaviyāḥ eka ābaddham karonti atha nam pāde gahetvā āviñchanti palāla pīṭhakanti  chekā kāraṇikā chavi cammam a chinditvā nisada potakāhi aṭṭhīni chinditvā kesesu gahetvā  ukkhipanti maṃsa rāsiyā iva hoti atha nam kesehā iva gaṇhanti palāla pīṭham  katvā katipayāni divasāni āhāram a datvā chāta sunakhehi
translated: They make it into one piece with the earth. Then they pull it out by the feet. A straw mat:🔽after the skin has been removed by the butchers, the bones are cut with hatchets, and the flesh is pulled off with hooks.🔽It is like a mass of flesh. Then they wrap it up in the skin, like a straw mat, and roll it up. With good-natured cocks:

original: khādāpenti. Te muhuttena aṭṭhisaṅkhalikameva karonti. Evampi kissatīti evampi vighātaṃ
analyzed: khādāpenti te muhuttena aṭṭhisaṅkhalikam eva karonti evam pi kissati iti evam pi vighātam
translated: after not being fed for several days, they make it eaten by good-natured cocks. In a moment they make it a skeleton. Thus:

original: pāpuṇāti. Parikissatīti sabbabhāgena vighātaṃ pāpuṇāti. Parikilissatīti upatāpaṃ pāpuṇāti.🔽Puna aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ dassento “atha vā kāmataṇhāya abhibhūto”tiādimāha. Tattha kāmataṇhāyāti
analyzed: pāpuṇāti parikissati iti sabba bhāgena vighātam pāpuṇāti parikilissati iti upatāpam pāpuṇāti  puna aññam kāraṇam dassento atha vā kāma taṇhāya abhibhūtaḥ iti ādim āha tattha kāma taṇhāya ati
translated: in this way it comes to destruction. It is destroyed: it comes to complete destruction. It is corrupted: it comes to affliction.

original: pañcakāmaguṇikalobhena. Abhibhūtoti tena maddito. Pariyādinnacittoti kusalācāraṃ
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇika lobhena abhibhūtaḥ iti tena madditaḥ kusala ācāram
translated: Again, showing another reason, he said: “Or else, overcome by craving for sensual pleasures” . Herein, craving for sensual pleasures is the greed for the five strands of sensual pleasure. Overcome: oppressed by that. His mind is overcome: his mind is not inclined to virtue.

original: khepetvā gahitacitto. Bhoge pariyesantoti dhanaṃ gavesamāno. Nāvāya mahāsamuddaṃ
analyzed: khepetvā gahita cittaḥ bhoge dhanam gavesamānaḥ nāvāya mahā samuddaṃ
translated: Seeking wealth: seeking money.

original: pakkhandatīti taraṇīsaṅkhātāya nāvāya mahantaṃ loṇasāgaraṃ pavisati. Sītassa purakkhatoti
analyzed: pakkhandati iti taraṇī saṅkhātāya nāvāya mahantam loṇa sāgaram pavisati sītassa purakkhato ti
translated: He boards a ship and sets out on the great ocean: he enters the great salt ocean in a ship called a “taruna.”🔽In the cold: making cold his priority.

original: sītaṃ purato katvā. Uṇhassa purakkhatoti uṇhaṃ purato katvā. Ḍaṃsāti piṅgalamakkhikā.🔽Makasāti makasā eva. Pīḷiyamānoti ḍaṃsādisamphassehi vihesiyamāno. Khuppipāsāya miyyamānoti
analyzed: sītam puratas katvā uṇhassa purakkhataḥ ti uṇham puratas katvā ḍaṃsā ati piṅgala makkhikā  makasā ati makasā eva pīḷiyamānaḥ ti ḍaṃsa ādi samphassehi vihesiyamānaḥ khuppipāsāya miyyamānaḥ iti
translated: In the heat: making heat his priority.🔽Mosquitoes: tawny flies.🔽Gnats: gnats.🔽He is afflicted: he is tormented by the contact of mosquitoes, etc.

original: khuddāpipāsāya maramāno. Tigumbaṃ gacchatītiādīni mūlapadaṃ gacchatītipariyosānāni
analyzed: khuddā pipāsāya maramānaḥ tigumbam gacchati iti ādīni mūla padam gacchati iti pariyosānāni
translated: He dies of hunger and thirst: he dies of slight hunger and thirst.🔽He goes to the Tigumnagara: the twenty-four terms beginning with “he goes to the Tigumnagara”

original: catuvīsati padāni raṭṭhanāmena vuttāni. Marukantāraṃ gacchatīti vālukakantāraṃ tārakasaññāya
analyzed: catuvīsati padāni raṭṭha nāmena vuttāni maru kantāram gacchati iti vāluka kantāram tāraka saññāya
translated: are spoken by the name of the country.

original: gacchati. Jaṇṇupathanti jāṇūhi gantabbamaggaṃ. Ajapathanti ajehi gantabbamaggaṃ.
analyzed: gacchati jaṇṇu pathanti jāṇūhi gantabba maggam aja pathanti ajehi gantabba maggam
translated: He goes to the desert: he goes to the desert of sand, taking the stars as a sign.🔽The knee-deep path: a path that can be traversed on knees.🔽The goat-path: a path that can be traversed by goats.

original: Meṇḍapathepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: meṇḍa pathe pi e sā iva nayo
translated: The same method applies to the sheep-path.

original: Saṅkupathanti khāṇuke koṭṭetvā tehi uggamitabbaṃ khāṇumaggaṃ, taṃ gacchanto pabbatapāde🔽ṭhatvā ayasiṅghāṭakaṃ yottena bandhitvā uddhaṃ khipitvā pabbate laggāpetvā yottenāruyha
analyzed: saṅkupathanti khāṇuke koṭṭetvā tehi uggamitabbam khāṇu maggam tam gacchantaḥ pabbata pāde  ṭhatvā aya siṅghāṭakam yottena bandhitvā uddham khipitvā pabbate laggāpetvā yottena āruyha
translated: A ‘crooked path’ is a path of tree-trunks that have been cut into lengths and are leaning together in the direction in which the path leads. When he goes along it he stands on the side of the mountain,🔽ties a rope to an iron hook, throws the rope up, gets it hooked on to the mountain, climbs up by it,

original: vajiraggena lohadaṇḍena pabbataṃ vijjhitvā khāṇukaṃ koṭṭetvā tattha ṭhatvā siṅghāṭakaṃ
analyzed: vaji raggena loha daṇḍena pabbatam vijjhitvā khāṇukam koṭṭetvā tattha ṭhatvā siṅghāṭakam
translated: and with an iron crowbar he digs out the tree-trunks, which he then throws down. He stands on them, pulls up the rope,

original: ākaḍḍhitvā puna upari laggāpetvā tattha ṭhito cammayottaṃ olambetvā taṃ ādāya otaritvā
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitvā punar upari laggāpetvā tattha ṭhitaḥ camma yottam olambetvā tam ādāya otaritvā
translated: gets it hooked on to the mountain again, and climbs up by it. He hangs a leather strap down from the top of the tree-trunks,

original: heṭṭhimakhāṇuke bandhitvā vāmahatthena yottaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇahatthena muggaraṃ ādāya🔽yottaṃ paharitvā khāṇukaṃ nīharitvā puna abhiruhati. Etenupāyena pabbatamatthakaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhima khāṇuke bandhitvā vāma hatthena yottam gahetvā dakkhiṇa hatthena muggaram ādāya  yottam paharitvā khāṇukam nīharitvā puna abhiruhati etena upāyena pabbata matthakam
translated: climbs down by it, ties it to the lower tree-trunks, takes the rope in his left hand, takes an iron hammer in his right,🔽and with the hammer he hits the rope and pulls out the tree-trunks. He climbs up again. By this means he climbs to the top of the mountain.

original: abhiruyha parato otaranto purimanayeneva paṭhamaṃ pabbatamatthake khāṇukaṃ koṭṭetvā
analyzed: abhiruyha paratas otarantaḥ purima nayena iva paṭhamam pabbata matthake khāṇukam koṭṭetvā
translated: When he wants to come down on the other side, he first digs out a tree-trunk at the top of the mountain,

original: cammapasibbake yottaṃ bandhitvā khāṇuke veṭhetvā sayaṃ antopasibbake nisīditvā makkaṭakānaṃ
analyzed: camma pasibbake yottam bandhitvā khāṇuke veṭhetvā sayam anta upasibbake nisīditvā makkaṭakānam
translated: ties the rope to the leather strap, winds it round the tree-trunk, sits down inside the strap himself,🔽and lets himself down head first.

original: suttavissajjanākārena yottaṃ viniveṭhetvā otarati. Tena vuttaṃ – “khāṇuke koṭṭetvā🔽tehi uggamitabbaṃ khāṇumagga”nti. Chattapathanti cammachattena vātaṃ gāhāpetvā sakuṇehi
analyzed: sutta vissajjana ākārena yottam viniveṭhetvā otarati tena vuttam khāṇuke koṭṭetvā  tehi uggamitabbam khāṇu magganti chatta pathanti camma chattena vātam gāhāpetvā sakuṇehi
translated: and he descends by turning back the current by means of the explanation of the Thread. Hence it was said: “By knocking off the log,🔽and by means of the log he can get up” . The path of the birds is where birds fly by catching the wind with a skin stretched on a frame, or by means of their wings,🔽

original: viya otaritabbaṃ maggaṃ. Vaṃsapathanti veṇugumbachedanasatthena chinditvā rukkhaṃ
analyzed: viya otaritabbam maggam vaṃsa pathanti veṇu gumba chedana satthena chinditvā rukkham
translated: He descends by turning back the current by means of the current of his own momentum. Hence it is said: “He goes by making a bridge of the tree trunks and descending by means of them.” The “path of the birds” is a path by which one descends like a bird by catching hold of the wind with a leathern wing.

original: pharasunā koṭṭetvā maggaṃ karonto veḷuvane nisseṇiṃ katvā veḷugumbe āruyha veḷuṃ🔽chinditvā aparassa veḷugumbassa upari pātetvā veḷugumbamatthakeneva gantabbaṃ maggaṃ
analyzed: pharasunā koṭṭetvā maggam karontaḥ veḷu vane nisseṇim katvā veḷu gumbe āruyha veḷum  chinditvā aparassa veḷu gumbassa upari pātetvā veḷu gumba matthakena iva gantabbam maggam
translated: The “bamboo path” is a path made by cutting down a tree with a bamboo saw and chopping it up with an axe, and then making a path by means of the bamboo stumps, like the path made by the Elder Mahā Deva in the Bamboo Grove.

original: sandhāya “vaṃsapathaṃ gacchatī”ti vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya vaṃsa patham gacchati iti vuttam ti veditabbam
translated: The “path of the saw” should be understood as a path by which one goes by means of the tops of the bamboo clumps after climbing up the bamboo clumps and cutting down the bamboos with a bamboo saw and throwing them on top of the other bamboo clump.

original: Gavesanto na vindati, alābhamūlakampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti avindanamūlakampi kāyikacetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: gavesantaḥ na vindati alābha mūlakam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisaṃvedeti iti a vindana mūlakam pi kāyika cetasikam dukkham paṭilabhati
translated: He experiences pain and grief born of non-gain: he experiences bodily and mental pain and grief born of non-gain.

original: Laddhāti labhitvā. Ārakkhamūlakanti rakkhaṇamūlakampi. Kinti me bhogeti kena upāyena
analyzed: laddhā ati labhitvā ārakkha mūlakanti rakkhaṇa mūlakam pi kinti me bhoge iti kena upāyena
translated: Having gained: having obtained. Born of guarding: born of the guarding of what has been gained. By what means: by what method.

original: mama bhoge. Neva rājāno hareyyuṃ…pe… na appiyā dāyādā hareyyunti. Gopayatoti mañjūsādīhi
analyzed: mama bhoge na iva rājānaḥ hareyyuṃ pe na appiyāḥ dāyādāḥ hareyyunti gopayata uti mañjūsādīhi
translated: ‘My wealth will not be taken away by kings or thieves or water or fire or unloved heirs.’🔽‘While he is guarding it’: while he is guarding it with locks and bolts, etc.,

original: gopayantassa. Vippalujjantīti vinassanti.
analyzed: gopayantassa vippalujjanti iti vinassanti
translated: ‘It will slip away’: it will be lost.

original: 56. Etamādīnavaṃ ñatvā, muni pubbāpare idhāti etaṃ “yaso kitti ca yā pubbe, hāyate
analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā muni pubba apare idha ati etam yaso ca yā pubbe hāyate
translated: ‘The sage, knowing this danger here,🔽both before and after,

original: vāpi tassa sā”ti ito pabhuti vutte pubbāpare idha imasmiṃ sāsane pubbato apare samaṇabhāvato🔽vibbhantakabhāve ādīnavaṃ muni ñatvā.
analyzed: vā api tassa sāti itas vutte pubba apare idha imasmim sāsane pubbataḥ apare samaṇa bhāvataḥ  vibbhantaka bhāve ādīnavam muni ñatvā
translated: should make it firm’: this is a reference to the words ‘should make it strong.’

original: Daḷhaṃ kareyyāti niddesapadassa uddesapadaṃ. Thiraṃ kareyyāti asithilaṃ kareyya. Daḷhaṃ samādāno assāti thirapaṭiñño bhaveyya. Avaṭṭhitasamādānoti sanniṭṭhānapaṭiñño.
analyzed: daḷham kareyya ati niddesa padassa uddesa padam thiram kareyya ati asithilam kareyya daḷham samādānaḥ assa ati thira paṭiññaḥ bhaveyya avaṭṭhita samādānaḥ iti sanniṭṭhāna paṭiññaḥ
translated: ‘Should make it firm’: should make it not loose. ‘Should make his undertaking strong’: should make his resolution firm. ‘Should not be one who wavers in his undertaking’: should be one who does not waver in his resolution.

original: 57. Etaṃ ariyānamuttamanti yadidaṃ vivekacariyā, etaṃ buddhādīnaṃ ariyānaṃ uttamaṃ.
analyzed: etam yat idam viveka cariyā etam buddha ādīnam ariyānam uttamam
translated: ‘This is the supreme austerity of the noble ones’: this is the practice of seclusion. This is the supreme austerity of the noble ones, of the Enlightened Ones, etc.

original: Tasmā vivekaṃyeva sikkhethāti adhippāyo. Na tena seṭṭho maññethāti tena ca vivekena
analyzed: tasmā vivekam yeva sikkhetha ati adhippāyaḥ na tena seṭṭhaḥ maññetha ati tena ca vivekena
translated: ‘Therefore one should train in seclusion’: this is the purport. ‘He should not think himself great because of that’

original: attānaṃ “seṭṭho aha”nti na maññeyya, tena mānathaddho na bhaveyyāti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Unnatinti ussāpanaṃ. Unnamanti uggantvā paṭṭhapanaṃ. Mānanti ahaṃkāraṃ. Thāmanti
analyzed: attānam seṭṭhaḥ aham ti na maññeyya tena mā anathaddhaḥ na bhaveyya ati vuttam hoti  unnatinti ussāpanam unnamanti uggantvā paṭṭhapanam mānanti ahaṃkāram thāmanti
translated: He should not think “I am the best” of himself, he should not be conceited.

original: balakkāraṃ. Thambhanti thaddhakaraṇaṃ. Thaddhoti amaddavo. Patthaddhoti visesena
analyzed: balakkāram thambhanti thaddha karaṇam thaddho ti amaddavaḥ patthaddho ti visesena
translated: “Arrogance” is exaltation. “Pride” is the state of being puffed up. “Conceit” is self-esteem. “Self-satisfaction” is the state of being satisfied with oneself. “Self-exaltation” is the state of being exalted. “Self-inflation” is the state of being inflated. “Self-stiffening” is the state of being stiff. “Self-rigidity” is the state of being rigid. “Self-stiffening” is the state of being stiff. “Self-rigidity” is the state of being rigid. “Self-inflation” is the state of being inflated. “Self-exaltation” is the state of being exalted. “Self-satisfaction” is the state of being satisfied with oneself. “Self-esteem” is self-esteem. “Pride” is the state of being puffed up. “Arrogance” is exaltation.

original: amaddavo. Paggahitasiroti uṭṭhitasīso. Sāmantāti na ārakā. Āsanneti na dūre. Avidūreti🔽samīpe. Upakaṭṭheti santike.🔽58. Rittassāti vivittassa, kāyaduccaritādīhi virahitassa. Oghatiṇṇassa pihayanti,
analyzed: amaddavaḥ paggahita siro ti uṭṭhita sīso sāmantā ati na ārakā āsanne iti na dūre avidūrā iti  samīpe upakaṭṭhā iti santike  rittassa ati vivittassa kāya duccarita ādīhi virahitassa ogha tiṇṇassa pihayanti
translated: “Not far away” means not far. “Not distant” means not far. “Not too far” means near. “Near” means close.

original: kāmesu gadhitā pajāti vatthukāmesu laggā sattā tassa caturoghatiṇṇassa pihayanti
analyzed: kāmesu gadhitā pajāti vatthu kāmesu laggā sattā tassa catur ogha tiṇṇassa pihayanti
translated: “Solitary” means secluded, devoid of bodily misconduct, etc. “They long for one who has crossed the flood” means that beings who are infatuated with sensual pleasures, who are attached to sensual pleasures, long for one who has crossed the four floods.

original: iṇāyikā viya āṇaṇyassāti arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: iṇāyikā viya āṇaṇyassa ati arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: “As if longing for one free from debt” means that he concluded the teaching with the peak of arahantship.

original: Rittassāti sabbakilesehi tucchassa. Vivittassāti suññassa. Pavivittassāti ekakassa.
analyzed: rittassa ati sabba kilesehi tucchassa vivittassa ati suññassa pavivittassa ati ekakassa
translated: “Solitary” means empty of all defilements. “Secluded” means void. “Seated alone” means alone.

original: Idāni yehi ritto hoti, te dassento “kāyaduccaritena rittassā”tiādimāha. Tattha kilesapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: idāni yehi rittaḥ hoti te dassento kāya duccaritena rittassa ati ādim āha tattha kilesa paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Now, showing what it is empty of, he said, “Empty of bodily misconduct,” and so on. Herein, the emptiness should be understood as twofold, according to defilement and according to the path.

original: maggapaṭipāṭiyāti dvidhā rittatā veditabbā. Kilesapaṭipāṭiyā tāva rāgo moho thambho
analyzed: magga paṭipāṭiyā ti dvidhā ritta tā veditabbā kilesa paṭipāṭiyā tāva rāgaḥ moho thambho
translated: According to defilement, first, lust, delusion, stiffness,

original: sārambho māno madoti, imehi chahi kilesehi arahattamaggena ritto hoti; doso kodho
analyzed: sa ārambhaḥ mānaḥ madaḥ ti imehi chahi kilesehi arahatta maggena rittaḥ hoti dosaḥ kodho
translated: agitation, conceit, and intoxication are the six defilements of which the path of arahatship is empty. Hatred, anger,

original: upanāho pamādoti, imehi catūhi kilesehi anāgāmimaggena ritto hoti; atimāno makkho
analyzed: upanāhaḥ pamādaḥ ti imehi catūhi kilesehi anāgāmi maggena rittaḥ hoti atimānaḥ makkho
translated: resentment, and negligence are the four defilements of which the path of non-return is empty. Arrogance, contempt,

original: paḷāso issā macchariyaṃ māyā sāṭheyyanti, imehi sattahi sotāpattimaggena ritto hoti.🔽Maggapaṭipāṭiyā pana sotāpattimaggena atimāno makkho paḷāso issā macchariyaṃ māyā🔽sāṭheyyanti; imehi sattahi ritto hoti, anāgāmimaggena doso kodho upanāho pamādoti,
analyzed: paḷāsaḥ issā macchariyam māyā sāṭheyyam ti imehi sattahi sotāpatti maggena rittaḥ hoti  magga paṭipāṭiyā pana sotāpatti maggena atimānaḥ makkhaḥ paḷāsaḥ issā macchariyam māyā  sāṭheyyam ti imehi sattahi rittaḥ hoti anāgāmi maggena dosaḥ kodhaḥ upanāhaḥ pamādaḥ ti
translated: conceit, envy, selfishness, deceit, and fraud are the seven defilements of which the path of stream-entry is empty.

original: imehi catūhi ritto hoti; arahattamaggena rāgo moho thambho sārambho māno madoti,
analyzed: imehi catūhi rittaḥ hoti arahatta maggena rāgaḥ mohaḥ thambho sa ārambhaḥ mānaḥ mado ti
translated: According to the path, the path of stream-entry is empty of the seven defilements, namely, arrogance, contempt, conceit, envy, selfishness, deceit, and fraud. The path of non-return is empty of the four defilements, namely, hatred, anger, resentment, and negligence. The path of arahatship is empty of the six defilements, namely, lust, delusion, stiffness, agitation, conceit, and intoxication.

original: imehi chahi ritto hoti. Tīṇi duccaritāni sabbakilesehītiādinā nayena avasesāpi yathāyogaṃ yojetabbā.
analyzed: imehi chahi rittaḥ hoti tīṇi duccaritāni sabba kilesehi iti ādinā nayena avasesā api yathāyogam yojetabbā
translated: He is devoid of these six. The rest should be construed in the appropriate way according to the method stated by the words “The three kinds of misconduct, all the defilements, etc.”

original: Vatthukāme parijānitvāti tebhūmake vatthukāme ñātatīraṇapariññāhi samāpanavasena
analyzed: vatthu kāme parijānitvā ti tebhūmake vatthu kāme samāpana vasena
translated: Having fully understood sense desires as objects: having fully understood sense desires as objects in the three planes by reaching them through the full understanding of defining and full understanding of determining.

original: jānitvā. Kilesakāme pahāyāti chandādayo kilesakāme pahānapariññāya jahitvā. Byantiṃ
analyzed: jānitvā kilesa kāme pahāya ati chanda ādayaḥ kilesa kāme pahāna pariññāya jahitvā byantim
translated: Having abandoned sense desires as defilements: having abandoned sense desires as defilements, such as zeal, etc., by means of the full understanding of abandoning.

original: karitvāti vigatantaṃ vigatakoṭiṃ karitvā.
analyzed: karitvā ati vigatantam vigata koṭim karitvā
translated: Having made an end of sense desires as objects: having made an end of sense desires as objects, having made them without remainder, without end.

original: Kāmoghaṃ tiṇṇassāti anāgāmimaggena avasānasaṅkhātaṃ kāmoghaṃ taritvā ṭhitassa. Bhavoghanti
analyzed: kāma ogham tiṇṇassa ati anāgāmi maggena avasāna saṅkhātam kāma ogham taritvā ṭhitassa bhava ogham ti
translated: Having crossed the flood of sense desires: having crossed the flood of sense desires called the “culmination of the round of rebirths” by means of the non-return path. The flood of becoming:🔽by means of the Arahant path. The flood of views:🔽by means of the path of stream-entry. The flood of ignorance:

original: arahattamaggena. Diṭṭhoghanti sotāpattimaggena. Avijjoghanti arahattamaggena. Sabbaṃ
analyzed: arahatta maggena sotāpatti maggena avijjoghanti arahatta maggena sabbam
translated: by means of the Arahant path. The whole course of the round of rebirths:

original: saṃsārapathanti sabbakhandhadhātuāyatanapaṭipāṭisaṅkhātaṃ pathaṃ arahattamaggeneva
analyzed: saṃsāra pathanti sabba khandha dhātu āyatana paṭipāṭi saṅkhātam patham arahatta maggena iva
translated: having crossed the course of the round of rebirth called the “round of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases” by means of the Arahant path.

original: taritvā ṭhitassa. Sotāpattimaggena uttiṇṇassa. Sakadāgāmimaggena nittiṇṇassa. Anāgāmimaggena
analyzed: taritvā ṭhitassa sotāpatti maggena uttiṇṇassa sakadāgāmi maggena nittiṇṇassa anāgāmi maggena
translated: Having crossed over by means of the path of stream-entry. Having crossed over by means of the path of once-return. Having crossed over by means of the path of non-return.

original: kāmadhātuṃ atikkantassa. Arahattamaggena sabbabhavaṃ samatikkantassa. Phalasamāpattivasena
analyzed: kāmadhātum atikkantassa arahatta maggena sabba bhavam samatikkantassa phala samāpatti vasena
translated: of one who has gone beyond the sense-desire element.🔽By the path of arahatship of one who has gone beyond all becoming.🔽By means of the attainment of fruition

original: vītivattassa. Pāraṃgatassātiādīni nibbānavasena vuttāni. Yathā iṇāyikā āṇaṇyanti
analyzed: vītivattassa pāraṃgatassa ati ādīni nibbāna vasena vuttāni yathā iṇāyikāḥ āṇaṇyanti
translated: and “gone beyond the world of sensual desire” means “gone beyond the world of sensual desire” by the path of non-return. And “gone beyond the world of existence” means “gone beyond all existence” by the path of Arahantship. And “gone beyond” means “gone beyond” by the attainment of fruition. And “gone to the further shore” and so on are said with respect to Nibbāna. Just as a debtor becomes debt-free

original: pavaḍḍhakaiṇaṃ ādāya vicarantā āṇaṇyaṃ. Patthentīti patthanaṃ uppādenti. Ābādhikā
analyzed: ādāya vicarantāḥ āṇaṇyam patthenti iti patthanam uppādenti ābādhikā
translated: when he has paid off his debts, so too, when they have paid off the debt to the Buddha by giving a gift, they are said to “become debt-free.” “They long for” means they arouse longing. “They long for health” means they long for the recovery of health. Just as

original: ārogyanti pittādirogāturo bhesajjakiriyāya taṃrogavūpasamanatthaṃ ārogyaṃ. Yathā
analyzed: pitta ādi roga āturaḥ bhesajja kiriyāya ārogyam yathā
translated: those who are sick long for health in order to cure their illness of bile, etc.,🔽just as those who are bound long for freedom from bondage,

original: bandhanabaddhāti nakkhattadivase bandhanāgāre baddhapurisā. Yathā dāsā bhujissanti
analyzed: bandhana baddhā ati nakkhatta divase bandhanāgāre baddha purisāḥ yathā dāsāḥ bhujissanti
translated: just as slaves long for the state of being masters,

original: yasmā bhujissā purisā yaṃ icchanti, taṃ karonti, na naṃ koci balakkārena tato nivatteti,
analyzed: yasmai bhujissā purisāḥ yam icchanti tam karonti na nam koci balakkārena tatas nivatteti
translated: because when they are masters they do what they want and no one can turn them back by force,

original: tasmā dāsā bhujissabhāvaṃ patthenti. Yathā kantāraddhānapakkhandāti yasmā balavanto
analyzed: tasmai dāsāḥ bhujissa bhāvam patthenti yathā yasmai balavantaḥ
translated: therefore slaves long for the state of being masters. Just as those who have set out on a desert path long for a resting place,

original: purisā hatthabhāraṃ gahetvā sajjāvudhā saparivārā kantāraṃ paṭipajjanti, te corā
analyzed: purisāḥ hattha bhāram gahetvā sajja āvudhā sa parivārā kantāram paṭipajjanti te corā
translated: because strong men, taking their provisions, their weapons ready, set out on a desert path with their retinue, and the thieves

original: dūratova disvā palāyanti. Te sotthinā kantāraṃ nittharitvā khemantaṃ patvā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā
analyzed: dūratas iva disvā palāyanti te sa utthinā kantāram nittharitvā khemantam patvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhā
translated: and they flee far away. They cross the desert safely and, when they reach the place of safety, they are glad and🔽delighted. Therefore they long for the place of safety in the desert. At the conclusion of the

original: honti. Tasmā kantārapakkhandā khemantabhūmiṃ patthenti. Desanāpariyosāne tisso sotāpattiphalaṃ
analyzed: honti tasmai kantāra pakkhandā khemanta bhūmim patthenti desanā pariyosāne tisso sotāpatti phalam
translated: teaching Tissa attained the fruit of stream-entry.

original: patvā pacchā pabbajitvā arahattaṃ sacchākāsi.
analyzed: patvā pacchā pabbajitvā arahattam sacchākāsi
translated: Later he went forth and realized arahatship.

original: Saddhammapajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammapajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Tissa- Metteyya Sutta in the Mahdniddesa is

original: Tissametteyyasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽8. Pasūrasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tissametteyya sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: completed.🔽. The commentary on the Pasura Sutta

original: 59. Aṭṭhame pasūrasuttaniddese paṭhamagāthāya tāva saṅkhepo – ime diṭṭhigatikā attano
analyzed: aṭṭhame pasūra sutta niddese paṭhama gāthāya tāva saṅkhepaḥ ime diṭṭhi gatikāḥ attano
translated: . In the eighth sutta in the Niddesa section, the Pasura Sutta, in the first stanza, the brief

original: diṭṭhiṃ sandhāya “idheva suddhī”ti vadanti. Aññesu pana dhammesu visuddhiṃ nāhu,
analyzed: diṭṭhim sandhāya idha iva suddhī iti vadanti aññesu pana dhammesu visuddhim na āhu
translated: explanation is this: These people who hold views say, “Here alone is purity,” referring to🔽their own views. But they do not proclaim purity in other teachings.🔽In this way, those who rely on their own teachers, etc., become proponents of what is

original: evaṃ yaṃ attano satthārādiṃ nissitā, tattheva “esa vādo subho”ti evaṃ subhavādā hutvā
analyzed: evam yam attano satthārā ādim nissitā tattha iva esa vādo subhaḥ ti evam subha vādā hutvā
translated: good, saying, “This doctrine is good.”🔽The various ascetics and brahmins are fixed on their own particular truths, such as

original: puthū samaṇabrāhmaṇā “sassato loko”tiādīsu paccekasaccesu niviṭṭhā.
analyzed: puthū samaṇa brāhmaṇā sassataḥ loka uti ādīsu paccekasaccesu niviṭṭhā
translated: “The world is eternal,” etc.

original: Sabbe paravāde khipantīti sabbā paraladdhiyo chaḍḍenti. Ukkhipantīti dūrato khipanti.🔽Parikkhipantīti samantato khipanti. Subhavādāti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Sobhanavādāti
analyzed: sabbe para vāde khipanti iti sabbā para laddhiyaḥ chaḍḍenti ukkhipanti iti dūratas khipanti  parikkhipanti iti samantataḥ khipanti subha vādā ati niddesassa uddesa padam sobhana vādā ati
translated: They throw away all the doctrines of others: they reject all the tenets of others. They throw them far away: they throw them far off.🔽They throw them all around: they throw them about on all sides. Good speakers: this is a word of introduction to the description. Fine speakers:

original: “etaṃ sundara”nti kathentā. Paṇḍitavādāti “paṇḍitā maya”nti evaṃ kathentā. Thiravādāti
analyzed: etam kathentā paṇḍita vādā ati paṇḍitāḥ evam kathentā thira vādā ati
translated: they say, “This is beautiful.” Clever speakers: they say, “We are clever.” Firm speakers:

original: “niddosavādaṃ vadāmā”ti kathentā. Ñāyavādāti “yuttavādaṃ vadāmā”ti kathentā. Hetuvādāti
analyzed: niddosa vādam vadāma ati kathentā ñāya vādā ati yutta vādam vadāma ati kathentā hetu vādā ati
translated: they say, “We speak without fault.” Speakers of what is right: they say, “We speak what is fitting.” Speakers of reasons:

original: “kāraṇasahitaṃ vadāmā”ti kathentā. Lakkhaṇavādāti “sallakkhetabbaṃ vadāmā”ti vadantā.
analyzed: kāraṇa sahitam vadāma iti kathentā lakkhaṇa vādā ati sallakkhetabbam vadāma ati vadantā
translated: they say, “We speak with reasons.” Speakers of characteristics: they say, “We speak what should be characterized.”

original: Kāraṇavādāti “udāharaṇayuttavādaṃ vadāmā”ti kathentā. Ṭhānavādāti “pakkamituṃ asakkuṇeyyavādaṃ vadāmā”ti vadantā.
analyzed: kāraṇa vādā ati udāharaṇa yutta vādam vadāma iti kathentā ṭhāna vādā ati pakkamitum asakkuṇeyya vādam vadāma iti vadantā
translated: Speakers of instances: they say, “We speak what is fit for instances.” Speakers of grounds: they say, “We speak what cannot be left out.”

original: Niviṭṭhāti antopaviṭṭhā. Patiṭṭhitāti tattheva ṭhitā.
analyzed: niviṭṭhā ati anta upaviṭṭhā patiṭṭhitā ati tattha eva ṭhitā
translated: They are settled: they are settled inside. They are established: they are established right there.

original: 60. Evaṃ niviṭṭhā ca “te vādakāmā”ti dutiyagāthā. Tattha bālaṃ dahantī mithu aññamaññanti
analyzed: evam niviṭṭhā ca te vāda kāmā ti dutiya gāthā tattha bālam dahantī mithu
translated: Thus settled, they are “eager for debate.” The second verse. Herein, they burn up the fool, each one another,

original: “ayaṃ bālo, ayaṃ bālo”ti evaṃ dvepi janā aññamaññaṃ bālaṃ dahanti, bālato passanti.
analyzed: ayam bālaḥ ayam bālo ti evam dve api janāḥ aññam aññam bālam dahanti bālataḥ passanti
translated: “This man is a fool, this man is a fool” — thus both men burn each other with the word “fool,” and they see each other as fools.

original: Vadanti te aññasitā kathojjanti te aññamaññasatthārādinissitā kalahaṃ vadanti. Pasaṃsakāmā
analyzed: vadanti te añña sitā kalaham vadanti pasaṃsa kāmā
translated: They speak with mutual contempt, they quarrel, they are hostile to each other’s teachers, etc., and they praise each other’s virtues in the hope of gain.

original: kusalāvadānāti pasaṃsatthikā ubhopi “mayaṃ kusalāvadānā paṇḍitavādā”ti evaṃ saññino hutvā.🔽Vādatthikāti vādena atthikā. Vādādhippāyāti vādajjhāsayā. Vādapurekkhārāti vādameva
analyzed: kusala avadānā ati pasaṃsatthikāḥ ubho pi mayam kusala avadānā paṇḍita vādā ti evam saññinaḥ hutvā  vādatthikā ati vādena atthikā vāda adhippāyā ati vāda ajjhāsayā vāda purekkhārā ati vādam eva
translated: They are skilled in finding fault: both of them think: “We are skilled in finding fault, we are wise in finding fault.”

original: purato katvā caramānā. Vādapariyesanaṃ carantāti vādameva gavesanaṃ caramānā. Vigayhāti
analyzed: puratas katvā caramānāḥ vāda pariyesanam carantā ati vādam eva gavesanam caramānāḥ vigayhāti
translated: They are eager for debate: they are eager for the debate itself. They are intent on debate: they are intent on the debate. They are bent on debate: they go about with the debate in front. They are in quest of debate: they go about in search of the debate. They are in pursuit of debate: they go about in pursuit of the debate.

original: pavisitvā. Ogayhāti otaritvā. Ajjhogāhetvāti nimujjitvā. Pavisitvāti antokatvā.
analyzed: pavisitvā ogayha ati otaritvā ajjhogāhetvā ati nimujjitvā pavisitvā ati antokatvā
translated: They enter into it: they penetrate it. They plunge into it: they descend into it. They throw themselves into it: they immerse themselves in it. They plunge in headlong: they plunge in with their whole being.

original: Anojavantīti nihīnaojavatī, tejavirahitāti attho. Sā kathāti esā vācā. Kathojjaṃ vadantīti nittejaṃ bhaṇanti. Evaṃ vadānesu ca tesu eko niyamato eva.
analyzed: anojavantī iti nihīna ojavatī teja virahitā ati attho sā kathā ati esā vācā kathojjam vadanti iti nittejam bhaṇanti evam vadānesu ca tesu ekaḥ niyamataḥ eva
translated: They are without vigour: they are of low vigour, devoid of energy, is the meaning. That talk: that speech. They speak with mutual contempt: they speak without energy.

original: 61. Yutto kathāyanti gāthā. Tattha yutto kathāyanti vādakathāya ussukko. Pasaṃsamicchaṃ
analyzed: yuttaḥ kathāyanti gāthā tattha yuttaḥ kathāyanti vāda kathāya ussukko pasaṃsam iccham
translated: The verse: “He’s eager for debate” . Herein, he’s eager for debate is eager for the talk of the discussion. He’s eager for praise

original: vinighāti hotīti attano pasaṃsaṃ icchanto “kathaṃ nu kho niggahessāmī”tiādinā nayena🔽pubbeva vādā kathaṃkathī vinighātī hoti. Apāhatasminti pañhavīmaṃsakehi “atthāpagataṃ
analyzed: vinighāti hoti iti attano pasaṃsam icchantaḥ katham nu kho niggahessāmi itiādinā nayena  pubbā iva vādā kathaṃkathī vinighātī hoti apāhatasmin ti pañha vīmaṃsakehi attha apagatam
translated: and he destroys it is eager for his own praise, thinking “How can I stop him?” and so on.

original: te bhaṇitaṃ, byañjanāpagataṃ te bhaṇita”ntiādinā nayena apaharite vāde. Nindāya so
analyzed: te bhaṇitam byañjana apagatam te bhaṇita nti ādinā nayena apaharite vāde nindāya saḥ
translated: When it’s refuted is when the discussion has been refuted by means of the questions and investigations thus “Your statement is devoid of any meaning, your statement is devoid of any expression” and so on. He’s angry at the blame

original: kuppatīti evaṃ apāhatasmiñca vāde uppannāya nindāya so kuppati. Randhamesīti yassa🔽randhameva gavesanto.🔽Thomananti vaṇṇabhaṇanaṃ. Kittinti pākaṭakaraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇahāriyanti guṇavaḍḍhanaṃ. Pubbeva
analyzed: kuppati iti evam apāhatasmin ca vāde uppannāya nindāya saḥ kuppati randhamesī iti yassa  randhamā iva gavesantaḥ  thomanam ti vaṇṇa bhaṇanam kittinti pākaṭa karaṇam vaṇṇa hāriyanti guṇa vaḍḍhanam pubbā iva
translated: is when the discussion has been refuted in this way, he is angry at the blame that has arisen. He seeks for a flaw is one who seeks only a flaw in another.

original: sallāpāti sallāpato puretarameva. “Kathamidaṃ kathamida”nti kathaṃkathā assa atthīti
analyzed: sallāpa ati sallāpataḥ puretaram eva katham idam katham idam ti kathaṃkathā assa atthi iti
translated: He’s a doubter is one who speaks in praise. He’s a braggart is one who makes himself obvious. He’s a flatterer is one who increases his own good qualities. He’s a talker is one who talks before the talk has started thus “How is this? How is this?” He’s a chatterbox is one who has a lot of talk.

original: kathaṃkathī. Jayo nu kho meti mama jayo. Kathaṃ niggahanti kena pakārena niggaṇhanaṃ.
analyzed: kathaṃkathī jayaḥ nu khalu mā iti mama jayaḥ katham niggahanti kena pakārena niggaṇhanam
translated: “How can I win?”: “May I win.” “How can I restrain?”: “By what means can I restrain?”

original: Paṭikammaṃ karissāmīti mama laddhiṃ parisuddhiṃ karissāmi. Visesanti atirekaṃ. Paṭivisesanti
analyzed: paṭikammam karissāmi iti mama laddhim parisuddhim karissāmi visesa anti atirekam paṭivisesa anti
translated: “I will make a counter-move”: “I will make my own position pure.” “Superiority”: “Superiority.” “Re-superiority”:

original: punappunaṃ visesaṃ. Āveṭhiyaṃ karissāmīti pariveṭhanaṃ karissāmi. Nibbeṭhiyanti mama🔽nibbeṭhanaṃ mocanaṃ nikkhamanaṃ. Chedanti vādachindanaṃ. Maṇḍalanti vādasaṅghātaṃ.
analyzed: punappunam visesam āveṭhiyam karissāmi iti pariveṭhanam karissāmi nibbeṭhiyanti mama  nibbeṭhanam mocanam nikkhamanam chedanti vāda chindanam maṇḍalanti vāda saṅghātam
translated: “Superiority again and again.” “I will make a counter-re-superiority”: “I will make a counter-re-superiority.” “I will be released”:🔽“I will be released, I will be freed, I will go forth.” “I will cut off”: “I will cut off the argument.” “I will make a circle”: “I will make a circle of the argument.”

original: Pārisajjāti paricārikā. Pāsārikāti kāraṇitā. Apaharantīti paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: pārisajjā ati paricārikā pāsārikā ati kāraṇitā apaharanti iti paṭibāhanti
translated: “An assembly”: “Attendants.” “A crowd”: “Those who are employed.” “I will drive away”: “I will drive away.”

original: Atthāpagatanti atthato apagataṃ, attho natthīti. Atthato apaharantīti atthamhā paṭibāhanti.🔽Attho te dunnitoti tava attho na sammā upanīto. Byañjanaṃ te duropitanti tava byañjanaṃ
analyzed: attha apagatam ti atthataḥ apagatam atthaḥ na atthi iti atthataḥ apaharanti iti atthamhā paṭibāhanti  atthaḥ te dunnitaḥ ti tava atthaḥ na sammā upanītaḥ byañjanam te duropitanti tava byañjanam
translated: “Gone from the meaning”: “Gone from the meaning, there is no meaning.” “I will drive away from the meaning”: “I will drive away from the meaning.”🔽“Your meaning is badly stated”: “Your meaning is not properly brought up.” “Your phrasing is badly brought”: “Your phrasing

original: duppatiṭṭhāpitaṃ. Niggaho te akatoti tayā niggaho na kato. Paṭikammaṃ te dukkaṭanti
analyzed: duppatiṭṭhāpitam niggaho te a katoti tayā niggahaḥ na kato paṭikammam te dukkaṭam ti
translated: is badly established.” “You have not made a counter-move”: “You have not made a counter-move.” “Your counter-move is badly done”:

original: tayā attano laddhipatiṭṭhāpanaṃ duṭṭhu kataṃ. Visamakathaṃ dukkathitanti na sammā
analyzed: tayā attanaḥ laddhi patiṭṭhāpanam duṭṭhu katam visama katham dukkathita nti na sammā
translated: You have made a bad foundation for yourself. Visamakathaṃ dukkathitanti na sammā

original: kathitaṃ. Dubbhaṇitanti bhaṇantenapi duṭṭhu bhaṇitaṃ. Dullapitanti na sammā vissajjitaṃ.
analyzed: kathitam dubbhaṇitanti bhaṇantena api duṭṭhu bhaṇitam dullapitanti na sammā vissajjitam
translated: kathitaṃ: It is not spoken of well. Dubbhaṇitanti bhaṇantenapi duṭṭhu bhaṇitaṃ: It is spoken of badly by one who speaks. Dullapitanti na sammā vissajjitaṃ: It is not well released.

original: Duruttanti aññathā bhaṇitaṃ. Dubbhāsitanti virūpaṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: durutta nti aññathā bhaṇitam dubbhāsita nti virūpam bhāsitam
translated: Duruttanti aññathā bhaṇitaṃ: It is spoken of otherwise. Dubbhāsitanti virūpaṃ bhāsitaṃ: It is spoken of in a distorted way.

original: Nindāyāti garahaṇena. Garahāyāti dosakathanena. Akittiyāti aguṇakathanena. Avaṇṇahārikāyāti aguṇavaḍḍhanena.
analyzed: nindāya ati garahaṇena garahāya ati dosa kathanena akittiyā ati aguṇa kathanena avaṇṇa hārikāya ati aguṇa vaḍḍhanena
translated: Nindāyāti garahaṇena: By way of censure. Garahāyāti dosakathanena: By way of speaking of faults. Akittiyāti aguṇakathanena: By way of speaking of no good qualities. Avaṇṇahārikāyāti aguṇavaḍḍhanena: By way of not increasing good qualities.

original: Kuppatīti pakatibhāvaṃ jahetvā calati. Byāpajjatīti dosavasena pūtibhāvaṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: kuppati iti pakati bhāvam jahetvā calati byāpajjati iti dosa vasena pūti bhāvam āpajjati
translated: Kuppatīti pakatibhāvaṃ jahetvā calati: It moves, having abandoned its natural state. Byāpajjatīti dosavasena pūtibhāvaṃ āpajjati: It falls into corruption by way of hate.

original: Patiṭṭhīyatīti kodhavasena gaṇabhāvaṃ gacchati. Kopañcāti kupitabhāvaṃ. Dosañcāti
analyzed: patiṭṭhīyati iti kodha vasena gaṇa bhāvam gacchati kopam ca ati kupita bhāvam dosam ca ati
translated: Patiṭṭhīyatīti kodhavasena gaṇabhāvaṃ gacchati: It goes into a group by way of anger. Kopañcāti kupitabhāvaṃ: Anger is the state of being angry. Dosañcāti

original: dūsanaṃ. Apaccayañcāti atuṭṭhākārañca. Pātukarotīti pākaṭaṃ karoti. Randhamesīti
analyzed: dūsanam a paccayam ca ati a tuṭṭhākāram ca pātukaroti iti pākaṭam karoti randhamesi iti
translated: dūsanaṃ: Hate is corruption. Apaccayañcāti atuṭṭhākārañca: Displeasure is the state of being dissatisfied. Pātukarotīti pākaṭaṃ karoti: It makes it clear. Randhamesīti

original: antaragavesī. Virandhamesīti chiddagavesī. Aparaddhamesīti guṇaṃ apanetvā dosameva
analyzed: antara gavesī virandha mesī iti chidda gavesī aparaddha mesī iti guṇam apanetvā dosam eva
translated: antaragavesī: It seeks an opening. Virandhamesīti chiddagavesī: It seeks a crack. Aparaddhamesīti guṇaṃ apanetvā dosameva

original: gavesī. Khalitamesīti pakkhalanagavesī. Gaḷitamesīti patanagavesī. “Ghaṭṭitamesī”tipi
analyzed: gavesī khalita mesī iti pakkhalana gavesī gaḷita mesī iti patana gavesī ghaṭṭita mesī iti pi
translated: “One who seeks a fall” is one who seeks a stumble. “One who seeks a slip” is one who seeks a fall.

original: pāṭho, tassa pīḷanagavesīti attho. Vivaramesīti dosagavesī.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ tassa pīḷana gavesī iti atthaḥ vivara mesī iti dosa gavesī
translated: A seeker of faults: a seeker of slips. A seeker of downfalls: a seeker of falls. The reading is also ghaṭṭitamesī ; the meaning is a seeker of troubles. A seeker of openings: a seeker of hatred.

original: 62. Na kevalañca so kuppati, apica kho pana “yamassa vāda”nti gāthā. Tattha parihīnamāhu,
analyzed: na kevalam ca so kuppati api ca kho pana yamassa vādanti gāthāḥ tattha parihīnam āhu
translated: And not only does he get angry, but also he says “What is the point of this talk? ”🔽There they say it is lost,

original: apāhatanti atthabyañjanādito apāhataṃ parihīnaṃ vadanti. Paridevatīti tatonimittaṃ🔽so “aññaṃ mayā āvajjita”ntiādīhi vippalapati. Socatīti “tassa jayo”tiādīni ārabbha
analyzed: apāhatanti attha byañjana āditaḥ apāhatam parihīnam vadanti paridevati iti tatonimittam  so aññam mayā āvajjita nti ādīhi vippalapati socati iti tassa jayoti ādīni ārabbha
translated: they say it is lost, abandoned, in respect of both meaning and phrasing. He laments:🔽because of that he prattles “I have overlooked something” and so on. He sorrows:🔽he sorrows about “His victory” and so on. He weeps:

original: socati. “Upaccagā ma”nti anutthunātīti “so maṃ vādena vādaṃ atikkanto”tiādinā nayena🔽suṭṭhutaraṃ vippalapati.
analyzed: socati upaccagā manti anutthunāti iti saḥ mama vādena vādam atikkantā iti ādinā nayena  suṭṭhutaram vippalapati
translated: he weeps “I am overcome” and so on.

original: Parihāpitanti na vaḍḍhitaṃ. Aññaṃ mayā āvajjitanti aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ mayā avanamitaṃ.
analyzed: parihāpitanti na vaḍḍhitam aññam mayā āvajjitanti aññam kāraṇam mayā avanamitam
translated: He is not helped: he is not assisted. I have overlooked something: I have not brought forward a reason.

original: Cintitanti vīmaṃsitaṃ. Mahāpakkhoti mahanto ñātipakkho etassāti mahāpakkho. Mahāparisoti
analyzed: cintitam ti vīmaṃsitam mahā pakkhaḥ ti mahantaḥ ñāti pakkhaḥ etassa ati mahā pakkhaḥ mahā parisaḥ
translated: I have thought: I have considered. He has a great following: he has a great clan-following. He has a great retinue: he has a great following of pupils.

original: mahāparicārikapariso. Mahāparivāroti mahādāsadāsiparivāro. Parisā cāyaṃ vaggāti ayañca
analyzed: mahā paricārika parisaḥ mahā parivāraḥ ti mahā dāsa dāsi parivāraḥ parisā ca ayam ayam ca
translated: and a great retinue of servants. Great retinue of servants: a great retinue of male and female slaves. And this assembly is a faction.

original: parisā vaggā, na ekā. Puna bhañjissāmīti puna bhindissāmi.
analyzed: parisā vaggā na ekā puna bhañjissāmi iti puna bhindissāmi
translated: and a great retinue of attendants. Great retinue: a great retinue of male and female slaves. And this assembly is divided: and this assembly is divided, not one. I will break it up again: I will break it up again.

original: 63. Ete vivādā samaṇesūti ettha pana samaṇā vuccanti bāhiraparibbājakā. Etesu ugghātinighāti
analyzed: ete vivādā samaṇesu iti ettha pana samaṇāḥ vuccanti bāhira paribbājakāḥ etesu ugghāti nighāti
