translated: As to “these disputes among the ascetics,” etc., here “ascetics” are the outside sectarians. He is one who is agitated and destroyed

original: hotīti etesu vādesu jayaparājayādivasena cittaugghātanighātaṃ vā pāpuṇanto ugghāti
analyzed: etesu vādesu jaya parājaya ādi vasena citta ogghāta nighātam vā pāpuṇantaḥ ugghāti
translated: by them: he is one who is agitated and destroyed by them by way of victory and defeat, etc., in these doctrines.

original: ca nighāti ca hoti. Virame kathojjanti pajaheyya kalahaṃ. Na haññadatthatthi pasaṃsalābhāti🔽na hi ettha pasaṃsalābhato añño attho atthi. Uttāno vāti na gambhīroti attho “pañcime
analyzed: ca nighāti ca hoti virame pajaheyya kalaham na  na hi ettha pasaṃsa lābhataḥ aññaḥ atthaḥ atthi uttānaḥ vā ati na gambhīraḥ ti pañcime
translated: Let him shun a quarrel: let him abandon a quarrel. There is no good in it: there is no good in it at all.🔽For there is no other good here than the gain of praise.

original: kāmaguṇā”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: kāma guṇa ati ādīsu
translated: It is not deep: the meaning is, it is not profound, like the five cords of sensual pleasure, etc.

original: Gambhīro vāti duppaveso appatiṭṭho paṭiccasamuppādo viya. Gūḷho vāti paṭicchanno
analyzed: gambhīraḥ vāti duppavesaḥ appatiṭṭho paṭiccasamuppādaḥ viya gūḷhaḥ vāti paṭicchanno
translated: It is deep: the meaning is, it is hard to enter, not well-founded, like dependent origination. It is hidden: it is concealed,🔽like the words “Delight in it, Nanda, I guarantee you the state of a paccekabuddha” .

original: hutvā ṭhito “abhirama nanda ahaṃ te pāṭibhogo”tiādīsu viya. Paṭicchanno vāti apākaṭo
analyzed: hutvā ṭhitaḥ abhirama nanda aham te paṭicchannaḥ vāti apākaṭaḥ
translated: It is concealed: it is not obvious,

original: “mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā”tiādīsu viya. Neyyo vāti nīharitvā kathetabbo “asaddho akataññū
analyzed: mātaram pitaram hantvā ati ādīsu viya neyyaḥ vā ati nīharitvā kathetabbaḥ asaddhaḥ akataññū
translated: To be led on: to be spoken of after being led out, as in the passage beginning, “The faithless, the ungrateful” .

original: cā”tiādīsu viya. Nīto vāti pāḷiyā ṭhitaniyāmena kathetabbo “cattārome, bhikkhave,🔽ariyavaṃsā”tiādīsu viya. Anavajjo vāti niddosattho “kusalā dhammā”tiādīsu viya. Nikkileso
analyzed: ca ati ādīsu viya nītaḥ vā ati pāḷiyā ṭhita niyāmena kathetabbo cattāro me bhikkhave  ariya vaṃsā ti ādīsu viya anavajjaḥ vā ati niddosa atthaḥ kusalā dhammā ti ādīsu viya nikkilesaḥ
translated: To be led: to be spoken of in the order in which it occurs in the text, as in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are these four noble lineages” .🔽To be blameless: to be spoken of as free from blame, as in the passage beginning, “Profitable ideas” .🔽Or to be free from defilement: to be spoken of as free from defilement, as in the case of insight .

original: vāti kilesavirahito vipassanā viya. Vodāno vāti parisuddho lokuttaraṃ viya. Paramattho
analyzed: vāti kilesa virahitaḥ vipassanā viya vodānaḥ vāti parisuddhaḥ lokuttaram viya paramattho
translated: To be purified: to be spoken of as purified, as in the case of the supramundane .

original: vāti uttamattho uttamatthabhūto attho khandhadhātuāyatananibbānāni viya.🔽64. Chaṭṭhagāthāyattho – yasmā ca na haññadatthatthi pasaṃsalābhā, tasmā paramaṃ
analyzed: vāti uttama atthaḥ uttama attha bhūtaḥ attho khandha dhātu āyatana nibbānāni viya  yasmā ca na tasmā paramam
translated: Or to be the ultimate meaning: to be spoken of as the ultimate meaning, as in the case of the categories of aggregates, bases, elements, and extinction .

original: lābhaṃ labhantopi “sundaro aya”nti tattha diṭṭhiyā pasaṃsito vā pana hotīti taṃ vādaṃ
analyzed: lābham labhanto pi sundaraḥ ayanti tattha diṭṭhiyā pasaṃsito vā pana hoti iti tam vādam
translated: The meaning of the sixth stanza is this. Since there is no one who is killed, there is no one who gains praise. Therefore, even though one gains the highest gain, one is not “beautiful” in that sense. Or one may be praised by the view that “He is beautiful” .

original: parisāya majjhe dīpetvā tato so tena jayatthena tuṭṭhiṃ vā dantavidaṃsakaṃ vā āpajjanto
analyzed: parisāya majjhe dīpetvā tatas saḥ tena jayatthena tuṭṭhim vā danta vidaṃsakam vā āpajjantaḥ
translated: Then, after that, he should illuminate that doctrine in the midst of an assembly. Then, because of that, he may be satisfied with that as a reason for victory, or he may break out into a smile.

original: hassati, mānena ca unnamati. Kiṃ kāraṇaṃ? Yasmā taṃ jayatthaṃ pappuyya yathāmano jāto.
analyzed: hassati mānena ca unnamati kim kāraṇam yasmā tam jayattham yathā manaḥ jātaḥ
translated: and with conceit he exalts himself. Why? Because he has attained to victory as he desired.

original: Thambhayitvāti pūretvā. Brūhayitvāti vaḍḍhetvā. Imissā gāthāya niddeso uttānattho.🔽65. Evaṃ unnamato ca “yā unnatī”ti gāthā. Tattha mānātimānaṃ vadate panesoti eso
analyzed: thambhayitvā iti pūretvā brūhayitvā ati vaḍḍhetvā imissā gāthāya niddesaḥ uttāna attho  evam unnamato ca yā unnatī iti gāthā tattha māna atimānam vadate pana iso ti eso
translated: Having filled up, having increased: the commentary on this verse is plain in meaning.🔽So too with the verse “When he exalts himself” . Herein, he who speaks thus, “I am better,” is conceited and over-conceited.

original: pana taṃ unnatiṃ “vighātabhūmī”ti abujjhamāno mānañca atimānañca vadati. Evaṃ imissāpi🔽gāthāya niddeso uttānattho.
analyzed: pana tam unnatim vighāta bhūmī iti a bujjhamānaḥ mānam ca atimānam ca vadati evam imissā api  gāthāya niddesaḥ uttāna ttho
translated: Not understanding that exaltation to be a ground for vexation, he speaks of conceit and over-conceit. So too with the commentary on this verse.

original: 66. Evaṃ vāde dosaṃ dassetvā idāni tassa vādaṃ asampaṭicchanto “sūro”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tattha rājakhādāyāti rājakhādanīyena, bhattavetanenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Abhigajjameti🔽paṭisūramicchanti yathā so paṭisūraṃ icchanto abhigajjanto eti, evaṃ diṭṭhigatiko
analyzed: evam vāde dosam dassetvā idāni tassa vādam a sampaṭicchantaḥ sūraḥ iti gātham āha  tattha rāja khādāya ati rāja khādanīyena bhatta vetanena ati vuttam hoti  paṭisūram icchanti yathā saḥ paṭisūram icchantaḥ abhigajjantaḥ eti evam diṭṭhi gatikaḥ
translated: Having thus shown the fault in his speech, the Master now, in refusing to accept his challenge, spoke the verse “The hero” .

original: diṭṭhigatikanti dasseti. Yeneva so tena palehīti yena so tuyhaṃ paṭisūro, tena gaccha.
analyzed: diṭṭhigatikanti dasseti yena iva saḥ tena palehi iti yena saḥ tuyham paṭisūro tena gaccha
translated: Herein, he who eats the king’s food is one who lives on the king’s rations, on the king’s maintenance. He who seeks a rival is one who seeks a counterpart. Just as he goes seeking and seeking a counterpart, so the view-attainer shows a view-attainer. Go by the way he went: go by the way he went, your counterpart.

original: Pubbeva natthi yadidaṃ yudhāyāti yaṃ pana kilesajātaṃ yuddhāya siyā, taṃ idha pubbeva
analyzed: pubbā iva na atthi yat idam yudhāya ati yam pana kilesa jātam yuddhāya siyā tam idha pubbā iva
translated: “There is no battle here at all”: but whatever defilement there might be that could be a battle, that is not here at all.

original: natthi, bodhimūleyevassa pahīnanti dasseti.
analyzed: natthi dasseti
translated: And before there was no one to fight with: but here he shows that there was no defilement that could be a foe to him, for that was already abandoned by him at the foot of the tree.

original: Sūroti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Suṭṭhu uro sūro, vissaṭṭhauro ninnauroti attho. Vīroti
analyzed: sūra iti niddesassa uddesa padam suṭṭhu uro sūraḥ vissaṭṭha auro ninna auro ti attho vīra iti
translated: Sūro: this is a word of introduction to the description. The meaning is: he is a hero with a broad chest, a well-developed chest, a deep chest. Vīro:

original: parakkamavanto. Vikkantoti saṅgāmaṃ pavisanto. Abhīrūtiādayo vuttanayā eva. Puṭṭhoti
analyzed: parakkamavantaḥ vikkantaḥ iti saṅgāmam pavisantaḥ abhīru uti ādayaḥ vutta nayāḥ eva puṭṭhaḥ iti
translated: he is valiant. Vikkanto: he is ready to enter the fray. Abhīru: and so on as above. Puṭṭho:

original: niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Positoti thūlakato. Āpāditoti upaḍḍhabalito paṭipādito. Vaḍḍhitoti tato tato bhāvito.
analyzed: niddesassa uddesa padam posito ti thūlakataḥ āpādito iti upaḍḍhabalitaḥ paṭipādito vaḍḍhito ti tatas tatas bhāvito
translated: this is a word of introduction to the description. Posito: he is well-nourished. Āpādito: he is half-trained. Vaḍḍhito: he is fully trained.

original: Gajjantoti abyattasarena gajjanto. Uggajjantoti ukkuṭṭhiṃ karonto. Abhigajjantoti
analyzed: gajjantaḥ iti abyatta sarena gajjantaḥ uggajjantaḥ iti ukkuṭṭhim karontaḥ abhigajjantaḥ iti
translated: Gajjanto: he is roaring with a deep voice. Uggajjanto: he is roaring with a loud voice. Abhigajjanto:

original: sīhanādaṃ karonto. Etīti āgacchati. Upetīti tato samīpaṃ gacchati. Upagacchatīti
analyzed: sīha nādam karontaḥ eti iti āgacchati upeti iti tatas samīpam gacchati upagacchati iti
translated: he is roaring with a lion’s roar. Etī: he comes. Upetī: he goes near. Upagacchati:

original: tato samīpaṃ gantvā na nivattati. Paṭisūranti nibbhayaṃ. Paṭipurisanti sattupurisaṃ.
analyzed: tatas samīpam gantvā na nivattati nibbhayam paṭipurisanti sattu purisam
translated: he does not turn back after going near. Paṭisūranti: he is fearless. Paṭipurisanti: he is a man’s man.

original: Paṭisattunti sattu hutvā abhimukhe ṭhitaṃ. Paṭimallanti paṭisedhaṃ hutvā yujjhantaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisattunti sattu hutvā abhimukhe ṭhitam paṭimallanti paṭisedham hutvā yujjhantam
translated: “Face to face” : standing face to face. “Opposing” : opposing, fighting.

original: Icchantoti ākaṅkhamāno.
analyzed: icchantaḥ iti ākaṅkhamānaḥ
translated: “If he wishes” : if he desires.

original: Palehīti gaccha. Vajāti mā tiṭṭha. Gacchāti samīpaṃ upasaṅkama. Abhikkamāti parakkamaṃ karohi.
analyzed: palehi iti gaccha vajāti mā tiṭṭha gaccha ati samīpam upasaṅkama abhikkama ati parakkamam karohi
translated: “Go away” : depart. “Do not stand” : do not stay. “Go” : approach. “Advance” : make an effort.

original: Bodhiyā mūleti mahābodhirukkhassa samīpe. Ye paṭisenikarā kilesāti ye kilesā paṭipakkhakarā.
analyzed: bodhiyāḥ mūle ti mahā bodhi rukkhassa samīpe ye kilesā ati ye kilesā paṭipakkha karā
translated: “To the foot of the Bodhi tree” : near the great Bodhi tree. “The defilements that are his opponents” : the defilements that are his adversaries.

original: Paṭilomakarāti paṭāṇīkarā. Paṭikaṇṭakakarāti vinivijjhanakarā. Paṭipakkhakarāti sattukarā.🔽67. Ito paraṃ sesagāthā pākaṭasambandhā eva. Tattha vivādayantīti vivadanti. Paṭisenikattāti
analyzed: paṭiloma karā ati paṭāṇī karā paṭikaṇṭaka karā ati vinivijjhana karā paṭipakkha karā ati sattu karā  itas param sesa gāthā pākaṭa sambandhā eva tattha vivādayanti iti vivadanti paṭisenikattā ati
translated: “That make him turn back” : that make him retreat. “That are his adversaries” : that are his enemies.

original: paṭilomakārakā. “Na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsī”tiādinā nayena viruddhavacanaṃ vivādo.
analyzed: paṭiloma kārakā na tvam imam dhamma vinayam ājānāsi iti ādinā nayena viruddha vacanam vivādaḥ
translated: The rest of the stanzas are self-explanatory. Herein, “they dispute” means they argue. “That make him turn back” means that make him retreat. “You do not understand this Dhamma and Discipline” is a dispute in the sense of a contradictory statement.

original: Sahitaṃ meti mama vacanaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ. Asahitaṃ teti tava vacanaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ.
analyzed: sahitam mā iti mama vacanam attha saṃhitam a sahitam te iti tava vacanam anattha saṃhitam
translated: “My statement is connected with the goal” means my statement is connected with the benefit. “Your statement is not connected with the goal” means your statement is not connected with the benefit.

original: Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti yaṃ taṃ adhiciṇṇaṃ cirakālasevanavasena paguṇaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: adhiciṇṇam te viparāvattanti yam tam adhiciṇṇam cira kāla sevana vasena paguṇam tam
translated: “What you have undertaken has turned back” : what you have undertaken has been worn out by long practice.

original: mama vādaṃ āgamma nivattaṃ. Āropito te vādoti tuyhaṃ upari mayā doso āropito. Cara
analyzed: mama vādam āgamma nivattam āropito te vādo ti tuyham upari mayā doso āropito cara
translated: “The charge has been laid against you” : a fault has been laid against you by me.

original: vādappamokkhāyāti bhattapuṭaṃ ādāya taṃ taṃ upasaṅkamitvā vādā pamokkhatthāya uttaraṃ
analyzed: vāda ppamokkhāya ati bhatta puṭam ādāya tam tam upasaṅkamitvā vāda a pamokkha tthāya uttaram
translated: “Go and wander about for the sake of release from the charge” : taking your bowl and robe, go and wander about seeking a reply in order to be released from the charge by approaching this and that person.

original: pariyesamāno vicara. Nibbeṭhehi vāti atha vā mayā āropitadosato attānaṃ mocehi. Sace
analyzed: pariyesamānaḥ vicara nibbeṭhehi vā ati atha vā mayā āropita dosataḥ attānam mocehi sace
translated: “Get out of it” : or else, free yourself from the fault that has been laid against you.

original: pahosīti sace sakkosi.
analyzed: pahosi iti sace sakkosi
translated: “If you can” : if you are able.

original: Āveṭhiyāya āveṭhiyanti āveṭhetvā nivattanena nivattanaṃ. Nibbeṭhiyāya nibbeṭhiyanti dosato mocanena mocanaṃ. Chedena chedanti evamādi heṭṭhā vuttanayattā yathāyogaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: āveṭhiyāya āveṭhiyanti āveṭhetvā nivattanena nivattanam nibbeṭhiyāya nibbeṭhiyanti dosataḥ mocanena mocanam chedena evamādi heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā yathāyogam yojetabbam
translated: “By turning back, one turns back” : by turning back by way of turning back. “By getting out of it, one gets out of it” : by getting out of it by way of getting out of it. “By cutting it off, one cuts it off” : etc., should be construed in the appropriate way because the method has already been stated above.

original: 68. Visenikatvāti kilesasenaṃ vināsetvā. Kiṃ labhethāti paṭimallaṃ kiṃ labhissasi.
analyzed: kilesa senam vināsetvā kim labhetha ati paṭimallam kim labhissasi
translated: “Having routed” : having destroyed the army of defilements. “What will you get?” : what opponent will you get?

original: Pasūrāti taṃ paribbājakaṃ ālapati. Yesīdha natthīti yesaṃ idha natthi. Imāyapi gāthāya
analyzed: tam paribbājakam ālapati yesam idha natthi iti yesam idha natthi imāya api gāthāya
translated: The meaning of this verse is also

original: niddeso uttānatthoyeva.
analyzed: niddesaḥ uttānatthaḥ yeva
translated: self-evident.

original: 69. Pavitakkanti “jayo nu kho me bhavissatī”tiādīni vitakkento. Dhonena yugaṃ samāgamāti
analyzed: jayaḥ nu kho me bhavissati itiādīni vitakkentaḥ dhonena yugam
translated: ‘Thinking’ : thinking ‘Will I win?’ etc. ‘With the one who is pure’ : with the Buddha who has shaken off the defilements. ‘You cannot come to grips’ :

original: dhutakilesena buddhena saddhiṃ yugaggāhaṃ samāpanno. Na hi tvaṃ sakkhasi sampayātaveti🔽kotthuādayo viya sīhādīhi dhonena saha yugaṃ gahetvā ekapadampi sampayātuṃ yugaggāhameva
analyzed: dhuta kilesena buddhena saddhim yugaggāham samāpannaḥ na hi tvam sakkhasi sampayātave ti  sīha ādīhi saha yugam gahetvā eka padam pi sampayātum yuga ggāham eva
translated: you cannot come to grips with even one step of the Buddha, as a lion with a jackal, and so make a contest with him.

original: vā sampādetuṃ na sakkhissasīti.🔽Manoti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Cittanti cittatāya cittaṃ. “Ārammaṇaṃ minamānaṃ jānātī”ti
analyzed: vā sampādetum na sakkhissasi iti  manaḥ ti niddesassa uddesa padam cittanti cittatāya cittam ārammaṇam minamānam jānāti iti
translated: Or you cannot make a contest with him even in a contest.🔽‘Mind’ is the term of expression for the ‘indicative’ . ‘Thought’ is mind in the sense of thinking. ‘It knows, thinking “I am thinking” ‘.

original: mano. Mānasanti mano eva. “Antalikkhacaro pāso, yvāyaṃ carati mānaso”ti hi ettha
analyzed: manaḥ mānasanti manaḥ eva antalikkha caraḥ pāsaḥ yvā ayam carati mānasaḥ iti hi ettha
translated: ‘Mind’ is mind itself. ‘The snare that goes by mind’ .

original: pana sampayuttakadhammo mānasoti vutto.
analyzed: pana sampayuttaka dhammo mānasaḥ ti vutto
translated: Here the associated states are called ‘mind’.🔽‘How can you, Lord, have a disciple

original: “Kathañhi bhagavā tuyhaṃ, sāvako sāsane rato;
analyzed: katham hi bhagavā tuyham sāvakaḥ sāsane rataḥ
translated: who delights in your Dispensation,

original: Appattamānaso sekkho, kālaṃkayirā janesutā”ti. –
analyzed: a patta mānasaḥ sekkhaḥ janesutā ti
translated: May die, and that would be a loss.”

original: Ettha arahattaṃ mānasanti vuttaṃ. Idha pana manova mānasaṃ, byañjanavasena hetaṃ padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.🔽Hadayanti cittaṃ. “Cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmī”ti ettha uro🔽hadayanti vuttaṃ. “Hadayā hadayaṃ maññe aññāya tacchatī”ti ettha cittaṃ. “Vakkaṃ
analyzed: ettha arahattam mānasanti vuttam idha pana manaḥ uva mānasam byañjana vasena ha itam padam vaḍḍhitam  hadayanti cittam cittam vā te khipissāmi hadayam vā te phālessāmi iti ettha uro  hadayanti vuttam hadayā hadayam maññe aññāya tacchati iti ettha cittam vakkam
translated: Here the word “mind’s ideal” is used for arahatship. But here the word “mind” is used for the mind itself, the word being extended by metaphor.

original: hadaya”nti ettha hadayavatthu. Idha pana cittameva abbhantaraṭṭhena “hadaya”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Tameva parisuddhaṭṭhena paṇḍaraṃ, bhavaṅgaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Yathāha “pabhassaramidaṃ,
analyzed: hadayanti ettha hadaya vatthu idha pana cittam eva abbhantara ṭṭhena hadayanti vuttam  tam eva parisuddha ṭṭhena paṇḍaram bhavaṅgam sandhāya itam vuttam yathā āha pabhassaram idam
translated: “Heart” is the heart-basis. Here, however, the word “heart” is used for the mind itself in the sense of the inner core.

original: bhikkhave, cittaṃ, tañca kho āgantukehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭha”nti. Tato nikkhantattā🔽pana akusalampi gaṅgāya nikkhantā nadī gaṅgā viya godhāvarito nikkhantā godhāvari
analyzed: bhikkhave cittam tat ca kho āgantukehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhanti tatas nikkhanta ttā  pana akusalam pi gaṅgāya nikkhantā nadī gaṅgā viya godhāvaritaḥ nikkhantā godhāvari
translated: It is called “pure” in the sense of purified. It is said with reference to the life-continuum, according to the sutta: “Monks, this mind is luminous, but it is defiled by taints that come from without” .🔽But because it has emerged from that , it is called “white” like a river that has emerged from the Ganges is called the “Gaṅgā” even though it is mixed with the water of another river,

original: viya ca “paṇḍara”ntveva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viya ca vuttam
translated: and like a river that has emerged from the Godhāvarī is called the “Godhāvarī” even though it is mixed with the water of another river.

original: Mano manāyatananti idha pana manogahaṇaṃ manasseva āyatanabhāvadīpanatthaṃ. Tenetaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ mana āyatananti idha pana manaḥ gahaṇam manassa iva āyatana bhāva dīpana attham tena itam
translated: But here the inclusion of mind is to show that mind is a sense base. So he shows

original: dīpeti “nayidaṃ devāyatanaṃ viya manassa āyatanattā manāyatanaṃ, atha kho mano eva🔽āyatanaṃ manāyatana”nti. Tattha nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: dīpeti na idam devāyatanam viya manassa āyatanattā manāyatanam atha kho manaḥ eva  āyatanam manāyatananti tattha nivāsa ṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: that it is not a sense base because it is a base for the divine eye, etc., as the divine eye, etc., are, but rather that

original: sañjātidesaṭṭhena kāraṇaṭṭhena ca āyatanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi loke “issarāyatanaṃ🔽vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ āyatananti vuccati. “Suvaṇṇāyatanaṃ rajatāyatana”ntiādīsu🔽ākaro. Sāsane pana “manorame āyatane, sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā”tiādīsu samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽“Dakkhiṇāpatho gunnaṃ āyatana”ntiādīsu sañjātideso. “Tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ
analyzed: sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca āyatanam veditabbam tathā hi loke issara āyatanam  vāsudevāyatana ntiādīsu nivāsa ṭṭhānam āyatananti vuccati suvaṇṇāyatanam rajatāyatana ntiādīsu  pana manorame āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamāti ādīsu samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam  dakkhiṇāpathaḥ gunnam āyatana nti ādīsu sañjā atidesaḥ tatra tatra iva
translated: it is a sense base because it is a base for the divine ear, etc., as the divine ear, etc., are. Herein, a sense base should be understood as a dwelling place, as a source, as a meeting place,

original: pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ. Idha pana sañjātidesaṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatana iti ādīsu kāraṇam idha pana sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: as a place of origin, and as a reason. For in ordinary usage such passages as “The king’s palace” are found in which the word āyatana is used in the sense of a dwelling place. And in such passages as “Gold is the source of the colour of gold” it is used in the sense of a source. In the scriptures it is used in the sense of a meeting place in such passages as “In a delightful place, a delightful sense base, birds delight” . It is used in the sense of a place of origin in such passages as “The southern region is the source of horses” . And it is used in the sense of a reason in such passages as “He has attained the ability to be a witness , wherever there is a suitable sense base” . Here it is used in the sense of a place of origin and in the sense of a meeting place.

original: kāraṇaṭṭhenāti tidhāpi vaṭṭati.
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭṭhena ati tidhā api vaṭṭati
translated: It is also tenable in the three ways of taking it as a reason.

original: Phassādayo hi dhammā ettha sañjāyantīti sañjātidesaṭṭhenapi etaṃ āyatanaṃ. Bahiddhā
analyzed: phassa ādayaḥ hi dhammā ettha sañjāyanti iti etam āyatanam bahiddhā
translated: For the states of contact, etc., are generated here, thus it is a sense base in the sense of a place of generation.

original: rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbā ārammaṇabhāvenettha osarantīti samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhenapi
analyzed: rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbāḥ ārammaṇa bhāvena ittha osaranti iti samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena api
translated: External visible data, sounds, odours, flavours and tangible data descend here as objects, thus it is a sense base in the sense of a place of descent.

original: āyatanaṃ. Phassādīnaṃ pana sahajātādipaccayaṭṭhena kāraṇattā kāraṇaṭṭhenāpi āyatananti
analyzed: āyatanam phassa ādīnam pana sahajāta ādi paccaya ṭṭhena kāraṇa ttā kāraṇa ṭṭhena api āyatanam ti
translated: But it should be understood that the eye, etc., are sense bases in the sense of a reason since they are a reason for contact, etc., in the sense of being its conascence condition, and so on.

original: veditabbaṃ. Manindriyaṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: veditabbam man indriyam vutta ttham eva
translated: The mind base is in the sense stated.

original: Vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ. Viññāṇameva khandho viññāṇakkhandho. Tassa rāsiādivasena attho
analyzed: vijānāti iti viññāṇam viññāṇam eva khandhaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho tassa rāsi ādi vasena attho
translated: Cognition is consciousness . The aggregate of consciousness is the aggregate of consciousness . The meaning should be understood as a mass, and so on.

original: veditabbo. “Mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchatī”ti ettha hi rāsaṭṭhena khandho🔽vutto. “Sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandho”tiādīsu guṇaṭṭhena. “Addasa kho bhagavā mahantaṃ
analyzed: veditabbaḥ mahā udaka khandhaḥ tu eva saṅkham gacchati iti ettha hi rāsaṭṭhena khandho  vuttaḥ sīla kkhandhaḥ samādhi kkhandho ti ādīsu guṇa ṭṭhena addasa kho bhagavā mahantam
translated: For here in the passage, “becomes known as a great mass of water” , a mass is called an aggregate in the sense of a heap.🔽In the passage, “The aggregate of virtue, the aggregate of concentration” , it is a quality that is called an aggregate.🔽In the passage, “The Blessed One saw a great log in the water” , it is a mere concept that is called an aggregate.

original: dārukkhandha”nti ettha paṇṇattimattaṭṭhena. Idha pana rūḷhito khandho vutto. Rāsaṭṭhena
analyzed: dāru khandhanti ettha paṇṇattimatta ṭṭhena idha pana rūḷhitaḥ khandhaḥ vuttaḥ rāsa ṭṭhena
translated: But here a mass is called an aggregate in the sense of a heap.

original: hi viññāṇakkhandhassa ekadeso ekaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Tasmā yathā rukkhassa ekadesaṃ chindanto
analyzed: hi viññāṇa kkhandhassa eka deso ekam viññāṇam tasmā yathā rukkhassa eka desam chindanto
translated: for a single consciousness is a part of the consciousness aggregate. Therefore, just as one who cuts a part of a tree

original: rukkhaṃ chindatīti vuccati, evameva viññāṇakkhandhassa ekadesabhūtaṃ ekampi viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: rukkham chindati iti vuccati evam eva viññāṇa kkhandhassa eka desa bhūtam ekam pi viññāṇam
translated: is said to cut the tree, so too a single consciousness, which is a part of the consciousness aggregate,

original: rūḷhito viññāṇakkhandhoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: rūḷhitaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho ti vuttam
translated: is called the consciousness aggregate.

original: Tajjā manoviññāṇadhātūti tesaṃ phassādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ anucchavikā manoviññāṇadhātu.
analyzed: tajjā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu ti tesam phassa ādīnam dhammānam anucchavikā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: The corresponding mind-consciousness element: the mind-consciousness element that is appropriate to those states beginning with contact.

original: Imasmiñhi pade ekameva cittaṃ minanaṭṭhena mano, vijānanaṭṭhena viññāṇaṃ, sabhāvaṭṭhena
analyzed: imasmin hi pade ekam eva cittam minana ṭṭhena manaḥ vijānana ṭṭhena viññāṇam sabhāva ṭṭhena
translated: For in this passage a single consciousness is called mind in the sense of “that which is contracted” , consciousness in the sense of “that which is aware” ,

original: nissattaṭṭhena vā dhātūti tīhi nāmehi vuttaṃ.🔽Saddhiṃ yugaṃ samāgamanti ekappahārena saddhiṃ. Sammāgantvāti pāpuṇitvā. Yugaggāhaṃ
analyzed: nissatta ṭṭhena vā dhātu iti tīhi nāmehi vuttam  saddhim yugam samāgamanti eka pahārena saddhim sammā āgantvā ati pāpuṇitvā yuga ggāham
translated: and element in the sense of “own-nature” or “non-existence of a being” .

original: gaṇhitvāti yugapaṭibhāgaṃ gahetvā. Sākacchetunti saddhiṃ kathetuṃ. Sallapitunti allāpasallāpaṃ🔽kātuṃ. Sākacchaṃ samāpajjitunti saddhiṃ kathanaṃ paṭipajjituṃ. Na paṭibalabhāve kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhitvā iti yuga paṭibhāgam gahetvā sākacchetum iti saddhim kathetum sallapitum iti allāpa sallāpam 🔽kātum sākaccham samāpajjitum ti saddhim kathanam paṭipajjitum na paṭibala bhāve kāraṇam
translated: Together with its pair: together with its counterpart. Having come together: having reached. Having seized the yoke: having taken up the counterpart. To converse: to talk together. To converse by way of questions and answers: to carry on a discussion. To enter into conversation: to engage in talk together.

original: dassetuṃ “taṃ kissahetu, pasūro paribbājako hīno”tiādimāha. So hi bhagavā aggo cāti🔽asadisadānaaggattā asamānapaññattā aggo ca. Seṭṭho cāti sabbaguṇehi appaṭisamaṭṭhena🔽seṭṭho ca. Mokkho cāti savāsanehi kilesehi muttattā mokkho ca. Uttamo cāti attano
analyzed: dassetum tam kissahetu pasūraḥ paribbājakaḥ hīnaḥ iti ādim āha saḥ hi bhagavā aggaḥ ca ati  asadisa dāna agga ttā asamāna paññattā aggaḥ ca seṭṭhaḥ ca ati sabba guṇehi appaṭisamaṭṭhena  seṭṭho ca mokkho ca ati sa vāsanehi kilesehi mutta ttā mokkho ca uttamo ca ati attano
translated: and to show this he says, “And why? Because the wanderer Pāyāsi is inferior,” and so on. For this Blessed One is the foremost,🔽the best, the supreme, the highest, the most excellent, and the unequalled.

original: uttaritaravirahitattā uttamo ca. Pavaro cāti sabbalokena abhipatthanīyattā pavaro
analyzed: uttaritara virahita ttā uttamo ca pavaro ca ati sabba lokena abhipatthanīya ttā pavaro
translated: He is the foremost because he is the foremost of all givers of gifts. He is the best because he is the best of all beings. He is the supreme because he is the supreme of all beings. He is the highest because he is the highest of all beings. He is the most excellent because he is the most excellent of all beings. He is the unequalled because he is the unequalled of all beings.

original: ca. Mattena mātaṅgenāti pabhinnamadena hatthinā.🔽Kotthukoti jiraṇasiṅgālo. Sīhena migaraññā saddhinti kesarasīhena migarājena saha.🔽Taruṇakoti chāpako. Dhenupakoti khīrapako. Usabhenāti maṅgalasammatena usabhena.
analyzed: ca mattena mātaṅgena ati pabhinna madena hatthinā  kotthukoti jiraṇasiṅgālo sīhena miga raññā kesarasīhena miga rājena saha  taruṇakaḥ uti chāpakaḥ usabhena ati maṅgala sammatena usabhena
translated: With a rutting elephant: with an elephant in rut.🔽With a jackal: with an old jackal. With a lion: with a lion, king of beasts.🔽With a young bull: with a bull. With a calf: with a calf. With a bull: with a bull considered auspicious.

original: Calakakunā saddhinti calamānakakunā saddhiṃ. Dhaṅkoti kāko. Garuḷena venateyyena
analyzed: cala kakunā calamāna kakunā saddhim kākaḥ garuḷena venateyyena
translated: With a crow: with a crow. With a vulture: with a vulture. With a hawk: with a hawk. With a garuḍa: with a garuḍa.

original: saddhinti ettha garuḷenāti jātivasena nāmaṃ. Venateyyenāti gottavasena. Caṇḍāloti
analyzed: ettha garuḷena ati jāti vasena nāmam venateyyena ati gotta vasena
translated: ‘Together with’ means with Garula. ‘Venateyya’ is a clan name. ‘The outcast’ is a

original: chavacaṇḍālo. Raññā cakkavattināti cātuddīpikacakkavattinā. Paṃsupisācakoti kacavarachaḍḍanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: chava caṇḍālaḥ raññā cakkavattinā ati cātuddīpika cakkavattinā paṃsu pisācako ti kaca vara chaḍḍana ṭhāne
translated: dog-keeper. ‘The king who turns the wheel’ is the king who turns the wheel over the four continents. ‘The ghost of the dust-heap’ is a ghost born in a place

original: nibbattako yakkho. Indena devaraññā saddhinti sakkena devarājena saha. So hi bhagavā🔽mahāpaññotiādīni chappadāni heṭṭhā vitthāritāni. Tattha paññāpabhedakusaloti attano🔽anantavikappe paññābhede cheko. Pabhinnañāṇoti anantappabhedapattañāṇo. Etena paññāpabhedakusalattepi
analyzed: nibbattakaḥ yakkhaḥ indena deva raññā saddhinti sakkena devarājena saha saḥ hi bhagavā  mahāpañño ti ādīni chappadāni heṭṭhā vitthāritāni tattha paññā apabheda kusalo ti attano  ananta vikappe paññā bhede chekaḥ pabhinna ñāṇo ti ananta ppabheda patta ñāṇo etena paññā pabheda kusala tte pi
translated: where rubbish is thrown away. ‘Together with’ means with Indra, the king of the gods. He is the Blessed One.

original: sati tāsaṃ paññānaṃ anantabhedattaṃ dasseti. Adhigatapaṭisambhidoti paṭiladdhaaggacatupaṭisambhidañāṇo.
analyzed: sati tāsam paññānam ananta bheda ttam dasseti adhigata paṭisambhidaḥ ti paṭiladdha agga catu paṭisambhida ñāṇo
translated: The Blessed One is ‘endowed with great wisdom’ and so on. The six terms beginning with ‘great wisdom’ are explained below. Therein, ‘skilled in the analysis of wisdom’ means skilled in the analysis of wisdom in his own infinite rebirths. ‘One of expansive knowledge’ means one who has attained knowledge of infinite analysis. By this he shows that although he is skilled in the analysis of wisdom, still the analysis of that wisdom is infinite. ‘One who has attained discernment’ means one who has attained the knowledge of the four discriminations.

original: Catuvesārajjappattoti cattāri visāradabhāvasaṅkhātāni ñāṇāni patto. Yathāha –
analyzed: catu vesārajja patto ti cattāri visārada bhāva saṅkhātāni ñāṇāni pattaḥ yathā āha
translated: ‘One who has attained the fourfold intrepidity’ means one who has attained the four knowledges called ‘intrepidity’. As it is said:

original: “Sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato ‘ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā’ti, tatra vata maṃ samaṇo
analyzed: sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānataḥ ime dhammāḥ an abhisambuddhāḥ ati tatra vata mama samaṇaḥ
translated: “If you claim to be fully enlightened, then these things are not fully awakened to by you.🔽

original: vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti
analyzed: vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā devaḥ vā māraḥ vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmim sahadhammena paṭicodessati iti
translated: “When I claim to be fully enlightened, there is no one — ascetic or brahmin, god, Mara, Brahma, or anyone in the world — who can legitimately say of me:🔽‘You have not realized these things.’

original: nimittametaṃ, bhikkhave, na samanupassāmi, etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto
analyzed: nimittam etam bhikkhave na samanupassāmi etam aham bhikkhave nimittam a samanupassantaḥ
translated: I do not see any grounds for that.

original: khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.🔽“Khīṇāsavassa te paṭijānato ‘ime āsavā aparikkhīṇā’ti…pe… ‘ye kho pana te antarāyikā
analyzed: khema ppattaḥ abhaya ppattaḥ vesārajja ppattaḥ viharāmi  khīṇa asavassa te paṭijānataḥ ime āsavāḥ a parikkhīṇa atipe ye kho pana te antarāyikā
translated: Not seeing any grounds for that, I dwell secure, fearless, & self-confident.🔽“When I claim to be free from effluents, there is no one — ascetic or brahmin, god, Mara, Brahma, or anyone in the world — who can legitimately say of me:🔽‘These effluents are not ended for you.’…🔽‘These qualities that you say are obstructive are not actually obstructive for one who practices them.’…

original: dhammā vuttā, te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyā”ti…pe… yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo
analyzed: dhammāḥ vuttā te paṭisevataḥ na alam antarāyāya atipe yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo
translated: ‘The Dhamma that you teach for the abandoning of effluents does not lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering & stress, to unbinding.’🔽I do not see any grounds for that.

original: desito, so na niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyāti, tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā🔽brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti
analyzed: desitaḥ saḥ na niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkha kkhayāya āti tatra vata mama samaṇaḥ vā 🔽brāhmaṇaḥ vā devaḥ vā māraḥ vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmim sahadhammena paṭicodessati iti
translated: Not seeing any grounds for that,

original: nimittametaṃ, bhikkhave, na samanupassāmi, etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto
analyzed: nimittam etam bhikkhave na samanupassāmi etam aham bhikkhave nimittam a samanupassantaḥ
translated: I do not see that reason, bhikkhus,

original: khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmī”ti.
analyzed: khema ppattaḥ abhaya ppattaḥ vesārajja ppattaḥ viharāmi iti
translated: and not seeing that reason, I dwell secure, fearless, and confident.”

original: Dasabalabaladhārīti dasa balāni etesanti dasabalā, dasabalānaṃ balāni dasabalabalāni,
analyzed: dasa bala bala dhārī iti dasa balāni dasa balāḥ balāni dasa bala balāni
translated: “Possessor of the ten powers’ powers”: those who have these ten powers are the “possessors of the ten powers,” and the powers of the possessors of the ten powers are the “ten powers’ powers.”

original: tāni dasabalabalāni dhārayatīti dasabalabaladhārī, dasabalañāṇabaladhārīti attho.
analyzed: tāni dasa bala balāni dhārayati iti dasa bala bala dhārī dasa bala ñāṇa bala dhārī iti
translated: He “possesses” these ten powers’ powers, thus he is the “possessor of the ten powers’ powers.” The meaning is: he possesses the power of the ten powers’ knowledge.

original: Etehi tīhi vacanehi anantappabhedānaṃ neyyānaṃ pabhedamukhamattaṃ dassitaṃ. Soyeva
analyzed: etehi tīhi vacanehi ananta ppabhedānam neyyānam pabheda mukha mattam dassitam
translated: By means of these three terms the mere entrance to the classification of the infinite kinds of disciples is shown.

original: paññāpayogavasena abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena purisāsabho. Asantāsaṭṭhena purisasīho.
analyzed: paññā apayoga vasena abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena purisa asabhaḥ asantāsa ṭṭhena purisa sīhaḥ
translated: He is the “bull of a man” in the sense of being considered an auspicious object by the use of the term “paññāpa.” He is the “lion of a man” in the sense of being fearless.

original: Mahantaṭṭhena purisanāgo. Pajānanaṭṭhena purisājañño. Lokakiccadhuravahanaṭṭhena purisadhorayho.
analyzed: mahanta ṭṭhena purisa nāgaḥ pajānana ṭṭhena purisa ajaññaḥ loka kicca dhura vahana ṭṭhena purisa dhorayho
translated: He is the “elephant of a man” in the sense of being great. He is the “king of a man” in the sense of being a knower. He is the “leader of a man” in the sense of bearing the burden of the world’s task.🔽Then, desiring to show the special qualities obtained from the infinite knowledge of fire, etc.,

original: Atha tejādikaṃ anantañāṇato laddhaṃ guṇavisesaṃ dassetukāmo tesaṃ tejādīnaṃ anantañāṇamūlabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atha teja ādikam ananta ñāṇataḥ laddham guṇa visesam dassetu kāmo tesam teja ādīnam ananta ñāṇa mūla bhāvam
translated: he said: “The infinite knowledge of fire, etc., is the root of the special qualities of fire, etc.”

original: dassento “anantañāṇo”ti vatvā “anantatejo”tiādimāha. Tattha anantañāṇoti gaṇanavasena🔽ca pabhāvavasena ca antavirahitañāṇo. Anantatejoti veneyyasantāne mohatamavidhamanena🔽anantañāṇatejo. Anantayasoti paññāguṇeheva lokattayavitthatānantakittighoso. Aḍḍhoti🔽paññādhanasamiddhiyā samiddho. Mahaddhanoti paññādhanavaḍḍhattepi pabhāvamahattena🔽mahantaṃ pavattapaññādhanamassāti mahaddhano. “Mahādhano”ti vā pāṭho. Dhanavāti pasaṃsitabbapaññādhanavattā
analyzed: dassentaḥ ananta ñāṇo ti vatvā ananta tejaḥ ti ādim āha tattha ananta ñāṇo ti gaṇana vasena  ca ca veneyya santāne moha tama vidhamanena  ananta ñāṇa tejaḥ ananta yaso ti paññā guṇehi iva lokattaya vitthata ananta kitti ghoso aḍḍho ti  paññādhana samiddhiyā samiddhaḥ mahat dhanoti paññādhana vaḍḍhatte pi pabhāva mahattena  mahantam pavatta paññādhanam assa ati mahat dhanaḥ mahā dhanaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ dhanavā ati pasaṃsitabba paññādhanavattā
translated: and after saying “of infinite knowledge” he says “of infinite splendour” and so on. Herein, of infinite knowledge : his knowledge is without limit either in the sense of number or in the sense of excellence. Of infinite splendour : his knowledge is of infinite splendour in the sense of the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in the mental continuities of those who are teachable. Of infinite fame : his fame is spread out in the three worlds without limit by means of the excellence of his knowledge. Rich : he is rich in the abundance of the wealth of knowledge. Greatly wealthy : his wealth of knowledge is great because of the greatness of his excellence, in other words, he is greatly wealthy. Or alternatively, the reading is “mahādhana” , and the meaning is that he is greatly wealthy because of the greatness of his wealth of knowledge. Possessed of wealth : he is possessed of the wealth of knowledge that is praiseworthy.

original: niccayuttapaññādhanavattā atisayabhāvena paññādhanavattā dhanavā. Etesupi hi tīsu🔽atthesu idaṃ vacanaṃ saddavidū icchanti.
analyzed: nicca yutta paññā dhanavattā atisaya bhāvena paññā dhanavattā dhanavā etesu pi hi tīsu  atthesu idam vacanam sadda vidū icchanti
translated: and after showing his knowledge as infinite, he shows his glory as infinite, etc., in the next line. Herein, his knowledge is infinite in the sense of number and in the sense of greatness, thus his knowledge is infinite . His glory is infinite as the light of knowledge, thus his glory is infinite . His fame is infinite as the sound of his praise spread throughout the three worlds, thus his fame is infinite . He is rich with the wealth of knowledge, thus he is rich . He is wealthy with the wealth of knowledge, thus he is wealthy . The reading “mahādhana” is also allowable. He is wealthy with the wealth of knowledge that is praiseworthy, with the wealth of knowledge that is always useful, with the wealth of knowledge that is pre-eminent, thus he is wealthy . For this statement is desired by those who know the texts as referring to these three meanings.

original: Evaṃ paññāguṇena bhagavato attasampattisiddhiṃ dassetvā puna paññāguṇeneva lokahitasampattisiddhiṃ
analyzed: evam paññā guṇena bhagavataḥ atta sampatti siddhim dassetvā puna paññā guṇena iva loka hita sampatti siddhim
translated: Having thus shown the Blessed One’s success in his own welfare by means of the special quality of his knowledge, he now shows his success in the welfare of the world by means of the same special quality of his knowledge.

original: dassento “netā”tiādimāha. Tattha veneyye saṃsārasaṅkhātabhayaṭṭhānato nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ🔽khemaṭṭhānaṃ netā. Tattha nayanakāle eva saṃvaravinayapahānavinayavasena veneyye🔽vinetā. Dhammadesanākāle eva saṃsayacchedanena anunetā. Saṃsayaṃ chinditvā saññāpetabbaṃ🔽atthaṃ paññāpetā. Tathā paññāpitānaṃ nicchayakaraṇena nijjhāpetā. Tathā nijjhāpitassa
analyzed: dassentaḥ netā iti ādim āha tattha veneyye saṃsāra saṅkhāta bhaya ṭṭhānataḥ nibbāna saṅkhātam  khema ṭṭhānam netā tattha nayana kāle eva saṃvara vinaya pahāna vinaya vasena veneyye  vinetā dhamma desanā kāle eva saṃsaya chedanena anunetā saṃsayam chinditvā saññāpetabbam  attham paññāpetā tathā paññāpitānam nicchaya karaṇena nijjhāpetā tathā nijjhāpitassa
translated: He shows this in the stanza beginning, “The Leader, the Controller, the Guide, the One who shows the way.” Herein, the Leader is he who leads beings from the place of fear called the round of rebirths to the place of security called Nibbāna. The Controller is he who controls beings by the control of restraint and the control of eradication at the time of leading them. The Guide is he who guides beings by the way of the eightfold path at the time of teaching the Dhamma. The One who shows the way is he who shows the way to the city of Nibbāna. The One who knows the way is he who knows the way to the city of Nibbāna. The One who goes the way is he who goes the way to the city of Nibbāna. The One who has crossed over and gone beyond is he who has crossed over and gone beyond the ocean of the round of rebirths. The One who has reached the goal is he who has reached the goal of the welfare of himself and others. The One who has passed beyond the pathways is he who has passed beyond the four pathways.

original: atthassa paṭipattipayojanavasena pekkhetā. Tathāpaṭipanne paṭipattibalena pasādetā.
analyzed: atthassa paṭipatti payojana vasena pekkhetā tathā paṭipanne paṭipatti balena pasādetā
translated: He shows this in the verse beginning with the word “leader.” Herein, he is a leader in the sense of leading to the place of safety, which is Nibbāna, from the place of danger, which is the round of rebirths, for those who are to be led. At the time of leading, he is a trainer in the sense of training those who are to be trained in the training of restraint and in the training of abandoning. At the time of teaching the Dhamma, he is a persuader in the sense of persuading by resolving doubts. Having resolved doubts, he is a demonstrator in the sense of demonstrating the meaning that has to be demonstrated. Having demonstrated it thus, he is a bestower in the sense of bestowing the deathless on those who have been trained. Having bestowed it thus, he is a seer in the sense of seeing the purpose of practice. Having seen it thus, he is a gladdener in the sense of gladdening those who are practising by the power of their practice.

original: So hi bhagavāti ettha hi-kāro anantaraṃ vuttassa atthassa kāraṇopadese nipāto.🔽Anuppannassa maggassa uppādetāti sakasantāne nauppannapubbassa chaasādhāraṇañāṇahetubhūtassa
analyzed: saḥ hi bhagavā iti ettha hikāraḥ anantaram vuttassa atthassa kāraṇa upadese nipātaḥ  anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā ati saka santāne na uppanna pubbassa cha a sādhāraṇa ñāṇa hetu bhūtassa
translated: “He is the Blessed One”: the word “hi” is a particle indicating a reason.

original: ariyamaggassa bodhimūle lokahitatthaṃ sakasantāne uppādetā. Asañjātassa maggassa
analyzed: ariya maggassa bodhi mūle loka hitattham saka santāne uppādetā asañjātassa maggassa
translated: He is the one who causes to arise the path that has not arisen: he is the one who causes to arise in his own mental continuity the noble path, which has not arisen there before, which is the cause of the knowledge that is not shared by disciples, for the sake of the welfare of the world at the foot of the Bodhi Tree. He is the one who causes to arise the path that has not arisen.

original: sañjanetāti veneyyasantāne asañjātapubbassa sāvakapāramīñāṇahetubhūtassa ariyamaggassa
analyzed: sañjanetā ati veneyya santāne a sañjāta pubbassa sāvaka pāramī ñāṇa hetu bhūtassa ariya maggassa
translated: He is the one who causes to arise: he is the one who causes to arise the noble path, which has not arisen before in the mental continuities of disciples, and which is the cause of the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship.

original: dhammacakkappavattanato pabhuti yāvajjakālā veneyyasantāne sañjanetā. Sāvakaveneyyānampi
analyzed: dhamma cakka ppavattanataḥ pabhuti yāvajjakālā veneyya santāne sañjanetā sāvaka veneyyānam pi
translated: From the time of setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma until the end of the world, he is the one who causes to arise in the mental continuities of disciples.

original: hi santāne bhagavatā vuttavacaneneva ariyamaggassa sañjananato bhagavā sañjanetā🔽nāma hoti. Anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātāti aṭṭhadhammasamannāgatānaṃ buddhabhāvāya🔽kathābhinīhārānaṃ bodhisattānaṃ buddhabhāvāya byākaraṇaṃ datvā anakkhātapubbassa
analyzed: hi santāne bhagavatā vutta vacanena iva ariya maggassa sañjananataḥ bhagavā sañjanetā  nāma hoti an akkhātassa maggassa akkhātā ati aṭṭha dhamma samannāgatānam buddha bhāvāya  kathābhinīhārānam bodhisattānam buddha bhāvāya byākaraṇam da tvā an akkhāta pubbassa
translated: For the noble path arises in the mental continuities of disciples through the words spoken by the Blessed One.

original: pāramitāmaggassa “buddho bhavissatī”ti byākaraṇamatteneva bodhimūle uppajjitabbassa🔽ariyamaggassa akkhātā. Ayaṃ nayo paccekabodhisattabyākaraṇepi labbhatiyeva. Maggaññūti
analyzed: pāramitā maggassa buddhaḥ bhavissati iti byākaraṇa mattena iva bodhi mūle uppajjitabbassa  ariya maggassa ayam nayo pacceka bodhisatta byākaraṇe pi
translated: He is the one who has declared the path that was not declared: after giving the prediction of Buddhahood to Bodhisattas who have made a resolution for the sake of Buddhahood and who are endowed with the eight factors, he is the one who has declared the path of the perfections, which was not declared before, by merely giving the prediction, “You will become a Buddha,” of the noble path that should arise at the foot of the Bodhi Tree.🔽This method is also applicable to the prediction of Paccekabuddhas.🔽He is the one who knows the path: he is the one who knows the noble path that he has himself aroused by way of reviewing.

original: paccavekkhaṇāvasena attano uppāditassa ariyamaggassa ñātā. Maggavidūti veneyyasantāne
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇā vasena attano uppāditassa ariya maggassa ñātā magga vidū ti veneyya santāne
translated: He is the one who has travelled the path: he is the one who has travelled the noble path in the mental continuities of disciples.

original: janetabbassa ariyamaggassa kusalo. Maggakovidoti bodhisattānaṃ akkhātabbamagge vicakkhaṇo.🔽Atha vā abhisambodhipaṭipatti maggaññū, paccekabodhipaṭipatti maggavidū, sāvakabodhipaṭipatti
analyzed: janetabbassa ariya maggassa kusalaḥ magga kovidaḥ ti bodhisattānam akkhātabba magge vicakkhaṇaḥ  atha vā abhisambodhi paṭipatti maggaññū pacceka bodhi paṭipatti magga vidū sāvaka bodhi paṭipatti
translated: and he is skilled in the noble path that should be developed. He is skilled in the path of the bodhisattas, he is skilled in the path of the paccekabuddhas, and he is skilled in the path of the disciples.🔽Or alternatively, he is skilled in the path of the development for the supreme enlightenment, he is skilled in the path of the development for the paccekabuddha’s enlightenment, and he is skilled in the path of the development for the disciple’s enlightenment.

original: maggakovido. Atha vā –
analyzed: magga kovidaḥ atha vā
translated: Or alternatively,

original: “Etena maggena tariṃsu pubbe,
analyzed: etena maggena tariṃsu pubbe
translated: “By this path in the past they crossed,

original: Tarissanti ye ca taranti ogha”nti. –🔽Vacanato yathāyogaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannabuddhapaccekabuddhasāvakānaṃ maggavasena
analyzed: tarissanti ye ca taranti oghanti  vacanataḥ yathāyogam atīta anāgata paccuppanna buddha paccekabuddha sāvakānam magga vasena
translated: And those who cross are crossing now the flood” .🔽according as is fitting, by means of the path of the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples of the past, future, and present,

original: ca suññatānimittaappaṇihitamaggavasena ca ugghaṭitaññūvipañcitaññūneyyapuggalānaṃ🔽maggavasena ca yathākkamenettha yojanaṃ karonti. Maggānugā ca panassāti bhagavato
analyzed: ca suñña tā nimitta appaṇihita magga vasena ca ugghaṭita ññū vipañcita ññūneyya puggalānam  magga vasena ca yathākkamena ittha yojanam karonti magga anugā ca bhagavataḥ
translated: and by means of the paths of emptiness, the signless, and the undirected, and by means of the paths of the person who is a discoverer of the apparently evident, the person who is a discoverer of the investigated, and the person who is a discoverer of what is to be done by practice.🔽They explain it in this way in due succession. And he is a follower of the path of the Blessed One:

original: gatamaggānugāmino hutvā. Ettha ca-saddo hetuatthe nipāto, etena ca bhagavatā magguppādanādiguṇādhigamāya
analyzed: gata magga anugāminaḥ hutvā ettha ca saddaḥ hetu atthe nipātaḥ etena ca bhagavatā magga uppādana ādi guṇa adhigamāya
translated: he is a follower of the path gone by the Blessed One. And the word “ca” has the meaning of a causal particle; by means of this path the Blessed One reached the attainment of the special qualities beginning with the generation of the path.

original: hetu vutto hoti. Pana-saddo katatthe nipāto, tena bhagavatā katamaggakaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: hetu vuttaḥ hoti pana saddo kata atthe nipāto tena bhagavatā kata magga karaṇam vuttam
translated: is said. The word ‘but’ is a particle in the sense of ‘that’, and by it is said the Blessed One’s making of the Path.

original: hoti. Pacchā samannāgatāti paṭhamaṃ gatassa bhagavato pacchā sīlādiguṇena samannāgatā.🔽Iti thero “anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā”tiādīhi yasmā sabbepi bhagavato sīlādayo
analyzed: hoti pacchā samannāgatā ati paṭhamam gatassa bhagavato pacchā sīla ādi guṇena samannāgatā  iti theraḥ anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā ati ādīhi yasmā sabbe pi bhagavato sīla ādayaḥ
translated: ‘Later on endowed’ : after the Blessed One had gone, later on endowed with virtue and so on.🔽Thus, because all the Blessed One’s virtues of virtue and so on🔽came about by depending on the path of arahatship, therefore the Elder, by ‘maker of the unmade path’ and so on,

original: guṇā arahattamaggameva nissāya āgatā, tasmā arahattamaggameva nissāya guṇaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: guṇāḥ arahatta maggam eva nissāya āgatā tasmai arahatta maggam eva nissāya guṇam kathesi
translated: explained the virtue by depending on the path of arahatship.

original: Jānaṃ jānātīti jānitabbaṃ jānāti, sabbaññutāya yaṃkiñci paññāya jānitabbaṃ nāma atthi,
analyzed: jānam jānāti iti jānitabbam jānāti sabbaññutāya yaṃ kiñci paññāya jānitabbam nāma atthi
translated: ‘Knowing, he knows’ : he knows what is to be known, and by his omniscience whatever there is that is to be known by understanding,

original: taṃ sabbaṃ pañcaneyyapathabhūtaṃ paññāya jānātīti attho. Passaṃ passatīti passitabbaṃ🔽passati, sabbadassāvitāya taṃyeva neyyapathaṃ cakkhunā diṭṭhaṃ viya karonto paññācakkhunā
analyzed: tam sabbam pañcaneyya patha bhūtam paññāya jānāti iti attho passam passati iti passitabbam  passati sabba dassāvitāya taṃ yeva neyya patham cakkhunā diṭṭham viya karonto paññā cakkhunā
translated: the meaning is that he knows it all by understanding, which is the way to what is to be known. ‘ Seeing, he sees’ : he sees what is to be seen,

original: passatīti attho. Yathā vā ekacco viparītaṃ gaṇhanto jānantopi na jānāti, passantopi
analyzed: passati iti atthaḥ yathā vā ekaccaḥ viparītam gaṇhantaḥ jānantaḥ api na jānāti passantaḥ api
translated: by his all-seeing, making that very way to what is to be known as though it were seen with the eye, he sees it with the eye of understanding, is the meaning. Or just as one who misapprehends, though he knows, does not know,🔽and though he sees, does not see,

original: na passati, na evaṃ bhagavā. Bhagavā pana yathāsabhāvaṃ gaṇhanto jānanto jānātiyeva,
analyzed: na passati na evam bhagavā bhagavā pana yathā sabhāvam gaṇhantaḥ jānantaḥ jānātiyā iva
translated: He does not see, the Blessed One does not. But the Blessed One, taking it as it really is, knowing, knows,

original: passanto passatiyeva. Svāyaṃ nayana pariṇāyakaṭṭhena cakkhubhūto. Viditatādiatthena
analyzed: passantaḥ passatiyā iva cakkhu bhūtaḥ viditatā ādi atthena
translated: seeing, sees. He is the eye because of the function of guiding the eye. He is the knowledge because of the meaning of being known,

original: ñāṇabhūto. Aviparītasabhāvaṭṭhena vā pariyattidhammapavattanato hadayena cintetvā🔽vācāya nicchāritadhammamayoti vā dhammabhūto. Seṭṭhaṭṭhena brahmabhūto. Atha vā cakkhu🔽viya bhūtoti cakkhubhūto. Ñāṇaṃ viya bhūtoti ñāṇabhūto. Aviparītadhammo viya bhūtoti
analyzed: ñāṇa bhūtaḥ aviparīta sabhāva ṭṭhena vā pariyatti dhamma pavattanataḥ hadayena cintetvā  vācāya nicchārita dhamma mayo ti vā dhamma bhūto seṭṭhaṭṭhena brahma bhūtaḥ atha vā cakkhu  viya bhūtoti cakkhu bhūtaḥ ñāṇam viya bhūtoti ñāṇa bhūtaḥ aviparīta dhammaḥ viya bhūtoti
translated: because of the function of turning the known dhammas. Or he is the Dhamma because of the function of being spoken of after thinking with the heart and

original: dhammabhūto. Brahmā viya bhūtoti brahmabhūto. Yvāyaṃ dhammassa vacanato vattanato
analyzed: dhamma bhūtaḥ brahmā viya bhūto ti brahma bhūtaḥ yvā ayam dhammassa vacanataḥ vattanataḥ
translated: after being uttered with speech. He is the Brahma because of the meaning of best. Or he is the eye because of being like the eye. He is the knowledge because of being like knowledge. He is the Dhamma because of being like the undeluded nature. He is the Brahma because of being like Brahma. He who is the speaker because of the utterance of the Dhamma,

original: vā vattā. Nānappakārehi vacanato vattanato vā pavattā. Atthaṃ nīharitvā dassanato
analyzed: vā vattā nānappakārehi vacanataḥ vattanataḥ vā pavattā attham nīharitvā dassanataḥ
translated: or because of the function of the utterance. He is the utterer because of the utterance in various ways. He is the guide of the meaning because of showing the meaning after extracting it.

original: atthassa ninnetā. Amatādhigamāya paṭipattidesanato, amatappakāsanāya vā dhammadesanāya
analyzed: atthassa ninnetā amata adhigamāya paṭipatti desanataḥ amata ppakāsanāya vā dhamma desanāya
translated: Because of teaching the way to the attainment of the deathless, or because of teaching the Dhamma for the manifestation of the deathless,

original: amatassa adhigamāpanato amatassa dātā. Lokuttarassa dhammassa uppāditattā veneyyānurūpena
analyzed: amatassa adhigama āpanataḥ amatassa dātā lokuttarassa dhammassa uppādita ttā veneyya anurūpena
translated: He is the Giver of the Deathless because of the attainment of the Deathless. He is the Revealer of the Deathless because of the revealing of the Deathless to disciples by him. He is the One Who Shows the Way to the Deathless because of showing the way to the Deathless to disciples by him.

original: yathāsukhaṃ lokuttaradhammassa dānena ca dhammesu issaroti dhammassāmī. Tathāgatapadaṃ heṭṭhā vuttatthaṃ.
analyzed: yathāsukham lokuttara dhammassa dānena ca dhammesu issaroti dhammassāmī tathāgata padam heṭṭhā vutta ttham
translated: He is the Giver of the Deathless because he has attained the Deathless. He is the Lord of the Dhamma because he has aroused the supramundane Dhamma and because he gives the supramundane Dhamma to his disciples according to their wish. He is the Master of the Dhamma because he is the master of the Dhamma in all its aspects. The expression “the Tathagata’s word” has the same meaning as given above .

original: Idāni “jānaṃ jānātī”tiādīhi vuttaguṇaṃ sabbaññutāya visesetvā dassetukāmo sabbaññutaṃ
analyzed: idāni jānam jānāti iti ādīhi vutta guṇam sabbaññu tāya visesetvā dassetu kāmo sabbaññu tam
translated: Now, wishing to show by way of omniscience the special quality of the Blessed One, which is stated in the above passage beginning with the words “knowing, he knows,” the author of the commentary,

original: sādhento “natthī”tiādimāha. Evaṃbhūtassa hi tassa bhagavato pāramitāpuññaphalappabhāvanipphannena🔽arahattamaggañāṇena sabbadhammesu savāsanassa sammohassa vihatattā asammohato sabbadhammānaṃ🔽ñātattā aññātaṃ nāma natthi. Tatheva ca sabbadhammānaṃ cakkhunā viya ñāṇacakkhunā
analyzed: sādhentaḥ na atthi itiādim āha evaṃbhūtassa hi tassa bhagavataḥ pāramitā puñña phala ppabhāva nipphannena  arahatta magga ñāṇena sabba dhammesu sa vāsanassa sammohassa vihata ttā a sammohataḥ sabba dhammānaṃ  ñāta ttā aññātam nāma natthi tathā iva ca sabba dhammānam cakkhunā viya ñāṇa cakkhunā
translated: in order to establish omniscience, says “there is nothing that he does not know” , etc. For the Blessed One, who is such, by the knowledge of the path of arahatship, which is the result of the merit of his perfections,🔽has destroyed all the defilements together with their residues in regard to all dhammas. Therefore, because of his non-delusion, there is nothing that he does not know in regard to all dhammas.

original: diṭṭhattā adiṭṭhaṃ nāma natthi. Ñāṇena pattattā aviditaṃ nāma natthi. Asammohasacchikiriyāya
analyzed: diṭṭha ttā adiṭṭham nāma natthi ñāṇena patta ttā aviditam nāma natthi asammoha sacchikiriyāya
translated: And because he has seen all dhammas with the eye of knowledge, as if with the physical eye, there is nothing that he has not seen. Because he has attained all dhammas with knowledge, there is nothing that he has not attained. Because he has realized all dhammas by the realization of non-delusion,

original: sacchikatattā asacchikataṃ nāma natthi. Asammohapaññāya phuṭṭhattā paññāya aphassitaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: sacchikata ttā a sacchikatam nāma natthi a sammoha paññāya phuṭṭha ttā paññāya a phassitam nāma natthi
translated: There is nothing not realized by him, since he has realized the truth. There is nothing not contacted by his knowledge, since he has contacted it with his knowledge free from confusion.

original: Paccuppannanti paccuppannaṃ kālaṃ vā dhammaṃ vā. Upādāyāti ādāya, antokatvāti attho.
analyzed: paccuppannam ti paccuppannam kālam vā dhammam vā upādāya ati ādāya antokatvā iti attho
translated: Present: either the present time or a present state. In dependence on: taking, meaning including.

original: Upādāyavacaneneva kālavinimuttaṃ nibbānampi gahitameva hoti. “Atītā”divacanāni ca
analyzed: upādāya vacanena iva kāla vinimuttam nibbānam pi gahitam eva hoti atīta ādi vacanāni ca
translated: By the words “in dependence on” Nibbāna, which is free from time, is included too. The words “past” and so on🔽are confirmed by the words “there is no” and so on, or by the words “all” and so on.

original: “natthī”tiādivacaneneva ghaṭiyanti, “sabbe”tiādivacanena vā. Sabbe dhammāti sabbasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatadhammapariyādānaṃ.
analyzed: natthi iti ādi vacanena iva ghaṭiyanti sabbe iti ādi vacanena vā sabbe dhammā ati sabba saṅkhata asaṅkhata dhamma pariyādānam
translated: All dhammas: all formed and unformed dhammas without exception.

original: Sabbākārenāti sabbadhammesu ekekasseva dhammassa aniccākārādisabbākārapariyādānaṃ.
analyzed: sabba ākārena ati sabba dhammesu ekekassa iva dhammassa anicca ākāra ādi sabba ākāra pariyādānam
translated: In all aspects: in all the aspects of impermanence, etc., of each of the dhammas without exception.

original: Ñāṇamukheti ñāṇābhimukhe. Āpāthaṃ āgacchantīti osaraṇaṃ upenti. Jānitabbanti padaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa mukhā iti ñāṇa abhimukhe āpātham āgacchanti iti osaraṇam upenti jānitabbanti padam
translated: Facing the knowledge: facing the knowledge. Coming into range: approaching the range. Should be known: the word “known”

original: neyyanti padassa atthavivaraṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: neyyan ti padassa attha vivaraṇa attham vuttam
translated: is said for the purpose of explaining the meaning of the word “known.”

original: Attattho vātiādīsu vā-saddo samuccayattho. Attatthoti attano attho. Paratthoti paresaṃ
analyzed: atta atthaḥ vā iti ādīsu vā saddo samuccaya tthaḥ atta atthaḥ ti attanaḥ attho para tthaḥ ti paresam
translated: In the passage beginning “The meaning of self” the word “and” has the conjunctive sense. The meaning of self: the meaning of self. The meaning of other: the meaning of another.

original: tiṇṇaṃ lokānaṃ attho. Ubhayatthoti attano ca paresañcāti sakiṃyeva ubhinnaṃ attho.🔽Diṭṭhadhammikoti diṭṭhadhamme niyutto, diṭṭhadhammappayojano vā attho. Samparāye
analyzed: tiṇṇam lokānam attho ubhayattho ti attanaḥ ca paresam ca ati sakiṃyeva ubhinnam  diṭṭhadhammikaḥ ti diṭṭhadhamme niyuttaḥ diṭṭhadhamma ppayojanaḥ vā attho samparāye
translated: for the benefit of the three worlds. For the benefit of both: for the benefit of both oneself and others.🔽In this very life: devoted to this very life, or the meaning is: employed in this very life. In the life to come: devoted to the life to come, or employed in the life to come.

original: niyutto, samparāyappayojano vā samparāyiko. Uttānotiādīsu vohāravasena vattabbo sukhapatiṭṭhattā🔽uttāno. Vohāraṃ atikkamitvā vattabbo suññatāpaṭisaṃyutto dukkhapatiṭṭhattā gambhīro.
analyzed: niyuttaḥ samparāya payojanaḥ vā samparāyikaḥ uttānaḥ ti ādīsu vohāra vasena vattabbo sukha patiṭṭha ttā  uttānaḥ vohāram atikkamitvā vattabbaḥ suñña tā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ dukkha patiṭṭha ttā gambhīro
translated: The obvious: it is called “obvious” because it is easy to understand by way of the conventional.🔽The profound: it is called “profound” because it is difficult to understand by way of the supramundane.

original: Lokuttaro accantatirokkhattā gūḷho. Aniccatādiko ghanādīhi paṭicchannattā paṭicchanno.
analyzed: lokuttaraḥ gūḍhaḥ anicca tā ādikaḥ ghana ādīhi paṭicchanna ttā paṭicchannaḥ
translated: The hidden: it is called “hidden” because it is very hidden.

original: Apacuravohārena vattabbo yathārutaṃ aggahetvā adhippāyassa netabbato neyyo. Pacuravohārena
analyzed: a pacuravohārena vattabbaḥ yathārutam aggahetvā adhippāyassa netabbataḥ neyyaḥ pacuravohārena
translated: The recondite: it is called “recondite” because it is to be understood by way of the intention, not by taking the words literally.

original: vattabbo vacanamatteneva adhippāyassa nītattā nīto. Suparisuddhasīlasamādhivipassanattho
analyzed: vattabbaḥ vacana mattena iva adhippāyassa nīta ttā nītaḥ su parisuddha sīla samādhi vipassana attho
translated: The explicit: it is called “explicit” because the intention is understood by the words.

original: tadaṅgavikkhambhanavasena vajjavirahitattā anavajjo. Kilesasamucchedanato ariyamaggattho
analyzed: tad aṅga vikkhambhana vasena vajja virahita ttā anavajjaḥ kilesa samucchedanataḥ ariya magga tthaḥ
translated: It is blameless since it is free from blame by reason of the suppression of the states associated with it. It is not subject to cankers since it is the meaning of the noble path.

original: nakkileso. Kilesapaṭippassaddhattā ariyaphalattho vodāno. Saṅkhatāsaṅkhatesu aggadhammattā🔽nibbānaṃ paramattho. Parivattatīti buddhañāṇassa visayabhāvato abahibhūtattā antobuddhañāṇe
analyzed: na kilesaḥ kilesa paṭippassaddha ttā ariya phala atthaḥ vodāno saṅkhata asaṅkhatesu agga dhamma ttā  nibbānam paramattho parivattati iti buddha ñāṇassa visaya bhāvataḥ a bahibhūta ttā anto buddha ñāṇe
translated: It is purified since it is the meaning of the noble fruit by reason of the tranquilization of cankers. It is the ultimate meaning since it is the supreme state among the formed and the formless.

original: byāpitvā vā samantā vā alaṅkaritvā vā visesena vā vattati.🔽“Sabbaṃ kāyakamma”ntiādīhi bhagavato ñāṇavisayataṃ dasseti. Ñāṇānuparivattīti ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: byāpitvā vā samantā vā alaṅkaritvā vā visesena vā vattati  sabbam kāya kamma nti ādīhi bhagavataḥ ñāṇa visaya tam dasseti ñāṇa anuparivattī iti ñāṇam
translated: It revolves in the Buddha’s knowledge since it is not excluded from being the province of the Buddha’s knowledge. It revolves in the Buddha’s knowledge by pervading it, or by adorning it all round, or by occurring in a distinguished way.

original: anuparivatti, ñāṇavirahitaṃ na hotīti attho. Appaṭihatanti nirāvaraṇataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: anuparivatti ñāṇa virahitam na hoti iti attho appaṭihatam ti nirāvaraṇa tam dasseti
translated: “All bodily action” and so on show the Buddha’s knowledge as the province of the Buddha’s knowledge. It revolves in the knowledge since it is not without knowledge. The meaning is that it is not without knowledge. It is unobstructed shows that it is without obstruction.

original: Puna sabbaññutaṃ upamāya sādhetukāmo “yāvataka”ntiādimāha. Tattha jānitabbanti neyyaṃ.
analyzed: puna sabbaññu tam upamāya sādhetu kāmaḥ yāvatakanti ādim āha tattha jānitabbam ti na iyyam
translated: Again, wishing to prove omniscience by means of a simile, he said “As far as” and so on. Herein, what is to be known is the knowable.

original: Neyyapariyanto neyyāvasānamassa atthīti neyyapariyantikaṃ. Asabbaññūnaṃ pana neyyāvasānameva
analyzed: neyya pariyantaḥ neyya avasānam assa atthi iti neyya pariyantikam asabbaññūnam pana neyya avasānam eva
translated: It has an end of the knowable, a limit of the knowable, thus it is the end of the knowable. But for those who are not omniscient, the end of the knowable is

original: natthi. Ñāṇapariyantikepi eseva nayo. Purimayamake vuttatthameva iminā yamakena visesetvā🔽dasseti, tatiyayamakena paṭisedhavasena niyametvā dasseti. Ettha ca neyyaṃ ñāṇassa
analyzed: natthi ñāṇa pariyantike pi esa iva nayo purima yamake vutta ttham eva iminā yamakena visesetvā  dasseti tatiya yamakena paṭisedha vasena niyametvā dasseti ettha ca na iyyam ñāṇassa
translated: There is none. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the knowledge of the future. The third pair shows the same thing by way of negation.🔽Herein, the path of intimation is so called because it is the path of the knowledge of what is intimated.

original: pathattā neyyapatho. Aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyinoti neyyañca ñāṇañca khepetvā ṭhānato🔽aññamaññassa pariyante ṭhānasīlā.🔽Āvajjanapaṭibaddhāti manodvārāvajjanāyattā, āvajjitānantarameva jānātīti attho. Ākaṅkhapaṭibaddhāti🔽ruciāyattā, āvajjanānantaraṃ javanañāṇena jānātīti attho. Itarāni dve padāni imesaṃ🔽dvinnaṃ padānaṃ yathākkamena atthappakāsanatthaṃ vuttāni. Āsayaṃ jānātīti ettha āsayanti
analyzed: pathattā neyya pathaḥ aññamañña pariyanta ṭṭhāyino ti neyyam ca ñāṇam ca khepetvā ṭhānato  aññamaññassa pariyante ṭhāna sīlā  āvajjana paṭibaddhā ati manaḥ dvāra āvajjana āyattā āvajjita anantaram eva jānāti iti attho ākaṅkha paṭibaddhā ati  ruci āyattā āvajjana anantaram javana ñāṇena jānāti iti itarāni dve padāni imesam  dvinnam padānam yathākkamena attha ppakāsana attham vuttāni āsayam jānāti iti ettha āsayanti
translated: Having excluded both the intimated and the knowledge of it, the other two terms are respectively the habit of being situated at the end of each other and the habit of being situated at the end of the other’s situation.🔽The first pair is called “bound up with adverting” because it is dependent on the adverting of the mind-door. The meaning is that it is known immediately next to the adverting. The second pair is called “bound up with desire” because it is dependent on desire. The meaning is that it is known by the impulsion- impulsions of the javanas immediately next to the adverting. The other two terms are stated in order to illustrate respectively the meaning of these two pairs of terms.

original: nissayanti etthāti āsayo, micchādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhiyā kāmādīhi nekkhammādīhi vā
analyzed: nissayanti ettha ati āsayaḥ micchādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhiyā kāma ādīhi nekkhamma ādīhi vā
translated: Herein, the meaning of “knowing the inclination” is this. The inclination is that on which one insists;🔽or the inclination is that to which one is attached. The meaning is that it is known by the knowledge of impulsion immediately next to the adverting.

original: paribhāvitassa santānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sattasantānaṃ anusenti anupavattentīti
analyzed: paribhāvitassa santānassa itam adhivacanam satta santānam anusenti anupavattenti iti
translated: and this is a term for the stream that has been saturated. They follow along with the stream of being, they occur in continuity with it, thus they are underlying tendencies ;

original: anusayā, thāmagatānaṃ kāmarāgādīnaṃva etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Anusayaṃ jānātīti anusayakathā heṭṭhā vuttāyeva.
analyzed: etam adhivacanam anusayam jānāti iti anusaya kathā heṭṭhā vuttāya iva
translated: and this is a term for lust, etc., that have become chronic. He knows the underlying tendency, thus the explanation of the underlying tendency is given below.

original: Caritanti pubbe katakusalākusalakammaṃ. Adhimuttinti sampati kusale akusale vā cittavosaggo.🔽Apparajakkheti paññāmaye akkhimhi appaṃ rāgādirajo etesanti apparajakkhā. Appaṃ rāgādirajo🔽etesanti vā apparajakkhā, te apparajakkhe. Mahārajakkheti ñāṇamaye akkhimhi mahantaṃ
analyzed: caritanti pubbe kata kusala akusala kammam adhimuttinti sampati kusale akusale vā citta vosaggo  apparajakkha iti paññā maye akkhimhi appam rāga ādi rajaḥ etesanti apparajakkhāḥ appam rāga ādi rajaḥ  vā apparajakkhāḥ te apparajakkhe mahārajakkha iti ñāṇa maye akkhimhi mahantam
translated: Conduct is profitable and unprofitable kamma done formerly. Bent on is the mind’s leaning towards profitable or unprofitable things in the present.🔽Little dust: they have little dust of lust, etc., in the eye of understanding, thus they are of little dust. Or alternatively, they have little dust in the eye of understanding, thus they are of little dust. They are of little dust,

original: rāgādirajo etesanti mahārajakkhā. Mahantaṃ rāgādirajo etesanti vā mahārajakkhā, te
analyzed: rāga ādi rajaḥ mahārajakkhāḥ mahantam rāga ādi rajaḥ vā mahārajakkhāḥ te
translated: Great dust: they have much dust of lust, etc., in the eye of understanding, thus they are of great dust. Or alternatively, they have much dust in the eye of understanding, thus they are of great dust. They are of great dust.

original: mahārajakkhe. Tikkhindriye mudindriyeti tikkhāni saddhādīni indriyāni etesanti tikkhindriyā.
analyzed: mahārajakkhe tikkha indriye mud indriya iti tikkhāni saddhā ādīni indriyāni etesanti tikkha indriyā
translated: Sharp faculties, blunt faculties: they have sharp faith, etc., thus they are of sharp faculties. They are of sharp faculties.

original: Mudūni saddhādīni indriyāni etesanti mudindriyā. Svākāre dvākāreti sundarā saddhādayo🔽ākārā koṭṭhāsā etesanti svākārā. Kucchitā garahitā asaddhādayo ākārā koṭṭhāsā etesanti
analyzed: mudūni saddhā ādīni indriyāni su ākāre dvi ākārā iti  ākārā koṭṭhāsāḥ su ākārā kucchitāḥ garahitāḥ asaddha ādayaḥ ākārā koṭṭhāsāḥ etesanti
translated: Those with soft faculties are mudindriya. Those with beautiful aspects are svākārā.

original: dvākārā. Suviññāpaye duviññāpayeti ye kathitaṃ kāraṇaṃ sallakkhenti sukhena sakkā🔽honti viññāpetuṃ, te suviññāpayā. Tabbiparītā duviññāpayā. Bhabbābhabbeti bhabbe🔽ca abhabbe ca. Ariyāya jātiyā bhavanti jāyantīti bhabbā. Vattamānasamīpe vattamānavacanaṃ.🔽Bhavissanti jāyissanti vāti bhabbā, bhājanabhūtāti attho. Ye ariyamaggapaṭivedhassa
analyzed: dvi ākārā su viññāpaye du viññāpayeti ye kathitam kāraṇam sallakkhenti sukhena sakkā  honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayā tad biparītāḥ du viññāpayā bhabba abhabbā iti bhabbe  ca abhabbe ca ariyāya jātiyā bhavanti jāyanti iti bhabbāḥ vattamāna samīpe vattamāna vacanam  bhavissanti jāyissanti vā ati bhabbāḥ bhājana bhūtā ti atthaḥ ye ariya magga paṭivedhassa
translated: Those with ugly aspects are dvākārā. Those who are easy to admonish are suviññāpayā. Those who are difficult to admonish are duviññāpayā. Those who are capable and incapable are bhabbābhabbā.🔽Those who are capable are bhabbā. Those who are incapable are abhabbā. Those who are capable are those who are born or will be born in the noble lineage. The present tense is used in the vicinity of the future tense.

original: anucchavikā upanissayasampannā, te bhabbā. Vuttapaṭipakkhā abhabbā.
analyzed: anucchavikāḥ upanissaya sampannā te bhabbāḥ vutta paṭipakkhāḥ abhabbā
translated: Those who are capable are those who will be born or will be born in the future. The meaning is: they are vessels. Those who are suitable for penetrating the noble path and are endowed with the necessary conditions are capable. Those who are the opposite of what has been said are incapable.

original: Satte pajānātīti rūpādike ārammaṇe lagge laggite satte pajānāti. Sadevako lokoti
analyzed: satte pajānāti iti rūpa ādike ārammaṇe lagge laggite satte pajānāti sa devakaḥ
translated: He knows beings: he knows beings who are attached to objects such as form.

original: saha devehi sadevako. Saha mārena samārako. Saha brahmunā sabrahmako. Saha samaṇabrāhmaṇehi🔽sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī. Pajātattā pajā. Saha devamanussehi sadevamanussā. “Pajā”ti sattalokassa🔽pariyāyavacanametaṃ. Tattha sadevakavacanena pañcakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ, samārakavacanena🔽chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ. Sabrahmakavacanena brahmakāyikādibrahmaggahaṇaṃ. Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇīvacanena
analyzed: saha devehi sa devakaḥ saha mārena sa mārakaḥ saha brahmunā sa brahmakaḥ saha samaṇa brāhmaṇehi  sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇī pajāta ttā pajā saha deva manussehi sa deva manussā pajāti satta lokassa  pariyāya vacanam etam tattha sa devaka vacanena pañca kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam sa māraka vacanena  chaṭṭha kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam sa brahmaka vacanena brahmakāyika ādi brahma ggahaṇam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇī vacanena
translated: together with the gods, together with the world of Brahmas, together with all beings, together with the generation of devas and men.🔽The word pajā is a synonym for the world of beings.

original: sāsanassa paccatthikapaccāmittasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇaṃ samitapāpabāhitapāpasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇañca.
analyzed: sāsanassa paccatthika pacca amitta samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam samita pāpa bāhita pāpa samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam ca
translated: Herein, the word “together with the gods” includes the five kinds of deities of the sense sphere. The word “together with Māra” includes the six kinds of sense-sphere deities. The word “together with Brahmā” includes the deities of the Brahmā-world. The word “together with recluses and brahmans” includes the recluses and brahmans who are enemies and adversaries of the Dispensation, and also those who have abandoned evil and are free from evil.

original: Pajāvacanena sattalokaggahaṇaṃ. Sadevamanussavacanena sammutidevaavasesamanussaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pajā vacanena satta loka ggahaṇam sa deva manussa vacanena sammuti deva avasesa manussa ggahaṇam
translated: The word “together with the generation” includes the world of beings. The word “together with devas and men” includes the generally recognized devas and the rest of mankind.

original: Evamettha tīhi padehi okāsaloko. Dvīhi pajāvasena sattaloko gahitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha tīhi padehi okāsa lokaḥ dvīhi pajā vasena satta lokaḥ gahitaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: Thus the three terms should be understood to include the world of the physical basis, and the two terms the world of beings.

original: Aparo nayo – sadevakaggahaṇena arūpāvacaraloko gahito, samārakaggahaṇena chakāmāvacaraloko,🔽sabrahmakaggahaṇena rūpāvacarabrahmaloko, sassamaṇabrāhmaṇādiggahaṇena catuparisavasena
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sa devaka ggahaṇena arūpāvacara lokaḥ gahitaḥ sa māraka ggahaṇena cha kāmāvacara loko  sa brahmaka ggahaṇena rūpāvacara brahma lokaḥ sa samaṇa brāhmaṇa ādi ggahaṇena catu parisa vasena
translated: Another method: the world of beings in the immaterial sphere is included by the words “with its gods”; the world of beings in the six sense sphere, by the words “with its Māras”;🔽the world of beings in the fine-material sphere, by the words “with its Brahmās”; and the world of human beings together with the gods of popular tradition, by the words “with its ascetics and brahmins.”

original: sammutidevehi vā saha manussaloko, avasesasabbasattaloko vā. Api cettha sadevakavacanena
analyzed: sammuti devehi vā saha manussa lokaḥ avasesa sabba satta lokaḥ vā api ca ittha sa devaka vacanena
translated: Or else, the words “with its gods” include the whole world of beings,

original: ukkaṭṭhaparicchedato sabbassapi lokassa antobuddhañāṇe parivattanabhāvaṃ sādheti.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha paricchedato sabbassa api lokassa antar buddha ñāṇe parivattana bhāvam sādheti
translated: for they are a term that includes the highest beings.

original: Tato yesaṃ siyā “māro mahānubhāvo chakāmāvacarissaro vasavattī, kiṃ sopi antobuddhañāṇe
analyzed: tatas yesam siyā māraḥ mahā anubhāvo vasa vattī kim saḥ api antar buddha ñāṇe
translated: But if anyone should think, “Māra is powerful, the lord of the beings in the sense sphere, all-powerful. Is he too included in the Buddha’s knowledge?”

original: parivattatī”ti. Tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamento “samārako”ti āha. Yesaṃ pana siyā “brahmā🔽mahānubhāvo, ekaṅguliyā ekasmiṃ cakkavāḷasahasse ālokaṃ pharati. Dvīhi…pe… dasahi
analyzed: parivattati iti tesam vimatim vidhamento āha yesam pana siyā brahmā  mahā anubhāvaḥ ekaṅguliyā ekasmin cakkavāḷa sahasse ālokam pharati dvīhipe dasahi
translated: the words “with its Māras” are stated to remove his uncertainty. But if anyone should think, “Brahmā is powerful,🔽he illuminates a world system of a thousand worlds with one finger, with two fingers … with ten fingers,

original: aṅgulīhi dasasu cakkavāḷasahassesu ālokaṃ pharati, anuttarañca jhānasamāpattisukhaṃ
analyzed: aṅgulīhi dasasu cakkavāḷa sahassesu ālokam pharati anuttaram ca jhāna samāpatti sukham
translated: and he experiences the bliss of the unsurpassed jhāna attainments,”

original: paṭisaṃvedeti, kiṃ sopi antobuddhañāṇe parivattatī”ti. Tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamento “sabrahmako”ti🔽āha. Tato yesaṃ siyā “puthū samaṇabrāhmaṇā sāsanapaccatthikā, kiṃ tepi antobuddhañāṇe
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedeti kim saḥ api antar buddha ñāṇe parivattati iti tesam vimatim vidhamento  āha tatas yesam siyā puthū samaṇa brāhmaṇā sāsana paccatthikā kim te pi antar buddha ñāṇe
translated: Does he too revolve in the Buddha’s knowledge? ” In order to remove their doubt he said “together with Brahma” .

original: parivattantī”ti. Tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamento “sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā”ti āha.🔽Evaṃ ukkaṭṭhānaṃ antobuddhañāṇe parivattanabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā atha sammutideve avasesamanusse
analyzed: parivattanti iti tesam vimatim vidhamentaḥ āha  evam ukkaṭṭhānam antar buddha ñāṇe parivattana bhāvam pakāsetvā atha sammuti deve avasesa manusse
translated: Then, in order to remove the doubt of those who might think “There are many ascetics and brahmins who are adversaries of the Dispensation. Do they too revolve in the Buddha’s knowledge? ” he said “together with ascetics and brahmins” .

original: ca upādāya ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena sesasattalokassa antobuddhañāṇe parivattanabhāvaṃ🔽pakāsento “sadevamanussā”ti āha. Ayamettha anusandhikkamo. Porāṇā panāhu “sadevakoti🔽devatāhi saddhiṃ avasesaloko. Samārakoti mārena saddhiṃ avasesaloko. Sabrahmakoti
analyzed: ca upādāya ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena sesa satta lokassa antar buddha ñāṇe parivattana bhāvam  pakāsentaḥ sa deva manussā iti āha ayam ettha anusandhi kkamaḥ porāṇā pana āhu sa devakā iti  devatāhi saddhim avasesa loko sa mārako ti mārena saddhim avasesa loko sa brahmako ti
