translated: Having thus shown the revolving of the highest in the Buddha’s knowledge, he then said “together with the world of men and gods” in order to show the revolving of the rest of the world of beings, by way of the highest limit, beginning with the gods of the sense-sphere and the rest of men.

original: brahmehi saddhiṃ avasesaloko. Evaṃ sabbepi tibhavūpage satte tīhākārehi tīsu padesu
analyzed: brahmehi saddhim avasesa lokaḥ evam sabbe pi ti bhava upage satte tīha ākārehi tīsu padesu
translated: This is the sequence of the connection here. But the ancients said: “Together with the gods means together with the rest of the world together with the gods. Together with Mara means together with the rest of the world together with Mara. Together with Brahma means together with the rest of the world together with Brahma. Thus all beings in the three worlds are included in three ways in three places.

original: pakkhipitvā puna dvīhākārehi pariyādātuṃ ‘sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā’ti
analyzed: pakkhipitvā puna dvīhākārehi pariyādātum sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇī pajā sa deva manussā ati
translated: and then again in two ways, ‘the world with its devas and men’ is exhausted.

original: vuttaṃ. Evaṃ pañcahi padehi tena tena ākārena tedhātukameva pariyādinnaṃ hotī”ti.🔽Antamasoti uparimantena. Timitimiṅgalanti ettha timi nāma ekā macchajāti, timiṃ gilituṃ🔽samatthā tato mahantasarīrā timiṅgalā nāma ekā macchajāti, timiṅgalampi gilituṃ samatthā🔽pañcayojanasatikasarīrā timitimiṅgalā nāma ekā macchajāti. Idha jātiggahaṇena ekavacanaṃ🔽katanti veditabbaṃ. Garuḷaṃ venateyyanti ettha garuḷoti jātivasena nāmaṃ. Venateyyoti
analyzed: vuttam evam pañcahi padehi tena tena ākārena tedhātukam eva pariyādinnam hoti iti  ettha timi nāma ekā timim gilitum  samatthā tatas mahanta sarīrā timiṅgalā nāma ekā maccha jāti gilitum samatthā  pañca yojana satika sarīrā timitimiṅgalā nāma ekā maccha jāti idha jāti ggahaṇena ekavacanam  katam ti veditabbam garuḷam venateyyanti ettha garuḷo iti jāti vasena nāmam venateyyo ti
translated: So the three worlds are exhausted in these five ways in these various ways.”

original: gottavasena. Padeseti ekadese. Sāriputtasamāti sabbabuddhānaṃ dhammasenāpatitthere
analyzed: gotta vasena padese ti ekadese sāriputta samā ati sabba buddhānam dhammasenāpati there
translated: “In the end”: with the upper end. “Timi and timiṅgala”: here timi is a kind of fish, and timiṅgalas are a kind of fish with a larger body than timis and able to swallow them. Timitimiṅgalas are a kind of fish with a body five leagues long and able to swallow timiṅgalas. Here the singular number in “fish” should be understood as a conventional singular. “Garuḍa and Veta,” here garuḍa is the name for a species, and Veta is the clan name. “In a part”: in one part. “Like Sāriputta,” this should be understood as said by way of taking the Elder Sāriputta, the chief of the Dhamma among all the Buddhas.🔽For the other disciples are not called “like Sāriputta”

original: gahetvā vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Sesasāvakā hi paññāya dhammasenāpatittherena samā nāma
analyzed: gahetvā vuttan ti veditabbam sesa sāvakāḥ hi paññāya dhammasenāpati therena samāḥ nāma
translated: because of their wisdom.

original: natthi. Yathāha – “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ mahāpaññānaṃ yadidaṃ
analyzed: na atthi yathā āha etat aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam bhikkhūnam mahā paññānam yat idam
translated: There is none. As it is said: “The most possessed of great wisdom among my bhikkhu disciples is Sāriputta” .

original: sāriputto”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyañca vuttaṃ –
analyzed: sāriputto ti aṭṭhakathāyañca vuttam
translated: And in the Commentary it is said:🔽Except the Lord of the World,

original: “Lokanāthaṃ ṭhapetvāna, ye caññe santi pāṇino;
analyzed: lokanātham ṭhapetvāna ye caññe santi pāṇino
translated: No other being can🔽Compare with a sixteenth part

original: Paññāya sāriputtassa, kalaṃ nāgghanti soḷasi”nti.🔽Pharitvāti buddhañāṇaṃ sabbadevamanussānampi paññaṃ pāpuṇitvā ṭhānato tesaṃ paññaṃ🔽pharitvā byāpitvā tiṭṭhati. Abhibhavitvāti sabbadevamanussānampi paññaṃ atikkamitvā,
analyzed: paññāya sāriputtassa kalam na agghanti soḷasinti  pharitvā ti buddha ñāṇam sabba deva manussānam pi paññam pāpuṇitvā ṭhānataḥ tesam paññam  pharitvā byāpitvā tiṭṭhati abhibhavitvā ati sabba deva manussānam pi paññam atikkamitvā
translated: Of Sāriputta’s wisdom.

original: tesaṃ avisayabhūtampi sabbaṃ neyyaṃ abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhatīti attho.
analyzed: tesam avisaya bhūtam api sabbam neyyam abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati iti attho
translated: “Having pervaded”: having reached the wisdom of all gods and men, it stands pervading, extending, their wisdom. “Having overcome”: having surpassed the wisdom of all gods and men, it stands, having overcome all the knowable that is not within their range.

original: Paṭisambhidāyaṃ pana “atighaṃsitvā”ti pāṭho, ghaṃsitvā tuditvāti attho. Yepi tetiādīhi🔽evaṃ pharitvā abhibhavitvā ṭhānassa paccakkhakāraṇaṃ dasseti. Tattha paṇḍitāti paṇḍiccena
analyzed: paṭisambhidā ayam pana atighaṃsitvā iti pāṭhaḥ ghaṃsitvā tuditvā ati atthaḥ ye pi te iti ādīhi 🔽evam pharitvā abhibhavitvā ṭhānassa paccakkha kāraṇam dasseti tattha paṇḍitā ti paṇḍiccena
translated: But in the Paṭisambhidā the reading is “having overcome” , the meaning being “having cut through, having broken through.”🔽By the words “and those who are reckoned as wise” he shows the reason for the fact that the wisdom of the Elder Sāriputta stands out pre-eminent.🔽Herein, “wise” means endowed with wisdom.

original: samannāgatā. Nipuṇāti saṇhasukhumabuddhino sukhume atthantare paṭivijjhanasamatthā.
analyzed: samannāgatā nipuṇāti saṇha sukhuma buddhinaḥ sukhume atthantare paṭivijjhana samatthā
translated: and they are skilled in the sense that they are gentle and subtle in their understanding, and they are able to penetrate subtle meanings.

original: Kataparappavādāti viññātaparappavādā ceva parehi saddhiṃ katavādaparicayā ca. Vālavedhirūpāti
analyzed: kata para ppavādā ati viññāta para ppavādā ca iva parehi saddhim kata vāda paricayā ca vālavedhi rūpā ati
translated: They are versed in other doctrines in the sense that they have understood other doctrines and have had practice in discussion with others.🔽They are like a hair-splitting arrow in the sense that they are like an arrow that splits a hair.

original: vālavedhidhanuggahasadisā. Vo bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatānīti
analyzed: vāla vedhi dhanuggaha sadisāḥ vaḥ bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhi gatāni iti
translated: They seem to go about splitting views with the view of their own wisdom.

original: vālavedhī viya vālaṃ sukhumānipi paresaṃ diṭṭhigamanāni attano paññāgamanena bhindantā
analyzed: vāla vedhī viya vālam sukhumāni api paresam diṭṭhi gamanāni attanaḥ paññā gamanena bhindantā
translated: The meaning is that they go about splitting even the subtle views of others with the view of their own wisdom, as if with an arrow that splits a hair.

original: viya carantīti attho. Atha vā “gūthagataṃ muttagata”ntiādīsu viya paññā eva paññāgataṃ.
analyzed: viya caranti iti attho atha vā gūtha gatam mutta gatam ti ādīsu viya paññā eva paññā gatam
translated: Or else, “the view of their own wisdom” is wisdom itself, as in the case of such expressions as “in the urine” and “in the excrement.”🔽“The views” are the views of others.

original: Diṭṭhiyo eva diṭṭhigatāni. Pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvāti dvipadampi tipadampi
analyzed: diṭṭhiyaḥ eva diṭṭhi gatāni pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvā ati dvipadam pi tipadam pi
translated: Having framed the questions, having framed the questions: having composed the questions in twos, threes, and fours.

original: catupadampi pucchaṃ racayitvā tesaṃ pañhānaṃ atibahukattā sabbasaṅgahatthaṃ dvikkhattuṃ
analyzed: catu padam pi puccham racayitvā tesam pañhānam ati bahuka ttā sabba saṅga hattham dvi kkhattum
translated: Because of the great number of questions, the expression “having framed the questions” is used twice in order to include all.🔽The reading “the hidden and the concealed” is an alternative reading.

original: vuttaṃ. Gūḷhāni ca paṭicchannāni ca atthajātānīti pāṭhaseso. Tesaṃ tathā vinayaṃ
analyzed: vuttam gūḷhāni ca paṭicchannāni ca attha jātāni iti pāṭha sesaḥ tesam tathā vinayam
translated: The meaning of the words is this: They go about splitting the views of others with the view of their own wisdom, as if with an arrow that splits a hair.

original: disvā attanā abhisaṅkhataṃ pañhaṃ pucchantīti evaṃ bhagavatā adhippetattā pañhaṃ
analyzed: disvā attanā abhisaṅkhatam pañham pucchanti iti evam bhagavatā adhippeta ttā pañham
translated: and so they ask the question they have themselves thought out.

original: pucchanti. Aññesaṃ pana pucchāya okāsameva adatvā bhagavā upasaṅkamantānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti. Yathāha –
analyzed: pucchanti aññesam pana pucchāya okāsam eva a datvā bhagavā upasaṅkamantānam dhammam deseti yathā āha
translated: But the Blessed One does not give them an opportunity to ask a question. He teaches them the Dhamma as they approach him. As it is said:

original: “Te pañhaṃ abhisaṅkharonti ‘imaṃ mayaṃ pañhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma,
analyzed: te pañham abhisaṅkharonti imam mayam pañham samaṇam gotamam upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma
translated: “They think out a question, ‘We will approach the recluse Gotama and ask him this question.

original: sace no samaṇo gotamo evaṃ puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma,
analyzed: sace naḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ evam puṭṭhaḥ evam byākarissati evam assa mayam vādam āropessāma
translated: If he is questioned thus, he will answer thus, and we will take issue with him thus;

original: evaṃ cepi no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāmā’ti. Te suṇanti
analyzed: evam ce pi no puṭṭhaḥ evam byākarissati evam pissa mayam vādam āropessāma ati te suṇanti
translated: if he is questioned thus, he will answer thus, and we will take issue with him thus.’ They hear:

original: ‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osaṭo’ti. Te yena samaṇo🔽gotamo tenupasaṅkamanti. Te samaṇo gotamo dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti
analyzed: samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotamaḥ amukam nāma gāmam vā nigamam vā te yena samaṇaḥ  gotamaḥ tena upasaṅkamanti te samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti
translated: ‘The recluse Gotama has come to such and such a village or town.’ They approach the recluse Gotama.🔽The recluse Gotama instructs, urges, rouses, and encourages them with a talk on the Dhamma.

original: samuttejeti sampahaṃseti. Te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā
analyzed: samutteja iti sampahaṃsa iti te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā
translated: They are instructed, urged, roused, and encouraged by the recluse Gotama with a talk on the Dhamma.

original: samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ceva samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, kutossa vādaṃ
analyzed: samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ca iva samaṇam gotamam pañham pucchanti kutas sa vādam
translated: and they are not able to ask the ascetic Gotama a question, let alone refute his doctrine.

original: āropessanti, aññadatthu samaṇasseva gotamassa sāvakā sampajjantī”ti.
analyzed: āropessanti aññadatthu samaṇassa iva gotamassa sāvakā sampajjanti iti
translated: and they do not ask the recluse Gotama a question, how can they take issue with his doctrine? They are only the disciples of the recluse Gotama who will understand it.”

original: Kasmā pañhe na pucchantīti ce? Bhagavā kira parisamajjhe dhammaṃ desento parisāya🔽ajjhāsayaṃ oloketi, tato passati “ime paṇḍitā gūḷhaṃ rahassaṃ pañhaṃ ovaṭṭikasāraṃ🔽katvā āgatā”ti. So tehi apuṭṭhoyeva “pañhapucchāya ettakā dosā, vissajjane ettakā,
analyzed: kasmā pañhe na pucchanti iti ce bhagavā kira parisamajjhe dhammam desento parisāya  ajjhāsayam oloketi tatas passati ime paṇḍitāḥ gūḷham rahassam pañham ovaṭṭika sāram  katvā āgatā ati so tehi a puṭṭhaḥ yā iva pañha pucchāya ettakāḥ dosāḥ vissajjane ettakā
translated: Why do they not ask a question? The Exalted One, it seems, when he is teaching the Dhamma in the midst of the assembly,🔽looks into the dispositions of the assembly. Then he sees that some are wise, clever, and intelligent, and have come with a secret question, a question of great import,

original: atthe, pade, akkhare ettakāti; imaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanto evaṃ puccheyya, vissajjento🔽evaṃ vissajjeyyā”ti; iti ovaṭṭikasāraṃ katvā ānīte pañhe dhammakathāya antare pakkhipitvā
analyzed: atthe pade akkhare ettakā ati imam pañham pucchantaḥ evam puccheyya vissajjentaḥ  evam vissajjeyya iti ovaṭṭika sāram katvā ānīte pañhe dhammakathāya antare pakkhipitvā
translated: a question that is like a key. Without being asked, he points out the question and says: “In asking this question, you have incurred so many faults in the question and so many in the answer.🔽If you had asked the question in this way, I would have answered in this way.”

original: dasseti. Te paṇḍitā “seyyā vata no, ye mayaṃ ime pañhe na pucchimhā. Sacepi mayaṃ
analyzed: te paṇḍitā seyyāḥ vata naḥ ye mayam ime pañhe na pucchimhā sace pi mayam
translated: Thus he includes the question in the Dhamma talk and explains it. The wise ones think: “It would have been better for us if we had not asked the question. If we had asked it in this way,

original: puccheyyāma, appatiṭṭhite no katvā samaṇo gotamo khipeyyā”ti attamanā bhavanti.🔽Api ca buddhā nāma dhammaṃ desentā parisaṃ mettāya pharanti. Mettāpharaṇena dasabalesu
analyzed: puccheyyāma appatiṭṭhite no katvā samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ khipeyya iti atta manāḥ bhavanti  api ca buddhāḥ nāma dhammam desentā parisam mettāya pharanti mettā pharaṇena dasa balesu
translated: and if we were to ask him, he might not answer us, but might despise us.🔽But when Buddhas teach Dhamma, they suffuse the assembly with loving-kindness. When they do so,🔽the minds of the people in the assembly become serene with the ten powers of a Buddha,

original: mahājanassa cittaṃ pasīdati. Buddhā nāma rūpaggappattā honti dassanasampannā madhurassarā
analyzed: mahājanassa cittam pasīdati buddhāḥ nāma rūpagga ppattāḥ honti dassana sampannāḥ madhurassarā
translated: and they become endowed with the supreme beauty of form, with the perfection of appearance, with a sweet voice,

original: mudujivhā suphusitadantāvaraṇā, amatena hadayaṃ siñcantā viya dhammaṃ kathenti. Tatra🔽nesaṃ mettāpharaṇena pasannacittānaṃ evaṃ hoti – “evarūpaṃ advejjhakathaṃ amoghakathaṃ
analyzed: mudu jivhā su phusita danta āvaraṇā amatena hadayam siñcantā viya dhammam kathenti tatra  nesam mettā pharaṇena pasanna cittānam evam hoti evarūpam a dvejjha katham a mogha katham
translated: with a soft tongue, with teeth that are even and set close together, and they speak Dhamma as if sprinkling nectar into the heart.

original: niyyānikakathaṃ kathentena bhagavatā saddhiṃ na sakkhissāma paccanīkaggāhaṃ gaṇhitu”nti
analyzed: niyyānika katham kathentena bhagavatā saddhim na sakkhissāma paccanīka ggāham gaṇhitun ti
translated: Then, when they are suffused with loving-kindness by the Buddha, they think: “We shall not be able to take up a contrary view in debate with the Blessed One, who speaks thus with such a sweet voice, with such a soft tongue, with teeth that are even and set close together, and who speaks Dhamma as if sprinkling nectar into the heart.”

original: attano pasannabhāveneva pañhe na pucchantīti.
analyzed: attanā u pasanna bhāvena iva pañhe na pucchanti iti
translated: And because they are serene, they do not ask questions.

original: Kathitā vissajjitā vāti “evaṃ tumhe pucchathā”ti apucchitapañhānaṃ uccāraṇena te
analyzed: kathitā vissajjitā vā ati evam tumhe pucchatha ati apucchita pañhānam uccāraṇena te
translated: “Asked and answered”: the questions were asked by the Blessed One himself, saying, “You should ask thus,” and he answered them by his utterance.

original: pañhā bhagavatā kathitā eva honti. Yathā ca te vissajjetabbā, tathā vissajjitā eva
analyzed: pañhāḥ bhagavatā kathitāḥ eva honti yathā ca te vissajjetabbā tathā vissajjitāḥ eva
translated: and the questions are answered by the Blessed One in the way they should be answered.

original: honti. Niddiṭṭhakāraṇāti iminā kāraṇena iminā hetunā evaṃ hontīti evaṃ sahetukaṃ🔽katvā vissajjanena bhagavatā niddiṭṭhakāraṇā eva honti te pañhā. Upakkhittakā ca🔽te bhagavato sampajjantīti khattiyapaṇḍitādayo bhagavato pañhavissajjaneneva bhagavato
analyzed: honti niddiṭṭha kāraṇā ati iminā kāraṇena iminā hetunā evam honti iti evam sa hetukam  katvā vissajjanena bhagavatā niddiṭṭha kāraṇāḥ eva honti te pañhāḥ upakkhittakā ca  te bhagavataḥ sampajjanti iti khattiya paṇḍita ādayaḥ bhagavataḥ pañha vissajjanena iva bhagavataḥ
translated: They are answered by the Blessed One with a reason, with a cause, thus: ‘They are like this because of this reason, they are like this because of this cause.’🔽And the questions are put to the Blessed One as a challenge.

original: samīpe khittakā pakkhittakā sampajjanti; sāvakā vā sampajjanti, upāsakā vāti attho;
analyzed: samīpe khittakā pakkhittakā sampajjanti sāvakā vā sampajjanti upāsakā vā ti attho
translated: The wise nobles, etc., are challenged by the Blessed One’s answers to the questions, and they are satisfied in the Blessed One’s presence. Or the meaning can be taken as ‘they are satisfied as disciples or as male lay followers.’

original: sāvakasampattiṃ vā pāpuṇanti, upāsakasampattiṃ vāti vuttaṃ hoti. Athāti anantaratthe,
analyzed: sāvaka sampattim vā pāpuṇanti upāsaka sampattim vā iti vuttam hoti atha ati anantara atthe
translated: Or the meaning can be taken as ‘they attain the distinction of being disciples or the distinction of being male lay followers.’ Then: in the sense of ‘next,’

original: tesaṃ upakkhittakasampattisamanantaramevāti attho. Tatthāti tasmiṃ ṭhāne, tasmiṃ
analyzed: tesam upakkhittaka sampatti samanantaram eva ati attho tattha ati tasmim ṭhāne tasmim
translated: the meaning being ‘immediately next to their satisfaction as a challenge.’ There: in that place,

original: adhikāre vā. Atirocatīti ativiya jotati pakāsati. Yadidaṃ paññāyāti yāyaṃ bhagavato
analyzed: adhikāre vā atirocati iti ativiya jotati pakāsati yat idam paññāyāti yā ayam bhagavato
translated: or in that matter. He extols: he shines forth, he illuminates. What: that is, the Blessed One’s

original: paññā, tāya paññāya bhagavāva atirocatīti attho. Iti-saddo kāraṇattho, iminā kāraṇenāti
analyzed: paññā tāya paññāya bhagavā ava atirocati iti atthaḥ iti saddo kāraṇa atthaḥ iminā kāraṇena ati
translated: and wisdom, the Blessed One is pre-eminent through that wisdom, is the meaning. The word iti has the meaning of ‘reason’, for this reason,

original: attho. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭamevāti.
analyzed: attho sesam sabbattha pākaṭam evā ti
translated: and wisdom. The meaning is: the Blessed One excels in that wisdom. The word iti has the meaning of cause, the meaning is: for this cause. The rest is clear in all places.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Great Commentary on the Niddesa, the illumination of the True Dhamma,

original: Pasūrasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pasūra sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Pasūra Sutta is finished.

original: 9. Māgaṇḍiyasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽70. Navame māgaṇḍiyasuttaniddese paṭhamagāthāya tāva ajapālanigrodhamūle nānārūpāni
analyzed: navame māgaṇḍiya sutta niddese paṭhama gāthāya ajapāla nigrodha mūle nānā rūpāni
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the Māgaṇḍiya Sutta

original: nimminitvā abhikāmaṃ āgataṃ māradhītaraṃ disvāna taṇhaṃ aratiṃ ragañca chandamattampi
analyzed: nimminitvā abhikāmam āgatam māradhītaram disvāna taṇham aratim ragan ca
translated: In the ninth Māgaṇḍiya Sutta explanation, in the first verse, having created various forms at the foot of the Ajapāla Nigrodha tree, seeing Māra's daughter who came with desire, he had no craving, displeasure, passion, or even a mere wish

original: methunasmiṃ nāhosi, kimevidaṃ imissā dārikāya muttakarīsapuṇṇaṃ rūpaṃ disvā bhavissati,
analyzed: methunasmim kim eva idam imissā dārikāya mutta karīsa puṇṇam rūpam disvā bhavissati
translated: for sexual intercourse. What could this be, seeing the form of this girl filled with urine and feces?

original: sabbathā pādāpi naṃ samphusituṃ na icche, kutonena saṃvasitunti.
analyzed: sabbathā nam samphusitum na icche kutonena saṃvasitunti
translated: In every way, he did not even want to touch her feet, let alone live with her.

original: Muttapuṇṇanti āhārautuvasena vatthipuṭantaraṃ pūretvā ṭhitamuttena pūritaṃ. Karīsapuṇṇanti
analyzed: mutta puṇṇanti āhāra otu vasena vatthi puṭa antaram pūretvā ṭhita muttena pūritam karīsa puṇṇanti
translated: Filled with urine means filled with urine that remains inside the skin due to the power of food and season. Filled with feces means

original: pakkāsayasaṅkhāte heṭṭhānābhipiṭṭhikaṇṭakamūlānaṃ antare ubbedhena aṭṭhaṅgulamatte🔽antāvasāne ṭhitavaccena puṇṇaṃ. Semhapuṇṇanti udarapaṭale ṭhitaekapattappamāṇena
analyzed: pakka āsaya saṅkhāte heṭṭhā nābhi piṭṭhikaṇṭaka mūlānam antare ubbedhena aṭṭhaṅgula matte  anta avasāne ṭhita vaccena puṇṇam semha puṇṇam nti udara paṭale ṭhita eka patta ppamāṇena
translated: Inside the belly, between the navel and the base of the spine, is the receptacle for digested food, eight fingerbreadths high,🔽and it is filled with the dregs of digested food. It is full of phlegm,

original: semhena pūritaṃ. Ruhirapuṇṇanti yakanassa heṭṭhābhāgaṃ pūretvā hadayavakkapapphāsānaṃ
analyzed: semhena pūritam ruhira puṇṇanti yakanassa heṭṭhābhāgam pūretvā hadaya vakka papphāsānam
translated: which is the measure of a bowl placed on the surface of the stomach. It is full of blood,

original: upari thokaṃ thokaṃ paggharantena vakkahadayayakanapapphāse temayamānena ṭhitena🔽ekapattassa pūraṇamattena sannicitalohitasaṅkhātena ca kesalomanakhadantānaṃ maṃsavinimuttaṭṭhānañceva🔽thaddhasukkhacammañca ṭhapetvā dhamanījālānusārena sabbaṃ upādiṇṇakasarīraṃ pharitvā
analyzed: upari thokam thokam paggharantena vakka hadaya yakana papphāse temayamānena ṭhitena  eka pattassa pūraṇa mattena sannicita lohita saṅkhātena ca kesa loma nakha dantānam maṃsa vinimutta ṭṭhānam ca iva  thaddha sukkha cammañca ṭhapetvā dhamanī jāla anusārena sabbam upādiṇṇaka sarīram pharitvā
translated: which fills the lower part of the liver and moistens the kidneys, heart, and lungs with a little that trickles down from there.

original: ṭhitasaṃsaraṇalohitasaṅkhātena ca duvidhena ruhirena puṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhita saṃsaraṇa lohita saṅkhātena ca duvidhena ruhirena puṇṇam
translated: It is the measure of filling a bowl. And it is full of the two kinds of blood,🔽that is to say, the blood stored up in the body and the blood that circulates in the body.

original: Aṭṭhisaṅghātanti sakalasarīre heṭṭhā aṭṭhīnaṃ upariṭṭhitāni sādhikāni tīṇi aṭṭhisatāni,
analyzed: aṭṭhi saṅghātam ti sakala sarīre heṭṭhā aṭṭhīnam upariṭṭhitāni sādhikāni tīṇi aṭṭhi satāni
translated: The stored blood fills the whole of the physical frame except for the flesh that is devoid of blood in the nails, teeth, the hard dry skin,🔽and the sinews, and it does so by following the network of veins.🔽The circulating blood fills the whole of the physical frame except for the hard dry skin.

original: tehi aṭṭhīhi ghaṭitaṃ. Nhārusambandhanti sakalasarīre aṭṭhīni ābandhitvā ṭhitāni🔽nava nhārusatāni, tehi nhārūhi sambandhaṃ ābandhaṃ. Rudhiramaṃsāvalepananti saṃsaraṇalohitena
analyzed: tehi aṭṭhīhi ghaṭitam sakala sarīre aṭṭhīni ābandhitvā ṭhitāni  nava nhāru satāni tehi nhārūhi sambandham ābandham saṃsaraṇa lohitena
translated: It is held together by bones. It is bound by sinews: it is bound by the nine hundred sinews that bind the bones together all over the body.

original: ca sādhikāni tīṇi aṭṭhisatāni anulimpetvā ṭhitena navamaṃsapesisatena ca anulittaṃ🔽sarīraṃ. Cammavinaddhanti sakalasarīraṃ pariyonandhitvā pākaṭakilomakassa upari chaviyā🔽heṭṭhā ṭhitaṃ cammaṃ, tena cammena vinaddhaṃ pariyonaddhaṃ. “Cammāvanaddha”ntipi
analyzed: ca sādhikāni tīṇi aṭṭhi satāni anulimpetvā ṭhitena nava maṃsa pesi satena ca anulittam  sarīram camma vinaddhanti sakala sarīram pariyonandhitvā pākaṭa kilomakassa upari chaviyā  heṭṭhā ṭhitam cammam tena cammena vinaddham pariyonaddham camma avanaddham tipi
translated: It is smeared with blood and flesh: the body is smeared with the blood that circulates in the process of decay and with the nine hundred pieces of flesh.🔽It is covered with a moist skin: the skin is situated under the outer cuticle, which is visible on the surface of the body, and covers the whole body.

original: pāḷi. Chaviyā paṭicchannanti atisukhumachaviyā paṭicchannaṃ chādetvā ṭhitaṃ. Chiddāvachiddanti🔽anekachiddaṃ. Uggharantanti akkhimukhādīhi uggharantaṃ. Paggharantanti adhobhāgena
analyzed: chaviyā paṭicchannanti ati sukhuma chaviyā paṭicchannam chādetvā ṭhitam  aneka chiddam akkhi mukha ādīhi uggharantam paggharantam adhobhāgena
translated: The text reads “covered with a skin” . It is concealed by the cuticle: it is concealed and covered by the cuticle, which is extremely fine.🔽It is full of holes: it has many holes.🔽It trickles and oozes: it trickles and oozes through the eyes, nose, etc.

original: paggharantaṃ. Kimisaṅghanisevitanti sūcimukhādīhi nānāpāṇakulasamūhehi āsevitaṃ.
analyzed: paggharantam sūci mukha ādīhi nānā pāṇa kula samūhehi āsevitam
translated: It is frequented by a swarm of worms: it is frequented by a multitude of families of worms with different names.

original: Nānākalimalaparipūranti anekavidhehi asucikoṭṭhāsehi pūritaṃ.
analyzed: anekavidhehi asuci koṭṭhāsehi pūritam
translated: Nānākalimalaparipūranti filled with the various kinds of impurities, with the various kinds of unclean things.

original: 71. Tato māgaṇḍiyo “pabbajitā nāma mānusake kāme pahāya dibbakāmatthāya pabbajanti,
analyzed: tatas māgaṇḍiyaḥ pabbajitāḥ nāma mānusake kāme pahāya dibba kāma tthāya pabbajanti
translated: Then Māgandiya thought: “Those who go forth from home to homelessness do so in order to abandon human sensual desires and to attain divine sensual desires,

original: ayañca dibbepi kāme na icchati, idampi itthiratanaṃ, kā nu assa diṭṭhī”ti pucchituṃ
analyzed: ayam ca dibbe pi kāme na icchati idam pi itthi ratanam kā nu assa diṭṭhī iti pucchitum
translated: but this man does not even want divine sensual desires. This is also a treasure of a woman. What is his view?” and he asked him,🔽saying the second stanza:

original: dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha etādisaṃ ce ratananti dibbitthiratanaṃ sandhāya bhaṇati.
analyzed: dutiyam gātham āha tattha etādisam ce ratanam ti dibbitthi ratanam sandhāya bhaṇati
translated: Etādisaṃ ce ratan. Here he is referring to a treasure of a divine woman.

original: Nārinti attano dhītaraṃ sandhāya. Diṭṭhigataṃ sīlavataṃ nu jīvitanti diṭṭhiñca sīlañca
analyzed: nārinti attanaḥ dhītaram sandhāya diṭṭhi gatam sīlavatam nu jīvitanti diṭṭhiñca sīlañca
translated: Nāriṃ. Here he is referring to his own daughter. Diṭṭhigataṃ sīlavataṃ nu jīvitaṃ. Here he is referring to his own view, virtue,

original: vatañca jīvitañca. Bhavūpapattiñca vadesi kīdisanti attano bhavūpapattiṃ vā tuvaṃ kīdisaṃ vadesi.
analyzed: vatam ca jīvitam ca bhava upapattiñca vadesi kīdisanti attanaḥ bhava upapattim vā tuvam kīdisam vadesi
translated: and life. Bhavūpapattiñca vadesi kīdisaṃ. Here he is asking: “What kind of rebirth in a future existence do you declare for yourself?”

original: 72. Ito parā dve gāthā vissajjanapucchānayena pavattattā pākaṭasambandhāyeva. Tāsu
analyzed: itas parāḥ dve gāthāḥ vissajjana pucchā nayena pavatta tā pākaṭa sambandhāya iva tāsu
translated: From here on the two stanzas proceed by way of question and answer. Their connection is obvious.

original: paṭhamagāthāya saṅkhepattho – tassa mayhaṃ māgaṇḍiya dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatadhammesu
analyzed: paṭhama gāthāya saṅkhepa atthaḥ tassa mayham māgaṇḍiya dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata dhammesu
translated: The meaning of the first stanza in brief is this: “Māgandiya, in regard to the sixty-two views,

original: nicchinitvā “idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti evaṃ idaṃ vadāmīti samuggahītaṃ na hoti
analyzed: nicchinitvā idam eva saccam mogham aññanti evam idam vadāmi iti samuggahītam na hoti
translated: He does not grasp at it, thinking: “This alone is the truth, other ideas are worthless.”

original: natthi na vijjati, kiṃ kāraṇā? Ahañhi passanto diṭṭhīsu ādīnavaṃ kañci diṭṭhiṃ aggahetvā
analyzed: natthi na vijjati kim kāraṇā aham hi passantaḥ diṭṭhīsu ādīnavam kañci diṭṭhim aggahetvā
translated: Why is there no grasping? Because I, seeing danger in all views, not grasping at any view,

original: saccāni pavicinanto ajjhattaṃ rāgādīnaṃ santibhāvena ajjhattasantisaṅkhātaṃ nibbānameva addasanti.
analyzed: saccāni pavicinantaḥ ajjhattam rāga ādīnam santi bhāvena ajjhatta santi saṅkhātam nibbānam eva addasanti
translated: seeing only Nibbāna, which is called the inner peace, I see the truths.

original: Ādīnavanti upaddavaṃ. Sadukkhanti kāyikadukkhena sadukkhaṃ. Savighātanti cetasikadukkhena🔽sahitaṃ. Saupāyāsanti upāyāsasahitaṃ. Sapariḷāhanti sadarathaṃ. Na nibbidāyāti na🔽vaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya. Na virāgāyāti na vaṭṭe virāgatthāya. Na nirodhāyāti na vaṭṭassa🔽nirodhatthāya. Na upasamāyāti na vaṭṭassa upasamatthāya. Na abhiññāyāti na vaṭṭassa
analyzed: ādīnavanti upaddavam sa dukkhanti kāyika dukkhena sa dukkham sa vighātanti cetasika dukkhena  sahitam upāyāsa sahitam sa pariḷāhanti sadaratham na nibbidā āyāti na  vaṭṭe nibbindana tthāya na virāgāya ati na vaṭṭe virāga tthāya na nirodhāya ati na vaṭṭassa  nirodha tthāya na upasamāyāti na vaṭṭassa upasama tthāya na abhiññāyāti na vaṭṭassa
translated: Danger means calamity. With suffering means with bodily suffering. With anguish means with mental suffering.🔽With despair means with despair. With fever means with heat. Not for revulsion towards the round means not for the purpose of revulsion towards the round. Not for dispassion means not for the purpose of dispassion towards the round. Not for cessation means not for the purpose of cessation of the round.

original: abhijānanatthāya. Na sambodhāyāti na kilesaniddāvigamena vaṭṭato sambujjhanatthāya.
analyzed: abhijānana tthāya na sambodhāya ati na kilesa niddā vigamena vaṭṭataḥ sambujjhana tthāya
translated: Not for peace means not for the purpose of peace of the round. Not for direct knowledge means not for the purpose of direct knowledge of the round. Not for full understanding means not for the purpose of full understanding of the round by the disappearance of ignorance.

original: Na nibbānāyāti na amatanibbānatthāya. Ettha pana “nibbidāyā”ti vipassanā. “Virāgāyā”ti
analyzed: na nibbānāya ati na amata nibbāna atthāya ettha pana nibbidāya ati vipassanā virāgāya ati
translated: Not for the sake of nibbana: not for the sake of the deathless nibbana. Herein, “for the sake of dispassion” is insight;🔽“for the sake of fading away” is the path;🔽“for the sake of cessation” and “for the sake of peace” are nibbana;

original: maggo. “Nirodhāya upasamāyā”ti nibbānaṃ. “Abhiññāya sambodhāyā”ti maggo. “Nibbānāyā”ti🔽nibbānameva. Evaṃ ekasmiṃ ṭhāne vipassanā, tīsu maggo, tīsu nibbānaṃ vuttanti evaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ nirodhāya upasamāyāti nibbānam abhiññāya sambodhāya ati maggaḥ nibbānāya ati  nibbānam eva evam ekasmin ṭhāne vipassanā tīsu maggo tīsu nibbānam vuttan ti evam
translated: “for the sake of direct knowledge” and “for the sake of full understanding” are the path;🔽“for the sake of nibbana” is nibbana itself. So insight is mentioned in one place, the path in three places, and nibbana in three places. This is how the exposition should be known here.

original: vavatthānakathā veditabbā. Pariyāyena pana sabbānipetāni maggavevacanānipi nibbānavevacanānipi hontiyeva.🔽Ajjhattaṃ rāgassa santinti ajjhattarāgassa santabhāvena nibbutabhāvena ajjhattasantisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: vavatthāna kathā veditabbā pariyāyena pana sabbānipetāni magga vevacanāni pi nibbāna vevacanāni pi  ajjhattam rāgassa santinti ajjhatta rāgassa santa bhāvena nibbuta bhāvena ajjhatta santi saṅkhātam
translated: But all these terms are also terms for the path and terms for nibbana in a secondary, not primary, sense.

original: nibbānaṃ olokesiṃ. Dosassa santintiādīsupi eseva nayo. Pacinanti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam dosassa santi nti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ pacinanti niddesassa uddesa padam
translated: “For the sake of the stilling of lust within” : he looked upon nibbana, called “the stilling within,” as the stilling, the subsiding, of lust within himself. The same method applies in the case of “for the sake of the fading away of hatred” and so on.

original: Vicinantoti saccāni vaḍḍhento vibhāvento. Pavicinantoti tāneva paccekaṃ vibhāvento.
analyzed: vicinantaḥ ti saccāni vaḍḍhentaḥ vibhāventaḥ pavicinantaḥ ti tān eva paccekam vibhāventaḥ
translated: “He discerned and defined and analysed” : he discerned by discerning the truths, he defined by defining them, he analysed by analysing them.

original: Keci “gavesanto”ti vaṇṇayanti. Adassanti olokesiṃ. Adakkhinti vinivijjhiṃ. Aphassinti
analyzed: keci gavesantoti vaṇṇayanti a dassanti olokesim a dakkhinti vinivijjhim a phassinti
translated: Some commentators explain “gavesanto” as “seeking” . “Adassana” is looking. “Adassana” is penetrating. “Aphassana” is

original: paññāya phusiṃ. Paṭivijjhinti ñāṇena paccakkhaṃ akāsiṃ.
analyzed: paññāya phusim paṭivijjhinti ñāṇena paccakkham akāsim
translated: touching with wisdom. “Paṭivijjha” is making it evident by means of knowledge.

original: 73. Dutiyagāthāya saṅkhepattho – yānimāni diṭṭhigatāni tehi tehi sattehi vinicchinitvā🔽gahitattā “vinicchayā”ti ca attano paccayehi abhisaṅkhatabhāvādinā nayena “pakappitānī”ti
analyzed: dutiya gāthāya saṅkhepa atthaḥ yāni imāni diṭṭhi gatāni tehi tehi sattehi vinicchinitvā  ca attanaḥ paccayehi abhisaṅkhata bhāva ādinā nayena pakappitāni iti
translated: The meaning of the second stanza in brief is this: “These views are called ‘vinicchaya’ because they are held by beings after having been investigated and

original: ca vuccanti, te ve munī diṭṭhigatadhamme aggahetvā ajjhattasantīti yametamatthaṃ
analyzed: ca vuccanti te ve munī diṭṭhi gata dhamme aggahetvā ajjhatta santī iti yam etam attham
translated: grasped. They are also called ‘pakappita’ because they are created by one’s own conditions and so on. The Muni, not grasping these views, has peace within himself. This is the meaning of what you say.

original: brūsi, ācikkha me, kathaṃ nu dhīrehi paveditaṃ taṃ kathaṃ pakāsitaṃ dhīrehīti vadati.
analyzed: brūsi ācikkha me katham nu dhīrehi paveditam tam katham pakāsitam dhīrehi iti vadati
translated: Explain to me, how is it proclaimed by the wise? How is it made known by the wise?”

original: Imissā gāthāya niddeso uttānattho ṭhapetvā paramatthapadaṃ. Tattha yaṃ paramatthanti yaṃ uttamaṃ nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: imissā gāthāya niddesaḥ uttāna atthaḥ ṭhapetvā paramattha padam tattha yam paramatthanti yam uttamam nibbānam
translated: The commentary on this stanza is clear in meaning, except for the word “paramattha.” Therein, “what is the supreme goal” is the supreme Nibbana.

original: 74. Athassa bhagavā yathā yena upāyena taṃ padaṃ dhīrehi pakāsitaṃ, taṃ upāyaṃ sapaṭipakkhaṃ
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā yathā yena upāyena tam padam dhīrehi pakāsitam tam upāyam sa paṭipakkham
translated: Then the Blessed One, by what means the wise proclaim that state, that means together with its opposite,

original: dassento “na diṭṭhiyā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha na diṭṭhiyātiādīhi diṭṭhisutiaṭṭhasamāpattiñāṇabāhirasīlabbatāni
analyzed: dassentaḥ na diṭṭhiyā iti gātham āha tattha na diṭṭhiyā ati ādīhi diṭṭhi suti aṭṭha samāpatti ñāṇa bāhira sīlabbatāni
translated: He said the verse, “I do not say purification is by view” . Herein, by the words “I do not say purification is by view” and so on he rejects the purification by view, the knowledge of the eight attainments, the external virtue and practice,

original: paṭikkhipati. “Suddhimāhā”ti ettha vuttaṃ āha-saddaṃ sabbattha nakārena saddhiṃ yojetvā
analyzed: paṭikkhipati suddhim āha iti ettha vuttam āha saddam sabbattha nakārena saddhim yojetvā
translated: and the purification by faith. In the words “I say purification is by faith” the word “say” should be construed with “faith” in all three terms,

original: purimapadattayaṃ netvā “diṭṭhiyā suddhiṃ nāha na kathemī”ti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: netvā diṭṭhiyā suddhim na āha na kathemi iti evam atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: and the meaning should be understood thus: “I do not say, I do not declare, purification is by view.”

original: Yathā cettha, evaṃ uttarapadesupi. Tattha ca adiṭṭhiyā nāhāti dasavatthukaṃ sammādiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: yathā ca ittha evam uttara padesu pi tattha ca adiṭṭhiyā na āhāti dasa vatthukam sammādiṭṭhim
translated: And just as here, so also in the subsequent passages. Herein, by “I do not say without view” he means that he does not declare purification without right view with its ten objects.

original: vinā na kathemi. Tathā assutiyāti navaṅgaṃ savanaṃ vinā. Añāṇāti kammassakatasaccānulomikañāṇaṃ🔽vinā. Asīlatāti pātimokkhasaṃvaraṃ vinā. Abbatāti dhutaṅgavataṃ vinā. Nopi tenāti
analyzed: vinā na kathemi tathā assutiyā ati navaṅgam savanam vinā añāṇā ti kammassakata sacca ānulomika ñāṇam  vinā pātimokkha saṃvaram vinā dhutaṅgavatam vinā na upi tena ati
translated: Similarly, by “I do not say without hearing” he means that he does not declare purification without the ninefold hearing . By “I do not say without knowledge” he means that he does not declare purification without the knowledge that accords with the truth of the ownership of kamma.🔽By “I do not say without virtue” he means that he does not declare purification without the virtue of the Pāṭimokkha. By “I do not say without practice” he means that he does not declare purification without the practice of the ascetic qualities. By “I do not say without that” he means that he does not declare purification by means of even one of these, view, etc., alone.

original: tesu ekamekena diṭṭhiādimattenāpi na kathemīti evamattho veditabbo. Ete ca nissajja
analyzed: tesu ekam ekena diṭṭhi ādi mattena api na kathemi iti evam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ete ca nissajja
translated: The meaning should be understood thus. Having rejected

original: anuggahāyāti ete ca purimadiṭṭhiādibhede kaṇhapakkhike dhamme samugghātakaraṇena🔽nissajja, pacchime adiṭṭhiādibhede sukkapakkhikepi atammayatāpajjanena anuggahāya.🔽Santo anissāya bhavaṃ na jappeti imāya paṭipattiyā rāgādivūpasamena santo cakkhādīsu
analyzed: anuggahāya āti ete ca purima diṭṭhi ādi bhede kaṇha pakkhike dhamme samugghāta karaṇena  nissajja pacchime adiṭṭhi ādi bhede sukka pakkhike pi anuggahāya  santaḥ a nissāya bhavam na jappeti imāya paṭipattiyā rāga ādi vūpasamena santaḥ cakkha ādīsu
translated: ‘For the sake of support’: for the sake of supporting the bright side of dhammas, such as right view, etc., by abandoning the dark side of dhammas, such as wrong view, etc., which have already been seen, and by developing non-complacency with regard to the bright side of dhammas, such as right view, etc., which have been seen.

original: kañci dhammaṃ anissāya ekampi bhavaṃ na jappe, apihetuṃ apatthetuṃ samattho siyā,
analyzed: kañci dhammam a nissāya ekam pi bhavam na jappe apihetum apatthetum samatthaḥ siyā
translated: ‘The peaceful one, not clinging, does not yearn for becoming’: the peaceful one, by the quieting of lust, etc., through this practice, does not cling to any dhamma, such as the eye, etc., and does not yearn for even a single becoming, does not wish for a cause for becoming.

original: ayamassa ajjhattasantīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ayam assa ajjhatta santī ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he is peaceful internally.

original: Savanampi icchitabbanti suttādivasena suṇanampi ākaṅkhitabbaṃ. Sambhārā ime dhammāti
analyzed: savanam pi icchitabbanti sutta ādi vasena suṇanam pi ākaṅkhitabbam sambhārāḥ ime dhammā ti
translated: ‘Hearing too should be wished for’: hearing too, through the suttas, etc., should be wished for.🔽‘These dhammas are requisites’: right view, etc., are requisites in the sense of being helpful.

original: sammādiṭṭhiādikā ime dhammā upakāraṭṭhena sambhārā honti. Kaṇhapakkhikānanti akusalapakkhe
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi ādikāḥ ime dhammāḥ upakāra ṭṭhena sambhārāḥ honti kaṇhapakkhikānam ti akusala pakkhe
translated: ‘For the dark side of dhammas’: for the unwholesome side of dhammas.

original: bhavānaṃ. Samugghātato pahānaṃ icchitabbanti sammā hananato samucchedato pahānaṃ
analyzed: bhavānam samugghātataḥ pahānam icchitabbanti sammā hananataḥ samucchedataḥ pahānam
translated: ‘Abandoning through uprooting’: abandoning through complete destruction by means of right abandoning.

original: ākaṅkhitabbaṃ. Tedhātukesu kusalesu dhammesūti kāmarūpārūpasaṅkhātesu tebhūmakesu
analyzed: ākaṅkhitabbam tedhātukesu kusalesu dhammesu iti kāmarūpa arūpa saṅkhātesu tebhūmakesu
translated: and he should wish to ask. In the profitable ideas in the three planes : in those in the three planes consisting of the sensual-desire, the fine-material, and the immaterial .

original: kosallasambhūtesu. Atammayatāti nittaṇhabhāvo.
analyzed: kosalla sambhūtesu nittaṇha bhāvaḥ
translated: The state of being uninfatuated is the state of being free from infatuation.

original: 75. Evaṃ vutte vacanatthaṃ asallakkhento māgaṇḍiyo “no ce kirā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha🔽diṭṭhādīni vuttanayāneva. Kaṇhapakkhikāniyeva pana sandhāya ubhayatrāpi āha. Āha-saddaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte vacana attham a sallakkhentaḥ māgaṇḍiyaḥ no ce kirāti gātham āha tattha  diṭṭha ādīni vutta nayānā iva kaṇha pakkhikāniyā iva pana sandhāya ubhayatra api āha āha saddam
translated: When this was said, Magandiya, who had not investigated the meaning of the words, spoke this stanza:

original: pana “no ce”ti saddena yojetvā no ce kira āha no ce kira kathesīti evaṃ attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: pana no ca iti saddena yojetvā no ce kira āha no ce kira kathesi iti evam atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Herein, seen and so on are as already stated. He said both times in reference to the dark side only. The word āha is to be construed with no ce kira, so the meaning should be regarded as “ If he does not say, if he does not speak”.

original: Momūhanti atimūḷhaṃ, mohanaṃ vā. Paccentīti jānanti. Imissāpi gāthāya niddeso uttāno.
analyzed: momūhanti ati mūḷham mohanam vā paccenti iti jānanti imissā api gāthāya niddesaḥ uttānaḥ
translated: Momūha is very infatuated or infatuation. Pacenti = know. The demonstration of this stanza too is plain.

original: 76. Athassa bhagavā taṃ diṭṭhiṃ nissāya pucchaṃ paṭikkhipanto “diṭṭhiñca nissāyā”ti
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tam diṭṭhim nissāya puccham paṭikkhipantaḥ diṭṭhiñca nissāya ati
translated: Then the Blessed One, in order to reject his question based on that view, spoke this stanza:

original: gāthamāha. Tassattho – tvaṃ māgaṇḍiya diṭṭhiṃ nissāya punappunaṃ pucchamāno yāni
analyzed: gātham āha tassa atthaḥ tvam māgaṇḍiya diṭṭhim nissāya punappunam pucchamānaḥ yāni
translated: “ Depending on a view, Magandiya, you ask again and again,

original: te diṭṭhigatāni samuggahitāni, tesveva samuggahītesu pamohaṃ āgato tvaṃ ito ca mayā
analyzed: te diṭṭhi gatāni samuggahitāni tesu eva samuggahītesu pamoham āgataḥ tvam itas ca mayā
translated: You have not seen even a little sign of suitability in this Dhamma,

original: vuttaajjhattasantito paṭipattito dhammadesanato vā aṇumpi yuttasaññaṃ na passasi,
analyzed: vutta ajjhatta santitaḥ paṭipattitaḥ dhamma desanataḥ vā aṇum pi yutta saññam na passasi
translated: either in the practice of the way or in the teaching of the Dhamma,

original: tena kāraṇena tvaṃ imaṃ dhammaṃ momūhato passasīti.
analyzed: tena kāraṇena tvam imam dhammam momūhataḥ passasi iti
translated: for that reason you see this Dhamma as confused.”

original: Lagganaṃ nissāya laggananti diṭṭhilagganaṃ allīyitvā diṭṭhilagganaṃ. Bandhananti diṭṭhibandhanaṃ. Palibodhanti diṭṭhipalibodhaṃ.
analyzed: lagganam nissāya laggananti diṭṭhi lagganam allīyitvā diṭṭhi lagganam bandhananti diṭṭhi bandhanam palibodhanti diṭṭhi palibodham
translated: “Clinging to rules and observances” is clinging to the view, being attached to the view, being bound to the view, being fettered to the view, being obstructed by the view,

original: Andhakāraṃ pakkhandosīti bahalandhakāraṃ paviṭṭhosi. Yuttasaññanti samaṇadhamme yuttasaññaṃ.🔽Pattasaññanti samaṇadhamme paṭiladdhasaññaṃ. Lagganasaññanti sañjānitasaññaṃ. Kāraṇasaññanti
analyzed: andhakāram pakkhandosi iti bahala andhakāram paviṭṭhaḥ asi yutta saññam ti samaṇa dhamme yutta saññam  patta saññanti samaṇa dhamme paṭiladdha saññam laggana saññanti sañjānita saññam kāraṇa saññanti
translated: “You have fallen into great darkness” means you have entered great darkness. “Sign of suitability” means a sign of suitability in the ascetic practice.🔽“Sign of attainment” means a sign of attainment in the ascetic practice. “Sign of clinging” means a sign of recognition. “Sign of reason” means

original: hetusaññaṃ. Ṭhānasaññanti kāraṇasaññaṃ. Na paṭilabhasīti na vindasi. Kuto ñāṇanti
analyzed: hetu saññam ṭhāna saññanti kāraṇa saññam na paṭilabhasi iti na vindasi kutas ñāṇam ti
translated: a sign of cause. “Sign of place” means a sign of reason. “You do not obtain” means you do not find. “From where is your knowledge?” means

original: maggañāṇaṃ pana kena kāraṇena labhissasi. Aniccaṃ vāti hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena pañcakkhandhā
analyzed: magga ñāṇam pana kena kāraṇena labhissasi aniccam vā ati hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena pañca kkhandhāḥ
translated: But how will you get path knowledge? The five aggregates are impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been.

original: aniccaṃ. Aniccasaññānulomaṃ vāti “pañcakkhandhā aniccā”ti uppannā saññā aniccasaññā,
analyzed: aniccam anicca saññā anulomam vā ti pañca kkhandhāḥ aniccā ati uppannā saññā anicca saññā
translated: The perception of impermanence is in conformity with that: the perception that arises with the words “The five aggregates are impermanent” is the perception of impermanence.

original: tāya saññāya anulomaṃ appaṭikkūlaṃ aniccasaññānulomaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Dvinnaṃ
analyzed: tāya saññāya anulomam appaṭikkūlam anicca saññā anulomam kim tat vipassanā ñāṇam dvinnam
translated: In conformity with that perception, not contrary to it, is the knowledge of insight. What is that? It is the knowledge of insight.

original: vipassanāñāṇānaṃ dukkhānattasaññānulomānampi eseva nayo.🔽77. Evaṃ samuggahitesu pamohena māgaṇḍiyassa vivādāpattiṃ dassetvā idāni tesu aññesu
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇānam dukkhānatta saññā anulomānam pi esa eva nayo  evam samuggahitesu pamohena māgaṇḍiyassa vivāda āpattim dassetvā idāni tesu aññesu
translated: The same method applies to the perception of pain and the perception of non-self.

original: ca dhammesu vigatappamohassa attano nibbivādataṃ dassento “samo visesī”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tassattho – yo evaṃ tidhā mānena vā diṭṭhiyā vā puggalena vā maññati, so tena mānena
analyzed: ca dhammesu vigata ppamohassa attanaḥ nibbivāda tam dassentaḥ samaḥ visesi iti gātham āha  tassa atthaḥ yaḥ evam tidhā mānena vā diṭṭhiyā vā puggalena vā maññati saḥ tena mānena
translated: Having thus shown by way of the three kinds of conceit that the disputant’s position is untenable, the Master now shows his own freedom from dispute by the stanza, “The equal, the better, the worse.”🔽The meaning is this: One who conceives himself in the three ways by conceit, by view, or by person, would dispute with another on the basis of that conceit,

original: tāya vā diṭṭhiyā tena vā puggalena vivadeyya. Yo pana amhādiso imāsu tīsu vidhāsu
analyzed: tāya vā diṭṭhiyā tena vā puggalena vivadeyya yaḥ pana amhādisaḥ imāsu tīsu vidhāsu
translated: that view, or that person. But one like me, who has no conceit, no view, and no person,

original: avikampamāno, samo visesīti na tassa hoti, na ca hīnoti pāṭhaseso. Imissāpi gāthāya niddeso uttānova.
analyzed: a vikampamānaḥ samaḥ visesī iti na tassa hoti na ca hīnaḥ iti pāṭha sesaḥ imissā api gāthāya niddesaḥ uttānaḥ va
translated: He does not think “I am equal or superior” and he does not think “I am inferior” . The commentary on this stanza is also self-evident.

original: 78. Kiñca bhiyyo – “saccanti so”ti gāthā. Tassattho – so evarūpo pahīnamānadiṭṭhiko
analyzed: kiñca bhiyyas saccanti saḥ ti gāthā tassa atthaḥ saḥ evarūpaḥ pahīna māna diṭṭhiko
translated: And what is more, there is the stanza: “Saccanti so” . Its meaning is this. Such a person, who has abandoned conceit and views,

original: “mādiso ‘bāhitapāpattā’dinā nayena brāhmaṇo, idameva sacca”nti kiṃ vadeyya kiṃ vatthuṃ🔽bhaṇeyya, kena vā kāraṇena bhaṇeyya, “mayhaṃ saccaṃ, tuyhaṃ musā”ti vā kena mānena
analyzed: mādisaḥ kim vadeyya kim  bhaṇeyya kena vā kāraṇena bhaṇeyya mayham saccam tuyham vā kena mānena
translated: “A brahmin like me, who has expelled evil states, etc.,” by what would he say, by what would he speak, by what would he say “This alone is the truth”?

original: diṭṭhiyā puggalena vā vivadeyya. Yasmiṃ mādise khīṇāsave “sadisohamasmī”ti pavattiyā
analyzed: diṭṭhiyā puggalena vā vivadeyya yasmin mādise khīṇa āsave sadisā uham asmi iti pavattiyā
translated: By what conceit, by what view, by what person would he dispute, saying “My view is true, yours is false”? In such a person, who is free from cankers, there is no conceit that he is equal to those who have reached the same level as himself,

original: samaṃ vā, itaradvayabhāvena pavattiyā visamaṃ vā maññitaṃ natthi, samānādīsu kena
analyzed: samam vā itara dvaya bhāvena pavattiyā visamam vā maññitam na atthi samāna ādīsu kena
translated: or that he is unequal to them, by the other two ways of conceiving. By what would he join issue with those who are equal to him, etc.?

original: vādaṃ paṭisaṃyujeyya paṭipphareyyāti. Imissāpi gāthāya niddeso uttāno.
analyzed: vādam paṭisaṃyujeyya paṭipphareyya ati imissā api gāthāya niddesaḥ uttānaḥ
translated: The commentary on this stanza is also self-evident.

original: 79. Nanu ekaṃseneva evarūpo puggalo? “Okaṃ pahāyā”ti gāthā. Tattha okaṃ pahāyāti
analyzed: nanu ekaṃsena iva evarūpaḥ puggalaḥ okam pahāya ati gāthā tattha okam pahāya ati
translated: But is not such a person one who has reached the state of no-return? There is the stanza: “Okaṃ pahāyā” . Herein, okaṃ pahāyā = having abandoned the home

original: rūpadhātvādiviññāṇassokāsaṃ tatra chandarāgappahānena chaḍḍetvā. Aniketasārīti rūpanimittaniketādīni🔽taṇhāvasena asaranto. Gāme akubbaṃ muni santhavānīti gāme gihisanthavāni akaronto.🔽Kāmehi rittoti kāmesu chandarāgābhāvena sabbakāmehi puthubhūto. Apurakkharānoti āyatiṃ🔽attabhāvaṃ anabhinibbattento. Kathaṃ na viggayha janena kayirāti janena saddhiṃ viggāhikakathaṃ na katheyya.
analyzed: rūpa dhātu ādi viññāṇassa ukāsam tatra chanda rāga ppahānena chaḍḍetvā aniketa sārī iti rūpa nimitta niketa ādīni  taṇhā vasena a sarantaḥ gāme akubbam muni santhavāni iti gāme gihi santhavāni a karontaḥ  kāmehi rittaḥ ti kāmesu chanda rāga abhāvena sabba kāmehi puthu bhūtaḥ āyatim  atta bhāvam an abhinibbattentaḥ katham na viggayha janena janena saddhim viggāhika katham na katheyya
translated: Having abandoned the ‘space’ for the consciousness of the form-world, etc., by abandoning desire and lust for them. ‘Wandering without a home’: not taking as a home the signs of form, etc.,🔽through craving. ‘The sage, not entering into a village for alms’: not entering a village for the sake of conversation with householders.🔽‘Free from sensual desires’: separated from all sensual desires by the absence of desire and lust for sensual desires. ‘Not looking forward’: not bringing about a future🔽existence. ‘How not to quarrel with people?’: how not to engage in argumentative talk with people?🔽

original: Hāliddakānīti evaṃnāmako gahapati. Yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkamīti yenāti bhummatthe🔽karaṇavacanaṃ. Tasmā yattha mahākaccāno, tattha upasaṅkamīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: hāliddakāni iti evaṃnāmakaḥ gahapati yena ayasmai mahākaccāno tena upasaṅkamīti yena ati bhummatthe  karaṇa vacanam tasmai yattha mahākaccāno tattha upasaṅkamī iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: and he has abandoned the ‘space’ for the consciousness of the form-element, etc., by abandoning desire and lust for them. ‘Wandering without a home’: he does not take refuge in the signs of form, etc., through craving. ‘The sage does not enter the village for social interaction’: he does not enter the village for social interaction with householders. ‘Free from sensual desires’: he is separated from all sensual desires by the absence of desire and lust for sensual desires. ‘Not looking forward’: he does not bring about the rebirth of a future individual existence. ‘How should one not engage in disputes with people?’: one should not engage in quarrelsome talk with people. ‘Hāliddaka’: a householder of that name. ‘Approached the venerable Mahā Kaccāna’: ‘yena’ is a locative case🔽expression. Therefore, the meaning here should be seen thus: ‘he approached where Mahā Kaccāna was’.

original: Yena vā kāraṇena mahākaccāno devamanussehi upasaṅkamitabbo, tena kāraṇena upasaṅkamīti
analyzed: yena vā kāraṇena mahākaccānaḥ deva manussehi upasaṅkamitabbaḥ tena kāraṇena upasaṅkamīti
translated: Or, ‘yena’ means ‘for what reason’. Therefore, the meaning here should be seen thus: ‘he approached for the reason that Mahā Kaccāna should be approached by gods and humans’.

original: evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Kena ca kāraṇena mahākaccāno upasaṅkamitabbo? Nānappakāraguṇavisesādhigamādhippāyena,
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ kena ca kāraṇena mahākaccānaḥ upasaṅkamitabbaḥ nānā pakāra guṇa visesa adhigama adhippāyena
translated: With the aim of attaining the various kinds of special qualities,

original: sāduphalūpabhogādhippāyena dijagaṇehi niccaphalitamahārukkho viya. Upasaṅkamīti ca
analyzed: sādu phala upabhoga adhippāyena dija gaṇehi nicca phalita mahā rukkhaḥ viya upasaṅkamīti ca
translated: like a great fruit tree that is always laden with fruit for the enjoyment of flocks of birds.🔽“Approached” means “went.”

original: gatoti vuttaṃ hoti. Upasaṅkamitvāti upasaṅkamanapariyosānadīpanaṃ. Atha vā evaṃ gato
analyzed: gataḥ ti vuttam hoti upasaṅkamitvā iti upasaṅkamana pariyosāna dīpanam atha vā evam gataḥ
translated: Or else, having gone in this way,

original: tato āsannataraṃ ṭhānaṃ mahākaccānassa samīpasaṅkhātaṃ gantvātipi vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Abhivādetvāti pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā. Idāni yenatthena mahākaccānassa upaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tatas āsannataram ṭhānam mahākaccānassa samīpa saṅkhātam gantvā iti pi vuttam hoti  abhivādetvā iti pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā idāni yena atthena mahākaccānassa upaṭṭhānam
translated: he went to a place nearer still, called “the vicinity” of Mahākaccāna.🔽“Having paid homage” means having saluted with the five-point posture.🔽Now, wanting to ask about the purpose for which he had come to Mahākaccāna’s attendance,

original: āgato, taṃ pucchitukāmo dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalaṃ añjaliṃ sirasi patiṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: āgataḥ tam pucchitu kāmaḥ dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalam añjalim sirasi patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: placing his head at Mahākaccāna’s feet,

original: ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantanti bhāvanapuṃsakaniddeso “visamaṃ candimasūriyā parivattantī”tiādīsu
analyzed: ekamantam nisīdi bhāva napuṃsaka niddesaḥ visamam candima sūriyā parivattanti itiādīsu
translated: he sat down to one side. “To one side” is a demonstrative pronoun, as in such passages as “The moon and sun revolve irregularly” .

original: viya. Tasmā yathā nisinno ekamantaṃ nisinno hoti, evaṃ nisīdīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya tasmai yathā nisinnaḥ ekamantam nisinnaḥ hoti evam nisīdī iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So the meaning here should be regarded as “he sat down on one side after sitting down in whatever way he was sitting down.”🔽Or else this is a word of respectful salutation in the sense of “he sat down on one side after sitting down in such a way that he was on one side and the Blessed One on the other.”

original: Bhummatthe vā etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Nisīdīti nisajjaṃ kappesi. Paṇḍitā hi devamanussā
analyzed: bhummatthe vā etam upayoga vacanam nisīdi iti nisajjam kappesi paṇḍitāḥ hi deva manussā
translated: For wise human and divine beings,

original: garuṭṭhāniyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā āsanakusalatāya ekamantaṃ nisīdanti. Ayañca gahapati
analyzed: garuṭṭhāniyam upasaṅkamitvā āsana kusala tāya ekamantam nisīdanti ayam ca gahapati
translated: after approaching one who is worthy of respect, sit down on one side after sitting down in such a way that they are on one side and the other is on the other, being skilled in posture.

original: tesaṃ aññataro, tasmā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
analyzed: tesam aññataraḥ tasmai ekamantam nisīdi
translated: And this householder was one of those. That is why it is said, “he sat down on one side.”

original: Kathaṃ nisinno ca pana ekamantaṃ nisinno hotīti? Cha nisajjadose vajjetvā. Seyyathidaṃ?
analyzed: katham nisinnaḥ ca pana ekamantam nisinnaḥ hoti iti nisajja dose
translated: But how does one sit down on one side? By avoiding the six faults of sitting, that is to say,

original: Atidūraṃ accāsannaṃ uparivātaṃ unnatappadesaṃ atisammukhaṃ atipacchāti. Atidūre nisinno
analyzed: ati dūram acca āsannam upari vātam unnata ppadesam ati sammukham ati pacchā ati ati dūre nisinnaḥ
translated: sitting too far away, too near, upwind, on a higher seat, in front, or across.🔽For if one sits too far away,

original: hi sace kathetukāmo hoti, uccāsaddena kathetabbaṃ hoti. Accāsanne nisinno saṅghaṭṭanaṃ
analyzed: hi sace kathetu kāmaḥ hoti uccāsaddena kathetabbam hoti accāsanne nisinnaḥ saṅghaṭṭanam
translated: one has to speak loudly and if one sits too near, one may touch the other.

original: karoti. Uparivāte nisinno sarīragandhena bādhati. Unnatappadese nisinno agāravaṃ
analyzed: karoti upari vāte nisinnaḥ sarīra gandhena bādhati unnata ppadese nisinnaḥ agāravam
translated: If one sits upwind, one is offended by the smell of the other’s breath, and if one sits on a higher seat, one offends him.

original: pakāseti. Atisammukhā nisinno sace daṭṭhukāmo hoti, cakkhunā cakkhuṃ āhacca daṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: pakāseti atisammukhā nisinnaḥ sace daṭṭhu kāmo hoti cakkhunā cakkhum āhacca daṭṭhabbam
translated: If he is sitting too close in front, if he wants to see, he has to look at the other’s eyes.

original: hoti. Atipacchā nisinno sace daṭṭhukāmo hoti, gīvaṃ pasāretvā daṭṭhabbaṃ hoti. Tasmā
analyzed: hoti atipacchā nisinnaḥ sace daṭṭhu kāmo hoti gīvam pasāretvā daṭṭhabbam hoti tasmā
translated: If he is sitting too far behind, if he wants to see, he has to stretch his neck.

original: ayampi ete cha nisajjadose vajjetvā nisīdi. Tena vuttaṃ – “ekamantaṃ nisīdī”ti.
analyzed: ayam pi ete cha nisajja dose vajjetvā nisīdi tena vuttam ekamantam nisīdi iti
translated: Therefore, avoiding these six faults in posture, he sat down. Hence it was said: “He sat down at one side” .

original: Etadavocāti etaṃ avoca. Vuttamidaṃ bhante kaccāna bhagavatā aṭṭhakavaggiye māgaṇḍiyapañheti aṭṭhakavaggiyamhi māgaṇḍiyapañho nāma atthi, tasmiṃ pañhe.
analyzed: etat avoca ati etam avoca vuttam idam bhante kaccāna bhagavatā aṭṭhakavaggiye māgaṇḍiya pañhe iti aṭṭhakavaggiyamhi māgaṇḍiya pañhaḥ nāma atthi tasmin pañhe
translated: This he said: he said this. “This has been said by the Blessed One, venerable sir, in the Book of Eights, in the Magandiya-sutta.” There is a sutta called the Magandiya-sutta in the Book of Eights.

original: Rūpadhātūti rūpakkhandho adhippeto. Rūpadhāturāgavinibandhanti rūpadhātumhi rāgena🔽vinibaddhaṃ. Viññāṇanti kammaviññāṇaṃ. Okasārīti gehasārī ālayasārī. Kasmā panettha
analyzed: rūpadhātu uti rūpa kkhandhaḥ adhippetaḥ rūpadhātu rāga vinibandhanti rūpadhātumhi rāgena  vinibaddham viññāṇanti kamma viññāṇam oka sārī iti geha sārī ālaya sārī kasmā pana ittha
translated: The form element is intended by the words “the form element.” “Bound by passion for the form element”: bound by passion for the form element,🔽bound by passion for the form aggregate. “Consciousness”: kamma-generated consciousness. “Wandering on”: wandering in a house, wandering in a home. But why is it said here,

original: “viññāṇadhātu kho gahapatī”ti na vuttanti? Sammohavighātatthaṃ. “Oko”ti hi atthato
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu kho gahapati iti na vuttan ti sammoha vighāta attham okaḥ ti hi atthato
translated: “The consciousness element, householder”?—for the purpose of dispelling confusion. For “home” in the sense of

original: paccayo vuccati, purejātañca kammaviññāṇaṃ pacchājātassa kammaviññāṇassapi vipākaviññāṇassapi,🔽vipākaviññāṇañca vipākaviññāṇassapi kammaviññāṇassapi paccayo hoti, tasmā “kataraṃ
analyzed: paccayaḥ vuccati purejātañca kamma viññāṇam pacchājātassa kamma viññāṇassa api vipāka viññāṇassa api  vipāka viññāṇañca vipāka viññāṇassa api kamma viññāṇassa api paccayaḥ hoti tasmā kataram
translated: And the kamma-process consciousness that is a prenascent condition for the resultant consciousness is also a condition for the kamma-resultant consciousness and for the kamma-process consciousness that is a postnascent condition for it.

original: nu kho idha viññāṇa”nti sammoho bhaveyya. Tassa vighātatthaṃ taṃ aggahetvā asambhinnāva
analyzed: nu kho idha viññāṇanti sammohaḥ bhaveyya tassa vighāta attham tam aggahetvā
translated: And the resultant consciousness is a condition for the resultant consciousness and for the kamma-process consciousness. So there would be confusion as to which of these is meant by “consciousness” here.🔽So in order to avoid confusion, the teaching is given without mixing them up.

original: desanā katāti. Apica vipākaārammaṇavasena catasso abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṭṭhitiyoti vuttāti
analyzed: desanā katā ati api ca vipāka ārammaṇa vasena catasso abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti vuttā ati
translated: Besides, the four kinds of consciousness classed as “consciousness standing on a footing of its own choosing” are called “consciousness” because they are stated thus: “Four stations of consciousness, friends, have been declared by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened. What four?

original: tā dassetumpi idha viññāṇaṃ na gahitaṃ.
analyzed: tā dassetum pi idha viññāṇam na gahitam
translated: So they are not included here.

original: Upayupādānāti taṇhūpayadiṭṭhūpayavasena dve upayā, kāmupādānādīni cattāri upādānāni
analyzed: upayupādānā ti taṇhu upaya diṭṭhu upaya vasena dve upayā kāma upādāna ādīni cattāri upādānāni
translated: “Appropriation and clinging”: there are two kinds of appropriation, namely, that of craving and that of views, and there are four kinds of clinging, namely, clinging to sense desires, clinging to views, clinging to rules and vows, and clinging to a doctrine of self.

original: ca. Cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayāti akusalacittassa adhiṭṭhānabhūtā ceva abhinivesabhūtā
analyzed: ca cetasaḥ adhiṭṭhāna abhinivesa anusayā ati akusala cittassa adhiṭṭhāna bhūtā ca iva abhinivesa bhūtā
translated: “Determination, insistence, and underlying tendency”: these are the determinations, the insistences, and the underlying tendencies of unprofitable consciousness.

original: ca anusayabhūtā ca. Tathāgatassāti sammāsambuddhassa. Sabbesampi hi khīṇāsavānaṃ
analyzed: ca anusaya bhūtā ca tathāgatassa ati sammāsambuddhassa sabbesam pi hi khīṇāsavānam
translated: “The Tathāgata”: the fully enlightened one.

original: ete pahīnāva, satthu pana khīṇāsavabhāvo loke atipākaṭoti uparimakoṭiyā evaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Viññāṇadhātuyāti idha viññāṇaṃ kasmā gahitaṃ? Kilesappahānadassanatthaṃ. Kilesā hi
analyzed: ete pahīnā ava satthu pana khīṇāsava bhāvo loke ati pākaṭaḥ ti uparima koṭiyā evam vuttam  viññāṇa dhātuyā ti idha viññāṇam kasmā gahitam kilesa ppahāna dassana ttham kilesāḥ hi
translated: But the Exalted One’s state of being an Arahant is well known in the world. Therefore it is said that he has gone to the further shore.

original: na kevalaṃ catūsuyeva khandhesu pahīnā pahīyanti, pañcasupi pahīyantiyevāti kilesappahānadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: na kevalam catūsu yeva khandhesu pahīnā pahīyanti pañcasu pi pahīyanti yeva ati kilesa ppahāna dassana ttham
translated: Why is consciousness included here? In order to show the abandoning of defilements. For defilements are not abandoned only in the four aggregates, but also in the fifth aggregate. In order to show this,

original: gahitaṃ. Evaṃ kho gahapati anokasārī hotīti evaṃ kammaviññāṇena okaṃ asarantena anokasārī nāma hoti.🔽Rūpanimittaniketavisāravinibandhāti rūpameva kilesānaṃ paccayaṭṭhena nimittaṃ, ārammaṇakiriyasaṅkhātena🔽nivāsaṭṭhena niketanti rūpanimittaniketaṃ. Visāro ca vinibandho ca visāravinibandhā.
analyzed: gahitam evam kho gahapati an oka sārī hoti iti evam kamma viññāṇena okam a sarantena an oka sārī nāma hoti  rūpa nimitta niketa visāra vinibandhā ati rūpam eva kilesānam paccaya ṭṭhena nimittam ārammaṇa kiriya saṅkhātena  nivāsa aṭṭhena niketanti rūpa nimitta niketam visāraḥ ca vinibandhaḥ ca visāra vinibandhā
translated: consciousness is included. Thus, householder, one is a non-goer in the sense that one does not go to the destination of the kamma-process.🔽The sign of form, the abode, the spreading out, the bond: the form itself is the sign in the sense of being a condition for the defilements. It is the abode in the sense of being a dwelling for the activity of the defilements. Thus it is the sign of form and the abode of form. The spreading out and the bond are the spreading out and the bond.

original: Ubhayenapi hi kilesānaṃ patthaṭabhāvo ca vinibandhanabhāvo ca vutto, rūpanimittanikete
analyzed: ubhayena api hi kilesānam patthaṭa bhāvaḥ ca vinibandhana bhāvaḥ ca vuttaḥ rūpa nimitta nikete
translated: For by both terms the state of being firmly established and the state of being bound of the defilements are expressed. The sign of form and the abode of form are the sign of form and the abode of form.

original: visāravinibandhāti rūpanimittaniketavisāravinibandhā, tasmā rūpanimittaniketamhi🔽uppannena kilesavisārena ceva kilesavinibandhanena cāti attho. Niketasārīti vuccatīti🔽ārammaṇakaraṇavasena nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena niketasārīti vuccati. Pahīnāti te rūpanimittanikete
analyzed: visāra vinibandhā ati rūpa nimitta visāra vinibandhā tasmā  uppannena kilesa visārena ca iva kilesa vinibandhanena ca ati attho niketasārī iti vuccati iti  ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena niketasārī iti vuccati pahīnā ati te rūpa nimitta nikete
translated: ‘With the bond of proliferation’ means with the bond of proliferation of the sign of materiality and the proliferation of the abode of materiality. The meaning is: with the bond of the proliferation of defilements and with the proliferation of defilements that have arisen in regard to the sign of materiality and the abode of materiality. ‘Is called a wanderer in an abode’ means that he is called a wanderer in an abode in the sense of a place of dwelling by making it his object. ‘Has abandoned’ means that he has abandoned the sign of materiality and the abode of materiality.

original: kilesavisāravinibandhā pahīnā.
analyzed: kilesa visāra vinibandhā pahīnā
translated: The ‘spreading’ and ‘binding’ are the spreading and binding of defilements by the sign of materiality as a place of abode. So the meaning is that the defilements spread and bind by the sign of materiality as a place of abode. ‘Is called a wanderer in a place of abode’: it is called a wanderer in a place of abode in the sense of a dwelling place by making that the object. ‘Abandoned’: the spreading and binding of defilements by the sign of materiality as a place of abode are abandoned.

original: Kasmā panettha pañcakkhandhā ca “okā”ti vuttā, cha ārammaṇāni “niketa”nti? Chandarāgassa
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha pañca kkhandhā ca okā ati vuttā cha ārammaṇāni niketanti chandarāgassa
translated: But why are the five aggregates called ‘house’ and the six bases ‘place of abode’?

original: balavadubbalatāya. Samānepi hi etesaṃ ālayaṭṭhena visayabhāve okoti nippariyāyena
analyzed: balavat ubbala tāya samāne api hi etesam ālaya ṭṭhena visaya bhāve nippariyāyena
translated: Because of the strength and weakness of desire and lust. For although they are alike in being the abode and the objective field, the house is called the ‘house’ in the primary sense,

original: suddhaṃ gehameva vuccati, niketanti “ajja asukaṭṭhāne kīḷissāmā”ti katasaṅketānaṃ
analyzed: suddham geham eva vuccati niketanti ajja asuka ṭṭhāne kīḷissāma ati kata saṅketānam
translated: and the place of abode is called the ‘place of abode’ in the sense of a dwelling place.🔽Herein, just as desire and lust for the house that is full of children, wife, wealth, and corn is strong,

original: nivāsanaṭṭhānaṃ uyyānādi. Tattha yathā puttadāradhanadhaññapuṇṇagehe chandarāgo balavā
analyzed: nivāsana ṭṭhānam uyyāna ādi tattha yathā putta dāra dhana dhañña puṇṇa gehe chanda rāgaḥ balavā
translated: and

original: hoti, evaṃ ajjhattikesu khandhesu. Yathā pana uyyānaṭṭhānādīsu tato dubbalataro hoti,
analyzed: hoti evam ajjhattikesu khandhesu yathā pana uyyāna ṭṭhāna ādīsu tatas dubbalataraḥ hoti
translated: so too the external six bases are less important than the internal aggregates.

original: evaṃ bāhiresu chasu ārammaṇesūti chandarāgassa balavadubbalatāya evaṃ desanā katāti veditabbā.🔽Sukhitesu sukhitoti upaṭṭhākesu dhanadhaññalābhādivasena sukhitesu “idānāhaṃ manāpaṃ
analyzed: evam bāhiresu chasu ārammaṇesu iti chandarāgassa balavat ubbala tāya evam desanā katā ati veditabbā  sukhitesu sukhitaḥ ti upaṭṭhākesu dhana dhañña lābha ādi vasena sukhitesu idānāham manāpam
translated: This is how the teaching should be understood as given in accordance with the relative importance of the lust and greed.

original: cīvaraṃ manāpaṃ bhojanaṃ labhissāmī”ti gehassitasukhena sukhito hoti, tehi pattasampattiṃ🔽attanā anubhavamāno viya carati. Dukkhitesu dukkhitoti tesaṃ kenacideva kāraṇena
analyzed: cīvaram manāpam bhojanam labhissāmi iti geha ssita sukhena sukhitaḥ hoti tehi patta sampattim  attanā anubhavamānaḥ viya carati dukkhitesu dukkhitaḥ ti tesam kenacid eva kāraṇena
translated: He is happy when they are happy: when the attendants are happy with the gain of wealth, grain, etc., he is happy with the happiness of householders, thinking, “Now I shall get to wear pleasant cloth and to eat pleasant food.” He goes about as if he were sharing in their success.

original: dukkhe uppanne sayaṃ dviguṇena dukkhena dukkhito hoti. Kiccakaraṇīyesūti kiccasaṅkhātesu
analyzed: dukkhe uppanne sayam dviguṇena dukkhena dukkhitaḥ hoti kicca karaṇīyesu iti kicca saṅkhātesu
translated: He is unhappy when they are unhappy: when they are unhappy because of some misfortune, he is unhappy with double the unhappiness.

original: karaṇīyesu. Voyogaṃ āpajjatīti upayogaṃ sayaṃ tesaṃ kiccānaṃ kattabbataṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: karaṇīyesu voyogam āpajjati iti upayogam sayam tesam kiccānam kattabba tam āpajjati
translated: He takes on the work: he takes on the work that is to be done, which is called “work.”

original: Kāmesūti vatthukāmesu. Evaṃ kho gahapati kāmehi aritto hotīti evaṃ kilesakāmehi aritto hoti.
analyzed: kāmesu uti vatthu kāmesu evam kho gahapati kāmehi arittaḥ hoti iti evam kilesa kāmehi arittaḥ hoti
translated: In the sense-pleasures : in the sense-desire objects. Thus, householder, he is not freed from sense-desires : thus he is not freed from the defilement-sense-desires.

original: Anto kāmānaṃ bhāvena atuccho. Sukkapakkho tesaṃ abhāvena ritto tucchoti veditabbo.
analyzed: antaḥ kāmānam bhāvena atucchaḥ sukkapakkho tesam abhāvena rittaḥ tucchaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: He is empty with the presence of sense-desires within himself. The bright fortnight should be understood as empty with the absence of those .

original: Purakkharānoti vaṭṭaṃ purato kurumāno. Evaṃrūpo siyantiādīsu dīgharassakāḷodātādīsu
analyzed: vaṭṭam puratas kurumānaḥ evaṃrūpaḥ siyanti ādīsu dīgha rassa kāḷodāta ādīsu
translated: With the round : making the round in front. In the passages beginning with “Thus would I be” , he wishes to be of such a form in the forms such as long, short, black, white, etc.;🔽in the feelings such as pleasant, etc., he wishes to be of such a feeling; in the perceptions such as blue, etc.,

original: rūpesu evaṃrūpo nāma bhaveyyanti pattheti. Sukhādīsu vedanāsu evaṃvedano nāma. Nīlasaññādīsu🔽saññāsu evaṃsañño nāma. Puññābhisaṅkhārādīsu saṅkhāresu evaṃsaṅkhāro nāma. Cakkhuviññāṇādīsu
analyzed: rūpesu evaṃrūpaḥ nāma bhaveyyanti pattheti sukha ādīsu vedanāsu evaṃvedanaḥ nāma nīla saññā ādīsu  saññāsu evaṃsañño nāma puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīsu saṅkhāresu evaṃsaṅkhāro nāma cakkhu viññāṇa ādīsu
translated: he wishes to be of such a perception; in the volitions such as the formation of merit, etc., he wishes to be of such a volition; in the consciousnesses such as eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: viññāṇesu evaṃviññāṇo nāma bhaveyyanti pattheti.🔽Apurakkharānoti vaṭṭaṃ purato akurumāno. Sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ teti tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇesu evaṃviññāṇaḥ nāma bhaveyyanti pattheti  vaṭṭam puratas a kurumānaḥ sahitam me a sahitam te iti tuyham vacanam
translated: he wishes to be of such a consciousness.🔽Without the round : not making the round in front. “My words are coherent, your words are incoherent” : your words are incoherent, unmethodical; my words are coherent, methodical, sweet, sweet as a drink.

original: asahitaṃ asiliṭṭhaṃ, mayhaṃ sahitaṃ siliṭṭhaṃ madhuraṃ madhurapānasadisaṃ. Adhiciṇṇaṃ
analyzed: asahitam a siliṭṭham sahitam siliṭṭham madhuram madhura pāna sadisam adhiciṇṇam
translated: “My words are well-spoken, your words are ill-spoken” : my words are well-spoken, well-ordered, well-arranged, well-spoken, well-composed, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well-spoken, well

original: te viparāvattanti yaṃ tuyhaṃ dīghena kālena paricitaṃ suppaguṇaṃ, taṃ mama vādaṃ
analyzed: te viparāvattanti yam tuyham dīghena kālena paricitam su paguṇam tam mama vādam
translated: They turn back on you, and what you have long known and cherished as good, that turns back on you, turns away from you, when it comes to my view.

original: āgamma sabbaṃ khaṇena viparāvattaṃ nivattaṃ. Āropito te vādoti tuyhaṃ doso mayā āropito.🔽Cara vādappamokkhāyāti taṃ taṃ ācariyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā uttaraṃ pariyesanto imassa
analyzed: āgamma sabbam khaṇena viparāvattam nivattam āropitaḥ te vādaḥ iti tuyham dosaḥ mayā āropito  cara vāda pamokkhāya ati tam tam ācariyam upasaṅkamitvā uttaram pariyesantaḥ imassa
translated: Your view is refuted: your fault is refuted by me.🔽Go and be released from your view: go and seek a reply from this and that teacher, and go wandering about for release from this view.🔽Or be released right here if you can: if you can, be released right here.

original: vādassa mokkhāya cara āhiṇḍa. Nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti atha sayameva pahosi, idheva nibbeṭhehīti.
analyzed: vādassa mokkhāya cara āhiṇḍa nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosi iti atha sayam eva pahosi idha iva nibbeṭhehi iti
translated: This is the kind of person who is “secluded from the kinds of views” .

original: 80. So evarūpo “yehi vivitto”ti gāthā. Tattha yehīti yehi diṭṭhigatādīhi. Vivitto🔽vicareyyāti ritto careyya. Na tāni uggayha vadeyya nāgoti “āguṃ na karotī”tiādinā
analyzed: saḥ evarūpaḥ yehi vivittaḥ ti gāthā tattha yehi iti yehi diṭṭhi gata ādīhi vivittaḥ  vicareyya ati ritto careyya na tāni uggayha vadeyya āgum na karoti itiādinā
translated: Herein, from the kinds of views means from the kinds of view beginning with “soul-view” .🔽He should wander secluded : he should wander alone.

original: nayena nāgo tāni diṭṭhigatāni uggahetvā na careyya. Elambujanti elasaññite ambumhi
analyzed: nayena nāgaḥ tāni diṭṭhigatāni uggahetvā na careyya elambujanti ela saññite ambumhi
translated: He should not go about proclaiming those views: he should not go about proclaiming those views in the way that an elephant in rut does not go about trumpeting.🔽The lotus-creeper: the lotus-creeper is a creeper that grows in water and has a stalk and a bud.

original: jātaṃ kaṇṭakanāḷaṃ vārijaṃ, padumanti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathā jalena paṅkena canūpalittanti
analyzed: jātam kaṇṭaka nāḷam vāri jam padumanti vuttam hoti yathā jalena paṅkena
translated: The lotus is what is meant.🔽As though untouched by water and mud:

original: taṃ padumaṃ yathā jalena ca paṅkena ca anupalittaṃ hoti. Evaṃ muni santivādo agiddhoti
analyzed: tam padumam yathā jalena ca paṅkena ca an upalittam hoti evam muni
translated: Just as the lotus is unsoiled by the water and mud, so the sage’s speech is unsoiled by greed.

original: evaṃ ajjhattasantivādo muni gedhābhāvena agiddho. Kāme ca loke ca anūpalittoti duvidhepi
analyzed: evam ajjhatta santivādaḥ gedhā bhāvena agiddhaḥ kāme ca loke ca duvidhe pi
translated: Thus the sage’s speech is unsoiled by greed because of the absence of greed in his mind. He is unsoiled by sensual pleasures and the world: by the two defilements

original: kāme apāyādike ca loke dvīhi silesehi anupalitto hoti.🔽Āguṃ na karotīti akusalādidosaṃ na karoti. Na gacchatīti agativasena na gacchati.🔽Nāgacchatīti pahīnakilese na upeti. Pāpakāti lāmakā. Akusalāti akosallasambhūtā.🔽Te kilese na punetīti ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese puna na eti. Na paccetīti paṭi
analyzed: kāme apāya ādike ca loke dvīhi silesehi an upalittaḥ hoti  āgum na karoti iti akusala ādi dosam na karoti na gacchati iti agati vasena na gacchati  na āgacchati iti pahīna kilese na upeti pāpakā ati lāmakā akusalā ati akosalla sambhūtā  te kilese na puneti iti ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese puna na eti na pacceti iti paṭi
translated: and by the world consisting of the lower worlds, etc.🔽He does not create evil: he does not create the evil of unwholesome states, etc. He does not go: he does not go by way of rebirth.

original: na upeti. Na paccāgacchatīti puna na nivattati.
analyzed: na upeti na paccāgacchati iti puna na nivattati
translated: He does not come: he does not approach the defilements that have been abandoned. He does not accumulate evil: he does not approach again the defilements that have been abandoned. He does not return: he does not return again.

original: Kharadaṇḍoti kharapattadaṇḍo pharusadaṇḍo. Cattagedhoti vissaṭṭhagedho. Vantagedhoti
analyzed: khara daṇḍo ti khara patta daṇḍo pharusa daṇḍo catta gedho ti vissaṭṭha gedho vanta gedho ti
translated: A rough staff: a rough wooden staff. A rough covering: a rough cloth covering. A rough shelter: a rough shelter.

original: vamitagedho. Muttagedhoti chinnabandhanagedho. Pahīnagedhoti pajahitagedho. Paṭinissaṭṭhagedhoti🔽yathā na puna cittaṃ āruhati, evaṃ paṭivissajjitagedho. Upari vītarāgādīsupi eseva🔽nayo. Sabbāneva tāni gahitaggahaṇassa vissaṭṭhabhāvavevacanāni.🔽81. Kiñca bhiyyo – “na vedagū”ti gāthā. Tattha na vedagū diṭṭhiyāyakoti catumaggavedagū
analyzed: vamita gedhaḥ mutta gedho ti chinna bandhana gedhaḥ pahīna gedho ti pajahita gedho paṭinissaṭṭha gedho ti  yathā na puna cittam āruhati evam paṭivissajjita gedhaḥ upari vīta rāga ādīsu pi esā iva  nayo tāni gahita ggahaṇassa vissaṭṭha bhāva vevacanāni  kiñca bhiyyas na vedagū ti gāthā tattha na vedagū diṭṭhiyāyako ti catu magga vedagū
