translated: “One who has vomited the poison” is one who has vomited the poison of conceit. “One who has cut the bond” is one who has cut the bond of conceit. “One who has abandoned the poison” is one who has abandoned the poison of conceit. “One who has given up the poison” is one who has given up the poison of conceit. “One who has rejected the poison” is one who has rejected the poison of conceit.🔽In the same way, the rest of the terms should be understood as synonyms for the state of being free from the grasping of the grasped and the grasper.🔽“And what is more” is a term for the following verse. “One who is not a knower of the path” is one who is not a knower of the four paths.

original: mādiso diṭṭhiyāyako na hoti, diṭṭhiyā gacchanto vā, taṃ sārato paccento vā na hoti.🔽Tattha vacanattho – yāyatīti yāyako. Karaṇavacanena diṭṭhiyā yāyatīti diṭṭhiyāyako.🔽Upayogatthe sāmivacanenapi diṭṭhiyā yātītipi diṭṭhiyāyako. Na mutiyā sa mānametīti🔽mutarūpādibhedāya mutiyāpi so mānaṃ na eti. Na hi tammayo soti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena
analyzed: mādisaḥ diṭṭhiyāyakaḥ na hoti diṭṭhiyā gacchantaḥ vā tam sārataḥ paccentaḥ vā na hoti 🔽tattha vacana atthaḥ yāyati iti yāyako karaṇa vacanena diṭṭhiyā yāyati iti diṭṭhiyāyako 🔽upayoga atthe sāmi vacanena api diṭṭhiyā yāti iti pi diṭṭhiyāyakaḥ na mutiyā sa mānam eti iti 🔽muta rūpa ādi bhedāya mutiyā api saḥ mānam na eti na hi tad mayaḥ saḥ ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena

original: tammayo hoti tapparāyaṇo, ayaṃ pana na tādiso. Na kammunā nopi sutena neyyoti puññābhisaṅkhārādinā
analyzed: tad mayaḥ hoti tad parāyaṇaḥ ayam pana na tādisaḥ na kammunā na upi sutena puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādinā
translated: He is bound to it, he is dependent on it. But this one is not like that.

original: kammunā vā, sutasuddhiādinā sutena vā so netabbo na hoti. Anūpanīto sa nivesanesūti
analyzed: kammunā vā suta suddhi ādinā sutena vā so netabbaḥ na hoti anūpanītaḥ sa nivesanesu uti
translated: He is not led by kamma or by learning. He is not led by kamma consisting in the performance of meritorious and other kinds of deeds, or by learning consisting in the purification of virtue, etc.

original: so dvinnampi upayānaṃ pahīnattā sabbesu taṇhādiṭṭhinivesanesu anupanīto.🔽Mutarūpena vāti ettha mutarūpaṃ nāma gandharasaphoṭṭhabbāni. Mānaṃ netīti asmimānaṃ na eti. Na upetīti samīpaṃ na eti. Na upagacchatīti upagantvā na tiṭṭhati. Tammayoti tappakato.
analyzed: so dvinnam pi upayānam pahīna ttā sabbesu taṇhā diṭṭhi nivesanesu anupanītaḥ  muta rūpena vā ti ettha muta rūpam nāma gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbāni mānam neti iti asmimānam na eti na upeti iti samīpam na eti na upagacchati iti upagantvā na tiṭṭhati tammayaḥ ti tad pakato
translated: He is not led by either of these two. He is not led by craving and views.

original: Paññāvimuttassāti vipassanāpubbaṅgamāya bhāvanāya sabbakilesehi vimuttassa. Iminā🔽sukkhavipassako adhippeto. Saññañca diṭṭhiñca ye aggahesuṃ, te ghaṭṭamānā vicaranti
analyzed: paññā vimuttassa ati vipassanā pubbaṅgamāya bhāvanāya sabba kilesehi vimuttassa iminā  sukkha vipassakaḥ adhippeto saññam ca diṭṭhiñca ye aggahesum te ghaṭṭamānāḥ vicaranti
translated: “Liberated in wisdom”: liberated from all defilements by the development of insight preceded by serenity. This refers to🔽the dry-insight worker.🔽“Those who have grasped at perception and view,

original: loketi ye pana kāmasaññādikaṃ saññaṃ aggahesuṃ, te visesato gahaṭṭhā kāmādhikaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: loke iti ye pana kāma saññā ādikam saññam aggahesum te visesataḥ gahaṭṭhāḥ kāma adhikaraṇam
translated: they wander, colliding”: but those who have grasped at perception such as sensual perception, they are especially prone to quarrels about sensual desires,

original: ye ca diṭṭhiṃ aggahesuṃ, te visesato pabbajitā dhammādhikaraṇaṃ aññamaññaṃ ghaṭṭentā vicarantīti.🔽Yo samathapubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāvetīti yo puggalo samathapubbaṅgamaṃ purecārikaṃ🔽katvā sahavipassanaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti, paṭhamaṃ samādhiṃ uppādetvā pacchā sahavipassanaṃ
analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhim aggahesum te visesataḥ pabbajitāḥ dhamma adhikaraṇam aññam aññam ghaṭṭentāḥ vicaranti iti  yaḥ samatha pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti iti yaḥ puggalaḥ samatha pubbaṅgamam purecārikam  katvā saha vipassanam ariya maggam bhāveti paṭhamam samādhim uppādetvā pacchā saha vipassanam
translated: and those who have grasped at views are especially prone to quarrels about the Dhamma as recluses.🔽“Who develops the noble path preceded by serenity”: this person develops the noble path with insight preceded by serenity,

original: ariyamaggaṃ uppādetīti attho. Tassa āditoti tassa puggalassa paṭhamajjhānādito. Upādāyāti
analyzed: ariya maggam uppādeti iti attho tassa āditaḥ ti tassa puggalassa paṭhamajjhāna āditaḥ upādāya ati
translated: the meaning is that he first arouses concentration and then arouses the noble path with insight. “From the beginning”: from the first jhāna. “Taking that as a basis”:

original: paṭicca āgamma. Ganthā vikkhambhītā hontīti ganthā dūrīkatā bhavanti. Arahatte patteti
analyzed: paṭicca āgamma ganthāḥ vikkhambhītāḥ honti iti ganthāḥ dūrīkatāḥ bhavanti arahatte patteti
translated: ‘The fetters are suppressed’: the fetters are removed. ‘When he has reached Arahantship’:

original: arahattaphalaṃ patte. Arahatoti arahattaphale ṭhitassa. Ganthā ca mohā cātiādayo
analyzed: arahatta phalam patte arahato ti arahatta phale ṭhitassa ganthā ca mohā ca ati ādayo
translated: when he has reached the fruition of Arahantship. ‘The fetters and the confusions’:

original: sabbe kilesā pahīnā honti.
analyzed: sabbe kilesā pahīnāḥ honti
translated: all the defilements are abandoned.

original: Yo vipassanāpubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāvetīti yo puggalo vipassanaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ purecārikaṃ🔽katvā ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti, paṭhamaṃ vipassanaṃ uppādetvā pacchā ariyamaggasampayuttaṃ🔽samādhiṃ bhāvetīti attho. Tassa ādito upādāyāti tassa puggalassa vipassanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: yaḥ vipassanā pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti iti yaḥ puggalaḥ vipassanam pubbaṅgamam purecārikam  katvā ariya maggam bhāveti paṭhamam vipassanam uppādetvā pacchā ariya magga sampayuttam  samādhim bhāveti iti attho tassa āditaḥ upādāya ati tassa puggalassa vipassanataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: ‘He who develops the noble path with insight as the forerunner’: the person who develops the noble path with insight as the forerunner, as the prior condition,🔽as the first, as the leader, as the forerunner, as the cause, as the condition, as the basis, as the foundation, as the support, as the basis for the arising of the noble path.

original: vipassanaṃ paṭicca. Mohā vikkhambhitā hontīti ettha vikkhambhitāti dūraṃ pāpitā saññāvasena.
analyzed: vipassanam paṭicca mohāḥ vikkhambhitāḥ honti iti ettha vikkhambhitā ati dūram pāpi tā saññā vasena
translated: ‘From the beginning’: from the time of insight. ‘The confusions are suppressed’: here ‘suppressed’ means ‘removed far away’ by the perception of insight.

original: Ghaṭṭentīti ye kāmasaññādiṃ gaṇhanti, te saññāvasena pīḷenti. Saṅghaṭṭentīti tato
analyzed: ghaṭṭenti iti ye kāma saññā ādim gaṇhanti te saññā vasena pīḷenti saṅghaṭṭenti iti tatas
translated: ‘They clash’: the perceptions that grasp sense desires, etc., oppress by means of the perception of insight. ‘They collide’:

original: tato pīḷenti. Idāni ghaṭṭente dassetuṃ “rājānopi rājūhi vivadantī”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: tatas pīḷenti idāni ghaṭṭente dassetum rājānaḥ api rājūhi vivadanti itiādinā nayena
translated: Then they oppress. Now, in order to show that they strike, the following is said in detail: “Kings quarrel with kings.”

original: vitthāro vutto. Aññamaññaṃ pāṇīhipi upakkamantīti ettha aññamaññaṃ hatthehi paharanti.
analyzed: vitthāraḥ vuttaḥ aññamaññam upakkamanti iti ettha aññamaññam hatthehi paharanti
translated: In the passage “they attack one another with their hands,” they strike one another with their hands.

original: Leḍḍūhīti kapālakhaṇḍehi. Daṇḍehīti aḍḍhadaṇḍakehi. Satthehīti ubhatodhārehi satthehi.
analyzed: leḍḍūhi iti kapāla khaṇḍehi daṇḍehi iti aḍḍhadaṇḍakehi satthehi iti ubhatodhārehi satthehi
translated: “With clods” means with pieces of broken pots. “With sticks” means with half-sticks. “With swords” means with double-edged swords.

original: Abhisaṅkhārānaṃ appahīnattāti puññādiabhisaṅkhārānaṃ appahīnabhāvena. Gatiyā ghaṭṭentīti🔽gantabbāya patiṭṭhābhūtāya gatiyā pīḷenti ghaṭṭanaṃ āpajjanti. Nirayādīsupi eseva
analyzed: abhisaṅkhārānam appahīna ttā ti puñña ādi abhisaṅkhārānam appahīna bhāvena gatiyā ghaṭṭenti iti  gantabbāya patiṭṭhā bhūtāya gatiyā pīḷenti ghaṭṭanam āpajjanti niraya ādīsu pi esā iva
translated: “Because they have not abandoned the formations” means because they have not abandoned the formations of merit, etc. “They strike the destination” means

original: nayo. Sesamettha vuttanayattā uttānameva.🔽Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya🔽Māgaṇḍiyasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽10. Purābhedasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽83. Dasame purābhedasuttaniddese kathaṃdassīti imassa suttassa ito paresañca pañcannaṃ
analyzed: nayo sesam ettha vutta naya ttā uttānam eva 🔽saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya 🔽māgaṇḍiya sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽        🔽dasame purābheda sutta niddese imassa suttassa itas paresam ca
translated: they oppress and strike the destination which is the basis for going. The same method applies to the hells, etc. The rest is clear.

original: kalahavivādacūḷabyūhamahābyūhatuvaṭakaattadaṇḍasuttānaṃ sammāparibbājanīyasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: kalaha vivāda cūḷabyūha mahābyūha tuvaṭaka attadaṇḍa suttānam sammāparibbājanīya sutta vaṇṇanāyam
translated: In the commentaries on the Kalahavivāda, Cūḷabyūha, Mahābyūha, Tuvaṭaka, and Attadaṇḍa Suttas,🔽

original: vuttanayeneva sāmaññato uppatti veditabbā. Visesato pana yatheva tasmiṃ mahāsamaye
analyzed: vutta nayena iva sāmaññataḥ uppatti veditabbā visesataḥ pana yathā iva tasmin mahā samaye
translated: The origin of the sutta in general should be understood in the way already stated in the commentary on the Sammāparibbājaniya Sutta .

original: rāgacaritadevatānaṃ sappāyavasena dhammaṃ desetuṃ nimmitabuddhena attānaṃ pucchāpetvā🔽sammāparibbājanīyasuttanta- mabhāsi, evaṃ tasmiṃyeva mahāsamaye “kiṃ nu kho purā
analyzed: rāga carita devatānam sappāya vasena dhammam desetum nimmita buddhena attānam pucchāpetvā  sammāparibbājanīya suttanta mabhāsi evam tasmin yeva mahā samaye kim nu kho purā
translated: But in particular, just as the Buddha of Apparition, in order to teach the Dhamma in a way suitable for the deities of lustful temperament,🔽had himself questioned by the Buddha of the Akaniṭṭha heaven and then delivered the Sammāparibbājaniya Sutta,

original: sarīrabhedā kattabba”nti uppannacittānaṃ devatānaṃ cittaṃ ñatvā tāsaṃ anuggahatthaṃ
analyzed: sarīra bhedā kattabbanti uppanna cittānam devatānam cittam ñatvā tāsam anuggaha ttham
translated: so too, in that same great aeon, after discerning the thoughts of deities who had arisen from the brahma-world and were thinking, “What must we do🔽before the dissolution of the body in order to be reborn in the brahma-world?” and after bringing by the air-path a Buddha of Apparition surrounded by 1,320,000 bhikkhus,

original: aḍḍhateḷasabhikkhusataparivāraṃ nimmitabuddhaṃ ākāsena ānetvā tena attānaṃ pucchāpetvā imaṃ suttamabhāsi.
analyzed: aḍḍhateḷasa bhikkhu sata parivāram nimmitabuddham ākāsena ānetvā tena attānam pucchāpetvā imam suttam abhāsi
translated: had himself questioned by that Buddha of Apparition and then delivered this sutta.

original: Kathaṃ? Buddhā nāma mahantā ete sattavisesā, yaṃ sadevakassa lokassa diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ
analyzed: katham buddhāḥ nāma mahantāḥ ete satta visesāḥ yam sa devakassa lokassa diṭṭham sutam
translated: How? The Buddhas are great, and they have seven special qualities. There is nothing in the seen or heard,

original: mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā na kiñci katthaci nīlādivasena
analyzed: mutam viññātam pattam pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā na kiñci katthaci nīla ādi vasena
translated: in the sensed or cognized, in what is attained, sought, pondered by the mind—nothing anywhere—that is not known to them.

original: vibhattarūpārammaṇesu vibhattarūpārammaṇaṃ vā, bherisaddādivasena vibhattasaddārammaṇādīsu
analyzed: vibhatta rūpa ārammaṇesu vibhatta rūpa ārammaṇam vā bheri sadda ādi vasena vibhatta sadda ārammaṇa ādīsu
translated: Or, among visible-data objects that are differentiated, he discerns the visible-data object that is the object of his knowledge, as in the case of the sound of a drum, etc., or among sound objects that are differentiated, he discerns the sound object that is the object of his knowledge, and so on as far as the mind object.

original: saddādiārammaṇaṃ vā atthi, yaṃ etesaṃ ñāṇamukhe āpāthaṃ nāgacchati. Yathāha – “yaṃ,
analyzed: sadda ādi ārammaṇam vā atthi yam etesam ñāṇa mukhe āpātham na āgacchati yathā āha yam
translated: There is no object of these kinds that does not come within the range of his knowledge, as is said:

original: bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa…pe… sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ🔽pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ jānāmi tamahaṃ abbhaññāsi”nti. Evaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: bhikkhave sa devakassa lokassape sa deva manussāya diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam pattam  pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā tam aham jānāmi tam aham abbhaññāsin ti evam sabbattha
translated: “Bhikkhus, I know the world with its devas, with Māra and Brahmā, with this generation, with recluses and brahmans, with devas and men, as it really is” .

original: appaṭihatañāṇo bhagavā sabbāpi tā devatā bhabbābhabbavasena dve koṭṭhāse akāsi. “Kammāvaraṇena
analyzed: appaṭihata ñāṇaḥ bhagavā sabbā api tāḥ devatāḥ bhabba abhabba vasena dve koṭṭhāse akāsi kamma āvaraṇena
translated: Thus the Blessed One, whose knowledge is unobstructed as to all objects, divided all those deities into two classes, according as they were capable or incapable .

original: vā samannāgatā”tiādinā hi nayena vuttā sattā abhabbā nāma. Te ekavihāre vasantepi
analyzed: vā samannāgatā ati ādinā hi nayena vuttā sattā abhabbāḥ nāma te eka vihāre vasante pi
translated: For those beings described in the way beginning, “Endowed with action as a requisite condition” , are called “incapable” . The Buddhas do not look at them even if they live in the same monastery.

original: buddhā na olokenti. Viparītā pana bhabbā nāma. Te dūre vasantepi gantvā saṅgaṇhanti.
analyzed: buddhāḥ na olokenti viparītā pana bhabbāḥ nāma te dūre vasante api gantvā saṅgaṇhanti
translated: But those described in the opposite way are called “capable” . The Buddhas go and gather them even if they live far away.

original: Tasmiṃ devatāsannipāte ye abhabbā, te pahāya bhabbe pariggahesi. Pariggahetvā “ettakā
analyzed: tasmin devatā sannipāte ye abhabbā te pahāya bhabbe pariggahesi pariggahetvā ettakā
translated: So the Blessed One, having excluded those deities that were incapable, included those that were capable. Having included them, he considered:

original: ettha rāgacaritā, ettakā dosādicaritā”ti cariyavasena cha koṭṭhāse akāsi. Atha nesaṃ
analyzed: ettha rāga caritā ettakā dosa ādi caritā ati cariya vasena cha koṭṭhāse atha nesam
translated: He made six groups according to temperament. Then,

original: sappāyadhammadesanaṃ upadhārento “rāgacaritānaṃ devānaṃ sammāparibbājanīyasuttaṃ
analyzed: sappāya dhamma desanam upadhārentaḥ rāga caritānam devānam sammāparibbājanīya suttam
translated: as he considered what kind of Dhamma talk would be suitable for them, he thought thus: “I shall give the Sammāparibhāvana Sutta to the gods of the Rūpa world who are of the Rāga temperament;

original: kathessāmi, dosacaritānaṃ kalahavivādasuttaṃ, mohacaritānaṃ mahābyūhasuttaṃ, vitakkacaritānaṃ
analyzed: kathessāmi dosa caritānam kalaha vivāda suttam moha caritānam mahā byūha suttam vitakka caritānam
translated: the Kalahavivāda Sutta to those of the Dosa temperament; the Mahābyūha Sutta to those of the Moha temperament;

original: cūḷabyūhasuttaṃ, saddhācaritānaṃ tuvaṭakasuttaṃ, buddhicaritānaṃ purābhedasuttaṃ🔽kathessāmī”ti desanaṃ vavatthāpetvā puna taṃ parisaṃ manasākāsi “attajjhāsayena nu
analyzed: cūḷabyūha suttam saddhā caritānam tuvaṭaka suttam buddhi caritānam purābheda suttam  kathessāmi iti desanam vavatthāpetvā puna tam parisam manasā akāsi nu
translated: the Cūḷabyūha Sutta to those of the Vitakka temperament; the Tuvaṭaka Sutta to those of the Saddhā temperament; and the Purābheda Sutta to those of the Buddhi temperament.”🔽Having thus determined the Dhamma talk, he again considered the assembly thus: “Will they understand by themselves, or by the prompting of others, or by the occurrence of a miracle, or by a question?”

original: kho jāneyya, parajjhāsayena, aṭṭhuppattikena, pucchāvasenā”ti. Tato “pucchāvasena🔽jāneyyā”ti ñatvā “atthi nu kho koci devatānaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ gahetvā cariyavasena pañhaṃ
analyzed: kho jāneyya parajjhāsayena aṭṭhuppattikena pucchā vasena ati tatas pucchā vasena  jāneyya ati ñatvā atthi nu kho koci devatānam ajjhāsayam gahetvā cariya vasena pañham
translated: Then he thought: “They will understand by a question.”🔽After that he considered: “Is there anyone among the five hundred bhikkhus who is able to ask a question after having grasped the inclination of the gods?”

original: pucchituṃ samattho”ti “tesu pañcasatesu bhikkhūsu ekopi na sakkotī”ti addasa. Tato
analyzed: pucchitum samatthaḥ ti tesu pañcasatesu bhikkhūsu ekaḥ api na sakkoti iti addasa tatas
translated: He saw that not a single bhikkhu was able to do so.

original: asītimahāsāvake, dve aggasāvake ca samannāharitvā “tepi na sakkontī”ti disvā cintesi🔽– “sace paccekabuddho bhaveyya, sakkuṇeyya nu kho”ti. “Sopi na sakkuṇeyyo”ti ñatvā🔽“sakkasuyāmādīsu koci sakkuṇeyyā”ti samannāhari. Sace hi tesu koci sakkuṇeyya, taṃ
analyzed: asīti mahāsāvake dve aggasāvake ca samannāharitvā te pi na sakkonti iti disvā cintesi  sace paccekabuddhaḥ bhaveyya sakkuṇeyya nu kho ti saḥ api na sakkuṇeyya iti ñatvā  sakkasuyāma ādīsu koci sakkuṇeyya ati sace hi tesu koci sakkuṇeyya tam
translated: and then he thought, “If there were a Paccekabuddha, would he be able to do it?” and he saw that he would not be able to do it.🔽Then he thought, “Would Sakka or anyone else be able to do it?” and he saw that they would not be able to do it.

original: pucchāpetvā attanā vissajjeyya. Na pana tesupi koci sakkoti. Athassa etadahosi –
analyzed: pucchāpetvā attanā vissajjeyya na pana tesu pi koci sakkoti
translated: If anyone had been able to do it, he would have asked him to do it and would have answered the question himself. But since no one was able to do it, he thought,

original: “mādiso buddhoyeva sakkuṇeyya, atthi pana katthaci añño buddho”ti anantāsu lokadhātūsu
analyzed: mādisaḥ buddhaḥ yeva sakkuṇeyya atthi pana katthaci aññaḥ buddhaḥ ti anantāsu lokadhātūsu
translated: “Only a Buddha like me would be able to do it. But is there any other Buddha anywhere?” and he extended his infinite knowledge to infinite world systems

original: anantañāṇaṃ pattharitvā lokaṃ olokento na aññaṃ buddhaṃ addasa. Anacchariyañcetaṃ,
analyzed: ananta ñāṇam pattharitvā lokam olokentaḥ na aññam buddham addasa
translated: and surveyed the world. He did not see any other Buddha. But this is not surprising,

original: idāni attanā samaṃ na passeyya, yo jātadivasepi brahmajālavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayena
analyzed: idāni attanā samam na passeyya yaḥ jāta divase pi brahmajāla vaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena
translated: since he did not see anyone equal to himself even on the day of his birth, as has been related in the Brahmajala Sutta .

original: attanā samaṃ apassanto “aggohamasmi lokassā”ti appaṭivattiyaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadi. Evaṃ
analyzed: attanā samam a passantaḥ aggo ham asmi lokassa ati appaṭivattiyam sīha nādam nadi evam
translated: Not seeing anyone equal to himself, he uttered the lion’s roar of the Great Man, which cannot be uttered by anyone else: “I am the chief in the world, I am the eldest in the world, I am the foremost in the world.”

original: aññaṃ attanā samaṃ apassitvā cintesi “sace ahaṃ pucchitvā ahameva vissajjeyyaṃ, evaṃ🔽tā devatā na sakkhissanti paṭivijjhituṃ. Aññasmiṃ pana buddheyeva pucchante mayi
analyzed: aññam attanā samam a passitvā cintesi sace aham pucchitvā aham eva vissajjeyyam evam  tāḥ devatāḥ na sakkhissanti paṭivijjhitum aññasmin pana buddhe iva iva pucchante mayi
translated: and not seeing anyone equal to himself, he thought, “If I were to ask and answer myself,🔽then those deities would not be able to penetrate it. But if I were to ask another Buddha and

original: ca vissajjante accherakaṃ bhavissati, sakkhissanti ca devatā paṭivijjhituṃ, tasmā
analyzed: ca vissajjante accherakam bhavissati sakkhissanti ca devatā paṭivijjhitum tasmai
translated: answer myself, it would be too much for them, and they would be able to penetrate it. Therefore

original: nimmitabuddhaṃ māpessāmī”ti abhiññāpādakaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya “pattacīvaraggahaṇaṃ🔽ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritañca mama sadisaṃyeva hotū”ti kāmāvacaracittehi
analyzed: nimmita buddham māpessāmi iti abhiññāpādakam jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya patta cīvara ggahaṇam  ālokitam vilokitam samiñjitam pasāritam ca mama sadisam yā iva hotu uti kāmāvacara cittehi
translated: I will create a phantom Buddha.” He entered into jhāna as the basis for direct knowledge, and🔽emerged and resolved, “Let the taking up of the bowl and robe, the looking to the right and left,

original: parikammaṃ katvā “pācīnayugandharaparikkhepato ullaṅghayamānaṃ candamaṇḍalaṃ bhinditvā
analyzed: parikammam katvā pācīna yugandhara parikkhepataḥ ullaṅghayamānam canda maṇḍalam bhinditvā
translated: and the stride be just like mine.” He then performed the preliminary work with sense-sphere🔽consciousness, and resolved with a fine-material-sphere consciousness, “Let it come as if breaking

original: nikkhamanto viya āgacchatū”ti rūpāvacaracittena adhiṭṭhāsi. Devasaṅgho taṃ disvā
analyzed: nikkhamantaḥ viya āgacchatu uti rūpāvacara cittena adhiṭṭhāsi deva saṅghaḥ tam disvā
translated: through the eastern range of the Himalayas and emerging.” The company of deities saw it and🔽said, “Has another moon risen, sir?” Then, leaving the moon aside, they saw the nearer one and said,

original: “aññopi nu kho bho, cando uggato”ti āha. Atha candaṃ ohāya āsannatare jāte “na cando,
analyzed: aññaḥ api nu kho bho candaḥ uggataḥ ti āha atha candam ohāya āsannatare jāte na cando
translated: “It is not the moon,

original: sūriyo uggato”ti. Puna āsannatare jāte “na sūriyo, devavimānaṃ eta”nti. Puna āsannatare
analyzed: sūriyaḥ uggataḥ iti punar āsannatare jāte na sūriyaḥ deva vimānam punar āsannatare
translated: and then, as it came nearer, “It is not the sun, it is a celestial mansion.” And then, as it came nearer,

original: jāte “na devavimānaṃ, devaputto eso”ti. Puna āsannatare jāte “na devaputto, mahābrahmā
analyzed: jāte na deva vimānam deva putto punar āsannatare jāte na deva puttaḥ mahābrahmā
translated: “It is not a celestial mansion, it is a celestial being.” And then, as it came nearer,🔽“It is not a celestial being, it is Great Brahmā.” And then, as it came nearer,

original: eso”ti. Puna āsannatare jāte “na mahābrahmā, aparopi bho buddho āgato”ti āha.
analyzed: esaḥ iti punar āsannatare jāte na mahābrahmā aparaḥ api bho buddhaḥ āgataḥ iti āha
translated: “It is not Great Brahmā, it is another Blessed One come.”

original: Tattha puthujjanadevatā cintayiṃsu – “ekabuddhassa tāva ayaṃ devatāsannipāto. Dvinnaṃ
analyzed: tattha puthujjana devatā cintayiṃsu ekabuddhassa tāva ayam devatā sannipātaḥ dvinnam
translated: Herein, the deities who were ordinary men thought, “This is the gathering of deities for one Blessed One.

original: kīvamahanto bhavissatī”ti. Ariyadevatā cintayiṃsu – “ekissā lokadhātuyā dve buddhā🔽nāma natthi, addhā bhagavā attanā sadisaṃ aññaṃ ekaṃ buddhaṃ nimminī”ti. Athassa🔽devasaṅghassa passantasseva nimmitabuddho āgantvā dasabalaṃ avanditvāva sammukhaṭṭhāne
analyzed: kīva mahantaḥ bhavissati iti ariya devatā cintayiṃsu ekissā lokadhātuyā dve buddhā  nāma natthi addhā bhagavā attanā sadisam aññam ekam buddham nimminīti athassa  deva saṅghassa passantassa iva nimmita buddhaḥ āgantvā dasabalam a vanditvā ava sammukha ṭṭhāne
translated: How great it will be for two!” But the deities who were Noble Ones thought, “There are not two Buddhas in one world-system.🔽Surely the Blessed One has created a second Buddha like himself.” Then, while the assembly of deities was looking on, the Created One came and, without paying homage to the One of Ten Powers, he took up a position opposite him,

original: samasamaṃ katvā māpite āsane nisīdi. Bhagavato bāttiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, nimmitassāpi,
analyzed: samasamam katvā māpite āsane nisīdi bhagavataḥ bāttiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni nimmitassa api
translated: making himself equal in size to him, and he sat down on the seat prepared for him. The thirty-two marks of a Great Man were on the Blessed One,🔽and on the Created One,

original: bhagavato sarīrā chabbaṇṇarasmiyo nikkhamanti, nimmitassāpi, bhagavato sarīrarasmiyo
analyzed: bhagavato sarīrā chabbaṇṇa rasmiyaḥ nikkhamanti nimmitassa api bhagavato sarīra rasmiyaḥ
translated: and the rays of the Exalted One’s body issued forth in six colours, and the rays of the created Buddha’s body

original: nimmitasarīre paṭihaññanti, nimmitassa rasmiyo bhagavato kāye paṭihaññanti. Tā dvinnampi
analyzed: nimmita sarīre paṭihaññanti nimmitassa rasmiyaḥ bhagavato kāye paṭihaññanti tāḥ dvinnam pi
translated: were reflected in the Exalted One’s body, and the rays of the Exalted One’s body were reflected in the created Buddha’s body.

original: buddhānaṃ sarīrato uggamma bhavaggaṃ āhacca tato tato paṭinivattitvā devatānaṃ matthakamatthakapariyantena
analyzed: buddhānam sarīrataḥ uggamma bhavaggam āhacca tatas tatas paṭinivattitvā devatānam matthaka matthaka pariyantena
translated: Rising from the bodies of the two Buddhas, they reached the highest point in the universe, and then turning back, they descended to the highest point of the gods and men,

original: otaritvā cakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ suvaṇṇamayavaṅkagopānasivinaddhamiva🔽cetiyagharaṃ virocittha. Dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatā ekacakkavāḷe rāsibhūtā dvinnaṃ
analyzed: otaritvā cakkavāḷa mukha vaṭṭiyam patiṭṭhahiṃsu sakala cakkavāḷa gabbham suvaṇṇa maya vaṅka gopānasi vinaddham iva  cetiya gharam virocittha dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa devatāḥ eka cakkavāḷe rāsi bhūtāḥ
translated: and they stood on the rim of the world. The whole womb of the universe was illuminated as if it were filled with golden lotuses. The deities of the ten-thousandfold world system,

original: buddhānaṃ rasmiabbhantaraṃ pavisitvā aṭṭhaṃsu. Nimmito nisīdantoyeva “kathaṃdassī
analyzed: buddhānam rasmi abbhantaram pavisitvā aṭṭhaṃsu nimmitaḥ nisīdanto yā iva kathaṃdassī
translated: gathered in one place in the single universe, entered the rays of the two Buddhas and stood there. The created Buddha, as he sat down, asked the question beginning thus: “How does one see? How does one conduct himself? How is one called ‘tranquil’?”

original: kathaṃsīlo, upasantoti vuccatī”tiādinā nayena adhipaññādikaṃ pucchanto gāthamāha.
analyzed: kathaṃsīlaḥ upasanto ti vuccati itiādinā nayena adhi paññā ādikam pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: and so on, and he spoke the stanza.

original: Tattha pucchāya tāva so nimmito kathaṃdassīti adhipaññaṃ, kathaṃsīloti adhisīlaṃ, upasantoti adhicittaṃ pucchati. Sesaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: tattha pucchāya tāva so nimmito kathaṃdassī iti adhipaññam kathaṃsīlo ti adhisīlam upasantaḥ ti adhicittam pucchati sesam pākaṭam eva
translated: Herein, in the first question, “How does the apparition see? ” he asks about the higher understanding; “How is he in virtue? ” he asks about the higher virtue; “How is he in peace? ” he asks about the higher consciousness. The rest is clear.

original: Nimmitabuddhādivibhāvanatthaṃ peṭake –
analyzed: nimmita buddha ādi vibhāvana attham peṭake
translated: In order to show the distinction between the apparition and the Enlightened One, etc., the Basket of Discourses says:

original: “Upeti dhammaṃ paripucchamāno, kusalaṃ atthupasañhitaṃ;
analyzed: upeti dhammam paripucchamānaḥ kusalam attha upasañhitam
translated: “He who, in questioning, comes to the Dhamma, To the good, to what is connected with the good,

original: Na jīvati na nibbuto na mato, taṃ puggalaṃ katamaṃ vadanti buddhā. ;
analyzed: na jīvati na nibbutaḥ na mataḥ tam puggalam katamam vadanti buddhāḥ
translated: Not living, not extinguished, not dead, What kind of person do the Enlightened Ones declare him to be?

original: “Saṃsārakhīṇo na ca vantarāgo, na cāpi sekkho na ca diṭṭhadhammo;
analyzed: saṃsāra khīṇaḥ na ca vanta rāgaḥ na ca api sekkhaḥ na ca diṭṭha dhammo
translated: “One whose round of births is ended, not one with lust remaining, Not a learner, not one who has seen the Dhamma in this visible world,

original: Akhīṇāsavo antimadehadhārī, taṃ puggalaṃ katamaṃ vadanti buddhā.
analyzed: akhīṇa āsavaḥ antima deha dhārī tam puggalam katamam vadanti buddhāḥ
translated: Not one whose cankers are ended, but one who bears his last body: What kind of person do the Enlightened Ones declare him to be?

original: “Na dukkhasaccena samaṅgibhūto, na maggasaccena kuto nirodho;
analyzed: na dukkha saccena samaṅgi bhūtaḥ na magga saccena kutas nirodhaḥ
translated: “Not one who is endowed with the truth of suffering, Not one who is endowed with the truth of the path, how much less with cessation,

original: Samudayasaccato suvidūravidūro, taṃ puggalaṃ katamaṃ vadanti buddhā.
analyzed: samudaya saccataḥ tam puggalam katamam vadanti buddhāḥ
translated: Far, far away from the truth of the origin of suffering: What kind of person do the Enlightened Ones declare him to be?

original: “Ahetuko nopi ca rūpanissito, apaccayo nopi ca so asaṅkhato;
analyzed: ahetukaḥ no upi ca rūpa nissitaḥ apaccayaḥ no upi ca so asaṅkhataḥ
translated: “Not one without cause, not one who is based on form, Not one without conditions, not one unconditioned,

original: Asaṅkhatārammaṇo nopi ca rūpī, taṃ puggalaṃ katamaṃ vadanti buddhā”ti. –
analyzed: asaṅkhata ārammaṇaḥ na u pi ca rūpī tam puggalam katamam vadanti buddha ati
translated: Not one with an unconditioned object, not one who is formless: What kind of person do the Enlightened Ones declare him to be? ”

original: Vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam
translated: This is said.

original: Tattha paṭhamagāthā nimmitabuddhaṃ sandhāya, dutiyagāthā pacchimabhavikabodhisattaṃ
analyzed: tattha paṭhama gāthā nimmita buddham sandhāya dutiya gāthā pacchima bhavika bodhisattam
translated: Herein, the first stanza should be understood as referring to the Buddha created by psychic power, the second to the Bodhisatta in his last birth,

original: sandhāya, tatiyagāthā arahattaphalaṭṭhaṃ sandhāya, catutthagāthā arūpe nibbānapaccavekkhaṇamanodvārapurecārikacittasamaṅgiṃ🔽sandhāya vuttāti ñātabbā. Kīdisena dassanenāti kīdisavasena dassanena. Kiṃsaṇṭhitenāti
analyzed: sandhāya tatiya gāthāḥ arahatta phala aṭṭham sandhāya catuttha gāthāḥ arūpe nibbāna paccavekkhaṇa manaḥ dvāra purecārika citta samaṅgiṃ  sandhāya vuttā ati ñātabbā kīdisena dassanena ati kīdisa vasena dassanena kiṃsaṇṭhitena ati
translated: the third to one who has attained Arahantship, and the fourth to one who is reviewing Nibbāna in the immaterial world by means of the mind-door process of absorption.

original: kiṃsarikkhena. Kiṃpakārenāti kiṃvidhena. Kiṃpaṭibhāgenāti kiṃākārena.🔽Yaṃ pucchāmīti yaṃ puggalaṃ pucchāmi, taṃ mayhaṃ viyākarohi. Yācāmīti āyācāmi. Ajjhesāmīti
analyzed: kiṃsarikkhena kiṃpakārena ati kiṃvidhena kiṃpaṭibhāgena ati kiṃākārena  yam pucchāmi iti yam puggalam pucchāmi tam mayham viyākarohi yācāmi iti āyācāmi ajjhesāmi iti
translated: What kind of seeing? —in what way. What kind of being? —what kind of person. What kind of being? —what kind of being. What kind of appearance? —what kind of form.

original: āṇāpemi. Pasādemīti tava santāne somanassaṃ uppādemi. Brūhīti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ.
analyzed: āṇāpemi pasādemi iti tava santāne somanassam uppādemi brūhi iti niddesassa uddesa padaṃ
translated: What I ask—the person I ask. Answer me—explain to me. I beg—I request. I entreat—I implore. I have faith—I arouse joy in your mind. Say—this is a term for the heading of the description.

original: Ācikkhāti desetabbānaṃ “imāni nāmānī”ti nāmavasena kathehi. Desehīti dassehi. Paññapehīti
analyzed: ācikkhāti desetabbānam imāni nāmāni iti nāma vasena kathehi desehi iti dassehi paññapehi iti
translated: Explain—tell by name those things that should be taught, saying “These are the names for them.” Show—demonstrate. Make plain—

original: jānāpehi. Ñāṇamukhavasena hi appanaṃ ṭhapento “paññapehī”ti vuccati. Paṭṭhapehīti
analyzed: jānāpehi ñāṇa mukha vasena hi appanam ṭhapento paññapehi iti vuccati paṭṭhapehi iti
translated: “Make known”: one who establishes absorption by way of the door of knowledge is said to “make known” . “Make to appear” means🔽“make to occur.” Or “make to stand at the door of knowledge.”

original: paññāpehi, pavattāpehīti attho. Ñāṇamukhe ṭhapehīti vā. Vivarāti vivaṭaṃ karohi,
analyzed: paññāpehi pavattāpehi iti atthaḥ ñāṇa mukhe ṭhapehi iti vā vivarāti vivaṭam karohi
translated: “Open up” means “make open.” The meaning is, “having opened up, show.”🔽“Analyze” means “having analyzed by way of analysis, show.”

original: vivaritvā dassehīti attho. Vibhajāti vibhāgakiriyāya vibhāvento dassehīti attho.🔽Uttānīkarohīti pākaṭabhāvaṃ karohi.
analyzed: vivaritvā dassehi iti attho vibhajāti vibhāga kiriyāya vibhāventaḥ dassehi iti attho  uttānīkarohi iti pākaṭa bhāvam karohi
translated: “Make plain” means “make evident.”

original: Atha vā ācikkhāti desanādīnaṃ channaṃ padānaṃ mūlapadaṃ. Desanādīni cha padāni etassa🔽atthassa vivaraṇatthaṃ vuttāni. Tattha desehīti ugghaṭitaññūnaṃ vasena saṅkhepato
analyzed: atha vā ācikkhāti desanā ādīnam channam padānam mūla padam desanā ādīni cha padāni etassa  atthassa vivaraṇa attham vuttāni tattha desehi iti ugghaṭita ññūnam vasena saṅkhepataḥ
translated: Or else, “explain” is the root-word for the six terms beginning with “teaching.” The six terms beginning with “teaching”🔽are stated for the purpose of elucidating this meaning. Herein, “teach” means teach by way of the first enunciation in brief for those who are of-quick-understanding.

original: paṭhamaṃ uddesavasena desehi. Ugghaṭitaññū hi saṅkhepena vuttaṃ paṭhamaṃ vuttañca
analyzed: paṭhamam uddesa vasena desehi ugghaṭita ññū hi saṅkhepena vuttam paṭhamam vuttam ca
translated: For those who are of-quick-understanding penetrate what is stated in brief and what is stated first.

original: paṭivijjhanti. Paññapehīti vipañcitaññūnaṃ vasena tesaṃ cittatosanena buddhinisānena
analyzed: paṭivijjhanti paññapehi iti vipañcita ññūnam vasena tesam citta tosanena buddhi nisānena
translated: “Make known” means by way of those who are of-slow-understanding, by way of their mental-weariness, by way of the inclination of their understanding.

original: ca paṭhamaṃ saṃkhittassa vitthārato niddesavaseneva paññapehi. Paṭṭhapehīti tesaṃyeva
analyzed: ca paṭhamam saṃkhittassa vitthārataḥ niddesa vasena iva paññapehi paṭṭhapehi iti tesam yeva
translated: and first of all, make a brief demonstration of the extended meaning.

original: niddiṭṭhassa niddesassa paṭiniddesavasena vitthāritavasena ṭhapeti paṭṭhapehi. Vivarāti🔽niddiṭṭhassapi punappunaṃ vacanena vivarāhi. Vibhajāti punappunaṃ vuttassāpi vibhāgakaraṇena
analyzed: niddiṭṭhassa niddesassa paṭiniddesa vasena vitthārita vasena ṭhapeti paṭṭhapehi  niddiṭṭhassa api punappunam vacanena vivarāhi vibhajāti punappunam vuttassa api vibhāga karaṇena
translated: ‘Make a detailed demonstration’ means that he should make a detailed demonstration of the meaning of the demonstration already given.🔽‘Open it up’ means that he should open it up by repeating what has been demonstrated.🔽‘Analyze it’ means that he should analyze it by making a division of what has been repeated.

original: vibhajāhi. Uttānīkarohīti vivaṭassa vitthārataravacanena vibhattassa ca nidassanavacanena
analyzed: vibhajāhi uttānīkarohi iti vivaṭassa vitthāratara vacanena vibhattassa ca nidassana vacanena
translated: ‘Make it clear’ means that he should make it clear by demonstrating what has been opened up and analyzed by means of a more extended statement.

original: uttāniṃ karohi. Ayaṃ desanā neyyānampi paṭivedhāya hotīti.
analyzed: uttānim karohi ayam desanā paṭivedhāya hoti iti
translated: This demonstration is for the penetration of the disciples.

original: 84. Vissajjane pana bhagavā sarūpena adhipaññādīni avissajjetvāva adhipaññādippabhāvena🔽yesaṃ kilesānaṃ upasamā “upasanto”ti vuccati, nānādevatānaṃ āsayānulomena tesaṃ upasamameva
analyzed: vissajjane pana bhagavā sarūpena adhipaññā ādīni a vissajjetvā ava adhipaññā ādi ppabhāvena  yesam kilesānam upasamā upasanto ti vuccati nānā devatānam āsayā anulomena tesam upasamam eva
translated: But in the answer the Exalted One, without answering the questions about higher wisdom, etc., in terms of their literal meaning,🔽answered by showing the stilling of the defilements that are called “still,” and by showing the stilling of the defilements that are called “not still” in terms of the inclinations of various deities.

original: dīpento “vītataṇho”tiādikā gāthāyo abhāsi. Tattha ādito aṭṭhannaṃ gāthānaṃ “taṃ brūmi
analyzed: dīpentaḥ vīta taṇhā iti ādikāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi tattha āditaḥ aṭṭhannam gāthānam tam brūmi
translated: ‘I call him a brahmin’—in the first eight stanzas he shows the stilling of the defilements that are called “still” in terms of the inclinations of the deities.

original: upasanto”ti imāya gāthāya sambandho veditabbo, tato parāsaṃ “sa ve santoti vuccatī”ti🔽iminā sabbapacchimena padena.
analyzed: upasanto ti imāya gāthāya sambandhaḥ veditabbo tato parāsam sa ve santo ti vuccati iti  iminā sabba pacchimena padena
translated: The rest of the verses should be connected with the last word “he is called peaceful” .

original: Anupadavaṇṇanānayo – vītataṇho purābhedāti yo sarīrabhedā pubbameva pahīnataṇho.🔽Pubbamantamanissitoti atītaddhādibhedaṃ pubbaantaṃ anissito. Vemajjhe nupasaṅkheyyoti
analyzed: vīta taṇhaḥ purā bhedā ti yaḥ sarīra bhedā pubbam eva pahīna taṇho  pubbam antam anissitaḥ ti atīta ddha ādi bhedam pubba antam anissitaḥ vemajjhe n upasaṅkheyyaḥ ti
translated: The method of commenting on the verses beginning with “Free from craving” : He who is free from craving before the breakup of the body is one who has abandoned craving before the breakup of the body.🔽Not depending on the past is not depending on the past as divided into the past, future, etc. He should not be reckoned in the middle is one who should not be reckoned in the present as “lustful” , etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.

original: paccuppannepi addhani “ratto”tiādinā nayena na upasaṅkhātabbo. Tassa natthi purakkhatanti
analyzed: paccuppanne pi addhani ratto ti ādinā nayena na upasaṅkhātabbo tassa natthi purakkhatanti
translated: He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.

original: tassa arahato dvinnaṃ purekkhārānaṃ abhāvā anāgate addhani purakkhatamapi natthi,🔽taṃ brūmi upasantoti evamettha yojanā veditabbā. Esa nayo sabbattha.🔽Purā kāyassa bhedāti karajakāyassa bhedato pubbeyeva. Attabhāvassāti sakalattabhāvassa.
analyzed: tassa arahataḥ dvinnam purekkhārānam abhāvā anāgate addhani purakkhatam api na atthi  tam brūmi upasanto ti evam ettha yojanā veditabbā esa nayo sabbattha  purā kāyassa bhedā ati karaja kāyassa bhedato pubbe iya iva atta bhāvassa ati sakala atta bhāvassa
translated: He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.

original: Kaḷevarassa nikkhepāti kaḷevarassa nikkhepato sarīrassa ṭhapanato. Jīvitindriyassa
analyzed: kaḷevarassa nikkhepā ti kaḷevarassa nikkhepataḥ sarīrassa ṭhapanataḥ jīvitindriyassa
translated: He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future, etc.🔽He has no future is one who has no future as divided into the future, etc. He has no past is one who has no past as divided into the past, future,

original: upacchedāti duvidhassa jīvitindriyassa upacchedato pubbameva.
analyzed: upacchedā ti duvidhassa jīvitindriyassa upacchedato pubbam eva
translated: By cutting off : before the cutting off of the two kinds of life faculty.

original: Pubbanto vuccati atīto addhāti pubbasaṅkhāto anto koṭṭhāso “atīto addhāti, atikkanto kālo”ti kathīyati. Atītaṃ addhānaṃ ārabbhāti atītakālaṃ paṭicca taṇhā pahīnā.
analyzed: pubbantaḥ vuccati atītaḥ addhā iti pubba saṅkhātaḥ antaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ atītaḥ addhā iti atikkantaḥ kālo iti kathīyati atītam addhānam ārabbha ati atīta kālam paṭicca taṇhā pahīnā
translated: The past extent is called the past period : the past section of the extent is called the past period. The past period is spoken of as the past time. Craving is abandoned in regard to the past period : craving is abandoned in regard to the past time.

original: Aparampi bhaddekarattapariyāyaṃ dassento “atha vā”tiādimāha. Tattha evaṃrūpo ahosinti
analyzed: aparam pi bhaddekaratta pariyāyam dassentaḥ atha vā ti ādim āha tattha evaṃrūpaḥ ahosin ti
translated: Showing another method of the Thread’s meaning, he said “Or else” . Herein, I was of such-and-such form :

original: kāḷopi samāno indanīlamaṇivaṇṇo ahosinti evaṃ manuññarūpavaseneva evaṃrūpo ahosiṃ.
analyzed: samānaḥ inda nīla maṇi vaṇṇo ahosin ti evam manuñña rūpa vasena iva evaṃrūpaḥ ahosin
translated: though I was black, I was of such-and-such a lovely form, namely the colour of sapphire.🔽I was of such-and-such feeling : I was of such-and-such pleasant feeling, namely of profitable happiness and gladness.

original: Kusalasukhasomanassavedanāvaseneva evaṃvedano. Taṃ sampayuttānaṃyeva saññādīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: kusala sukha so manassa vedanā vasena iva evaṃvedano tam sampayuttānam yā iva saññā ādīnam vasena
translated: I was of such-and-such perception : I was of such-and-such perception of that associated with the perception.🔽I was of such-and-such determinations : I was of such-and-such determinations of that associated with the determinations.

original: evaṃsañño. Evaṃsaṅkhāro. Evaṃviññāṇo ahosiṃ atītamaddhānanti tattha nandiṃ na samannānetīti
analyzed: evaṃsaññaḥ evaṃsaṅkhāro evaṃviññāṇaḥ ahosim atītam addhānam ti tattha nandim na samannāneti iti
translated: I was of such-and-such consciousness : I was of such-and-such consciousness of that associated with the consciousness.🔽I was in the past period : he does not lead craving to that in regard to those forms, etc.,

original: tesu rūpādīsu taṇhaṃ vā taṇhāsampayuttadiṭṭhiṃ vā nānupavattayati. Aparena pariyāyena
analyzed: tesu rūpa ādīsu taṇham vā taṇhā sampayutta diṭṭhim vā na anupavattayati aparena pariyāyena
translated: or he does not pursue craving or the view associated with craving. By another method

original: mahākaccānabhaddekarattapariyāyaṃ dassento “atha vā iti me cakkhu ahosī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: mahākaccānabhadda ekaratta pariyāyam dassentaḥ atha vā iti me cakkhu ahosi itiādim āha
translated: He is showing the Great Elder’s Thread of the Single Night, and he says “Or else, ‘My eye was thus’ and so on.

original: Tattha cakkhūti cakkhupasādo. Rūpāti catusamuṭṭhānikarūpā. Iminā nayena sesāyatanānipi
analyzed: tattha cakkhu uti cakkhu pasādaḥ rūpa ati catu samuṭṭhānika rūpāḥ iminā nayena sesa āyatanāni pi
translated: Herein, eye is eye sensitivity. Visible data are the four kinds of physical visible data. In this way the other bases should be understood too.

original: veditabbāni. Viññāṇanti nissayaviññāṇaṃ. Na tadabhinandatīti taṃ cakkhuñceva rūpañca🔽taṇhādiṭṭhivasena nābhinandati. Iti me mano ahosi iti dhammāti ettha pana manoti
analyzed: veditabbāni viññāṇanti nissaya viññāṇam na tat abhinandati iti tam cakkhuñca iva rūpañca  taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena na abhinandati iti me manaḥ ahosi iti ettha pana manaḥ ti
translated: Consciousness is the consciousness that is the support. He does not delight in that: he does not delight in that eye and visible data by taking them as a self or as belonging to a self.🔽Thus my mind was thus, my thoughts were thus: here mind is the life-continuum consciousness. Thoughts are the object of the three kinds of consciousness belonging to the three planes.

original: bhavaṅgacittaṃ. Dhammāti tebhūmakadhammārammaṇaṃ. Hasitalapitakīḷitānīti dantavidaṃsakahasitañca
analyzed: bhavaṅga cittam tebhūmaka dhamma ārammaṇam hasita lapita kīḷitāni iti danta vidaṃsaka hasitam ca
translated: Laughing, talking, playing: laughing is laughing with bared teeth;

original: vācālapitañca kāyakīḷādikīḷitañcāti hasitalapitakīḷitāni. Na tadassādetīti tāni hasitādīni
analyzed: vācā lapitam ca kāya kīḷā ādi kīḷitam ca ati hasita lapita kīḷitāni na tat assādeti iti tāni hasita ādīni
translated: talking is talking with words; playing is playing with the body, and so on. He does not enjoy that: he does not delight in that laughing, etc.,

original: nābhinandati. Na taṃ nikāmetīti kantaṃ na karoti. Na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjatīti tena
analyzed: na abhinandati na tam nikāmeti iti kantam na karoti na ca tena vittim āpajjati iti tena
translated: by taking it as a self or as belonging to a self. He does not wish for that: he does not make it desirable. He does not take to that:

original: ca tuṭṭhiṃ na pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: ca tuṭṭhim na pāpuṇāti
translated: he does not find satisfaction in that.

original: Taṃ taṃ paccayaṃ paṭicca uppannoti paccuppanno. Rattoti nupasaṅkheyyoti rāgena rattoti
analyzed: tam tam paccayam paṭicca uppannaḥ ti paccuppannaḥ rattaḥ iti nu upasaṅkheyyaḥ iti rāgena rattaḥ iti
translated: “Arisen” means arisen in dependence on this or that condition. “One who is lustful” means one who is lustful because of lust.

original: gaṇanaṃ na upanetabbo. Uparipi eseva nayo. Evarūpo siyantiādīsu paṇītamanuññarūpādivaseneva
analyzed: gaṇanam na upanetabbo upari pi esa iva nayaḥ evarūpaḥ siyanti ādīsu paṇīta manuñña rūpa ādi vasena iva
translated: “One who cannot be reckoned” means one who cannot be reckoned as lustful. The same method applies to the rest. In the passages beginning “one who is of such a kind” ,

original: taṇhādiṭṭhipavattanasaṅkhātā nandī samannānayanā veditabbā. Na paṇidahatīti patthanāvasena
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi pavattana saṅkhātā nandī samannānayanā veditabbā na paṇidahati iti patthanā vasena
translated: the delight called craving and views should be understood as the act of directing the mind to the object in the form of the desirable, etc.🔽“One who does not resolve” means one who does not determine by way of aspiration.

original: na ṭhapeti. Appaṇidhānapaccayāti na patthanāṭhapanakāraṇena.
analyzed: na ṭhapeti appaṇidhāna paccayā ti na patthanā ṭhapana kāraṇena
translated: “Not resolving” means not resolving as a cause of aspiration and determination.

original: 85. Asantāsīti tena tena alābhato asantasanto. Avikatthīti sīlādīhi avikatthanasīlo.🔽Akukkucoti hatthakukkuccādivirahito. Mantabhāṇīti mantāya pariggahetvā vācaṃ bhāsitā.
analyzed: asantā asi iti tena tena alābhataḥ asanta santaḥ avikatthī iti sīla ādīhi a vikatthana sīlaḥ  akukkucaḥ ti hattha kukkucca ādi virahitaḥ manta bhāṇī iti mantāya pariggahetvā vācam bhāsitā
translated: “One who is not agitated” means one who is not agitated by this or that non-gain. “One who is not contemptuous” means one who is not contemptuous by way of virtue, etc.🔽“One who is not overbearing” means one who is free from the overbearingness of the hands, etc. “One who speaks after reflection” means one who speaks after having taken up the speech by way of reflection.

original: Anuddhatoti uddhaccavirahito. Sa ve vācāyatoti so vācāya yato saṃyato catudosavirahitaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
analyzed: uddhacca virahitaḥ sa ve vācāyato iti saḥ vācāya catu dosa virahitam vācam bhāsitā hoti
translated: “One who is not restless” means one who is free from restlessness. “One who is restrained in speech” means one who is restrained, controlled, in speech, and who speaks speech free from the four faults.

original: Akkodhanoti yañhi kho vuttanti “na kodhano akodhano kodhavirahito”ti yaṃ kathitaṃ,
analyzed: akkodhanoti yat hi kho vuttanti na kodhanaḥ akodhanaḥ kodha virahitaḥ ti yam kathitam
translated: “One who is not angry” means one who is not angry, who is free from anger. “One who is not scornful” means one who is not scornful, who is free from scorn.

original: taṃ paṭhamaṃ tāva kodhaṃ kathetukāmo “apica kodho tāva vattabbo”ti āha. Kodho tāva
analyzed: tam paṭhamam tāva kodham kathetu kāmaḥ apica kodho tāva vattabbaḥ iti āha kodho tāva
translated: He is about to speak about anger, and so he says, “Anger should be spoken about first.”

original: vattabboti paṭhamaṃ kodho kathetabbo. Dasahākārehi kodho jāyatīti dasahi kāraṇehi
analyzed: vattabbaḥ ti paṭhamam kodhaḥ kathetabbaḥ dasahā ākārehi kodhaḥ jāyati iti dasahi kāraṇehi
translated: Anger should be spoken about first: anger should be spoken about first. Anger arises in ten ways: anger arises for ten reasons.

original: kodho uppajjati. Anatthaṃ me acarīti avaḍḍhiṃ me akāsi, iminā upāyena sabbapadesu🔽attho veditabbo. Aṭṭhāne vā pana kodho jāyatīti akāraṇe kodho uppajjati. Ekacco hi
analyzed: kodhaḥ uppajjati anattham me acari iti avaḍḍhim me akāsi iminā upāyena sabba padesu  atthaḥ veditabbaḥ aṭṭhāne vā pana kodhaḥ jāyati iti akāraṇe kodhaḥ uppajjati ekaccaḥ hi
translated: He has done me harm: he has caused me misfortune. The meaning should be understood in this way in all the passages.

original: “devo ativassatī”ti kuppati, “na vassatī”ti kuppati, “sūriyo tappatī”ti kuppati,🔽“na tappatī”ti kuppati, vāte vāyantepi kuppati, avāyantepi kuppati, sammajjituṃ asakkonto
analyzed: devaḥ ativassati iti kuppati na vassati iti kuppati sūriyaḥ tappati iti kuppati  na tappati iti kuppati vāte vāyante api kuppati avāyante api kuppati sammajjitum a sakkontaḥ
translated: Or anger arises without reason: anger arises without cause. For one man gets angry because “the god is raining too much,” another because “the god is not raining,” another because “the sun is too hot,”

original: bodhipaṇṇānaṃ kuppati, cīvaraṃ pārupituṃ asakkonto vātassa kuppati, upakkhalitvā🔽khāṇukassa kuppati. Idaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “aṭṭhāne vā pana kodho jāyatī”ti. Tattha
analyzed: bodhipaṇṇānam kuppati cīvaram pārupitum a sakkontaḥ vātassa kuppati upakkhalitvā 🔽khāṇukassa kuppati idam sandhāya vuttam aṭṭhāne vā pana kodhaḥ jāyati iti tattha
translated: another because “the sun is too cold,” another when the wind is blowing, another when it is not blowing, another because he cannot get his leaves for making a fan, another because he cannot get a thread to sew his robe, another because he has stumbled over a stump.

original: heṭṭhā navasu ṭhānesu satte ārabbha uppannattā kammapathabhedo hoti.
analyzed: heṭṭhā navasu ṭhānesu satte ārabbha uppanna ttā kammapatha bhedaḥ hoti
translated: It is a course of kamma in the nine remaining instances because it arises in reference to beings.

original: Aṭṭhānaghāto pana saṅkhāresu uppanno kammapathabhedaṃ na karoti. Cittaṃ āghātento
analyzed: aṭṭhāna ghātaḥ pana saṅkhāresu uppanno kamma patha bhedam na karoti cittam āghātento
translated: But the act of hating does not make a course of kamma. It arises in one who hates the mind.

original: uppannoti cittassa āghāto. Tato balavataro paṭighāto. Paṭihaññanavasena paṭighaṃ.🔽Paṭivirujjhatīti paṭivirodho. Kuppanavasena kopo. Pakopo sampakopoti upasaggavasena
analyzed: uppannaḥ ti cittassa āghāto tatas balavataraḥ paṭighāto paṭihaññana vasena paṭighaṃ  paṭivirujjhati iti paṭivirodhaḥ kuppana vasena kopaḥ pakopaḥ sampakopo ti upasagga vasena
translated: It is a mental state that arises in one who hates the mind. It is more violent than the latter. It is resistance because it occurs with resistance.🔽It is opposition because it opposes. It is anger because it is angry. It is resentment because it is the state of being resentful.

original: padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ. Dussanavasena doso. Padoso sampadosoti upasaggavasena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.🔽Cittassa byāpattīti cittassa vipannatā viparivattanākāro. Manaṃ padūsayamāno uppajjatīti
analyzed: padam vaḍḍhitam dussana vasena doso padoso sampadoso ti upasagga vasena padam vaḍḍhitam  cittassa byāpatti iti cittassa vipanna tā viparivattana ākāraḥ manam padūsayamānaḥ uppajjati iti
translated: The word is extended by the addition of a prefix. It is hate because it hates. It is ill will because it is the state of being ill-will. The word is extended by the addition of a prefix.🔽It is a mental affliction because it is a corruption of the mind, a state of perversion of the mind. It arises in one who corrupts the mind.

original: manopadoso. Kujjhanavasena kodho. Kujjhanākāro kujjhanā. Kujjhitassa bhāvo kujjhitattaṃ.
analyzed: mana upadosaḥ kujjhana vasena kodhaḥ kujjhana ākāraḥ kujjhanā kujjhitassa bhāvaḥ kujjhita ttam
translated: It is spite because it is spiteful. It is spitefulness because it is the state of being spiteful. It is spitefulness because it is the state of being spiteful.🔽It is hate because it hates. It is enmity because it is the state of being an enemy. The word is extended by the addition of a prefix. It is enmity because it is the state of being an enemy. The word is extended by the addition of a prefix.

original: Dussatīti doso. Dussanāti dussanākāro. Dussitattanti dussitabhāvo. Pakatibhāvavijahanaṭṭhena
analyzed: dussati iti dosaḥ dussanā ati dussana ākāraḥ dussita ttam ti dussita bhāvaḥ pakati bhāva vijahana ṭṭhena
translated: It is corruption because it corrupts. It is corruption because it is the state of being corrupt. The word is extended by the addition of a prefix.

original: byāpajjanaṃ byāpatti. Byāpajjanāti byāpajjanākāro. Virujjhatīti virodho. Punappunaṃ🔽virujjhatīti paṭivirodho. Viruddhākārapaṭiviruddhākāravasena vā idaṃ vuttaṃ. Caṇḍiko🔽vuccati caṇḍo, thaddhapuggalo, tassa bhāvo caṇḍikkaṃ. Na etena suropitaṃ vacanaṃ🔽hoti, duruttaṃ aparipuṇṇameva hotīti asuropo. Kuddhakāle hi paripuṇṇavacanaṃ nāma
analyzed: byāpajjanam byāpatti byāpajjanāti byāpajjana ākāraḥ virujjhati iti virodhaḥ punappunam  virujjhati iti paṭivirodhaḥ viruddha ākāra paṭiviruddha ākāra vasena vā idam vuttam caṇḍiko  vuccati caṇḍaḥ thaddha puggalo tassa bhāvaḥ caṇḍikkam na etena su ropitam vacanam  hoti duruttam a paripuṇṇam eva hoti iti kuddha kāle hi paripuṇṇa vacanam nāma
translated: “Malice” is the state of being malicious. “Maliciously” is the mode of being malicious. “Hostility” is the state of being hostile. “Repeated hostility” is the state of being hostile again and again. Or this is said with reference to the mode of being hostile and the mode of being hostile again and again. “Fierce” is said of one who is fierce, a hard person; his state is “fierceness.” “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not fully spoken. For at the time of anger, speech is not fully spoken.🔽

original: natthi, sacepi kassaci hoti, taṃ appamāṇaṃ. Apare pana “assujananaṭṭhena assuropanato🔽assuropo”ti vadanti, taṃ akāraṇaṃ somanassassāpi assujananato. Heṭṭhāvuttaattamanatāpaṭipakkhato🔽na attamanatāti anattamanatā. Sā pana yasmā cittasseva, na sattassa, tasmā “cittassā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Adhimattaparittatā veditabbāti adhimattabhāvo parittabhāvo ca, balavabhāvo mandabhāvoti
analyzed: natthi sace pi kassaci hoti tam appamāṇam apare pana assu janana ṭṭhena 🔽assuropo ti vadanti tam akāraṇam somanassassa api assu jananataḥ heṭṭhā vutta atta manatā paṭipakkhato 🔽na atta mana tā ati anattamana tā sā pana yasmā cittassa iva na sattassa tasmā cittassa ati vuttam 🔽adhimatta paritta tā veditabbā ati adhimatta bhāvo paritta bhāvo ca balava bhāvaḥ manda bhāvaḥ ti
translated: “Malice” is the state of being malicious. “Maliciously” is the mode of being malicious. “Hostility” is the state of being hostile. “Hostility again and again” is the state of being hostile again and again. Or alternatively, this is said with reference to the mode of being hostile and the mode of being hostile again and again. “Fierce” is the same as “fierce-tempered” . The state of that is “fierceness” . “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not well expressed. “Not well spoken” is not well spoken, not well uttered, not

original: attho. Kañci kāleti ekadā. “Kañci kāla”ntipi pāṭho. Cittāvilakaraṇamatto hotīti cittassa
analyzed: kañci kāle iti ekadā kañci citta āvila karaṇa matto hoti iti cittassa
translated: At some time: at one time. The reading is also “at some time” (kañci kāla). It is merely the non-illumination of consciousness:

original: āvilakaraṇappamāṇo, cittakiliṭṭhakaraṇappamāṇoti attho. “Cittālasakaraṇamatto”tipi🔽pāṭho, taṃ na sundaraṃ. Tassa cittakilamathakaraṇamattoti attho. Na ca tāva mukhakulānavikulāno🔽hotīti mukhassa saṅkocanavisaṅkocano na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva hanusañcopano hotīti🔽dvinnaṃ hanūnaṃ aparāparaṃ calano na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva pharusavācaṃ nicchāraṇo🔽hotīti paresaṃ mammacchedakaṃ pharusavācaṃ mukhato nīharaṇena bahi nikkhamano na
analyzed: āvila karaṇa ppamāṇo citta kiliṭṭha karaṇa ppamāṇo ti attho citta alasa karaṇa matto tipi  tam na sundaram tassa citta kilamatha karaṇam atto ti attho na ca tāva mukha kulāna vikulānaḥ  hoti iti mukhassa saṅkocana visaṅkocanaḥ na ca tāva hoti na ca tāva hanu sañcopanaḥ hoti iti  dvinnam apara aparam calanaḥ na ca tāva na ca tāva pharusa vācam  hoti iti paresam mamma chedakam pharusa vācam mukhataḥ nīharaṇena bahi nikkhamanaḥ na
translated: ‘At a time’: at one time. ‘At a time’ is also read. ‘The extent of the disturbance of consciousness’: the extent of the disturbance of consciousness,

original: ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva disāvidisānuvilokano hotīti parassa abbhukkiraṇatthaṃ daṇḍādiatthāya🔽disañca anudisañca punappunaṃ vilokano na ca tāva hoti.
analyzed: ca tāva hoti na ca tāva disā vidisā anuvilokano hoti iti parassa abbhuk kiraṇa attham daṇḍa ādi atthāya 🔽disam ca anudisam ca punappunam vilokanaḥ na ca
translated: the extent of the defilement of consciousness, is the meaning. ‘The extent of the disturbance of mind’ is also read, but that is not good. The meaning is: the extent of the disturbance of the mind. ‘The mouth is not yet drawn in and out’: the mouth is not yet drawn in and out. ‘The jaw is not yet thrust forward’: the jaw is not yet thrust forward. ‘Harsh speech is not yet emitted’: harsh speech, which cuts others to the quick, is not yet emitted from the mouth and goes out. ‘The directions are not yet looked over’: looking again and again in the directions and the quarters is not yet done for the purpose of striking another with a stick or something else.

original: Na ca tāva daṇḍasatthaparāmasano hotīti āghātanatthaṃ daṇḍañca ekatodhārādisatthañca🔽ādiyano na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva daṇḍasatthaabbhukkiraṇo hotīti vuttappakāraṃ
analyzed: na ca tāva daṇḍa sattha parāmasanaḥ hoti iti āghātana attham daṇḍam ca ekatodhāra ādi sattham ca  ādiyanaḥ na ca tāva hoti na ca tāva daṇḍa sattha abbhukkiraṇaḥ hoti iti vutta ppakāram
translated: But he is not yet one who has taken up a weapon or a knife. He is not yet one who has taken up a weapon or a knife for the purpose of killing.

original: daṇḍasatthaṃ ukkhipitvā paharaṇo na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva daṇḍasatthaabhinipātano🔽hotīti etaṃ duvidhaṃ parassa paharaṇatthaṃ na ca tāva khipano hoti. Na ca tāva chinnavicchinnakaraṇo
analyzed: daṇḍa sattham ukkhipitvā paharaṇaḥ na ca tāva hoti na ca tāva daṇḍa sattha abhinipātano  hoti iti etam duvidham parassa paharaṇa attham na ca tāva khipanaḥ hoti na ca tāva chinna vicchinna karaṇaḥ
translated: But he is not yet one who has raised a weapon or a knife. He is not yet one who has raised a weapon or a knife for the purpose of striking.🔽But he is not yet one who has struck. He is not yet one who has thrown a weapon or a knife at another for the purpose of killing.

original: hotīti daṇḍasatthādikhipanena parasarīraṃ dvidhākaraṇo ca vividhākārena vaṇakaraṇo🔽ca na tāva hoti. “Chiddavicchiddakaraṇo”tipi pāṭho. Na ca tāva sambhañjanapalibhañjano🔽hotīti sarīraṃ bhañjitvā cuṇṇavicuṇṇakaraṇo na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva aṅgamaṅgaapakaḍḍhano
analyzed: hoti iti daṇḍa sattha ādi khipanena para sarīram ca vividha ākārena  ca na tāva pāṭhaḥ na ca tāva sambhañjana palibhañjanaḥ  hoti iti sarīram bhañjitvā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa karaṇaḥ na ca hoti na ca aṅgam aṅga apakaḍḍhanaḥ
translated: But he is not yet one who has cut off or caused to be cut off. He is not yet one who has cut another’s body in two or caused it to be cut in two.🔽But he is not yet one who has crushed or caused to be crushed. He is not yet one who has crushed another’s body to pieces or caused it to be crushed to pieces. The reading “chinnavicchinnakaraṇo” is also found.

original: hotīti aṅgapaccaṅgaṃ sampaggahetvā apanetvā kaḍḍhano na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva
analyzed: hoti iti aṅga paccaṅgam sampaggahetvā apanetvā kaḍḍhanaḥ na ca tāva hoti na ca tāva
translated: But he is not yet one who has torn out or caused to be torn out. He is not yet one who has torn out another’s limbs or caused them to be torn out.

original: jīvitā voropano hotīti jīvitindriyato voropano na ca tāva hoti. Na ca tāva sabbacāgapariccāgāya
analyzed: jīvitā voropanaḥ hoti iti jīvitindriyato voropanaḥ na ca tāva hoti na ca tāva sabba cāga pariccāgāya
translated: He is not yet one who has given up all,🔽he is not yet one who has set out to give up all.🔽He is not yet one who has settled down to give up all.

original: saṇṭhito hotīti sabbaṃ parassa jīvitaṃ nāsetvā attano jīvitanāsanatthāya saṇṭhito🔽na ca tāva hoti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yadā aññaṃ jīvitā voropetvā attānaṃ jīvitā voropanatthāya
analyzed: saṇṭhitaḥ hoti iti sabbam parassa jīvitam nāsetvā attanaḥ jīvita nāsana tthāya saṇṭhitaḥ  na ca tāva hoti idam vuttam hoti yadā aññam jīvitā voropetvā attānam jīvitā voropana tthāya
translated: He is not yet one who has settled down to give up all his own life after destroying all the life of others.🔽This is what is meant. When he has destroyed the life of another and has settled down to destroy his own life, then he is one who has given up all,

original: ṭhito, tadā sabbacāgapariccāgā nāma hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ tadā sabbacāgapariccāgā nāma hoti vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: as it is said by the Blessed One:🔽“He sleeps happily who has cut out anger;

original: “Kodhaṃ chetvā sukhaṃ seti, kodhaṃ chetvā na socati;
analyzed: kodham chetvā sukham seti kodham chetvā na socati
translated: He who has cut out anger does not grieve.🔽The noble ones praise the cutting out

original: Kodhassa visamūlassa, madhuraggassa brāhmaṇa;
analyzed: kodhassa visa mūlassa madhuraggassa brāhmaṇa
translated: Of the bitter-rooted, sweet-trunked,

original: Vadhaṃ ariyā pasaṃsanti, tañhi chetvā na socatī”ti. ;
analyzed: vadham ariyā pasaṃsanti tat hi chetvā na socati iti
translated: And he who has cut it out does not grieve” .🔽When: at the time when.🔽Having destroyed another person: having killed another person.

original: Yatoti yadā. Parapuggalaṃ ghāṭetvāti parapuggalaṃ nāsetvā. Attānaṃ ghāṭetīti attānaṃ
analyzed: yatas iti yadā para puggalam ghāṭetvā ati para puggalam nāsetvā attānam ghāṭeti iti attānam
translated: He destroys himself: he kills himself.🔽He has reached the highest degree of power: he has reached the highest degree of strength.

original: māreti. Paramussadagatoti atibalavabhāvaṃ gato. Paramavepullappattoti ativipulabhāvaṃ
analyzed: māra iti ati balava bhāvam gataḥ parama vepulla patto ti ati vipula bhāvam
translated: He has reached the highest degree of growth: he has reached the highest degree of abundance.

original: patto. Kodhassa pahīnattāti anāgāmimaggena vuttappakārassa kodhassa pahīnabhāvena.🔽Kodhavatthussa pariññātattāti kodhassa patiṭṭhābhūtassa kāraṇabhūtassa piyāpiyaaṭṭhānasaṅkhātassa🔽vatthussa ñātatīraṇapariññāhi byāpetvā ñātabhāvena. Kodhahetussa upacchinnattāti
analyzed: patto kodhassa pahīna ttā ti anāgāmi maggena vutta ppakārassa kodhassa pahīna bhāvena  kodha vatthussa pariññāta ttā ati kodhassa patiṭṭhā bhūtassa kāraṇa bhūtassa piya apiya aṭṭhāna saṅkhātassa  vatthussa ñāta tīraṇa pariññāhi byāpetvā ñāta bhāvena kodha hetussa upacchinna ttā ti
translated: ‘Because anger has been abandoned’: because anger of the kind already described has been abandoned by means of the non-return path.🔽‘Because the basis of anger has been fully understood’: because the basis of anger, which is the cause of anger, which is called the pair, dear and undear, has been fully understood by means of the full understanding of the known and the penetrative knowledge of the known.

original: kodhassa janakahetuno domanassasahagatacittuppādassa ucchinnabhāvena.🔽Tāsīti bhāyanasīlo hoti. Uttāsīti atibhāyanasīlo. Parittāsīti samantato bhāyanasīlo.
analyzed: kodhassa janaka hetuno domanassa sahagata cittuppādassa ucchinna bhāvena  tāsi iti bhāyana sīlaḥ hoti uttā asi iti ati bhāyana sīlaḥ parittā asi iti samantataḥ bhāyana sīlaḥ
translated: ‘Because the cause of anger has been cut off’: because the cause of anger, which is the state of mind accompanied by grief, has been cut off.🔽‘He is timid, fearful, diffident’: he is timid, fearful, diffident, in the sense of being afraid of wrongdoing.

original: Bhāyatīti bhayaṃ uppajjati. Santāsaṃ āpajjatīti virūpabhāvaṃ pāpuṇāti. Katthī hotīti
analyzed: bhāyati iti bhayam uppajjati santāsam āpajjati iti virūpa bhāvam pāpuṇāti katthī hoti iti
translated: ‘He is frightened, terrified, alarmed’: fear arises in him; he is frightened, terrified, alarmed, in the sense of being afraid of wrongdoing.

original: attano vaṇṇabhaṇanasīlo hoti. Vikatthīti vividhā nānappakārato vaṇṇabhaṇanasīlo.
analyzed: attanaḥ vaṇṇa bhaṇana sīlaḥ hoti vikatthī iti vividhā nānā pakārataḥ vaṇṇa bhaṇana sīlo
translated: ‘He is a braggart, a boaster, a self-promoter’: he is a braggart, a boaster, a self-promoter, in the sense of being one who boasts about himself.

original: Jātiyā vāti khattiyabhāvādijātisampattiyā vā. Gottena vāti gotamagottādinā ukkaṭṭhagottena
analyzed: jātiyā vā ati khattiya bhāva ādi jāti sampattiyā vā gottena vā ati gotama gotta ādinā ukkaṭṭha gottena
translated: ‘By birth’: by the excellence of his birth as a noble, etc. ‘By race’: by the excellence of his race, such as being of the Gotama race, etc.

original: vā. Kolaputtiyena vāti mahākulabhāvena vā. Vaṇṇapokkharatāya vāti vaṇṇasampannasarīratāya
analyzed: vā kola puttiyena vā ati mahā kula bhāvena vā vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya vā ati vaṇṇa sampanna sarīra tāya
translated: Or by beauty of complexion: by having a body endowed with beauty of complexion.

original: vā. Sarīrañhi “pokkhara”nti vuccati, tassa vaṇṇasampattiyā abhirūpabhāvenāti attho.
analyzed: vā sarīram hi pokkharanti vuccati tassa vaṇṇa sampattiyā abhirūpa bhāvena ati attho
translated: For the body is called “a lotus,” the meaning is that it is beautiful by the possession of the beauty of complexion.

original: Dhanena vātiādīni uttānatthāneva.🔽Kukkuccanti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Tattha kukkuccanti kucchitaṃ kataṃ kukataṃ, tassa
analyzed: dhanena vāti ādīni uttāna tthāna eva  niddesassa uddesa padam tattha kukkuccanti kucchitam katam kukatam tassa
translated: Or by wealth, etc., are in the obvious sense.🔽Scruples: this is a term of introduction to the description. Herein, scruples are what are shrunk, made shrunk, made small,

original: bhāvo kukkuccaṃ. Taṃ pacchānutāpalakkhaṇaṃ, katākatānusocanarasaṃ, vippaṭisārapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,🔽katākatapadaṭṭhānaṃ, dāsabyaṃ viya daṭṭhabbaṃ. Hatthakukkuccampīti hatthehi kucchitaṃ
analyzed: bhāvaḥ kukkuccam tam pacchā anutāpa lakkhaṇam kata akata anusocana rasam vippaṭisāra paccupaṭṭhānam  kata akata padaṭṭhānam dāsabyam viya daṭṭhabbam hattha kukkuccampi iti hatthehi kucchitam
translated: the state of that is scrupulousness. Its characteristic is subsequent regret. Its function is to grieve over what is done and what is not done. It is manifested as remorse.🔽Its proximate cause is what is done and what is not done. It should be regarded as slavery.🔽Scruples about the hands: what is shrunk, made shrunk, made small, by the hands,

original: kataṃ kukataṃ, tassa bhāvo hatthakukkuccaṃ. Pādakukkuccādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: katam kukatam tassa bhāvaḥ hattha kukkuccam pāda kukkucca ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: the state of that is scruples about the hands. So too with scruples about the feet, etc.

original: Akappiye kappiyasaññitāti acchamaṃsaṃ sūkaramaṃsanti khādati, dīpimaṃsaṃ migamaṃsanti
analyzed: akappiye kappiya saññitā ati accha maṃsam sūkara maṃsanti khādati dīpi maṃsam miga maṃsanti
translated: Perceiving what is not allowable as allowable: he eats what is not left by the giver, thinking it is left by him; he eats human flesh, thinking it is the flesh of an animal.

original: khādati, akappiyabhojanaṃ kappiyabhojananti bhuñjati, vikāle kālasaññitāya bhuñjati,
analyzed: khādati akappiya bhojanam kappiya bhojananti bhuñjati vikāle kāla saññitāya bhuñjati
translated: He eats what is not allowable as food, thinking it is allowable food. He eats at the wrong time, thinking it is the right time.

original: akappiyapānakaṃ kappiyapānakanti pivati. Ayaṃ akappiye kappiyasaññitā. Kappiye akappiyasaññitāti
analyzed: akappiya pānakam kappiya pānakam ti pivati ayam akappiye kappiya saññitā kappiye akappiya saññitā ati
translated: He drinks what is not allowable as a beverage, thinking it is allowable. This is “what is not allowable as food, etc., but is regarded as allowable.” What is allowable as food, etc., but is regarded as not allowable:

original: sūkaramaṃsaṃ acchamaṃsanti khādati, migamaṃsaṃ dīpimaṃsanti khādati, kappiyabhojanaṃ
analyzed: sūkara maṃsam acchamaṃsanti khādati miga maṃsam dīpimaṃsanti khādati kappiya bhojanam
translated: he eats pork, thinking it is dog meat; he eats deer meat, thinking it is elephant meat; he eats what is allowable as food, thinking it is not allowable as food;

original: akappiyabhojananti bhuñjati, kāle vikālasaññitāya bhuñjati, kappiyapānakaṃ akappiyapānakanti🔽pivati. Ayaṃ kappiye akappiyasaññitā. Avajje vajjasaññitāti niddose dosasaññitā.
analyzed: akappiya bhojananti bhuñjati kāle vikāla saññitāya bhuñjati kappiya pānakam akappiya pānakam ti  pivati ayam kappiye akappiya saññitā avajje vajja saññitā ati niddose dosa saññitā
translated: he eats at the right time, thinking it is the wrong time; he drinks what is allowable as a beverage, thinking it is not allowable.🔽This is “what is allowable as food, etc., but is regarded as not allowable.” What is blameworthy is regarded as blameless: what is faulty is regarded as faultless.

original: Vajje avajjasaññitāti sadose niddosasaññitā. Kukkuccāyanāti kukkuccāyanākāro. Kukkuccāyitattanti
analyzed: vajje a vajja saññitā ati sa dose niddosa saññitā kukkuccāyanā ati kukkuccāyana ākāraḥ
translated: What is blameless is regarded as blameworthy: what is faultless is regarded as faulty. He is anxious: he has the appearance of being anxious. He is anxious about:

original: kukkuccāyitabhāvo. Cetaso vippaṭisāroti cittassa virūpo paṭisaraṇabhāvo. Manovilekhoti cittassa vilekho.
analyzed: kukkuccāyita bhāvo cetasaḥ vippaṭisāro ti cittassa virūpaḥ paṭisaraṇa bhāvaḥ manaḥ vilekho iti cittassa vilekho
translated: he has the state of being anxious. Mental disquiet: the state of the mind’s turning away from its object. Mental reservation: reservation in the mind.

original: Katattā ca akatattā cāti kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ katabhāvena ca kāyasucaritādīnaṃ akatabhāvena
analyzed: katattā ca a katattā ca ati kāya duccarita ādīnam kata bhāvena ca kāya su carita ādīnam a kata bhāvena
translated: And by the doing and the not doing: by the doing of bodily misconduct, etc., and by the not doing of bodily good conduct, etc.

original: ca. Kataṃ me kāyaduccaritanti mayā kāyena kilesapūtikattā duṭṭhu caritaṃ kāyena kataṃ.
analyzed: ca katam me kāya duccaritan ti mayā kāyena kilesa pūtikattā duṭṭhu caritam kāyena katam
translated: “Bodily misconduct has been done by me”: by the body, which is defiled by defilements, evil has been done, evil has been conducted by the body.

original: Akataṃ me kāyasucaritanti mayā kāyena suṭṭhu caritaṃ na kataṃ. Vacīduccaritavacīsucaritādīsupi
analyzed: a katam me kāya su caritanti mayā kāyena suṭṭhu caritam na katam vacī duccarita vacī su carita ādī supi
translated: “Bodily good conduct has not been done by me”: good has not been done by the body, good has not been conducted by the body. The same method applies to verbal misconduct, etc.

original: eseva nayo nirodhapariyosānesu.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ nirodha pariyosānesu
translated: The same method applies to the rest of the terms up to “the cessation of becoming.”

original: Cittassāti na sattassa na posassa. Uddhaccanti uddhatākāro. Avūpasamoti na vūpasamo.🔽Ceto vikkhipatīti cetaso vikkhepo, bhantattaṃ cittassāti cittassa bhantabhāvo bhantayānabhantagoṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: cittassa ati na sattassa na posassa uddhaccanti uddhata ākāraḥ a vūpasamaḥ ti na vūpasamaḥ  cetaḥ vikkhipati iti cetasaḥ vikkhepaḥ bhantattam cittassa ati cittassa bhanta bhāvaḥ bhanta yāna bhanta goṇa ādīnam
translated: “Of the mind”: not of a being, not of a person. “Restlessness”: the restless state. “Non-tranquility”: not tranquil.

original: viya. Iminā ekārammaṇasmiṃyeva vipphandanaṃ kathitaṃ. Uddhaccañhi ekārammaṇe vipphandati,
analyzed: viya iminā eka ārammaṇasmiṃ yeva vipphandanam kathitam uddhaccam hi eka ārammaṇe vipphandati
translated: “Disturbs the mind”: the disturbance of the mind, the agitated state of the mind, like a cow that is agitated, not agitated, etc. By this the vacillation in regard to a single object is stated. For restlessness vacillates in regard to a single object,

original: vicikicchā nānārammaṇeti. Idaṃ vuccati uddhaccanti ayaṃ uddhatabhāvo kathīyati.
analyzed: vicikicchā nānā ārammaṇā iti idam vuccati ayam uddhata bhāvo kathīyati
translated: while doubt vacillates in regard to various objects. This is called restlessness.

original: Musāvādaṃ pahāyāti ettha musāti visaṃvādanapurekkhārassa atthabhañjako vacīpayogo
analyzed: musāvādam pahāya ati ettha musā ati visaṃvādana purekkhārassa attha bhañjakaḥ vacī payogaḥ
translated: Abandoning false speech: here, false is a verbal act or bodily act that is a means of deceiving another,

original: kāyapayogo vā. Visaṃvādanādhippāyena panassa paravisaṃvādakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo.
analyzed: kāya payogaḥ vā visaṃvādana adhippāyena pana assa para visaṃvādaka kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ
translated: or the volition that instigates a verbal or bodily act to deceive another, with the intention of deceiving another, is false speech.

original: Aparo nayo – musāti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu. Vādoti tassa bhūtato tacchato viññāpanaṃ.
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ musā ati abhūtam ataccham vatthu vādo ti tassa bhūtataḥ tacchataḥ viññāpanam
translated: Another method: false is an unreal, untrue matter. Speech is the making known of that as real and true.

original: Lakkhaṇato pana atathaṃ vatthuṃ tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: lakkhaṇato pana atatham vatthum tathatas param viññāpetu kāmassa tathā viññatti samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: But by characteristic false speech is the volition that instigates the act of making known to another as real and true a matter that is not so, in one who wishes to make known thus.

original: cetanā musāvādo, taṃ musāvādaṃ. Pahāyāti imaṃ musāvādacetanāsaṅkhātaṃ dussīlyaṃ pajahitvā.
analyzed: cetanā musāvādaḥ tam musāvādam pahāya ati imam musāvāda cetanā saṅkhātam dussīlyam pajahitvā
translated: That false speech: having abandoned that misconduct consisting in the volition called “false speech,”

original: Paṭiviratoti pahīnakālato paṭṭhāya tato dussīlyato orato viratova. Natthi tassa vītikkamissāmīti🔽cakkhusotaviññeyyā dhammā, pageva kāyaviññeyyāti iminā nayena aññesupi evarūpesu
analyzed: paṭivirataḥ ti pahīna kālato paṭṭhāya tatas dussīlyato orataḥ virataḥ va natthi tassa vītikkamissāmi iti  cakkhu sota viññeyyā dhammā pagā iva kāya viññeyyā ti iminā nayena aññesu pi evarūpesu
translated: refraining: from the time of abandoning it, he is refraining, turning away, from that misconduct. There is no transgressing for him.

original: padesu attho veditabbo.
analyzed: padesu atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Things cognizable by the eye and ear: the meaning should be understood in this way in other such instances too.

original: Saccaṃ vadatīti saccavādī. Saccena saccaṃ sandahati ghaṭetīti saccasandho, na antarantarā🔽musā vadatīti attho. Yo hi puriso kadāci musā vadati, kadāci saccaṃ, tassa musāvādena
analyzed: saccam vadati iti sacca vādī saccena saccam sandahati ghaṭa iti iti sacca sandhaḥ na antar antarā  musā vadati iti atthaḥ yaḥ hi puriso kadāci musā vadati kadāci saccam tassa musāvādena
translated: He speaks truth, thus he is truthful. He joins truth to truth, he connects truth with truth, thus he is one who joins truth to truth. The meaning is that he does not speak falsehood in between. For when a man sometimes speaks falsehood and sometimes truth, then his truthfulness is interrupted by falsehood.

original: antaritattā saccaṃ saccena na ghaṭiyati, tasmā so na saccasandho, ayaṃ pana na tādiso,
analyzed: saccam saccena na tasmā saḥ na sacca sandhaḥ ayam pana na tādisaḥ
