translated: He speaks truth: thus he is truthful . He joins truth to truth, he joins it to truth without mixing it with falsehood: thus he is one who joins truth to truth . The meaning is that he does not speak falsehood at intervals. For when a man sometimes speaks falsehood and sometimes truth, then his truth is not joined to truth without mixing it with falsehood because of the falsehood spoken at intervals. But this man is not like that;

original: jīvitahetupi musā avatvā saccena saccaṃ sandahatiyevāti saccasandho.🔽Thetoti thiro, thirakathoti attho. Eko hi puggalo haliddirāgo viya, thusarāsimhi🔽nikhātakhāṇu viya, assapiṭṭhe ṭhapitakumbhaṇḍamiva ca na thirakatho hoti, eko pāsāṇalekhā
analyzed: musā avatvā saccena saccam sandahatiyā iva ati sacca sandho  theto ti thiraḥ thira kathaḥ ti attho ekaḥ hi puggalaḥ haliddi rāgaḥ viya thusa rāsimhi  nikhāta khāṇu viya assa piṭṭhe ṭhapita kumbhaṇḍam iva ca na thira kathaḥ hoti ekaḥ pāsāṇa lekhā
translated: he joins truth to truth without mixing it with falsehood, not even for the sake of his life. Thus he is one who joins truth to truth.

original: viya, indakhīlā viya ca thirakatho hoti, asinā sīsaṃ chindantepi dve kathā na katheti, ayaṃ vuccati theto.
analyzed: viya indakhīlā viya ca thira kathaḥ hoti asinā sīsam chindante pi dve kathā na kathā iti ayam vuccati
translated: He is firm: thus he is steadfast . The meaning is that he is one whose talk is firm. For one kind of person is not one whose talk is firm, being like a turmeric spray, or like a post stuck in a termite-hill, or like a water jug on the deck of a ship. But another kind of person is one whose talk is firm, being like a line drawn on stone, or like an iron post, or like a man who would not tell two stories even if his head were cut to pieces with a saw. He is called steadfast.

original: Paccayikoti pattiyāyitabbako, saddhāyitabbakoti attho. Ekacco hi puggalo na paccayiko
analyzed: paccayikaḥ ti pattiyāyitabbako saddhāyitabbako ti attho ekaccaḥ hi puggalaḥ na paccayikaḥ
translated: He is one who has confidence : he is one who should be trusted. The meaning is that he is one who is worthy of confidence. For one kind of person is not one who has confidence,

original: hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “mā tassa vacanaṃ saddahathā”ti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte mā tassa vacanam saddahatha ati vattabbatam
translated: “This was said by so-and-so,” he says, “Do not believe his word.”

original: āpajjati. Eko paccayiko hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “yadi tena vuttaṃ,
analyzed: āpajjati ekaḥ paccayikaḥ hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte yadi tena vuttam
translated: “This was said by so-and-so,” he says, “If he said it,

original: idameva pamāṇaṃ, idāni upaparikkhitabbaṃ natthi, evameva ida”nti vattabbataṃ āpajjati,
analyzed: idam eva pamāṇam idāni upaparikkhitabbam na atthi evam eva idam ti vattabba tam āpajjati
translated: this is the only standard, there is nothing more to investigate, it is just so.”

original: ayaṃ vuccati paccayiko.
analyzed: ayam vuccati paccayikaḥ
translated: This is called a reasoner.

original: Avisaṃvādako lokassāti tāya saccavāditāya lokaṃ na visaṃvādetīti attho.🔽Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāyātiādīsu yāya vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tassa hadaye attano
analyzed: a visaṃvādakaḥ lokassa ati tāya sacca vāditāya lokam na visaṃvādeti iti attho  pisuṇam vācam pahāya ati ādīsu vācāya yassa tam vācam bhāsati tassa hadaye
translated: He does not deceive the world by his truthfulness: the meaning is that he does not deceive the world by his truthfulness.

original: piyabhāvaṃ parassa ca suññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇā vācā. Yāya pana attānampi parampi🔽pharusaṃ karoti, yā vācā sayampi pharusā, neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayaṅgamā, ayaṃ pharusā
analyzed: piya bhāvam parassa ca suñña bhāvam karoti sā pisuṇā vācā yāya pana attānam pi param pi  pharusam karoti yā vācā sayam pi pharusā na iva kaṇṇa sukhā na hadayaṅgamā ayam pharusā
translated: Having abandoned malicious speech: by means of speech whereby he makes himself dear to the heart of another and makes him empty of another, that is malicious speech. But by means of speech whereby he makes himself and another

original: vācā. Yena samphaṃ palapati niratthakaṃ, so samphappalāpo. Yā tesaṃ mūlabhūtā cetanāpi
analyzed: vācā yena sampham palapati niratthakam so sampha ppalāpaḥ yā tesam mūla bhūtā cetanā api
translated: harsh, and that speech is itself harsh, not pleasing to the ear, not appealing to the heart, that is harsh speech. That by means of which he prattles nonsense, that is purposeless talk. The volition that is the root of these

original: pisuṇavācādināmameva labhati, sā eva ca idha adhippetā.
analyzed: pisuṇa vācā ādi nāmam eva labhati sā eva ca idha adhippetā
translated: and the kind of speech that is divisive is what is meant here.

original: Imesaṃ bhedāyāti yesaṃ ito vuttānaṃ santike sutaṃ, tesaṃ bhedāya. Bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātāti
analyzed: imesam bhedāya ati yesam itas vuttānam santike sutam tesam bhedāya bhinnānam vā sandhātā ati
translated: For the purpose of dividing: for the purpose of dividing those who are spoken to from those from whom the talk is heard.

original: dvinnaṃ mittānaṃ vā samānupajjhāyakādīnaṃ vā kenacideva kāraṇena bhinnānaṃ ekamekaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam mittānam vā samāna upajjhāyaka ādīnam vā kenacid eva kāraṇena bhinnānam ekam ekam
translated: Or for the purpose of uniting those who are divided: for the purpose of uniting those who are divided, either two friends or two pupils of the same teacher, etc.,

original: upasaṅkamitvā “tumhākaṃ īdise kule jātānaṃ evaṃ bahussutānaṃ idaṃ na yutta”ntiādīni
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā tumhākam īdise kule jātānam evam bahu sutānam idam na yutta nti ādīni
translated: by approaching each separately and saying, “It is not right for those of your family, who are so learned, to be divided,” etc.,

original: vatvā sandhānaṃ kattā anukattā.
analyzed: vatvā sandhānam kattā anukattā
translated: and then acting as a go-between.

original: Anuppadātāti sandhānānuppadātā. Dve jane samagge disvā “tumhākaṃ evarūpe kule jātānaṃ
analyzed: anuppadātā ati sandhāna anuppadātā dve jane samagge disvā tumhākam evarūpe kule jātānam
translated: For the purpose of not causing to arise: for the purpose of not causing to arise what has not arisen. Having seen two people who are in agreement, he says, “It is not proper for those of your family,

original: evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānaṃ anucchavikameta”ntiādīni vatvā daḷhīkammaṃ kattāti🔽attho. Samaggo ārāmo assāti samaggārāmo, yattha samaggā natthi, tattha vasitumpi
analyzed: evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānam anucchavikam etat ti ādīni vatvā daḷhīkammam kattā ati  attho samaggaḥ ārāmaḥ assa ati samagga ārāmaḥ yattha samaggā natthi tattha vasitum pi
translated: who are so learned, to be divided,” etc., and so he acts as a consolidator.

original: na icchatīti attho. “Samaggarāmo”tipi pāḷi, ayamevettha attho. Samaggaratoti samaggesu
analyzed: na icchati iti ayam eva ittha atthaḥ samaggarato ti samaggesu
translated: The meaning is that he does not wish to live where there are no people in agreement. The text reads “agreeable to living in agreement” . The meaning is the same.

original: rato, te pahāya aññatra gantumpi na icchatīti attho. Samagge disvāpi sutvāpi nandatīti
analyzed: rato te pahāya aññatra gantum pi na icchati iti samagge disvā api sutvā api nandati iti
translated: He delights in unity: he delights in seeing and hearing unity.

original: samagganandī. Samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti yā vācā satte samaggeyeva karoti, taṃ
analyzed: samagga nandī samagga karaṇim vācam bhāsitā ati yā vācā satte samaggeya iva karoti tam
translated: He speaks words that lead to unity: he speaks words that lead to unity of beings.

original: sāmaggiguṇaparidīpikameva vācaṃ bhāsati, na itaranti.🔽Parassa mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā ekantapharusacetanā pharusā vācā,
analyzed: sāmaggi guṇa paridīpikam eva vācam bhāsati na itaranti  parassa ekanta pharusa cetanā pharusā vācā
translated: He speaks words that are illuminating the special qualities of unity, not others.🔽Harsh speech is a volition that is utterly unsympathetic and arises to instigate bodily or verbal acts of oppression.

original: nelāti elaṃ vuccati doso, nassā elanti nelā, niddosāti attho “nelaṅgo setapacchādo”ti🔽ettha vuttanelaṃ viya. Kaṇṇasukhāti byañjanamadhuratāya kaṇṇānaṃ sukhā, sūcivijjhanaṃ
analyzed: nelā ti elam vuccati dosaḥ nassā elanti nelā niddosā ti attho nelaṅgo seta pacchādo ti  ettha vutta nelam viya byañjana madhura tāya kaṇṇānam sukhā
translated: It is called “without ela” because it has no ela, that is, no hate. The word ela is a synonym for hate,🔽like the ela mentioned in the passage, “An ela-limbed man with a white covering” .🔽It is pleasing to the ear because of the sweetness of its expression. It does not give rise to ear-ache, like a needle.

original: viya kaṇṇasūlaṃ na janeti. atthamadhuratāya sakalasarīre kopaṃ ajanetvā pemaṃ janetīti
analyzed: viya kaṇṇa sūlam na janeti attha madhura tāya sakala sarīre kopam a janetvā pa imam janeti iti
translated: It gives rise to love because of the sweetness of its meaning. It does not give rise to anger in the whole body.

original: pemanīyā. Hadayaṃ gacchati apaṭihaññamānā sukhena cittaṃ pavisatīti hadayaṅgamā.
analyzed: pemanīyā hadayam gacchati a paṭihaññamānā sukhena cittam pavisati iti hadayaṅgamā
translated: It goes to the heart because it enters the mind easily without being repulsed.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇatāya pure bhavāti porī, pure saṃvaḍḍhanārī viya sukumārātipi porī, purassa🔽esātipi porī, nagaravāsīnaṃ kathāti attho. Nagaravāsino hi yuttakathā honti, pitimattaṃ
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa tāya pure bhavāti porī pure porī purassa  porī nagara vāsīnam kathā ati atthaḥ nagara vāsinaḥ hi yutta kathāḥ honti
translated: “Porī” is one who has been a porī in the past, because of being full of good qualities. She is also called “porī” because she is delicate, like a porī in the past.🔽“Porī” is also one who has been a porī in the past. The meaning is: the talk of the city-dwellers. For the city-dwellers are talkative, they are satisfied with talk.

original: pitāti bhātimattaṃ bhātāti vadanti. Evarūpī kathā bahuno janassa kantā hotīti bahujanakantā.
analyzed: pitā ati bhātimattam bhātā ati vadanti evarūpī kathā bahunaḥ janassa kantā hoti iti bahu jana kantā
translated: “She is a gossip because she is full of qualities” : she is a gossip because she is full of qualities such as faith, etc. “She is a gossip because she is a former” : she is a gossip because she is a former, a former who has been brought up in luxury like a former queen. “She is a gossip because she is of the city” : she is a gossip because she is of the city, a resident of the city. The meaning is that she is a talker of the city. For the residents of the city are talkers. They say: “Father is pleased, brother is pleased.” “She is a gossip because she is dear to many people” : such talk is dear to many people.

original: Kantabhāveneva bahuno janassa manāpā cittavuḍḍhikarāti bahujanamanāpā.
analyzed: kanta bhāvena iva bahunaḥ janassa manāpā citta vuḍḍhi karā ati bahu jana manāpā
translated: “She is a gossip because she is pleasing to many people” : because of its being dear, it is pleasing to many people, it causes the mind to grow.

original: Anatthaviññāpikā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā samphappalāpo. Kālena vadatīti🔽kālavādī, vattabbayuttakālaṃ sallakkhetvā vadatīti attho. Bhūtaṃ tathaṃ tacchaṃ sabhāvameva
analyzed: anattha viññāpikā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā akusala cetanā samphappalāpaḥ kālena vadati iti  kāla vādī vattabba yutta kālam sallakkhetvā vadati iti atthaḥ bhūtam tatham taccham sabhāvam eva
translated: “She is a gossip because she is a source of harm” : it is a source of harm, a source of unwholesome volition that arises from bodily and verbal effort.🔽“She is a gossip because she speaks at the proper time” : the meaning is that she speaks after considering the proper time for what should be said.🔽“She is a gossip because she speaks what is true” : she speaks what is true, what is factual, what is real, what is just as it is.

original: vadatīti bhūtavādī. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthasannissitameva katvā vadatīti atthavādī.
analyzed: vadati iti bhūtavādī diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika attha sannissitam eva katvā vadati iti atthavādī
translated: “She is a gossip because she speaks what is meaningful” : the meaning is that she speaks after considering what is connected with the good of this world and the next.

original: Navalokuttaradhammasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti dhammavādī. Saṃvaravinayapahānavinayasannissitaṃ🔽katvā vadatīti vinayavādī.
analyzed: nava lokuttara dhamma sannissitam katvā vadati iti dhamma vādī saṃvara vinaya pahāna vinaya sannissitam  katvā vadati iti vinaya vādī
translated: He speaks depending on the nine supramundane states, thus he is a “Dhamma speaker.” He speaks depending on restraint, discipline, and abandoning, thus he is a “Vinaya speaker.”

original: Nidhānaṃ vuccati ṭhapanokāso, nidhānamassa atthīti nidhānavatī, hadaye nidhātabbayuttakaṃ🔽vācaṃ bhāsitāti attho. Kālenāti evarūpiṃ bhāsamānopi ca “ahaṃ nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ
analyzed: nidhānam vuccati ṭhapana ukāsaḥ nidhānam assa atthi iti nidhānavatī hadaye nidhātabba yuttakam  vācam bhāsitā ati kālena ati evarūpim bhāsamānaḥ api ca aham nidhānavatim vācam
translated: A place for keeping is called a “store.” He has a store, thus he is “endowed with a store.” The meaning is: he speaks words that are fit to be kept in the heart.

original: bhāsissāmī”ti na akālena bhāsati, yuttakālaṃ pana apekkhitvāva bhāsatīti attho. Sāpadesanti
analyzed: bhāsissāmi iti na akālena bhāsati yutta kālam pana apekkhitvā ava bhāsati iti attho sa apadesan ti
translated: Even when he speaks in this way, he does not speak at the wrong time, thinking: “I will speak words that are endowed with a store.” The meaning is: he speaks after considering the right time.

original: saupamaṃ, sakāraṇanti attho. Pariyantavatinti paricchedaṃ dassetvā yathāssā paricchedo🔽paññāyati, evaṃ bhāsatīti attho. Atthasaṃhitanti anekehipi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātuṃ
analyzed: saupamam sakāraṇam ti paricchedam dassetvā yathā assā paricchedaḥ  paññāyati evam bhāsati iti atthaḥ attha saṃhitan ti anekehi pi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātum
translated: With a reason is with a simile, the meaning is: with a cause.🔽Having shown the limit, he speaks in such a way that the limit of it is known, thus is the meaning.

original: asakkuṇeyyatāya atthasampannaṃ bhāsati. Yaṃ vā so atthavādī atthaṃ vadati, tena atthena
analyzed: a sakkuṇeyyatāya attha sampannam bhāsati yam vā saḥ attha vādī attham vadati tena atthena
translated: He speaks with a meaning that is rich in meaning, because even when he analyzes in many ways, it cannot be exhausted. Or the meaning is: he speaks the meaning that he, as a speaker of meaning, speaks.

original: sahitattā atthasaṃhitaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, na aññaṃ nikkhipitvā aññaṃ bhāsatīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: sahita ttā attha saṃhitam vācam bhāsati na aññam nikkhipitvā aññam bhāsati iti vuttam
translated: He speaks in a way that is connected with what is proper, he does not speak one thing and then another.

original: hoti. Catuddosāpagataṃ vācaṃ bhāsatīti musāvādādīhi catūhi dosehi apagataṃ vācaṃ
analyzed: hoti catur dosa apagatam vācam bhāsati iti musāvāda ādīhi catūhi dosehi apagatam vācam
translated: He speaks in a way that is free from the four flaws, he speaks in a way that is free from the four flaws of lying, etc.

original: bhāsati. Dvattiṃsāya tiracchānakathāyāti dvattiṃsāya saggamokkhānaṃ tiracchānabhūtāya kathāya.
analyzed: bhāsati dvattiṃsāya tiracchāna kathāya ati dvattiṃsāya sagga mokkhānam tiracchāna bhūtāya kathāya
translated: He speaks in a way that is free from the thirty-two kinds of idle chatter, he speaks in a way that is free from the thirty-two kinds of idle chatter that are not conducive to going beyond the worldly round.

original: Dasa kathāvatthūnīti appicchatādīni dasa vivaṭṭanissitāya kathāya vatthubhūtāni kāraṇāni.
analyzed: dasa kathā vatthūni iti appiccha tā ādīni dasa vivaṭṭa nissitāya kathāya vatthu bhūtāni kāraṇāni
translated: He speaks in a way that is free from the ten kinds of unprofitable talk, he speaks in a way that is free from the ten kinds of talk about the world that is a basis for unprofitable thoughts.

original: Appicchakathanti ettha appicchoti icchāvirahito aniccho nittaṇho. Ettha hi byañjanaṃ
analyzed: ettha appiccho ti icchā virahitaḥ anicchaḥ nittaṇhaḥ ettha hi byañjanam
translated: As regards the words “talk about fewness of wishes” , the person who has few wishes is one who is without wishes, who does not wish, who is uninterested.🔽For here the wording is as if it were incomplete,

original: sāvasesaṃ viya, attho pana niravaseso. Na hi khīṇāsavassa aṇumattāpi icchā nāma atthi.
analyzed: sa avasesam viya atthaḥ pana niravasesaḥ na hi khīṇāsavassa aṇumattā api icchā nāma atthi
translated: but the meaning is complete. For one whose cankers are destroyed there is no such thing as even the slightest wish.🔽And here the distinction should be understood as follows:

original: Apicettha atricchatā pāpicchatā mahicchatā appicchatāti ayaṃ bhedo veditabbo – tattha🔽sakalābhe atittassa paralābhapatthanā atricchatā nāma, tāya samannāgatassa ekabhājane
analyzed: apica ittha atricchatā pāpicchatā mahicchatā appicchatā ati ayam bhedaḥ veditabbo tattha 🔽saka lābhe a tittassa para lābha patthanā atricchatā nāma tāya samannāgatassa eka bhājane
translated: The wish for what is unattainable is called “excessive wishing” . One who possesses it is called “excessively wishful” .

original: pakkapūvepi attano patte patite na supakko viya khuddako viya ca khāyati, sveva pana
analyzed: pakka pūve pi attanaḥ patte patite na su pakkaḥ viya khuddakaḥ viya ca khāyati su eva pana
translated: and when the ripe cakes fell into his own bowl, they seemed to him to be unripe and small.

original: parassa patte pakkhitto supakko viya mahanto viya ca khāyati. Asantaguṇasambhāvanatā🔽pana paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññutā pāpicchatā nāma, sā “idhekacco asaddho samāno saddhoti
analyzed: parassa patte pakkhittaḥ su pakkaḥ viya mahantaḥ viya ca khāyati asanta guṇa sambhāvana tā  pana paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññu tā pāpiccha tā nāma sā idha ekaccaḥ asaddhaḥ samānaḥ saddho ti
translated: and when they fall into his own bowl they seem to him to be small and not well cooked, but when they are put into another’s bowl they seem to him to be large and well cooked.🔽But the state of esteeming as a virtue the fact that one has no such qualities as faith, etc., and the state of being insatiable in receiving are called “covetousness” .

original: maṃ jano jānātū”tiādinā nayena atreva āgatāyeva. Tāya ca samannāgato puggalo kohaññe
analyzed: mam janaḥ jānātu uti ādinā nayena atra iva āgatāya iva tāya ca samannāgato puggalo kohaññe
translated: And that is included in the following clause, “Here someone, lacking faith, thinks …” , etc.,🔽and a person possessing it is established in stinginess.

original: patiṭṭhāti. Santaguṇasambhāvanatā pana paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññutā mahicchatā nāma,🔽sāpi “idhekacco saddho samāno saddhoti maṃ jano jānātūti icchati, sīlavā samāno sīlavāti
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti santa guṇa sambhāvana tā pana paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññu tā mahiccha tā nāma  sā api idha ikaccaḥ saddhaḥ samānaḥ saddho iti mama janaḥ jānātu uti icchati sīlavā samānaḥ sīlavā ati
translated: But the state of esteeming as a virtue the fact that one has such qualities as faith, etc., and the state of being insatiable in receiving are called “miserliness” .🔽And that is included in the following clause, “Here someone, possessing faith, thinks, ‘Let people know me as a person of faith’ …

original: maṃ jano jānātū”ti iminā nayena āgatāyeva. Tāya samannāgato puggalo dussantappayo
analyzed: mam janaḥ jānātu iti iminā nayena āgatāya iva tāya samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ
translated: and possessing virtue, thinks, ‘Let people know me as a person of virtue’” ,

original: hoti, vijātamātāpissa cittaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: hoti vijāta mātā api sa cittam gahetum na sakkoti tena itam vuccati
translated: and a person possessing it is one who is difficult to support, and his mother and father cannot take him as a son.

original: “Aggikkhandho samuddo ca, mahiccho cāpi puggalo;
analyzed: aggi kkhandho samuddaḥ ca mahicchaḥ ca api puggalo
translated: And one with great desires,🔽A cart, and requisites, should give;

original: Sakaṭena paccaye detu, tayopete atappayā”ti. ;
analyzed: sakaṭena paccaye detu tayā upete atappayāti
translated: These three are not to be despised” .

original: Santaguṇanigūhanatā pana paṭiggahaṇe ca mattaññutā appicchatā nāma, tāya samannāgato🔽puggalo attani vijjamānampi guṇaṃ paṭicchādetukāmatāya saddho samāno “saddhoti maṃ
analyzed: santa guṇa nigūhana tā pana paṭiggahaṇe ca mattaññu tā appiccha tā nāma tāya samannāgato  puggalaḥ attani vijjamānam api guṇam paṭicchādetu kāma tāya saddhaḥ samānaḥ saddhā iti mama
translated: But the virtue of concealing one’s own special qualities and knowing the right measure in accepting are called fewness of wishes.🔽A person who possesses these does not wish to have it said of him: “He is faithful” when he is faithful,

original: jano jānātū”ti na icchati. Sīlavā… pavivitto… bahussuto… āraddhavīriyo… samādhisampanno…
analyzed: janaḥ jānātu uti naḥ icchati sīlavā pavivittaḥ bahu sutaḥ āraddha vīriyaḥ samādhi sampannaḥ
translated: “He is virtuous” when he is virtuous, “He is secluded” when he is secluded, “He is learned” when he is learned, “He is energetic” when he is energetic, “He is attained to concentration” when he has attained to concentration,

original: paññavā… khīṇāsavo samāno “khīṇāsavoti maṃ jano jānātū”ti na icchati seyyathāpi majjhantikatthero.
analyzed: paññavā khīṇa asavo samānaḥ khīṇa asavaḥ ti mamam janaḥ jānātu uti naḥ icchati sa iyyathā api majjhantika tthero
translated: “He is wise” when he is wise, “He is one of perfect knowledge and conduct” when he is one of perfect knowledge and conduct, “He is a fully enlightened Buddha” when he is a fully enlightened Buddha, because he is desirous of concealing his own special qualities.🔽And such a bhikkhu generates new gains and makes old gains increase.

original: Evaṃ appiccho ca pana bhikkhu anuppannaṃ lābhaṃ uppādeti, uppannaṃ thāvaraṃ karoti,🔽dāyakānaṃ cittaṃ ārādheti, yathā yathā hi so attano appicchatāya appaṃ gaṇhāti, tathā
analyzed: evam appicchaḥ ca pana bhikkhu anuppannam lābham uppādeti uppannam thāvaram karoti  dāyakānam cittam ārādheti yathā yathā hi saḥ attanaḥ appicchatāya appam gaṇhāti tathā
translated: He wins the confidence of donors,

original: tathā tassa vatte pasannā manussā bahū denti.
analyzed: tathā tassa vatte pasannāḥ manussāḥ bahū denti
translated: for the more he accepts through his fewness of wishes, the more the donors’ confidence in him grows and the more they give him.

original: Aparopi catubbidho appiccho paccayaappiccho dhutaṅgaappiccho pariyattiappiccho adhigamaappicchoti.🔽Tattha catūsu paccayesu appiccho paccayaappiccho. So dāyakassa vasaṃ jānāti, deyyadhammassa
analyzed: aparaḥ api catubbidhaḥ appicchaḥ paccaya appicchaḥ dhutaṅga appicchaḥ pariyatti appicchaḥ adhigama appicchaḥ ti  tattha catūsu paccayesu appicchaḥ paccaya appiccho so dāyakassa vasam jānāti deyya dhammassa
translated: The other kind of fewness of wishes is fourfold as fewness of wishes about requisites, about the ascetic practices, about learning, and about realization.

original: vasaṃ jānāti, attano thāmaṃ jānāti. Yadi hi deyyadhammo bahu hoti, dāyako appaṃ dātukāmo,🔽dāyakassa vasena appaṃ gaṇhāti. Deyyadhammo appo, dāyako bahuṃ dātukāmo, deyyadhammassa
analyzed: vasam jānāti attanaḥ thāmam jānāti yadi hi deyya dhammaḥ bahu hoti dāyakaḥ appam dātu kāmo  dāyakassa vasena appam gaṇhāti deyya dhammaḥ appaḥ dāyakaḥ bahum dātu kāmaḥ deyya dhammassa
translated: Herein, one who is few in wishes about the four kinds of requisites is few in wishes about requisites. He knows the measure in taking what is requisite. For if the requisite is abundant and the giver wishes to give only a little,🔽he accepts only a little out of deference to the giver. If the requisite is scarce and the giver wishes to give abundantly,

original: vasena appaṃ gaṇhāti. Deyyadhammopi bahu, dāyakopi bahuṃ dātukāmo, attano thāmaṃ
analyzed: vasena appam gaṇhāti deyya dhammaḥ api bahu dāyakaḥ api bahum dātu kāmaḥ attanaḥ thāmam
translated: he accepts only what is requisite out of deference to the requisite. If the requisite is abundant and the giver wishes to give abundantly,

original: ñatvā pamāṇeneva gaṇhāti.🔽Dhutaṅgasamādānassa attani atthibhāvaṃ na jānāpetukāmo dhutaṅgaappiccho nāma. Yo
analyzed: ñatvā pamāṇena iva gaṇhāti  dhutaṅga samādānassa attani atthi bhāvam na jāna apetu kāmaḥ dhutaṅga appicchaḥ nāma yaḥ
translated: he accepts only the measure out of deference to himself.🔽One who is few in wishes about undertaking the ascetic practices is called few in wishes about the ascetic practices. He does not advertise his possession of the ascetic practices.

original: pana bahussutabhāvaṃ na jānāpetukāmo, ayaṃ pariyattiappiccho nāma. Yo pana sotāpannādīsu
analyzed: pana bahu ssuta bhāvam na ayam nāma yaḥ pana sotāpanna ādīsu
translated: One who is few in wishes about learning is called few in wishes about learning. He does not advertise his possession of learning.🔽One who is few in wishes about realization is called few in wishes about realization. He does not advertise his possession of the states of stream-entry, etc.

original: aññataro hutvā sotāpannādibhāvaṃ jānāpetuṃ na icchati, ayaṃ adhigamaappiccho nāma.🔽Khīṇāsavo pana atricchataṃ pāpicchataṃ mahicchataṃ pahāya sabbaso icchāpaṭipakkhabhūtāya
analyzed: aññataraḥ hutvā sotāpanna ādi bhāvam na icchati ayam adhigamaappicchaḥ nāma  khīṇāsavaḥ pana atricchatam pāpicchatam mahicchatam pahāya sabbaso icchā paṭipakkha bhūtāya
translated: He does not wish to make known his own attainment of stream-entry, etc.,

original: alobhasaṅkhātāya parisuddhāya appicchatāya samannāgatattā appiccho nāma. “Āvuso,🔽atricchatā pāpicchatā mahicchatāti, ime dhammā pahātabbāti, tesu ādīnavaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: alobha saṅkhātāya parisuddhāya appiccha tāya samannāgata ttā appicchaḥ nāma āvuso  atricchatā pāpicchatā mahicchatā ati ime dhammā pahātabbā ati tesu ādīnavam dassetvā
translated: He is called “content” because he is endowed with the purity of non-greed called “contentment,” which is the opposite of the three kinds of greed,🔽“Friends, there are these three kinds of greed: greed for sensual desires, greed for becoming, and greed for non-becoming. These states should be abandoned.🔽Having shown the danger in these states,

original: evarūpaṃ appicchataṃ samādāya vattitabba”nti vadanto appicchakathaṃ katheti nāma.🔽Santuṭṭhīkathantiādīsu visesatthameva dīpayissāma, yojanā pana vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: evarūpam samādāya vattitabbanti vadantaḥ appicchakatham kathā iti nāma  santuṭṭhī kathan ti ādīsu visesa attham eva dīpayissāma yojanā pana vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: he speaks in praise of the kind of contentment that is the opposite of the three kinds of greed.🔽We shall deal with the rest of the terms in the way that suits the occasion.

original: Santuṭṭhīkathanti itarītarapaccayasantosaṃ nissitaṃ kathaṃ. So panesa santoso dvādasavidho
analyzed: santuṭṭhī kathanti itarītara paccaya santosam nissitam katham saḥ pana esa santosaḥ dvādasavidhaḥ
translated: Contentment is the basis for the talk. Contentment is of twelve kinds:

original: hoti. Seyyathidaṃ – cīvare yathālābhasantoso, yathābalasantoso, yathāsāruppasantosoti
analyzed: hoti sā iyyathidam cīvare yathā lābha santosaḥ yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ iti
translated: contentment with regard to robe-material, with regard to alms food, with regard to lodging, with regard to medicines and provisions for the sick, and with the five mundane kinds of gains, and with the four Noble Paths, and with the four kinds of fruits, and with the five aggregates affected by clinging, and with the six internal bases, and with the six external bases, and with the six classes of consciousness, and with the six classes of contact, and with the eighteen kinds of mental exploration.

original: tividho. Evaṃ piṇḍapātādīsupi.
analyzed: tividhaḥ evam piṇḍapāta ādī supi
translated: and so on as to alms food, etc.

original: Tassāyaṃ pabhedavaṇṇanā – idha bhikkhu cīvaraṃ labhati sundaraṃ vā asundaraṃ vā.
analyzed: tassa ayam pabheda vaṇṇanā idha bhikkhu cīvaram labhati sundaram vā asundaram vā
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu gets a robe, whether it is a fine one or not,

original: So teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti. Ayamassa cīvare yathālābhasantoso.
analyzed: so tena iva yāpeti aññam na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa cīvare yathā lābha santoso
translated: and he makes do with that very one; he does not seek another, and if he gets another he does not use it. This is his contentment with what he gets as to robes.

original: Atha pana yo pakatidubbalo vā hoti, ābādhajarābhibhūto vā, garucīvaraṃ pārupanto
analyzed: atha pana yaḥ pakati dubbalaḥ vā hoti ābādha jarā abhibhūtaḥ vā garu cīvaram
translated: But if he is naturally weak or is overcome by sickness or old age and finds it irksome to wear a heavy robe,

original: kilamati. So sabhāgena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ taṃ parivattetvā lahukena yāpentopi santuṭṭhova
analyzed: kilamati saḥ sabhāgena bhikkhunā saddhim tam parivattetvā lahukena yāpentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva
translated: then if he exchanges it for a light one with a bhikkhu of similar qualities and makes do with that, he is still content.

original: hoti. Ayamassa cīvare yathābalasantoso. Aparo paṇītapaccayalābhī hoti. So pattuṇṇacīvarādīnaṃ🔽aññataraṃ mahagghacīvaraṃ, bahūni vā pana cīvarāni labhitvā “idaṃ therānaṃ cirapabbajitānaṃ,
analyzed: hoti ayam assa cīvare yathābala santoso aparaḥ paṇīta paccaya lābhī hoti so pattuṇṇa cīvara ādīnam  aññataram mahaggha cīvaram bahūni vā pana cīvarāni labhitvā idam therānam cira pabbajitānam
translated: This is his contentment with what is befitting as to robes. Another gets valuable robes such as silk, fine silk, and wool,🔽or many robes, and he gives them to the elders who have long gone forth,

original: idaṃ bahussutānaṃ anurūpaṃ, idaṃ gilānānaṃ, idaṃ appalābhīnaṃ hotū”ti datvā tesaṃ
analyzed: idam bahussutānam anurūpam idam gilānānam idam appalābhīnam hotu uti da tvā tesam
translated: thinking, “These are suitable for those who are learned,” or to those who are sick, or to those who have no supporters,🔽and

original: purāṇacīvaraṃ vā saṅkārakūṭādito vā nantakāni uccinitvā tehi saṅghāṭiṃ katvā dhārentopi
analyzed: purāṇa cīvaram vā saṅkāra kūṭa āditaḥ vā nantakāni uccinitvā tehi saṅghāṭim katvā dhārentaḥ api
translated: He wears a double-stitched robe made from rags picked out of the rubbish heap,

original: santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa cīvare yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa cīvare yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: and he is content with that. This is his contentment with regard to robes as regards kind.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ🔽na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti. Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathālābhasantoso. Yo pana
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā so tena iva yāpeti aññam  na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā lābha santosaḥ yaḥ pana
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets almsfood whether it is coarse or fine, and he makes do with that.

original: attano pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā piṇḍapātaṃ labhati, yenassa paribhuttena
analyzed: attanaḥ pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā piṇḍapātam labhati yena assa paribhuttena
translated: He does not seek anything more. If he gets anything more, he does not take it. This is his contentment with regard to almsfood as regards amount. But if he gets almsfood that is unsuitable for him because it is contrary to his normal diet or to what is needed to cure his illness,

original: aphāsu hoti, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa hatthato sappāyabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: a phāsu hoti saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhuno da tvā tassa hatthato sappāya bhojanam bhuñjitvā
translated: and if by eating it he would be uncomfortable, he gives it to a fellow monk who is in good health and eats suitable food himself,

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathābalasantoso. Aparo
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathābala santosaḥ aparaḥ
translated: and he does his work as a recluse. He is content with that. This is his contentment with regard to almsfood as regards what is suitable. Another

original: bahuṃ paṇītaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ labhati, so taṃ cīvaraṃ viya theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ
analyzed: bahum paṇītam piṇḍapātam labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya thera cira pabbajita bahu ssuta appa lābhī gilānānam
translated: gets much fine almsfood, and he gives the best of it to those elder bhikkhus who are few in years but have long gone forth, to those who are learned, to the heads of fellowships, to the teachers of groups, and to those who are in charge of important duties,🔽and he eats what is left. He is content with that. This is his contentment with regard to almsfood as regards what is proper.

original: datvā tesaṃ vā sesakaṃ piṇḍāya vā caritvā missakāhāraṃ bhuñjantopi santuṭṭhova hoti.
analyzed: datvā tesam vā sesakam piṇḍāya vā caritvā missaka āhāram bhuñjantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti
translated: Or else, having given the rest of it to them, he eats what he gets by wandering for alms. Even so, he is content.

original: Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathāsāruppasantoso.🔽Idha pana bhikkhu senāsanaṃ labhati manāpaṃ vā amanāpaṃ vā, so tena neva somanassaṃ
analyzed: ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā sāruppa santosaḥ  idha pana bhikkhu senāsanam labhati manāpam vā amanāpam vā so tena na iva somanassam
translated: This is his contentment with regard to almsfood as to what is enough.

original: na domanassaṃ uppādeti, antamaso tiṇasanthārakenāpi yathāladdheneva tussati. Ayamassa
analyzed: na domanassam uppādeti antamasaḥ tiṇa santhārakena api yathā laddhena iva tussati
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets a lodging, whether good or bad, and he does not arouse gladness or displeasure over it. He is content with whatever comes by way of lodging, even a spread of grass. This is his

original: senāsane yathālābhasantoso. Yo pana attano pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā
analyzed: senāsane yathā lābha santosaḥ yaḥ pana pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā
translated: contentment with regard to lodging as to what is enough. But if he gets a lodging that is unsuitable for him because it is contrary to his temperament or to his illness,

original: senāsanaṃ labhati, yatthassa vasato aphāsu hoti, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā
analyzed: senāsanam labhati yatthassa vasataḥ a phāsu hoti saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhunaḥ da tvā
translated: where he would be uncomfortable if he used it, he gives it to a fellow monk and

original: tassa santake sappāyasenāsane vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathābalasantoso.
analyzed: tassa santake sappāya senāsane vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathābala santoso
translated: lives in the lodging of a fellow monk that is suitable for him. Even so, he is content. This is his contentment with regard to lodging as to what is enough.

original: Aparo mahāpuñño leṇamaṇḍapakūṭāgārādīni bahūni paṇītasenāsanāni labhati, so taṃ cīvaraṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ leṇa maṇḍapa kūṭāgāra ādīni bahūni paṇīta senāsanāni labhati saḥ tam cīvaram
translated: Another, though he has great merit and gets many fine lodgings such as caves, huts, and rest houses,

original: viya theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ datvā yattha katthaci vasantopi🔽santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso. Yopi “uttamasenāsanaṃ nāma
analyzed: thera cira pabbajita bahussuta appa lābhī gilānānam da tvā yattha katthaci vasantaḥ api  santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathā sāruppa santosaḥ yaḥ api uttama senāsanam nāma
translated: and he is content with whatever dwelling he has, whether high or low, and so on. This is his contentment with regard to dwellings as regards their suitability.

original: pamādaṭṭhānaṃ, tattha nisinnassa thinamiddhaṃ okkamati, niddābhibhūtassa puna paṭibujjhato
analyzed: pamāda ṭṭhānam tattha nisinnassa thinam iddham okkamati niddā abhibhūtassa puna paṭibujjhataḥ
translated: Or he may think, “A fine dwelling is a basis for negligence. Sitting in it, one becomes drowsy and falls asleep. Overcome by drowsiness,

original: pāpavitakkā pātubhavantī”ti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisaṃ senāsanaṃ pattampi na sampaṭicchati,🔽so taṃ paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsarukkhamūlādīsu vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa
analyzed: pāpa vitakkā pātubhavanti iti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisam senāsanam pattam pi na sampaṭicchati  so tam paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsa rukkha mūla ādīsu vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa
translated: on waking evil thoughts appear.” So he refuses a dwelling even if offered to him.

original: senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso.🔽Idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so yaṃ labhati, teneva
analyzed: senāsane yathā sāruppa santosaḥ  idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā saḥ yam labhati tena iva
translated: And living in the open air, at the foot of a tree, and so on, he is content. This is his contentment with regard to dwellings as regards their suitability.

original: tussati, aññaṃ na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti. Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathālābhasantoso.
analyzed: tussati aññam na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā lābha santoso
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets coarse or fine medicines. He is satisfied with whatever he gets and does not seek anything else. If he gets something else, he does not use it. This is his contentment with regard to medicines as regards their suitability.

original: Yo pana telena atthiko phāṇitaṃ labhati, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa
analyzed: yaḥ pana telena atthikaḥ phāṇitam labhati saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhunaḥ da tvā tassa
translated: But if one who needs oil gets molasses, he gives it to a fellow-mendicant who is in need of molasses and gets oil from him.

original: hatthato telaṃ gahetvā aññadeva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti.
analyzed: hatthato telam gahetvā aññatra deva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti
translated: Or he makes medicine with whatever he can get hold of. He is content with that.

original: Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathābalasantoso.
analyzed: ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathābala santoso
translated: This is his contentment with what he gets as to requisites for the sick.

original: Aparo mahāpuñño bahuṃ telamadhuphāṇitādipaṇītabhesajjaṃ labhati, so taṃ cīvaraṃ viya
analyzed: aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ bahum tela madhu phāṇita ādi paṇīta bhesajjam labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya
translated: Another who has great merit gets much fine medicine such as oil, honey, molasses, etc.,

original: theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ datvā tesaṃ ābhatena yena kenaci yāpentopi🔽santuṭṭhova hoti. Yo pana ekasmiṃ bhājane catumadhuraṃ ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ muttaharītakaṃ🔽“gaṇha, bhante, yadicchasī”ti vuccamāno “sacassa tesu aññatarenapi rogo vūpasammati,
analyzed: thera cira pabbajita bahussuta appa lābhī gilānānam da tvā tesam ābhatena yena kenaci yāpentaḥ api  santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti yaḥ pana ekasmin bhājane catu madhuram ṭhapetvā ekasmin mutta harītakam  gaṇha bhante yat icchasi iti vuccamāno saca assa tesu aññatarena api rogaḥ vūpasammati
translated: and he gives it to the elders, the long-celibate, the learned, and the sick, and he makes do with whatever he gets from them.🔽But if he is told, “Take whichever you like, venerable sir, from this vessel of four ingredients and this vessel of harītaki,”🔽and he refuses the four ingredients, saying, “If my illness can be cured with one of these, let it be cured;

original: atha muttaharītakaṃ nāma buddhādīhi vaṇṇita”nti catumadhuraṃ paṭikkhipitvā muttaharītakena
analyzed: atha muttaharītakam nāma buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitan ti catu madhuram paṭikkhipitvā mutta harītakena
translated: but harītaki is praised by the Enlightened One and his disciples,” and he makes use of the harītaki,

original: bhesajjaṃ karonto paramasantuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: bhesajjam karonto parama santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: He is content with the medicine he gets, and so he is satisfied with whatever is in conformity with the Dhamma. This is his satisfaction with the requisite of medicine as it occurs.

original: Imesaṃ pana paccekapaccayesu tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ santosānaṃ yathāsāruppasantosova aggo.
analyzed: imesam pana paccekapaccayesu tiṇṇam tiṇṇam santosānam yathā sāruppa santosaḥ uva aggaḥ
translated: But of the three kinds of satisfaction in each of these requisites, the satisfaction with what is in conformity with the Dhamma is the foremost.

original: Arahā ekekasmiṃ paccaye imehi tīhipi santuṭṭhova.
analyzed: arahā ekekasmin paccaye imehi tīhi pi santuṭṭhaḥ uva
translated: The Arahant is satisfied with each requisite with all three of these kinds of satisfaction.

original: Pavivekakathanti pavivekanissitaṃ kathaṃ. Tayo hi vivekā kāyaviveko cittaviveko upadhivivekoti.🔽Tattha eko gacchati, eko tiṭṭhati, eko nisīdati, eko seyyaṃ kappeti, eko gāmaṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: paviveka kathanti paviveka nissitam katham tayaḥ hi vivekā kāya viveko citta viveko upadhi viveko ti  tattha ekaḥ gacchati ekaḥ tiṭṭhati ekaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ seyyam kappeti ekaḥ gāmam piṇḍāya
translated: Talk about seclusion: talk concerned with the three kinds of seclusion, that is to say, bodily seclusion, mental seclusion, and seclusion from the hindrances.

original: pavisati, eko paṭikkamati, eko abhikkamati, eko caṅkamaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, eko carati,
analyzed: pavisati ekaḥ paṭikkamati ekaḥ abhikkamati ekaḥ caṅkamam adhiṭṭhāti ekaḥ carati
translated: Herein, bodily seclusion is when one goes alone, sits alone, and so on, and when one enters the village alone to get alms and returns alone from it, and when one stands alone, walks, and sits alone, and when one lies down alone after getting up.

original: eko viharatīti ayaṃ kāyaviveko nāma. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo pana cittaviveko nāma. Nibbānaṃ upadhiviveko nāma.
analyzed: ekaḥ viharati iti ayam kāya vivekaḥ nāma aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pana citta vivekaḥ nāma nibbānam upadhi vivekaḥ nāma
translated: Mental seclusion is the eight attainments. Seclusion from the hindrances is Nibbāna.

original: Vuttampi hetaṃ – “kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ nekkhammābhiratānaṃ. Cittaviveko
analyzed: vuttam pi ha etam kāya viveko ca viveka ṭṭha kāyānam nekkhamma abhiratānam citta viveko
translated: And this is said: “Bodily seclusion for those whose bodies are secluded, delighting in renunciation, whose thoughts are purified, mental seclusion,

original: ca parisuddhacittānaṃ paramavodānappattānaṃ. Upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ
analyzed: ca parisuddha cittānam parama vodāna pattānam upadhi viveko ca nirupadhīnam puggalānam
translated: and of those whose minds are purified and who have attained the supreme security from bondage. And seclusion from acquisitions is for those who are free from acquisitions,

original: visaṅkhāragatāna”nti.🔽Asaṃsaggakathanti ettha pana savanasaṃsaggo dassanasaṃsaggo samullapanasaṃsaggo sambhogasaṃsaggo🔽kāyasaṃsaggoti pañcavidho saṃsaggo. Tesu idha bhikkhu suṇāti “amukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame
analyzed: visaṅkhāra gatān anti  a saṃsagga kathanti ettha pana savana saṃsaggo dassana saṃsaggo samullapana saṃsaggo sambhoga saṃsaggo  kāya saṃsaggo ti pañcavidhaḥ saṃsaggo tesu idha bhikkhu suṇāti amukasmin gāme vā nigame
translated: who have reached the unconditioned.”🔽The discussion of non-association: Herein, there are five kinds of association, that is to say, hearing association, seeing association, conversing association, using association,

original: vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā”ti,
analyzed: vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatā ati
translated: and bodily contact association. Herein, a bhikkhu hears that in such and such a village or town a woman or a girl is beautiful, pleasant, attractive, accomplished in all the arts, endowed with the supreme beauty of complexion.

original: so taṃ sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhādubbalyaṃ🔽anāvikatvā hīnāyāvattati. Evaṃ parehi kathiyamānarūpādisampattiṃ attanā vā hasitalapitagītasaddaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tam sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretum sikkhā dubbalyam  anāvika tvā hīnāya avattati evam parehi kathiyamāna rūpa ādi sampattim attanā vā hasita lapita gīta saddam
translated: On hearing this he becomes lustful and cannot maintain the spiritual life. He breaks out of the training and reverts to the secular life.

original: suṇantassa sotaviññāṇavīthivasena uppanno rāgo savanasaṃsaggo nāma.
analyzed: suṇantassa sota viññāṇa vīthi vasena uppannaḥ rāgaḥ savana saṃsaggo nāma
translated: So too, when he hears the sound of laughter or talk or singing, lust arises in him through the ear-consciousness. This is called hearing association.

original: “Idha bhikkhu na heva kho suṇāti, api ca kho sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ vā kumāriṃ vā abhirūpaṃ
analyzed: idha bhikkhu na ha iva kho suṇāti api ca kho sāmam passati itthim vā kumārim vā abhirūpam
translated: “Here a bhikkhu does not hear that a certain woman or man is beautiful, pleasant, attractive, of noble aspect, and endowed with the beauty of perfect complexion.

original: dassanīyaṃ pāsādikaṃ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṃ, so taṃ disvā saṃsīdati
analyzed: dassanīyam pāsādikam paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatam saḥ tam disvā saṃsīdati
translated: But he sees her with his own eyes. Having seen her, lust infects his mind and remains.

original: visīdati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhādubbalyaṃ anāvikatvā hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: visīdati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretum sikkhā dubbalyam anāvika tvā hīnāya avattati
translated: He is not able to maintain the spiritual life and so he tells his friends and companions, his kinsmen and relatives, ‘I cannot maintain the spiritual life, I shall break out’…

original: Evaṃ visabhāgarūpaṃ olokentassa pana cakkhuviññāṇavīthivasena uppannarāgo dassanasaṃsaggo nāma.
analyzed: evam visa bhāga rūpam olokentassa pana cakkhu viññāṇa vīthi vasena uppanna rāgaḥ dassana saṃsaggaḥ nāma
translated: But when one looks at an object of the opposite sex with lust aroused in the visual consciousness, this is called looking with attachment.🔽When lust arises through mutual conversation, this is called talking with attachment.

original: Aññamaññaṃ allāpasallāpavasena uppannarāgo pana samullapanasaṃsaggo nāma. Bhikkhuno🔽bhikkhuniyā santakaṃ bhikkhuniyā vā bhikkhussa santakaṃ gahetvā paribhogakaraṇavasena
analyzed: aññamaññam allāpa sallāpa vasena uppanna rāgaḥ pana samullapanasaṃsaggo nāma bhikkhuno  bhikkhuniyā santakam bhikkhuniyā vā bhikkhussa santakam gahetvā paribhoga karaṇa vasena
translated: When lust arises through using the other’s belongings, this is called using with attachment.

original: uppannarāgo sambhogasaṃsaggo nāma. Hatthaggāhādivasena uppannarāgo pana kāyasaṃsaggo
analyzed: uppanna rāgaḥ sambhoga saṃsaggo nāma hatthaggāha ādi vasena uppanna rāgaḥ pana kāya saṃsaggo
translated: When lust arises through holding hands, etc., this is called touching with attachment.

original: nāma. Arahā imehi pañcahi saṃsaggehi catūhipi parisāhi saddhiṃ asaṃsaṭṭho, gāhamuttako
analyzed: nāma arahā imehi pañcahi saṃsaggehi catūhi pi parisāhi saddhim a saṃsaṭṭhaḥ gāha muttakaḥ
translated: The Arahant is not associated with these five kinds of association with the four kinds of assemblies. He is free from the association of going and the association of meeting.

original: ceva saṃsaggamuttako ca. Asaṃsaggassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanto asaṃsaggakathaṃ katheti nāma.
analyzed: ca iva saṃsagga muttako ca a saṃsaggassa vaṇṇam bhaṇantaḥ a saṃsagga katham kathā iti nāma
translated: When he praises non-association, he is said to preach the sermon on non-association.

original: Vīriyārambhakathanti ettha yo paggahitavīriyo paripuṇṇakāyikacetasikavīriyo hoti,
analyzed: vīriya ārambha kathanti ettha yo paggahita vīriyo paripuṇṇa kāyika cetasika vīriyaḥ hoti
translated: The sermon on the arousing of energy: here, one who has undertaken energy and is perfect in bodily and mental energy

original: gamane uppannaṃ kilesaṃ ṭhānaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na deti, ṭhāne uppannaṃ kilesaṃ nisajjaṃ,🔽nisajjāya uppannaṃ kilesaṃ sayanaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na deti, daṇḍena kaṇhasappaṃ uppīḷetvā
analyzed: gamane uppannam kilesam ṭhānam pāpuṇitum na deti ṭhāne uppannam kilesam nisajjam  nisajjāya uppannam kilesam sayanam pāpuṇitum na deti daṇḍena kaṇha sappam uppīḍetvā
translated: does not allow the defilements that arise in going to reach a state of full maturity; he does not allow the defilements that arise in standing to reach a state of full maturity;🔽he does not allow the defilements that arise in sitting to reach a state of full maturity; he does not allow the defilements that arise in lying down to reach a state of full maturity.

original: gaṇhanto viya amittaṃ gīvāya akkamanto viya ca vicarati, tādisassa āraddhavīriyassa
analyzed: gaṇhantaḥ viya amittam akkamantaḥ viya ca vicarati tādisassa āraddha vīriyassa
translated: He goes about his business like one who squeezes a black snake with a stick or like one who treads on his enemy’s neck.

original: vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanto vīriyārambhakathaṃ katheti nāma.
analyzed: vaṇṇam bhaṇantaḥ vīriya ārambha katham kathā iti nāma
translated: When he praises one who has aroused energy in this way, he is said to preach the sermon on the arousing of energy.

original: Sīlakathantiādīsu sīlanti catupārisuddhisīlaṃ. Samādhīti vipassanāpādakā aṭṭha samāpattiyo.
analyzed: sīla kathanti ādīsu sīlam ati catu pārisuddhi sīlam samādhi iti vipassanā pādakāḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ
translated: The sermon on virtue, etc.: virtue is the virtue of the fourfold purification . Concentration is the eight attainments that are the basis for insight .

original: Paññāti lokiyalokuttarañāṇaṃ. Vimuttīti arahattaphalavimutti. Vimuttiñāṇadassananti
analyzed: paññā ati lokiya lokuttara ñāṇam vimutti iti arahatta phala vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassanan ti
translated: “Understanding” is mundane and supramundane knowledge. “Liberation” is the liberation that is the fruit of arahantship. “Knowledge and vision of liberation” is the knowledge of reviewing, which is of nineteen kinds.

original: ekūnavīsatividhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ. Sīlādīnaṃ guṇaṃ pakāsento sīlādikathaṃ katheti nāma.
analyzed: ekūnavīsatividham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam sīla ādīnam guṇam pakāsento sīla ādi katham kathā iti nāma
translated: When he expounds the virtues of virtue, etc., he is said to expound the exposition of virtue, etc.

original: Satipaṭṭhānakathantiādīni saṅgajālamaticca so munītipariyosānāni pubbe vuttānusārena veditabbāni.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna katha nti ādīni saṅga jālam aticca saḥ muni iti pariyosānāni pubbe vutta anusārena veditabbāni
translated: The exposition of the foundations of mindfulness, etc., should be understood in the same way as stated above in the case of the exposition of virtue, etc.

original: 86. Nirāsattīti nittaṇho. Vivekadassī phassesūti paccuppannesu cakkhusamphassādīsu
analyzed: nirāsattī iti nittaṇhaḥ viveka dassī phassesu ti paccuppannesu cakkhu samphassa ādīsu
translated: “Without grasping” : without craving. “Seeing the danger in contact” : he sees the danger in the present eye-contact, etc.

original: attādibhāvavivekaṃ passati. Diṭṭhīsu ca na nīyatīti dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu kāyaci diṭṭhiyā na nīyati.
analyzed: attā ādi bhāva vivekam passati diṭṭhīsu ca na nīyati iti dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu kāyaci diṭṭhiyā na nīyati
translated: “He is not led by views” : he is not led by any of the sixty-two views.

original: Vipariṇataṃ vā vatthuṃ na socatīti pakatibhāvaṃ jahitvā naṭṭhe kismiñci vatthusmiṃ na sokaṃ āpajjati. Vipariṇatasmiṃ vāti vinassamāne vatthumhi.
analyzed: vipariṇatam vā vatthum na socati iti pakati bhāvam jahitvā naṭṭhe kismiñci vatthusmiṃ na sokam āpajjati vipariṇatasmim vā ati vinassamāne vatthumhi
translated: “He does not grieve over a destroyed object” : he does not grieve over any object that has lost its former condition. “Over a destroyed object” : over an object that is being destroyed.

original: Cakkhusamphassoti cakkhuṃ vatthuṃ katvā cakkhuviññāṇasahajāto phasso cakkhusamphasso.
analyzed: cakkhu samphasso ti cakkhum vatthum katvā cakkhu viññāṇa sahajātaḥ phassaḥ cakkhu samphasso
translated: Eye-contact : the contact associated with eye-consciousness that has the eye as its physical basis is eye-contact.

original: Sesesupi eseva nayo. Ettha ca purimā cakkhupasādādivatthukāva, manosamphasso hadayavatthukopi
analyzed: sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca purimā cakkhu pasāda ādi vatthukā āva manaḥ samphassaḥ hadaya vatthukaḥ pi
translated: The same method applies in the case of the rest. And here the contact that has the first four bases beginning with the eye is only of the four planes. But the contact that has the mind as its basis is of the four planes and is also without a basis.

original: avatthukopi sabbo catubhūmako phasso. Adhivacanasamphassoti pariyāyena etassa nāmaṃ🔽hotiyeva. Tayo hi arūpino khandhā sayaṃ piṭṭhivaṭṭakā hutvā attano sahajātasamphassassa
analyzed: avatthukaḥ api sabbaḥ catu bhūmako phassaḥ adhivacana samphassaḥ ti pariyāyena etassa nāmam  tayo hi arūpino khandhā sayam piṭṭhivaṭṭakā hutvā attanaḥ sahajāta samphassassa
translated: The contact called “contact with the verbal determinations” is so called only figuratively.

original: adhivacanasamphassoti nāmaṃ karonti. Paṭighasamphassoti nippariyāyena pana paṭighasamphasso
analyzed: adhivacana samphassaḥ iti nāmam karonti paṭigha samphassaḥ iti nippariyāyena pana paṭigha samphassaḥ
translated: For the three immaterial aggregates, which are like a ball of thread, make the name “contact with the verbal determinations” for the contact associated with them.🔽The contact called “contact with resistance” is so called literally. It is the contact of the five doors.

original: nāma pañcadvārikaphasso. Adhivacanasamphasso nāma manodvārikaphasso. Sukhavedanīyo
analyzed: nāma pañca dvārika phassaḥ adhivacana samphassaḥ nāma manaḥ dvārika phassaḥ sukha vedanīyo
translated: The contact called “contact with the verbal determinations” is the contact of the mind door.

original: phassoti sukhavedanāya hito uppādako phasso. Itaradvayepi eseva nayo. Kusalo phassoti
analyzed: phasso ti sukha vedanāya hitaḥ uppādako phasso itara dvaye pi esa iva nayo kusalaḥ phasso ti
translated: Contact that is to be felt as pleasant is contact that is beneficial and productive of pleasant feeling. The same method applies in the case of the other two kinds of feeling.

original: ekavīsatikusalacittasahajāto phasso. Akusaloti dvādasaakusalasahajāto phasso. Abyākatoti
analyzed: ekavīsati kusala citta sahajātaḥ phassaḥ akusalaḥ ti dvādasa akusala sahajātaḥ phassaḥ abyākataḥ ti
translated: Contact that is profitable is contact associated with the twenty-one kinds of profitable consciousness. Contact that is unprofitable is contact associated with the twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness. Contact that is indeterminate is contact associated with the eight kinds of indeterminate consciousness.

original: chappaññāsaabyākatasahajāto phasso. Kāmāvacaroti catupaññāsakāmāvacarasahajāto phasso.🔽Rūpāvacaroti kusalādipañcadasarūpāvacarasampayutto. Arūpāvacaroti kusalābyākatavasena
analyzed: chappaññāsa abyākata sahajātaḥ phasso kāmāvacaro ti catu paññāsa kāmāvacara sahajātaḥ phasso  rūpā avacaroti kusala ādi pañcadasa rūpāvacara sampayuttaḥ arūpā avacaroti kusala abyākata vasena
translated: Contact associated with the indeterminate is the fifty-five kinds of contact associated with the indeterminate.🔽Contact belonging to the sense sphere is the fifty-four kinds of contact associated with the sense sphere.

original: dvādasaarūpāvacarasampayutto.🔽Suññatoti anattānupassanāvasena vipassantassa uppanno maggo suññato, tena sahajāto🔽phasso suññato phasso. Itaradvayepi eseva nayo. Animittoti ettha aniccānupassanāvasena
analyzed: dvādasa arūpa avacara sampayutto  suññato ti anatta anupassanā vasena vipassantassa uppannaḥ maggo suññato tena sahajāto  phasso suññataḥ phasso itara dvaye pi esā iva nayaḥ animitto ti ettha anicca anupassanā vasena
translated: Contact belonging to the fine-material sphere is that associated with the fifteen kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness. Contact belonging to the immaterial sphere is that associated with the twelve kinds of immaterial-sphere consciousness, both profitable and indeterminate.🔽Contact related to the void is the contact associated with the path of seeing that arises in one who is contemplating the signless by way of contemplation of not-self.

original: vipassantassa uppanno maggo animitto. Appaṇihitoti dukkhānupassanāvasena vipassantassa🔽uppanno maggo appaṇihito. Lokiyoti loko vuccati lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena vaṭṭo, tasmiṃ
analyzed: vipassantassa uppannaḥ maggaḥ animittaḥ appaṇihito ti dukkha anupassanā vasena vipassantassa  uppannaḥ maggaḥ appaṇihitaḥ lokiyaḥ ti lokaḥ vuccati lujjana palujjana aṭṭhena vaṭṭaḥ tasmin
translated: Contact related to the signless is the contact associated with the path of seeing that arises in one who is contemplating impermanence. Contact related to the desireless is the contact associated with the path of seeing that arises in one who is contemplating pain.

original: pariyāpannabhāvena loke niyuttoti lokiyo, tebhūmako dhammo. Lokuttaroti lokato uttaro
analyzed: pariyāpanna bhāvena loke niyutto ti lokiyaḥ tebhūmako dhammo lokuttaro ti lokataḥ uttaro
translated: The mundane is the world ; the world is so called because of the breaking up and falling away of what is formed . The mundane is that which is included in the world. The supramundane is that which is beyond the world.

original: uttiṇṇoti lokuttaro, loke apariyāpannabhāvenapi lokuttaro. Attena vāti attabhāvena
analyzed: uttiṇṇaḥ ti lokuttaraḥ loke a pariyāpanna bhāvena api lokuttaraḥ attena vāti atta bhāvena
translated: “Emerged” : supramundane, supramundane by being unincluded in the world. “By that self” : by that individual essence.

original: vā. Attaniyena vāti attāyattena vā.
analyzed: vā attaniyena vā ati attāyattena vā
translated: “By that which is his own” : by that which is his own self.

original: 87. Patilīnoti rāgādīnaṃ pahīnattā tato apagato. Akuhakoti avimhāpako tīhi kuhanavatthūhi.🔽Apihālūti apihanasīlo, patthanātaṇhāya rahitoti vuttaṃ hoti. Amaccharīti pañcamaccheravirahito.
analyzed: patilīnaḥ ti rāga ādīnam pahīna ttā tatas apagataḥ akuhako ti a vimhāpako tīhi kuhana vatthūhi  apihālu uti apihana sīlo patthanā taṇhāya rahito ti vuttam hoti amaccharī iti pañca macchera virahito
translated: “Gone beyond” : gone beyond greed, etc., by having abandoned them. “Not a deceiver” : not a cheat, by means of the three kinds of scheming.🔽“Not a despiser” : not a contemner, not one who has the habit of despising, not one who is devoid of aspiration-craving, is what is meant. “Not a cheat” : not one who is devoid of the five kinds of cheating.🔽“Not a swindler” : not one who is a swindler by body, etc. “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc.

original: Appagabbhoti kāyapāgabbhiyādivirahito. Ajegucchoti sampannasīlāditāya ajegucchanīyo🔽asecanako manāpo. Pesuṇeyye ca no yutoti dvīhi ākārehi upasaṃharitabbe pisuṇakamme ayutto.
analyzed: appagabbhaḥ ti kāya pāgabbhiya ādi virahitaḥ ajeguccho ti sampanna sīla ādi tāya ajegucchanīyaḥ  asecanakaḥ manāpaḥ pesuṇeyye ca no yutaḥ ti dvīhi ākārehi upasaṃharitabbe pisuṇa kamme ayutto
translated: “Not a cheat” : not one who is a cheat by body, etc. “Not a swindler” : not one who is a swindler by body, etc. “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc.🔽“Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc. “Not a cheat” : not one who is a cheat by body, etc. “Not a swindler” : not one who is a swindler by body, etc. “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc.🔽“Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc. “Not a cheat” : not one who is a cheat by body, etc. “Not a swindler” : not one who is a swindler by body, etc. “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc.🔽“Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc. “Not a cheat” : not one who is a cheat by body, etc. “Not a swindler” : not one who is a swindler by body, etc. “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc.

original: Rāgassa pahīnattāti arahattamaggena rāgakilesassa pahīnabhāvena. Asmimāno pahīno hotīti asmīti unnatimāno samucchedavasena pahīno hoti.
analyzed: rāgassa pahīna ttā ati arahatta maggena rāga kilesassa pahīna bhāvena asmimānaḥ pahīnaḥ hoti iti asmi iti unnati māno samuccheda vasena pahīnaḥ hoti
translated: “Not a deceiver” : not one who is a deceiver by body, etc. “Not a cheat” : not one who is a cheat by body, etc. “Not a swindler” :

original: Tīṇi kuhanavatthūnīti tīṇi vimhāpanakāraṇāni. Paccayapaṭisevanasaṅkhātaṃ kuhanavatthūtiādīsu
analyzed: tīṇi kuhana vatthūni iti tīṇi vimhāpana kāraṇāni paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātam kuhana vatthu ti ādīsu
translated: Three grounds for hypocrisy: three reasons for deceiving others. The ground for hypocrisy called “accepting requisites” is as follows.

original: cīvarādīhi nimantitassa tadatthikasseva sato pāpicchataṃ nissāya paṭikkhipanena te
analyzed: cīvara ādīhi nimantitassa tad atthikassa iva sataḥ pāpicchatam nissāya paṭikkhipanena te
translated: When one who is in need has been invited to accept robe-material, etc., and he refuses out of greed for the material,

original: ca gahapatike attani suppatiṭṭhitapasāde ñatvā puna tesaṃ “aho ayyo appiccho, na🔽kiñci paṭiggaṇhituṃ icchati, suladdhaṃ vata no assa, sace appamattakampi kiñci paṭiggaṇheyyā”ti
analyzed: ca gahapatike attani suppatiṭṭhita pasāde ñatvā puna tesam aho ayyaḥ appicchaḥ na  kiñci paṭiggaṇhitum icchati su laddham vata no assa sace appamattakam pi kiñci paṭiggaṇheyya ati
translated: and then when the householders have come to know that he has great confidence in them,🔽and they bring him various kinds of fine robe-material, etc., with many entreaties, saying, “It would be good if you would accept something, venerable sir,”

original: nānāvidhehi upāyehi paṇītāni cīvarādīni upanentānaṃ tadanuggahakāmataṃyeva avikatvā🔽paṭiggahaṇena ca tato pabhuti api sakaṭabhārehi upanāmanahetubhūtaṃ vimhāpanaṃ paccayapaṭisevanasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: nānāvidhehi upāyehi paṇītāni cīvara ādīni upanentānam tad anuggaha kāma taṃyā iva a vikatvā  paṭiggahaṇena ca tatas pabhuti api sakaṭa bhārehi upanāmana hetu bhūtam vimhāpanam paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātam
translated: and he does not reveal his real desire for them,🔽and he accepts, and then afterwards they bring him even on carts as much as he wants, the deceiving of them is called “the ground for hypocrisy called accepting requisites.”

original: kuhanavatthūti veditabbaṃ. Pāpicchasseva pana sato sambhāvanādhippāyena katena iriyāpathena
analyzed: kuhana vatthu uti veditabbam pāpa icchassa iva pana sato sambhāvanā adhippāyena katena iriyāpathena
translated: But when one who is greedy for gain and honour goes about in the way of life of the Noble Ones,

original: vimhāpanaṃ iriyāpathasaṅkhātaṃ kuhanavatthūti veditabbaṃ. Pāpicchasseva pana sato
analyzed: vimhāpanam iriyāpatha saṅkhātam kuhana vatthu uti veditabbam pāpa icchassa iva pana sataḥ
translated: The kind of deception that should be understood as the ground for the pretence of being something one is not is the kind called “posturing” .

original: uttarimanussadhammādhigamaparidīpanavācāya tathā tathā vimhāpanaṃ sāmantajappanasaṅkhātaṃ🔽kuhanavatthūti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: uttari manussa dhamma adhigama paridīpana vācāya tathā tathā vimhāpanam sāmanta jappana saṅkhātam  kuhana vatthu uti veditabbam
translated: The kind of deception that should be understood as the ground for the pretence of purity is the kind called “dissembling” .

original: Katamaṃ paccayapaṭisevanasaṅkhātanti ettha paccayapaṭisevananti evaṃ saṅkhātaṃ paccayapaṭisevanasaṅkhātaṃ.
analyzed: katamam paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātanti ettha paccaya paṭisevananti evam saṅkhātam paccaya paṭisevana saṅkhātam
translated: What is called “the receiving of requisites”? The receiving of requisites is called “the receiving of requisites.”

original: Nimantentīti idha gahapatikā “bhikkhaṃ gaṇhathā”ti bhikkhū nimantenti. Ayameva vā
analyzed: nimantenti iti idha gahapatikāḥ bhikkham gaṇhatha ati bhikkhū nimantenti ayam eva vā
translated: Herein, householders invite bhikkhus, saying, “Venerable sirs, please accept requisites from me.” This is the reading.

original: pāṭho. “Nimantetī”ti vā “vadantī”ti vā keci paṭhanti. Tādise nimantāpenti. Nimantentīti🔽pāṭhassa sambhavo daṭṭhabbo. Cīvaraṃ paccakkhātīti cīvaraṃ paṭikkhipati. Etaṃ sāruppaṃ,
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ nimanteti iti vā vadanti iti vā paṭhanti nimantāpenti nimantenti iti  pāṭhassa sambhavaḥ daṭṭhabbo cīvaram paccakkhāti iti cīvaram paṭikkhipati etam sāruppam
translated: Some read “invites” as “says.” They invite in this way. The reading should be understood thus.🔽“He refuses robe-cloth”: he rejects robe-cloth. This is appropriate,

original: yaṃ samaṇoti yaṃ cīvaradhāraṇaṃ samaṇo karoti, etaṃ sāruppaṃ anucchavikaṃ. Pāpaṇikā
analyzed: yam samaṇaḥ iti yam cīvara dhāraṇam samaṇaḥ karoti etam sāruppam anucchavikam
translated: that is, what an ascetic does in the way of wearing robe-cloth is appropriate, suitable.

original: vā nantakānīti āpaṇadvāre patikāni antavirahitāni pilotikāni. Uccinitvāti saṃkaḍḍhitvā.🔽Uñchācariyāyāti bhikkhācaraṇena. Piṇḍiyālopenāti piṇḍaṃ katvā laddhaālopena. Pūtimuttena🔽vāti gomuttena vā. Osadhaṃ kareyyāti bhesajjakiccaṃ kareyya. Tadupādāyāti tato paṭṭhāya.
analyzed: vā nantakāni iti āpaṇa dvāre patikāni anta virahitāni pilotikāni uccinitvā iti saṃkaḍḍhitvā  uñchā cariyāya ati bhikkhā caraṇena piṇḍiyā lopena ati piṇḍam katvā laddha ālopena pūti muttena  vā ti gomuttena vā osadham kareyya ati bhesajja kiccam kareyya tat upādāya ati tatas paṭṭhāya
translated: and the ends of the cloth were at the shop door. He took them and gathered them together.🔽By means of the practice of gleaning: by means of the practice of going for alms. With what he got by collecting alms: with what he got by collecting alms after making them into a lump. With urine🔽as medicine: with cow’s urine. He would make medicine: he would make a medicine. From that time on: from that time.

original: Dhutavādoti dhutaguṇavādī. Bhiyyo bhiyyo nimantentīti uparūpari nimantenti. Sammukhībhāvāti
analyzed: dhuta vādī iti dhuta guṇa vādī bhiyyas bhiyyas nimantenti iti upari upari nimantenti sammukhībhāvāt
translated: The one who spoke of the ascetic practices: the one who spoke of the virtues of the ascetic practices. They invited him again and again: they invited him repeatedly. By the presence:

original: sammukhībhāvena, vijjamānatāyāti attho. Pasavatīti paṭilabhati. Saddhāya sammukhībhāvena
analyzed: sammukhībhāvena vijjamāna tāya ati attho pasavati iti paṭilabhati saddhāya sammukhībhāvena
translated: by the presence, by the existence, is the meaning. He would have: he would obtain. By the presence of faith:

original: sakkā kātunti “saddhāya sammukhībhāvā”tiādimāha. Deyyadhammā sulabhā dakkhiṇeyyā
analyzed: sakkā kātunti saddhāya sammukhībhāva ati ādim āha deyya dhammā sulabhā dakkhiṇeyyā
translated: because of the presence of faith. It can be done: he said “By the presence of faith” because gifts are easy to get and there are those worthy of offerings,

original: ca, saddhā pana dullabhā. Puthujjanassa hi saddhā athāvarā, padavāre padavāre nānā
analyzed: ca saddhā pana dullabhā puthujjanassa hi saddhā atha avarā padavāre padavāre nānā
translated: but faith is difficult to get. For the faith of an ordinary person is inferior, and it is different at every step,

original: hoti. Tenevassa mahāmoggallānasadisopi aggasāvako pāṭibhogo bhavituṃ asakkonto āha
analyzed: hoti tena iva assa mahāmoggallāna sadisaḥ api aggasāvakaḥ pāṭibhogaḥ bhavitum a sakkontaḥ āha
translated: at every moment. Therefore, even a chief disciple like the Venerable Moggallana, who was unable to be a recipient, said:

original: “dvinnaṃ kho nesaṃ āvuso dhammānaṃ pāṭibhogo bhogānañca jīvitassa ca, saddhāya pana tvaṃ pāṭibhogo”ti.
analyzed: dvinnam kho nesam āvuso dhammānam pāṭibhogaḥ bhogānam ca jīvitassa ca saddhāya pana tvam pāṭibhogaḥ ti
translated: “You are a debtor, friend, for two things, namely, wealth and life, but you are a debtor for faith.”🔽Herein, “by merit” is an ablative in the sense of cause.🔽You will be deprived of merit, you will be turned away from it. “Grumbling” is the making of a wry face, which is shown by the expression “with a wry face” .

original: Evaṃ tumhe puññena paribāhirā bhavissathāti ettha puññenāti nissakkatthe karaṇavacanaṃ.🔽Puññato parihīnā parammukhā bhavissatha. Bhākuṭikāti mukhānaṃ padhānapurimaṭṭhitabhāvadassanena🔽bhākuṭikaraṇaṃ, mukhasaṅkocoti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhākuṭikaraṇaṃ sīlamassāti bhākuṭiko,🔽bhākuṭikassa bhāvo bhākuṭiyaṃ. Kuhanāti vimhāpanā. Kuhassa āyanā kuhāyanā. Kuhitassa bhāvo kuhitattaṃ.🔽Pāpicchoti asantaguṇadīpanakāmo. Icchāpakatoti icchāya apakato, upaddutoti attho.
analyzed: evam tumhe puññena paribāhirāḥ bhavissatha ati ettha puññena ati nissakka tthe karaṇavacanam  puññatas parihīnāḥ parammukhāḥ bhavissatha bhākuṭikā ati mukhānam padhāna purima ṭṭhita bhāva dassanena  bhākuṭi karaṇam mukha saṅkocaḥ ti vuttam hoti bhākuṭi karaṇam sīlam assa ati bhākuṭikaḥ  bhākuṭikassa bhāvaḥ bhākuṭiyam kuhanā ati vimhāpanā kuhassa āyanā kuhāyanā kuhitassa bhāvaḥ kuhitattam  pāpa iccho ti asanta guṇa dīpana kāmo icchā apakato ti icchāya apakato upadduto ti attho
translated: One who has the habit of making a wry face is a “grumbler” .🔽The state of a grumbler is “grumbling” . “Scheming” is deception. “Schemingly” is the act of scheming. “Schemedness” is the state of being schemed.

original: Sambhāvanādhippāyoti bahumānajjhāsayo. Gamanaṃ saṇṭhapetīti abhikkamādigamanaṃ abhisaṅkharoti,
analyzed: sambhāvanā adhippāyaḥ ti gamanam saṇṭhapeti iti abhikkama ādi gamanam abhisaṅkharoti
translated: “Evil desire” is the desire to display non-existent good qualities. “Bent on gain” : bent by gain, is the meaning. “Bent on honour” : bent by honour. “Bent on craving” : bent by craving. “Bent on fame” : bent by fame. “Bent on gain, honour, craving, and fame” : bent by gain, honour, craving, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving for gain, honour, and fame. “Bent on craving for gain, honour, and fame” : bent by craving

original: pāsādikabhāvaṃ karotīti vuttaṃ hoti. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Paṇidhāya gacchatīti patthanaṃ🔽ṭhapetvā gacchati. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Samāhito viya gacchatīti upacārappatto viya
analyzed: pāsādika bhāvam karoti iti vuttam hoti itaresu pi esā iva nayaḥ paṇidhāya gacchati iti patthanam  ṭhapetvā gacchati sesesu pi esā iva nayo samāhitaḥ viya gacchati iti upacāra ppatto viya
translated: he makes himself lovable. The same method applies to the rest. He goes having resolved: having set up a resolution🔽he goes. The same method applies to the rest. He goes as if concentrated: having reached access concentration,

original: gacchati. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: gacchati sesa isupi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: He makes himself inspiring: he makes himself inspiring to others. The same method applies to the rest. He goes with a vow: he goes having made a vow. The same method applies to the rest. He goes as if he were absorbed in meditation: he goes as if he were absorbed in access concentration. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Āpāthakajjhāyīva hotīti sammukhā āgatānaṃ manussānaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjanto viya santabhāvaṃ
analyzed: āpāthaka jhāyī iva hoti iti sammukhāḥ āgatānam manussānam jhānam samāpajjantaḥ viya santa bhāvam
translated: He is as though in jhāna in the presence of those who come up to him: he shows himself to be calm as though he were entering upon jhāna in the presence of people who have come up to him.🔽In the postures: in the four postures.

original: dasseti. Iriyāpathassāti catuiriyāpathassa. Āṭhapanāti ādiṭṭhapanā, ādarena vā ṭhapanā.
analyzed: dasseti iriyāpathassa ati catu iriyāpathassa āṭhapanā ati ādiṭṭhapanā ādarena vā ṭhapanā
translated: In the placing: in the placing, or in the steady placing, of the feet.

original: Ṭhapanāti ṭhapanākāro. Saṇṭhapanāti abhisaṅkharaṇaṃ, pāsādikabhāvakaraṇanti vuttaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapanā ati ṭhapana ākāraḥ saṇṭhapanā ati abhisaṅkharaṇam pāsādika bhāva karaṇanti vuttam
translated: In the placing: in the mode of placing. In the steadying: in the steadying, in the making, as it were, of a foundation.🔽He makes himself inspiring: he makes himself inspiring to others.

original: hoti. Ariyadhammasannissitanti lokuttaradhammapaṭibaddhaṃ. Kuñcikanti avāpuraṇaṃ.
analyzed: hoti ariya dhamma sannissitanti lokuttara dhamma paṭibaddham kuñcikam ti avāpuraṇam
translated: Dependent on the noble states: bound up with the supramundane states.🔽The key: the bolt.

original: Mittāti sinehavanto. Sandiṭṭhāti diṭṭhamattā. Sambhattāti daḷhamittā. Uddaṇḍeti eko patissayaviseso.
analyzed: mittā ati sinehavantaḥ sandiṭṭhā ati diṭṭhamattā sambhattā ati daḷhamittā uddaṇḍā iti ekaḥ patissaya viseso
translated: Friends: those who are friendly. Acquaintances: those who are seen. Companions: those who are close friends. Associates: a particular kind of intimate.

original: Korajikakorajikoti saṅkocasaṅkocako, atisaṅkocakoti vuttaṃ hoti. “Koracakakoracako”ti🔽vā pāṭho. Bhākuṭikabhākuṭikoti ativiya mukhasaṅkocanasīlo. Kuhakakuhakoti ativiya🔽vimhāpako. Lapakalapakoti ativiya sallāpako. Mukhasambhāvikoti attano mukhavasena🔽aññehi saha sambhāviko, appitacittoti eke. Santānanti kilesasantatāya santānaṃ. Samāpattīnanti
analyzed: korajika korajikaḥ iti saṅkoca saṅkocakaḥ ati saṅkocakaḥ iti vuttam hoti koracaka koracakaḥ iti  vā pāṭhaḥ bhākuṭika bhākuṭikaḥ uti mukha saṅkocana sīlaḥ kuhaka kuhakaḥ uti  vimhāpakaḥ lapaka lapakoti ativiya sallāpakaḥ mukhasambhāvikoti attanaḥ mukha vasena  aññehi saha sambhāvikaḥ appita citto ti eke santānanti kilesa santatāya santānam samāpattīnam ti
translated: “Kora-jikora” is “kosa-kosa,” “very contracted,” “very contracted in,” is what is meant. Or the reading may be “kora-caka-kora-caka,”🔽“bent-bent,” “bent in,” “bent in.” “Bhākuṭika-bhākuṭika” is “very much bhākuṭika,” “very much contracted in the face.” “Kuhaka-kuhaka” is “very much🔽deceiving.” “Lapaka-lapaka” is “very much talking.” “Mukhasambhāvī” is “one who associates with others by means of his face,” “one who is full of flattery,” say some. “Santāna” is “continuance” by the continuity of defilements. “Samāpatti” is🔽

original: samāpajjitabbānaṃ. Gambhīranti ninnapatiṭṭhānaṃ. Gūḷhanti dassetuṃ dukkhaṃ. Nipuṇanti🔽sukhumaṃ. Paṭicchannanti padatthena duppaṭivijjhādhippāyaṃ. Lokuttaranti dhammadīpakaṃ.🔽Suññatāpaṭisaññuttanti nibbānapaṭisaññuttaṃ. Atha vā lokuttarasuññatāpaṭisaññuttanti
analyzed: samāpajjitabbānam gambhīranti ninna patiṭṭhānam gūḷhanti dassetum dukkham nipuṇanti  sukhumam paṭicchannam ti padatthena duppaṭivijjhā adhippāyam lokuttaram ti dhamma dīpakam  suñña tā paṭisaññuttanti nibbāna paṭisaññuttan atha vā lokuttara suñña tā paṭisaññuttanti
translated: “Kora-jikora” is “kosa-kosaka,” “very much a concealer,” “kora-caka-kora” is another reading. “Bhākuṭika-bhākuṭika” is “very much a pouter,” “kuhaka-kuhaka” is “very much a deceiver,” “lapaka-lapaka” is “very much a chatterer,” “mukhasambhāvana” is “sambhāvana with one’s own mouth,” “appitacitta” is according to some. “Santāna” is “santāna by continuity of defilements.” “Samāpatti” is “that which should be attained.” “Gambhīra” is “having a deep basis.” “Gūḷha” is “difficult to show.” “Nipuṇa” is “subtle.” “Paṭicchannā” is “having the meaning of ‘covered,’ the intention being ‘difficult to penetrate.’ ” “Lokuttara” is “illuminated by the Dhamma.”

original: lokuttaradhammabhūtanibbānapaṭisaññuttaṃ.
translated: “Suññatāpaṭisaññutta” is “associated with the perception of Nibbāna.” Or alternatively, “suññatāpaṭisaññutta lokuttara” is “associated with the perception of Nibbāna which is the supramundane state.”

original: Kāyikaṃ pāgabbhiyanti kāye bhavaṃ kāyikaṃ. Vācasikacetasikesupi eseva nayo. Acittīkārakatoti🔽bahumānakiriyarahito. Anupāhanānaṃ caṅkamantānanti upāhanavirahitānaṃ caṅkamantānaṃ🔽samīpe, anādare vā sāmivacanaṃ. Saupāhanoti upāhanārūḷho hutvā caṅkamati. Nīce caṅkame🔽caṅkamantānanti akataparicchedāya bhūmiyā caṅkamante paricchedaṃ katvā vālukaṃ ākiritvā
analyzed: kāyikam kāye bhavam kāyikam vācasika cetasikesu pi esa eva nayaḥ a cittīkāraka to ti  bahu māna kiriya rahitaḥ upāhana virahitānam caṅkamantānam  samīpe anādare vā sāmi vacanam saupāhanoti upāhana ārūḍhaḥ hutvā caṅkamati nīce caṅkame  a kata paricchedāya bhūmiyā caṅkamante paricchedam katvā vālukam ākiritvā
translated: “Bodily crookedness” is what is in the body. The same method applies to “verbal crookedness” and “mental crookedness.” “Not paying respect” means not doing honour. “Walking without sandals” means walking without shoes. “In the vicinity” means in the vicinity of those who are walking with sandals. Or the word “vicinity” is used here in the sense of disrespect. “Wearing sandals” means walking with shoes on. “On a low walking-path” means on a walking-path that has not been delimited. Or having delimited the ground, sand has been spread out.

original: ālambanaṃ yojetvā katacaṅkame nīcepi caṅkame caṅkamante. Ucce caṅkame caṅkamatīti🔽iṭṭhakacayanasampanne vedikāparikkhitte ucce caṅkame caṅkamati. Sace pākāraparikkhitto🔽hoti dvārakoṭṭhakayutto, pabbatantaravanantarabhūmantarassa vā suppaṭicchanno, tādise🔽caṅkame caṅkamituṃ vaṭṭati, appaṭicchannepi upacāraṃ muñcitvā vaṭṭati. Ghaṭṭayantopi
analyzed: ālambanam yojetvā kata caṅkame nīce api caṅkame caṅkamante ucce caṅkame caṅkamati iti 🔽iṭṭhaka cayana sampanne vedikā parikkhitte ucce caṅkame caṅkamati sace pākāra parikkhitto 🔽hoti dvāra koṭṭhaka yutto pabbata antara vanantara bhūma antarassa vā su paṭicchanno tādise 🔽caṅkame caṅkamitum vaṭṭati appaṭicchanne api upacāram muñcitvā vaṭṭati ghaṭṭayantaḥ api
translated: “Bodily crookedness” is what is in the body.
