original: Ganthā tassa na vijjantīti tassa khīṇāsavassa dve diṭṭhiganthā sotāpattimaggena na
analyzed: ganthā tassa na vijjanti iti tassa khīṇāsavassa dve diṭṭhi ganthā sotāpatti maggena na
translated: ganthā tassa na vijjantīti tassa khīṇāsavassa dve diṭṭhiganthā sotāpattimaggena na

original: santi. Byāpādo kāyagantho anāgāmimaggena. Abhijjhākāyagantho arahattamaggena.🔽93. Idāni tameva upasantaṃ pasaṃsanto āha “na tassa puttā”ti evamādi. Tattha puttā
analyzed: santi byāpādaḥ kāya ganthaḥ anāgāmi maggena abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ arahatta maggena 🔽idāni tam eva upasantam pasaṃsantaḥ āha na tassa puttā ati evamādi tattha puttā
translated: santi | byāpādo kāyagantho anāgāmimaggena | abhijjhā kāyagantho arahattamag

original: atrajādayo cattāro. Ettha ca puttapariggahādayo puttādināmena vuttāti veditabbā.🔽Te hissa na vijjanti, tesaṃ vā abhāvena puttādayo na vijjantīti. Attāti “attā atthī”ti🔽gahitā sassatadiṭṭhiṃ natthi. Nirattāti “ucchijjatī”ti gahitā ucchedadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: cattāro ettha ca putta pariggaha ādayo putta ādi nāmena vuttā iti veditabbā  te hi ssa na vijjanti tesam vā abhāvena putta ādayaḥ na vijjanti iti attā ati attā atthi iti  gahitā sassata diṭṭhim natthi nirattā ati ucchijjati iti gahitā uccheda diṭṭhi
translated: The four beginning with “not born here” . And here the four beginning with “not having a son” should be understood as stated by the name of the son, etc.,🔽because they do not exist in him or because of the non-existence of those, the son, etc., do not exist. “Self” : the eternalist view that “a self exists” is not. “No self” : the annihilationist view that “it is annihilated” is not.

original: Natthīti gahetabbaṃ natthi. Muñcitabbaṃ natthīti mocetabbaṃ natthi. Yassa natthi🔽gahitanti yassa puggalassa taṇhādiṭṭhivasena gahitaṃ na vijjati. Tassa natthi muñcitabbanti
analyzed: natthi iti gahetabbam natthi muñcitabbam natthi iti mocetabbam natthi yassa natthi  gahitanti yassa puggalassa taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena gahitam na vijjati tassa na atthi muñcitabbanti
translated: “There is nothing to be taken up” : there is nothing to be taken up. “There is nothing to be laid aside” : there is nothing to be laid aside. “There is no one for whom there is nothing to be taken up” :🔽there is no person for whom there is nothing to be taken up by way of craving and views. “There is no one for whom there is nothing to be laid aside” :

original: tassa puggalassa muñcitabbaṃ na vijjati. Gāhamuñcanasamatikkantoti gahaṇañca mocanañca
analyzed: tassa puggalassa muñcitabbam na vijjati gāha muñcana samatikkanto ti gahaṇañca mocanañca
translated: there is no person for whom there is nothing to be laid aside. “He has gone beyond taking up and laying aside” : he has gone beyond taking up and laying aside.

original: vītivatto. Vuddhiparihānivītivattoti vuḍḍhiñca hāniñca atikkanto.
analyzed: vītivattaḥ vuddhi parihāni vītivattaḥ iti vuḍḍhim ca hānim ca atikkantaḥ
translated: “He has gone beyond growth and decline” : he has gone beyond growth and decline.

original: 94. Yena naṃ vajjuṃ puthujjanā, atho samaṇabrāhmaṇāti yena taṃ rāgādinā vajjena puthujjanā
analyzed: yena nam vajjum puthujjanāḥ atho samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati yena tam rāga ādinā vajjena puthujjanāḥ
translated: “By which the worldling and the recluse and the brahmin would blame him” : by which the worldling and the recluse and the brahmin would blame him with the dart of lust, etc.

original: sabbepi devamanussā itova bahiddhā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca rattoti vā duṭṭhoti vā vadeyyuṃ.
analyzed: sabbe api deva manussāḥ itas va bahiddhā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca ratto iti vā duṭṭho ti vā vadeyyuṃ
translated: and all gods and men and recluses and brahmans outside this Dispensation would say of him that he was lustful or hating or deluded.

original: Taṃ tassa apurakkhatanti taṃ rāgādivajjaṃ tassa arahato apurakkhataṃ. Tasmā vādesu
analyzed: tam tassa apurakkhatanti tam rāga ādi vajjam tassa arahataḥ apurakkhatam tasmai vādesu
translated: That fault of his, lust, etc., is not manifest to him. Therefore

original: nejatīti taṃkāraṇā nindāvacanesu na kampati.🔽Nejatīti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Na iñjatīti calanaṃ na karoti. Na calatīti na tattha
analyzed: nejati iti nindā vacanesu na kampati  nejati iti niddesassa uddesa padam na iñjati iti calanam na karoti na calati iti na tattha
translated: he does not waver in the face of censure.🔽“Wavers” is a synonym for “trembles.” “Does not tremble” means he does not shake. “Does not quake” means he does not lean in that direction.

original: namati. Na vedhatīti kampetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya na phandati. Nappavedhatīti na kampati.
analyzed: namati na vedhati iti kampetum a sakkuṇeyyatāya na phandati na pavedhati iti na kampati
translated: “Does not quake with fear” means he does not quiver because he is unable to tremble. “Does not shake with fear” means he does not tremble.

original: Na sampavedhatīti na parivattati.🔽95. Na ussesu vadateti visiṭṭhesu attānaṃ antokatvā “ahaṃ visiṭṭho”ti atimānavasena
analyzed: na sampavedhati iti na parivattati  na ussesu vadata iti visiṭṭhesu attānam antokatvā aham visiṭṭhaḥ iti atimāna vasena
translated: “Does not shake violently” means he does not turn round.🔽“Does not proclaim his own excellence” means he does not, by way of the conceit “I am excellent,” include himself among the excellent. The same method applies to the other two.

original: na vadati. Esa nayo itaresu dvīsu. Kappaṃ neti akappiyoti so evarūpo duvidhampi kappaṃ
analyzed: na vadati itaresu dvīsu kappam neti akappiyaḥ ti saḥ evarūpaḥ duvidham pi kappam
translated: “Does not go by the rule of what should not be done” means he does not go by either of the two rules,

original: na eti. Kasmā? Yasmā akappiyo, pahīnakappoti vuttaṃ hoti. Imissāpi gāthāya niddeso uttānova.
analyzed: na eti kasmai yasmai akappiyaḥ pahīna kappo ti vuttam hoti imissā api gāthāya niddesaḥ uttānaḥ va
translated: because they are not proper for him. What is meant is: he has abandoned the rule. The exposition here is evident.

original: 96. Sakanti mayhanti pariggahitaṃ. Asatā ca na socatīti avijjamānādinā asatā ca na
analyzed: pariggahitam asatā ca na socati iti avijjamāna ādinā asatā ca na
translated: “He is not sad” : he is not sad about what is non-existent, etc.

original: socati. Dhammesu ca na gacchatīti sabbadhammesu chandādivasena na gacchati. Sa ve
analyzed: socati dhammesu ca na gacchati iti sabba dhammesu chanda ādi vasena na gacchati sa ve
translated: “He does not go to the ideas” : he does not go to all ideas by means of will, etc.

original: santoti vuccatīti so evarūpo naruttamo “santo”ti vuccati. Imissāpi gāthāya niddeso🔽uttānova. Arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi. Desanāpariyosāne koṭisatasahassadevatānaṃ
analyzed: santo ti vuccati iti saḥ evarūpaḥ naruttamo santo ti vuccati imissā api gāthāya niddesaḥ  uttānaḥ iva arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi desanā pariyosāne koṭi sata sahassa devatānam
translated: “He is called a man of peace” : such a man is called “a man of peace” . The demonstration of this stanza is the same as that of the previous one.

original: arahattappatti ahosi, sotāpannādīnaṃ gaṇanā natthīti.
analyzed: arahatta patti ahosi sotāpanna ādīnam gaṇanā natthi iti
translated: The Exalted One concluded the teaching with the climax of arahatship. At the conclusion of the teaching, a hundred thousand myriads of deities attained arahatship, and there was no counting the number of stream-enterers, etc.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Great Commentary on the Niddesa, a lamp for the true Dhamma,

original: Purābhedasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽11. Kalahavivādasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽97. Ekādasame kalahavivādasuttaniddese kutopahūtā kalahā vivādāti kalaho ca tassa
analyzed: purābheda sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā           ekādasame kalahavivāda sutta niddese kutopahūtā kalahāḥ kalaho ca tassa
translated: the commentary on the Purābheda Sutta is completed.🔽Commentary on the Kalahavivāda Sutta

original: pubbabhāgo vivādo cāti ime kuto jātā. Paridevasokā sahamaccharā cāti paridevasokā
analyzed: pubba bhāgaḥ vivādaḥ ca ati ime kutas jātā parideva sokā sahamaccharā ca ati parideva sokā
translated: In the eleventh sutta, the Kalahavivāda Sutta, “From where do quarrels and disputes arise?” means: from where do quarrels and disputes arise? “And lamentations, sorrow, and dejection with despair” means: lamentations, sorrow, and dejection

original: ca sahamaccharā ca kuto pahūtā. Mānātimānā sahapesuṇā cāti mānā ca atimānā ca pesuṇā🔽ca kuto pahūtā. Teti te sabbepi aṭṭha kilesadhammā. Tadiṅgha byūhīti taṃ mayā pucchitamatthaṃ
analyzed: ca saha maccharā ca kutas pahūtā māna atimānā saha pesuṇā ca ati mānā ca atimānā ca pesuṇā  ca kutas pahūtā te iti te sabbe api aṭṭha kilesa dhammā tad iṅgha byūhi iti tam mayā pucchitam attham
translated: and envy and stinginess, and pride and haughtiness and slander,🔽from where do they come? “They”: all these eight defilements. “So tell me now”:

original: brūhi, yācāmi taṃ ahanti. Yācanattho hi iṅghāti nipāto.
analyzed: brūhi yācāmi tam aham ti yācana atthaḥ hi iṅghā iti nipātaḥ
translated: tell me the meaning of what I have asked. “I beg of you”: the particle iṅgha has the meaning of “I beg of you.”

original: Ekena ākārenāti ekena kāraṇena. Aparena ākārenāti aparena kāraṇena. Āgārikā daṇḍapasutāti
analyzed: ekena ākārena ati ekena kāraṇena aparena ākārena ati aparena kāraṇena āgārikā daṇḍapasutā ati
translated: “In one way”: for one reason. “In another way”: for another reason. “The householders, with stick and sword,”

original: gahapatino vihesamānā. Pabbajitā āpattiṃ āpajjantāti anagārikā sattasu āpattikkhandhesu
analyzed: gahapatino vihesamānāḥ pabbajitāḥ āpattim āpajjantā ati anagārikā sattasu āpatti khandhesu
translated: are the householders who are harming. “The ascetics, with offense,” are the non-householders who are committing

original: aññataraṃ āpajjamānā.🔽Kutopahūtāti kutobhūtā. Kutojātāti kuto paṭiladdhabhāvā. Kutosañjātāti upasaggena🔽padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ. Kutonibbattāti kuto nibbattalakkhaṇaṃ pattā. Upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: aññataram āpajjamānā  kutas upahūtā ati kutobhūtā kutojātā ati kutas paṭiladdha bhāvā kutosañjātā ati upasaggena  padam vaḍḍhitam kutonibbattā ati kutas nibbatta lakkhaṇam pattā upasaggena padam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: an offense in one of the seven classes of offense.🔽“From where do they come?” means “from where do they originate?” “From where are they born?” means “from where do they get their being?” “From where do they arise?” means🔽the word is extended by the prefix upa. “From where do they come forth?” means “from where do they get the characteristic of being produced?” The word is extended by the prefix upa.

original: “kutoabhinibbattā”ti vuttaṃ. Kutopātubhūtāti kutopākaṭībhūtā. Kiṃ nidānātiādīsu attano
analyzed: kutas abhinibbattā ti vuttam kutas upātubhūtā ati kutas upākaṭībhūtā kim nidānā ati ādīsu attanaḥ
translated: “From where are they produced?” is what is meant. “From where do they become manifest?” means “from where do they become evident?” “What is their source?” and so on:

original: phalaṃ nidetīti nidānaṃ. Etasmā phalaṃ samudetīti samudayo. Etasmā phalaṃ jāyatīti
analyzed: phalam nideti iti nidānam etasmai phalam samudeti iti samudayaḥ etasmai phalam jāyati iti
translated: “It is a source” means it is a source of fruit. “It is a source” means it is a source of fruit. “It is a source” means it is a source of fruit.

original: jāti. Etasmā phalaṃ pabhavatīti pabhavo. Mūlaṃ pucchatīti kalahassa kāraṇaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: etasmai phalam pabhavati iti pabhavaḥ mūlam pucchati iti kalahassa kāraṇam pucchati
translated: “It sets fruit” : it is a nidāna. “From this fruit springs up” : it is a samudaya. “From this fruit is born” : it is a jāti. “From this fruit comes forth” : it is a pabhava. “It asks for a root” : it asks for a cause of dispute.

original: Kāraṇañhi patiṭṭhaṭṭhena mūlaṃ. Attano phalanipphādanatthaṃ hinoti pavattatīti hetu.🔽“Handa naṃ gaṇhathā”ti dassentaṃ viya attano phalaṃ nidetīti nidānaṃ. Etasmā phalaṃ🔽sambhavatīti sambhavo. Pabhavati phalaṃ etasmāti pabhavo. Samuṭṭhāti ettha phalaṃ,🔽etena vā samuṭṭhātīti samuṭṭhānaṃ. Attano phalaṃ āharatīti āhāro. Apaṭikkhipitabbaṭṭhena🔽attano phalaṃ ārametīti ārammaṇaṃ. Etaṃ paṭicca apaṭikkhipitvā phalaṃ eti pavattatīti
analyzed: kāraṇam hi patiṭṭha ṭṭhena mūlam attanaḥ phala nipphādana ttham hinoti pavattati iti hetu  handa nam gaṇhatha ati dassentam viya attanaḥ phalam nideti iti nidānam etasmai phalam  sambhavati iti sambhavaḥ pabhavati phalam etasmā ati pabhavaḥ ettha phalam  etena vā samuṭṭhāti iti samuṭṭhānam attanaḥ phalam āharati iti āhāraḥ a paṭikkhipitabba ṭṭhena  attanaḥ phalam ārameti iti ārammaṇam etam paṭicca a paṭikkhipitvā phalam eti pavattati iti
translated: For a cause is a root in the sense of a foundation. “It descends” : it occurs for the purpose of producing its own fruit.🔽“It sets fruit” : it shows its own fruit as if saying “Come, take it.” “From this fruit springs up” : it is a sambhava. “From this fruit comes forth” : it is a pabhava. “Fruit springs up here” : it is a samudaya.

original: paccayo. Etasmā phalaṃ samudetīti samudayoti evametesaṃ padānaṃ vacanattho veditabbo.
analyzed: paccayaḥ etasmā phalam samudeti iti samudayaḥ ti evam etesam padānam vacana tthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “It occurs” : it is an uppada. “It is taken” : it is a gahaṇa. “It is a cause” : it is a paccaya. “From this fruit springs up” : it is a samudaya. This is how the meaning of the terms should be understood.

original: Taṃ sandhāya “kalahassa ca vivādassa ca mūlaṃ pucchatī”tiādinā nayena desanā vuttā.
analyzed: tam sandhāya kalahassa ca vivādassa ca mūlam pucchati iti ādinā nayena desanā vuttā
translated: The teaching was given in the way beginning, “He asks the root of quarrelling and disputes” with reference to that.

original: 98. Piyappahūtāti piyavatthuto jātā. Maccherayuttā kalahā vivādāti iminā kalahavivādādīnaṃ🔽na kevalaṃ piyavatthumeva, macchariyampi paccayaṃ dasseti. Kalahavivādasīsena cettha🔽sabbepi te dhammā vuttāti veditabbā. Yathā ca etesaṃ macchariyaṃ, tathā pesuṇānañca
analyzed: piya ppahūtā ati piya vatthutaḥ jātā macchera yuttā kalahā vivādā ti iminā kalaha vivāda ādīnam  na kevalam piya vatthum eva macchariyam pi paccayam dasseti kalaha vivāda sīsena ca ittha  sabbe api te dhammā vuttā ati veditabbā yathā ca etesam macchariyam tathā pesuṇānam ca
translated: “Born of what is dear” : arisen from a basis that is dear. “Quarrels and disputes accompanied by stinginess” : by this he shows that stinginess is a condition for quarrels and disputes,🔽and not only a basis that is dear. And in this stanza all those states should be understood as spoken of under the heading of quarrels and disputes.

original: vivādaṃ. Tenāha “vivādajātesu ca pesuṇānī”ti. Imissā gāthāya niddeso uttānatthoyeva.🔽99. Piyā su lokasmiṃ kutonidānā, ye cāpi lobhā vicaranti loketi “piyappahūtā kalahā”ti
analyzed: vivādam tena āha vivāda jātesu ca pesuṇāni iti imissā gāthāya niddesaḥ uttāna atthaḥ yeva  piyā su lokasmim kutonidānā ye ca api lobhāḥ vicaranti loke iti piya pahūtā
translated: And just as stinginess is for these, so too slander is for disputes. Therefore it was said, “And when disputes arise, there is slander” . The commentary to this stanza is clear in meaning.

original: ye ettha vuttā, te piyā lokasmiṃ kutonidānā, na kevalañca piyā, ye cāpi khattiyādayo
analyzed: ye ettha vuttā te piyāḥ lokasmim kutonidānāḥ na kevalam ca piyāḥ ye ca api khattiya ādayo
translated: “What is the source of what is dear in the world? And what are the cravings that wander in the world?” : “Quarrels and disputes born of what is dear” are what is said here. What is the source of what is dear in the world? And not only what is dear, but also those who wander in the world, such as nobles,

original: loke vicaranti lobhahetu lobhenābhibhūtā vicaranti, tesaṃ so lobho ca kutonidānoti
analyzed: loke vicaranti lobha hetu lobhena abhibhūtāḥ vicaranti tesam saḥ lobhaḥ ca kutonidānaḥ ti
translated: wander because of craving, overwhelmed by craving. What is the source of that craving of theirs?

original: dve atthe ekāya pucchāya pucchati. Kutonidānāti cettha kiṃnidānā kiṃhetukāti paccattavacanassa
analyzed: dve atthe ekāya pucchāya pucchati kutonidānā ati ca ittha kiṃnidānā kiṃhetukā ati paccatta vacanassa
translated: He asks about two things with one question. As to “whence their origin,” here the substitution of “to” for “kiṃ” should be understood as a locative of source,

original: toādeso veditabbo, samāse cassa lopābhāvo. Atha vā nidānāti jātā, uppannāti attho.
analyzed: to ādesaḥ veditabbo samāse cassa lopa abhāvaḥ atha vā nidānā ati jātā uppannā ati attho
translated: and the absence of elision in the compound. Or alternatively, “origin” is what is born, arisen.

original: Tasmā kuto jātā kuto uppannāti vuttaṃ hoti. Āsā ca niṭṭhā cāti āsā ca tassā āsāya
analyzed: tasmā kutas jātā kutas uppannā iti vuttam hoti āsā ca niṭṭhā ca ati āsā ca tassā āsāya
translated: So “whence their origin” means “whence their birth, whence their arising.” “Hope and trust” is the hope and the success of that hope.

original: samiddhi ca. Ye samparāyāya narassa hontīti ye narassa samparāyāya honti, parāyanā
analyzed: samidh hi ca ye samparāyāya narassa honti iti ye narassa samparāyāya honti parāyanā
translated: “Which are a man’s” means which are a man’s going beyond, his going to the further shore.

original: hontīti vuttaṃ hoti. Ekā evāyampi pucchā.
analyzed: honti iti vuttam hoti ekā eva ayam pi pucchā
translated: This is one question.

original: Dīpā hontīti patiṭṭhā bhavanti. Saraṇā hontīti dukkhanāsanā honti. Niṭṭhāparāyanā hontīti samiddhiparāyanā honti.
analyzed: dīpāḥ honti iti patiṭṭhāḥ bhavanti saraṇāḥ honti iti dukkha nāsanāḥ honti niṭṭhā parāyanāḥ honti iti samiddhi parāyanāḥ honti
translated: “Which are his lights” means which are his foundations. “Which are his refuge” means which are his destruction of suffering. “Which are his hope and trust” means which are his success and trust.

original: 100. Chandānidānānīti kāmacchandādichandanidānāni. Ye cāpi lobhā vicarantīti ye cāpi
analyzed: chandā nidānāni iti kāmacchanda ādi chanda nidānāni ye ca api lobhāḥ vicaranti iti ye ca api
translated: “Which have desire as their source” : they have sensual desire, etc., as their source. “And all the greed that wanders” : all the greed of nobles, etc., that wanders.

original: khattiyādayo lobhā vicaranti, tesaṃ lobhopi chandanidānoti dvepi atthe ekato vissajjeti.
analyzed: khattiya ādayaḥ lobhāḥ vicaranti tesam lobhaḥ api chanda nidānaḥ ti dve api atthe ekatas vissajjeti
translated: He answers both these things together: “Greed is their source.”

original: Itonidānāti chandanidānā evāti vuttaṃ hoti. “Itonidānā”ti hi chandaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: itonidānā ati chanda nidānā eva ati vuttam hoti itonidānā iti hi chandam sandhāya āha
translated: “From this source”: from the source of desire, is what is meant. For “from this source” refers to desire.🔽For greed, etc., have desire as their source. The grammatical analysis here is “from this source” = ito + nidānaṃ .

original: Chandanidānā hi lobhādayo. “Itonidānā”ti saddasiddhi cettha “kutonidānā”ti ettha
analyzed: chanda nidānāḥ hi lobha ādayaḥ itonidānāḥ ati ca ittha kutonidānā ati ettha
translated: “From where is their source?” = kuto + nidānaṃ .🔽“Fulfilment” is said to be “hope” = niṭṭhā = ajjhāsayanibbattipaṭilābho .

original: vuttanayena veditabbā. Āsāya samiddhi vuccati niṭṭhāti ajjhāsayanibbattipaṭilābho kathīyati.
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbā āsāya samiddhi vuccati niṭṭhāti ajjhāsaya nibbatti paṭilābho kathīyati
translated: “Decision” = taṇhādiṭṭhivinicchaya .

original: 101. Vinicchayāti taṇhādiṭṭhivinicchayā. Ye cāpi dhammā samaṇena vuttāti ye ca aññepi kodhādīhi sampayuttā, tathārūpā vā akusalā dhammā buddhasamaṇena vuttā, te kutopahūtāti.
analyzed: vinicchayā ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vinicchayā ye ca api dhammā samaṇena vuttā ati ye ca aññe pi kodha ādīhi sampayuttā tathārūpāḥ vā akusalā dhammā buddha samaṇena vuttā te kutas upahūtā ati
translated: “And also those things that are called by the ascetic” = those other unwholesome things that are associated with anger, etc., or that are similar to them, and that are called by the ascetic the Buddha, are called “from where is their source?”🔽“Of another kind” = of a different nature.🔽“Of another description” = existing in another way.

original: Aññajātikāti aññasabhāvā. Aññavihitakāti aññenākārena ṭhitā. Samitapāpenāti nibbāpitapāpena.🔽Bāhitapāpadhammenāti pahīnalāmakadhammena. Bhinnakilesamūlenāti kilesamūlāni bhinditvā
analyzed: añña jātikā ati añña sabhāvā añña vihitakā ati aññena ākārena ṭhitā samita pāpena ati nibbāpita pāpena  bāhita pāpa dhammena ati pahīna lāmaka dhammena bhinna kilesa mūlena ati kilesa mūlāni bhinditvā
translated: “With evil destroyed” = with evil extinguished.🔽“With evil states expelled” = with evil and corruption expelled.🔽“With the root of all unwholesome states cut off” = having stood by cutting off the roots of the defilements.

original: ṭhitena. Sabbākusalamūlabandhanā pamuttenāti dvādasaakusalabandhanaṃ mocetvā ṭhitena.
analyzed: ṭhitena sabba akusala mūla bandhanā pamuttena ati dvādasa akusala bandhanam mocetvā ṭhitena
translated: “Freed from all bondage of unwholesome roots” = having stood by freeing oneself from the twelve unwholesome bonds.

original: Vuttāti kathitā. Pavuttāti pakārena kathitā.
analyzed: vuttā iti kathitā pavuttā ati pakārena kathitā
translated: “Said” : spoken. “Uttered” : spoken by way of utterance.

original: 102. Tamūpanissāya pahoti chandoti taṃ sukhadukkhavedanaṃ tadubhayavatthusaṅkhātaṃ🔽sātāsātaṃ upanissāya saṃyogaviyogapatthanāvasena chando pahoti. Ettāvatā “chando
analyzed: tam ūpanissāya pahoti chandaḥ ti tam sukha dukkha vedanam tad ubhaya vatthu saṅkhātam  sāta asātam upanissāya saṃyoga viyoga patthanā vasena chando pahoti ettāvatā chando
translated: “Desire arises in dependence on that” : in dependence on that pleasant and painful feeling, which is called the basis of both,

original: nu lokasmiṃ kutonidāno”ti ayaṃ pañho vissajjito hoti. Rūpesu disvā vibhavaṃ bhavañcāti🔽rūpesu vayañca uppādañca disvā. Vinicchayaṃ kubbati jantu loketi apāyādike loke ayaṃ
analyzed: nu lokasmim kutonidānaḥ ti ayam pañho vissajjitaḥ hoti rūpesu disvā vibhavam bhavañca ati  rūpesu vayam ca uppādam ca disvā vinicchayam kubbati loka iti apāya ādike loke ayam
translated: desire arises in the form of the wish for union with the pleasant and separation from the painful. So far the question, “What is the source of desire in the world?” is answered.🔽“Having seen the rise and fall of forms” : having seen the rise and fall of forms.

original: jantu bhogādhigamatthaṃ taṇhāvinicchayaṃ “attā me uppanno”tiādinā nayena diṭṭhivinicchayañca
analyzed: jantu bhoga adhigama attham taṇhā vinicchayam attā me uppannaḥ iti ādinā nayena diṭṭhi vinicchayam ca
translated: “The being makes his choice in the world” : in the world of the planes of misery, etc., this being makes the choice of craving for the purpose of obtaining wealth, and the choice of views, thinking “I have arisen.”

original: kurute. Ettāvatā “vinicchayā cāpi kutopabhūtā”ti ayaṃ pañho vissajjito hoti.
analyzed: kurute ettāvatā vinicchayā ca api ayam pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti
translated: So far the question, “And from what source does choice arise?” is answered.

original: Sātāsātaṃ nissāyāti madhurañca amadhurañca upanissayaṃ katvā. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhanti iṭṭhārammaṇañca aniṭṭhārammaṇañca.
analyzed: sāta asātam nissāya ati madhuram ca a madhuram ca upanissayam katvā iṭṭha aniṭṭhanti iṭṭha ārammaṇañca aniṭṭha ārammaṇañca
translated: “In dependence on the pleasant and painful” : having made the sweet and the sour a basis. “The desirable and the undesirable” : the desirable object and the undesirable object.

original: Surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyoganti ettha surāti piṭṭhasurā pūvasurā odanasurā🔽kiṇṇapakkhittā sambhārasaṃyuttāti pañca surā. Merayanti pupphāsavo phalāsavo madhvāsavo🔽guḷāsavo sambhārasaṃyuttoti pañca āsavā. Taṃ sabbampi madakaraṇavasena majjaṃ. Pamādaṭṭhānanti🔽pamādakāraṇaṃ, yāya cetanāya taṃ majjaṃ pivati, tassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Anuyoganti
analyzed: ettha surā ti piṭṭha surā pūva surā odana surā  kiṇṇa pakkhittā sambhāra saṃyuttā ati pañca surāḥ merayanti pupphāsavaḥ phalāsavaḥ madhvāsavaḥ  guḷāsavo sambhāra saṃyutto ti pañca āsavā tam sabbam pi mada karaṇa vasena majjam pamāda ṭṭhānam ti  pamāda kāraṇam yāya cetanāya tam majjam pivati tassa itam adhivacanam
translated: “The pursuit of the practice of storing up of intoxicants consisting in wines, liquors, ebriets”: here “wines” are the five kinds of wines made from honey, from molasses, from fermented marine products, from fermented animal urine, and from fermented fruit juice. “Liquors” are the five kinds of liquors made from rice, from flour, from molasses, from honey, and from fermented tree sap. “Ebriets” are all those that intoxicate by their intoxicating power. “The practice of storing up” is the cause of negligence. This is a designation for the volition by means of which one drinks that intoxicant. “The pursuit” is the pursuit of the practice of storing up of intoxicants consisting in wines, liquors, and ebriets.

original: taṃ surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuāyogaṃ punappunaṃ karaṇaṃ. Yasmā ca pana🔽taṃ anuyuttassa me uppannā ceva bhogā parihāyanti, anuppannā ca nuppajjanti, tasmā
analyzed: tam surā meraya majja ppamāda ṭṭhāna anuyogam anuāyogam punappunam karaṇam yasmai ca pana  tam anuyuttassa me uppannā ca iva bhogāḥ parihāyanti anuppannā ca na uppajjanti tasmā
translated: “Pursuit of the practice of storing up of intoxicants that are a basis for heedlessness”: here, “intoxicants” are the five kinds of intoxicants, namely, the “back-house” intoxicant, the “front-house” intoxicant, the “house-corner” intoxicant, the “friend” intoxicant, and the “friend’s friend” intoxicant. “Store” is the five kinds of stores, namely, the store of roots, the store of stalks, the store of flowers, the store of fruits, and the store of miscellaneous articles. “Intoxicants” are the five kinds of intoxicants, namely, the intoxicant of flowers, the intoxicant of fruits, the intoxicant of honey, the intoxicant of molasses, and the intoxicant of miscellaneous articles. All these are “intoxicants” in the sense of causing intoxication. “Basis for heedlessness” is the cause for heedlessness. This is a designation for the volition by means of which one drinks that intoxicant. “Pursuit” is the repeated performance of that pursuit of the practice of storing up of intoxicants that are a basis for heedlessness. And because one who is devoted to that practice loses the wealth that has arisen and does not acquire that which has not yet arisen,

original: “me bhogā parikkhayaṃ khīṇabhāvaṃ gacchantī”ti jānāti. Evaṃ sabbattha. Vikālavisikhācariyānuyoganti
analyzed: me bhogāḥ parikkhayam khīṇa bhāvam gacchanti iti jānāti evam sabbattha
translated: one knows: “My wealth is going to destruction, to loss.” So in all cases. “Pursuit of the practice of wandering about at night and frequenting evil” :

original: avelāya visikhāsu cariyānuyuttaṃ. Samajjābhicaraṇanti naccādidassanavasena samajjābhigamanaṃ.🔽Ālasyānuyoganti kāyālasiyatāya yuttappayuttataṃ. Apāyamukhāni na sevatīti bhogānaṃ
analyzed: avelāya visikhāsu cariyā anuyuttam sa majjābhicaraṇam ti nacca ādi dassana vasena sa majjābhigamanam  apāya mukhāni na sevati iti
translated: He is devoted to walking up and down at unfitting times. He frequents fairs means he goes to fairs in order to see dancing, etc.

original: vināsadvārāni na sevati.
analyzed: vināsa dvārāni na sevati
translated: He is devoted to indolence means he is devoted to the indolence of bodily work. He does not frequent places of ill repute means he does not frequent the places that are the doors to the destruction of his wealth.

original: Kasiyā vāti kasikammena vā. Vaṇijjāya vāti dhammikavaṇijjakammena vā. Gorakkhena🔽vāti gopālakammena vā. Issatthena vāti dhanusippena vā. Rājaporisena vāti rājasevakakammena
analyzed: kasiyā vā ati kasi kammena vā vaṇijjāya vā ati dhammika vaṇijja kammena vā gorakkhena  vāti gopāla kammena vā issatthena vāti dhanu sippena vā rāja porisena vāti rāja sevaka kammena
translated: By farming means by farming work. By trade means by such work as trading in accordance with the Dhamma.🔽By cattle raising means by tending cattle. By archery means by the craft of the archer. By service to the king means by work as a servant to the king.

original: vā. Sippaññatarena vāti kumbhakārādisippānaṃ aññatarena vā. Paṭipajjatīti payogaṃ🔽karoti. Cakkhusmiṃ uppanne jānātīti sasambhāracakkhusmiṃ uppanne jānāti. “Attā me
analyzed: vā sippa aññatarena vā ati kumbhakāra ādi sippānam aññatarena vā paṭipajjati iti payogam  karoti cakkhusmiṃ uppanne jānāti iti sa sambhāra cakkhusmiṃ uppanne jānāti attā me
translated: By a craft means by one of the crafts such as pottery, etc. He engages in means he makes an effort.🔽When the eye arises he knows means he knows when the eye with its associated phenomena arises. He assumes the view: “The self arises for me.” When the eye is destroyed he assumes the view:

original: uppanno”ti diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Cakkhusmiṃ antarahiteti tasmiṃ vinaṭṭhe. Attā me antarahitoti
analyzed: uppannaḥ ti diṭṭhim gaṇhāti cakkhusmiṃ antarahitā iti tasmin vinaṭṭhe attā me antarahitā ti
translated: “The self is destroyed for me.”

original: “mama attā vinaṭṭho”ti diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Vigato me attāti vītikkanto mama attā. Sotasmintiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: mama attā vinaṭṭhaḥ iti diṭṭhim gaṇhāti vigataḥ me attā ati vītikkantaḥ mama attā sotasmin ti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: He takes the view that his self is destroyed. ‘My self has passed beyond’: my self has gone beyond. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the ear, etc.

original: 103. Etepi dhammā dvayameva santeti ete kodhādayo dhammā sātāsātadvaye sante eva🔽honti uppajjanti. Ettāvatā tatiyapañhopi vissajjito hoti. Idāni yo evaṃ vissajjitesu🔽etesu pañhesu kathaṃkathī bhaveyya, tassa kathaṃkathāpahānūpāyaṃ dassento āha “kathaṃkathī
analyzed: ete api dhammā dvayam eva santa iti ete kodha ādayaḥ dhammā sāta asāta dvaye sante eva  honti uppajjanti ettāvatā tatiya pañhaḥ api vissajjitaḥ hoti idāni yaḥ evam vissajjitesu  etesu pañhesu kathaṃkathī bhaveyya tassa kathaṃkathā apahāna upāyam dassentaḥ āha kathaṃkathī
translated: These things occur only when there is a duality: these things, anger, etc., occur only when there is a duality of pleasant and unpleasant.

original: ñāṇapathāya sikkhe”ti, ñāṇadassanañāṇādhigamanatthaṃ tisso sikkhā sikkheyyāti vuttaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa pathāya sikkhā iti ñāṇa dassana ñāṇa adhigamana attham tissaḥ sikkhā sikkheyya iti vuttam
translated: So far the third question has been answered. Now, the Exalted One shows the way to abandon the doubt of one who would be doubtful about the answers given thus: “Train for direct knowledge of the way of doubt” . He should train in the three trainings for the purpose of attaining the knowledge of insight and direct knowledge.

original: hoti. Kiṃkāraṇā? Ñatvā pavuttā samaṇena dhammā. Buddhasamaṇena hi ñatvā dhammā vuttā,
analyzed: hoti kiṃkāraṇā ñatvā pavuttā samaṇena dhammā buddha samaṇena hi ñatvā dhammā vuttā
translated: Why? Because the states proclaimed by the recluse are proclaimed by one who knows. The states proclaimed by the recluse are proclaimed by the recluse who is the Buddha.

original: natthi tassa dhammesu aññāṇaṃ, attano pana ñāṇānubhāvena te ajānanto na jāneyya,
analyzed: natthi tassa dhammesu aññāṇam attanaḥ pana ñāṇa anubhāvena te a jānantaḥ na jāneyya
translated: There is no ignorance of those states on his part. But if he did not know them by the power of his own knowledge, he would not know them.

original: na desanādosena. Tasmā kathaṃkathī ñāṇapathāya sikkhe, ñatvā pavuttā samaṇena dhammāti.🔽Pakkhepabandhanena vā baddhoti nāgarikabandhena baddho. Parikkhepabandhanena vāti🔽vatiparikkhepabandhanena vā. Gāmabandhanenātiādīsu tasmā tasmā ṭhānato nikkhamituṃ🔽alabhanto gāmabandhanādīhi baddho nāma hoti. Tassa bandhanassa mokkhatthāyāti etassa
analyzed: na desanā dosena tasmai kathaṃkathī ñāṇa pathāya sikkhe ñatvā pavuttā samaṇena dhammā ti  pakkhepa bandhanena vā baddho ti nāgarika bandhena baddho parikkhepa bandhanena vā ati  vati parikkhepa bandhanena vā gāma bandhanena ati ādīsu tasmā tasmā ṭhānataḥ nikkhamitum  a labhantaḥ gāma bandhana ādīhi baddhaḥ nāma hoti tassa bandhanassa mokkha tthāya ati etassa
translated: not by the fault of the teaching. So: “Inquire, be a questioner of what is heard; having known, the recluse will speak the Dhamma.”

original: vuttappakārassa bandhanassa mocanatthaṃ.🔽Ñāṇampi ñāṇapathoti pure uppannaṃ ñāṇaṃ aparāparuppannassa ñāṇampi ñāṇassa sañcaraṇamaggoti🔽ñāṇampi ñāṇapatho. Ñāṇassa ārammaṇampi ñāṇapathoti ñāṇassa paccayopi taṃ ālambitvā
analyzed: vutta ppakārassa bandhanassa mocana attham  ñāṇam pi ñāṇa patho ti pure uppannam ñāṇam apara apara uppannassa ñāṇam pi ñāṇassa sañcaraṇa maggo ti  ñāṇam pi ñāṇa pathaḥ ñāṇassa ārammaṇam pi ñāṇa pathaḥ ti ñāṇassa paccayaḥ pi tam ālambitvā
translated: “Bound by the bond of the village” means bound by the bond of the town. “Bound by the bond of the field” means bound by the bond of the field. “Bound by the bond of the house” means bound by the bond of the house. “Bound by the bond of the family” means bound by the bond of the family. “Bound by the bond of the village, etc.,” means that one who is unable to leave a particular place is said to be bound by the bond of the village, etc. “For the sake of release from that bond” means for the sake of the release of that kind of bond.🔽“Knowledge is the path of knowledge” means that knowledge arisen previously is also the path of knowledge for the knowledge that arises later and later.🔽“Knowledge is the path of knowledge” also means that the object of knowledge is the path of knowledge because it arises by taking that as its object.

original: uppajjanato ñāṇapatho. Ñāṇasahabhunopi dhammā ñāṇapathoti ñāṇena sahuppannā avasesā
analyzed: uppajjanataḥ ñāṇa pathaḥ ñāṇa sahabhunaḥ api dhammāḥ ñāṇa pathaḥ ti ñāṇena sahuppannāḥ avasesā
translated: “The states associated with knowledge are the path of knowledge” means that the remaining states that arise together with knowledge are the path of knowledge.

original: cittacetasikā dhammāpi ñāṇapatho. Idāni upamāya sādhento “yathā ariyamaggo ariyapatho”tiādimāha.🔽Kathaṃkathī puggaloti vicikicchāvanto puggalo. Sakaṅkhoti sadveḷhako. Savilekhoti🔽cittarājivanto. Sadveḷhakoti kaṅkhāvanto. Savicikicchoti sandehavanto. Ñāṇādhigamāyāti
analyzed: citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ api ñāṇa pathaḥ idāni upamāya sādhentaḥ yathā ariya maggaḥ ariya pathaḥ ti ādim āha  kathaṃkathī puggalo ti vicikicchāvanto puggalo sa kaṅkho ti sa dveḷhakaḥ sa vilekho ti  citta rājivantaḥ sa dveḷhakaḥ uti kaṅkhāvantaḥ sa vicikiccho ti sandehavantaḥ ñāṇa adhigamāya ati
translated: and the mental states of consciousness and its concomitants are the path of knowledge. Now, in order to prove this by means of a simile, he says “Just as the Noble Path is the Noble Path of Purification.”

original: ñāṇapaṭilābhatthāya. Ñāṇaphusanāyāti ñāṇapaṭivijjhanatthāya. Atha vā ñāṇavindanatthāya.🔽Ñāṇasacchikiriyāyāti ñāṇassa paccakkhakaraṇatthāya. Sanidānāhanti ahaṃ sanidānaṃ🔽sapaccayaṃ katvā dhammadesanaṃ karomi. Sappāṭihāriyanti niyyānikaṃ katvā. No appāṭihāriyanti
analyzed: ñāṇa paṭilābha tthāya ñāṇa phusanāya ati ñāṇa paṭivijjhana tthāya atha vā ñāṇa vindana tthāya  ñāṇa sacchikiriyāya ati ñāṇassa paccakkha karaṇa atthāya sa nidānā aham ti aham sa nidānam  sa paccayam katvā dhamma desanam karomi sa pāṭihāriyanti niyyānikam katvā no appāṭihāriyanti
translated: One who is doubtful is one who has doubts. One who is anxious is one who is timid. One who is suspicious is one who is defiled in mind. One who is timid is one who is anxious. One who has doubts is one who is undecided. For the attainment of knowledge means for the purpose of obtaining knowledge. For the realization of knowledge means for the purpose of penetrating knowledge. Or else, for the purpose of finding knowledge.

original: aniyyānikaṃ akatvā dhammadesanaṃ karomi.
analyzed: aniyyānikam a katvā dhamma desanam karomi
translated: For the realization of knowledge by direct experience means for the purpose of making knowledge evident. With its cause means I teach the Dhamma having made the cause clear. With its outcome means having made the outcome clear. Without its cause means I teach the Dhamma without having made the cause clear. Without its outcome means without having made the outcome clear.

original: 104. Sātaṃ asātañca kutonidānāti ettha sātāsātanti sukhadukkhavedanā eva adhippetā.
analyzed: sātam asātam ca kutonidānā ti ettha sāta asātam ti sukha dukkha vedanā eva adhippetā
translated: Pleasant and painful means only the feelings of pleasure and pain are intended here.

original: Na bhavanti heteti na bhavanti ete. Vibhavaṃ bhavañcāpi yametamatthaṃ, etaṃ me pabrūhi
analyzed: na bhavanti hetā iti na bhavanti ete vibhavam bhavan ca api yam etam attham etam me pabrūhi
translated: “They do not exist” means “they do not exist.”🔽“The non-existence of existence and non-existence,”🔽please explain this to me.

original: yatonidānanti sātāsātānaṃ vibhavaṃ bhavañca etampi yaṃ atthaṃ. Liṅgabyattayo ettha
analyzed: vibhavam bhavan ca etam pi yam attham liṅga byattayaḥ ettha
translated: “They do not exist” : they do not exist. “The non-existence and existence of this” : the non-existence and existence of this matter. “The source of which” : the source of this matter, namely, the non-existence and existence of the agreeable and disagreeable. Here the feminine gender is used in the words “bhavassa” and “vibhavo” .

original: kato. Idaṃ pana vuttaṃ hoti – sātāsātānaṃ vibhavo bhavo cāti yo esa attho, etaṃ me🔽pabrūhi yatonidānanti. Ettha ca sātāsātānaṃ vibhavabhavavatthukā vibhavabhavadiṭṭhiyo🔽eva vibhavabhavāti atthato veditabbā. Tathā hi imassa pañhassa vissajjanapakkhe “bhavadiṭṭhipi
analyzed: kataḥ idam pana vuttam hoti sāta asātānam vibhavaḥ bhavaḥ ca ati yaḥ esa atthaḥ etam me  pabrūhi yatonidānam ti ettha ca vibhava bhava vatthukāḥ vibhava bhava diṭṭhiyaḥ  eva vibhava bhavā ti atthataḥ veditabbā tathā hi imassa pañhassa vissajjana pakkhe
translated: This is what is meant: “The non-existence and existence of the agreeable and disagreeable—the source of which?”

original: phassanidānā, vibhavadiṭṭhipi phassanidānā”ti upari niddese vakkhati. Imāya gāthāya🔽niddese vattabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: phassa nidānā phassa nidānā ti upari niddese vakkhati imāya gāthāya  niddese vattabbam na atthi
translated: Here the views of non-existence and existence that have as their object the basis for the non-existence and existence of the agreeable and disagreeable should be understood as “the non-existence and existence” . For in the answer to this question, the Exalted One will say: “The view of existence has contact as its source, and the view of non-existence has contact as its source” . In this stanza there is nothing to be explained.

original: 105. Itonidānanti phassanidānaṃ. Imāyapi vattabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: itonidānam ti phassa nidānam imāya api vattabbam na atthi
translated: “The source of which” : the source of which is contact. In this stanza there is nothing to be explained.

original: 106. Kismiṃ vibhūte na phusanti phassāti kismiṃ vītivatte cakkhusamphassādayo pañca phassā na phusanti. Imāyapi vattabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: kismin vibhūte na phusanti phassā ati kismin vītivatte cakkhu samphassa ādayo pañca phassā na phusanti vattabbam natthi
translated: When what is destroyed, do the five kinds of contact not contact? When what has ceased do the five kinds of contact beginning with eye-contact not contact? There is nothing to be said here.

original: 107. Nāmañca rūpañca paṭiccāti sampayuttakanāmañca vatthārammaṇarūpañca paṭicca. Rūpe vibhūte na phusanti phassāti rūpe vītivatte pañca phassā na phusanti.
analyzed: nāmañca rūpañca paṭicca ati sampayuttaka nāmañca vattha ārammaṇa rūpañca paṭicca rūpe vibhūte na phusanti phassa ati rūpe vītivatte pañca phassāḥ na phusanti
translated: With name-and-form as condition: with associated name and with the form of the physical basis as object. When form is destroyed, do the five kinds of contact not contact? When form has ceased, the five kinds of contact do not contact.

original: Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phassoti cakkhurūpaviññāṇānaṃ tiṇṇannaṃ saṅgatiyā phasso jāyati. Cakkhu
analyzed: tiṇṇam saṅgati phasso ti cakkhu rūpa viññāṇānam tiṇṇannam saṅgatiyā phasso jāyati cakkhu
translated: The meeting of three is contact: contact arises with the meeting of the three, that is, eye, visible form, and consciousness.

original: ca rūpā ca rūpasminti pasādacakkhuñca rūpārammaṇāni ca rūpabhāge rūpakoṭṭhāse katvā.
analyzed: ca rūpā ca rūpasmin ti pasāda cakkhuñca rūpa ārammaṇāni ca rūpa bhāge rūpa koṭṭhāse katvā
translated: Eye and visible form in the field of form: the sensitive matter of the eye and the visible-form objects.

original: Cakkhusamphassaṃ ṭhapetvāti tiṇṇaṃ saṅgatiyā uppannaphassaṃ muñcitvā. Sampayuttakā
analyzed: cakkhu samphassam ṭhapetvā tiṇṇam saṅgatiyā uppanna phassam muñcitvā sampayuttakā
translated: Except for eye-contact: omitting the contact that arises with the meeting of the three. Associated states🔽are in the field of name: the remaining states associated with contact, that is, feeling, etc., are in the field of name.

original: dhammā nāmasminti avasesā vedanādayo phassena sahajātā dhammā nāmabhāge. Sotañca
analyzed: dhammā nāmasmin ti avasesāḥ vedanā ādayo phassena sahajātāḥ dhammāḥ nāma bhāge sotam ca
translated: With ear and sound as condition …

original: paṭiccātiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: paṭicca ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the case of the ear, etc.

original: Catūhākārehi rūpaṃ vibhūtaṃ hotīti catūhi kāraṇehi rūpaṃ vītivattaṃ hoti. Ñātavibhūtenāti🔽pākaṭaṃ katvā vītivattena. Tīraṇavibhūtenāti aniccādito tīrayitvā vītivattena. Pahānavibhūtenāti
analyzed: catūha ākārehi rūpam vibhūtam hoti iti catūhi kāraṇehi rūpam vītivattam hoti ñāta vibhūtena ati  pākaṭam katvā vītivattena tīraṇa vibhūtena ati anicca āditas tīrayitvā vītivattena pahāna vibhūtena ati
translated: “By four modes form is abandoned”: by four reasons form is gone beyond. “By abandonment through knowing”: by making it evident and going beyond. “By abandonment through surmounting”: by going beyond by surmounting the four formless attainments.

original: chandarāgapahānato vītivattena. Samatikkamavibhūtenāti catunnaṃ arūpasamāpattīnaṃ🔽paṭilābhavasena vītivattena.
analyzed: chanda rāga apahānataḥ vītivattena samatikkama vibhūtena ati catunnam arūpa samāpattīnam  paṭilābha vasena
translated: “By abandonment through crossing over”: by going beyond by obtaining the crossing over of the four paths.

original: 108. Kathaṃ sametassāti kathaṃ paṭipannassa. Vibhoti rūpanti rūpaṃ vibhavati, na bhaveyya vā. Sukhaṃ dukhañcāti iṭṭhāniṭṭharūpameva pucchati.
analyzed: katham sametassa ati katham paṭipannassa vibhoti rūpam iti rūpam vibhavati na bhaveyya vā sukham dukham ca ati iṭṭha aniṭṭha rūpam eva pucchati
translated: “How does it come to be abandoned for one who is practicing rightly?” How does it come to be abandoned for one who is practicing rightly? “Form is abandoned”: form is abandoned, does not exist. “Pleasure and pain”: he asks about desirable and undesirable form.

original: Jāneyyāmāti jānissāma. Ājāneyyāmāti visesena jānissāma. Vijāneyyāmāti anekavidhena jānissāma. Paṭivijāneyyāmāti sammā jānissāma. Paṭivijjheyyāmāti cittena bujjhissāma.
analyzed: jāneyyāma ati jānissāma ājāneyyāma ati visesena jānissāma vijāneyyāma ati anekavidhena jānissāma paṭivijāneyyāma ati sammā jānissāma paṭivijjheyyāma ati cittena bujjhissāma
translated: “I would know”: we would know. “I would understand”: we would understand in particular. “I would fully understand”: we would understand in many ways. “I would penetrate”: we would fully understand. “I would experience”: we would experience with the mind.

original: 109. Na saññasaññīti yathā sametassa vibhoti rūpaṃ, so pakatisaññāya saññīpi na hoti.
analyzed: na sañña saññī iti yathā sametassa vibhoti rūpam so pakati saññāya na hoti
translated: “Not perceiving any percept”: as form is abandoned for one who is practicing rightly, he is not perceiving any percept in the usual sense.

original: Na visaññasaññīti visaññāyapi virūpāya saññāya visaññī na hoti ummattako vā khittacitto
analyzed: na visañña saññī iti virūpāya saññāya visaññī na hoti ummattakaḥ vā khitta cittaḥ
translated: He is not one who has perception of non-perception, that is, he is not one who has perception of the non-perception of the repulsive, and he is not one who is insane or mentally deranged.🔽Nor is he one without perception, that is, he is not one who has entered upon the attainment of cessation, nor is he an immaterial-sphere being devoid of perception.

original: vā. Nopi asaññīti saññāvirahitopi na hoti nirodhasamāpanno vā asaññasatto vā. Na
analyzed: vā no upi asaññī iti saññā virahitaḥ api na hoti nirodha samāpannaḥ vā asañña sattaḥ vā na
translated: Nor is he one who has perception of the percipient, that is, he is not one who has perception of the percipient as immaterial-sphere beings, and he is not one who has perception of the percipient as the immaterial-sphere jhānas.

original: vibhūtasaññīti “sabbaso rūpasaññāna”ntiādinā nayena samatikkantasaññīpi na hoti arūpajjhānalābhī.🔽Evaṃ sametassa vibhoti rūpanti etasmiṃ saññasaññitādibhāve aṭṭhatvā yadetaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: vibhūta saññī iti sabbasas rūpa saññā nanti ādinā nayena na hoti arūpa jjhāna lābhī  evam sametassa vibho ti etasmin sañña saññi tā ādi bhāve etasmin sañña saññi tā ādi bhāve vuttam
translated: Nor is he one who has perception of the non-percipient, that is, he is not one who has perception of the non-percipient as beings in the non-percipient realm, and he is not one who has perception of the non-percipient as the attainment of cessation.

original: “so evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya cittaṃ abhinīharatī”ti,🔽evaṃ sametassa arūpamaggasamaṅgino vibhoti rūpaṃ. Saññānidānā hi papañcasaṅkhāti
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citta īpe ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpatti paṭilābha atthāya cittam abhinīharati iti  evam sametassa arūpa magga samaṅginaḥ vibho ti rūpam saññā nidānā hi papañca saṅkhāti
translated: Nor is he one who has perception of the percipient and non-percipient, that is, he is not one who has perception of the percipient and non-percipient as the immaterial-sphere beings and beings in the non-percipient realm, and he is not one who has perception of the percipient and non-percipient as the immaterial-sphere jhānas and the attainment of cessation.🔽Nor is he one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient, that is, he is not one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient realm, and he is not one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the attainment of the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient Jhāna.🔽Nor is he one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient realm, and he is not one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the attainment of the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient Jhāna.

original: evaṃ paṭipannassāpi ca yā saññā, taṃnidānā taṇhādiṭṭhipapañcāssa appahīnāva hontīti dasseti.
analyzed: evam paṭipannassa api ca yā saññā taṃnidānā taṇhā diṭṭhi papañcā assa appahīnā ava honti iti dasseti
translated: Nor is he one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient realm, and he is not one who has perception of the neither percipient nor non-percipient as the attainment of the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient Jhāna.🔽Nor

original: Asaññino vuccanti nirodhasamāpannāti saññāvedanā nirodhetvā nirodhasamāpannā saññābhāvena asaññinoti kathīyanti. Asaññasattāti sabbena sabbaṃ saññābhāvena asaññabhave nibbattā.🔽So evaṃ samāhite citteti tattha soti so bhikkhu. Evanti catutthajjhānakkamanidassanametaṃ,
analyzed: asaññinaḥ vuccanti nirodha samāpannā ti saññā vedanā nirodhetvā nirodha samāpannā saññā bhāvena asaññinaḥ iti kathīyanti asañña sattā ati sabbena sabbam saññā bhāvena asañña bhave nibbattā  saḥ evam samāhite citte iti tattha saḥ ti saḥ bhikkhu evam ti catuttha jjhāna kkama nidassanam etam
translated: “The non-percipient” : those who have attained cessation are called “non-percipient” because they have ceased perception and feeling. “The beings called non-percipient” : those who have been reborn in the plane of non-percipient beings by the complete absence of perception.🔽“With his mind thus concentrated”: here “thus” indicates the attainment of the fourth jhāna.

original: iminā kamena catutthajjhānaṃ paṭilabhitvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Samāhiteti iminā catutthajjhānasamādhinā
analyzed: iminā kamena catuttha jhānam paṭilabhitvā iti vuttam hoti samāhita iti iminā catuttha jhāna samādhinā
translated: “With his mind thus concentrated” means with his mind concentrated by means of the fourth jhāna.

original: samāhite. Parisuddhetiādīsu pana upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvena parisuddhe. Parisuddhattāyeva
analyzed: samāhite parisuddha iti ādīsu pana upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvena parisuddhe parisuddha ttāya iva
translated: “Pure” : purified by the purification of equanimity and mindfulness.🔽“Bright” : by virtue of that very purity, it is said to be bright and radiant.

original: pariyodāte, pabhassareti vuttaṃ hoti. Sukhādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ ghātena vihatarāgādiaṅgaṇattā
analyzed: pariyodāte pabhassarā iti vuttam hoti sukha ādīnam paccayānam ghātena vihata rāga ādi aṅgaṇa ttā
translated: “Without blemish” : because the factors of the fourth jhāna, such as pleasure, etc., have destroyed the blemishes of lust, etc.🔽“Without defilement” : by virtue of the absence of blemishes,

original: anaṅgaṇe. Anaṅgaṇattā eva ca vigatūpakkilese. Aṅgaṇena hi cittaṃ upakkilissati. Subhāvitattā
analyzed: an aṅgaṇe an aṅgaṇa ttā eva ca vigata upakkilese aṅgaṇena hi cittam upakkilissati su bhāvita ttā
translated: the mind is without defilement. For the mind is defiled by blemishes.

original: mudubhūte, vasībhāvappatteti vuttaṃ hoti. Vase vattamānañhi cittaṃ mudūti vuccati.🔽Muduttāyeva ca kammaniye, kammakkhame kammayoggeti vuttaṃ hoti. Mudu hi cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ
analyzed: mudu bhūte vasībhāva ppattā iti vuttam hoti vase vattamānañ hi cittam mudu iti vuccati  ca kammaniye kamma kkhame kamma yogge iti vuttam hoti mudu hi cittam kammaniyam
translated: “malleable” means “having become wieldy.” For the mind that is wieldy is called “malleable.”🔽And because it is malleable, it is “workable,” “fit for work,” “capable of being worked.” For a malleable mind is workable,

original: hoti suddhantamiva suvaṇṇaṃ. Tadubhayampi ca subhāvitattāyeva. Yathāha “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave,🔽aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃ bhāvitaṃ kammaniyaṃ hoti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, citta”nti.🔽Etesu hi parisuddhabhāvādīsu ṭhitattā ṭhite. Ṭhitattāyeva āneñjappatte acale niriñjaneti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Mudukammaññabhāvena vā attano vase ṭhitattā ṭhite. Saddhādīhi pariggahitattā🔽āneñjappatte. Saddhāpariggahitañhi cittaṃ assaddhiyena na iñjati, vīriyapariggahitaṃ
analyzed: hoti suddhantam iva suvaṇṇam tat ubhayam pi ca su bhāvita ttāya iva yathā āha na aham bhikkhave 🔽aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evam bhāvitam kammaniyam hoti yathā idam bhikkhave cittam ti 🔽etesu hi parisuddha bhāva ādīsu ṭhita ttā ṭhite ṭhita ttāya iva āneñja ppatte acale niriñjane iti 🔽vuttam hoti mudu kammañña bhāvena vā attanaḥ vase ṭhita ttā ṭhite saddhā ādīhi pariggahita ttā 🔽āneñja ppatte saddhā pariggahitañhi cittam assaddhiyena na iñjati vīriya pariggahitam
translated: “Flexible” is said of it; “malleable” is said of it; “workable” is said of it; “well completed” is said of it; “well purified” is said of it; “well penetrated” is said of it; “well emerged” is said of it; “well emancipated” is said of it; “well developed” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of superficies” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of cross-sections” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of round logs” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of surface views” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of cleaving” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for sensual desires” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for existence” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for the brahma-world” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for views” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for mere rules and vows” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for sensual desires, the search for existence, the search for the brahma-world, the search for views, the search for mere rules and vows” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for sensual desires, the search for existence, the search for the brahma-world, the search for views, the search for mere rules and vows, the search for the inward and the search for the outward” is said of it; “well penetrated to the end of the inherent tendency to the manner of the search for sensual desires, the search for existence, the search for the brahma-world, the search for views, the search for mere rules and vows, the search for the inward, the search for the outward, the search

original: kosajjena na iñjati, satipariggahitaṃ pamādena na iñjati, samādhipariggahitaṃ uddhaccena
analyzed: kosajjena naḥ iñjati sati pariggahitam pamādena naḥ iñjati samādhi pariggahitam uddhaccena
translated: He does not tremble with laziness, he does not tremble with negligence when it is taken hold of by mindfulness, he does not tremble with agitation when it is taken hold of by concentration,

original: na iñjati, paññāpariggahitaṃ avijjāya na iñjati, obhāsagataṃ kilesandhakārena na
analyzed: na iñjati paññā pariggahitam avijjāya na iñjati obhāsa gatam kilesa andhakārena na
translated: He does not waver through idleness. He does not waver through negligence when it is embraced by mindfulness. He does not waver through agitation when it is embraced by concentration. He does not waver through ignorance when it is embraced by understanding. He does not waver through the darkness of defilement when it is penetrated by illumination. It is when it is embraced by these six things that it reaches imperturbability.

original: iñjati. Imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahituṃ āneñjappattaṃ hoti. Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: iñjati imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahitum āneñja ppattam hoti evam aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam
translated: When it possesses these eight factors,

original: cittaṃ abhinīhārakkhamaṃ hoti ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya.
analyzed: cittam abhinīhāra kkhamam hoti ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpatti paṭilābha atthāya
translated: it is capable of exertion for the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽Another method: when it is concentrated by means of the fourth jhāna,🔽when it is purified of hindrances by remoteness from them,

original: Aparo nayo – catutthajjhānasamādhinā samāhite. Nīvaraṇadūrībhāvena parisuddhe. Vitakkādisamatikkamena
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ catuttha jhāna samādhinā samāhite nīvaraṇa dūrībhāvena parisuddhe vitakka ādi samatikkamena
translated: when it is bright by surmounting applied thought, etc.,🔽when it is unblemished by the presence of evil states opposed to the jhāna and by the range of the will’s activity,🔽when it is free from dejection by absence of greed, etc.,🔽when it is free from agitation by absence of hate, etc.,

original: pariyodāte. Jhānapaṭilābhapaccanikānaṃ pāpakānaṃ icchāvacarānañca abhāvena anaṅgaṇe.
analyzed: pariyodāte jhāna paṭilābha paccanikānam pāpakānam icchāvacara anaṅgaṇe
translated: when it is free from stiffness and torpor by absence of stiffness and torpor,🔽when it is free from uncertainty by absence of uncertainty,🔽when it is free from loss of mindfulness by absence of loss of mindfulness,🔽when it is free from distraction by absence of distraction,🔽when it is free from covetousness by absence of covetousness,🔽when it is free from ill will by absence of ill will,

original: Icchāvacarānanti icchāya avacarānaṃ, icchāvasena otiṇṇānaṃ pavattānaṃ nānappakārānaṃ
analyzed: icchā avacarānam ti icchāya avacarānam icchā vasena otiṇṇānam pavattānam nānappakārānam
translated: when it is free from wrong view by absence of wrong view,🔽when it is free from the defilements of the mind by absence of the defilements of the mind,🔽when it is free from the subsidiary defilements of the mind by absence of the subsidiary defilements of the mind,

original: kopaappaccayānanti attho. Abhijjhādīnaṃ cittūpakkilesānaṃ vigamena vigatūpakkilese.
analyzed: kopa appaccayānam ti atthaḥ abhijjhā ādīnam citta upakkilesānam vigamena vigata upakkilese
translated: when it is free from the subsidiary defilements of the mind by absence of the subsidiary defilements of the mind,🔽when it is free from the hindrances by absence of the hindrances,🔽when it is free from the unprofitable by absence of the unprofitable,🔽when it is free from the states opposed to the path by absence of the states opposed to the path,🔽when it is free from the states opposed to the jhāna by absence of the states opposed to the jhāna,🔽when it is free from the hindrances to the jhāna by absence of the hindrances to the jhāna,🔽when it is free from the hindrances to the path by absence of the hindrances to the path,🔽when

original: Ubhayampi cetaṃ aṅgaṇasuttavatthasuttānusāreneva veditabbaṃ. Vasippattiyā mudubhūte.
analyzed: ubhayam pi ca itam aṅgaṇa sutta vattha sutta anusārena iva veditabbam vasi ppattiyā mudu bhūte
translated: and this can be understood by the method of the Aṅguttara Sutta and the Aṅgaṇa Sutta.

original: Iddhipādabhāvūpagamanena kammaniye. Bhāvanāpāripūriyā paṇītabhāvūpagamena ṭhite āneñjappatte,
analyzed: iddhipāda bhāva upagamanena kammaniye bhāvanā pāripūriyā paṇīta bhāva upagamena ṭhite āneñja ppatte
translated: They are malleable in the sense of being capable of being made to enter upon the jhāna of the base consisting of boundless space, and they are wieldy in the sense of being capable of being made to stay there for the remaining part of the life.🔽They are steady in the sense of being attained to immovability, and they are attained to imperturbability in the sense of being attained to the imperturbability of the fourth jhāna.🔽The meaning is that they are steady in the sense of being attained to the state of imperturbability.

original: yathā āneñjabhāvaṃ āneñjappattaṃ hoti, evaṃ ṭhiteti attho. Evampi aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgamena🔽cittaṃ abhinīhārakkhamaṃ hoti ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya pādakaṃ padaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: yathā āneñja bhāvam āneñja ppattam hoti evam ṭhitā iti attho evam pi aṭṭhaṅga samannāgamena  cittam abhinīhāra kkhamam hoti ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpatti paṭilābha atthāya pādakam padaṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: So too, in the case of the base consisting of boundless space, the mind is wieldy in the sense of being wieldy for the arousing of the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽It is malleable in the sense of being malleable for the arousing of the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽It is steady in the sense of being steady when entered upon and dwelt in.🔽It is attained to imperturbability in the sense of being attained to the imperturbability of the fourth jhāna.

original: Āruppamaggasamaṅgīti arūpasamāpattiyā gamanamaggena aparihīno. Papañcāyeva papañcasaṅkhāti taṇhādipapañcāyeva papañcasaṅkhā.
analyzed: āruppa magga samaṅgī iti arūpa samāpattiyāḥ gamana maggena a parihīnaḥ papañcāya iva papañca saṅkhā ati taṇhā ādi papañcāya iva papañca saṅkhā
translated: So too, in the case of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, the mind is wieldy in the sense of being wieldy for the arousing of the attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness,🔽and so on.🔽Some here call this the highest purity,🔽For a ghost’s, they say, is purified thereby.🔽But do they say that this is all there is,

original: 110. Ettāvataggaṃ nu vadanti heke, yakkhassa suddhiṃ idha paṇḍitāse. Udāhu aññampi🔽vadanti ettoti ettāvatā nu idha paṇḍitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā aggaṃ suddhiṃ sattassa vadanti,
analyzed: nu vadanti ha ike yakkhassa suddhim idha paṇḍitāse udāhu aññam pi 🔽vadanti ettoti ettāvatā nu idha paṇḍitā samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ aggam suddhim sattassa vadanti
translated: Or do they say that something more besides🔽Is needed for the highest purity?

original: udāhu aññampi etto arūpasamāpattito adhikañca vadantīti pucchati.
analyzed: udāhu aññam pi ettas arūpa samāpattitaḥ adhikañca vadanti iti pucchati
translated: He asks: “Do they say that there is something more than this, namely, the immaterial jhānas?”

original: Etto arūpasamāpattitoti etasmā arūpasamāpattito.
analyzed: ettas a rūpa samāpattitaḥ ti etasmai a rūpa samāpattitaḥ
translated: From this, the immaterial jhāna: from this immaterial jhāna.

original: 111. Ettāvataggampi vadanti heketi eke sassatavādā samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitamānino ettāvatāpi
analyzed: vadanti heke iti eke sassata vādā samaṇa brāhmaṇā paṇḍita māninaḥ ettāvatā api
translated: Some say that this is the limit of purification: some eternalists, recluses and brahmins, conceited with conceit of learning, say that this is the limit of purification,

original: aggaṃ suddhiṃ vadanti. Tesaṃ paneke samayaṃ vadantīti tesaññeva eke ucchedavādā samayaṃ
analyzed: aggam suddhim vadanti tesam pana eke samayam vadanti iti tesam eva eke uccheda vādāḥ samayam
translated: the highest purification. But some say that this is the occasion: some annihilationists among the same say that this is the occasion,

original: ucchedaṃ vadanti. Anupādisese kusalāvadānāti anupādisese kusalavādā samānā.
analyzed: ucchedam vadanti an upādisese an upādisese kusala vādā samānā
translated: the annihilation. Having a remainder of clinging: having a remainder of profitable clinging.

original: Bhavatajjitāti bhavato bhītā. Vibhavaṃ abhinandantīti ucchedaṃ paṭicca tussanti.
analyzed: bhavatat jitā ati bhavataḥ bhītāḥ vibhavam abhinandanti iti ucchedam paṭicca tussanti
translated: Frightened by existence: afraid of existence. They delight in non-existence: they are pleased with annihilation.

original: Te sattassa samanti te ucchedavādino puggalassa samaṃ anuppattiṃ vadanti. Upasamanti
analyzed: te sattassa samanti te uccheda vādinaḥ puggalassa samam anuppattim vadanti upasamanti
translated: They say that there is a rebirth of a being: those annihilationists say that there is a rebirth of the person. They say that there is a settlement:

original: atīva samaṃ. Vūpasamanti santaṃ. Nirodhanti anuppādaṃ. Paṭipassaddhinti apunuppattiṃ.
analyzed: atīva samam vūpasamanti santam nirodhanti an uppādam paṭipassaddhinti a punuppattim
translated: they say that there is a very complete settlement. They say that there is a quieting: they say that there is a stilling. They say that there is a cessation: they say that there is a non-arising. They say that there is a complete quieting: they say that there is a non-re-arising.

original: 112. Ete ca ñatvā upanissitāti ete ca diṭṭhigatike sassatucchedadiṭṭhiyo nissitāti🔽ñatvā. Ñatvā munī nissaye so vīmaṃsīti nissaye ca ñatvā so vīmaṃsī paṇḍito buddhamuni.🔽Ñatvā vimuttoti dukkhāniccādito dhamme ñatvā vimutto. Bhavābhavāya na sametīti punappunaṃ🔽upapattiyā na samāgacchati. Aparāmasanti aparāmasanto. Parāmāsaṃ nāpajjantoti attho.🔽Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya🔽Kalahavivādasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ete ca ñatvā upanissitā ati ete ca diṭṭhi gatike sassatu cheda diṭṭhiyaḥ nissitā ati  ñatvā ñatvā munī nissaye so vīmaṃsī iti nissaye ca ñatvā saḥ vīmaṃsī paṇḍitaḥ buddha muni  ñatvā vimuttaḥ ti dukkha anicca āditaḥ dhamme ñatvā vimuttaḥ bhava abhavāya na sameti iti punappunam  upapattiyā na samāgacchati a parāmasanti a parāmasantaḥ parāmāsam na āpajjanto ti attho  saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya  kalaha vivāda sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: 112. Having known these views, their dependence, etc. Having known these theorists’ views of eternalism and annihilationism, their dependence, etc.

original: 12. Cūḷabyūhasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽Dvādasame cūḷabyūhasuttaniddese sakaṃsakaṃdiṭṭhiparibbasānāti idampi tasmiṃyeva mahāsamaye🔽“sabbepime diṭṭhigatikā ‘sādhurūpāmhā’ti bhaṇanti, kiṃ nu kho sādhurūpāva ime attano
analyzed: 🔽dvādasame cūḷa byūha sutta niddese idam pi tasmin yeva mahā samaye 🔽sabbe pi ime diṭṭhigatikā sādhu rūpā amhā iti bhaṇanti kim nu kho ime attanaḥ
