analyzed: upayoga vacanam atthataḥ pana bhummam eva purebhatta iti esa nayo pacchābhatta ādīsu
translated: “Arisen internally” : arisen in the mind. “Before the meal” : before the meal in the day. The word “use” is used in the sense of extreme connection . But in the meaning of “before the meal” the earth itself is intended. This is the method with “after the meal” , etc.

original: Pacchābhattanti divābhattato pacchākālaṃ. Purimaṃ yāmanti rattiyā paṭhamakoṭṭhāsaṃ.
analyzed: pacchābhattanti divābhattataḥ pacchākālam purimam yāmanti rattiyā paṭhama koṭṭhāsam
translated: “After the meal” : after the meal in the day. “The first watch” : the first division of the night.

original: Majjhimaṃ yāmanti rattiyā dutiyakoṭṭhāsaṃ. Pacchimaṃ yāmanti rattiyā tatiyakoṭṭhāsaṃ.🔽Kāḷeti kāḷapakkhe. Juṇheti sukkapakkhe. Vasseti cattāro vassānamāse. Hemanteti cattāro
analyzed: majjhimam yāmanti rattiyā dutiya koṭṭhāsam pacchimam yāmanti rattiyā tatiya koṭṭhāsam  kāḷeti kāḷapakkhe juṇheti sukkapakkhe vasseti cattāraḥ vassānamāse hemanteti cattāraḥ
translated: The middle watch of the night is the second part of the night. The last watch of the night is the third part of the night.🔽The dark half is the waning fortnight. The bright half is the waxing fortnight. The rainy season is the four months of the rains. The winter is the four months of winter.

original: hemantamāse. Gimheti cattāro gimhānamāse. Purime vayokhandheti paṭhame vayokoṭṭhāse,🔽paṭhamavayeti attho. Tīsu ca vayesu vassasatāyukassa purisassa ekekasmiṃ vaye catumāsādhikāni
analyzed: hemanta māse gimha iti cattāraḥ gimhāna māse purime vayaḥ khandha iti paṭhame vayaḥ koṭṭhāse  paṭhama vayā iti attho tīsu ca vayesu vassa sata āyukassa purisassa ekekasmin vaye catu māsa adhikāni
translated: The summer is the four months of summer. The first period of life is the first part of life.

original: tettiṃsa vassāni honti.
analyzed: tettiṃsa vassāni honti
translated: The meaning is: the first stage of life. And in the three stages of life, in each stage of the person of a hundred years’ life span there are thirty-four years and three months.

original: 152. Evaṃ paṭhamagāthāya tāva tīhi sikkhāhi yuttaṃ desanaṃ arahattanikūṭena desetvā
analyzed: evam paṭhama gāthāya tāva tīhi sikkhāhi yuttam desanam arahatta nikūṭena desetvā
translated: Thus, having taught the doctrine, which is connected with the three trainings, by means of the first stanza, up to the peak of the arahant path,

original: puna mānappahānavasena desetuṃ “yaṃ kiñcī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha yaṃ kiñci dhammamabhijaññā
analyzed: puna māna ppahāna vasena desetum yam kiñci iti gātham āha tattha yam kiñci dhammam abhijaññā
translated: he again taught it by means of the abandoning of conceit, saying, “Whatever,” etc. Herein, whatever things he may know,

original: ajjhattanti yaṃ kiñci uccākulīnatādikaṃ attano guṇaṃ jāneyya. Atha vāpi bahiddhāti
analyzed: ajjhattam ti yam kiñci ucca akulīna tā ādikam attanaḥ guṇam jāneyya atha vā api bahiddhā ti
translated: inside: he may know any of his own qualities such as high birth, etc. Or else outside:

original: atha vā bahiddhāpi ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ vā guṇaṃ jāneyya. Na tena thāmaṃ kubbethāti
analyzed: atha vā bahiddhā api ācariya upajjhāyānam vā guṇam jāneyya na tena thāmam kubbetha ati
translated: Or else he should know the virtues of his teachers and preceptors even outside the Dispensation.

original: tena guṇena mānaṃ na kareyya.
analyzed: tena guṇena mānam na kareyya
translated: He should not be conceited with that: he should not be proud of that virtue.🔽The peaceful: those who have the virtue of peace. The calm: those whose continuity is calm.

original: Satānanti santaguṇavantānaṃ. Santānanti nibbutasantānaṃ. Na vuttāti na kathitā. Nappavuttāti na vissajjitā.
analyzed: satānam santa guṇavantānam santānam nibbuta santānam na vuttā ati na kathitā na pavuttā ati na vissajjitā
translated: Not spoken: not told. Not spoken of: not discussed.

original: 153. Idānissa akaraṇavidhiṃ dassento “seyyo na tenā”ti gāthamāha. Tassattho – tena
analyzed: idānissa akaraṇa vidhim dassentaḥ seyyaḥ na tena iti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ tena
translated: Now, showing the method of non-doing, he uttered the stanza ‘Better than that is not to be conceited’. Its meaning is this.

original: ca mānena “seyyoha”nti vā “nīcoha”nti vā “sarikkhoha”nti vāpi na maññeyya. Tehi ca
analyzed: ca mānena seyyohanti vā nīcohanti vā sarikkhohanti vā api na maññeyya tehi ca
translated: He should not think ‘I am better’ or ‘I am lower’ or ‘I am equal’ with that conceit.

original: uccākulīnatādīhi guṇehi phuṭṭho anekarūpehi “ahaṃ uccā kulā pabbajito”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: ucca akulīna tā ādīhi guṇehi phuṭṭhaḥ aneka rūpehi aham uccā kulā pabbajitaḥ iti ādinā nayena
translated: And he should not stand by making a distinction about himself in various ways, thinking ‘I have gone forth from a high family’ and so on, being possessed of such virtues as high birth and so on.

original: attānaṃ vikappento na tiṭṭheyyāti.🔽154. Evaṃ mānappahānavasenapi desetvā idāni sabbakilesūpasamavasena desetuṃ “ajjhattamevā”ti
analyzed: attānam vikappentaḥ na tiṭṭheyya ati  evam māna ppahāna vasena api desetvā idāni sabba kilesa upasama vasena desetum ajjhattam eva ati
translated: This is the method of non-doing.🔽Having taught in this way by means of the abandoning of conceit, now, in order to teach by means of the complete quieting of all defilements, he uttered the stanza ‘Only in oneself is peace to be found’ .

original: gāthamāha. Tattha ajjhattamevupasameti attani eva rāgādisabbakilese upasameyya. Na
analyzed: gātham āha tattha ajjhattam eva upasameti attani eva rāga ādi sabba kilese upasameyya na
translated: There, only in oneself is peace to be found: he should quiet all the defilements of lust, etc., in himself.

original: aññato bhikkhu santimeseyyāti ṭhapetvā ca satipaṭṭhānādīni aññena upāyena santiṃ
analyzed: aññatas bhikkhu santim eseyya ati ṭhapetvā ca sati paṭṭhāna ādīni aññena upāyena santim
translated: “He should not seek peace from another”: he should not seek peace by some other means than the foundations of mindfulness, etc.

original: na pariyeseyya. Kuto nirattā vāti nirattā kutoyeva.
analyzed: na pariyeseyya kutas nirattā vāti nirattā kutas yā iva
translated: “From where can there be freedom?”: from where can there be freedom?

original: Na eseyyāti sīlabbatādīhi na maggeyya. Na gaveseyyāti na olokeyya. Na pariyeseyyāti punappunaṃ na ikkheyya.
analyzed: na eseyya ati sīlabbata ādīhi na maggeyya na gaveseyya ati na olokeyya na pariyeseyya ati punappunam na ikkheyya
translated: “He should not seek”: he should not seek by means of virtue and practices, etc. “He should not look”: he should not look. “He should not seek”: he should not investigate again and again.🔽Now, in order to show the state of one whose cankers are destroyed, who is internally peaceful, the Master uttered the following stanza:

original: 155. Idāni ajjhattaṃ upasantassa khīṇāsavassa tādibhāvaṃ dassento “majjhe yathā”ti🔽gāthamāha. Tassattho – yathā mahāsamuddassa upariheṭṭhimabhāgānaṃ vemajjhasaṅkhāte🔽catuyojanasahassappamāṇe majjhe pabbatantare ṭhitassa vā majjhe samuddassa ūmi no
analyzed: idāni ajjhattam upasantassa khīṇāsavassa ta ādi bhāvam dassentaḥ majjhe yathā iti  gātham āha tassa atthaḥ yathā mahā samuddassa upari heṭṭhima bhāgānam vemajjha saṅkhāte  catu yojana sahassa ppamāṇe majjhe pabbata antare ṭhitassa vā majjhe samuddassa no
translated: “In the middle, as it were” .🔽The meaning is as follows: As the waves of the great ocean do not arise in the middle, which is called the “middle region” and is four yojanas in extent,

original: jāyati, ṭhitova so hoti avikampamāno, evaṃ anejo khīṇāsavo lābhādīsu ṭhito assa avikampamāno,
analyzed: jāyati ṭhitaḥ uva saḥ hoti a vikampamānaḥ evam anejaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ lābha ādīsu ṭhitaḥ assa a vikampamānaḥ
translated: or as the waves do not arise in the middle of the ocean which is situated between the mountains in the middle of the earth,🔽so the bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed should be unshaken, undisturbed, by gain, etc., and should be like the ocean which is not agitated in the middle.

original: so tādiso rāgādiussadaṃ bhikkhu na kareyya kuhiñcīti.
analyzed: saḥ tādisaḥ rāga ādi ussadam bhikkhu na kareyya kuhiñci iti
translated: “Such a bhikkhu would not arouse” the agitation of lust, etc.

original: Ubbedhenāti heṭṭhābhāgena. Gambhīroti udakapiṭṭhito paṭṭhāya caturāsītiyojanasahassāni🔽gambhīro. “Ubbedho”tipi pāṭho, taṃ na sundaraṃ. Heṭṭhāti antoudakaṃ. Uparīti uddhaṃudakaṃ.🔽Majjheti vemajjhe. Na kampatīti ṭhitaṭṭhānato na calati. Na vikampatīti ito cito🔽ca na calati. Na calatīti niccalaṃ hoti. Na vedhatīti na phandati. Nappavedhatīti🔽na parivattati. Na sampavedhatīti na paribbhamati. Aneritoti na erito. Aghaṭṭitoti
analyzed: ubbedhena ati heṭṭhā bhāgena gambhīraḥ ti udaka piṭṭhitaḥ paṭṭhāya caturāsīti yojana sahassāni  gambhīraḥ ubbedhaḥ tipi pāṭhaḥ tam na sundaram heṭṭhā ati antar udakam upari iti uddhaṃ udakam  majjhe iti vemajjhe na kampati iti ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ na calati na vikampati iti itas citas  ca na calati na calati iti niccalam hoti na vedhati iti na phandati na pavedhati iti  na parivattati na sampavedhati iti na paribbhamati an eritaḥ uti na eritaḥ a ghaṭṭitaḥ uti
translated: There is also the reading ‘ubbedhena’, which is not good. ‘Below’ means the water below. ‘Above’ means the water above.

original: akkhobho. Acalitoti na kampito. Aluḷitoti na kalalībhūto. Tatra ūmi no jāyatīti tasmiṃ🔽ṭhāne vīci na uppajjati.🔽Sattannaṃ pabbatānaṃ antarikāsūti yugandharādīnaṃ sattannaṃ pabbatānaṃ antarantarā.
analyzed: akkhobhaḥ a calitaḥ iti na kampitaḥ a luḍitaḥ iti na kalalībhūtaḥ tatra ūmi no jāyati iti tasmin 🔽ṭhāne vīci na uppajjati 🔽sattannam pabbatānam antarikāsu uti yugandhara ādīnam sattannam pabbatānam antar antarā
translated: ‘In the middle’ means in the middle. ‘Does not quake’ means it does not move from its place. ‘Does not tremble’ means it does not move from here and there. ‘Does not waver’ means it is motionless. ‘Does not quake’ means it does not shake. ‘Does not tremble’ means it does not move round. ‘Does not waver’ means it does not revolve. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not moved’ means it is not shaken. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated. ‘Is not disturbed’ means it is not disturbed. ‘Is not agitated’ means it is not agitated

original: Sīdantarāti antamaso simbalītūlampi tesu patitapatitaṃ sīdatīti sīdā, pabbatantare
analyzed: sīdantarā ati antamasaḥ simbalī tūlam pi tesu patita patitam sīdati iti sīdā pabbata antare
translated: Sīdantarā: sīdā means that even a simbal fruit or a lamp-wick falls down in them; antarā means that it is born in the middle of a mountain.

original: jātattā antarā. “Antarasīdā”tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: antarā antarasīda atipi
translated: “Antarasīdā” is also a reading.

original: 156. Idāni evaṃ arahattanikūṭena desitaṃ dhammadesanaṃ abbhānumodento tassa ca arahattassa
analyzed: idāni evam arahatta nikūṭena desitam dhamma desanam tassa ca arahattassa
translated: Now, the Buddha-image, approving the teaching of the Dhamma which was thus demonstrated by the peak of arahatship,🔽and asking for the beginning of the path of that arahatship, spoke the stanza, “Akittati.”

original: ādipaṭipadaṃ pucchanto nimmitabuddho “akittayī”ti gāthamāha. Tattha akittayīti ācikkhi.
analyzed: ādi paṭipadam pucchantaḥ nimmitabuddhaḥ akittayi iti gātham āha tattha akittayi iti ācikkhi
translated: There, akittati means that he has explained.

original: Vivaṭacakkhūti vivaṭehi anāvaraṇehi pañcahi cakkhūhi samannāgato. Sakkhidhammanti
analyzed: vivaṭa cakkhu iti vivaṭehi anāvaraṇehi pañcahi cakkhūhi samannāgato sakkhi dhammanti
translated: Vivaṭacakkhū means that he is endowed with the five eyes which are open and unobstructed. Sakkhidhamman ti

original: sakāyattaṃ sayaṃ abhiññātaṃ attapaccakkhadhammaṃ. Parissayavinayanti parissayavinayanaṃ.
analyzed: sa kāyattam sayam abhiññātam atta paccakkha dhammam parissaya vinayanti parissaya vinayanam
translated: sakāyattaṃ sayaṃ abhiññātaṃ attapaccakkhadhammaṃ. Parissayavinayaṃ means the destruction of the danger.

original: Paṭipadaṃ vadehīti idāni paṭipattiṃ vadehi. Bhaddanteti bhaddaṃ tava atthūti bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: paṭipadam vadehi iti idāni paṭipattim vadehi bhaddanta iti bhaddam tava atthu iti bhagavantam
translated: Paṭipadaṃ vadehī ti idāni paṭipattiṃ vadehi. Bhaddante ti bhaddaṃ tava atthū ti bhagavantaṃ

original: ālapanto āha. Atha vā bhaddaṃ sundaraṃ tava paṭipadaṃ vadehītipi vuttaṃ hoti. Pātimokkhaṃ
analyzed: ālapantaḥ āha atha vā bhaddam sundaram tava paṭipadam vadehi iti pi vuttam hoti pātimokkham
translated: addressing, said. Or, it is said: “Bhaddan” means good. Vadehi paṭipadaṃ ti vadehi. Pātimokkhaṃ

original: atha vāpi samādhinti tameva paṭipadaṃ bhinditvā pucchati. Paṭipadanti etena vā maggaṃ
analyzed: atha vā api tam eva paṭipadam bhinditvā pucchati paṭipadanti etena vā maggam
translated: By “or in practice” he asks about the path.

original: pucchati. Itarehi sīlaṃ samādhiñca pucchati.
analyzed: pucchati itarehi sīlam samādhiñca pucchati
translated: By the other two terms he asks about virtue and concentration.🔽“With the fleshly eye” means with the fleshly eye that is accompanied by the jhāna.

original: Maṃsacakkhunāpīti sasambhārikamaṃsacakkhunāpi. Dibbacakkhunāpīti dibbasadisattā dibbaṃ.🔽Devānañhi sucaritakammanibbattaṃ pittasemharuhirādīhi apalibuddhaṃ upakkilesavinimuttatāya
analyzed: maṃsa cakkhunā api iti sa sambhārika maṃsa cakkhunā api dibba cakkhunā api iti dibba sadisa ttā dibbam  devānam hi su carita kamma nibbattam pitta semha ruhira ādīhi apalibuddham upakkilesa vinimutta tāya
translated: “With the divine eye” means with the divine eye that is similar to the divine eye of the devas.

original: dūrepi ārammaṇasampaṭicchanasamatthaṃ dibbaṃ pasādacakkhu hoti. Idañcāpi vīriyabhāvanābalanibbattaṃ
analyzed: dūre pi ārammaṇa sampaṭicchana samattham dibbam pasāda cakkhu hoti idam ca api vīriya bhāvanā bala nibbattam
translated: For the devas have a divine eye that is produced by the kamma consisting in good conduct, that is not obstructed by skin, flesh, blood, etc., and that is capable of receiving an object even at a distance because it is free from the impurities of the eye such as eye disease, etc.🔽This eye of knowledge produced by the power of the development of energy is similar to that divine eye,

original: ñāṇacakkhu tādisamevāti dibbasadisattā dibbaṃ. Dibbavihāravasena paṭiladdhattā, attanā
analyzed: ñāṇa cakkhu tādisam eva ati dibba sadisa ttā dibbam dibba vihāra vasena paṭiladdha ttā attanā
translated: therefore it is called “divine” . It is also called “divine” because it is obtained by the practice of the divine abidings,🔽and because it is itself the support for the divine abidings.🔽It is also called “divine” because it is endowed with great radiance by the perception of light,

original: ca dibbavihārasannissitattāpi dibbaṃ. Ālokapariggahena mahājutikattāpi dibbaṃ. Tirokuṭṭādigatarūpadassanena
analyzed: ca dibba vihāra sannissita ttā api dibbam āloka pariggahena mahā jutika ttā api dibbam tirokuṭṭa ādi gata rūpa dassanena
translated: and because it has great range by seeing visible forms even behind walls, etc.

original: mahāgatikattāpi dibbaṃ. Taṃ sabbaṃ saddasatthānusārena veditabbaṃ. Dassanaṭṭhena
analyzed: mahāgatika ttā api dibbam tam sabbam sadda sattha anusārena veditabbam dassana ṭṭhena
translated: All this should be understood according to the Suttas and the commentaries.

original: cakkhu, cakkhukiccakaraṇena cakkhumivātipi cakkhu, dibbañca taṃ cakkhu cāti dibbacakkhu.
analyzed: cakkhu cakkhu kicca karaṇena cakkhumiva atipi cakkhu dibbam ca tam cakkhu ca ati dibbacakkhu
translated: and it is eye because it is the doing of the eye’s function, and it is divine and it is eye, thus it is the divine eye .

original: Tena dibbacakkhunāpi vivaṭacakkhu. Idāni pañcavidhaṃ cakkhuṃ vitthārena kathetuṃ
analyzed: tena dibba cakkhunā api vivaṭa cakkhu idāni pañcavidham cakkhum vitthārena kathetum
translated: and with that divine eye he is also open-eyed. Now, in order to tell in detail the five kinds of eye,

original: “kathaṃ bhagavā maṃsacakkhunāpi vivaṭacakkhū”tiādimāha. Maṃsacakkhumhi bhagavato🔽pañcavaṇṇā saṃvijjantīti ettha sasambhārādikacakkhumhi buddhassa bhagavato pañca
analyzed: katham bhagavā maṃsacakkhunā api vivaṭa cakkhu iti ādim āha maṃsacakkhumhi bhagavataḥ  pañca vaṇṇā saṃvijjanti iti ettha sa sambhāra ādika cakkhumhi buddhassa bhagavato pañca
translated: he said “How is it that the Blessed One is open-eyed with the fleshly eye?” In the case of the fleshly eye,🔽the Blessed One’s fleshly eye has five colours,

original: koṭṭhāsā paccekaṃ paccekaṃ upalabbhanti.🔽Nīlo ca vaṇṇoti umāpupphavaṇṇo. Pītako ca vaṇṇoti kaṇikārapupphavaṇṇo. Lohitako ca
analyzed: koṭṭhāsā paccekam paccekam upalabbhanti  nīlo ca vaṇṇoti umā puppha vaṇṇo pītako ca vaṇṇoti kaṇikāra puppha vaṇṇo lohitako ca
translated: in the case of the eye with its accessories, etc., the Blessed One’s eye has five parts that are found separately.

original: vaṇṇoti indagopakavaṇṇo. Kaṇho ca vaṇṇoti añjanavaṇṇo. Odāto ca vaṇṇoti osadhitārakavaṇṇo.
analyzed: vaṇṇoti indagopaka vaṇṇo kaṇho ca vaṇṇoti añjana vaṇṇo odāto ca vaṇṇoti osadhi tāraka vaṇṇo
translated: Blue colour: the colour of the umā flower. Yellow colour: the colour of the kaṇikāra flower. Red colour: the colour of the indragopaka gem. Black colour: the colour of collyrium. White colour: the colour of the osadhitāraka star.

original: Yattha ca akkhilomāni patiṭṭhitānīti yasmiṃ ṭhāne akkhilomāni patiṭṭhahitvā uṭṭhitāni.
analyzed: yattha ca akkhi lomāni patiṭṭhitāni iti yasmin ṭhāne akkhi lomāni patiṭṭhahitvā uṭṭhitāni
translated: And the eyelashes are set in it: the eyelashes are set in that place and grow up.

original: Taṃ nīlaṃ hoti sunīlanti ettha nīlanti sabbasaṅgāhakavasena vuttaṃ. Sunīlanti antaravirahitaṃ
analyzed: tat nīlam hoti su nīlam ti ettha nīlam ti sabba saṅgāhaka vasena vuttam su nīlam ti antara virahitam
translated: “It is blue, a good blue”: here “blue” is said as a general term. “A good blue” is a very blue,

original: suṭṭhu nīlaṃ. Pāsādikanti pasādajanakaṃ. Dassaneyyanti dassanīyaṃ. Umāpupphasamānanti
analyzed: suṭṭhu nīlam pāsādikanti pasāda janakam dassaneyyanti dassanīyam umā puppha samānam
translated: without any admixture. “Delightful”: causing delight. “Worth looking at”: worth seeing. “Like the umma flower”:

original: dakasītalapupphasadisaṃ. Tassa paratoti tassa samantā bāhirapasse. Pītakanti sabbasaṅgāhakaṃ.
analyzed: daka sītala puppha sadisam tassa paratas ti tassa samantā bāhira passe pītakanti sabba saṅgāhakam
translated: like the dakasītalapuppha. “All round it”: on the outside all round it. “Yellow”: as a general term.

original: Supītakanti antaravirahitaṃ suṭṭhu pītakaṃ. Ubhayato ca akkhikūṭānīti dve ca akkhikoṭiyo.
analyzed: su pītakanti antara virahitam suṭṭhu pītakam ubhayatas ca akkhi kūṭāni iti dve ca akkhi koṭiyo
translated: “A good yellow”: a very yellow, without any admixture. “The two eyeballs”: the two eyeballs.

original: Lohitakānīti sabbasaṅgāhakavasena vuttaṃ. Sulohitakānīti apaññāyamānavivarāni suṭṭhu🔽lohitakāni. Majjhe kaṇhanti akkhīnaṃ majjhimaṭṭhānaṃ añjanasadisaṃ kaṇhaṃ. Sukaṇhanti
analyzed: lohitakāni iti sabba saṅgāhaka vasena vuttam su lohitakāni iti a paññāyamāna vivarāni suṭṭhu  lohitakāni majjhe kaṇhanti akkhīnam majjhima ṭṭhānam añjana sadisam kaṇham su kaṇhanti
translated: “Red”: as a general term. “A good red”: without any gaps showing, a very🔽red. “In the middle, black”: the middle of the eyes is black like collyrium. “A good black”:

original: antaravirahitaṃ suṭṭhu kaṇhaṃ. Alūkhanti pāsādikaṃ. Siniddhanti paṇītaṃ. Bhaddāriṭṭhakasamānanti
analyzed: antara virahitam suṭṭhu kaṇham pāsādikam paṇītam
translated: without any admixture, a very black. “Clear”: delightful. “Pure”: excellent. “Like a bhaddaṭṭhaka seed”:

original: apanītatacabhaddāriṭṭhakaphalasadisaṃ. “Addāriṭṭhakasamāna”ntipi pāḷi, tassā tintakākasadisanti🔽attho. Odātanti sabbasaṅgāhakavasena vuttaṃ. Suodātanti antaravirahitaṃ rajatamaṇḍalasadisaṃ
analyzed: apanīta taca bhaddāriṭṭhaka phala sadisam tassā tinta kāka sadisanti  attho odātanti sabba saṅgāhaka vasena vuttam su odātanti antara virahitam rajata maṇḍala sadisam
translated: like a ripe mango fruit. The reading is “like a mango fruit” . Its meaning is “like a sour tamarind fruit.” “White” is said in the sense of all-embracing. “Very white” is like a silver disk without any intervening space.

original: suṭṭhu odātaṃ. Setaṃ paṇḍaranti dvīhipi atiodātataṃ dasseti. Pākatikena maṃsacakkhunāti
analyzed: suṭṭhu odātam setam paṇḍaranti ati odātatam dasseti pākatikena maṃsa cakkhunā ati
translated: like a ripe mango or a ripe palm-fruit. The reading is “like a ripe mango” . The meaning is “like a ripe palm-fruit.” “White” is said in the sense of all-embracing. “Very white” is like a silver disk without any intervening space. “Pure” and “bright” show that it is extremely white. “With the natural eye” :🔽with the ordinary fleshly eye. “With the eye that is his own” :

original: pakatimaṃsacakkhunā. Attabhāvapariyāpannenāti attabhāvasannissitena. Purimasucaritakammābhinibbattenāti
analyzed: pakati maṃsa cakkhunā atta bhāva pariyāpannena ati atta bhāva sannissitena purima su carita kamma abhinibbattena ati
translated: with the eye that is dependent on his own self. “Produced by kamma that was done in the past” :

original: purimesu tattha tatthuppannesu attabhāvesu kāyasucaritādikammunā uppāditena. Samantā🔽yojanaṃ passatīti samantato catugāvutappamāṇe yojane tirokuṭṭādigataṃ rūpaṃ āvaraṇavirahitaṃ
analyzed: purimesu tattha tattha uppannesu atta bhāvesu kāya su carita ādi kammunā uppāditena samantā  yojanam passati iti samantataḥ yojane tiro kuṭṭa ādi gatam rūpam āvaraṇa virahitam
translated: produced by the kamma consisting in bodily good conduct, etc., done in the various previous existences. “He sees a league all around” :

original: pakatimaṃsacakkhunā dakkhati.
analyzed: pakati maṃsa cakkhunā dakkhati
translated: he sees visible forms a league away in all directions, on the other side of walls, etc., without any obstruction, with his ordinary fleshly eye.🔽“Both by day and by night” :

original: Divā ceva rattiñcāti divasabhāge ca rattibhāge ca. Caturaṅgasamannāgatoti catūhi
analyzed: divā ca iva rattim ca ati divasa bhāge ca ratti bhāge ca catur aṅga samannāgatā iti catūhi
translated: in the daytime and at night. “Endowed with the four” :

original: aṅgehi samannāgato paripuṇṇaandhakāro ālokavirahito. Sūriyo vā atthaṅgatoti sūrabhāvaṃ
analyzed: aṅgehi samannāgataḥ paripuṇṇa andhakāraḥ āloka virahitaḥ sūriyaḥ vā atthaṅgataḥ ti sūra bhāvam
translated: He is endowed with the limbs, complete, with darkness, without light. The sun has set: the sun, having risen, has gone down,

original: janayanto uṭṭhito sūriyo vigato. Kāḷapakkho ca uposathoti kāḷapakkhe cātuddasīuposathadivaso
analyzed: janayantaḥ uṭṭhitaḥ sūriyaḥ vigataḥ kāḷapakkhaḥ ca uposathaḥ ti kāḷapakkhe cātuddasī uposatha divaso
translated: having generated the state of being bright. The dark fortnight is the Uposatha day of the dark fortnight, the fourteenth day of the Uposatha.

original: ca. Tibbo ca vanasaṇḍoti gahano ca rukkharāsi. Mahā ca kāḷamegho abbhuṭṭhitoti mahanto🔽kāḷamegho abbhapaṭalo ca uṭṭhito hoti. Kuṭṭo vāti iṭṭhakācayo vā. Kavāṭaṃ vāti dvāravātapānādikavāṭaṃ🔽vā. Pākāro vāti mattikādipākāro vā. Pabbato vāti paṃsupabbatādipabbato vā. Gacchaṃ
analyzed: ca tibbaḥ ca vanasaṇḍo ti gahanaḥ ca rukkha rāsi mahā ca kāḷa meghaḥ abbhuṭṭhito ti mahanto  kāḷameghaḥ abbha paṭalo ca uṭṭhitaḥ hoti kuṭṭaḥ vāti iṭṭhakā cayaḥ vā kavāṭam vāti dvāra vāta pāna ādi kavāṭam  vā pākāraḥ vā ati mattikā ādi pākāraḥ vā pabbataḥ vā ati paṃsu pabbata ādi pabbataḥ vā gacchan
translated: And the dense jungle: a dense mass of trees. And a great black cloud has risen: a great🔽black cloud and a rain cloud have risen. A wall: a wall of bricks or a wall of stones. A door: a door of a door, a window, etc.

original: vāti taruṇagacchādigacchaṃ vā. Latā vāti karavindādi latā vā. Āvaraṇaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāyāti
analyzed: vāti taruṇagaccha ādi gaccham vā latā vāti karavinda ādi latā vā āvaraṇam dassanāya āti
translated: A rampart: a rampart of clay, etc. A mountain: a mountain of sand, etc. A tree: a young tree, etc. A creeper: a lotus creeper, etc. An obstruction to the seeing of visible objects:

original: rūpārammaṇānaṃ dassanatthāya paṭisedhaṃ natthi. Ekañce tilaphalaṃ nimittaṃ katvāti
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇānam dassana tthāya paṭisedham natthi ekaṃ ce tila phalam nimittam katvā ati
translated: there is no obstruction to the seeing of visible-data objects. If he defines one visible-data unit:

original: sace ekaṃ tilabījaṃ saññāṇaṃ katvā. Tilavāhe pakkhipeyyāti dve sakaṭe tilarāsimhi
analyzed: sace ekam tila bījam saññāṇam katvā tila vāhe pakkhipeyyāti dve sakaṭe tila rāsimhi
translated: he could put down two cartloads of sesame seeds.

original: khipeyya. Keci pana “vāho nāma kumbhātirekadvesakaṭa”nti vadanti. Taññeva tilaphalaṃ
analyzed: khipeyya keci pana vāhaḥ nāma kumbha atireka dvesa kaṭanti vadanti tañca eva tila phalam
translated: But some say that a ‘cartload’ is two and a half cartloads.🔽He could take up that very sesame seed

original: uddhareyyāti taṃnimittakataṃ tilabījaṃyeva uddharitvā gaṇheyya.
analyzed: uddhareyya iti uddharitvā gaṇheyya
translated: as a sign.

original: Dibbena cakkhunāti idaṃ vuttatthameva. Visuddhenāti cutūpapātadassanena diṭṭhivisuddhihetuttā
analyzed: dibbena cakkhunā ti idam vutta ttham eva visuddhena āti cutūpapāta dassanena diṭṭhi visuddhi hetu ttā
translated: With the divine eye: the meaning of this is stated. With the purified: it is purified because it is the cause for the purification of view.

original: visuddhena. Yo hi cutimattameva passati na upapātaṃ, so ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Yo
analyzed: visuddhena yaḥ hi cutimattam eva passati na upapātam so uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhāti yaḥ
translated: For one who sees only death and not rebirth seizes the view of annihilation.

original: upapātameva passati na cutiṃ, so navasattapātubhāvasassatadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Yo pana🔽tadubhayaṃ passati, so yasmā duvidhampi taṃ diṭṭhigataṃ ativattati, tasmāssa taṃ
analyzed: upapātam eva passati na cutim so nava satta pātubhāva sassata diṭṭhim gaṇhāti yaḥ pana  tat ubhayam passati saḥ yasmā duvidham pi tam diṭṭhi gatam ativattati tasmā assa tam
translated: One who sees only rebirth and not death seizes the view of eternalism, the manifestation of a new being.🔽But one who sees both🔽avoids both views. Therefore his seeing is the cause for the purification of view.

original: dassanaṃ diṭṭhivisuddhihetu hoti, ubhayañcetaṃ buddhaputtā passanti. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: dassanam diṭṭhi visuddhi hetu hoti ubhayam ca etam buddha puttā passanti tena vuttam
translated: And the sons of the Buddha see both.

original: – “cutūpapātadassanena diṭṭhivisuddhihetuttā visuddha”nti. Manussūpacāraṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: cutūpapāta dassanena diṭṭhi visuddhi hetuttā visuddhanti manussu upacāram atikkamitvā
translated: “Pure” means that it is a cause for the purification of view by seeing the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: rūpadassanena atikkantamānusakaṃ, mānusakaṃ vā maṃsacakkhuṃ atikkantattā atikkantamānusakanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa dassanena atikkanta mānusakam mānusakam vā maṃsa cakkhum atikkanta ttā atikkanta mānusakam ti veditabbam
translated: “Surpassing that of men” should be understood as either surpassing the human by transcending the human sphere, or surpassing the human by transcending the human eye.

original: Tena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passatīti manussamaṃsacakkhunā🔽viya satte oloketi. Cavamāne upapajjamāneti ettha cutikkhaṇe upapattikkhaṇe vā dibbacakkhunā
analyzed: tena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati iti manussa maṃsa cakkhunā  viya satte oloketi cavamāne upapajjamāne iti ettha cuti khaṇe upapatti khaṇe vā dibba cakkhunā
translated: “With the divine eye” he sees beings with the divine eye, as if with the human eye.

original: daṭṭhuṃ na sakkā. Ye pana āsannacutikā idāni cavissanti, te cavamānā. Ye ca gahitapaṭisandhikā
analyzed: daṭṭhum na sakkā ye pana āsanna cutikāḥ idāni cavissanti te cavamānāḥ ye ca gahita paṭisandhikā
translated: “Passing away and reappearing” : at the moment of death and at the moment of rebirth, beings cannot be seen with the divine eye. But those who are about to die and those who are about to be reborn are called “passing away” and “reappearing,” respectively.

original: sampatinibbattāva, te upapajjamānāti adhippetā. Te evarūpe cavamāne upapajjamāne
analyzed: sampatinibbattā ava te upapajjamānā ati adhippetā te evarūpe cavamāne upapajjamāne
translated: He sees beings as such who are passing away and reappearing in this way.

original: ca passatīti dasseti. Hīneti mohanissandayuttattā hīne. Tabbiparīte paṇīte. Suvaṇṇeti
analyzed: ca passati iti dasseti hīne iti moha nissanda yutta ttā hīne tad biparīte paṇīte suvaṇṇa iti
translated: “Low” means associated with the result of delusion. “High” means the opposite. “Fair” means

original: adosanissandayuttattā iṭṭhakantamanāpavaṇṇayutte. Tabbiparīte dubbaṇṇe, abhirūpe
analyzed: a dosa nissanda yutta ttā iṭṭha kanta manāpa vaṇṇa yutte tad biparīte dubbaṇṇe abhirūpe
translated: and because of the outcome of non-hate, in the beautiful, the agreeable, the pleasant. In the ugly, the unlovely, the unpleasant,🔽the opposite of that. In the fortunate, in the fortunate destiny,

original: virūpeti attho. Sugateti sugatigate, alobhanissandayuttattā vā aḍḍhe mahaddhane.
analyzed: virūpā iti sugati gate alobha nissanda yutta ttā vā aḍḍhe mahat dhane
translated: because of the outcome of non-greed, in the rich, in the very rich.🔽In the unfortunate, in the unfortunate destiny,

original: Duggateti duggatigate, lobhanissandayuttattā vā dalidde appannapāne. Yathākammūpageti🔽yaṃ yaṃ kammaṃ upacitaṃ, tena tena upagate. Tattha purimehi “cavamāne”tiādīhi dibbacakkhukiccaṃ
analyzed: duggata iti duggati gate lobha nissanda yutta ttā vā dalidde appanna pāne yathākammūpage iti  yam yam kammam upacitam tena tena upagate tattha purimehi cavamāna iti ādīhi dibba cakkhu kiccam
translated: because of the outcome of greed, in the poor, in the very poor. In accordance with kamma,🔽in accordance with whatever kamma has been stored up. Herein, the first part beginning with “dying”

original: vuttaṃ. Iminā pana padena yathākammūpagañāṇakiccaṃ.🔽Tassa ca ñāṇassa ayamuppattikkamo – idha bhikkhu heṭṭhānirayābhimukhaṃ ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: vuttam iminā pana padena yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa kiccam  tassa ca ñāṇassa ayam uppatti kkamaḥ idha bhikkhu heṭṭhāniraya abhimukham ālokam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: shows the function of the divine eye. But this phrase shows the function of knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings.

original: nerayike satte passati mahādukkhaṃ anubhavamāne, taṃ dassanaṃ dibbacakkhukiccameva.
analyzed: nerayike satte passati mahā dukkham anubhavamāne tam dassanam dibba cakkhu kiccam eva
translated: And the order of arising of this knowledge is as follows. Here a bhikkhu extends light downwards towards the hells and sees hell beings experiencing great suffering. That seeing is only the function of the divine eye.

original: So evaṃ manasi karoti “kiṃ nu kho kammaṃ katvā ime sattā etaṃ dukkhaṃ anubhavantī”ti,
analyzed: saḥ evam manasi karoti kim nu kho kammam katvā ime sattāḥ etam dukkham anubhavanti iti
translated: He gives attention to it thus: “What is the cause, what is the reason, why these beings experience such suffering?”

original: athassa “idaṃ nāma katvā”ti taṃ kammārammaṇaṃ ñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Tathā uparidevalokābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: athassa idam nāma katvā ati tam kamma ārammaṇam ñāṇam uppajjati tathā upari deva loka abhimukham
translated: Then knowledge arises in him with reference to that action, “This one did this and that.”

original: ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā nandanavana missakavana phārusakavanādīsu satte passati mahāsampattiṃ🔽anubhavamāne. Tampi dassanaṃ dibbacakkhukiccameva. So evaṃ manasi karoti “kiṃ nu🔽kho kammaṃ katvā ime sattā etaṃ sampattiṃ anubhavantī”ti. Athassa “idaṃ nāma katvā”ti
analyzed: ālokam vaḍḍhetvā nandana vana missaka vana phārusaka vana ādīsu satte passati mahā sampattim  anubhavamāne tam pi dassanam dibba cakkhu kiccam eva saḥ evam manasi karoti kim nu  kho kammam katvā ime sattāḥ etam sampattim anubhavanti iti atha assa idam nāma katvā ati
translated: Similarly, he extends light upwards towards the world of high deities, and he sees beings in the Nandana Grove, the Missaka Grove, the Phārusaka Grove, etc., experiencing the abundant happiness of the high deities.🔽That seeing is also the function of the divine eye. He considers thus, “What action did they perform by performing which they are now experiencing such and such a happiness?”

original: taṃ kammārammaṇaṃ ñāṇamuppajjati. Idaṃ yathākammūpagañāṇaṃ nāma. Imassa visuṃ parikammaṃ
analyzed: tam kamma ārammaṇam ñāṇam uppajjati idam yathā kammūpaga ñāṇam nāma imassa visum parikammaṃ
translated: Then knowledge arises in him with reference to that action, “This one did this and that.” This is called knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.🔽There is no separate preparatory task for this.

original: nāma natthi. Yathā ca imassa, evaṃ anāgataṃsañāṇassāpi. Dibbacakkhupādakāneva hi
analyzed: nāma natthi yathā ca imassa evam anāgataṃsa ñāṇassa api hi
translated: And just as there is not for this, so too there is not for knowledge of the future.

original: imāni dibbacakkhunā saheva ijjhanti.
analyzed: imāni dibba cakkhunā saha iva ijjhanti
translated: For these are successful only with the divine eye,🔽which is their basis.

original: Ime vata bhontotiādīsu imeti dibbacakkhunā diṭṭhānaṃ nidassanavacanaṃ. Vatāti anusocanatthe
analyzed: ime vata bhonto tiādīsu ime iti dibba cakkhunā diṭṭhānam nidassana vacanam vata ati anusocana atthe
translated: “These beings, friends, who…are reborn” : this is said in order to point out those seen with the divine eye.

original: nipāto. Bhontoti bhavanto. Duṭṭhu caritaṃ, duṭṭhuṃ vā caritaṃ kilesapūtikattāti duccaritaṃ;
analyzed: nipātaḥ bhonto ti bhavantaḥ duṭṭhu caritam duṭṭhum vā caritam kilesa pūti kattā ati duccaritam
translated: is a noun. Sirs, means sirs. Bad conduct is corrupt conduct, conduct that is corrupt with defilements.

original: kāyena duccaritaṃ, kāyato vā uppannaṃ duccaritanti kāyaduccaritaṃ. Itaresupi eseva
analyzed: kāyena duccaritam kāyataḥ vā uppannam duccaritam ti kāya duccaritam itaresu pi eṣā iva
translated: Bad conduct of body is bad conduct that arises in the body or bad conduct that arises from the body. The same method applies in the case of the other two kinds of conduct.

original: nayo. Samannāgatāti samaṅgībhūtā.🔽Ariyānaṃ upavādakāti buddhapaccekabuddhabuddhasāvakānaṃ ariyānaṃ antamaso gihisotāpannānampi
analyzed: samannāgatā ati  ariyānam upavādakā ati buddha paccekabuddha buddha sāvakānam ariyānam antamasaḥ gihi sotāpannānam pi
translated: Endowed with means possessed of.

original: anatthakāmā hutvā antimavatthunā vā guṇaparidhaṃsanena vā upavādakā, akkosakā garahakāti
analyzed: anattha kāmāḥ hutvā antima vatthunā vā guṇa paridhaṃsanena vā upavādakāḥ akkosakāḥ garahakā ati
translated: Reproving the Noble Ones means reproving the Noble Ones, the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples, and even the noble worldlings, the lay followers, by speaking unfavourably about them, either by way of the ultimate purport or by way of disparaging their special qualities.🔽They are reprovers, abusers, and finders of fault.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha “natthi imesaṃ samaṇadhammo, assamaṇā ete”ti vadanto antimavatthunā🔽upavadati. “Natthi imesaṃ jhānaṃ vā vimokkho vā maggo vā phalaṃ vā”tiādīni vadanto
analyzed: vuttam hoti tattha na atthi imesam samaṇa dhammo assamaṇāḥ ete iti vadantaḥ antima vatthunā  upavadati na atthi imesam jhānam vā vimokkhaḥ vā maggaḥ vā phalam vā ti ādīni vadantaḥ
translated: Herein, one who says, “There is no recluse-dhamma in them; they are not recluses,” reproves by way of the ultimate purport.🔽One who says, “There is no jhāna, or freedom, or path, or fruition in them,” reproves by way of disparaging their special qualities.

original: guṇaparidhaṃsanena upavadatīti veditabbo. So ca jhānaṃ vā upavadeyya ajhānaṃ vā,
analyzed: guṇa paridhaṃsanena upavadati iti veditabbaḥ saḥ ca jhānam vā upavadeyya ajhānam vā
translated: He may reprove by way of jhāna or by way of non-jhāna.

original: ubhayathāpi ariyūpavādova hoti; atibhāriyaṃ kammaṃ, anantariyakammasadisaṃ, saggāvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: ubhayathā api hoti atibhāriyam kammam anantariya kamma sadisam sagga āvaraṇam
translated: In both cases he is a corrupter of families and his action is very weighty, like the action of an immediate offense, a hindrance to heaven,

original: maggāvaraṇañca, satekicchaṃ pana hoti. Tasmā yo ariyaṃ upavadati, tena gantvā sace
analyzed: magga āvaraṇam ca sa tekiccham pana hoti tasmai yaḥ ariyam upavadati tena gantvā sace
translated: and a hindrance to the path. But it can be cured. Therefore, if anyone should corrupt a noble one, he should go to him

original: attanā vuḍḍhataro hoti, ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā “ahaṃ āyasmantaṃ idañcidañca avacaṃ,
analyzed: attanā vuḍḍhataraḥ hoti ukkuṭikam nisīditvā aham āyasmantam idañca idañca avacam
translated: and, if he is older, sit down cross-legged and say, “I said such and such to you, venerable sir.

original: taṃ me khamāhī”ti khamāpetabbo. Sace pana navakataro hoti, vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā
analyzed: tam me khamāhi iti khamāpetabbo sace pana navakataraḥ hoti vanditvā ukkuṭikam nisīditvā
translated: Please forgive me.” If he is younger, he should pay respect, sit down cross-legged,

original: añjaliṃ paggahetvā “ahaṃ, bhante, tumhe idañcidañca avacaṃ, taṃ me khamathā”ti khamāpetabbo.
analyzed: añjalim paggahetvā aham bhante tumhe idañca idañca avacam tam me khamatha ati khamāpetabbaḥ
translated: raise his joined palms, and say, “I said such and such to you, venerable sir. Please forgive me.”

original: Sace so nakkhamati, disāpakkanto vā hoti, sayaṃ vā gantvā saddhivihārike vā pesetvā
analyzed: sace so na khamati disā pakkantaḥ vā hoti sayam vā gantvā saddhivihārike vā pesetvā
translated: If the other does not forgive him, he should go to him or send a pupil or a student to him,🔽saying, “I said such and such to you, venerable sir.

original: khamāpetabbo. Sace nāpi gantuṃ na pesetuṃ sakkā hoti, ye tasmiṃ vihāre bhikkhū vasanti,
analyzed: khamāpetabbo sace na api gantum na pesetum sakkā hoti ye tasmin vihāre bhikkhū vasanti
translated: Please forgive me.” If he is unable to go or send a message, he should go to the monks in that monastery

original: tesaṃ santikaṃ gantvā sace navakatarā honti, ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā sace vuḍḍhatarā,
analyzed: tesam santikam gantvā sace navakatarāḥ honti ukkuṭikam nisīditvā sace vuḍḍhatarā
translated: and, if they are younger, sit down cross-legged and, if they are older,

original: vuḍḍhe vuttanayeneva paṭipajjitvā “ahaṃ, bhante, asukaṃ nāma āyasmantaṃ idañcidañca
analyzed: vuḍḍhe vutta nayena iva paṭipajjitvā aham bhante asukam nāma āyasmantam idañca idam ca
translated: If he is senior, he should conduct himself as already described and then say, “Venerable sir, I said so and so to the venerable one;

original: avacaṃ, taṃ khamatu me so āyasmā”ti vatvā khamāpetabbo. Sammukhā akhamantepi etadeva
analyzed: avacam tam khamatu me saḥ vatvā khamāpetabbaḥ sammukhāḥ a khamante pi etat eva
translated: may he forgive me” and ask for his forgiveness. If he does not forgive him in his presence, he should still do as already stated.

original: kātabbaṃ. Sace ekacārikabhikkhu hoti, neva tassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ na gataṭṭhānaṃ paññāyati,
analyzed: kātabbam sace ekacārika bhikkhu hoti na iva tassa vasana ṭṭhānam na gata ṭṭhānam paññāyati
translated: If he is a bhikkhu who goes about alone and it is not known where he lives or where he has gone,

original: ekassa paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno santikaṃ gantvā “ahaṃ, bhante, asukaṃ nāma āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: ekassa paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno santikam gantvā aham bhante asukam nāma āyasmantam
translated: he should go to a wise bhikkhu and say, “Venerable sir, I said so and so to the venerable one such and such;

original: idañcidañca avacaṃ, taṃ me anussarato anussarato vippaṭisāro hoti, kiṃ karomī”ti
analyzed: idam ca idam ca avacam tam me anussarataḥ anussarataḥ vippaṭisāraḥ hoti kim karomi iti
translated: as I keep remembering it, remorse keeps on occurring to me; what must I do?”

original: vattabbaṃ. So vakkhati “tumhe mā cintayittha, thero tumhākaṃ khamati, cittaṃ vūpasamethā”ti.
analyzed: vattabbam saḥ vakkhati tumhe mā cintayittha thero tumhākam khamati cittam vūpasametha ati
translated: The other will say, “Do not worry, venerable sir, the elder forgives you, your mind may be at ease.”

original: Tenapi ariyassa gatadisābhimukhena añjaliṃ paggahetvā “khamathā”ti vattabbaṃ. Yadi
analyzed: tena api ariyassa gata disa abhimukhena añjalim paggahetvā khamatha ati vattabbam yadi
translated: And he should say, “Forgive” with his hands raised palms together in the direction in which the other has gone. If

original: so parinibbuto hoti, parinibbutamañcaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā yāva sivathikaṃ gantvāpi khamāpetabbo.
analyzed: so parinibbutaḥ hoti parinibbuta mañca ṭṭhānam gantvā yāva sivathikam gantvā api khamāpetabbaḥ
translated: the other is fully extinguished, he should go to the place where the bed had been on which he was extinguished, and he should go as far as the cemetery where he was cremated and ask for his forgiveness.

original: Evaṃ kate neva saggāvaraṇaṃ na maggāvaraṇaṃ hoti, pākatikameva hotīti.
analyzed: evam kate na iva sagga āvaraṇam na magga āvaraṇam hoti pākatikam eva hoti iti
translated: When this is done, there is no obstruction to heaven or to the path, and the way is clear.

original: Micchādiṭṭhikāti viparītadassanā. Micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānāti micchādiṭṭhivasena
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhikā ati viparīta dassanā micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā ati micchādiṭṭhi vasena
translated: “Wrong view” is wrong insight. “Taking up what is due to wrong view” is the various kinds of kamma that are done by way of wrong view.

original: samādinnanānāvidhakammā, ye ca micchādiṭṭhimūlakesu kāyakammādīsu aññepi samādapenti.
analyzed: samādinna nānāvidha kammā ye ca micchādiṭṭhi mūlakesu kāya kamma ādīsu aññe pi samādapenti
translated: And those who encourage others in the kamma rooted in wrong view are also included.

original: Ettha ca vacīduccaritaggahaṇeneva ariyūpavāde, manoduccaritaggahaṇena ca micchādiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: ettha ca vacī duccarita ggahaṇena iva ariya upavāde manaḥ duccarita ggahaṇena ca micchādiṭṭhiyā
translated: And although the abuse of one who is worthy is included by the phrase “verbal misconduct,” and wrong view is included by the phrase “mental misconduct,”

original: saṅgahitāyapi imesaṃ dvinnaṃ punavacanaṃ mahāsāvajjabhāvadassanatthanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: imesam dvinnam punavacanam mahā sāvajja bhāva dassana atthan ti veditabbam
translated: the repetition of these two phrases should be understood to show their great harmfulness.

original: Mahāsāvajjo hi ariyūpavādo ānantariyasadiso. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: mahā sāvajjaḥ hi ānantariya sadisaḥ
translated: For the abuse of one who is worthy is extremely harmful, being comparable to the immediate offenses . And this is said:

original: “Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva
analyzed: seyyathā api sāriputta bhikkhu sīla sampannaḥ samādhi sampannaḥ paññā sampannaḥ diṭṭhā iva
translated: “Sariputta, suppose a bhikkhu possessed of virtue, concentration, and wisdom were to attain final knowledge in this very life.

original: dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya, evaṃsampadamidaṃ, sāriputta, vadāmi. Taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ
analyzed: dhamme aññam ārādheyye evaṃsampadam idam sāriputta vadāmi tam vācam appahāya tam
translated: If he were not to abandon that talk,

original: cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye”ti.
analyzed: cittam appahāya tam diṭṭhim a paṭinissajjitvā yathābhatam nikkhittaḥ evam niraya iti
translated: and he will be cast into hell as he deserves for not abandoning that view and that thought.”

original: Micchādiṭṭhito ca mahāsāvajjataraṃ nāma aññaṃ natthi. Yathāha –
analyzed: micchā diṭṭhito ca mahāsāvajjataram nāma aññam natthi yathā āha
translated: And there is nothing more blameworthy than wrong view, as is said:

original: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃmahāsāvajjaṃ yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, micchādiṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhiparamāni bhikkhave, mahāsāvajjānī”ti.
analyzed: na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evaṃmahāsāvajjam yathā yidam bhikkhave micchādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi paramāni bhikkhave mahāsāvajjāni iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, I do not consider even the slightest thing that is more blameworthy than wrong view. Wrong view is the most blameworthy.”

original: Kāyassa bhedāti upādinnakkhandhapariccāgā. Paraṃ maraṇāti tadanantarābhinibbattakkhandhaggahaṇe.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā ati upādinna kkhandha pariccāgā param maraṇā ati tad anantara abhinibbatta kkhandha ggahaṇe
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death: with the giving up of the life faculty at the breakup of the aggregates acquired through kamma that has reached its culmination.🔽Or alternatively, with the breakup of the body means with the severence of the life faculty. After death means after the death consciousness.

original: Atha vā kāyassa bhedāti jīvitindriyassupacchedā. Paraṃ maraṇāti cuticittato uddhaṃ.
analyzed: atha vā kāyassa param maraṇā ati cuti cittataḥ
translated: Or again, with the breakup of the body means with the cutting off of the life faculty. After death means after the death consciousness.

original: Apāyanti evamādi sabbaṃ nirayavevacanameva. Nirayo hi saggamokkhahetubhūtā puññasammatā
analyzed: apāyanti evamādi sabbam niraya vevacanam eva nirayaḥ hi saggamokkha hetu bhūtā puñña sammatā
translated: The states of deprivation, etc., are all synonyms for hell. For hell is a state of deprivation because it is the non-arrival at merit, which is the arrival at a good destination,

original: ayā apetattā, sukhānaṃ vā āyassa abhāvā apāyo. Dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti duggati,
analyzed: ayā apeta ttā sukhānam vā āyassa abhāvā apāyaḥ dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti duggati
translated: or because of the absence of pleasure; it is a bad destination because it is the going and reappearance in an evil place,

original: dosabahulatāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā gatīti duggati. Vivasā nipatanti tattha
analyzed: dosa bahula tāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā gatīti duggati vivasāḥ nipatanti tattha
translated: Or alternatively, it is a state of loss because it is a destination produced by kamma that is corrupted by the corruption of hate, which is abundant there.🔽It is a bad destination because bad people go there.

original: dukkaṭakārinoti vinipāto, vinassantā vā ettha nipatanti sambhijjamānaṅgapaccaṅgātipi
analyzed: dukkaṭa kārino ti vinipātaḥ vinassantāḥ vai ettha nipatanti
translated: It is a downfall because evil-doers fall into it, or because the limbs and minor parts of the body are broken there.

original: vinipāto. Natthi ettha assādasaññito ayoti nirayo.
analyzed: vinipātaḥ na atthi ettha assāda saññitaḥ ayaḥ ti nirayo
translated: It is hell because there is no delight there.

original: Atha vā apāyaggahaṇena tiracchānayoniṃ dīpeti, tiracchānayoni hi apāyo sugatito apetattā.
analyzed: atha vā apāya ggahaṇena tiracchānayonim dīpeti tiracchānayoni hi apāyaḥ sugatitaḥ apeta tā
translated: Or alternatively, by the word “states of loss” he shows the animal generation, for that is a state of loss since it has departed from the happy destinies.

original: Na duggati, mahesakkhānaṃ nāgarājādīnaṃ sambhavato. Duggatiggahaṇena pettivisayaṃ
analyzed: na duggati mahesakkhānam nāga rāja ādīnam sambhavataḥ duggati ggahaṇena petti visayam
translated: It is not a bad destination, because of the existence there of such mighty beings as the Nāga kings.

original: dīpeti, so hi apāyo ceva duggati ca sukhato apetattā dukkhassa ca gatibhūtattā, na
analyzed: dīpeti saḥ hi apāyaḥ ca iva duggati ca sukhataḥ apeta ttā dukkhassa ca gati bhūta ttā na
translated: By the word “bad destinations” he shows the ghost realm, for that is a state of loss and a bad destination since it has departed from happiness and is a destination for suffering.🔽But it is not a downfall, because it does not fall like the Asura generation.

original: tu vinipāto, asurakāyasadisaṃ avinipatitattā. Vinipātaggahaṇena asurakāyaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: tu vinipātaḥ asura kāya sadisam a vinipatita ttā vinipāta ggahaṇena asura kāyam dīpeti
translated: By the word “downfalls” he shows the Asura generation.

original: So hi yathāvuttena atthena apāyo ceva duggati ca sabbasamussayehi ca vinipatitattā
analyzed: so hi yathā vuttena atthena apāyaḥ ca iva duggati ca sabba samussayehi ca vinipatita ttā
translated: For that is a state of loss and a bad destination in the way already stated, and it is a downfall because it has fallen into the general misfortune of all the unhappy destinies.

original: vinipātoti vuccati. Nirayaggahaṇena avīciādianekappakāraṃ nirayameva dīpetīti. Upapannāti
analyzed: vinipāto ti vuccati niraya ggahaṇena avīci ādi aneka ppakāram nirayam eva dīpeti iti upapannā ati
translated: is called the ‘downfall.’ By the word ‘hell’ is meant the various kinds of hell such as the Avīci Hell, etc.

original: upagatā, tattha abhinibbattāti adhippāyo. Vuttavipariyāyena sukkapakkho veditabbo.
analyzed: upagatā tattha abhinibbattā ti adhippāyaḥ vutta vipariyāyena sukkapakkhaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: ‘Have been reborn’ : the meaning is, have gone there and been reborn there. The bright side should be understood in the opposite sense.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – tattha sugatiggahaṇena manussagatipi saṅgayhati. Saggaggahaṇena
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ tattha sugati ggahaṇena manussa gati pi saṅgayhati sagga ggahaṇena
translated: But there is this difference: by the word ‘good destination’ the human destination is also included,🔽and by the word ‘heaven’ only the divine destination.

original: devagatiyeva. Tattha sundarā gatīti sugati. Rūpādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu aggoti saggo.
analyzed: deva gatiyā iva tattha sundarā gatī iti sugati rūpa ādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu aggo ti saggo
translated: Herein, ‘good destination’ is a good destination because it is a beautiful destination . ‘Heaven’ is a place where one goes well , that is, by means of the vehicle of jhāna and path.

original: So sabbopi lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti ayaṃ vacanattho. Iti dibbena cakkhunātiādi🔽sabbaṃ nigamanavacanaṃ.🔽Evaṃ dibbena cakkhunā passatīti ayamettha saṅkhepattho – dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ parittapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena
analyzed: so sabbaḥ api lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena loko ti ayam vacana atthaḥ iti dibbena cakkhunā atiādi  sabbam nigamana vacanam  evam dibbena cakkhunā passati iti ayam ettha saṅkhepa atthaḥ dibba cakkhu ñāṇam paritta paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena
translated: All that is called ‘world’ in the sense of being subject to pressure and counter-pressure . This is the word meaning.🔽‘Thus with the divine eye’ and so on is the summing up.🔽The condensed meaning here is this: knowledge of the divine eye occurs with respect to four objects, namely, as limited, as exalted, as past, and as present, internal and external.

original: catūsu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Yathākammūpagañāṇaṃ parittamahaggatātītaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena
analyzed: catūsu ārammaṇesu pavattati yathā kammūpaga ñāṇam paritta mahaggata atīta ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena
translated: Knowledge of passing away and reappearance occurs with respect to three objects, namely, as limited, as exalted, and as past, internal and external.

original: pañcasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Anāgataṃsañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataappamāṇamaggaanāgataajjhattabahiddhānavattabbārammaṇavasena
analyzed: pañcasu ārammaṇesu pavattati anāgataṃsañāṇam paritta mahaggata appamāṇa magga anāgata ajjhatta bahiddhā anavattabba ārammaṇa vasena
translated: It occurs with respect to five objects. Knowledge of the future occurs with respect to the limited, exalted, and measureless, the path, the future, internally, externally, and not so classifiable.

original: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattatīti.
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati iti
translated: It occurs with respect to five objects. Knowledge of the future occurs with respect to eight objects: the limited, exalted, and measureless, the path, the future, the internal, the external, and the not-so-classifiable.

original: Ākaṅkhamāno ca bhagavāti bhagavā icchamāno. Ekampi lokadhātuṃ passeyyāti ekaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ🔽olokeyya. Sahassimpi cūḷanikanti ettha yāvatā candimasūriyā pariharanti, disā bhānti🔽virocamānā, tāva sahassadhā loko, esā sahassicūḷanikā nāma. Cūḷanikanti khuddakaṃ.🔽Dvisahassimpi majjhimikaṃ lokadhātunti ettha sahassacakkavāḷānaṃ sahassabhāgena gaṇetvā
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānaḥ ca bhagavā ati bhagavā icchamānaḥ ekam pi lokadhātum passeyya ati ekam cakkavāḷam  ettha yāvatā candima sūriyā pariharanti disā bhānti  virocamānā tāva sahassadhā lokaḥ esā sahassicūḷanikā nāma cūḷanikam ti khuddakam  dvi sahassim pi majjhimikam lokadhātun ti ettha sahassa cakkavāḷānam sahassa bhāgena gaṇetvā
translated: “If he wishes, the Blessed One can see one world-element”: if he wishes, he can see one world-sphere.🔽“A small chiliocosm”: the small chiliocosm is a thousand worlds of the size of our world-sphere.🔽“A medium dichiliocosm”: the medium dichiliocosm is a world-sphere of two thousand worlds.

original: dasasatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇā dvisahassī majjhimikā lokadhātu nāma. Ettakena buddhānaṃ
analyzed: dasa sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇā dvi sahassī majjhimikā lokadhātu nāma ettakena buddhānam
translated: “A great trichiliocosm”: the great trichiliocosm is a world-sphere of three thousand worlds.

original: jātikkhettaṃ nāma dassitaṃ. Bodhisattānañhi pacchimabhave devalokato cavitvā mātukucchiyaṃ
analyzed: jātikkhettam nāma dassitam bodhisattānam hi pacchima bhave deva lokataḥ cavitvā mātukucchiyam
translated: “The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes”: the Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can see as far as he wishes. The Blessed One can

original: paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase ca mātukucchito nikkhamanadivase ca mahābhinikkhamanadivase
analyzed: paṭisandhi ggahaṇa divase ca mātukucchitaḥ nikkhamana divase ca mahā abhinikkhamana divase
translated: and on the day of his conception, on the day of his birth, on the day of his Great Renunciation,

original: ca sambodhidhammacakkapavattanaāyusaṅkhārossajjanaparinibbānadivasesu ca ettakaṃ ṭhānaṃ kampati.
analyzed: ca sambodhi dhamma cakka pavattana āyu saṅkhāra ussajjana parinibbāna divasesu ca ettakam ṭhānam kampati
translated: on the day of his enlightenment, on the day of his setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma, on the day of his laying down the life-term, and on the day of his final extinction, this extent of earth quaked.

original: Tisahassimpi. Mahāsahassimpi lokadhātunti sahassito paṭṭhāya tatiyāti tisahassī,
analyzed: ti sahassim pi mahā sahassim pi lokadhātunti sahassitaḥ paṭṭhāya tatiyā ati ti sahassī
translated: Tisahassimpi. Mahāsahassimpi lokadhātunti Sahassito paṭṭhāya tatiyāti tisahassī,

original: paṭhamasahassiṃ sahassadhā katvā gaṇitaṃ majjhimikaṃ sahassadhā katvā gaṇitattā mahantehi
analyzed: paṭhama sahassim sahassadhā katvā gaṇitam majjhimikam sahassadhā katvā gaṇita ttā mahantehi
translated: Paṭhamasahassiṃ sahassadhā katvā gaṇitaṃ majjhimikaṃ sahassadhā katvā gaṇitattā mahante

original: sahassehi gaṇitāti mahāsahassī. Ettāvatā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇo loko dassito
analyzed: sahassehi gaṇitā ati mahā sahassī ettāvatā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇaḥ lokaḥ dassitaḥ
translated: Sahassehi gaṇitāti mahāsahassī. Ettāvatā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇo loko dassito

original: hoti. Gaṇakaputtatissatthero pana evamāha – “na hi tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuyā
analyzed: hoti gaṇakaputta tissa theraḥ pana evam āha na hi ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātuyā
translated: Hoti. Gaṇakaputtatissatthero pana evamāha— “Na hi tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuyā

original: etaṃ parimāṇaṃ. Idañhi ācariyānaṃ sajjhāyamūlakaṃ vācāya parihīnaṭṭhānaṃ, dasakoṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇaṃ
analyzed: etam parimāṇam idam hi ācariyānam sajjhāya mūlakam vācāya parihīna ṭṭhānam dasa koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇam
translated: Etaṃ parimāṇaṃ. Idañhi ācariyānaṃ sajjhāyamūlakaṃ vācāya parihīnaṭṭhānaṃ, dasakoṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇaṃ

original: pana ṭhānaṃ tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātu nāmā”ti. Ettāvatā hi bhagavato āṇākkhettaṃ
analyzed: pana ṭhānam ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātu nāma ati ettāvatā hi bhagavataḥ āṇā kkhettam
translated: but the world system consisting of a thousand times a thousand worlds is called a great world system.”🔽For this much is the extent of the Blessed One’s range of authority.

original: nāma dassitaṃ. Etasmiñhi antare āṭānāṭiyaparitta- isigiliparitta- dhajaggaparitta-
analyzed: nāma dassitam etasmin hi antare āṭānāṭiya paritta isigili paritta dhajagga paritta
translated: For the protection given by the Āṭānāṭiya, Isigili, Dhajagga,

original: bojjhaṅgaparittakhandhaparitta- moraparitta- mettaparitta- ratanaparittānaṃ āṇā pharati.
analyzed: bojjhaṅga paritta khandha paritta mora paritta metta paritta ratana parittānam āṇā pharati
translated: Bojjhaṅga, Khandha, Mora, Metta, and Ratana Suttas extends as far as this great world system.

original: Yāvatakaṃ vā pana ākaṅkheyyāti yattakaṃ vā iccheyya. Iminā visayakkhettaṃ dassitaṃ.
analyzed: yāvatakam vā pana ākaṅkheyya ati yattakam vā iccheyya iminā visaya khettam dassitam
translated: “As far as he wishes”: as far as he desires. This shows the extent of the range of his knowledge.

original: Buddhānañhi visayakkhettassa pamāṇaparicchedo nāma natthi, natthikabhāve cassa imaṃ
analyzed: buddhānam hi visaya kkhettassa pamāṇa paricchedaḥ nāma natthi natthika bhāve ca ssa imaṃ
translated: For the range of the Buddhas’ knowledge is not limited by any such divisions as “the great world system,” “a thousand worlds,” “a million worlds,” etc.;🔽and in order to illustrate this fact they cite this simile:

original: upamaṃ āharanti – koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷamhi yāva brahmalokā sāsapehi pūretvā sace
analyzed: upamam āharanti koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷamhi yāva brahmalokā sāsapehi pūretvā sace
translated: If all the worlds in a system of a thousand million worlds were filled with water,

original: koci puratthimāya disāya ekacakkavāḷe ekaṃ sāsapaṃ pakkhipanto āgaccheyya, sabbepi
analyzed: koci puratthimāya disāya eka cakkavāḷe ekam sāsapam pakkhipantaḥ āgaccheyya sabbe pi
translated: and if someone were to drop into them a single grain of mustard seed for every world,🔽all those grains of mustard seed would be exhausted, but the worlds would not be exhausted.

original: te sāsapā parikkhayaṃ gaccheyyuṃ. Na tveva puratthimāya disāya cakkavāḷāni. Dakkhiṇādīsupi
analyzed: te sāsapā parikkhayam gaccheyyum na tu eva puratthimāya disāya cakkavāḷāni dakkhiṇa ādīsu pi
translated: And so it is with the worlds in the southern, western, and northern directions,

original: eseva nayo. Tattha buddhānaṃ avisayo nāma natthi. Tāvatakaṃ passeyyāti tattakaṃ olokeyya.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tattha buddhānam avisayaḥ nāma natthi tāvatakam passeyya ati tattakam olokeyya
translated: and so on. Herein, there is nothing that is beyond the Buddhas’ range of knowledge. As far as he can see: he would see as far as that.

original: Evaṃ parisuddhaṃ bhagavato dibbacakkhūti dibbacakkhukathaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: evam parisuddham bhagavataḥ dibba cakkhu iti dibba cakkhu katham niṭṭhāpesi
translated: So his divine eye is quite purified. He concluded the discussion of the divine eye.

original: Kathaṃ bhagavā paññācakkhunāpi vivaṭacakkhūti kenappakārena paññācakkhunā apihitacakkhu?
analyzed: katham bhagavā paññā cakkhunā api vivaṭa cakkhu iti kenappakārena paññā cakkhunā apihita cakkhu
translated: How is it that the Blessed One is also open-eyed with the eye of understanding? In what way is he open-eyed with the eye of understanding?

original: Mahāpañño puthupaññotiādikaṃ tattha atirocati yadidaṃ paññāyāti pariyosānaṃ heṭṭhā vuttatthameva.
analyzed: mahāpañño puthu pañño ti ādikam tattha atirocati yat idam paññāya āti pariyosānam heṭṭhā vutta ttham eva
translated: The passage beginning “He has great understanding, wide understanding” and ending “The Blessed One shines among the multitude” is of the same meaning as the passage quoted above .

original: Buddhacakkhunāti indriyaparopariyattañāṇena ca āsayānusayañāṇena ca. Imesaṃ dvinnaṃ🔽ñāṇānaṃ buddhacakkhūti nāmaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇassa samantacakkhūti, tiṇṇaṃ maggañāṇānaṃ
analyzed: buddha cakkhunā ti indriya para upari yatta ñāṇena ca āsaya anusaya ñāṇena ca imesam dvinnam  ñāṇānam buddha cakkhū iti nāmam sabbaññuta ññāṇassa samanta cakkhū iti tiṇṇam magga ñāṇānam
translated: The Buddha eye is the name for the two kinds of knowledge, namely, knowledge of penetration of the minds of others and knowledge of the memories of past lives.🔽The name “all-seeing eye” is that for the knowledge of omniscience. The name “eye of Dhamma” is that for the three kinds of knowledge,🔽namely, knowledge of the way things are , knowledge of the way things become , and knowledge of the past .

original: dhammacakkhūti. Lokaṃ volokento addasa satteti satte addakkhi. Apparajakkhetiādīsu
analyzed: dhammacakkhū ti lokam volokentaḥ addasa satta iti satte addakkhi apparajakkha iti ādīsu
translated: Looking down upon the world with the eye of understanding, he saw that some beings had little dust on their eyes,

original: yesaṃ vuttanayeneva paññācakkhumhi rāgādirajaṃ appaṃ, te apparajakkhā. Yesaṃ taṃ
analyzed: yesam vutta nayena iva paññā cakkhumhi rāga ādi rajam appam te apparajakkhāḥ yesam tam
translated: and so on. Those in whom, in the way already stated, the dust of greed, etc., is small are those “with little dust on their eyes.” Those in whom it is large are those “with much dust on their eyes.”

original: mahantaṃ, te mahārajakkhā. Yesaṃ saddhādīni indriyāni tikkhāni, te tikkhindriyā.
analyzed: mahantam te mahārajakkhāḥ yesam saddhā ādīni indriyāni tikkhāni te tikkhindriyāḥ
translated: are of great value, Great King. Those who have keen faculties of faith, etc., are of keen faculties.

original: Yesaṃ tāni mudūni, te mudindriyā. Yesaṃ teyeva saddhādayo ākārā sundarā, te svākārā.
analyzed: tāni mudūni te mud indriyāḥ yesam teyā iva saddha ādayaḥ ākārā sundarā te su ākārā
translated: Those who have weak faculties are of weak faculties. Those who have beautiful aspects of faith, etc., are of beautiful aspects.

original: Ye kathitakāraṇaṃ sallakkhenti, sukhena sakkā honti viññāpetuṃ te suviññāpayā. Ye
analyzed: ye kathita kāraṇam sallakkhenti sukhena sakkāḥ honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayāḥ ye
translated: Those who can be easily addressed, who can be advised by being told the reason for what is said, are of easy-to-admonish nature.

original: paralokañceva vajjañca bhayato passanti, te paralokavajjabhayadassāvino nāma.🔽Uppaliniyanti uppalavane. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Antonimuggaposīnīti yāni antonimuggāneva🔽posiyanti. Udakaṃ accuggamma tiṭṭhantīti udakaṃ atikkamitvā tiṭṭhanti. Tattha yāni
analyzed: para lokañca iva vajjañca bhayataḥ passanti te para loka vajja bhaya dassāvinaḥ nāma  uppaliniyanti uppala vane itaresu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ antonimugga posīni iti yāni  posiyanti udakam accuggamma tiṭṭhanti iti udakam atikkamitvā tiṭṭhanti tattha yāni
translated: Those who see the other world and the danger in evil are called “seers of the other world and the danger in evil.”🔽“In the lotus pond” means in the lotus grove. The same method applies to the rest. “With their heads turned inward and their faces turned inward” means that they are nourished with their heads turned inward.

original: yāni accuggamma ṭhitāni, tāni tāni sūriyarasmisamphassaṃ āgamayamānāni ṭhitāni ajja
analyzed: yāni accuggamma ṭhitāni tāni tāni sūriya rasmi samphassam āgamayamānāni ṭhitāni ajja
translated: “They stand with their heads above the water” means that they stand above the water. Therein, those that stand with their heads above the water, being struck by the sun’s rays, stand as if they were today’s flowers.

original: pupphanakāni. Yāni samodakaṃ ṭhitāni, tāni sve pupphanakāni. Yāni udakā anuggatāni
analyzed: pupphanakāni yāni samodakam ṭhitāni tāni sve pupphanakāni yāni udakā anuggatāni
translated: Those that stand with their heads in the water will be tomorrow’s flowers. Those that are submerged in the water

original: antonimuggaposīni, tāni tatiyadivaseva pupphanakāni. Udakā pana anuggatāni aññānipi
analyzed: tāni tatiya divasā iva pupphanakāni udakā pana anuggatāni aññāni pi
translated: and the water-lilies with their buds inside, which will flower on the third day. But the water is continuous.

original: sarogauppalāni nāma atthi, yāni neva pupphissanti, macchakacchapabhakkhāneva bhavissanti,
analyzed: sa roga auppalāni nāma atthi yāni na iva pupphissanti maccha kacchapa bhakkhānā iva bhavissanti
translated: There are also water-lilies without flowers, which will never flower, but will only be eaten by fish and turtles.

original: tāni pāḷiṃ nārūḷhāni, āharitvā pana dīpetabbānīti dīpitāni.🔽Yatheva hi tāni catubbidhapupphāni, evameva ugghaṭitaññū vipañcitaññū neyyo padaparamoti
analyzed: tāni pāḷim na ārūḍhāni āharitvā pana dīpetabbāni iti dīpitāni  yathā iva hi tāni catubbidha pupphāni evam eva ugghaṭita ññū vipañcita ññū neyyaḥ pada paramaḥ ti
translated: They are not mentioned in the text, but they are implied by the word ‘etc.’.🔽Just as there are these four kinds of flowers, so there are four kinds of persons:🔽The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the Dhamma is taught in brief is called

original: cattāro puggalā. Yassa puggalassa udāhaṭavelāya dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ vuccati🔽puggalo ugghaṭitaññū. Yassa puggalassa saṃkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthe vibhajīyamāne
analyzed: cattāro puggalāḥ yassa puggalassa udāhaṭa velāya dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati  puggalaḥ ugghaṭita ññū yassa puggalassa saṃkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthe vibhajīyamāne
translated: a person who understands from a condensed statement. The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the meaning of the condensed statement is explained in detail is called🔽a person who understands from an expanded statement. The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the Dhamma is taught by way of a summary is called

original: dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo vipañcitaññū. Yassa puggalassa uddesato
analyzed: dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati puggalo vipañcitaññū yassa puggalassa uddesato
translated: a person who is led by the summary. The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the Dhamma is taught by way of questions and careful attention is called

original: paripucchato yoniso manasikaroto kalyāṇamitte sevato bhajato payirupāsato dhammābhisamayo
analyzed: paripucchataḥ yonisaḥ manasikarotaḥ kalyāṇa mitte sevataḥ bhajataḥ payis upāsataḥ dhamma abhisamayo
translated: a person who is led by questions. The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when he associates with, attends upon, and serves good friends is called🔽a person who is led by association.

original: hoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo neyyo. Yassa puggalassa bahumpi suṇato bahumpi bhaṇato🔽bahumpi dhārayato bahumpi vācato na tāya jātiyā dhammābhisamayo hoti, ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: hoti ayam vuccati puggalaḥ neyyaḥ yassa puggalassa bahum pi suṇataḥ bahum pi bhaṇataḥ  bahum pi dhārayataḥ bahum pi vācataḥ na tāya jātiyā dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati
translated: this person is called one who is led. In the case of the person who, though he listens to much, recites much,

original: puggalo padaparamo. Tattha bhagavā uppalavanādisadisaṃ dasasahassilokadhātuṃ olokento🔽ajja pupphanakāni ugghaṭitaññū, sve pupphanakāni vipañcitaññūti evaṃ sabbākārato
analyzed: puggalaḥ pada paramaḥ tattha bhagavā uppala vana ādi sadisam dasa sahassi lokadhātum olokento  ajja pupphanakāni ugghaṭita ññū sve pupphanakāni vipañcita ññū ti evam sabba ākārataḥ
translated: remembers much, and speaks much, there is no penetration of the Dhamma in this very life, this person is called one who is at the level of the words. There the Blessed One, looking over the ten-thousand world-element like a blue lotus-bed,

original: ca addasa. Tattha tiṇṇaṃ puggalānaṃ imasmiṃyeva attabhāve bhagavato dhammadesanā
analyzed: ca addasa tattha tiṇṇam puggalānam imasmin yeva atta bhāve bhagavataḥ dhamma desanā
translated: saw in all aspects that today the flower-buds are those who are quick in understanding, and tomorrow the flower-buds are those who are analytical. There the teaching of the Dhamma by the Blessed One in this very life succeeds in the case of three persons,

original: atthaṃ sādheti, padaparamānaṃ anāgatatthāya vāsanā hoti.🔽Rāgacaritotiādīsu rajjanavasena ārammaṇe caraṇaṃ etassa atthīti rāgacarito. Dussanavasena
analyzed: attham sādha iti anāgata tthāya vāsanā hoti  rāga caritaḥ ti ādīsu rajjana vasena ārammaṇe caraṇam etassa atthi iti rāga caritaḥ dussana vasena
translated: and in the case of one who is at the level of the words it becomes a perfume for the future.

original: ārammaṇe caraṇaṃ etassa atthīti dosacarito. Muyhanavasena ārammaṇe caraṇaṃ etassa
analyzed: ārammaṇe caraṇam etassa atthi iti dosa caritaḥ muyhana vasena ārammaṇe caraṇam etassa
translated: In the case of the person who is of lustful temperament, etc., there is the act of going in the object by way of lust, thus he is of lustful temperament. There is the act of going in the object by way of hatred, thus he is of hating temperament. There is the act of going in the object by way of delusion, thus he is of deluded temperament.

original: atthīti mohacarito. Vitakkanavasena ūhanavasena ārammaṇe caraṇaṃ etassa atthīti vitakkacarito.
analyzed: atthi iti moha caritaḥ vitakkana vasena ūhana vasena ārammaṇe caraṇam etassa atthi iti vitakka caritaḥ
translated: He has the mode of conceiving in the sense of thinking and in the sense of surmounting, thus he is a conceiver.

original: Okappanasaddhāvasena ārammaṇe caraṇaṃ etassa atthīti saddhācarito. Ñāṇameva caraṇaṃ,
analyzed: okappana saddhā vasena ārammaṇe caraṇam etassa atthi iti saddhā caritaḥ ñāṇam eva caraṇam
translated: He has the mode of conceiving in the sense of looking, thus he is a looker-on.

original: ñāṇena vā caraṇaṃ, ñāṇassa vā caraṇaṃ, ñāṇato vā caraṇaṃ etassa atthīti ñāṇacarito.
analyzed: ñāṇena vā caraṇam ñāṇassa vā caraṇam ñāṇataḥ vā caraṇam etassa atthi iti ñāṇa caritaḥ
translated: He has the mode of knowing, or he has the mode of conduct by means of knowing, or he has the mode of conduct from knowing, thus he is a knower.

original: Rāgacaritassāti rāgussadassa rāgabahulassa. Paratopi eseva nayo.
analyzed: rāga caritassa ati rāga ussadassa rāga bahulassa paratas pi esa iva nayo
translated: Of one of greedy temperament: of one with a predominance of greed, of one who has much greed. The same method applies in each instance.

original: Asubhakathaṃ kathetīti uddhumātakādidasavidhaṃ asubhapaṭisaṃyuttakathaṃ ācikkhati.🔽Vuttañhetaṃ – “asubhā bhāvetabbā rāgassa pahānāyā”ti. Mettābhāvanaṃ ācikkhatīti mettābhāvanaṃ
analyzed: asubha katham kathā iti iti uddhumātaka ādi dasavidham asubha paṭisaṃyutta katham ācikkhati  vuttam ha etam asubhā bhāvetabbā rāgassa pahānāya ati mettā bhāvanam ācikkhati iti mettā bhāvanam
translated: He expounds the meditation subject beginning with the bloated: he explains the talk connected with the meditation subject beginning with the bloated.🔽For this is said: “The meditation subject should be developed for the abandoning of lust” . He expounds the development of loving-kindness: he expounds the development of loving-kindness, which is the endearing of the mind.

original: cittasinehanaṃ katheti. Vuttañhetaṃ – “mettā bhāvetabbā byāpādassa pahānāyā”ti. Uddeseti
analyzed: citta sinehanam kathā iti vuttam ha etam mettā bhāvetabbā byāpādassa pahānāya ati uddeseti
translated: For this is said: “The meditation subject should be developed for the abandoning of ill will” . In the recitation:

original: sajjhāyane. Paripucchāyāti aṭṭhakathāya. Kālena dhammassavaneti yuttappattakāle uttari
analyzed: sajjhāyane paripucchāya ati aṭṭhakathāya kālena dhammassavane iti yuttappatta kāle uttari
translated: in the learning. In the questioning: in the commentaries. In listening to the Dhamma at the proper time: at the time suitable for it,

original: pariyattidhammassavane. Dhammasākacchāyāti aññehi saddhiṃ sākacchāya. Garusaṃvāseti
analyzed: pariyatti dhamma ssavane dhamma sākacchāya ati aññehi saddhim sākacchāya garu saṃvāsa iti
translated: In listening to the Dhamma of the scriptures. In discussion of the Dhamma: in discussion with others. In living with the elders:

original: garūnaṃ payirupāsane. Nivesetīti ācariyānaṃ santike patiṭṭhāpeti. Ānāpānassatiṃ ācikkhatīti
analyzed: garūnam payirupāsane niveseti iti ācariyānam santike patiṭṭhāpeti āna apāna ssatim ācikkhati iti
translated: in attending on the elders. He establishes: he establishes in the presence of the teachers. He teaches mindfulness of breathing:

original: ānāpānassatisampayuttakammaṭṭhānaṃ katheti. Vuttañhetaṃ – “ānāpānassati bhāvetabbā
analyzed: āna apāna ssati sampayutta kammaṭṭhānam kathā iti vuttam ha etam āna apāna ssati bhāvetabbā
translated: he explains the meditation subject consisting of mindfulness of breathing. For this is said: “Mindfulness of breathing should be developed.

original: vitakkupacchedāyā”ti. Pasādanīyaṃ nimittaṃ ācikkhatīti cūḷavedalla- mahāvedallā-
analyzed: vitakka upacchedāya ati pasādanīyam nimittam ācikkhati iti cūḷavedalla mahāvedallā
translated: It is directly effective here and now, sublime, inviting, peaceful, productive of the deathless, and it is rightly expounded. It is a pleasant abiding that is noble and emancipating, and it leads to the complete destruction of suffering” . He teaches a sign that inspires confidence: he explains the Cūḷavedalla, the Mahāvedalla,

original: dipasādajanakaṃ suttaṃ katheti. Buddhasubodhinti buddhassa bhagavato buddhattapaṭivedhaṃ.
analyzed: dipasāda janakam suttam kathā iti buddha su bodhinti buddhassa bhagavataḥ buddha tta paṭivedham
translated: and the Discourse on the Simile of the Jewel . The enlightenment of the Enlightened One: the penetration of the Enlightened One, the Blessed One, to the supreme enlightenment.

original: Dhammasudhammatanti navavidhalokuttaradhammassa svākkhātataṃ. Saṅghasuppaṭipattinti
analyzed: dhamma su dhamma tanti navavidha lokuttara dhammassa su ākkhāta tam saṅgha su paṭipattiṃ ti
translated: The true nature of the Dhamma: the well-proclaimedness of the ninefold supramundane Dhamma. The good practice of the Community:

original: aṭṭhavidhaariyasaṅghassa suppaṭipannatādisuṭṭhupaṭipattiṃ. Sīlāni ca attanoti attano
analyzed: aṭṭhavidha ariya saṅghassa suppaṭipanna tā ādi suṭṭhu paṭipattim sīlāni ca attanoti attano
translated: the good practice of the eight-fold noble Community, their good way of life. And his own virtue:

original: santakasīlāni ca. Ācikkhati vipassanānimittanti udayabbayādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ katheti.
analyzed: santaka sīlāni ca ācikkhati vipassanā nimittam ti udaya bbaya ādi paṭisaṃyuttam kathā iti
translated: and his own virtue that is fulfilled. He teaches the sign of insight: he explains the rise and fall, etc., of the five aggregates.

original: Aniccākāranti hutvā abhāvākāraṃ. Dukkhākāranti udayabbayapaṭipīḷanākāraṃ. Anattākāranti avasavattanākāraṃ.
analyzed: anicca ākāranti hutvā abhāva ākāram dukkha ākāranti udaya bbaya paṭipīḷana ākāram anatta ākāranti a vasavattana ākāram
translated: The aspect of impermanence is the aspect of non-existence after having been. The aspect of pain is the aspect of oppression by rise and fall. The aspect of not-self is the aspect of non-existence as self.

original: Sele yathā pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhitoti selamaye ekagghane pabbatamuddhani ṭhitova, na🔽hi tattha ṭhitassa dassanatthaṃ abhimukhe gīvukkhipanapasāraṇādikiccaṃ atthi. Tathūpamanti
analyzed: sele yathā pabbata muddhani ṭṭhito ti sela maye ekagghane pabbata muddhani ṭhitaḥ uva na  hi tattha ṭhitassa dassana attham abhimukhe gīvukkhipana pasāraṇa ādi kiccam atthi tathūpamanti
translated: As though on mountain-top of crystal : as though standing on the peak of a single crystal mountain,🔽for there is no need to turn the neck and eyes to see in all directions. So too,

original: tappaṭibhāgaṃ selapabbatūpamaṃ. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho – yathā selapabbatamuddhanti
analyzed: tad paṭibhāgam sela pabbata upamam ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ yathā sela pabbatam uddhanti
translated: in a way similar to that, in a way that is a counterpart to that, in a way that is like the crystal mountain. But the meaning here in brief is this. As though standing on the peak of a crystal mountain,

original: ṭhitova cakkhunā puriso samantato janataṃ passeyya. Sumedha sundarapañña sabbaññutaññāṇena
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ iva cakkhunā puriso samantataḥ janatam passeyya sumedha sundara pañña sabbaññuta ññāṇena
