translated: a man with eyes could see the people all around. Wise Sumedha, you who have the all-knowing knowledge,

original: samantacakkhu bhagavā dhammamayaṃ paññāmayaṃ pāsādamāruyha sayaṃ apetasoko sokāvatiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: samantacakkhu bhagavā dhamma mayam paññā mayam pāsādam āruyha sayam apeta soko soka avatiṇṇam
translated: you who have the eye that sees all around, having ascended the palace of Dhamma and of wisdom,

original: jātijarābhibhūtañca janataṃ avekkhassu upadhārayatu upaparikkhatu.
analyzed: jāti jarā abhibhūtam ca janatam avekkhassu upadhārayatu upaparikkhatu
translated: you who are yourself free from grief, look down, consider, examine the people who are overcome by grief and by birth and ageing.🔽The intention here is this. As though having made a great field all around the mountain peak,

original: Ayaṃ panettha adhippāyo – yathā hi pabbatapādasāmantā mahantaṃ khettaṃ katvā tattha
analyzed: ayam pana ittha adhippāyaḥ  yathā hi pabbata pāda sāmantāḥ mahantam khettam katvā tattha
translated: and

original: kedārapāḷīsu kuṭiyo katvā rattiṃ aggiṃ jāleyya, caturaṅgasamannāgatañca andhakāraṃ
analyzed: kedāra pāḷīsu kuṭiyaḥ katvā rattim aggim jāleyya catur aṅga samannāgatam ca andhakāram
translated: and they built huts in the rice fields and lit fires at night. And there was darkness endowed with four factors,

original: assa, atha tassa pabbatassa matthake ṭhatvā cakkhumato purisassa bhūmiṃ olokayato🔽neva khettaṃ na kedārapāḷiyo na kuṭiyo na tattha sayitamanussā paññāyeyyuṃ, kuṭikāsu
analyzed: assa atha tassa pabbatassa matthake ṭhatvā cakkhumato purisassa bhūmiṃ olokayato  na iva khettam na kedāra pāḷiyaḥ na kuṭiyaḥ na tattha sayita manussā paññāyeyyum kuṭikāsu
translated: and a man with good eyesight standing on the top of the mountain looking down at the ground below

original: pana aggijālamattameva paññāyeyya. Evaṃ dhammapāsādaṃ āruyha sattakāyaṃ olokayato🔽tathāgatassa ye te akatakalyāṇā sattā, te ekavihāre dakkhiṇajāṇupasse nisinnāpi buddhacakkhussa
analyzed: pana aggi jāla mattam eva paññāyeyya evam dhammapāsādam āruyha satta kāyam olokayato  tathāgatassa ye te a kata kalyāṇā sattā te eka vihāre dakkhiṇajāṇupasse nisinnā api buddha cakkhussa
translated: would not see the fields, the rice-field boundaries, the huts, or the people sleeping there, but he would see only the glow of the fires. So too, when one ascends the Palace of Dhamma and looks down at the mass of beings,

original: āpāthaṃ nāgacchanti, rattiṃ khittasarā viya honti. Ye pana katakalyāṇā veneyyapuggalā,🔽te evassa dūrepi ṭhitā āpāthaṃ gacchanti, te eva aggi viya himavantapabbato viya
analyzed: āpātham na āgacchanti rattim khitta sarāḥ viya honti ye pana kata kalyāṇāḥ veneyya puggalā  te evassa dūre pi ṭhitāḥ āpātham gacchanti te eva aggi viya himavanta pabbataḥ viya
translated: the Tathāgata sees those beings who have not done good deeds as if they were not within the range of vision, as if they were hidden in the night. But those beings who have done good deeds, who are fit to be trained,

original: ca. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: ca vuttam pi ca itam
translated: even though they are far away, come within the range of vision, just as the fire does and the Himalaya mountain. And this is said:

original: “Dūre santo pakāsenti, himavantova pabbato;
analyzed: dūre santaḥ pakāsenti himavantaḥ iva pabbato
translated: “The good shine afar, like the Himalaya mountain,

original: Asantettha na dissanti, rattiṃ khittā yathā sarā”ti. ;
analyzed: asantā ittha na dissanti rattim khittā yathā sarāti
translated: As though they had been cast away At night upon a desert road.

original: Sabbaññutaññāṇanti ettha pañcaneyyapathappabhedaṃ sabbaṃ aññāsīti sabbaññū. Saṅkhatāsaṅkhatādibhedā
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇan ti ettha pañcaneyya patha ppabhedam sabbam aññāsi iti sabbaññū saṅkhata asaṅkhata ādi bhedā
translated: As to the knowledge of omniscience: he knows all the five kinds of things to be taught classed as formed and unformed, etc., thus he is omniscient .

original: sabbadhammā hi saṅkhāro vikāro lakkhaṇaṃ nibbānaṃ paññattīti pañceva neyyapathā honti.
analyzed: sabba dhammāḥ hi saṅkhāraḥ vikāraḥ lakkhaṇam nibbānam paññatti iti pañca iva neyya pathāḥ honti
translated: For all states are of five kinds classed as formed, as change-of- what-is-formed, as characteristic, as Nibbāna, and as designation.🔽The state of being omniscient is omniscience . The knowledge that is omniscience should be called “the knowledge of omniscience” .

original: Sabbaññussa bhāvo sabbaññutā, sabbaññutā eva ñāṇaṃ “sabbaññutāñāṇa”nti vattabbe “sabbaññutaññāṇa”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Sabbaññūti ca kamasabbaññū sakiṃsabbaññū satatasabbaññū sattisabbaññū ñātasabbaññūti
analyzed: sabbaññussa bhāvaḥ sabbaññu tā sabbaññu tā eva ñāṇam sabbaññu tā ñāṇanti vattabbe sabbaññu taññāṇanti  vuttam sabbaññū iti ca kama sabbaññū sakiṃsabbaññū satata sabbaññū satti sabbaññū ñāta sabbaññū iti
translated: But it is said to be “the knowledge of omniscience” .

original: pañcavidhā sabbaññuno siyuṃ. Tesu kamena sabbajānanakālāsambhavato kamasabbaññutā
analyzed: pañcavidhā sabbaññuno siyum tesu kamena sabba jānana kāla asambhavataḥ kama sabbaññu tā
translated: And the omniscient ones are of five kinds as follows: the omniscient by act , the omniscient by once-knowing , the omniscient by continuity , the omniscient by penetration , and the omniscient by knowing .🔽Of these, the omniscience by act is not so because it is impossible for him to know all at the time of acting;🔽the omniscience by once-knowing is not so because he does not apprehend all objects at one time;

original: na hoti, sakiṃ sabbārammaṇaggahaṇābhāvato sakiṃsabbaññutā na hoti, cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: na hoti sakim sabba ārammaṇa ggahaṇa abhāvataḥ sakiṃsabbaññutā na hoti cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: the omniscience by continuity is not so because eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: yathārammaṇacittasambhavato bhavaṅgacittavirodhato yuttiabhāvato ca satatasabbaññutā
analyzed: yathā ārammaṇa citta sambhavataḥ bhavaṅga citta virodhataḥ yutti abhāvataḥ ca satata sabbaññu tā
translated: arise according to the object, because it is contrary to the life-continuum consciousness, and because it is illogical.

original: na hoti, parisesato sabbajānanasamatthatāya sattisabbaññutā vā siyā, viditasabbadhammattā🔽ñātasabbaññutā vā, sattisabbaññuno sabbajānanattaṃ natthīti tampi na yujjati, “na
analyzed: na hoti parisesataḥ sabba jānana samattha tāya satti sabbaññu tā vā siyā vidita sabba dhamma ttā  ñāta sabbaññu tā vā satti sabbaññuno sabba jānana ttam natthi iti tat pi na yujjati na
translated: Or else it may be called “omniscience in the sense of penetration” because of the ability to penetrate all knowables.🔽Or else it may be called “omniscience in the sense of knowing” because of the knowing of all dhammas.

original: tassa adiṭṭhamidhatthi kiñci…pe… samantacakkhū”ti vuttattā ñātasabbaññutā eva yujjati.
analyzed: tassa samanta cakkhu iti vutta ttā ñāta sabbaññu tā eva yujjati
translated: But it is not right to say that the omniscient one does not know all, for it is said: “There is nothing not seen by him, nothing not known” , etc. Therefore it is only right to say that it is omniscience in the sense of knowing.

original: Evañhi sati kiccato asammohato kāraṇasiddhito āvajjanapaṭibaddhato sabbaññutameva
analyzed: evam hi sati kiccataḥ asammohataḥ kāraṇa siddhitaḥ āvajjana paṭibaddhato sabbaññu tam eva
translated: For in that case it is omniscience in the sense of function, in the sense of non-delusion, in the sense of the establishment of the reason, and in the sense of being bound up with adverting.

original: hotīti. Tena ñāṇenāti tena sabbajānanañāṇena.
analyzed: hoti iti tena ñāṇena ati tena sabba jānana ñāṇena
translated: “By that knowledge”: by that knowledge of omniscience.

original: Puna aparena pariyāyena sabbaññubhāvasādhanatthaṃ “na tassā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha
analyzed: puna aparena pariyāyena sabbaññu bhāva sādhana ttham na tassa iti gātham āha tattha
translated: Again, in order to prove his omniscience by another method, he says the stanza beginning, “There is nothing not seen by him.” Herein

original: na tassa addiṭṭhamidhatthi kiñcīti tassa tathāgatassa idha imasmiṃ tedhātuke loke🔽imasmiṃ paccuppannakāle vā paññācakkhunā adiṭṭhaṃ nāma kiñci appamattakampi na atthi
analyzed: na tassa addiṭṭham idhatthi kiñci iti tassa tathāgatassa idha imasmin tedhātuke loke 🔽imasmin paccuppanna kāle vā paññācakkhunā adiṭṭham nāma kiñci appamattakam pi na atthi
translated: there is nothing not seen by him: there is nothing, not even the smallest thing, not seen by the knowledge of omniscience of the Tathāgata in this triple world,🔽in this present time.

original: na saṃvijjati. Atthīti idaṃ vattamānakālikaṃ ākhyātapadaṃ, iminā paccuppannakālikassa
analyzed: na saṃvijjati atthi iti idam vattamāna kālikam ākhyāta padam iminā paccuppanna kālikassa
translated: does not exist. The word “is” is a word in the present tense;

original: sabbadhammassa ñātabhāvaṃ dasseti. Gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ panettha da-kāro payutto.🔽Atho aviññātanti ettha athoti vacanopādāne nipāto. Aviññātanti atītakālikaṃ aviññātaṃ
analyzed: sabba dhammassa ñāta bhāvam dasseti gāthā bandha sukha attham pana ittha dakāraḥ payutto  atho aviññātam ti ettha atho ti vacana upādāne nipātaḥ aviññātam ti atīta kālikam aviññātam
translated: this shows the knowability of all states in the present. But the letter “da” is used here for the sake of ease in versification.🔽“And what is not known”: here the word “and” is a particle of addition. “What is not known” is a certain kind of state in the past tense that is not known.

original: nāma kiñci dhammajātaṃ nāhosīti pāṭhaseso. Abyayabhūtassa atthi-saddassa gahaṇe pāṭhasesaṃ
analyzed: nāma kiñci dhamma jātam pāṭha sesaḥ abyaya bhūtassa atthi saddassa gahaṇe pāṭha sesam
translated: The reading “was not” is an alternative reading. Without the alternative reading,

original: vināpi yujjatiyeva. Iminā atītakālikassa sabbadhammassa ñātabhāvaṃ dasseti. Ajānitabbanti🔽anāgatakālikaṃ ajānitabbaṃ nāma dhammajātaṃ na bhavissati natthīti. Iminā anāgatakālikassa
analyzed: vinā api iminā atīta kālikassa sabba dhammassa ñāta bhāvam dasseti a jānitabbam ti  anāgata kālikam a jānitabbam nāma dhamma jātam na bhavissati natthi iti iminā anāgata kālikassa
translated: the word “is” in the neuter form is appropriate. This shows the knowability of all states in the past. “What is not to be known”

original: sabbadhammassa ñātabhāvaṃ dasseti. Jānanakiriyāvisesamattameva vā ettha a-kāro. Sabbaṃ
analyzed: sabba dhammassa ñāta bhāvam dasseti jānana kiriyā visesa mattam eva vā ettha akāraḥ sabbam
translated: is a certain kind of state in the future tense that is not to be known. “Will not be” is an alternative reading. This shows the knowability of all states in the future. Or the letter “a” here may be taken as merely a particular of the act of knowing. All

original: abhiññāsi yadatthi neyyanti ettha yaṃ tekālikaṃ vā kālavinimuttaṃ vā neyyaṃ jānitabbaṃ
analyzed: abhiññāsi yat atthi neyyam ti ettha yam tekālikam vā kāla vinimuttam vā neyyam jānitabbam
translated: “He has understood what is to be known”: here, any kind of state that is to be known, whether it is occasional or not occasional,

original: kiñci dhammajātaṃ atthi, taṃ sabbaṃ tathāgato abhiññāsi adhikena sabbaññutaññāṇena🔽jāni paṭivijjhi, ettha atthi-saddena tekālikassa kālavimuttassa ca gahaṇā atthi-saddo
analyzed: kiñci dhamma jātam atthi tat sabbam tathāgataḥ abhiññāsi adhikena sabbaññuta ññāṇena  ettha atthi saddena tekālikassa kāla vimuttassa ca gahaṇā atthi saddaḥ
translated: the Tathāgata has understood it all by means of the superior knowledge of omniscience.🔽He has known and penetrated it. Here, the word “what” should be regarded as an indeclinable word,

original: abyayabhūtoyeva daṭṭhabbo. Tathāgato tena samantacakkhūti kālavasena okāsavasena
analyzed: abyaya bhūtaḥ yeva daṭṭhabbaḥ tathāgato tena kāla vasena okāsa vasena
translated: because it includes both the occasional and the not occasional. “The Tathāgata is the all-seeing one”: because of the time and the place,

original: ca nippadesattā samantā sabbato pavattaṃ ñāṇacakkhu assāti samantacakkhu, tena yathāvuttena
analyzed: ca nippadesa ttā samantā sabbatas pavattam ñāṇa cakkhu assa ati samantacakkhu tena yathāvuttena
translated: he is the all-seeing one, the one who has the eye of knowledge that extends everywhere, that extends to all. By means of that,

original: kāraṇena tathāgato samantacakkhu sabbaññūti vuttaṃ hoti. Imissā gāthāya puggalādhiṭṭhānāya
analyzed: kāraṇena tathāgataḥ samanta cakkhu sabbaññū ti vuttam hoti imissā gāthāya puggala adhiṭṭhānāya
translated: it is said that the Tathāgata is the all-seeing one, the omniscient one, for the above-mentioned reason. In this stanza, which is a teaching based on a person,

original: desanāya sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ sādhitaṃ.
analyzed: desanāya sabbaññuta ññāṇam sādhitam
translated: the knowledge of omniscience is accomplished.

original: Na itihitihanti “evaṃ kira āsi, evaṃ kira āsī”ti na hoti. Na itikirāyāti “evaṃ kira
analyzed: na evam kiraḥ āsi evam kiraḥ āsi iti na na iti kirāya ati evam kira
translated: “He does not say ‘It was’ or ‘It was like this’: “It was like this, it was like that” does not occur for him. “It was like this”:

original: eta”nti na hoti. Na paramparāyāti paramparakathāyāpi na hoti. Na piṭakasampadāyāti
analyzed: na hoti na paramparā āyāti na na piṭaka sampadā āyāti
translated: ‘This is it’ does not occur. ‘Not by report’ : by hearsay also it does not occur. ‘Not by what is in a book’ :🔽‘It meets with our book’ does not occur. ‘Not by reasoning’ : by reasoning out a theory it does not occur.

original: amhākaṃ piṭakatantiyā saddhiṃ sametīti na hoti. Na takkahetūti takkaggāhenapi na🔽hoti. Na ākāraparivitakkenāti “sundaramidaṃ kāraṇa”nti evaṃ kāraṇaparivitakkenapi🔽na hoti. Na diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyāti amhākaṃ nijjhāyitvā khamitvā gahitadiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: amhākam piṭaka tantiyā saddhim sameti iti na hoti na takka hetu uti takka ggāhena api na  hoti na ākāra parivitakkena ati sundaram idam kāraṇam ti evam kāraṇa parivitakkena api  na hoti na diṭṭhi nijjhāna khantiyā ati amhākam nijjhāyitvā khamitvā gahita diṭṭhiyā
translated: ‘Not by the appearance of a scholar’ : by thinking ‘This is a good theory’ it does not occur. ‘Not by the apparent correctness of a view’ :

original: saddhiṃ sametītipi na hoti.🔽Atha vāpi samādhinti ettha samādhinti kusalacittekaggatā samādhi. Kenaṭṭhena samādhīti?🔽Samādhānaṭṭhena. Kimidaṃ samādhānaṃ nāma? Ekārammaṇe cittacetasikānaṃ samaṃ sammā
analyzed: saddhim sameti itipi na  atha vā api samādhinti ettha samādhinti kusala citta ekagga tā samādhi kenaṭṭhena samādhi iti  samādhāna aṭṭhena kim idam samādhānam nāma eka ārammaṇe citta cetasikānam samam sammā
translated: ‘It meets with our view grasped by pondering and accepted’ does not occur.

original: ca ādhānaṃ, ṭhapananti vuttaṃ hoti. Tasmā yassa dhammassa ānubhāvena ekārammaṇe cittacetasikā
analyzed: ca ādhānam ṭhapananti vuttam hoti tasmā yassa dhammassa ānubhāvena eka ārammaṇe citta cetasikā
translated: ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness of a view’ : by the apparent correctness of a view it does not occur. ‘Or by the seeming competence of a speaker’ : by the seeming competence of a speaker it does not occur. ‘Or by the apparent correctness

original: samaṃ sammā ca avikkhippamānā avippakiṇṇā ca hutvā tiṭṭhanti, idaṃ samādhānanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: samam sammā ca a vikkhippamānā a vippakiṇṇā ca hutvā tiṭṭhanti idam samādhānam ti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that steadiness is the steadying of the mind evenly and rightly without wobbling or vacillation.

original: Tassa kho pana samādhissa –
analyzed: tassa kho pana samādhissa
translated: And the characteristic of this concentration is

original: “Lakkhaṇaṃ tu avikkhepo, vikkhepaddhaṃsanaṃ raso;
analyzed: lakkhaṇam tu avikkhepaḥ vikkhepa ddhaṃsanam rasaḥ
translated: undistractedness, its function is to eliminate distraction,

original: Akampanamupaṭṭhānaṃ, padaṭṭhānaṃ sukhaṃ pana”. ;
analyzed: akampanam upaṭṭhānam padaṭṭhānam sukham pana
translated: its manifestation is unshakableness, and its proximate cause is bliss.

original: Samādhi anāvilaacalabhāvena ārammaṇe tiṭṭhatīti ṭhiti. Parato padadvayaṃ upasaggavasena🔽vaḍḍhitaṃ. Api ca sampayuttadhamme ārammaṇamhi sampiṇḍetvā tiṭṭhatīti saṇṭhiti. Ārammaṇaṃ🔽ogāhetvā anupavisitvā tiṭṭhatīti avaṭṭhiti. Kusalapakkhasmiñhi cattārova dhammā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: anāvila acala bhāvena ārammaṇe tiṭṭhati iti paratas pada dvayam upasagga vasena  vaḍḍhitam api ca sampayutta dhamme ārammaṇamhi sampiṇḍetvā tiṭṭhati iti saṇṭhiti ārammaṇam  ogāhetvā an upavisitvā tiṭṭhati iti avaṭṭhiti kusala pakkhasmin hi cattāro va dhammāḥ ārammaṇam
translated: It is steadying because it stands on the object without wobbling or vacillating through lack of clarity. The next two terms are derived by prefixing a preposition to the root sthā, to stand.

original: ogāhanti saddhā sati samādhi paññāti. Teneva saddhā “okappanā”ti vuttā, sati “apilāpanatā”ti,
analyzed: ogāhanti saddhā sati samādhi paññā ati tena iva saddhā okappanā ati vuttā sati apilāpana tā ati
translated: Moreover, it is steadying because it stands by combining the associated states and the object into one. It is steadying because it stands without going under or over the object. For in the profitable class four things go under the object, namely, faith, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding. That is why faith is called “acquiescence,” mindfulness “non-forgetting,”

original: samādhi “avaṭṭhitī”ti, paññā “pariyogāhanā”ti. Akusalapakkhe pana tayo dhammā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: samādhi avaṭṭhiti iti paññā pariyogāhanā ati akusala pakkhe pana tayo dhammā ārammaṇam
translated: concentration “steadying,” and understanding “scrutiny.” But in the unprofitable class three things go under the object,

original: ogāhanti taṇhā diṭṭhi avijjāti. Tenevete “oghā”ti vuttā. Cittekaggatā panettha na
analyzed: ogāhanti taṇhā diṭṭhi avijjā ti tena iva ete oghā ti vuttā citta ekagga tā pana ittha na
translated: They are called “floods” because they flood the mind. But unification of mind here is not

original: balavatī hoti. Yathā hi rajuṭṭhānaṭṭhāne udakena siñcitvā sammaṭṭhe thokameva kālaṃ
analyzed: balavatī hoti yathā hi raju ṭṭhāna ṭṭhāne udakena siñcitvā sammaṭṭhe thokam eva kālam
translated: strong. For just as when a place is dusty and a little water is sprinkled on it, the dust is laid low for a moment,

original: rajo sannisīdati, sukkhante sukkhante puna pakatibhāveneva vuṭṭhāti, evameva akusalapakkhe
analyzed: rajaḥ sannisīdati sukkhante sukkhante puna pakati bhāvena iva vuṭṭhāti evam eva akusala pakkhe
translated: but when the sun heats it, it bounces up again and lies as it was before, so too, unification of mind in the unprofitable

original: cittekaggatā na balavatī hoti.🔽Uddhaccavicikicchāvasena pavattassa visāhārassa paṭipakkhato avisāhāro. Uddhaccavicikicchāvaseneva
analyzed: citta ekagga tā na balavatī hoti  uddhacca vicikicchā vasena pavattassa visāhārassa paṭipakkhataḥ avisāhāraḥ uddhacca vicikicchā vasena iva
translated: is not strong.

original: gacchantaṃ cittaṃ vikkhipati nāma. Ayaṃ pana tathāvidho vikkhepo na hotīti avikkhepo.
analyzed: gacchantam cittam vikkhipati nāma ayam pana tathāvidhaḥ vikkhepaḥ na hoti iti avikkhepaḥ
translated: It is “without prompting” in the sense of the opposite of prompting, which occurs with agitation and uncertainty. For when the mind goes with agitation and uncertainty, it is said to be “prompted.” But this is not such prompting,🔽so it is “without prompting.”

original: Uddhaccavicikicchāvaseneva cittaṃ visāhaṭaṃ nāma hoti, ito cito ca harīyati, ayaṃ
analyzed: uddhacca vicikicchā vasena iva cittam visāhaṭam nāma hoti itas citas ca harīyati ayam
translated: The mind is said to be “prompted” when it goes with agitation and uncertainty, and it is carried here and there. But this is🔽the state of one whose mind is not thus carried, so it is “not carried away.”

original: pana evaṃ avisāhaṭamānasassa bhāvoti avisāhaṭamānasatā. Samathoti tividho samatho
analyzed: pana evam avisāhaṭa mānasassa bhāvo ti avisāhaṭa mānasa tā samatho ti tividhaḥ samatho
translated: There are three kinds of serenity:

original: cittasamatho adhikaraṇasamatho sabbasaṅkhārasamathoti. Tattha aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
analyzed: citta samatho adhikaraṇa samatho sabba saṅkhāra samatho ti tattha aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
translated: The stilling of cognizance, the stilling of cognizances, the stilling of all processes. Herein,

original: cittekaggatā cittasamatho nāma. Tañhi āgamma cittacalanaṃ cittavipphanditaṃ sammati🔽vūpasammati, tasmā so “cittasamatho”ti vuccati. Sammukhāvinayādisattavidho samatho
analyzed: citta ekagga tā citta samathaḥ nāma tat hi āgamma citta calanam citta vipphanditam sammati  tasmā so citta samatho ti vuccati sammukha avinaya ādi sattavidho samatho
translated: the unification of cognizance in the eight attainments is called the stilling of cognizance. For that is stilled and allayed on the arrival of that,

original: adhikaraṇasamatho nāma. Tañhi āgamma tāni tāni adhikaraṇāni sammanti vūpasammanti,
analyzed: adhikaraṇa samathaḥ nāma tat hi āgamma tāni tāni adhikaraṇāni sammanti vūpasammanti
translated: and that is why it is called the stilling of cognizance. The seven kinds of settlement beginning with settlement by face-to-face verdict is called the stilling of cognizance. For that is stilled and allayed on the arrival of that,

original: tasmā so “adhikaraṇasamatho”ti vuccati. Yasmā pana sabbe saṅkhārā nibbānaṃ āgamma
analyzed: tasmā so adhikaraṇa samatho ti vuccati yasmā pana sabbe saṅkhārāḥ nibbānam āgamma
translated: and that is why it is called the stilling of cognizance. But since all processes are stilled and allayed on the arrival of extinction,

original: sammanti vūpasammanti vūpasammanti, tasmā taṃ “sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti vuccati. Imasmiṃ🔽atthe cittasamatho adhippeto. Samādhilakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti samādhindriyaṃ.
analyzed: sammanti vūpasammanti vūpasammanti tasmā tam sabba saṅkhāra samatho ti vuccati imasmin  atthe citta samathaḥ adhippeto samādhi lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti samādhindriyam
translated: that is why it is called the stilling of all processes. It is the stilling of cognizance that is intended here.🔽It makes the cognizance steady in the characteristic of concentration, thus it is the concentration faculty.

original: Uddhacce na kampatīti samādhibalaṃ. Sammāsamādhīti yāthāvasamādhi niyyānikasamādhi.
analyzed: uddhacce na kampati iti samādhi balam sammāsamādhi iti yāthāva samādhi niyyānika samādhi
translated: It does not tremble in agitation, thus it is the concentration power. Right concentration is concentration in the true way, concentration that ends in emancipation.

original: 157. Athassa bhagavā yasmā indriyasaṃvaro sīlassa rakkhā, yasmā vā iminānukkamena
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā yasmai indriya saṃvaro sīlassa rakkhā yasmai vā iminā anukkamena
translated: Then the Blessed One, since restraint of the faculties is the guarding of virtue, or since this teaching,

original: desiyamānā ayaṃ desanā tāsaṃ devatānaṃ sappāyā, tasmā indriyasaṃvarato pabhuti paṭipadaṃ🔽dassento “cakkhūhī”tiādi āraddho. Tattha cakkhūhi neva lolassāti adiṭṭhadakkhitabbādivasena
analyzed: desiyamānā desanā tāsam devatānam sappāyā tasmai indriya saṃvarato paṭipadam  dassento cakkhūhi itiādi āraddhaḥ tattha cakkhūhi na iva lolassa ti a diṭṭha dakkhitabba ādi vasena
translated: being taught in this order, is suitable for those devatās, therefore, showing the way of practice🔽beginning with restraint of the faculties, he began with the words “With the eye” . Herein, he is not excited by what is seen: he is not excited by the eye faculty with the desire to see what need not be seen, and so on.

original: cakkhūhi lolo neva assa. Gāmakathāya āvaraye sotanti tiracchānakathāya sotaṃ āvareyya.
analyzed: cakkhūhi lolaḥ na iva assa gāma kathāya āvaraye sotam ti tiracchāna kathāya sotam āvareyya
translated: He guards the ear faculty: he would guard the ear faculty against what should not be heard, such as animal talk.

original: Cakkhuloliyenāti cakkhudvāre uppannalolavasena cakkhuloliyena. Adiṭṭhaṃ dakkhitabbanti🔽adiṭṭhapubbaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ passituṃ yuttaṃ. Diṭṭhaṃ samatikkamitabbanti diṭṭhapubbarūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu loliyena ati cakkhu dvāre uppanna lola vasena cakkhu loliyena adiṭṭham dakkhitabbanti  a diṭṭha pubbam rūpa ārammaṇam passitum yuttam diṭṭham samatikkamitabbam ti diṭṭha pubba rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: By excitement of the eye: by excitement of the eye, that is, by the excitement arisen in the eye door.🔽What should not be seen: what has not been seen before and is not suitable to be seen.🔽What should be seen: what has been seen before and is suitable to be seen.

original: atikkamituṃ yuttaṃ. Ārāmena ārāmanti pupphārāmādiārāmena phalārāmādiṃ vā pupphārāmādiṃ
analyzed: atikkamitum yuttam ārāmena puppha ārāma ādi ārāmena phala ārāma ādim vā puppha ārāma ādim
translated: From pleasure park to pleasure park: from a pleasure park such as a flower garden to a pleasure park such as a fruit garden, or from a pleasure park such as a flower garden to a pleasure park such as a pleasure grove,

original: vā. Dīghacārikanti dīghacaraṇaṃ. Anavaṭṭhitacārikanti asanniṭṭhānacaraṇaṃ. Anuyutto
analyzed: vā dīgha cārikanti dīgha caraṇam anavaṭṭhita cārikanti a sanniṭṭhāna caraṇam anuyuttaḥ
translated: “Long-distance walking” is walking a long distance. “Uninterrupted walking” is walking without stopping.

original: hoti rūpadassanāyāti rūpārammaṇadassanatthāya punappunaṃ yutto hoti.🔽Antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhoti ummārabbhantaraṃ paviṭṭho. Vīthiṃ paṭipannoti antaravīthiṃ🔽otiṇṇo. Gharamukhāni olokentoti gharadvārāni avalokento. Uddhaṃ ullokentoti uparidisaṃ
analyzed: hoti rūpa dassanāya ati rūpa ārammaṇa dassana tthāya punappunam yuttaḥ hoti  antara gharam paviṭṭhaḥ ti ummāra bhantaram paviṭṭhaḥ vīthim paṭipannaḥ ti antara vīthim  otiṇṇaḥ ghara mukhāni olokentaḥ iti ghara dvārāni avalokentaḥ uddham ullokentaḥ iti upari disam
translated: “Is intent on seeing forms” means he is intent again and again for the purpose of seeing forms as object.🔽“Having entered an inhabited area” means having entered the area between the outskirts. “Is walking along a street” means he has entered an intermediate street.

original: uddhaṃmukho hutvā vilokento.🔽Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti kāraṇavasena cakkhūti laddhavohārena rūpadassanasamatthena
analyzed: uddhaṃmukhaḥ hutvā  cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati kāraṇa vasena cakkhu iti laddha vohārena rūpa dassana samatthena
translated: “Is looking into the entrances to houses” means he is looking at the doors of houses. “Is looking up” means he is looking upwards with his face turned upwards.🔽“Having seen a form with the eye” means having seen a form with eye-consciousness, which is called “eye” because it is the cause, and which is capable of seeing a form.

original: cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvā. Porāṇā panāhu – “cakkhu rūpaṃ na passati acittakattā,
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam disvā porāṇā pana āhu cakkhu rūpam na passati acittakattā
translated: But the ancients said: “The eye does not see because it is without consciousness;

original: cittaṃ na passati acakkhukattā. Dvārārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭe pana pasādavatthukena cittena
analyzed: cittam na passati acakkhuka ttā dvāra ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭe pana pasāda vatthukena cittena
translated: consciousness does not see because it is without eyes. But when there is a conjunction of door and object, one sees with consciousness that has the eye as its basis and has the nature of transparency.

original: passati. Īdisī panesā ‘dhanunā vijjhatī’tiādīsu viya sasambhārakathā nāma hoti. Tasmā
analyzed: passati īdisī pana esā dhanunā vijjhati iti ādīsu viya sa sambhārakathā nāma hoti tasmā
translated: But this is called a statement with a complete complement, like such statements as ‘One is struck by a bow’ . Therefore

original: cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvāti ayamettha attho”ti. Nimittaggāhīti itthipurisanimittaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam disvā ti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti nimitta ggāhī iti itthi purisa nimittam
translated: The meaning here is: ‘Having seen a visible object with eye-consciousness.’

original: vā subhanimittādikaṃ vā kilesavatthubhūtaṃ nimittaṃ chandarāgavasena gaṇhāti, diṭṭhamatteyeva🔽na saṇṭhāti. Anubyañjanaggāhīti kilesānaṃ anuanubyañjanato pākaṭabhāvakaraṇato anubyañjananti
analyzed: vā subha nimitta ādikam vā kilesa vatthu bhūtam nimittam chanda rāga vasena gaṇhāti  na kilesānam pākaṭa bhāva karaṇataḥ
translated: Seizes on the sign: he seizes on the sign of a woman or man, or on the sign of beauty, etc., which is the sign that is a basis for defilements. He does not stop at mere seeing but🔽goes further and

original: laddhavohāraṃ hatthapādasitahasitakathitaālokitavilokitādibhedaṃ ākāraṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: laddha vohāram hattha pāda sita hasita kathita ālokita vilokita ādi bhedam ākāram gaṇhāti
translated: Seizes on the secondary characteristics: he goes further and seizes on the mode, which is called the secondary characteristic because it is the secondary characteristic of the defilements, because it makes them manifest. The mode is classed as the various ways in which the defilements manifest, such as by hand, by foot, by laughter, by talk, by looking here and there, and so on.

original: Yatvādhikaraṇamenantiādimhi yaṃkāraṇā yassa cakkhundriyāsaṃvarassa hetu etaṃ puggalaṃ🔽satikavāṭena cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ apihitacakkhudvāraṃ hutvā viharantaṃ ete abhijjhādayo
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enanti ādimhi yaṃkāraṇā yassa cakkhu indriya asaṃvarassa hetu etam puggalam  sati kavāṭena cakkhu indriyam a saṃvutam apihita cakkhu dvāram hutvā viharantam ete abhijjhā ādayaḥ
translated: For the sake of which: for the sake of which, for the reason of which, because of which restraint of the eye faculty,🔽those things beginning with covetousness would invade, would overpower, would overcome that person who dwells with the eye faculty unrestrained, with the door of the eye faculty unclosed.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ anuppabandheyyuṃ ajjhotthareyyuṃ. Tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjatīti
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyum an uppabandheyyum ajjhotthareyyum tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjati iti
translated: He does not practice in order to abandon that.

original: tassa cakkhundriyassa satikavāṭena pidahanatthāya na paṭipajjati. Evaṃbhūtoyeva ca
analyzed: tassa cakkhu indriyassa sati kavāṭena pidahana tthāya na paṭipajjati evaṃbhūtaḥ yā iva ca
translated: He does not practice for the purpose of guarding the eye faculty with the guard of mindfulness.

original: na rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ. Na cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjatītipi vuccati. Tattha
analyzed: na rakkhati cakkhu indriyam na cakkhu indriye saṃvaram āpajjati iti pi vuccati tattha
translated: He is called “one who does not guard the eye faculty” and “one who does not practice restraint of the eye faculty.”

original: kiñcāpi cakkhundriye saṃvaro vā asaṃvaro vā natthi. Na hi cakkhupasādaṃ nissāya sati
analyzed: kiñca api cakkhu indriye saṃvaraḥ vā asaṃvaraḥ vā natthi na hi cakkhu pasādam nissāya sati
translated: Herein, although there is no restraint or non-restraint in the eye faculty,🔽mindfulness or forgetfulness arises in dependence on the eye faculty.

original: vā muṭṭhassaccaṃ vā uppajjati. Apica yadā rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchati,
analyzed: vā muṭṭhassaccam vā uppajjati apica yadā rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhussa āpātham āgacchati
translated: When a visible form as object comes into the eye’s focus,

original: tadā bhavaṅge dvikkhattuṃ uppajjitvā niruddhe kiriyāmanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā
analyzed: tadā bhavaṅge dvi khattum uppajjitvā niruddhe kiriyā manodhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā
translated: then, after the life-continuum has arisen and ceased twice, the functional mind element accomplishing the function of adverting arises and ceases.

original: uppajjitvā nirujjhati, tato cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ, tato manodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccaṃ,🔽tato vipākāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu santīraṇakiccaṃ, tato kiriyāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhati tatas cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam tatas manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccam  tatas vipāka ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇa kiccam tatas kiriyā hetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: After that, eye-consciousness accomplishing the function of seeing arises and ceases. After that, the mind element accomplishing the function of receiving arises.

original: voṭṭhabbanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā uppajjitvā nirujjhati, tadanantaraṃ javanaṃ javati.
analyzed: voṭṭhabbana kiccam sādhayamānā uppajjitvā nirujjhati tad anantaram javanam javati
translated: After that, the resultant root-causeless mind-consciousness element accomplishing the function of investigating arises and ceases. After that, the functional root-causeless mind-consciousness element accomplishing the function of determining arises and ceases.🔽After that, impulsion impels.

original: Tatrāpi neva bhavaṅgasamaye na āvajjanādīnaṃ aññatarasamaye saṃvaro vā asaṃvaro vā
analyzed: tatra api na iva bhavaṅga samaye na āvajjana ādīnam aññatara samaye saṃvaraḥ vā asaṃvaraḥ vā
translated: Herein, neither restraint nor unrestraint exists at the time of the life-continuum or at any of the times beginning with adverting.

original: atthi. Javanakkhaṇe pana sace dussīlyaṃ vā muṭṭhassaccaṃ vā aññāṇaṃ vā akkhanti vā
analyzed: atthi javana khaṇe pana sace dussīlyam vā muṭṭhassaccam vā aññāṇam vā akkhanti vā
translated: But if unvirtuousness, or inattentiveness, or unknowing, or impatience, or

original: kosajjaṃ vā uppajjati, asaṃvaro hoti. Evaṃ honto pana so “cakkhundriye asaṃvaro”ti
analyzed: kosajjam vā uppajjati asaṃvaraḥ hoti evam honto pana so cakkhu indriye
translated: sloth, arises at the moment of impulsion, then there is unrestraint. And when it is, it is called “unrestraint in the eye faculty.”

original: vuccati. Kasmā? Yasmā tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi aguttaṃ hoti, bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīnipi
analyzed: vuccati kasmai yasmai tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi aguttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni pi
translated: Why? Because when there is this unrestraint, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum, the adverting, etc., and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series

original: vīthicittāni. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā nagare catūsu dvāresu asaṃvutesu kiñcāpi antogharadvārakoṭṭhakagabbhādayo🔽saṃvutā, tathāpi antonagare sabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ arakkhitaṃ agopitameva hoti. Nagaradvārena
analyzed: vīthi cittāni yathā kim yathā nagare catūsu dvāresu a saṃvutesu kiñca api antar ghara dvāra koṭṭhaka gabbha ādayaḥ  saṃvutā tathā api antonagare sabbam bhaṇḍam arakkhitam a gopitam eva hoti nagara dvārena
translated: are unguarded too. How so? Just as when a town has its four gates unguarded, then although the houses inside the town, the town gates, the watch towers, the moats, the walls, etc.,

original: hi pavisitvā corā yadicchanti taṃ kareyyuṃ, evameva javane dussīlyādīsu uppannesu
analyzed: hi pavisitvā corāḥ yat icchanti tam kareyyuṃ evam eva javane dussīlya ādīsu uppannesu
translated: may be well guarded, nevertheless all the property in the town is unguarded and unprotected; for thieves can enter the town by the unguarded gates and do as they like, so too when there is unrestraint in the impulsion, then

original: tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi aguttaṃ hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīnipi vīthicittāni.
analyzed: tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi aguttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni pi vīthi cittāni
translated: when there is this unrestraint, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum, the adverting, etc., and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series are unguarded too.

original: Saddhādeyyānīti kammañca phalañca idhalokañca paralokañca saddahitvā dinnāni. “Ayaṃ🔽me ñātīti vā, mittoti vā, idaṃ vā paṭikarissati, idaṃ vānena katapubba”nti vā evaṃ
analyzed: saddhādeyyāni iti kammañca phalañca idha lokañca para lokañca saddahitvā dinnāni ayam  me ñātī iti vā mitto ti vā idam vā paṭikarissati idam vā anena kata pubbanti vā evam
translated: “Given in faith”: given after faith in action and result, in this world and the other world, has arisen. “This person is my relative or friend, or he will repay it, or he has repaid it before,”🔽🔽

original: na dinnānīti attho. Evaṃ dinnāni hi na saddhādeyyāni nāma honti. Bhojanānīti ca desanāsīsamattametaṃ,🔽atthato pana saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā cīvarāni pārupitvā senāsanāni sevamānā
analyzed: na dinnāni iti attho evam dinnāni hi na saddhādeyyāni nāma honti bhojanāni iti ca desanā sīsa mattam etam  atthataḥ pana saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā cīvarāni pārupitvā senāsanāni sevamānā
translated: “Given in faith”: given after faith in action and result, in this world and the other world, has arisen. The meaning is that they are not given thinking, “This person is my relative or friend,” or “This person will repay me,” or “This person did a service for me.” For what is given in such a way is not called “given in faith.” “Food” is mentioned only as a heading;🔽the meaning is that having eaten the food given in faith, having worn the robes given in faith, having used the lodgings given in faith, having used the medicine given in faith for curing the sick,

original: gilānapaccayabhesajjaṃ paribhuñjamānāti sabbametaṃ vuttameva hoti.
analyzed: gilāna paccaya bhesajjam paribhuñjamānā ati sabbam etam vuttam eva hoti
translated: all this is included.

original: Seyyathidanti nipāto. Tassattho, katamo hoti. Naccaṃ nāma yaṃkiñci naccaṃ, taṃ maggaṃ🔽gacchantenāpi gīvaṃ pasāretvā daṭṭhuṃ na vaṭṭati. Gītanti yaṃkiñci gītaṃ. Vāditanti
analyzed: seyyathidam ti nipātaḥ tassa atthaḥ katamaḥ hoti naccam nāma yat kiñci naccam tam maggam  gacchantena api gīvam pasāretvā daṭṭhum na vaṭṭati yaṃkiñci gītam vāditanti
translated: “Such as”: this is a particle; the meaning is, “what kind of.” “Dancing” : any kind of dancing;

original: yaṃkiñci vāditaṃ. Pekkhanti naṭasamajjaṃ. Akkhānanti bhāratarāmāyanādikaṃ. Yasmiṃ
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci vāditam pekkhanti naṭa samajjam akkhānanti bhārata rāmāyana ādikam yasmin
translated: it is not allowable for one going along a road even to look at it by turning his neck. “Singing”: any kind of singing. “Music”: any kind of music. “To see” : a performance by actors. “To hear” : the Bhārata, the Rāmāyaṇa, etc.

original: ṭhāne kathīyati, tattha gantumpi na vaṭṭati. Pāṇissaranti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, “pāṇitāḷa”ntipi🔽vadanti. Vetāḷanti ghanatāḷaṃ, “mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpana”ntipi eke. Kumbhathūṇanti🔽caturassaambaṇakatāḷaṃ, “kumbhasadda”ntipi eke. Sobhanakanti naṭānaṃ abbhokkiraṇaṃ;🔽sobhanakaraṃ vā, paṭibhānacittanti vuttaṃ hoti. Caṇḍālanti ayoguḷakīḷā, “caṇḍālānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhāne kathīyati tattha gantum pi na vaṭṭati pāṇissaranti kaṃsa tāḷam pāṇi tāḷanti pi  vadanti vetāḷanti ghana tāḷam mantena eke kumbha thūṇanti  eke  sobhana karam vā paṭibhāna cittanti vuttam hoti caṇḍālanti ayaḥ guḷa kīḷā caṇḍālānam
translated: If it is being played in a place, it is not allowable to go there. Pāṇissaranti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, “pāṇitāḷa”ntipi vadanti. Vetāḷanti ghanatāḷaṃ, “mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpana”ntipi eke. Kumbhathūṇanti🔽caturassaambaṇakatāḷaṃ, “kumbhasadda”ntipi eke. Sobhanakanti naṭānaṃ abbhokkiraṇaṃ;🔽sobhanakaraṃ vā, paṭibhānacittanti vuttaṃ hoti. Caṇḍālanti ayoguḷakīḷā, “caṇḍālānaṃ🔽

original: sāṇadhovanakīḷā”tipi vadanti. Vaṃsanti veṇuṃ ussāpetvā kīḷanaṃ.🔽Dhovananti aṭṭhidhovanaṃ, ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti,🔽nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti. Atha tesaṃ pūtibhūtaṃ kāyaṃ ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā🔽gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti. Te nakkhattakāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ
analyzed: vadanti vaṃsanti veṇum ussāpetvā kīḷanam 🔽dhovananti aṭṭhi dhovanam ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti 🔽nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti atha tesam pūti bhūtam kāyam ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā 🔽gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti te nakkhatta kāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ
translated: If it is being played in a place, it is not allowable to go there. Pāṇissaranti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, “pāṇitāḷa”ntipi vadanti. Vetāḷanti ghanatāḷaṃ, “mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpana”ntipi eke. Kumbhathūṇanti caturassaambaṇakatāḷaṃ, “kumbhasadda”ntipi eke. Sobhanakanti naṭānaṃ abbhokkiraṇaṃ; sobhanakaraṃ vā, paṭibhānacittanti vuttaṃ hoti. Caṇḍālanti ayoguḷakīḷā, “caṇḍālānaṃ sāṇadhovanakīḷā”tipi vadanti. Vaṃsanti veṇuṃ ussāpetvā kīḷanaṃ. Dhovananti aṭṭhidhovanaṃ, ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti, nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti. Atha tesaṃ pūtibhūtaṃ kāyaṃ ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti. Te nakkhattakāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ

original: ṭhāne surādīni ṭhapetvā rodantā paridevantā suraṃ pivanti. Vuttampi cetaṃ “atthi
analyzed: ṭhāne surā ādīni ṭhapetvā rodantā paridevantā suram pivanti vuttam pi atthi
translated: and they put the liquor in a place and wept and wailed and drank the liquor. And this is said:

original: bhikkhave dakkhiṇesu janapadesu dhovanaṃ nāma, tattha hoti annampi pānampi khajjampi
analyzed: bhikkhave dakkhiṇesu janapadesu dhovanam nāma tattha hoti annam pi pānam pi khajjam pi
translated: and they put the liquor, etc., in a place and then wept and wailed and drank the liquor. And this is said: “There is, monks, a place called Dhovana in the southern country,

original: bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi. Atthekaṃ bhikkhave dhovanaṃ,
analyzed: bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi attha ekam bhikkhave dhovanam
translated: where there is food and drink and solid food and hard food and refreshments and beverages and dancing and singing and music,🔽and there is a place called Dhovana, I say.

original: netaṃ natthīti vadāmī”ti. Ekacce pana “indajālena aṭṭhidhovanaṃ dhovana”nti vadanti.
analyzed: na etam natthi iti vadāmi iti ekacce pana inda jālena aṭṭhidhovanam dhovananti vadanti
translated: But some say that the place where bones are washed after a battle is called Dhovana.

original: Hatthiyuddhādīsu bhikkhuno neva hatthiādīhi saddhiṃ yujjhituṃ, na te yujjhāpetuṃ,
analyzed: hatthi yuddha ādīsu bhikkhunaḥ na iva hatthi ādīhi saddhim yujjhitum na te yujjhāpetum
translated: In the case of elephant fights, etc., it is not proper for a monk to fight with the elephants, etc., or to get others to fight,

original: na yujjhante daṭṭhuṃ vaṭṭati. Nibbuddhanti mallayuddhaṃ. Uyyodhikanti yattha sampahāro🔽diyyati. Balagganti balagaṇanaṭṭhānaṃ. Senābyūhanti senāniveso, sakaṭabyūhādivasena
analyzed: na yujjhante daṭṭhum vaṭṭati nibbuddha nti malla yuddham uyyodhikam ti yattha sampahāraḥ  diyyati balagganti bala gaṇana ṭṭhānam senā byūhanti senā niveso sakaṭa byūha ādi vasena
translated: or to watch those that are fighting. Nibbuddham means a wrestling bout. Uyyodhika means a place where a fight is taking place.

original: senāya nivesanaṃ. Anīkadassananti “tayo hatthī pacchimaṃ hatthānīka”ntiādinā nayena
analyzed: senāya nivesanam anīka dassananti tayaḥ hatthī pacchimam hattha anīkam ti ādinā nayena
translated: Balagga means a place where troops are mustered. Senābyūha means the array of an army, the positioning of the army in the form of a cart, etc. Anīkadassana means the inspection of the army, as follows: “Three elephants in the rear rank are the elephant division,” and so on.

original: vuttassa anīkassa dassanaṃ.
analyzed: vuttassa anīkassa dassanam
translated: and the seeing of the line of march.

original: Na nimittaggāhī hotīti chandarāgavasena vuttappakāraṃ nimittaṃ na gaṇhāti. Evaṃ sesapadānipi
analyzed: na nimitta ggāhī hoti iti chanda rāga vasena vutta ppakāram nimittam na gaṇhāti evam sesa padāni pi
translated: He does not grasp at signs: he does not grasp the signs of the kind already described in the way beginning, “He sees it as a mere sign of desire” . The rest should be understood in the way already described.

original: vuttapaṭipakkhanayena veditabbāni. Yathā ca heṭṭhā javane dussīlyādīsu uppannesu
analyzed: vutta paṭipakkha nayena veditabbāni yathā ca heṭṭhā javane dussīlya ādīsu uppannesu
translated: And just as, when unvirtuousness, etc., arise in the impulsions below,

original: tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi aguttaṃ hoti, bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīnipi vīthicittānīti
analyzed: tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi aguttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni pi vīthi cittāni iti
translated: then, with that lack of restraint, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum, the adverting, etc., and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series are unguarded too,

original: vuttaṃ, evamidha tasmiṃ sīlādīsu uppannesu dvārampi guttaṃ hoti, bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīnipi🔽vīthicittāni. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā nagaradvāresu saṃvutesu kiñcāpi antogharādayo asaṃvutā
analyzed: vuttam evam idha tasmin sīla ādīsu uppannesu dvāram pi guttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni pi  vīthi cittāni yathā kim yathā nagara dvāresu saṃvutesu kiñca api antar ghara ādayaḥ a saṃvutā
translated: so, when virtue, etc., arise in the impulsions here, then, with that restraint, the door is guarded, and the life-continuum, the adverting, etc.,🔽and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series are guarded too. How? Just as, when the city gates are closed, then, although the houses inside, etc., may be unguarded,

original: honti, tathāpi antonagare sabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ surakkhitaṃ sugopitameva hoti, nagaradvāresu
analyzed: honti tathā api antonagare sabbam bhaṇḍam su rakkhitam su gopitam eva hoti nagara dvāresu
translated: nevertheless all the goods in the city are well guarded and well protected, and thieves have no access to the city even at the gates,

original: pihitesu corānaṃ paveso natthi. Evameva javane sīlādīsu uppannesu dvārampi guttaṃ
analyzed: pihitesu corānam pavesaḥ natthi evam eva javane sīla ādīsu uppannesu dvāram pi guttam
translated: so too, when virtue, etc., arise in the impulsions, then, with that restraint, the door is guarded, and the life-continuum, the adverting, etc.,🔽and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series are guarded too.

original: hoti, bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīnipi vīthicittāni. Tasmā javanakkhaṇe uppajjamānopi “cakkhundriye
analyzed: hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni pi vīthi cittāni tasmā java nakkhaṇe uppajjamānaḥ api cakkhu indriye
translated: That is why, although it arises at the javana stage, it is called “restraint of the eye faculty.”

original: saṃvaro”ti vutto. Ito paraṃ heṭṭhā ca upari ca vuttapariyāyena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: saṃvaraḥ ti vuttaḥ itas param heṭṭhā ca upari ca vutta pariyāyena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood by the method stated below and above.

original: Visūkadassanāti paṭāṇīdassanato. Gāmakathāti gāmavāsīnaṃ kathā. Bāttiṃsāti dvattiṃsa.
analyzed: visūka dassanā ti paṭāṇī dassanataḥ gāma kathā ati gāma vāsīnam kathā bāttiṃsā ati dvattiṃsa
translated: “Gossip” is talk about villages, etc., “Thirty-two” is thirty-two.

original: Aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā kathāti tiracchānakathā. Tattha
analyzed: aniyyānika ttā sagga mokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtā kathā ati tiracchāna kathā tattha
translated: It is “animal talk” because it does not lead to the attainment of heaven or deliverance.

original: rājānaṃ ārabbha “mahāsammato mandhātā dhammāsoko evaṃ mahānubhāvo”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: rājānam ārabbha mahāsammataḥ mandhātā dhammāsokaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ iti ādinā nayena
translated: Herein, talk about kings, such as “Mahāsammata, Mandhātu, Dhammāsoka was so and so powerful,” etc.,

original: pavattā kathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu. Tesu “asuko rājā abhirūpo dassanīyo”tiādinā
analyzed: pavattā kathā rāja kathā esa nayo cora kathā ādīsu tesu asukaḥ rājā abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ iti ādinā
translated: is “talk about kings.” The same method applies to talk about thieves, etc. Herein, talk that is mere idle talk, such as “So and so a king is handsome, good-looking,” etc.,

original: nayena gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā hoti. “Sopi nāma evaṃ mahānubhāvo khayaṃ
analyzed: nayena tiracchāna kathā hoti saḥ api nāma evam mahā anubhāvaḥ khayam
translated: is “animal talk.” But that which occurs thus, “He who was so and so powerful has come to an end,

original: gato”ti evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve tiṭṭhati. Coresupi “mūladevo evaṃ mahānubhāvo,
analyzed: gataḥ ti evam pavattā pana kammaṭṭhāna bhāve tiṭṭhati coresu pi mūladevaḥ evam mahā anubhāvo
translated: has perished,” stands as a meditation subject. As regards thieves, “Mūladeva was so and so powerful,

original: meghamālo evaṃ mahānubhāvo”ti tesaṃ kammaṃ paṭicca “aho sūrā”ti gehassitakathāva🔽tiracchānakathā. Yuddhepi bhāratayuddhādīsu “asukena asuko evaṃ mārito evaṃ viddho”ti
analyzed: meghamālaḥ evam mahā anubhāvo ti tesam kammam paṭicca aho sūra ati  tiracchāna kathā yuddhe pi bhārata yuddha ādīsu asukena asukaḥ evam māritaḥ evam viddhaḥ iti
translated: “Megha the seer is so powerful,” and so on.🔽Talk about the war in the past, such as, “So-and-so was killed like this, so-and-so was wounded like this,”

original: kāmassādavaseneva kathā tiracchānakathā. “Tepi nāma khayaṃ gatā”ti evaṃ pavattā pana
analyzed: kāmassāda vasena iva kathā tiracchāna kathā te pi nāma khayam gatā ati evam pavattā pana
translated: is also animal talk. But when it occurs as “Even they have passed away,”

original: sabbattha kammaṭṭhānameva hoti.🔽Api ca annādīsu “evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ gandhavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha🔽bhuñjimha pivimha paribhuñjimhā”ti kāmassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ
analyzed: sabbattha kammaṭṭhānam eva hoti  api ca anna ādīsu evam vaṇṇavantam gandhavantam rasavantam phassa sampannam khādimha  bhuñjimha pivimha paribhuñjimha ati kāma ssāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati sātthakam
translated: it is a meditation subject in all cases.🔽Moreover, it is not proper to talk about food, etc., with relish, saying, “We ate such-and-such food, so beautiful, so tasty, so flavoursome,”

original: pana katvā “pubbe evaṃ vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ sayanaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ
analyzed: pana katvā pubbe evam vaṇṇa ādi sampannam annam pānam vattham sayanam mālam gandham
translated: but it is proper to talk about them with a sense of their meaning, saying, “In the past we gave such-and-such beautiful food, drink, clothes, beds, garlands, scents,

original: sīlavantānaṃ adamha, cetiyapūjaṃ akarimhā”ti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Ñātikathādīsu pana
analyzed: sīlavantānam adamha cetiya pūjam akarimha iti kathetum vaṭṭati ñāti kathā ādīsu pana
translated: to the virtuous, and we made offerings to the shrines.”

original: “amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā”ti vā, “pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi yānehi vicarimhā”ti
analyzed: amhākam ñātakā sūrā samatthā ati vā pubbe mayam evam vicitrehi yānehi vicarimha ati
translated: As regards talk about relatives, etc., it is not proper to say, “Our relatives are powerful and able,” or, “In the past we travelled about in such-and-such various vehicles,”

original: vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “tepi no ñātakā khayaṃ gatā”ti
analyzed: vā assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā te pi no ñātakā khayam gatā ati
translated: but it is not proper to speak of them as if they were still alive. But if it is done with a beneficial purpose, it is proper to say, “They too are dead.”🔽

original: vā, “pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamhā”ti vā kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Gāmakathāpi🔽suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena “asukagāmavāsino sūrā samatthā”ti
analyzed: vā pubbe mayam evarūpāḥ upāhanā saṅghassa adamha ati vā kathetum vaṭṭati gāma kathā api  suniviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha subhikkha dubbhikkha ādi vasena asuka gāma vāsinaḥ sūrā samatthā ti
translated: but it is not allowable to speak of them with relish, saying, “They were our relatives too,” or “Formerly we gave sandals like these to the Community.”🔽It is not allowable to speak of a village with relish, saying, “The people of such-and-such a village are brave and able,”

original: vā evaṃ assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “saddhā pasannā”ti vā,
analyzed: vā evam assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā saddhā pasannā ati vā
translated: according to whether it is well or badly populated, or whether there is good or bad alms resort there, but it is allowable to speak of it with a purpose, saying, “They are faithful and confident,”

original: “khayavayaṃ gatā”ti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: khaya vayam gatā ati vā vattum vaṭṭati
translated: or “They have come to an end and passed away.”

original: Nigamanagarajanapadakathāsupi eseva nayo. Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca🔽assādavasena na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā, khayavayaṃ gatā”ti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi
analyzed: nigama nagara janapada kathāsu pi esa iva nayaḥ itthi kathā api vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīni paṭicca  assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khaya vayam gatā ati evam eva vaṭṭati sūrakathā api
translated: The same method applies to the speaking of a town, a city, and a country. It is not allowable to speak of a woman with relish,🔽according to her complexion, figure, etc., but it is allowable to speak of her with a purpose, saying, “She is faithful and confident,”🔽or “She has come to an end and passed away.” It is not allowable to speak of a hero with relish, saying,

original: “nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosī”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati. “Saddho ahosi, khayavayaṃ
analyzed: nandimittaḥ nāma yodhaḥ sūraḥ ahosi iti assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhaḥ ahosi khaya vayam
translated: “The warrior named So-and-so was a hero,” but it is allowable to say, “He was faithful,” or “He has come to an end and passed away.”

original: gato”ti evameva vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi “asukā visikhā suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā
analyzed: gataḥ ti evam eva vaṭṭati visikhā kathā api asukā visikhā su niviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā
translated: “gone” is allowable. The talk of constellations is not allowable as enjoyment thus: “So-and-so’s constellation is well placed, so-and-so’s is badly placed, so-and-so’s is strong,

original: samatthā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati. “Saddhā pasannā, khayavayaṃ gatā”icceva vaṭṭati.
analyzed: samatthā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khaya vayam gatā iccā iva vaṭṭati
translated: so-and-so’s is weak,” but it is allowable as “Faithful, confident, gone to destruction and disappearance.”

original: Kumbhaṭṭhānakathāti udakaṭṭhānakathā, “udakatitthakathā”tipi vuccati, kumbhadāsikathā
analyzed: kumbha ṭṭhāna kathā ati udaka ṭṭhāna kathā udaka tittha kathā ati pi vuccati kumbhadāsikathā
translated: The talk of water-pots is talk of water-drawing places, which is also called “talk of water-drawing places,” or it is talk of a water-carrying maid,

original: vā. Sāpi “pāsādikā, naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā”tiādinā
analyzed: vā sā api pāsādikā naccitum gāyitum chekā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā ati ādinā
translated: which is not allowable as enjoyment thus: “She is lovely, she is good at dancing, she is good at singing,” but it is allowable as “Faithful, confident,” and so on.

original: nayena vaṭṭati. Pubbapetakathāti atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadisova vinicchayo.
analyzed: nayena vaṭṭati pubba peta kathā ati atīta ñāti kathā tattha vattamāna ñāti kathā sadisaḥ eva vinicchayaḥ
translated: The talk of the past is talk of what has happened in the past. Herein, the exposition is similar to that for talk of what is happening now.

original: Nānattakathāti purimapacchimakathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā niratthakakathā.🔽Lokakkhāyikāti “ayaṃ loko kena nimmito? Asukena nāma nimmito. Kāko seto aṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: nānatta kathā ati purima pacchima kathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānā sabhāvā niratthaka kathā  lokakkhāyikā ti ayam loko kena nimmitaḥ asukena nāma nimmitaḥ kāko seto aṭṭhīnam
translated: The talk of many things is talk about various matters that is unconnected with what is said before and after and is pointless.

original: setattā, balākā rattā lohitassa rattattā”ti evamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā.
analyzed: seta ttā balākā rattā lohitassa ratta ttā ati evamādikā lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā
translated: The talk of the world’s description is talk of the kind beginning thus: “By whom was this world created? It was created by a certain person called so-and-so. The crow is white because its bones are white. The heron is black because its blood is black” .

original: Samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddo sāgaro? Sāgaradevena khatattā sāgaro, “khato me”ti
analyzed: samuddakkhāyikāḥ nāma kasmā samuddaḥ sāgaraḥ sāgara devena khatattā sāgaraḥ khataḥ mā iti
translated: The story of the ocean: why is the ocean called “the ocean”? It is called “the ocean” because it was dug by the ocean-god. “It was dug by me,”

original: hatthamuddāya sayaṃ niveditattā samuddoti evamādikā niratthakā samuddakkhānakathā.
analyzed: hattha muddāya sayam nivedita ttā samuddaḥ ti evamādikā niratthakā samudda khāna kathā
translated: “Sea-stories” : why is the sea called sāgara? Because it was dug by the god Sāgara, therefore it is sāgara. Because he himself announced: “It is dug by me” with his hand raised, therefore it is samudda. Such are the purposeless stories about the sea.

original: Bhavoti vuddhi. Abhavoti hāni. Iti bhavo iti abhavoti yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhavoti hāni iti bhavo iti abhavoti yam vā tam vā niratthaka kāraṇam
translated: “Existence” means increase. “Non-existence” means decrease. “Existence” or “non-existence” is the purposeless talk that goes on after giving a reason in this way or that way.

original: vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā.🔽Āvareyyāti āvaraṇaṃ kareyya. Nivāreyyāti ārammaṇato vāreyya. Saṃvareyyāti sammā nissesaṃ
analyzed: vatvā iti bhava abhava kathā  āvareyya ati āvaraṇam kareyya nivāreyya ati ārammaṇataḥ vāreyya saṃvareyya ati sammā nissesam
translated: “Stories about existence and non-existence” are the stories that go on after giving a reason in this way or that way.🔽“Would obstruct” : would make an obstruction. “Would prevent” : would keep away from the object. “Would restrain” : would keep away completely.

original: katvā vāreyya. Rakkheyyāti rakkhaṃ kareyya. Gopeyyāti saṃgopeyya. Pidaheyyāti pidahanaṃ
analyzed: katvā vāreyya rakkheyya ati rakkham kareyya gopeyya ati saṃgopeyya pidaheyya ati pidahanam
translated: “Would guard” : would make guarding. “Would protect” : would protect. “Would conceal” : would conceal.

original: kareyya. Pacchindeyyāti sotaṃ chindeyya.
analyzed: kareyya pacchindeyya ati sotam chindeyya
translated: “Would cut off” : would cut off the ear.

original: Tena tena na tussantīti tena tena ambilādinā rasena na santosaṃ āpajjanti. Aparāparaṃ pariyesantīti uparūpari gavesanti.
analyzed: tena tena na tussanti iti tena tena ambila ādinā rasena na santosam āpajjanti apara aparam pariyesanti iti upari upari gavesanti
translated: “They are not satisfied with this or that” : they do not attain satisfaction with this or that taste such as sour. “They seek for something else” : they seek for something higher.

original: 158. Phassenāti rogaphassena. Bhavañca nābhijappeyyāti tassa phassassa vinodanatthāya🔽kāmabhavādibhavañca na pattheyya. Bheravesu ca na sampavedheyyāti tassa phassassa🔽paccayabhūtesu sīhabyagghādīsu bheravesu ca na sampavedheyya, avasesesu vā ghānindriyamanindriyavisayesu🔽na sampavedheyya. Evaṃ paripūro indriyasaṃvaro ca vutto hoti. Purimehi vā indriyasaṃvaraṃ
analyzed: phassena ati roga phassena bhavan ca na abhijappeyya ati tassa phassassa vinodana tthāya  kāma bhava ādi bhavam ca na bheravesu ca na sampavedheyya ati tassa phassassa  paccaya bhūtesu sīha byaggha ādīsu bheravesu ca na avasesesu vā gha anindriya manindriya visayesu  na sampavedheyya evam paripūraḥ indriya saṃvaro ca vutto hoti purimehi vā indriya saṃvaram
translated: ‘By the impact’: by the impact of disease. ‘Nor crave for being’: in order to remove that impact🔽he should not crave for the kinds of being in the sense sphere, etc. ‘Nor be afraid of terrifying things’: he should not be afraid of terrifying things such as lions and tigers, which are the conditions for that impact,

original: dassetvā iminā “araññe vasatā bheravaṃ disvā vā sutvā vā nappavedhitabba”nti dasseti.🔽Ekenākārenāti ekena kāraṇena. Bhayampi bheravampi taññevāti bhayanti ca bheravanti
analyzed: dassetvā iminā araññe vasatā bheravam disvā vā sutvā vā na pavedhitabbanti dasseti  ekena ākārena ati ekena kāraṇena bhayam pi bheravam pi tat na eva ati bhayanti ca bheravanti
translated: or of the remaining objects of the nose and tongue faculties. Thus the fulfilment of restraint of the faculties is stated. Or else, having shown restraint of the faculties by the preceding lines, he shows by this line that ‘one who lives in the forest should not be afraid on seeing or hearing terrifying things.’

original: ca khuddakampi mahantampi uttāsanimittameva. Tamevatthaṃ dassetuṃ “vuttaṃ heta”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: ca khuddakam pi mahantam pi uttāsa nimittam eva tam eva attham dassetum vuttam hetat ti ādim āha
translated: ‘By one means’: by one cause. ‘Fear and terror are just that’: fear and terror are just the sign of terror, whether slight or great. In order to show that meaning he said ‘For this is said’ .

original: Bhayanti tappaccayā uppannabhayaṃ. Bhayānakanti ākāraniddeso. Chambhitattanti bhayavasena
analyzed: bhayanti tad paccayāḥ uppanna bhayam bhayānakam ti ākāra niddeso chambhita ttam ti bhaya vasena
translated: Fear: the fear that has arisen because of that. Frightening: this is a description of the mode. Terrified: by reason of fear.

original: gattacalanaṃ. Lomahaṃsoti lomānaṃ haṃsanaṃ uddhaggabhāvo. Iminā padadvayena kiccato
analyzed: gatta calanam lomahaṃso ti lomānam haṃsanam uddhagga bhāvaḥ iminā pada dvayena kiccato
translated: ‘Fear’ is the fear arisen from that. ‘Dread’ is a description of the mode. ‘Terror’ is the trembling of the body through fear. ‘Horripilation’ is the bristling of the hairs through fear. By these two terms he shows fear as a function.

original: bhayaṃ dassetvā puna “cetaso ubbego utrāso”ti sabhāvato dasseti. Ubbeggoti bhīruko,
analyzed: bhayam dassetvā puna cetasaḥ ubbegaḥ utrāsaḥ ti sabhāvataḥ dasseti ubbeggaḥ uti bhīrukaḥ
translated: Having shown fear as a function, he shows it again as a state of being with ‘agitation of the mind, a state of perturbation’. ‘Agitation’ is fearfulness.

original: utrāsoti cittakkhobho. Jātibhayanti jātiṃ paṭicca uppannabhayaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: citta kkhobhaḥ jāti bhayanti jātim paṭicca uppanna bhayam sesesu pi esa eva nayo
translated: ‘Perturbation’ is mental disturbance. ‘Fear of birth’ is the fear arisen from birth. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the rest.

original: Rājato uppannabhayaṃ rājabhayaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Attānuvādabhayanti pāpakammino
analyzed: rājataḥ uppanna bhayam rāja bhayam sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ atta anuvāda bhayanti pāpa kammino
translated: ‘Fear of kings’ is the fear arisen from kings. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the rest. ‘Fear of blame’ is the fear arisen in one who has done evil

original: attānaṃ anuvadantassa uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Parānuvādabhayanti parassa anuvādato uppajjanakabhayaṃ.🔽Daṇḍabhayanti āgārikassa raññā pavattitadaṇḍaṃ, anāgārikassa vinayadaṇḍaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: attānam anuvadantassa uppajjanaka bhayam para anuvāda bhayanti parassa anuvādataḥ uppajjanaka bhayam  daṇḍa bhayanti āgārikassa raññā pavattita daṇḍam anāgārikassa vinaya daṇḍam paṭicca
translated: through self-reproach. ‘Fear of punishment’ is the fear arisen through the reproach of others.

original: uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Duggatibhayanti cattāro apāye paṭicca uppajjanakabhayaṃ. Ūmibhayanti
analyzed: uppajjanaka bhayam duggati bhayanti cattāraḥ apāye paṭicca uppajjanaka bhayam ūmi bhayanti
translated: ‘Fear of a bad destination’ is the fear arisen through the four bad destinations. ‘Fear of waves’ is the fear arisen in one who is afraid of waves.

original: mahāsamudde udakaṃ orohantassa pavattabhayaṃ. Mahāsamudde kira mahindavīci nāma saṭṭhi
analyzed: mahā samudde udakam orohantassa pavatta bhayam mahā samudde kira mahindavīci nāma
translated: The danger that arises when the water in the ocean is receding is the danger of the ocean’s receding. It seems that in the ocean there is a wave called the “Mahinda wave” which rises 60 leagues high,

original: yojanāni uggacchati, taraṅgavīci nāma paṇṇāsa yojanāni, rohaṇavīci nāma cattālīsa🔽yojanāni uggacchati. Evarūpā ūmiyo paṭicca pavattaṃ ūmibhayaṃ. Kumbhīlato pavattaṃ
analyzed: yojanāni uggacchati taraṅgavīci nāma paṇṇāsa yojanāni rohaṇavīci nāma cattālīsa  yojanāni uggacchati evarūpāḥ ūmiyaḥ paṭicca pavattam ūmi bhayam kumbhīlato pavattam
translated: a wave called the “Taraṅga wave” which rises 50 leagues high, and a wave called the “Rohaṇa wave” which rises 40 leagues high.

original: bhayaṃ kumbhīlabhayaṃ. Udakāvaṭṭato bhayaṃ āvaṭṭabhayaṃ. Susukā vuccati caṇḍamaccho,
analyzed: bhayam kumbhīla bhayam udaka avaṭṭataḥ bhayam āvaṭṭa bhayam susukā vuccati caṇḍamaccho
translated: The danger that arises because of such waves is the danger of the waves. The danger that arises from the “pot-belly” is the danger of the pot-belly. The danger that arises from the “whirlpool” is the danger of the whirlpool. The “susuka” is a kind of fierce fish;

original: tato bhayaṃ susukābhayaṃ. Ājīvikabhayanti jīvitavuttito bhayaṃ ājīvikabhayaṃ. Asilokabhayanti garahato bhayaṃ.
analyzed: tatas bhayam susukā bhayam ājīvika bhayanti jīvita vuttitaḥ bhayam ājīvika bhayam asi loka bhayanti garahataḥ bhayam
translated: the danger that arises from it is the danger of the susuka. The danger of livelihood is the danger that arises from the means of living. The danger of bad reputation is the danger that arises from blame.

original: 159. Laddhā na sannidhiṃ kayirāti etesaṃ annādīnaṃ yaṃkiñci dhammena labhitvā “araññe ca senāsane vasatā dullabha”nti cintetvā sannidhiṃ na kareyya.
analyzed: laddhā na sannidhim etesam anna ādīnam yaṃ kiñci dhammena labhitvā araññe ca senāsane vasatā dullabhanti cintetvā sannidhim na kareyya
translated: Having obtained, he should not make a store: having obtained any of these things such as food, etc., in accordance with the Dhamma, he should not make a store, thinking, “It is difficult to get these things while living in the forest and in the dwelling for seclusion.”

original: Odanoti sāli vīhi yavo godhumo kaṅgu varako kudrūsakoti sattannaṃ dhaññānaṃ dhaññānulomānañca
analyzed: odanaḥ uti sāli vīhi yavaḥ godhumaḥ kaṅgu varako kudrūsakaḥ iti sattannam dhaññānam dhañña anulomānam ca
translated: Rice, etc.: of the seven kinds of grain, namely, rice, barley, wheat, green gram, cow-pea, millet, and leeks, and of the things that are similar to grain.

original: taṇḍulehi nibbatto. Kummāsoti yavehi nibbatto. Sattūti sāliādīhi katasattu. Maccho
analyzed: taṇḍulehi nibbatto kummāso ti yavehi nibbatto sattu uti sāli ādīhi kata sattu macchaḥ
translated: Rice-gruel: made with rice. Barley-gruel: made with barley. Meat-juice: made with rice, etc. Fish:

original: dakasambhavo. Maṃsaṃ pākaṭameva. Ambapānanti āmehi vā pakkehi vā ambehi katapānaṃ.🔽Tattha āmehi karontena ambataruṇāni bhinditvā udake pakkhipitvā ātape ādiccapākena
analyzed: daka sambhavaḥ maṃsam pākaṭam eva amba pānam ti āmehi vā pakkehi vā ambehi kata pānam  tattha āmehi karontena amba taruṇāni bhinditvā udake pakkhipitvā ātape ādicca pākena
translated: born in water. Meat: obvious. Palm-juice: made with unripe or ripe palmyra fruits.🔽Herein, one who makes it with unripe fruits should break open the young palmyra fruits, put them in water,

original: pacitvā parissāvetvā tadahu paṭiggahitehi madhusakkarakappūrādīhi yojetvā kātabbaṃ.🔽Jambupānanti jambuphalehi katapānaṃ. Cocapānanti aṭṭhikehi kadaliphalehi katapānaṃ.
analyzed: pacitvā parissāvetvā tadahu paṭiggahitehi madhu sakkara kappūra ādīhi yojetvā kātabbam  jambu pānam ti jambu phalehi kata pānam coca pānam ti aṭṭhikehi kadali phalehi kata pānam
translated: boil them in the sun, strain them, and mix them with honey, sugar, cloves, etc., that have been obtained on that same day.🔽Rose-apple juice: made with rose-apples. Sugar-cane juice: made with sugar-canes.

original: Mocapānanti anaṭṭhikehi kadaliphalehi katapānaṃ. Madhukapānanti madhukānaṃ jātirasena
analyzed: moca pānam ti anaṭṭhikehi kadali phalehi kata pānam madhuka pānam ti madhukānam jāti rasena
translated: Betel-juice: made with betel. Honey-juice: made with honey.

original: katapānaṃ. Taṃ pana udakasambhinnaṃ vaṭṭati, suddhaṃ na vaṭṭati. Muddikapānanti muddikā
analyzed: kata pānam tam pana udaka sambhinnam vaṭṭati suddham na vaṭṭati muddika pānam ti muddikā
translated: But that is allowable mixed with water; pure, it is not allowable. Syrup: made with sugar, etc.,

original: udake madditvā ambapānaṃ viya katapānaṃ. Sālūkapānanti rattuppalanīluppalādīnaṃ sālūke
analyzed: udake madditvā amba pānam viya kata pānam sālūka pānam rattuppala nīluppala ādīnam sālūke
translated: like palm-juice. Lotus-juice: made with red or blue lotuses, etc.,

original: madditvā katapānaṃ. Phārusakapānanti phārusakehi ambapānaṃ viya katapānaṃ. Kosambapānanti
analyzed: madditvā kata pānam phārusaka pānanti phārusakehi amba pānam viya kata pānam kosamba pānanti
translated: What is made by squeezing is what is made by squeezing out the juice of the fruits. The eleven kinds of drinks are these:🔽Palm-juice drink, which is made from the palm fruit;🔽Kosambī drink, which is made from the kosambī fruit;🔽kola drink, which is made from the kola fruit;

original: kosambaphalehi katapānaṃ. Kolapānanti kolaphalehi katapānaṃ. Badarapānanti mahākolaphalehi
analyzed: kosamba phalehi kata pānam kola pānanti kola phalehi kata pānam badara pānanti mahā kola phalehi
translated: badara drink, which is made from the large kola fruit like palm-juice drink;

original: ambapānaṃ viya katapānaṃ. Imāni ekādasa pānāni, tānipi ādiccapākāni vaṭṭanti.
analyzed: amba pānam viya kata pānam imāni ekādasa pānāni tāni api ādicca pākāni vaṭṭanti
translated: these are the eleven kinds of drinks. These are allowed if they are not intoxicating.

original: Ghatapānanti sappipānaṃ. Telapānanti tilatelādīnaṃ pānaṃ. Payopānanti khīrapānaṃ.
analyzed: ghata pānam ti sappi pānam tela pānam tila tela ādīnam pānam payaḥ pānam ti khīra pānam
translated: Ghatapāna is a drink made from herbs. Oil drink is a drink made from sesame oil, etc. Milk drink is a drink made from cow’s milk, etc.

original: Yāgupānanti sītalādiyāgupānaṃ. Rasapānanti sākādirasapānaṃ. Piṭṭhakhajjakanti sattannaṃ
analyzed: yāgu pānam ti sītala ādi yāgu pānam rasa pānam ti sāka ādi rasa pānam piṭṭhakhajjakanti
translated: Rice-gruel drink is a drink made from cold rice-gruel, etc. Juice drink is a drink made from the juice of vegetables, etc. Powdered-cake is what is made from the powder of the seven cereals, of what is similar to the seven cereals, and of other fruits,

original: tāva dhaññānaṃ dhaññānulomānaṃ aparaṇṇānañca piṭṭhaṃ panasapiṭṭhaṃ labujapiṭṭhaṃ🔽ambāṭakapiṭṭhaṃ sālapiṭṭhaṃ khīravallipiṭṭhañcāti evamādīnaṃ piṭṭhehi kataṃ piṭṭhakhajjakaṃ.
analyzed: tāva dhaññānam dhaññānulomānam aparaṇṇānam ca piṭṭham panasa piṭṭham labuja piṭṭham  ambāṭaka piṭṭham sāla piṭṭham khīra valli piṭṭham ca ati evamādīnam piṭṭhehi katam piṭṭhakhajjakam
translated: such as the powder of rice, the powder of beans, the powder of lentils,🔽the powder of horse gram, the powder of sesame, the powder of jujube, and the powder of milk vine.

original: Pūvakhajjakampi etehiyeva kataṃ. Mūlakhajjakanti mūlakamūlaṃ khārakamūlaṃ cuccumūlanti
analyzed: pūvakhajjakampi katam mūlakhajjakanti mūlaka mūlam khāraka mūlam cuccumūlanti
translated: Powdered-cake is made from these powders. Cake is made from the same things. Root-cake is what is made from the root of the sweet potato, the root of the white yam, the root of the cassava,

original: evamādi. Tacakhajjakanti ucchutacādayo. Pattakhajjakanti nimbapaṇṇakuṭajapaṇṇapaṭolapaṇṇasulasapaṇṇādayo.
analyzed: evamādi taca khajjakanti ucchu taca ādayaḥ patta khajjakanti nimba paṇṇa kuṭaja paṇṇa paṭola paṇṇa sulasa paṇṇa ādayaḥ
translated: and so on. “Edible garden produce” is garlic, etc. “Edible forest produce” is neem leaves, kuṭaja leaves, snake-gourd leaves, sulasa leaves, etc.

original: Pupphakhajjakanti mūlakapupphakhārakapupphasetavaraṇasigguuppalapadumakādayo. Phalakhajjakanti🔽panasalabujatālanāḷikeraambāṭakatintiṇikamātuluṅgakapiṭṭhaphalaalābukumbhaṇḍaphussa-
analyzed: puppha khajjakanti mūlaka puppha khāraka puppha setavaraṇa siggu uppala padumaka ādayaḥ phala khajjakanti  panasa labuja tāla nāḷikera ambāṭaka tintiṇika mātuluṅgaka piṭṭhaphala alābu kumbhaṇḍa phussa
translated: “Edible flowers” is the root-flower, the khāraka flower, the white varāṇa flower, the siggu flower, the lotus flower, etc. “Edible fruits” is🔽the fruit of the pansala, the buja, the tāla, the nāḷikerā, the ambāṭaka, the tinduka, the mātuṅga, the kaṇḍu, the ālabu, the kumbhaṇḍa, the phussa,

original: phalatimbarūsakatilavātiṅgaṇacocamocamadhukādīnaṃ phalānaṃ khajjakaṃ.
analyzed: phala timba rūsaka tila vātiṅgaṇa coca moca madhuka ādīnam khajjakam
translated: the timbaru, the ūsaka, the tilavāti, the gaṇḍha, the camoca, the moca, the madhu, etc.

original: Na kuhanāyāti na vimhāpanāya. Na lapanāyāti paccayatthaṃ na lapanāya. Vihāraṃ āgate
analyzed: na kuhanāya ati na vimhāpanāya na lapanāya ati paccaya ttham na lapanāya vihāram āgate
translated: “Not for the sake of amusement” is not for the purpose of entertainment. “Not for the sake of ornamentation” is not for the purpose of beautifying the body. When people come to the monastery

original: manusse disvā “kimatthāya bhonto āgatā”ti bhikkhū nimantetunti. “Yadi evaṃ gacchatha,
analyzed: manusse disvā kimatthāya bhontaḥ āgatā ati bhikkhū nimantetun ti yadi evam gacchatha
translated: and see the monks, they ask, “What is the purpose of your coming, sirs?” “To invite the monks.” “If that is so, then go and

original: ahaṃ pacchato gahetvā āgacchāmī”ti evaṃ na lapanāya. Atha vā attānaṃ upanetvā “ahaṃ
analyzed: aham pacchatas gahetvā āgacchāmi iti evam na lapanāya atha vā attānam upanetvā aham
translated: tell the monks.” “I will come after taking this.” In this way, not for the purpose of beautifying the body. Or else, after introducing oneself, “I am

original: tisso, mayi rājā pasanno, mayi asuko rājā asuko ca rājamahāmatto pasanno”ti evaṃ
analyzed: tissaḥ mayi rājā pasannaḥ mayi asukaḥ rājā asukaḥ ca rāja mahāmatto pasannaḥ iti evam
translated: a thera, the king is pleased with me, the king and the king’s chief minister are pleased with me,” in this way,🔽not for the purpose of beautifying the body.

original: na lapanāya. Na nemittikatāyāti yena kenaci paresaṃ paccayadānasaññājanakena kāyavacīkammena
analyzed: na lapanāya na nemittika tāya ati yena kenacid paresam paccaya dāna saññā janakena kāya vacī kammena
translated: Not for the sake of boasting. Not for the sake of hinting: not for the sake of hinting by some bodily or verbal act that one is in need of requisites.🔽Not for the sake of winking: winking is a sign made with the eyes.🔽Not for the sake of giving a broad hint: a broad hint is a sign made by speech.🔽Not for the sake of indirect talk: indirect talk is talk that leads to other talk.🔽Not for the sake of fortune-telling: fortune-telling is the telling of good or bad luck.

original: na nemittikatāya. Na nippesikatāyāti yā paresaṃ akkosanādikiriyā yasmā veḷupesikā🔽viya abbhaṅgaṃ parassa guṇaṃ nippeseti nipuñchati, yasmā vā gandhajātaṃ nipisitvā🔽gandhamagganā viya paraguṇe nipisitvā vicuṇṇetvā esā lābhamagganā hoti, tasmā “nippesikatā”ti
analyzed: na nemittika tāya na nippesika tāya ati yā paresam akkosana ādi kiriyā yasmā veḷu pesikā  viya abbhaṅgam parassa guṇam nippeseti nipuñchati yasmai vā gandha jātam nipisitvā  gandha magganā viya para guṇe nipisitvā vicuṇṇetvā esā lābha magganā hoti tasmā
translated: Not for the sake of the divine: the divine is the telling of omens.🔽Not for the sake of the heavenly: the heavenly is the telling of dreams.🔽Not for the sake of the brutish: the brutish is the telling of portents.

original: vuccati. Na evarūpāya nippesikatāya. Na lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanatāyāti ettha nijigīsanatāti
analyzed: vuccati na evarūpāya nippesika tāya na lābhena lābham nijigīsana tāya ati ettha nijigīsana tā ati
translated: Not for the sake of the mundane: the mundane is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a place.🔽Not for the sake of the supermundane: the supermundane is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a path.

original: magganā, aññato laddhañhi aññattha haraṇavasena lābhena lābhamagganā nāma hoti. Na🔽evarūpāya lābhena lābhamagganāya.
analyzed: magganā aññatas laddhan hi aññattha haraṇa vasena lābhena lābha magganā nāma hoti na  evarūpāya lābhena lābha magganāya
translated: Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.🔽Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a forest.🔽Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.🔽Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a forest.🔽Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.🔽Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a forest.🔽Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.🔽Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a forest.🔽Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.🔽Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a forest.🔽Not for the sake of the worldly: the worldly is the telling of the good and bad aspects of a village.

original: Na dārudānenāti na paccayahetukena dārudānena vihāre uṭṭhitañhi araññato vā āharitvā
analyzed: na dāru dānena ati na paccaya hetukena dāru dānena vihāre uṭṭhitam hi araññataḥ vā āharitvā
translated: Not for the sake of the unworldly: the unworldly is the

original: rakkhitagopitadāruṃ “evaṃ me paccayaṃ dassantī”ti upaṭṭhākānaṃ dātuṃ na vaṭṭati.🔽Evañhi jīvikaṃ kappento anesanāya micchājīvena jīvati, so diṭṭheva dhamme garahaṃ
