analyzed: rakkhita gopita dārum evam me paccayam dassanti iti upaṭṭhākānam dātum na vaṭṭati  evam hi jīvikam kappentaḥ an esanāya micchājīvena jīvati so diṭṭhe iva dhamme garaham
translated: If he gives it to his attendants to give to those who will supply him with requisites, thinking, “They will give me requisites in return,” it is not allowable.

original: pāpuṇāti, samparāye ca apāyaparipūrako hoti. Attano puggalikaṃ dāruṃ kusalaṅgahatthāya🔽dadanto kuladūsakadukkaṭaṃ āpajjati, parapuggalikaṃ theyyacittena dadanto bhaṇḍagghena
analyzed: pāpuṇāti samparāye ca apāya paripūrakaḥ hoti attanaḥ puggalikam dārum kusalaṅga hatthāya  dadantaḥ kula dūsaka dukkaṭam āpajjati parapuggalikam theyya cittena dadantaḥ bhaṇḍagghena
translated: For by so doing he lives by a wrong means of livelihood, and he is one who “lives by a wrong means of livelihood in a bad way,” and he is “one who has undertaken a training rule in a bad way.” He gets a bad reputation in this world, and in the next world he is filled with the states of loss.

original: kāretabbo. Saṅghikepi eseva nayo. Sace pana taṃ issaratāya deti, garubhaṇḍavissajjanaṃ
analyzed: kāretabbo saṅghike pi esā iva nayaḥ sace pana tam issaratāya deti garu bhaṇḍa vissajjanam
translated: If he gives his own wood for the purpose of making merit, he commits an offense entailing confession for corrupting families. If he gives another person’s wood with the intention of stealing it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession. The same is said of the Sangha’s wood. But if he gives it because he is the Sangha’s superior, he commits an offense entailing confession for misappropriating what has not been given.

original: āpajjati. Kataraṃ pana dāru garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti, kataraṃ na hotīti? Yaṃ tāva aropimaṃ
analyzed: āpajjati kataram pana dāru garu bhaṇḍam hoti kataram na hoti iti yam tāva
translated: But what kind of wood is to be considered valuable and what kind is not?

original: sayaṃjātaṃ, taṃ saṅghena paricchinnaṭṭhāneyeva garubhaṇḍaṃ, tato paraṃ na garubhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: sayaṃjātam tam saṅghena garu bhaṇḍam tato param na garu bhaṇḍam
translated: The wood that has been planted and that has grown by itself is to be considered valuable only in the place that has been set aside by the Sangha. It is not to be considered valuable elsewhere.

original: Ropimaṭṭhāne ca sabbena sabbaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ, pamāṇato sūcidaṇḍakappamāṇaṃ garubhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: ropima ṭṭhāne ca sabbena sabbam garubhaṇḍam pamāṇato sūci daṇḍaka pamāṇam garubhaṇḍam
translated: And the wood that has been planted is to be considered valuable everywhere. Wood that is as much as a cubit long is to be considered valuable.

original: Na veḷudānenātiādīsupi na veḷudānenāti na paccayahetukena veḷudānenātiādi sabbaṃ
analyzed: na veḷu dānena ati ādīsu pi na veḷu dānena ati na paccaya hetukena veḷu dānena ati ādi sabbam
translated: In the case of the rest of the passages beginning with “not by the gift of bamboos,” etc., “not by the gift of bamboos” means not by a gift of bamboos as a condition, etc.

original: na dārudānenāti ettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Veḷu pana pamāṇato telanāḷippamāṇo🔽garubhaṇḍaṃ, na tato heṭṭhā. Manussā vihāraṃ gantvā veḷuṃ yācanti, bhikkhū “saṅghiko”ti🔽dātuṃ na visahanti, manussā punappunaṃ yācanti vā tajjenti vā, tadā bhikkhūhi “daṇḍakammaṃ
analyzed: na dāru dānena āti ettha vutta nayena iva veditabbam veḷu pana pamāṇato tela nāḷi pamāṇaḥ  garu bhaṇḍam na tatas heṭṭhā manussāḥ vihāram gantvā veḷum yācanti bhikkhū saṅghiko ti  dātum na visahanti manussā punappunam yācanti vā tajjenti vā tadā bhikkhūhi daṇḍa kammaṃ
translated: In the case of the rest of the passage beginning with “not by giving bamboo” it should be understood in the way already given in the case of “not by giving wood.” But bamboo is heavy goods if it is the size of a sugar-cane stalk;

original: katvā gaṇhathā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭati, veḷudānaṃ nāma na hoti. Sace te daṇḍakammatthāya
analyzed: katvā gaṇhatha iti vattum vaṭṭati veḷudānam nāma na hoti sace te daṇḍa kammatthāya
translated: it is not if it is less than that. People come to the monastery and ask for bamboo. The bhikkhus, thinking it belongs to the Community, do not dare to give it. The people ask again and again or remind them. Then the bhikkhus may say, “Take it after you have done the work of cutting it down,” but it is not a case of giving bamboo.

original: vāsipharasuādīni vā khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā denti, gahetuṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vā khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam vā denti gahetum na vaṭṭati
translated: If they give an axe, a saw, etc., for the work of cutting it down, or if they give fresh or cooked food, it is not allowable to accept it.

original: Vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “daḍḍhagehā manussā gaṇhitvā gacchantā na vāretabbā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vinaya ṭṭhakathāyam pana daḍḍha gehāḥ manussāḥ gaṇhitvā gacchantā na vāretabbā iti vuttam
translated: But in the Vinaya Commentary it is said that people whose houses have been burnt down and who are going away may take it without asking for it.

original: Sace saṅghassa veḷugumbe veḷudūsikā uppajjati, taṃ akoṭṭāpentānaṃ veḷu nassati. “Kiṃ
analyzed: sace saṅghassa veḷu gumbe veḷu dūsikā uppajjati tam a koṭṭāpentānam veḷu nassati kim
translated: If a disease of bamboo arises in the bamboo grove belonging to the Community, the bamboo perishes if it is not cut down. “What is to be done?”

original: kātabba”nti bhikkhācāre manussānaṃ ācikkhitabbaṃ. Sace koṭṭetuṃ na icchanti, “samaṃ
analyzed: kātabbanti bhikkhācāre manussānam ācikkhitabbam sace koṭṭetum na icchanti samam
translated: He should announce it to people who are begging for alms. If they do not want to cut it, he should say, “You will get an equal share.”

original: bhāgaṃ labhissathā”ti vattabbā. Na icchantiyeva, “dve koṭṭhāse labhissathā”ti vattabbā.
analyzed: bhāgam labhissatha iti vattabbā na icchantiyā iva dve koṭṭhāse labhissatha iti vattabbā
translated: If they still do not want it, he should say, “You will get two shares.”

original: Evampi anicchantesu naṭṭhena attho natthi, “tumhākaṃ khaṇe sati daṇḍakammaṃ karissatha,🔽koṭṭetvā gaṇhathā”ti vattabbā, veḷudānaṃ nāma na hoti. Veḷugumbe aggimhi uṭṭhitepi
analyzed: evam pi an icchantesu naṭṭhena atthaḥ natthi tumhākam khaṇe sati daṇḍa kammam karissatha  koṭṭetvā gaṇhatha ati vattabbā veḷu dānam nāma na hoti veḷu gumbe aggimhi uṭṭhite pi
translated: If they still do not want it, there is no point in losing it. He should say, “If you don’t take it, you will be punished.🔽Take it after cutting it.” It is not a gift of bamboo.

original: udakena vuyhamānaveḷūsupi eseva nayo.🔽Pattadāne garubhaṇḍatāya ayaṃ vinicchayo – pattampi hi yattha vikkāyati, gandhakārādayo
analyzed: udakena vuyhamāna veḷū supi esā iva nayaḥ  patta dāne ayam vinicchayaḥ
translated: If a fire breaks out in a bamboo grove, or if the bamboo is being carried away by water, the same rule applies.

original: gandhapaliveṭhanādīnaṃ atthāya gaṇhanti, tādise dullabhaṭṭhāneyeva garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti.
analyzed: gandha paliveṭhana ādīnam atthāya gaṇhanti tādise dullabha ṭṭhāneyā iva garubhaṇḍam hoti
translated: As for the giving of leaves, the following is the rule for determining whether it is a heavy or a light article: Leaves are heavy only in places where they are rare, such as in the perfume-makers’ village, where they are used for making fans, for wrapping up perfumes, etc.

original: Esa tāva kiṃsukapattakaṇṇapiḷandhanatālapattādīsu vinicchayo. Tālapaṇṇampi imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: esa tāva kiṃsuka patta kaṇṇa piḷandhana tāla patta ādīsu vinicchayaḥ tāla paṇṇam pi
translated: This is the rule for determining whether the leaves of the kimsuka, the piḷandhu, the tāla, etc., are heavy or light. The leaves of the tāla tree are also used in the same way.

original: ṭhāne kathetabbaṃ – tālapaṇṇampi hi sayaṃjāte tālavane saṅghena paricchinnaṭṭhāneyeva
analyzed: ṭhāne kathetabbam tāla paṇṇam pi hi sayaṃjāte tāla vane saṅghena paricchinna ṭṭhāneya iva
translated: If it is to be spoken of in its proper place, then even a palm leaf is heavy property only in a place that has been defined by the Sangha as such in a palm grove that has grown up by itself.

original: garubhaṇḍaṃ, na tato paraṃ, ropimatālesu sabbampi garubhaṇḍaṃ, tassa pamāṇaṃ heṭṭhimakoṭiyā
analyzed: garu bhaṇḍam na tato param ropima tālesu sabbam pi garu bhaṇḍam tassa pamāṇam heṭṭhima koṭiyā
translated: But not beyond that. In planted palm groves all the palms are heavy property. The measure of it is this.

original: aṭṭhaṅgulappamāṇopi rittapotthako. Tiṇampi ettheva pakkhipitvā kathetabbaṃ. Yattha🔽pana tiṇaṃ natthi, tattha tālanāḷikerapaṇṇādīhipi chādenti. Tasmā tānipi tiṇeneva
analyzed: aṭṭha aṅgula ppamāṇaḥ api ritta potthakaḥ tiṇam pi ettha iva pakkhipitvā kathetabbam yattha  pana tiṇam natthi tattha chādenti tasmā tāni pi tiṇena iva
translated: Even a potsherd eight fingerbreadths long is heavy property. Grass is to be spoken of in the same way as that.🔽But where there is no grass, they cover it with palm leaves, etc., from palm leaf huts. So these are included by the word “grass.”

original: saṅgahitāni. Iti muñjapalālādīsu yaṃkiñci muṭṭhippamāṇaṃ tiṇaṃ. Nāḷikerapaṇṇādīsu🔽ca ekapaṇṇampi saṅghassa dinnaṃ vā tattha jātaṃ vā bahiārāme saṅghassa tiṇavatthumhi🔽jātatiṇaṃ vā rakkhitagopitaṃ vā garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Taṃ pana saṅghakamme ca cetiyakamme
analyzed: saṅgahitāni iti muñja palāla ādīsu yaṃkiñci muṭṭhippamāṇam tiṇam nāḷikera paṇṇa ādīsu  ca eka paṇṇam pi saṅghassa dinnam vā tattha jātam vā bahi ārāme saṅghassa tiṇa vatthumhi  jāta tiṇam vā rakkhita gopitam vā garu bhaṇḍam hoti tam pana saṅgha kamme ca cetiya kamme
translated: So any handful of munja grass, reeds, etc.,🔽and any single palm leaf, etc., given to the Sangha or grown in a monastery outside the territory of a particular monastery, is heavy property in the grass plot belonging to the Sangha.

original: ca kate atirekaṃ puggalikakamme dātuṃ vaṭṭati. Heṭṭhā vuttadāruveḷūsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ca kate atirekam puggalika kamme dātum vaṭṭati heṭṭhā vutta dāru veḷūsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: But when work is being done for the benefit of the Sangha or for a shrine, it is allowable to give the surplus to an individual. The same method applies to the wood and bamboo mentioned above.

original: Pupphadāne “ettakesu rukkhesu pupphāni vissajjitvā yāgubhattatthāya upanentu, ettakesu
analyzed: puppha dāne ettakesu rukkhesu pupphāni vissajjitvā yāgu bhatta tthāya upanentu ettakesu
translated: In the case of the flower-offering, he should say, “Having offered the flowers to the trees, bring them for the rice gruel and for the meal.

original: senāsanapaṭisaṅkharaṇe upanentū”ti evaṃ niyamitaṭṭhāneyeva pupphāni garubhaṇḍāni🔽honti. Yadi sāmaṇerā pupphāni ocinitvā rāsiṃ karonti, pañcaṅgasamannāgato pupphabhājako
analyzed: senāsana paṭisaṅkharaṇe upanentu uti evam niyamita ṭṭhāneya iva pupphāni garubhaṇḍāni  honti yadi sāmaṇerā pupphāni ocinitvā rāsim karonti pañcaṅga samannāgato puppha bhājako
translated: In the case of flowers given for distribution, the flowers are heavy goods only in the place where they have been allocated thus, “Take these flowers to the trees and distribute them for the making of medicinal pills; take these to the refectory and distribute them for the making of medicinal drinks; take these to the sick ward and distribute them for the sick to smell; take these to the monastery and distribute them for the decoration of the shrine terrace and the Uposatha pavilion.”

original: bhikkhu bhikkhusaṅghaṃ gaṇetvā koṭṭhāse karoti. So sampattaparisāya saṅghaṃ anāpucchitvāva
analyzed: bhikkhu bhikkhu saṅgham gaṇetvā koṭṭhāse karoti saḥ sampatta parisāya saṅgham an āpucchitvā ava
translated: If the novices gather the flowers and make a heap, then a monk who distributes flowers possessing five qualities should count the resident monks and make them into groups. He is then allowed to give the flowers to the assembly without asking the Order. But if he is not agreed upon, he should give them after asking.

original: dātuṃ labhati. Asammatena pana āpucchitvā dātabbaṃ. Bhikkhuno pana kassa pupphāni🔽dātuṃ labbhati, kassa na labbhatīti? Mātāpitūnaṃ gehaṃ haritvāpi gehato pakkosāpetvāpi🔽“vatthupūjaṃ karothā”ti dātuṃ labbhati, piḷandhanatthāya na labbhati. Sesañātīnaṃ
analyzed: dātum labhati asammatena pana āpucchitvā dātabbam bhikkhuno pana kassa pupphāni  dātum labbhati kassa na labbhati iti mātā pitūnam geham haritvā api gehataḥ pakkosāpetvā api  vatthu pūjam karotha ati dātum labbhati piḷandhana atthāya na labbhati sesa ñātīnam
translated: But to whom is a monk allowed to give flowers and to whom is he not allowed?

original: pana haritvā na dātabbaṃ, pakkosāpetvā pūjanatthāya dātabbaṃ. Sesajanassa pūjanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana haritvā na dātabbam pakkosāpetvā pūjana tthāya dātabbam sesa janassa pūjana ṭhānam
translated: He is allowed to give them to his mother and father after taking them to their house or after having them brought to the monastery, saying, “Make an offering with the flowers.” He is not allowed to give them for the purpose of making garlands. But he is not allowed to give them to others after taking them to their house. He is allowed to give them for the purpose of making an offering after having them brought to the monastery. As regards the rest of the people,

original: sampattassa apaccāsīsantena dātabbaṃ, pupphadānaṃ nāma na hoti.
analyzed: sampattassa a paccāsīsantena dātabbam puppha dānam nāma na hoti
translated: If he has received it, he should give it to those who are not yet back. It is not a gift of flowers.

original: Vihāre bahūni pupphāni pupphanti, bhikkhunā piṇḍāya carantena manusse disvā “vihāre🔽bahūni pupphāni pūjethā”ti vattabbaṃ, vacanamatte doso natthi, “manussā khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ
analyzed: vihāre bahūni pupphāni pupphanti bhikkhunā piṇḍāya carantena manusse disvā vihāre  bahūni pupphāni pūjetha iti vattabbam vacana matte doso natthi manussā khādanīya bhojanīyam
translated: If there are many flowers in the monastery, and a monk who is walking for alms sees people, he may say, “There are many flowers in the monastery.

original: ādāya āgamissantī”ti cittena pana na vattabbaṃ. Sace vadati, khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ🔽na paribhuñjitabbaṃ. Manussā attano dhammatāya “vihāre pupphāni atthī”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: ādāya āgamissanti iti cittena pana na vattabbam sace vadati khādanīya bhojanīyam  na paribhuñjitabbam manussāḥ attanaḥ dhammatāya vihāre pupphāni atthi iti pucchitvā
translated: Worship with them.” There is no offense in saying this. But he should not say it with the thought, “People will bring fresh or cooked food.” If he does say it, he should not consume any fresh or cooked food.

original: “asukadivase vihāraṃ āgamissāma, sāmaṇerānaṃ pupphāni ocinituṃ mā dethā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: asuka divase vihāram āgamissāma sāmaṇerānam pupphāni ocinitum mā detha iti vadanti
translated: If people come to the monastery on their own initiative, asking, “Are there flowers in the monastery?” and saying, “We’ll come to the monastery on such-and-such a day. Don’t let the novices pick the flowers,”

original: Bhikkhu sāmaṇerānaṃ kathetuṃ pamuṭṭho, sāmaṇerehi pupphāni ocitāni, manussā bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu sāmaṇerānam kathetum pamuṭṭhaḥ sāmaṇerehi pupphāni ocitāni manussāḥ bhikkhum
translated: and if the monk, forgetting to tell the novices, the novices pick the flowers, those people should approach the monk

original: upasaṅkamitvā mayaṃ tumhākaṃ asukadivase evaṃ ārocayimha “sāmaṇerānaṃ pupphāni ocinituṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā mayam tumhākam asuka divase evam ārocayimha sāmaṇerānam pupphāni ocinitum
translated: and say, “We informed you on such-and-such a day, ‘Don’t let the novices pick the flowers.’

original: mā dethā”ti, kasmā na vārayitthāti? “Sati me pamuṭṭhā, pupphāni ocinitamattāneva,🔽na tāva pūjā katā”ti vattabbaṃ, “gaṇhatha pūjethā”ti na vattabbaṃ. Sace vadati, āmisaṃ🔽na paribhuñjitabbaṃ. Aparo bhikkhu sāmaṇerānaṃ ācikkhati “asukagāmavāsino ‘pupphāni
analyzed: mā detha iti kasmai na vārayittha ati sati me pamuṭṭhā pupphāni  na tāva pūjā katā ati vattabbam gaṇhatha pūjetha ati na vattabbam sace vadati āmisam  na paribhuñjitabbam aparaḥ bhikkhu sāmaṇerānam ācikkhati asuka gāma vāsinaḥ pupphāni
translated: Why didn’t you stop them?” He should say, “My mindfulness was confused. I had just started picking the flowers.🔽I hadn’t yet made an offering.” He should not say, “Take them and make an offering.” If he says that, he commits an offense entailing confession for the effort.

original: mā ocinitthā’ti āhaṃsū”ti manussāpi āmisaṃ āharitvā dānaṃ datvā vadanti “amhākaṃ🔽manussā na bahukā, sāmaṇere amhehi saha pupphāni ocinituṃ āṇāpethā”ti. “Sāmaṇerehi
analyzed: mā ocinittha ati āhaṃsu iti manussā api āmisam āharitvā dānam da tvā vadanti amhākam  manussāḥ na bahukā sāmaṇere amhehi saha pupphāni ocinituṃ āṇāpetha ati sāmaṇerehi
translated: If another monk tells the novices, “The people of such-and-such a village say, ‘Don’t pick flowers,’” and if the people bring him material support and give it to him, saying,

original: bhikkhā laddhā. Ye bhikkhācāraṃ na gacchanti, te sayameva jānissanti upāsakā”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhā laddhā ye bhikkhācāram na gacchanti te sayam eva jānissanti upāsakā ti vattabbam
translated: “We have few people. Tell the novices to pick flowers with us,” he should say, “The novices have received almsfood. Those who don’t go on almsround will know for themselves.”

original: Ettakaṃ nayaṃ labhitvā sāmaṇere putte vā bhātike vā katvā pupphāni ocināpetuṃ doso
analyzed: ettakam nayam labhitvā sāmaṇere putte vā bhātike vā katvā pupphāni ocināpetum dosaḥ
translated: Having understood it in this way, there’s no offense in making someone your son or brother and then having him pick flowers.

original: natthi, pupphadānaṃ nāma na hoti.
analyzed: natthi puppha dānam nāma na hoti
translated: But it’s not a flower offering.

original: Phaladāne phalampi pupphaṃ viya niyamitameva garubhaṇḍaṃ hoti. Vihāre bahukasmiṃ
analyzed: phala dāne phalam pi puppham viya niyamitam eva garu bhaṇḍam hoti vihāre bahukasmin
translated: As regards the giving of fruit, the fruit tree is a heavy piece of property like the flower tree. If there is much fruit in the monastery

original: phalāphale sati aphāsukamanussā āgantvā yācanti, bhikkhū “saṅghika”nti dātuṃ na ussahanti,
analyzed: phala aphale sati aphāsuka manussāḥ āgantvā yācanti bhikkhū saṅghikanti dātum na ussahanti
translated: and people come and ask for it, the bhikkhus are reluctant to give it because it belongs to the Community.

original: manussā vippaṭisārino akkosanti paribhāsanti, tattha kiṃ kātabbanti? Phalehi vā rukkhehi🔽vā paricchinditvā kathikā kātabbā “asuke ca rukkhe asuke ca rukkhe ettakāni phalāni
analyzed: manussāḥ vippaṭisārino akkosanti paribhāsanti tattha kim kātabbanti phalehi vā rukkhehi  vā paricchinditvā kathikā kātabbā asuke ca rukkhe asuke ca rukkhe ettakāni phalāni
translated: The people are disappointed and they abuse and revile them. What should be done then? Either the fruit trees🔽or the fruit should be assigned to a caretaker. A notice should be put up saying, “So many fruits may be taken from such-and-such trees

original: gaṇhantā, ettakesu vā rukkhesu phalāni gaṇhantā na vāretabbā”ti. Corā vā issarā vā
analyzed: gaṇhantā ettakesu vā rukkhesu phalāni gaṇhantā na vāretabbā ati corā vā issarā vā
translated: or from so many trees. Those who take them need not be stopped.” If thieves or powerful people take them by force,

original: balakkārena gaṇhantā na vāretabbā. Kuddhā hi te sakalavihārampi nāseyyuṃ, ādīnavo pana kathetabboti.
analyzed: balakkārena gaṇhantā na vāretabbā kuddhāḥ hi te sakala vihāram pi na āseyyuṃ ādīnavaḥ pana kathetabbaḥ ti
translated: they need not be stopped. For if they are angry they might destroy the whole monastery. But the disadvantage should be pointed out to them.

original: Sinānadāne sinānacuṇṇāni koṭṭitāni na garubhaṇḍāni, akoṭṭito rukkhe ṭhitova rukkhataco
analyzed: sināna dāne sināna cuṇṇāni koṭṭitāni na a koṭṭitaḥ rukkhe ṭhitaḥ iva rukkha taco
translated: As regards the giving of bathing powder, the lumps of bathing powder are not a heavy piece of property. The powder in the tree is not assigned to anyone.

original: garubhaṇḍaṃ, cuṇṇaṃ pana agilānassa rajananipakkaṃ vaṭṭati. Gilānassa yaṃkiñci cuṇṇaṃ dātuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva.🔽Na cuṇṇadānenāti vuttanayena sirīsacuṇṇādīnaṃ dānena. Mattikādānemattikā hi yattha
analyzed: garu bhaṇḍam cuṇṇam pana agilānassa rajana nipakkam vaṭṭati gilānassa yaṃkiñci cuṇṇam dātum vaṭṭati yā iva  na cuṇṇa dānena ati vutta nayena sirīsa cuṇṇa ādīnam dānena mattikā dāne mattikāḥ hi
translated: But if it is not for one who is sick, it is allowable to give him a lump of powder that is not ready for dyeing. But anything at all is allowable to give to one who is sick.🔽By giving powder: by giving such things as the powder of the sīsaka tree, etc., in the way already described under ‘giving dye.’

original: dullabhā hoti, tattheva garubhaṇḍaṃ. Sāpi heṭṭhimakoṭiyā tiṃsapalaguḷapiṇḍappamāṇāva,
analyzed: dullabhā hoti tattha iva garu bhaṇḍam sā api heṭṭhima koṭiyā tiṃsa palaguḷa piṇḍa ppamāṇā ava
translated: By giving clay: for clay is heavy only where it is difficult to get. But that is only as much as thirty lumps the size of jujube kernels.

original: tato heṭṭhā na garubhaṇḍanti.
analyzed: tatas heṭṭhā na garubhaṇḍanti
translated: What is less than that is not heavy.

original: Dantakaṭṭhadāne dantakaṭṭhaṃ acchinnakameva garubhaṇḍaṃ. Yesaṃ sāmaṇerānaṃ saṅghato
analyzed: dantakaṭṭha dāne dantakaṭṭham acchinnakam eva garubhaṇḍam yesam sāmaṇerānam saṅghato
translated: By giving tooth sticks: a tooth stick that is uncut is heavy. Those novices to whom the turn for tooth sticks has come

original: dantakaṭṭhavāro pāpuṇāti, te attano ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ dātuṃ na labhanti.
analyzed: dantakaṭṭhavāro pāpuṇāti te attanaḥ ācariya upajjhāyānam pāṭiyekkam dātum na labhanti
translated: in the Community are not allowed to give them separately to their own teachers and preceptors.

original: Yehi pana “ettakāni dantakaṭṭhāni āharitabbānī”ti paricchinditvā vārā gahitā, te
analyzed: yehi pana ettakāni dantakaṭṭhāni āharitabbāni iti paricchinditvā vārā gahitā te
translated: But those who have taken their turn after having limited it to so many tooth sticks,

original: atirekāni ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ dātuṃ labhanti. Ekena bhikkhunā dantakaṭṭhamāḷakato
analyzed: atirekāni ācariya upajjhāyānam dātum labhanti ekena bhikkhunā danta kaṭṭha māḷakato
translated: are allowed to give the extra ones to their teachers and preceptors. If a bhikkhu takes

original: bahūni dantakaṭṭhāni na gahetabbāni, devasikaṃ ekekameva gahetabbaṃ. Pāṭiyekkaṃ vasantenāpi🔽bhikkhusaṅghaṃ gaṇayitvā yattakāni attano pāpuṇanti, tattakāneva gahetvā gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: bahūni dantakaṭṭhāni na gahetabbāni devasikam ekekam eva gahetabbam pāṭiyekkam vasantena api  bhikkhu saṅgham gaṇayitvā yattakāni attanaḥ pāpuṇanti tattakān eva gahetvā gantabbam
translated: He should not take many tooth cleaners; he should take one a day.🔽If he lives alone, he should count the members of the Community and take that number.

original: Antarā āgantukesu vā āgatesu disaṃ vā pakkamantesu āharitvā gahitaṭṭhāneyeva ṭhapetabbāni.
analyzed: antarā āgantukesu vā āgatesu disam vā pakkamantesu āharitvā gahita ṭṭhāneya iva ṭhapetabbāni
translated: If there are newcomers or if he is going away, he should leave the tooth cleaners where he got them.

original: Na mukhodakadānenāti na mukhadhovanaudakadānena.
analyzed: na mukha udaka dānena ati na mukha dhovana odaka dānena
translated: Not for the sake of a mouth-washing water giver: not for the sake of one who gives water for washing the mouth.

original: Na cāṭukamyatāyātiādīsu cāṭukamyatā vuccati attānaṃ dāsaṃ viya nīcaṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā🔽parassa khalitavacanampi saṇṭhapetvā piyakāmatāya paggayhavacanaṃ. Na muggasūpyatāyāti
analyzed: na cāṭu kamyatāya ati ādīsu cāṭu kamyatā vuccati attānam dāsam viya nīca ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā  parassa khalita vacanam pi saṇṭhapetvā piya kāma tāya paggayha vacanam na mugga sūpya tāya ati
translated: Not for the sake of flattery: flattery is said to be the speaking of words of endearment after putting oneself in a low position as if one were a slave,🔽with the desire to be loved. Not for the sake of bean soup:

original: na muggasūpasamānatāya. Muggasūpasamānatāti saccālikena jīvikaṃ kappanatāya etaṃ
analyzed: na mugga sūpa samāna tāya mugga sūpa samāna tā ati sacca alikena jīvikam kappana tāya etam
translated: not for the sake of being the same as bean soup. Being the same as bean soup is a term for making a living by means of a true statement.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Yathā hi muggasūpe paccante bahū muggā pākaṃ gacchanti thokā na gacchanti,
analyzed: adhivacanam yathā hi mugga sūpe paccante bahū muggā pākam gacchanti thokāḥ na gacchanti
translated: For just as when beans are being cooked, many beans go to destruction and few do not,

original: evameva saccālikena jīvikakappake puggale bahu alikaṃ hoti, appakaṃ saccaṃ. Yathā🔽vā muggasūpassa apavisanaṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthi, evameva saccālikavuttino puggalassa🔽appatiṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthi. Siṅghāṭakaṃ viya icchiticchitaṭṭhānassa patiṭṭhāti. Tenassa
analyzed: evam eva sacca alikena jīvika kappake puggale bahu alikam hoti appakam saccam yathā  vā mugga sūpassa apavisana ṭhānam nāma natthi evam eva saccālika vuttino puggalassa  appatiṭṭhānam nāma natthi siṅghāṭakam viya icchiticchita ṭṭhānassa patiṭṭhāti tena assa
translated: So too, in the case of a person who makes a living by telling the truth, there is much falsehood and little truth.🔽Or just as there is no place for the water of a pot of mung-bean soup to settle down, so too, there is no place for the words of a person who speaks the truth to settle down.🔽He is established wherever he wishes, like a lion’s lair. Therefore his falsehood is called “mung-bean-soupery.”

original: sā musāvāditā “muggasūpyatā”ti vuttā. Na pāribhaṭyatāyāti na paribhaṭakammabhāvena.
analyzed: sā musāvādi tā mugga sūpya tā ati vuttā na pāribhaṭya tāya ati na paribhaṭa kamma bhāvena
translated: Not by the nature of a spy: not by the nature of a spy’s work.

original: Paribhaṭassa hi kammaṃ pāribhaṭyaṃ, tassa bhāvo pāribhaṭyatā, alaṅkārakaraṇādīhi
analyzed: paribhaṭassa hi kammam pāribhaṭyam tassa bhāvaḥ pāribhaṭya tā alaṅkāra karaṇa ādīhi
translated: For a spy’s work is spying, and the nature of that is spying-nature. This is a term for such childish games as the making of ornaments.

original: dārakakīḷāpanassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Na pīṭhamaddikatāyāti na sahasā gharaṃ pavisitvā🔽pīṭhake nisīdanakatāya.
analyzed: dāraka kīḷāpanassa etam adhivacanam na pīṭha maddika tā āyāti na sahasā gharam pavisitvā  pīṭhake nisīdanakatāya
translated: Not by the nature of a chair-snatcher: not by the nature of one who enters a house all of a sudden and sits down on a chair.

original: Na vatthuvijjāyātiādīsu vatthuvijjā nāma gāmanigamanagarādīnaṃ suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhajānanasatthaṃ.
analyzed: na vatthuvijjāya ati ādīsu vatthuvijjā nāma gāma nigama nagara ādīnam su niviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha jānana sattham
translated: Not by the nature of a geomancer: a geomancer is one who knows the good and bad features of a village, town, city, etc.

original: Tiracchānavijjā nāma aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā aṅgasatthanimittādikā🔽avasesavijjā. Aṅgavijjā nāma itthipurisānaṃ subhagadubbhagalakkhaṇajānanaṃ. Nakkhattavijjā
analyzed: tiracchāna vijjā nāma aniyyānika ttā sagga mokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtā aṅga sattha nimitta ādikā  avasesa vijjā aṅga vijjā nāma itthi purisānam subhaga dubbhaga lakkhaṇa jānanam nakkhatta vijjā
translated: “Lore of the beasts” is the lore of the beasts, which is not the way to heaven or liberation, and which consists of omens from parts of the body, etc.;

original: nāma nakkhattānaṃ yogajānanasatthaṃ.🔽Na dūtagamanenāti na dūteyyaṃ katvā gamanena. Na pahiṇagamanenāti na gihīnaṃ sāsanaṃ
analyzed: nāma nakkhattānam yoga jānana sattham  na dūta gamanena ati na dūteyyam katvā gamanena na pahiṇa gamanena ati na gihīnam sāsanam
translated: “Other lore” is the lore of the arts. “Lore of the stars” is the lore of the stars, which is a means of livelihood.

original: gahetvā gharā gharaṃ pahitassa gamanena. Na jaṅghapesaniyenāti gāmantaradesantarādīsu
analyzed: gahetvā gharā gharam pahitassa gamanena na jaṅgha pesaniyena ati gāmantara desantara ādīsu
translated: “Not as a messenger”: not by going on a message. “Not as a go-between”: not by going as a go-between to take a message from a man to a woman or from a woman to a man. “Not as an errand boy”: not by going on errands from one village to another, from one town to another, etc.

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ gihīnaṃ sāsanapaṭisāsanaṃ haraṇena. Idañhi jaṅghapesaniyaṃ nāma attano
analyzed: tesam tesam gihīnam sāsana paṭisāsanam haraṇena idam hi jaṅghapesaniyam nāma attano
translated: This is called being an errand boy:

original: mātāpitūnaṃ, ye cāssa mātāpitaro upaṭṭhahanti, tesaṃ sāsanaṃ gahetvā katthaci gamanavasena
analyzed: mātā pitūnam ye ca assa mātā pitaraḥ upaṭṭhahanti tesam sāsanam gahetvā katthaci gamana vasena
translated: going somewhere with a message for one’s mother or father or for those who are looking after one’s mother and father.

original: vaṭṭati. Cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā attano vā kammaṃ karontānaṃ vaḍḍhakīnampi sāsanaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā attanaḥ vā kammam karontānam vaḍḍhakīnam pi sāsanam
translated: It is allowable to go on a message for builders who are building a shrine or a dwelling for the Community or for oneself.

original: harituṃ vaṭṭati. Manussā “dānaṃ dassāma, pūjaṃ karissāma, bhikkhusaṅghassa ācikkhathā”ti
analyzed: haritum vaṭṭati manussāḥ dānam dassāma pūjam karissāma bhikkhu saṅghassa ācikkhatha ati
translated: It is allowable to take it. People say, “We will give a gift, we will do an offering. Tell us about the community of bhikkhus.”

original: ca vadanti; “asukattherassa nāma dethā”ti piṇḍapātaṃ vā bhesajjaṃ vā cīvaraṃ vā denti,
analyzed: ca vadanti asuka therassa nāma detha ati piṇḍapātam vā bhesajjam vā cīvaram vā denti
translated: Or they give alms food, medicines, or robes, saying, “Give it to the elder so-and-so.”

original: “vihāre pūjaṃ karothā”ti mālāgandhavilepanādīni vā dhajapaṭākādīni vā niyyātenti.
analyzed: vihāre pūjam karotha ati mālā gandha vilepana ādīni vā dhaja paṭāka ādīni vā
translated: Or they send garlands, perfumes, ointments, flags, and banners, saying, “Do an offering in the monastery.”🔽All this is allowable to take. It is not a case of “to be taken on a carrying pole.”

original: Sabbaṃ harituṃ vaṭṭati, jaṅghapesaniyaṃ nāma na hoti. Sesasāsanaṃ gahetvā gacchantassa🔽padavāre padavāre doso.
analyzed: sabbam haritum vaṭṭati jaṅghapesaniyam nāma na hoti sesa sāsanam gahetvā gacchantassa  padavāre padavāre doso
translated: If he takes the rest of the dispensation, there is an offense for every step he takes.

original: Na vejjakammenāti na vejjena hutvā kāyatikicchanādibhesajjakaraṇena. Bhesajjaṃ pana
analyzed: na vejja kammena ati na vejjena hutvā kāya tikicchana ādi bhesajja karaṇena bhesajjam pana
translated: Not as a medical treatment: not by treating the body with medicine, etc., as a doctor. But medicine

original: pañcannaṃ sahadhammikānaṃ kātabbaṃ bhikkhussa bhikkhuniyā sikkhamānāya sāmaṇerassa
analyzed: pañcannam sahadhammikānam kātabbam bhikkhussa bhikkhuniyā sikkhamānāya sāmaṇerassa
translated: may be prepared for the five who have a claim to be treated as a son: for a bhikkhu, a bhikkhunī, a female trainee, a male novice, and a female novice.

original: sāmaṇeriyā. Samasīlasaddhāpaññānañhi etesaṃ tīsu sikkhāsu yuttānaṃ bhesajjaṃ akātuṃ
analyzed: sāmaṇeriyā sama sīla saddhā paññānam hi etesam tīsu sikkhāsu yuttānam bhesajjam a kātum
translated: For these, who are equal to him in virtue, faith, and understanding, and who are devoted to the three trainings, it is proper not to prepare medicine.

original: na labbhati. Mātāpitūnaṃ tadupaṭṭhākānaṃ attano veyyāvaccakarassa paṇḍupalāsassāti
analyzed: na labbhati mātā pitūnam tad upaṭṭhākānam attanaḥ veyyāvacca karassa paṇḍu palāsassa ati
translated: It is not allowable. It is allowable for his mother and father, for those who are looking after them, for his own attendants, and for one who is sick with jaundice.

original: etesaṃ pañcannampi kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Jeṭṭhabhātu, kaniṭṭhabhātu, jeṭṭhabhaginiyā, kaniṭṭhabhaginiyā,
analyzed: etesam pañcannam api kātum vaṭṭati jeṭṭha bhātu kaniṭṭha bhātu jeṭṭha bhaginiyā kaniṭṭha bhaginiyā
translated: It is allowable for five of these. It is allowable for his elder brother, younger brother, elder sister, younger sister,

original: cūḷamātuyā, mahāmātuyā, cūḷapituno, mahāpituno, pitucchāya, mātucchāyāti etesaṃ pana
analyzed: cūḷa mātuyā mahā mātuyā cūḍa pitunaḥ mahā pitunaḥ pitu chāya mātu chāya ati etesam pana
translated: his mother’s sister, his father’s sister, his mother’s full brother, his father’s full brother, his mother’s father, his father’s father.

original: dasannampi karontena tesaṃyeva santakaṃ bhesajjaṃ gahetvā kevalaṃ yojetvā dātabbaṃ.
analyzed: karontena tesam yeva santakam bhesajjam gahetvā kevalam yojetvā dātabbam
translated: But when he is doing it for these ten, he should take medicine belonging to them, mix it himself, and give it.

original: Sace nappahoti, attano santakaṃ tāvakālikaṃ dātabbaṃ. Etesaṃ puttaparamparā yāva🔽sattamā kulaparivaṭṭā, tāva cattāro paccaye āharāpentassa akataviññatti vā, bhesajjaṃ
analyzed: sace na pahoti attanaḥ santakam tāvakālikam dātabbam etesam putta paramparā yāva  sattamā kula parivaṭṭā tāva cattāro paccaye āharāpentassa a kata viññatti vā bhesajjam
translated: If that is not enough, he should give his own for the time being.🔽For one who brings the four requisites for the children of these, for the children’s children, and so on down to the seventh generation of descendants, there is no offence of failure in courtesy, no offence of doing a doctor’s work, no offence of defiling a family,

original: karontassa vejjakammaṃ vā, kuladūsakāpatti vā na hoti.
analyzed: karontassa vejja kammam vā kula dūsaka āpatti vā na hoti
translated: whether or not he has been asked.

original: Na piṇḍapaṭipiṇḍakenāti ettha piṇḍapāto kassa dātabbo, kassa na dātabbo? Mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: na piṇḍa paṭipiṇḍakena ati ettha piṇḍapāto kassa dātabbo kassa na dātabbaḥ mātā pitūnam
translated: As regards “not in the form of a selection from the alms” , to whom should alms food be given? To whom should it not be given? To his mother and father,

original: tadupaṭṭhākānaṃ veyyāvaccakarassa paṇḍupalāsassa sampattassa dāmarikacorassa issarassāpi🔽dātabbo. Etesaṃ datvā pacchā laddhampi piṇḍapaṭipiṇḍaṃ nāma na hoti. Na dānānuppadānenāti🔽attano dinnakānaṃ na puna dānena. Dhammenāti dhammena uppannaṃ. Samenāti kāyasucaritādinā.
analyzed: tad upaṭṭhākānam veyyāvacca karassa paṇḍu palāsassa sampattassa dāmarika corassa issarassa api  dātabbaḥ etesam da tvā pacchā laddham pi piṇḍa paṭipiṇḍam nāma na hoti na dāna an uppadānena ati  attanaḥ dinna kānam na puna dānena dhammena ati dhammena uppannam samena ati kāya su carita ādinā
translated: and to the attendant, the servant, the slave, the hired man, the hired girl, the one who is there out of fear, the one who is there for a meal, the one who is there for shelter, the one who is there for a job, the one who is there for clothes, the one who is there for a living, the one who is there for a reward, the one who is there for a boon, the one who is there for a favour.🔽After giving to them, what is left over is not called ‘almsfood’. ‘Not by the giving of gifts’:🔽not by giving again of what has been given by oneself. ‘By Dhamma’: arisen by Dhamma. ‘By what is fitting’: by bodily good conduct, etc.

original: Laddhāti kāyena laddhā. Labhitvāti cittena pāpuṇitvā. Adhigantvāti sampāpuṇitvā.🔽Vinditvāti ñāṇena vinditvā. Paṭilabhitvāti punappunaṃ labhitvā.🔽Annasannidhinti ettha duvidhā annakathā vinayavasena ca sallekhavasena ca. Vinayavasena🔽tāva yaṃkiñci annaṃ ajja paṭiggahitaṃ aparajju sannidhikārakaṃ hoti, tassa paribhoge🔽pācittiyaṃ. Attanā laddhaṃ pana sāmaṇerānaṃ datvā tehi laddhaṃ ṭhapāpetvā dutiyadivase
analyzed: laddhā ati kāyena laddhā labhitvā ati cittena pāpuṇitvā adhigantvā ati sampāpuṇitvā 🔽vinditvā ati ñāṇena vinditvā paṭilabhitvā ati punappunam labhitvā 🔽ettha duvidhā anna kathā vinaya vasena ca sallekha vasena ca vinaya vasena 🔽tāva yaṃkiñci annam ajja paṭiggahitam aparajju sannidhi kārakam hoti tassa paribhoge 🔽pācittiyam attanā laddham pana dutiya divase
translated: It should be given to those who attend on him, to the one who does his menial services, to the one who has given him a robe of coarse hemp, to the one who has given him a robe of mixed hemp and cotton, to the one who has given him a robe of cotton, to the one who has given him a robe of silk, to the one who has given him a robe of wool, to the one who has given him a robe of linen, to the one who has given him a robe of cotton waste, to the one who has given him a robe of tree bark, to the one who has given him a robe of antelope hide, to the one who has given him a robe of strips of leather, to the one who has given him a robe of human hair, to the one who has given him a horse-hair robe, to the one who has given him a rope-fibre robe, to the one who has given him a blanket of coarse animal wool, to the one who has given him a blanket of fine sheep’s wool, to the one who has given him a blanket of rabbit fur, to the one who has given him a blanket of wild sheep wool, to the one who has given him a blanket of yāva grass, to the one who has given him a blanket of kosiya grass, to the one who has given him a blanket of kusa grass, to the one who has given him a blanket of reeds, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the śirīṣa tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the pippala tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the dhava tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the tinduka tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the kṣīra tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the śāla tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the śirīṣa tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the pippala tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the dhava tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the tinduka tree, to the one who has given him a blanket of bark from the kṣīra

original: bhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati, sallekho pana na hoti.
analyzed: bhuñjitum vaṭṭati sallekhaḥ pana na hoti
translated: It is allowable to use it, but there is no keeping.

original: Pānasannidhimhipi eseva nayo. Ettha pānaṃ nāma ambapānādīni aṭṭha pānāni, yāni ce tesaṃ anulomāni.
analyzed: pāna sannidhimhi pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha pānam nāma amba pāna ādīni aṭṭha pānāni yāni ce tesam anulomāni
translated: The same method applies in the case of drinks. Herein, drinks are the eight drinks beginning with honey, and whatever else is similar to that.

original: Vatthasannidhintiādimhi anadhiṭṭhitāvikappitaṃ sannidhi ca hoti sallekhañca kopeti.🔽Ayaṃ pariyāya kathāva, nippariyāyato pana ticīvarasantuṭṭhena bhavitabbaṃ, catutthaṃ
analyzed: vattha sannidhi ti ādimhi anadhiṭṭhita avikappitam sannidhi ca hoti sallekham ca kopeti  ayam pariyāya nippariyāyataḥ pana ti cīvara santuṭṭhena bhavitabbam catuttham
translated: In the case of the cloth, etc., the storing is not determined and the keeping is not determined.

original: labhitvā aññassa dātabbaṃ. Sace yassa kassaci dātuṃ na sakkoti, yassa pana dātukāmo🔽hoti, so uddesatthāya vā paripucchatthāya vā gato, āgatamatte dātabbaṃ, adātuṃ na
analyzed: labhitvā aññassa dātabbam sace yassa kassaci dātum na sakkoti yassa pana dātu kāmo  hoti saḥ uddesa tthāya vā paripuccha tthāya vā gataḥ āgata matte dātabbam a dātum na
translated: This is the explanation in detail. But in brief, he should be satisfied with the triple robe. If he gets a fourth, he should give it away. If he is unable to give it to anyone, but he wants to give it to a certain person,

original: vaṭṭati. Cīvare pana appahonte satiyā paccāsāya anuññātakālaṃ ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. Sūcisuttacīvarakārakānaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati cīvare pana appahonte satiyā paccāsāya anuññāta kālam ṭhapetum vaṭṭati sūci sutta cīvara kārakānam
translated: and that person has gone away for the purpose of recitation or for the purpose of questioning, it should be given to him as soon as he returns. It is not allowable not to give it. But if the robes are insufficient, it is allowable to keep it until the robe season. If needles, thread, etc., for making robes are not available,

original: alābhena tato parampi vinayakammaṃ katvā ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. “Imasmiṃ jiṇṇe puna īdisaṃ
analyzed: alābhena tato param pi vinaya kammam katvā ṭhapetum vaṭṭati imasmin jiṇṇe puna īdisam
translated: it is allowable to keep it beyond that time, having done the legal procedure. If he thinks, “I will make another like this when this is worn out,”

original: kuto labhissāmī”ti pana ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca vikopeti.🔽Yānasannidhimhi yānaṃ nāma vayhaṃ ratho sakaṭaṃ sandamānikā sivikā pāṭaṅkīti netaṃ
analyzed: kutas labhissāmi iti pana ṭhapetum na vaṭṭati ca hoti sat lekham ca  yāna sannidhimhi yānam nāma vayham ratho sakaṭam sandamānikā sivikā pāṭaṅkī iti
translated: But it is not allowable to keep it thinking, “Where shall I get another?” It is hoarding, and it is a violation of the ascetic ideal.

original: pabbajitassa yānaṃ. Upāhanā pana pabbajitassa yānaṃyeva. Ekabhikkhussa hi eko araññatthāya,🔽ekā dhotapādakatthāyāti ukkaṃsato dve upāhanasaṅghāṭā vaṭṭanti, tatiyaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: pabbajitassa yānam upāhanā pana pabbajitassa yānam yeva eka bhikkhussa hi ekaḥ arañña atthāya  ekā dhota pādakatthāyā ati ukkaṃsataḥ dve upāhana saṅghāṭāḥ vaṭṭanti tatiyam labhitvā
translated: As regards the vehicle, a vehicle is a carriage, a chariot, a cart, a palanquin, a sedan-chair. This is not a vehicle for an ascetic. But sandals are a vehicle for an ascetic. For one bhikkhu two sandals are allowable, one for going in the monastery and one for going out of it,

original: aññassa dātabbo, “imasmiṃ jiṇṇe aññaṃ kuto labhissāmī”ti hi ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati,
analyzed: aññassa dātabbaḥ imasmin jiṇṇe aññam kutas labhissāmi iti hi ṭhapetum na vaṭṭati
translated: on the score that one is for the wilderness and one for washing the feet. If he gets a third, it should be given to someone else. For it is not allowable to keep it thinking, “When this one is worn out I shall have another.”

original: sannidhi ca hoti, sallekhañca vikopeti.🔽Sayanasannidhimhi sayananti mañco. Ekassa bhikkhuno eko gabbhe eko divāṭṭhāneti ukkaṃsato
analyzed: sannidhi ca hoti sat lekham ca  sayana sannidhimhi sayananti mañcaḥ ekassa bhikkhuno ekaḥ gabbhe ekaḥ divāṭṭhāne iti ukkaṃsataḥ
translated: It is hoarding, and it is a violation of the ascetic ideal.🔽As regards the bed, a bed is a couch. For one bhikkhu two couches are allowable, one for sleeping in the dwelling and one for sitting in by day,

original: dve mañcā vaṭṭanti, tato uttari labhitvā aññassa bhikkhuno vā gaṇassa vā dātabbo,
analyzed: dve mañcāḥ vaṭṭanti tatas uttari labhitvā aññassa bhikkhuno vā gaṇassa vā dātabbo
translated: on the score that one is for the wilderness and one for washing the feet. If he gets a third, it should be given to someone else.

original: adātuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi ceva hoti, sallekhañca kopeti.
analyzed: a dātum na vaṭṭati sannidhi ca iva hoti sat lekham ca
translated: It is not allowable not to give it. It is hoarding, and it is a violation of the ascetic ideal.

original: Gandhasannidhimhi bhikkhuno kaṇḍukacchuchavidosādiābādhe sati gandho vaṭṭati. Tena
analyzed: gandha sannidhimhi bhikkhuno kaṇḍu kacchu chavi dosa ādi ābādhe sati gandhaḥ vaṭṭati tena
translated: If a monk has an itch, a rash, or the like, he can use scent as a remedy.

original: gandhena tasmiṃ roge vūpasante aññesaṃ vā ābādhikānaṃ dātabbo. Dvāre pañcaṅgulagharadhūpanādīsu🔽vā upanetabbo. “Puna roge sati bhavissatī”ti ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, gandhasannidhi
analyzed: gandhena tasmim roge vūpasante aññesam vā ābādhikānam dātabbaḥ dvāre pañcaṅgula ghara dhūpana ādīsu  vā upanetabbo puna roge sati bhavissati iti ṭhapetum na vaṭṭati gandha sannidhi
translated: When the affliction has subsided, he can give the scent to others who are afflicted. Or he can put it in the five-fingered incense holder or in the incense burner at the gateway.

original: ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti.🔽Āmisanti annādivuttāvasesaṃva daṭṭhabbaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – idhekacco bhikkhu “tathārūpe
analyzed: ca hoti sat lekham ca kopa iti  āmisanti anna ādi vutta avasesam va daṭṭhabbam seyyathidam idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu tathārūpe
translated: But he should not keep it thinking, “If I get an affliction again, I’ll use it.” For that would be a store of scent, and it would also be a store of requisites.

original: kāle upakārāya bhavissantī”ti tilataṇḍulamuggamāsanāḷikeraloṇamacchamaṃsavallūrasappitelaguḷa-🔽bhājanādīni āharāpetvā ṭhapeti. So vassakāle kālasseva sāmaṇerehi yāguṃ pacāpetvā
analyzed: kāle upakārāya bhavissanti iti  bhājana ādīni āharāpetvā ṭhapeti saḥ vassa kāle kālassa iva sāmaṇerehi yāgum pacāpetvā
translated: “Food” should be understood as the rest of what is called “material possessions”. It is like this. A monk has rice, flour, beans, sesame seeds, molasses, meat, dried fish, ghee, oil, sugar, and vessels brought and stored, thinking, “They will be useful at such and such a time.”🔽In the rainy season, he has the novices cook the rice in the morning,

original: bhuñjitvā “sāmaṇera udakakaddame dukkhaṃ gāmaṃ pavisituṃ, gaccha asukakulaṃ gantvā
analyzed: bhuñjitvā sāmaṇeraḥ udaka kaddame dukkham gāmam pavisitum gaccha asuka kulam gantvā
translated: and he eats it. Then he says, “It’s uncomfortable to enter the village in the rain. Go to such and such a family and bring back whatever they give you.”

original: mayhaṃ vihāre nisinnabhāvaṃ ārocehi, asukakulato dadhiādīni āharā”ti peseti. Bhikkhūhi
analyzed: mayham vihāre nisinna bhāvam ārocehi asuka kulataḥ dadhi ādīni āharāti peseti bhikkhūhi
translated: “Tell my family that I am sitting in the dwelling and to bring curd and so on.”

original: “kiṃ, bhante, gāmaṃ pavisathā”ti vuttepi “duppaveso āvuso idāni gāmo”ti vadati. Te
analyzed: kim bhante gāmam pavisatha ati vutte pi duppavesaḥ āvuso idāni gāmaḥ ti vadati te
translated: When the monks say, “Venerable, why don’t you go to the village?” he says, “The village is hard to enter.”

original: “hotu, bhante, acchatha tumhe, mayaṃ bhikkhaṃ pariyesitvā āharissāmā”ti gacchanti.
analyzed: hotu bhante acchatha tumhe mayam bhikkham pariyesitvā āharissāma ati gacchanti
translated: “Very well, Venerable, you stay put. We’ll get almsfood and bring it back.”

original: Atha sāmaṇeropi dadhiādīni āharitvā bhattañca byañjanañca sampādetvā upaneti, taṃ
analyzed: atha sāmaṇeraḥ api dadhi ādīni āharitvā bhattam ca byañjanam ca sampādetvā upaneti tam
translated: The novice monk then gets curd and so on, prepares the meal and the curry, and serves it.

original: bhuñjantasseva upaṭṭhākā bhattaṃ pahiṇanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ bhuñjati. Atha
analyzed: bhuñjantassa iva upaṭṭhākāḥ bhattam pahiṇanti tatas api manāpam manāpam bhuñjati atha
translated: While he is eating, the attendants bring more food. He eats that too.

original: bhikkhū piṇḍapātaṃ gahetvā āgacchanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ gīvāyāmakaṃ bhuñjatiyeva.
analyzed: bhikkhū piṇḍapātam gahetvā āgacchanti tatas api manāpam manāpam gīvāyāmakam bhuñjatiyā iva
translated: Then the monks return with almsfood. He eats that too.

original: Evaṃ catumāsampi vītināmeti. Ayaṃ vuccati bhikkhu “muṇḍakuṭumbikajīvikaṃ jīvati,
analyzed: evam catu māsam pi vītināmeti ayam vuccati bhikkhu muṇḍa kuṭumbika jīvikam jīvati
translated: He spends four months in this way. This is called “living like Muṇḍakuṭhomi,

original: na samaṇajīvika”nti. Evarūpo āmisasannidhi nāma hoti.
analyzed: na evarūpaḥ āmisasannidhi nāma hoti
translated: not like a monastic.” This is called “having a store of material things.”

original: Bhikkhuno pana vasanaṭṭhāne ekā taṇḍulanāḷi eko guḷapiṇḍo catubhāgamattaṃ sappīti
analyzed: bhikkhuno pana vasanaṭṭhāne ekā taṇḍula nāḷi ekaḥ guḷa piṇḍo catu bhāga mattam sappi iti
translated: But in the dwelling of a bhikkhu there is a basket of rice, a lump of sugar, and a quarter-pana-measure of ghee.

original: ettakaṃ nidhetuṃ vaṭṭati akāle sampattacorānaṃ atthāya. Te hi ettakampi āmisapaṭisanthāraṃ
analyzed: ettakam nidhetum vaṭṭati akāle sampatta corānam atthāya te hi ettakam pi āmisa paṭisanthāram
translated: But in a monk’s dwelling place it is allowable to store a single basket of rice, a single lump of jaggery, and a measure of ghee for the sake of thieves who may come in time of famine. For if they do not get even this much hospitality of material things,

original: alabhantā jīvitāpi voropeyyuṃ, tasmā sacepi ettakaṃ natthi, āharāpetvāpi ṭhapetuṃ
analyzed: a labhantā jīvitā api voropeyyum tasmā sace pi ettakam natthi āharāpetvā api ṭhapetum
translated: they might even deprive him of life. So if he has not got even that much, he can have it brought and stored.

original: vaṭṭati. Aphāsukakāle ca yadettha kappiyaṃ, taṃ attanāpi paribhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Kappiyakuṭiyaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati a phāsuka kāle ca yat ettha kappiyam tam attanā api paribhuñjitum vaṭṭati kappiya kuṭiyam
translated: And in a time of scarcity whatever is allowable in the monastery may be used by himself.

original: pana bahuṃ ṭhapentassāpi sannidhi nāma natthi.
analyzed: pana bahum ṭhapentassa api sannidhi nāma natthi
translated: But even if he stores much in a store-house for allowable things, it is not a store of his.

original: 160. Jhāyī na pādalolassāti jhānābhirato ca na ca pādalolo assa. Virame kukkuccā nappamajjeyyāti hatthakukkuccādikukkuccaṃ vinodeyya, sakkaccakāritāya cettha nappamajjeyya.
analyzed: jhāyī na pāda lolassa ati jhāna abhirato ca na ca pāda lolaḥ assa virame kukkuccā na pamajjeyya ati hattha kukkucca ādi kukkuccam vinodeyya sakkacca kāritāya ca ittha na pamajjeyya
translated: The meditator, not a foot-licker: devoted to jhāna, not a flatterer. He should shun deceit, be heedful: he should remove deceit of hand, deceit of speech, deceit of eyes, and deceit of body. And he should be heedful here in the doing of what is proper.

original: Ekattamanuyuttoti ekībhāvaṃ anuyutto. Paramatthagarukoti uttamatthagaruko. “Sakatthagaruko”ti vā pāṭho.
analyzed: ekattam anuyutto ti ekībhāvam anuyuttaḥ parama attha garuko ti uttama attha garuko sakattha garukaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: Intent on unity: devoted to unity. He should be intent on the ultimate meaning: the reading is doubtful here.

original: Paṭisallānārāmoti āramaṇaṃ ārāmo, tato tato ārammaṇato paṭisaṃharitvā ekībhāve paṭisallāne🔽ārāmo yassa so paṭisallānārāmo. Assāti bhaveyya. Tasmiṃ ratoti paṭisallānarato. Etehi🔽sīlesu paripūrakāritaṃ dasseti. Taṃ kissa hetu? Sīlavipannassa ekaggatāpi na sampajjati.
analyzed: paṭisallāna ārāmaḥ ti āramaṇam ārāmaḥ tatas tatas ārammaṇato paṭisaṃharitvā ekībhāve paṭisallāne  ārāmaḥ yassa so paṭisallāna ārāmaḥ assa ati bhaveyya tasmin rataḥ ti paṭisallāna rataḥ etehi  sīlesu paripūra kāritam dasseti tam kissa hetu sīla vipannassa ekagga tā api na sampajjati
translated: He delights in solitude: delight is delighting; he delights in the solitude of the state of composure that is attained by turning away from those objects of attachment here and there, by turning away from the five cords of sense desire, and by turning away from the hindrances.🔽He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude.🔽He shows that he has fulfilled virtue. And why is that? Because one whose virtue is deficient does not attain even one-pointedness of mind.

original: Ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyuttoti attano cittasamathe yutto. Ettha hi ajjhattanti🔽vā attanoti vā etaṃ ekatthaṃ, byañjanameva nānaṃ. Bhummatthe panetaṃ upayogavacanaṃ.🔽Anūti iminā upasaggena yoge siddhaṃ.🔽Anirākatajjhānoti bahi anihatajjhāno avināsitajjhāno vā. Nīharaṇavināsatthañhi idaṃ
analyzed: ajjhattam cetaḥ samatham anuyuttaḥ ti attano citta samathe yuttaḥ ettha hi ajjhattam ti  vā attanoti vā etam ekattham byañjanam eva nānam bhumma tthe upayoga vacanam  iminā upasaggena yoge siddham  a nirākata jhānaḥ ti bahi a nihata jhānaḥ a vināsita jhānaḥ vā nīharaṇa vināsa attham hi idam
translated: He delights in solitude: delight is delighting. Solitude is seclusion. He who has delight in that is a delight-in-solitude.

original: nirākaraṇaṃ nāma. “Thambhaṃ niraṃkatvā nivātavuttī”tiādīsu cassa payogo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: nirākaraṇam nāma thambham niraṃkatvā nivāta vutti iti ādīsu ca ssa payogaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude.
