He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is one who delights in solitude. He is

original: Vipassanāya samannāgatoti sattavidhāya anupassanāya yutto. Sattavidhā anupassanā
analyzed: vipassanāya samannāgataḥ ti sattavidhāya anupassanāya yuttaḥ sattavidhā anupassanā
translated: “Endowed with insight”: furnished with the seven contemplations. The seven contemplations are

original: nāma aniccānupassanā dukkhānupassanā anattānupassanā nibbidānupassanā virāgānupassanā
analyzed: nāma anicca anupassanā dukkha anupassanā anatta anupassanā nibbida anupassanā virāga anupassanā
translated: contemplation of impermanence, contemplation of suffering, contemplation of non-self, contemplation of dispassion, contemplation of fading away,

original: nirodhānupassanā paṭinissaggānupassanāti. Tā visuddhimagge vitthāritā. Byūhetā suññāgārānanti🔽vaḍḍhetā suññāgārānaṃ. Ettha ca samathavipassanāvasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā rattindivaṃ🔽suññāgāraṃ pavisitvā nisīdamāno bhikkhu “brūhetā suññāgārāna”nti veditabbo. Ekabhūmakādibhede
analyzed: nirodha anupassanā paṭinissagga anupassanā ti tāḥ visuddhi magge vitthāritāḥ  vaḍḍhetā suññāgārānaṃ ettha ca samatha vipassanā vasena kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā rattindivam  suññāgāram pavisitvā nisīdamānaḥ bhikkhu veditabbo eka bhūmaka ādi bhede
translated: contemplation of cessation, and contemplation of relinquishment. These are explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga. “He enlarges the empty places”:🔽he increases the empty places. And here the bhikkhu who, having taken up a meditation subject by way of serenity and insight, enters and dwells in an empty place day and night

original: pāsāde kurumānopi suññāgārānaṃ brūhetāti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: pāsāde kurumānaḥ api daṭṭhabbo
translated: should be understood as “he who enlarges the empty places.” Even one who is building a multi-storied mansion with many rooms should be regarded as “he who enlarges the empty places.”

original: Sakkaccakārītiādīsu dānādīnaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyyadhammassa
analyzed: sakkacca kārī iti ādīsu dāna ādīnam kusala dhammānam bhāvanāya puggalassa vā deyya dhammassa
translated: “He who acts respectfully”: he who acts respectfully towards the wholesome states such as giving, etc., or towards the person who is the object of giving,

original: vā sakkaccakāritāvasena sakkaccakārī. Assāti bhaveyya. Satatabhāvo sātaccaṃ, sātaccakāritāvasena
analyzed: vā sakkacca kāri tā vasena sakkacca kārī assa ati bhaveyya satata bhāvaḥ sātaccam sātacca kāri tā vasena
translated: by way of development. “He would be” means he would be. “Continuous state” is a state of continuity. By way of a state of continuity,

original: sātaccakārī. Nirantarakāritāya aṭṭhitakārī. Yathā nāma kakaṇṭako thokaṃ gantvā thokaṃ🔽tiṭṭhati, na nirantaraṃ gacchati, evameva yo puggalo ekadivasaṃ dānaṃ datvā pūjaṃ🔽vā katvā dhammaṃ vā sutvā samaṇadhammaṃ vā katvā puna cirassaṃ karoti, taṃ na nirantaraṃ🔽pavatteti. So “asātaccakārī, ṭhitakārī”ti vuccati. Yo pana evaṃ na hoti, so aṭṭhitakārī.🔽Anolīnavuttikoti nirantarakaraṇasaṅkhātassa vipphārassa atthitāya na olīnavuttiko.🔽Anikkhittacchandoti kusalakiriyāya vīriyacchandassa anikkhittabhāvena anikkhittacchando.
analyzed: sā atacca kārī nirantara kāritāya aṭṭhita kārī yathā nāma kakaṇṭakaḥ thokam gantvā thokam  tiṭṭhati na nirantaram gacchati evam eva yaḥ puggalaḥ eka divasam dānam da tvā pūjam  vā katvā dhammam vā sutvā samaṇa dhammam vā katvā puna cirassam karoti tam na nirantaram  pavattā iti saḥ asātacca kārī ṭhita kārī iti vuccati yaḥ pana evam na hoti so aṭṭhita kārī  anolīnavuttikaḥ ti nirantara karaṇa saṅkhātassa vipphārassa atthitāya na olīnavuttiko  a nikkhitta chandaḥ ti kusala kiriyāya vīriya chandassa a nikkhitta bhāvena a nikkhitta chandaḥ
translated: He is a doer of what is timely. He is a doer of what is not interrupted because he does it without interruption. Just as a porcupine moves a little and then stops, and so does not go without stopping, so too, a person who gives a gift, performs an act of worship, listens to the Dhamma, or practices the Dhamma of the noble ones on one day and then does so again only after a long time does not do it without interruption. He is called a doer of what is not timely, a doer of what is interrupted. But one who does not do so is a doer of what is timely.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to cure because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to cure,” which is conduct that is not uninterrupted, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to support because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to support,” which is conduct that is not continuous, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to satisfy because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to satisfy,” which is conduct that is not timely, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to nourish because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to nourish,” which is conduct that is not uninterrupted, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to please because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to please,” which is conduct that is not timely, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to live with because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to live with,” which is conduct that is not uninterrupted, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to support because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to support,” which is conduct that is not continuous, that is, conduct that is interrupted.🔽He is not one who acts in a way that is hard to satisfy because he does not have the kind of conduct that is called “hard to satisfy,” which is conduct that is not timely,

original: Anikkhittadhuroti vīriyadhurassa anoropako, anosakkitamānasoti attho.
analyzed: a nikkhitta dhurā ti vīriya dhurassa anoropakaḥ anosakkita mānasaḥ ti attho
translated: He is a doer of what is hard. He is a doer of what is hard because he does what is hard to do. He is a doer of what is not easy. He is a doer of what is not easy because he does what is not easy to do. He is a doer of what is timely. He is a doer of what is timely because he does what should be done at the proper time. He is a doer of what is suitable. He is a doer of what is suitable because he does what is suitable to the occasion. He is a doer of what is productive of welfare. He is a doer of what is productive of welfare because he does what is productive of welfare. He is a doer of what is not overdone. He is a doer of what is not overdone because he does not overdo. He is a doer of what is not undone. He is a doer of what is not undone because he does not leave undone. He is a doer of what is not left out. He is a doer of what is not left out because he does not leave out. He is a doer of what is not mixed up. He is a doer of what is not mixed up because he does not mix up. He is a doer of what is not untimely. He is a doer of what is not untimely because he does not do at the wrong time. He is a doer of what is not excessive. He is a doer of what is not excessive because he does not overdo. He is a doer of what is not deficient. He is a doer of what is not deficient because he does not underdo. He is a doer of what is not low. He is a doer of what is not low because he does not do what is low. He is a doer of what is not exalted. He is a doer of what is not exalted because he does not do what is exalted. He is a doer of what is not fickle. He is a doer of what is not fickle because he does not do what is fickle. He is a doer of what is not vacillating. He is a doer of what is not vacillating because he does not do what is vacillating. He is a doer of what is not agitated. He is a doer of what is not agitated because he does not do what is agitated. He is

original: Appaṭivānīti anivattanaṃ. Adhiṭṭhānanti kusalakaraṇe patiṭṭhābhāvo. Anuyogoti anuyuñjanaṃ. Appamādoti satiyā avippavāso.
analyzed: appaṭivānī iti anivattanam adhiṭṭhānam ti kusala karaṇe patiṭṭhā bhāvaḥ anuyogaḥ iti anuyuñjanam appamādaḥ ti satiyāḥ a vippavāsaḥ
translated: Unwavering: not turning back. Resolution: the state of being established in doing what is skillful. Application: the act of applying. Mindfulness: non-lapse of mindfulness.

original: 161. Tandiṃ māyaṃ hassaṃ khiḍḍanti ālasiyañca māyañca hassañca kāyikaṃ vācasikaṃ khiḍḍañca. Savibhūsanti saddhiṃ vibhūsāya.🔽Rattindivaṃ chakoṭṭhāsaṃ karitvāti purimayāmamajjhimayāmapacchimayāmavasena rattiṃ
analyzed: tandim māyam hassam khiḍḍanti ālasiyam ca māyam ca hassam ca kāyikam vācasikam khiḍḍam ca sa vibhūsanti saddhim vibhūsāya  rattindivam cha koṭṭhāsam karitvā ati purima yāma majjhima yāma pacchima yāma vasena rattim
translated: Sloth, deceit, vanity, and play: laziness, deceit, vanity, and bodily and verbal play. With adornment: together with adornment.🔽Having divided the day and night into six periods: at night🔽he divides it into three periods: the first period, the middle period, and the last period;

original: tayo tathā divāti chabbidhaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ katvā. Pañcakoṭṭhāsaṃ paṭijaggeyyāti rattiṃ🔽majjhimayāmaṃ vissajjetvā avasesapañcakoṭṭhāsesu na niddaṃ okkameyya. Ekakoṭṭhāsaṃ
analyzed: tayo tathā divā iti chabbidham koṭṭhāsam katvā pañca koṭṭhāsam paṭijaggeyya ati rattim  majjhima yāmam vissajjetvā avasesa pañca koṭṭhāsesu na niddam okkameyya eka koṭṭhāsam
translated: and likewise during the day. He should keep to five periods: at night🔽he should omit the middle period and not go to sleep during the remaining five periods. He should lie down during one period:

original: nipajjeyyāti ekaṃ majjhimayāmakoṭṭhāsaṃ sato sampajāno nipajjitvā niddaṃ okkameyya.
analyzed: nipajjeyya ati ekam majjhima yāma koṭṭhāsam sataḥ sampajānaḥ nipajjitvā niddam okkameyya
translated: he should go to sleep during the one middle period, being mindful and clearly comprehending.

original: Idha bhikkhu divasampi pubbaṇhe majjhanhe sāyanheti tayopi divasakoṭṭhāsā gahitā.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu divasam pi pubbaṇhe majjhanhe sāyanhe ti tayaḥ api divasa koṭṭhāsāḥ gahitā
translated: Herein, the three periods of the day—morning, midday, and afternoon—are included in the day.

original: Caṅkamena nisajjāyāti sakalaṃ divasaṃ iminā iriyāpathadvayeneva viharanto cittassa🔽āvaraṇato āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi pañcahi nīvaraṇehi sabbākusaladhammehi vā. Cittaṃ
analyzed: caṅkamena nisajja āyāti sakalam divasam iminā iriyāpatha dvayena iva viharantaḥ cittassa  āvaraṇataḥ āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi pañcahi nīvaraṇehi sabba akusala dhammehi vā cittam
translated: By pacing and sitting: by these two postures he should spend the whole day.

original: parisodheyyāti tehi dhammehi cittaṃ visodheyya. Ṭhānaṃ panettha kiñcāpi na gahitaṃ,
analyzed: parisodheyya ati tehi dhammehi cittam visodheyya ṭhānam pana ittha kiñcā api na gahitam
translated: By cleansing the mind of obstructive states: by cleansing the mind of those states that obstruct the jhānas, namely, the five hindrances or all the unprofitable courses of action.🔽Although the text does not mention it, the place should be understood as included, for it should be chosen carefully.

original: caṅkamanisajjāsannissitaṃ pana katvā gahetabbameva. Paṭhamaṃ yāmanti sakalasmimpi paṭhamayāme.
analyzed: pana katvā gahetabbam eva paṭhamam yāman ti sakalasmin pi paṭhama yāme
translated: In the first watch: in the whole of the first watch.

original: Seyyanti ettha kāmabhogīseyyā petaseyyā sīhaseyyā tathāgataseyyāti catasso seyyā.
analyzed: seyyanti ettha kāmabhogī seyyā peta seyyā sīha seyyā tathāgata seyyā ati catasso seyyā
translated: In the lion’s posture: there are four postures: the lustful man’s posture, the ghost’s posture, the lion’s posture, and the Tathāgata’s posture.

original: Tattha “yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, kāmabhogī vāmena passena sentī”ti ayaṃ kāmabhogīseyyā.🔽Tesu hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇapassena sayāno nāma natthi. “Yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, petā
analyzed: tattha yebhuyyena bhikkhave kāma bhogī vāmena passena senti iti ayam kāmabhogīseyyā  tesu hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇa passena sayānaḥ nāma natthi yebhuyyena bhikkhave petā
translated: Herein, the lustful man’s posture is that of the man who lies with his head on the woman’s breasts, putting his arms round her shoulders.🔽For they lie mostly with their right side to her. The ghost’s posture is that of one who lies prone with his face on the ground.

original: uttānā sentī”ti ayaṃ petaseyyā. Appamaṃsalohitattā hi aṭṭhisaṅghāṭaghaṭṭitā ekena
analyzed: uttānā senti iti ayam petaseyyāḥ appa maṃsa lohita ttāḥ hi aṭṭhi saṅghāṭa ghaṭṭitāḥ ekena
translated: For ghosts mostly lie prone.

original: passena sayituṃ na sakkonti, uttānāva senti. “Sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā dakkhiṇena
analyzed: passena sayitum na sakkonti uttānā ava senti sīhaḥ bhikkhave miga rājā dakkhiṇena
translated: they cannot lie on their sides. They lie as though stretched out. “Monks, a lion, king of beasts, lies down on his right side,

original: passena seyyaṃ kappeti…pe… attamano hotī”ti ayaṃ sīhaseyyā. Tejussadattā hi sīho🔽migarājā dve purimapāde ekasmiṃ pacchimapāde ekasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭhaṃ antarasatthimhi
analyzed: passena seyyam kappetipe atta manaḥ hoti iti ayam sīha seyyā tejussa dattā hi sīhaḥ  miga rājā dve purima pāde ekasmim pacchima pāde ekasmim ṭhāne ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭham antara satthimhi
translated: … and is pleased.” This is the lion-like posture. For a lion, king of beasts, is confident because of his fiery energy.🔽He places one of his two front paws on one hind paw, and he places his tail between his thighs.

original: pakkhipitvā purimapādapacchimapādanaṅguṭṭhānaṃ ṭhitokāsaṃ sallakkhetvā dvinnaṃ purimapādānaṃ
analyzed: pakkhipitvā purima pāda pacchima pāda naṅguṭṭhānam ṭhita ukāsam sallakkhetvā dvinnam purima pādānam
translated: He looks at the space between his front paws and his hind paws, and he places his head on the top of his forepaws.

original: matthake sīsaṃ ṭhapetvā sayati. Divasampi sayitvā pabujjhamāno na utrasto pabujjhati,
analyzed: matthake sīsam ṭhapetvā sayati divasam pi sayitvā pabujjhamānaḥ na utrastaḥ pabujjhati
translated: Even when he has slept all day and is waking up, he does not wake up uncollected.

original: sīsaṃ pana ukkhipitvā purimapādādīnaṃ ṭhitokāsaṃ sallakkheti. Sace kiñci ṭhānaṃ vijahitvā
analyzed: sīsam pana ukkhipitvā purima pāda ādīnam ṭhita ukāsam sallakkheti sace kiñci ṭhānam vijahitvā
translated: But he raises his head and looks at the space between his forepaws, etc. If he finds that he has left out any part,

original: ṭhitaṃ hoti, “nayidaṃ tuyhaṃ jātiyā, na sūrabhāvassa anurūpa”nti anattamano hutvā
analyzed: ṭhitam hoti nayidam tuyham jātiyā na sūra bhāvassa anurūpanti anatta manaḥ hutvā
translated: he is displeased, thinking, “This is not worthy of you, this is not becoming.”

original: tattheva sayati, na gocarāya pakkamati. Avijahitvā ṭhite pana “tuyhaṃ jātiyā ca sūrabhāvassa🔽ca anurūpamida”nti haṭṭhatuṭṭho uṭṭhāya sīhavijambhitaṃ vijambhitvā kesarabhāraṃ🔽vidhunitvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā gocarāya pakkamati. Catutthajjhānaseyyā pana
analyzed: tattha iva sayati na gocarāya pakkamati a vijahitvā ṭhite pana tuyham jātiyā ca sūra bhāvassa  ca anurūpam idam ti haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ uṭṭhāya sīha vijambhitam vijambhitvā kesara bhāram  vidhunitvā tikkhattum sīha nādam naditvā gocarāya pakkamati catuttha jhāna seyyā pana
translated: He lies down there and does not go out for alms. But if it is not lost, he thinks, “This is suitable to your kind and your smell,” and he gets up pleased and satisfied, yawns like a lion, shakes his mane,🔽and after roaring his lion’s roar three times, he goes out for alms. As to the fourth kind of sleep, that of the jhāna-dweller,🔽

original: tathāgataseyyāti vuccati. Tāsu idha sīhaseyyā āgatā. Ayañhi tejussadairiyāpathattā uttamaseyyā nāma.
analyzed: tathāgataseyyā ti vuccati tāsu idha sīha seyyā āgatā ayam hi tejussa dairiyā pathattā uttamaseyyā nāma
translated: He lies down there and does not go out for alms. But if it is not broken, he gets up pleased and satisfied, yawns a lion’s yawn, shakes his mane, roars his lion’s roar three times, and then goes out for alms. The sleep of one who has reached the fourth jhāna is called the sleep of a tathāgata. Of these, the sleep of a lion is given here. For this is called the best sleep because it is the sleep of one who has the best of all kinds of confidence.

original: Pāde pādanti dakkhiṇapāde vāmapādaṃ. Accādhāyāti atiādhāya īsakaṃ atikkamma ṭhapetvā.🔽Gopphakena hi gopphake, jāṇunā vā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇhaṃ vedanā uppajjati,
analyzed: pāde pādanti dakkhiṇa pāde vāma pādam accādhāya ati atiādhāya īsakam atikkamma ṭhapetvā  gopphakena hi gopphake jāṇunā vā jāṇumhi saṅghaṭṭiyamāne abhiṇham vedanā uppajjati
translated: Placing one foot on the other: placing the right foot on the left thigh, or the left foot on the right thigh.

original: cittaṃ ekaggaṃ na hoti, seyyā aphāsu hoti. Yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti, evaṃ atikkamma
analyzed: cittam ekaggam na hoti seyyā aphāsu hoti yathā pana na saṅghaṭṭeti evam atikkamma
translated: For if the ankle of one foot is pressed against the knee of the other, pain arises frequently and the mind does not become concentrated, and the sleep is not peaceful. But if he places the foot thus, he does not experience that pain.

original: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, seyyā phāsu hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “pāde
analyzed: ṭhapite vedanā nuppajjati cittam ekaggam hoti seyyā phāsu hoti tena vuttam pāde
translated: When it is set up, feeling does not arise, the mind becomes unified, and there is ease. Hence it was said: ‘Having placed one foot upon the other’ .

original: pādaṃ accādhāyā”ti. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ceva sampajānapaññāya ca samannāgato
analyzed: pādam accādhāya ati sataḥ sampajānoti satiyā ca iva sampajāna paññāya ca samannāgato
translated: Mindfully and with clear comprehension: endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension.

original: hutvā. Iminā supariggāhakaṃ satisampajaññaṃ kathitaṃ. Uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasikaritvāti
analyzed: hutvā iminā su pariggāhakam sati sampajaññam kathitam uṭṭhāna saññam manasikaritvā iti
translated: By this he shows that the mindfulness and clear comprehension are well-established.

original: “asukavelāya nāma uṭṭhahissāmī”ti evaṃ uṭṭhānavelāparicchedakaṃ uṭṭhānasaññaṃ citte
analyzed: asuka velāya nāma uṭṭhahissāmi iti evam uṭṭhāna velā paricchedakam uṭṭhāna saññam citte
translated: Having given attention to the perception of light: having placed in the mind the perception of light that defines the time for rising thus, ‘At such a time I will rise.’

original: ṭhapetvā. Evaṃ katvā nipanno hi yathāparicchinnakāleyeva uṭṭhāti.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā evam katvā nipannaḥ hi uṭṭhāti
translated: For one who goes to sleep in this way, rising at the defined time is not difficult.

original: Vīriyindriyaniddese cetasikoti idaṃ vīriyassa niyamato cetasikabhāvadīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: vīriya indriya niddese cetasikaḥ ti idam vīriyassa niyamato cetasika bhāva dīpana attham vuttam
translated: In the description of the faculty of energy, ‘mental’ is said in order to show that energy is necessarily mental.🔽For this energy is included in the definition of the enlightenment factor of energy thus: ‘Now what, bhikkhus, is the enlightenment factor of energy?🔽Whatever energy, striving, endeavour,

original: idañhi vīriyaṃ “yadapi, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ vīriyaṃ, tadapi vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, yadapi
analyzed: idam hi vīriyam yat api bhikkhave kāyikam vīriyam tat api vīriya sambojjhaṅgaḥ yat api
translated: exertion, endeavour, devoted effort, mental force,

original: cetasikaṃ vīriyaṃ, tadapi vīriyasambojjhaṅgoti. Itihidaṃ uddesaṃ gacchatī”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: cetasikam vīriyam tat api vīriya sambojjhaṅgā iti uddesam gacchati iti evamādīsu
translated: mental alertness, mental readiness, non-remissness, mindfulness, clear comprehension, and persistence there is in one who acts in this way—this is called the enlightenment factor of energy’ .

original: suttesu caṅkamādīni karontassa uppajjanatāya kāyikanti vuccamānampi kāyaviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: suttesu caṅkama ādīni karontassa uppajjana tāya kāyikan ti vuccamānam pi kāya viññāṇam
translated: And though it is called bodily because it arises in one who is walking up and down, standing, sitting, or lying down, as the case may be, among the kinds of bodily consciousness mentioned in the texts,🔽

original: viya kāyikaṃ nāma natthi, cetasikameva panetanti dīpetuṃ “cetasiko”ti vuttaṃ. Vīriyārambhoti
analyzed: viya kāyikam nāma natthi cetasikam eva pana itanti dīpetum cetasikaḥ iti vuttam vīriya ārambhaḥ ti
translated: And though it is called bodily because it arises in one who is walking up and down, etc., in the texts, still it is not called bodily as is bodily consciousness. But it is called mental in order to show that it is mental, not bodily.🔽Exertion of energy: the exertion called energy.

original: vīriyasaṅkhāto ārambho. Ayañhi ārambhasaddo kamme āpattiyaṃ kiriyāyaṃ vīriye hiṃsāyaṃ
analyzed: vīriya saṅkhātaḥ ārambhaḥ ayam hi ārambha saddo kamme āpattiyam kiriyāyam vīriye hiṃsāyam
translated: For this word ārambha is found to have several meanings: as action, as transgression, as performance, as energy, as violence,

original: vikopaneti anekesu atthesu āgato.
analyzed: vikopana iti anekesu atthesu āgato
translated: and as disturbance.

original: “Yaṃ kiñci dukkhaṃ sambhoti, sabbaṃ ārambhapaccayā;
analyzed: yam kiñci dukkham sambhoti sabbam ārambha paccayā
translated: “Whatever suffering originates is all conditioned by exertion;

original: Ārambhānaṃ nirodhena, natthi dukkhassa sambhavo”ti. –
analyzed: ārambhānam nirodhena na atthi dukkhassa sambhavaḥ ti
translated: With the cessation of exertion there is no origination of suffering” .

original: Ettha hi kammaṃ ārambhoti āgataṃ. “Ārambhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hotī”ti ettha āpatti.
analyzed: ettha hi kammam ārambhoti āgatam ārambhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti iti ettha āpatti
translated: Here it is action that is called exertion. “He is one who exerts himself and has remorse” . Here it is transgression.

original: “Mahāyaññā mahārambhā, na te honti mahapphalā”ti ettha yūpussāpanādikiriyā. “Ārambhatha
analyzed: mahā yaññāḥ mahā ārambhāḥ na te honti mahapphalāḥ ti ettha yūpussāpana ādi kiriyāḥ
translated: “Great sacrifices, great undertakings, are not productive of great fruit” . Here it is the performance of the act of raising the sacrificial post, and so on. “Exert yourselves,

original: nikkamatha, yuñjatha buddhasāsane”ti ettha vīriyaṃ. “Samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ uddissa pāṇaṃ
analyzed: nikkamatha yuñjatha buddha sāsane iti ettha vīriyam samaṇam gotamam uddissa pāṇam
translated: go forth, and apply yourselves to the Dispensation of the Buddha” . Here it is energy. “Having slain living beings for the recluse Gotama” .

original: ārambhantī”ti ettha hiṃsā. “Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hotī”ti ettha🔽chedanabhañjanādikaṃ vikopanaṃ. Idha pana vīriyameva adhippetaṃ. Tenāha “vīriyārambhoti
analyzed: ettha hiṃsā bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambhā paṭivirataḥ hoti iti ettha  chedana bhañjana ādikam vikopanam idha pana vīriyam eva adhippetam tena āha vīriya ārambhā ti
translated: Herein, the “initiating” is the violence. In the passage “he is one who abstains from initiating violence by sticks and knives” ,🔽the “disturbing” is the cutting, breaking, etc.,

original: vīriyasaṅkhāto ārambho”ti. Vīriyañhi ārambhanavasena ārambhoti vuccati. Idamassa🔽sabhāvapadaṃ. Kosajjato nikkhamanavasena nikkamo. Paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanavasena
analyzed: vīriya saṅkhātaḥ ārambho ti vīriyam hi ārambhana vasena ārambho ti vuccati idam assa  sabhāva padam kosajjataḥ nikkhamana vasena nikkamaḥ param param ṭhānam akkamana vasena
translated: Here, however, it is energy that is intended. Thus he says: “initiating is the initiating called energy.” For energy is called initiating because of the initiating of the work . This is its characteristic.

original: parakkamo. Uggantvā yamanavasena uyyāmo. Vāyamanavasena vāyāmo. Ussahanavasena ussāho.🔽Adhimattussahanavasena ussoḷhī. Thirabhāvaṭṭhena thāmo. Cittacetasikānaṃ dhāraṇavasena
analyzed: parakkamaḥ uggantvā yamana vasena uyyāmaḥ vā āyamana vasena vāyāmaḥ ussahana vasena ussāhaḥ  adhimatta ussahana vasena ussoḷhī thira bhāva ṭṭhena thāmo citta cetasikānam dhāraṇa vasena
translated: It is “striving” in the sense of going out from idleness. It is “endeavour” in the sense of going to higher and higher stages. It is “zeal” in the sense of going by leaping over. It is “persistence” in the sense of exerting. It is “upholding” in the sense of holding on.

original: avicchedato vā pavattanavasena kusalasantānaṃ dhāretīti dhiti.🔽Aparo nayo – nikkamo ceso kāmānaṃ panudanāya. Parakkamo ceso bandhanacchedāya. Uyyāmo
analyzed: a vicchedataḥ vā pavattana vasena kusala santānam dhāreti iti 🔽aparaḥ nayaḥ nikkamaḥ ceso kāmānam panudanāya parakkamaḥ ceso bandhana chedāya uyyāmaḥ
translated: It is “fortitude” in the sense of firmness. It is “strength” in the sense of the strength of mind . It is “power” in the sense of the power of mind . It is “steadfastness” in the sense of non-wavering. It is “resolution” in the sense of resolution on an object. It is “non-discouragement” in the sense of non-discouragement about an object. It is “non-remorse” in the sense of non-remorse about an object. It is “non-wavering” in the sense of non-wavering about an object. It is “non-agitation” in the sense of non-agitation about an object. It is “non-disturbance” in the sense of non-disturbance about an object. It is “non-confusion” in the sense of non-confusion about an object. It is “non-bewilderment” in the sense of non-bewilderment about an object. It is “non-agitation” in the sense of non-agitation about an object. It is “non-disturbance” in the sense of non-disturbance about an object. It is “non-confusion” in the sense of non-confusion about an object. It is “non-bewilderment” in the sense of non-bewilderment about an object. It is “non-agitation” in the sense of non-agitation about an object. It is “non-disturbance” in the sense of non-disturbance about an object. It is “non-confusion” in the sense of non-confusion about

original: ceso oghassa nittharaṇāya. Vāyāmo ceso pāraṃ gamanaṭṭhena. Ussāho ceso pubbaṅgamaṭṭhena.🔽Ussoḷhī ceso adhimattaṭṭhena. Thāmo ceso palighugghāṭanatāya. Dhiti ceso aṭṭhitakāritāyāti.🔽“Kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca, aṭṭhi ca avasissatū”ti evaṃ pavattikāle asithilaparakkamavasena
analyzed: ceso oghassa nittharaṇāya vāyāmo ceso pāram gamana ṭṭhena ussāho ceso pubbaṅgama ṭṭhena  ussoḷhī ceso adhimatta ṭṭhena thāmo ceso palighugghāṭana tāya ceso aṭṭhita kāri tāya ati  kāmam taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu uti evam pavatti kāle asithila parakkama vasena
translated: This is the crossing over of the flood. This is the going beyond of the round. This is the going to the further shore. This is the going to the end of suffering. This is the going to the exhaustion of the substratum. This is the going to the destruction of craving. This is the going to dispassion. This is the going to cessation. This is the going to Nibbāna. This is the going to the destruction of the round. This is the going to the destruction of the flood. This is the going to the destruction of the cankers. This is the going to the destruction of the defilements. This is the going to the destruction of the taints. This is the going to the destruction of the round. This is the going to the destruction of the flood. This is the crossing over of the flood. This is the going beyond of the round. This is the going to the further shore. This is the going to the end of suffering. This is the going to the exhaustion of the substratum. This is the going to the destruction of craving. This is the going to dispassion. This is the going to cessation. This is the going to Nibbāna. This is the going to the destruction of the round. This is the going to the destruction of the flood. This is the crossing over of the flood. This is the going beyond of the round. This is the going to the further shore. This is the going to the end of suffering. This is the going to the destruction of the round. This is the going to the destruction of the flood. This is the crossing over of the flood. This is the going beyond of the round. Yasmā panetaṃ vīriyaṃ🔽kusalakammakaraṇaṭṭhāne chandaṃ na nikkhipati, dhuraṃ na nikkhipati, na otāreti na🔽vissajjeti, anosakkitamānasataṃ āvahati, tasmā “anikkhittacchandatā anikkhittadhuratā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. original: kusalakammakaraṇaṭṭhāne dhuraṃ na nikkhipati paggaṇhāti, tasmā “dhurasampaggāho”ti
analyzed: kusala kamma karaṇa ṭhāne dhuram na nikkhipati paggaṇhāti tasmā dhura sampaggāho ti
translated: He does not lay aside the plough in the place of doing profitable action, he takes it up, thus it is said he “joins the yoke” .

original: vuttaṃ. Paggahalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti vīriyindriyaṃ. Kosajje na kampatīti vīriyabalaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam paggaha lakkhaṇe indaṭṭham kāreti iti vīriya indriyam kosajje na kampati iti vīriya balam
translated: He makes the faculty of energy the leader in the characteristic of taking up , thus it is the energy faculty. He does not waver in idleness, thus it is the energy strength.

original: Yāthāvaniyyānikakusalavāyāmatāya sammāvāyāmo.
analyzed: yāthāva niyyānika kusala vāyāma tāya sammāvāyāmo
translated: It is right endeavour because it is the right kind of endeavour for one who is going to the end of suffering.

original: Tandīti jātiālasiyaṃ. Tandiyanāti tandiyanākāro. Tandimanakatāti tandiyā abhibhūtacittatā.
analyzed: tandī iti tandiyā abhibhūta citta tā
translated: “Dull” is the natural laziness of the kind described in the way beginning, “There is what is called dullness” . “Dullness” is the state of being dull. “Dullness-benumbed” is the state of being overwhelmed by dullness.

original: Alasassa bhāvo ālasyaṃ, ālasyāyanākāro ālasyāyanā. Ālasyāyitassa bhāvo ālasyāyitattaṃ.
analyzed: alasassa bhāvaḥ ālasyam ālasya ayana ākāraḥ ālasya ayanāḥ ālasya āyitassa bhāvaḥ
translated: “Idleness” is the state of being idle. “Idleness-and-sloth” is the state of being idle and slothful. “Idleness-and-sloth-drowsiness” is the state of being idle, slothful, and drowsy.

original: Iti sabbehi imehi padehi kilesavasena kāyālasiyaṃ kathitaṃ.🔽Vañcanikā cariyāti vañcanikā kiriyā. Mā maṃ jaññāti vācaṃ bhāsatīti jānaṃyeva paṇṇattiṃ
analyzed: iti sabbehi imehi padehi kilesa vasena kāya ālasiyam kathitam  vañcanikā cariyā ati vañcanikā kiriyā mā mama jaññāti vācam bhāsati iti jānaṃyā iva paṇṇattim
translated: So all these terms refer to bodily laziness as defilement.🔽“Deceitful conduct” is the kind of action that is deceitful. “He speaks the word ‘Do not know me’” is a bhikkhu who, when he is known, transgresses by means of a description that is the opposite of the truth, thinking “They do not know me.”

original: vītikkamanto bhikkhu bhāriyaṃ karoti, amhākaṃ pana vītikkamaṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthīti
analyzed: vītikkamantaḥ bhikkhu bhāriyam karoti amhākam pana vītikkamaṭṭhānam nāma natthi iti
translated: But we have no place for transgression.

original: upasanto viya bhāsati. Kāyena parakkamatīti “mayā kataṃ idaṃ pāpakammaṃ mā keci jāniṃsū”ti
analyzed: upasantaḥ viya bhāsati kāyena parakkamati iti mayā katam idam pāpa kammam mā keci jāniṃsu iti
translated: He speaks as if he were calm. He acts with the body: he acts with the body in such a way that no one will know that he has done this evil deed.

original: kāyena vattaṃ karoti. Vijjamānadosapaṭicchādanato cakkhumohanamāyā viyāti māyā, māyāvino
analyzed: kāyena vattam karoti vijjamāna dosa paṭicchādanato cakkhu mohana māyā viyāti māyā māyāvino
translated: Concealing the evil that is actually there, he is like a magic trick that deceives the eye. Thus it is called “deception” . The state of being a deceiver is “deceptive behaviour” .

original: bhāvo māyāvitā. Katvā pāpaṃ puna paṭicchādanato ati assarati etāya sattoti accasarā.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ māyāvitā katvā pāpam puna paṭicchādanataḥ ati assarati etāya accasarā
translated: Having done evil, he conceals it again. Thus he “exceeds” with this .

original: Kāyavācākiriyāhi aññathā dassanato vañcetīti vañcanā. Etāya sattā nikarontīti nikati,🔽micchā karontīti attho. “Nāhaṃ evaṃ karomī”ti pāpānaṃ nikkhipanato nikiraṇā. “Nāhaṃ
analyzed: kāya vācā kiriyāhi aññathā dassanataḥ vañceti iti vañcanā etāya sattāḥ nikaronti iti  micchā karonti iti atthaḥ na aham evam karomi iti pāpānam nikkhipanataḥ nikiraṇāḥ na aham
translated: He deceives by showing otherwise through bodily and verbal actions. Thus it is called “deception” . Through this, beings are led astray; thus it is called “misleading” .🔽The meaning is, they are made to do what is wrong. “I do not do this” . Thus he “disperses” his evil. “I do not do this” . Thus he “avoids” it by keeping away from it. He “conceals” it by covering it up with bodily and verbal actions.

original: evaṃ karomī”ti parivajjanato pariharaṇā. Kāyādīhi saṃvaraṇato gūhanā. Sabbato bhāgena
analyzed: evam karomi iti parivajjanataḥ pariharaṇā kāya ādīhi saṃvaraṇataḥ gūhanā sabbatas bhāgena
translated: He “conceals it completely” by covering it up in every way.

original: gūhanā parigūhanā. Tiṇapaṇṇehi viya gūthaṃ kāyavacīkammehi pāpaṃ chādiyatīti chādanā.
analyzed: gūhanā parigūhanā tiṇa paṇṇehi viya gūtham kāya vacī kammehi pāpam chādiyati iti chādanā
translated: He “conceals” evil by covering it up with bodily and verbal actions, as if with grass and leaves.

original: Sabbato bhāgena chādanā paricchādanā. Na uttānaṃ katvā dassetīti anuttānīkammaṃ.
analyzed: sabbatas bhāgena chādanā paricchādanā na uttānam katvā dasseti iti an uttānīkammam
translated: He “conceals it completely” by covering it up in every way. He does not show it openly. Thus it is called “not open” .

original: Na pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetīti anāvikammaṃ. Suṭṭhu chādanā vocchādanā. Katapāpapaṭicchādanavasena
analyzed: na pākaṭam katvā dasseti iti anāvikammam suṭṭhu chādanā vā ucchādanā kata pāpa paṭicchādana vasena
translated: He does not show it openly: he does not reveal it. He conceals it well: he conceals it thoroughly.

original: punapi pāpassa karaṇato pāpakiriyā. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ katapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā🔽māyā nāma vuccati. Yāya samannāgato puggalo bhasmāpaṭicchanno viya aṅgāro, udakapaṭicchanno
analyzed: puna api pāpassa karaṇato pāpa kiriyā ayam vuccati iti ayam kata paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā  māyā nāma vuccati yāya samannāgataḥ puggalo bhasma apaṭicchannaḥ viya aṅgāro udaka paṭicchanno
translated: He commits evil: he commits evil again because of his concealment of the evil he has done.🔽This is called: this characteristic of concealing what one has done is called “deceit.”🔽By which a person is like a charcoal pit concealed by ashes,🔽like a stump concealed by water,

original: viya khāṇu, pilotikāya paliveṭhitaṃ viya ca satthaṃ hoti. Ativelaṃ dantavidaṃsakaṃ
analyzed: viya khāṇu pilotikāya paliveṭhitam viya ca sattham hoti ativelam danta vidaṃsakam
translated: like a knife concealed by its scabbard.

original: hasatīti pamāṇātikkantaṃ dantaṃ vivaritvā paresaṃ dassetvā hāsaṃ somanassaṃ uppādetvā hasati.
analyzed: hasati iti pamāṇa atikkantam dantam vivaritvā paresam dassetvā hāsam somanassam uppādetvā hasati
translated: He laughs immoderately: he laughs by showing his teeth beyond the proper measure, thus causing others to feel joy and delight.

original: Kāyikā ca khiḍḍāti kāyena pavattā kīḷā. Eseva nayo vācasikāyapi. Hatthīhipi kīḷantīti
analyzed: ca khiḍḍā ati kāyena pavattā kīḷā esā iva nayaḥ hatthīhi pi kīḷanti iti
translated: He plays bodily: he plays with his body. The same method applies to “verbal” .

original: hatthīhi kīḷitatthāya purato dhāvanaādhāvanapiṭṭhanisīdanādikīṭṭhāya kīḷanti. Eseva
analyzed: hatthīhi kīḷita tthāya puratas dhāvana ādhāvana piṭṭha nisīdana ādi kīṭṭhāya kīḷanti esā iva
translated: He plays with elephants: he plays with elephants for the purpose of playing with them, by running in front of them, by mounting their backs, and so on.

original: nayo assarathesupi. Aṭṭhapadepi kīḷantīti ekekāya pantiyā aṭṭha aṭṭha padāni assāti
analyzed: nayaḥ assa rathesu pi aṭṭhapade pi kīḷanti iti ekekāya pantiyā aṭṭha aṭṭha padāni assa ati
translated: The same method applies to “horses” and “chariots.”🔽He plays with birds: he plays with birds by training them to fly and to return to his shoulder, and so on.

original: aṭṭhapadaṃ, tasmiṃ aṭṭhapade. Dasapadepi eseva nayo. Ākāsepīti aṭṭhapadadasapadesu
analyzed: aṭṭha padam tasmin aṭṭhapade dasa pade pi esa iva nayo ākāse pi iti aṭṭhapada dasa padesu
translated: In the eight- or ten-part game: in the eight-part or ten-part game. In the same way with the “in the air” game.

original: viya ākāseyeva kīḷanti. Parihārapathepīti bhūmiyaṃ nānāpathamaṇḍalaṃ katvā tattha
analyzed: viyaḥ ākāseya iva kīḷanti parihāra pathe iva iti bhūmiyam nānāpatha maṇḍalam katvā tattha
translated: In the “avoiding” game: on the ground they make various circular tracks, and

original: pariharitabbapathaṃ pariharantā kīḷanti. Santikāyapi kīḷantīti santikakīḷāya kīḷanti,
analyzed: pariharitabba patham pariharantā kīḷanti santikāya api kīḷanti iti santika kīḷāya kīḷanti
translated: they play by avoiding the tracks. In the “near” game: they play the “near” game,

original: ekajjhaṃ ṭhapitā sāriyo vā pāsāṇasakkharāyo vā acālentā nakheneva apanenti ca upanenti
analyzed: ekajjham ṭhapitā sāriyaḥ vā pāsāṇa sakkharāyaḥ vā a cālentāḥ nakhena iva apanenti ca upanenti
translated: they move a piece forward or backward with their fingernail without moving the pieces placed next to it.

original: ca. Sace tattha kāci calati, parājayo hotīti.
analyzed: ca sace kāci calati parājayaḥ hoti iti
translated: If one of them moves, they lose.

original: Khalikāyāti jūtaphalake pāsakakīḷāya kīḷanti. Ghaṭikāyāti ghaṭikā vuccati dīghadaṇḍakena
analyzed: khalikāya ati jūta phalake pāsaka kīḷāya kīḷanti ghaṭikāya ati ghaṭikā vuccati dīgha daṇḍakena
translated: In the “dice” game: they play the “dice” game with a board and pieces. In the “hourglass” game: the “hourglass” is a game with long and short sticks

original: rassadaṇḍakaṃ paharaṇakīḷā, tāya kīḷanti. Salākahatthenāti lākhāya vā mañjaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: rassa daṇḍakam paharaṇa kīḷā tāya kīḍanti sa lāka hatthena ati lākhāya vā mañjaṭṭhiyā
translated: and a hitting stick. They play that game. In the “handwriting” game: they moisten their hand with lac or with a paste of yellow orpiment,

original: vā piṭṭhodakena vā salākahatthaṃ temetvā “kiṃ hotū”ti bhūmiyaṃ vā bhittiyaṃ vā taṃ
analyzed: vā piṭṭha udakena vā salākahattham temetvā kim hotu uti bhūmiyam vā bhittiyam vā tam
translated: and they write on the ground or on a wall, “What will be, will be.”

original: paharitvā hatthiassādirūpāni dassentā kīḷanti. Akkhenāti guḷena. Paṅkacīrenāti paṅkacīraṃ🔽vuccati paṇṇanāḷikā, taṃ dhamantā kīḷanti. Vaṅkakenāti gāmadārakānaṃ kīḷanakena khuddakanaṅgalena.🔽Mokkhacikāyāti samparivattakakīḷāya, ākāse vā daṇḍaṃ gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ vā sīsaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: paharitvā hatthi assa ādi rūpāni dassentā kīḷanti akkhena ati guḷena paṅka cīrena ati paṅka cīram  vuccati paṇṇa nāḷikā tam dhamantā kīḷanti vaṅkakena ati gāma dārakānam kīḷanakena khuddaka naṅgalena  mokkhacikāya ati samparivattaka kīḷāya ākāse vā daṇḍam gahetvā bhūmiyam vā sīsam ṭhapetvā
translated: They play by hitting each other and showing the forms of elephants, horses, etc. ‘With a ball’: with a ball of thread. ‘With a ring’: a ring is called a tube of leaves. They play by blowing it. ‘With a toy plough’: with a small plough used as a toy by village boys.

original: heṭṭhupariyabhāvena parivattantā kīḷantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Ciṅgulakenāti ciṅgulakaṃ🔽vuccati tālapaṇṇādīhi kataṃ vātappahārena paribbhamanacakkaṃ, tena kīḷanti. Pattāḷhakenāti🔽pattāḷhakaṃ vuccati paṇṇanāḷi, tāya vālikādīni minantā kīḷanti. Rathakenāti khuddakarathena.🔽Dhanukenāti khuddakadhanunā. Akkharikāyāti akkharikā vuccati ākāse vā piṭṭhiyaṃ vā
analyzed: heṭṭhupariya bhāvena parivattantā kīḷanti iti vuttam hoti ciṅgulakena ati ciṅgulakam 🔽vuccati tāla paṇṇa ādīhi katam vāta ppahārena paribbhamana cakkam tena kīḷanti patta āḷhakena ati 🔽pattāḷhakam vuccati paṇṇa nāḷi tāya vālikā ādīni minantā kīḷanti rathakena ati khuddaka rathena 🔽dhanukena ati khuddaka dhanunā akkharikāya ati akkharikā vuccati ākāse vā piṭṭhiyam vā
translated: ‘With a skipping rope’: with a skipping rope. They play by skipping. ‘With a toy cart’: with a small cart. ‘With a toy bow’: with a small bow. ‘With a toy measure’: a toy measure is called a measure used in the air or on the back.

original: akkharajānanakīḷā, tāya kīḷanti. Manesikāyāti manesikā vuccati manasā cintitajānanakīḷā,🔽tāya kīḷanti. Yathāvajjenāti yathāvajjaṃ vuccati kāṇakuṇikhujjādīnaṃ yaṃ yaṃ vajjaṃ,🔽taṃ taṃ payojetvā dassanakīḷā, tāya kīḷanti. Mukhabherikanti mukhasaddena bherī viya
analyzed: akkhara jānana kīḷā tāya kīḷanti manesikāya ati manesikā vuccati manasā cintita jānana kīḷā  tāya kīḷanti yathāvajjena ati yathāvajjam vuccati kāṇa kuṇi khujja ādīnam yam yam vajjam  tam tam payojetvā dassana kīḷā tāya kīḷanti mukhabherikanti mukha saddena bherī viya
translated: They play the game of guessing letters. They play the game of guessing what is thought of by the mind. They play the game of guessing what is thought of by the mind: guessing what is thought of by the mind is called the game of guessing what is thought of by the mind.

original: vādanaṃ. Mukhālambaranti mukhānulittabherisaddakaraṇaṃ. Mukhaḍiṇḍimakanti mukhena🔽pahatabherisaddakaraṇaṃ. Mukhavalimakanti oṭṭhamaṃsaṃ jimhaṃ katvā saddakaraṇaṃ.🔽“Mukhatalika”ntipi pāṭho, mukhaṃ parivattetvā dhamanaṃ. Mukhabheruḷakanti mukhena🔽bherivādanaṃ. Nāṭakanti abhinayaṃ dassetvā uggaṇhāpanaṃ. “Naṭṭaka”ntipi pāṭho. Lāpanti🔽ukkuṭṭhitakaraṇaṃ. Gītanti gāyanaṃ. Davakammanti hassakīḷākaraṇaṃ. Ayaṃ vācasikā
analyzed: vādanam mukha ālambaranti mukha anulitta bheri sadda karaṇam mukha ḍiṇḍimakanti mukhena 🔽pahata bheri sadda karaṇam oṭṭha maṃsam jimham katvā sadda karaṇam 🔽pāṭhaḥ mukham dhamanam mukha bheruḷakanti mukhena 🔽bheri vādanam nāṭakanti abhinayam dassetvā uggaṇhāpanam naṭṭakanti pi pāṭhaḥ lāpanti 🔽ukkuṭṭhita karaṇam gītanti gāyanam dava kammanti hassa kīḷā karaṇam ayam vācasikā

original: khiḍḍāti ayaṃ kīḷā vācāya jātā vacīdvāre uppannā.
analyzed: ayam kīḍā vācāya jātā vacī dvāre uppannā
translated: “Play” is the play that arises with speech, that occurs through the speech door.🔽“Hair and beard” : without cutting the hair with a razor, as is done in the case of the hair on the head,

original: Kesā ca massu cātiādīsu kesānaṃ kattarikāya ṭhānātirittāni akatvā kattarikāya chedanaṃ🔽massūnaṃ dāṭhikaṃ ṭhapetvā kappāsanañca ekatovaṇḍikādimālā ca mūlagandhādigandhā
analyzed: kesā ca massu ca ati ādīsu kesānam kattarikāya ṭhāna atirittāni a katvā kattarikāya chedanam  massūnam dāṭhikam ṭhapetvā kappāsanam ca ekatovaṇḍika ādi mālā ca mūla gandha ādi gandhā
translated: and without leaving a beard, as is done in the case of the hair on the face,🔽one shaves the hair on the head and face. “Perfume” is the perfume of roots, etc.,🔽“Necklaces” are the necklaces worn around the neck, etc. “Jewellery” is the jewellery worn on the head, etc.

original: ca chavikaraṇavilepanā ca. Gīvādīsu piḷandhanaābharaṇā ca sīse paṭimuñcanapasādhanapiḷandhanā🔽ca sarīranivāsanavicitravatthā ca saṃvelliyabandhanapasādhanañca. “Parāsana”ntipi
analyzed: ca chavi karaṇa vilepanā ca gīvā ādīsu piḷandhana ābharaṇā ca sīse paṭimuñcana pasādhana piḷandhanā  ca ca ca
translated: “Clothes” are the inner and outer garments. “Bedding” is the bedding and the equipment used for adorning the bed.

original: pāṭho. Sīsaveṭhanapaṭasaṅkhātaveṭhanañca.
analyzed: sīsa veṭhana paṭa saṅkhāta veṭhanam ca
translated: “Furniture” is the furniture used for sitting, etc. “Massage” is the rubbing of the body with fragrant pastes, etc.

original: Ucchādanādīsu mātukucchito nikkhantadārakānaṃ sarīragandho dvādasamattavassakāle
analyzed: ucchādana ādīsu mātukucchitaḥ nikkhanta dārakānam sarīra gandhaḥ dvādasa matta vassa kāle
translated: “In the case of bathing, anointing, and massaging” : the body odour of a child that has just come out of the mother’s womb disappears when it is twelve years old.

original: nassati, tesaṃ sarīragandhaharaṇatthāya gandhacuṇṇādīhi ucchādenti, evarūpaṃ ucchādanaṃ
analyzed: tesam sarīra gandha haraṇa atthāya gandha cuṇṇa ādīhi ucchādenti evarūpam ucchādanam
translated: In order to remove the body odour, they bathe with fragrant pastes, etc.

original: na vaṭṭati. Puññavante pana dārake ūrūsu nipajjāpetvā telena makkhetvā hatthapādaūrunābhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati puññavante pana dārake ūrūsu nipajjāpetvā telena makkhetvā hattha pāda ūru nābhi ādīnam
translated: It is not allowable. But if the children are meritorious, they can be made to lie on his thighs, and after being anointed with oil, their hands, feet,🔽

original: saṇṭhānasampādanatthaṃ parimaddanti, evarūpaṃ parimaddanaṃ na vaṭṭati.🔽Nhāpananti tesaṃyeva dārakānaṃ gandhādīhi nhāpanaṃ. Sambāhananti mahāmallānaṃ viya
analyzed: saṇṭhāna sampādana attham parimaddanti evarūpam parimaddanam na vaṭṭati  tesam yeva dārakānam gandha ādīhi nhāpanam sambāhananti mahā mallānam viya
translated: It is not allowable. But if the children are meritorious, they may be made to lie on their parents’ laps, and after being smeared with oil, they may be massaged in order to make their hands and feet, etc., grow straight. Such massaging is not allowable.

original: hatthapāde muggarādīhi paharitvā bāhuvaḍḍhanaṃ. Ādāsanti yaṃkiñci ādāsaṃ pariharituṃ
analyzed: hattha pāde muggara ādīhi paharitvā bāhu vaḍḍhanam ādāsanti yaṃkiñci ādāsam pariharitum
translated: Bathing: bathing those same children with perfumes, etc., is not allowable. Rubbing down: rubbing down the hands and feet, etc., with clubs, etc., in order to make them grow like the great wrestlers.

original: na vaṭṭati. Añjanaṃ alaṅkārañjanameva. Mālāti baddhamālā vā abaddhamālā vā. Vilepananti🔽yaṃkiñci chavirāgakaraṇaṃ. Mukhacuṇṇakaṃ mukhalepananti mukhe kāḷapīḷakādīnaṃ haraṇatthāya🔽mattikākakkaṃ denti. Tena lohite calite sāsapakakkaṃ denti, tena dose khādite tilakakkaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati añjanam alaṅkāra añjanam eva baddha mālā vā a baddha mālā vā  yaṃ kiñci chavi rāga karaṇam mukha cuṇṇakam mukha lepanam mukhe kāḷapīḷaka ādīnam haraṇa tthāya  mattikā kakkam denti tena lohite calite sāsapa kakkam denti tena dose khādite tila kakkam
translated: Mirror: it is not allowable to carry any kind of mirror. Collyrium: only ornamental collyrium. Garlands: either bound garlands or unbound garlands. Anointing:🔽any kind of unguent for the skin. Face-powder: they give a lump of clay to put on the face in order to remove blackheads, etc.🔽When blood appears, they give a lump of clay with asafoetida, in order to remove the poison. When the poison has been removed, they give a lump of clay with turmeric,

original: denti, tena lohite sannisinne haliddikakkaṃ denti, tena chavivaṇṇe ārūḷhe mukhacuṇṇakena
analyzed: denti tena lohite sannisinne haliddikakkam denti tena chavi vaṇṇe ārūḍhe mukha cuṇṇakena
translated: in order to make the skin colour even. When the skin colour has become even, they give face-powder in order to make it shine.

original: mukhaṃ cuṇṇenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: mukham cuṇṇenti tat sabbam na vaṭṭati
translated: All this is not allowable.

original: Hatthabandhādīsu hatthe vicitrasaṅkhakapālādīni bandhitvā vicaranti, taṃ vā aññaṃ
analyzed: hattha bandha ādīsu hatthe vicitra saṅkha kapāla ādīni bandhitvā vicaranti tam vai aññam
translated: As regards armlets, etc., some go about with their arms adorned with various things such as conches, cowries, etc., tied on, or with armlets,

original: vā sabbampi hatthābharaṇaṃ na vaṭṭati. Apare sikhaṃ bandhitvā vicaranti, suvaṇṇacīrakamuttāvaḷiādīhi
analyzed: vā sabbam pi hattha ābharaṇam na vaṭṭati apare sikham bandhitvā vicaranti
translated: or they tie up their hair with gold, etc., and they surround it with gold leaf, pearls, etc.,

original: ca taṃ parikkhipanti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati. Apare catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana
analyzed: ca tam parikkhipanti tam sabbam na vaṭṭati apare catu hattha daṇḍam vā aññam vā pana
translated: or they go about with a decorated staff in their hands, four cubits long or of some other length,

original: alaṅkatadaṇḍakaṃ gahetvā vicaranti, tathā itthipurisarūpādivicittaṃ bhesajjanāḷikaṃ🔽suparikkhittaṃ vāmapasse olaggenti, apare anekacitrakosaṃ atitikhiṇaṃ asiṃ, pañcavaṇṇasuttasibbitaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkata daṇḍakam gahetvā vicaranti tathā itthi purisa rūpa ādi vicittam bhesajja nāḷikam  su parikkhittam vāma passe olaggenti apare aneka citra kosam ati tikhiṇam asim pañca vaṇṇa sutta sibbitam
translated: or they carry on their left side a medicine bag with various things such as pictures of men and women,🔽or they carry a very sharp sword in a scabbard of various colours such as is worn by a warrior,🔽or they carry an umbrella with a handle decorated with the tusk of an elephant or some such thing and with ribs of variously coloured cane,

original: makaradantakādivicittaṃ chattaṃ, suvaṇṇarajatādivicitrā morapiñchādiparikkhittā upāhanā,
analyzed: makara dantaka ādi vicittam chattam suvaṇṇa rajata ādi vicitrā mora piñcha ādi parikkhittā upāhanā
translated: or they wear sandals with uppers of gold or silver, etc., surrounded by peacock’s tail feathers, etc.,

original: keci ratanamattāyāmaṃ caturaṅgulavitthataṃ kesantaparicchedaṃ dassetvā meghamukhe
analyzed: keci ratana matta āyāmam catur aṅgula vitthatam kesanta paricchedam dassetvā megha mukhe
translated: and some, after showing a fringe of hair an arrow’s breadth long and four fingers wide, on their chins,

original: vijjulataṃ viya nalāṭe uṇhīsapaṭṭaṃ bandhitvā cūḷāmaṇiṃ dhārenti, cāmaravālabījaniṃ
analyzed: vijju latam nalāṭe uṇhīsa paṭṭam bandhitvā cūḷāmaṇim dhārenti
translated: They wear a turban on their foreheads as if they were a lightning flash, and they wear a crest jewel. They hold a yak’s tail fan.

original: dhārenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dhārenti tam sabbam na vaṭṭati
translated: All this is not allowable.🔽This putrid body: this corpse made of the four primary elements.

original: Imassa vā pūtikāyassāti imassa cātumahābhūtamayassa kuṇapasarīrassa. Keḷanāti kīḷāpanā.
analyzed: imassa vā pūti kāyassa ati imassa cātumahābhūta mayassa kuṇapa sarīrassa keḷanā ati kīḷāpanā
translated: Play: amusement.

original: Parikeḷanāti sabbato bhāgena kīḷāpanā. Gedhitatāti abhikaṅkhitatā. Gedhitattanti
analyzed: parikeḷanā ati sabbatas bhāgena kīḷāpanā gedhita tā ati abhikaṅkhita tā gedhita tanti
translated: Amusement: amusement in every way. Longing: desire. Longing:

original: giddhabhāvo abhikaṅkhitabhāvo. Capalatāti alaṅkārakaraṇaṃ. Cāpalyanti capalabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: alaṅkāra karaṇam cāpalyanti capala bhāvam
translated: longing, desire. Fickleness: ornamentation. Fickleness: fickleness.

original: Savibhūsantiādīsu vibhūsāya saha savibhūsaṃ. Chavirāgakaraṇasaṅkhātena parivārena saha saparivāraṃ. Paribhaṇḍena saha saparibhaṇḍaṃ. Parikkhārena saha saparikkhāraṃ.
analyzed: sa vibhūsanti ādīsu vibhūsāya saha sa vibhūsam chavi rāga karaṇa saṅkhātena parivārena saha sa parivāram paribhaṇḍena saha sa paribhaṇḍam parikkhārena saha sa parikkhāram
translated: Adorned: together with adornment. With a retinue: together with a retinue in the sense of a surrounding. With furniture: together with furniture. With equipment: together with equipment.

original: 162. Āthabbaṇanti āthabbaṇikamantappayogaṃ. Supinanti supinasatthaṃ. Lakkhaṇanti maṇilakkhaṇādiṃ. No vidaheti nappayojeyya. Virutañcāti migādīnaṃ vaṭṭetvā vassitaṃ.
analyzed: āthabbaṇam iti āthabbaṇika manta ppayogam supinam iti supina sattham lakkhaṇam iti maṇi lakkhaṇa ādim no vidaha iti na payojeyya virutam ca ati miga ādīnam vaṭṭetvā vassitam
translated: ‘Divination’ is the use of spells for divining what is good or bad. ‘Dreams’ is the interpretation of dreams. ‘Signs’ is the interpretation of the signs of the hand, the face, etc. ‘He should not consult’ means he should not employ. ‘Omens’ is the interpretation of the cries of birds, etc.

original: Āthabbaṇikāti parūpaghātamantajānanakā. Āthabbaṇaṃ payojentīti āthabbaṇikā kira sattāhaṃ🔽aloṇakaṃ bhuñjitvā dabbe attharitvā pathaviyaṃ sayamānā tapaṃ caritvā sattame divase🔽susānabhūmiṃ sajjetvā sattame pade ṭhatvā hatthaṃ vaṭṭetvā vaṭṭetvā mukhena vijjaṃ
analyzed: āthabbaṇikā ati para upaghāta manta jānanakāḥ āthabbaṇam payojenti iti āthabbaṇikā kira sattāham  a loṇakam bhuñjitvā dabbe attharitvā pathaviyam sayamānā tapam caritvā sattame divase  su sāna bhūmim sajjetvā sattame pade ṭhatvā hattham vaṭṭetvā vaṭṭetvā mukhena vijjam
translated: ‘Diviners’ are those who know the spells for divining what is good or bad. ‘Consult’ means they consult the diviners. It seems that they live on salt-free food for seven days,🔽then they lie down on the bare ground and practise austerities. On the seventh day they prepare a charnel-ground site,

original: parijappanti, atha tesaṃ kammaṃ samijjhati. Evarūpaṃ sandhāya “āthabbaṇaṃ payojentī”ti🔽āha. Tattha payojentīti yuttappayuttā honti. Nagare vā ruddheti nagare samantato
analyzed: parijappanti atha tesam kammam samijjhati evarūpam sandhāya āthabbaṇam payojenti iti  āha tattha payojenti iti yutta ppayuttāḥ honti nagare vā ruddhā iti nagare samantataḥ
translated: stand on the seventh step, wave their hands, and recite the spells with their mouths. Then their work succeeds. With such people as these in mind it is said, ‘Consult the diviners.’

original: rundhitvā āvaritvā gahite. Saṅgāme vā paccupaṭṭhiteti raṇe upagantvā ṭhite. Paccatthikesu
analyzed: rundhitvā āvaritvā gahite saṅgāme vā paccupaṭṭhitā iti raṇe upagantvā ṭhite paccatthikesu
translated: Herein, ‘consult’ means they are occupied with consulting. ‘In a besieged city’ means in a city that is surrounded on all sides and besieged. ‘In a battle that is raging’ means in a battle that has begun and is in progress. ‘Against enemies’ means

original: paccāmittesūti paṭāṇībhūtesu verīsu. Ītiṃ uppādentīti sarīracalanaṃ kampanaṃ, tassa🔽uppādanaṃ karonti. Upaddavanti kāyapīḷanaṃ karonti. Roganti byādhiṃ. Pajjarakanti
analyzed: pacca amittesu iti paṭāṇībhūtesu verīsu ītim uppādenti iti sarīra calanam kampanam tassa  uppādanam karonti upaddavanti kāya pīḷanam karonti roganti byādhim pajjarakanti
translated: ‘Enemies’: those who have become enemies, adversaries. ‘They cause trembling’: they cause the shaking of the body.🔽‘They cause affliction’: they cause bodily pain. ‘Disease’: sickness. ‘Old age’:

original: jaraṃ. Sūlanti uddhumātakaṃ. Visūcikanti vijjhanaṃ. Pakkhandikanti lohitapakkhandikaṃ.
analyzed: jaram sūlanti uddhumātakam visūcikanti vijjhanam pakkhandikanti lohitapakkhandikam
translated: decay. ‘Swelling’: bloating. ‘Dysentery’: diarrhea. ‘Dyspnea’: shortness of breath.

original: Karontīti uppādenti.
analyzed: karonti iti uppādenti
translated: ‘They cause’: they bring about.

original: Supinapāṭhakāti supinabyākaraṇakā. Ādisantīti byākaronti. Yo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ supinaṃ🔽passatītiādīsu accantasaṃyoge upayogavacanaṃ, pubbaṇhasamayeti attho. Evaṃ vipāko
analyzed: supina pāṭhakāḥ ati supina byākaraṇakāḥ ādisanti iti byākaronti yaḥ pubbaṇha samayam supinam  passati iti ādīsu accanta saṃyoge upayoga vacanam pubbaṇha samaya iti atthaḥ evam vipākaḥ
translated: ‘Dream interpreters’: those who explain dreams. ‘They declare’: they explain. ‘One who sees a dream

original: hotīti iṭṭhāniṭṭhavasena evarūpo vipāko hoti. Avakujja nipannoti adhomukho hutvā
analyzed: hoti iti iṭṭha aniṭṭha vasena evarūpaḥ vipākaḥ hoti avakujja nipanno ti adhomukhaḥ hutvā
translated: in the morning time’ and so on: the word ‘in’ is used in the sense of ‘at the end of’ in the sense of ‘at the end of the morning time’. ‘Such is the result’ means that such a result occurs in the form of what is desirable or undesirable. ‘One who lies down with his head towards the ground’

original: nipanno passati. Evaṃ supinapāṭhakā supinaṃ ādisanti.
analyzed: nipanno passati evam supina pāṭhakā supinam ādisanti
translated: means one who lies down with his face downwards. ‘Thus the dream interpreters declare the dream.’

original: Tañca pana supinaṃ passanto catūhi kāraṇehi passati dhātukkhobhato vā anubhūtapubbato
analyzed: tat ca pana supinam passantaḥ catūhi kāraṇehi passati dhātu kkhobhataḥ vā anubhūta pubbataḥ
translated: And one who sees a dream sees it for four reasons: through a disturbance of the elements, through what was experienced in the past,

original: vā devatopasaṃhārato vā pubbanimittato vāti. Tattha pittādīnaṃ khobhakaraṇapaccayayogena
analyzed: vā devatā upasaṃhārataḥ vā pubba nimittataḥ vā ati tattha pitta ādīnam khobha karaṇa paccaya yogena
translated: or by the influence of a deity, or by an omen. Herein, one who sees a dream by the disturbance of the elements sees a dream by the disturbance of the elements through the condition of the disturbance of the bile, etc.,

original: khubhitadhātuko dhātukkhobhato supinaṃ passati, passanto ca nānāvidhaṃ supinaṃ passati.🔽Anubhūtapubbato passanto pubbe anubhūtapubbaṃ ārammaṇaṃ passati. Devatopasaṃhārato
analyzed: khubhita dhātukaḥ dhātu khobhataḥ supinam passati passantaḥ ca nānāvidham supinam passati  anubhūta pubbataḥ passantaḥ pubbe anubhūta pubbam ārammaṇam passati devatā upasaṃhārato
translated: and what he sees is of various kinds.🔽One who sees a dream by what was done in the past sees an object that was experienced in the past.

original: passanto devatānaṃ ānubhāvena ārammaṇāni passati. Pubbanimittato passanto puññāpuññavasena
analyzed: passantaḥ devatānaṃ ānubhāvena ārammaṇāni passati pubba nimittato passantaḥ puñña apuñña vasena
translated: One who sees a dream by the influence of a deity sees objects through the influence of deities.

original: uppajjitukāmassa atthassa vā anatthassa vā pubbanimittabhūtaṃ supinaṃ passati. Tattha
analyzed: uppajjitu kāmassa atthassa vā anatthassa vā pubba nimitta bhūtam supinam passati tattha
translated: One who sees a dream by an omen sees a dream that is an omen of what is to happen, whether good or bad. Herein,

original: yaṃ dhātukkhobhato anubhūtapubbato ca supinaṃ passati, na taṃ saccaṃ hoti. Yaṃ devatopasaṃhārato
analyzed: yam dhātu khobhataḥ anubhūta pubbataḥ ca supinam passati na tat saccam hoti yam devatā upasaṃhārato
translated: the dream that one sees by the disturbance of the elements and by what was done in the past is not true. The dream that one sees by the influence of a deity

original: passati, taṃ saccaṃ vā hoti alikaṃ vā. Kuddhā hi devatā upāyena vināsetukāmā viparītampi
analyzed: passati tam saccam vā hoti alikam vā kuddhāḥ hi devatāḥ upāyena vinā setu kāmāḥ viparītam pi
translated: is either true or false. For deities who are angry and want to destroy someone through a stratagem see a false dream🔽and tell it to him, thinking, “By this stratagem we will destroy him.”

original: katvā dassenti. Yaṃ pana pubbanimittato passati, taṃ ekantasaccameva hoti. Etesaṃ
analyzed: katvā dassenti yam pana pubba nimittato passati tam ekanta saccam eva hoti etesam
translated: But what he sees as an omen is entirely true.

original: catunnaṃ mūlakāraṇānaṃ saṃsaggabhedatopi supinabhedo hotiyeva. Tañca panetaṃ catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: catunnam mūla kāraṇānam saṃsagga bhedataḥ pi supina bhedaḥ tat ca pana itam catubbidham
translated: And there is a further kind of dream that is due to the difference of the four primary elements’ interaction.

original: supinaṃ sekkhaputhujjanāva passanti appahīnavipallāsattā. Asekkhā na passanti pahīnavipallāsattā.
analyzed: supinam sekkha puthujjanāḥ ava passanti appahīna vipallāsa ttā asekkhāḥ na passanti pahīna vipallāsa ttā
translated: And this fourfold dream is seen by both trainers and ordinary men because they have not abandoned perversion of perception. It is not seen by those in higher training because they have abandoned perversion of perception.

original: Kiṃ panetaṃ passanto sutto passati, udāhu paṭibuddho, udāhu neva sutto na paṭibuddhoti?🔽Kiñcettha – yadi tāva sutto passati, abhidhammavirodho āpajjati. Bhavaṅgacittena
analyzed: kim pana etam passantaḥ suttaḥ passati udāhu paṭibuddhaḥ udāhu na iva suttaḥ na paṭibuddhaḥ ti  kiñca ittha yadi tāva sutto passati abhidhamma virodhaḥ āpajjati bhavaṅga cittena
translated: But as to the question, “Is it the sleeping man who sees the dream or the waking man or neither the sleeping man nor the waking man?”🔽What is the point here? If it is the sleeping man who sees it, there is the contradiction of the Abhidhamma to be faced. For he sleeps with the life-continuum consciousness, and that is not associated with greed, etc., or with the object consisting of a visible datum, etc., as the dream is.

original: hi supati, taṃ rūpanimittādiārammaṇaṃ rāgādisampayuttaṃ vā na hoti, supinaṃ passantassa🔽ca īdisāni cittāni uppajjanti. Atha paṭibuddho passati, vinayavirodho āpajjati. Yañhi
analyzed: hi supati tam rūpa nimitta ādi ārammaṇam rāga ādi sampayuttam vā na hoti supinam passantassa 🔽ca īdisāni cittāni uppajjanti atha paṭibuddhaḥ passati vinaya virodhaḥ āpajjati yat hi
translated: And the kinds of consciousness that occur in one who sees a dream are not of that kind.🔽But if it is the waking man who sees it, there is the contradiction of the Vinaya to be faced. For the Vinaya says: “If a monk should dream that he has done one of the things that constitute grounds for formal meetings of the Order, he should be told by his companions in the holy life: ‘Friend, this is not a ground for a formal meeting of the Order. You have not done this while you were fully aware. You were dreaming when you did it.’

original: paṭibuddho passati, taṃ sabbohārikacittena passati, sabbohārikacittena ca kate vītikkame
analyzed: paṭibuddhaḥ passati tam sabbohārika cittena passati sabbohārika cittena ca kate vītikkame
translated: If he sees when he is awake, he sees with a mind that is not perverted; and if there is an offence, it is one that is incurred by what is done with a mind that is not perverted.

original: anāpatti nāma natthi, supinaṃ passantena pana kate vītikkame ekantaṃ anāpatti eva.🔽Atha neva sutto na paṭibuddho passati, ko nāma passati. Evañca sati supinassa abhāvova
analyzed: anāpatti nāma natthi supinam passantena pana kate vītikkame ekantam anāpatti eva  atha na iva suttaḥ na paṭibuddhaḥ passati kaḥ nāma passati evañca sati supinassa abhāvaḥ uva
translated: There is no such thing as an offence that is not an offence. But when an offence is incurred by one who is dreaming, it is certainly not an offence.🔽If he does not see when he is asleep or when he is awake, who then is it that sees? And if that is so, then the non-existence of dreams

original: āpajjati, na abhāvo. Kasmā? Yasmā kapiniddāpareto passati. Vuttañhetaṃ – “majjhūpagato,
analyzed: āpajjati na abhāvaḥ kasmā yasmā kapi niddā paretaḥ passati vuttam ha etam majjhūpagataḥ
translated: is the consequence. But it is not their non-existence. Why not? Because one who is possessed of monkey sleep sees. For this is said:

original: mahārāja, kapiniddāpareto supinaṃ passatī”ti.
analyzed: mahā rāja kapi niddā paretaḥ supinam passati iti
translated: “Your Majesty, one who is possessed of monkey sleep sees dreams.”

original: Kapiniddāparetoti makkaṭaniddāya yutto. Yathā hi makkaṭassa niddā lahuparivattā hoti,
analyzed: kapi niddā paretaḥ ti makkaṭa niddāya yuttaḥ yathā hi makkaṭassa niddā lahu parivattā hoti
translated: “Possessed of monkey sleep”: endowed with monkey sleep. For just as a monkey’s sleep is frequently interrupted,

original: evaṃ yā niddā punappunaṃ kusalādicittavokiṇṇattā lahuviparivattā. Yassā pavattiyaṃ
analyzed: evam yā niddā punappunam kusala ādi citta vokiṇṇattā lahu viparivattā yassā
translated: so too the sleep that is frequently interrupted by profitable and unprofitable consciousnesses is called “monkey sleep.” In the occurrence of that sleep

original: punappunaṃ bhavaṅgato uttaraṇaṃ hoti, tāya yutto supinaṃ passati. Tenāyaṃ supino
analyzed: punappunam bhavaṅgataḥ uttaraṇam hoti tāya yuttaḥ supinam passati tena ayam supinaḥ
translated: one who is “possessed of monkey sleep” sees dreams. Therefore this dream

original: kusalopi hoti akusalopi abyākatopi. Tattha supinante cetiyavandanadhammassavanadhammadesanādīni🔽karontassa kusalo, pāṇātipātādīni karontassa akusalo, dvīhi antehi mutto āvajjanatadārammaṇakkhaṇe
analyzed: kusalaḥ pi hoti akusalaḥ pi abyākataḥ pi tattha cetiya vandana dhamma ssavana dhamma desanā ādīni  karontassa kusalaḥ pāṇātipāta ādīni karontassa akusalaḥ dvīhi antehi muttaḥ āvajjana tad ārammaṇa kkhaṇe
translated: It is profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. Herein, when one is dreaming and worshipping a shrine, listening to the Dhamma, teaching the Dhamma, etc., then the dream is profitable;

original: abyākatoti veditabbo. Svāyaṃ dubbalavatthukattā cetanāya paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhituṃ asamattho,
analyzed: abyākataḥ ti veditabbaḥ svāyam dubbala vatthuka ttā cetanāya paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhitum asamatthaḥ
translated: when one is dreaming that one is killing living beings, etc., then it is unprofitable; and when it is neither profitable nor unprofitable, then it is indeterminate. This should be understood as follows. The dream consciousness is unable to draw along the rebirth-linking consciousness because it is weak in strength.

original: pavatte pana aññehi kusalākusalehi upatthambhito vipākaṃ deti.🔽Maṇilakkhaṇādīsu evarūpo maṇi pasattho, evarūpo apasattho, sāmino ārogyaissariyādīnaṃ🔽hetu hoti, na hotīti evaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena maṇiādīnaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ ādisantīti attho.
analyzed: pavatte pana aññehi kusala akusalehi upatthambhitaḥ vipākam deti  maṇi lakkhaṇa ādīsu evarūpaḥ maṇi pasatthaḥ evarūpaḥ apasatthaḥ sāminaḥ ārogya aissariya ādīnam  hetu hoti na hoti iti evam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena maṇi ādīnam lakkhaṇam ādisanti iti attho
translated: But in the course of an existence it gives its result when assisted by other profitable and unprofitable kinds of consciousness.🔽In the case of the characteristics of gems, etc., a gem is commended when it has such and such colour, shape, etc., and it is not commended when it has other characteristics; and it is a source of welfare and otherwise for its owner when it has such and such characteristics and not when it has other characteristics. So the meaning is that they teach the characteristics of gems, etc., in this way.

original: Tattha āvudhalakkhaṇanti ṭhapetvā asiādīni avasesaṃ āvudhaṃ. Itthilakkhaṇādīnipi
analyzed: tattha āvudha lakkhaṇam ti ṭhapetvā asi ādīni avasesam āvudham itthi lakkhaṇa ādīni pi
translated: Herein, the characteristics of weapons are those of all weapons except swords, etc.,🔽The characteristics of women, etc., should be understood according to the prosperity or decline of the families in which they are born.

original: yamhi kule itthipurisādayo vasanti, tassa vuddhihānivaseneva veditabbāni. Ajalakkhaṇādīsu
analyzed: yamhi kule itthi purisa ādayaḥ vasanti tassa vuddhi hāni vasena iva veditabbāni aja lakkhaṇa ādīsu
translated: In the case of the characteristics of knots, etc.,

original: pana “evarūpānaṃ ajādīnaṃ maṃsaṃ khāditabbaṃ, evarūpānaṃ na khāditabba”nti ayampi viseso veditabbo.🔽Api cettha godhāya lakkhaṇe cittakammapiḷandhanādīsupi “evarūpāya godhāya sati idaṃ
analyzed: pana evarūpānam aja ādīnam maṃsam khāditabbam evarūpānam na khāditabbam ti ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbaḥ  api ca ittha godhāya lakkhaṇe citta kamma piḷandhana ādīsu pi evarūpāya godhāya sati idam
translated: But the distinction should be understood that “the flesh of such animals as the goat may be eaten, but not the flesh of such as the camel.”

original: nāma hotī”ti ayampi viseso veditabbo. Kaṇṇikālakkhaṇaṃ piḷandhanakaṇṇikāyapi gehakaṇṇikāyapi
analyzed: nāma hoti iti ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbo kaṇṇikā lakkhaṇam piḷandhana kaṇṇikāya api geha kaṇṇikāya api
translated: And here the distinction should be understood that “when there is a goat with such-and-such characteristics, then this is the name for it” even in the case of the painting of a goat, a goat-skin rug, and so on. The characteristics of the hare should be understood in the case of a hare-skin rug and a house-hare.

original: vasena veditabbaṃ. Kacchapalakkhaṇampi godhalakkhaṇasadisameva. Migalakkhaṇaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ
analyzed: vasena veditabbam kacchapa lakkhaṇam pi godha lakkhaṇa sadisam eva miga lakkhaṇam sabba saṅgāhikam
translated: The characteristics of the tortoise are similar to those of the goat. The characteristics of the deer are stated in a general way

original: sabbacatuppadānaṃ lakkhaṇavasena vuttaṃ. Evaṃ lakkhaṇapāṭhakā lakkhaṇaṃ ādisantīti
analyzed: sabba catuppadānam lakkhaṇa vasena vuttam evam lakkhaṇa pāṭhakāḥ lakkhaṇam ādisanti iti
translated: as the characteristics of all quadrupeds. So when those who recite the Characteristics are teaching the Characteristics,

original: evaṃ lakkhaṇasatthavācakā lakkhaṇaṃ ādisanti kathenti.🔽Nakkhattānīti kattikādīni aṭṭhavīsati nakkhattāni. Iminā nakkhattena gharappaveso
analyzed: evam lakkhaṇa sattha vācakāḥ lakkhaṇam ādisanti kathenti  nakkhattāni iti kattikā ādīni aṭṭhavīsati nakkhattāni iminā nakkhattena ghara ppaveso
translated: they teach them in this way.

original: kātabboti gehappavesamaṅgalaṃ kātabbaṃ. Makuṭaṃ bandhitabbanti pasādhanamaṅgalaṃ
analyzed: kātabbaḥ iti geha pavesa maṅgalam kātabbam makuṭam bandhitabban ti pasādhana maṅgalam
translated: “Constellations”: the twenty-eight constellations beginning with the Pleiades. “Under this constellation the house-entering should be done”: the house-entering ceremony should be performed. “The diadem should be bound”: the diadem-binding ceremony should be performed.

original: kātabbaṃ. Vāreyyanti “imassa dārakassa asukakulato asukanakkhattena dārikaṃ ānethā”ti
analyzed: kātabbam vāreyyanti imassa dārakassa asuka kulataḥ asuka nakkhattena dārikam ānetha ati
translated: Should be performed. Should be married: “Bring a girl from such-and-such a family, with such-and-such a constellation, for this boy.”

original: āvāhakaraṇañca “imaṃ dārikaṃ asukassa nāma dārakassa asukanakkhattena detha, evaṃ
analyzed: āvāha karaṇam ca imam dārikam asukassa nāma dārakassa asuka nakkhattena detha evam
translated: And after the betrothal ceremony, which is the agreement “Give this girl to such-and-such a boy, with such-and-such a constellation,

original: etesaṃ vuḍḍhi bhavissatī”ti vivāhakaraṇañca vatvā vāreyyasaṅkhātaṃ āvāhavivāhamaṅgalaṃ
analyzed: etesam vuḍḍhi bhavissati iti vivāha karaṇam ca vatvā vāreyya saṅkhātam āvāha vivāha maṅgalam
translated: and in this way their prosperity will be assured,” the marriage ceremony, which is called the “marriage ceremony,”

original: kātabbanti ādisanti. Bījanīhāroti bījānaṃ vappatthāya bahi nīharaṇaṃ. “Niharo”tipi
analyzed: kātabbanti ādisanti bīja nīhāraḥ iti bījānam vappa atthāya bahi nīharaṇam niharoti pi
translated: should be performed. Should be announced: the taking out of seeds for sowing. “Nīharaṇa” is a reading.

original: pāḷi. Migavākkanti idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikanāmaṃ, sabbasakuṇacatuppadānaṃ rutañāṇavaseneva
analyzed: idam sabba saṅgāhika nāmam sabba sakuṇa catu padānam ruta ñāṇa vasena iva
translated: The bird-language: this is a name for all languages, spoken by all birds and animals. It is said by one who knows the language of birds and animals.

original: vuttaṃ. Migavākkapāṭhakāti sakuntacatuppadānaṃ saddabyākaraṇakā. Migavākkaṃ ādisantīti
analyzed: vuttam miga vākka pāṭhakāḥ ti sakunta catuppadānam sadda byākaraṇakāḥ miga vākkam ādisanti iti
translated: Bird-language reciters: those who can interpret the sounds of birds and animals. Should announce the bird-language:

original: tesaṃ saddaṃ sutvā byākaronti. Rutanti saddaṃ. “Ruda”nti vā pāḷi. Vassitanti vācaṃ.🔽Gabbhakaraṇīyāti vinassamānassa gabbhassa puna avināsāya osadhadānena gabbhasaṇṭhānakārakā.
analyzed: tesam saddam sutvā byākaronti rutanti saddam rudanti vā pāḷi vassitanti vācam 🔽gabbha karaṇīyā ati vinassamānassa gabbhassa puna a vināsāya osadha dānena gabbha saṇṭhāna kārakā
translated: having heard their sounds, they interpret them. The language: the sound. “Ruda” is a reading. Should speak: should utter speech.

original: Gabbho hi vātena pāṇakehi kammunā cāti tīhi kāraṇehi vinassati. Tattha vātena vinassante
analyzed: gabbhaḥ hi vātena pāṇakehi kammunā ca ati tīhi kāraṇehi vinassati tattha vātena vinassante
translated: For the embryo is destroyed by three causes: by wind, by water creatures, and by kamma. Herein, when it is destroyed by wind,

original: vātavināsanaṃ sītalaṃ bhesajjaṃ deti. Pāṇakehi vinassante pāṇakānaṃ paṭikammaṃ karoti.
analyzed: vāta vināsanam sītalam bhesajjam deti pāṇakehi vinassante pāṇakānam paṭikammam karoti
translated: he gives cool medicine. When it is destroyed by water creatures, he acts against the water creatures.

original: Kammunā vinassante pana buddhāpi paṭibāhituṃ na sakkonti. Tasmā na taṃ idha gahitaṃ.🔽Sālākiyanti salākavejjakammaṃ. Sallakattiyanti sallakattavejjakammaṃ. Kāyatikicchanti🔽mūlabhesajjādīni yojetvā kāyatikicchavejjakammaṃ. Bhūtiyanti bhūtavejjakammaṃ. Komārabhaccanti🔽komārakavejjakammaṃ. Kuhāti vimhāpakā. Thaddhāti dārukkhandhaṃ viya thaddhasarīrā.
analyzed: kammunā vinassante pana buddhāḥ api paṭibāhitum na sakkonti tasmā na tam idha gahitam  sālākiyanti salāka vejja kammam sallakattiyanti sallakatta vejja kammam  mūla bhesajja ādīni yojetvā kāyatikiccha vejja kammam bhūtiyanti bhūta vejja kammam komārabhaccanti  komāraka vejja kammam kuhāti vimhāpakā dāru kkhandham viya thaddha sarīrā
translated: But when it is destroyed by kamma, even Buddhas cannot prevent it. That is why it is not included here.🔽‘Salākī’ is a lottery. ‘Sallakatti’ is a doctor’s practice. ‘Kāyatika’ is a doctor’s practice using roots, etc. ‘Bhūti’ is a doctor’s practice using spirits. ‘Komārabhacca’ is a doctor’s practice using children. ‘Kuhā’ are quacks. ‘Thaddhā’ are those whose bodies are stiff as if they were logs.

original: Lapāti paccayapaṭibaddhavacanakā. Siṅgiti maṇḍanapakatikā. Unnaḷāti uggatamānanaḷā.
analyzed: paccaya paṭibaddha vacanakā maṇḍana pakatikā unnaḷāti uggata mānanaḷā
translated: ‘Lapā’ are those who talk about conditions. ‘Siṅgī’ are those who have a trick of making a hissing sound. ‘Unnaḷā’ are those who have a trick of raising their arms.

original: Asamāhitāti upacārappanāsamādhivirahitā.
analyzed: asamāhitā ati upacāra ppanā samādhi virahitā
translated: ‘Asamāhitā’ are those who lack access and absorption concentration.

original: Na gaṇheyyātiādīsu uddesaggahaṇavasena na gaṇheyya. Sajjhāyavasena na uggaṇheyya.🔽Citte ṭhapanavasena na dhāreyya. Samīpaṃ katvā ṭhapanavasena na upadhāreyya. Upaparikkhāvasena🔽na upalakkheyya. Aññesaṃ vācanavasena nappayojeyya.
analyzed: na gaṇheyya ati ādīsu uddesa ggahaṇa vasena na gaṇheyya sajjhāya vasena na uggaṇheyya  citte ṭhapana vasena na dhāreyya samīpam katvā ṭhapana vasena na upadhāreyya upaparikkhā vasena  na upalakkheyya aññesam vācana vasena na ppayojeyya
translated: As regards the words he should not learn, etc., he should not learn by way of the recitation of the text. He should not learn by way of the recitation of the text.

original: 163. Pesuṇiyanti pesuññaṃ. Sesaniddeso ca vuttatthoyeva.🔽164. Kayavikkayeti pañcahi sahadhammikehi saddhiṃ vañcanavasena vā udayapatthanāvasena🔽vā na tiṭṭheyya. Upavādaṃ bhikkhu na kareyyāti upavādakare kilese anibbattento attani🔽parehi samaṇabrāhmaṇehi upavādaṃ na janeyya. Gāme ca nābhisajjeyyāti gāme ca gihisaṃsaggādīhi🔽nābhisajjeyya. Lābhakamyā janaṃ na lapayeyyāti lābhakāmatāya janaṃ na lapayeyya.
analyzed: pesuṇiyanti pesuññam sesa niddeso ca vutta tthaḥ yā eva 🔽kaya vikkaya iti pañcahi sahadhammikehi saddhim vañcana vasena vā udaya patthanā vasena 🔽vā na tiṭṭheyya upavādam bhikkhu na kareyya ati upavāda kare kilese a nibbattento attani 🔽parehi samaṇa brāhmaṇehi upavādam na janeyya gāme ca na abhisajjeyya ati gāme ca gihi saṃsagga ādīhi 🔽na abhisajjeyya lābha kamyā janam na lapayeyya ati lābha kāma tāya janam na lapayeyya
translated: He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind by way of fixing the mind. He should not bear in mind

original: Ye kayavikkayā vinaye paṭikkhittāti ye dānapaṭiggahaṇavasena kayavikkayasikkhāpade🔽na vaṭṭatīti paṭikkhittā, idhādhippetaṃ kayavikkayaṃ dassetuṃ “pañcannaṃ saddhiṃ
analyzed: ye kaya vikkayāḥ vinaye paṭikkhittā ati ye dāna paṭiggahaṇa vasena kaya vikkaya sikkhāpade  na vaṭṭati iti paṭikkhittā idha adhippetam kaya vikkayam dassetum pañcannam saddhim
translated: ‘Trading’ is what is prohibited in the training rule on giving and receiving,

original: pattaṃ vā cīvaraṃ vā”tiādimāha. Tattha pañcannaṃ saddhinti pañcahi sahadhammikehi
analyzed: pattam vā cīvaram vā iti ādim āha tattha pañcannam saddhinti pañcahi sahadhammikehi
translated: which is not allowable. In order to show the trading that is intended here, he says ‘with the five together with the bowl or the robe.’ Herein, ‘with the five together’ means together with the five who are of the same religion.

original: saha. Pañca sahadhammikā nāma bhikkhubhikkhunīsikkhamānasāmaṇerasāmaṇeriyo. Vañcaniyaṃ🔽vāti paṭirūpakaṃ dassetvā vañcaniyaṃ vā. Udayaṃ vā patthayantoti vuḍḍhiṃ patthento
analyzed: saha pañca sahadhammikāḥ nāma bhikkhu bhikkhunī sikkhamāna sāmaṇera sāmaṇeriyaḥ vañcaniyam  vā ti paṭirūpakam dassetvā vañcaniyam vā udayam vā patthayantaḥ ti vuḍḍhim patthentaḥ
translated: The five who are of the same religion are monks, nuns, female trainees, male novices, and female novices. ‘Deceiving’ means deceiving by showing something else.

original: vā. Parivattetīti parivattanaṃ karoti.🔽Iddhimantoti ijjhanapabhāvavanto. Dibbacakkhukāti dibbasadisañāṇacakkhukā. Atha vā
analyzed: vā parivatteti iti parivattanam karoti  iddhimanto ti dibba sadisa ñāṇa cakkhukāḥ atha vā
