translated: ‘Seeking a profit’ means seeking an increase. ‘Exchanges’ means makes an exchange.🔽‘Those who have supernormal power’ means those who have the power of success. ‘Those with the divine eye’ means those who have the knowledge of the divine eye. Or alternatively,

original: dibbavihārasannissayena laddhañāṇacakkhukā. Paracittavidunoti attano cittena paresaṃ
analyzed: dibba vihāra sannissayena laddha ñāṇa cakkhukā attano cittena paresam
translated: those who have the knowledge of the divine eye by depending on the divine life. ‘Those who know the minds of others’ means those who know the minds of others with their own mind.

original: cittajānanakā. Te dūratopi passantīti ekayojanatopi yojanasatatopi yojanasahassatopi
analyzed: citta jānanakā te dūratas pi passanti iti eka yojanataḥ pi yojana satataḥ pi yojana sahassataḥ pi
translated: They know the mind of others. They see from afar: they see and know from a distance of a league, a hundred leagues, a thousand leagues, a hundred thousand leagues, from one world-system to another.

original: yojanasatasahassatopi cakkavāḷatopi dvetīṇicattāripañcadasavīsaticattālīsasahassatopi
analyzed: yojana sata sahassataḥ pi cakkavāḷataḥ pi dve tīṇi cattāri pañcadasa vīsati cattālīsa sahassataḥ pi
translated: They see and know from a distance of two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, forty thousand world-systems, and even more.

original: tato atirekatopi cakkavāḷato passanti dakkhanti. Āsannāpi na dissantīti samīpe ṭhitāpi
analyzed: tatas atirekataḥ pi cakkavāḷato passanti dakkhanti āsannā api na dissanti iti samīpe ṭhitā api
translated: They do not see what is near: they do not see or know what is near,

original: nisinnāpi na paññāyanti. Cetasāpi cittaṃ pajānantīti attano cittenāpi paresaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: nisinnāḥ api na paññāyanti cetasā api cittam pajānanti iti attano cittena api paresam cittam
translated: whether standing or sitting. They know the mind with the mind: they know the mind of others with their own mind.

original: pajānanti. Devatāpi kho santi iddhimantiniyoti devatāpi evaṃ saṃvijjanti ijjhanapabhāvavantiniyo.
analyzed: pajānanti devatāḥ api kho santi iddhimantiniyaḥ uti devatāḥ api evam saṃvijjanti
translated: There are also deities who have psychic power: there are also deities who have the psychic power of success.🔽They know the minds of others: they know the minds of others.

original: Paracittaviduniyoti paresaṃ cittaṃ jānantiyo. Oḷārikehi vā kilesehīti kāyaduccaritādikehi
analyzed: para citta viduniyaḥ ti oḷārikehi vā kilesehi iti kāya duccarita ādikehi
translated: With gross defilements: with gross bodily misconduct, etc.🔽With medium defilements: with medium sensual thoughts, etc.

original: vā upatāpehi. Majjhimehi vāti kāmavitakkādikehi vā. Sukhumehi vāti ñātivitakkādikehi
analyzed: vā upatāpehi majjhimehi vā ati kāma vitakka ādikehi vā sukhumehi vā ati ñāti vitakka ādikehi
translated: With subtle defilements: with subtle thoughts about relatives, etc.

original: vā. Kāyaduccaritādayo kammapathavasena, kāmavitakkādayo vaṭṭamūlakakilesavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: vā kāya duccarita ādayaḥ kamma patha vasena kāma vitakka ādayaḥ vaṭṭa mūlaka kilesa vasena veditabbā
translated: and so on. The bodily misconduct, etc., should be understood as the courses of kamma; the sensual, malevolent, and cruel thoughts as the defilements that are the roots of the round.

original: Ñātivitakkādīsu “mayhaṃ ñātayo sukhajīvino sampattiyuttā”ti evaṃ pañcakāmaguṇasannissitena🔽gehasannissitapemena ñātake ārabbha uppannavitakko ñātivitakko. “Mayhaṃ ñātayo khayaṃ
analyzed: ñāti vitakka ādīsu mayham ñātayo sukha jīvino sampatti yuttāḥ ti evam pañca kāmaguṇa sannissitena  geha sannissita pemena ñātake ārabbha uppanna vitakkaḥ ñāti vitakkaḥ mayham ñātayaḥ khayam
translated: The thought “My relatives are happy, prosperous, and successful” is the thought of relatives that occurs in one who is attached to the five strands of sense pleasure and who is devoted to the household life.

original: gatā vayaṃ gatā saddhā pasannā”ti evaṃ pavatto pana ñātivitakko nāma na hoti.
analyzed: gatāḥ vayam gatā saddhā pasannā iti evam pavattaḥ pana ñāti vitakkaḥ nāma na hoti
translated: But the thought that occurs thus, “My relatives have passed away, have gone to destruction, have disappeared,” is not called the thought of relatives.

original: “Amhākaṃ janapado subhikkho sampannasasso”ti tuṭṭhamānasassa gehassitapemavasena🔽uppannavitakko janapadavitakko. “Amhākaṃ janapade manussā saddhā pasannā khayaṃ gatā
analyzed: amhākam janapadaḥ subhikkhaḥ sampanna sassaḥ ti tuṭṭha mānasassa geha ssita pema vasena  uppanna vitakkaḥ janapada vitakkaḥ amhākam janapade manussā saddhā pasannā khayam gatā
translated: The thought “Our country is prosperous, has plenty of grass, and is successful” is the thought of country that occurs in one who is attached to the household life and who is devoted to the household life.

original: vayaṃ gatā”ti evaṃ pavatto pana janapadavitakko nāma na hoti.
analyzed: vayam gatā iti evam pavattaḥ pana janapada vitakkaḥ nāma na hoti
translated: But the thought that occurs thus, “In our country people have faith and confidence, have passed away, have gone to destruction, have disappeared,” is not called the thought of country.

original: Amarattāya vitakko, amaro vā vitakkoti amaravitakko. Tattha ukkuṭikappadhānādīhi
analyzed: amara attāya vitakkaḥ amaraḥ vā vitakkoti amaravitakko tattha ukkuṭika ppadhāna ādīhi
translated: The thought of immortality is either the thought of immortality or the thought about immortality. Herein, the thought of immortality is the thought that occurs thus:

original: dukkhe nijiṇṇe samparāye attā sukhī hoti. Amaroti dukkarakārikaṃ karontassa tāya
analyzed: dukkhe nijiṇṇe samparāye attā sukhī hoti dukkara kārikam karontassa tāya
translated: and when suffering has been discarded, the self becomes happy in the next world. ‘Immortal’ means that one who does the difficult task, by that

original: dukkarakārikāya paṭisaṃyutto vitakko amarattāya vitakko nāma. Diṭṭhigatiko pana “sassataṃ🔽vadesī”tiādīni puṭṭho “evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi
analyzed: dukkara kārikāya paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ amarattāya vitakko nāma diṭṭhi gatiko pana sassatam  vadesi itiādīni puṭṭhaḥ evam ipi me no tathā atipi me no aññathā atipi me no no tipi
translated: and when suffering is worn out, he is happy in the life to come. The “perplexity” called “immortality” is the thinking associated with the performance of that difficult practice.

original: me no, no notipi me no”ti vikkhepaṃ āpajjati, tassa so diṭṭhigatapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko,🔽yathā amaro nāma maccho udake gahetvā māretuṃ na sakkā, ito cito ca dhāvati gāhaṃ
analyzed: me no no no ti pi me no ti vikkhepam āpajjati tassa saḥ diṭṭhigata paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakko  yathā amaraḥ nāma macchaḥ udake gahetvā māretum na sakkā itas citas ca dhāvati gāham
translated: But the view-attainer, when asked, “Do you declare the eternal?” etc., falls into perplexity, saying, “I do not say ‘It is so,’ I do not say ‘It is not so,’ I do not say ‘It is otherwise,’ I do not say ‘It is not’ I do not say ‘It is not not’” .🔽His thinking associated with that view-attainer is called “perplexity.”

original: na gacchati, evameva ekasmiṃ pakkhe asaṇṭhahanato na maratīti amaro nāma hoti, taṃ
analyzed: na gacchati evam eva ekasmin pakkhe a saṇṭhahanataḥ na marati iti amaraḥ nāma hoti tam
translated: Just as a fish called “immortal” cannot be caught and killed in water, it swims here and there and does not come to a catch, so too, because it does not settle down on one side, it does not die, and so it is called “immortal.”

original: duvidhampi ekato katvā “amaravitakko”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: duvidham pi ekatas katvā amara vitakkaḥ ti vuttam
translated: Both these kinds of thinking are called “perplexity” when taken together.

original: Parānuddayatāpaṭisaññuttoti anuddayatāpaṭirūpakena gehassitapemena paṭisaṃyutto.
analyzed: para anuddaya tā paṭisaññuttaḥ ti anuddaya tā paṭirūpakena geha sita pemena paṭisaṃyuttaḥ
translated: Associated with the perception of non-ill-will: associated with the affection of the kind called “non-ill-will.”

original: Upaṭṭhākesu nandakesu socantesu ca tehi saddhiṃ diguṇaṃ nandati diguṇaṃ socati, tesu
analyzed: upaṭṭhākesu nandakesu socantesu ca tehi saddhim diguṇam nandati diguṇam socati tesu
translated: He rejoices twice as much as they do when they are pleased, and he sorrows twice as much as they do when they are displeased.

original: sukhitesu diguṇaṃ sukhito hoti, dukkhitesu diguṇaṃ dukkhito hoti. Uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu
analyzed: sukhitesu diguṇam sukhitaḥ hoti dukkhitesu diguṇam dukkhitaḥ hoti uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu
translated: When they are happy he is happy, and when they are miserable he is miserable.🔽When there is work to be done, he takes it upon himself.

original: attanā voyogaṃ āpajjati. Tāni tāni kiccāni sādhento paññattiṃ vītikkamati, sallekhaṃ🔽kopeti. Yo tasmiṃ saṃsaṭṭhavihāre tasmiṃ vā voyogāpajjane gehassito vitakko, ayaṃ
analyzed: attanā voyogam āpajjati tāni tāni kiccāni sādhentaḥ paññattim vītikkamati sallekham  kopeti yaḥ tasmin saṃsaṭṭha vihāre tasmin vā voyoga āpajjane geha sitaḥ vitakkaḥ ayam
translated: In getting things done he transgresses the rules of training and neglects seclusion.

original: parānuddayatāpaṭisaññutto vitakko nāma.
analyzed: vitakkaḥ nāma
translated: The thought of living in close association with them or of taking on the work is called “thought associated with non-affliction.”

original: Lābhasakkārasilokapaṭisaññuttoti cīvarādilābhena ceva sakkārena ca kittisaddena ca🔽saddhiṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena paṭisaññutto. Anavaññattipaṭisaññuttoti “aho vata maṃ
analyzed: lābha sakkāra siloka paṭisaññuttaḥ ti cīvara ādi lābhena ca iva sakkārena ca kitti saddena ca  saddhim ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena paṭisaññuttaḥ anavaññatti paṭisaññuttaḥ ti aho vata mama
translated: “Associated with gain, honour, and fame”: associated with the objects consisting of gain, etc.,

original: pare na avajāneyyuṃ, na sodhetvā visodhetvā katheyyu”nti evaṃ anavaññātabhāvapatthanāya
analyzed: pare na avajāneyyum na sodhetvā visodhetvā katheyyun ti evam an avaññāta bhāva patthanāya
translated: by making them the object. “Associated with non-disparagement”: the wish for non-disparagement, thinking, “Oh, that others might not disparage me! That they might not speak of me after having investigated and analyzed!”

original: saddhiṃ uppajjanakavitakko. So tasmiṃ “mā maṃ pare avajāniṃsū”ti uppanne vitakke
analyzed: saddhim uppajjanaka vitakkaḥ saḥ tasmin mā mama pare avajāniṃsu iti uppanne vitakke
translated: and the thought that arises together with it. The thought that arises in one who thinks “Let no one despise me”

original: pañcakāmaguṇasaṅkhātagehanissito hutvā uppannavitakko anavaññattipaṭisaññutto vitakko.🔽Tatra tatra sajjatīti tesu tesu ārammaṇesu laggati. Tatra tatra gaṇhātīti vuttappakāraṃ
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa saṅkhāta geha nissitaḥ hutvā uppanna vitakkaḥ anavaññatti paṭisaññuttaḥ vitakko  tatra tatra sajjati iti tesu tesu ārammaṇesu laggati tatra tatra gaṇhāti iti vutta ppakāram
translated: and who is attached to the household life with its five cords of sensual pleasure is called “thought associated with desire for non-disparagement.”🔽“He is attached here and there”: he is stuck here and there on the objects. “He takes hold here and there”: he enters into the objects of the kinds already mentioned.

original: ārammaṇaṃ pavisati. Bajjhatīti tehi tehi ārammaṇehi saddhiṃ bajjhati ekībhavati.
analyzed: ārammaṇam pavisati bajjhati iti tehi tehi ārammaṇehi saddhim bajjhati ekībhavati
translated: “He is bound here and there”: he is bound together with the objects here and there, he becomes one with them.

original: Anayabyasananti tattha tattha avaḍḍhiṃ vināsaṃ. Āpajjatīti pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: anaya byasananti tattha tattha avaḍḍhim vināsam āpajjati iti pāpuṇāti
translated: “He comes to ruin and downfall”: he comes to non-prosperity and destruction. “He comes to grief”: he comes to suffering.

original: Āmisacakkhukassāti cīvarādiāmisalolassa. Lokadhammagarukassāti lokuttaradhammaṃ muñcitvā
analyzed: āmisa cakkhukassa ati cīvara ādi āmisa lolassa loka dhamma garukassa ati lokuttara dhammam muñcitvā
translated: “The one who is greedy for material things”: the one who is lustful for material things such as robes. “The one who is scrupulous about worldly things”: the one who, having abandoned the supramundane things,

original: rūpādilokadhammameva garuṃ katvā carantassa. Ālapanāti vihāraṃ āgatamanusse disvā
analyzed: rūpa ādi loka dhammam eva garum katvā carantassa vihāram āgata manusse disvā
translated: goes about considering only the worldly things such as form, etc., as important. “He chats”: when he sees people coming to the monastery,

original: “kimatthāya bhonto āgatā, kiṃ bhikkhū nimantetuṃ, yadi evaṃ gacchatha, ahaṃ pacchato
analyzed: kim atthāya bhontaḥ āgatāḥ kim bhikkhū nimantetum yadi evam gacchatha aham pacchatas
translated: he says: “What is the purpose of your coming, sirs? Are you inviting the bhikkhus? If so, go along. I will come later.

original: bhikkhū gahetvā āgacchāmī”ti evaṃ āditova lapanā. Atha vā attānaṃ upanetvā “ahaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhū gahetvā āgacchāmi iti evam āditas va lapanā atha vā attānam upanetvā aham
translated: “I’ll come and get the monks.” Or else, having approached, “I’ll come and get you.

original: tisso, mayi rājā pasanno, mayi asuko ca asuko ca rājamahāmatto pasanno”ti evaṃ attupanāyikā
analyzed: tissaḥ mayi rājā pasannaḥ mayi asuko ca asukaḥ ca rāja mahāmatto pasannaḥ iti evam attupanāyikā
translated: “I’ll come and get the monks.” Or else, after introducing himself, he speaks thus: “I am a lay follower of so-and-so monastery. The king is pleased with me. So-and-so and so-and-so, royal ministers, are pleased with me.” This is called “self-praise.”

original: lapanāti ālapanā. Lapanāti puṭṭhassa sato vuttappakārameva lapanaṃ.
analyzed: lapanā ati ālapanā lapanā ati puṭṭhassa sataḥ vutta ppakāram eva lapanam
translated: “Flattery” is the act of speaking in the way already described to one who asks.

original: Sallapanāti gahapatikānaṃ ukkaṇṭhane bhītassa okāsaṃ datvā suṭṭhu lapanā. Ullapanāti
analyzed: sallapanā ati gahapatikānam ukkaṇṭhane bhītassa okāsam da tvā suṭṭhu lapanā ullapanā ati
translated: “Persuasion” is the act of speaking well, giving an opportunity to householders who are dissatisfied. “Praise” is the act of speaking with reference to the future thus:

original: “mahākuṭumbiko mahānāviko mahādānapatī”ti evaṃ uddhaṃ katvā lapanā. Samullapanāti🔽sabbato bhāgena uddhaṃ katvā lapanā. Unnahanāti “upāsakā pubbe īdise kāle navadānaṃ
analyzed: mahā kuṭumbikaḥ mahā nāvikaḥ mahā dānapatiḥ iti evam katvā lapanā samullapanā ati  sabbatas bhāgena uddham katvā upāsakā pubbe īdise kāle nava dānam
translated: “You are a great family, a great clan, a great donor.” “Extolling” is the act of speaking with reference to all sides thus:

original: detha, idāni kiṃ na dethā”ti evaṃ yāva “dassāma bhante, okāsaṃ na labhāmā”tiādīni
analyzed: detha idāni kim na detha ati evam yāva dassāma bhante okāsam na labhāma ati ādīni
translated: “You are a great family, a great clan, a great donor.” “Encouraging” is the act of encouraging further and further thus: “Lay followers, in the past you gave fresh foods at this time. Why do you not do so now?” until they say, “We will give, venerable sir, but we do not get the opportunity.”

original: vadanti, tāva uddhaṃ uddhaṃ nahanā, veṭhanāti vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā ucchuhatthaṃ disvā
analyzed: vadanti tāva uddham uddham nahanā veṭhanā iti vuttam hoti atha vā ucchu hattham disvā
translated: Or else, seeing a hand with a ring on it, he says, “Your son is well, I suppose?”

original: “kuto ābhataṃ upāsakā”ti pucchati. Ucchukhettato bhanteti. Kiṃ tattha ucchu madhuranti.
analyzed: kutas ābhatam upāsakā iti pucchati bhante iti kim tattha ucchu madhuranti
translated: “Where did you get it, lay follower?” “From a sugar-cane field, venerable sir.” “Is the sugar-cane sweet there?”

original: Khāditvā bhante jānitabbanti. Na upāsakā “bhikkhussa ucchuṃ dethā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: khāditvā bhante jānitabbanti na upāsakāḥ bhikkhussa ucchum detha ati vattum vaṭṭati iti
translated: “You will know when you have tasted it, venerable sir.” It is not allowable to say to a lay follower, “Give sugar-cane to the bhikkhu.”

original: yā evarūpā nibbeṭhentassapi niveṭhanakakathā, sā unnahanā. Sabbato bhāgena punappunaṃ🔽unnahanā samunnahanā. Ukkācanāti “etaṃ kulaṃ maṃyeva jānāti, sace ettha deyyadhammo
analyzed: yā evarūpā nibbeṭhentassa api niveṭhanaka kathā sā unnahanā sabbatas bhāgena punappunam  unnahanā samunnahanā etam kulam maṃyā iva jānāti sace ettha deyya dhammo
translated: When there is talk of this kind to one who is trying to dissuade him, this is hinting. Repeatedly and in various ways is importuning.

original: uppajjati, mayhaṃyeva detī”ti evaṃ ukkhipitvā kācanā ukkācanā, uddīpanāti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Sabbato bhāgena pana punappunaṃ ukkācanā samukkācanā. Anuppiyabhāṇitāti paccayavasena
analyzed: uppajjati mayham yeva deti iti evam ukkhipitvā kācanā ukkācanā uddīpanā iti vuttam  hoti sabbatas bhāgena pana punappunam ukkācanā samukkācanā anuppiya bhāṇitā ati paccaya vasena
translated: Repeatedly and in various ways importuning is importuning again and again by all sorts of approaches. Suggesting is saying, “This family thinks it knows me well. If there is anything to be given, it will give it to me.”🔽Repeatedly and in various ways suggesting is suggesting again and again by all sorts of approaches. Flattery is speaking words of endearment again and again by way of a requisite.

original: punappunaṃ piyavacanabhaṇanā. Saṇhavācatāti muduvacanatā. Sakhilavācatāti mandapamāṇayuttavacanatā
analyzed: punappunam piya vacana bhaṇanā saṇha vāca tā ati mudu vacana tā sa khila vāca tā ati manda pamāṇa yutta vacana tā
translated: Soft words is mildness of speech. Words of familiar kind is speech that is suitable to the occasion and to the person addressed.

original: sithilavacanatā vā. Sithilavācatāti allīyavacanatā. Apharusavācatāti madhuravacanatā.
analyzed: sithila vacana tā vā sithila vāca tā ati allīya vacana tā apharusa vāca tā ati madhura vacana tā
translated: Or else, slackness of speech is the state of being slack in speech. Smoothness of speech is the state of being sweet-voiced.

original: Purāṇaṃ mātāpettikanti pure uppannaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ santakaṃ. Antarahitanti paṭicchannaṃ
analyzed: purāṇam mātāpettikam ti pure uppannam mātā pitūnam santakam antarahitam ti paṭicchannam
translated: The parents’ property that has been long in the family: the property of the parents that has been in the family for a long time. Hidden away: concealed,

original: tirobhūtaṃ. Ñāyāmīti pākaṭo homi. Asukassa kulūpakoti asukassa amaccassa kulapayirupāsako.
analyzed: tirobhūtam ñāyāmi iti pākaṭaḥ homi asukassa kulūpako ti asukassa amaccassa
translated: covered up. I’ll be known: I’ll be famous. I’m a supporter of such a family: I’m a supporter of such a minister’s family.

original: Asukāyāti asukāya upāsikāya. Maṃ ujjhitvāti maṃ vissajjitvā.
analyzed: asukāya ati asukāya upāsikāya mam ujjhitvā ati mam vissajjitvā
translated: Such a woman: such a laywoman. Having abandoned me: having rejected me.

original: 165. Payuttanti cīvarādīhi sampayuttaṃ, tadatthaṃ vā payojitaṃ. Imissā gāthāya niddeso sabbo heṭṭhā vuttanayova.
analyzed: payuttam ti cīvara ādīhi sampayuttam tad attham vā payojitam imissā gāthāya niddesaḥ sabbaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayaḥ eva
translated: Connected: connected with robes, etc., or employed for that purpose. The whole of the commentary on this verse is in the way already stated.

original: 166. Mosavajje na niyyethāti musāvāde na niyyetha.Jīvitenāti jīvikāya.
analyzed: mosa vajje na niyyetha ati musāvāde na niyyetha jīvitena ati jīvikāya
translated: He should not be led into false speech: he should not be led into lying. For the sake of life: for the sake of his livelihood.

original: Saṭhoti asantaguṇadīpanato na sammā bhāsitā. Sabbato bhāgena saṭho parisaṭho. Yaṃ
analyzed: saṭho ti asanta guṇa dīpanataḥ na sammā bhāsitā sabbatas bhāgena saṭhaḥ parisaṭhaḥ yaṃ
translated: Crafty: not speaking properly because of showing off non-existent good qualities. All-round crafty: crafty in every way. What

original: tatthāti yaṃ tasmiṃ puggale. Saṭhanti asantaguṇadīpanaṃ kerāṭiyaṃ. Saṭhatāti saṭhākāro.
analyzed: tattha ati yam tasmin puggale saṭhanti asanta guṇa dīpanam kerāṭiyam saṭhatā ati saṭhākāraḥ
translated: there: what there is in that person. Crafty: the craft of showing off non-existent good qualities. Craftily: in a crafty way.

original: Sāṭheyyanti saṭhabhāvo. Kakkaratāti padumanāḷassa viya aparāmasanakkhamo pharusabhāvo.
analyzed: sāṭheyyanti saṭha bhāvaḥ kakkaratā ati paduma nāḷassa viya a parāmasana khamaḥ pharusa bhāvo
translated: Sāṭheyyanti saṭhabhāvo, kakkaratāti padumanāḷassa viya aparāmasanakkhamo pharusabhāvo.

original: Kakkariyantipi tasseva vevacanaṃ. Parikkhattatā pārikkhattiyanti padadvayena nikhaṇitvā
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam parikkhatta tā pārikkhattiyanti pada dvayena nikhaṇitvā
translated: Kakkariyantipi tasseva vevacanaṃ. Parikkhattatā pārikkhattiyanti padadvayena nikhaṇitvā

original: ṭhapitaṃ viya daḷhakerāṭiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Keci pana “kakkaratāti sambhāvayitvā vacanaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhapitam viya daḷha kerāṭiyam vuttam keci pana sambhāvayitvā vacanam
translated: ṭhapitaṃ viya daḷhakerāṭiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Keci pana “kakkaratāti sambhāvayitvā vacanaṃ.

original: Kakkariyanti sambhāvayitvā vacanabhāvo. Parikkhattatāti alaṅkaraṇākāro. Pārikkhattiyanti
analyzed: sambhāvayitvā vacana bhāvaḥ alaṅkaraṇa ākāraḥ
translated: Kakkariyanti sambhāvayitvā vacanabhāvo. Parikkhattatāti alaṅkaraṇākāro. Pārikkhattiyanti

original: alaṅkaraṇabhāvo”ti atthaṃ vaṇṇayanti. Idaṃ vuccatīti idaṃ attano avijjamānaguṇappakāsanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkaraṇa bhāvaḥ ti attham vaṇṇayanti idam vuccati iti idam attanaḥ a vijjamāna guṇa pakāsana lakkhaṇam
translated: alaṅkaraṇabhāvo”ti atthaṃ vaṇṇayanti. Idaṃ vuccatīti idaṃ attano avijjamānaguṇappakāsanalakkhaṇaṃ

original: sāṭheyyaṃ nāma vuccati. Yena samannāgatassa puggalassa kucchiṃ vā piṭṭhiṃ vā jānituṃ na sakkā.
analyzed: sāṭheyyam nāma vuccati yena samannāgatassa puggalassa kucchim vā piṭṭhim vā jānitum na sakkā
translated: sāṭheyyaṃ nāma vuccati. Yena samannāgatassa puggalassa kucchiṃ vā piṭṭhiṃ vā jānituṃ na sakkā.

original: “Vāmena sūkaro hoti, dakkhiṇena ajāmigo;
analyzed: vāmena sūkaraḥ hoti dakkhiṇena ajāmigo
translated: “Vāmena sūkaro hoti, dakkhiṇena ajāmigo;

original: Sarena nelako hoti, visāṇena jaraggavo”ti. –
analyzed: sarena nelakaḥ hoti visāṇena jaraggavaḥ ti
translated: Sarena nelako hoti, visāṇena jaraggavo”ti. –

original: Evaṃ vuttayakkhasūkarasadiso hoti. Atimaññatīti atikkamitvā maññati.
analyzed: evam vutta yakkha sūkara sadisaḥ hoti atimaññati iti atikkamitvā maññati
translated: Evaṃ vuttayakkhasūkarasadiso hoti. Atimaññatīti atikkamitvā maññati.

original: Kiṃ panāyaṃ bahulājīvoti ayaṃ pana puggalo ko nāma bahulājīvako. Sabbaṃ saṃbhakkhetīti
analyzed: kim pana ayam bahulājīvaḥ ti ayam pana puggalo kaḥ nāma bahulājīvako sabbam saṃbhakkheti iti
translated: But what is this “living by dependence”? — This person is called a “living by dependence”.

original: laddhaṃ sabbaṃ khādati. Appapuññoti mandapuñño. Appesakkhoti parivāravirahito. Paññāsampannoti
analyzed: laddham sabbam khādati appa puññaḥ ti manda puññaḥ appesakkho ti parivāra virahito paññā sampanno ti
translated: “He eats all that he gets”: he eats all that he gets. “He has little merit”: he has little merit. “He has little influence”: he is devoid of a following. “He is endowed with wisdom”:

original: sampannapañño paripuṇṇapañño. Pañhaṃ vissajjetīti pañhaṃ katheti byākaroti.
analyzed: sampanna paññaḥ paripuṇṇa paññaḥ pañham vissajjeti iti pañham kathā iti byākaroti
translated: he is endowed with wisdom, he is possessed of wisdom. “He answers a question”: he answers a question, he explains it.🔽“Having heard, he is angry, and speaks much that is unpleasant

original: 167. Sutvā rusito bahuṃ vācaṃ, samaṇānaṃ vā puthujanānanti rusito ghaṭṭito parehi
analyzed: sutvā rusitaḥ bahum vācam samaṇānam vā rusitaḥ ghaṭṭitaḥ parehi
translated: to ascetics or to other people.” Having heard, he is angry, he is struck by others.

original: tesaṃ samaṇānaṃ vā khattiyādibhedānaṃ vā aññesaṃ puthujanānaṃ bahumpi aniṭṭhaṃ vācaṃ
analyzed: tesam samaṇānam vā khattiya ādi bhedānam vā aññesam puthu janānam bahum pi aniṭṭham vācam
translated: Having heard much that is unpleasant spoken by those ascetics or by other people of various kinds,

original: sutvā. Na paṭivajjāti na paṭivadeyya. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Na hi santo paṭiseniṃ karonti.
analyzed: sutvā na paṭivajjāti na paṭivadeyya kim kāraṇā na hi santaḥ paṭisenim karonti
translated: he does not return it. Why not? Because the good do not return a blow.

original: Kakkhaḷenāti dāruṇena. Santoti nibbutakilesā. Paṭiseninti paṭisattuṃ. Paṭimallanti🔽paṭiyodhaṃ. Paṭikaṇṭakanti paṭiveriṃ. Paṭipakkhanti kilesapaṭipakkhaṃ, kilesavasena
analyzed: kakkhaḷena ati dāruṇena santaḥ ti nibbuta kilesā paṭiseninti paṭisattum paṭimallanti  paṭiyodham paṭikaṇṭakanti paṭiverim paṭipakkhanti kilesa paṭipakkham kilesa vasena
translated: “With a harsh word”: with a cruel word. “The good”: those whose defilements are extinguished. “A blow”: a return blow. “A counter-blow”:🔽a counter-attack. “A foe”: an enemy. “An opponent”: an opponent of the defilements. The meaning is: they do not take up a position

original: saṅgaṃ na karontīti attho.
analyzed: saṅgam na karonti iti
translated: on the side of the defilements.

original: 168. Etañca dhammamaññāyāti sabbametaṃ yathāvuttaṃ dhammaṃ ñatvā. Vicinanti vicinanto. Santīti nibbutiṃ ñatvāti nibbutiṃ rāgādīnaṃ santīti ñatvā.
analyzed: etat ca dhammam aññāya ati sabbam etam yathā vuttam dhammam ñatvā vicinanti vicinantaḥ santi iti nibbutim ñatvā ati nibbutim rāga ādīnam santi iti ñatvā
translated: ‘And having understood this Dhamma’ means having understood all this Dhamma as stated. ‘He discerns, discerning’ means ‘he discerns, discerning the peaceful’. ‘Having understood the peaceful as the peaceful’ means having understood the peaceful as the peaceful, i.e. the extinction of lust, etc.

original: Samañcāti kāyasucaritādiṃ. Visamañcāti kāyaduccaritādiṃ. Pathañcāti dasakusalakammapathaṃ.
analyzed: samañca ati kāya su carita ādim visamañca ati kāya duccarita ādim pathañca ati dasa kusala kamma patham
translated: ‘The right’ means right bodily conduct, etc. ‘The wrong’ means wrong bodily conduct, etc. ‘The path’ means the tenfold path of good conduct.

original: Vipathañcāti dasaakusalakammapathaṃ. Sāvajjañcāti akusalañca. Anavajjañcāti kusalañca.
analyzed: vipatham ca ati dasa akusala kamma patham sāvajjam ca ati akusalam ca anavajjam ca ati kusalam ca
translated: ‘The wrong path’ means the tenfold path of misconduct. ‘The blameworthy’ means the unwholesome. ‘The blameless’ means the wholesome.

original: Hīnapaṇītakaṇhasukkaviññūgarahitaviññūpasatthanti idampi kusalākusalameva. Tattha
analyzed: hīna paṇīta kaṇha sukka viññūga rahita viññū pasatthanti idam pi kusala akusalam eva tattha
translated: ‘The inferior and the superior, the black and the white, the disparaging and the non-disparaging’ also refer to the unwholesome and the wholesome. Herein,

original: kāyasucaritādi samakaraṇato samaṃ. Kāyaduccaritādi visamakaraṇato visamaṃ. Dasakusalakammapathā
analyzed: kāya su carita ādi sama karaṇataḥ samam kāya duccarita ādi visama karaṇataḥ visamam dasa kusala kamma pathā
translated: right bodily conduct, etc., are right because they are done rightly. Wrong bodily conduct, etc., are wrong because they are done wrongly. The tenfold path of good conduct

original: sugatigamanapathattā pathaṃ. Dasaakusalakammapathā sugatigamanapaṭipakkhattā apāyagamanapathattā
analyzed: sugati gamana patha ttā patham dasa akusala kamma pathā sugati gamana paṭipakkha ttā apāya gamana patha ttā
translated: is the path because it is the path to a good destination. The tenfold path of misconduct is the wrong path because it is the opposite of the path to a good destination and because it is the path to an evil destination.

original: vipathaṃ. Akusalaṃ sadosattā sāvajjaṃ. Kusalaṃ niddosattā anavajjaṃ. Tathā mohena
analyzed: vipatham akusalam sa dosa ttā sāvajjam kusalam niddosa ttā anavajjam tathā mohena
translated: The unwholesome is blameworthy because it is associated with blame. The wholesome is blameless because it is free from blame. Likewise, the unwholesome is dark because it is associated with delusion.

original: vā dosamohena vā lobhamohena vā sampayuttattā hīnaṃ. Alobhaadosaamohasampayuttattā
analyzed: vā dosa mohena vā lobha mohena vā sampayutta ttā hīnam alobha a dosa a moha sampayutta ttā
translated: superior because of being associated with non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion.

original: paṇītaṃ. Kaṇhavipākattā kaṇhaṃ. Sukkavipākattā sukkaṃ. Buddhādīhi viññūhi garahitattā
analyzed: paṇītam kaṇha vipāka ttā kaṇham sukka vipāka ttā sukkam buddha ādīhi viññūhi garahita ttā
translated: It is dark because of having dark kamma-result. It is bright because of having bright kamma-result. It is despised by the wise, the Buddhas, etc. It is

original: viññūgarahitaṃ. Tehi eva thomitattā viññūpasatthanti ñātabbaṃ.🔽169. Kiṃ kāraṇā nappamajjeyya iti ce – abhibhū hi soti gāthā. Tattha abhibhūti rūpādīnaṃ
analyzed: viññūga rahitam tehi eva thomita ttā viññūpasatthanti ñātabbam  kim kāraṇā na appamajjeyya iti ce hi saḥ ti gāthā tattha abhibhūti rūpa ādīnam
translated: honoured by the wise because it is praised by them.🔽Why should one not be negligent? The verse: “For he is overcome” .

original: abhibhavitā. Anabhibhūtoti tehi anabhibhūto. Sakkhidhammamanītihamaddasīti paccakkhameva
analyzed: abhibhavitā an abhibhūtaḥ ti tehi an abhibhūtaḥ paccakkham eva
translated: Herein, overcome means overcome by visible forms, etc. Not overcome means not overcome by them. He has seen the Dhamma for himself,

original: anītihaṃ dhammaṃ addakkhi. Sadā namassa’manusikkheti sadā namassanto tisso sikkhāyo sikkheyya.
analyzed: anīti ham dhammam addakkhi sadā namassam anusikkha iti sadā namassantaḥ tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ sikkheyya
translated: not on the authority of another, and thus he is one who has seen the Dhamma for himself. He should always honour the three trainings.

original: Kehici kilesehīti kehici rāgādiupatāpakarehi kilesehi. Abhibhosi neti te kilese abhibhavi. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: kehici kilesehi iti kehici rāga ādi upatāpa karehi kilesehi abhibhosi na iti te kilese abhibhavi sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: By some defilements means by some defilements that cause oppression, such as greed, etc. He overcomes them means he overcomes those defilements. The rest is clear.

original: Kevalaṃ pana ettha “cakkhūhi neva lolo”tiādīhi indriyasaṃvaro, “annānamatho pānāna”ntiādīhi🔽sannidhipaṭikkhepamukhena paccayapaṭisevanasīlaṃ, methunamosavajjapesuṇiyādīhi pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ,
analyzed: kevalam pana ettha cakkhūhi na iva lolo ti ādīhi indriya saṃvaraḥ annānam atho pāna ananti ādīhi  sannidhi paṭikkhepa mukhena paccaya paṭisevana sīlam methuna mosa vajja pesuṇiya ādīhi pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam
translated: But here in this stanza the restraint of the faculties is given in the first line, “Not greedy with the eye,”🔽and the virtue of livelihood purification in the third line, “In food and clothing,”🔽and the virtue consisting in the Pātimokkha restraint in the second line, “Not a drunkard,” etc.,

original: “āthabbaṇaṃ supinaṃ lakkhaṇa”ntiādīhi ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ, “jhāyī na pādalolassā”ti
analyzed: āthabbaṇam supinam lakkhaṇa nti ādīhi ājīva pārisuddhi sīlam jhāyī na pāda lolassa ati
translated: and concentration in the fourth line, “The meditator not greedy for the path,”

original: iminā samādhi, “vicinaṃ bhikkhū”ti iminā paññā, “sadā sato sikkhe”ti iminā puna saṅkhepato🔽tissopi sikkhā, “atha āsanesu sayanesu, appasaddesu bhikkhu vihareyya, niddaṃ na
analyzed: iminā samādhi bhikkhu iti iminā paññā sadā sataḥ sikkha iti iminā puna saṅkhepato  tissaḥ api sikkhāḥ atha āsanesu sayanesu appasaddesu bhikkhu vihareyya niddam na
translated: and the three trainings in brief again in the fifth line, “Always mindful, he should train,”

original: bahulīkareyyā”tiādīhi sīlasamādhipaññānaṃ upakārānupakārasaṅgaṇhanavinodanāni vuttānīti.
analyzed: bahulīkareyya ati ādīhi sīla samādhi paññānam upakāra anupakāra saṅgaṇhana vinodanāni vuttāni iti
translated: and the avoidance and practice of what is helpful and harmful to the three trainings in the sixth line, “In seats and beds,” etc.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā nimmitassa paripuṇṇapaṭipadaṃ vatvā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi,
analyzed: evam bhagavā nimmitassa paripuṇṇa paṭipadam vatvā arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: So the Blessed One, having spoken of the disciple’s fulfilled practice, concluded the teaching with the peak of the arahants.

original: desanāpariyosāne purābhedasutte vuttasadisoyevābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: desanā pariyosāne purābheda sutte vutta sadisaḥ yeva abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: And at the conclusion of the teaching the penetration was the same as that given in the Purābheda Sutta .

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Great Commentary Illuminating the True Dhamma

original: Tuvaṭakasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽15. Attadaṇḍasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tuvaṭaka sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Commentary on the Tuvatakasutta is finished.🔽. Commentary on the Attadaṇḍasuttaniddesa

original: 170. Pannarasame attadaṇḍasuttaniddese attadaṇḍā bhayaṃ jātanti paṭhamagāthāya attho
analyzed: pannarasame attadaṇḍa sutta niddese attadaṇḍāḥ bhayam jātanti paṭhama gāthāya attho
translated: . In the fifteenth sutta, the Attadaṇḍasuttaniddesa, the meaning of the first stanza, “Fear has arisen from self-punishment,” is this:

original: – yaṃ lokassa diṭṭhadhammikaṃ vā samparāyikaṃ vā bhayaṃ jātaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ attadaṇḍā
analyzed: yam lokassa diṭṭhadhammikam vā samparāyikam vā bhayam jātam tam sabbam atta daṇḍā
translated: Whatever fear has arisen in the world, whether in this life or the next, all that fear

original: bhayaṃ jātaṃ attano duccaritakāraṇā jātaṃ, evaṃ santepi janaṃ passatha medhagaṃ,🔽imaṃ sākiyādijanaṃ passatha aññamaññaṃ medhagaṃ hiṃsakaṃ bādhakanti. Evaṃ taṃ paṭiviruddhaṃ
analyzed: bhayam jātam attanaḥ duccarita kāraṇā jātam evam sante pi janam passatha medha gam  imam sākiya ādi janam passatha aññam aññam medha gam hiṃsakam bādhakam ti evam tam paṭiviruddham
translated: has arisen from self-punishment, arisen from one’s own evil conduct. Even so, “see the people, wise,🔽one against another inflicting harm and injury.” Thus having reproved the people who are opposed to the Dhamma

original: vippaṭipannaṃ janaṃ paribhāsitvā attano sammā paṭipattidassanena tassa saṃvegaṃ janetuṃ
analyzed: vippaṭipannam janam paribhāsitvā attano sammā paṭipatti dassanena tassa saṃvegam janetuṃ
translated: and who are on the wrong path, in order to arouse a sense of spiritual urgency in them by showing his own right conduct,

original: āha “saṃvegaṃ kittayissāmi, yathā saṃvijitaṃ mayā”ti. Pubbe bodhisatteneva satāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āha saṃvegam kittayissāmi yathā saṃvijitam mayā ati pubbe bodhisattena iva satā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: he said, “I will tell of the sense of urgency as it was experienced by me.” The intention is that it was experienced by the Bodhisatta in the past.🔽.

original: Tayoti gaṇanaparicchedo. Daṇḍāti duccaritā. Kāyadaṇḍoti kāyaduccaritaṃ. Vacīdaṇḍādīsupi
analyzed: tayā iti gaṇana paricchedaḥ daṇḍā ati duccaritā kāya daṇḍā iti kāya duccaritam vacī daṇḍa ādī supi
translated: ‘Ten’: the delimitation by number. ‘Stick’: misconduct. ‘Stick of body’: bodily misconduct. ‘Stick of speech’ and so on.

original: eseva nayo. Tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritanti pāṇātipātādikāyato pavattaṃ duṭṭhuṃ caritaṃ,🔽kilesapūtikattā vā duṭṭhu caritanti laddhanāmaṃ tividhaṃ duccaritaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ.🔽Catubbidhanti musāvādādicatubbidhaṃ. Tividhanti abhijjhāditividhaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammikanti🔽diṭṭheva dhamme imasmiṃyeva attabhāve paṭisaṃvedanīyaṃ. Samparāyikanti anāgate attabhāve🔽paṭisaṃvedanīyaṃ. Āgucārīti pāpakārī aparādhakārī. Tamenaṃ rājā paribhāsatīti pāpakāriṃ
analyzed: tividham kāya duccaritanti pāṇa atipāta ādi kāyato pavattam caritam  vā duṭṭhu caritanti laddha nāmam tividham duccaritam kāya duccaritam  catubbidhanti musāvāda ādi catubbidham tividhanti abhijjha ādi tividham diṭṭhadhammikam ti  diṭṭhe iva dhamme imasmiṃ yeva atta bhāve paṭisaṃvedanīyam samparāyikanti anāgate atta bhāve  paṭisaṃvedanīyam āgu cārī iti pāpa kārī aparādha kārī tam enam rājā paribhāsati iti pāpa kārim
translated: ‘Three’: this is a delimitation by number. ‘Stick’: it is misconduct. ‘Stick of the body’: misconduct of the body. The same method applies in the case of the stick of speech, etc. ‘Misconduct of the body is threefold’: misconduct that occurs by means of the body, such as killing breathing things, etc.,

original: rājā paribhāsati, bhayaṃ uppādeti. Dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ🔽cetasikaṃ domanassaṃ vindati. Etaṃ bhayaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassanti evarūpaṃ bhayañca
analyzed: rājā paribhāsati bhayam uppādeti dukkham domanassam paṭisaṃvedeti iti kāyikam dukkham 🔽cetasikam domanassam vindati etam bhayam dukkham domanassanti evarūpam bhayam ca
translated: or misconduct that has become evil because of the defilements, and so is called ‘misconduct.’ ‘Fourfold’: the four kinds of misconduct beginning with false speech. ‘Threefold’: the three kinds of misconduct beginning with covetousness. ‘In this very life’ : to be experienced in this very existence, in this very individual existence. ‘In the life to come’ : to be experienced in a future existence. ‘The king rebukes him’ : the king reproaches the evildoer, he causes fear to arise in him. ‘He experiences pain and grief’ : he finds bodily pain and mental grief. ‘This fear and pain and grief’ : such fear and

original: dukkhañca domanassañca. Kuto tassāti tassa corassa kuto uppannaṃ. Attadaṇḍato jātanti
analyzed: dukkham ca domanassam ca kutas tassa ati tassa corassa kutas uppannam atta daṇḍataḥ jātanti
translated: and pain and grief. Whence is it? Whence has it arisen for that thief?

original: attanā kataduccaritato uppannaṃ.
analyzed: attanā kata duccaritataḥ uppannam
translated: From the punishment of himself: it has arisen from the evil he has himself done.🔽In the end: from below. He makes him speak thus: “You will not get out of here” he says, “You will not get out of this village, etc.,

original: Antamasoti heṭṭhimato. Savacanīyampi karoti “na te labbhā ito pakkamitu”nti ito imamhā🔽gāmādinā gantuṃ na labbhā. Na sakkā bahi nikkhamitunti palibodhaṃ saṅgaṃ karoti.
analyzed: antamasaḥ ti heṭṭhimataḥ savacanīyam pi karoti na te labbhā itas pakkamitum ti itas imamhā  gāma ādinā gantum na labbhā na sakkā bahi nikkhamitunti palibodham saṅgam karoti
translated: and go away.” He makes an obstacle, a hindrance, to his going outside.

original: Dhanajānipaccayāpīti dhanaparihānikāraṇāpi. Rājā tassa vividhā kammakāraṇā kārāpeti.🔽Kasāhipi tāḷetīti kasādaṇḍakehi potheti. Vettehipi tāḷetīti sakaṇṭakavettalatāhi🔽potheti. Aḍḍhadaṇḍakehītiādayo heṭṭhā vuttanayāyeva. Sunakhehipi khādāpetīti katipayāni
analyzed: dhana jāni paccayā api iti dhana parihāni kāraṇā api rājā tassa vividhā kamma kāraṇā kārāpeti  tāḷeti iti kasā daṇḍakehi vettehi pi tāḷeti iti sa kaṇṭaka vetta latāhi  potha iti aḍḍhadaṇḍakehi iti ādayaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayāya iva su nakhehi pi khādāpeti iti katipayāni
translated: And because of the loss of his wealth: for the reason of the loss of his wealth the king has him flogged with various punishments.

original: divasāni āhāre adatvā chātasunakhehi khādāpeti. Te muhuttena aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikameva
analyzed: divasāni āhāre a datvā chāta sunakhehi khādāpeti te muhuttena aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam eva
translated: He has him whipped: he has him beaten with canes. He has him flogged with the leather strap: he has him beaten with a whip. He has him fettered in wooden fetters: he has him fettered with wooden fetters. He has him fettered in iron fetters: he has him fettered with iron fetters. He has him confined in stocks: he has him confined in a cage. He has him confined in prison: he has him confined in a prison. He has him banished: he has him expelled from the country. He has him deprived of his property: he has his property confiscated. He has him mutilated: he has a hand or a foot or a nose cut off. He has him sewn up in a sack: he has him sewn up in a sack and thrown into the water. He has him devoured by dogs: he has him thrown to dogs to eat. He has him impaled alive on a stake: he has him impaled alive on a stake. He has him beheaded: he has his head cut off with a sword.🔽He has him devoured by vultures: he has him thrown to vultures to eat. He has him devoured by hawks: he has him thrown to hawks to eat. He has him devoured by herons: he has him thrown to herons to eat. He has him devoured by tigers: he has him thrown to tigers to eat. He has him devoured by hyenas: he has him thrown to hyenas to eat. He has him devoured by wolves: he has him thrown to wolves to eat. He has him devoured by dogs: he has him thrown to dogs to eat. He has him devoured by various creatures: he has him thrown to various creatures to eat. He has him burned on a pyre: he has him thrown on a pyre and burned. He has him drowned: he has him thrown into the water and drowned.

original: karoti. Sūle uttāsetīti sūlaṃ āropeti. Rājā imesaṃ catunnaṃ daṇḍānaṃ issaroti imāsaṃ
analyzed: karoti sūle uttāseti iti sūlam āropeti rājā imesam catunnam daṇḍānam issaroti imāsam
translated: He makes them do so. He impales them on the stake: he makes them mount the stake. The king is the lord of these four punishments:

original: catunnaṃ āṇānaṃ kātuṃ rājā samattho.🔽Sakena kammenāti sayaṃkatena kammena. Tamenaṃ nirayapālāti ettha ekacce therā “nirayapālā🔽nāma natthi, yantarūpaṃ viya kammameva kāraṇaṃ kāretī”ti vadanti. Tesaṃ taṃ “atthi
analyzed: catunnam āṇānam kātum rājā samatthaḥ  sakena kammena ati sayaṃkatena kammena tam enam niraya pālā ati ettha ekacce therāḥ niraya pālā  nāma natthi viya kammam eva kāraṇam kāreti iti vadanti tesam tam atthi
translated: He impales him on the stake: he makes him climb on to the stake. The king is the lord of these four punishments: the king is able to inflict these four orders.🔽By his own action: by his own deed. The wardens of hell: here some elders say that there are no wardens of hell, that kamma itself acts as the cause like a machine. That is refuted in the Abhidhamma in the way beginning:

original: nirayesu nirayapālāti, āmantā. Atthi ca kāraṇikā”tiādinā nayena abhidhamme paṭisedhitameva.
analyzed: nirayesu niraya pālā ati āmantā atthi ca kāraṇikā ati ādinā nayena abhidhamme paṭisedhitam eva
translated: “Are there wardens of hell? Yes, there are wardens of hell, and there are those who inflict suffering.”

original: Yathā hi manussaloke kammakāraṇakārakā atthi, evameva nirayesu nirayapālā atthīti.🔽Tattaṃ ayokhilanti tigāvutaṃ attabhāvaṃ sampajjalitāya lohapathaviyā uttānakaṃ nipajjāpetvā
analyzed: yathā hi manussa loke kamma kāraṇa kārakā atthi evam eva nirayesu niraya pālā atthi iti  tat tam tigāvutam atta bhāvam sampajjalitāya loha pathaviyāḥ uttānakam
translated: Just as in the human world there are those who do the work of executioners, so too in hell there are wardens of hell.🔽He makes him lie prone on a heated iron surface that is as smooth as a mirror and as hard as a diamond, and they drive an iron stake through his left side.

original: dakkhiṇahatthe tālappamāṇaṃ ayasūlaṃ pavesenti, tathā vāmahatthādīsu. Yathā ca uttānakaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇa hatthe tāla ppamāṇam aya sūlam pavesenti tathā vāma hattha ādīsu yathā ca uttānakam
translated: And they do likewise with his right hand and the other parts of his body.

original: nipajjāpetvā evaṃ urenapi vāmapassenapi dakkhiṇapassenapi nipajjāpetvā taṃ kammakāraṇaṃ karontiyeva.🔽Saṃvesetvāti jalitāya lohapathaviyā tigāvutaṃ attabhāvaṃ nipajjāpetvā. Kuṭhārīhīti🔽mahatīhi gehacchādanassa ekapakkhamattāhi kuṭhārīhi tacchenti, lohitaṃ nadī hutvā
analyzed: nipajjāpetvā evam urena api vāma passena api dakkhiṇa passena api nipajjāpetvā tam kamma kāraṇam karontiyā iva  saṃvesetvā ati jalitāya loha pathaviyā tigāvutam atta bhāvam nipajjāpetvā kuṭhārīhi iti  mahatīhi geha chādanassa eka pakkha mattāhi kuṭhārīhi tat chenti lohitam nadī hutvā
translated: and after making them lie down on their backs, on their chests, on their left sides, and on their right sides, they do their work.🔽Having made them lie down: having made them lie down on the heated iron plate, extending over an area of four yojanas. With axes:🔽with axes as big as the side-pieces of a house. The blood flows like water in a river.

original: sandati, lohapathavito jālā uṭṭhahitvā tacchitaṭṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti, mahādukkhaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: sandati loha pathavitaḥ jālā uṭṭhahitvā tad chita ṭṭhānam gaṇhāti mahā dukkham uppajjati
translated: From the iron plate flames shoot up and seize the place that is being cut. Great pain arises.

original: tacchantā pana suttāhataṃ karitvā dāru viya aṭṭhaṃsampi chaḷaṃsampi karonti. Vāsīhīti🔽mahāsuppapamāṇāhi vāsīhi. Rathe yojetvāti saddhiṃ yugayottaupakkharacakkakubbarapājanehi
analyzed: tad śantā pana sutta āhatam karitvā dāru viya aṭṭhaṃsam pi chaḍaṃsam pi karonti vāsīhi iti  mahā suppa pamāṇāhi vāsīhi rathe yojetvā ati saddhim
translated: But when they cut, they make the body as straight as a post, and then cut it into eight or ten pieces. With knives:

original: sabbato pajjalite rathe yojetvā. Mahantanti mahākūṭāgārappamāṇaṃ. Āropentīti sampajjalitehi
analyzed: sabbatas pajjalite rathe yojetvā mahantanti mahā kūṭāgāra ppamāṇam āropenti iti sampajjalitehi
translated: with knives as big as a ploughshare. Having yoked: having yoked them to a burning chariot together with the yoke, the shafts, the wheels, the axles, and the pole. To a great: as big as a great gabled house. They make them get up:🔽and having made them get up, they make them sit down, lie down, and do all the other things.

original: ayamuggarehi pothentā āropenti. Sakimpi uddhanti supakkutthitāya ukkhaliyā pakkhittataṇḍulaṃ
analyzed: ayam uggarehi pothentāḥ āropenti su pakka utthitāya ukkhaliyā pakkhitta taṇḍulam
translated: They put it on the fire, stirring it with a ladle. They take it off the fire when it is well cooked.

original: viya uddhaṃ adho tiriyañca gacchati. Mahānirayeti avīcimahānirayamhi.
analyzed: viyat uddham adhas tiriyan ca gacchati mahāniraya iti avīci mahānirayamhi
translated: They are lifted up by being dragged along with the ploughs. They are lifted up at once, like rice in a rice-huller when the rice falls in evenly. They go up, down, and across. The Great Hell is the Great Avīci Hell.

original: Catukkaṇṇoti caturassamañjūsāsadiso. Vibhattoti catudvāravasena vibhatto. Bhāgaso
analyzed: catukkaṇṇo ti catu rassa mañjūsā sadisaḥ vibhatto ti catu dvāra vasena vibhattaḥ bhāgaso
translated: Four-cornered: like a four-cornered brick. Divided: divided by means of four doors.🔽Sectioned: sectioned by being placed in sections by means of the doors and the passages.

original: mitoti dvāravīthīnaṃ vasena bhāge ṭhapetvā ṭhapetvā vibhatto. Pariyantoti parikkhitto.
analyzed: mitaḥ iti dvāra vīthīnam vasena bhāge ṭhapetvā ṭhapetvā vibhattaḥ pariyantaḥ ti parikkhittaḥ
translated: Surrounded: enclosed.

original: Ayasāti upari navayojanikena ayapattena chādito. Samantā yojanasataṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: ayasā ti upari nava yojanikena aya pattena chāditaḥ samantā yojana satam pharitvā tiṭṭhati iti
translated: Iron: covered above with an iron roof nine leagues thick. It extends for a hundred leagues all around.

original: evaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, yathā samantā yojanasate ṭhatvā olokentassa akkhīni yamakagoḷakā
analyzed: evam pharitvā tiṭṭhati yathā samantā yojana sate ṭhatvā olokentassa akkhīni yamakagoḷakā
translated: It extends thus, and it stands there, so that when one looks at it from a distance of a hundred leagues all around, the eyes seem to be drawn out as if by magnets.

original: viya nikkhamanti. Kadariyātapanāti sabbepi te ussadehi saddhiṃ aṭṭha mahānirayā kadariyā
analyzed: viya nikkhamanti kadariya ātapanā ati sabbe pi te ussadehi saddhim aṭṭha mahānirayā kadariyā
translated: The Fiery Furnace: all these hells together with the embers are the eight great hells. They are the Fiery Furnace because they constantly burn.

original: niccaṃ tapantīti kadariyātapanā. Balavadukkhatāya ghorā. Kappaṭṭhikānaṃ accīnaṃ atthitāya
analyzed: niccam tapanti iti kadariya ātapanā balava dukkha tāya ghorā kappaṭṭhikānam accīnam atthi tāya
translated: They are terrible because of their intense pain. They are the Hell of Blisters because of the presence of blisters that last for an eon.

original: accimanto. Āsādetuṃ ghaṭṭetuṃ dukkaratāya durāsadā. Diṭṭhamattā vā sutamattā vā lomāni
analyzed: accimantaḥ āsādetum ghaṭṭetum dukkara tāya durāsadāḥ diṭṭha mattāḥ vā suta mattāḥ vā lomāni
translated: are hard to approach, hard to attain, because of the difficulty of attaining them by mere seeing or hearing.

original: haṃsentīti lomahaṃsanarūpā. Bhīsanatāya bhismā. Bhayajananatāya paṭibhayā. Sukhābhāvena dukhā.
analyzed: haṃsentī iti lomahaṃsana rūpā bhīsa natāya bhismā bhaya janana tāya paṭibhayā sukha abhāvena dukhā
translated: and flaming. They are hard to approach because of the difficulty of enduring them when they are seen or heard about. They are hair-raising because of causing the body hairs to stand up. They are terrible because of being terrifying. They are fearful because of causing fear. They are painful because of being devoid of pleasure.

original: Puratthimāya bhittiyātiādigāthānaṃ evaṃ avīcinirayoti pariyantaṃ katvā ayaṃ saṅkhepattho🔽– aggijālānaṃ vā pana sattānaṃ vā tesaṃ dukkhassa vā vīci antaraṃ natthi etthāti🔽avīci. Tatra hi puratthimādīhi bhittīhi jālārāsi uṭṭhahitvā pāpakammino puggale jhāpento🔽pacchimādīsu bhittīsu paṭihaññati paharati, tā ca bhittiyo vinivijjhitvā parato yojanasataṃ
analyzed: puratthimāya bhittiyā iti ādi gāthānam evam avīci nirayaḥ iti pariyantam katvā ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ  aggi jālānam vā pana sattānam vā tesam dukkhassa vā vīci antaram natthi ettha ati  tatra hi puratthima ādīhi bhittīhi jālārāsi uṭṭhahitvā pāpa kammino puggale jhāpento  pacchima ādīsu bhittīsu paṭihaññati paharati tāḥ ca bhittiyaḥ vinivijjhitvā paratas yojana satam
translated: The meaning of the first verse is this:

original: gaṇhāti, heṭṭhā uṭṭhitā upari paṭihaññati, upari uṭṭhitā heṭṭhā paṭihaññati. Evaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhāti heṭṭhā uṭṭhitā upari paṭihaññati upari uṭṭhitā heṭṭhā paṭihaññati evam
translated: There is no interval in the flames or in the beings or in the suffering there, thus it is Avīci . For there the mass of flames rises up striking the beings from the eastern and other directions against the western and other walls, and it penetrates the walls and goes a hundred leagues beyond them. The flames that rise from below are struck by those that rise from above, and those that rise from above are struck by those that rise from below.

original: tāvettha jālānaṃ vīci nāma natthi. Tassa pana anto yojanasataṭṭhānaṃ khīravallipiṭṭhassa
analyzed: tāva ettha jālānam vīci nāma natthi tassa pana antar yojana sata ṭṭhānam khīra valli piṭṭhassa
translated: But there is no interval between the hells here. The hundred leagues inside it are filled with beings like a tube full of cream of pounded sesame seed.

original: pūritanāḷi viya sattehi nirantaraṃ pūritaṃ catūhi iriyāpathehi paccantānaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: pūrita nāḷi viya sattehi nirantaram pūritam catūhi iriyāpathehi paccantānam sattānam
translated: There is no measure of the beings who roast there, moving about in the four postures.

original: pamāṇaṃ natthi, na ca aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti, sakasakaṭṭhāneyeva paccanti. Evamettha🔽sattānaṃ vīci nāma natthi. Yathā pana jivhagge cha madhubindūni sattamassa tambalohabinduno🔽anudahanabalavatāya abbohārikāni honti, tathā tattha anudahanabalavatāya sesā cha🔽akusalavipākupekkhā abbohārikā honti, dukkhameva nirantaraṃ paññāyati. Evamettha
analyzed: pamāṇam natthi na ca aññam aññam byābādhenti saka saka ṭṭhāneya iva paccanti evam ettha  sattānam nāma natthi yathā pana jivhagge cha madhu bindūni sattamassa tamba loha binduno  anudahana balavatāya abbohārikāni honti tathā tattha anudahana balavatāya sesā cha  akusala vipāka upekkhāḥ abbohārikāḥ honti dukkham eva nirantaram paññāyati evam ettha
translated: They do not obstruct each other, but each one roasts in his own place. So there is no interval between the beings here.

original: dukkhassa vīci nāma natthi. Nirassādaṭṭhena nirayo.
analyzed: dukkhassa vīci nāma natthi nirassāda ṭṭhena nirayaḥ
translated: But just as six drops of honey on the tip of a tongue do not satisfy a man who wants honey, so too, the six kinds of equanimity that are results of unprofitable kamma do not satisfy here; only pain is continuously manifest. So there is no interval between the pain here. It is a hell because it is without consolation.

original: Tattha sattā mahāluddāti tasmiṃ nibbattā sattā mahantā luddā. Mahākibbisakārinoti
analyzed: tattha sattāḥ mahā luddā ti tasmin nibbattā sattāḥ mahantāḥ luddāḥ mahā kibbisa kārino ti
translated: Beings are greatly tormented there: beings reborn there are greatly tormented. They are great offenders: they have committed great offences.

original: mahantadāruṇakammakārino. Accantapāpakammantāti ekaṃsena pāpakammino. Paccanti na🔽ca miyyareti channaṃ jālānamantare paccanti, na ca miyyanti. Jātavedasamo kāyoti🔽tesaṃ sarīraṃ aggisadisaṃ. Tesaṃ nirayavāsinanti tesaṃ pāpakammānaṃ nirayavāsīnaṃ.🔽Passa kammānaṃ daḷhattanti pāpakammānaṃ thirabhāvaṃ olokehi. Na bhasmā hoti napī
analyzed: mahanta dāruṇa kamma kārinaḥ accanta pāpa kammantā ati ekaṃsena pāpa kammino paccanti na  ca channam jālānam antare na ca jātavedasamaḥ  tesam sarīram aggi sadisam tesam niraya vāsinaṃ ti tesam pāpa kammānam niraya vāsīnam  passa kammānam daḷha ttanti pāpa kammānam thira bhāvam olokehi na hoti
translated: who do great and terrible deeds. ‘They who do the most wicked deeds’ means: they who do only wicked deeds. ‘They are cooked, but do not die’ means: they are cooked in the midst of the six nets, but they do not die. ‘Like the fire that burns the dead’ means:🔽their bodies are like fire. ‘Those who live in hell’ means: those who live in hell because of their wicked deeds.🔽‘See the strength of deeds’ means: look at the firmness of wicked deeds. ‘They do not become ashes, nor do they die’ means: they do not become ashes, nor do they die.

original: masīti chārikāpi na hoti aṅgāropi. Puratthimenāti yadā taṃ dvāraṃ apārutaṃ hoti,
analyzed: masī iti chārikā api na hoti aṅgāraḥ api puratthimena ati yadā tam dvāram a pārutam hoti
translated: Who do the most terrible deeds. Who do the most evil deeds: who do only evil deeds. Are roasted, but do not die: they are roasted in the midst of the six-barred cage, but they do not die. Like the fire of the world’s end: their bodies are like the fire at the end of the world. Of those who dwell in hell: of those who dwell in hell, who have done evil deeds. See the firmness of deeds: look at the firmness of evil deeds. It is not ashes, nor is it soot: it is not even cinders, nor is it charcoal. In the east: when that gate is opened,

original: atha tadabhimukhā dhāvanti, tesaṃ tattha chaviādīni jhāyanti. Dvārasamīpaṃ pattānañca🔽tesaṃ taṃ pīdhīyati, pacchimaṃ apārutaṃ viya khāyati. Esa nayo sabbattha. Abhinikkhamitāsā
analyzed: atha tad abhimukhāḥ dhāvanti tesam tattha chavi ādīni jhāyanti dvāra samīpam pattānam ca  tesam tam pīdhīyati pacchimam a pārutam viya khāyati esa nayo sabbattha
translated: they run towards it. Their skin and so on are burnt as they go there. And when they reach the gate,

original: teti nirayā nikkhamituṃ āsā etesanti nikkhamitāsā. Mokkhagavesinoti muñcanupāyaṃ
analyzed: te iti nirayāḥ nikkhamitum āsāḥ nikkhamita asāḥ mokkha gavesino ti muñcan upāyam
translated: it closes as if it had been closed before. The same method applies everywhere. Who have no hope of escape: who have no hope of escaping from hell. Who seek release: who seek a means of escape.

original: esantā gavesantāpi. Na te tato nikkhamituṃ, labhanti kammapaccayāti te sattā nirayato🔽nikkhamanadvāraṃ pāpakammapaccayā nādhigacchanti. Tesañca pāpakammantaṃ, avipakkaṃ
analyzed: esantā gavesantā api na te tatas nikkhamitum labhanti kamma paccayā ati te sattāḥ nirayataḥ  nikkhamana dvāram pāpa kamma paccayāḥ na adhigacchanti tesam ca pāpa kammantam avipakkam
translated: Searching, seeking, they cannot find a way out of it. They cannot get out of hell because of their kamma.🔽And they have done much evil kamma whose result has not yet matured.

original: kataṃ bahunti tesañca sattānaṃ lāmakaṃ dāruṇakammaṃ avipākaṃ bahuvidhaṃ nānappakāraṃ
analyzed: katam bahunti tesam ca sattānam lāmakam dāruṇa kammam avipākam bahuvidham nānappakāram
translated: They have done much evil kamma, kamma that is bad, kamma that is of various kinds, kamma that is of many sorts, kamma that has not yet matured, kamma that has not yet borne fruit.

original: adinnavipākaṃ kataṃ upacitaṃ atthi.🔽Saṃveganti vinilanaṃ. Ubbeganti ṭhitaṭṭhānato gamanaṃ. Utrāsanti ubbejanaṃ asanniṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Bhayanti cittutrāsanaṃ. Pīḷananti ghaṭṭanaṃ. Ghaṭṭananti pīḷākaraṇaṃ. Upaddavanti
analyzed: adinna vipākam katam upacitam atthi  vinilanam ubbeganti ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ gamanam utrāsanti ubbejanam a sanniṭṭhānam  bhayanti cittu trāsanam pīḍananti ghaṭṭanam ghaṭṭananti pīḷā karaṇam upaddavanti
translated: They have done it and stored it up.🔽They are anxious: they are anxious about it. They are afraid: they are afraid of it. They are terrified: they are terrified of it.🔽They are alarmed: they are alarmed by it. They are distressed: they are distressed by it. They are in despair: they are in despair about it.

original: ītiṃ. Upasagganti rundhanaṃ.
analyzed: ītim upasagganti rundhanam
translated: They are in danger: they are in danger from it. They are in trouble: they are in trouble from it.

original: 171. Idāni yathānena saṃvijitaṃ, taṃ pakāraṃ dassento “phandamāna”ntiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni yathā anena saṃvijitam tam pakāram dassentaḥ phandamāna nti ādim āha tattha
translated: Now, showing the way in which he searched, he said “trembling” , etc. Herein

original: phandamānanti taṇhādiṭṭhīhi kampamānaṃ. Appodaketi appe udake. Aññamaññehi byāruddhe
analyzed: phandamānam ti taṇhā diṭṭhīhi kampamānam appa udaka iti appe udake aññamaññehi byāruddhe
translated: trembling means shaking through craving and views. In a little water means in a little pond. They are hostile to one another means they are hostile to one another because of the little water.

original: disvāti nānāsatte ca aññamaññehi saddhiṃ viruddhe disvā. Maṃ bhayamāvisīti maṃ bhayaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: disvā iti nānāsatte ca aññamaññehi saddhim viruddhe disvā mam bhayam āvisi iti mam bhayam paviṭṭham
translated: Having seen: having seen various creatures quarrelling with one another. Fear entered me: fear entered me.

original: Kilesaphandanāya phandamānanti rāgādikilesacalanāya calamānaṃ. Payogoti kāyavacīmanopayogo.🔽Viruddhāti virodhamāpannā. Paṭiviruddhāti paṭimukhaṃ hutvā virodhamāpannā, suṭṭhu
analyzed: kilesa phandanāya rāga ādi kilesa calanāya calamānam kāya vacī manaḥ upayogaḥ  viruddhā ati virodham āpannā paṭiviruddhā ati paṭimukham hutvā virodham āpannā suṭṭhu
translated: Shaking with the shaking of defilements: shaking with the shaking of lust, etc. Effort: bodily, verbal, and mental effort.🔽Quarrelled: fallen into quarrel. Contended: fallen into quarrel face to face, or fallen into quarrel well.

original: viruddhā vā. Āhatāti kodhena āhatā pahatā. Paccāhatāti paṭimallā hutvā āhatā. Āghātitāti
analyzed: viruddhā vā āhatā ati kodhena āhatā pahatā paccāhatā ati paṭimallāḥ hutvā āhatāḥ āghātitā ati
translated: Attacked: attacked, struck down, by anger. Counter-attacked: attacked in return.

original: ghaṭṭitā. Paccāghātitāti visesena ghaṭṭitā. Pāṇīhipi upakkamantīti hatthehipi paharanti.
analyzed: ghaṭṭitā paccāghātitā ati visesena ghaṭṭitā pāṇīhi pi upakkamanti iti hatthehi pi paharanti
translated: Gnawed: gnawed at. Counter-gnawed: gnawed at in return. Even with their hands they would attack: they would strike with their hands.

original: 172. Samantamasāro lokoti nirayaṃ ādiṃ katvā samantato loko asāro niccasārādirahito.
analyzed: samantam asāraḥ nirayam ādim katvā samantataḥ lokaḥ asāraḥ nicca sāra ādi rahitaḥ
translated: The world is worthless all around: the world beginning with hell is worthless all around, devoid of any permanent worth such as permanence, etc.

original: Disā sabbā sameritāti sabbā disā aniccatāya kampitā. Icchaṃ bhavanamattanoti attano
analyzed: disā sabbā sameritā ati sabbāḥ disāḥ anicca tāya kampitāḥ iccham bhavanam attanoti attano
translated: All directions are shaken: all directions are shaken by impermanence. I wished for my own dwelling:

original: tāṇaṃ icchanto. Nāddasāsiṃ anositanti kiñci ṭhānaṃ jarādīhi anajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ nāddakkhinti.🔽Asāroti na sāro, sāravirahito vā. Nissāroti sabbena sabbaṃ sāravirahito. Sārāpagatoti
analyzed: tāṇam icchantaḥ kiñci ṭhānam jarā ādīhi an ajjhāvuṭṭham  asāraḥ ti na sāraḥ sāra virahitaḥ vā nissāraḥ ti sabbena sabbam sāra virahito sāra apagato ti
translated: Seeking a refuge, I saw none.🔽Unsustained: without a core. Without a core: devoid of core. Devoid of core:

original: sārato apagato. Niccasārasārena vāti satatasārasaṅkhātena sārena vā. Uparipadadvayepi🔽eseva nayo. Ye puratthimāya disāya saṅkhārāti ye puratthimāya disāya paccayehi saṅgamma
analyzed: sārataḥ apagataḥ nicca sāra sārena vāti satata sāra saṅkhātena sārena vā upari pada dvaye pi  esa iva nayaḥ ye puratthimāya disāya saṅkhārā ati ye puratthimāya disāya paccayehi saṅgamma
translated: devoid of a core. With a core of constant core: with a core called “constant.” In the case of the other two directions,🔽the method is the same. Whatever determinations there are in the eastern direction: whatever determinations there are that have come together and have been formed through conditions in the eastern direction.

original: samāgamma katā saṅkhārā. Tepi eritāti tepi saṅkhārā kampitā. Sameritāti sammā kampitā.🔽Calitāti calanaṃ gatā. Ghaṭṭitāti udayabbayena pīḷitā. Aniccatāyāti hutvā abhāvatāya.🔽Jātiyā anugatāti nibbattiyā anupaviṭṭhā. Jarāya anusaṭāti paripakkatāya anupatthaṭā.
analyzed: samāgamma katā saṅkhārā tepi eritā ati tepi saṅkhārā kampitā sameritā ati sammā kampitā  calitā ati calanam gatā ghaṭṭitā ati udaya bbayena pīḍitā anicca tāya ati hutvā abhāva tāya  jātiyā anugatā ati nibbattiyā anupaviṭṭhā jarāya anusaṭā ati paripakka tāya anupatthaṭā
translated: Those determinations too are shaken: those determinations too are shaken up. They are thoroughly shaken: they are shaken up well.🔽They are stirred: they have become stirred. They are agitated: they are oppressed by rise and fall. By impermanence: by the state of having come to be and then disappearing.🔽They are followed by birth: they are followed by arising. They are overtaken by aging: they are overtaken by decay.

original: Byādhinā abhibhūtāti cātuvisamena uppannabyādhinā ajjhotthaṭā. Maraṇena abbhāhatāti
analyzed: byādhinā abhibhūtā ati cātuvisamena uppanna byādhinā ajjhotthaṭā maraṇena abbhāhatā ati
translated: They are overcome by sickness: they are overcome by the four hundred and four diseases. They are struck down by death:

original: maccunā abhiāhatā pahatā. Atāṇāti rakkhavirahitā. Aleṇāti leṇavirahitā. Asaraṇāti
analyzed: maccunā abhiāhatā pahatā a tāṇā ati rakkha virahitā a leṇā ati leṇa virahitā a saraṇā ati
translated: without a protector, without a refuge, without a shelter,🔽without a refuge: they have no refuge, they are without a refuge,

original: natthi etesaṃ saraṇanti asaraṇā. Asaraṇībhūtāti sayaṃ saraṇakiccaṃ na karontīti asaraṇībhūtā.
analyzed: natthi etesam saraṇanti asaraṇā asaraṇībhūtā ati sayam saraṇa kiccam na karonti iti asaraṇībhūtā
translated: they are not a refuge for themselves.🔽Their own state: this is the subject-of-reference word for the demonstrative word ‘this’.

original: Attano bhavananti niddesapadassa uddesapadaṃ. Tāṇanti pālanaṃ. Leṇanti leṇaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ bhavananti niddesa padassa uddesa padam tāṇanti pālanam leṇanti leṇa ṭṭhānam
translated: A protector: a guardian. A shelter: a place of shelter.

original: Saraṇanti dukkhanāsanaṃ. Gatinti patiṭṭhaṃ. Parāyananti paraṃ ayanaṃ. Ajjhositaṃyeva
analyzed: saraṇam ti dukkha nāsanam gatinti patiṭṭham parāyanam ti param ayanam ajjhositam yeva
translated: A refuge: a state that removes suffering. A destination: a support. A final resort: a final going.🔽They saw only: he saw only what was struck down by ageing, etc.,

original: addasanti jarādīhi madditaṃyeva addakkhiṃ. Sabbaṃ yobbaññanti yobbanabhāvo yobbaññaṃ,
analyzed: addasanti jarā ādīhi addakkhim sabbam yobbaññanti yobbana bhāvaḥ yobbaññam
translated: All youth: youthfulness is youth.🔽All the youth of the conscious beings,

original: sacetanānaṃ sabbaṃ yobbaññaṃ. Jarāya ositanti paripākāya jarāya avasitaṃ madditaṃ. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: sa cetanānam sabbam yobbaññam jarāya ositanti paripākāya jarāya avasitam madditam evam sabbattha
translated: struck down, struck down by ageing, by the ageing that is the state of ripening. So in each case.🔽When I saw that they were caught,

original: 173. Osāne tveva byāruddhe, disvā me aratī ahūti yobbaññādīnaṃ osāneyeva antagamake
analyzed: osāne tu eva byāruddhe disvā me aratī ahū iti yobbañña ādīnam osāne yā iva anta gamake
translated: I felt aversion. When I saw that they were caught,

original: eva vināsake eva jarādīhi byāruddhe āhatacitte satte disvā arati me ahosi. Athettha
analyzed: eva vināsake eva jarā ādīhi byāruddhe āhata citte satte disvā arati me atha itthā
translated: caught in the snare of ageing, etc., in the snare of death, I felt aversion.

original: sallanti atha etesu sattesu rāgādisallaṃ. Hadayassitanti cittanissitaṃ.
analyzed: sallam ti atha etesu sattesu rāga ādi sallam hadayassitam ti citta nissitam
translated: ‘Arrow’ : the arrow of lust, etc., among these beings. ‘In the heart’ : in the mind.

original: Yobbaññaṃ jarā osāpetīti jarā atthaṅgameti vināseti. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: yobbaññam jarā osāpeti iti jarā atthaṅgamā iti vināsā iti evam sabbattha
translated: ‘Old age overtakes youth’ : old age destroys, annihilates youth. So with all.

original: 174. “Kathaṃ ānubhāvaṃ salla”nti ce? Yena sallena otiṇṇoti gāthā. Tattha disā sabbā
analyzed: katham ānubhāvam sallanti ce yena sallena otiṇṇo ti gāthā tattha disā sabbā
translated: ‘How does the arrow come to be?’ : the verse ‘By what arrow is one pierced’ . Herein, ‘All directions’

original: vidhāvatīti sabbā duccaritadisāpi puratthimādidisāpi vidisāpi dhāvati. Tameva sallamabbuyha,
analyzed: vidhāvati iti sabbā duccarita disā api puratthima ādi disā api vidisā api dhāvati tam eva sallam abbuyha
translated: ‘Run’ : all directions of misconduct run, and also the directions of the east, etc., run. ‘Having drawn out that arrow’

original: na dhāvati na sīdatīti tameva sallaṃ uddharitvā tā ca disā na dhāvati, caturoghe ca na sīdati.🔽Aññāṇantiādīsu ñāṇadassanapaṭipakkhato aññāṇaṃ adassanaṃ. Abhimukho hutvā dhammena🔽na sameti na samāgacchatīti anabhisamayo. Anurūpato dhamme bujjhatīti anubodho. Tappaṭipakkhatāya
analyzed: na dhāvati na sīdati iti tam eva sallam uddharitvā tāḥ ca disāḥ na dhāvati catur oghe ca na sīdati  aññāṇa nti ādīsu ñāṇa dassana paṭipakkhataḥ aññāṇam adassanam abhimukhaḥ hutvā dhammena  na sameti na samāgacchati iti anabhisamayaḥ anurūpatas dhamme bujjhati iti anubodhaḥ tad paṭipakkha tāya
translated: ‘Does not run’ : having drawn out that arrow, he does not run in those directions, and he does not sink in the four floods.🔽‘Ignorance’ , etc. : ignorance is the opposite of knowledge and seeing. ‘Does not come together’

original: ananubodho. Aniccādīhi saddhiṃ yojetvā na bujjhatīti asambodho. Asantaṃ asamañca
analyzed: ananubodhaḥ anicca ādīhi saddhim yojetvā na bujjhati iti asambodhaḥ asantam asamañca
translated: : does not meet, does not come together with the Dhamma. ‘Non-penetration’ : non-penetration of the truths in the proper order. ‘Non-awakening’ : non-awakening through the opposite of that. ‘Non-understanding’ : non-understanding of the Dhamma in the proper order. ‘Non-realization’ : non-realization of the non-existent and the non-existent together with the impermanent, etc.

original: bujjhatītipi asambodho. Catusaccadhammaṃ na paṭivijjhatīti appaṭivedho. Rūpādīsu🔽ekadhammampi aniccādisāmaññato na saṅgaṇhātīti asaṅgāhaṇā. Tameva dhammaṃ na pariyogāhatīti
analyzed: bujjhati iti pi asambodhaḥ catu sacca dhammam na paṭivijjhati iti appaṭivedhaḥ rūpa ādīsu  eka dhammam pi anicca ādi sāmaññataḥ na saṅgaṇhāti iti asaṅgāhaṇā tam eva dhammam na pariyogāhati iti
translated: “Awakening” is non-awakening. “Penetration” is non-penetration. “The four noble truths” is non-penetration. “Any single truth” is non-penetration. “The general characteristics of impermanence, etc.” is non-penetration. “To comprehend” is non-comprehension. “To comprehend” is non-comprehension. “To comprehend” is non-comprehension.

original: apariyogāhaṇā. Na samaṃ pekkhatīti asamapekkhanā. Dhammānaṃ sabhāvaṃ pati na apekkhatīti apaccavekkhaṇā.🔽Kusalākusalakammesu viparītavuttiyā sabhāvagahaṇābhāvena vā ekampi kammaṃ etassa
analyzed: a pariyogāhaṇā na samam pekkhati iti asamapekkhanā dhammānam sabhāvam na apekkhati iti apaccavekkhaṇā  kusala akusala kammesu viparīta vuttiyā sabhāva gahaṇa abhāvena vā ekam pi kammam etassa
translated: and it is non-awakening since it does not awaken to the four noble truths. It is non-penetration since it does not penetrate the four noble truths. It is non-comprehending since it does not comprehend any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence. It is non-grasping since it does not grasp any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence. It is non-apprehending since it does not apprehend any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence. It is non-regard since it does not look on with equanimity. It is non-reviewing since it does not review the individual essences of states.

original: paccakkhaṃ natthi, sayaṃ vā kassaci dhammassa paccakkhakaraṇaṃ nāma na hotīti apaccakkhakammaṃ.🔽Yaṃ etasmiṃ anuppajjamāne cittasantānaṃ mejjhaṃ bhaveyya suci vodānaṃ, taṃ duṭṭhuṃ🔽mejjhaṃ imināti dummejjhaṃ. Bālānaṃ bhāvo bālyaṃ. Muyhatīti moho. Balavataro moho
analyzed: paccakkham natthi sayam vā kassaci dhammassa paccakkha karaṇam nāma na hoti iti a paccakkha kammam 🔽yam etasmin an uppajjamāne citta santānam mejjham bhaveyya suci vodānam tam duṭṭhum 🔽mejjham imināti dummejjham bālānam bhāvaḥ bālyam muyhati iti mohaḥ balavataraḥ mohaḥ
translated: It is non-witnessing of action since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning with form as a general characteristic such as impermanence, or since it does not witness any one of the states beginning

original: pamoho. Samantato muyhatīti sammoho. Vijjāya paṭipakkhabhāvato na vijjāti avijjā.
analyzed: pamohaḥ samantataḥ muyhati iti sammohaḥ vijjāya paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ na vijjāti avijjā
translated: Delusion is bewilderment. Delusion is bewilderment in all ways. It is non-knowledge because it is the opposite of knowledge.

original: Oghayogattho vuttoyeva. Thāmagataṭṭhena anusetīti anusayo. Cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhāti abhibhavatīti
analyzed: ogha yoga tthaḥ thāma gata ṭṭhena anuseti iti anusayaḥ cittam pariyuṭṭhāti abhibhavati iti
translated: The meaning of “flood” and “bond” has already been given. It is a latent tendency because it tends to adhere to the mind. It is an obsession because it obsesses the mind and overpowers it.

original: pariyuṭṭhānaṃ. Hitaggahaṇābhāvena hitābhimukhaṃ gantuṃ na sakkoti aññadatthu laṅgatiyevāti🔽laṅgī, khañjatīti attho. Durugghāṭanaṭṭhena vā laṅgī. Yathā hi mahāpalighasaṅkhātā🔽laṅgī durugghāṭā hoti, evamayampi laṅgī viyāti laṅgī. Sesaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhānam hita ggahaṇa abhāvena hita abhimukham gantum na sakkoti añña datthu laṅgatiyā iva ati  laṅgī khañjatī iti atthaḥ durugghāṭana ṭṭhena vā laṅgī yathā hi mahā paligha saṅkhātā  laṅgī durugghāṭā hoti evam ayam pi laṅgī viyāti laṅgī sesam uttāna attham eva
translated: It is a clinging because it is unable to go towards what is beneficial because of the absence of the grasping of what is beneficial, but rather it strays elsewhere.

original: Yā evarūpā kaṅkhāti ettha kaṅkhanavasena kaṅkhā. Kaṅkhaṃ ānayatīti kaṅkhāyanā. Purimakaṅkhā🔽hi uttarakaṅkhaṃ ānayati nāma. Ākāravasena vā etaṃ vuttaṃ. Kaṅkhāsamaṅgicittaṃ kaṅkhāya🔽āyitattā kaṅkhāyitaṃ nāma. Tassa bhāvo kaṅkhāyitattaṃ. Vimatīti vigatā mati vimati.
analyzed: yā evarūpā kaṅkhā ati ettha kaṅkhana vasena kaṅkhā kaṅkham ānayati iti kaṅkhāyanā purima kaṅkhā 🔽hi uttara kaṅkham ānayati nāma ākāra vasena vā etam vuttam kaṅkhā samaṅgi cittam kaṅkhāya 🔽āyita ttā kaṅkhāyitam nāma tassa bhāvaḥ kaṅkhāyita ttam vimati iti vigatā mati vimati
translated: It is a straying, the meaning is that it strays. Or it is a straying because it is difficult to remove, just as a straying animal called a “paligha” is difficult to remove, so too is this straying called a “straying” because it is difficult to remove. The rest is clear.

original: Vicikicchāti vigatā cikicchā vicikicchā, sabhāvaṃ vā vicinanto kicchati kilamati
analyzed: vicikicchāti vigatā cikicchā vicikicchā sabhāvam vā vicinantaḥ kicchati kilamati
translated: Doubt is vicikicchā . The word kicchati is derived from the verb kicchati , which means “to be in need of something,” “to be in want of something,” “to be in want,” “to be in need.”

original: etāyāti vicikicchā. Sā saṃsayalakkhaṇā, kampanarasā, anicchayapaccupaṭṭhānā, anekaṃsaggāhapaccupaṭṭhānā
analyzed: etāya ati vicikicchā sā saṃsaya lakkhaṇā kampana rasā anicchaya paccupaṭṭhānā aneka saggāha paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: The word vicikicchā is derived from the verb kicchati in the sense of “to be in need of something” and from the noun vicikicchā in the sense of “doubt.” Doubt is characterized by vacillation. Its function is to waver. It is manifested as an inability to decide.

original: vā, ayonisomanasikārapadaṭṭhānā, paṭipattiyā antarāyakarāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: vā a yoniso manasikāra padaṭṭhānā paṭipattiyāḥ antarāya karā ti daṭṭhabbā
translated: Or it is manifested as the grasping of many sides. Its proximate cause is unwise reflection. It should be regarded as an obstruction to the practice of the path.

original: Kampanaṭṭhena dvidhā eḷayatīti dveḷhakaṃ. Paṭipattinivāraṇena dvidhāpatho viyāti
analyzed: kampana ṭṭhena dvidhā eḷayati iti dveḷhakam paṭipatti nivāraṇena dvidhā pathaḥ viyāti
translated: It is called twofold because it causes vacillation in two ways. It is called a fork in the road because it causes the path to be divided in two ways.

original: dvedhāpatho. “Niccaṃ vā idaṃ aniccaṃ vā”tiādipavattiyā ekasmiṃ ākāre saṇṭhātuṃ asamatthatāya
analyzed: dvedhā pathaḥ niccam vā idam aniccam vā ati ādi pavattiyā ekasmin ākāre saṇṭhātum a samattha tāya
translated: It is called doubt because it spreads out in all directions, being unable to settle down on a single aspect such as “permanent” or “impermanent.”

original: samantato setīti saṃsayo. Ekaṃsaṃ gahetuṃ asamatthatāya na ekaṃsaggāhoti anekaṃsaggāho.🔽Nicchetuṃ asakkontī ārammaṇato osakkatīti āsappanā. Ogāhituṃ asakkontī parisamantato
analyzed: samantataḥ seti iti saṃsayaḥ ekaṃsam gahetum a samattha tāya na ekaṃsa ggāho ti an ekaṃsa ggāho  nicchetum asakkontī ārammaṇataḥ osakkati iti āsappanā ogāhitum asakkontī parisamantataḥ
translated: It is called the grasping of many sides because it is unable to grasp a single side.

original: sappatīti parisappanā. Pariyogāhituṃ asamatthatāya apariyogāhaṇā. Nicchayavasena
analyzed: sappati iti parisappanā pariyogāhitum a samattha tāya a pariyogāhaṇā nicchaya vasena
translated: It is called indecision because it is unable to decide. It is called hesitation because it is unable to plunge in. It is called uncertainty because it is unable to be certain. It is called wavering because it is unable to be certain in the sense of being sure.

original: ārammaṇe pavattituṃ asamatthatāya chambhitattaṃ cittassa, thaddhabhāvoti attho. Vicikicchā🔽hi uppajjitvā cittaṃ thaddhaṃ karoti, yasmā pana sā uppajjamānā ārammaṇaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: ārammaṇe pavattitum asamattha tāya chambhita ttam cittassa thaddha bhāvaḥ ti atthaḥ vicikicchā  hi uppajjitvā cittam thaddham karoti yasmā pana sā uppajjamānā ārammaṇam gahetvā
translated: It is the state of the mind’s being frightened because it is incapable of occurring with respect to an object. The meaning is: it is the state of the mind’s being stiff.🔽For doubt, having arisen, makes the mind stiff. But because it arises as if it were scratching an object,

original: manaṃ vilikhantī viya, tasmā manovilekhoti vuttā.🔽Viddhoti sallena laddhappahāro. Phuṭṭhoti ghaṭṭito. Paretoti pīḷito. Dhāvatīti purato
analyzed: manam vilikhantī viya tasmā manovilekhā iti vuttā  viddhaḥ iti sallena laddha pahāro phuṭṭho ti ghaṭṭito paretaḥ iti pīḷitaḥ dhāvati iti puratas
translated: it is called “mental scratching.”

original: gacchati. Vidhāvatīti anekavidhena gacchati. Sandhāvatīti vegena dhāvati. Saṃsaratīti ito cito ca carati.🔽Acelakoti niccolo, naggoti attho. Muttācāroti visaṭṭhācāro, uccārakammādīsu lokiyakulaputtācārena
analyzed: gacchati vidhāvati iti anekavidhena gacchati sandhāvati iti vegena dhāvati saṃsarati iti ito cito ca carati  acelakaḥ ti niccolaḥ naggaḥ ti attho mutta ācāro ti visaṭṭha ācāraḥ uccāra kamma ādīsu lokiya kula putta ācārena
translated: “Pierced” : struck by a dart. “Touched” : struck. “Afflicted” : oppressed. “Runs” : goes forward. “Runs about” : goes in many ways. “Runs hither and thither” : it runs quickly. “Roams” : it moves here and there.

original: virahito ṭhitakova uccāraṃ karoti, passāvaṃ karoti, khādati bhuñjati. Hatthāpalekhanoti
analyzed: virahitaḥ uccāram karoti passāvam karoti khādati bhuñjati
