translated: and “having attained awakening.” “Awakening” is a synonym for “awakened.” Herein, just as a blue or red cloth is said to be “blue” or “red” because of the combination of the qualities of blueness or redness, so it is said that he is a “Buddha” because of the combination of the qualities of a Buddha.

original: Tato paraṃ buddhoti netaṃ nāmantiādi “atthamanugatā ayaṃ paññattī”ti ñāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: tatas param buddho ti na itam nāma nti ādi attham anugatā ayam paññattī iti ñāpana attham
translated: After that, the passage beginning “‘Buddha’ is not his name” is said in order to show that this designation is in accordance with the meaning.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha mittā sahāyā. Amaccā bhaccā. Ñātī pitupakkhikā. Sālohitā mātupakkhikā.
analyzed: vuttam tattha mittā sahāyāḥ amaccāḥ bhaccāḥ ñātī pitu pakkhikā sālohitā mātu pakkhikā
translated: Herein, friends are companions. Counsellors are advisers. Relatives are those on the father’s side. Kinsmen are those on the mother’s side.

original: Samaṇā pabbajjupagatā. Brāhmaṇā bhovādino, samitapāpabāhitapāpā vā. Devatā sakkādayo
analyzed: samaṇāḥ pabbajjupagatāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ bhovādino samitapāpa bāhitapāpāḥ vā devatā sakka ādayaḥ
translated: Ascetics are those who have gone forth. Brahmins are those who use the vocative “bhavam.” Or they are those who have expelled evil and removed evil. Gods are those such as Sakka.

original: brahmāno ca. Vimokkhantikanti vimokkho arahattamaggo, vimokkhassa anto arahattaphalaṃ,
analyzed: brahmānaḥ ca vimokkhantikanti vimokkhaḥ arahatta maggaḥ vimokkhassa antaḥ arahatta phalam
translated: and the Brahmas. The end of freedom: the path of arahatship is freedom; the fruit of arahatship is at the end of freedom;

original: tasmiṃ vimokkhante bhavaṃ vimokkhantikaṃ nāmaṃ. Sabbaññubhāvo hi arahattamaggena
analyzed: tasmin vimokkha ante bhavam vimokkhantikam nāmam sabbaññu bhāvaḥ hi arahatta maggena
translated: that existence is called “the end of freedom” . For the state of omniscience is accomplished by the path of arahatship;

original: sijjhati, arahattaphalodaye siddhaṃ hoti. Tasmā sabbaññubhāvo vimokkhante bhavo hoti.
analyzed: sijjhati arahatta phala udaye siddham hoti tasmā sabbaññu bhāvaḥ bhavaḥ hoti
translated: it is accomplished with the arising of the fruit of arahatship. Therefore the state of omniscience is the end of freedom.

original: Taṃ nemittikampi nāmaṃ vimokkhante bhavaṃ nāma hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “vimokkhantikametaṃ
analyzed: tat nemittikam pi nāmam vimokkha ante bhavam nāma hoti tena vuttam vimokkha antikam etam
translated: That name “the end of freedom” is also a name for the existence of the one who is free. Therefore it is said: “This is the end of freedom for the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones.”

original: buddhānaṃ bhagavantāna”nti. Bodhiyā mūle saha sabbaññutaññāṇassa paṭilābhāti mahābodhirukkhamūle
analyzed: buddhānam bhagavantānam ti bodhiyāḥ mūle saha sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa mahā bodhi rukkha mūle
translated: Together with the acquisition of the knowledge of omniscience at the root of the Bodhi tree: at the moment mentioned above, together with the acquisition of the knowledge of omniscience at the root of the Bodhi tree.

original: yathāvuttakkhaṇe sabbaññutaññāṇassa paṭilābhena saha. Sacchikā paññattīti arahattaphalasacchikiriyāya
analyzed: yathāvutta kkhaṇe sabbaññuta ññāṇassa paṭilābhena saha sacchikā paññatti iti arahatta phala sacchikiriyāya
translated: The proclamation of the discovery: the proclamation that arose through the discovery of the fruit of arahatship,

original: sabbadhammasacchikiriyāya vā jātā paññatti. Yadidaṃ buddhoti paññatti. Ayaṃ byañjanato
analyzed: sabba dhamma sacchikiriyāya vā jātā paññatti yat idam buddhaḥ iti paññatti ayam byañjanato
translated: or through the discovery of all dhammas, that is to say, the proclamation “He is the Buddha,” is the letter.

original: buddhavibhāvanā. Ito paraṃ vahassetaṃ bhāranti pariyosānaṃ tattha tattha vuttanayattā🔽yathāpāḷimeva niyyāti.
analyzed: buddha vibhāvanāḥ itas param vahassa etam bhāranti pariyosānam tattha tattha vutta naya ttā  yathāpāḷim eva niyyāti
translated: The rest of the verse is self-evident.

original: 193. Catutthagāthāya vijigucchatoti jātiādīhi aṭṭīyato. Rittamāsananti vivittaṃ mañcapīṭhaṃ. Pabbatānaṃ guhāsu vāti pabbataguhāsu vā rittamāsanaṃ bhajatoti sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha gāthāya vijigucchato ti jāti ādīhi aṭṭīyato rittam āsanam ti vivittam mañca pīṭham pabbatānam guhāsu vā ati pabbata guhāsu vā rittam āsanam bhajato ti sambandhitabbam
translated: In the fourth verse, “Who is disgusted with birth” : who is afraid of birth and so on. “A lonely lodging” : a solitary bed or chair. Or the construction may be made thus: “Who resorts to a lonely lodging in the caves of mountains.”

original: Jātiyā vijigucchatoti jātiṃ vijigucchato. Jarāya. Byādhinātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Bhajatoti🔽evamādīsu bhajatoti bhajantassa. Sevatoti sevantassa. Nisevatoti sammā sevantassa.
analyzed: jātiyā vijigucchato iti jātim vijigucchataḥ jarāya eṣa iva nayaḥ bhajatoti  evamādīsu bhajatoti bhajantassa sevatoti sevantassa nisevatoti sammā sevantassa
translated: “Who is disgusted with birth” : who is disgusted with birth. “With ageing” , etc., is to be construed in the same way. “Resorts to” :

original: Saṃsevatoti punappunaṃ sevantassa. Paṭisevatoti upagantvā sevantassa. Pabbatapabbhārāti pabbatakucchiyo.
analyzed: saṃsevato ti punappunam sevantassa paṭisevato ti upagantvā sevantassa pabbata pabbhārā ti pabbata kucchiyaḥ
translated: in such passages as “resorts to a lonely lodging” , “resorts to” means “frequents.” “Frequents” : “frequents” . “Approaches” : “approaches” . “Mountains and mountain caves” : mountain clefts.

original: 194. Pañcamagāthāya uccāvacesūti hīnapaṇītesu. Sayanesūti vihārādīsu senāsanesu. Kīvanto tattha bheravāti kittakā tattha bhayakāraṇā. “Kuvanto”tipi pāṭho, kūjantoti cassa attho.
analyzed: pañcama gāthāya uccāvacesu iti hīna paṇītesu sayanesu iti vihāra ādīsu senāsanesu kīvantaḥ tattha bheravā ti kittakā tattha bhaya kāraṇā kuvantaḥ iti pi pāṭhaḥ kūjantaḥ ti cassa attho
translated: In the fifth stanza, in the high and low: in the inferior and superior. In the beds: in the kinds of resting places such as monasteries. How many terrors there? How many causes of fear there? The reading “kuvanto” is also allowable, and its meaning is “crying.”

original: Kuvantoti saddāyanto. Kūjantoti abyattasaddaṃ karonto. Nadantoti ukkuṭṭhiṃ karonto.
analyzed: kuvantaḥ iti saddāyantaḥ kūjantaḥ iti abyatta saddam karontaḥ nadantaḥ iti ukkuṭṭhim karontaḥ
translated: “Kuvanto” is “making a noise.” “Kūjanto” is “making a confused noise.” “Nadanto” is “making a sound of distress.”

original: Saddaṃ karontoti vācaṃ bhāsanto. Katīti pucchā. Kittakāti pamāṇapucchā. Kīvatakāti🔽paricchedapucchā. Kīvabahukāti pamāṇaparicchedapucchā. Te bheravāti ete bhayajananupaddavā
analyzed: saddam karonto ti vācam bhāsanto kati iti pucchā kittakā ati pamāṇa pucchā kīvatakā ati  pariccheda pucchā kīva bahukā ati pamāṇa pariccheda pucchā te bheravā ati ete bhaya jananupaddavā
translated: “Saddaṃ karonto” is “speaking.” “Kati” is a question word. “Kittaka” is a word for a measure. “Kīvataka” is a🔽question word for a limit. “Kīvabahuka” is a question word for a measure and a limit. These terrors: these causes of fear, these calamities,

original: bhayārammaṇā. Kīvabahukāti pucchite ārammaṇe dassetuṃ “sīhā byagghā dīpī”tiādīhi vissajjeti.🔽195. Chaṭṭhagāthāya kati parissayāti kittakā upaddavā. Agataṃ disanti nibbānaṃ. Tañhi
analyzed: bhaya ārammaṇā kīvabahukā ati pucchite ārammaṇe dassetum sīhāḥ byagghāḥ dīpī iti ādīhi vissajja iti  chaṭṭhagāthāya kati parissayā ati kittakāḥ upaddavāḥ agatam disanti nibbānam tat hi
translated: these objects of fear. When the question “kīvabahuka” is asked about the object, he answers it with “siha byagghā dīpī” .

original: agatapubbattā agataṃ, niddisitabbato disā cāti. Tena vuttaṃ – “agataṃ disa”nti. Amataṃ
analyzed: agata pubba ttā agatam niddisitabbataḥ disā ca ati tena vuttam agatam disanti amatam
translated: In the sixth stanza, how many dangers? How many calamities? The unvisited direction: Nibbāna. For that is the unvisited because it has not been visited before, and it is the direction because it is to be shown. Hence it was said: “The unvisited direction.” The deathless

original: disa”ntipi pāṭho. Abhisambhaveti abhisambhaveyya. Pantamhīti pariyante.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ abhisambhava iti pariyante
translated: Pantamhīti pariyante .🔽Agatapubbā sā disāti yā disā supinantenapi na gatapubbā.🔽Na sā disā gatapubbāti esā disā vuttanayena na gatapubbā.

original: Agatapubbā sā disāti yā disā supinantenapi na gatapubbā. Na sā disā gatapubbāti esā disā vuttanayena na gatapubbā. Iminā dīghena addhunāti anena dīghakālena.
analyzed: a gata pubbā sā disā ati yā disā supin antena api na gata pubbā na sā disā gata pubbā ati esā disā vutta nayena na gata pubbā iminā dīghena addhunā ati anena dīgha kālena
translated: Iminā dīghena addhunāti anena dīghakālena.🔽Samatittikanti antomukhavaṭṭilekhaṃ pāpetvā samabharitaṃ.

original: Samatittikanti antomukhavaṭṭilekhaṃ pāpetvā samabharitaṃ. Anavasekanti anavasiñcanakaṃ
analyzed: sama tittikam ti antar mukha vaṭṭi lekham pāpetvā sama bharitam an avasekam ti an avasiñcanakam
translated: Anavasekanti anavasiñcanakaṃ🔽aparisiñcanakaṃ katvā.🔽Telapattanti pakkhittatelaṃ telapattaṃ.

original: aparisiñcanakaṃ katvā. Telapattanti pakkhittatelaṃ telapattaṃ. Parihareyyāti hareyya
analyzed: a parisiñcanakam katvā tela pattam ti pakkhitta telam tela pattam parihareyya ati hareyya
translated: Parihareyyāti hareyya🔽ādāya gaccheyya.

original: ādāya gaccheyya. Evaṃ sacittamanurakkheti taṃ telabharitaṃ pattaṃ viya attano cittaṃ
analyzed: ādāya gaccheyya evam sa cittam anurakkheti tam tela bharitam pattam viya attano cittam
translated: Evaṃ sacittamanurakkheti taṃ telabharitaṃ pattaṃ viya attano cittaṃ

original: kāyagatāya satiyā gocare ceva sampayuttasatiyā cāti ubhinnaṃ antare pakkhipitvā yathā
analyzed: kāya gatāya satiyā gocare ca iva sampayutta satiyā ca ati ubhinnam antare pakkhipitvā yathā
translated: kāyagatāya satiyā gocare ceva sampayuttasatiyā cāti ubhinnaṃ antare pakkhipitvā yathā

original: muhuttampi bahiddhā gocare na vikkhipati, tathā paṇḍito yogāvacaro rakkheyya gopayeyya.
analyzed: muhuttam pi bahiddhā gocare na vikkhipati tathā paṇḍitaḥ yogāvacaraḥ rakkheyya gopayeyya
translated: muhuttampi bahiddhā gocare na vikkhipati, tathā paṇḍito yogāvacaro rakkheyya gopayeyya.

original: Kiṃkāraṇā? Etassa hi –
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā etassa hi
translated: Kiṃkāraṇā? Etassa hi –

original: “Dunniggahassa lahuno, yatthakāmanipātino;
analyzed: dunniggahassa lahunaḥ yattha kāma nipātinaḥ
translated: “Hard to curb, light, ever darting away,

original: Cittassa damatho sādhu, cittaṃ dantaṃ sukhāvahaṃ”. ;
analyzed: cittassa damatho sādhu cittam dantam sukha āvaham
translated: The mind is tamed by the wise, and the tamed mind brings happiness.”

original: Tasmā –
analyzed: tasmai
translated: Therefore:

original: “Sududdasaṃ sunipuṇaṃ, yatthakāmanipātinaṃ;
analyzed: su duddasam su nipuṇam yattha kāma nipātinam
translated: “Hard to see, subtle, ever darting away,

original: Cittaṃ rakkhetha medhāvī, cittaṃ guttaṃ sukhāvahaṃ”. ;
analyzed: cittam rakkhetha medhāvī cittam guttam sukha āvaham
translated: The wise man should guard the mind, for the guarded mind brings happiness.”

original: Idañhi –
analyzed: idam hi
translated: For this:

original: “Dūraṅgamaṃ ekacaraṃ, asarīraṃ guhāsayaṃ;
analyzed: dūraṅgamam eka caram a sarīram guhā sayam
translated: “Far-ranging, solitary, bodiless, lying in ambush,

original: Ye cittaṃ saṃyamessanti, mokkhanti mārabandhanā”. ;
analyzed: ye cittam saṃyamessanti mokkhanti māra bandhanā
translated: Those who will restrain the mind are freed from Mara’s bonds.”

original: Itarassa pana –
analyzed: itarassa pana
translated: But for the other:

original: “Anavaṭṭhitacittassa, saddhammaṃ avijānato;
analyzed: an avaṭṭhita cittassa saddhammam a vijānataḥ
translated: “For one whose mind is not steady, who does not know the true Dhamma,

original: Pariplavapasādassa, paññā na paripūrati”. ;
analyzed: pariplava pasādassa paññā na paripūrati
translated: Whose confidence is fickle, wisdom does not grow to perfection.”

original: Thirakammaṭṭhānasahāyassa pana –
analyzed: thira kammaṭṭhāna sahāyassa pana
translated: But for one who has a firm meditation subject and a friend:

original: “Anavassutacittassa, ananvāhatacetaso;
analyzed: an avassuta cittassa an anvāhata cetasaḥ
translated: “For one whose mind is not defiled, whose heart is not full of hate,

original: Puññapāpapahīnassa, natthi jāgarato bhayaṃ”. ;
analyzed: puñña pāpa pahīnassa na atthi jāgarataḥ bhayam
translated: Who has abandoned both merit and evil, there is no fear while waking or sleeping.”

original: Tasmā etaṃ –
analyzed: tasmai etam
translated: Therefore:

original: “Phandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ, dūrakkhaṃ dunnivārayaṃ;
analyzed: phandanam capalam cittam dūrakkham dunnivārayam
translated: “The mind is restless, unsteady, ever darting away, hard to guard, hard to tie,

original: Ujuṃ karoti medhāvī, usukārova tejanaṃ”. ;
analyzed: ujum karoti medhāvī usukārāḥ uva tejanam
translated: But the wise man restrains it, as a fletcher straightens an arrow.”

original: Evaṃ ujuṃ karonto sacittamanurakkhe.
analyzed: evam ujum karontaḥ sa cittam anurakkhe
translated: Thus he should guard his mind by keeping it straight.

original: Patthayāno disaṃ agatapubbanti imasmiṃ kāyagatāsatikammaṭṭhāne kammaṃ ārabhitvā anamatagge
analyzed: patthayānaḥ disam a gata pubbanti imasmim kāya gata asati kammaṭṭhāne kammam ārabhitvā anamatagge
translated: Seeking the quarter never sought before: the meaning is that he should guard his own mind in the way already described while seeking the quarter never sought before in the beginningless round of rebirths, having begun work on this meditation subject of mindfulness of the body.

original: saṃsāre agatapubbaṃ disaṃ patthento vuttanayena sakaṃ cittaṃ rakkheyyāti attho. Kā panesā disā nāma –
analyzed: saṃsāre agata pubbam disam patthentaḥ vutta nayena sakam cittam rakkheyya ati attho kā pana esā disā nāma
translated: But what is this “quarter” ?🔽“East is the quarter of one’s mother and father,

original: “Mātāpitā disā pubbā, ācariyā dakkhiṇā disā;
analyzed: mātā pitā disā pubbā ācariyāḥ dakkhiṇāḥ disā
translated: South the quarter of one’s teacher,🔽West the quarter of one’s wife,

original: Puttadārā disā pacchā, mittāmaccā ca uttarā.
analyzed: puttadārā disā pacchā mittāmaccā ca uttarā
translated: North the quarter of one’s friends,🔽“Below is the quarter of servants and workers,

original: “Dāsakammakarā heṭṭhā, uddhaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇā;
analyzed: dāsa kamma karāḥ heṭṭhā uddham samaṇa brāhmaṇā
translated: Above the quarter of brahmans;🔽One should honour these quarters

original: Etā disā namasseyya, alamatto kule gihī”ti. –
analyzed: etāḥ disā namasseyya alam attaḥ kule gihi iti
translated: As a householder with wealth. ”

original: Ettha tāva mātāpitādayo “disā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: ettha tāva mātā pitā ādayaḥ disā iti vuttā
translated: Here the mother and so on are called “the quarter.”🔽“The four quarters and the four intermediate directions,

original: “Disā catasso vidisā catasso, uddhaṃ adho dasa disā imāyo;
analyzed: disā catassaḥ vidisā catassaḥ uddham adhas dasa disāḥ
translated: The zenith and the nadir: these are the ten directions.🔽In which direction does the king of nāgas stand,

original: Katamaṃ disaṃ tiṭṭhati nāgarājā, yamaddasā supine chabbisāṇa”nti. –
analyzed: katamam disam tiṭṭhati nāga rājā yamaddasā supine
translated: Who in his dreams sees the six-tusked one? ”

original: Ettha puratthimādibhedā disāva “disā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: ettha puratthima ādi bhedā disā ava disā ti vuttā
translated: Here the eastern direction and so on are called “the quarter.”

original: “Agārino annadapānavatthadā, avhāyikā tampi disaṃ vadanti;
analyzed: agārinaḥ anna da pāna vattha dāḥ a vhāyikā tam pi disam vadanti
translated: “The quarter that gives food and drink and clothes,

original: Esā disā paramā setaketu, yaṃ patvā dukkhī sukhino bhavantī”ti. –🔽Ettha nibbānaṃ “disa”nti vuttaṃ. Idhāpi tadeva adhippetaṃ. Taṇhakkhayaṃ virāgantiādīhi
analyzed: esā disā paramā seta ketu yam patvā dukkhī sukhinaḥ bhavanti iti  ettha nibbānam disanti vuttam idha api tat eva adhippetam taṇha kkhayam virāga nti ādīhi
translated: This is the supreme direction, the banner of the white umbrella, Having reached which, the sorrowful become happy.”🔽Herein, Nibbāna is called the “direction.” Here too it is that which is intended. It is seen and not seen by the ending of craving, by fading away, by cessation, by stilling, by Nibbāna.

original: dissati apadissati tasmā “disā”ti vuccati. Anamatagge pana saṃsāre kenaci bālaputhujjanena🔽supinenapi agatapubbatāya “agatapubbā disā nāmā”ti vuccati. Taṃ patthayantena kāyagatāsatiyā
analyzed: dissati apadissati tasmā disā ti vuccati anamatagge pana saṃsāre kenaci bāla puthujjanena  supinena api a gatapubba tāya a gata pubbā disā nāma ati vuccati tam patthayantena kāya gata asatiyā
translated: Therefore it is called the “direction.” But in the beginningless round of rebirths no fool or ordinary man has ever gone there even in a dream.🔽Therefore it is called the “undirected direction.” One who aspires to reach it should do so by means of mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: yogo karaṇīyoti. Vajatotiādīsu ettha magguppādato samīpaṃ vajato. Ṭhitikkhaṇe gacchato.
analyzed: yogo karaṇīyaḥ ti vajato ti ādīsu ettha magga uppādato samīpam vajato ṭhiti kkhaṇe gacchato
translated: As to “going, etc.,” here the “direction” is near to the arising of the path, it is gone to at the moment of its presence,

original: Phalodayato atikkamato.
analyzed: phala udayataḥ atikkamataḥ
translated: it is gone beyond at the arising of fruition.🔽“End” is at the end. “Middle” is in the middle. “Limit” is at the limit.

original: Anteti antamhi ṭhite. Panteti vanagahanagambhīre ṭhite. Pariyanteti dūrabhāvena pariyante🔽ṭhite. Selanteti pabbatānaṃ ante. Vananteti vanaghaṭānaṃ ante. Nadanteti nadīnaṃ
analyzed: anta iti antamhi ṭhite pantā iti vana gahana gambhīre ṭhite pariyantā iti dūra bhāvena pariyante 🔽ṭhite selantā iti pabbatānam ante vanantā iti vana ghaṭānam ante nadantā iti nadīnam
translated: “Cliff” is at the edge of a rock. “Forest” is in the middle of a forest.

original: ante. Udakanteti udakānaṃ pariyante. Yattha na kasīyati na vapīyatīti yasmiṃ kasanañca
analyzed: ante udakantā iti udakānam pariyante yattha na kasīyati na vapīyati iti yasmin kasanam ca
translated: At the end: at the end of the waters. Where no ploughshare turns: where no ploughing is done,

original: vapanañca na karīyati. Janantaṃ atikkamitvā ṭhite. Manussānaṃ anupacāreti kasanavapanavasena
analyzed: vapanam ca na karīyati janantam atikkamitvā ṭhite manussānam an upacāreti kasana vapana vasena
translated: where no seed is sown. Standing after crossing over the generation: standing in a monastery not frequented by people,

original: manussehi anupacaritabbe senāsane.
analyzed: manussehi an upacaritabbe senāsane
translated: after crossing over the generation that ploughs and sows.

original: 196. Sattamagāthāya kyāssa byappathayo assūti kidisāni tassa vacanāni assu.
analyzed: sattama gāthāya assu iti kidisāni tassa vacanāni assu
translated: In the seventh verse, what sort of speech will he have?

original: Musāvādaṃ pahāyāti ettha musāti visaṃvādanapurekkhārassa atthabhañjanako vacīpayogo🔽kāyapayogo vā. Visaṃvādanādhippāyena panassa paravisaṃvādakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā🔽cetanā musāvādo. Aparo nayo – musāti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu, vādoti tassa bhūtato
analyzed: musāvādam pahāya ati ettha musā ati visaṃvādana purekkhārassa attha bhañjanakaḥ vacī payogaḥ  kāya payogaḥ vā visaṃvādana adhippāyena pana assa para visaṃvādaka kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā  cetanā musāvādaḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ musā ati abhūtam ataccham vatthu vādo ti tassa bhūtataḥ
translated: Having abandoned false speech: here, “false” is a verbal expression or bodily act that breaks the meaning of what is said

original: tacchato viññāpanaṃ. Lakkhaṇato pana atathaṃ vatthuṃ tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa
analyzed: tacchataḥ viññāpanam lakkhaṇato pana atatham vatthum tathatas param viññāpetu kāmassa
translated: with the intention to deceive. But the intention that originates the bodily and verbal acts of deceiving another is false speech. Another method: “false” is an unreal, untrue matter; “speech” is the making known of that as real and true. But in terms of its characteristics, it is the intention of one who wishes to make known to another🔽an unreal matter as real and true.

original: tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo. So yamatthaṃ bhañjati, tassa appatāya🔽appasāvajjo, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Api ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ attano santakaṃ adātukāmatāya
analyzed: tathā viññatti samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ saḥ yam attham bhañjati tassa appa tāya  appa sāvajjaḥ mahanta tāya mahāsāvajjaḥ api ca gaha ṭṭhānam attanaḥ santakam a dātu kāma tāya
translated: So too, the volition that originates the intimation is lying.🔽If the thing he lies about is of little value, the offence is less serious; if it is of great value, the offence is more serious.

original: “natthī”tiādinayappavatto appasāvajjo, sakkhinā hutvā atthabhañjanatthaṃ vutto mahāsāvajjo.🔽Pabbajitānaṃ appakampi telaṃ vā sappiṃ vā labhitvā hasādhippāyena “ajja gāme telaṃ🔽nadī maññe sandatī”ti pūraṇakathānayena pavatto appasāvajjo, adiṭṭhaṃyeva pana diṭṭhantiādinā
analyzed: natthi iti ādi naya ppavattaḥ appasāvajjo sakkhinā hutvā attha bhañjana attham vuttaḥ mahāsāvajjo  pabbajitānam appakampi telam vā sappim vā labhitvā hasa adhippāyena ajja gāme telam  nadī maññe sandati iti pūraṇa kathā nayena pavattaḥ appasāvajjaḥ adiṭṭham yeva pana diṭṭha nti ādinā
translated: Moreover, in the case of householders, lying that is not giving what is one’s own is less serious; lying that is giving what is not one’s own is more serious.🔽In the case of those gone forth, lying that is mere talk, such as saying, “Today in the village oil was cheap, the river was in spate, it seems,” and so on, out of a desire to laugh, is less serious; but lying that is giving evidence after becoming a witness is more serious.

original: nayena vadantānaṃ mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: nayena vadantānam mahāsāvajjaḥ
translated: And lying that is saying, “I have seen what was not seen,” and so on, is more serious still.

original: Tassa cattāro sambhārā honti – atathaṃ vatthu visaṃvādanacittaṃ tajjo vāyāmo parassa
analyzed: tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ honti atatham vatthu visaṃvādana cittam tad jaḥ vā āyāmaḥ parassa
translated: It has four constituents: the untrue thing, the intention to deceive, the effort belonging with that, and the other’s understanding of what was said.

original: tadatthavijānananti. Eko payogo sāhatthikova. So ca kāyena vā kāyapaṭibaddhena vā
analyzed: tad attha vijānanam ti ekaḥ payogo sāhatthikaḥ uva saḥ ca kāyena vā kāya paṭibaddhena vā
translated: There is one method of procedure, namely, by one’s own person or by what is connected with one’s person.

original: vācāya vā paravisaṃvādakakiriyākaraṇe daṭṭhabbo. Tāya ce kiriyāya paro tamatthaṃ
analyzed: vācāya vā para visaṃvādaka kiriyā karaṇe daṭṭhabbo tāya ce kiriyāya paraḥ tam attham
translated: or by speech, in the act of deceiving another. And if, by that act, another person

original: jānāti, ayaṃ kiriyasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanākkhaṇeyeva musāvādakammunā bajjhati.
analyzed: jānāti ayam kiriya samuṭṭhāpikā musāvāda kammunā bajjhati
translated: Or it can be seen as the performance of the action of deceiving another by speech. If the other person understands the meaning of the action, then at the moment of the volition that instigates the action, the person is bound by the kamma of false speech.

original: Saccaṃ vadatīti saccavādī. Saccena saccaṃ sandahati ghaṭetīti saccasandho, na antarantarā
analyzed: saccam vadati iti sacca vādī saccena saccam sandahati ghaṭa iti iti sacca sandhaḥ na antar antarā
translated: He speaks truth: saccaṃ vadeti = saccavādi. He joins truth to truth by means of truth: saccena saccaṃ sandhāyati = saccasandho. The meaning is: he does not speak falsehood in between .

original: musā vadatīti attho. Yo hi puriso kadāci musā vadati, kadāci saccaṃ, tassa musāvādena🔽antarikatāya saccaṃ saccena na ghaṭiyati, tasmā na so saccasandho. Ayaṃ pana na tādiso,
analyzed: musā vadati iti atthaḥ yaḥ hi puriso kadāci musā vadati kadāci saccam tassa musāvādena  antarikatāya saccam saccena na tasmā na saḥ sacca sandho ayam pana na tādiso
translated: For when a person sometimes speaks falsehood and sometimes truth, his truth is not joined to truth by means of truth because of the admixture of falsehood.

original: jīvitahetupi musā avatvā saccena saccaṃ sandahatiyevāti saccasandho.
analyzed: musā avatvā saccena saccam sandahatiyā iva ati sacca sandho
translated: But this person is not like that; he joins truth to truth without ever speaking falsehood even for the sake of his life. Thus he is saccasandho.

original: Thetoti thiro, thirakathoti attho. Eko puggalo haliddirāgo viya thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇu
analyzed: theto ti thiraḥ thira kathaḥ ti attho ekaḥ puggalaḥ haliddi rāgaḥ viya thusa rāsimhi
translated: Firm: theto = thiro. The meaning is: he is a firm speaker. One person is not a firm speaker like a turmeric root, a post buried in a heap of straw,

original: viya assapiṭṭhe ṭhapitakumbhaṇḍamiva ca na thirakatho hoti. Eko pāsāṇalekhā viya
analyzed: viya assa piṭṭhe ṭhapita kumbhaṇḍam iva ca na thira kathaḥ hoti ekaḥ pāsāṇa lekhā viya
translated: or a water pot placed on the back of a donkey. Another is not a firm speaker like a line drawn on stone,

original: indakhīlo viya ca thirakatho hoti, asinā sīsaṃ chindantepi dvekathā na katheti. Ayaṃ vuccati theto.🔽Paccayikoti pattiyāyitabbo, saddhāyitabbakoti attho. Ekacco hi puggalo na paccayiko
analyzed: indakhīlaḥ viya ca thira kathaḥ hoti asinā sīsam chindante pi dvekathā na kathā iti ayam vuccati  paccayikaḥ ti pattiyāyitabbaḥ saddhāyitabbakaḥ ti attho ekaccaḥ hi puggalaḥ na paccayikaḥ
translated: He is firm in speech like an indakhīla, and even if his head were being cut off with a sword he would not speak two words. This is called truthfulness.

original: hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “mā tassa vacanaṃ saddahathā”ti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte mā tassa vacanam saddahatha ati vattabbatam
translated: He is a person who should be relied on, who should be trusted, is the meaning. For one kind of person is not a person who should be relied on. When it is said, “So-and-so said this,” he is one who should be told, “Do not trust his word.”

original: āpajjati. Eko paccayiko hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “yadi tena vuttaṃ,
analyzed: āpajjati ekaḥ paccayikaḥ hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte yadi tena vuttam
translated: Another is a person who should be relied on. When it is said, “So-and-so said this,” he is one who should be told, “If he said it,

original: idameva pamāṇaṃ, idāni upaparikkhitabbaṃ natthi, evameva ida”nti vattabbataṃ āpajjati,
analyzed: idam eva pamāṇam idāni upaparikkhitabbam na atthi evam eva idam ti vattabba tam āpajjati
translated: that is the measure. There is no need to investigate further. It must be so.”

original: ayaṃ vuccati paccayiko. Avisaṃvādako lokassāti tāya saccavāditāya lokaṃ na visaṃvādetīti attho.
analyzed: ayam vuccati paccayikaḥ a visaṃvādakaḥ lokassa ati tāya sacca vādi tāya lokam na visaṃvādeti iti attho
translated: He does not deceive the world by means of that truthfulness.

original: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāyātiādīsu yāya vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tassa hadaye attano
analyzed: pisuṇam vācam pahāya ati ādīsu vācāya yassa tam vācam bhāsati tassa hadaye
translated: Abandoning malicious speech: by means of the speech by which he speaks that speech, in the heart of the one to whom he speaks that speech,

original: piyabhāvaṃ parassa ca suññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇavācā. Yāya pana attānampi parampi
analyzed: piya bhāvam parassa ca suñña bhāvam karoti sā pisuṇa vācā yāya pana attānam pi param pi
translated: and it makes the other person’s affection for the one who is spoken about disappear, that is malicious speech.

original: pharusaṃ karoti, yā vācā sayampi pharusā, neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayaṅgamā, ayaṃ pharusavācā.
analyzed: pharusam karoti yā vācā sayam pi pharusā na iva kaṇṇa sukhā na hadayaṅgamā ayam pharusa vācā
translated: But the speech that hurts both oneself and another, or that is itself harsh, unpleasant to the ear and grating to the heart, is harsh speech.

original: Yena samphaṃ palapati niratthakaṃ, so samphappalāpo. Tesaṃ mūlabhūtāpi cetanā pisuṇavācādināmameva
analyzed: yena sampham palapati niratthakam so sampha ppalāpaḥ tesam mūla bhūtā api cetanā pisuṇa vācā ādi nāmam eva
translated: The mental volition that is the root cause of that is called malicious speech, etc.,

original: labhati, sā eva idha adhippetāti.
analyzed: labhati sā eva idha adhippetā ati
translated: and it is that that is intended here.

original: Tattha saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa paresaṃ vā bhedāya attano piyakamyatāya vā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: tattha saṃkiliṭṭha cittassa paresam vā bhedāya attanaḥ piya kamyatāya vā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: Herein, malicious speech is the mental volition that occurs in a defiled mind to divide others or to endear oneself to others by means of body or speech.

original: cetanā pisuṇavācā. Sā yassa bhedaṃ karoti, tassa appaguṇatāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā.🔽Tassā cattāro sambhārā honti – bhinditabbo paro, “iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissantī”ti
analyzed: cetanā pisuṇa vācā sā yassa bhedam karoti tassa appaguṇa tāya appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā  tassā cattāro sambhārāḥ honti bhinditabbaḥ paraḥ iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissanti iti
translated: It is less blameworthy when the person divided has few good qualities, and more blameworthy when he has great qualities.🔽It has four constituents: another to be divided,

original: bhedapurekkhāratā vā, “iti ahaṃ piyo bhavissāmi vissāsiko”ti piyakamyatā vā, tajjo
analyzed: bheda purekkhāra tā vā iti aham piyaḥ bhavissāmi vissāsikaḥ iti piya kamya tā vā tajjo
translated: the intention to divide them by thinking, “So they will be divided, they will be estranged,” or the desire to endear oneself by thinking, “So I shall be dear to them, I shall be loved,”

original: vāyāmo, tassa tadatthavijānananti.
analyzed: vāyāmaḥ
translated: and the energy of one who knows the meaning of that.

original: Imesaṃ bhedāyāti yesaṃ itoti vuttānaṃ santike sutaṃ, tesaṃ bhedāya. Bhinnānaṃ vā
analyzed: imesam bhedāya ati yesam itas ti vuttānam santike sutam tesam bhedāya bhinnānam vā
translated: For the sake of their division: for the sake of dividing those from whom one has heard it in the vicinity.

original: sandhātāti dvinnaṃ mittānaṃ vā samānupajjhāyakādīnaṃ vā kenacideva kāraṇena bhinnānaṃ
analyzed: sandhātā ati dvinnam mittānam vā samāna upajjhāyaka ādīnam vā kenacid eva kāraṇena bhinnānam
translated: For the sake of their union: for the sake of uniting two friends or two pupils of the same teacher who have been divided for some reason.

original: ekamekaṃ upasaṅkamitvā “tumhākaṃ īdise kule jātānaṃ evaṃ bahussutānaṃ idaṃ na yutta”ntiādīni🔽vatvā sandhānaṃ kattā. Anuppadātāti sandhānānuppadātā, dve jane samagge disvā “tumhākaṃ
analyzed: ekam ekam upasaṅkamitvā tumhākam īdise kule jātānam evam bahu sutānam idam na yutta nti ādīni  vatvā sandhānam kattā anuppadātā ati sandhāna anuppadātā dve jane samagge disvā tumhākam
translated: Approaching each one separately, one should say, “This is not proper for those born in such and such a family, who are so learned,” etc.,

original: evarūpe kule jātānaṃ evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānaṃ anucchavikameta”ntiādīni vatvā
analyzed: evarūpe kule jātānam evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānam anucchavikam etat ti ādīni vatvā
translated: and so effect their union. For the sake of their non-arising: for the sake of preventing their arising. Seeing two people in harmony, one should say, “This is becoming for those born in such and such a family, who possess such and such qualities,” etc.,

original: daḷhīkammaṃ kattāti attho.🔽Samaggo ārāmo assāti samaggārāmo, yattha samaggā natthi, tattha vasitumpi na icchatīti
analyzed: daḷhīkammam kattā iti attho  samaggaḥ ārāmaḥ assa ati samagga ārāmaḥ yattha samaggā natthi tattha vasitum pi naḥ icchati iti
translated: and so strengthen their bond.

original: attho. “Samaggarāmo”tipi pāḷi, ayamevattho. Samaggaratoti samaggesu rato, te pahāya
analyzed: atthaḥ samagga rāmaḥ tipi ayam eva atthaḥ samagga rataḥ ti samaggesu rataḥ te pahāya
translated: He delights in harmony: he delights in harmony, the meaning is that he does not wish to live where there is no harmony. The reading is also “samaggarāmo,” with the same meaning. He delights in those who delight in harmony: he delights in those who delight in harmony, having abandoned those who do not delight in harmony.

original: aññatra gantumpi na icchatīti attho. Samagge disvāpi sutvāpi nandatīti samagganandī.
analyzed: aññatra gantum pi na icchati iti samagga nandī
translated: The meaning is, he does not want to go elsewhere even when he sees or hears that there is a schism. He delights in unity: he delights in unity when he sees or hears of it.

original: Samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti yā vācā satte samaggeyeva karoti, taṃ sāmaggiguṇaparidīpakameva🔽vācaṃ bhāsati, na itaranti.
analyzed: samagga karaṇim vācam bhāsitā ati yā vācā satte samaggeya iva karoti tam sāmaggi guṇa paridīpakam eva  vācam bhāsati naḥ itaranti
translated: He speaks speech that leads to unity: he speaks speech that reveals the special qualities of unity,🔽not the other kind.

original: Parassa mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā ekantapharusacetanā pharusavācā.🔽Mammacchedakopi payogo cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti. Mātāpitaro hi kadāci puttake🔽evampi vadanti “corā vo khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ karontū”ti, uppalapattampi ca nesaṃ upari
analyzed: parassa ekanta pharusa cetanā pharusa vācā  payogo citta saṇhatāya pharusa vācā na hoti mātā pitaraḥ hi kadāci  evam pi vadanti corāḥ vaḥ khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam karontu uti uppala pattam pi upari
translated: Harsh speech is the intention to be utterly harsh that occurs as the instigation to the bodily and verbal actions of cutting off another’s life.🔽The instigation to cut off another’s life is not harsh speech, because it is associated with the mind. For parents sometimes say to their children, “Let thieves cut you limb from limb,”

original: patantaṃ na icchanti. Ācariyupajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evaṃ vadanti “kiṃ ime ahirikā
analyzed: patantam na icchanti ācariya upajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evam vadanti kim ime ahirikā
translated: and they do not want even a lotus leaf to fall on them. And teachers and preceptors sometimes say to their pupils, “What is the use of these shameless,🔽immoral rascals? Drive them out,”

original: anottappino caranti, niddhamatha ne”ti. Atha ca nesaṃ āgamādhigamasampattiṃ icchanti.
analyzed: caranti caranti atha ca āgama adhigama sampattim icchanti
translated: and yet they want them to acquire the scriptures and the realizations.

original: Yathā ca cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti, evaṃ vacanasaṇhatāya apharusavācāpi🔽na hoti. Na hi mārāpetukāmassa “imaṃ sukhaṃ sayāpethā”ti vacanaṃ apharusavācā hoti,
analyzed: yathā ca citta saṇhatāya pharusa vācā na evam vacana saṇhatāya a pharusa vācā api  na hoti na hi māra apetu kāmassa imam sukham vacanam a pharusa vācā hoti
translated: And just as harsh speech is not so when the mind is gentle, so too abusive speech is not so when the words are gentle. For when one who wants to have someone killed says, “Let him lie on a comfortable bed,” his words are not abusive speech.

original: cittapharusatāya panesā pharusavācāva, sā yaṃ sandhāya pavattitā. Tassa appaguṇatāya
analyzed: citta pharusa tāya pana isā pharusa vācā ava sā yam sandhāya tassa appaguṇa tāya
translated: But it is abusive speech when it is uttered with a mind that is harsh. It is less blameworthy when the person to whom it is uttered has few good qualities,

original: appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā tayo sambhārā – akkositabbo paro kupitacittaṃ akkosanāti.
analyzed: appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā tassā tayo sambhārā akkositabbo parassa kupita cittam
translated: and more blameworthy when he has great qualities. It has three constituents: the other person is one who should be abused, one is angry, and one abuses.

original: Nelāti elaṃ vuccati doso, nāssā elanti nelā, niddosāti attho. “Nelaṅgo setapacchādo”ti
analyzed: na ilā ti elam vuccati dosaḥ na assā elanti na ilā niddosā ati attho na ilaṅgo seta pacchādo ti
translated: “Free from elan” : elan is hate; it is free from that, thus it is elan-free . The meaning is, without hate. As it is said, “Elan-free, with white behind” .

original: ettha vuttanelaṃ viya. Kaṇṇasukhāti byañjanamadhuratāya kaṇṇānaṃ sukhā, sūcivijjhanaṃ
analyzed: ettha vutta nelam viya byañjana madhura tāya kaṇṇānam sukhā
translated: “Pleasant to the ear” : it is pleasant to the ears because of the sweetness of the words, like a well-turned phrase. It does not produce a pain in the ears.

original: viya kaṇṇasūlaṃ na janeti. Atthamadhuratāya sakalasarīre kopaṃ ajanetvā pemaṃ janetīti
analyzed: viya kaṇṇa sūlam na janeti attha madhura tāya sakala sarīre kopam a janetvā pa imam janeti iti
translated: Because of the sweetness of the meaning, it does not produce anger in the whole body, but it produces love.

original: pemaniyā. Hadayaṃ gacchati apaṭihaññamānā sukhena cittaṃ pavisatīti hadayaṅgamā.
analyzed: pemaniyāḥ hadayam gacchati a paṭihaññamānā sukhena cittam pavisati iti hadayaṅgamā
translated: “Going to the heart” : it enters the mind easily without being repelled.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇatāya pure bhavāti porī. Pure saṃvaddhanārī viya sukumārātipi porī. Purassa🔽esātipi porī, nagaravāsīnaṃ kathāti attho. Nagaravāsino hi yuttakathā honti, pitimattaṃ🔽pitāti bhātimattaṃ bhātāti vadanti. Evarūpī kathā bahuno janassa kantā hotīti bahujanakantā.
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa tāya pure bhavāti porī pure porī purassa  porī nagara vāsīnam kathā ati atthaḥ nagara vāsinaḥ hi yutta kathāḥ honti  pitā ati bhātimattam bhātā ati vadanti evarūpī kathā bahunaḥ janassa kantā hoti iti bahu jana kantā
translated: “She is a lady” : she is a lady because she is perfect in good qualities. Or alternatively, she is a lady because she is tender, like a woman brought up in luxury. Or alternatively, she is a lady because she is the foremost of those who live in a city. The meaning is: she is the talk of the city-dwellers. For the city-dwellers are talkative. They say: “So-and-so is a father, so-and-so is a mother, so-and-so is a brother, so-and-so is a sister.” Such talk is dear to many people, thus it is “dear to many people.”🔽🔽

original: Kantabhāveneva bahuno janassa manāpā cittavuḍḍhikarāti bahujanamanāpā.🔽Anatthaviññāpikā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā samphappalāpo. So āsevanamandatāya🔽appasāvajjo, āsevanamahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Tassa dve sambhārā – bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādiniratthakakathā🔽purekkhāratā, tathārūpīkathākathanañca.🔽Kālena vadatīti kālavādī, vattabbayuttakālaṃ sallakkhetvā vadatīti attho. Bhūtaṃ
analyzed: kanta bhāvena iva bahunaḥ janassa manāpā citta vuḍḍhi karā ati bahu jana manāpā 🔽anattha viññāpikā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā akusala cetanā samphappalāpaḥ saḥ āsevana manda tāya 🔽appasāvajjaḥ āsevana mahanta tāya mahāsāvajjaḥ tassa dve sambhārā bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi niratthaka kathā 🔽purekkhāra tā tathārūpī kathā kathanañca 🔽kālena vadati iti kāla vādī vattabba yutta kālam sallakkhetvā vadati iti atthaḥ bhūtam
translated: “He is a speaker of what is correct” : he is a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being complete in good qualities, in the sense of being tender like a woman brought up in the inner apartments, and in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being a of what is correct in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of being a speaker of what is correct in the sense of

original: tacchaṃ sabhāvameva vadatīti bhūtavādī. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthasannissitameva🔽katvā vadatīti atthavādī. Navalokuttaradhammasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti dhammavādī.
analyzed: tat śam sabhāvam eva vadati iti bhūta vādī diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika attha sannissitam eva  katvā vadati iti attha vādī nava lokuttara dhamma sannissitam katvā vadati iti dhamma vādī
translated: He speaks only of what is in accordance with the true nature of things, thus he is a speaker of what is. He speaks only of what is connected with welfare in this life and in the life to come,

original: Saṃvaravinayapahānavinayasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti vinayavādī. Nidhānaṃ vuccati
analyzed: saṃvara vinaya pahāna vinaya sannissitam katvā vadati iti vinaya vādī nidhānam vuccati
translated: thus he is a speaker of welfare. He speaks only of what is connected with the nine supramundane states, thus he is a speaker of the Dhamma. He speaks only of what is connected with restraint and relinquishment, thus he is a speaker of discipline.

original: ṭhapanokāso, nidhānamassā atthīti nidhānavatī, hadaye nidhātabbayuttaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti
analyzed: ṭhapana ukāsaḥ nidhānam assāḥ atthi iti nidhānavatī hadaye nidhātabba yuttam vācam bhāsitā ati
translated: A store is a place for keeping things. She has a store, thus she is a store-possessor. The meaning is: she speaks words that are fit to be kept in the heart.🔽In season: even when speaking in this way, she does not speak out of season, thinking, “I will speak words that are a store-possessor”; the meaning is that she speaks only after considering the right time.

original: attho. Kālenāti evarūpiṃ bhāsamānopi ca “ahaṃ nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsissāmī”ti na🔽akālena bhāsati, yuttakālaṃ pana apekkhitvāva bhāsatīti attho. Sāpadesanti saupamaṃ,🔽sakāraṇanti attho. Pariyantavatinti paricchedaṃ dassetvā yathāssā paricchedo paññāyati,
analyzed: attho kālena ati evarūpim bhāsamānaḥ api ca aham nidhānavatim vācam bhāsissāmi iti na  akālena bhāsati yutta kālam pana apekkhitvā ava bhāsati iti attho sa apadesa nti sa aupamam  sa kāraṇam ti paricchedam dassetvā yathā assā paricchedaḥ paññāyati
translated: With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning.

original: evaṃ bhāsatīti attho. Atthasaṃhitanti anekehi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya
analyzed: evam bhāsati iti atthaḥ attha saṃhitan ti anekehi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātum a sakkuṇeyya tāya
translated: With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With reference to the goal: with a simile, is the meaning. With

original: atthasampannaṃ. Yaṃ vā so atthavādī atthaṃ vadati, tena atthena sahitattā atthasaṃhitaṃ
analyzed: attha sampannam yam vā saḥ attha vādī attham vadati tena atthena sahita ttā attha saṃhitam
translated: and is meaningful. Or else, since it is associated with the meaning that the speaker of the truth speaks, it is connected with the meaning.

original: vācaṃ bhāsati, na aññaṃ nikkhipitvā aññaṃ bhāsatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vācam bhāsati na aññam nikkhipitvā aññam bhāsati iti vuttam hoti
translated: He speaks in a way that is not incoherent, is what is meant.

original: Catūhi vacīsucaritehīti “musāvādaṃ pahāyā”tiādinā nayena vuttehi catūhi vācāhi yuttehi🔽suṭṭhu caritehi. Samannāgatoti aparihīno. Catudosāpagataṃ vācaṃ bhāsatīti appiyādīhi
analyzed: catūhi vacī su caritehi iti musāvādam pahāya ati ādinā nayena vuttehi catūhi vācāhi yuttehi  suṭṭhu caritehi samannāgato ti a parihīno catu dosa apagatam vācam bhāsati iti appiya ādīhi
translated: Endowed with the four kinds of verbal good conduct: with the four kinds of verbal conduct stated in the way beginning, “Having abandoned false speech” ,🔽and with the conduct that is good in being well endowed with them.

original: catūhi dosehi apagataṃ parihīnaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati.
analyzed: catūhi dosehi apagatam parihīnam vācam bhāsati
translated: He speaks in a way that is free from the four defects: he speaks in a way that is free from, devoid of, the four defects beginning with dislike.

original: Atthi agocaroti kiñcāpi thero samaṇācāraṃ samaṇagocaraṃ kathetukāmo “atthi agocaro,
analyzed: atthi agocaro ti kiñcā api thero samaṇa ācāram samaṇa gocaram kathetu kāmo atthi agocaro
translated: There is a sphere of activity that is not the right one: although the elder was desirous of speaking about the recluse’s practice and the recluse’s sphere of activity, he uttered the words “There is a sphere of activity that is not the right one,

original: atthi gocaro”ti padaṃ uddhari, yathā pana maggakusalo puriso maggaṃ ācikkhanto “vāmaṃ
analyzed: atthi gocaro ti padam yathā pana magga kusalaḥ puriso maggaṃ ācikkhantaḥ vāmam
translated: there is a sphere of activity that is the right one” . But just as a man skilled in the road, when he is asked “Which is the road to the town?”

original: muñca, dakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhā”ti paṭhamaṃ muñcitabbaṃ sabhayamaggaṃ uppathamaggaṃ ācikkhati,
analyzed: muñca dakkhiṇam gaṇhāti paṭhamam muñcitabbam sa bhaya maggam uppatha maggam ācikkhati
translated: first points out the road to be avoided, which is a dangerous road and a wrong road, saying “Leave that road on the left,”

original: pacchā gahetabbaṃ khemamaggaṃ ujumaggaṃ, evameva maggakusalapurisasadiso dhammasenāpati
analyzed: pacchā gahetabbam khema maggam uju maggam evam eva magga kusala purisa sadisaḥ dhamma senāpati
translated: knowing the route, would lead a company of merchants by a route through a jungle wilderness to safety, to a road frequented by men, in the same way the Master of the Dhamma, the Elder Sāriputta,

original: paṭhamaṃ pahātabbaṃ buddhapaṭikuṭṭhaṃ agocaraṃ ācikkhitvā pacchā gocaraṃ ācikkhitukāmo
analyzed: paṭhamam pahātabbam buddha paṭikuṭṭham a gocaram ācikkhitvā pacchā gocaram ācikkhitu kāmo
translated: first pointed out the evil jungle wilderness of the wrong road to be abandoned, and afterwards he wanted to point out the right road.🔽“What is the wrong road?”

original: “katamo agocaro”tiādimāha. Purisena hi ācikkhitamaggo sampajjeyya vā na vā, tathāgatena
analyzed: katamaḥ agocaraḥ ti ādim āha purisena hi ācikkhita maggo sampajjeyya vā na vā tathāgatena
translated: The road pointed out by a man might or might not lead to the goal, but the road pointed out by the Tathāgata

original: ācikkhitamaggo apaṇṇako indavissaṭṭhaṃ vajiraṃ viya avirajjhanako nibbānanagaraṃyeva🔽samosarati. Tena vuttaṃ – “puriso maggakusaloti kho tissa tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ
analyzed: ācikkhita maggaḥ apaṇṇakaḥ inda vissaṭṭham vajiram viya a virajjhanakaḥ nibbāna nagaram yeva  samosarati tena vuttam puriso magga kusalaḥ ti kho tissa tathāgatassa etam adhivacanam
translated: leads infallibly to the city of Nibbāna, like a well-aimed arrow shot by a skillful archer.

original: arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
analyzed: arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “The man skilled in the road is a designation for the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.”

original: Yasmā vā sasīsaṃ nhānena pahīnasedamalajallikassa purisassa mālāgandhavilepanādivibhūsanavidhānaṃ
analyzed: yasmai vā sa sīsam nhānena pahīna seda mala jallikassa purisassa mālā gandha vilepana ādi vibhūsana vidhānam
translated: Or just as it is fitting for a man who has bathed from the soles of his feet up to the crown of his head to adorn himself with garlands, scents, and unguents,

original: viya pahīnapāpadhammassa kalyāṇadhammasamāyogo sampannarūpo hoti, tasmā sedamalajallikaṃ
analyzed: viya pahīna pāpa dhammassa kalyāṇa dhamma samāyogaḥ sampanna rūpaḥ hoti tasmai sa idam alajallikam
translated: so it is fitting for one who has abandoned evil states to take up good states. Therefore the Elder said: “The man with dust and dirt on his head and clothes”

original: viya pahātabbaṃ paṭhamaṃ agocaraṃ ācikkhitvā pahīnasedamalajallikassa mālāgandhavilepanādivibhūsanavidhānaṃ
analyzed: viya pahātabbam paṭhamam agocaram ācikkhitvā pahīna seda mala jallikassa mālā gandha vilepana ādi vibhūsana vidhānam
translated: and then the description of the adornment with garlands, scents, and unguents, etc., after the stain of stinginess has been removed,

original: viya pacchā gocaraṃ ācikkhitukāmopi “katamo agocaro”tiādimāha.
analyzed: viya pacchā gocaram ācikkhitu kāmaḥ api katamaḥ agocara iti ādim āha
translated: so too, though he wants to describe the right object of desire first, he says “What is the wrong object of desire?” and so on.

original: Tattha gocaroti piṇḍapātādīnaṃ atthāya upasaṅkamituṃ yuttaṭṭhānaṃ. Ayuttaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tattha gocaro ti piṇḍapāta ādīnam atthāya upasaṅkamitum yutta ṭṭhānam a yutta ṭṭhānam
translated: Herein, the right object of desire is a place suitable for visiting for the sake of alms food, etc.,🔽the wrong object of desire is a place unsuitable for visiting.

original: agocaro. Vesiyā gocaro assāti vesiyāgocaro, mittasanthavavasena upasaṅkamitabbaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: a gocaraḥ vesiyā gocaraḥ assa ati vesiyā gocaraḥ mitta santhava vasena upasaṅkamitabba ṭhānan ti
translated: A prostitute’s resort: a place that can be visited by way of friendship and intimacy.

original: attho. Tattha vesiyā nāma rūpūpajīviniyo yena kenacideva sulabhajjhācāratā mittasanthavasinehavasena
analyzed: attho tattha vesiyāḥ nāma rūpa upajīviniyaḥ yena kenacid eva sulabha jjhācāra tā mitta santhava sineha vasena
translated: Herein, prostitutes are those who live on their beauty and can be had by anyone who has the price, no matter who he is.🔽One who visits them by way of friendship and intimacy is called “one who resorts to prostitutes.”

original: upasaṅkamanto vesiyāgocaro nāma hoti. Tasmā evaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ na vaṭṭati. Kiṃkāraṇā?
analyzed: upasaṅkamantaḥ vesiyāgocaraḥ nāma hoti tasmai evam upasaṅkamitum na vaṭṭati kiṃkāraṇā
translated: That is why it is not allowable to visit them in this way. Why not?

original: Ārakkhavipattito. Evaṃ upasaṅkamantassa hi cirarakkhitagopitopi samaṇadhammo katipāheneva
analyzed: ārakkha vipattitaḥ evam upasaṅkamantassa hi cira rakkhita gopitaḥ api samaṇa dhammo kati pāhena iva
translated: Because of the danger of losing one’s purity. For if one visits them in this way, the recluse- dharma that has been acquired and guarded for a long time is lost in a moment.

original: nassati. Sacepi na nassati, garahaṃ labhati. Dakkhiṇāvasena pana upasaṅkamantena
analyzed: nassati sace pi na nassati garaham labhati dakkhiṇā vasena pana upasaṅkamantena
translated: And even if it is not lost, one gets a bad reputation. But if one visits them by way of giving alms, etc.,

original: satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ.🔽Vidhavā vuccanti matapatikā vā pavuṭṭhapatikā vā. Thullakumāriyoti mahallikā anibbiddhakumāriyo.
analyzed: satim upaṭṭhapetvā upasaṅkamitabbam  vidhavāḥ vuccanti mata patikāḥ vā pavuṭṭha patikāḥ vā thulla kumāriyaḥ ti mahallikāḥ a nibbiddha kumāriyaḥ
translated: He should approach them after establishing mindfulness.🔽Widows are those whose husbands are dead or have gone away. A wanton woman is a lustful woman.

original: Paṇḍakāti lokāmisanissitakathābahulā ussannakilesā avūpasantapariḷāhā napuṃsakā.
analyzed: paṇḍakā ati loka āmisa nissita kathā bahulāḥ ussanna kilesāḥ a vūpasanta pariḷāhāḥ napuṃsakā
translated: Eunuchs are those who are full of lust, whose defilements are unabated, whose passions are not calmed, who are full of talk about worldly matters, and who are impotent.

original: Tesaṃ sabbesampi upasaṅkamane ādīnavo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Bhikkhunīsupi eseva
analyzed: tesam sabbesam pi upasaṅkamane ādīnavaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ bhikkhunīsu pi esā iva
translated: The danger in approaching all of them should be understood in the way already described. The same method applies

original: nayo. Api ca bhikkhū nāma ussannabrahmacariyā honti, tathā bhikkhuniyo. Te aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: nayaḥ api ca bhikkhū nāma ussanna brahmacariyāḥ honti tathā bhikkhuniyaḥ te aññamaññam
translated: to nuns. Moreover, monks are full of the holy life, and so are nuns. They

original: santhavavasena katipāheneva rakkhitagopitasamaṇadhammaṃ nāsenti. Gilānapucchakena
analyzed: santhava vasena kati pāhena iva rakkhita gopita samaṇa dhammam na āsenti gilāna pucchakena
translated: destroy the well-taught Dhamma by their intimacy.

original: pana gantuṃ vaṭṭati. Bhikkhunā pupphāni labhitvā pūjanatthāyapi ovādadānatthāyapi gantuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: pana gantum vaṭṭati bhikkhunā pupphāni labhitvā pūjana tthāya api ovāda dāna tthāya api gantum vaṭṭati yeva
translated: But it is allowable to go to them if one is sick and wants to ask for something. And it is allowable for a monk to go to a nunnery to get flowers for the purpose of worship or to give advice.

original: Pānāgāranti surāpānagharaṃ, taṃ brahmacariyantarāyakarehi surāsoṇḍehi avivittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: surā pāna gharam tam brahmacariya antarāya karehi surā soṇḍehi a vivittam hoti
translated: A drinking house is a place where liquor is drunk. It is not secluded because it is frequented by drunkards who are an obstacle to the holy life.

original: Tattha tehi saddhiṃ sahasoṇḍavasena upasaṅkamituṃ na vaṭṭati, brahmacariyantarāyo
analyzed: tattha tehi saddhim saha soṇḍavasena upasaṅkamitum na vaṭṭati brahmacariya antarāyaḥ
translated: It is not allowable to go to them and associate with them as friends and companions. It is a hindrance to the life of purity.

original: hoti. Saṃsaṭṭho viharati rājūhītiādīsu rājānoti abhisittā vā hontu anabhisittā vā,🔽ye rajjamanusāsanti. Rājamahāmattāti rājūnaṃ issariyasadisāya mahatiyā issariyamattāya🔽samannāgatā. Titthiyāti viparītadassanā bāhiraparibbājakā. Titthiyasāvakāti bhattivasena
analyzed: hoti saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati rājūhi itiādīsu rājānaḥ ti abhisittāḥ vā hontu an abhisittāḥ vā  ye rajjam anusāsanti rāja mahā mattāti issariya sadisāya mahatiyā issariya mattāya  samannāgatā titthiyā ati viparīta dassanā bāhira paribbājakā titthiya sāvakā ati bhatti vasena
translated: Associates with and befriends: kings, etc. Kings: whether they are anointed or unanointed,

original: tesaṃ paccayadāyakā, etehi saddhiṃ saṃsaggajāto hotīti attho.
analyzed: tesam paccaya dāyakāḥ etehi saddhim saṃsagga jātaḥ hoti iti attho
translated: they are called “kings” if they rule a kingdom. Great officers: those who have great authority like that of kings. Sectarians: outside sectarians with perverted views. Sectarians’ disciples: those who give them material support. The meaning is that he becomes one who has intercourse with them.

original: Ananulomikena saṃsaggenāti ananulomikasaṃsaggo nāma tissannaṃ sikkhānaṃ ananulomo🔽paccanīkasaṃsaggo. Yena brahmacariyantarāyaṃ paññattivītikkamaṃ sallekhaparihāniñca
analyzed: ananulomikena saṃsaggena ati ananulomika saṃsaggaḥ nāma tissannam sikkhānam ananulomo  paccanīka saṃsaggaḥ yena brahmacariya antarāyam paññatti vītikkamam sallekha parihāniñca
translated: With those who are not in conformity: non-conformity is intercourse that is not in conformity with the three trainings.🔽It is intercourse that is contrary to it. By means of it one comes to the hindrance of the life of purity, to transgression of the rules, and to loss of the development of serenity and insight.

original: pāpuṇāti. Seyyathidaṃ? Rājarājamahāmattehi saddhiṃ sahasokitā sahananditā samasukhadukkhatā
analyzed: pāpuṇāti sā iyyathidam rāja rāja mahāmattehi saddhim saha sokitā saha nanditā sama sukha dukkha tā
translated: What is it? Associating with kings and great officers, rejoicing with them, sharing their joys and sorrows,

original: uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā yogaṃ āpajjanatā titthiyatitthiyasāvakehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: uppannesu kicca karaṇīyesu attanā yogam āpajjanatā titthiya titthiya sāvakehi saddhim
translated: In the case of duties that have arisen, the quality of being one who takes part in them is the quality of being one who is ready to take part in them.

original: ekacchandarucisamācāratā ekacchandarucisamācārabhāvāvaho vā sinehabahumānasanthavo.
analyzed: eka chanda ruci samācāra tā eka chanda ruci samācāra bhāva āvahaḥ vā sineha bahu māna santhavaḥ
translated: The quality of having the same desires, likings, and practices as the sectarians and their disciples is the quality of being one who has the same desires, likings, and practices as them, or the quality of being one who has the bond of affection and respect for them.

original: Tattha rājarājamahāmattehi saddhiṃ saṃsaggo brahmacariyantarāyakaro, itarehi titthiyasāvakehi
analyzed: tattha rāja rāja mahāmattehi saddhim saṃsaggaḥ brahmacariya antarāya karo itarehi titthiya sāvakehi
translated: Herein, association with kings and royal ministers is an obstacle to the life of purity. The others, with sectarians and their disciples,

original: tesaṃ laddhiggahaṇaṃ. Tesaṃ pana vādaṃ bhinditvā attano laddhiṃ gaṇhāpetuṃ samatthena🔽upasaṅkamituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: tesam laddhi ggahaṇam tesam pana vādam bhinditvā attanaḥ laddhim gaṇhāpetum samatthena  upasaṅkamitum vaṭṭati
translated: are the taking up of their views. But it is proper to approach them if one is able to break down their views and get them to take up one’s own views.

original: Idāni aparenapi pariyāyena agocaraṃ dassetuṃ “yāni vā pana tāni kulānī”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni aparena api pariyāyena agocaram dassetum yāni vā pana tāni kulāni iti ādi āraddham
translated: Now, in order to point out the wrong domain by another method, the text is stated thus: “Or whatever other families are without faith” .

original: Tattha assaddhānīti buddhādīsu saddhāvirahitāni. Tāni “buddho sabbaññū, dhammo niyyāniko,
analyzed: tattha assaddhāni iti buddha ādīsu saddhā virahitāni tāni buddhaḥ sabbaññū dhammaḥ niyyānikaḥ
translated: Herein, without faith means devoid of faith in the Buddha, etc. They do not have faith that “The Buddha is omniscient, the Dhamma is well-expounded,

original: saṅgho suppaṭipanno”ti na saddahanti. Appasannānīti cittaṃ pasannaṃ anāvilaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: saṅghaḥ suppaṭipannaḥ ti na saddahanti appasannāni iti cittam pasannam anāvilam kātum
translated: the Saṅgha is practicing well.” Without confidence means that they do not have confidence that can make the mind clear and pure.

original: na sakkonti. Akkosakaparibhāsakānīti akkosakāni ceva paribhāsakāni ca. “Corosi, bālosi,
analyzed: na sakkonti akkosaka paribhāsakāni iti akkosakāni ca iva paribhāsakāni ca coraḥ asi bālaḥ asi
translated: They were unable to do so. They reviled and abused them: they reviled them and abused them with the ten kinds of abuse, saying: “You are a thief, a fool,

original: mūḷhosi, oṭṭhosi, goṇosi, gadrabhosi, āpāyikosi, nerayikosi, tiracchānagatosi, natthi
analyzed: mūḷhaḥ asi oṭṭhaḥ asi goṇaḥ asi gadrabhaḥ asi āpāyikaḥ asi nerayikaḥ asi tiracchāna gataḥ asi natthi
translated: a fool, a donkey, a bull, a camel, you are doomed to hell, you are going to hell, you are an animal, there is no good

original: tuyhaṃ sugati, duggatiyeva tuyhaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā”ti evaṃ dasahi akkosavatthūhi akkosanti.
analyzed: tuyham sugati duggatiyā iva tuyham evam dasahi akkosa vatthūhi akkosanti
translated: state for you, only a bad destination is to be expected for you.”

original: “Hotu, idāni taṃ paharissāma, bandhissāma, vadhissāmā”ti evaṃ bhayadassanena paribhāsanti cāti attho.🔽Anatthakāmānīti atthaṃ na icchanti, anatthameva icchanti. Ahitakāmānīti ahitameva🔽icchanti, hitaṃ na icchanti. Aphāsukāmānīti phāsukaṃ na icchanti, aphāsukameva icchanti.
analyzed: hotu idāni tam paharissāma bandhissāma vadhissāma ati evam bhaya dassanena paribhāsanti ca ati attho  anattha kāmāni iti attham na icchanti anattham eva icchanti ahita kāmāni iti ahitam eva  icchanti hitam naḥ icchanti a phāsu kāmāni iti phāsukam naḥ icchanti a phāsukam eva icchanti
translated: They abused them by showing them fear, saying: “Now we will beat you, we will bind you, we will kill you.”🔽They did not wish them well: they did not wish them well, but wished them ill. They did not wish them benefit: they did not wish them benefit, but wished them harm. They did not wish them comfort: they did not wish them comfort, but wished them discomfort.

original: Ayogakkhemakāmānīti catūhi yogehi khemaṃ nibbhayaṃ na icchanti, sabhayameva icchanti.
analyzed: a yoga kkhema kāmāni iti catūhi yogehi khemam nibbhayam naḥ icchanti sa bhayam eva icchanti
translated: They did not wish them security from bondage: they did not wish them security from bondage, but wished them fear.

original: Bhikkhūnanti ettha sāmaṇerāpi saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Bhikkhunīnanti ettha sikkhamānāsāmaṇeriyopi.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam ti ettha sāmaṇerā api saṅgaham gacchanti bhikkhunīnam ti ettha sikkhamānā sāmaṇeriyā api
translated: “Monks” here includes novices. “Nuns” here includes probationers and female novices.

original: Sabbesampi hi bhagavantaṃ uddissa pabbajitānañceva saraṇagatānañca catunnampi parisānaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam pi hi bhagavantam uddissa pabbajitānam ca iva saraṇa gatānam ca catunnam pi parisānam
translated: For all four assemblies,

original: tāni anatthakāmāniyeva. Tathārūpāni kulānīti evarūpāni khattiyakulādīni kulāni. Sevatīti
analyzed: tāni anattha kāmāni iva tathārūpāni kulāni iti evarūpāni khattiya kula ādīni kulāni sevati iti
translated: are not for their benefit. “Such families” are families of such kinds as nobles. “Associates with”

original: nissāya jīvati. Bhajatīti upasaṅkamati. Payirupāsatīti punappunaṃ upasaṅkamati. Ayaṃ🔽vuccatīti ayaṃ vesiyādigocarassa vesiyādiko rājādisaṃsaṭṭhassa rājādiko assaddhakulādisevakassa
analyzed: nissāya jīvati bhajati iti upasaṅkamati payirupāsati iti punappunam upasaṅkamati ayam  vuccati iti ayam vesiyā ādi gocarassa vesiyā ādikaḥ rāja ādi saṃsaṭṭhassa rāja ādikaḥ assaddha kula ādi sevakassa
translated: means depends on for a living. “Frequents” means visits. “Consorts with” means visits again and again. “This is called”

original: assaddhakulādiko cāti tippakāropi ayuttagocaro “agocaro”ti veditabbo.
analyzed: assaddha kula ādiko ca ati tippakāraḥ pi ayutta gocaraḥ agocaraḥ ti veditabbo
translated: means that this triple kind of improper resort, namely, the resort of a harlot, etc., that of a king, etc., and that of a family lacking in faith, etc., should be understood as “improper resort.”

original: Tassa imināpi pariyāyena agocaratā veditabbā – vesiyādiko tāva pañcakāmaguṇanissayato
analyzed: tassa iminā api pariyāyena agocara tā veditabbā vesiya ādikaḥ tāva pañca kāmaguṇa nissayato
translated: The impropriety of these should be understood in this way: the resort of a harlot, etc., should be understood as improper because it is the basis for the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: agocaro veditabbo. Yathāha – “ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo, yadidaṃ
analyzed: agocaraḥ veditabbaḥ yathā āha kaḥ ca bhikkhave bhikkhuno agocaraḥ para visayaḥ yat idam
translated: As it is said: “What, bhikkhus, is the bhikkhu’s improper resort, his enemy’s domain?

original: pañca kāmaguṇā”ti. Rājādiko jhānānuyogassa anupanissayato lābhasakkārāsanicakkanipphādanato
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇā ti rāja ādikaḥ jhāna anuyogassa an upanissayataḥ lābha sakkāra āsani cakka nipphādanato
translated: and the five strands of sense pleasure. ” The royal family, etc., are a wrong resort because they are not a condition for the development of jhāna, because they produce the loss of the opportunity for seclusion,

original: diṭṭhivipattihetuto ca, assaddhakulādiko saddhāhānicittapadosāvahanato agocaro.🔽Antaragharappavesādiko ca cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā nimittaggāhādiko ca saddhādeyyāni🔽bhojanāni bhuñjitvā visūkadassanānuyogo ca pañca kāmaguṇā cāti catubbidhopi pana
analyzed: diṭṭhi vipatti hetutaḥ ca assaddha kula ādiko saddhā hāni citta padosa āvahanataḥ agocaro  antara ghara ppavesa ādiko ca cakkhunā rūpam disvā nimitta ggāha ādiko ca saddhādeyyāni  bhojanāni bhuñjitvā ca pañca kāmaguṇā ca ati catubbidhaḥ api pana
translated: and because they are a cause for the failure of view. The family without faith, etc., are a wrong resort because they arouse lack of faith, lack of confidence, and lack of respect.

original: kilesuppattivasena agocaroti veditabbo.
analyzed: kilesuppatti vasena agocaraḥ ti veditabbo
translated: The family that enters the house, etc., are a wrong resort because they cause one to look at the women, etc., and because they cause one to look at the various kinds of merchandise. The family that gives food, etc., are a wrong resort because they cause one to look at the various kinds of food, etc., and because they cause one to look at the various kinds of people. The five strands of sense pleasure are a wrong resort because they cause the arising of defilements.

original: Mā bhikkhave agocare carathāti carituṃ ayuttaṭṭhāne mā caratha. Paravisayeti sattuvisaye.🔽Agocare bhikkhave caratanti ayuttaṭṭhāne carantānaṃ. “Cara”ntipi pāṭho. Lacchatīti
analyzed: mā bhikkhave agocare caratha ati caritum ayutta ṭṭhāne mā caratha para visaye iti sattu visaye  agocare bhikkhave caratanti ayutta ṭṭhāne carantānam caranti pi pāṭhaḥ lacchati iti
translated: “Do not wander for alms in an unsuitable place”: do not wander for alms in a place unsuitable for wandering for alms. “Another’s domain”: another’s territory.

original: labhissati passissati. Māroti devaputtamāropi maccumāropi. Otāranti randhaṃ chiddaṃ vivaraṃ.
analyzed: labhissati passissati māroti devaputtam āropi maccum āropi randham chiddam vivaram
translated: “If you wander for alms in an unsuitable place”: if you wander for alms in a place unsuitable for wandering for alms. The reading “cara” is also correct. “You will get” : you will obtain, you will see. “A demon”: a demon-son or a death-demon. “A hole”: a gap, a fissure, an opening.

original: Gocaraniddese na vesiyāgocaro hotītiādīni vuttapaṭipakkhavasena veditabbāni. Ayaṃ
analyzed: gocara niddese na vesiyā gocaraḥ hoti itiādīni vutta paṭipakkha vasena veditabbāni ayam
translated: In the description of the domain, the words “he does not frequent the domain of courtesans” and so on should be understood in the opposite sense to the words of the sutta.

original: pana viseso – cattāro satipaṭṭhānā gocaroti carituṃ yuttaṭṭhānavasena catusatipaṭṭhānā
analyzed: pana viseso cattāro sati paṭṭhānāḥ gocaraḥ ti caritum yutta ṭṭhāna vasena catu sati paṭṭhānā
translated: But there is this difference: the four foundations of mindfulness are the domain in the sense of being the place suitable for wandering about.

original: gocaro. Saketi attano santake. Pettike visayeti pitito āgatavisaye.🔽Āraddhavīriyassāti sammāupaṭṭhitacatusammappadhānavīriyavantassa. Thāmagatassāti🔽balappattassa. Daḷhaparakkamassāti thiravīriyassa. Yassatthāya pesitoti yena arahattatthāya🔽attabhāvo pariccatto. Attatthe cāti attano atthe arahattaphale ca. Ñāye cāti ariye🔽aṭṭhaṅgike magge ca. Lakkhaṇe cāti aniccādilakkhaṇapaṭivedhe ca. Kāraṇe cāti hetumhi
analyzed: gocaraḥ sake iti attanaḥ santake pettike visaye ti pititaḥ āgata visaye  āraddha vīriyassa ati sammā upaṭṭhita catu sammappadhāna vīriyavantassa thāma gatassa ati  bala ppattassa daḷha parakkamassa ati thira vīriyassa yassa atthāya pesitaḥ ti yena arahat tatthāya  atta bhāvo pariccattaḥ attatthe ca ati attano atthe arahatta phale ca ñāye ca ati ariye  aṭṭhaṅgike magge ca lakkhaṇe ca ati anicca ādi lakkhaṇa paṭivedhe ca kāraṇe ca ati hetumhi
translated: “In his own district” means in his own country. “In his father’s domain” means in the domain that has come down from his father.

original: ca. Ṭhānāṭhāne cāti ṭhāne ca aṭṭhāne ca, kāraṇākāraṇe cāti attho. Idāni vitthāretvā
analyzed: ca ṭhāna aṭhāne ca ati ṭhāne ca aṭṭhāne ca kāraṇa akāraṇe ca ati atthaḥ idāni vitthāretvā
translated: “One who has aroused energy” means one who has the energy of the four right strivings that have been properly undertaken. “One who has attained steadfastness” means one who has reached strength. “One who has strong determination” means one who has firm energy. “For the sake of which he was sent forth” means for the sake of which he has given up his former life. “For his own welfare” means for the welfare of his own self, i.e., for the fruit of arahatship. “For the right method” means for the noble eightfold path. “For the characteristics” means for the penetration of the characteristics of impermanence, etc. “For the reason” means for the cause. “For the proper and the improper” means for the proper and the improper, i.e., for the cause and the non-cause.🔽Now, in order to explain this in detail,

original: dassetuṃ “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dassetum sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā iti ādim āha
translated: He said, “All formations are impermanent” and so on in order to show it.

original: 197. Aṭṭhamagāthāya ekodi nipakoti ekaggacitto paṇḍito.
analyzed: aṭṭhama gāthāya ekodi ekagga citto paṇḍito
translated: In the eighth stanza, “he is one-pointed, discerning” means that he is wise and has one-pointedness of mind.

original: Jātarūpassa oḷārikampi malaṃ dhamatīti suvaṇṇassa thūlaṃ jallaṃ aggisaṃyogena nīharati.
analyzed: jātarūpassa oḷārikam pi malam dhamati iti suvaṇṇassa thūlam jallam aggi saṃyogena nīharati
translated: “He burns off the gross impurities of gold” means that he removes the gross impurities of gold by heating it with fire.

original: Sandhamatīti sammā nīharati. Niddhamatīti apunabhavappattikaṃ katvā nīharati. “Jhāpetī”ti
analyzed: sandhamati iti sammā nīharati niddhamati iti apunabhavappattikam katvā nīharati jhāpeti iti
translated: “He burns them away” means that he removes them completely. “He burns them up” means that he removes them so that they will not arise again.🔽Some say that he “burns them up” .

original: keci vadanti. Majjhimakampīti tato sukhumatarampi. Sukhumakampīti atisukhumatarampi.
analyzed: keci vadanti majjhima kampi iti tatas sukhumataram pi sukhuma kampi iti ati sukhumataram pi
translated: “The middle ones” are more subtle than the gross ones. “The subtle ones” are more subtle than the middle ones.

original: Evamevāti opammasampaṭipādanaṃ. Attano oḷārikepi kilese dhamatīti kāyaduccaritādike
analyzed: evam eva ati opamma sampaṭipādanam attanaḥ oḷārike pi kilese dhamati iti kāya duccarita ādike
translated: “Just so” is a simile. “He burns off the gross defilements” means that he removes the gross defilements such as bodily misconduct

original: thūlakilese vīriyātapena nīharati. Majjhimakepi kileseti kāmavitakkādike oḷārikasukhumānaṃ
analyzed: thūla kilese vīriya ātapena nīharati majjhimake pi kilesa iti kāma vitakka ādike oḷārika sukhumānam
translated: by the heat of energy. “The middle defilements” are the middle ones among the gross and subtle defilements such as sensual thoughts.

original: majjhimakepi. Sukhumakepīti ñātivitakkādike atisaṇhakepi kilese. Sammādiṭṭhiyā micchādiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: majjhimake pi sukhumake pi iti ñāti vitakka ādike ati saṇhake pi kilese sammādiṭṭhiyā micchādiṭṭhiṃ
translated: “The subtle ones” are the very subtle defilements such as thoughts of relatives. By right view he removes wrong view,

original: dhamatīti saha vipassanāya maggasampayuttāya sammādiṭṭhiyā viparītasaṅkhātaṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: dhamati iti saha vipassanāya magga sampayuttāya sammādiṭṭhiyā viparīta saṅkhātam micchādiṭṭhim
translated: He abandons wrong view, which is called “perverted,” by means of right view associated with the path and insight.

original: nīharati. Sammāsaṅkappādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽198. Evaṃ āyasmatā sāriputtena tīhi gāthāhi bhagavantaṃ thometvā pañcahi gāthāhi
analyzed: nīharati sammā saṅkappa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ  evam āyasmatā sāriputtena tīhi gāthāhi bhagavantam thometvā pañcahi gāthāhi
translated: The same method applies to right thought, etc.

original: pañcasatānaṃ sissānamatthāya ca senāsanagocarasīlavatādīni pucchito tamatthaṃ pakāsetuṃ
analyzed: pañca satānam sissānam atthāya ca senāsana gocara sīlavata ādīni pucchitaḥ tam attham pakāsetum
translated: Having thus extolled the Blessed One with three stanzas, the venerable Sāriputta asked him about the dwelling place, the resort, the virtue, the concentration, the wisdom, etc., of his five hundred pupils,

original: “vijigucchamānassā”tiādinā nayena vissajjanamāraddhaṃ. Tattha paṭhamagāthāya tāvattho
analyzed: vijigucchamānassa ati ādinā nayena vissajjanam āraddham tattha paṭhama gāthāya
translated: and the Blessed One answered him in the way beginning, “For one who is disgusted … ” . Herein, the meaning of the first stanza is this.🔽For one who is disgusted with birth, etc., and who resorts to an empty place for his bed and seat,

original: – jātiādīhi jigucchamānassa rittāsanaṃ sayanaṃ sevato ve sambodhikāmassa sāriputta
analyzed: jāti ādīhi jigucchamānassa ritta āsanam sayanam sevataḥ ve sambodhi kāmassa sāriputta
translated: for a bhikkhu who desires full enlightenment, Sāriputta,

original: bhikkhuno yadidaṃ phāsu yo phāsuvihāro yathānudhammaṃ yo ca anudhammo, taṃ te pavakkhāmi
analyzed: bhikkhuno yat idam phāsu yaḥ phāsu vihāro yathānudhammam yo ca anudhammo tam te pavakkhāmi
translated: I will tell you the comfort, the pleasant abiding, the conformity with the Dhamma, and the Dhamma,

original: yathā pajānaṃ yathā pajānanto vadeyya, evaṃ vadāmīti. Yaṃ phāsuvihāranti yaṃ sukhavihāraṃ.
analyzed: yathā pajānam yathā pajānantaḥ vadeyye evam vadāmi iti yam yam sukha vihāram
translated: so that, knowing thus, he might speak thus, I say. The pleasant abiding is the pleasant abiding in bliss.

original: Asappāyarūpadassanenāti itthirūpādisamaṇāsappāyarūpadassanena. Taṃ bodhiṃ bujjhitukāmassāti🔽taṃ catumaggañāṇasaṅkhātaṃ bodhiṃ bujjhituṃ icchantassa. Anubujjhitukāmassāti anurūpāya
analyzed: asappāya rūpa dassanena ati itthi rūpa ādi samaṇa asappāya rūpa dassanena tam bodhim bujjhitu kāmassa ati  tam catu magga ñāṇa saṅkhātam bodhim bujjhitum icchantassa anubujjhitu kāmassa ati anurūpāya
translated: By seeing an improper visible object: by seeing a visible object such as a woman’s form that is a condition for passion. Who is desirous of enlightenment:

original: paṭipattiyā bujjhitukāmassa. Paṭivijjhitukāmassāti abhimukhe katvā nibbijjhitukāmassa.
analyzed: paṭipattiyāḥ bujjhitu kāmassa paṭivijjhitu kāmassa ati abhimukhe katvā nibbijjhitu kāmassa
translated: who is desirous of awakening to the enlightenment consisting of the four paths. Who is desirous of awakening to it: who is desirous of awakening to it by means of a suitable practice. Who is desirous of penetrating it: who is desirous of penetrating it by making it evident.

original: Sambujjhitukāmassāti pahīnakilese apaccāgamanavasena sammā bujjhituṃ icchantassa.
analyzed: sambujjhitu kāmassa ati pahīna kilese apaccāgamana vasena sammā bujjhitum icchantassa
translated: Who is desirous of fully awakening to it: who is desirous of fully awakening to it by means of a complete awakening without relapse of the defilements that have been abandoned.

original: Adhigantukāmassāti pāpuṇitukāmassa. Sacchikātukāmassāti paṭilābhasacchikiriyāya pattukāmassa.🔽Atha vā bujjhitukāmassāti sotāpattimaggañāṇaṃ ñātukāmassa. Anubujjhitukāmassāti sakadāgāmimaggañāṇaṃ
analyzed: adhigantu kāmassa ati pāpuṇitu kāmassa sacchikātu kāmassa ati paṭilābha sacchikiriyāya pattu kāmassa  atha vā bujjhitu kāmassa ati sotāpatti magga ñāṇam ñātu kāmassa anubujjhitu kāmassa ati sakadāgāmi magga ñāṇam
translated: Who is desirous of attaining it: who is desirous of reaching it. Who is desirous of realizing it: who is desirous of arriving at it by the realization of obtainment.🔽Or alternatively, who is desirous of awakening to it: who is desirous of knowing the knowledge of the path of stream-entry. Who is desirous of awakening to it: who is desirous of knowing the knowledge of the path of once-returner.

original: puna ñātukāmassa. Paṭivijjhitukāmassāti anāgāmimaggañāṇaṃ paṭivedhavasena ñātukāmassa.
analyzed: puna ñātu kāmassa paṭivijjhitu kāmassa ati anāgāmi magga ñāṇam paṭivedha vasena ñātu kāmassa
translated: Who is desirous of penetrating it: who is desirous of knowing the knowledge of the path of non-returner by means of penetration.

original: Sambujjhitukāmassāti arahattamaggañāṇaṃ sammā ñātukāmassa. Adhigantukāmassāti catubbidhampi
analyzed: sambujjhitu kāmassa ati arahatta magga ñāṇam sammā ñātu kāmassa adhigantu kāmassa ati catubbidham pi
translated: Who is desirous of fully understanding: who is desirous of fully knowing the path of arahatship. Who is desirous of attaining: who is desirous of attaining the four kinds of analytical knowledge.

original: adhigantukāmassa. Phassitukāmassāti ñāṇaphusanāya phusitukāmassa. Sacchikātukāmassāti🔽paccavekkhaṇāya paccakkhaṃ kattukāmassa.
analyzed: adhigantu kāmassa phassitu kāmassa ati ñāṇa phusanāya phusitu kāmassa sacchikātu kāmassa ati  paccavekkhaṇāya paccakkham kattu kāmassa
translated: Who wants to fully understand: who wants to fully know the path knowledge of Arahantship. Who wants to reach: who wants to reach the four paths. Who wants to experience: who wants to experience with the experience of knowledge. Who wants to realize: who wants to realize by reviewing.

original: Catunnaṃ maggānaṃ pubbabhāge vipassanāti catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ purimakoṭṭhāse uppannaudayabbayādivipassanāñāṇāni.
analyzed: catunnam maggānam pubbabhāge vipassanā ati catunnam ariya maggānam purima koṭṭhāse uppanna odaya bbaya ādi vipassanā ñāṇāni
translated: In the insight section of the four paths: the insight knowledges of rise and fall, etc., that arise in the prior stage of the four noble paths.

original: 199. Dutiyagāthāya sapariyantacārīti sīlādīsu catūsu pariyantesu caramāno. Ḍaṃsādhipātānanti
analyzed: dutiya gāthāya sa pariyanta cārī iti sīla ādīsu catūsu pariyantesu caramānaḥ
translated: In the second stanza, he is a “wanderer with a limit”: he wanders within the four limits of virtue, etc. “From the bites of vipers and of flies”:

original: piṅgalamakkhikānañca sesamakkhikānañca. Te hi tato tato adhipatitvā khādanti, tasmā
analyzed: piṅgala makkhikānam ca sesa makkhikānam ca te hi tatas tatas adhipatitvā khādanti tasmai
translated: for the tawny house-lizard and the black house-lizard are called “bites” because they bite here and there.

original: “adhipātā”ti vuccanti. Manussaphassānanti corādiphassānaṃ.
analyzed: adhipātā ti vuccanti manussa phassānam ti cora ādi phassānam
translated: “From the touch of men”: from the touch of thieves, etc.

original: Cattāro pariyantāti cattāro mariyādā paricchedā. Antopūtibhāvaṃ paccavekkhamānoti
analyzed: cattāro pariyantā ati cattāro mariyādā paricchedāḥ antopūtibhāvam paccavekkhamāno ti
