translated: The four limits: the four boundaries, the four bounds. Reviewing the state of being rotten within:

original: abbhantare kucchitabhāvaṃ sīlavirahitabhāvaṃ olokayamāno. Anto sīlasaṃvarapariyante🔽caratīti sīlasaṃvaraparicchedabbhantare carati vicarati. Mariyādaṃ na bhindatīti
analyzed: abbhantare kucchita bhāvam sīla virahita bhāvam olokayamānaḥ antar sīla saṃvara pariyante  carati iti sīla saṃvara pariccheda bbhantare carati vicarati mariyādam na bhindati iti
translated: He goes within the bounds of virtue: he goes within the bounds of the enclosure of virtue, he moves within it.

original: sīlamariyādaṃ sīlaparicchedaṃ na kopeti.
analyzed: sīla mariyādam sīla paricchedam na kopeti
translated: He does not break the fence: he does not violate the fence of virtue, the enclosure of virtue.🔽He reflects on the Simile of the Burning: he looks at the teaching of the simile of the burning.

original: Ādittapariyāyaṃ paccavekkhamānoti ādittadesanaṃ olokento. Akkhabbhañjanavaṇapaṭicchādanaputtamaṃsūpamaṃ🔽paccavekkhamānoti sākaṭikassa akkhabbhañjanaupamañca, kuṭṭhabyādhino vaṇānaṃ paṭicchādanatelapilotikaupamañca,🔽kantārapaṭipannānaṃ jāyampatikānaṃ puttamaṃsakhādanaupamañca olokento. Bhaddekarattavihāraṃ paccavekkhamānoti –
analyzed: āditta pariyāyam paccavekkhamāno ti āditta desanam olokento  paccavekkhamānaḥ ti sākaṭikassa akkhabbhañjana opamam ca kuṭṭha byādhinaḥ vaṇānam paṭicchādana tela pilotika opamam ca  kantāra paṭipannānam jāyampatikānam putta maṃsa khādana opamañcaḥ olokentaḥ bhadda eka ratta vihāram paccavekkhamāno ti
translated: He reflects on the Simile of the Axle-Spindle, the Simile of the Salve, the Simile of the Concealed Dung, and the Simile of the Piece of Meat: he looks at the Simile of the Axle-Spindle of the carter, and the Simile of the salve, the ointment, the oil-cloth, and the bandage of the leper,

original: “Atītaṃ nānvāgameyya, nappaṭikaṅkhe anāgataṃ;🔽Taṃ ve ‘bhaddekaratto’ti, santo ācikkhate munī”ti. –
analyzed: atītam na anvāgameyya na paṭikaṅkhe anāgatam 🔽tam ve bhaddekaratto ti santaḥ ācikkhate munī iti
translated: and the Simile of the piece of meat for the quarrelling jackals, which are stated in the passage beginning, “Just as, bhikkhus, in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, when the sky is clear and free of clouds, the sun rises over the world dispelling all obscurity and darkness with its radiance, so too, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu … enters upon the rains in a residence … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase it’ … and he reflects thus: ‘I now have the opportunity to develop the meditation subject that has been allotted to me, to make it grow and increase

original: Evaṃ vuttaṃ bhaddekarattavihāraṃ olokento. Tā uppatitvā uppatitvā khādantīti nippatitvā nippatitvā khādanti.
analyzed: evam vuttam bhaddekarattavihāram olokento tāḥ uppatitvā uppatitvā khādanti iti nippatitvā nippatitvā khādanti
translated: He said this looking at the Bhaddekaratta-vihāra. “They eat, having flown down and flown down”: they eat, having flown down and flown down.

original: 200. Tatiyagāthāya paradhammikā nāma sattasahadhammikavajjā sabbepi te bāhirakā. Kusalānuesīti kusaladhamme anvesamāno.
analyzed: tatiya gāthāya paradhammikāḥ nāma satta sahadhammika vajjāḥ sabbe pi te bāhirakā kusala anuesī ti kusala dhamme anvesamānaḥ
translated: In the third stanza, “those who follow another’s doctrine” are all those outside the Dispensation who are guilty of the seven kinds of wrongness. “Seeking what is wholesome” : seeking wholesome states.

original: Satta sahadhammike ṭhapetvāti bhikkhubhikkhunīsikkhamānāsāmaṇerasāmaṇerīupāsakaupāsikāyo vajjetvā. Athāparānipi atthi abhisambhotabbānīti aparānipi madditabbāni atthi saṃvijjanti.
analyzed: satta sahadhammike ṭhapetvā ti bhikkhu bhikkhunī sikkhamānā sāmaṇera sāmaṇerī upāsaka upāsikāyaḥ vajjetvā atha aparāni api atthi abhisambhotabbāni iti aparāni api madditabbāni atthi saṃvijjanti
translated: “Excepting the seven who share the same goal” : excepting bhikkhus, bhikkhunis, male and female novices, male and female workers, and male and female lay followers. “There are others to be subdued” : there are others to be conquered.

original: 201. Catutthagāthāya ātaṅkaphassenāti rogaphassena. Sītaṃ athuṇhanti sītañca uṇhañca.🔽So tehi phuṭṭho bahudhāti so tehi ātaṅkādīhi anekehi ākārehi phuṭṭho samāno. Anokoti
analyzed: catuttha gāthāya ātaṅka phassena ati roga phassena sītam athuṇhanti sītam ca uṇham ca  so tehi phuṭṭhaḥ bahudhā ati saḥ tehi ātaṅka ādīhi anekehi ākārehi phuṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ
translated: In the fourth stanza, “by the touch of fever” : by the touch of disease. “Cold and heat” : cold and hot.

original: abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇādīnaṃ anokāsabhūto. Abbhantaradhātupakopavasena vāti sarīrabbhantare
analyzed: abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇa ādīnam anokāsa bhūtaḥ abbhantara dhātu pakopa vasena vāti sarīra abbhantare
translated: “He, being touched by many” : he, being touched by many kinds of fever, etc. “Not a void” : not a void of the formations-consciousness, etc. “By the disturbance of the internal elements” : by the disturbance of the elements within the body.

original: āpodhātukkhobhavasena vā aññadhātukkhobhavasena vā. Uṇhanti sarīrabbhantare tejodhātukkhobhavasena
analyzed: āpaḥ dhātu khobha vasena vā añña dhātu khobha vasena vā uṇhanti sarīra abbhantare tejaḥ dhātu khobha vasena
translated: Heat: through disturbance of the fire element in the body.

original: uṇhaṃ bhavati. Abhisaṅkhārasahagataviññāṇassāti kusalākusalacetanāsampayuttacittassa.
analyzed: uṇham bhavati abhisaṅkhāra sahagata viññāṇassa ati kusala akusala cetanā sampayutta cittassa
translated: Conjoined with volition: associated with profitable and unprofitable volition.

original: Okāsaṃ na karotīti avakāsaṃ patiṭṭhaṃ na karoti. Avatthitasamādānoti otaritvā gāhako.
analyzed: okāsam na karoti iti avakāsam patiṭṭham na karoti avatthita samādānaḥ ti otaritvā gāhako
translated: Does not give scope: does not give an opportunity, a footing.

original: 202. Evaṃ “bhikkhuno vijigucchato”tiādīhi tīhi gāthāhi puṭṭhamatthaṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: evam bhikkhunaḥ vijigucchataḥ tiādīhi tīhi gāthāhi puṭṭham attham vissajjetvā
translated: Having answered the question asked in the three stanzas beginning, “When a bhikkhu is disgusted,”

original: idāni “kyāssa byappathayo”tiādinā nayena puṭṭhaṃ vissajjento “theyyaṃ na kāre”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni theyyam na kārā iti ādim āha
translated: he now answers the question asked in the way beginning, “What are his wanderings?” with the words, “He does not steal.”

original: Tattha phasseti phuseyya. Yadāvilattaṃ manaso vijaññāti yaṃ cittassa āvilattaṃ vijāneyya,
analyzed: tattha phasseti phuseyya yat āvilattam manasaḥ vijaññāti yam cittassa āvilattam vijāneyya
translated: Herein, he would touch is phasse. He would know is vijaññā.

original: taṃ sabbaṃ “kaṇhassa pakkho”ti vinodayeyya.
analyzed: tam sabbam kaṇhassa pakkhaḥ iti vinodayeyya
translated: The whole of that defilement of mind is the dark side.

original: Adinnādānaṃ pahāyāti ettha adinnassa ādānaṃ adinnādānaṃ, parasaṃharaṇaṃ, theyyaṃ
analyzed: a dinna ādānam pahāya ati ettha a dinnassa ādānam a dinna ādānam para saṃharaṇam theyyam
translated: Having abandoned stealing: here the taking of what is not given is stealing, taking what belongs to another,

original: corikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha adinnanti parapariggahitaṃ, yattha paro yathākāmakāritaṃ🔽āpajjanto adaṇḍāraho anupavajjo ca hoti; tasmiṃ parapariggahite parapariggahitasaññino
analyzed: corikā iti vuttam hoti tattha adinnam ti para pariggahitam yattha paraḥ yathā kāma kāritam  āpajjantaḥ a daṇḍa ārahaḥ an upavajjaḥ ca hoti tasmin para pariggahite para pariggahita saññinaḥ
translated: “Stealing” is what is meant. Herein, “another’s property” is what is owned by another, where the other can do what he likes with it,🔽give it, etc., without incurring an offence. When that property is owned by another, and the doer of the act perceives it as such,

original: tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā theyyacetanā adinnādānaṃ. Taṃ hīne parassa santake
analyzed: tad ādāyaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā theyya cetanā adinnādānam tam hīne parassa santake
translated: and the intention to steal arises in him, and he makes an effort, and the property is removed from where it was, this is taking what is not given. It is less blameworthy when the other’s property is of little value,

original: appasāvajjaṃ, paṇīte mahāsāvajjaṃ. Kasmā? Vatthupaṇītatāya. Vatthusamatte sati guṇādhikānaṃ🔽santake vatthusmiṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ, taṃ taṃ guṇādhikaṃ upādāya tato tato hīnaguṇassa
analyzed: appa sāvajjam paṇīte mahā sāvajjam kasmā vatthu paṇīta tāya vatthu samatte sati guṇa adhikānam  santake vatthusmim mahā sāvajjam tam tam guṇa adhikam upādāya tatas tatas hīna guṇassa
translated: more blameworthy when it is of great value. Why? Because of the value of the property. When the value of the property is the same,🔽it is more blameworthy when the other is a person of greater qualities,

original: santake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ.
analyzed: santake vatthusmim appasāvajjam
translated: and less blameworthy when the other is a person of lesser qualities.

original: Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – parapariggahitaṃ, parapariggahitasaññitā, theyyacittaṃ,
analyzed: tassa pañca sambhārāḥ honti para pariggahitam para pariggahita saññitā theyya cittam
translated: It has five constituents: another’s property, the perception of it as such, the intention to steal,

original: upakkamo, tena haraṇanti. Pahāyāti imaṃ adinnādānacetanāsaṅkhātaṃ dussīlyaṃ pajahitvā.
analyzed: tena haraṇanti pahāya ati imam adinnādāna cetanā saṅkhātam dussīlyam pajahitvā
translated: the effort, and the removal of the property from where it was. “Having abandoned” : having given up the unvirtuousness called the intention to steal.

original: Paṭiviratoti pahīnakālato paṭṭhāya tato dussīlyato orato viratova. Dinnameva ādiyatīti🔽dinnādāyī. Cittenapi dinnameva paṭikaṅkhatīti dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Thenetīti theno, na
analyzed: paṭivirataḥ ti pahīna kālato paṭṭhāya tatas dussīlyato orataḥ virataḥ uva dinnam eva ādiyati iti  dinna ādāyī cittena api dinnam eva paṭikaṅkhati iti dinna pāṭikaṅkhī thenā iti iti thenaḥ na
translated: “Abstained” : from the time of abandoning, he is “abstained” from that unvirtuousness. “He takes only what is given” :

original: thenena athenena. Athenattāyeva sucibhūtena. Attanāti attabhāvena, athenaṃ sucibhūtaṃ🔽attabhāvaṃ katvā viharatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Ito paraṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: thenena athenena athenattāya iva sucibhūtena attanāti atta bhāvena athenam sucibhūtam  atta bhāvam katvā viharati iti vuttam hoti itas param vutta nayam eva
translated: “He who takes only what is given” . He desires only what is given even in his mind. “He is a man” : he is a man. “Not a man” : not a man. “Not a man” because of being pure. “With himself” : with his own person. “He lives” : he lives with his own person made pure. The rest is in the way already stated.

original: Mettāyanavasena metti. Mettākāro mettāyanā. Mettāya ayitassa mettāsamaṅgino cittassa🔽bhāvo mettāyitattaṃ. Anudayatīti anudayā, rakkhatīti attho. Anudayākāro anudayanā.
analyzed: mettāyana vasena metti mettā ākāraḥ mettāyanā mettāya ayitassa mettā samaṅgino cittassa  bhāvaḥ mettāyitattam anudayati iti anudayā rakkhati iti atthaḥ anudaya ākāraḥ anudayanā
translated: “Loving” : through the state of loving-kindness. “The aspect of loving-kindness” : loving-kindness. “The state of loving-kindness” : the state of the mind of one possessing loving-kindness.🔽“He is one who has loving-kindness” . “He guards” : the meaning is that he protects. “The aspect of guarding” : guarding.

original: Anudayitassa bhāvo anudayitattaṃ. Hitassa esanavasena hitesitā. Anukampanavasena
analyzed: anudayitassa bhāvaḥ anudayita ttam hitassa esana vasena hita isitāḥ anukampana vasena
translated: “The state of guarding” : the state of one who guards. “He wishes for the welfare” : through the state of seeking welfare. “He has compassion” : through the state of compassion.

original: anukampā. Sabbehipi imehi padehi upacārappanāppattāva mettā vuttā. Vipulenāti ettha
analyzed: anukampā sabbehi pi imehi padehi mettā vuttā vipulena ati ettha
translated: Through all these terms loving-kindness that has reached access and absorption is spoken of. “Extensive” :

original: pharaṇavasena vipulatā daṭṭhabbā. Bhūmivasena pana taṃ mahaggataṃ. Paguṇavasena appamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: pharaṇa vasena vipula tā daṭṭhabbā bhūmi vasena pana tam mahaggatam paguṇa vasena appamāṇam
translated: It should be seen as extensive in the sense of pervading. But it is exalted in the sense of plane. It is immeasurable in the sense of being not limited by loving-kindness, etc., and in the sense of being not limited by the measure of beings’ lives, etc.

original: Sattārammaṇavasena ca appamāṇaṃ. Byāpādapaccatthikappahānena averaṃ. Domanassappahānato
analyzed: satta ārammaṇa vasena ca appamāṇam byāpāda paccatthika ppahānena averam domanassa ppahānato
translated: It is immeasurable in the sense of being not limited by the measure of beings’ lives, etc., and in the sense of being not limited by the measure of the extent of the earth, etc.🔽It is friendless in the sense of absence of hate because of the abandoning of ill will and enmity.

original: abyāpajjaṃ, niddukkhanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: a byāpajjam niddukkham ti vuttam hoti
translated: It is harmless in the sense of absence of annoyance because of the abandoning of annoyance.🔽It is unclouded in the sense of absence of anger.

original: Āvilanti appasannaṃ. Luḷitanti kalalaṃ. Eritanti asanniṭṭhānaṃ. Ghaṭṭitanti ārammaṇena ghaṭṭanamāpāditaṃ. Calitanti kampamānaṃ. Bhantanti vibbhantaṃ. Avūpasantanti anibbutaṃ.
analyzed: āvilanti appasannam luḷitanti kalalam eritanti a sanniṭṭhānam ghaṭṭitanti ārammaṇena ghaṭṭanam āpāditam calitanti kampamānam bhantanti vibbhantam a vūpasantanti anibbutaṃ
translated: It is unruffled in the sense of absence of agitation. It is undisturbed in the sense of absence of disturbance. It is unmoved in the sense of absence of movement. It is unagitated in the sense of absence of agitation. It is calm in the sense of absence of burning up.

original: Yo so māroti evamādīsu mahājanaṃ anatthe niyojetvā māretīti māro. Kaṇhakammattā kaṇho.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ māro ti evamādīsu mahājanam anatthe niyojetvā māreti iti māro kaṇha kammattā kaṇho
translated: As to the words “This is Mara, the Evil One,” etc., he is Mara because he causes great multitudes of people to be led to what is unprofitable and to be destroyed. He is the Black One because of the blackness of the unprofitable.

original: Kāmāvacarissarattā adhipati. Maraṇaṃ pāpanato antagū. Muñcituṃ appadānaṭṭhena namuci.
analyzed: adhipati maraṇam pāpanataḥ antagū muñcitum appadāna ṭṭhena namuci
translated: He is the Lord because he is the chief of the sense-desire realm. He is the Ender because he is the end of evil. He is Namuci because he is incapable of being released.

original: Mārassa baḷisanti mārabaḷisaṃ. Vaṭṭasannissitaṭṭhena mārassa āmisanti mārāmisaṃ.
analyzed: mārassa baḷisanti māra baḷisam vaṭṭa sannissita ṭṭhena mārassa āmisanti māra āmisam
translated: The bait of Mara is the bait of Mara. The bait of Mara’s realm is the bait of Mara’s realm.

original: Vasavattanaṭṭhena mārassa visayoti māravisayo. Gocaraṭṭhena mārassa nivāsoti māranivāso.
analyzed: vasa vattana ṭṭhena mārassa visayo ti māra visayaḥ gocara ṭṭhena mārassa nivāso ti māra nivāso
translated: As the domain of the Lord of Death by way of the domain of the Lord of Death, as the abode of the Lord of Death by way of the abode of the Lord of Death,

original: Kāmacāraṃ caraṭṭhena mārassa gocaroti māragocaro. Duppamuñcanaṭṭhena mārassa bandhananti
analyzed: kāmacāram cara ṭṭhena mārassa gocaro ti māra gocaraḥ duppamuñcana ṭṭhena mārassa bandhanan ti
translated: as the domain of the Lord of Death by way of the domain of the Lord of Death, as the bondage of the Lord of Death by way of the bondage of the Lord of Death,

original: mārabandhanaṃ. Dukkhuddayoti dukkhabandhano.
analyzed: māra bandhanam dukkhuddayo ti dukkha bandhano
translated: as the bondage of suffering by way of the bondage of suffering.🔽And their root would stand exposed: the root of their anger and conceit,

original: 203. Mūlampi tesaṃ palikhañña tiṭṭheti tesaṃ kodhātimānānaṃ yaṃ avijjādikaṃ mūlaṃ,🔽tampi palikhaṇitvā tiṭṭheyya. Addhā bhavanto abhisambhaveyyāti etaṃ piyāpiyaṃ abhibhavanto
analyzed: mūlam pi tesam palikhañña tiṭṭha iti tesam kodha atimānānam yam avijjā ādikam mūlam  tam pi palikhaṇitvā tiṭṭheyya addhā bhavantaḥ abhisambhaveyya ati etam piya apiyam abhibhavantaḥ
translated: which is ignorance, would stand exposed.🔽You would certainly attain full enlightenment: the meaning is that, overcoming the dear and the not dear,

original: ekaṃseneva abhibhaveyya, na tattha sithilaṃ parakkameyyāti adhippāyo.🔽Avijjā mūlantiādayo avijjā kodhassa upanissayasahajātādivasena mūlaṃ hoti. Anupāyamanasikāro
analyzed: ekaṃsena iva abhibhaveyya na tattha sithilam parakkameyya ati adhippāyaḥ  avijjā mūlam ti ādayaḥ avijjā kodhassa upanissaya sahajāta ādi vasena mūlam hoti anupāya manasikāro
translated: you would certainly overcome them without exception, and you would not be slack in exerting yourself in that.🔽Ignorance is the root, etc.: ignorance is the root of anger by way of decisive support, conascence, etc.;🔽wrong reflection and conceit are the roots by way of decisive support only;

original: ca asmimāno ca ime dve upanissayavaseneva. Ahirikaanottappauddhaccā ime tayo upanissayasahajātādivasena
analyzed: ca asmimāno ca ime dve upanissaya vasena iva ahirika anottappa auddhaccāḥ ime tayo upanissaya sahajāta ādi vasena
translated: shamelessness, fearlessness of wrongdoing, and agitation are the roots by way of decisive support, conascence, etc.;

original: mūlāni honti, tathā atimānassāpi.
analyzed: mūlāni honti tathā atimānassa api
translated: so too with conceit.

original: 204. Paññaṃ purakkhatvāti paññaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā. Kalyāṇapītīti kalyāṇapītiyā samannāgato. Caturo sahetha paridevadhammeti anantaragāthāya vuccamāne paridevanīyadhamme saheyya.🔽Vicayabahuloti parivīmaṃsanabahulo. Pavicayabahuloti visesena vīmaṃsanabahulo. Pekkhāyanabahuloti
analyzed: paññam purakkhatvā ati paññam pubbaṅgamam katvā kalyāṇa pītī iti kalyāṇa pītiyā samannāgataḥ caturo sahetha parideva dhamme iti anantara gāthāya vuccamāne paridevanīya dhamme saheyya  vicaya bahulo ti parivīmaṃsana bahulaḥ pavicaya bahulaḥ ti visesena vīmaṃsana bahulaḥ pekkhāyana bahulaḥ ti
translated: “With wisdom gone before”: with wisdom as the forerunner. “Possessed of noble rapture”: endowed with noble rapture. “Bear the four kinds of reproach”: he would bear the things that are the basis for reproach mentioned in the following verse.🔽“Abundant in investigation”: abundant in investigation of the general characteristics. “Abundant in search”: abundant in search of the specific characteristics. “Abundant in looking about”:

original: ikkhaṇabahulo. Samekkhāyanabahuloti esanabahulo. Vibhūtavihārīti pākaṭaṃ katvā ñātavihārī.
analyzed: ikkhaṇa bahulaḥ samekkhāyana bahulaḥ iti esana bahulaḥ vibhūta vihārī iti pākaṭam katvā ñāta vihārī
translated: abundant in looking about by way of the four foundations of mindfulness. “Abundant in scrutiny”: abundant in scrutiny by way of the four noble truths.

original: Abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha tāva abhikkantaṃ vuccati gamanaṃ. Paṭikkantaṃ nivattanaṃ.
analyzed: abhikkante paṭikkante iti ettha tāva abhikkantam vuccati gamanam paṭikkantam nivattanam
translated: “In going out and coming back”: here, going out is called going forward, and coming back is called returning.

original: Tadubhayampi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati. Gamane tāva purato kāyaṃ abhiharanto abhikkamati
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati gamane tāva puratas kāyam abhiharantaḥ abhikkamati
translated: Both are found in the four postures. In going forward, one goes forward by advancing the body.

original: nāma. Paṭinivattento paṭikkamati nāma. Ṭhānepi ṭhitakova kāyaṃ purato onamento abhikkamati
analyzed: nāma paṭinivattento paṭikkamati nāma ṭhāne pi ṭhitakaḥ uva kāyam puratas onamentaḥ abhikkamati
translated: In returning, one returns by withdrawing the body. In standing, one goes forward and comes back by bending and stretching the body respectively.

original: nāma. Pacchato apanāmento paṭikkamati nāma. Nisajjāyapi nisinnakova āsanassa purimaaṅgābhimukho
analyzed: nāma pacchatas apanāmento paṭikkamati nāma āsanassa purima aṅga abhimukho
translated: He is said to go forward when he moves forward. He is said to go backward when he moves backward.

original: saṃsaranto abhikkamati nāma. Pacchimaaṅgappadesaṃ pacchā saṃsaranto paṭikkamati nāma.
analyzed: saṃsarantaḥ abhikkamati nāma pacchima aṅga ppadesam pacchā saṃsarantaḥ paṭikkamati nāma
translated: He is said to go forward when he moves forward. He is said to go backward when he moves backward.

original: Nipajjāyapi eseva nayo.
analyzed: nipad jāyapi e sa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies to sitting and lying down.

original: Sampajānakārī hotīti sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī, sampajaññameva vā kārī hoti. So
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti iti sampajaññena sabba kicca kārī sampajaññam eva vā kārī hoti saḥ
translated: He is said to be “fully aware” when he does all his actions with full awareness, or when he is simply an agent of full awareness.

original: hi abhikkantādīsu sampajaññaṃ karoteva, na katthaci sampajaññavirahito hoti. Ālokite
analyzed: hi abhikkanta ādīsu sampajaññam karotā iva na katthaci sampajañña virahitaḥ hoti ālokite
translated: For he is fully aware of going forward, etc., and he is never devoid of full awareness in any posture.

original: vilokiteti ettha pana ālokitaṃ nāma purato pekkhanaṃ. Vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhanaṃ.
analyzed: vilokita iti ettha pana ālokitam nāma puratas pekkhanam vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhanam
translated: When he looks straight on, etc., here, looking straight on is looking in front. Looking away is looking in the other directions.

original: Aññānipi heṭṭhā upari pacchato pekkhanavasena olokitaullokitaapalokitāni nāma honti.
analyzed: aññāni api heṭṭhā upari pacchatas pekkhana vasena olokita aullokita apalokitāni nāma honti
translated: There are also looking down, looking up, and looking around.

original: Tāni idha na gahitāni. Sāruppavasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni, iminā vā mukhena
analyzed: tāni idha na gahitāni sāruppa vasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni iminā vā mukhena
translated: But these are not included here. Or these two are included by way of their resemblance to looking straight on and looking away.

original: sabbāni gahitānevāti.
analyzed: sabbāni gahitāni eva ati
translated: Or all are included by this method.

original: Samiñjite pasāriteti pabbānaṃ samiñjanapasāraṇe. Saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇeti ettha
analyzed: samiñjite pasāritā iti pabbānam samiñjana pasāraṇe saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇā iti ettha
translated: In flexing and extending: in the flexing and extending of the limbs. In wearing the robe, bowl, and the other requisites:

original: saṅghāṭicīvarānaṃ nivāsanapārupanavasena, pattassa bhikkhāpaṭiggahaṇādivasena paribhogo🔽dhāraṇaṃ nāma. Asitādīsu asiteti piṇḍapātabhojane. Pīteti yāguādipāne. Khāyiteti
analyzed: saṅghāṭi cīvarānam nivāsana pārupana vasena pattassa bhikkhā paṭiggahaṇa ādi vasena paribhogaḥ  dhāraṇam nāma asita ādīsu asita iti piṇḍapāta bhojane pīta iti yāgu ādi pāne
translated: Herein, wearing the robe and the other requisites is the use of the outer robe, etc., by way of wearing it, and the use of the bowl by way of carrying it, etc.🔽This is called wearing. In eating, drinking, tasting, and sucking: in eating alms food, etc.; in drinking beverages, etc.; in tasting such things as mouthfuls of food, etc.;

original: piṭṭhakhajjakādikhādane. Sāyiteti madhuphāṇitādisāyane. Uccārapassāvakammeti uccārassa🔽ca passāvassa ca karaṇe. Gatādīsu gateti gamane. Ṭhiteti ṭhāne. Nisinneti nisajjāya.
analyzed: piṭṭha khajjaka ādi khādane sāyita iti madhu phāṇita ādi sāyane uccāra passāva kammā iti uccārassa  ca passa avassa ca karaṇe gata ādīsu gatā iti gamane ṭhitā iti ṭhāne nisinnā iti nisajjāya
translated: and in sucking such things as molasses, etc. In defecating and in urinating:🔽in defecating and in urinating. In walking, standing, sitting, lying down, staying awake: in walking, etc.

original: Sutteti sayane. Jāgariteti jāgaraṇe. Bhāsiteti kathane. Tattha upādārūpassa saddāyatanassa
analyzed: sutta iti sayane jāgarita iti jāgaraṇe bhāsita iti kathane tattha upādā rūpassa sadda āyatanassa
translated: In speaking and in remaining silent: when there is no occurrence of the sound base as a derivative materiality,

original: appavatte sati bhāsitā nāma na hoti, tasmiṃ pavattante hotīti pariggāhako bhikkhu
analyzed: appavatte sati bhāsitā nāma na hoti tasmin pavattante hoti iti pariggāhakaḥ bhikkhu
translated: there is no speaking; when there is its occurrence, there is speaking. Thus the bhikkhu who is the observer of this is called one who is aware of speaking.

original: bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma hoti. Vimuttāyatanasīsena dhammaṃ desentopi bāttiṃsatiracchānakathaṃ
analyzed: bhāsite sampajāna kārī nāma hoti vimutta āyatana sīsena dhammam desentaḥ api
translated: In teaching the Dhamma by way of the thirty-two basic contemplations,

original: pahāya dasakathāvatthunissitaṃ kathaṃ kathentopi bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma. Tuṇhībhāveti
analyzed: pahāya dasa kathā vatthu nissitam katham kathentaḥ api bhāsite sampajāna kārī nāma tuṇhībhāveti
translated: “Silence” is

original: akathane. Tattha upādārūpassa saddāyatanassa pavattiyaṃ tuṇhībhāvo nāma natthi, appavattiyaṃ
analyzed: a kathane tattha upādā rūpassa sadda āyatanassa pavattiyam tuṇhībhāvaḥ nāma natthi appavattiyam
translated: non-speaking. Herein, there is no such thing as the non-occurrence of the sound base, which is a derived materiality.

original: hotīti pariggāhako bhikkhu tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāma hoti. Aṭṭhatiṃsaārammaṇesu🔽cittaruciyaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā nisinnopi dutiyajjhānaṃ samāpannopi tuṇhībhāve
analyzed: hoti iti pariggāhakaḥ bhikkhu tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī nāma hoti aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇesu  cittaruciyam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā nisinnaḥ api dutiya jhānam samāpannaḥ api tuṇhībhāve
translated: So the bhikkhu who is the subject of the exercise is called “one who is fully aware of the act of silence” when he is not speaking.🔽When he is sitting down after taking a meditation subject from among the thirty-eight meditation subjects, or when he has attained the second jhāna, he is called “one who is fully aware of the act of silence.”

original: sampajānakārī nāma. Ettha ca eko iriyāpatho dvīsu ṭhānesu āgato. So heṭṭhā abhikkante🔽paṭikkanteti ettha bhikkhācāragāmaṃ gacchato āgacchato ca addhānagamanavasena kathito.
analyzed: sampajānakārī nāma ettha ca ekaḥ iriyāpathaḥ dvīsu ṭhānesu āgataḥ saḥ heṭṭhā abhikkante  paṭikkantā iti ettha bhikkhācāra gāmam gacchataḥ āgacchataḥ ca addhāna gamana vasena kathito
translated: And here one bodily action is mentioned in two places. It is mentioned in the first place as “going forward and returning” in the passage, “On going forward and on going back” , where it is called “going forward” in the sense of going out to the alms-resort village, and “returning” in the sense of coming back from there.🔽And it is mentioned in the second place as “in going, in standing … in walking” in the passage, “In going forward and in returning” , where it is called “going” in the sense of the progress of the path, and “returning” in the sense of the progress of the place already traversed.

original: Gate ṭhiteti ettha vihāre cuṇṇikapāduddhāravasena kathitoti veditabbo. Buddhānussativasenātiādayo
analyzed: gate ṭhitā iti ettha vihāre cuṇṇika pāda uddhāra vasena kathitaḥ iti veditabbaḥ buddha anussati vasena ati ādayaḥ
translated: “By means of recollection of the Buddha” , etc.,

original: heṭṭhā tattha tattha pakāsitā eva.
analyzed: heṭṭhā tattha tattha pakāsitāḥ eva
translated: are all stated in the appropriate places below.

original: Aratīti ratipaṭikkhepo. Aratitāti aramanākāro. Anabhiratīti anabhiratabhāvo. Anabhiramanāti
analyzed: arati iti rati paṭikkhepaḥ a rati tā ati a ramana ākāraḥ an abhirati iti an abhirata bhāvaḥ
translated: Displeasure is the opposite of pleasure. Disliking is the state of not liking. Discontentedness is the state of being discontented. Discontent is the state of being discontent.

original: anabhiramanākāro. Ukkaṇṭhitāti ukkaṇṭhanākāro. Paritassitāti ukkaṇṭhanavaseneva paritassanā.
analyzed: an abhiramana ākāraḥ ukkaṇṭhitā ati ukkaṇṭhana ākāraḥ paritassitā ati ukkaṇṭhana vasena iva paritassanā
translated: Disenchantment is the state of being disenchanted. Anxiety is the state of being anxious, due to disenchantment.

original: 205. Kiṃ sū asissanti kiṃ bhuñjissāmi. Kuva vā asissanti kuhiṃ vā asissāmi. Dukkhaṃ
analyzed: kim sū asissanti kim bhuñjissāmi kuva vā asissanti kuhim vā asissāmi dukkham
translated: “What shall I eat? What shall I eat? Where shall I eat? Where shall I eat?

original: vata settha kuvajja sessanti imaṃ rattiṃ dukkhaṃ sayiṃ, ajja āgamanarattiṃ kattha
analyzed: vata settha kuvajja sessanti imam rattim dukkham sayim ajja āgamana rattim kattha
translated: Oh, what suffering! Where shall I lie down this night? I lay down in suffering last night. Where shall I lie down

original: sayissaṃ. Ete vitakketi ete piṇḍapātanissite dve, senāsananissite dveti cattāro vitakke.
analyzed: ete vitakke iti ete piṇḍapāta nissite dve senāsana nissite dve iti cattāraḥ vitakke
translated: on the night of my arrival?” These are the four thoughts connected with almsfood and the two connected with lodging, making six thoughts.

original: Aniketacārīti apalibodhacārī nittaṇhacārī.
analyzed: aniketa cārī iti a palibodha cārī nittaṇha cārī
translated: “One who goes without a fixed abode” is one who goes without obstruction, one who goes without attachment.

original: Phalake vāti vaṅkādiphalakapīṭhe ca. Āgāmirattinti āgamanirattiyaṃ. Ādevaneyyeti visesena devaniyye. Paridevaneyyeti samantato devaniyye.
analyzed: phalake vāti vaṅka ādi phalaka pīṭhe ca āgāmi rattinti āgama nirattiyam ādevaneyyā iti visesena deva niyye paridevaneyyā iti samantataḥ deva niyye
translated: “On a plank” is on a plank bed, etc. “On the night of arrival” is on the night of arrival. “To be invited” is to be invited in particular. “To be invited all round” is to be invited everywhere.🔽“At the time of almsfood” is at the time of almsfood, which is called food, or at the time of robes, which is called

original: 206. Kāleti piṇḍapātakāle piṇḍapātasaṅkhātaṃ annaṃ vā, cīvarakāle cīvarasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: kāla iti piṇḍapāta kāle piṇḍapāta saṅkhātam annam vā cīvara kāle cīvara saṅkhātam
translated: robes.

original: vasanaṃ vā laddhā dhammena samenāti adhippāyo. Mattaṃ sa jaññāti pariggahe ca paribhoge
analyzed: vasanam vā laddhā dhammena samena ati adhippāyaḥ mattam sa jaññāti pariggahe ca paribhoge
translated: or having received robes, he uses them according to the Dhamma. The meaning is: he knows the right amount in acquiring and using.

original: ca so pamāṇaṃ jāneyya. Idhāti sāsane, nipātamattameva vā etaṃ. Tosanatthanti santosatthaṃ,
analyzed: ca saḥ pamāṇam jāneyyaḥ idha ati sāsane nipātam attam eva vai etam tosanatthanti santosattham
translated: or having received the robe-cloth, he should be satisfied with it in accordance with the Dhamma. This is the intention. He should know the right amount: he should know the measure in receiving and in using. Here: in the Dispensation. Or this is merely a particle. For the sake of contentment: for the sake of being satisfied.

original: etadatthaṃ mattaṃ jāneyyāti vuttaṃ hoti. So tesu guttoti so bhikkhu tesu paccayesu🔽gutto. Yatacārīti saññatavihāro, rakkhitairiyāpatho rakkhitakāyavacīmanodvāro cāti
analyzed: etad attham mattam jāneyya iti vuttam hoti saḥ tesu guttaḥ ti saḥ bhikkhu tesu paccayesu  guttaḥ yata cārī iti saññata vihāraḥ rakkhita eriyāpathaḥ rakkhita kāya vacī manaḥ dvāro ca ati
translated: What is meant is: he should know the right amount for that. He should be restrained: that bhikkhu should be restrained with regard to those requisites.🔽One who goes about secluded: one who lives restrained, one who guards the doors of the sense faculties, one who is moderate in eating, and one who is devoted to vigilance.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. “Yaticārī”tipi pāṭho, esoyevattho. Rusitoti rosito. Ghaṭṭitoti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Dvīhi kāraṇehi mattaṃ jāneyyāti dvīhi bhāgehi pamāṇaṃ jāneyya. Paṭiggahaṇato vāti🔽parehi diyyamānaggahaṇakālato vā. Paribhogato vāti paribhuñjanakālato vā. Thokepi
analyzed: vuttam hoti yaticārī iti pi pāṭhaḥ rusitaḥ iti rositaḥ ghaṭṭitaḥ iti vuttam hoti  dvīhi kāraṇehi mattam jāneyya ati dvīhi bhāgehi pamāṇam jāneyya paṭiggahaṇataḥ vā ati  parehi diyyamāna ggahaṇa kālataḥ vā paribhogataḥ vā ati paribhuñjana kālataḥ vā thoke pi
translated: The reading yaticārī is also found, and the meaning is the same. Angry: enraged.

original: diyyamāneti appakepi diyyamāne. Kulānudayāyāti kulānaṃ anudayatāya. Kulānurakkhāyāti
analyzed: diyyamāne iti appake api diyyamāne kula anudayāya ati kulānam anudaya tāya kula anurakkhāya ati
translated: He should know the right amount for two reasons: he should know the measure in two ways. From the receiving: from the time of receiving what is given by others. Or from the using: from the time of using. Even if only a little is given: even if only a small amount is given. For the sake of the growth of families: for the sake of the prosperity of families. For the sake of the protection of families: for the sake of the security of families.

original: kulānaṃ anurakkhaṇatthāya. Paṭiggaṇhātīti thokampi gaṇhāti. Bahukepi diyyamāneti
analyzed: kulānam anurakkhaṇa tthāya paṭiggaṇhāti iti thokam pi gaṇhāti bahuke pi diyyamāne iti
translated: for the purpose of protecting the families. He accepts: he accepts even a little. Even if given in small quantities:

original: anappakepi diyyamāne. Kāyaparihārikaṃ cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhātīti ettha kāyaṃ pariharati
analyzed: anappake pi diyyamāne kāyaparihārikam cīvaram paṭiggaṇhāti iti ettha kāyam pariharati
translated: even if given in small quantities. He accepts robe-cloth for bodily use: here, it is bodily use

original: posetīti kāyaparihārikaṃ. Kucchiparihārikanti kucchiṃ pariharati posetīti kucchiparihārikaṃ.
analyzed: posa iti iti kāya parihārikam kucchi parihārikam ti kucchim pariharati posa iti iti kucchi parihārikam
translated: because it protects the body, it nourishes it. It is for stomach use because it protects the stomach, it nourishes it.

original: Itarītarapaccayasantosena samannāgatassa bhikkhuno aṭṭha parikkhārā vaṭṭanti tīṇi
analyzed: itarītara paccaya santosena samannāgatassa bhikkhuno aṭṭha parikkhārāḥ vaṭṭanti tīṇi
translated: The eight requisites are allowable for a bhikkhu who is satisfied with whatever is obtained as the necessary conditions for the life of a bhikkhu. They are

original: cīvarāni patto dantakaṭṭhacchedanavāsi ekā sūci kāyabandhanaṃ parissāvananti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –🔽“Ticīvarañca patto ca, vāsi sūci ca bandhanaṃ;
analyzed: cīvarāni pattaḥ danta kaṭṭha chedana vāsi ekā sūci kāyabandhanam parissāvananti vuttam pi ca itam  ti cīvaram ca patto ca vāsi sūci ca bandhanam
translated: three robes, a bowl, a razor, a needle, a belt, and a water strainer. And this is said:

original: Parissāvanena aṭṭhete, yuttayogassa bhikkhuno”ti. ;
analyzed: parissāvanena aṭṭhete yutta yogassa bhikkhuno ti
translated: “Three robes, a bowl, a razor, A needle, a belt, and a water strainer, These eight are allowable for a bhikkhu Who is devoted to the practice of meditation.”

original: Te sabbe kāyaparihārikāpi honti kucchiparihārikāpi. Kathaṃ? Ticīvaraṃ tāva nivāsetvā
analyzed: te sabbe kāya parihārikāḥ api honti kucchi parihārikāḥ api katham ti cīvaram nivāsetvā
translated: All these are for bodily use and for stomach use. How? First, the three robes: having put on the upper robe and the inner robe,

original: ca pārupitvā ca vicaraṇakāle kāyaṃ pariharati posetīti kāyaparihārikaṃ hoti. Cīvarakaṇṇena
analyzed: ca ca vicaraṇa kāle kāyam pariharati posa iti iti kāya parihārikam hoti cīvara kaṇṇena
translated: and when he walks about wearing it, it is a body-covering.

original: udakaṃ parissāvetvā pivanakāle khāditabbaphalāphalaggahaṇakāle ca kucchiṃ pariharati🔽posetīti kucchiparihārikaṃ hoti.
analyzed: udakam parissāvetvā pivana kāle khāditabba phala a phala ggahaṇa kāle ca kucchim pariharati  posā iti iti kucchi parihārikam hoti
translated: When he wets the edge of the robe with water and drinks it, and when he picks up the fruit of trees to eat, it is a belly-covering.

original: Pattopi tena udakaṃ uddharitvā nhānakāle kuṭiparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca kāyaparihāriko
analyzed: pattaḥ api tena udakam uddharitvā nhāna kāle kuṭi paribhaṇḍa karaṇa kāle ca kāya parihārikaḥ
translated: The bowl, too, is a body-covering when he uses it to scoop up water for bathing, and when he uses it as a tool for making repairs to the hut.

original: hoti. Āhāraṃ gahetvā bhuñjanakāle kucchiparihāriko. Vāsipi tāya dantakaṭṭhacchedanakāle🔽mañcapīṭhānaṃ aṅgapādacīvarakuṭidaṇḍakasajjanakāle ca kāyaparihārikā hoti. Ucchucchedananāḷikerāditacchanakāle🔽kucchiparihārikā. Sūci cīvarasibbanakāle kāyaparihārikā hoti. Pūvaṃ vā phalaṃ vā
analyzed: āhāram gahetvā bhuñjana kāle kucchiparihārikaḥ danta kaṭṭha chedana kāle  aṅga pāda cīvara kuṭi daṇḍaka sajjana kāle ca kāya parihārikāḥ ucchu chedana nāḷikera ādi tacchana kāle  kucchi parihārikā sūci cīvara sibbana kāle kāya parihārikā hoti pūvam vā phalam vā
translated: It is a belly-covering when he eats his meal after taking it in the bowl.🔽The knife is a body-covering when he uses it to cut tooth-cleansers,🔽and it is a belly-covering when he uses it to cut the tops off sugar-cane, coconuts, etc.,

original: vijjhitvā khādanakāle kucchiparihārikā. Kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā vicaraṇakāle kāyaparihārikaṃ.
analyzed: vijjhitvā khādana kāle kucchi parihārikā kāya bandhanam bandhitvā vicaraṇa kāle kāya parihārikam
translated: The needle is a body-covering when he uses it to sew robes, and it is a belly-covering when he uses it to sew a bag for carrying rice.🔽The waist-band is a body-covering when he wears it after tying it on.

original: Ucchuādīni bandhitvā gahaṇakāle kucchiparihārikaṃ. Parissāvanaṃ tena udakaṃ parissāvetvā🔽nhānakāle senāsanaparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca kāyaparihārikaṃ, pānīyapāṇakaparissāvanakāle
analyzed: ucchu ādīni bandhitvā gahaṇa kāle kucchi parihārikam parissāvanam tena udakam parissāvetvā  nhāna kāle senāsana paribhaṇḍa karaṇa kāle ca kāya parihārikam pānīya pāṇaka parissāvana kāle
translated: When he is taking it up, binding it together, etc., it is for the sake of the belly.🔽When he is bathing, and when he is making a sunshade or a carrying- net for his bowl, it is for the sake of the body.

original: teneva tilataṇḍulaputhukādīni gahetvā khādanakāle ca kucchiparihārikaṃ.🔽Paṭisaṅkhāyonisoti upāyena pathena paṭisaṅkhāya ñatvā, paccavekkhitvāti attho. Ettha
analyzed: tena iva tila taṇḍula puthuka ādīni gahetvā khādana kāle ca kucchi parihārikam  paṭisaṅkhāya unisaḥ ti upāyena pathena paṭisaṅkhāya ñatvā paccavekkhitvā atthaḥ ettha
translated: When he is straining water for drinking or washing, and when he is taking up sesame seeds, rice, cakes, etc., with it, it is for the sake of the belly.🔽With proper attention: having properly and wisely reflected, having considered, is the meaning.

original: ca “sītassa paṭighātāyā”tiādinā nayena vuttapaccavekkhaṇameva yoniso paṭisaṅkhāti
analyzed: ca sītassa paṭighātāya ati ādinā nayena vutta paccavekkhaṇam eva yonisas
translated: And here the proper reflection should be understood to be that stated in the way beginning, “He considers thus: ‘I am now using robe-material for the purpose of warding off cold, for the purpose of warding off heat’ , etc.🔽Herein, robe-material is any kind of robe-material, inner cloth, etc.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tattha cīvaranti antaravāsakādīsu yaṃkiñci. Paṭisevatīti paribhuñjati🔽nivāseti vā pārupati vā. Yāvadevāti payojanāvadhiparicchedaniyamavacanaṃ. Ettakameva
analyzed: veditabbam tattha cīvaranti antaravāsaka ādīsu yaṃ kiñci paṭisevati iti paribhuñjati  nivāsa iti vā vā yāvat eva ati payojana avadhi pariccheda niyama vacanam ettakam eva
translated: He uses: he makes use of it, or he wears it.

original: hi yogino cīvarapaṭisevane payojanaṃ, yadidaṃ sītassa paṭighātāyātiādi, na ito bhiyyo.
analyzed: hi yogino cīvara paṭisevane payojanam yat idam sītassa paṭighātāya atiādi na itas bhiyyas
translated: As much as: this is a delimitation by definition of the extent of the purpose. For this is the extent of the purpose in using robe-material, that is to say, for the purpose of warding off cold, etc.; there is no purpose beyond this.

original: Sītassāti ajjhattadhātukkhobhavasena vā bahiddhā utupariṇāmanavasena vā uppannassa🔽yassa kassaci sītassa.
analyzed: sītassa ati ajjhatta dhātu khobha vasena vā bahiddhā utu pariṇāmana vasena vā uppannassa  yassa kassaci sītassa
translated: ‘Cold’: any cold that has arisen either through disturbance of the elements in the body or through change of weather.

original: Paṭighātāyāti paṭihananatthaṃ. Yathā sarīre ābādhaṃ na uppādeti, evaṃ tassa vinodanatthaṃ.🔽Sītabbhāhate hi sarīre vikkhittacitto yoniso padahituṃ na sakkoti. Tasmā sītassa
analyzed: paṭighātāya ati paṭihanana attham yathā sarīre ābādham na uppādeti evam tassa vinodana attham  sīta bbha āhate hi sarīre vikkhitta cittaḥ yonisas padahitum na sakkoti tasmā sītassa
translated: ‘For the purpose of warding off’: for the purpose of warding it off, for the purpose of dispelling it, so that it does not arise in the body.🔽For when the body is afflicted by cold, the mind is distracted and cannot be concentrated properly. Therefore the Blessed One allowed the use of robes

original: paṭighātāya cīvaraṃ sevitabbanti bhagavā anuññāsi. Esa nayo sabbattha. Kevalañhettha
analyzed: paṭighātāya cīvaram sevitabbanti bhagavā anuññāsi esa nayaḥ sabbattha kevalam ha ittha
translated: ‘For the purpose of warding off cold.’ The same method applies in all cases. Herein,

original: uṇhassāti aggisantāpassa, tassa vanadāhādīsu sambhavo veditabbo. Ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānanti
analyzed: uṇhassa ati aggi santāpassa tassa vana dāha ādīsu sambhavaḥ veditabbaḥ ḍaṃsa makasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassānam ti
translated: ‘heat’ is the heat of a fire. Its source should be understood as a forest conflagration, and so on. ‘The touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles’

original: ettha pana ḍaṃsāti ḍaṃsanamakkhikā. “Andhamakkhikā”tipi vuccanti. Makasāti makasā
analyzed: ettha pana ḍaṃsā ati ḍaṃsanamakkhikā andhamakkhikā ati pi vuccanti makasā ati makasā
translated: Herein, ‘flies’ are flies that bite. They are also called ‘blind flies.’ ‘Mosquitoes’ are mosquitoes.

original: eva. Vātāti sarajaarajādibhedā. Ātapoti sūriyātapo. Sarīsapāti ye keci sarantā gacchanti
analyzed: eva saraja araja ādi bhedāḥ ye keci sarantā gacchanti
translated: ‘Wind’ is of many kinds, such as the dust-raising wind, and so on. ‘Sun’ is the sun’s heat. ‘Reptiles’ are those that move by crawling, such as ants, termites, and so on.

original: dīghajātikā sappādayo, tesaṃ daṭṭhasamphasso ca phuṭṭhasamphasso cāti duvidho samphasso;
analyzed: tesam daṭṭha samphasso ca phuṭṭha samphasso ca ati duvidhaḥ samphasso
translated: Long-lived animals such as snakes, etc., have two kinds of contact: contact by seeing and contact by touching.

original: sopi cīvaraṃ pārupitvā nisinnaṃ na bādhati. Tasmā tādisesu ṭhānesu tesaṃ paṭighātatthāya
analyzed: saḥ api cīvaram nisinnam na bādhati tasmā tādisesu ṭhānesu tesam paṭighāta tthāya
translated: But that does not annoy him when he is wearing the robe and sitting down. Therefore, in such places,

original: paṭisevati. Yāvadevāti puna etassa vacanaṃ niyatapayojanāvadhiparicchedadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisevati yāvat eva ati punar etassa vacanam niyata payojana avadhi pariccheda dassana attham
translated: he uses it for the purpose of warding off contact with them. As much as is necessary: this is said in order to show the limit of the purpose.

original: Hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthanti niyatapayojanaṃ, itarāni kadāci honti. Tattha hirikopīnanti🔽taṃ taṃ sambādhaṭṭhānaṃ. Yasmiṃ yasmiñhi aṅge vivariyamāne hirī kuppati vinassati,
analyzed: niyata payojanam itarāni kadāci honti tattha hiri kopīna nti  tam tam sambādha ṭṭhānam yasmin yasmin hi aṅge vivariyamāne hirī kuppati vinassati
translated: For the purpose of covering the parts of the body that should be kept concealed out of shame: this is the purpose. The other things are sometimes for that purpose.🔽Herein, the parts of the body that should be kept concealed out of shame are🔽any parts of the body that are covered up. For whatever part of the body is uncovered, shame arises in him.

original: taṃ taṃ hiriṃ kopanato hirikopīnanti vuccati. Tassa ca hirikopīnassa paṭicchādanatthanti
analyzed: tam tam hirim kopanataḥ hiri kopīnanti vuccati tassa ca hiri kopīnassa paṭicchādana tthanti
translated: Because it is covered up out of shame, it is called the “part of the body that should be kept concealed out of shame.” For the purpose of covering the parts of the body that should be kept concealed out of shame:

original: hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthaṃ. “Hirikopīnaṃ paṭicchādanattha”ntipi pāṭho.
analyzed: hiri kopīna paṭicchādana tham hiri kopīnam paṭicchādana tham tipi pāṭhaḥ
translated: for the purpose of covering the part of the body that should be kept concealed out of shame. There is also the reading hirikopinaṃ paṭicchādanatthaṃ.🔽Alms food: any kind of nutriment. For whatever kind of nutriment is given to a bhikkhu in his bowl, it is called

original: Piṇḍapātanti yaṃkiñci āhāraṃ. Yo hi koci āhāro bhikkhuno piṇḍolyena patte patitattā
analyzed: piṇḍapātam ti yaṃkiñci āhāram yaḥ hi koci āhāro bhikkhuno piṇḍolyena patte patita ttā
translated: alms food because it has fallen into the bowl.

original: “piṇḍapāto”ti vuccati. Piṇḍānaṃ vā pāto piṇḍapāto, tattha tattha laddhānaṃ bhikkhānaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍapāto ti vuccati piṇḍānam vā pāto piṇḍapāto tattha tattha laddhānam bhikkhānam
translated: is called “alms food.” Or alternatively, the meaning is that it is the “arrival” of the “alms” obtained here and there.

original: sannipāto, samūhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: sannipātaḥ samūhaḥ ti vuttam hoti sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: “Alms food” is what is called. Or the falling together of the alms, the falling together of the alms is alms food. The gathering, the collection, of the alms obtained here and there is what is meant. The rest is as already stated.

original: Senāsananti sayanañca āsanañca. Yattha yattha hi seti vihāre vā aḍḍhayogādimhi vā,
analyzed: senāsananti sayananti ca āsananti yattha yattha hi sā iti vihāre vā aḍḍha yoga ādimhi vā
translated: “A resting place” is both a bed and a seat. For wherever one lies down, whether in a monastery or in a hut, etc.,

original: taṃ senaṃ. Yattha yattha āsati nisīdati, taṃ āsanaṃ, taṃ ekato katvā “senāsana”nti
analyzed: tam senam yattha yattha āsati nisīdati tam āsanam tam ekatas katvā
translated: that is a bed. Wherever one sits, that is a seat. All these together are called “a resting place.”

original: vuccati. Utuparissayavinodanapaṭisallānārāmatthanti parisahanaṭṭhena utuyeva utuparissayo.
analyzed: vuccati utu parissaya vinodana paṭisallāna ārāma tthanti parisahana ṭṭhena utuyā iva utu parissayo
translated: For the purpose of warding off the danger from weather and for the purpose of delight in seclusion: the weather itself is a danger from weather in the sense of oppressing.

original: Utuparissayassa vinodanatthañca paṭisallānārāmatthañca. Yo sarīrābādhacittavikkhepakaro🔽asappāyo utu senāsanapaṭisevanena vinodetabbo hoti, tassa vinodanatthaṃ ekībhāvasukhatthañcāti
analyzed: utu parissayassa vinodana ttham ca paṭisallāna ārāma ttham ca yo sarīra ābādha citta vikkhepa karo  asappāyaḥ utu senāsana paṭisevanena vinodetabbaḥ hoti tassa vinodana attham ekībhāva sukha attham ca ati
translated: For the purpose of warding off the danger from weather and for the purpose of delight in seclusion. That which is unwholesome,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Kāmañca sītapaṭighātādināva utuparissayavinodanaṃ vuttameva. Yathā pana
analyzed: vuttam hoti kāmam ca utu parissaya vinodanam vuttam eva yathā pana
translated: which causes bodily affliction and mental distraction, can be warded off by using a resting place. The meaning is, for the purpose of warding off that and for the purpose of the pleasure of solitude. And indeed the warding off of the danger from weather by means of the use of a resting place is stated by the words “for the purpose of warding off cold, etc.” But it is stated

original: cīvarapaṭisevane “hirikopīnapaṭicchādanaṃ niyatapayojanaṃ, itarāni kadāci kadāci
analyzed: cīvara paṭisevane hiri kopīna paṭicchādanam niyata payojanam itarāni kadāci kadāci
translated: In the case of the dwelling, it is said that the “protection of modesty” is the fixed purpose, while the others are occasional.

original: bhavantī”ti vuttaṃ, evamidhāpi niyatautuparissayavinodanaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttanti
analyzed: bhavanti iti vuttam evam idha api niyata autu parissaya vinodanam sandhāya idam vuttan ti
translated: So too here, it should be understood, the expression “for the removal of the dangers of climate” refers to the fixed purpose.

original: veditabbaṃ. Atha vā ayaṃ vuttappakāro utu utuyeva. Parissayo pana duvidho pākaṭaparissayo🔽ca paṭicchannaparissayo ca. Tattha pākaṭaparissayo sīhabyagghādayo, paṭicchannaparissayo
analyzed: veditabbam atha vā ayam vutta ppakāraḥ utu utuyā iva parissayaḥ pana duvidhaḥ pākaṭa parissayo  ca paṭicchanna parissayo ca tattha pākaṭa parissayo sīha byaggha ādayo paṭicchanna parissayo
translated: Or alternatively, this kind of climate is simply climate. But danger is of two kinds: manifest danger and concealed danger.🔽Here manifest danger is lions, tigers, etc., and concealed danger is lust, hatred, etc.

original: rāgadosādayo. Te yattha apariguttiyā ca asappāyarūpadassanādinā ca ābādhaṃ na karonti,🔽taṃ senāsanaṃ evaṃ jānitvā paccavekkhitvā paṭisevanto bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso senāsanaṃ🔽utuparissayavinodanatthaṃ paṭisevatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: rāga dosa ādayaḥ te yattha a pariguttiyā ca asappāya rūpa dassana ādinā ca ābādham na karonti  tam senāsanam evam jānitvā paccavekkhitvā paṭisevantaḥ bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas senāsanaṃ  utu parissaya vinodana attham paṭisevati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: When a bhikkhu knows and sees that a dwelling is such that it does not cause affliction through lack of protection and through seeing unsuitable visible objects, etc.,🔽then it should be understood that he uses the dwelling for the removal of the dangers of climate wisely, after making an investigation.

original: Gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāranti ettha rogassa paṭiayanaṭṭhena paccayo, paccanīkagamanaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāran ti ettha rogassa paṭiayana ṭṭhena paccayaḥ paccanīka gamana ṭṭhena ati
translated: As to “requisites of medicine for use in sickness”: a requisite is a condition in the sense of that which causes occurrence , and in the sense of that which is opposed to what is not a condition .

original: attho. Yassa kassaci sappāyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Bhisakkassa kammaṃ tena anuññātattāti
analyzed: atthaḥ yassa kassaci sappāyassa etam adhivacanam bhisakkassa kammam tena anuññāta ttā ti
translated: “For the sake of” : this is a term for what is suitable. It is medicine because it is permitted by the physician.

original: bhesajjaṃ. Gilānapaccayova bhesajjaṃ gilānapaccayabhesajjaṃ, yaṃ kiñci gilānassa🔽sappāyaṃ bhisakkakammaṃ telamadhuphāṇitādīti vuttaṃ hoti. Parikkhāroti pana “sattahi
analyzed: bhesajjam gilāna paccayo uva bhesajjam gilāna paccaya bhesajjam yam kiñci gilānassa  sappāyam bhisakka kammam tela madhu phāṇi tādi iti vuttam hoti parikkhāro ti pana sattahi
translated: “Medicines” : the requisite of medicine is only what is suitable for the sick.🔽Any kind of suitable treatment by a physician is what is meant by “medicine,” such as oil, honey, sugar-cane juice, etc.🔽But in such passages as “It is well-supplied with the seven requisites of a city” , “equipment” is what is meant;

original: nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhattaṃ hotī”tiādīsu parivāro vuccati. “Ratho sīlaparikkhāro,🔽jhānakkho cakkavīriyo”tiādīsu alaṅkāro. “Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā🔽samudānetabbā”tiādīsu sambhāro. Idha pana sambhāropi parivāropi vaṭṭati. Tañca gilānapaccayabhesajjaṃ
analyzed: nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhattam hoti itiādīsu parivāraḥ vuccati ratho sīla parikkhāro  cakka vīriya uti ādīsu alaṅkāraḥ ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvita parikkhārā  samudānetabba ati ādīsu sambhāraḥ idha pana sambhāraḥ api parivāraḥ api vaṭṭati tat ca gilāna paccaya bhesajjam
translated: in such passages as “The chariot of virtue, the axle of meditation, the wheel of energy” , “ornament” is what is meant;🔽in such passages as “These requisites of life that are to be obtained by one who has gone forth” , “equipment” is what is meant. But here both “equipment” and “ornament” are applicable.

original: jīvitassa parivāropi hoti, jīvitanāsakābādhuppattiyā antaraṃ adatvā rakkhaṇato sambhāropi.
analyzed: jīvitassa parivāraḥ api hoti jīvita nāsaka ābādha uppattiyā antaram a datvā rakkhaṇato sambhāraḥ api
translated: And that requisite of medicine for the sick is an equipment for life, because it protects by preventing the arising of the sickness that would end in death. It is an equipment in the sense of being a cause for the life that goes on for as long as it does.

original: Yathāciraṃ pavattati, evamassa kāraṇabhāvato; tasmā “parikkhāro”ti vuccati. Evaṃ
analyzed: yathāciram pavattati evam assa kāraṇa bhāvato tasmā parikkhāraḥ iti vuccati evam
translated: Therefore it is called “requisite” .

original: gilānapaccayabhesajjañca taṃ parikkhāro cāti gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāro, taṃ
analyzed: gilāna paccaya bhesajjam ca tam parikkhāro ca ati gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāro tam
translated: And the requisite of medicine for the sick is a requisite for him, thus it is the requisite of medicine for the sick.

original: gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ. Gilānassa yaṃ kiñci sappāyaṃ bhisakkānuññātaṃ telamadhuphāṇitādijīvitaparikkhāranti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram gilānassa yam kiñci sappāyam bhisakka anuññātam tela madhu phāṇita ādi jīvita parikkhāram ti vuttam hoti
translated: What is suitable for the sick is permitted by the Buddha as medicine, such as oil, honey, sugar, etc., is what is meant.

original: Uppannānanti jātānaṃ bhūtānaṃ nibbattānaṃ. Veyyābādhikānanti ettha byābādhoti dhātukkhobho
analyzed: uppannānam ti jātānam bhūtānam nibbattānam veyyābādhikānam ti ettha byābādhaḥ ti dhātu kkhobhaḥ
translated: Arisen: come to be, come to birth, come to manifestation. Afflictions: here “affliction” is a disturbance of elements,

original: taṃsamuṭṭhānā ca kuṭṭhagaṇḍapīḷakādayo, byābādhato uppannattā veyyābādhikā. Vedanānanti
analyzed: tad samuṭṭhānā ca kuṭṭha gaṇḍa pīḷaka ādayaḥ byābādhataḥ uppanna ttāḥ veyyābādhikāḥ
translated: and the boils, carbuncles, etc., that arise from that are “afflictions” . Feelings:

original: dukkhavedanā, akusalavipākavedanā, tāsaṃ veyyābādhikānaṃ vedanānaṃ. Abyābajjhaparamatāyāti
analyzed: dukkha vedanā akusala vipāka vedanā tāsam veyyābādhikānam vedanānam a byābajjha parama tāya ati
translated: painful feelings, unwholesome resultants, those feelings that are afflictions.

original: niddukkhaparamatāya. Yāva taṃ dukkhaṃ sabbaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, tāvāti attho.
analyzed: niddukkha parama tāya yāva tat dukkham sabbam pahīnam hoti tāva ati attho
translated: To the utmost: to the highest degree. As long as: as long as all that pain is abandoned, is what is meant.

original: Santuṭṭho hotīti paccayasantosena santuṭṭho hoti. Itarītarena cīvarenāti thūlasukhumalūkhapaṇītathirajiṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti paccaya santosena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti itarītarena cīvarena ati thūla sukhuma lūkha paṇīta thira jiṇṇānam
translated: Is content: is satisfied with contentment about requisites. With any kind of robe: with thick, thin, rough, smooth, long, short, torn, darned,

original: yena kenaci. Atha kho yathāladdhādīnaṃ itarītarena yena kenaci santuṭṭho hotīti attho.
analyzed: yena kenaci atha kho yathā laddha ādīnam itarītarena yena kenaci santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti attho
translated: With any kind of: the meaning is that he is satisfied with whatever kind of comes to him, whether good or bad.

original: Cīvarasmiñhi tayo santosā yathālābhasantoso yathābalasantoso yathāsāruppasantosoti.
analyzed: cīvarasmin hi tayo santosā yathā lābha santosaḥ yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ iti
translated: For there are three kinds of satisfaction with robes: satisfaction with what one gets, satisfaction with what one has, and satisfaction with what is proper.

original: Piṇḍapātādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Vaṇṇavādīti eko santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa vaṇṇaṃ na katheti, eko na santuṭṭho hoti,
analyzed: piṇḍapāta ādī supi esā iva nayoḥ  vaṇṇa vādī iti ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa vaṇṇam na katheti ekaḥ na santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: The same method applies in the case of alms food, etc.🔽One who is satisfied does not praise satisfaction: one who is satisfied with what he gets does not praise satisfaction.

original: santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti, eko neva santuṭṭho hoti, na santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti,
analyzed: santosassa vaṇṇam katheti ekaḥ na iva santuṭṭhaḥ hoti na santosassa vaṇṇam katheti
translated: One who is not satisfied praises satisfaction: one who is not satisfied with what he gets praises satisfaction.

original: eko santuṭṭho ca hoti, santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti, taṃ dassetuṃ “itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā🔽ca vaṇṇavādī”ti vuttaṃ. Anesananti dūteyyapahīnagamanānuyogappabhedaṃ nānappakāraṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ santuṭṭho ca hoti santosassa vaṇṇam katheti tam dassetum itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā  ca vaṇṇa vādī iti vuttam anesanam ti dūteyya pahīna gamana anuyoga ppabhedam nāna ppakāram
translated: One who is satisfied praises satisfaction: one who is satisfied with what he gets praises satisfaction.🔽With any kind of: with any kind of search, that is to say, with any kind of search of the kinds beginning with going by message and solicitation.🔽Improper: unfitting.

original: anesanaṃ. Appatirūpanti ayuttaṃ. Aladdhā cāti alabhitvā. Yathā ekacco “kathaṃ nu
analyzed: an esanam appatirūpanti ayuttam a laddhā ca ati a labhitvā yathā ekacco katham nu
translated: Without having obtained: without having got.

original: kho cīvaraṃ labhissāmī”ti puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekato hutvā kohaññaṃ karonto
analyzed: kho cīvaram labhissāmi iti puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhim ekatas hutvā kohaññam karontaḥ
translated: “I shall get robe-cloth,” and he is elated and inflates himself and becomes arrogant and morally shameless and morally reckless.

original: uttassati paritassati, santuṭṭho bhikkhu evaṃ aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na paritassati.
analyzed: uttassati paritassati santuṭṭhaḥ bhikkhu evam a laddhā ca cīvaram na paritassati
translated: But a monk who is content does not become anxious if he does not get robe-cloth.

original: Laddhā cāti dhammena samena labhitvā. Agadhitoti vigatalobhavanto. Amucchitoti adhimattataṇhāya🔽mucchaṃ anāpanno. Anajjhāpannoti taṇhāya anotthaṭo apariyonaddho. Ādīnavadassāvīti🔽anesanāpattiyañca gadhitaparibhoge ca ādīnavaṃ passamāno. Nissaraṇapaññoti “yāvadeva🔽sītassa paṭighātāyā”ti vuttaṃ nissaraṇaṃ eva pajānanto. Itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyāti🔽yena kenaci cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā. Nevattānukkaṃsetīti “ahaṃ paṃsukūliko, mayā upasampadamāḷeyeva
analyzed: laddhā ca ati dhammena samena labhitvā agadhito ti vigata lobhavantaḥ amucchito ti adhimatta taṇhāya  muccham an āpannaḥ an ajjhāpannaḥ ti taṇhāya an otthaṭaḥ a pariyonaddhaḥ ādīnava dassāvī iti  anesanāpattiyam ca gadhita paribhoge ca ādīnavam passamānaḥ nissaraṇa pañño ti yāvat eva  sītassa paṭighātāya ati vuttam nissaraṇam eva pajānantaḥ itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā ti  yena kenacid cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā na iva tā anukkaṃseti iti aham paṃsukūlikaḥ mayā upasampadam āḷeya iva
translated: Having gotten it legitimately and properly, he is not greedy for it. He is not infatuated with it. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of craving.

original: paṃsukūlikaṅgaṃ gahitaṃ, ko mayā sadiso atthī”ti attukkaṃsanaṃ na karoti. Na paraṃ
analyzed: paṃsukūlika aṅgam gahitam kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti attukkaṃsanam na karoti na param
translated: He is not infatuated with the infatuation of views. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of conduct. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of self-mortification. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of these five kinds of infatuation. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the fetters. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the bonds. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the underlying tendencies. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the hindrances. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the aggregates. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the sense-spheres. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. He is not infatuated with the infatuation of the defilements of the world. original: vambhetīti “ime panaññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā”ti vā “paṃsukūlikamattampi etesaṃ
analyzed: vambheti iti ime pana aññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā ati vā paṃsukūlika mattam pi etesam
translated: “He disparages” means that he disparages them, saying, “These other monks are not refuse-rag wearers,” or “They have no more than the mere refuse-rag robe.”🔽

original: natthī”ti vā evaṃ paraṃ na vambheti.
analyzed: natthi iti vai evam param na vambheti
translated: “He does not disparage” means that he does not disparage others, saying, “These other bhikkhus are not refuse-rag wearers,” or “They do not even have the virtue of refuse-rag wearing.”

original: Yo hi tattha dakkhoti yo tasmiṃ cīvarasantose vaṇṇavādī, tāsu vā dakkho cheko byatto.
analyzed: yaḥ hi tattha dakkho ti yaḥ tasmin cīvara santose vaṇṇa vādī tāsu vā dakkhaḥ chekaḥ byatto
translated: “He who is skilled in that” : he who is skilled, clever, and capable in praising that kind of austerity of robes.

original: Analasoti sātaccakiriyāya ālasiyavirahito. Sampajāno paṭissatoti sampajānapaññāya
analyzed: analasaḥ ti sātacca kiriyāya ālasiya virahito sampajāno paṭissataḥ ti sampajāna paññāya
translated: “Not lazy” : not lazy in the performance of his duties. “Possessed of clear comprehension and mindfulness” : endowed with the clear comprehension of wisdom and with mindfulness.

original: ceva satiyā ca yutto. Porāṇeti na adhunuppattike. Aggaññeti “aggo”ti jānitabbe. Ariyavaṃse🔽ṭhitoti ariyānaṃ vaṃse patiṭṭhito. Ariyavaṃsoti ca yathā hi khattiyavaṃso brāhmaṇavaṃso
analyzed: ca iva satiyā ca yutto porāṇe iti na adhunuppattike aggaññe iti aggo ti jānitabbe ariya vaṃse  ṭhito ti ariyānam vaṃse patiṭṭhitaḥ ariya vaṃso ti ca yathā hi khattiya vaṃsaḥ brāhmaṇa vaṃso
translated: “Ancient” : not newly arisen. “To be known as the foremost” : to be known as the best.🔽“Established in the noble lineage” : established in the lineage of the noble ones.

original: vessavaṃso suddavaṃso samaṇavaṃso kulavaṃso rājavaṃso, evaṃ ayampi aṭṭhamo ariyavaṃso
analyzed: vessa vaṃso sudda vaṃsaḥ samaṇa vaṃso kula vaṃso rāja vaṃso evam ayam pi aṭṭhamaḥ ariya vaṃso
translated: “Noble lineage” : just as there is the lineage of the nobles, the lineage of the brahmins, the lineage of the merchants, the lineage of the workers, the lineage of ascetics, the lineage of families, the lineage of kings, so this is the eighth noble lineage.🔽“Noble lineage” is called the noble tradition.

original: ariyatanti ariyapaveṇī nāma hoti. So kho panāyaṃ ariyavaṃso imesaṃ vaṃsānaṃ mūlagandhādīnaṃ
analyzed: ariya tanti ariyapaveṇī nāma hoti saḥ kho pana ayam ariya vaṃsaḥ imesam vaṃsānam mūla gandha ādīnam
translated: This noble lineage is the root-virtue, etc., of these lineages.

original: kāḷānusārigandhādayo viya aggamakkhāyati. Ke pana te ariyā yesaṃ eso vaṃsoti? Ariyā🔽vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca tathāgatasāvakā ca, etesaṃ ariyānaṃ vaṃsoti ariyavaṃso.🔽Ito pubbe hi satasahassakappādikānaṃ catunnaṃ asaṅkhyeyyānaṃ matthake taṇhaṅkaro🔽meṅkero saraṇaṅkaro dīpaṅkaroti cattāro buddhā uppannā, te ariyā, tesaṃ ariyānaṃ🔽vaṃsoti ariyavaṃso. Tesaṃ buddhānaṃ parinibbānato aparabhāge ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ atikkamitvā🔽koṇḍañño nāma buddho uppanno…pe… imasmiṃ kappe kakusandho koṇāgamano kassapo amhākaṃ🔽bhagavā gotamoti cattāro buddhā uppannā, tesaṃ ariyānaṃ vaṃsoti ariyavaṃso. Api ca
analyzed: kāḷānusāri gandha ādayaḥ viya aggam akkhāyati ke pana te ariyāḥ yesam esaḥ vaṃso ti ariyāḥ  vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca tathāgata sāvakā ca etesam ariyānam vaṃso ti ariya vaṃso  itas pubbe hi sata sahassa kappa ādikānam catunnam asaṅkhyeyyānam matthake  meṅkero saraṇaṅkaraḥ dīpaṅkaraḥ ti cattāraḥ buddhāḥ uppannā te ariyā tesam ariyānam  vaṃsaḥ ti ariya vaṃsaḥ tesam buddhānam parinibbānataḥ apara bhāge ekam asaṅkhyeyyam atikkamitvā  koṇḍaññaḥ nāma buddhaḥ uppanna upe imasmin kappe kakusandhaḥ koṇāgamanaḥ kassapaḥ amhākam  bhagavā gotamaḥ ti cattāraḥ buddhāḥ uppannā tesam ariyānam vaṃsaḥ ti ariya vaṃsaḥ api ca
translated: It is called the Noble Ones’ Lineage because it is the lineage of the Noble Ones, just as the lineages of Kāḷāgaṇi, Anusārigandhā, and so on are called after them.🔽But who are these Noble Ones?🔽The Noble Ones are the Buddhas, the Paccekabuddhas, and the Buddhas’ chief disciples. The lineage of these Noble Ones is the Noble Ones’ Lineage.🔽For in the past, at the end of the four incalculable ages, there were four Buddhas, Taṇhaṅkara,🔽Meṅkera, Saraṇaṅkara, and Dīpaṅkara. They were Noble Ones, and the lineage of these Noble Ones was the Noble Ones’ Lineage.🔽After the parinibbāna of these Buddhas, at the end of one incalculable age,🔽there was a Buddha named Koṇḍañña. … In this present world age there have been four Buddhas, Kakusandha, Koṇāgamana, Kassapa, and our own Exalted One Gotama. They were Noble Ones, and the lineage of these Noble Ones is the Noble Ones’ Lineage.🔽Moreover,🔽
