original: tasmiṃ ariyavaṃse patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: tasmin ariya vaṃse patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: he is established in the Noble Ones’ family.

original: Itarītarena piṇḍapātenāti yena kenaci piṇḍapātena. Senāsanādīsupi eseva nayo. Āyatanesūti cakkhādīsu āyatanesu.
analyzed: itarītarena piṇḍapātena ati yena kenacid piṇḍapātena senāsana ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ āyatanesu ti cakkha ādīsu āyatanesu
translated: With any kind of alms food: with whatever kind of alms food. The same method applies in the case of the dwelling, etc. In the sense bases: in the eye, etc.🔽Controlled: restrained.🔽Guarded:🔽protected.

original: Yatoti saññato. Yattoti yattavā. Paṭiyattoti ativiya yattavā. Guttoti rakkhito. Gopitoti
analyzed: yatoti saññataḥ yattoti yat tava paṭiyattoti ativiya yat tava guttoti rakkhito gopitoti
translated: Restrained:

original: mañjūsāya viya paṭṭhapito. Rakkhitoti paṭisāmito. Saṃvutoti dvārasaṃvaraṇena pihito.
analyzed: mañjūsāya viya paṭṭhapito rakkhitoti paṭisāmito saṃvuto ti dvāra saṃvaraṇena pihito
translated: closed by the restraint of the doors.🔽Reproved: censured.🔽Blamed: disparaged.🔽Reprimanded: reproached.

original: Khuṃsitoti garahito. Vambhitoti apasādito. Ghaṭṭitoti ghaṭṭanamāpādito. Garahitoti
analyzed: khuṃsitaḥ iti gara hitaḥ vambhitaḥ iti apasāditaḥ ghaṭṭitaḥ uti ghaṭṭanam āpāditaḥ gara hitaḥ uti
translated: Censured: despised.

original: avamaññito. Upavaditoti akkosito.
analyzed: avamaññitaḥ upavaditaḥ iti akkositaḥ
translated: Abused: reviled.🔽With harsh speech: with speech that cuts the flesh.🔽With rough speech: with cruel speech.

original: Pharusenāti mammacchedanavacanena. Kakkhaḷenāti dāruṇena. Nappaṭivajjāti paṭippharitvā na katheyya.🔽207. Jhānānuyuttoti anuppannuppādanena uppannasevanena ca jhānena anuyutto. Upekkhamārabbha
analyzed: pharusena ati mamma chedana vacanena kakkhaḷena ati dāruṇena na paṭivajja ati paṭippharitvā na katheyya 🔽jhāna anuyuttaḥ ti anuppanna uppādanena uppanna sevanena ca jhānena anuyuttaḥ upekkham ārabbha
translated: He should not return abuse: he should not reply in kind.

original: samāhitattoti catutthajjhānupekkhaṃ uppādetvā samāhitacitto. Takkāsayaṃ kukkuccañcupacchindeti🔽kāmavitakkādivitakkañca kāmasaññādikaṃ vitakkassa āsayañca hatthakukkuccādikukkuccañca upacchindeyya.
analyzed: samāhita ttaḥ ti catuttha jjhāna upekkham uppādetvā samāhita cittaḥ takka āsayam kukkuccañcu acchinda iti  kāma vitakka ādi vitakkañca kāma saññā ādikam vitakkassa āsayam ca hattha kukkucca ādi kukkuccañca upacchindeyya
translated: And he should sever the underlying tendency to scepticism, which is a tendency to scepticism about the four noble truths, and the underlying tendency to doubt, which is doubt about the four noble truths.🔽“For the arising of the unarisen first jhāna”: for the arousing in this his present existence of the first jhāna that has not already arisen in it.🔽Or for the obtaining of it if previously it has arisen and been abandoned.

original: Anuppannassa vā paṭhamassa jhānassa uppādāyāti tasmiṃ attabhāve anuppannassa vā uppajjitvā🔽parihīnassa vā paṭhamajjhānassa uppādanatthaṃ attano santāne paṭilābhatthaṃ. Uppannaṃ🔽vā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ āsevatītiādīsu ettha ādarena sevati paguṇaṃ karoti bhāveti vaḍḍheti🔽bahulīkaroti punappunaṃ karoti.🔽Upekkhāti catutthajjhāne uppannā tatramajjhattupekkhā. Upekkhāti sabhāvapadaṃ. Upekkhanāti
analyzed: anuppannassa vā paṭhamassa jhānassa uppādāya ati tasmin atta bhāve anuppannassa vā uppajjitvā  parihīnassa vā paṭhamajjhānassa uppādana tham attanaḥ santāne paṭilābha ttham uppannam  vā paṭhamam jhānam āsevati iti ādīsu ettha ādarena sevati paguṇam karoti bhāveti vaḍḍheti  bahulīkaroti punappunam karoti  upekkhā ati catuttha jhāne uppannā tatram ajjhatta upekkhā upekkhā ati sabhāva padam upekkhanāti
translated: “He cultivates … the arisen first jhāna”: here, “he cultivates” is the same as “he frequents,” “he favours,” “he multiplies,” “he consolidates,” “he develops.”

original: upapattito ikkhanākāro. Ajjhupekkhanāti adhikā hutvā ikkhanā. Cittasamatāti cittassa
analyzed: upapattitaḥ ikkhanā ākāraḥ ajjhupekkhanā ati adhikā hutvā ikkhanā citta samatā ati cittassa
translated: “Equanimity”: the equanimity that arises in the fourth jhāna. “Equanimity” is a word that denotes the individual essence. “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity. “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it. “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it and giving attention to it. “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it, giving attention to it, and giving attention to it as “peaceful.” “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it, giving attention to it, giving attention to it as “peaceful,” and giving attention to it as “to be comprehended by understanding.” “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it, giving attention to it, giving attention to it as “peaceful,” giving attention to it as “to be comprehended by understanding,” and giving attention to it as “to be abandoned by development.” “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it, giving attention to it, giving attention to it as “peaceful,” giving attention to it as “to be comprehended by understanding,” giving attention to it as “to be abandoned by development,” and giving attention to it as “to be realized by development.” “Equanimity” is the seeing of the state of equanimity after entering upon it, giving attention to it, giving attention to it as “peaceful,” giving attention to it as “to be comprehended by understanding,” giving attention to it as “to be abandoned

original: samatā cittassa ūnātirittataṃ vajjetvā samabhāvo. Cittappassaddhatāti cittassa appagabbhatā,
analyzed: sama tā cittassa ūna atiritta tam vajjetvā sama bhāvaḥ citta passaddha tā ati cittassa appagabbha tā
translated: Equanimity of mind is the state of balance in the mind, avoiding the extremes of depression and excitement.🔽Tranquillization of consciousness is the state of non-agitation in consciousness,🔽the state of non-distraction. Equanimity of mind is the state of balance in the mind, not in the person,

original: athaddhabhāvoti attho. Majjhattatā cittassāti na sattassa na posassa, cittassa majjhattabhāvoti
analyzed: athaddha bhāvaḥ ti attho majjhatta tā cittassa ati na sattassa na posassa cittassa majjhatta bhāvo ti
translated: the state of balance in consciousness.

original: attho. Catutthe jhāne upekkhaṃ ārabbhāti catutthasmiṃ jhānasmiṃ uppannaṃ tatramajjhattupekkhaṃ
analyzed: catutthe jhāne upekkham ārabbhāti catutthasmim jhānasmim uppannam tatram ajjhatta upekkham
translated: With regard to equanimity in the fourth jhāna: in the fourth jhāna, dependent on the equanimity that has arisen there,🔽with a mind that is unified: with a mind that has become one in the sense of occurring in a single cognitive series.

original: paṭicca. Ekaggacittoti ekārammaṇe pavattacitto. Avikkhittacittoti uddhaccavirahito na vikkhittacitto.🔽Nava vitakkā vuttanayā eva. Kāmavitakkānaṃ kāmasaññāsayoti kāmavitakkaṃ vitakkentassa
analyzed: paṭicca ekagga citto ti eka ārammaṇe pavatta cittaḥ avikkhitta citto ti uddhacca virahitaḥ na vikkhitta cittaḥ  nava vitakkāḥ vutta nayāḥ eva kāma vitakkānam kāma saññā sayo ti kāma vitakkam vitakkentassa
translated: With a mind that is not distracted: without distraction, without being scattered outwardly from its object.🔽The nine kinds of applied thought are in the way already stated.🔽The underlying tendency to lust is the underlying tendency to the perception of sensual pleasure that arises in one who applies his thought to sensual lust.

original: uppannā kāmasaññā tesaṃ vitakkānaṃ āsayo vasanokāsoti kāmasaññāsayo. Byāpādavitakkādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: uppannā kāma saññā tesam vitakkānam āsayaḥ vasanokāsaḥ ti kāma saññā āsayaḥ byāpāda vitakka ādīsu pi esā iva nayo
translated: The underlying tendency to ill will … the underlying tendency to cruelty is the underlying tendency to the perception of ill will … the perception of cruelty that arises in one who applies his thought to cruelty.

original: 208. Cudito vacībhi satimābhinandeti upajjhāyādīhi vācāhi codito samāno satimā hutvā
analyzed: cuditaḥ vacībhi satim abhinanda iti upajjhāya ādīhi vācāhi coditaḥ samānaḥ satimā hutvā
translated: When he is reproved, he delights in the reprover’s words: when he is reproved by preceptors, teachers, etc., with the words, “This is unallowable, this is improper,” he delights in their words, he is pleased with their words, he is satisfied with their words.

original: taṃ codanaṃ abhinandeyya. Vācaṃ pamuñce kusalanti ñāṇasamuṭṭhitaṃ vācaṃ pamuñceyya.
analyzed: tam codanam abhinandeyya vācam pamuñce kusalanti ñāṇa samuṭṭhitam vācam pamuñceyya
translated: He should approve of the accusation. He should release speech that is wholesome: he should release speech that is arisen from knowledge.

original: Nātivelanti ativelaṃ pana vācaṃ kālavelañca sīlavelañca atikkantaṃ nappamuñceyya.
analyzed: na ativelanti ativelam pana vācam kāla velañca sīla velañca atikkantam na ppamuñceyya
translated: Not at the wrong time: but he should not release speech at a time that is beyond the proper time, either in the morning or in the evening.

original: Janavādadhammāyāti janaparivādakathāya. Na cetayeyyāti cetanaṃ na uppādeyya.
analyzed: janavāda dhammāya ati jana parivāda kathāya na cetayeyya ati cetanam na uppādeyya
translated: For the sake of worldly talk: for the sake of talk about the world. He should not intend: he should not arouse intention.

original: Idaṃ te appattanti idaṃ tava na pattaṃ. Asāruppanti tava payogaṃ asāruppaṃ. Asīlaṭṭhanti
analyzed: idam te appattanti idam tava na pattam asāruppanti tava payogam asāruppam asīlaṭṭhanti
translated: This is not yours: this is not yours. It is not suitable: it is not suitable for your use. It is not a basis for virtue:

original: tava payogaṃ na sīle patiṭṭhanti asīlaṭṭhaṃ, sīle ṭhitassa payogaṃ na hotīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: tava payogam na sīle patiṭṭhanti a sīla ṭṭham sīle ṭhitassa payogam na hoti iti vuttam
translated: it is not a basis for virtue for your use. It is not suitable for one who stands on virtue: it is not suitable for one who stands on virtue to use.

original: hoti. Keci “asiliṭṭha”nti paṭhanti, amaṭṭhavacananti atthaṃ vaṇṇayanti.
analyzed: hoti keci a siliṭṭhanti paṭhanti attham vaṇṇayanti
translated: Some read “asiliṭṭha” and explain the meaning as “unbroken.”

original: Nidhīnanti tattha tattha nidahitvā ṭhapitānaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇādipūrānaṃ nidhikumbhīnaṃ.
analyzed: nidhīnam ti tattha tattha nidahitvā ṭhapitānam hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi pūrānam nidhi kumbhīnam
translated: Treasure stores: treasure pots filled with gold, silver, etc., that have been buried here and there.

original: Pavattāranti kicchajīvike duggatamanusse anukampaṃ katvā “ehi sukhena te jīvanupāyaṃ
analyzed: kiccha jīvike duggata manusse anukampam katvā ehi sukhena te jīvan upāyam
translated: For the sake of: after having taken pity on poor people who make a living with difficulty, thinking “Come, I will show you an easy way to make a living,

original: dassessāmī”ti nidhiṭṭhānaṃ netvā hatthaṃ pasāretvā “imaṃ gahetvā sukhaṃ jīvā”ti ācikkhitāraṃ🔽viya. Vajjadassinanti dve vajjadassino “iminā naṃ asāruppena vā khalitena vā saṅghamajjhe
analyzed: dassessāmi iti nidhiṭṭhānam netvā hattham pasāretvā imam gahetvā sukham jīvāti ācikkhitāram  dve vajja dassinanti dve vajja dassinaḥ iminā naṃ a sāruppena vā khalitena vā saṅgha majjhe
translated: and he shows him the treasure, leading him to the place and stretching out his hand and pointing to it, saying, “Take this, live happily,”

original: niggaṇhissāmī”ti randhagavesako ca aññātaṃ ñāpanatthāya ñātaṃ anuggaṇhatthāya sīlādinā🔽cassa vuddhikāmatāya taṃ taṃ vajjaṃ olokanena ullapanasabhāvasaṇṭhito ca. Ayaṃ idha
analyzed: niggaṇhissāmi iti randha gavesako ca aññātam ñāpana tthāya ñātam anuggaṇha tthāya sīla ādinā  cassa vuddhi kāma tāya tam tam vajjam olokanena ullapana sabhāva saṇṭhitaḥ ca ayam idha
translated: so too the other two kinds of treasure-revealer should be understood. The treasure-revealer who is a seeker of openings is one who thinks, “By this or that unseemly or improper action I will catch him out in the midst of the Sangha🔽and accuse him.” The treasure-revealer who is of a flattering nature is one who flatters him with his virtue, etc., in order to get him to acknowledge what he does not know and to confirm what he does know.

original: adhippeto. Yathā hi duggatamanusso “imaṃ gaṇhāhī”ti tajjetvā poṭṭhetvāpi nidhiṃ dassente🔽kopaṃ na karoti, pamuditova hoti, evameva evarūpe puggale asāruppaṃ vā khalitaṃ vā
analyzed: adhippetaḥ yathā hi duggata manussaḥ imam gaṇhāhi iti tat jetvā poṭṭhetvā api nidhim dassente  kopam na karoti pamuditaḥ uva hoti evam eva evarūpe puggale asāruppam vā khalitam vā
translated: It is the latter kind that is intended here.🔽For just as the unfortunate man does not get angry when he is shown the treasure after being threatened and struck, but on the contrary becomes glad,

original: disvā ācikkhante kopo na kātabbo, tuṭṭheneva bhavitabbaṃ. “Bhante mahantaṃ vo kataṃ
analyzed: disvā ācikkhante kopaḥ na kātabbo tuṭṭhena iva bhavitabbam bhante mahantam vo katam
translated: so too, when such a person is shown the unseemly or improper action, he should not get angry but should be glad.

original: kammaṃ, mayhaṃ ācariyupajjhāyaṭṭhāne ṭhatvā ovadantehi punapi maṃ vadeyyāthā”ti pavāretabbameva.
analyzed: kammam mayham ācariya upajjhāya ṭṭhāne ṭhatvā ovadantehi puna api mama vadeyyātha ati pavāretabbam eva
translated: “I will be able to correct you again when you are standing in the position of teacher or preceptor to me.”

original: Niggayhavādinti ekacco hi saddhivihārikādīnaṃ asāruppaṃ vā khalitaṃ vā disvā “ayaṃ
analyzed: niggayha vādin ti ekaccaḥ hi saddhivihārika ādīnam asāruppam vā khalitam vā disvā ayam
translated: One who speaks with restraint: there is one who, on seeing an impropriety or a lapse on the part of his pupils, is unable to say, “You are acting improperly; you are acting unseemly.”

original: me mukhodakadānādīhi sakkaccaṃ upaṭṭhahati, sace naṃ vakkhāmi, na maṃ upaṭṭhahissati,
analyzed: me mukha udaka dāna ādīhi sakkaccam upaṭṭhahati sace nam vakkhāmi na mama upaṭṭhahissati
translated: He thinks, “He is serving me carefully, giving me water to rinse my mouth, etc. If I tell him, he will not serve me.

original: evaṃ mama parihāni bhavissatī”ti vattuṃ avisahanto na niggayhavādī nāma hoti, so
analyzed: evam mama bhavissati iti vattum a visahantaḥ na niggayhavādī nāma hoti so
translated: Thus I will be at a loss.” He is not one who speaks with restraint.

original: imasmiṃ sāsane kacavaraṃ ākirati. Yo pana tathārūpaṃ vajjaṃ disvā vajjānurūpaṃ tajjetvā
analyzed: imasmin sāsane kaca varam ākirati yaḥ pana tathārūpam vajjam disvā vajja anurūpam tat jetvā
translated: He is a kind of rubbish in the Dispensation. But one who, on seeing such a fault, reproves him in accordance with the offense,

original: paṇāmento daṇḍakammaṃ karonto vihārā nīharanto sikkhāpeti, ayaṃ niggayhavādī nāma
analyzed: paṇāmentaḥ daṇḍa kammam karontaḥ vihārā nīharantaḥ sikkhāpeti ayam niggayhavādī nāma
translated: and, by imposing a penalty, expels him from the monastery, and trains him, is one who speaks with restraint.

original: seyyathāpi sammāsambuddho. Vuttañhetaṃ – “niggayha niggayhāhaṃ, ānanda, vakkhāmi,
analyzed: seyyathā api sammāsambuddhaḥ vuttam ha etam niggayha niggayha aham ānanda vakkhāmi
translated: He is like the Fully Enlightened One himself. For this is said: “I speak, Ananda, after discerning and after pondering,

original: pavayha pavayhāhaṃ, ānanda, vakkhāmi, yo sāro so ṭhassatī”ti. Medhāvinti dhammojapaññāya
analyzed: pavayha pavayha aham ānanda vakkhāmi yaḥ sāro saḥ ṭhassati iti medhāvin ti dhamma oja paññāya
translated: and what is essential will remain.” The wise one: the one who has understanding of the Dhamma.

original: samannāgataṃ. Tādisanti evarūpaṃ paṇḍitaṃ bhajeyya payirupāseyya. Tādisañhi ācariyaṃ
analyzed: samannāgatam tādisanti evarūpam paṇḍitam bhajeyya payirupāseyya tādisam hi ācariyam
translated: endowed with these qualities. Like this: one should attend on, serve, a wise man of such a kind. For such a teacher

original: bhajamānassa antevāsikassa seyyova hoti, na pāpiyo, vuḍḍhiyeva hoti, no parihānīti.🔽Ovadeyyāti uppanne vatthusmiṃ vadanto ovadati nāma, anuppanne “ayasopi te siyā”tiādivasena🔽anāgataṃ dassento anusāsati nāma. Sammukhā vadantopi ovadati nāma, parammukhā dūtaṃ🔽vā sāsanaṃ vā pesento anusāsati nāma. Sakiṃ vadantopi ovadati nāma, punappunaṃ vadanto🔽anusāsati nāma. Ovadanto eva vā anusāsati nāmāti evaṃ ovadeyya anusāseyya. Asabbhāti
analyzed: bhajamānassa antevāsikassa seyyaḥ uva hoti na pāpiyaḥ vuḍḍhiyā iva hoti no parihāni iti  ovadeyya iti uppanne vatthusmiṃ vadantaḥ ovadati nāma anuppanne ayasaḥ pi te siyā ādi vasena  anāgatam dassentaḥ anusāsati nāma sammukhāḥ vadantaḥ api ovadati nāma parammukhāḥ dūtam  vā sāsanam vā pesentaḥ anusāsati nāma sakim vadantaḥ api ovadati nāma punappunam vadantaḥ  anusāsati nāma ovadantaḥ eva vā anusāsati nāma ati evam ovadeyya anusāseyya
translated: endowed with these qualities. Such: one should associate with, attend upon, such a wise man. For when a pupil attends upon a teacher of this kind, he becomes better, not worse; he prospers, he does not decline.

original: akusaladhammā nivāreyya, kusaladhamme patiṭṭhapeyyāti attho. Satañhi so piyo hotīti
analyzed: akusala dhammā nivāreyya kusala dhamme patiṭṭhapeyya ati attho satañhi so piyaḥ hoti iti
translated: Admonish: when a matter has arisen, he admonishes by speaking; when a matter has not arisen, he admonishes by saying, “This might happen to you,” etc., and by showing what might happen. He admonishes by speaking face to face and by sending a message or a letter. He admonishes once and he admonishes repeatedly. He admonishes and he instructs. Thus he should admonish and instruct. The unwholesome: he should restrain from unwholesome states and establish in wholesome states. For the good man is dear:

original: so evarūpo puggalo buddhādīnaṃ sappurisānaṃ piyo hoti. Ye pana adiṭṭhadhammā avitiṇṇaparalokā
analyzed: saḥ evarūpaḥ puggalaḥ buddha ādīnam sappurisānam piyaḥ hoti ye pana adiṭṭha dhammā a vitiṇṇa para lokā
translated: such a person is dear to the Buddhas and the other noble ones. But those who have not seen the Dhamma, who have not penetrated to the other world,

original: āmisacakkhukā jīvikatthāya pabbajitā, tesaṃ asataṃ so ovādako anusāsako “na tvaṃ
analyzed: āmisa cakkhukā jīvika tthāya pabbajitā tesam asatam saḥ ovādakaḥ anusāsakaḥ na tvam
translated: who have gone forth for the sake of a livelihood, and he is not one of them,🔽

original: amhākaṃ upajjhāyo, na ācariyo, kasmā amhākaṃ ovadasī”ti evaṃ mukhasattīhi vijjhantānaṃ appiyo hotīti.
analyzed: amhākam upajjhāyaḥ na ācariyo kasmai amhākam ovadasi iti evam mukha sattīhi vijjhantānam appiyaḥ hoti iti
translated: He is not liked by those who have gone forth for the sake of a livelihood and are looking for material gains. When he gives them advice and instruction, they think, “You are not our preceptor or teacher. Why do you give us advice?” and they stab him in the face with abusive words.🔽“The same legal procedure”: the same procedure of information, etc.

original: Ekakammanti apalokanakammādikaṃ ekakammaṃ. Ekuddesoti nidānuddesādiko ekuddeso. Samasikkhatāti
analyzed: eka kammanti apalokana kamma ādikam eka kammam ekuddeso ti nidānuddesa ādikaḥ ekuddeso samasikkhata ati
translated: “The same recitation”: the same recitation of the introduction, etc.🔽“The same training”:🔽“The same attitude”: a hostile attitude.

original: samānasikkhatā. Āhatacittatanti kodhena pahatacittabhāvaṃ. Khilajātatanti thaddhabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: āhata citta tanti kodhena pahata citta bhāvam khila jāta tanti thaddha bhāvam
translated: “The same state of mind”: a hostile state of mind.

original: Pañcapi cetokhileti buddhadhammasaṅghasikkhāsabrahmacārīsu pañcasupi cittassa thaddhabhāve.
analyzed: cetaḥ khilā iti buddha dhamma saṅgha sikkhā sabrahmacārīsu pañcasu pi cittassa
translated: “The five mental obstructions”: the five hindrances in the mind.🔽“Speech that is born of knowledge”: speech that is produced by a mind associated with knowledge.

original: Ñāṇasamuṭṭhitaṃ vācanti ñāṇasampayuttacittena uppāditaṃ vākyaṃ. Muñceyyāti vissajjeyya.
analyzed: ñāṇa samuṭṭhitam vācanti ñāṇa sampayutta cittena uppāditam vākyam muñceyya ati vissajjeyya
translated: “He should release him”: he should dismiss him.

original: Atthūpasaṃhitanti atthasahitaṃ kāraṇasahitaṃ. Dhammūpasaṃhitanti dhammena yuttaṃ.
analyzed: attha upasaṃhitanti attha sahitam kāraṇa sahitam dhamma upasaṃhitanti dhammena yuttam
translated: “In accordance with the Teaching”: in accordance with the Teaching, in accordance with the Monastic Law.

original: Kālātikkantaṃ vācaṃ na bhāseyyāti kālātītaṃ vācaṃ na katheyya tassa kālassa atikkantattā.
analyzed: kāla atikkantam vācam na bhāseyya ati kāla atītam vācam na katheyya tassa kālassa atikkanta ttā
translated: He should not speak words that are untimely: he should not utter words that are out of time because the time for them has passed.

original: Velātikkantanti mariyādātītaṃ vacanaṃ na bhaṇeyya vacanamariyādassa atikkantattā.
analyzed: velā atikkanta nti mariyāda atītam vacanam na bhaṇeyya vacana mariyādassa atikkanta ttā
translated: He should not speak words that are excessive: he should not utter words that are beyond the proper limit because the limit for words has been exceeded.

original: Ubhayavasena kālavelā.
analyzed: ubhaya vasena kālavelā
translated: Both terms refer to time.

original: Yo ve kāle asampatteti attano vacanakāle asampatte. Ativelanti velātikkantaṃ katvā
analyzed: yaḥ kāle asampatte iti attanaḥ vacana kāle asampatte ativelanti velā atikkantam katvā
translated: When the time is not yet come for speaking: when the time for his own speaking has not yet come.🔽He speaks too much: he speaks beyond the proper measure, after exceeding the limit for speaking.

original: atirekappamāṇaṃ bhāsati. Nihato setīti nigghātito sayati. Kokilāyeva atrajoti kākiyā
analyzed: atireka ppamāṇam bhāsati nihataḥ seti iti nigghātitaḥ sayati kokilāya iva kākiyā
translated: He is defeated: he is struck down, he lies down.

original: paṭijaggito kokilāya abbhantare jāto kokilapotako viya.
analyzed: paṭijaggitaḥ kokilāya abbhantare jātaḥ kokila potakaḥ viya
translated: Like a cuckoo chick hatched from a crow’s egg: like a cuckoo chick brought up by a crow.🔽Then, from now on: from now on, hereafter.

original: 209. Athāparanti atha idāni ito parampi. Pañca rajānīti rūparāgādīni pañca rajāni.
analyzed: atha aparanti atha idāni itas parampi pañca rajāni iti rūpa rāga ādīni pañca rajāni
translated: Five kinds of dust: the five kinds of dust consisting of lust for visible forms, etc.

original: Yesaṃ satīmā vinayāya sikkheti yesaṃ upaṭṭhitassati hutvāva vinayanatthaṃ tisso sikkhā
analyzed: yesam sati imā vinayāya sikkha iti yesam upaṭṭhitassati hutvā ava vinayana attham tisso sikkhā
translated: He should train in mindfulness for their restraint: he should train in the three trainings for the purpose of restraining them by being possessed of established mindfulness.

original: sikkheyya. Evaṃ sikkhanto hi rūpesu…pe… phassesu sahetha rāgaṃ, na aññeti.
analyzed: sikkheyya evam sikkhantaḥ hi phassesu sahetha rāgam na aññā iti
translated: For one who trains thus, lust for visible forms, etc., will be endured, not indulged in.

original: Rūparajoti rūpārammaṇaṃ paṭicca uppanno rāgādirajo. Saddarajādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: rūpa rajaḥ ti rūpa ārammaṇam paṭicca uppannaḥ rāga ādi rajaḥ sadda raja ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The dust of form is the dust of lust, etc., that arises contingent upon form as object. The same method applies in the case of the dust of sound, and so on.

original: 210. Tato so tesaṃ vinayāya sikkhanto anukkamena – etesu dhammesūti gāthā. Tattha🔽etesūti rūpādīsu. Kālena so sammā dhammaṃ parivīmaṃsamānoti so bhikkhu yvāyaṃ “uddhate
analyzed: tatas saḥ tesam vinayāya sikkhantaḥ anukkamena etesu dhammesu iti gāthā tattha  etesu iti rūpa ādīsu kālena saḥ sammā dhammam parivīmaṃsamānaḥ ti saḥ bhikkhu yvā ayam uddhate
translated: Then, as he trains himself in order to abandon these states, he gradually reaches the stage of development described in the stanza beginning, “In these ideas.” Herein,🔽in these ideas means in the ideas of form, etc.🔽He, rightly pondering the Dhamma in its season,

original: citte samathassa kālo”tiādinā nayena kālo vutto, tena kālena sabbaṃ saṅkhatadhammaṃ🔽aniccādinayena parivīmaṃsamāno. Ekodibhūto vihane tamaṃ soti so ekaggacitto sabbaṃ
analyzed: citte samathassa kālaḥ iti ādinā nayena kālaḥ vuttaḥ tena kālena sabbam saṅkhata dhammam  anicca ādi nayena parivīmaṃsamānaḥ ekodi bhūtaḥ vihane tamam so ti saḥ ekagga citto sabbam
translated: In the passage beginning, “When the mind is excited, the time is not suitable for developing the tranquillity enlightenment factor” , the time has been stated. At that time, rightly pondering the Dhamma in its season,

original: mohāditamaṃ vihaneyya, natthi ettha saṃsayo.🔽Uddhate citteti vīriyindriyavasena citte avūpasante. Balavavīriyañhi mandasamādhiṃ
analyzed: moha āditamam vihaneyya natthi ettha saṃsayo  uddhate citta iti vīriyindriya vasena citte a vūpasante balava vīriyam hi manda samādhim
translated: he, with mind concentrated, would dispel the darkness.

original: vīriyassa uddhaccapakkhattā uddhaccaṃ abhibhavati. Evaṃ uddhate citte. Samathassa
analyzed: vīriyassa uddhacca pakkhattā uddhaccam abhibhavati evam uddhate citte samathassa
translated: When the mind is excited: when the mind is not calm through the faculty of energy. For strong energy overcomes sluggish concentration, since energy has the characteristic of agitation. When the mind is excited in this way,🔽the time is not suitable for developing the concentration enlightenment factor.

original: kāloti samādhissa bhāvanāya kālo. Samāhite citteti upacārappanāhi citte samāhite.
analyzed: kālo ti samādhissa bhāvanāya kālo samāhite citte iti upacāra ppanāhi citte samāhite
translated: “The time”: the time for developing concentration. “When the mind becomes concentrated”: when the mind is concentrated through access concentration.

original: Balavasamādhi hi mandavīriyaṃ samādhissa kosajjapakkhattā kosajjaṃ abhibhavati. Samādhi🔽vīriyena saññojito kosajje patituṃ na labhati. Vīriyaṃ samādhinā saññojitaṃ uddhacce
analyzed: balava samādhi hi manda vīriyam samādhissa kosajja pakkhattā kosajjam abhibhavati samādhi  vīriyena saññojitaḥ kosajje patitum na labhati vīriyam samādhinā saññojitam uddhacce
translated: For strong concentration overcomes indolence in one of little energy, since indolence is a hindrance to concentration.

original: patituṃ na labhati. Tasmā tadubhayaṃ samaṃ kātabbaṃ. Ubhayasamatāya hi appanā hoti.
analyzed: patitum na labhati tasmā tat ubhayam samam kātabbam ubhaya samatāya hi appanā hoti
translated: Concentration supported by energy does not fall into indolence. Energy supported by concentration does not fall into agitation. Therefore both should be made equal. For it is by the equality of the two that absorption is reached.

original: Vipassanāya kāloti evaṃ samāhite aniccādivasena vividhāya passanāya kālo, samādhikammikassa🔽balavatīpi saddhā vaṭṭati. Evaṃ saddahanto okappento appanaṃ pāpuṇāti. Samādhipaññāsu
analyzed: vipassanāya kālo ti evam samāhite anicca ādi vasena vividhāya passanāya kālo samādhi kammikassa  balavatī api saddhā vaṭṭati evam saddahantaḥ okappentaḥ appanam pāpuṇāti samādhi paññāsu
translated: “The time for insight”: when the mind is thus concentrated, it is time for the various kinds of insight classed as insight into impermanence, etc.

original: pana samādhikammikassa balavatī ekaggatā vaṭṭati. Evañhi so appanaṃ pāpuṇāti. Vipassanākammikassa
analyzed: pana samādhi kammikassa balavatī ekagga tā vaṭṭati evañhi so appanam pāpuṇāti vipassanā kammikassa
translated: Faith is also necessary for one who is engaged in concentration. For one who has such faith and confidence reaches absorption. But strong unification is necessary for one who is engaged in concentration. For it is by means of that that he reaches absorption.

original: pana paññā balavatī vaṭṭati. Evañhi so lakkhaṇappaṭivedhaṃ pāpuṇāti. Ubhinnaṃ pana
analyzed: pana paññā balavatī vaṭṭati evañhi so lakkhaṇa ppaṭivedham pāpuṇāti ubhinnam pana
translated: But strong understanding is necessary for one who is engaged in insight. For it is by means of that that he reaches penetration of the characteristics of impermanence, etc.

original: samattepi appanā hoti eva.
analyzed: samattepi appanā hoti eva
translated: and absorption is present even in the completed state.

original: Kāle paggaṇhati cittanti yasmiṃ samaye atisithilavīriyatādīhi līnaṃ cittaṃ hoti,
analyzed: kāle paggaṇhati cittam ti yasmin samaye ati sithila vīriya tā ādīhi līnam cittam hoti
translated: He encourages it when it is slack: when his mind is slack through excessive laxity of energy, etc.,

original: tasmiṃ samaye dhammavicayavīriyapītisambojjhaṅgasamuṭṭhāpanena taṃ cittaṃ paggaṇhāti.
analyzed: tasmin samaye dhamma vicaya vīriya pīti sambojjhaṅga samuṭṭhāpanena tam cittam paggaṇhāti
translated: then he encourages it by arousing the investigation-of-states, energy, and glad- ness enlightenment factors.

original: Niggaṇhatīti yasmiṃ samaye accāraddhavīriyatādīhi uddhataṃ cittaṃ hoti, tasmiṃ samaye🔽passaddhisamādhiupekkhāsambojjhaṅgasamuṭṭhāpanena taṃ cittaṃ niggaṇhāti. Sampahaṃsati
analyzed: niggaṇhati iti yasmin samaye uddhatam cittam hoti tasmin samaye  passaddhi samādhi upekkhā sambojjhaṅga samuṭṭhāpanena tam cittam niggaṇhāti sampahaṃsati
translated: He steadies it when excited: when his mind is excited through excessive energy, etc.,🔽then he steadies it by arousing the tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity enlightenment factors.

original: kālenāti yasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ paññāpayogamandatāya vā upasamasukhānaṃ vigamena vā
analyzed: kālena ati yasmin samaye cittam paññā apayoga manda tāya vā upasama sukhānam vigamena vā
translated: He does not over-exert it: when his mind is dispirited through weakness of understanding due to the function of understanding, or through lack of relish in the bliss of peace,

original: nirassādaṃ hoti, tasmiṃ samaye aṭṭhasaṃvegavatthupaccavekkhaṇena saṃvejeti. Aṭṭha
analyzed: nirassādam hoti tasmin samaye aṭṭha saṃvega vatthu paccavekkhaṇena saṃvejeti aṭṭha
translated: then he does not over-exert it by reviewing the eight grounds for arousing ardour .

original: saṃvegavatthūni nāma – jātijarābyādhimaraṇāni cattāri, apāyadukkhaṃ pañcamaṃ, atīte
analyzed: saṃvega vatthūni nāma jāti jarā byādhi maraṇāni cattāri apāya dukkham pañcamam atīte
translated: The eight grounds for arousing ardour are these: birth is discerned, ageing is discerned, sickness is discerned, death is discerned, the suffering of the states of loss is discerned, the unattractiveness of the body as a basis is discerned, the unsatisfactoriness of all conditioned things is discerned, and the danger in all kinds of becoming is discerned.

original: vaṭṭamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ anāgate vaṭṭamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ, paccuppanne āhārapariyeṭṭhimūlakaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭa mūlakam dukkham anāgate vaṭṭa mūlakam dukkham paccuppanne āhāra pariyeṭṭhi mūlakam
translated: The suffering rooted in the past round of rebirths, the suffering rooted in the future round of rebirths, the suffering rooted in the present search for requisites,

original: dukkhanti. Ratanattayaguṇānussaraṇenāssa pasādaṃ janeti. Ayaṃ vuccati “sampahaṃsati🔽kālenā”ti. Kāle cittaṃ samādaheti yasmiṃ samaye saddhāpaññānaṃ samādhivīriyānañca
analyzed: dukkhanti ratanattaya guṇa anussaraṇena assa pasādam janeti ayam vuccati sampahaṃsati  kālena ati kāle cittam samādaha iti yasmin samaye saddhā paññānam samādhi vīriyānam ca
translated: He generates confidence in himself by recollecting the special qualities of the Three Jewels. This is called “encouraging at the proper time.”

original: samabhāvo, tasmiṃ kāle cittaṃ samādaheyya.🔽Ajjhupekkhati kālenāti yasmiṃ samaye sammā paṭipattiṃ āgamma alīnaṃ anuddhataṃ anirassādaṃ🔽ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ samathavīthipaṭipannaṃ cittaṃ hoti, tadāssa paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu
analyzed: sama bhāvaḥ tasmin kāle cittam samādaheyya  ajjhupekkhati kālena ati yasmin samaye sammā paṭipattim āgamma a līnam an uddhatam a nirassādam  ārammaṇe sama pavattam samatha vīthi paṭipannam cittam hoti tadā assa paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu
translated: “He directs his mind at the proper time”: he should direct his mind at the time when faith, understanding, concentration, and energy are in balance.

original: na byāpāraṃ āpajjati sārathi viya samappavattesu assesu. Ayaṃ vuccati “ajjhupekkhati
analyzed: na byāpāram āpajjati sārathi viya sama pavattesu assesu ayam vuccati ajjhupekkhati
translated: “He looks on with equanimity at the proper time”: at the time when, by means of right practice, his mind occurs evenly, neither low nor excited, without obstruction, in the way of the path, then he does not engage in encouraging, restraining, or looking on with equanimity, like a charioteer with well-trained horses. This is called “looking on with equanimity at the proper time.”

original: kālenā”ti. So yogī kālakovidoti eso vuttappakāro kammaṭṭhānayoge niyutto paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanasamādahanaajjhupekkhanakālesu
analyzed: kālena ati saḥ yogī kāla kovidaḥ ti eso vutta ppakāro kammaṭṭhāna yoge niyuttaḥ paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsana samādahana ajjhupekkhana kālesu
translated: The meditator who is skilled in the proper time is adept in encouraging, restraining, looking on with equanimity, directing, and looking on with equanimity at the proper time in the practice of the meditation subject described above.

original: cheko byatto. Kimhi kālamhītiādinā paggahādikālaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: chekaḥ byattaḥ kimhi kālamhi itiādinā paggaha ādi kālam pucchati
translated: “At what time?” he asks, referring to the time of encouraging, etc.

original: Idāni paggahādikālaṃ vissajjento “līne cittamhī”tiādimāha. Atisithilavīriyatādīhi🔽citte līnabhāvaṃ gate dhammavicayavīriyapītisambojjhaṅgasamuṭṭhāpanena paggaho. Uddhatasmiṃ
analyzed: idāni paggaha ādi kālam vissajjentaḥ līne cittamhi iti ādim āha ati sithila vīriya tā ādīhi  citte līna bhāvam gate dhamma vicaya vīriya pīti sambojjhaṅga samuṭṭhāpanena paggahaḥ uddhatasmin
translated: Now, in reply to the question, “When is it lifted up?” he said, “When slack, I rouse it,” etc.🔽When the mind is slack through excessive slackness of energy, etc., then it should be lifted up by arousing the investigation-of-states, energy, and bliss enlightenment factors.

original: viniggahoti accāraddhavīriyatādīhi uddhate citte passaddhisamādhiupekkhāsambojjhaṅgasamuṭṭhāpanena🔽niggaho. Nirassādagataṃ cittaṃ, sampahaṃseyya tāvadeti paññāpayogamandatāya vā upasamasukhānaṃ
analyzed: viniggahaḥ ti acca āraddha vīriya tā ādīhi uddhate citte passaddhi samādhi upekkhā sambojjhaṅga samuṭṭhāpanena  niggahaḥ nirassāda gatam cittam sampahaṃseyya tāvadeti paññā apayoga manda tāya vā upasama sukhānam
translated: When it is excited, it should be steadied. When the mind is excited through excessive excitation of energy, etc., then it should be steadied by arousing the tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity enlightenment factors.🔽When the mind has sunk, it should be roused,

original: vigamena vā assādavirahitaṃ gataṃ aṭṭhasaṃvegavatthupaccavekkhaṇena vā ratanattayaguṇānussaraṇena
analyzed: vigamena vā assāda virahitam gatam aṭṭha saṃvega vatthu paccavekkhaṇena vā rata nattaya guṇa anussaraṇena
translated: When the mind has sunk through excessive sluggishness of energy, etc., then it should be roused by arousing the investigation-of-states, energy, and bliss enlightenment factors.

original: vā tasmiṃ khaṇe cittaṃ sampahaṃseyya.
analyzed: vā tasmin khaṇe cittam sampahaṃseyya
translated: When the mind is without joy, it should be gladdened,🔽When the mind is without joy owing to weakness in the application of understanding, or owing to the absence of the happiness of peace, or owing to lack of reflection on the special qualities of the Three Jewels, then it should be gladdened by arousing the faith enlightenment factor.

original: Sampahaṭṭhaṃ yadā cittanti yasmiṃ kāle vuttanayeneva sampahaṃsitaṃ cittaṃ hoti. Alīnaṃ
analyzed: sampahaṭṭham yadā cittam ti yasmin kāle vutta nayena iva sampahaṃsitam cittam hoti alīnam
translated: When the mind is gladdened, it should be steadied and concentrated,

original: bhavati nuddhatanti vīriyasamādhīhi saññojitattā līnuddhaccavirahitañca hoti. Samathanimittassāti
analyzed: bhavati vīriya samādhīhi saññojita ttā hoti samatha nimittassa ati
translated: When the mind is gladdened by gladdening it in this way, then it should be steadied and concentrated by arousing the tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity enlightenment factors.

original: samatho ca nimittañca samathanimittaṃ, tassa samathanimittassa. So kāloti yo so līnuddhaccavirahitakālo🔽vutto, so kālo. Ajjhattaṃ ramaye manoti jhānasampayuttaṃ cittaṃ kasiṇādigocarajjhatte
analyzed: samathaḥ ca nimittam ca samatha nimittam tassa samatha nimittassa saḥ kālo ti yaḥ saḥ līn uddhacca virahita kālo  vuttaḥ saḥ kālaḥ ajjhattam ramaye manaḥ ti jhāna sampayuttam cittam kasiṇa ādi gocara ajjhatte
translated: the time stated as being free from sluggishness and excitedness.

original: toseyya abhiramāpeyya.
analyzed: toseyya abhiramāpeyya
translated: He should delight his mind internally: he should delight, should gladden, the consciousness associated with the jhāna by repeatedly letting it see the sign of the jhāna that is in the internal mind-door.

original: Etena mevupāyenāti etena vuttaupāyena eva. Ma-kāro padasandhivasena vutto. Ajjhupekkheyya
analyzed: etena mā iva upāyena ati etena vutta aupāyena eva makāraḥ pada sandhi vasena vuttaḥ ajjhupekkheyya
translated: By this very means: by this very method stated. The letter “m” is given to show the connection of the words. He should look on

original: tāvadeti yadā upacārappanāhi taṃ cittaṃ samāhitaṃ, tadā “samāhitaṃ citta”nti jānitvā
analyzed: tāvat eti yadā cittam samāhitam tadā samāhitam cittam ti jānitvā
translated: at it thus: when his consciousness is concentrated by access and absorption, then he should know that his consciousness is concentrated,

original: paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu byāpāraṃ akatvā tasmiṃ khaṇe ajjhupekkhanameva kareyya.
analyzed: paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu byāpāram a katvā tasmin khaṇe ajjhupekkhanam eva kareyya
translated: and he should look on at it then without making any effort to arouse it, to steady it, or to encourage it.🔽Now, in order to answer the question, “At what time is there exertion?” he said,

original: Idāni “kimhi kālamhi paggāho”ti puṭṭhagāthaṃ nigamento “evaṃ kālavidū dhīro”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni kimhi kālamhi paggāho ti puṭṭhagātham nigamentaḥ evam kāla vidū dhīra iti ādim āha
translated: “The wise one, knowing the time, should know the time for looking on,” etc.

original: Kālena kālaṃ cittassa, nimittamupalakkhayeti kālānukālaṃ samādhisampayuttacittassa
analyzed: kālena kālam cittassa nimittam upalakkhayeti kāla anukālam samādhi sampayutta cittassa
translated: From time to time he should observe the sign of the consciousness associated with concentration.

original: ārammaṇaṃ sallakkheyya, upaparikkheyyāti attho. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva. Evaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇam sallakkheyya upaparikkheyya ati attho sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva evam
translated: “He should review the object” means he should investigate it. The rest is clear in all its parts.

original: arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesīti.
analyzed: arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi iti
translated: Thus he concluded the teaching with the peak of arahatship.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya mahāniddesaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya mahā niddesa ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Sāriputta Sutta in the Mahāniddesa,

original: Sāriputtasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sāriputta sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: the first part of the Sutta Nipāta, is finished.

original: Aṭṭhakavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Eight-part Sutta is finished.🔽The commentary on the meaning of the Mahāniddesa,

original: Saddhammappajjotikā nāma mahāniddesa-aṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikā nāma mahā niddesa aṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā
translated: the first part of the Sutta Nipāta, called The Illuminator of the True Dhamma, is finished.
